div.p: ASTREA.
A ROMANCE, WRITTEN IN FRENCH, BY Meire Honore D'Urfe;
AND TRANSLATED BY A Peron of Quality.
LONDON, Printed by W. W. for H. Moeley, T. Dring, and H. Herringman, And are to be old at their hops in St Pauls Church-yard, Fleettreet, and in the Lower vvalke in the New Exchange. 1657.

div.head: TO THE READER.
div.p:
OF all the Books that Mankind hath convers'd with, ince it was firt refin'd by Letters, none hath contributed o much to the civilization thereof, or gaind that eteeme and Authority with it, as thoe of POETRY; by which terme I meane, FICTION, in the larget extent. Under this, are comprehended the highet & noblet productions of man's wit, ROMANCES; a kinde of writing o full of charme and ininuation, that even Religious worhip, in the dis-illuminated times of Paganim, was oblig'd to it for mot of its Ceremonies, & the trange influence it had over the multitude. For, what were the Ora • les, what all ancient Mythologies, what Numa's pretended correpondence with his Nymph Aegeria, but o many politick Ro • ances, cunningly advanc'd, to create in the minds of the people a feare and veneration of ome power above humane Lawes, whereby they were deterr'd from thoe things which were out of their reach and cognizance? Hence was it that ome tumbled on that Paradoxe,
That mankinde, look't on generally, had made greater advantages of Fiction, than ever it had done of Truth; the one, it eemes, by reaon of her nakednee, finding o much the colder reception; the other, diguized in the drees of Witt, and Eloquence, the noblet entertainement that could be expected from reverence, admiration, and Idolatry.

But, if Endeavours of this nature were o uccesfull and advantageous to piety & a civill life, in their infancy, while they were yet hrowded in Fables and Oracular cheats and ambiguities, and lay levell to the capacities of the multitude, what may not thoe contribute, that are calculated to the meridian of the mot criticall and mot ingenious? What was before cenur'd as extravagance
of imagination, is now reconcil'd to probability, and retrain'd by judgement. What fally ravih'd the eager apprehenion into amazement at impertinent and Quixoticall Attempts doe • now but gently enflame the minde into an aemulation of the perfections, & a ympathy for the weakenes & ufferings it finds repreented. Thus an excee of Auterity in ome hath reduc'd many to a greater compliance with and ubmiion to Nature; and the elevation of the voice in Singing Maters above the note, does but direct the Learner to reach the tone.

This, READER, is the deigne of the worke thou now hat in thy hands. Here thou find't a cleare repreentation of the Noblet and mot generous images of life, and uch an accompt of the paions and actions of Men, as few bookes of this nature afford o plentifull; with uch variety of excellent dicoures, and an extraordinary ententiounee, as deervedly celebrate this above any Author of the kinde. Here thou hat a jealous and ditrutfull ASTREA; a depairing, yet faithfull CELADON; aickle and uncontant HYLAS; and uch intricate cenes of Courthip, Love, Jealouie, and the other paions, as cannot but raie in • ee a conideration of humane Affairs, utable to the everall emergencies. But to cloe up the elogies may be given this worke, with the greatet that any of this kind ever receiv'd, I hall onely adde • he judgement of it, of the late famous Cardinall of RICHELIEU, That he was not to be admitted into the Academy of Wit, who had not been before well read in ASTREA.

div.head: ASTREA.
The Firt part. Book I.
div.p: NEere the Antient Cittie of Lyons towards the Wet, lieth that part of the Country called Forrets, which in it's little circumference comprehends more varities then the ret of France: for being divided into Plaines and Mountaines both of them are o fertile, and eated in uch a temperate Aire, that the oile is capable of whatoever the indutrious Husbandman can expect or deire. In the heart of the Country is a mot Pleaan, plaine circled about, as with a trong wall, by its Neighbour hills, and watered with the River Loyre; which from its (not farre off) originall, glides gently through the midt of it, without any welling pride. Many other Rivulets doe in divers places betow their chrytall treams, the chiefe of which is Lignon, which, though extravagant in its coure, as well as delectable in its Scource, runs Meander-like through the plaine, neere unto the loty mountaines of Servieres and Chalmael, unto Feures, where the Loyre receiving it, and wallowing up its name, carrieth it as tribute unto the Ocean.

Upon the banks of thee delighting Rivers, are continually to be eene abundance of hepheards, who though litle beholding to fortune, yet by reaon of the aires naturall weetnee, and the Soiles fertilitie do live in abundance of contented happinee.

They would never have envied the golden contentednee of the firt happy age, had Love let them alone to enjoy that felicitie of which the heavens were o prodigall unto them: but lumbering upon the downy beds of eae, they became ubject unto Loves flattery, who preently turned his Authoritie into Tyranny. Celadon was one of them who did mot feelingly reent it, and who was o captivated with the perfections of Atrea, that the very odium of their Parents could not preerve him from loing himelfe in her. The truth is, that if ever happinee could be found in the loe of ones elfe, it was by him, in loing himelfe to gaine the favour of the faire Atrea; who being aured of his affection, did corne ingratitude, and received him and his ervices with reciprocall affection: o that if any changing bee eene in either of them afterwards, 'tis probable that the heavens did allow it, to hew, that nothing is more contant then incontancie, which is contant in alteration. For thee two having lived together mot happily the pace of three yeares, even then when they leat feared any dyaterous accident, they found themelves betrayed unto the wort of loves misfortunes, by the perfidie of Semyres: o as Celadon to diguie his affection from their Parents, who by reaon of an inveterate hatred amongt themelves, did trive to thwart their amorous deignes, did eeme as if his addrees to that hepheardee were rather out of civill coure, then any courthip: This umbrage was handome enough, if Semyres had not made it his talking hore to betray Atrea, which he ince repayed by many a igh and Teare.

As Fortune was, one day, this amorous hepheard, riing betimes to bid his thoughts
good morrow, and leaving his flocke to graze, he went to ret himelfe upon the banks of the River Lignon, there expecting the appearance of his faire hepheardee, who was not long behind him: for he out of too much fancy, had carcely cloed her eye that night. The Sunne no ooner begun to gild the top of the mountains of I oures and M • rcillies then this hepheard epied a farre off a flock which he preently knew belonged unto Atrea; for Melampe, a dogge much in favour with his hepheardee, as oone as ever he aw him, came and fauned upon him: beides, he oberved the beloved Sheep of his Mitrie; though that morning he did not weare her dree of various coloured Ribands, which her Mitrie was wont to decke her head with, in the fahion of a garland: for that hepheardee being much dipleaed, he did not give her elfe the leaure of dreing it, as uuall. She followed her flock as if her hooes were Lead; and, as might be judged by the garbe, o • thing much troubled her mind, o as being neare her hepheard he did not o much as tur • e an eye towards him, but et her elfe downe upon the bankes of the River. Celadon, not taking any notice of this, beleeving he did not ee him, but that he went to the place where he was wont to waite for her, did drive his flock towards her: he at upon the tumpe of an old Tree, with a drooping head, upported by her hand which leaned upon her kne • & he at in o ad a poture that if Celadon had not beene more then halfe blind, he mightplainely perceive that this orrow could not proceed from any thing but an opinion of a change in his affection, for no other dyater had power enough to caue uch ad thoughts. But an unexpected misfortune being far more hard to relih then an other, it eemes fate had a minde to urprie him unawares.

Thus being ignorant of his ill hap, after a choice of the fittet place for the grazing of his flock neare his dearet heepherdes, he went to bid her good morrow, being extreamly joyed to ee her: he returned anwer with looks and language o cold, as if a chill winter had frozen every yllable. The hepheard, unaccutomed to uch a ight, was infinitly atonihed; and though he could not imagine his dyater o great as afterwards he found it, yet the very thought of offending her he loved, was enough to cot him his life. Had the hepheardes deigned him a look, or had his zealous fancy permitted him to conider what might be the caue of her coldnes, certainly his apprehenions had vanihed. But Celadon mut not be the Phoenix of happines, as he was of Love; nor will fortune afford him more favour then other men, in matter of content. After a long and penive extaie, he rowed up himelfe, and turning towards his hepheardes, he perceived that he looked upon him, but it was with o ad an apect, that he truck him oulles. They were both o neer the River, that Celadon might eaily reach it with the end of his heephooke; and ome howers had o welled the water above its common marke that it digorged it elfe with a very impetuous treame, into the River Loure. The place where they at was a hill, a litle raied above the common levell, againt which the waves did beat in vaine, the foundation of it being a Rock covered over with ome mos. From this place, the hepheard did beat the waves of water with his heephook, and thoe waves were not halfe o turbulent as his thoughts; he ummoned up every action of his life, nay not a thought ecaped inquiition, and all to find out wherein he had offended: but his innocencie cleering up his concience, he was enboldned to aske her the reaon of her anger. She not oberving his actions, or ele oberving them to his diadvantage, her heart begun to be the more inflamed with choler; o as when he offered to peake, he would not permit him to expree himelfe without interruption, aying: Is it not enough & too much (perfidious and injurious hepheard) to have deluded her who leat deerved it from you; but you mut till perit in your wickednee? how dare you be o impudently bold, as to looke her in the face whom you have o groly offended? Cant thou without a bluh bring that diembling face into my preence? does not thy double oule tremble at its own villany, before me? Go go, and deceive ome other; get thee gone traytor, and imploy thy perfidies in beguiling ome that knowes them not; think not any longer to delude me, who am too too well accquainted with thy falnee. At this the poore hepheard fals downe upon his knees; lookes pale and wanne, as if blated with a Thunderbolt. Is it your deigne onely to try me, faire hepherdee, (aid he unto her) or ele to kill me with depaire? Nay, nay, fale man, repli'd he; I need not try thy infidelitie, for I am too well accquainted with it: Oh heavens, aid the hepherd. I wih this fatall day had never dawnd: It had beene happy for us both, replied he, if neither of us had ever een the light, then had thy infidelitie never troubled me. Go, go, perfidious wretch, I charge thee to be gone, and never againe looke me in the face, unlee I command it. Celadon would have replyed, had not his extafie of love bedeafed him: And as he was going away, he was forced to pull her
by the gowne, aying, I do not tay you deare hepherdee, to begge a Pardon for my unknowne fault; but only to hew you that this is the lat day of his life, whom you eeme o much to abhorre: but he being all in a fury, and not o much as looking upon him did violently break away, and left behind her a Riband, upon which by accident his hand did lie; and alo a Ring, which her Father had given her, was tyed in that Riband. The ad hepheard eeing her depart in uch a fury did tand awhile like a tock immovable; carce knowing what he had in his hand, though his eye was upon it. At lat recollecting himelfe with a deer igh and taking notice of the Riband Witnee, deare Riband, aid he, that rather then untie the leat knot of my affection, I would loe a hundred lives; when I am dead and my cruell faire one hall happily ee thee on my arme, aure her that never any was more faithfull, then I; nor never any more cruell, then he. Then tying it upon his arme, and kiing the Ring And thou, right emblem of true affection, aid he, let me enjoy thee to the lat, as a pledge of her promied affection to me. He had no ooner uttered thee words, but turning his eyes toward Atrea, he leaped into the River with croed arms.

Lignon in that place was very deep and violent, & by reaon of the Rocke which repuled the water, there was a kind of whirlpit: o as the hepheard was long before he unk to the bottom, and longer in comming up to the top againe. And when he did appeare, nothing could be een, but firt a leg, and then an arm: at lat being gulfed up by the turning of the waves, he was carried away under the water. Now Atrea runs to the Water ide, and eeing him whom he could not chue but love by her meanes o neer his death; he was o affrighted, that in lieu of lending any help, he falls into a wound and that o neer the water, that when he returned to her elfe, at the firt motion he fell in, and was in o much danger, as all that ome hepheards cloe by could do was litle enough to ave her by pulling her out by her garments; which kept her above the water, and gave them time to draw her unto the ide: but life was o farre pent, as he perceived it not. They carried her unto the next hepherds cabbin, whereby accident Phillis was, and where they hifted her cloaths: he all this while was o atonihed both at her owne accident and at that of Celadons, that he could not peake. Mean while, Celadon was hurried by the fury of the waves a farre off on the other ide of the River, amongt ome little trees; but with very little igne of life.

As oone as Phillis heard of this accident unto Atrea he made all hate poible and had not Lycidas met her, nothing ele could have topped her, yet he told him briefly, the danger in which Atrea was; not mentioning a word concerning Celadon, for he knew not any thing of his diater: this Lycidas was Celadons brother, and thee two were tyed fater together in amity then conanguinitie: on the other ide, Atrea and Phillis, being Couens, did love each other o well, as they deerved to be compared with the two brothers: As Celadon had a Sympatheticall affection unto Atrea, o Lycidas had as trong an inclination to erve Phillis, as Phillis had to favour Lycidas.

So it chanced, that as they came into the cottage, Atrea opened her eyes, but you may imagine that they had lot much of their wonted lutre, and looked heavy and dull, and their prightlines drowned in tears yet uch tears, as, flowing from an enflamed heart and lovely eyes moved abundance of love and pitty from all her beholders. When he epied her companion Phillis, he was much moved; but much more when he aw Lycidas and though he was loath to let the people about her know the caue of her diater; yet he was forced to ay, hat his brother was drowned in helping her. Lycidas was o atonihed at the newes, that he ran immediatly to the fatall place with all the ret of the hepheards, leaving Atrea and Phillis alone, who preently after, began to follow them, but o ad a pace, that though they had much to ay, yet they could not peake one yllable. Meane time the hepheards came to the River ide, and looking on every ide they could not finde the leat igne of what they ought; for only thoe, who went the lowet downe the River, chanced to find his hat, which the waves had cat up upon ome willows and reeds which grew by the water ide: this was all the newes they could heare: As for Celadon, he was carried by the water much lower and into a place where it was unpoible for them to find him. for as I told you before, the waves had wafted him over to the other ide, and he tucke upon a thick ruh of trees, where it was very hard to ee him.

When he was even betwixt life and death, there came to the place, three fair Nymphs, with diheavelled haire waving and hanging upon their houlders, under a garland of everall Pearles; their brets were naked their leeves turned up to the elbow, and their arms bare, onely covered with puret Lawne to the Wrets, on which they wore
rich bracelets of Orientall Pearls: each of them wore a quiver full of arrows, and in their hands they carried bowes of Ivorie: their petticotes were tucked up o high as permitted their golden buskins to be eene, as high as the knee. It eems they came unto that place upon ome deigne: for (aid one of them) this is the very place, earch well the ide of the River; See, ee! how impetuouly it wells it elf above its common levell: oberv that Tuft of trees, doubtlee it is the very ame which was repreented to us in the mirror. 'Tis true, (aid the chiefe of them,) but all the ret is nothing reemblant: but me thinkes I ee another odd place, more likely to find that which we looke for: its very probable (aid the third, who had not yet poke) for the place is o exactly decribed, as I beleeve there is not one tree, but you aw in the mirrour. In uch dicoure as this, they came o neere the place where Celadon was, that nothing but a few leaves did interpoe betweene him and their ight. They having exactly urvayed every thing, they concluded it to be the place which was hewed unto them, and therefore reolved to it downe. The principall of thee Nymphs as he was itting downe, epyed Celadon: and uppoing him to be ome hepheard aleepe and beckning with one hand unto her companions, he pointed to the place with the other; and treading very gently for feare of waking him he tepped forward; but being neerer, he beleeved him to be dead. For his feet did lie in the water, his right arme upon his head, and the left carlely hanging behind him; his neck awry as if his head were too heavy; his mouth halfe open, and almot full of and his face pale and dirtie, his eyes almot cloed: and his haire which he wore very long, o wet, that the water ran like a tream from it his countenance was the very picture of death; his backe o bended, that it eemed broke: and that made his belly eeme the more welled. The Nymphs, eeing him in this deplorable condition, were mooved with much pitty; and Leonida, as mot officious and pittifull, was the firt which laid hand upon him to draw him out of the river. The water, which he had wallowed came from him in uch abundance, that the Nimph finding ome warmth yet in him, did beleeve him to be recoverable. Then Galathia, who was the chiefe of them, turning towards the other Nymph, who looked on but did not help; Come Sylvia, (aid he unto her) why are you o idle? come and help, if not to eae your companions, yet out of pittie to this poore hepheard. I am conidering, Madam, (aid he) that though he be very much changed, yet me thinkes I hould know him. Then taking him by the other arme, and looking upon him more preciely, Certainly (aid he) I am not mitaken: Tis he I meane; and beleeve it, he merits all our helps: for he is not only of the firt family in all the country, but his merits are o many, as our bet indeavours to ave him will be well imployed: All this while, the water came from him in uch abundance, that the hepheard being more empty, began to breathe: but did not yet open his eyes nor come unto himelf. Galathia having an opinion that he was the man, of whom the Druid had poken unto her, he her elfe did help her companions: and commanded them to carry him unto her Pallace of Ioures, where he might have the bet accommodations of help. And accordingly with much adoe, they carryed him to the place, where the litle Merill wood with their chariot, into which they all did get. Leonida undertooke to be their guide; and, becaue they hould not be eene by the guards of the Catle, they went in at a backe ecret dore. As oone as they were gone, Atrea reviving from her wounding fit, did fall into the water, as I told you before: Lycidas and they who went to earch for Celadon, could heare no other tidings of him, then, as formerly I told you: o as Lycidas, being but too well aured of his brothers death, he went to Atrea to condole with her their common diater. She, ad oul, did nothing ele but walk mourning along the River ide, untill he was o weary that he was forced to it downe as full of anger griefe and amazement, as a little before, he was of inconideration and jealouie. She was itting a lone by herelfe; for, Phillis eeing Lycidas returne, went out to heare ome newes, as the ret did. This Shepheard when he came, being weary and deirous to know how this misfortune came to pae, he did it downe by her; and taking her by the hand began to talke; Oh heavens, fair hepherdee, (aid he) what a fatall michance is this, which hath happned unto us; I ay, us, for as I have lot a deare brother o you have lot one who was not himelfe without you. Whether Atreas mind was intent upon ome other thing, or whether this dicoure was dipleaant unto her, I know not, but he returned no anwer; At which Lycidas being angry thus aid; Is it poible Atrea, that the loe of this unfortunate Son (for o Atrea called him) hould o little perplex you, that you cannot afford him one teare? Had he not loved you; or had you been ignorant of his affection, then to reent his misfortune o lightly, had been excuable: but ince he loved you infinitly above himelfe and that you could not be ignorant of it; beleeve me, Atrea,
it grieves me to ee you, as little concerned at it as if he were a meere tranger unto you.

The hepherdes then looked adly towards him, and after a little paue of conideration, anwered. Shephered, I am much grieved at the death of your brother, not in conideration of any affection which he bore unto me, but in repect of his many other excellent qualities, which might well move any to grieve at his misfortune: for, as for the affection which you poke of, it was o common unto other hepheardees my companions, as it was their parts to lament him more then mine. Oh mot ungratefull hepherdee, cryed out Lycidas, I hall thinke the gods unjut, if they do not punih you for your injutice: you have mall reaon to thinke him uncontant, who, for all the anger of his Parents and cruelty of your rigour, would not diminih the leat parke of his affection to you. This is ingratitude in the height, ince all his actions and ervices could not aure you of the thing, which none living ever doubted of, but your elfe: This am I certaine of, that he would ooner have diobeyed the Supreame gods, then the leat of your commands. Then did the hepheardee in an angry manner anwer, that this dicoure was diadvantagious to his Brother; for he had ufficient tetimonies of his infidelitie. You fill me full of wonder (replied Lycidas,) but I beeech you how came you to the knowledge of it? Shepherd, (anwered Atrea) the tory is too long and lamentable to be told: atisfie your elfe with this that if you do not know it you are the only one that is ignorant of it: for there is not a hepherd about the banks of Lignon which cannot tell you, that Celadon had a hundred Mitries. And, to be hort, thee eares of mine were no longer then yeterday witnees of the amorous dicoure which he held with his Aminthé (for o he called her) and I had hearkned longer unto it, had I not beene dipleaed at his perfidie, or, to tell you truly, had I not other buinee which was more advantagious unto me. Lycidas at this, like a man ditracted, cryed out: oh now, I ee the caue of my brothers death; it was your jealouie, Atrea; your jealouy is the onely caue of this dire diater. Poore Celadon! I now remember thy Prophetique words, when thou aidet, thy fain'd affection would cot thee thy life. Then addreing himelfe unto her, Is it poible Atrea (aid he) that you hould forget thoe commands, which you o often and preingly, did lay upon him? five or ix times at the leat, I can witnee he was down upon his knees, begging a revocation of them: You may remember when he returned from Italie it was your firt injunction to diemble love unto another, which he intreated you rather to bid him die then do. My deare Atrea aid he, (I hall never forget his words) though I mut & will be perfectly obedient unto all your commands, yet I cannot chue but throw my elfe at your feet, imploring onely o much favour as to bid me Die, rather then bid me erve any other then Atrea, And you did anwer, Nay, Shepheard, far be it from my thoughts to command you to Die; but it is to try your affection, and principally to blind the eyes and top the mouths of all inquiitive pies, that I do enjoyn this diimulation upon you. He, not being able to diobey you in any thing, undertooke the difficulty; and indeed difficulty I rightly phrae it. For he never went unto the place, where hee was to put his diimulation into practice, but he firt laid himelfe downe upon his bed, as if a trembling fit of a feaver came upon him. Not above two dayes ince, I found him engraving upon a tree, thee enuing veres, whoe characters, if you have not quite forgotten both him and his ervices, you will know, if you pleae to turne your eyes towards yonder tree on the other ide of the River, which containes thee lines:

lg.l: So much urmount my elfe I may
Though I am all in flame
And burne in love both night and day,
Yet to deny the ame;
But then to play the Hypocrite
And eeme anothers lave,
Whilt I adore a tarre o bright;
A heart I cannot have.
Yet if, to doo't or die, you Doome
Then this hould bee my choice
Jut now to chue death's dimall Roome
And in your Doome rejoyce.

div.p: Then did Lycidas 'hew her a letter, which Celadon by way of Anwer had written unto him ome eaven or eight dayes before.

body.head: Celandons Anwer unto Lycidas.
body.p: ENquire no further what and how I do; but know, that I am till ick of my former dieae; to love and not dare to hew it: Not to love, yet weare the contrary, deare Brother, is the continuall coure or rather torment of thy Celadon: They ay two contraries, cannot ubit in one thing at one and the ame time. And yet, both true and fale affection, is ordinary in all my actions: but never wonder at it; for I am forced to the one by the perfections, and to the other by the commands of my Atrea: If this kind of l • fe eeme trange unto thee, conider, that miracles are the common workes of the gods, and why hould not my goddee doe the ame in me?

div.p: It was long before Atrea anwered a word; for the dicoure of Lycidas had almot atonihed her: but the parks of jealouie which yet had ome power in her oul, caued her to take the letter, as doubting whether or no it was Celadon which writ it And though he knew it well enough to be his hand, yet according to the humor of many who will often argue againt their owne opinions, he diputed it. At the ame time, many hepheards came from the quet of Celadon, but had found no other ignes of him, then that of his Hat, which was no mall grief unto Atrea. She remembring a privat retyring place which love helped them to find out, and which he would not have found out, did becken unto Phillis to take that away: but every one, began to lament, and extoll the poore hepherd, and not one but had ome Noble act or other to Trumpet, in his praie. But Atrea who was the mot enible was the leat talkative: he was contrained to be mute, and to hew her orrow the leat, knowing that it is the highet point of prudence, in love to conceale affection, or at leat never to let it appeare unprofitably: but becaue the contraint he was in, was great, and he not able to endure it, he came to Phillis and entreated her not to follow her, to the end others might do the like. So taking Celadons hat into her hand, he tole away alone, and followed the firt path he lightt upon. Every hepherd in the company knew of Celadons affection to Atrea, though the pervernee of their Parents did dicover it more then his actions: but he did carry the matter with o much dicretion, that none knew of hers to him, except Semira, Lycidas and Phillis: And though they knew very well that the loe of Celadon did much perplex her, yet they did attribute it more unto the goodnee of her nature then her love. However, he continued on her way; and every tep had its thought or rather griefe: o as, ometimes doubtfull, ometimes aured of Celadons affection, he knew not whether he hould lay the blame upon him or herelfe when he thought upon what Lycidas had aid he judged him innocent: when the dicoure he had with the hepherdee Aminthé, came into her memorie, he thought him culpable. In this labirinth of thoughts, he went wandring through a wood, without any election of path: but either by fortune, or by the direction of heaven, to manifet the innocence of Celadon, he came to the place where Lycidas aid he had engraved ome veres, upon a tree: which was o freh that hee quickly found them out. Oh heavens, how oone he knew them to be Celadons, and how readily he ran to read them! She at downe upon the ground, and beholding Celadons hat and letter in her lappe, he wrong her hands and looked fixedly upon the reliques of her deare hepherd: and eeing his hat to well a little in the place, where he was wont to put his letters, when he had a deigne to convey a letter unto her, he unripped the lining with her fingers, and pulled out a paper which Celadon the ame day, had put there: this was a device contrived betwixt them, when their parents had forbidden them any intercoure of language: for, he eeming to throw his hat in jeat unto her, they might eaily convey letters unto each other. With a trembling heart and hand, he tooke this letter out, and after he had remooved from her eyes a thouand pearly teares, he read thee words.

body.head: Celadons Letter unto Atrea.
body.p:
IF you did impoe this contrained diimulation upon, me with a deigne to kill me with griefe, alas, you might more eaily have done it with one ingle yllable, and have aid,
Die. If it was to punih me for my faults, you were too gentle a Judge, in ordaining me a lee punihment then death: If it was to try what power you had over me, why did you not find out a more peedy way of triall, then this which would be o long before you could be atified? I cannot think it your intention to umbrage our deigne; ince I not being able to live long under uch contraint, my death will be a deplorable tetimony of it. Oh pitty me, my brightet Starre, conider that I have endured torment enough; and that it is now full time to be Celadon againe, after o long and lamentable a diimulation of himelfe.

div.p: Oh how thee words did wound her oul, when he called to memorie, the command he had laid upon him, and the reolution which they fixed upon, to diemble their affection. But ee the trange enchantments of love; for though hee grieved extremely at the death of Celadon; yet he was not without ome conolation in the midt of her orrowes, to think that he was not perfidious, though this conideration brought much force with it to torment her: o as having no other remedie to fly unto but teares, as well to lament Celadon as her owne loe, he began with a river of teares, and afterwards with a thouand pittifull groanes, and ad ighes: She called to mind the faithfull affection of that hepheard, and the depaire wherein he was at her evere anwer: then againe, thinking upon the happy times pat, the pleaures and contentments which he formerly afforded her, and now the loe both of him and them, he extreamly condemned her elfe of illy imprudence.

On the otheride, Lycidas being o extreamly dipleaed at Atrea that he could hardly with patience thinke upon her, he did rie up from Phillis, and went away with eyes o full of teares and o ad a countenance, that his hepherdee eeing him in that condition, did follow him, not fearing how others might cenure her for it: he went away with folded armes, his hat pulled downe but his oul much more downe in orrow: and pittie obliging the ret of the hepheards to participate of his orrowes, they followed alo and lamented with him. But thee officious complements were only additions to his griefe: for in company, the oule dares not o freely disburthen it elfe of its load; but when it is once dicharged of its venime, then it is capable of conolation. Being in this ad etate, they accidentally found a young hepherd lying upon the graffe and two hepherdees with him: the one of them holding his head in her lappe, and the other playing upon a L • te whilt he ighed out thee veres, with eyes up to heaven and face all tears.

lg.head: Upon the death of Cleon.
lg.l: That beautie, once a glorious Sunne
Alas it Set and done.
Thoe eyes, once Angelike divine,
Againe will never hine
Shee's dead, who did all hearts revive
Unlee in mine alive.
Perfection from the world is fled,
Since hee the owner's dead.
What hopes amongt the living left
Since we of her bereaft?
It eems, deare Saint, your better fate
Death did anticipate,
And, lieu of Cradle, Coffin ent;
Since gone as oone as lent:
No, no, it is not you did die
But it is rather I:
For only you did animate
My oul and life create:
Both oul and heart, and what is mine
Eternally is thine;
Thus Love or'e death gets victorie
Since till you live in mee
Or ele (God-like) lets Lovers live
Yet them no hearts doth give.
A Sea of Teares from fluent eyes
To the, Ile acrifie;
And when thoe mountaines are growne dry
Ile come to thee, and die.

div.p: Lycidas and Phillis had a good mind to enquire the caue of this hepherds griefe, if their owne would have permitted them but finding him to tand as much in need of conolation as themelves, they would not add the mieries of another unto their owne. And therefore leaving the ret of the hepherds to hearken further, they went on their way and none followed them.

Lycidas was no ooner gon but they heard another voice a far off, which eemed to draw neere them: and etting themelves to hearken, they were interrupted by that hepherdee who held the head of a hepherd in her lappe, and uttered thee complaints; Fie, fie, thou obdurate peece of cruelty, thou pittilee hepheard; how long will thy heart be marble, and eares topped to my prayers? Why hould one who is not, be preferred before one that is vowed thine? Tircis, Tircis, thou Idolizer of the dead, and enemy of the living; looke upon my poore affection; Love thoe that are alive, and let the dead ret quiet; trouble not their happie ahes with thy unprofitable teares; take heed, thou dot not draw vengance upon thy elfe, for thy cruelty and injutice. The hepherd, not o much as turning towards her, coldly anwered; I wih, faire hepherdee, that I could give you atisfaction by my death: I would willingly die to rid both you and my elfe from our torments: conider I beeech you Laonice, that you have no reaon to urge me to put my deare Cleon twice to death; Its enough, he has once paid the debt due to Nature. If now he is dead, he hould once againe revive in me, by force of my affection: would you have me remove her, by entertaining a new love into my oul? No, no, hepherdee, all your arguments are too weake to make me hearken unto any uch counell: that which you call cruelty in me, I tearm fidelitie; and that which you thinke worthy of punihment, I conceive deerves exceeding commendations: I have already told you, that the acred memory of my Cleon hall live with me in my grave. I have vowed it a thouand times both unto her and the immortall gods with whom he is; and do you not thinke that they would punih Tircis, if he hould breake all thoe olemne vowes, and become unfaithfull? Yes yes: the heavens hall ooner raine Thunderbolts upon my head, then I will either offend againt my vowes, or my deare Cleon. She would have replyed, when the hepheard, which they heard inging came neere and interrupted her with thee veres.

lg.head: The Song of the incontant Hylas

lg.l: If ere my Mitrie me didaine, then hang me if I ere complaine;
Ile ne're be drowned in puling orrow, but court a new one ere to morrow.
It is a toile, would tire a hore, to make a woman Love by force.
Thoe beauties which are over wie, and our addrees do depie,
Have at their hearts a fire more hot, although o cloe we ee it not;
Whilt Lovers dote upon uch dames, Rivals do warme them at their flames.
Its flat Idolatry, by Jove, to court a cruell beauties Love;

l.hi: Will any man of wit adore Idols that have no help in tore?
A contant lover is but gull'd and by his Loyaltie befoold;

lg.l: That imple crue of faithfull Lovers, you'l find them alwayes full of dolors:
Compos'd of ighes and cries and teares, they do both leep and wake in feares.
So as a Lovers life is found, the wort that breathes upon the ground.
Such as do child-like Pule and crye, when they have lot ome foppery,
Cannot be called by the Name of men, who any honour claime;
A Loving foole is till mot fit for uch a illy Amourite;
Such fables I have learnt to fly which nothing bring but miery.
I can be wie by others follie, and 'pite of Love, I can be Jollie,
I Value not a Ruh, if all the Ladies me uncontant call.

div.p:
At this lat vere, this Shepherd was o neare Tircis, that he perceived the teares of Laonice: and, though trangers, yet having a uperficiall acquaintance, Hilas knowing how it was betweene Laonice and Tircis, he addreed himelfe thus unto him Diconolate hepheard (for o every one did call him by reaon of his adnee) If I were like unto you. I hould thinke my elfe the mot pittifull peece of misfortune that lives upon earth. Tircis hearing this, thus anwered. And I Hylas, were I like unto you, I hould think my elfe more unfortunate then I am. Should I like you, (replied Hylas) drop teares for every Mitrie that I have Lot, I hould teare out my eyes before I had done. Were you like unto me, (anwered Tircis you would have but one to drop any teares for. And were you like unto me (aid Hilas) you would not drop a teare for any. Thats the reaon (replyed the ad hepheard) I do think you mierable; for if love be the only price and reward of Love never any did love you, becaue you never loved any. How do you know (anwered Hilas) that I never loved any? I know it, aid Tircis, by your perpetuall changing You and I do differ in opinions (aid he) for I ever thought that the more a workman is exercied in his trade, the more perfect he is in it. Tis true, anwered Tircis, when he workes by the rules of Art: but if otherwie, he is like unto travellers out of their way, the more they goe, the more they erre, and further from the right way. And as the rowling tone never gathers any moe, but rather dirt; o your leight incontancy may get ome hame, but never any Love. You mut know, Hilas, that the wounds of Love are uch as will never heale. Heavens deliver me from any uch (aid Hilas). You have good reaon for your prayer, replied Tircis, For if every time you were wounded with a new beautie, you hould receive an incurable wound, I am afraid there would not be one ound part in all your body. Moreover you never can relih any of thoe weets and felicities which Love betowes upon all true Lovers, and that miraculouly, like the ret of his actions: for they are cured by the ame, which wounds, like the word of Telephus which both cuts and heales: and I am perwaded that were you once permitted to know the ecrets of that god, you would preently renounce your incontancy. Hilas at this miled and aid. There is very great reaon, Tircis, that you hould put your elfe in the number of thoe whom Love ueth very well but as for my part, I do with all my heart quit my hare in all his weets: you may keep to your elfe all his felicities and contentments without any feare that ever I hall envie you. 'Tis now a whole month ince firt we met, and I think we met every day; I do not remember that day, that hour, nay nor that minute in which you were not entertaining your Love forooth, with that good company of teares: on the contrary, tell me that day, that hour, or that minute in which you hea • d me bid Love welcome o much as with one ingle igh? There's no man whoe tate is not quite out of tune as yours is, but will find more weetnee in the pleaantnee of my life, then in your dolefull ighs and obs. Then turning himelfe towards the Shepheardee who complained o of Tircis; And you, faire but unwie Shepheardee, take courage, and deliver your elfe from the Tyranny of this unnaturall Shepheard: cheere
up and live Will you by your patience make your elfe a complice with him in his crimes? do you not ee, that he glories in your teares? know you not, that your upplications doe puff him up with o much arrogancy, as he thinkes you to be highly obliged unto him if he does hearken unto you with didaine? The Shepheardee with a deepe igh anwered, It is an eaie matter, Hylas, for him that is ound to counell the ick: but if you were in my tead, you would know that all this advice is in vaine: you might find that orrow would ooner drive my oule out of my body, then reaon can drive this paion out of my oul. For this my beloved Shepheard has uch a Soveraigne power over me, that his authoritie can command what he pleaeth: pare then all your apient adviements Hylas: they will but feter my wounds the more; for I am o wholly devoted unto Tircis, that my will is not my owne How! (aid the Shepheard) your will not your owne? to what purpoe is it then to Love and erve you? The ame (anwered the Shepheardee) that my Love and ervices are unto this Shepheard. That is as much to ay (anwered Hilas) that I hould loe both all my time and my paines, and that if I hould profee my affection unto you, you would only make ue of my words to expree your affection unto Tircis but ince uch is your humour, and ince I have more command over my elfe then you over yours, I will only kie your hand and take my leave: for I hall be ahamed to erve uch a poore and pittifull Mitrie. Neither you nor I (anwered he) hall receive any great loe by it. Were you as enible of your loe in loing me, aid Hilas, as you hew implicitie in courting him, you would lament the loe of me, ooner then deire the affection of Tircis: but if you care no more for loing me, then I do for loing you, ile warrant you, neither of our orrowes hall ever hurt us. Then walking merrily away he ung thee veres.

lg.l: Love having wings will fly away as well as Time and oone decay;
Then let's be wie, and from us banih the thing which of it elfe will vanih.
Let's cut Loves cords, and quench its fires, with all exorbitant deires.
That thing let's voluntary do which time at lat will force us to:
Thus or'e the Gyant Love hall we be victors, mot triumphantly.

div.p: Had this Shepheard come into the country in a more merry eaon, doubtlee with more friends: but Celadons loe did it o adly upon the oules of all that neighbourhood, that none was in any mood of rallarie; and therefore they left him: ome returned to their cabins & others in farther quet of Celadon; ome on this ide, & ome beyond the River Loire; neither tuft nor tree ecaped their inquiitive earch, yet all in vaine: for no newes could be heard of him. Only Silvander did meet Polemas jut at the place, where Galathea and the other Nymphes had a little before taken him up. And becaue he Governed the country under the Authoritie of the Nymph Amais the Shepheard, who had often eene him at Marcelles, did render him all poible honour; and acquainted him with the loe of Celadon; at which Polemas was very orry, being ever a Lover of all Celadons familie.

On the other ide Lycidas, who was walking with Phillis, after a long ilence, at lat he turned towards her; well, faire Shepheardee (aid he unto her) what do you thinke of your companion? he not yet knowing of Atreas Jealouie, did anwere him, that he could not be much blamed, if he upon uch a ad accident did hun all company; for Phillis thought that he complayned becaue he went away alone: Nay, nay, replyed Lycidas, that's nothing; but I doe thinke her to be the mot ungratefull woman in the world, and the leat worthy of any Love: for my brother never intended, nor could he Love any but only he: he knew it well enough, cruell woman that he was: the tetimonies he gave her, were too evident to be doubted: he overcame all difficulties, he topt not at impoibilities: he valued not the anger of Parents, but endured her rigours, her cruelties, and corns, and all this o long, that I beleeve no other but Celadon was able to do it. And yet for all this, <> did mot unworthilie change her mind: her foolih pretences of hatred and jealouy has
eternally exiled him: and being grown deperate, he did chue death rather then uch a piece of crueltie as he. Oh Heavens! Lycidas, (aid Phillis in a great amazement) whats this you ay? Is it poible, Atrea hould ever commit uch a crime? It is mot certainly true (anwered the Shepheard) he has partly told me as much, and I do conjecture the ret by his dicoure. She tryumphs in the death of my brother, and her infidelitie and ingratitude can palliate her crime: but I do weare unto you by all that's acred, never any Lover was fuller of affection and fidelitie then he: I care not whether or no he ever know her error, unlee to vexe and grieve her; for now I am as profeed an enemy unto her, as ever my brother was faithfull. Thus Lycidas and Phillis dicoured, he being infinitely grieved for the death of his brother, and as much offended againt Atrea: and he, very orry for Celadons death, angred at the anger of Lycidas, and atonihed at the Jealouie of her companion would not apply any extreame remedies, at the firt; but only ome gentle preparatives to mollifie him. She would not by any meanes that the death of Celadon hould cot her Lycidas: and he conidered that if any hatred was betweene him and Atrea, he mut of neceitie breake off with one of the two; yet Love would not yeeld unto friendhip. On the other ide, Atrea was o welled in teares and uncke in orrow: as having not teares enough to wah away her error, nor words enough to expree her griefe, both her eyes and mouth did leave their offices unto her imaginations o long as both eyes, toung, imagination, and all other faculties being tyred out, he fell aleepe.

Whilt things paed thus amongt the Shepheards and Shepheardees, Celadon was oberved by the three Nymphes in the Pallace of Ioures with all indulgent care: but the hurt which the water had done him was o great, that for all their remedies which they applied, he could not open his eyes nor give any igne of life, but only by the beating of his heart, paing all the day and a good part of the night, before he came to himelfe; And when he opened his eyes, he was in a great amazement to find himelfe in that place: for he very well remembred what he had done and how a rah depair had made him throw himelfe into the water: but he knew not how he came thither. And after he had tayed a long while in this confued thought, he asked whether he was alive or dead. If I be alive (aid he) how is it poible that the cruelty of Atrea hould not kill me? And if I be dead, why, cruell Love, dot thou torment me in the hades of death? is it not enough that thou hat my life, but thou mut receive my old flames out of my dead ahes? And the great perplexitie in which Atrea had left him having now foraken him, he called into his memory all his former conceptions, and his mind being full of imagination both of his mieries and alo of his former happinee, he fell into uch a ound leepe, that the Nymphes had time enough to come and ee him, and finding him fat aleepe, they opened the curtaines and windowes very gently, and did it downe by him, the better to view and contemplate upon him. Galathea, after a whiles confideration, did in a low voice for feare of wakeing him, ay, oh how this Shepheard is changed ince yeterday? What a freh complexion is upon a uddaine come into his face? eriouly I do not repent of all the paines I have taken in aving his life; for as you aid, weetheart (aid hee, and turned towards Silvia) he is one of the principall in al the country: Madam, (anwered the Nymph) mot certainly he is; for Alippes is his Father, and Amarillis his Mother. How? aid Galathea, that Alippe o famous, who to ave his freind, did break open the Prion of the Viigotts at Uum? The very ame, (aid Silvia) I have eene him everall times at feats, which are kept by the Townes about Lignon. And becaue Alippes eemed unto me mot worthy of obervation, I looked long upon him: for the formalitie of his beard, and the gravitie of his venerable age, did exact honour and obervance from every one.

But as for Celadon I remember, that of all the Shepheards, there was only he and Silvander, who had confidence enough to approach me; by Silvander I knew which was Celadon, and by Celadon which Silvander: for both of them, had in their Garbes and dicoure omthing more generous, then the name of Shepheard ueth to owne. Whilt Silvia pake, Love, in mock age of the ubtiltie of Climante and Polemas, who were the caue of Galatheas coming to the place where he tooke up Celadon, did begin to kindle new flames in this Nymph; for all the while that Silvia poke, he had her eyes upon the Shepheard; and the applauds which he gave him, did enter into her oul; and the more eailie, becaue he was prepared for it by the coming of Climante, who counterfetting himelfe to be a Druide, had foretold her, that the man whom he hould meet with, in the place where he found Celadon, hould be her husband, unlee he would be the mot mierable woman in the
world; the plot being, that Polemas hould go to that place at the hour, to the end that he might more willingly be induced to marry him, which otherwie, the affection he bore unto Lindamor would not permit. But Fortune and Love, are too hard for Prudence; and ent Celadon thither by chance, as I have told you: o as Galathea, intending to fixe Love upon this Shepheard, did thinke him to be extreame Lovely: And eeing he did not wake, he went out as gently as he could, to entertaine her new thoughts.

There was neere his chamber a backe paire of taires, which opened to a low Gallerie, out of which, by a draw bridge one might go into a Garden full of choice varieties, Fountaines, Statues Walkes, Arbors and all that Art could invent; out of this Garden was a dore into a Wildernee of everall orts of Trees: in which was everall Labirinthes, wherein one might wander to the loe of ones elfe, yet by reaon of the umbrage were very delightfull: In one of which was a Fountaine called The truth of Love, a place in truth marvelouly pleaing: for by force of Inchantment, a Lover who looked in it might ee her, he loved: if he were Loved, he might ee his Mitrie by him if he Loved another, that other would be preented and not himelfe: And becaue it did dicover all the deceipts of Lovers, it was called the Truth of Love. In another, Labirinth was the Cavern of Damon and Fortune; and in another was the denn of an old Mandrake, full of o many wonders and witchcrafts, that every vanitie appeared a freh miracle. Moreover, in the other parts of the wood, there was everall other Grotts, o well counterfeited, and neere the naturall, as the eye did oft deceive the judgment. It was in this Garden, where the Nymph did walke waiting for the waking of the Shepheard: And becaue her new deires would not permit her to be ilent, he faigned to forget omthing which he commanded Silvia to go and eeke: for he confided lee in her green youth, then in Leonidas whoe age was arrived at more maturitie, though both thee Nymphes were her ecret confidents. And being alone with Leonida, he thus aid unto her; what do thinke, Leonida, has not this Druide a trange knowledge of things? Does not the gods freely communicate themelves unto him? for what is future, he knowes as well as the preent: The truth is, anwered the Nymph, he did very directly hew you in the Mirror, the very place where you found this Shepheard, and alo told you the very time; but his words were o ambiguous, that I beleeve he hardly undertood them himelfe. Why do you ay o, anwered Galathea, ince he hath particularly told me every thing as perfectly as I my elfe do not now kow them, better than he did before they happened? he only told you, anwered Leonida, that you hould find in this place a thing of an inetimable value, though formerly it had beene didayned: Nay, Leonida, aid he, he has told me more then that: particularly; Madam, aid he, you have two very contrary influences: the one the mot unfortunate under the heavens; the other the mot happie that can be deired: And it is in your choice to take which you will: And to the end you may not deceive your elfe, be pleaed to know, that you are and hall be coveted by many great and Noble peronages, where vertues and merits may eaily moove you: but if you meaure your affection by their meritts, or their Love, and not by what I hall tell you: from the upream gods, I do Prognoticate, that you will be the mot mierable woman alive. And to the end you may not be mitaken in your choice, remember that uch a day you hall ee at Mareilles a Knight in uch a habit, who does and will court you for marriage: which if you permit, then I do pronounce your miery. And therefore I advie you to hun uch a man and thinke upon him rather as your ad fate, then as your ervant: on the contrary, oberve well the place which is repreented in this Mirror, for on uch a day at uch an hour you hall there meet a man, in whoe affection the heavens has placed all your felicitie: if you can o order it, that he do Love you, never beleeve the gods againe, if you become not more happie then you can deire: but be ure, that the firt of you two who hall meet, be the firt that hall begin Love. This, Leonida, is as cleere as the Sun at noone, and I do already perceive that his predictions are true. For I eeing this Shepheard firt, I mut tell you truly, I find ome parkes of affection towards him. Good heavens! Madam (aid Leonida unto her) do you intend to place your Love upon a Shepheard? do you not remember who you are? I do o, Leonida, aid he, and you mut know that Shepheards are men as well as Druides and Knights, and their Noblenee is as great as others, both being prung from one and the ame originall: o as if this Shepheard be well borne, why hould I not think him as worthy of me as any other: The truth is Madam, aid Leonda, digrace it as you will, he is a Shepheard: The truth is, aid Galathea, he is a well accomplihed man. But Madam, anwered Leonida, you who are o high a Nymph, Lady; after Amais, of all thee goodly Countries: can your courage decend o low as to Love a
man of common ranke? a Rutique a Shepheard, a man not worth a traw? Friend, replyed Galathea, remember that Enone became a Shepheardee for Paris his ake, and when he lot him, She hed many a bitter teare. Madam, laid Leonida, Paris was a Kings onne; and the error of another, ought not to move you to the like. If it be an error, anwered he, the blame is in the gods who advie me unto it by the Oracle of their Druides: but, my freind, Celadon is not o farre off in kindred from Paris: are they not both come from the ame originall? Did you not heare what Silvia aid of him and his Father? You mut know they are not hepheards out of any want, but becaue they would enjoy that weet and harmlee kind of life. But deare Madam, added Leonida, can you thus forget the affection and ervices of the generous Lindamour? I am not willing, aid Galathea that oblivion hould be the recompence of his ervices: but I am unwilling withall, that my affection unto him hould be the utter ruine of all my happinee. Oh Madam (aid Leonida) I beeech you remember how full of fidelity he hath ever been. Oh my friend, aid Galathea I beeech you conider what it is to be eternally mierable. Certainly, aid Leonida, an extream affection, a pure fidelitie, the imployment of a whole age and continuall ervices ought not to be o long entertained, but merited a better requitall then a change. For God ake Madam, conider what impotures all thee Fortune tellers are: they vent for truthes the idle imaginations of their fond dreames: they are flat lyars, ince of a hundred predictions hardly one happens truly, they are o foolihly ignorant, ince for all their buinee in others mens matters they know not their owne fortune: will you bee perwaded by the fantaticall talke of this fellow, to make that man mierable who hath bin o much yours? Look but a little upon his Love; conider what hazards he hath run for you; how he fought with Polemas; what depaire he was then in; what torments you now prepare for him, and how hee will certainly invent ome way of death to himelfe when he knowes it. Galathea did hake her head, and thus anwered; Leonida, I mut not now thinke upon either Lindamor or Polemas as heretofore; but upon my owne eternall either happinee or miery; the motives you ue are very good for your elfe, who will be concerned no further then to a little pittie: but for my elfe they are very dangerous, ince the miery does not menace me for a day but for ever. Tis true, were I in your place, and you in mine, perhaps I hould give the ame advice: but certainly an eternall miery is very terrible: As for the fabulous conjectures of thoe Divinres which you peak of; I will for your ake beleeve, that perhaps they will not o fall out, and perhaps they will but I beeech you tell me, do you think any prudent peron will for the atisfaction of another, conclude all his happinee or all his miery upon a perhaps? But if you Love me, ue no more of this dicoure: for if you do, I hall thinke you aime at the atisfaction of Lindamure, more then mine. And as for him, never feare, but he will find out a better way of care then death: reaon and time will temper him how many deparato's have you eene, whom a little time has not perfectly cured? Thee two faire Nymphs thus dicoured, when they aw Silvia returne, and therefore they broke off this dicoure; but Galathea aid thus unto Leonida, conider that not only my contentment, but all my felicitle is at the take: Leonida could not reply, beeaue Silvia was o neere as to heare their dicoure. She being come, Galathea undertood that Celadon was awake, for litning at the dore, he heard him igh and groane: Tis very true, that a little while after their departure from his chamber, he did waken and the Sun hining very plendently upon his bed, as he opened his eyes he was o dazled that being confued with o great a light, he knew not where he was: his lat dayes paine had much atonihed him, but at that time he was without any pain; o as remembring his fall into the River and the opinion which he had a little before of his being dead, and now finding himelfe in uch a glorious light, he knew not what to thinke, unles that Love had ravihed him into heaven in recompence of his fidelitie: and that which mot induced him to this opinion, was to ee the chamber hung with uch rich hangings, and admirable pictures, o lively that his yet weake eye could not ditinguih them from ubtances. On the one ide, he aw Saturne leaning upon her ithe with her dangling long trees, her forehead wrinkled, her eyes ullen, her Eagle noe, her mouth bemeared with blood and yet full with a morell of her children, one of which halfe eaten was an her left hand which by the prints of teeth did emblem cruelty to the life. This little infant was revered, prawling with heeles upward and armes hanging downwards, all meared with blood which trickled from the wound which this hag had made with her teeth, whoe long and dangling haire did drop with blood in which it had been teeped her nervous and uglie armes were growne over in many places with griely haire, as well as her leane and withered
thighes: She trode upon heapes of bones ome growne white with antiquitie, others green and halfe flehy. All about him was nothing but peeces of broken cepters crownes crahed into peeces, ruined edifices, o as only ome leight reemblance of what they had beene remained. A little further off was to be eene the picture of great Jupiter with an enflamed countenance, but grave and full of Majetie, in his eyes, a mixture of benignitie and terror: with a Croune upon his head: in his left hand a Scepter, which he reted upon his thigh where was to be eene the carre which he gott, when by the imprudence of the Nymph Semele, to ave little Bacchus, he was forced to open that place, and carry the marke of it unto the end of his tearme. In the other hand he held his three poynted Thunderbolt, o well repreented, that it eemed to fly from thence through the Aire. His feet trampled upon a great Globe: and neere him was a great Eagle which carried in her crooked beak a Thunderbolt: upon the back of this bird did ride the little G • mimede, cloathed after the mode of the Inhabitants on the mountaine Ida; fat, plump, faire Golden and curled Lockes: with one hand he troked the head of the bird; and with the other he offered to take hold of Jupiters Thunderbolt but the bird with her traine did repule his feeble arme. Cloe by, tood the Bain and Eure out of which this little Skinker powred out Nectar unto his Mater: and this little officer, powring it upon the hands of Jupiter: he let the Eure fall and looked back as if ahamed of his act. At the feet of this God was a great Tun: and all about him the Vowes, Prayers, and Sacrifices of Mortals variouly repreented; for the Sacrifices were figured by moke intermingled with fire: and vowes and prayers were repreented by uch light Ideas, as the eye might know the meaning of them This dicoure would be too long, if I hould relate every picture particularly: for the chamber was full of them. Venus alo in a Sea hell amongt the ret, looked upon the wound which the Grecian gave her in the Trojan warre: and litle Cupid looked upon her by the Lamp of the too curious Psyche; And this o well repreented, that the Shepheard could not dicerne it from counterfeit. When he was thus deepe in contemplation, the three Nymphes came into his chamber, whoe beautie and Majety, did more plunge him into admiration That which mot helped on his conceipt of being dead, was, his fancying the three Nymphes to be the three Graces, epecially eeing the litle Merill amongt them whoe tature, beautie, plumpnee, Golden Lockes and Jolly Lookes eemed unto him, a Cupid. And though he was much confued in himelfe, yet his courage which was alwayes above the qualitie of a Shepheard did prompt him unto o much confidence, as to aske them in what place he was. Unto which Galathea anwered Celadon you are in a place where the people of it do intend your perfect cure; and we are thoe who finding you floting in the water, did bring you hither, where you have full power to command whatoever you pleae. Then Silvia, tepped forward & aid is it poible Celadon you hould not know me? Did you never ee me in your Village? I hope faire Nymph (anwered Celadon) that the condition I am in, will excue the frailty of my memory; Do you not remember Silvia, (aid he) and two of her companions, who went to ee your ports upon the day which you dedicated to the goddee Venus? And after you had won the coure, Silvia was he who gave you a Garland of Flowers which you did preently put upon the head of the Shepheardee Atrea? I know not whether thee paages be vanihed out of your memorie; but I am ure when you Crowned Atrea with my Garland, every one did wonder at it, by reaon of the emnitie which was betweene your two families; particularly betweene your father Alcippes, and Alces the Father of Atrea: And when I enquired the occaion of it, I could not learne any further, then that Amarillis being the Mitrie of thoe two Shepheards, they did Rivallike perpetually quarrell, untill uch time as Amarillis married your Father: and then Alces and the prudent Hippolita marrying together, they did both of them harbor an inveterate hatred againt them: o Celadon, you ee I know you, and have given you good tetimonies of what I ay. The Shepheard hearing this, did by degrees recollect into his memorie all he aid, but he was o atonihed that he knew not how to anwere, for knowing Silvia to be the Nymph of Amais, and by reaon of his Rurall life, having no acquaintance with her nor her companions, he could not now imagine how he hould come amongt them. At lat he replyed; all you ay, faire Nymph, is mot true, and I remember that upon the Fetivall of Venus, three Nymphes did betow three Garlands: It was my fortune to winne that of running: Lycidas my Brother won, that of leaping, and gave his Garland unto Phillis; and Silvander did winn that of inging, and preented it to the age Belinda. But truly, I cannot remember the names of thoe Nymphes the doners, only we contented our elves with knowing that they were the Nymphes of Amais and Galathea: for we alas, are
Country Inhabitants of fields and woods, and our wits are not Calculated for any higher Meridian, and therefore made no further inquity of you. Have you met with no further knowledge of us ince that (aid Galathea?) The information that I had (anwered the Shepheard) was from the dicoure which my Father made of his fortunes, in which I have often oberved him to mention Amais, but I am not at all acquainted with any particulars concerning her, though I have much deired it. Your deire, Shepheard, replyed Galathea, hall be atisfied, and I will tell you, both who Amais is, and who we are.

Know therefore, welcome Shepheard, that Anciently this Country now called Forrets, all floated with a deepe Abye of waters, & only the high Mountaines about it was uncovered except ome hills in the middet of the plaine, as the Rock of Ioures & mount Verdon: o as all the Inhabitants did live upon the tops of the Mountaines. The Ancient families of this Country, have their names engraved upon old ruines, upon the tops of the hills. But about fourteen or fifteen ages ince, a Romane who in ten yeares conquered all the Gaules, did cut ome of the Mountaines, by which the water rann away and drained our plaines: which eemed o pleaant unto him as he would needs make them habitable: and to that end caued all thoe who lived on the Mountaines to come and live in the plaines and caued the firt building there, to be called after his owne name Julius. And becaue the humid plaines produced abundance of Trees, ome ay the country was called Forrets, and the people Forreters; whereas before they were called the Seguians: but thoe were much deceived. For the name of Forret did come from Forum, a little Towne which the Romans built and called Forum Seguianorum, as if they would have aid, the place or the marh of the Seguians, which indeed was onely the place where they kept their Armes whilt they were putting their neighbour Countries into order.

This, Celadon, is the antiquitie of this Province, as ome do confidently hold; but there are two opinions quite contrary. The Romans ay that when our plaines were all covered with water, the chate goddee Diana, thought the place o pleaant that he dwelt there very much: for her Driades and Amadriades, did live and hunt in thoe great woods and high hills, which circled about this great Levell of waters: and becaue there was no great tore of Fountaines, he came hither often with her Naiades which alo dwelt here: but when the waters were let out, the Naiades were forced to follow, and go with them into the wide Ocean. So as the Goddee loing halfe her Nymphs, and not being able to take her full winge of delight with o mall a Traine, he made choice of ome daughters of the Principall Druides and Knights, and joyned them unto the Nymphs which remained, unto whom alo he gave the name of Nymphs. But o it hapned, that many amongt them, ome being brought up under fond and tender Mothers, others ued to the courthip of ervants; and not being able to take the paines of hunting, nor loe the memorie of their affectionate ervants, they would needs go back to their houes againe and Marrie. At which the Goddee was o incened that She forooke this prophane Country, and did fly from that vice which he o much abhorred. But not to punih the vertues of ome for the errours of others, before he departed he did for ever mot ignominiouly banih out of the Country, all thoe who had beene faultie, and made choice of one, unto whom he gave the ame Authoritie which he had over all the Country, and willed that the Race of this one hould have all the Soveraigne power for ever: And ever after he permitted them to marry. Yet exprely forbidding that any man hould ever ucced her. Since this time there hath been no abue amongt us, & our Lawes have been ince mot inviolably oberved. But our Druides do tell a quite contrary tale: For they ay that our great Princee Galathea; daughter unto the King of Celtes, wife of the great Hercules, and Mother of Galathea who gave name unto the Gaules, that were before called Celtes, being infinitly in Love with her husband did follow him whither oever his courage and vertue did invite him againt the Monters and Gyants: At that time, thee mountaines which eperate us from A • vergne, and thoe more on the left hand which are called Cemene and Gebene, were a retreat unto ome Gyants, who were terrible unto all the Country. Hercules being advertied thereof, went thither and becaue he did infinitly love his deare Galathea, he left her in this Country, which was nearet to him, & where he might take much pleaure, either in hunting or in the company of the Country Ladies: and becaue he was Queen of all the Gaules, when Hercules had vanquihed the Gyants, & neceitie of affaires called him away; before her departure, in eternall memorie of the delight he tooke in that Country, he ordayned that which the Romans ay the Goddee Diana did. But whether it was Galathea or Diana, yet o it is, as if by a upernaturall priviledge, we have ever ince been maintained
in our priviledges, ince none ever troubled our tranquillitie. Nay Alaricke King of the Viigots, when with Aquitaine he had conquered all the Provinces on this ide Loire, knowing our tatutes, did confirme the priviledges, and without any uurpation, did leave us in our antient freedome. Perhaps you will thinke it trange I hould o particularly talke of things which trancend the capacity of my age; but you mut know that Pimander my Father was very inquiitive unto the Antiquities of this country; o as the mot knowing Druides did commonly make it their dicoure with him, & I gleaned uch fragments from them as mot delighted me. Thus I came to know that Amais my Mother was in a continued line decended from her whom the Goddee Diana or Galathea did elect: he being ole Lady of all thee Countryes, and having one Sonne called Clidaman; She brought up with us many young maides and daughters of Druides and Knights, where being in o good a choole, they might learne all the vertues which their age and exe was capable of. The Virgins go habited as you ee us, in the ame fahion which Diana or Galathea was accutomed to weare, and which in memorie of her we have contantly kept. Now, Celadon, I have acquainted you with our condition; and I am confident that before you part from us (for I would have you ee us altogether before you go) you will confee, that our aembly will not yeild unto any other, either in vertue or beautie.

Celadon now knowing who thee Nymphes were, he knew alo what reverence was due unto them; and though his converation had been onely amongt his equall Shepheards, yet his good education had taught him how to behave himelfe unto his uperiors. After he had rendred them all the honour which he thought himelfe obliged unto, I cannot chue but wonder, aid he, to find my elfe amongt o many great Nymphs: and I who am but a imple illie hepheard, to receive o many favours from them. Celadon (anwered Galathea) vertue, in what place oever it is will merit both Love and Honour as well when it is hrowded under the cheap habit of a hepheard, as under the rich and glorious Purple of a King; and for your particular, you are in no lee conideration amongt us, then the greatet of the Druides or Nobles of our Court; for ince your merits are as great, our favours hall be no lee. And as for your wonder at finding your elfe amongt us, know that it proceeds from the Providence of the Gods, who have o ordained it (as at more leaure you may know) either becaue they would not have o much vertue lot in the Forrets; or, intending to make you greater then you are, they will by you, make a peron who loves you, happy: live then, and be happy, for you need deire no more then your health. Madam (anwered the Shepheard who did not well undertand this language) If I mut deire mine owne health, it hall be only to render you ervice, in exchange of o many favours which you are pleaed to conferre upon me: But for my part, I mut thinke of no other coure but returning to the woods and Patures; otherwie the olemne vow which our Fathers have made unto the Gods, will accue us to be unworthy children of uch Fathers. What vow is that, ad the Nymph? The Hitory of it would be too long replyed Celadon, but in hort this, Madam; All thoe about the Rivers of Loire, Turan, Argent and all the ret of the Rivers, have everall yeares with one accord, aembled in that great Plaine which is neere Mount Verdum, and conidering the Inconveniences which ambition and deire of rule, in that people called Romans, hath brought upon all their Neighbours, they do all by mutuall conent weare to fly all ambition for ever, and they and their children to live peaceably in the habit of hepheards. And ever ince it hath been oberved (o pleaing was this vow unto the Gods) that whooever broke this oath, did never proper. And amongt us, my Father is the mot remarkable example: So as now eeing the will of heaven is to have us live in ret, we have a new ratified this vow, with o many acred oathes, as he that breakes it hall be mot detetable. I do profee, anwered the Nymph, I am very glad to heare this: for I never knew before, the reaon why o many good and antient families have foraken Townes and pend their dayes in woods and olitary places. But, Celadon, if your condition will permit you, I hall be very glad to heare you relate the fortune of your Father Alippes, and why he betooke himelfe to that kind of life, which he had o long laid aide; for I am mot confident, it is mot worthy of knowledge. Then the hepheard, though not very well, yet contrained himelfe to obey her, and began thus.

div.head: The Hitory of Alcippes.
div.p:
Madam, you command me to relate the mot intricate tory in the world; and in which one may learne that whooever contrives the hurt of another mut prepare himelfe for a great part of it. In obedience therefore to your commands I hall briefly tel you, what I have gleaned from the ordinary dicoure of him, unto whom all the things hapned: for, to make us more enible of our happinee in living at ret, my Father hath often related unto us his trange fortunes. Be pleaed to know then, Madam that Alcippes, being educated by his Father in the implicitie of a hepherd, had ever a Genius far different from his education; and any thing that melt of a Town pleaed him much better then a Field: So as when he was a little boy, his delight was in aembling other boys together, and etting them into order; and do what the grave Signiors could, he would till be teaching them how to arme themelves, and hoot in bowes. The Ancients of our village, who oberved his actions did Propheie great troubles to enue upon their country, and that Alcippes was of too turbulent a pirit to be kept within the compae of a hepherd. When his age became more virile he fell in Love with the hepherdee Amarillis, who was then ecretly corrted by another hepheard called Alces. And Alcippes having o good a conceipt of himelfe, that he thought any hepherdes would bid his affection welcome whenoever it was offered, he reolved not to ue much artifice, in declaring himelfe: o as meeting her at one of the Sacrifices unto Pan. as he was returning home to her village he aid unto her; I could never have believed my elfe o weake, as not to reit the blowes of an enemy, who hath wounded me and never thought upon it. She anwered him, that he who wounds againt his will ought not to be called an enemy. But I do find it otherwie, anwered he, and therefore I may very well give this name unto you: who I? replyed he, I was never o, either in thought or act: for I ever et a great valew upon your merit. This is one of the wounds you give me, aid he: but I ee you can carry Love in your eyes and in your mouth, but will not harbour it in your heart: The hepherdee then finding her elfe urpried, and that he did meane matter of Love, he anwered: I do et uch a value upon your vertue Alcippes as I ought to do; but as for any Love, whereof you peak, beleeve me I have none for any, either in my eyes or heart; epecially for uch pittyfull pirits as can content themelves to live like Savages in woods. It is not the election of love but my detinie which makes me yours, replyed the hepherd; and uch a reemblance of humor there is betwixt us, that I have borne a mot deadly hatred unto a hepherds life, which you corne o much, even from my very cradle: I do protet that if changing my condition will promote me into your favour I wil immediatly quit my flock and heephooke, and live amongt men, not amongt Salvages. You may change your condition, anwered Amarillis, but not me; for I am reolved to be till o much my elfe, as not to give my affection unto another. If therefore you would have us live as formerly we have done leave off this dicoure of affection and Love, and talke of uch things as we were wont, ele thinke it not trange that I banih you my preence ince it is impoible that Love and the Civilitie of Amarillis hould dwell together. Alippe not expecting uch an anwer was o confounded that it was a long while before he could anwer but, being come to himelfe, he was perwaded, that it was the bahfullnee of her age and exe, not want of any good will to him, made her give uch an anwer: And therefore he anwered: whatoever you are pleaed to be or ay, I hall never be any thing but your devoted ervant. And if the command you have impoed upon me were not incompatible with my affection, you may mot confidently beleeve, that nothing in the world can make me diobey. But I beeech you excue and uffer me to continue my deigne which is onely a tetimony of your merit: for whether you will or no, I am reolved to proecute it. The hepherdee then turning her eye milingly upon him, I know not Alippe (aid he unto him) whether this be for ome wager, or out of willfullnee, that you peake thus. It is both (anwered he) for I have laid a wager with my deires to overcome you, or to die: and this reolution is changed into obtinate willfullnee, ince nothing can divert me from that oath which I have taker. I hould have been very glad, anwered Amarillis, if you had made choice of ome other marke for your importunities: Nay, nay, aid the hepherd, all this cannot make me alter my deigne; Then think not much, replyed Amarillis, if I be as firme in my obtinacie, as you are in your importunitie. The hepherd would have replyed, but he was interrupted by many hepherds comming towards them. So as Amarillis for a concluion aid unto him in a low voice, you will do me a great dipleaure Alcippe, if your reolution hould be knowne: I can be contented to know your follies, but hould,
be much dipleaed if any other hould know them. Thus ended my Fathers firt dicoure with Amarillis, which did infinitly angment his deire of erving her. As they went along the way they met Celion and Belinda, who were oberving two turtles, billing and making Love unto each other, not caring a traw who aw them, which gave Alcippes an occaion to remember the lat commands of Amarillis, and to ing thee veres; and becaue his voice was very good, every one did lend a ilent eare.

lg.head: A Song upon the Contraints of honour.
