lg.l: Loook yonder on the open Loves of thoe two billing turtle Doves!
See how this happie little paire, in Love what libertines they are;
They kis, and care not who doth know it, but to the envious world do how it.
The Lawes of honour o unjut, like fettred laves oberve we mut.
This bugbeare Honour which affrights, fond Lovers in their free delights,
Will not allow them any blie, unlee they teal their happinee.
While thee free Lovers of the Aire, what eyes do ee them, doe not care.
But Love and kie, and take a pride, in that which honour bids us hide:
Honour's a Tyrant then, and we are laves, whilt turtle doves are free.

div.p: Since this time, Alcippes was o tranported with Love that he knew no Limits: And Amarillis on the contrary, hewed her elfe all Ice unto him: and one day when he was deired to ing he made this his ubject, thus put into vere.

lg.head: Upon the Coldnee of Amarillis.
lg.l: Her heart is Ice, her eyes all flame, mine all contrary to the ame;
I'me Ice without, within all fire, my hearts inflam'd with hot deire:
Love, I beeech thee, change deigne, and thaw her heart, or ele freeze mine.

div.p: At this very time, as I told you before, Alces was a profeed ervant unto Amarillis: and being a hepheard of very excellent qualities, alo held to be exceeding wie, the Father of Amarillis inclined more unto him then unto Alcippes, becaue of his turbulent pirit: On the contrary, the hepheardee loved my Father better, becaue their humours were more utable: which her Father knowing, and being unwilling to ue any violence or abolute authoritie over her, he conceived, that time and abence might worke an alteration in her; and therefore reolved to end her awhile unto Artemis, iter of Alces, who dwelt alone by the River of Allier. When Amarillis undertood her Fathers mind, he reolved to acquaint Alcippes with her good will unto him, before he went: and to that end, writ thee lines.

body.head: The Letter of Amarillis unto Alcippe.

p.hi: YOur reolutenee hath urpaed mine: and mine alo far urmounted my elfe, as to accquaint you that tomorrow, I am gone; And if you will meet me today, where we parted yeterday, I will there bid you adieu.

div.p: It would be too tedious Madam, to tell you all the particular paages betwixt them: let it uffice, to tell you in hort, that they met at the place appointed: and there it was, where my Father received the firt aurance of the Love of Amarillis: there he perwaded him, to quit a hepherds life, as unworthy of a noble pirit, promiing him to be mot contant to her reolution of loving him. After they were parted, Alcippes engraved thee veres upon a Tree in the wood.

lg.head: Alcippes, upon the Contancy of his Affection.

lg.l: When Rocks remove, and Rivers backwards run; when Marble melts; and Glowewormes dim the Sun;
And when Impoibilities are done; then may my heart my Amarillis hun.

l.hi: When it is knowne what is Eternitie; when Gnats o're Eagles getts the victorie;

lg.l: When Fire doth freeze, and the vat Ocean's dry; then may my Love to Amarillis die.
VVhen Swans and Snow are Metamorphos'd black; when Starres do fall; and the two Poles do crack;
When loving Turtles do their Mates for ake; Then may my Love to Amarillis lake.
VVhen in the Orient, Sun and Stars do et; when mortals, in a bagge the wind doe get;
VVhen Steele the attracting Loadtone will not meet; then Amarillis may I thee forget.
VVhen Shippes do aile full 'gaint the blating wind; when Light is darknee, Angells are unkind;
VVhen Heavens diolve; and Time an end does find; then Amarillis, thou art out of mind.

div.p: When he was gone; and when he began to reent the horrour of abence, he went to the ame place where he bad adieu unto his hepherdee, and ighed out thee veres everall times.

lg.head: In abence of Amarillis.
lg.l: Fair Amarillis and the Sun, do hold exact comparion;
And both alike dipeneth light, by preence; and by abence, Night.
What glorious Summer is it here when he is preent in our Sphere?
How like to winter lookes the day; when he her Rayes does not diplay?
When hee's not preent, I'me undon, as Earth in abence of the Sun;
With Owles, and Bats, and Birds of night; I it, and igh away delight;
And am ociety for none, but uch a ad companion.
Since abence was my dimal doome; my heart, alas, was not at home:
My eyes two Fountaines are, which vie with Lignon which hould firt be dry.
All faculties do droop and mourne, till Amarillis do returne.
But when the day hall dawne that he, within our Hemiphere hall be;
Then VVinter's gone, and Summer's come; I'le bid my heart a welcom home:
I'le wipe all teares from welled eyes, my Batts and Owles, I will depie;
And with the joviall birds in pring, to her an Antheme I will ing.

div.p: But he, not being able to abide in that place where he was wont to ee her, he reolved (whatoever came on't) to be gone; and as oone as he ought for an occaion, he found it to his hearts deire. A little before, the Mother of Amais died: and Preparations were in hand to entertaine her in the great Citie of Marelles as their new Lady, with abundance of Tryumph. This olemnity, did draw thither out of curloitie, mot of the Country: and amongt the ret, my Father obtained leave to be one: from hence did pring much of his mierie. He was in the prime of his age; faire, beyond any in the Country; his hair flaxen which naturally curled in rings, and which he wore very long; in briefe, Madam he was uch a one as I beleeve Love did chue out for a marke of revenge; and thus it was. There was a certain Lady which had een him and loved him in uch a ecret diguie that we could never know her name. When he came firt to Marelles, he came as a hepherd, but in a very handom mode; and to the end he hould not run into any extravagancyes, as he did in his owne Hamlet his Father ent two hepherds with him as guardians, the principall of which was called Cleantes, a man whoe humour was utable unto my Fathers, inomuch as he affected him exceedingly. This Cleantes had a Son called Clindor equall in age with my Father, and had a naturall inclination to Love Alcippe.

Alcippe, in retaliation of this affection, did alo Love him above any other; which was o pleaing unto Cleantes, that he could not deny my Father any thing and therefore, after they had oberved how other Gallants were habited: how they were armed; and how they fought at Barriers, both of them beeeched Cleantes for uch allowance as might put them into the equipage of appearing amongt thoe Knights and Gallants. Have you o much courage (aid Cleantes unto them) as to equal your elves with them? Why not? (anwered Alcippes) have I not armes and thighes as well as they? Though you have, (aid Cleantes) yet you have not learned the Garbe, and civill deportment of Townes. Tis true (anwered he) but uch ceremonies are not o difficult as to blat the hopes of quickly learning them. You have not yet the ue of your armes (aid Cleantes) nor know how to fence, or fight as they do: Tis no matter replyed Alcippes, we have courage enough to upply that defect. Why would you leave off a country life? Said Cleantes; what hould men do in woods (Anwered Alcippes) and what good can men learne amongt beats? It will vexe you, aid Alcippe, to be lighted by the Ladies, who will light and corne you, and upbraid you with the name of hepheards. If to be a Shepheard be ignominious, (aid Alcippe) let us own that profeion no longer; and if it be not, then the didain will not hurt us: for if they do, I will indeavour by my actions to get honour and eteem amongt them. At lat Cleantes eeing their reolutions to change their lives; well children (aid he) ince you are thus reolved, let me tell you that though you pae under the notion of hepherds, yet your extraction is from the bet branch in the Country, and the noblet Knights in all France, have no better a pedigree then you have, though your Ancienters upon ome certain coniderations, made choice of uch a retired kind of life. Never fear, therefore, the
finding a good reception amongt thee Cavaliers, ince the very bet amongt them is of your own blood. Thee words, did kindle the parks of their deire unto a flame; and made them more forward to put their reolutions into execution; never reflecting upon the future, nor thinking what inconveniency that kind of life might bring them; nor dorring at the dipleaure of Alcippes Father. Cleantes provides them all necearies; they did quickly ininuate themelves into acquaintance, and get love amongt the bet; Alcippes was grown o expert in armes; that he was accompted one of the bet Knights of his time.

During this feat, which lated two monthes, a certain Lady as I told you before, had een my Father, and was o much taken with him that he devied this Stratagem to bring her ends about. Upon a day when my Father was in the Temple; an old woman came and et her elfe cloe by him: and eeming as if he were at her prayers, he aid two or three times, Alcippes, Alcippes, but never looked towards him. He hearing himelfe named, did think to ask her what he would have with him, but eeing her eyes turned another way; he thought he had poken to ome other. She perceiving that he heard her, continued, Alcippes, it is to you I peak, though I did not look upon you; if you will enjoy a better fortune, then ever any Knight in our Court did, meet me in the twilight at the Piazza neere the Pallace, and there I will accquaint you further. Alcippe hearing this, anwered her with a regardlee look, that he would be there: and he failed not. For as oon as night came, he went to the place appointed, where he tarried not long for the old woman, who mufled up in a taffatle hood, took him aide and aid unto him, Young man thou art the happiet man alive in the affection of the fairet Lady, and greatet beautie in all this Court, whom (upon uch conditions as I hall require) if thou wilt, thou halt enjoy, and receive fullnee of delight. Young Alcippe hearing this faire offer, asked who the Lady was? Firt, aid he, you mut promie never to enquire her name, but to keep your happy fortune extreamly ecret; the next condition is, that you let me blind your eyes, when I conduct you to her. Alcippe told her, that as for enquiring her name, and keeping ecrey, he would mot willingly conent; but as for his being blinded, he would never uffer it. What dot thou fear man, (aid he): I fear not any thing, anwered he, but I would have mine eyes at liberty. Fond young man (aid the old woman) what a novice yet thou art? Cant thou find a heart to light uch a fair opportunity upon uch eaie conditions? Come come, never dorr at it, nor doubt any danger: where is the courage that thy preence promieth? can any imaginary perill affright thee from a mot certain happinee? Then eeing him un willing; Cured be thy mother (aid he) who brought thee forth: thou hat thy countenance & thy courage more from her, then thy father: Young Alcippes could not hear the language of this angry old woman without laughing: and afterwards bethinking himelfe what enemyes he had, he reolved to go along with her, provided he would let him weare his word; and o he uffered her to hood wink him, and conduct him whether he would. I hould be too long and tedious, Madam, hould I relate every particular of this night: but after many turnings and windings, and perhaps everall times one way, he was brought into a chamber, where blindfold, he was undreed by this old woman, and got into bed: A little after came the Lady who ent for him, and went to bed unto him, where after the light was taken away he did unmuffle his eyes: but, do what he could, he could not draw one yllable from her. So as he roe the next morning, and knew not who his bedfellow was, onely he imagined her to be young and fair: and an hour before day he who brought him thither; came to conduct him back again with the ame ceremonies: And it was agreed between them, that whenoever he was to come again; he hould find a little tone in a corner of the Piazza the ame morning.

Whilt thee things thus paed, Alcippes Father dyed: o as he was ole Mater of himelf; and had not the commands of Amarillis retrained him, perhaps he might have retired himelfe into a Country life again. For all the favours of this unknowne Lady could not drive her out of his mind. The great gifts which he often received from her, could not do it: nor could the favours of Pimander and Amais, which he had obtained, have retained him from the woods. But, it being hard for a young pirit to keep any thing ecret long, Clindor his dear friend eeing him pend after a vat rate, he asked him how he was able to maintaine o great an expence? At firt he was omthing hie; but afterwards, told him his adventure of this unknown Lady; and how all the art he had, could not dicover who he was Clindor advied him the next time he went to cut off a peece of the fringe at the foot of the bed and the next morning to go unto all the houes which he could upect, and try if he could find any uch bed; which he did; and by this trick my Father came to the knowledge
of her who was o favourable unto him. Yet he ever kept it o ecret, that neither Clindor, or any of his children could ever know it. But the firt time he went to her after this, when he was ready to rie in the morning he conjured her to conceal her elfe no longer, for he knew he was uch a one. She, hearing her elfe named, was ready to peak: yet he kept ilence, untill the old woman came: then when Alcippes was gone, he terrified her with a thouand meanaces, uppoing that he had dicovered her unto him; o as the poor old band came trembling to my Father and told him that he had deceived her. Then he in a miling manner told her his device which he had ued, and that it was the invention of Clindor. She, extreamly glad of this dicovery, after a thouand denialls of it, went to tell this Lady of it. And when he knew that Clindor was the inventor of this artifice, he turned her anger againt him, & eaily pardoned Alcippe, whom indeed he could not hate: yet from that day he never ent for him again. And ince nothing is o weet as revenge unto an offended pirit, this woman was never at ret till he had prung a quarrell between Clindor and one that was Cozen unto Pimander, whom Clindor killed; and though he was purued, yet by the help of Alcippes, he got into Anvergne and aved himelfe: But Amais tranacted o with Alerick King of the Viigots who was then at Thouloue, as he did imprion him at Uon with command unto his officers that they hould remit him into the hands of Pimander, who intended his death. Alcippe left no tone unturned to obtain his pardon but all in vaine. Wherefore foreeeing the inevitable ruine of his freind he reolved at what rate oever, eyther to ave him or die with him. He was then at Uon, as I told you before, a place o trong, as it eemed meere folly to attempt the getting him out: however not being able to live without Clindor, he reolved to be beforehand with thoe who were to go thither from Pimander: o as going away in a dicontent, he get a dozen freinds, and came to the gates of the Catle, clad like Country fellowes, having under their jackets hort words, and baskets on their armes, as if they came to ell omething. I have ince heard him ay, that there was three Forts all one within another. Thee reolute Peaants came to the outmot of them, where they found very few of the Viigots upon the Guard: for mot of them were gone into the Town, to provide necearies for the Garrion. Being come o neer, they offered their commodities to ell at o cheap a rate, that almot all within came to buy them. Then my Father, pying his opportunity got him who guarded the gate by the neck, killed him; and at that very intant every one of his commpanions killed his man and entring in, kept the ret out at the words point: then running to the Prions they found Clindor and o many others, as being armed they thought able to maintaine the Garrion. To abridge my dicoure, I will onely tell you Madam, that though upon the Alarme the gates of the Town were hut, yet they forced them and got out without the loe of one man, though the Governour who was killed there, did make a very brave reitance. Thus was Clindor aved, & Alerick being accquainted, that this enterprize was acted by my Father he was o incened againt him, as he ent to Amais to demand jutice upon him & he unwilling to loe his friendhip, ent preently to eae upon my Father: but his friends gave him uch timely notice of it, that he got out of the Country, and joyned himelfe with a Nation who a little after entred France and in hotile manner came as farr as the Rone and Arar, and ome part of the Allobroges; and being deirous to enlarge their territories they made a fierce warr upon the Viigots the Otrogots & the Romans: amongt thee was my Father entertained, & being known for a man of valour, was preently honoured with everall Commands. But within a few yeares, Gondioch King of this Nation dying, Gordebert his Sonn ucceeded him in the Throne of Bourgundie: and being deirous to ettle his affaires in the beginning he contracted peace with his neighbours, marrying his Son Sigimond unto one of the Daughters of Theodorick King of the Otrogots: and to hold faire with Alerick who was implacably offended againt Alcippes, he promied to entertaine him no longer. So as he departed thence, and cloed with another people, who from the Reihn •
did eae upon part of France in pight of the Gaules and Romans. But Madam, the dicoure would be much too tedious hould I particularie every paage of this voyage; for from thence he was forced to London unto King Arthur, who as I have heard did at that time intitute the order of Knights of the Round Table: afterwards being hunted out by Alerick, he paed the Seas, and went to Bizantium where the Emperour gave him the command of his Gallies. But the Love to ones own country being above all others, my Father though in great favour with o many Emperours, yet had greater deire to breathe in his own native aire: and Fortune did preent the meanes unto him when he leat expected it. Alerick died: and Tyherre his Son ucceeded him, who having many Brothers, had enough to do in maintaining
his own, without thinking upon his Fathers enemyes. And therefore, being deirous to carry fair withall in the beginning of his Reigne, he publihed a generall Act of Oblivion, which pardoned all offences committed in his Kingdome. This was a good tep to Alcippes returne, if Pimander had once forgot the injurie which he received: yet as the Viigots were intrumentall in his banihment, o Fortune would have them as forward in his repeal •
<> little before, (as I told you) Arthur, King of great Brittaine, had intituted the Knights of the Round Table: an order coniting of a certain number of young vertuous men, who were obliged to go and eek adventures, to punih the wicked, to relieve the oppreed, and to defend the honour of Ladies. Then the Viigots of Spaine which then dwelt in Pampoluna, in imitation of this Order, did chue out a number of Knights, who went into many Countries and hewed their valour. And at that time, there came one of thee Viigots, after a long wandring through many Countries, unto Marelles; where having made his accutomed challenge, he vanquihed many of Pimanders Knights whoe heads he all cut off, and as enigns of his valour, ent them unto a Lady in Spain whom he courted as his Mitris Amongt he ret Amarillis lot an Uncle, who, like my Father not relihing a Shepherds life, had betaken himelfe to armes. As oon as Amarillis heard of this ad Accident, he imparted the news by letter unto my Father; not with any deigne of his comming to her but only to make him a partner in her loe. Love, which ever prompts a noble oul unto a thouand generous deignes, would not permit my Father to know of Amarillis loe, and itt till: but he reolved immediatly upon revenge. Therefore with the Emperors leave he came diguied into Cleantes houe, who undertanding his reolution, did endeavour to diwade him, but Loves arguments were of more validity then his. One morning when Pimander was going to the Temple, Alcippes armed Cap a pe preented himelf before him; and though his helmet was up, yet his beard was o grown ince his departure, that he was not knowable. As oon as Pimander undertood his buinee, he ent an Herald to acquaint the Viigot with it: To be hort, my Father overcame him; and preented his word unto Pimander, who was exceedingly glad that this cruell Viigot was vanquihed. Then, not making himelfe known unto any, except Amarillis, who aw him in the houe of Cleantes, he returned unto Bizantium, where he found his accutomed entertainment. Mean while Cleantes deiring nothing more then to ee him in Forrets at liberty, did dicover him unto Pimander, who was extreamly deirous to know the name of that man who fought with the tranger. Pimander at firt was amazed; but afterwards being moved by the vertue of this man, he asked whether it was poible he hould be till alive? To whom Cleantes made anwer, relating all his long voyages and ervices of o many Kings: Oh, aid Pimander, this mans vertue merits reward and not banihment: let him returne, and aure him that his deerts hall find from me a full reward. I freely pardon him all that ever he did againt me. Thus my Father, after he had been eaven yeares in Greece, returned into his Country, and was much honoured both by Pimander and Amais, who conferred upon him one of the greatet offices about their perons. Abundance of any thing cloys and faded deires have no force in them. As oon as my Father, had tated the favours of Fortune in a full meaure, his tat was glutted and he depied them. Some good Angell, intending to draw him out of that Gulfe, in which he had o often been o nigh a hipwrack, did inpire him with uch coniderations as thee Come Alcippe, would he ay unto himelf, I mut take thee under examination; what doet thou intend to do? Wouldet thou enjoy happinee before thou dyet? If thou wouldet; be confident, it is not to be found any where but in Tranquillity: if in tranquillity, then it mut be farr from buinee: if farr from buinee, then far from the ambition of a Court: hat thou not had ufficient tryall of its incontancy? Conider well with thy elfe; ambition is a deire to command over many: and that many hath every one of them the ame deign as well as thee: they propoe unto themelves the very ame wayes thou dot; and ambition is o narrow a paage, that only one can keep it: o as thou mut defend thy elfe againt a thouand, who will aault thee by a thouand tratagems, or ele thou mut die; if thou dot defend thy elfe, what tranquillitie, what ret cant thou expect? Thou mut tand day and night upon thy Guard, both againt friends and enemies: if thou dot yeild, there is no creature o mierable as a cret-falne Courtier, out of favour. Conider thee things Alcippes; thy Father and Ancetors were full as wie as thou art; they well conidered thee things, and would never trut themelves upon the mutability of Fortune: Returne, returne therefore to thy native oil, cat off thy Purple, and aume thy firt habit; turne thy peare into a pade, and thy word into a heephook there thou halt meet with that tranquillity, which thou hat ought for, o many years, and couldt never find it,
and which can never be found any where ele. Thee, Madam, were the coniderations which brought my Father unto his firt Profeion. Wherein he enjoyed the height of happinee: for he was o much beloved and honored by all his neighbours, that they held him for their Oracle; yet this was not the end: For he was no ooner at home, but Love began to open his firt wound: and Amarillis did cot him more miery, then all the ret of his misfortunes. Then did he revive that Device which he bore in all his travells which was in French Penne de Gray, meaning thereby Peine I'ay; in Englih, The miery I endure. From this Love of his did grow an inveterate hatred. For Alces, Atreas Father, was alo infinitly in Love with Amarillis; and Amaril is, during my Fathers exile, did, by the command of her Parents, permit it: on the other ide Alcippe, though he had cat off his habit of Chivalrie, yet he retained his courage; and not being able to admit of any Rivall, did often fall foule with Alces, who alo had courage enough; And it was the thought of everyone, that if the Parents of Amarillis had not conented to give her unto Alcippes, one of them two had died for it. But though this marriage topped all quarrells, yet there till remaines uch roots of hatred, as will never be quite eradicated o as till there is no familiarity between Alces and Alcippes: Thus much fair Nymph (aid he unto Silvia) perhaps you have heard in our Town, when you were there for I am Son unto Alcippes and Amarillis; and Atrea is Daughter unto Alces and Hippolyta.

Thus Celadon ended his dicoure, and doubtlee not without much paine: for peaking was troubleome to him: and this was the reaon he did o abreylate his relation. But Galathea was unimaginably atisfied, when he heard of what Parents this Shepherd was decended, whom he o much Loved.

As long as day lated, thee faire Nymphes o entertained Celadon, that had not Atreas change infinitly dipleaed him, he had found no great caue to be weary of them: for they were very fair, and alo full of dicretion: Yet as the cae was with him, he could not chue but deire to be alone and foreeeing that would not be till night, which would force them away, he wihed for it every minute. When he was mot alone, he thought himelfe bet accompanied: for night being come, and the Nymphes retired to their chambers, his own thoughts came to accompany him with uch cruell Memorandums, as made him uncapable of any other companions dimall depaire did look him in the face; for if againt the unjut entence of his Mitris, he did oppoe his innocency, then the uddain execution of it did appear in the eyes of his fancy. And as he was falling from one thought into another his hand fell a cidentally upon the Riband tyed to his arme, in which was Atreas Ring: Oh what horrid memorialls came then into his mind? Then did he fancy the fury which her oul expreed both by words and actions, when he pronounced the entence of his banihment. Then after a long and ad contemplation upon this lat dyater, he began to think upon the change of his Fortune; how happy he had been, and how he favoured him. Then begun he to think what he had done for him how for his ake he had lighted many well qualified hepherds how little he valued the dipleaure of her Father, or anger of her Mother, when they oppoed againt her affection: then began he to conider, that Fortune is as fickle in matters of Love as in any thing ele: and how few of all her favours remained with him, which was only a Bracelet of her hair tyed about his arme; and a Picture which he wore at his bret, whoe Cae he kied many a time: as for the Ring which he wore about the other arme he eteemed that, rather as forced then of any benevolence. Then upon a uddain, he remembred the Letters which he had writ unto him in the happie dayes of his being in favour and which he alwayes carried about with him in a little bagg. Oh what rapture was he in when he firt thought upon them! for he feared let the Nymphes when they pulled off his cloathes hould have een them. In this doubt he called out aloud for the little Merril: for he allwayes waited in a Lobby cloe by. The little boy, hearing him call o hatily two or three times, came to ee what his pleaure was. My little officer (aith Celadon) doet thou know what is become of my clothes? for they containe omthing which would much perplex me to loe: Your clothes Sir, aid he, are not far from hence, but there is nothing in them, for I earched them. Oh Meril (aid the Shepheard) thou art much mitaken, for there was omething which I valued above my life; then turning towards the other ide of the bed he began to make exceeding ad complaints a long while together. Meril hearing him, was on the one ide very orry to heare him lament as he did; and on the other ide was in great doubt whether he hould tell him all he knew: at lat not being able to be longer a witnee of his orrowes; he told him that he needed not to trouble himelfe o much for he was ure the Nymph Galathea loved him too wel to keep from him any thing which he o much valued: At this, Celadon turned towards him, and asked whether
that Nymph had them; I beleeve it is the ame (aid he) at leat, I found a litle bundle of papers, and as I was bringing them unto you, he met me and took them from me. Oh Heavens aid the Shepheard, things are wore and wore, then turning on the otheride, he would peak no more. Mean time Galathea did read the Letters for it was true, he did take them from Merill; and as thoe in Love are alwayes full of curioitie, o he read them but he had trictly charged him to ay nothing, becaue he intended to retore them, as unknown that he had een them. Silvia held the candle whilt Galathea unlooed the tring which tyed them together: we hall ee (aid Silvia,) whether this Shepheard be uch a dull fellow as he would eeme to be and whether or no he be in Love: then Galathea took out the papers gently for feare of tearing them: and the firt he laid her hand upon, was this.

body.head: Atrea's Letter unto Celadon.
body.p: WHat's this you do attempt? Into what a confuion are you about to bring your elf? Take my advice, who counell you as a friend, and leave off this your deign of erving me tis too ful of inconveniency beleeve it; what content Celadon can you hope for? I hal be extreamly intolerable: you may with as much eae attempt an impoibility; you mut wait, and uffer, and be patient, and have neither eyes or Love for any but me: for never think, I will hare affection with any other, nor accept of halfe-love. I am full of upitions, extreamly Jealous; I am exceeding hard to be woon, and very eaily lot; quickly offended, but abominably hard to be pleaed: my will mut be detiny it elfe; my opinions mut pae for reaons, and my commands mut be inviolable Lawes. Shepheard, be wie, and keep out of this dangerous Labyrinth. Ceae from a deigne which may prove oruinous. I know my elfe better then you do: never think to alter my naturall Genius; I hall certainly break rather then bend, and if you will not beleeve what now I ay, do not hereafter complaine againt me.

div.p: Never credit me, (aid Galathea) if this Shepheard be not in Love. It cannot be doubted (aid Silvia) being o well accomplihed. Then Galathea gave her another Letter which had been wet, to hold unto the fire; meanewhile, he took another Letter which contained thee words.

body.head: Atrea's Letter unto Celadon.
body.p: YOu will not beleeve that I Love you, and yet you deire I hould beleev you Love me If I do not Love you, what will my credence in your affection profit you? perhaps you thinke, that beliefe will oblige me to it; but alas Celadon, that conideration is too weak, if your merits and ervices were not more coniderable: but this is the tate of your condition: I would not only have you know, that I think you Love me; but I would have you know alo that I do Love you: and amongt many other, this is an infallible argument of it, that I have valued my Love to you, above my obedience to my Parents. If you conider how great my duty is to them, you may by it value my Love to you, ince it is above all duties: Adieu; be not any longer incredulous.

div.p: As oon as this Letter was read Silvia brought the other, and Galathea told her with a ad heart, that Celadon was in Love, and which was wore, that he was extreamly loved which grieved her to the very oul: for now he aw that he was to force a Fort, which a victorious enemy was poeor of. For by thee Letters he found, that the humour of this Shepherdee was not to be halfe a Mitris, but would have an abolute command over uch as he daigned to accept as her ervants and her opinion of this was much fortified, when he read the other Letter which had been wet it was thus penned.

body.head: Atrea's Letter unto Celadon.
body.p: LYcidas told Phillis, that yeterday you were in a very bad humour. Am I the caue of it? or you? If it be I, it is without occaion: for did I ever deire any more then to Love, and be loved by you? And have you not worne a thouand times, that you would never deire any more to compleat your happinee? If your elfe be the caue of it, then you do me wrong, to dipoe of that which is mine, without my knowledge; for whatoever is yours, is by donation mine: accquaint me how the matter is, and I will conider, whether or no I can allow of thee humours; in the meane while, I forbid them.

div.p:
How imperiouly does this Shepherdes carry it, aid Galathea? She doth not injure him, (aid Silvia) ince he told him as much at the firt. And truly if it be he, whom I uppoe it is, She is one of the fairet and mot admirably qualified perons, that ever mine eyes beheld: her name is Atrea: and that which induceth me to beleeve it is he, is this word Phillis: for thoe two Shepherdees are intimate companions. And though, as I told you, her beauty be beyond al comparions, yet it is the leat amiable quality in her for he is o ful of everall perfections, as her beauty is the leat coniderable. This dicoure was but a wider opening of Galatheas wound, ince til greater difficulties appeared in the accomplihment of her deigne. And being unwilling to impart any more unto Silvia, he tyed up the papers and went to bed not without a croud of various thoughts, which leep by degrees did compoe. As oon as the day dawned, litle Merill went out of the Shepherds chamber, who had done nothing but lament all the night long: and Galathea having commanded him to have a very trict obervance over all the actions of Celadon, and to make a report unto her, he went out to accquaint her with his obervations: Galathea was awake, and talking aloud with Leonida, litle Merill knocked at the dore, and came in. Madam, aid he, not a wink of leep have I got all this night: for poor Celadon is even at deaths dore for want of thoe papers you took from me yeterday: and eeing him in uch lamentable depaire, I could not chue but comfort him a little, by telling him that you had them How? Replied the Nymph, knowes he that I have them? Yes Madam, aid Merill, and he told me that he would ask you for them, for he has a great eteem of them: had you heard as I did, how he lamented the loe of them, it would have forced your heart to pitty him. Good Merill, aid the Nymph, tell me what he aid? Madam, replied he, after he had enquired whether I aw his papers, and I told him that you had them, • he turned to the other ide, as if ditracted, and aid, Now are all things at the very wort; and after a while ilence, thinking me in bed and a leep, I heard him igh and ay aloud. Oh Atrea, Atrea, mut banihment be the recompence of all my faithfull ervices? If thy affection be changed, why dot thou blame me to excue thy elfe? If I have been faulty, why is not my fault made knowne unto me? Is there no Jutice in Heaven, nor pitty in thy heart? If therebe, why do I find no favour from either? that I might either dy, or obey Atreas comwand. Oh mot cruell command; if I hould die, would it not argue rather deficiency of Love, then excee of courage? Then he paued a while and afterwards began again But whither would my flattering and truycerous hopes tranport me? Dare ye once againe appear unto me? what hadow of any hope can poibly be, after o much time pent, after o many ervices performed o much affection expreed; o many didaines endured, and many impoibilities vanquihed. Mut abence be the pittifull reward of all thee? No, no, hope rather for a favour from a grave than from her. After much uch like dicoure, he was ilent a long while; then turning himelfe in bed, I heard him begin his lamentations, which continued untill day: and all were complaints againt one Atrea, whom he accued of change, and cruelty. Galathea knew o much of Celadons etate, by Atreas Letters, and by Merills report, that it had been better for her, if he had been more ignorant; yet flattering her elfe; he imagined that Atrea's corne might happily make the way more eaie to accomplih her deires: But thoe are Novits in the School of Love who know not, that Love never dies in a noble & generous heart: and that the root of it, is never quite pulled up. Yet in this hope he writ a note, and put it amongt the Letters of Atrea; afterwards, giving the bundle to Merill, Here Merill aid flie, carry this bundle unto Celadon and tel him, that I wih I could as well render him all the contentments which he wants. If he be well and deires to ee me, tel him I am not wel this morning. She aid this, to the end, he might have the more leaure to perue his papers,
and to read that which he had writ. Merill he went away; and Leonida being in another bed he did not ee the bundle, nor hear the meage which Galathea ent; but as oon as he was gone, he called her into the ame bed: then began thus to talke: You know Leonida, what dicoure we had yeterday concerning this Shepherd; ince that, I have met with more intelligence then I could have wihed; you heard what Merill aid, and what Silvia reported concerning Atreas perfections; o as ince the Fort is taken, I foreee a double difficultie in getting it againe: yet I find that this happy Shepheardee hath much offended him, and a generous heart cannot brook a didain with out a reent. Madam, anwered Leonida, I could wih with all my heart, you could extinguih all thee kind of thoughts: for if you continue in them, you will wrong your elfe exceedingly: do you think it poible to carry it alwaies ecretly what a blame will it be unto your honour, if it hould be knowne? The whole coure of your actions will be meaured by it; what would you think of another that hould lead uch a life? You wil anwer me perhaps, that you do no ill: Oh Madam, it is not enough for a peron of your quality to be free from crime, but they mut be alo free from candall. Were he a man worthy of you, I hould with ome patience allow of it; but Celadon though he be the chiefe of the Country, yet he is a Shepherd, and not known for any more; and this vaine opinion of happy or unhappy can it o far bewitch you, and o degenerate your pirit as to equall heep-keepers, clownes and halfe-avages with your elfe. For Heavens ake. Madam, conider thee things, and be your elfe, Leonida had continued on, if Galathea in a great rage had not interrupted her: I told you before, aid he, that I wil not allow any more of uch moral doctrine: I am reolved. When I ask your advice, ehen give it: mean time, no more of this dicoure, unlee you will incurre my dipleaure. Upon this, he turned away to the other ide of the bed in uch a fury, that Leonida knew he had much dipleaed her. Nothing comes neerer the quick, then to object honour againt Love; but the reaons of Love will be predominate. A little after Galathea turn'd about, and told her, that he did not, till now, ever think her o arrogant as to be her Governee: Madam, anwered he, uch thoughts were never mine, I know my duty better then o: but ince you take that ill, which I poke, out of my affection to you, I hall hereafter never give you any occaion to be angry with me, for that caue. I wonder, replied Galathea, that your opinion hould be void of all reaon can it ever be knowne that Celadon is here? Only thee are acquainted with it; we three, Meril, and my Nure his Mother: as for Merill he never goes out and beides he is very dicreet: as for my Nure her fidelitie is ufficiently known; and beides, the deigne of all the whole buinee hath its rie from her: for he reporting what the Druide foretold me, he who Loves me, as if her own child, did advie me to leight the advice. I beeech you Madam, aid Leonida, what is your deigne? To carry it o, anwered he, that this Shepheard may love me, and till then not to let him go from hence: and if I but get him once to love me, I will leave all the ret to the conduct of fortune. Madam, aid Leonida, Heavens well all your deires with full content: but I beeech you, give me leave to tell you only this once, that you will extreamly taine your honour. It will be an age before his grounded affection to Atrea, will be rooted out: whoe beautie and vertue has no econd. But Leonida, (anwered Galathea) Atrea lights him, he is offended at him, and he hath banihed him: can you beleeve his pirit o puillanimous as to endure all this? Oh Madam, replied Leonida, extinguih uch vain hopes: if he have no courage at all, then he will never reent thee things: and if he have a noble pirit then let me tell you, that a generous minded man will never give over an enterprie, becaue he finds it full of difficulties: for example, remember your coore entertainment of Lindamor, how cruelly you have treated him, yet how little all thoe didaines and cruelties do tartle him. But admit that Celadon who is a hepheard and whoe courage cannot come in compare with Lindamors, admit I ay that he hould fall off from Atrea; what hopes of any good can you conceive from thence? Do you think a man that's once deceived will ever be deceived a econd time by the ame ubject? No no Madam, he that is once burnt will not come neer the ame fire again: perhaps (and herein is your mot advantageous hopes) that time will cure him of his wound, and till then he will never ubject himelfe to be wounded againe by another: how long that may be, Heavens know: mean time is it poible to keep the knowledge of it o long from the Guards in the Court? Either they will ee him; for you cannot alwaies keep him mued up in your chamber, or ele Meril, as dicreet as he is, yet he is but a child & may blab it out Leonida, aid he, I charge you to pare your paines upon this ubject: I am reolved: & if you will have me think you love me, advance my deigne as much as you can: and leave the ret to my care. If Celadon be recovered, you may carry him this morning into the Garden: for I find my elfe a little indipoed,
and hall carce rie out of bed till towards night: Leonida was very orry that no argument would prevaile and returned no anwer: only this, that he would contribute her bet endeavours for her atisfaction.

Whilt thee two were thus dicouring, Merill did his office and delivered the meage: finding the hepherd awake, he bad him good morrow from the Nymph, and preented the papers unto him. Oh how ready he was to rie up and receive them? He caued the window and curtains to be opened in all hate: he opened the bundle after everall ceremonious kies. Oh my dear papers, aid he, how have thee trange hands ued you? then he orted them and laid them in order according to the time they were written, and finding another paper amongt them, he opened it, and read thee words.

Celadon, I would have you know that Galathea Loves you: and that Heaven hath permitted Atreas didaine, becaue they would not have a hepherdee any longer enjoy that which a Nymph deires: acknowledge your happinee and do not leight it.

The Shepheard was all wonder; but eeing that little Merill kept an obervant eye over all his actions, he would not uffer his wonder to be eene but tying up all the papers together, and laying them in his bed, he asked, who gave them unto him? I took them out of my Ladies cloet, (aid he) and had I not beene very deirous to eae you of that paine in which I aw you were, I hould hardly have dared to have brought them: for my Lady is not very well. Who is with her (asked Celadon): the two Nymphes you aw yeterday (aid he) the one is Leonida the Neece of Adamas; the other Silvia the Daughter of the glorious Deanta; and deervedly his Daughter he is; for he is owner of the mot tately Mine, that e're eye beheld.

Thus Celadon came to the firt notice of Galathea's affection to him. And he foreaw that it would prove an addition of miery unto him: therefore he prepared himelfe for it. Now eeing halfe the day was already pent: and finding himelfe very well, he would not any longer be a prioner to his bed; conceiving that the ooner he tirred abroad, the ooner he might take his leave of the faire Nymphes Riing therefore with that reolution, as he was going out to walk, he met Leonida and Silvia, whom Galathea had ent to beare him company; for he her elfe would not rie, nor be eene, being ahamed of the Letter he had written. They went into the Garden; and becaue Caladon would conceale his orrowes, he contrained himelfe into as blith an humour as he could; and eemed full of curioitie to know every thing he aw. Fair Nymphes (aid he unto them) are we not neer the place where the Fountaine of verity in Love is? I do much deire, if it may be, we may ee our elves in it. Tis very neer (anwered the Nymph) in yonder wood, but it is impoible to be een for which you may thank that Lady who is the caue of it (aid he, and pointed unto Silvia) I know no reaon why you hould accue me (anwered he): for, ought the word be blamed if an imprudent man lay his hand upon it, and cut himelfe? Tis very true (aid Leonida) but the peron who wounds with it, is to be blamed, and beleeue it your beauty is uch as cannot be looked upon, without homicide: Be it what it will, (anwered Silvia with a little bluh) it hath cords trong enough, never to let him go whom once it hath captivated. She aid this, as twitting her with the infidelitie of Agis, who once Loved her, and either out of jealouie or ome two monthes abence, was quite changed: alo upbraiding her with Polemas, who was tolne from her by another beauty which Leonida undertood very well and thus replied; I mut confee Siter, that my cords are eaily untyed and the eaier becaue I would never take o much paines as to tye them fater. Celadon hearkned unto their pretty quarrells with much delight, and to the end, they hould not end too oon, he aid unto Silvia: fair Nymph, ince it eemes you are the caue why this admirable Fountaine cannot be een, I beeech you oblige us o far, as to tell us, how it came to pae. Celadon, anwered the Nymph and miled, you have buinee enough at home, and need not meddle much in that of others: but if your Love will allow of o much curioitie, Leonida if you requet her may perhaps tell you the end, as he did undeired, the beginning. Siter anwered Leonida, ince you permit me, to tell the tory, I Love you o well, as I will not let your victories be unknowne, epecially thoe which you o much deire hould be knowne. But becaue I will not tyre this hepherd I will be as brief as poible I can. Not for that reaon, I beeech you (aid the hepherd) but if you will, becaue he may have time enough to do the like office for you. Never doubt that (replied Silvia) but according as he ueth me, I hall know how to repay her: Thus from their own mouthes, Celadon
was acquainted with all the particulars of their lives: and to the end, he might the better hear as they walked, they placed him in the mindt: and thus Leonida began.

div.head: The Hitory of Silvia.
div.p: WHooever aith that Love is ufficient to procure Love againe, never had any experience either in the eyes or the courage of this Nymph for if they had, they would have known that as water runs from the fountaine, o the Love of uch as Love her, run away and never troubleth her. If when you have heard the dicoure I intend to make, you do not acknowledge as much, I will freely give you leave to taxe my judgement.

Amais the mother of Galathea, hath a Son called Clidaman, owner of as many excellent qualities, as any peron of his age and ranke is capable of for he is exquiite at any thing which relates either to Arms or Ladyes. About three years agoe, to give ome tetimonie of his gentle dipoition, and by the permiion of Amais, he gave a ervant unto all the Nymphs and this not by election, but lot: for having put the names of all the Nymphs into one bain; and the names of all the young Caveliers into another, then in an open aembly, the bain in which the Nymphs were, was preented to the young Gallants: and the bain in which the young Gallants were, was preented unto the Nymphs. Then by the ound of everal trumpets; the young Clidaman did draw his lot and it chanced to be Silvia afterwards the young Nymph did draw her lot, and it chanced to be Clidaman. Great were the applaudes which every one gave but the behaviour of Clidaman was mot extolled who as oon as he had received his lot, went and kneeling down before this Nymph, did kis her fair hand She out of modety would not have uffered it without the command of Amais, who aid, it was the leat homage he could receive. After her all the ret took their chances: to ome it happned according to their deires, and to others, not. Galatheas fortune fel upon a brave Gallant called Lindamor, who then was newly returned from the armie: mine fell upon one, whoe name was Agis, the mot perfidious and uncontant wethercock that ever was Some of thee who took their fortunes did only in appearance like their chances: others did with their hearts ratifie what fortune had done: and thoe who were mot pleaed with their chances, were uch as before that, had conceived ome eeds of affection. Amongt the ret, young Ligdamon was one, whoe lot light upon Silera; a Nymph truly very amiable, but not to him, who had already dipoed of his heart. And certainly it was happy for him that he was then abent for he would never have performed that faigned homage which Amais would have commanded, & that perhaps would have brought him into digrace. For you mut know, that he was brought up amongt us, and was o faire and handome in all his actions, as every one eteemed him; epecially Silvia, they being both of an age. At firt their ordinary converation begot a Love like unto that between Brothers and Siters: uch a Love as their age was capable of; but as Ligdamon grew in years, o he did in affection, o as at fourteen or fifteen years of age, his wil began to change it elf into deires; and his deires, by degrees, became paions. Yet he carried the matter o dicreetly, that Silvia her elfe had never knowne it, if he had not forced him unto it. Afterwards when he knew his dieae, and confidered what mal hopes there was of his cure, then the mirth and pleaantnee which was wont to be in his lookes and all his actions, was turned into adnee, and from adnee into uch lumpih melancholy, that every one took notice of the alteration. Silvia was not the lat of thoe who asked him the reaon; but he could draw nothing from him but heartlee anwers. At lat when he aw his dulnee continued, one day when he was complaining againt the coldnee of his affection, and obliging him to conceale nothing from her, he perceived, that he could not o well contraine himelfe, but that a ad igh came out in lieu of an anwer. This moved her to beleeve, that perhaps Love was the caue of his ill. Did not poor Ligdamon carry the matter very dicretly all the while in all his actions, ince he could never imagine her elf to be the caue. Perhaps the Nymphes humour not liking the buinee, was partly the caue; however his prudence was great that could conceal uch ardent affection. Now Silvia begins to urge him more then he did before, and told him, that if Love was the caue he would contribute all her aitance, and do all the good offices, he could deire. The more he denied it, the more deirous was he to know it; at lat, not being able to hold any longer, he confeed that it was Love: but aid that he had worn never to tell with whom. Tis mot high preumption, aid he to love her; but being compelled to it by uch an unreitable beauty, I am the more excuable: yet hould I name her, what excue could I find for my rahnee? The ame excue that your friendhip
to me hath, aid Silvia. Then Madam; replied Ligdamor, that, and your command together, hall plead my excuse: do but look in that glae, and you will ee what you deire to know. Upon this he took up a little glae which he wore, and held it before her eyes. You may imagine how he was urpried at this: and he hath ince wore unto me, that he verily beleeved it to be Galathea whom he adored. Whilt he tood amazed in contemplation of her, he tood amazed at her own implicity: he was very angry with him, but more with her elfe, that he hould be o imple as to force this manifeto of Love from him. Yet all her haughty pirit would not permit her to condemne Ligdamor. but he did rie up upon a udden, and without a word went away full of rage, that any mortall durt preume to Love her. Proud beauty, that thinks none worthy of thee! Faithful Ligdamor tayes till, but without oul, like an immoveable tatue. At lat recollecting himelfe, he got to his lodging as well as he could, out of which he tirred not a long time: for Silvias cold entertainment of his affection, did o pierce his heart, that he fell ick; and when none hoped for any life, he writ this Letter unto her.

body.head: Lygdamors Letter to Silvia.
body.p: THe loe of my life, had not been ufficient, to dicover unto you the rahnee of your ervant without your expree command. If you conceive that it was my duty to die and he ilent, then you mut conider that your fairet eyes ought to have lee power over me: for if at the very firt ummons, their beauty forced me to urrender up my oul, what power is able to reit, when they do peremptori ie command? Yet, if I have offended in offering my heart unto your beauty; a thing of o poor a value, unto a Deitie of o much merit, I will in atisfaction of the fault, acrifice my life unto you, and never o much as grieve for the loe of it, ince it dipleaed you.

div.p: This Letter was brought unto Silvia when he was alone in her chamber; but I came in immediatly after, and indeed, happily for poor Ligdamor. For oberve the humour of this Nymph; he conceived uch a hatred againt him ever ince he dicovered his affection to her, as their former friendhip is not only out of mind: but he hates him: and is o carelee of him, that when he heares any, lamenting & deparing of his recovery, he is no more moved, then if he had never een him. I who particularly took notice of it, did not know what to think unles that her youth might make her forget abent perons; but at this time, when I aw her refue the Letter which came from him, then I knew there was ome fallings out betweene them. Therefore I took up the Letter which he refued, and which the boy who brought it, had by his Maters command left upon the table; Silvia, lee ubtile then he might have been, ran after me and deired me not to read it. I am reolved to ee it (aid I) though for no other reaon. but becaue you forbid it. Then he began to bluh, and aid, deare iter, do not read it, I beeech you oblige me, and let it alone; I conjure you to it by our friendhip: what can the buinee be, (anwered I) which you thus conceale from me? Beleeve it, Silvia, if you ue any diimulations to hide your matters from me, it will fill me o full of curioitie, as to dicover you. Why iter, (aid he) may I not hope well in your dicretion? No more, aid I, then I can in the inceritie of your affection.

After a long wrangling about this Letter, I made her weare to tell me all upon condition of ecrecy. Then he told me, what I have told you concerning Ligdamor: and at this very hour, (aid he) he troubles me with his Letters: but what have I to do with his complaints, or rather diimulations? Nay, anwered I, they are not diimulations, but truthes; Suppoe they be, aid he, what have I to do with his follies? You are obliged, anwered I, to help uch mierable men, as you have throwne downe a precipice. What helpe can I bring, aid he? mut I not live in the world? Why, is he where I am? Would you have me run away when he comes in preence? Let him keep at home, and I hall never trouble him. All thee excues, anwered I, are of no validitie; for doubtlee you are an acceary, if not a principal, in his miery: had you fewer perfections; were you lee amiable; did you not a ue o much care in your dree, beleeve it, he had never been brought to this extremity. Very good, aid he and laughed: you are very pleaant in charging me with thee faults: what would you have me to be, if you would not have me to be what I am? Do you not know; Silvia, anwered I that whooever harpens a word in a mad mans hand is culpable of all the harme he doth? That beauty which the heavens hath betowed upon you o liberally, hath
had a harp edge et upon by you, o as no eye can look upon it without a wound; may not you be jutly taxed with all the murders which your cruelty commits? Silvia you ought not to be o faire and full of perfections, unlee you tudie to make your elfe as good as you are fair, and get as much weetnee into your oul, as heavens have put into your face: but alas you are o farre from healing, that you are full of nothing but rigour and cruelty.

The reaon why I was o paionate in defence of Ligdamor, was beides a relation of kindred, never any knew him but loved him, and I had heard, unto what a pittifull condition he was brought. Then after much dicoure to this purpoe, I opened the Letter and read it aloud, that he might hear it. But it had no more operation upon her, than upon a tone, which I much wondred at, and perceived that I mut ue ome violent remedies, which did induce me to tell her, that whatoever came on it, I would not have Ligdamor perih. Well Siter, aid he, ince you are o pittifull, I may cure him. It is not upon me, anwered I, that his cure depends, but you; but I aure you, if you continue towards him as formerly you have, I hall pite you with a very notable dipleaure. For Amiis hall know it and I will tell it to every one I meet. In hort, I Love Ligdamor, and will not ee him dye, if I can hinder it. You ay very well, Leonida, (aid he in a fret) thee are the good offices I ever expected from your friendhip. My friendhip, aid he, hall be as much to you as him, and hall be for you againt him if he were in the wrong. Here we made a long paue, and poke not a word. At lat I asked her what her reolution was? What you will, aid he, o you will not publih the follies of Ligdamor; for though I cannot be charged with any crime yet I hould be orry, the buinee hould be divulged Oh Silvia, cryed I out this is an excellent humour; you are afraid it hould be known, that a man Loves you but you are not afraid to murder a man. Come, come looke a little better on Ligdamor give him as much hope, as may make him recover, then afterwards ue him as you pleae, o you let him live Write two lines of a little comfort to him. I had much adoe to obfaine this favour from her, yet I till did threaten to tell all, if he did not; but after a long debate, he writ thus unto him.

p.hi: IF there be any thing in you which can pleae me, it is your life mot, and your death leat; the acknowledgment of your fault, hath given me full atisfaction; and I deire no other revenge for your preumption then the paines you have endured. Beware for the time to come Adien, and Live.

div.p: And I writ thee words at the bottom of her Letter, to the end he might hope the more, having o good a econd.

body.head: Leonida's Potcript in Silvia's Anwer.
body.p: LEonida did put the pen into the hand of this Nymph: Love would have it o: your jutice did invite, me to it; her duty did exact it; but her obtinacy made a trong reitance; this is the firt favour I ever obtained for your live to enjoy it, and hope well in the interim.

div.p: This Letter came very opportunely: for when he had hardly o much trength as to read it, he found a command from Silvia, to live: and when he was reolved never to ue any more remedies, yet in obedience to this Nymph, he ordered himelfe o, as in a hort time he mended. But for all that, this fair peece of cruelty was till as cold as ice towards him, when he was recovered: the mot favorable anwere he ever could obtaine from her was, I Love you not: neither do I hate you: let this atisfie you, that of all thoe who erve me, you dipleae me the leat. When either he or I made any addrees to her, he gave us uch cruell language as is unimaginable by any but he, and inupportable to any but Ligdamor.

But to abbreviate this dicoure; Ligdamor loved her and courted her ever ince without any other appearance of hope, but what I have told you; till Clidaman by Lot bebecame her ervant: And had he not known by me, that Clidaman fared no better then he in her affection, I know not what would have become of him. But though this did a little comfort him, yet the grandure of his rivall infued ome fits of jealouie I remember, when once I told him, that he need not fear Clidaman, he returned me this anwer,
Fair Nymph, aid he, I will ingeniouly tell you, from whence my jealouie proceeds; and judge you whether or no I am in the right. I have had uch long experience of Silvia, as I mut needs know, that fidelity of affection nor extremity of Love will never move her: o as doubtlee uch motives will never move her: yet as I have learned from the reverend Adamas your Unckle, every one is ubject unto ome fatall troke, which they cannot avoide when they are once touched by it: what can I imagine will ubject this fair one, except it be grandure and power? Therefore I do fear, it is the fortune and not the merits of Clidaman will win her: his grandure and not his affection will carry her. But certainly, in this he was in the wrong, for neither the Love of Ligdamor, nor the grandure of Clidaman, could ever move the leat park of goodwill in Silvia. I beleeve. Love reerves her for an example unto others, intending to punih o much didaine by ome unaccutomed way. At this time, there chanced a very notable tetimonie of her beauty; or at leat, the power he had to make her elfe loved. Upon that Fetivall, which every yeare was celebrated the ixth day of the Moon in July on which Amais was wont to offer a olemne acrifice, as well by reaon of the feat, as becaue it was the birth day of Galathea, in the midt of the acrifice there came into the Temple, a number of men in the morning; amongt them was one o full of noble Majety as it was eay to imagine that he was Mater to the ret. He was o ad and melancholy, as it was evident omthing did much afflict his oul. His habit was deep black trayling upon the ground, which did eclipe the handomenee of his proportion: his head was bare; his hair fair and curling, as bright as Sun beames, which attracted the eyes of every one upon him. He came up as farre as the lowet tep of the Throne, where Amais did it; and after an humble reverence, he retired again waiting untill the acrifice was ended: and whether to his good or bad fortune I know not, he eated himelfe directly oppoite unto Silvia. He no ooner cat his eyes upon her but he knew her though he had never een her before: but for more uerty, he asked one of his ervants who knew us all, who anwered only with a deep igh: Afterwards as long as the ceromony lated, he never took his eyes off her. At lat the acrifice being ended, Amais returned to her Palace, where when audience was permitted, him he pake thus.

MADAM, Though the mourning you ee in my habit, be much blacker in my oul; yet it cannot equall the caue; but though my loe be extreame, yet I do not thinke I am the only loer; for you Madam, from amongt your faithfull ervants, are leed of one, who perhaps was not the leat affectionate nor the mot unprofitable in your ervice. This conideration gave me ome hopes, of obtaining a revenge of his death againt the homicide: but as oon as ever I entred into the Temple, I lot all my hopes, thinking that if the deire of revenge did die in me, who am a Brother to the injured, it would ooner die in you Madam, who have lee relation to him. Yet becaue I ee the armes of my Brothers murderer already prepared againt me, I hall as briefly as poible, tell you the Fortune of him whom I mourn for.

Though Madam I never had the honour to be known unto you yet I am confident, that at the name of my Brother, who never lived but in your ervice, you will lit me in the catalogue of your mot devoted ervants. His name was Aritander, both of us Sonnes unto the great Clemir, who in your ervice did o often viit Tiber, Reine, and Danube: I being the younger by nine yeares, as oon as he aw me capable of bearing armes, he ent me into the Armie of the great Merovea, the delight of men, the mot pleaing Prince, that ever came in Gaule. I cannot well tell you why he rather ent me to Merovea, then to Thierry King of the Viigots or to the King of the Burgundians. Yet I conceave his reaon was becaue I hould not erve a Prince o neer your Dominions, whom Fortune might make your enemy. My fate was this; that Childerick his Son, a warlike Prince and of great hopes, eeing me utable with him in age, did mot particularly favour me with his affection, more then any other: when I came firt to him, it was then when the great and prudent Aetius did treat an agreement with Merovea and the Frankes (for o he called all thoe who followed him) to reit that fatall courge of Heaven, Attilla King of the Hunnes, who having gathered together in the deerts of Aia an uncredible number of men, even five hundred thouand combatants, he decended like a Torrent, mot furiouly ravaging all Countries through which he marched and though this Aetius, the Lieutenant General of Valentinian in Gaule, came with an intention of making war upon Merovea, who during the Government of Catinus had eied upon part of Gaule; yet he thought it better to make him, the Viigots, and Burgundians alo his freinds, rather then hazard a defeat by Attilla, who having already paed Germany, was upon the
banks of Rheyne where he tayed not a long time, before he advanced into Gaule, and beeiged the Towne of Orleans, till the comming of Thierry King of the Viigotts, made him raie Seige, and take another way. But being met with by Merovea and Aetius with their confederates in the Cathalaunique fields, he was defeated, more by the valour of the Franks and prudence of Merovea, then any other force. After Aetius was laine, perhaps by his Maters command, upon ome dicontent, Merovea was received at Paris, Orleans, and the neighbouring Townes, as their Lord and King: and all the people ever ince, have borne him o much affection, as they called themelves Franks, as more pleaing unto him: and their Country in lieu of Gaule, took the name of France. Whilt I was imployed in the armes of France, the Gaules, the Romans, the Burgundians, the Viigotts and the Hunnes, my Brother was imployed in the Armes of Love; Armes the more dangerous becaue all wounds light upon the heart: uch was his diater, that being brought up with Clidema, he aw the fair Silvia: and in eeing her he aw his death alo, for he never was himelfe ince. I never knew the caue of this; for being with Childericke, I enjoyed all imaginable content, as being very gracious which my Mater, loved amongt all my equals, and generally honoured of all, out of a good opinion which they conceived of me in the preent affaires; which got me more credit and authoritie over them, then perhaps my age did merit: but hearing of my Brothers languihing condition, I could not tay any longer with Childericke; but taking my leave of him, and promiing to returne ere long, I hated to the place where my affection invited me: as oone as I came there, many did run to tell my Brother that Guyamant was come: for o I am called: when he heard it, his Love to me did give him o much feeble trength as to rie up in his bed, and to embrace me with abundance of affection. It is to no purpoe, to trouble you Madam, and grieve my elfe, with a relation of all particulars that paed betwixt us; only this, within two or three dayes after, my Brother was in uch extremity that he had hardly trength enough to breathe: all he had was only ighes and groanes, and nothing undertood to come from him but the name of Silvia. I being extreamly perplexed at my Brothers ad condition, was uch an enemy unto this unknown Silvia, as I could not chue but cure her: which my brother hearing, and his affection to her being above his malady; he forced himelf to ay thus: unlee Brother you will become my enemy, ceae thee imprecations, I beeech you, which ttouble me more then all my miery beides. What will they profit you further then to tetifie, that you hate what I do Love? I know my death will grieve you; but ince all men are deigned to the ame, why rather do you not with me thank the fates who have choen o good a death for me, and the fairet murderer that ever any had? The abundance of my affection, and the abundance of Silvias vertues, are the armes which her beauty made ue of, to bring me unto my grave: Can you cure her, whoe happinee I prefer before my own oul's? he would have aid more but his trength failed him: I anwer'd him thus. Brother, he who thus will ravih you from us, is the mot unjut peron that ever was: If he be fair, the gods themelves are guilty of injutice in making her o, for they hould have changed either her face or her heart. Aritander hearing this, aumed more trength and replied: for Heavens ake Guyamant, give over your blaphemy, and beleeve that Silvias heart is utable to her face. As the one is all beauty, o the other is all vertue: if I die for Loving her, never wonder at it. As no eye is able to gaze upon the Sun, o my oul is dazled at the rayes of o many Suns as hine in this beauty: it is impoible to gaze upon o many Divinities and live. Then aid I unto him, Is it poible Brother; that one ingle Divinity hould be the caue of your death? Brother, anwered he, I am in uch extremity as I am not able to anwer your demand; but Brother (continued he, and took me by the hand) I conjure you, by all that's acred, to promie me one thing: carry this kie from me to Silvia, and then he kied my hand: and when you ee that Nymph, tell her I bequeath you unto her: at this word he expired, and lay cold in my armes.

My reentments of this loe is unimaginable by any but my elfe: but without more condoling this diater, let me tell you Madam, that as oon as my orrow would permit me, I came to render unto you the homage which is due, and to demand Jutice for the death of Aritander: alo to preent unto her, what he left her by his lat will in writing. But as oone as I preented my elf before you and would have accued the murderer, I found my Brothers words to be true, and do not only excue his death, but deire and require the ame.

Here Madam, by your permiion, will I make my addree Then making an humble reverence unto Amais, he choe out Silvia, and kneeling unto her thus aid: Fair murderer, if
but one poor tear of pitty do but drop into that fair boome at the news of his death whom you conquered, your victory will be noble, and entire; but if you think o little water too much for thoe flames which you kindled in him, then at leat receive a zealous kis which he hath ent you, or rather his oul changed into this kis, which he preents unto you. Upon this he kied her hand, and did rie up: then thus continued. Amongt the papers where Aritander had left his lat will we found this; and becaue it was ealed and directed unto you, I have brought it with a protetation which by his tetament he commanded me to make unto you before you open it, that if it be not your pleaure, to grant the requet which he makes, then he beeeched you not to read it, to the end in his death, as in his life, he may not reent your cruelty: then he preented unto her a Letter, which Silvia had refued but for the command of Amais. I have hitherto, aid Guyamant, fullfilled the lat will of Aritander: it remaines that I proecute againt the murderer: but as heretofore I have been obedient to my Brothers commands, o Love now commands me to acrifice my own liberty upon the ame Altar which yet reekes with my Brothers blood, who when he lived told me, that all eyes which ever looked upon you did owe their hearts unto you as a jut tribute; and that thoe men were unworthy to live, which did not live in your ervice. Silvia a little ahamed at this encounter, tood mute a long while and gave no anwer: o that Amais took the Letter, and telling Guyamant that Silvia hould returne him an anwer, he took her aide, and breaking open the eale, he read thee words.

body.head: Aritanders Letters unto Silvia.
body.p: THough my affection could never render my ervice pleaing unto you, nor my ervice my affection: yet I hope, this affection will make you pitty my death, or ele my death will aure you of my affections fidelitie: And that, as never any adored one of more perfection, o never any loved and adored with more paion. The lat tetimony of it that ere I hall render unto you, hall be the gift of that which, next your elf, was mot dear unto me, and that is my Brother: for I am ure he is yours, ince I have enjoyned him to ee you; knowing very well by experience, that it is impoible to ee and not to love you. But fair Murderer, I beeech you, let him not inherit my fortune, but ue him kindly. He who writes this, is your dying ervant, who having more Love to you in his heart, then it is able to contain and live, will rather die then diminih it.

div.p: Amais calling Silvia to her, asked her what kind of trange cruelties he had ued towards Aritander, which had brought him to this extremitie? The Nymph with a bluh anwered, that he knew not wherein he had done him any wrong. I would have you, aid he, entertain Guyamant in his room. Then calling both before her, he asked him whether he would follow his Brothers inclination: He anwered, yes with all his heart. Then aid Amais, I hell entreat this Nymph, to admit you to his place and to ue you, better then he did him. Guyamant, after a very humble reverence unto Amais, offered to kis the hand of Silvia, in igne of ervitude: but he o lighted the declaration of his affection, that unlee Amais had commanded her, he would never have looked upon him.

When every one began to retire, Clidaman returned from hunting, and was told of this new ervant unto his Mitris. Againt which he made uch loud complaints, that Amais and Guyamant did hear them: and ince he could not imagine how this hould come about, he told him the whole buinee. When he had done Clidaman complained more then before that he hould uffer a thing o much to his diadvantage, and told her that he revoked the decree of Fate which his lot had given him, and which none hould ever ravih from him and live. This language proceeded from a heart full of affection, and was uttered with a bundance of vehemency, for he did Love Silvia extreamly. Guyamant, who beides the edge which his new Love had put upon him, had o good an opinion of himelfe as not to yeild unto any', returned an anwer, addreing his peech unto Amais. Madam, aid he, it eemes ome would not have me to be a ervant unto the fair Silvia: but uch are ignorant what Love is, otherwie they would never think, that your ordinances, or the ordinances of all the gods together, have power enough to divert the coure of affection: And therefore I do openly declare, that if any hall offer to forbid me that which is already permitted me, I hall diobey and rebell: It is neither duty nor any other conideration can make me change. Then turning towards Clidaman: as for you, Sir, I know what repects I
owe you, but withall, I know what power Love hath over me: as the detinies did give Silvia unto you, o her beauty did give me unto her: Judge you whether of thee gifts ought to be mot pleaing unto her. Clidaman would have replyed, but Amais interiupted him. Sonne, aid he, you have no reaon to complaine, unlee our ordinances were altred: you were commanded to erve Silvia, but others were not forbidden to do the ame. Smells are mot odoriferous, when tirred; and a Lover having Rivals has more tetimonie's of his merit. Thus Amais, ordained that both of them hould erve her. And thus is Silvia well tored of ervants, for Guyamant dreed up his affection in the bet trim, and Clidaman in envie of him, did tudie how to outvie him in courthip. Ligdamon, he erved her with o much dicretion and repect, that, leat others hould take notice of his affection, he durt eldome come neer her: and in my opinion his courthip was much more pleaing then any of the ret; but once, beleeve it, he was almot pat all his patience. It hapned that Amais had a bodkin in her hand, which was made in the fahion of a word, and which Silvia was wont to wear in her hair; and Clidaman being neer her, he gave it unto him to carry unto his Mitris: but he kept it all the day, purpoely to vex Guyamant, never o much as dreaming upon Ligdamon: but ee how one may wound one for another: the poyon which was prepared for Guyamant, did o neerly reach the heart of Ligdamon, that not being able to diemble he retired to his lodging, where after he had a while venomed himelfe by his own thoughts, he took pen and writ thee veres.

lg.head: Upon the Sword of Silvia, in the hands of Clidaman.

lg.l: Love like a Traytor doth me treat, and with a murdering word,
Hath given me a ad defeat in her whom I ador'd.
But jutly too, I needs mut ay, for being never able,
My do •• of ervices to pay, which were innumerable.
He takes a word and doth me trike, and all my hopes doth mother,
And cunningly he ueth me, more like a Souldier then a Lover.

div.p: At the lower end of thee veres, he added thee words.
I cannot chue, fair Leonida, but reemble Silvia to the Sun; which indifferently doth hine upon the mot vile things as well as upon the mot Noble.

He himelf brought me this coppie: I read it; but though I tudied, yet for my life I could not undertand it: nordraw any thing from it, unlee that Silvia had given him a great blow with a word, but he left me and went away the mot lot and undone man alive. Thus you ee what a cunning cutter Love is, who with uch trifling Armes, can make uch deep wounds. He vexed me to ee him in this condition, and to enquire further of things I went unto Silvia; but he proteted that he knew not what they meant. At lat after a reading of thee veres two or three times, he lifted up her hand to her head, & finding her bodkin not there, he begun to laugh and ay her bodkin was lot, that ome or other had found it, and that Ligdamon knew of it: She had no ooner aid o, but Clidaman came into the Hall with this murdering word in his hand. I intreated her to let him have it no longer: I will firt try his dicretion, aid he, afterwards, I will ue all the power I have with him. She was as good as her word, for as oone as he came, he aid unto him. This word is mine. He anwered, o Madam is he that hath it. I would have it, aid he. I wih with all my oul aid he, you would have all thats yours. Will you not retore it (aid the Nymph) how
can I will any thing, replied • e, ince I have no will at all? What have you done with that which you had (aid he)? You Madam have ravihed it from me (aid he) and at this very minute it is changed into yours. Since it is o (aid he) that your will is mine, you mut retore the bodkin, becaue my will is o. Since I would the ome that you would (aid he) it mut of neceity follow that I would have it alo. Silvia miled a little, but at lat he aid, I would have you give it me. I alo, aid he, would have you give it me. Then the Nymph put out her hand and took it. I will never deny you (aid he) though you would have me and all. Thus Silvia receaved her word, and I writ this Note unto Ligdamon.

p.hi: THat which you thought to be a favour conferred upon your Rivall, was only ravihed, and when the owner know of it, he took it from him againe. Judge you, how things are; the favours which your Rivall hath, proceed from ignorance, and his disfavours from deliberation.

div.p:
Thus was Ligdamon cured, not by the ame hand, but by the ame word which wounded him. In the meane time, Guyamants affection grew to this height, as it was little hort of Aritanders. On the other ide, Ligdamon, under the colour of Complement, did uffer a mot paion at Love, to plant it elfe in his oul.
