After that both of them had vyed which hould mot pleae Silvia, and found that he did equally favour and frown upon them both, they reolved one day to try which of them was mot in favour, and to that end, they both came to Silvia, from whom they both received uch cold anweres, that the controverie could not be decided. Then by the counel of a Druide who was grieved to eetwouch men, unprofitably loe that time which might better be pent in defence of their countryes, they went unto the Fountain of the veritie of Love. You know, what the property of that water is, and how it dicovers the mot ecret thoughts of Lovers: for he who lookes into it, hall there ee his Mitris, and if he Love him he hall ee himelfe by her: but if he Love another, then that other hall appear. Clidaman was the firt which preented himelfe before this Fountain: he kneeled downe upon the ground; kied the ide of the Fountain; and after he had implored the Angell of the place to be favorable unto him, he leaned a little over: immediatly Silvia was een, o admirably fair, that the tranported Lover could not chue but toope to kie her hand: but his contentment was oone cooled when he aw no body by her. He retired with a perplexed mind, and after a dicontented paue, he beckned unto Guyamant to come and try his fortune. He, having with all requiite ceremonies prayed unto the Dietie of the place, did cat his eye upon the Fountain, but he fared no better then Clidaman; for Silvia alone appeared, and with her fair eyes eemed to burn the water. Both of them much amazed at the matter, they went to a Druide who was highly vered in Magique and asked the caue. He anwered, that the reaon was becaue Silvia loved neither of them, nor any ele, as being capable of burning others but not of burning, herelfe. They who could not beleeve themelves to be o much out of favour, as they looked everally before, o now they would returne and looke in the water both together: and though both of them leand over on everall ides, yet the Nymph appeared alone. The Druide aw them retire, and miled, telling them that they might certainly beleeve themelves not loved for aid he, you mut know that as all other waters do repreent the body, this repreents the pirits. Now the pirit, which is only the will, the memorie, and the judgment, when it loves, is transformed into the thing loved. And therefore when you preent your elfe here, it receives the figure of your pirit, and not of your body, and your pirit being changed into Silvia, it repreents Silvia, and not you. If Silvia loved you, he would have been changed as well into you, as you into her, and o repreenting your pirit you hould ee Silvia, and eeing Silvia changed by Love, as I told you, you hould ee your elves alo. Clidaman litned very attentively unto this dicoure, and conidering that the concluion was an aurance of that which he mot feared, he drew his word and truck two or three times as hard as he could upon the Marble of the Fountain. His word broke in two, and left no impreion, or igns of his blows but till triving to break the tone, like an angry dogge, which bites the tone which is thrown at him, the Druide told him that he lot his labour, for the inchantment of the place would never end
by force, but by extremity of love but if he would make it uelee, he could inform him of a way. Clidaman had brought up for rarity in great Iron Cages, two Lyons, and two Unicornes, which he often baited with everall orts of Animals: Thee the Druide begged for guards of the Fountain, and o enchanted them, a • , though they ranne at libertie, yet they would never go • rom the entrance into the grate, nor will they ever offer any hurt, unlee to uch as will attempt upon the Fountain; but uch as will be o adventurous, they aault with extream fury; for, the Lions are o great and terrible, their Clawes o long and harp, they are o nimble and active, and o unimated unto this defence, as is incredible. Again, the Unicomes have Hornes o harp and trong, as they will pierce the hardet Rock, and do thrut with uch force and nimblenee as none can ecape them. Aoon as this guard was placed, Clidaman and Guyamant went to travell, and departed o ecretly, that neither Amais nor Silvia knew of it, untill they were gotten a great way from them. They went into Merovea and Childerick; for, finding themelves equally treated by Love, they would try whether Armes alo would be equally favourable unto them. Thus, courteous hepheard, have we lot the benefit of this Fountain, which did o well dicover all Juglers in love, as if all had been like Ligdamon, it had never been lot. When I heard that Clidaman and Guyamans intended to go thither, I advied him to make a third, auring my elfe, that he would finde mot favour; but, he made me this anwer, Fair Leonida, aid he, uch as are in doubt of their good or bad Fate, may ometimes hatard the enquitie; but, it were mot groe folly for uch, as have not the leat park of any hope, to earch for that, which they would mot unwillingly finde. For my part, I am in no doubt whether Silvia do love me or no; alas, I am too well aured of it: And when I deire to know more, I will never make enquirie of any, but her eyes and actions. However, his love was till the ame, and Heavens knowes, how cruelly this rigorous piece of Crueltie it elfe hath ever ued him: the time's to come, when ever he looked upon him without didam and everitie. For my part, I wondered at his patience, for all her actions towards him, are rather injuries then everities.
One day when he met her walking with me, I intreated him to ing; and having an excellent voice, he ung thee lines.

lg.l: WHat pain is this that I endure,
Which doth reemble fires,
And will not let me finde a cure?
Oh! 'tis mot hot deires,
Which to Superlatives apires.
Thee hot deires did firt proceed
From hope, I hould obtain:
But now, alas, my hopes are dead;
Yet, till deires remain,
And wells my widdowed oul with pain.
But why hould fond deires trive,
And beat the Aire in vain,
Since now there is no hopes alive,
Their ends e're to obtain?
The reaon for it is mot plain.
For ince from vertue you proceed,
Which recompence doth corn,
Though hope be quite decay'd and dead;
Yet you are not for lorn,
But live, and love, and igh, and mourn.

div.p:
He had no ooner ended, but Silvia repli'd, and aid, Ligdamon, ince I am not the caue of your miery, why hould you lay any blame upon me? I ee you do accue your
own vain deires, and indeed, it is they only which torment you. The paionate Ligdamon anwered, That it was true indeed; it was deire which tormented him; but, it was not that which ought to be blamed: it was that which caued it, which was the vertues and perfections of Silvia. If deires, replyed he, be not irregular and extravagant, they will not torment; but if they be o unruly, as to tranport beyond reaon, then they mut needs be but Batards and not the legitimate children of vertue, and are o unlike uch a mother, that they do nothing reemble her. All extream deires, Madam, (anwered Ligdamon) are not againt reaon and vertue; for all excellencies and goodnee, may with reaon be extreamly deired; Beauty, amongt other excellencies, may, with reaon, be extreamly and paionately loved: for, it cannot be aid to be againt reaon, but above it. This is a very nice ditinction, (replyed this cruell fair one) and I will never allow of any thing, either againt or above reaon. Then, to take away the opportunity of reply, he went away unto one of her Companions which followed. Upon a time, when Amais returned from Mount Brion, where the finenee of the Gardens, and olitude together, had tayed her longer then he intended, night did urprize us in our return to Marcelles; and the night being very cold, I went unto him, purpoely to make him talk before his Mitree, and asked him, if he were not very enible of the chill evening? To which he anwered, that neither heat nor cold could do him much hurt: And asking him why, and what antidote he had againt it? he anwered, that to the one he oppoed his burning deires, and to the other his cold hopes. If it be o, replyed I, how comes it to pae I hould o often hear you ay, that ometimes you burn with heat, and ometimes freeze with cold? Ah! fair Nymph, anwered he with a deep igh, my dieae is not out wardly, but all within, and that o deep, that there is not a corner of my oul, but adly reents it. And you mut know, that in any other peron, heat and cold are inconitent together: But I have in my heart a flaming fire, and alo chill ice, and I only, the gods do know, do feel the torments of it.

Silvia all this while was ilent, and ued none of her accutomed cruelties; but at lat, eeing him turn towards me, and igh, he alo turned, and in a merry manner, and didainfull, thus he aid: Oh! what a happy man is Ligdamon, that can command both heat and cold when he pleaeth? or, at leat, neither of them ever troubles him; for, if the coldnee of his hopes do freeze, his hot deires can caue a thaw; and, if his hot deires do burn him, he can freeze them up with a few cold hopes. It is but necearie, faire Silvia, (aid Ligdamon) that I hould ue thee remedies to keep me alive; otherwie, I hould live but a little; but alae, the Gods do know they are but poor comforts. Nay, nay replyed the Nymph, you can make your dieae jut as you would have it, either hot or cold. Truly Madam, anwered Ligdamon, to corch and freez both at once, is none of the leat miracles which proceed from you; but, the greater wonder is, that my heat hould proceed out of your ice, and your ice proceed out of my heat. Nay Ligdamon replyed the Nymph, the greatet wonder of all is, that a man, who has the reputation of rationall, hould have uch idle imaginations, and think uch impoibilities, as whooever hould credit them, may be taxed with want of as much judgment, as you of wit or truth. I do confee, Madam, aid he, that my imagination does conceive many impoibilities; but, the caue of it is, either my too much affection, or your too much cruelty, or both. And as this is not one of your I at effects, o this, wherewith you upbraid me, is not one of my leat torments. I believe, anwered he, that your torments and my effects lie mot in your tongue. 'Tis very hard, Madam, for the tongue to expree well, that which is not well reented, anwered Ligdamon. 'Tis very hard, replyed the Nymph, to undertand all the vain Ideas of an idle and a brain-ick fancy. If truth, aid Ligdamon, did not accompany this imagination, then hould I tand lee in need of your compaion. No, no, anwered the Nymph, men do build their trophees too much over the compaion of us women. Had it not been better aid, Madam, anwered he, That women do build their Trophees too much over our ruines? I never aw any yet o ruined, replyed Silvia, but like you, they will quickly recover.

The more of this Nymphs cruelties, and Ligdamon's patiences, I do relate, the fater they come into my memorie. When Clidaman, as I told you before, was to travell, Amais would have the greatet part of the young Gallantry in this Country, to go along with him under the conduct of Lindamour: amongt the ret Ligdamon, being a mot accomplihed Caveliere, he was not omitted: But this cruel Mitrie would not o much as daigne him an Adien; but faigned her elfe ick. Yet he would by ome meants or other firt let her know of it, and thereup on writ thee veres unto me.

lg.head: Upon a Departure.
lg.l: Since Love will have me live and die
Within his corching flames; then why
Should I thus fatally depart
From her that olely has my heart?

lg.head: I anwered him.
lg.l: The reaon of it is, fond Boy,
That thou mait find a fuller joy:
Dot thou not know the Phoenix came
From Ahes, when he dyed in flame?

div.p: He had thought himelfe very happy in this anwer: but this cruell one, finding me writing this, and being unwilling to do him any good or uffer another; he natcht away the paper by force out of my hand, telling me, that thee flatteries wherewith I fed Ligdamon, did make him o full of follie; and that he had more reaon to complain againt me then her: Then he writ thus unto him.

lg.head: Silvia's anwer.
lg.l: The Phoenix from the Ahes came,
But firt he died in the flame;
If Preence ineffectnall prove
Abence will never conquer Love:
Ice will not thaw by cold, when heat
No conquet over it cold get.

div.p: You may imagine with how much contentment he departed; it was a kind of happines to him, that he had been o long beforehand accutomed to uch blows: and that he remembred this Maxime, that the disfavours of a Mitris, mut often pae for favours: I well remember that upon this dicoure he thought himelfe the happiet lover in the world, imagining that the disfavours of Silvia, were arguments that he held him in her memorie, that he took him to be her ervant; and that ince he did not treat all the ret of her ervants in the like meaure, it was to be thought that this was the coyne in which he payed uch as he eteemed hers; and therefore he ought to cherih it, ince it had her tamp upon it, and upon this ubject he ent me thee Lines.

lg.head: A Sonnet.
lg.l: My Soveraigne beautie does intend to try,
The height and depth of my fidelity
By things impoible and farre above
Performances of any humaine Love:
And well; ince he will ha'te o, I'me content.
For o he'l ee the bottomlee extent
Of my affection; which is like a Well
That with unfathomable waters well:
The more he trives to pumpe and draw me dry,
The more hee'l ee my Loves eternitie,
The Fountainwhence I draw affection
Is her fair elfe and her perfection.
Then try me, fairet, to eternity,
The more you'l find I Love, the more you try.

div.p: Leonida had continued her dicoure, had he not een Galathea comming, who after he had been by her elfe alone a long while, and not being able any longer to be out of her hepherds ight, he dreed her elf to as much advantage as her glae could advie her, and o came without any other company but the little Merill: he was very fair, and worthy to be beloved of any whoe heart was not foretalled by anothers affection. At this very time, Celadons tomack began to be very ill, o as they were all contrained to retire, and the hepheard went to bed, which he kept a long time, as being neither very ick, nor very well.

Galathea, who in good earnet was in love, as long as Celadon's icknee lated, he careely tirred from his bed; and when he was contrained to go away, either to ret her elf, or do any other buinee, he left Leonida with him, and charged her to take all occaions, of letting the hepheard know her good-will towards him; thinking by this means to infue uch hopes in him, as his qualitie might perhaps forbid him: And certainly Leonida did not fail her; for, though he wihed with all her heart, that Lindamor might thrive in his deires; yet, ince the hopes of her advancement depended wholly upon Galathea, her deigne was wholly to pleae and comply with her. But Love, which often ueth to make himelfe merry at the prudence of Lovers, and is pleaed to thwart their intentions, did make Leonida, by the converation of this hepheard, to tand more in need of one to peak for her, then he to peak for another. The hepheard quickly perceived it: But his affection to Atrea, for all her harhnee, would not permit him to uffer this growing affection with patience. This was the reaon that he reolved to take his leave of Galathea, aoon as he began to be a little better.

But aoon as ever he mentioned any uch offer: How Celadon? (aid he unto him) has your entertainment by me been o bad, that you would be gone before you be recovered? And when he anwered, That it was, becaue he was troubleome to her, & becaue of ome buinee of her own, alo to aure his Parents and friends of his health; and therefore he deired to return home unto his own Village; Then he interrupted him, aying, No, no, Celadon, never fear any troubling of me; and as for your buinee and friends, it is no matter; me thinks your greatet buinee hould be, to atisfie your obligations unto me; and it will be high ingratitude in you, not to pend each minute of that life which you hold of me, in my ervice; beides, you mut not for the time to come, cat your eyes upon o low a thing as your life pat: You mut leave your Village and your Flocks to uch as want thoe merits which you have; and for the future, look upon me, who can and will recompence you, to the height, if your actions do not take away my good-will unto you.

Though the hepheard eemed, as if he did not undertand the meaning of this language, yet he did; and therefore he avoided talking with her in private as much as poibly he could; and he did o much digut this kinde of life, that being one day almot out of all patience, when Leonida heard him igh, he asked him the reaon, ince he was in a place, where nothing was more tudied then his contentment? Fair Nymph, anwered he, amongt all the mierable wretches of Fortune, I may profee my elfe the mot coorly treated; for others may grieve, and enjoy o much comfort as to complain, but this is denyed me, for my miery is hadowed with a Mask of happinee; and therefore, in lieu of pittie, I am rather blamed and taxed for a man of hallow judgment: But if you and Galathea knew, what bitter wormwood I do meet <…> in this place (happy truly unto all but me) I am confident you would betow ome pitty • pon my life. What is it you would have, aid he, that will comfort you? Nothing, <> he, unlee you will get me leave to depart. Would you have me olicite Galathea for it, (aid he)? I beeech you do it, (aid he) and I conjure you to it by that which you mot love. That then mut be your elfe, (aid the Nymph, and bluht). And o he went out of the Chamber to eek Galathea, whom he found alone in the Garden, and who already began to upect, that Leonida was in love with him, conceiving that he had not made any progree in the charge which he gave her, though he eldome or never tirred from him: Alo knowing very well, how charming the hepheard's beauty was, he imagined, that he might as well wound two as one; yet, being contrained to carry fair with her, he continued her uuall affability; and eeing her come towards her, he enquired of her how the hepheard did: As they were walking together, Galathea turned her elfe towards Leonida, and aid, Well Leonida, tell me, was there ever uch a piece of inenibilitie as Celadon, ince neither my behaviour, nor your perwaions, will work with him? I cannot tell what to think of him. For
my part anwered Leonida, I rather think him of a mean pirit, and wants judgment than one that wants apprehenion, he wants courage to pretend o high: Your perfections and favours cannot raie his thoughts o high, but the poornee of his merits and qualitie does more deject him; and no wonder, Vines will bear Grapes, and Okes Acornes, every thing will produce according to its nature. Can you imagine, that the courage of a Country Clown can produce any deignes, but uch as proceed from a bae and Peantique pirit? I do believe (anwered Galathea) that the great difference between our qualities may beget a great repect in him; but, I cannot think him o dully ignorant, as not to undertand unto what end I treat him o kindly: the greater fear is, that he is already o far engaged to Atrea, that he cannot retire. Aure your elfe, Madam, replyed Leonda, it is nothing but a ottih ignorance in him: I do believe as you do, that he loves Atreat but if he had any Judgment, he would light her for you, who beyond all degrees of comparion does merit more then he. And yet he is o encelely imple that whenoever I peak of you, he anwers me with his orrows for being o farre from Atrea, and thinkes his being here, no better then a torment. This very morning hearing him igh, I asked him the reaon, and he made me uch an anwer as would have moved tones to pitty him: and the concluion of all was, that I would be a Mediator unto you for his departure. Come come Leonida, (replyed Galathea, even red againe with anger, and unable to diemble her jealouie) confee the truth: has he not moved you? Yes Madam (anwered he) he has moved me to pitty him and me thinkes, ince he has uch an extream deire to go you ought not to keep him by force for Love is never whipped into a heart. I do not meane a matter of pitty (replyed Galathea) but tis no matter; perhaps when he is well recovered, he hall feele the effects of that anger which he hath infued into me, as oone as thoe effects of Love which he hath infued into you: meane time let me tell you, he hall not go from hence, when he, but when I will: as for you Leonida, (continued he) content you that I ay no more only be gone I care not for your company now you know my mind. Thus Leonida was put to ilence, and forc'd to go away, taking this affront o to heart, that he reolved to go unto Adamas her Unckle, and never have any more to do with Galatheas ecrets. Galathea, at the ame time called for Silvia who was walking alone in another Alley. Unto whom, contrary to her deigne, he imparted that which he had o cloely concealed from her and complayned againt Leonida. But Silvia, though young yet full of dicretion, did indeavour to excue Leonida all he could; apprehending very wiely, that if her companion hould be angry, and things come to be knowne, they would prove very candalous unto her Mitrie. And therefore after many other paages he aid thus unto her. You know Madam that you never opened any thing of this buinee unto me; and yet I can tell you o many particulars, as you hall ee I was not altogether o ignorant as I eemed. But uch is my humor, that I never could endure to meddle in matters, unto which I am not called. But perceiving my companion o aiduous about Celadon, I upected that Love might be the caue, more then her compaion upon his maladie; and becaue it was a buinee which neerely concerned us all, I reolved before I poke any more of it, to be a little better aured, and therefore began to oberve her actions more narrowly then I was accutomed; o as I got behind the hepherds bed whilt he was a leep, and preently Leonida entred, who making a little noie, did waken him: then after much common dicoure, he began to talk of his affection unto the hepherdee Atrea, and of hers to him: but beleeve me hepherd (aid he) Atreas Love is nothing in comparion of Galatheas unto you. To me? (aid he) Yes to you (replyed Leonida) you need not wonder o at it, for you know how oft I have told you o though all the language I have, cannot et forth the magnitude of it. Fair Nymph, (anwered the hepherd) I neither can merit nor beleeve, o great an honour unto me. For what can her deigne be upon poor me, who am a illy hepherd and will both live and die o? Your birth (replyed my companion) mut needs be noble, ince you are owner of o many excellent qualities and perfections. Oh Leonida (anwered the hepherd then) I cannot chue but think you Jeere me: can you think me o ignorant as not to know who Galathea is, & who I am 'Certainly, fair Nymph I know, better then o how to meaure the meanee of my qualitie with the grandure of her merits: with the meaure of duty: Oh hepherd (anwered Leonida) do you think that Love ueth the ame meaures that men do? No no, meaures are ued by uch as ue to buy and ellt gifts are never meaured, and Love being nothing ele but a meere gift, is never conferred by meaures: never make any quetion of this truth; but not to faile in your duty, pay unto her as much Love and affection as he betowes upon you. I do profee Madam, that till
now, I thought Leonida had poken for her elfe, and her dicoure atonihed me: but eeing with how much dicretion your actions are managed, I did much commend the power you have over them; knowing, that it is a thing of greater difficultie to command ones elfe, then another. Sweet heart, (anwered Galathea) did you but know, how I tand in need of Celadon's amitie, you would commend and advie me unto this deigne: For, do you remember the Druide who told us our Fortunes? Yes, Madam, anwered he, my memory is not o bad, as to forget a thing of o late an age. Then you remember (continued Galathea) how many truths he did foretell, both unto you and Leonida; and how he aured me, that if I married any other then Celadon, I hould be the mot mierable peron upon earth: Now ince our own experience may well make us credit what he foretells, why hould I light a buinee which o nearly concerties me? And therefore I take it very ill from Leonida, that he hould offer to upplant me. Madam, anwered Silvia, I would advie you not to vex her too much, let he hould be provoked to make a dicovery of the buinee. Friend, anwered Galathea (and embraced her) I do apprehend your advice to be both faithfull and good, and therefore promie you, to carry my elfe towards Leonida according to your counell. Whilt they were thus dicouring, Leonida went to Celadon, unto whom he related word for word, all the dicoure betwixt Galathea and her; and told him, that though the place where he was, eemed to be a place of freedome, yet, the truth was, it was no better then a Prion: Which newes did o pierce him to the heart, that he fell into a Feavour, and in uch a violent degree, that Galathea coming to ee him, and finding him o much impaired, he began to doubt his life, epecially the next day, when he wounded two or three times in their armes: And though thee Nymphs did continually watch with him without any ret, but interrupted lumbers, yet was he but very ill attended, there being in that place no manner of Medicines for one that was ick, nor durt they end abroad for any, let the matter hould come to a dicovery; o as the Shepheard did run a hazard of his life, inomuch as one evening the Nymphs gave him for dead: But at lat he returned to himelfe, and after an exceive bleeding, he took a little ret; and therefore the Nymphs left him alone with Merill: And being retired, Silvia much affrighted at this accident, addreed her elfe unto Galathea, and aid, Madam, we hall all be brought into trange confuion, unlee you take ome order; in what a cae would you be in, if this Shepheard hould die in your hands, for want of help? Alas, anwered he, I have conidered all this, ever ince his dieae encreaed; but what remedie is there? We are here detitute of all necearies for him, and as for getting them from other places, for my life I dare not, for fear of dicovery. Leonida, whoe affection made her peak more reolutely then Silvia, aid thus unto her; Madam, thoe fears are very good, o far as they do not concern the life of a man. Suppoe this hepheard hould die, can any imagine his death can be kept without dicovery? the Heavens themelves, as a punihment, will at lat lay all open. But, take every thing at the wort, and uppoe it were known that this hepheard were here, cannot you cover your act with a mask of compaion? If you will be pleaed to trut me with the whole buinee, I will manage it o, as none hall ever know it: For Madam, I have an Uncle in this Country, Adamas, the chiefe of the Druides, as you know very well: No ecret in Nature, or vertue in any Plant, is hid from him; he is a man full of widome and dicretion, and I know, he has a particular inclination to do you ervice; if you will employ him in the buinee, I am confident, that all things will ucceed according to your wih. Silvia apprehending this to be the bet expedient and conceiving that by the means of the grave Adamas, Galathea might perhaps be diverted from her thoughts of this hepheard; he advied her unto it as the afet coure: Unto which Galathea, for want of another, conented. Then Madam (aid Leonida) to the end I may keep within the compae of your commands, I beeech you tell me what is your pleaure I hould ay, or conceal, from Adamas? Silvia eeing Galathea tand mute, anwered, That the only way to move him unto ecrey, was, to eem as if he were wholly truted in the buinee; for nothing will ooner make a ecret come out, then mitrut: o as I conceive the way to charm Adamas unto privacy, is, to acquaint him before he comes with every thing, that he may dicover when he is here. I am o much beides my elfe, aid Galathea, that I know not what to ay, and therefore I refer the whole buinee unto your dicretions. Thus Leonida departed, with intention, though the night was very dark at firt, not to top, untill he came at her Uncles, whoe houe was on the ide of Marcelles Mountain, towards the Vetalls and Druides of Laigneau; but her journey proved longer then he
expected, for when he came at the break of day unto the houe of Adamas, he found that he was gone to Feurs, and would not return, untill three daies, thence; and therefore after halfe an houres ret, he went away; yet, o weary, that had he not been very zealous of her hepheard's cure, he would have tayed untill the return of Adamas: but, after he had gone a mile of her way, he pied afar off in the ame way a Nymph all alone, whom a little after he knew to be Silvia: This encounter put her into a ad perplexitie, fearing that Silvia brought the newes of Celadon's death; but it proved quite the contrary, for he brought newes, that ince her departure he had reted very well, and that the Feaver had left him; therefore Galathea had ent her, to give a top unto her proceedings, and to tell her, that ince the hepheard was in o good a condition, there was no need of bringing Adamas, or dicovering the buinee unto him. It is eaily imagined, how glad Lemida was of this newes; and after her thanks to Heaven, he aid thus unto her Companion, Siter, I undertand, that Galathea has acquainted you with her deigne upon this hepheard, and therefore in all freedome of language I will tell you, that this kinde of life doth infinitely dipleae me, and that I think it dihonourable both for her and us: for he is o paionately humorous, that upon every ditate this hepheard hall give her, he will be halfe ditracted; and builds o much upon the predictions of the Druide, as he thinks all her happinee depends upon loving him: Alo, as all Lovers do, he thinks him o lovely, as he believes every one does the like, as if all did look upon him with the ame eyes he doth and that's my griefe, for he is growne o jealous of me, that he cannot endure I hould come neer him. Now Siter, if this kinde of life come once to be known, as quetionlee it will; ince nothing is o ecret, but at lat is dicovered, judge you how the world will cenure us: I, for my part, have ued all poible arguments to divert from it, but all in vain. The cope of all this my dicoure is, that I do think very fit to finde out ome good remedie, and that I can conceive no better expedient, then the interpoition and mediation of my Uncle, who by his prudence and good counell, may happily do ome good upon her. Siter, anwered Silvia I do extreamly like your advice and that you may have more time to bring Adamas unto her, I will return, and tell her, that I have been at the houe of Adamas; but found neither him nor you. 'Tis very well, replyed Leonida, and it will not be amie, if we go and ret our elves under ome hedge, that it may eem as if you had been longer eeking me: Alo, to tell you truly, I am o tired that if I will get to my journeyes end, I mut leep a little. Come then (aid Silvia) and believe, it is a good work for your elfe, if you can get Celadon from amongt us; for I do foreee by Galathea's humour, that his tay here in a little time may caue you a great deal of dipleaure. And o looking about for a convenient place, where they might pae away part of the day, they pied a place on the other ide of Lignon, which eemed to be very fit for that purpoe; o as paing over at the Bridge of Botereux, and leaving Bonlieu, the houe of the Vetalls and Druides, on the left hand, and walking down the River, they came to a handom thicket of wood, where they both lept together. As they were thus repoing themelves, Atrea, Diana, and Phillis did accidentally drive their flocks unto the ame place; and never eeing the Nymphs, they at down by them. And as that friendhip which reeth out of adveritie, is often more firme, then that of properitie; o Diana had contracted a mot firme league with Atrea and Phillis, ince the diater of Celadon; and uch a correpondency was grown between them, that they were every day together. And certainly Atrea tood in need of all conolation, for almot at one and the ame time, he lot Alces her Father Hippolita her Mother; Hippolita died of a fright, when he heard that Atrea was fallen into the water: and Alces dyed for griefe, at the loe of his deer Wife: But, thee loes were a kinde of comfort unto her; for under the umbrage of mourning for her Father and Mother, he could lament the loe of Celadon. Now as I told you before, Diana, the Daughter of prudent Belinda, to perform the rites of neighbourhood, did go often unto Atrea, and found her humours o pleaing, and he hers, and Phillis both, that they vowed eternall friendhip, and never ince could eperate. This was the firt day Atrea came out of her Chamber ince her ad diaters; and he was no ooner et down, but he epied Semires coming towards her. This hepheard had been long in love with Atrea, and knowing that he loved Celadon, he caued this edition betwixt them, conceiving, that if he could once get rid of Celadon, then he hould with eae tep into his teed: And now he came unto her, in hopes to advance his deigne, but he was much mitaken: for Atrea having melt out his ubtletie, he conceived uch an inveterate hatred againt him, that aoon as he aw him, he put her hand before her eyes, as unwilling to
look upon uch a bae impotor, and deired Phillis to go and tell him from her, that he could not endure his company: Thee words were pronounced with o much vehemency, as her companions plainly perceived her great animoitie againt him, which made Phillis more haty in running towards this hepheard. When he heard this meage, he was o Planet-truck, as he eemed abolutely immovable: At lat being concious, and tung with the bitter ene of his own errour, he aid unto her, Dicreet Phillis, I mut needs ingenuouly confee, that the heavens are mot jut, in punihing a heart with more griefe, then it is able to endure; I cannot chue but adly ay, that the chatiement cannot equall the offence, ince I have detroyed the mot perfect league of friendhip that ever was. But, to the end the gods may top their vengeance, I beeech you tell that fair hepheardee, I mot cordially beg a pardon, both from her, and the ahes of Celadon; and aure her, that the extream affection which I bore unto her, was the only caue of my fault: But, I will go, and all my life long lament I have offended her, and thoe fair eyes which are o jutly incened againt me. After thee words he went away, o dimally dejected, that his repentance moved ome pitty in the heart of Phillis; who being returned to her companions, related all his anwer unto them. Alas, alas, dear Siter, aid Atrea, what ad caue have I to flie from this fatall villain? for 'tis he, he only, that is the caue of all my mierie. How Siter (aid he) Semires the caue? has he had uch power over you? If I durt relate his villanie, and my own implicitie (aid Atrea) I hould tell you, that he hath ued the mot cunning artifice, that ever any ubtle wit could invent. Diana believing, that it was by reaon of her, that he would not peak more clearly unto Phillis, ince their familiarity was not above even or eight daies old, he turned towards the ad Atrea, and aid, Fair Shepheardee, you will give me occaion to think you do not love me, if you ue lee freedome towards me then towards Phillis; for, though I have not been o long happy in your acquaintance as he hath, yet, you may be as confident of my affection as of hers. Phillis then anwered, I aure my elfe, that Atrea does peak as freely before you, as to her own elfe, for he cannot be halfe a friend; and ince amitie is vowed betwixt your, I believe he will open the very cloet of her heart unto you. Mot certainly I will (aid Atrea) but the reaon why I would peak no more of that ad buinee, was only, becaue I would not too much vex a wound, with too much rubbing upon it. If that be all, replied Diana, I hould think, that free imparting a miery unto a friend, is halfe the cure; and if I durt ue o much free boldnee, as to deire it, nothing would give me greater atisfaction, then to know the Hitorie of your life; which in requitall, I will repay with a relation of my own, whenoever you hall command it. Since it is your deire, replied Atrea, I hall make you a harer in my mierable torie; but with much brevitie, unlee it were fuller of good fortune then it is: So all three itting round, he thus began.

div.head: The Hitory of Atrea and Phillis.
div.p:
THoe who are of opinion, that loves and hates do hereditarilie decend from Father to Son, did they but know what hath been Celadons Fortune and mine, doubtlee would confee themelves mitaken. For, Fair Diana, perhaps you have heard of the implacable emnitie that was between Alces and Hippolyta, my Father and Mother; and Alcippes and Amarillis, the Father and Mother of Celadon, and how their hatred accompanied them to their graves, which have caued abundance of trouble amongt the hepheards of this Country, inomuch as I beleeve, few or none about the fatall River of Lignon are ignorant of it: and yet Love, to hew the greatnee of his power, did unite two of thee enemy-families, o firmly, that nothing could diolve the knots of their affection but only death. For Celadon no ooner arrived at the age of fourteen or fifteen yeares, and I at twelve or thirteen, but at an aembly in the Temple of Venus which is upon the top of a high Mountain, neer the Catle of Mount Brion, this young hepheard aw me; and as he ince hath told me he had long before an extream deire of it, by ome reports he had heard of me: but the jarres which were amongt our Parents was the impediment which hindred him: and I mut ingeniouly confee that I think his deire of it, was no greater then mine. For I know not why, but when I heard peak of him, my heart did beat; unlee it was a preage of thoe troubles which afterwards befell me by reaon of him, When he firt aw me, I cannot tell what caues of Love he found in me, but o it is, that ince that time he reolved to Love and erve me: and it eemes, that at the firt enterview we were both trucken with
the darts of Love, for as oon as ever they told me that he was the Son of Alcippes, I perceived a kind of chang in me, which was not ordinary; then all his actions beg in to pleae me, and eemed much more agreeable unto me then any other young hepheard whatoever; and becaue he durt not yet approach me, alo becaue peaking with me was forbidden him, his looks and eys by their turning to & fro did utter uch language unto me as I knew he deired to ay more. And indeed at a Braul which was held at the foot of a Mountain under a plump of antient Elmes which cat a pleaant haddow, he carried it o cunningly, that without any heed of me, and eeming as if it were out of a merry careleenee he got me by the hand. For my part, I eemed as if I took no notice of it, but carried my elfe to him as to all the ret, but he in taking my hand, did toope with his head as if he would kie his hand but I perceived his mouth upon mine; this did caue ome colour to come into my face: but I feigning to take no notice, did turne away my head, as if I only minded the braule which we danced: this caued him to tay a while ilent, not knowing I beleeve, how he hould begin to peak: at lat being unwilling to loe uch an opportunitie as this which he had long longed for, he came very neer me and whipering Corilas (who took me out to dance) in the eare, yet o loud (but eeming to whiper) that I did plainly heare what he aid, Oh Corilas (aid he) I wih with all my oul that the quarrells between this hepherdees Father and Mine, might be decided by her and me. To which Corilas anwered very loud, Nay never wih that, Celadon, for perhaps it is the mot dangerous wih, that ever you made. Let the hazard be what it will (anwered Celadon very lond) I'le not go from what I have aid, though I were to give my heart, as a pledge. And becaue I eemed to take no notice of their dicoures, he addreed himelfe unto me and thus aid: And you fair hepheardee, what opinion have you of this offer? I do not know, anwered I, what you peak of. He told me, replied Corilas, that to draw a great good from a great evil, he wihes that the inveterate hatred of your Fathers, were changed into love amongt their Children. How, (anwered I, eeming not to know him) are you Alcippes Son? Yes, (anwered he) and more then that; I am your mot devoted ervant. Me thinkes, aid I, that it had been more proper for you to have applied your dicoure unto ome other, who may be more agreeable to you then I: I have heard ay, replied Celadon, that the gods do ue to punih the inns of the Fathers upon their Children; but this is not the ue amongt men, unlee your beauty, which is divine, will aume the ame priviledges with the gods: and if you do, then like them, you mut give pardon when it is asked: how now hepheard (aid Corilas) what? Do you begin your combate with crying mercy? In uch a combate as this anwered he, to be vanquihed is a kind of victory: and for my part, I am mot willing to be o, provided he will be pleaed to take the poile. I think, they had continued their dicoure longer, had the Brawle, longer lated: but at lat we parted, and every one returned to his place.

Not long after the hepheards ued everall exercies, as wratling, running, leaping, and throwing the barre; and a Garland to be given unto him, who got the better in the everall activities. Celadon, as being too young was admitted only unto that of running, and did win the Garland, compoed of divers flowers, which was put upon his head by all the aembly with high commendations, that being o young as he was, he hould overcome o many other nimble hepheards. He, not valuing himelf did take it from his head, and put it upon mine, aying, This, fair one, is in confirmation of what I aid before. I was o urpried at this that I could not return any anwer: & had it not been for Artemis, your Mother Phillis, I had given it unto him again; not but that coming from his hand, it was very acceptable unto me; but it was becaue I feared Alces and Hippolyta would be angry with me. But Artemis who deired rather, to extinguih then enflame thee old grudges, did command me to receive it, and thank him. Which accordingly I did, but in uch a hollow manner as made every one think I did it only upon my Aunts command. All that day was thus pent, and the next day alo; in both which, the young hepheard lot no opportunities of manifeting his affection. And it was the cutome upon the third day, in the honour of Venus, to repreent the judgement which Paris gave of the three goddees. Celadon reolved to put himelf amongt the Maides in the habit of a hepherdee. You know that upon the third day after the banquett, he Grand Druide has a cutome to throw a Golden Apple amongt the Maides, upon which are written the names of the three hepheardees which eem unto him to be the fairet of all the company, with this Motto, Let this be given to the fairet of the three. Afterwards the peron that by lot was to repreent Paris, does enter into the Temple of Venus with the three hepheardees; where the dores being
hut, judgement is given upon the beauty of thee three eeing them all naked, except for a linnen cover which reacheth from the middle to the knee, and becaue ome abue had formerly been by ome hepheards who ued to mixe themelves amongt the hepheardees, it was ordained by publique Edict, that he who hould commit the like crime, hould without remiion be toned by the Maides at the gates of the Temple: but o it was, that this young Boy, never conidering the extream danger of it, did this day dree himelfe in the habit of a hepherdee, and putting himelfe into our company was taken for a maide. Then as if fortune was reolved to favour him, my name, and Malthea, and Stella, were written upon the Apple, and when they came to draw the name that was to repreent Paris, I heard Orithea named, which was the name that Celadon took upon him. Heavens knowes whether his oul was not infinitly joyed to ee his deigne thrive o well. At the lat, we were conducted into the Temple, where the Judge being et upon his Throne, the dores hut, and we three only within with him, we began, according to the Law, to undree our elves; and becaue each apart did go and peak unto the Iudge, and offer, as heretofore the three Goddees did unto Paris; Stella was the quicket to undree her elfe, and did firt preent her elfe whom the Judge did a while contemplate, and after a full hearing what he would ay for her elfe, he caued her to retire, and give place unto Malthea, who was forwarder in undreing her elfe then I was; for I being much ahamed to hew my elfe o naked, I trifled out the time as much as I could. Celadon, unto whom time eemed too long, and after he had lightly looked upon Malthea, eeing I did not come, he called me; o, ince contrained I went: But, Oh Heavens! how much ahamed am I to think upon it? My haire was dihevel'd, and almot covered me, over which, all the ornament I had, was the Garland which the day before he had given me. When the ret were retired, and he aw me in this then dree before him, I oberved, that he changed colour two or three times; but I could not yet o much as upect the caue. For my part, hame had o dyed my cheeks with a freh colour, that he has ince vowed unto me, he never aw me fairer, and could have been well contented to have pent the whole day in this contemplation; but fearing to be dicovered, he was contrained to abridge his delight: And eeing I aid nothing unto him (for hame had tyed up my tongue) Why fair Star (aid he unto me) do you think your caue o good, that as the ret have done, you need not plead it before your judge? No Orithia, anwered I, I will ubmit unto Stella and Malthea, both as well in beautie, as in Rhetorick; o as had not cutomobli • ged me to come, I hould never have appeared before you, in any hopes to win the prie. But if you do carry it from them both, anwered the hepheard, what remuneration may I expect from you? I hall then think (aid I unto him,) that, I have more then I do deerve What? (aid he) is this all the offer that you make? I know not what to offer (aid I, unto him) that deerves a reception; and therfore you mut firt aske. Then wear unto me, (aid the hepheard) that you will give me what I hall aske, and my judgement hall be in your advantage. After I had promied that I would, he asked a lock of my hair, for a Bracelet which I gave him; and after he had lapt it up in a paper he aid unto me; now Atrea, I will keep this hair as a tetimonie of this oath which you have taken, to the end that if ever you break it, I may offer it unto the Goddee Venus and beg revenge. That is but uperfluous, anwered I, ince I am fully reolved never to faile in it. Then with a miling countenance he aid unto me, the gods be praied, my fairet Atrea, that my deigne hath o happily propered; for know, that the thing which you have promied is, to Love me better then any in the world, and to receive me as your mot fathfull and vowed Servant, who am Celadon, and not Orithea, as you imagine: the very ame Celadon, that in pight of all old emnities betwixt our Parents, is o infinitly devoted yours, as he will rather die at the dore of the Temple, then not give a tetimony of his affection unto you. Imagine, wie Diana, in what a perplexitie I was now in: Love did forbid me from taking revenge; yet hame did animate me againt Love: at lat after a confued dipute with my elf, I could not poibly conent to make him die, becaue his offence proceeded only from his excee of loving me: but now knowing him to be a hepheard, I could not any longer tay in his ight: but without returning any anwer, I ran to my companions, whom I found to be almot dreed; and not well knowing what I did, I dreed my elf as oon as poibly I could: But to be hort; when we were al ready, the diguied Orithea tood at the threhold of the dore, and having all three about him: I do ordaine, aid he, that the prie of beauty be given unto Atrea; in tetimonie whereof I do preent unto her the golden apple: let none ever doubt of my judgement, for I have veiwed and examined
her, and finds her to be full of all perfection. Upon thee words, he preented the apple unto me, which I received with a troubled mind: but more, when he aid unto me in a low voice, take this apple as a pledge of my affection, which, like it, is pure, and endlee: To whom I anwered be contented, rah youth, that I receive it only to ave thy life, which otherwie, comming from thy hand, I would refue. He could not reply for fear of being heard and known. And becaue it was the cutom, that he who received the Ball, hould by way of thankes, kis the Judge, I was contrained to kie him. But, I aure you, I was at this ceremonie almot ready to dicover him. Then the grand Druide caued me to be carried in a chair, through all the croud with loud applauds and acclamations, o as every one did wonder why I did not enjoy this honour with more alacrity for truly I was o confounded betwixt Love and Anger, that I hardly knew what I did. As for Celadon, as oone as the ceremonies were done, he thrut himelf amongt the ret of the hepherds and by little and little without any notice taken, got out of the croud and putting off his borrowed habit, he aumed his own, in which he came preently unto us with uch confident lookes, as none could ever upect him: For my part when I aw him again, my heart was o full of hame and anger, that it would carcely let my eyes look upon him: but he who did take a eeming regardlee notice of it, did find an occaion to accot me, and in a loud voice aid: The Judge who conferred the prie upon you, hath hewed himelf a very right Judge of beauty, and yet, though your caue did merit his entence, you are in ome ort obliged unto him. I think hepheard, anwered I in a low voice, that he is more obliged to me then I to him: for he gave me an apple only, which in ome degree, I deerve and is my due; but I gave him his life, which for his impudent rahnee he deerved to loe. This is no more then was before reolved (anwered Celadon) for he does not valew his life further then to protrate it at your feet. Were it not more in regard of my elf then him, replied I, I hould have punihed his impudence: but, Celadon, no more; let us leave this dicoure: and, know that the reaon why I did not caue you to be punihed according to your merits is, only becaue I would not bring my elfe upon the tage, and not for want of any will to ee you chatised. If that be the only reaon, aid he, I beeech you tell me what death you will have me die: And you hall ee that I have as much courage to obey you, as I have Love to offend you.

This dicoure would be very long and tedious, if I hould include every particular. But o it was, he gave me o many tetimonies of his affection, that I could not poibly doubt it: but till eeming to be all anger, I aid thus unto him Shepheard, conider the emnity that is betwixt our Fathers, & believe that mine to thee hal be the ame, if thou dot till thus trouble me with thy follies, which for this time, thy youth and my own honour moves me to pardon. I mentioned a pardon, becaue I would infue a little courage unto him: for the very truth is, his beautie, and courage, and affection, did pleae me; but to the end he hould not reply, I turned from him and went to Stella, who was neer me. He all atonihed at this anwer, went out of the company o adly dejected as in a few dayes after he was grown not knowable, and kept himelf o private that, he frequented no places but the mot retired and wild partes of our woods. Of which, I being advertied by ome of my companoins, who did in a cloe manner tell me that I was the only caue; I began to reent his condition, and reolved to find out ome way or other to give him a little comfort; and becaue, as I told you, he hunned all manner of company, I was contrained to drive my flock towards that place which he mot frequented: and after two or three times being there in vaine, at lat after a long earch for him, me thought I heard his voice amongt ome trees, and I was not mitaken. For going neerer; I found him lying all along upon the ground, his eyes weld with teares, and hands held up to heaven which eemed to be immoveable. This object moved me to o much pitty, that I was reolved to give him a cordiall for his paine. And therefore, after a whiles conideration, and not willing he hould think I ought for him, I retired a little way from him, where eeming to take no notice I began to ing, o loud that my voice reached both his eares and his heart. As oon as ever he heard me, I aw him leap up and turning his eyes towards the place where I was, he tood like a tatue till in a ravihing admiration. Which I oberving, to give him o much boldnee as to approch neerer, I eemed as if I lept, yet held mine eyes halfe open to ee what he would do. And indeed, he did as I did imagine he would: for drawing neerer me with a oft and gentle tread, he kneeled down as neer me as he could; and after a long tay in this poture I till eeming to be fat aleep, he tooped down and kied me. Then eeing that he had taken courage enough; I opened mine eyes as if he had wakened me. And riing
up as if in a raging anger, thus aid unto him. Uncivill hepherd, how durt you be o bold as thus to interrupt my leep? He, with a trembling heart, and kneeling till, aid thus unto me; It is your elfe fair hepherdee, that did contrain me, and if I have inned, then, bright Starre, you mut dim your Luter, and punih your own perfections, which are the caue. This is alwayes your excue for your preumption (aid I unto him) but hepheard beleeve it, if you continue in this coure of offending me, I will not endure it. If you call it an offence, to love and adore you (anwered he) proceed to entence immediatly, and doome me to what death you pleae: for I do make a mot olemne vow, that I will o offend you as long as my life is in me. It is neither the rigour of your cruelties, nor the emnity of our Parents, no, nor all the impediments in the whole univere conpired together hall ever divert me from this reolution. But, Fair Diana I mut abbreviate thee pleaing dicoures, as being not utable unto my preent diaters, And will only tell you, that being overcome I aid thus unto him; hepheard what good can you hope for, when thoe who have the dipoe of you, does diapprove of your beginning? How? Said he, dipoe of me? Has Alcippe more power over my wil then I have my elf. You may dipence with your own wil (anwered I) but never with that obedience which is due unto a Father, without a mot horrid crime. The obedience which I owe unto him (aid he) mut be confined unto poibilities and it is no fault to faile, where power wants to performe: but admit, I mut obey in al things, ince of two evills, the greater is to be avoided. I will rather faile in my duty to him who is but a man, then in my duty to your fair elfe, who is all Divine. Our dicoure lated o long, and o prevalent he was in it, that I was forced to admit him my ervant: and both of us being too young to hadow our deignes with any artifice, Alcippe did oone find us out; and being loath this amitie hould grow up to any higher pitch, he reolved to end him upon o long a voyage with good old Cleantes, as that abence might wear out this young impreion of Love, But the eperation did as little good as all the ret of his artifices which he ued: for Celadon, though yet a Boy, did o fixe his reolution to overcome all difficulties, that though any other would have taken them for torments, yet he looked upon them only as proofes of himelfe, and called them the touchtones of his fidelitie. And becaue he knew that his voyage would lat long, he intreated me leave to bid him adieu. This leave I granted; but, Fair Diana, had you heard how paionatly he begged me to Love him and the vowes he made never to change, doubtlee you would have concluded nothing more impoible, then that this affection hould ever decay. At lat ince his time of tay was but hort, he thus aid unto me. My Atrea (for o he phraed me alwaies in private) I hall leave with you my Brother Lycidas, from whom I will never conceale any of my thoughts he knowes how I have vowed my elfe unto your ervice, I beeech you promie me, (if it be your pleaure I hould depart with any joy) that you will receive as from me all the ervices which he hall do you and by his preence renew the memorie of abent Celadon. And truly he had good reaon to make this requet unto me. For Lycidas during his abence, was o diligent to oberve his Brothers commands, that many thought that he ucceeded his Brother, in the affection which he bore unto me: this was the reaon why Alcippes after he had kept him three yeares out of this Country, did call him home, in a confidence that o long a time had worne away that light impreion of Love, which had a little entred into his green heart; and that he being now grown more wie, would weane Lycidas alo from my affection. But his returne was an extreame aurance of his fidelitie abence could not extinguih the ardency ot his Love; no nor all the o much admired Romane beauties, could ever tartle him. He intreated me by his Brother, that I would give him leave to come unto me: Oh Heavens, how gladly did he come when I gave him licence? I think I have his Letters about me, for alas, I have kept them better then him: then pulling a little bundle out of her pocket, like unto that which Celadon ued to carry, or in imitation of him and in which he very charily preerved thoe which came from him, he took the firt, for he kept them in order as they came unto her, then after he had wiped away her pearly teares, he read thee words.

p.hi: MY patience hath vanquihed my exile, and heavens grant alo that it may vanquih all hinderances of our happinee: I departed with o much orrow, and returne with o

much joy; That, not dying neither in going nor coming, it manifets that one cannot dy with too much delight, nor of too much adnee. Permitt me I beeech you to wait upon you, that I may relate my fortunes unto her, who is my only happinee.

div.p: Fair Diana, it is impoible to remember all the dicoure we then had unlee I hould open thoe wounds again, which are more dolorous to me then death. During Celadons abence, Artemis my Aunt and Mother of Phillis, did come upon a viit unto us, and brought with her this Fair hepherdee, Phillis: And becaue our manner of living, eemed more pleaant unto her then the hepherds of Allier he was pleaed to tay with us, which, beleeve it, was no mall contentment unto me: for her humours were very pleaing unto me, and I have paed over many tedious hours with her. When Celadon returned his judgment was o good, and he liked her o well, as I may truly ay he was the caue of the great League, which ever ince hath been twixt her and me. At this time he arrived at the age of eaventeen or eighteen, and I at fifteen or ixteen, and began to manage matters with more prudence: o as, to diguie our loves, I did intreat him, or rather indeed contraine him, to be very familiar with all hepheardees which could pretend unto any hadow of Beauty; to the end his applications unto me might be taken rather as common, then particular. I ay, I contreyned him unto it, for he did everall times upon his knees begge for a revocation of this command; and alas, he had good reaon o to do, for he did too well foreee, that from hence would proceed the caue of his death. Excue me, wie Diana, if a few due teares interrupt my dicoure, ince I have o much ad caue for them, as it were impiety to top them: Then after he had dryed her eyes, he began her dicoure again.

And becaue that Phillis was mot commonly with me, it was unto her that he firt made his addrees unto, according to my command. I could carly forbear my miles, epecially when Phillis beleeved him to be in good earnet, and treated him as it is the cutome to treat uch as begin the like addrees. I remember that when he was once very harply treated, he ang this Song which he compoed upon this ubject.

lg.l: CLoe by a River cleare, whoe bankes were clad
With Moie cuions, and a channell had;
Which like a Serpent wreathed, and did glide
A long a lovely plaine with welling pride,
Did it a Shepheard, chanting it in vere,
And with his Pipe did thee ad Lines reheare.
Ceae, Fair one, Ceae; ceae once your cruelty,
Let me enjoy one day before I die.
The torments I endure for loving you
Are greater farr, then is for hatred due;
If gods be good, and infinitly kind
Then Love and Hate a difference will find.
Is't poible a pure and perfect Love
Should never, never any pitty move?
Are animals inenible as tones,
Which never moved are with ighes and groanes?
Thoe amorous glances of your winning eyes,
Have oft encourag'd up my hopes to rie,
And ince they well with promises o fair
If they do violate, they perjured are;
Oft have they told me, that your tony heart
Would melt; and from everitie depart:
Each charming part of your fair face did ay,
In their fale Language, they would ne're betray.
But how? Does hepheardees eyes out vie,
The glitering Court in all its falitie?
Can they who live and only haunt the fields
Ue any art, but what plaine nature yeilds?
Has rurall beauties found a ubtile art
Though not their faces, yet to paint the heart?
Are thee the Doctrines that your Schoole affords
Only to flatter, and to give good words?
No no, my Fair one, thee are fallacies
And far unutable with your fair eyes;
Learne to be kind, and banih cruelty;
This cometh neeret to a Dietie;
Beauty that bringes not weetnee with it, might
Be likned to an eye that wanteth ight.
To her that has no Love and yet is fair,
A Corps without a Soul I will compare.

div.p: I do very well remember (aid Phillis and interrupted her) how his addrees unto me made you laugh: for commonly his dicoure, was only a few fragments of words o diordered as they could hardly hold ene: And commonly when he would name me, his thoughts o run upon you, that he would call me Atrea: But ee the variety of everall inclinations! I know very well that Celadon had ome advantages of nature above Lycidas; yet I thought, though I knew no reaon for it, Lycidas to be much more agreeable unto my fancy. Siter, aid Atrea to her, you bring into my memorle a dicoure which once he had concerning you and this fair hepheardee, (aid he and turned towards Diana) Fair hepherdee (aid he to me) the wie Belinda and Artemis your Aunt, are infinitly happy in two Daughters; and our Lignon is much obliged unto them ince by their meanes it has the honour to have thee two fair ones upon their bankes. And if I have any judgement they only do merit the amitie of Atrea, and therefore I do advie you to love them, for by that hort acquaintance I have had with them, I do foreee, you will receive much atisfaction in their familiarity: I wih that one of them would daigne to look upon my Brother Lycidas with as much affection as I do. And then, fair Diana, having but little acquaintance with you, I anwered him, that my deire was, he hould rather become a ervant unto Phillis: and it hapned as I did wih: for ordinarie dicoure between them firt begot a familiaritie, and at lat a Love in good earnet between them. One day finding fit opportunitie for it, he reolved to declare his affection to her, and to couch the mot Love in the fewet words he was able. Fair one (aid he to her) I hope you know your elfe o well, as to beleeve, that thoe who love you mut needs love you infinitly: It mut be my actions only which mut make my affection known unto you; and at the firt begge no more then an admittance into your favour. Celadon and I were o neer, as we could hear this declaration, and alo the anwer which Phillis returned, and which indeed was more harp then I expected from her. For he and I did long before know, by the eyes and actions of Lycidas that he loved her, and he did not dilike of it, that at this time he anwered him with o much harpnee, that Lycidas was almot deperate: and Celadon who loved his Brother very much, being extreamly angry he hould receive uch a baffle, he was halfe angry with me, at which I could not chue but laugh, and at lat tell him: Never be o angry Celadon at this harh anwer which Lycidas hath received: Phillis could do no lee; hepheards of thee times, do too much glorie in the eainee of their Mitries: but to the end you may ee that I do very well know the humour of Phillis, I will undertake to bring Lycidas into favour with her, provided he will but practie a little patience and continue on his addrees. I mut confee, when firt I pake unto her, he was o hie, as I knew not what to think, but till hoped and reolved to win her with time: But Lycidas he was out of all patience, and reolved to give her over, and Love her no longer: upon which occaion he writ thee veres.

lg.head: Upon a reolution not to Love.
lg.l: WHen I beheld thoe glorious eyes,
Triumphant in their Victories,
I did ubmit unto their darts,
As to the only Queen of hearts:
So lovely did they look, and kinde,
As if no rigour I hould finde:
But when it plainly does appear,
That cruelty it elfe is there,
'Tis time to hrink and fall away,
Rather than Tyranny obey,
For ever; which will only prove
Puillanimitie, not Love.
'Tis true, her lutre has uch arts,
As conquer can all human hearts.
But when reitance cannot doe,
Then flie, and 'tis dicretion too:
'Tis better far to make retreat,
Then tay, and have a ure defeat.

div.p: Lycidas had lot all hopes of ever obtaining; and therefore as Phillis and I were walking according to our cutom, by the River ide, we found him writing with his Sheephook, thee enuing veres upon a bed of Sand, which when he was gone a little further, (for he aw us not) we read: The veres were thee.

lg.head: Upon no hopes of ever being Loved.
lg.l: CAn it be thought the wanton winde will tay,
And whitle ever, where it does to day?
Will any think thee Letters in looe and
Can lat, and to eternity will tand?
If o, then there is hopes my Love may finde
Some ure foundation in her fleeting minde.
Away, away, with thee fond hopes, and think,
That and, and winde, and he, and all will hrink.

div.p:
Afterwards we heard him break out into thee dolefull expreions, lifting up his eyes to Heaven: O ye gods (aid he) if you are angry with me, becaue I do with more devotion adore the work of your hands, then I do you; I hope you will pardon that error, which you your elves have caued: Had it been contrary to your will, that Phillis hould be adored, urely you would have made her with fewer perfections, or ele infued lee knowledge of them into me. Would it not be prophanation, to offer lee affection unto a Divinitie of uch uperlative excellencies, as he is adorned with? I believe this Shepheard continued in uch dicoures, but I could not hear them; for Phillis forcing me by the arme I went with her: And when we were gone a little further, I aid unto her, Stonyhearted Phillis, why have you no more pitty upon this Shepheard, that is ready to die for you? Siter, anwered he, the Shepheards of this Country are o full of diimulation, that their hearts do commonly denie, what their tongues do promie; And if you do well oberve this Shepheard here, you will finde him all Artifice; and as for thoe expreions which now we have heard, I do believe, that when he epied us coming, he et himelf in the way purpoely, that we might hear his diembling complaints; otherwie, had they not been better poken unto us then to the aire and enlee woods? Siter, aid I, you have forbidden him any addrees to you Even this, anwered he, is a great argument of his little love to me. Is any command of power enough, to top the current of a violent affection? Believe it Siter, Love that can bend, is never trong: Do you think I hould
have loved him lee, if he had diobeyed me? But Siter, aid I unto her, he has obeyed you, and will you be angry with him for that? It's true Siter, replied he, he has obeyed me; but let me tell you, that I hold this obedience for very great diobedience; and leaving off his adrees to me, argues his paion very indifferent. If I had not interrupted her, I believe he would have continued her dicoure much longer; but becaue I much deired, that Lycidas might finde better entertainment for Celadon's ake, I told her, that this kinde of dicoure did become her towards Lycidas, but not towards me: Towards Lycidas it was allowable, by way of tryall, and I commended it; but towards me, it argued too much ditrut, to conceal any ecret of her oul. As for my part I would open all my heart unto her, and therefore told her, that ince it was impoible, but he mut love ome or other, he could not make a better choice then of Lycidas, ince he might already gather mot certain ymptomes of his affection. To which he anwered, that he never did, nor would, diemble or conceal any of her thoughts from me, but hould be extreamly orry I hould have any uch opinion of her. And ince I would have her entertain Lycidas, he would obey me. And hereupon Celadon finding her afterwards with me, brought her this Letter from his Brother, which was indited by my advice.

body.head: The Letter of Lycidas unto Phillis.

p.hi: IT is true, that of late I have lodged my love in my heart, and would not uffer it to appear, either in my eyes or my words: If in this I have done amie, then blame your own fair elfe, who commanded it. And if you do not believe I love you, put me to what Tet you pleae, and you hall finde it better, then by all my weak, though reall, expresions of words.

div.p:
At lat, wie Diana after many a perwaive argument, we brought things to that pae, as Lycidas was entertained; and ever ince, all foure of us have found much contentment in our lives, and invented many a tratagem to colour our deignes, both by dicoure and by writing one unto another. Perhaps you have taken notice of a great Rock, in the high way towards Rochell, which without much ado cannot be acended, but when one is at the top, there is no fear of any eye to dicover. And becaue it was neer the high way, we made choice of it for our rendevouz; if any did meet us, we eemed as if we went on in the high-way; but when the coat was clear, we acended. 'Tis true, that this Rock being o neer the high way, we were in ome danger of being heard by paengers, if we poke any thing loud and therefore commonly, Lycidas or Phillis were placed as guards, to pie when any came: And becaue buinee did ometimes o employ us, as we could not every day meet in this place, we ued to write one to another, and we made choice of another place of conveniercy, in which we laid our Letters one to another. In briefe, wie Diana, we ued all poible waies to conceal our elves; and Celadon and I, did o eldome convere together in publick, as many believed that Celadon's will was wholly changed; for aoon as ever he aw Phillis, then he made all his applications unto her, and he again treated him with all poible complacency: Alo as oon as Lycidas appeared, I left all other company to talk with him; o as in a hort time, Celadon himelfe had a conceit, that I loved Lycidas, and I believed that he loved Phillis: Phillis thought that Lycidas loved me, and Lycidas believed that Phillis loved Celadon: And thus unawares were we o intangled with thee opinions, as jealouie began by degrees to kindle amongt us. The truth is (aid Phillis) we were then but freh Schollars in the School of Love; for to what purpoe was it to conceal a reall love, and publih a fale one? was there not as much caue to fear the divulging of your love to Lycidas, as your love to Celadon? Siter, iter, aid Atrea, when a thing is not, we never fear what people think of it: But the contrary, when it is, then the leat upition of it, puts all out of order. But now (continued he, and turned to Diana), jealouie had o eized upon all foure, as I believe our lives had not been long, if ome good Genius had not inpired us to make all clear in the preence of one another. It was now even or eight daies ince we aw each other, at our Rocky rendevouz, and the Letters which paed 'twixt Celadon and me, were o different from the uuall train, as if they were writ by different perons. At lat, as I told you, ome good Angel having care of us, all foure did meet in one place, where no other company was: And Celadon, whoe affection had mot vigour in it, began thus to peak, Fair Atrea, did I think that time
would cure a dieae that raignes in me, I would wait for that remedje; but ince I know, the older it growes, the more it will encreae, I am forced to complain againt you for the wrongs which you have done me, and with more alacritie, ince I can do it before uch Judges as are my peers. When he would have gone on, Lycidas interrupted him, aying, that his pain was greater then his. Greater! aid Celadon, that's impoible, for mine is extream: And mine, believe it, aid Lycidas, is without any comparion. Whilft the Shepheards were thus debating the matter, I was upon Phillis, and aid, Do you ee, Siter, how thee Shepheards complain of us? Yes, anwered he; but I believe we have greater caue to complain of them. Though I am much incened againt Celadon, aid I unto her, yet, I am much more incened againt you, who under a diguie of friendhip, which you eemed to bear unto him, has drawn him from that affection which he bare unto me, o as I may well ay, you have tollen him from me. And becaue Phillis tood ilently amazed at this, and knew not what to anwer, Celadon addreed himelfe unto me, and aid, Ahl fair Shepheardee, but as ickle as fair; have you o oon lot the memory of all Celadon's ervices, and your own vowes? I cannot o much complain againt Lycidas, as againt you; for notwithtanding the conanguinity and amitie betwixt us, your perfections might well make him a Traitor, and forget his duty; but me thinks it hould be abolutely impoible, that o long a ervice as mine, and uch a perfect affection, hould ever finde the leat tain of incontancy in your oul. But admit, that all in me was too little, to deerve o great a happinee, how can you o far violate and dipence with your vowes, as before my eyes to entertain a new affection? At the ame time Lycidas took Phillis by the hand, and with a deep igh, aid, Oh fair hand, to whom I had given up my oul! can I live, and ee thee take poeion of any heart but my own? my owne, I ay, that did deerve the ame happinee, if ever any did deerve it, by the mot incere and pure affection that ever was? I could not hear any more what Lycidas aid, becaue I was contrained to anwer Celadon: Shepheard, Shepheard (aid I unto him) thee words, Fidelity and Affection, are more converant in your tongue then your heart, and I have more reaon to complain againt you, then hearken unto them: but becaue now I do not care for any thing that comes from you, I will not take o much pains as grieve at it; that office is more fitly yours, if your diembling heart would give you leave to do it. But, Celadon, ince things are thus love on, love Phillis till and erve her, her vertues will deerve it; and if I do afford thee a bluh, it is for anger that I hould uffer my elfe to be o groly deceived, and for over-loving one that is o much unworthy of it as thy elfe. Celadon was o much atonihed at this, that he tood tock till a long time, & could not anwer one word, which ilence gave me leaure to hearken unto that anwer, which Phillis returned unto Lycidas: Lycidas, Lycidas, aid he unto him, you that can call me ickle, incontant, and I know not what; you know full well, that thee titles are mot uitable unto yourelfe, and your own actions: Do you think that becaue you have got the tart, and complain firt, you can therefore palliate your faults, and wipe away the wrongs which you have done me? me, I ay, not ickle as your elfe is, who have more reaon to be ahamed of your changing then I have to be vexed at it: But that which mot vexeth me, is, that you hould charge me with your own faults, and counterfeit a good occaion for your own infidelity: But 'tis no matter, he that will deceive his own Brother, may well deceive her that is no relation to him. And then turning towards me, And you Atrea (aid he unto me) you that have tollen away the heart of a Servant from me; do you think to keep it any longer then the firt new object that hall preent it elfe' No, no, though I know your perfections have power enough to keep any heart, but uch a one as is compos'd of feathers, and has wings to flie away; yet, this light Butterflie will give you the lip. Phillis, replied I, you talk of ome perfections that hould be in me, but certainly they are much inferiour unto yours, ince they are not able to hold Celadon from you. Celadon had now a little recollected himelf, and kneeling down, he aid unto me, It is not, my Atrea, to undervalue the merits of Phillis, that I make thee mot olemn vowes before all the mot acred gods, but to convince you, that he did never kindle the leat park of love in my oul; and the wrong you have done me in changing, is not greater, then your taxing my pure affection with incontancy. The tory would be too tedious (age Diana) hould I trouble you with every particular of our dicoure: But o it was, that before we parted, we were all o well etled in our enes again, that all of us did acknowledge, that we had no reaon to upect one another, and gave thanks unto heaven, for this happy meeting all together, without which, I believe, the roots of jealouie had never been eradicated. As for my part, I think
it was impoible ever to have brought me to reaon, had I not heard Celadon declare himelfe o Ingenuouly before the face of Phillis.

After this, we were more dicret: but I no ooner got rid of this ditemper, then I entred into another no lee daingerous: for we could not o well diguie the buinee; but Alcippes had a jealouie that the parkes of his Sons affection were not quit extinguihed, and had uch a curious eye over all his actions, as oberving how Celadon went every day to the place where we were wont to lay our Letters, he himelfe went thither, and oberving how the grae was troden by our often going thither, a kind of tract did lead him to the very place where I had put a Letter for Celadon the night before: it contained thee words.

body.head: Atreas Letter unto Celadon.
body.p: YEterday we all went into the Temple, where every one aembled to offer Sacrifice unto Pan, I would have aid, to have kept a holy day, had you been there. But uch is my devotion to you, that even divine things themelves without, you are dipleaing to me. I am now o full of common buinee, as were it not for the promie I have made to write every day unto you, you hould hardly have heard from me. Receive therefore this only as a tetimony that I will for ever keep all my promies to you.

div.p: When Alcippes had read this Letter, he put it into the place again and hiding himelfe in hopes, that it would be fetched away, his Son came preently after, and having no paper about him, he writ thus upon the back of my Letter.

p.hi: YOu oblige and dioblige both at once, but pardon me if this expreion offend you: I am not more obliged unto the gods then unto you becaue you ay you Love me, but by aying you would not have written, unlee becaue you had promied; this doth infinitly dioblige me; for o I become a debtor only to your promie, and not to your affection: Conider I beeech you, that I am not yours becaue I have promied: but becaue I am purely yours, without any other circumtance nor do I wih for any Letters from you which come only upon the conditions which are betwixt us, but only uch as proceed from your good affection: I value them not as matters of Covenant and Marchandie, but as tetimonies of a pure affection.

div.p:
