Alcippes yet knew not who the hepherdee was, unto whom this Letter was intended, for it named none: but ee what a pirit of contradiction will do; he waited at the leat ix or eaven houres longer in expectation of her, who was to fetch this Letter, auring himelfe that it would be before night. It was very late before I came thither: as oon as he epied me, for feare I hould not take the Letter, he lay him down as if he were a leep; and I to avoid all upition, turned back and took another way: He, well atisfied with his paines, as oon as I was gone, did take the Letter and went home, from whence he intended to end his on immediatly: becaue he would not upon any tearms, there hould be any alliance betwixt us; by reaon of the deadly emnity that had been betwixt Alces and him; but on the contrary intended to marry him unto Malthea the Daughter of Forelle; To whoe houe he ent him During this eperation, Olimpia, daughter unto the Shepheard Lupeander, dwelling upon the confines of Forret, towards the River of Furan, came with her Mother unto our Town. This good old woman, did Love Amarillis very well, being brought up together from the cradle, and therefore came to viit her. This young hepheardee was not o fair as affected, and entertained o good a conceit of her elf, as he thought that all the hepheards which ever looked upon her were in Love with her. And therefore, as oon as he came into the houe of Alcippe, he began to buie her elfe with Lycidas, having an opinion, that the cruelties which he had ued towards her proceeded from Love: which as oone as Lycidas perceived, he came to ask our advice, how he hould behave himelf: And we counelled him to cherih this conceit in Olimpia, to the end he might the better umbrage his affection unto Phillis. And a little after, as ill luck was, it happned, that Artemis had ome buinee cloe by the River Allier, and, do what we could, he carried Phillis with her.
During this eparation which was ixe or eaven Monthes, the Mother of Olimpia returned and left her Daughter with Amarillis, in hopes that Lycidas would Marry her, becaue for ought he could ee, he loved her very well. And being an advantageous March for her, the Mother advied her, to trim her elfe up in as amarous a dree as poibly he could: and I aure you, Fair Diana, he did trick up her elfe accordingly, and did court more then he was courted, by much. One day, when he was gone into the woods to eeke a trayed heep, he met with her beloved hepheard: and after ome common dicoure, he laid her armes in a loving poture upon his houlders, and after he had kied him, thus aid Dear hepheard, what dipleaing qualities are in me, that I hould never find the leat demontration of favour from you? The reaon is, anwered he and miled becaue my favour is not worth the having: Should thoe words proceed from any but your elfe, aid he, I would ay the peaker either wanted judgment or was blind. But dear hepherd how mut I Love you, before I obtaine the blie of being loved againe? How many dayes mut I pend in courting you, before I find a returne? I beleeve thoe hepheardees who have the happinee of your addrees, are not more amiable then my elfe, nor have any advantages above me, unlee in the enjoyment of your favour. Olimpia uttered thee words with o much zealous paion, that Lycidas was tartled: and, Fair Diana, as oft as I think upon this paage I cannot chue but laugh, unlee my ad diater forbid it. But however, Phillis had commanded him to counterfeit Love of this Olimpia, who thinking his favours to be in good earnet, became ever ince his corne; and having made o much ue of her as erved his own turn, he fell to uch a didaining of her, as that he could not endure to come nigh her. But afterwards he came unto me with o many ignes of dicontent, as I was perwaded that he did repent of his foolery: but preently after, Olimpia proved to have a bigge bellie, and when he began to perceive it, Phillis returned from her Journey: and as I expected her with much impatience, o I received her with abundance of joy. But as it is ordinary for one to enquire of that which lyeth nearet the heart, o Phillis after the firt Salute, asked me how Lycidas did, and how he had behaved himelfe towards Olimpia? Very well, anwered I, and I am ure it will not be long before he make his appearance. I did cut off this dicoure as oon as I could, let I hould ay omthing which might prejudice Lycidas, who for his part was not in a little perplexitie, not knowing how to accot his hepheardee: but at lat, reolving to endure any torment rather then a banihment from her preence, he came unto her lodging, where he knew to find me. And when Phillis aw him, he runnes with open armes to alute him. But he retreating, thus aid unto her, Fair Phillis, I have not o much boldnee as to come neer you, unlee you will firt pardon a fault which I have committed. The hepheardee, thinking he meant his comming no ooner, thus anwered; There's nothing hall debarre me from the Salute of Lycidas, and though his crimes were more then they are, yet I would pardon them all. Upon this word, he went unto him and aluted him with abundance of affection. But her joyes were a little quelled, when he addreed himelfe unto me, and deired me to accquaint his Mitrie with his fault, that he might know unto what punihment he would condenme him: Not, aid he, but that my orrowes for offending her hall accompany me to my grave, but becaue I would know my entence. This word made colour come into the face of Phillis beleeving now, that the matter was of more moment then he expected. Of which Lycidas taking notice, Ah, fair one, aid he, I have not courage enough to hear your condemnation. But pardon, fair Mitris, if I leave you; if my life dipleae you, & my death will atisfie for my crime, then let me live no longer. At this word he went away, and though Phillis called him back, yet he would not returne, but pulled to the dore after him, and left us two alone. You may imagine it was not long before Phillis enquired what the matter was, & why he was in uch a perplexity and without any long prologue, I acquainted her, laying all the fault on our elves, who were o much unadvied as not to foreee that it was a piece of difficulty for uch a young man to reit uch a temptation, alo hinting unto her that the in was not of o horrid a degree, as to be impardonable. At the firt I could not mollifie her implacabilitie; nor obtaine the pardon which I deired: but a few dayes after, Lycidas by my advice came, and threw himelfe at her feet; and becaue he would not look upon him, he ran into another chamber, and out of that into another, till flying from Lycidas who till followed her, and was reolved never to leave her, untill he had obtained either his pardon or his death. At lat, when she could go no further, he tayed in her cloet, where Lycidas entring and hutting the dores after him, he fell down at her feet peaking not one word, but expecting her entence. But the importunity of this affectionate begger was more
prevalent, then all my perwaions: For, after he had a long time been there, and not a yllable proceeded from either of them, at lat he aid thus, Go, go, troubleome man, it is thy importunity and not thy elfe, that has obtained a pardon. Upon this bleed word he did rie, and kis'd her hand, then came and opened the dore, to hew me that he had got the victory; then was he in as good a condition as ever, and his Shepheardee did o fully pardon him, as eeing him much troubled to conceal the big belly of Olympia, who now did well o, as it was viible to the eye, he her elf went to viit and ait her all that poibly he could. This indeed (aid Diana, and interrupted) is a mot trange tetimony of affection; this, Phillis, was too much; and I mut confee my courage could never have brooked it. By this you may judge at the height of my affection, aid Phillis. It was rather a fault, aid Diana, then uperabundance of Love, to pardon o eaily an injury done againt the Lawes of Love. Oh Diana, aid Phillis, you know better how to make others love you, then how to love. If o, aid Diana, I am more obliged unto Heaven for it, then for my life. But however, am I not able to judge of love, unlee I love my elfe? No, aid Phillis, you cannot be a competent judge; for otherwie you will be of too hard a temper, and cannot pardon as love requires: For Love, if it be rightly in tune, reembles Muick coniting of everall parts, which, if all be well tuned, makes a melodious harmony; but, if one part dicord, then all is harh: So, cruell Diana, perhaps you will ay, that after one hath gon through a long and pleaing ervice, the firt offence will poile all the former ervices. 'Tis very true (aid Diana). Oh heavens! (cryed out Phillis) what a hard task hath he who loves you? He who loves me, replyed Diana, mut take heed he never offends me in matter of affection; and believe me, Phillis, you have done Lycidas more injury than he hath done you. Then aid Phillis, and laughed, heretofore I aid, that it was love that prompted me unto this act, but hereafter I will ay, it was revenge; and to uch as are the mot curious, I will ay, it was for uch a reaon as I learned of you. They will judge, added Diana, that heretofore you did love; and now, that you know what it is to love. However, anwered Phillis, if it be a fault, it proceeds from ignorance, and not from any defect in Love, for I think my elfe obliged unto it; but you that have been o long mute, I pray tell us, how I aited to bring this child into the world. Then Atrea replied thus:

Aoon as this Shepheardee declared her elfe, Lycidas did very confidently accept of her offer, and ent a young Shepheard unto Moin, to bring a Midwife from thence, with her eyes blinded, that he might not know whither he went. Diana then, as being atonihed, did put her finger to her mouth, and aid, Shepheardee, this is not uch a ecret as you imagine, for I remember I have heard of it. I beeech you, aid Phillis, tell us how you heard it, that we may ee how reports do jump. I cannot tell, added Diana, whether or no I do well remember it: the poor Philander was the relator, and aured me, that he had it from Lucina a Midwife. One day as he was walking in the Park, betwixt mount Brion and Moin, with everall of her companions, a young man came unto her, whom he knew not, and at firt brought ome commendations to her from ome of her friends who were at Feurs, and afterwards told her ome particulars, purpoely to draw her from the ret of her company, and when he had her alone, he told her, that a better occaion brought him thither, and it was, that for all pitties ake he would go and help an honet woman, who, without her aid, was in very great danger. The good woman was a little urpried at this, but the young man conjured her to conceale her wonder, for he would rather chue a death, then this buinee hould ever be upected. Lucina being now a little better aured, and promiing he would be ecret, he asked him the time when he hould be ready. Prepare your elfe, aid the young man, for a voyage of two months; and to the end you may be no loer by the bargain, here is as much mony as you can get any where ele in that time. Then he gave her ome pieces of gold in a paper, and asked her if he would go in the night: And the woman finding her wages to be very good, did anwer him, that he would go at what time he pleaed. About fifteen or ixteen daies after, as he was comming out of Moin, about five or ix of the clock in the evening, he aw him return, with his face quite altered: and coming to her, he aid, Mother, the time is come, we mut depart, the hores are ready, and neceitie requires hate: She would have gone into her houe to have taken order about ome buinee, but he would not let her, let he hould tell any: So going into a little private bottom, cloe by the way ide, he aw two hores, and a handome man in black cloths, who kept them: Aoon as this man aw Lucina, he came to meet her with a
miling face, and after many thanks, he et her on horeback behinde him who fetched her; then getting upon another hore, they et forward through the fields a good pace; and when they were got a little off the Towne, and night grew dark, this young man pulled a handkercher out of his pocket, and do what Lucina could, he blindfolded her: Then afterwards turning the hore halfe a core times round, to the end he hould not know which way they took, they travelled a good part of the night, he not knowing which way they carried her, unlee as he thought over a River two or three times; then cauing her to alight he walked a while on foot, and as he could guee, through a Wood, where he got a glimpe of light through the handkerchieffe, which preently after they untied, and then he found her elfe in a very fine Tent, hung with Tapetry, and made o cloe, as no winde could come in; on the one ide he aw a handome young woman lying in a little field bed groaning and crying out very loud, but masked; at the beds feet he aw another woman masked alo, who by her habit eemed to be well in years, and held up her hands, with tears in her eyes; on the other ide he aw a young Chamber maid masked, holding a candle in her hand: At this Tent dore, tood the man who held the hores, grieving much for the pain this woman was in; and the other man, behind whom he rid, did fetch all things that was neceary. You may eaily imagine how much Lucina was amazed at all this; for it is to be thought, that this young woman thus in pain was in Labour, and it was not long before he was delivered of a Daughter; o as he being well brought to bed, and the Child put into a Cradle, Lucina's eyes were again blinded, and after a full reward for her pains, he was carried the ame way he came: And all this I received from Philander. Atrea and Phillis harkened unto this tale very attentively, and Phillis could not chue but laugh, which Diana eeing, asked her the reaon: It is, aid he, becaue you have told us a tory which we are altogether ignorant of; and for my part, I cannot imagine who this hould be, for it cannot be Olympia, but mut of neceitie be ome other Shepheardee. Truly, anwered Diana, then I was mitaken; I took that handom man who held the hores for Lycidas; that old woman, for the Mother of Celadon; and the Chambermaid for you; and imagined that you were all masked, becaue you would pae unknown. I aure you (aid Atrea) it was not Olympia; for Phillis ued no other artifice, but only to get Lucina unto her houe, for, as fortune was, Artemis was then from home: And becaue Olympia was with Amarillis, he was to faigne her elfe ick, which, as the cae was with her, he might eaily do, and deire ome change of aire; o he was to come unto Phillis, who would be glad of her company: Amarillis yielded to the deire, and o Phillis came to fetch here And when her time drew neer, Lycidas got the Midwife and blinded her eyes, that he might be ignorant which way he went; but when he was come to the houe, her eyes was then at liberty; nor was Olympia or any masked, imagining that the Midwife could not know any of their faces. This was all the artifice that was ued; and when Olympia was well again, he returned home: Alo we have been told ince, that he ued a very fine device, for the bringing up of the child: She hired a woman to ay that it was hers, and then to lay it to the charge of a young fellow who erved her Mother; and becaue the fellow was altogether innocent, he denyed it; but was o ahamed, that he ran away: The woman purued even unto Lupeander's Chamber, and there, though the fellow till refued it, he et the child down in the midt of the room, and ran her waies. They ay, that Lupeander was very angry, and Olympia alo at this fellow. But, the concluion was, Olympia turning towards her Mother, However, aid he unto her, this child mut not be lot, it mut not be punihed for the fault of another; but it will be an act of charity to ee it brought up: Her Mother, who was of a good and charitable dipoition, conented unto it. And thus Olympia got her Daughter to be in the houe with her.

All this while Celadon was with Forella, and entertained with all poible welcomes; and Malthea, at her Fathers command, did currae him as much as he in civilitie, could. But Celadon was o dipleaed at this eparation from us; that all thee weets yielded him but a bitter relih; and he lived in uch a drooping way, as Forella being very angry, that his Daughter hould be o lighted did acquaint Alcippe with it, to the end he hould not expect any further progree in that match: who knowing the reolution of his on, and, as I think, moved unto ome pitty, he reolved once more to ue ome other artifice; and after that, never to trouble him any more. Then, whilt Celadon was with Malthea, Phocion my Uncle, o contrived it, that Corebes, a very rich and honet Shepheard, hould apply himelfe unto me: And ince he had all the good qualities that were deirable, it was already o divulged, as if the Wedding were reolved upon. Alcippes thinking to make
ue of this advantage, devied this trick, which I hall relate. There was a Shepheard called Squilinder, dwelling upon the borders of the Forret, in a Town called Argentall, a craftie fellow, and very perfidious, who, amongt the ret of his knavih qualities, had this, that he could counterfeit any hand o exactly, as the writer of the Originall could not know it from his Copy. To this man Alcippe's hewed that Letter of mine which he found, as I told you before, and writ another unto Celadon in my name, which was thus indited.

body.head: Atrea's counterfeit Letter unto Celadon.
body.p: SInce I am forced to it by the command of a Father, you mut not think it trange, if I intreat you to put a period unto that love, which heretofore I conjured you to make eternall. Alces hath betowed me upon Corebes: The match will be very advantageous to me, if I can but quickly enough forget you. But ince it is meer folly to attempt againt what mut be, I advie you o to forget all paages betwixt us, and to arme your elfe with uch reolution, as Celadon may blot Atrea out of his memorie, as Atrea, out of her duty to a Father, mut quit the remembrance of Celadon.

div.p: This Letter was cunningly conveyed unto Celadon by an unknown meenger. Oh! how his heart was unk, when he received this ad newes: Now Atrea, (did he ay) I ee there is nothing in this world that is durable, ince all thoe vowed reolutions betwixt us are o oon vanihed. Now I am a ad witnee, that all women, be they never o full of perfections, can eaily return to their naturall incontancy. Now, life end, ince Atrea has lot her affection, and ince I can do nothing ele, but grieve for my great diater. Thus did he breathe out abundance of ad complaints, and he was the ooner perwaded to believe uch a change in me might be, by the common reports of my marriage unto Corebes. He lay all the day upon his bed, and when night came, he tole out of all company, and got into a thick unfrequented wood, hunning all ociety like a alvage, and reolved never to come into any company again.

In this deperate reolution, he wandered over all the Mountains of Forrets, and at lat found out a deart unfrequented place, where he intended to finih the remainder of his dimall daies. The place was called Lapan, from whence the fatall Lignon hath his Originall: Upon the banks of this Spring, he built himelfe a little Cabin, where he made a hift to live above ix Months; during which time, his ordinary food was tears and ighs: And his olitude had continued longer, had not Alcippes commanded Lycidas to go and look him out, reolving (ince all was in vain) never to croe his affection more: But Lycidas had look'd long enough before he had found him, but for one accident which happened that day.

I chanced to be then by the banks of Lignon, looking upon the water, and condoling the loe of Celadon; Phillis and Lycidas looked alo in the water as well as I, and we oberved omthing which wimmed down the tream; Lycidas, to atisfie the curioity of his Mitree, who much deired to know what it was, did tep into the River, and with a bough brought it out; and finding it to be only a piece of paper, he threw it away upon the ground, being angry he had taken o much pains for a thing of no more value: Phillis, he took it up, and opening it, we read thee words:

p.hi: Go thou poor piece of paper, more happy than he that ends thee; go and view thoe banks where my Shepheardee ueth to walk: and if, being accompanied with thoe tears wherewith I well this River, thou halt chance to kie the hore where the prints of her feet are, tay there where my mierable fate will not uffer me to be: If it be thy chance to come into thoe hands, which have rob'd me of my heart, and he hall ask thee what I do, tell her, faithfull paper, that I am night and day wahing away her infidelity with my tears; and if thou dot move her to o much repentance, as to drop a tear upon thee, tell her of the in he hath committed againt her own faith and my affection; and that my orrowes are witnees both before men and gods, that he is both the fairet and the mot perfidious woman upon earth; and alo, that I am the mot faithfull, and the mot affectionate adorer of her that ever lived, with this aurance, that I hall never enjoy any contentment, but in death.

div.p:
We no ooner cat our eyes upon the writing, but we knew it to be the hand of Celadon:
this was the caue of Lycidas his gazing up the water to look for him: and he ued uch diligence that in two or three dayes he found him out in his olitary habitation, o much unlike what he was, that he was not knowable: But when Lycidas told him that he mut come to me, and that I did o command it; he could hardly be perwaded but that his Brother would deceive him. At lat, the Letter which he gave him from me did o revive him that in a few dayes he cheered up his countenance, and came unto us, yet not o oon but Alcippes: dyed before his return, and Amarillis followed him, a few dayes after. Then had we ome hopes that fortune had hot her wort arrowes againt us, ince they two who did mot croe our deignes were dead, but it did not o happen: for the buinee of Corebes o continued, that Alces, Hippolita and Phocion did much trouble my tranquillity; and yet our miery did not proceed from them, though Corebes was partly the caue of it: for when he came to make his addrees to me, being very rich, he brought many hepheards with him, amongt which was Semires; a hepheard truly of many excellent qualities, but the mot fale and cunning man that ever lived: as oon as ever he aw me, his deigne was to erve me, not valuing the friendhip twixt Corebes and him and ince Celadon and I had agreed to diemble it, the better to colour our loves, he to eeme as if he loved all hepheardees, and I to admit patiently of all addrees to me, he preently did think that my good reception of him did proceed from ome good affection to him. But he had not o oon knowne of the affection betwixt Celodon and me, had he not by ill luck found ome of my Letters: Now though all knew that he loved me, yet few beleeved that I loved him, o coldly did I carry my elfe towards him: and becaue Alcippes had found our Letters which had cot us o dear, we would not trut them that way any longer but invented another trick which we thought more afe. Celadon was wont to have a hole in the lining of his hat, in which he ued to put uch Letters as he writ unto me, then he would throw it at me in a jeting manner, or ele leave it by me, that I might take it out, and returne mine the ame way back againe: I know not how, but one day as ill luck was, I let fall one of my Letters, and Semires took it up; which when he read, he found thee lines.

body.head: Atreas Letter unto Celadon.
body.p: I Have received your Letter with as much joy, as I know you did mine; & there is not a yllable in it, but is a full atisfaction to me, unlee your thanks: they are neither becomming my affection, nor Celadon, who long ince gave me all he had: Thee thankes you give, are either yours or not yours: if they be not yours, then nothing that was this title, can be acceptable to me; if they be yours, why do you give me that which you gave me before? Celadon, I beeech you ue no more any of thee complements, unlee you will have me think you to be fuller of Civility then Love.

div.p:
After he had found this Letter, his thoughts were not o much of Love as how to make Celadon and me at odds, and he began thus. In the firt place, he beeeched me to pardon him for being o bold, as to lift up his eyes o high, as upon me, whoe beauty had contrained him unto it: & that he was o concious of his own mal merits, that he would never trouble me any more, only beeeched me to forget his rah attempt: afterwards he did o much court the friendhip and familiarity of Celadon, as if he had loved him above all the men in the world: And the more to blind me lie never met me, but took an occaion to peak very advantageouly of my hepheard, covering his intentions with uch a ubtile cloak, that none could imagine he had a deigne it it; his commends of the peron whom I loved, did, as I aid before, o deceive me that I took great delight in talking with him: & thus two or three Monthes paed very happily both for Celadon and me. But I think it was to make me the more: enible of of my enuing miery, which I hall never remember but with warry eyes: here he topped and in lieu of words, did by her tears repreent her orrowes unto the company, that neither he nor they durt open their mouthes fearing to augment her teares: for the more one thinkes to top the current of teares by reaon, the more they will flow. At lat he began to purue her former dicoure: Alas, wie Diana, aid he, I cannot remember this fatall diater without a tribute of ad teares, Semires now had gotten uch familiarity both with Celadon and me, as we were eldome aunder. And when he thought he had ufficiently ininuated himelfe into credence, and thought he could perwade me to what he would, one day after we had long talked of everall infidelities, which hepheards
ued towards hepherdees whom they faigned to Love. I wonder aid he, that o few hepherdees hould take warning by o many examples, though otherwie they are very dicreet and wie. The reaon is, anwered I, becaue Love hath blinded their eyes: 'Faith I think o, replied he, for otherwie it is impoible but you hould ee omthing which concernes your elf. Then holding his peace, and eeming as if he could ay more, but repented of what he had aid, Semires, Semires, (aid he, turning his back) what dot thou do? Dot thou not ee that he will be dipleaed at the knowledge of it? Why wilt thou then torment her? And then addreing himelf unto me, he went on: I ee, fair Atrea, that my talk had like to have dipleaed you, but pardon me I beeech you, ince it was only my zeal to your ervice, that I aid o much: Semires, aid I unto him, I am much obliged to you for your good will to me, and hould be much more if you would finih that dicoure which you begun: Oh hepheardee, (anwered he) I doubt I have aid too much already, but perhaps time will tell you more, and then you will know Semires to be your faithfull ervant. Oh deceitfull man, how good did he make his wicked promies unto me? For ince that I have known but too much, to know it with any deire of living: at that time he would tell me no more, purpoely to whet my deire of knowing it: but when he thought that my deire was now eager enough, & after I had very importunately urged him to tell it, he anwered me thus. Fair hepheardee, you eem to be o very deirous, that I hould think it a fault in me if I did diobey you: but truly, I am much afraid it will more dipleae you. Then after I had aured him there was nothing could much dipleae her, he knew o well how to perwade me that Celadon loved Aminthea Daughter unto the Sonne of Cleanthes, that jealouy, the uuall companion of all Soules who Love truly, began to make me think this might be true, forgetting the command which I had impoed uppon him, to faine all love unto all hepheardees. However, to diguie my dipleaure, I anwered Semires that I never did nor would beleeve, Celadon did more particularly apply himelf unto me then unto others; and that the familiarity which was between them, was only the conequent of a long acquaintance: but as for any matters of love, and addrees of that nature, that they were altogether indifferent unto me. Then this ubtile man anwered me thus, I thank the gods that your humour is uch; and ince it is o, you will take ome delight in hearing ome of thoe paionate expreions, which he betowed upon his deare Aminthea. I mut confee, wie Diana, when I heard Aminthea called, his, I changed colour: and becaue he offered to relate their dicoure, I eemed willing to heare more of the infidelity of Celadon, though alas more faithfull, then I was well advied. So I accepted of his offer, and indeed he made good his promies. For a little after, he came running unto me, and told me, he had left them together not farre off and that Celadon's head did lie in Amintheas lap, and he holding his head; relating thee particulars purpoely to nettle me the more. Then I followed him, though I neither knew which way I went, nor what I did, until we came very neere, though they neither heard nor aw us. I have ince thought, that it was becaue they cared not who either aw or heard them; but o it was, that I heard Celadon anwer her, Beleeve me, fair hepheardee, never did beautie make a deeper impreion in any oul, then it hath in mine: but Celadon anwered Aminthea, It is not poible a heart o young as yours, hould long retaine that impreion which love hath made in it. Incredulous hepheardee, (replyed my Celadon) let us leave off thee reaons; do not meaure me by the yard or weights of another: but bles me with your favour, and you hall ee whether or no my young heart can preerve them as long as it lives: Celadon, Celadon, replyed Aminthea, you would be but deervedly punihed, if your diimulations hould become truthes, and if heaven in my revenge hould make you love Aminthea in earnet, whom now I know you do but jeat with. Hitherto, all was well enough: but Oh heavens what a trange anwer of diimulation did he returne? Fair hepheardee, anwered he, if I do mock or jeat with you, may Love turne all my mockery upon my elf, & if I have merited it that he would punih me with your menaces. Aminthea, not being able to reach the intention of his dicoure did anwer him only with a igh and in uch a manner, as I in my language did interpret, that he would not have rejected him, if he could have credited his language. But that which mot perplexed me, was, that after Celadon had been a while ilent, he fetched a deep igh which preently he anwered with another: and when he did rie up to peak unto her he covered her eyes with her hand & bluht, as being ahamed that this igh had ecaped her: and after a little pauing ilence, Aminthea aid thus unto him. Come Celadon, are you o oone weary of my company? I rather feare (aid he) that I hall weary her, whom I extreamly deire to pleae and therefore ince you command it, I will tay. I dare not ue
commands (replied the Shepheardee) where intreaties perhaps will be too indicreet. Ue what termes you pleae, replied the Shepheard, but I am much your ervant. So he et himelfe down, and began thus.

lg.head: A Madrigall Upon a reemblance 'twixt his Lady and him.
lg.l: WEll may one ay, that our two hearts
Are like a Rock that never tarts:
A Rock in Contancy isimine,
A Rock inenible is thine.

div.p: Fair Diana, I was not able to tay any longer in this place, but tealing gently away, I returned to my flock, o ad, as all that day I could not utter one word, and paed away the night with a thouand ad conceits, and cryed as long as I had any tears. I do admire I hould be o blinded; for had I retained the leat park of judgment, I hould have remembered, that it was my command he hould faigne love: But the next morning when he came unto me, I gave him uch harh entertainment, as made him deperate, and caued him to throw himelfe into that gulph, where he and all my joyes were drowned together.
At this word he looked as pale as death, and had not Phillis revived her, taking her into her armes, he had wouned.

The noie which they made at Atrea's wouning was o great, that Leonida waked, and hearing ome talk o neer her, her curioity invited her to know who they were. And becaue thee three Shepheardees were rien up to go away, all he could do was to wake Silvia, to hew them unto her. Aoon as he aw them, he knew Atrea, though the diater of Celadon had much altered her. Leonida asked her, who were the other two? The one of them, aid he, who is on the left hand, is Phillis, her deer companion; and the other is Diana, daughter to the age Relinda and Celion: I am very orry we have lept o long, for I am confident we hould have received ome newes from them; for it is likely they came into this place o far from company, purpoely to talk with more freedome. I mut ingenuouly confee (aid Leonida) that I never in all my life aw any fairer then Atrea, he has the advantage of all others. Conider then, aid Silvia, what hopes Galathea has to divert the affection of this Shepheard from her. This conideration did touch Leonida o to the quick, that he did reent it more for her own caue than Galathea's: However, Love, which never leaves a Lover without ome weet hopes, would not treat this Nymph wore then others; and therefore, though with mall probability, yet, he promied her elfe thus much hope, that, perhaps abence from Atrea, together with her own kindnee, mightwork an alteration in him. Then, after ome other uch dicoure, thee two Nymphs parted, Leonida towards Feurs, and Silvia towards Ioures, whilt the three Shepheardees retired to their Cabins.

No ooner had they et foot in the great meadow, where of late they ued to meet, but they epied Lycidas talking with Silvander; yet, aoon as ever this Shepheard aw Atrea, he grew o pale and altered, that leat Silvander hould take notice of it, he broke from him with a hollow excue; but triving to avoid meeting with them, Phillis with Diana croed the way to overtake him, and when he came at him, he aid unto him, If you thus flie your friends, Lycidas, what would you do to your enemies? The company you keep o much, Phillis, anwered he, does not deerve the title of friend. She whom you o much complain of (anwered Phillis) does endure more torment for her offending of you, then you your elfe doth. There is no way to cure the wound (anwered the Shepheard) but by breaking the weapon which gave it. By this time Atrea was come up, who addreed her elfe unto Lycidas, and aid unto him, I am o far, Lycidas, from thinking your hatred of me unjut, as I mut confee, you cannot hate me o much as you have caue for; yet, if the memory of him, who caueth me to give you this ad atisfaction, be yet as freh in your minde, as it is, and ever hall be, in mine, you will alo remember, that I was he whom he loved above all the world. Lycidas would have anwered, and perhaps, according to his paion, very harply; but Diana topped his mouth with her hand, and aid, Lycidas, Lycidas, if you do not accept of this atisfaction, both I, and all the world, will ay, you are unreaonable. Atrea, not initing upon what Diana aid, and taking away her hand from before his mouth, he aid, No, no, wie Shepheardee, do not contrain Lycidas, let him ue all the harh language he pleath, I know they are
effects of a mot jut orrow; yet, I know withall, that his loe is not greater then mine. Lycidas hearing thee words, and not being able to command himelfe, he went away: Phillis followed, and knew o well how to repreent the griefe of Atrea, and the villany of Semires, that at lat he reconciled him to the Company.

But though Leonida made all the hate he could; yet, becaue he lept o long, he could get no further then Ponins; her Hot being a very honet man, lodged her in the bet lodging he had: In the next room unto hers, were lodged two other trangers, there being only a thin partition betwixt their two Chambers; o as Leonida could hear all that they aid, and hearkening at the partition, he heard one of them ay unto the other, What hould I ay more unto you, only, that Love has made you thus impatient. Leonida thought he hould know the voice, but he could not well remember it, untill the other pake, aying, But that, Climanthes, is not it which troubles me; for, the attempt hall never o much dimay me, but I will till hope for a good iue of our Enterprie. That which I mot fear, and which makes me fit upon uch thornes, as you ee me, is, that you have not made her well undertand what we have determined to do, or ele, that he does not give any credit unto your words. Leonida hearing this dicoure, and knowing very well who it was which poke, being both amuzed, and deirous to know more, he etled her elfe o neer the partition, that he lot not a word of what was poken: And then he heard Climanthes ay, I have oft told you, that the buinee is impoible. Yes, aid the other, only in your judgment. Truly, anwered Climanthes, to make you confee it, and to eae you of your pain, I will once more make you a repetition of the whole buinee. Then he began thus.

div.head: The Hitory of the Falities of Climanthes.
div.p:
AFter we were all parted, and you had by your dicoure made me acquainted with Galathea, Silvia, Leonida, and all the Nymphs of Amais, as afterwards you did by a ight of them, I conceived, that the next principall thing which might further our deigne, was, to know how Lindamor was habited the day of his departure: For, you know, that Clidaman and Guyamant being gone into Merovea, Amais commanded Lindamor to follow him, with all the brave Cavaliers of this Country, to the end that Clidaman might appear in more lutre. And it eemed, as ill luck was, that Lindamor intended to change the Livery of his ervants; but o it was, that I having an obervant eye of every thing, one night as he was in the treet, I heard him command one of his men to go unto his Taylor, and fetch the Coat that he had made againt the day of Rendevonz, that he might try how it fitted him: And ince he had charged the Taylor to let none ee it, he gave this ervant a Ring as a token, that he came from his Mater: I followed the ervant o cloe, that I knew the lodging and the name of the Taylor: The next morning betimes I went unto him, and told him that I came from Lindamor, to ee in what forwardnee his clothes were: for Amais was o preing to have him go, and his fears of his cloths not being finihed in time, made me come to bring him the certain truth, for he would not trut him; he would have given his Ring for a token (aid I) but he told me, this would be ufficient that I tell you, he ent lat night for the Coat, and he who came for it, brought it again. Thus I deceived the Taylor, and took notice of his cloths as well as poibly I could. Then I eeming to haten him with his work, he told me, that he had time enough; for, he had een a Letter which Amais did write unto the Maior of the Town, commanding him to ummon all the gallantry of the Town againt uch a day, on which Lindamor, and uch as went with him, were to depart. By this means I came to know the day of Lindamor's departure; and moreover, then you were in this country, which was an accident that fell out very happily for the furthering our deigne, which you had already been advertied of. In order to this, I retired my elfe into the great wood of Savignieu, neer a little River which •• ns through it; there I erected a little Hut of boughes, o cloe, that many paed by never epying me; and this I did, that it might be believed I had long dwelt there; for you know, that none in this Country knew me. And to make it eem I had long inhabited there, the leaves and boughes which covered my Cabin were all withered. I decked up a Table with a Looking-glae upon it, etround with Ivy, Miletoe, and Holline, and trewed my room with Ruhes, Vervin and uch like: I et my Lookingglae in the mot dark part of the room, to the end my Art might not be o oon dicovered; and oppoite to this mirrour, I placed my painted Paper, wherein I had o exactly
drawn the place which I intended to hew Galathea, as none could ditinguih between the Originall and the Copy. Above this glae did hang a plank, upon which an ugly grim viage was painted, and hanged by a mall thred, which, with the obcurity of the place, could not be dicerned; at the bottom of this plank was fixed a teel, which, when the plank fell, the teel did hit againt a piece of flint, purpoely o et, as it never failed of fire; about which place I had et a compoure of Sulphure, and Salt-peeter, which, when fire did fall into it, did break into trange kinde of flames, in uch a trange manner, and with uch celeritie as might well caue wonder. All this I invented, that it might be thought either ome Divinity, or ele ome Witchcraft. After all things were thus ordered, I did ometimes expoe my elfe to ight, but very eldome; and aoon as I perceived any aw me, I preently retreated into my Cell, where I made a how, as if I lived only upon roots herbs, and air, though in the night I changed habit, and provided all things neceary. Within a few daies many took notice of me, and my fame was o great, that it reached the ears of Amais, who ued often to come and walk in the Gardens of Mount-Brion. Upon a time, Sildres, Silvia, Leonida, and everall others of their company, did walk along the banks of my little River, where then I eemed, as if I were gathering ome herbs: aoon as I perceived they aw me, I ran hatily into my Cabin; they being full of curioity to ee me, and to talk with me, did come after me through the wood: I, by that time had got upon my knees, and when I aw them look through my dore, I went towards it, where the firt that met me was Leonida; and becaue he had thrut open the dore, and was ready to enter, I harply reprehended her, aying, Leonida, the Deities whom I adore, does command you not to prophane their Altar. Upon thee words he was a little urprized, and retreated for, my habit of a Druide got me reverence, and my naming (Deitle) did trike with terror: But, aften a little recollection of her elfe, he aid thus unto me, The Altars of your Deities be they whom they will, cannot be profaned, by receiving my devotion, which came hither only to render that honour which the heavens demands of us. The heavens indeed (anwered I) doth expect both devotion and honour, but not different from uch as they ordain. If any zeal to the divinity whom I adore, has brought you hither, then you mut oberve what he commands. What is her commandements (aid Silvia)? Silvia, (aid I unto her) if you come with the ame devotion that your companion doth, then do as I hall bid you, and your devotion will be acceptable unto my deitie. Before the Moon does enter into her decreae, wah your right thigh as low as your knee, and your right arm as low as your elbow, before day, in this River, which runs before this acred Cave; and afterwards come hither with a Chaplet of Vervine upon your head, and a Girdle of Fern about your middle; then hall I declare unto you the myteries of this holy place. Then taking her by the hand, I aid thus unto her, Would you have me (for a tetimony of that favour, which the deities are pleaed to confer upon me) tell you ome paages of your life pat, and ome that are to come? No, not I (aid he) for I am not o full of curioity: but you my Companion (aid he, and turned towards Leonida) I have known you heretofore full of uch curioity. And o I am till (aid Leonida, and preented her hand unto me). Then calling to memorie what you told me concerning thee Nymphs in particular, I took her hand, and asked her, whether he was born in the night, or in the day time; and undertanding that it was in the night, I took her left hand, and after a conidering paue, I aid unto her, Leonida, This Line of Life being handome, well marked, and long, does demontrate, that you mut live long, and free from any corporeall maladies; but this little Croe upon the ame Line, almot at the top of the Angle, does portend ome maladies of Love, which will hinder you from being o ound in minde as in body: and thee five or ix little Points, which are owed like little grainee here and there, upon the ame Line, do ignifie, that you will never hate them that love you, and will much delight in being courted. Then look upon the other Line, which takes its root from that which we poke of before, which paing through the midt of the hand, does raie it elfe up towards the hill of the Moon, it is called the middle naturall Line; Thee fractions which you ee and eem o little, do ignifie, that you are eaily angred, even againt thoe, over whom Love has given you authoritie: And this little tar which turnes againt the riing of the pule, doth hew, that you are full of goodnee and weetnee, and that your anger is oon over. But oberve that Line which we call the Table Line, which joynes it elfe with the middle naturall Line, o as both do make an Angle, this doth demontrate various troubles in matter of Love, and which will often render your life very dipleaing, and tells me, that it will be very long or never, before
your deres come to a concluion. I would have continued, when he pulled back her hand and told me, that this was not that which he did ask of me, but he defired to know what would become of that deigne which he had in hand, and that I would not peak o generally as before, but come to particulars. To which I anwered, that the Divine powers did keep the future to themelves, unlee omtimes out of their goodnee they revealed them unto their ervants and that omtimes for the publique good, omtimes to atisfie the ervent prayers of thoe who do often importune them at their Altars: and very often to how that nothing is hid from them; but alwayes unto uch as are prudent and dicreet: for the ecrets of the gods would not be made common, or divulged, but upon peciall occaions. I tell you this, that your curioitie may ret contented, though I have not o clearely dicovered things unto you, as you deire. Nor is it either expedient or neceary, I hould tell you any more: but to the end you may know, that the gods are not niggards of their favours but peak familiarly unto me. I will tell you of uch things as have happened unto you, by which you may very well Judge, that I do know them.

In the firt place, fair Nymph, you know that though I never aw you before, yet at the very firt entrance I called you by your names; which I did, that you might beleeve me to be above the common degree of knowledge, not that I do acribe any glory unto my elfe, for that would be high preumption, but unto the gods whom I do adore in this place. Then you beleeve that all I ay, I learned from my mater. (And in this I lyed not, for it was you Polemas who told me all) But, continued I, particularities will make my dicoure very long; it were convenient, if we went under ome of thoe hady trees. Upon this we went, and then I began thus; Truly, Clemanthes (aid Polemas to him and interrupted him) you could not carry out this beginning with more artifice. You hall judge, anwered Cleanthes, whether I did not continue it with as much or more prudence: Then thus I began, Fair Nymph, it is now about three yeares ince the noble Agis in a full aembly was given unto you for a Servant. At the firt, you were very indifferent; for then the unripenee of both your ages, had not made you capable of uch paions as Love did conceive: but ince that time, your beautie in him, and his addrees unto you, did by degrees kindle thoe ires which nature at the firt had laid a foundation for: o as that which at the firt was but indifferent in you both, became now particular; and Love did furnih his oul with all uch paions as uually do accompany it: likwie you began to bear him o much good will as to accept of his affection and ervices above others. The firt time he ever made any overtures unto you, was when Amais did walk in the gardens of Mount-Brion, when he took you by the hand, and after a long paue, upon a uddain he broke into thee expreions: Fair Nymph I will no longer dipute with my elfe, whether I hould or I hould not declare, the thoughts of my oul unto you, for now my oul begins to be angry with me, and contraines me to it. Here I topt, and aid, unto her; Leonida, will you have me repeat the very ame words to a yllable, that you ued in anwer to him? Beleeve me, (aid Polemas them) you run a great hazard to be dicovered. No no, anwered Cleanthes, and to give a tetimonie that I have not lot my memorie, I wil repeat unto you the ame words: But replyed Polemas, perhaps I might either forget or mitake them: Oh never doubt that (aid Cleanthes) for I beleeve he herelf cannot remember her own very words; o as having an opinion that I recieved mine from the gods, doubtlee he would have beleeved them the ame, though you had never been familiar with her. But remembring that you erved her long, and that your ervices were alwayes well received untill you changed affection and addreed it unto Galathea, and upon that reaon he took part with Lindamor againt you, therefore I poke more confidently of the pat paages, knowing well that Love wil not let a lover conceal any thing from the party loved; but to returne to the purpoe, he anwered me; I ee you can tell us what you wil, but we can believe what we pleae, this he aid, as being a little nettled in that which perhaps he would have concealed from her companions: however I went on True, Leonida, (aid I,) you may beleeve what you pleae, but I am ure tell you nothing but what you know is true: you anwered Agis, as if you did not undertand his meaning, whatoever it be, Agis (aid you unto him) out with it: for diimulation misbecomes all men, epecially uch as you. This advice (anwered he) together which my own paion contraines me to tell your Fair Nymph, That the inequality of my merits compared with yours is not able to top the violence of my affection but if the will of a giver be more to be looked unto, then the quality of the gift, I dare boldly ay, that mine is not a depiable acrifice. For the heart which I do give, I do give it with all the affections, with all the faculties, and with all the power of my oul; and this o abolutely,
as hereafter, it is not mine, I do diavow and renounce it as a thing that does not belong unto me: untowhich you anwered; Agis, I hall beleeve thee words, when time and your ervices has told as much as your tongue: This, Leonida, was the firt declaration of affection which you received from him, which afterwards he did proecute with many addrees and quarrells which he underwent againt many when he was jealous. It was now the time, Leonida, when you, as you were curling your haire with hot Irons, you burned your cheek, upon which ubject he compoed thee veres.

lg.head: Agis, Upon the burning of Leonida's cheeke.

lg.l: AS Love was porting in the fuire
And lovely trees of your haire,
A parkle of his fire did eek;
To kie the beauty of your cheeke.
And being full of hot deire,
He kied it as hot as fire.
Judge cruell Nimph, by this, what pain
Poor lovers by Lov's fire utaine:
Since but apittance, or a part
Of his great fire, can caue uch mart.
The corching Luter of your eyes,
So full of flaming cruelties
Againt my heart a hundred ends
Whilt only one, your cheek offends;
But had Love bit aright the mark
Upon your heart had light the park.
Judge cruell Nymph, by this, what pain
Poor Lovers by Loves fire utain:
Since but a pittance, or a part
Of his great flame, can cae uch mart.

div.p:
Now, Leonida, to make it appear, that I do know al thee things from a Divinitie who never lies, and whoe eye and eare does look into the very center of all hearts; I will tell you one thing which none did ever know but your elf and Agis. She was now afraid, let I hould dicover ome ecret which would anger her, and indeed it was my deign to make her have that apprehenion and therefore with a troubled mind, he aid thus unto me; man of God, though I do not fear that you or any other can ay any thing which will much prejudice me, yet the dicovery of ecrets is a thing of o tender a concernment as be they touched by never o gentle a hand, yet it wil annoy: therefore I beeech you let this dicoure have an end; he uttered thee words with o much alteration in her lookes, and in uch a faint tone, as to cheere her up, I was forced to ay thus; you need not think me of o hallow dicretion, but that I know how to conceale any thing which will offend you: and therefore fince you will know no more, I know how to be ilent; alo it is time for me to returne to that Divinity who calls me: then I did rie up, and bad them adieu. Then after I had ceremoniouly wahed my hand in this River, upon my knees, I aid, Oh Soveraigne Dietie which reides in this place, behold how in this water I wah away, and purifie my elf from all the prophanitie which the converation with men might have defiled me withall, ince I came out of thy holy Temple. At this word, I wahed my hands, my head, my feet, and all parts over, o entred into my cabin, not peaking a word after unto her: and becaue I did imagine, that their curioitie would invite them to come and ee what I did, I went unto my Altar, and kneeling down; I let down, the plank which had the teel in it, and which immediatly fell upon the flint, and fired my compoition. The Nymphs firt eeing my looking glae which cat a very replendent Luter, and after uch a flaming combution upon a udden, they returned home with a great opinion of my anctitie, and reverence towards the Divinitie whom I adored. Could matters be better executed then
this? No certainly, anwered Polemas, for I believe any one that was not acquainted with it, might have been deceived as well as the Nymphs.

Whilt Climanthes talked thus, Leonida who heard him, was o ravihed out of her elfe, as he hardly knew whether he was awake or aleep, for he found all he related to be very true; and yet he could not well believe that it was o: But whilt he was thus in dipute with her elfe, he heard Climanthes begin again thus, Then thee Nymphs went away, and what reports they made of me, I know not; but I conjecture they talked very highly of me, and uch trange things, that all the Court was full of me: for, as fame alwaies encreaeth by paing from mouth to mouth; o an infinite number came to ee me, ome out of curioity, others to know their Fortunes, and many to ee whether all reports of me were true; o as I was put to all my hifts for maintaining my reputation. To avoid ome, I aid, that this was a day on which the deitie would not hear nor anwer; to others I aid, that ome had offended the divinity, and therefore they would give no return, untill I had appeaed them by fating; to others, I did precribe a long pennance before I could undertake them: And when all was done, I aid, they had either done too much, or too little, of that which I did impoe upon them, and o I alwaies gained time: As for uch as I knew any thing of their buinee, I dipatched them readily enough; and that was the reaon, why all others, who deired to know as much as they, did wholly ubmit unto whatoever I did impoe upon them. At the lat, Amais her elfe came to ee me, and brought Galathea with her; after I had atisfied Amais in all her demands, which in um was, whether Clideman hould be properous in his voyage: and I anwered her, that he hould run through much varietie of fortune, that he hould be wounded, and that he hould be in three Battles with the Princes of France; but that at lat, he hould return with much glory; Then he went away well atisfied, and deired me to recommend her on unto the tuition of the deitie whom I adored. But Galathea much fuller of curioity then her Mother, taking me aide, thus aid unto me, Good Father, I beeech you oblige me o far, as to let me know, what Fate I mut expect. Then I did bid her hew me her hand, I looked her in the face, I made two or three circles on the ground, and turned towards the ame; then I took the meaure of her hand, of her foot, of her neck, and many other ceremonies did I ue. At lat, looking tedfatly upon her, I aid, Galathea, You are infinitely happy, if you can but know how to take the advantage of one houre; and you are extreamly mierable, if either out of carelenee, or out of love or out of fear, you let this houre lip: But, the very truth is, unlee you would make your elfe uncapable of that happinee, unto which the heavens detined you, you cannot attain unto greater felicity; all your happinee, or all your miery, depends upon Love. Be advied therefore, and take a trong reolution, not to be intangled by the allurements of love; let neither the counell of Friends, nor command of Parents, tagger you; for if you do, then there is none under heaven will be more mierable then your elfe. Oh heavens! (aid Galathea then) how you amaze me. Nay, never wonder (aid I unto her) for this which I tell you is only for your good: and to the end you may carry your elfe with more prudence, I will dicover unto you, as much as the deitie will permit me; but be ure you keep all I hall ay mot ecret, and do not impart it to any upon earth. After he had promied me o to do, I proceeded on. Daughter (aid I) for o my divine office allowes me to call you, you hall be courted and ued unto, by many noble Cavaliers, whoe vertues and merits may haply move you to cat an eye upon ome of them: but, if you do meaure your affection, either by their merits, or by their loves, and not by what I hall ay unto you, then you will become as mierable, as one, that is out of the favour of the gods, can be. As for me, who am the interpreter of their will, by thus telling you, I do deprive you of all excues, which can be drawn from ignorance. You know, that heaven requires obedience and ubmiion above all other acrifices, therefore be ure you remember what I ay. Upon the Bacchanalian feat day, when men are well'd with the enthuiams of their god, you hall be in the great Town of Marcelles, where many Gallants will ee you; but, take good heed of him who hall wear a uit made of green cloth of gold: If you do love him, I hall lament your ad fate, for you hall be the Butt of all diaters and misfortunes. Father, aid he unto me, I do know a good remedie againt all thee, and that is, to love none at all My Child (aid I unto her) there is danger alo in this remedie; for, you may as well offend the gods, in not doing that which they would have you do, as in doing that which they would not have you do; therefore take heed of that. How then mut I behave my elfe (aid he)? I have already told you what you mut not do, (anwered I); And now I will
tell you what you mut do: In the firt place you mut know, that all corporeall or phituall bodies, have their ympathies and antipathies from the leer we may come to the proof of the greater. My aim is, to make you undertand, that you have both a good and a bad Genius waiting upon you, one contrary to the other; and to avoid the bad, you mut court the good, who will make you infinitely happy, did you but know to hit your houre Oh Father! (aid he) I do conjure you by the divinity whom you adore to tell me what I hould do. There is another peron, (anwered I) whom if you do marry, you will enjoy more felicitie, then ever any mortall did. I beeech you, aid Galathea, who is it? That, fair Nymph (aid I) mut not come from me, but only from Hecathe whom I adore, o as if I do not atisfie you in that, do not think it is for want of any good will, but becaue he hath not yet revealed it unto me; may be, becaue I had not o much curioity as to enquire it. But if you would know, then oberve what I hall ay unto you, and then you hall know as much as is neceary: for, as the Gods do liberally dipence their benefits unto men when they pleae, o they would be acknowledged Gods: The acrifices of mortalls are pleaing unto them, as tetimonies, that they are not ungratefull for the benefits which they receive. The Nymph much ravihed then, anwered, That he deired no more, and that he would punctually oberve whatoever I hould ordain. Now then is the time, aid I unto her, for the Moon is now at the full, or very neer it; and if you hould let her decreae, it would for ever after be too late. Then I did command her to do the ame things I did Silvia and Leonida, to wah her elfe before day in this little River, both thighes and armes, and to come thus, with a Chaplet of Vervine, and a Girdle of Moe or Fem, before my Cell, and that I would prepare all things neceary for the acrifice. Well, aid he, I will come, and bring two of my Nymphs with me, and o privatly, that none hall ever know of my coming but they: but, be ure you be well advied what you peak before them of this buinee, for they wil endeavour all they can to divert me. I was very glad of this caution, having my elfe the ame fears; and becaue I perceived, that he reolved to follow my counell, otherwie he would not have cared who had known it. Thus he went away, with a full reolution to return the third day after. The reaon why I aid, that it mut be before the Moones decreae, was, to the end, that if any came to me in the mean time, I might put them off with an excue, that the Mocil was not yet at the full. Alo I aid, that it mut be before day, to the end I might have fewer people come to trouble me And as for the Bacchanalian Feat, I had computed it to fall upon the ame day, on which Lindamor was to take his leave of Amais at Marcelles, and conequently of Galathea; and alo, that he hould wear this day a green uit. All things then being thus reolved upon, and prepared, I took order for the acrifice: and though I was not well vered in that mytery, yet, I hewed all the skill I had, let they hould finde me ignorant in any thing.

The morning being come, and day within little of dawning, I found her in the ame poture I appointed, with Silvia and Leonida. I wihed with all my oul, Polemas, that you had been there, that you might have enjoyed the happinee to have een this fair one, in uch a lovely mode; you had een how the wanton winde did play with her lovely locks, which hung looe in curious curles upon her alabater houlders, and had no other cover, but the Chaplet of Vervine. There you might have bleed your eyes with a ight of her naked armes and •• ighes, no how o white; and her pretty little feet might have hamed Thetis.

I mut ingenuouly confee, that I wihed the wings of time had been clipped, that I might have looked longer upon thee beauties, who, as I told them, mut needs be well perfumed with the finet Aromatique mells, let the viions of the deity of Styx hould offend them, and to that end hewed them a place more private, where they could not eaily be een.

Upon the ide of a hill from whence this little River runs, there was a very cloe and thick thicket of wood, whoe branches were o enterwoven with leaves, they did make mot cloe and delightfull umbrage; o as the penetrating Sun-beams could not reach into the hollow vault under it: This gloomy hade did encourage them unto much boldnee, but yet their curioity to be informed of what they defired, much more: There then it was where thee three Nymphs began to undree themelves, and ue all uch neceary perfumes as I precribed; and I knowing the place very well, did teal my elfe o neer, as I could eaily ee them naked. I mut confee, I never aw o lovely a ight in all my life; but above all, I found Leonida mot admirable, both in the traight proportion of her body,
in the purely whitenee of her skin, in the moothnee and plumpnee of every part he excelled them all by much; o as I began to dicommend your judgment, and think you a man unexpert in hidden beauties, ince you quitted Leonida for Galathea: who, it is true, has omthing that is fair in her face; but, her other parts are o fat hort, of what by her face might be expected, as he may be truly called a deceiver. Oh heavens! Climanthes (aid Polemas, who could not endure to hear her whom he o loved thus poken of) leave off this dicoure, for Leonida's face is not worthy to come in comparion with Galathea's. Well ir, (anwered Climanthes) think what you pleae, but I am ure Leonida's face is the leat fair part about all her body. Then I would advie her (aid Polemas) to hide her face, and hew us what is more fair: But I believe, Climanthes, your eyes were not competent judges; for the obcurity of the place, perhaps, would not uffer you to ee them perfectly. But i beeech you let this dicoure alone, and go on with your tory. Leonida, who heard all this, and eeing with what corn Polemas did peak of her, he began to be o much offended with him, as he reolved never to pardon him. On the contrary, though he hated thee impotures of Climanthes, yet he could not chue but love to hear her elfe o much commended: for nothing does more tickle a young Lady, than applauding her beauty, epecially, when there is no upition of flattery. Whilt he was in thee thoughts, he heard Climanthes continue his tory, on thus, Then thee three Nymphs came unto me, where they found me before my Cell, and preparing all things for the acrifice I lighted up three candles, and I burned incene three times round the room then I took off their Chaplets of Vervine, and crowned them with Poppy, and put ome falt into their mouths, and bad them chew it: Then I took three black Heifers, the bet I could chue, and nine Ewes which had never taken the Ramm, whoe black and long wool reembled ilk, o oft and mooth it was I cut off the hair which grew between their hornes, and cot it into the fire, prinkling upon it milk, wine, flower, and honey; and after I had called upon Hecathe three times, I thrut my knife into the hearts of thee Animals, one after another, and took their blood in a great baon: Then falling upon my knees, I called again upon Hecathe; afterwards I roe up, and eemed as if I were tranported, aying unto the Nymphs, See, ee, the deitie! it is time, it is time, it is time! then taking Galathoa by the hand, I tared with my eyes, hook my head, gaped with my mouth, made my breat to pant, and all my body trembled, as if I were in a holy rapture: Then being neer the altar, I aid, Oh holy deitie, who reides in this place, give unto me power to atisfie this Nymph in her demands with all truth. The room was dark, and had no light, but uch a hollow gloominee as the candles gave; but the day being now light, and the Sun up, it hined upon the painted paper, and made it repreent it elfe much better in the Looking glae; afterwards I addreed my elfe unto Galathea, aying, Oh fair Nymph! thou art the favourit of heaven, thy prayers are heard, and thy acrifice is received It is the pleaure of the deitie, that not only by the ear, but alo by the eye, thou mait know the place where thou halt finde thy happinee. Come neer this altar, and ay after me, Oh, mot mighty Hecathe, whoe habitation is in the Stygian Lake, at whom the churlih Dog with three heads never barks; may thy altars ever moak with acceptable acrifices, which I do vow annually to pay, o as, great goddee, thou wilt let me ee what I deire. At this word I let down the plank which had the teel in it, which being fallen upon the flint, the fire did flah preently, o as Galathea was urpried with fear: But I did ay unto her, Fear not fair Nymph, it is Hecathe who hewes you what you deire. Then the moak by degrees vanihing, the Looking glae was to be een; and, as good luck was, the Sun hined o clearly and directly upon it, as made the painted paper mot plainly appear in it: After they had a while beheld it, I aid unto Galathea, Know Nymph, that Hecathe by me does let thee know, It is in this place which you ee in the Glae, where you hall finde a jewell, halfe lot and depied, out of a thought that it is fale; and yet it is of an inetimable value, take it and keep it carefully. This River which you ee in it, is Lignon: that Grove of Willowes beyond it is towards Mount Verdan. Oberve well the place and remember it. Then taking Galathea aide, I aid unto her, You have, as I told you before, a Genius, that wells with abundance of malevolent influence; and another, the mot benign and weet, as poibly can be deired From the evill influence guard your elfe, if you do love your own contentment: the good influence is that which you do ee in the mirrour. Oberve well the place which I have let you ee, and to the end you may the better remember it, I bid you go and ee it, and oberve it well; for, when the Moon hall be jut of the ame age, that this day he is, a little ooner, or a little later, you hall
finde him whom you mot love: If he ee you before you ee him, he hall love you, and you with much a do will love him: On the contrary, if you ee him firt, he hall be hardly brought to love you, but you will love him immediately: But however, you mut overcome your elfe and love him, yea, and overcome him alo, if need be; for doubtlee you will at lat bring it to pae: If you do not meet him the firt time, then go again the next Moon, upon the ame day, and ame houre, and o to the third; for come he will, though Hecathe will not aure me of the day. Then taking a little branch of Hollin in my hand, I went unto the Looking-glae, and with the end of it, hewed her all thee places: Look, (aid I) ee where the Mountain of I oures is; ee where Mount Verdun is, ee where the River Lignon is, ee, a little beyond it, where the Meadow is, through which you have oft gone to hunt: All thee places you may perhaps know, but I do not know them. Now Nymph, the acred deitie of this place commands me to tell you, that if you do not punctually oberve what I ay, and what you have promied, he will augment all the mieries which your detiny does threaten you with all: For my part, I do think my elfe happy, that before my departure I have given you this advice: for, though I am not of this Country; yet, your vertue and piety does oblige me to love you, and to pray unto Hecathe to make you fully happy: And with this prayer I will take my leave of you; for the goddee whom I adore hath commanded me to depart before the day, to morrow. An this word I did put them all out of my Cabin, after I had taken from them their Vervine, Ferne, and Hollin Chaplets, which I did burn in the fire.

I did prefix her three Moones, to the end, that if you failed one day, you might be there another. I told her that if he aw you firt, then he hould eaily love you; and if you aw her firt, the contrary; only becaue I knew very well you would be firt there o as he would finde in her elfe the truth of my prediction, for you know, he loves Lindamor. I told her that I was to depart before to morrow, to the end he hould not think trange at my departure, if out of ome freh curioity he hould come again: For having now done as much as my aimes did drive at, my bet way was to hate away, let ome Druide hould hear of me, and punih me, which, you know, was alwaies my fear. Do you think, Polemas, I have omitted any materiall circumtance? No certainly aid Polemas, only me thinks you gave her too large a time; I would you had confined her to one day, and then I hould have been ure to have met with her. For my part, aid Climanthes, I know not what to think, but that he hath counted the age of the Moon wrong; and I do verily believe, that but for this Shepheard who was drowned, and who caued many people to eek about for him, you had met with him that day: But let us have a little patience, for I am confident, that the ame reaon which made you retreat, did alo make her do the like. But, me thinks it is time to rie, to the end we may depart. Then opening the window, he perceived it to be bright day. Away, away, make hate (aid Climanthes to Polemas) the houre will be pat ele; you had better be many houres too oon, then a minute too late. Would you have me go thither now (aid Polemas)? do you think he will come, ince it is fifteen daies pat the prefixed time? No matter (anwered he) perhaps he has micounted the dayes, who can tell? and therefore let us go.

Leonida was afraid leat Polemas and Climanthes hould ee her, and therefore durt not rie till they were gone: but when they were out of the houe he dreed herelf. And after he had taken leave of her hot, he continued on her Journey o confued at the cunning artifice of thee two perons, as he almot never minded her way and he was touched o to the quick, that Polemas hould o depie her beauty, that to be revenged of him, he would make Lindamor acquainted with his treachery, which he thought he could not better do then by the meanes of her Uncle Adamas unto whom he intended to communicate the, matter. And in this reolution, he made all the hate he could unto Feurs, where he thought to find him; but he came too late, for he went homwards betimes in the morning, having the day before, finihed all ceremonies belonging to the acrifice: as he went the day was very hot, therefore when he was in the plain of Mount Verdun, he turned out of the way where he aw a handom hade of trees, to ret himelf a while. And he was no ooner come at it, but he epied a hepheard comming and eeming as if he intended to take the ame conveniency of hade. And becaue when he came neere, he eemed to be exceeding penive, he would not take any notice of him, let he hould diturbe his thoughts, but haded himelfe purpoely to heare what he would ay: at lat, he heard him break out thus: Why hould I be o imple as to love this wethercock? in the firt place her beauty cannot much move, for he has o little as all he has cannot merit the name of Fair: moreover, there are
no other coniderations that can help out her merits, or retaine any man of parts in her ervice: Again, her affection is all that can poibly oblige me, and that is of uch a mutable temper, as if he have any impreion of Love in heart, I beleeve it is but like unto wax and wax o oft as will eaily take any new impreion and deface the old: at the mot, if I do love her, I mut confee it is meerly becaue I think he loves me. This hepheard had gone on his dicoure, had not a hepheardee overtaken him, who it eemes followed after him: and itting down by him thus began to ay: Come, Corilas, come, what new digut is it, that makes you thus penive' The hepheard returned as didaining an anwer as he could, and never o much as turning his head towards her, anwered thus; I am thinking what a trick of Legerdemaine you have ued, to get away from them whom even now you loved; why Corilas (aid he) can you think I Love any but your elf? Than you? Said the hepheard, can you think I beleeve you Love me? What then do you beleeve of me (aid he) I beleeve you are a foole, (aid he) to love one that hates you. You have a very trange opinion of me (aid he): And you (aid Corilas) have trange effects in yourelf Oh heavens (aid the hepheardee) what kind of a man have I met withall? I have more reaon to ay in o meeting with Stella, anwered he, what kind of a woman have I met withall? For never was any more incapable of amity then you; you I ay, who delights in nothing more then deceiving thoe who trut you; who imitates Hunters, that with abundance of toyle does hunt the game, and then gives it, as a reward, to the dogges. There is o litele reaon in all you ay (aid he) as thoe have lee that wil tay to anwer you. I wih (aid the hepheard) that I had alwaies as much reaon in my oul, as there is at this time in my words, then hould I not grieve o much as I do. Afterwards both of them being ilent a long while, at lat he began to ing and thus in inging to expree her elf unto him. Alo he, becaue he would not it mute without returning anwer, thus replyed unto her.
div.stage: The Dialogue between Stella and Corilas.

l.hi: COme hepheard come and tell me why
For want of Love thou dot me fly?
Becaue to follow uch a light
And ayrie pirit, is a flight,
Which mut be followed with wings,
And men do never ue uch things.
I do remember well the time
When Loving me, you thought no crime;
Of paed time no talking pend,
He lives but ill that does not mend;
Time pat, is pat recovery;
And o with it, my memorie:
To Love, I fear, you do not know
Only can make a loving how:
Why do you lay on me the blame
When you are guilty of the ame?
You Love by fale opinions voice
And not by any prudent choice:
By heaven, I Love you, and lament
You unto changing thus are bent;
Where once my Love becomes a due
I am unalterably true,
And think me not in Love like you
Who every day does love a new;
No no, I find thee faint and hollow
And can a new affection follow;
If any time you pleaed me
Then did I think you fair to be;
T'was only thought; the troth is this,
You did no beauty e're poee:
Perfidious Lover; cant thou find
A heart to kill her, that is kind?
You charge me when your elf offends;
Mut he that's injur'd make the mends?
But I ne're Lov'd; and tak't from me,
What never was, will never be:
Nay, once you lov'd me; but 'its trange
That you o cruelly can change:
When loving you, a crime I find,
'Tis widom ure to change my mind;
Repentance late is better farre
Then never turne, when one does erre;
Tis fitter far you did regret
Your infidelity o great;
What you call infidelity
Dicretion is, and policie:
And this is all that can be aid
All Love betwixt us two is dead.

div.p: The hepheardee eeing he had all his replyes o ready, he left off her inging, and aid thus unto him, why Corilas is there no manner of hope in you? No, aid he, no more then there is in your fidelity. Never think that all your flattery and fair language can make me change my reolution; for, beleeve it, I am mot firmly fixed. It is meer vanitie to make ue of any armes or charmes againt me, they are all too weak. I would advie you Stella to imploy them and your time upon ome other, who not knowing you, will not perhaps leight you as I do Noveltie is pleaing you know: and perhaps you may meet with ome, whom heaven having a deigne to punih, may Love you: The hepheardee was in good earnet nettled at this yet turning it into a eeming Jeat, he miled and aid: Oh Corilas I cannot chue but laugh at your cholerique humor, but ere long I hall ee you in a better mood: Nay I know, replyed the hepheard, that it is your humour to laugh at thoe who love you, but I aure you, that you may laugh long enough at me before I do Love you; Thus thee two enemies parted: and Adamas knowing by their names of what families they were he had a deire to know more of their buinee: and calling Corilas by his name, he came unto him; and cauing him to it down by him, he thus aid, my Son (for o I may call you out of the affection I ever had unto your familie) you need not be orry that you have poken o freely unto Stella before me: I am very glad to ee you o dicreet: but I do deire to know further of your buinee, to the end I may give you my faithfull advice. As oon as Corilas aw the Druide, he remembred that he had often een him officiating in everall Sacrifices: but ince he had never poke to him before, he had not the confidence to relate the paages twixt Stella and him; that he was ever willing that all the world did know the Jutice of his caue, and the perfidy of Stella: which Adamas perceiving, by way of encouragement told him that he was partly acquainted with the buinee already, and that to his comfort many did peak in his behalfe. I am afraid, Father (aid Corilas) that the trifles of our villages will be very tedious unto you. No No: replyed Adamas, a relation of this buinee will much pleae me, and time alo will be well imployed by o pending away the heat of the day.

div.head: The Hitory of Stella and Corilas.
div.p: SInce, Father, you command it o (aid the Shepheard) I will relate the whole matter unto you.
