Stella is the Widow of a Husband which Heaven gave her, rather for a name then ought ele: for, beides his icknee: his age, which was above ixtie ix, had o impaired his trength, that he left her a luty young Widow, before he was almot married: And the affection he had unto him was not o much, as to make her grieve too much for her loe; nor indeed was her humour uch, as to take any thing too much to heart. When he aw her elfe ridd of two heavy yokes, both almot at once to wit, a riddance from an old, cray, and peevih Husband, and from that trictet obervance which is expected from Ghildren to Parents, he then began to hew her elfe, and ruffle in the world with a great noie: And as he was none of thoe killing beauties, that make themelves loved by force, o her affectednee did not at all pleae any that looked upon her. Her age was ome eventeen or eighteen, an age that is apt to commit much folly, when liberty is given unto it. This was the reaon that Saliam her Brother, a very honet and dicreet Shepheard, not being able to endure the expenive coures which he drew upon him, and in ome ort to retrain her, did get her out of his village, into uch a place, where he might live in lee danger of candall: in order to which, he intreated Cleanthes, that he would be pleaed to let her accompany his Daughter Amintha, becaue they uited o well in age, though Stella had a little the tart of her: And Cleanthes being content, there grew uch a familiarity betwixt thee two Shepheardees, and they lived uch private lives and contented, as they were never out of ight of one another. Many did wonder, that thee two being of uch different tempers, yet they did o well comply; but the weet and loving dipoition of Amintha, and the upple and eaie nature of Stella, were the caues; o Amintha never croed the deignes of her Companion, and Stella never thwarted whatoever Amintha deired; o as they kept uch a correpondency together, as nothing was hid from each other. But at lat, Lyis, the Son of the Shepheard Genetian, leaving the frozen valleyes of Mount Luna, and coming into our more pleaant plaines, and eeing Stella at an aembly in the Temple of Venus, when Atrea did carry away the prie of beauty, he fell o in love with Stella, as I do not well know whether or no, it hath not ent him to his Grave: And he was o compliant to him, as after everall journeyes and meages, things were come to that pae, as Lyis moved her to marriage, unto which he gave as favourable an anwer as he could deire. At this time, Saliant was contrained unto uch a far off journey, as he knew nothing of this treaty: beides, he did now take upon her elfe uch abolute authority, as he did not communicate her matters unto him. On the other ide, Amintha eeing her o oon reolved upon marriage, did often ask her, whether or no he was in good earnet; and told her, that it was a matter of o great importance, as required very great and erious conideration. Amintha, anwered he, never trouble your elfe, for I am not gon o far, but I can eaily make a retreat. Mean time, Lyis did make himelfe o ure of marriage, as that he et down the day, invited many of his friends, and was at uch charges, as are uuall upon uch occaions. But Stella, according to the cutome of many women, who are proud of their own libertie, tarted from her firt intentions, and broke all off by uch unreaonable demands, as he knew the Parents of Lyis would never conent unto: But, his love being above all difficulties and atisfying all her unreaonable demands, he was at lat forced to break off with him upon no other pretence, but the lendernee of his affection to her. You may eaily imagine how Lyis reented this affront; but however, he could not yet mater his love: And I remember upon this ubject, he compoed thee Veres, which afterwards he gave unto me.

lg.head: Upon Anger againt Love.

l.hi: IS Anger mad, in making me to go
Gaint uch a fatall and puiant foe?
Mut I conducted be into the field
By uch a Captain, as is ure to yield?
A Leader in uch lamentable armes,
Gaint love that's arm'd with arrowes and with charmes.
Can faint and feeble Anger ever think
Victorious Love to conquer, and make hrink?
No, no, the wafting of his wing will hatter
Thy Squadrons all, and will thy Bulwarks batter.
Love hath of anger uch infinite of odds,
As with his fore-works he can conquer Gods:
Reitance will but add unto his glory,
And being conquer'd, make more ad my tory.
I'le therefore mercy ask, and quarter cry,
Which if my fairet hepheardee deny,

lg.l: Then triumph in Elizian hades will I,

l.hi: And my own death hall be my victory.

div.p:
The caue of Stella's change in her affection, was the courthip of another Shepheard called Semires, which did imprint it elfe very deep in her oul, and which Lyis did perceive the lat of all men, for he did conceal it more from him than any other. This Shepheard Semires was of all men that my converation ever met with, the mot diembling and crafty; that he was otherwie a man of very excellent parts, which caued this Shepheardee to go againt her own promie, and reject the match with Lyis, and to confer all her favours upon her new Lover, who yet did not long triumph in this victory. For o it happened, that Lupeander making a great Feat at the marriage of his Daughter Olympia, Lyis and Stella were invited thither; and I being a kinman unto the Bride, I would not ail to be there alo. I know not whether Love did it cut of revenge, or whether it was the naturall giddinee of Stella's wavering temper; but o it was, that he no ooner aw Lyis, then he had a minde to recall him into her favour; and in order to that, pruced up her elfe in all her affectednee which nature had very imprudently been prodigall of unto her: But, the offended pirit of this Shepheard had armed him with o much courage, as to hide all his affection to her, though he could not extinguih the flames of love. Towards night, when every one prepared for dancing, and to apply themelves unto thoe perons mot utable to their liking; Stella did o purue Lyis; that he being in a corner of a window, he could not handomely avoid her, but was forced to receive the aaults of his loving enemy. Semires all this while oberving how he purued Lyis; all the evening, according to the naturall temper of all Lovers, he began to be prinkled with jealouie, knowing well, that a candle newly extinguihed, will oon light again: And eeing her o cloe to Lyis, he got o neer, as eeming to talk unto another, he heard her ask Lyis, why he hunned her o much? To which Lyis replied, The reaon is, becaue you do o impudently purue me. But Shepheard, replyed Stella, I know from whence your dicontents proceed, and I believe, not from him whom you imagine. For gods-ake (anwered Lyis) let me alone in quietnee; it is enough that thy offence proceeds from your hating me, and your hatred from your own levity: But 'tis no matter, all's forgotten, and now I have no minde to love. Well, well, (anwered he) I know from whence all your anger proceeds, and certainly you have ome eeming reaon for it; but, I beeech you conider it a little better. Is it uch an impardonable injury, not to take a man to a husband, as oon as ever he hath asked the quetion? Is it not the cutome of our Country, that he hould ask that quetion twice? The truth is, if I had marryed another, I had done you an injury: But, what likelyhood is there, that I hould ever refue a man o contant, that hath loved me almot thee three months? The offended pirit of Lyis not uffering him to love her, and his affection not uffering him to hate her, he did not know in what termes to anwer her; and yet, to top the torrent of words, he thus aid unto her: I have had ufficient experience, Stella, that you know better how to ay then do, and that you abound much more in words than reaon: but, take this for an unalterable certainty, that look how much I loved you heretofore, o much, or more, do I hate you now, and hall do as long as I live; o as there hall not be a day, in which I will nor divulge you unto all the world, for the mot ungratefull and conening woman under heaven. Upon this, forcing his affection and the arme of Stella away, he broke from her, and left her alone in the window, whilt he went amongt the ret of the Shepheards. Semires, who, as I told you, heard all this dicoure, was both o amazed and ill atisfied with her, as he reolved ever ince to make no more addrees unto uch a wavering weathercock; which reolution was much more confirmed by me; for, I having long looked for an opportunity of peaking to her, and eeing Lyis had
left her alone, I accoted her; for I mut confee that her allurements had ome power upon my oul, and o much as the affronts which he had put upon Lyis would not let me ee her imperfections, and fleeting dipoition. And as every one is apt to flatter himelfe in his own deires; o I uppoed that what the merits of Lyis could not obtaine from her, my good fortune might. As long as Lyis courted her, I would not let my affection appeare, for beides conangunity, there was a great league of amitie betwixt us: but when I aw he was off, and thinking the place vacant (for I never took notice of Semires) I thought it a fit time to open my elf, before he entertained any other o addreing my elfe unto her, and finding her all penivenee, I aid unto her, that certainly it was ome great occaion which thus had altered her; for adnee was eldom een in her pleaant humour. It is that troubleome Lyis (anwered he) who has put me in mind of old tories, and till upbraids me with the refuing of him: Does that trouble you, (aid I unto her?) can it chue (anwered)? how he for affection is not o oon put off as ones cloaths are but becaue I did a little delay his deires, he took it for an abolute dicharge: Truly (aid I) Lyis did not deerve the honour of your favour: for what he could not compae by his merits, he ought to have tryed what all his ervices accompanied with a long patience would do, but his boyling temper, together with perhaps his too little love would not permit him. Had the ame happinee hapned unto me as unto him, with what affection hould I have entertained it? And with what patience hould I have waited for it? You would think it trange (reverend Father) to heare me tell you, how uddenly this hepheardee changed: yet I protet he entertained the overture of my Love, as oon as ever I made it: and in uch a manner, as, before we parted, he permitted me to call my elf her ervant. You may eaily conceive that Semires, who heard all this, was no better atisfied with me then he was with Lyis: but ever ince he hath dicontinued his addrees, yet o dicreetly as many think Stella to be the caue, for he eemed not to care for it, becaue the place of her affection was poeed with the new hopes he had of me, which was the caue that I received many favours from her and which Lyis quickly perceived. But Love which alwaies will tryumph over freindhip, did keep me from peaking unto him, let I hould offend the hepheardee: and though he was much offended that I hould thus conceale my my elfe from him, yet I never did peak unto him without Stella's leave, who alo eemed deirous it hould be o. But I who then was ignorant of her tricks, and trived at nothing but how to content her, one night when Lyis and I were together, I had this dicoure with him: I mut confee Lyis (aid I unto him) that I have not o clearly opened my elf unto you, as our freindhip required; but now you mut help me out, or ele I am undon: I (anwered Lyis) why you may be aured that I will never faile the part of a friend, though your mitrut of me might alter the cae: and yet do not think but I do know of your Love but your ilence o offended me, that I aid nothing of it: Since you did know it, replied I, and never poke to me of it, I have the greater caue to be offended: for I do confee, that I have omthing failed in point of freindhip by my ilence: but you mut conider that a lover is not himelfe, and his dieae is an excue for all his errours: but you who are not troubled with the ame paionate dieae, you have no excue for your failings in point of freindhip. Lyis hearing my reaons, began to mile and aid. You are very pleaant Corilas, and I will not contradict you, but I pray you tell me, how I may make amends for my fault: In doing that for me, aid I, which you could not: for your elf, which is that I may obtain the affection of Stella: Oh heavens (cryed out Lyis then) unto what a dangerous precipice have you brought your elf: Shun it, Corilas, hun it, for it is a mot dangerous paage, which ruines all thoe which ever took it: I peak unto you by experience; you know it, I know, that from any other, your merits can obtaine more then mine; but it is groe folly to hope for any thing from this perfidious woman, whom neither vertue nor reaon will move; to which I anwered that to hear him ay o, was no mal contentment: for, aid I, until now I was afraid you had retained ome thoughts for your elf, & therefore I was o reerved but ince, tha¯ks be to the fates, it is not o, I wil in this buines put you to the tryal of friendhip: I know that the hatred which ucceeds Love is alwaies meaured according to the grandure of its predeceor: and that you once loving this hepheardee: and now comming to hate her your hatred will be far greater then if you had never loved her: Yet undertanding from Stella her elf, that I can never arrive at my deires but by your meanes, I do conjure you Lyis by our friendhip to aide me, either by adviing or peaking for me or any other way. I will take it as a mot extream proof of your fidelity. Lyis was extreamly urpried at this deire, expecting any other prayer fro¯ me then this; by which, beides his dilike from this of
peaking unto Stella, he had lot a freind whom he loved mot. Yet he anwered thus unto me; Corilas, I will do as you deire, you can expect no more from me: but till remember that in meages of Love uch perons hould be imployed as are not hated. Thus poor Liis in lieu of a lover became a meenger of Love: a difficultie which his affection to me made him undertake, and he had full intentions to erve me, though afterwards he changed his mind; but the violence of his Love mut plead his excue, for Love hath a mot predominate power over men: and truly his affection to me is to be both commended and admired, ince he was once willing to part from her he loved to let me enjoy her. One day watching an opportunitie of peaking unto her, he found her at home by herelf, none being by to interrupt their dicoure: then calling to memorie the affronts he formerly had received he o armed himelf againt her charmes, as Love at this time could have no hope of overcomming. And though the hepheardee tudied alwaies to tryumph over him, yet he did o oppoe his pleen againt her and his freindhip to me, that at this combate he was conquerer Before he began to peak he went to meet him, and pumped for ome of her affected language; What new happynee is this, aid he, that hath brought back my long'd for Lyis to me? What an unexpected favour is this? Come come, ince you are returned I will begin to hope againe for I dare wear that never ince you left me, have I enjoyed a minute of content; to which the hepheard anwered: More eloquent then faithfull hepheardee, I am better atisfied with this your ingenuous confeion, then if I had not been offended at your in fidelity; but let us leave off this kind of dicoure, and forget it for ever: anwer me only to uch demands as I hall make unto you. Are you till reolved to deceive all thoe who hall ever Love you? For my part, I mut beleeve you are; for none of your humours are unknowne unto me: but I came to ee and ask how many adorers: you have, and whether you did not ay and protet and wear unto them, that none hould ever be deceived by you; for if you did, certainly they are in my predicament and rank. The hepheardee did not expect thee reproaches yet he anwered him, and thus. Shepheard, though you came only with deignes to wrong me, yet I give you thanks for the viit, and confee that you have reaon to complaine againt me. I complaine (anwered he)? no I pray you let that alone; I will neither wrong you nor complain againt you: but am o farre from it, that I will rather commend your humour: for had you eemed to love me any longer, I had been longer deluded: And I pray God, the loe of your Love bring me no more hurt then it doth orrow, you hall never heare that I complain of you: for injurie and truth cannot ubit together, no more then you & fidelity: can but take this for a mot certain truth, that you are the mot deluding and ungrateful hepheardee in all Forrets. Me thinks, dicourteous hepheard, (anwered Stella) that this language would become any other mouth better then yours. Then Lyis began to addree himelf in another dialect: Hitherto (aid he) I have borrowed my language from the jut anger of Lyis; but now I will borrow it of one that hath more to do with you then Lyis hath; & that is from a dicreet hepheard who loves you, and who values nothing upon earth comparable to your favorable acceptance of him & his ervices. She thinking that Liis mocked her, anwered him thus; Leave off this dicoure, Lyis: it is enough that you once did Love me without any reviving of the memorie of your errors; 'Tis very true, aid the Shepheard, they were errors indeed that moved me to love you; out you erre as much as I did, if you think that I do love you now, or that I peak for my elfe: No, no I peak in behalfe of poor Corilas, who is o wholly your devoted, as nothing can draw him off: I told him how I had tried you, and what little aurance there was to be found in your oul and words: I wore unto him, that you would certainly deceive him, and that I was ure you would keep me from being forworn: But, the poor, mierable, loving thing, is o blinded, as he thinks, what I cannot obtain, his merits can; and yet to undeceive him, I told him, that merit was the greatet impediment to obtain any thing from you. And to the end you may believe what I ay, I pray read this Letter which he hath ent you. But becaue Stella would not read my Letter, Lyis did open it, and read it aloud unto her.

body.head: The Letter of Corilas unto Stella.

p.hi: IT is mot impoible, that any eye hould look upon you, and not love; and as imposible to love you, and not be extream in his affection: If you pleae but to conider this truth, when this paper hall be preented unto your mot lovely eyes, I aure my elfe, that the grandure

of my pain will, out of pitty, finde a pardon for apiring unto uch a height as your merits, though this preumption does jutly merit punihment. In expectation of your doom, I beeech you give my thoughts leave to kie your fair hands a hundred thouand times, not being able within the compae of that number, to include thoe orrowes, which the deniall of this upplication will give me, nor thoe joyes which will well me, if you receive me, as mot truly I am

closer.signed: Your mot affectionate and mot faithfull Servant.

div.p: Aoon as Lyis had read this Letter, he went on with his dicoure: Come Stella, (aid he) what death mut he die, or how mut he live? For my part, I pitty him with all my heart, and wih you could do the like. I pray conider how bitter your deniall will be to him. This dicoure did touch this Shepheardee to the quick, and eeing how far Lyis was from loving her, he interrupted him in this manner, Me thinks Lyis (aid he) if Corilas were in uch a minde as this paper peaks him, he was very ill advied to employ you, ince your mediation is more like to procure him hatred then love, and you rather a meenger of war then peace. Stella, it's true, anwered he, he was very ill advied in his choice; but if he had hewed as much judgment in the ret of his actions, as in this, he would not have tood in need of your help; he has had tryall of your diimulations, he knowes what force your charmes have; and what friend could he have made choice of, without the danger of a competitor, unlee my elfe, whom you hate even unto death? But, let us leave this dicoure, and pray tell me plainly and in good earnet, whether or no you will hew him any favour; for the truth is, I dare not return to him, unlee I carry a good anwer with me, unto which I do conjure you, both by his affection that now is, and mine that was: Unto this, the Shepheard added o many arguments, and importunate prayers, as the Shepheardee believed him to be in good earnet; and her own naturall dipoition did eaily encline her to it; for, it is the cutome of uch as eaily love, to believe as eaily that they are loved but Lyis at this time could obtain no further from her, then that the affection of his couin for want of his, hould not be diagreeable unto her; but time hould advie her farther. And ince this, Lyis has everall waies o olicited her, that he got from her as much aurance as he deired; and becaue he was well acquainted with her levitie, he obtained from her a promie in writing under her hand, and knew o well how to turn her, that he obtained of her whatoever he deired. Thus he returned to me, and gave me an account of all he had done, except of this promie: for, knowing Stella's humour, he alwaies doubted he would deceive him, and that if he hewed me this paper, it would imbarque me the more, and be harder to get me off. All this was unknown unto Amintha, from whom Stella concealed it more, then from any other. After I had received o much aurance, as I could deire no more, and after I had given her all humble and hearty thanks, I began, by her permiion, to take orders for the marriage, and pake it very freely and openly, though Lyis alwaies foretold me, that in the end I hould be deceived. But, the very hadow of that good which we deire does o flatter us, that we lend but a deaf ear unto any that hall tell us the contrary. Whilt this Marriage was preparing, and publickly divulged, Semires, who, as I told you, dicontinued his addrees by reaon of Lyis and me, he being netled with the dicoure which went of him, reolved, at what rate oever, to infinuate himelfe into her favour, with a deigne to quit her afterwards, and make it appear, that this eparation proceeded from himelfe: There needed no great artifice to bring this about, for her ickle humour, according to its fleeting temper, did at the very firt aault, quit me for Semires as a little before he had quitted Semires for me: But for all that, the promie which he had given under her hand, and which he could not deny, did exceedingly tick in her tomack. At lat, the Marriage day being come, and I had aembled together all my Parents, my Friends, and Neighbours, I held my elfe o ure, as I thought upon nothing but bidding them welcome. But he, whoe thoughts were quite another away, when we came to the very point of Marriage, he tarted back, and formed excues far wore then her firt; at which I was o extreamly offended, that I went away without ever bidding her adieu; and ever ince I held her in uch didain, that he could never infinuate her elfe again into my eteem.

Judge (reverend Father) whether or no I had good reaon to hearken to her, and whether thoe who peak in my diadvantage be not wrongly informed. Truly, anwered Adamas, he is a woman that is unworthy of her name; and I do wonder, ince he has deluded o many, that any man will ever trut her. Nay Sir, aid Corilas, I have not yet told
you all; for after every one was fallen from her except Lyis, all her artifice was, how to get the promie which he had out of his hands, becaue he aw, that it was a great thorn in her ide: Therefore with an impudent and diembling brow, he thus poke unto him, Is it poible Lyis, (aid he) you hould have lot all that affection which you have o often vowed unto me? Is there no park of love yet left in you? In me, (aid Lyis)? no, I'le ooner die. Upon this word, he went out of the houe; but he followed him o cloe, as he got hold of his hand, and holding it between hers, he brought him back in uch an amorous poture, as any would have judged them to be very loving; and though he knew her deluding humour well enough, yet could he not chue but be pleaed with her flatteries, although he gave no faith unto them; and therefore thus aid unto her, Oh heavens, Stella! why do you o abue thoe favours, which the heavens have o prodigally betowed upon you? Did but that fair body contain a oul that had any neer reemblance unto it, who could poibly reit it? She who knew well enough what charms were in her carrees, did ue all the artifice of her eyes mouth, tongue, and all the invention he had to make him melt, inomuch as he was almot out of himelfe; And at lat he came out with thee words, Lovely Shepheard, (aid he) if you be the ame Lyis who was once o weetly affectionate unto me; I beeech you hearken unto thee words, and believe them: and if you do finde any caue of complaint, I will make it evidently appear, that this which you eteem as a econd fault, was committed only as a remedy for the firt, which I will repair with all poible and deirable atisfaction. Thee mooth words wrought upon Lyis, and did overcome him; yet, not to hew himelfe o imply weak, he anwered thus: Stella, I am o incredulous of all you ay, as I believe not a yllable; and if I knew any thing which would dipleae you, I would do it. If you would dipleae me, aid the Shepheardee, then come into the houe. With that intention, I will, (anwered he). Thus when they were entred into the houe, and tood neer the fire, he began thus; Now Shepheard, will I unmask the Riddle of all my diimulations with you, and make it mot apparent, that poor Stella, whom you have accounted uch a leight huswife, is much more contant then you imagine her, and will let you plainly ee, that in atisfaction of thoe wrongs you have done me, that you have reaon to confee them, and be orry: But, aid he, upon a uddain, what have you done with that promie which once you had of me, in favour of Corilas? for, if you have given it unto him, it will extreamly croe our deignes. Who could poibly imagine, but that after all this, he had loved Lyis? So this Shepheard having an opinion, that he would do that for him, which he had refued me, he retored back unto her that promie, which he had o cloely kept from me. Aoon as ever he aw it, he took it, and tore it all in pieces then threw it into the fire: Afterwards, turning towards Lyis, & laughing, he thus aid unto him, Honet Shepheard, you may now be gon when you pleae, I know none that will hinder you, and it is very late. Oh heavens! (cryed out Lyis, eeing himelfe over-reached) is it poible I hould be o imple, as to be gulled three times by one and the ame peron? What reaon have you to ay, aid Stella, that you are gulled? Oh! mot perfidious woman, (aid he) did you not tell me, that you would make it appear, that your econd fault was committed, only to give atisfaction for the firt? and to hew me that you were contant, you would dicover your very heart and intentions to me? Lyis, aid he, you are till harping upon the wrong tring; pray tell me, wherein have I wronged you, if I did never love you, am I not contant, in not loving you till? And do I not dicover my heart and intentions to you, ince now I have gotten that from you which I deired, I give you free libertie to go home in peace? Could you think that all my words which I have given you for this houre together, tended to any other purpoe, but to get this paper from you? and now I have it, I will bid you good-night, good Lyis. You may imagine what cretfallen Shepheard Lyis was, when he heard all this; he was o damped, that he neaked away, and never gave one word. But ince this, Semires revenged all our quarrells, and he who, as I told you was the caue of my miery, or indeed, my happinee (for o may my eparation from her be called) he, I ay, reenting till the firt affront which he put upon him, and conidering her extream levity, as Lyis and I were erved, o erved he her, and broke off the Marriage with her in the midt of the Congregation which gave many an occaion to ay, That often he who hurts another, receives her punihment by the ame armes.

Thus Corilas concluded: and Adamas in a miling manner aid thus unto him, The bet counell I can give you is to fly this deluder; to beware of her fallacies, and to pleae your Parents who do o much deire to ee you married. When any good match is offered take
it, and never init upon the circumtances of Love; for nothing will ooner wah off thee itains which this giddy woman has cat upon your honour, nor ooner purchae eteem amongt your neighbours, then to marry your elf not by Love but by Reaon: for that is the greatet action of your life; Upon which depends all the happinee or miery of man. Upon thee words they parted towards their everall homes, for it began to be late.

Againe, Leonida not finding Adamas at home, he went away again as oon as ever he had dined: and becaue he was reolved to tay all that night, with thoe fair hepheardees which he had een the day before, out of a deire he had to be more intimately acquainted with them, he went to the place where he found them before; and there he epied one a farre off, but could not dicerne who it was: yet drawing neere he perceived it to be the ame he looked for. She might very well eteem this as a happy meeting: for all thee hepheardees, as chance was, were come out of the Town purpoely to pas away all the ret of the day together, to the end they might more freeely impart their ecrets unto each other out of the reach of all eares. So as Leonida could never have come in a more opportune time to atisfie her curoitie, then he did: and tealing neer them he heard Atrea, ay unto Diana; Now wie hepheardee I hope you will performe your promie unto Phillis and me, in acquainting us with your tory, ince we have imparted ours unto you.

Fair Atrea, anwered Diana, my promie doubtles obligeth me unto it, but much more the amity that is betwixt us; knowing well that amongt friends it is a crime impardonable to conceale any corner of their oules from each other: the only reaon why it is o long before I have given you that atisfaction, beleeve it dear hepheardee, was, becaue time and leaure would not permit it: And though I am certain, that I cannot relate the follies of my youth unto you without many bluhes: yet that dificulty will eaily be over come when I conider that it is to pleae you: Why hould you bluh at all (anwered Phillis) ince it is no crime to Love? If it be not one (replied Diana), yet it is uch a hadow of one, and o reemblant as one is oft taken for the other. Such as are o deceived (anwered Phillis) ure have very ill eyes. Tis very true indeed, (aid Diana) but this is our miery, that there is more bad eyes then good ones: we hall be very angry, aid Atrea, if you think ours uch. The Love I beare unto you both (anwered Diana) may aure you that I cannot make a wrong judgement of you: and I dare trut you with my very oul: But hould I impart my elf o freely unto ome, I hould find my actions meet with a wrong contruction: And therefore ince it is your pleaure and command, that I hould relate my life unto you, I do conjure you both, by all the acred Lawes of friendhip, never to peak of it again. Then both of them proteting to bury all in eternall ilence, he thus began her dicoure.

div.head: The Hitorie of Diana.
div.p:
IT will be very trange Fair and dicreet hepheardees, if this dicoure which you deire hould be related, do not prove tedious unto you, ince the relation I hall make, has not o many words it it, as it hath cot me teares: but ince it is your pleaure I hould revive the ad remembrance of them, I beeech you give me leave to make it as hort as I can. I do aure my elfe, that though you have never eene either Celion or Belinda, yet you have heard that they were my Father and Mother; and perhaps have heard of the croes which they met withall for the Love of one another, which hall pare me the relating of them, though they were preages of my enuing mieries. And be pleaed to know, that after the heats of Love were a little cool'd by marriage, to the end they might not be idle, they began to look narrowly into the buinee of their etate, and had envolved themelves into o many uites of Law, as they were forced to compoe ome of them, by mediation of friends. Amongt the ret, a neighbour of theirs called Phormion, did o trouble them, that to top all thoe gaps, their friends advied them to make ome alliance with him: and becaue neither of them had any children (neither having been long married) they both wore by Theutates upon the Altar of Belinus, that if they had but one Son and one Dauyhter, they hould Marry together: and this promie was confirmed by o many acred oathes, as he who broke them was the mot perjured man in the world. A little after, my Father had a Son, who perihed when the Goths and Otrogoths did ravage this Province. A little after that, I was born, but in uch an unhappy houre for me, that my Father never aw me, he dying before I was born. Phormion, eeing my Father dead, and my Brother lot, (for
thoe barbarians, took him away, and either killed him, or let him tarve for want) and that my Uncle Diamis was gone away in dipleaure at this loe, he reolved if he had a Son, to accomplih their former promie. It happened a little after, that his wife was brought to bed, but it was of a Daughter, and fearing let he hould have no more children by his wife, he caued it to be rumored, that it was a Son, and carried it o cunningly that none knew the contrary. And it was the more eaie to be don, becaue none believed that he would ue any uch tricks: alo, the better to colour the matter, he caued her to be named Philidas. Whom, when he was grown to an age of practiing uch excercies as young hepheards ue he was not ill at them. Phormions deigne was, that eeing me without Father, Brother and Uncle, to make himelf Mater of my etate, by this diembled marriage: and when Philidas and I were growen bigger, then to marry me unto one of his Nephews whom he loved very well: and truly he was not frutrated in his deigne: for Belinda was too religious to be wanting in any duty to her husband. But yet, he eeing me ravihed away and gotten into their hands (for preently upon this pretended marriage, I was eied into Phormions cutody) he did o dilike this coure, as not being able to endure it, he left the Country, and went into the Lake Lemane, to be Mitree of the Vetalls and Druides of Emenes as the aged Cleontine did Propheie by her Oracle. Meane while I was in the hands of Phormion, who preently ent for his Nephew, • upon whom he intended to betow me, whoe name was Amindor: here did begin my griefes: For Phormion his Uncle did let him undertand that by reaon of our nonage, the marriage of Philiduss and me, was not o aured, but that if we two did not well agree, he could well enough break it off: and that if uch a thing hould be, he had rather he hould marry me then any other; therefore he advied him to carry it with o much dicretion as none hould take any notice of it, but till to win upon my affection as much as he could, to the end I might betow my elf upon him when I was free. This young hepheard did o take this deigne to heart, as he neglected no manner of courthip and complacency towards me. At the ame time Daphnis a very handom and dicreet hepheardes returned from the confines of Furan, where he had lived many yeares: and becaue we were neigbours, our converation made us uch friends as I began to be lee dicontented then I was wont: for I mut confee that the humour of Philidas was o dipleaing unto me, as I could hardly endure her: alo her feares of my growing more knowing, made her o jealous of me, that I could hardly peak unto any. Things being upon thee tearms, Phormion fel uddenly ick, and was o oon tuffed with a cattarh that he could neither peak, nor give any order either about his own buinee or mine. Philidas at the firt was a little troubled; but afterwards eeing that he was abolute Mitree of her elf and me alo, he reolved to keep up this authority, conidering that the libertie which the name of Man doth carry with it, was much more pleaing then the ervitude of our ex. Nor was he inenible of that wonder which would be over all the Country, when he hould declare her elfe to be a woman: upon thee reaons, he continued in the ame name and notion, which he did when her Father was alive; and fearing more then ever, let ome hould dicover what he was, he kept me o neer her, as he was eldom or never without me. But, Fair hpheardees ince you mut know all my young follies. I mut firt begge your excues, and that you will know, I had o great an inclination to Love, another way: but that my heart was o hardned againt Philadis and Amindor as love had not armes or arrowes trong and harpe enough to peirce o much as my skin. But alas, it was the hepheard Filander, who had my heart; Filander who having given me ome aurance of his love, and now not being, has carried with him all that was mine; urely (aid Atrea, and interrupted her) either Filanders affection was very little, or ele you did carry it with a great deale of prudence for I never o much as heard of it. Which is a thing very trang. That it was not talked of, anwered Diana, I am more obliged unto your good intentions then our prudence. And as for the affection of this hepheard, you may judge what it was, by my enuing dicoure. And the heavens, who know our pure and cleere intentions, had a mind to favour them. The firt time I ever aw him, was upon that day which we celebrated unto Apollo and Diana, when he came into thoe ports in the company of a Siter, o extreamly like him that the eies of all the aembly were upon them. And becaue he was neerely allyed unto my dear friend Daphnis, as oone as I aw her, I did o imbrace and carree her as ever ince he thought her elf obliged to love me; Her name was Callirea, and was married unto a hepheard called Geretan, upon the confines of Furan, whom he had never een untill the very day he married him, which was a reaon why there was but a very flender affection between them. My complacence to the Siter gave occaion
unto the Brother to tand by me, as long as the acrifice lated; and I cannot tell, whether to his good or bad fortune, but I had that day dreed up my elfe in my bet trim, conceiving that my very name upon this feat, did more particularly oblige me to it, then any other. And he, being a tranger, and having no other acquaintance amongt the Shepheards and Shepheardees, than uch as his Siter brought him, did not leave us all that day: So as, I conceiving my elfe in ome ort obliged to entertain him, I did what I could to pleae him, and my labour was not lot; for, from that time, this poor Shepheard did begin uch affection to me as did not end till he died: And I am mot confident, that if the dead have any remembrance of the living, he loves me till; and in his ahes preerves that pure affection which he vowed unto me. Daphnis took notice of this, the very ame day, and at night told me of it; but I did o long reject any uch thoughts, as he was forced to ay thus unto me. I ee, Diana, you will not believe me; but, be aured, that Filander does extreamly love you. This advertiment did o imprint it elfe in my minde, as the next day made me oberve omthing, which induced me to be of her opinion: For, in the afternoons, we were accutomed to aemble under ome hady tree, and itting round, to ing. It chanced, that Filander having no acquaintance but Daphnis and me, he did it down between us, which Amindor taking notice of, did well with uch a pittifull fit of jealouie, that he, in a fuming chafe, left the company; and firt looking upon me, as if it were I that he meant, he went away, inging this Catch.

lg.l: God, in his mercy, may do much, and ave her;
But he that commeth next is ure to have her.
Can any be o blinde,
As think to get her Love;
Who wavers like the winde,
Which wantonly doth rove?
No, God in's mercy may do much and ave her,
But he that cometh next is ure to have her.
A Weather-cock can move
At every blat of winde;
And he at any love,
Can turne her fleeting minde.
So God in's mercy may do much and ave her;
But he that commeth next is ure to have her.
One Nail drives out another,
And he that next does kie her,
Will quite drive out the other,
And make the firt to mie her.
God, in thy mercy, I beeech thee make her
In Love more contant; ele, the Devill take her.

div.p: I had o much power over my elfe, as not to eem any thing troubled at this ong; and Daphnis out of her dicreet affection unto me, never taying the end of this Catch, did interrupt him, and begun another ong, addreing her elfe unto me.

lg.head: The Madrigall of Daphnis, upon the affection he bore unto Diana.

lg.l: SInce, fair Diana, I do finde you prove

l.hi: The Center, unto which all hearts do move:
Then, why not mine? why hould I not adore
Her, that of beautles hath the greatet tore.
And ince they ay, the puret Love of all,
Hath from reemblance its Originall:
Then our affections needs mut be extream,
Since both our Sexes are the very ame.

div.p: Then, the better to cover the colour of my cheeks, and to make it eem, I took no notice of Amindor's invective Catch; aoon as Daphnis had done, I anwered her thus.

lg.head: A Madrigall, upon the ame Subject.
lg.l: WHy uch a wonder hould it eem, that I
And you, though both be women, yet hould vie
Affection? Is't a miracle to ee,
That women well as men hould Lovers be?
But if impoible; Oh, then be you
The Shepheardee, and I the Shepheard true.

div.p: After us, every one ung their own fancies; and Filander when it came to his turn, he did ing thee enuing Veres with an excellent voice.

lg.head: Filander, upon the begining of his Love.

lg.l: THough I foreaw my expectation high,
And my deires; were well'd with vanity:
That Love was full of flaming fire and pain;
And though I lov'd, hould not be lov'd again:
Yet till I hoped, and at her I aim'd,
Only becaue I would be more inflam'd.
'Twas o decreed by fate, and 'twas not I
That could anticipate my detinie:
No wonder then; that in obedience
Unto this dire and fatall Ordinance,
I hould adore her, and, I hope, no crime:
A heart that's bae o high could never clime.
But as the fading Marygold doth die,
And wither only by the world's fair Eye:
So I, like it, did ay, Oh! glorious Sun,
Let me be corched, till my daies be done:
For in that death, this pleaure I hall have,
No fire but thine could burn me to my grave.
When as the Phoenix, by an art o rare,
And nature, both together, doth prepare;
To make her Cradle in her Tombe, he aies
Unto the fire, wherein her corps he laies,
By dying in thy flame I will aume
My glory out of ahes, now my Tombe.

div.p:
Many more did then expree their everall conceptions in vere, but I have forgotten them: But o it was, that me thought Filanders words were aimed at me, and I cannot well tell, whether it was the hint which Daphnis had given me, or the language of his eyes, which poke much more plain then his tongue: I cannot tell, but either the one, or both, made me apply this ong to my elfe; and as thee veres did give me a little light of it, o his dicretion did a little after, much more plainly tetifie it unto me: For, it is the principall effect of a true affection, to carry it dicreetly, and never to let it be known, but by thoe effects which cannot be hid. This young Shepheard knew of Amindor's humour, and love had taught him o much curioity, as to finde out, that his jealouy was no lee than that of Philidas; and therefore he conceived, that the bet way to blinde both their
eyes, was, to court their friendhip: and Love had made him o ubtle and prudent, that in the carriage of the matter, he did not only deceive Amindor's, but almot all eyes ele; for he would never come where we were, but uffered us alwaies to come unto him. 'Tis true, that crafty Daphnis did preently finde it out; for, aid he, Amindor is not a man of uch agreeable parts, as to attract unto him uch a well accomplihed Shepheard as Filander, but there mut needs be ome farther reach in all Filanders addrees to him; he indeed did prompt me to take the firt notice of it, and I mut confee, that his dicretion did o pleae me, that if I would uffer any to love me, it hould be him; but, the time was not yet come, that I could be wounded this way, although his actions and carriage did pleae me, and though I did in ome fore approve of his deigne. When we at any time took our leaves of him, he would alwaies wait upon us a long way; and at parting, I never heard uch expreions of friendhip, as he ued to Amindor; nor uch offers of ervice, as he tendred unto Philidas: Then would lie Daphnis whiper me in the ear, and ay, All thee expreions are meant unto you, and you do him wrong if you do not anwer him. And when he thanked Amindor for any favour, he would ay, Oh what a fool is he, to think, that thee offerings are intended to his Altar? And he o well knew how to diemble, that he erued himelfe into the very heart of Amindor: And Philidas was o tickled with his high commendations of her, as he would often end, to deire him he would come & ee her. Heavens knowes, how oft he had olicited for this opportunity, for it was as much as he could deire, thinking his deigne could not poibly have a better beginning. As fortune was, one day when Daphnis and I were walking under ome hady trees, and talked our elves almot quite out of dicoure, we heard a voice, which at the firt we thought to be of ome tranger; the deire of knowing who it was, made us draw towards the place, and Daphnis going firt, he epied Filander before me, and beckned unto me, that I hould tread gently; and when I was come neer her, he named Filander in a low voice, who was laid down, leaning his head againt a tree, and began thus, I hould defie and corn Love, and all his policies and charms, did he not make ue of my fairet Diana's armes againt me. And o went on.

When I heard my elfe named, fair Shepheardees, I trembled, and trode upon the ground, as if a Serpent were under my feet; and without any longer tay, I went away as gently as I could, let I hould be een, though Daphnis, in hopes to make me come again, did let me go by my elfe: At lat, he eeing I continued on my way he alo tole oftly off, and afterwards ran after me as fat me as fat as he could, and, when he could hardly draw her breath, he chid me in a very interrupted manner; but when he had recovered her wind and could peak plain, he thus aid unto me: As I live Diana, if the heavens do not punih you, I hall think they are unjut: Could you be o cruell, as not o much as to lend him a hearing? What good could I do unto him, (aid I) by taying any longer there? You might have heard what hurt you have don him, aid he unto me. I do him hurt, anwered I? you do me wrong, in aying I could hurt one whom I never thought upon. Therein, aid he, you hurt him mot; for, did you ofter think upon him, you could not chue but be moved unto pitty. I bluhed at that word, and the changing of my colour did make Daphnis believe, that I was offended with her, and therefore in a miling manner, he aid unto me, I did but jeat, Diana, and do not believe he thought upon you; and as for uing your name, I believe he meant ome other of the ame name that yours is. Thus we went on talking and walking we knew not whither, untill another path had brought us unto the ame place, where Filander was; and though I did it out of heedlenee, yet Daphnis perhaps did it out of deigne, however, I was forced to look upon him lying upon the ground, leaning his head upon his arme, and eeming as if he were awake; for he had a Letter before him, all wet with tears which trickled down his cheeks: but, indeed he was aleep and we were more aured of it, when Daphnis, more conident then I, tooped gently down, and brought me the Letter, all teeped in tears, which ight did much move me to pitty, and much more the Letter, which was thus written.

body.head: Filanders Letter unto Diana.
body.p:
THoe who have the honour to ee you, do run a mot dangerous piece of fortune: If they do love you, then they are too bold; and if they do not, then they have no judgment, your perfections being uch, as, with reaon, they can neither be loved nor not loved; and
I being contrained to fall into one of thee two errors, have choen that which is mot congruent to my humour, and from it, it is imposible to retreat. Do not take it ill, fair Diana, that ince it is an abolute imposibility to look upon you, and not love, that ince I have een you, I do o. If my rahnee do merit punihment, remember, that I had rather love you, and die, than live, and not love you. But alas! why do I ay, I had rather? as if it were in my choice; for I mut out of a fatall neceitie be your mot humble ervant, and you mut be what you are, which is, the fairet Shepheardee that ever lived: So as without any Rathers, I mut both live and die under this fatall, Mut.

div.p:
I had no ooner read this Letter, but, with a trembling hand, I returned it, and Daphnis did gently put it in the place where he found it: he came oftly off without waking him, and coming unto me, who tood a pretty ditance off; I pray, weet Diana, aid he unto me, give me leave to peak freely unto you. Our friendhip Daphnis (anwered I) does give you that power without the asking. Then, Diana, aid he, I mut tell you, that I do pitty Filander with all my heart, for mot certainly he loves you; and your own oul, I'me ure cannot deny it. Daphnis, (aid I unto her) let the faulty do the penance. If o, aid he, then I'me ure that Filander mut not: for, I cannot allow it any fault to love you, but, I believe, his fault had been much greater if he had not loved you; for fair ones were made only to be loved. I dare appeal unto your judgment, anwered I, whether I can pretend unto that title. But however, I do conjure you by our friendhip, not to let him undertand that I have any knowledge of his intention; and if you do love him, advie him never to mention it unto me: For eteeming both him and Callirea his Siter, as I do, I hould be very orry to banih him our company, which, you know, I hould be forced unto, if ever he peak of it unto me. How then would you have him to live, aid he unto me? I would have him live, replied I, as he did before he ever aw me. But that he cannot do, replied he, for then he was not corched with thoe flames which now do burn him. Then, aid I, let him eek ome remedy to quench thoe flames, without offending me. The fire is great, added he, and will not be quenched. Be the fire as great as it will, aid I, it will not burn him, if he will not come neer it. Although, anwered he, the burned ue to flie the fire; yet, if he do flie, he will carry his fire with him, and the pain too. In concluion I told her, that if it was o, then let him burn on, for I could not help him. With uch dicoure as this we returned towards our flocks, and at night to our lodgings, where we found Filander o carreed by Philidas, and Amindor alo, that Daphnis believed he had bewitched them, it not being their humours to ue others o. He tayed many daies amongt us, and all that while, he made not the leat hew of any thing unto me, but lived in uch a dicreet manner, that had not Daphnis and Ieen, what we did, we had never entertained the leat upition of his intention. At lat he was forced to depart, and not knowing what to reolve upon, he went unto his Siters houe, for he loved her, and had as great a confidence in her, as in himelfe. This Shepheardee, as I told you, was married by force, and had no other contentment, but in the friendhip of her Brother: As oon as ever he aw him, after the firt alute, he was very inquiitive to know from whence he came: and he anwering, that he came from Philidas, he asked him how Daphnis and I did: And he telling her alo, peaking very highly in my commendations; he whipered him in the ear, and aid, I am afraid Brother, that you do love her better then you do me. He anwered, that indeed he did love me, as my merits did oblige him to do. Then I have gueed right, (aid he) for I know not a Shepheardee in the whole world, that is owner of more merit; and I mut confee, that were I a man, I would, whether he would or no, devote my elfe her ervant. May I believe Siter, aid he, that you peak this in good earnet? Yes truly Brother, anwered he, I will wear it, by that which is mot dear unto me. Then I do believe, replied he, that if you were a man, you would have a hard task in hand; for, I perceive her to be of an humour that is not eaily bended: Moreover, Philidas and Amindor are o deadly jealous of her, as one or both of them are never out of her ight. Oh deare Brother (cryed he out) I plainly ee that you are taken, ince you have o preciely oberved thee particulars, I do beeech you conceal it no longer from me: for Love, if it be a fault is very pardonable: and he was o importunate, that, after a thouand protetations and uplications never to impart it, he confeed it unto her, and in uch paionate expreions, as he could not poibly doubt it. And when he asked him how I received this declaration? Oh heavens, aid he unto her, did you but know her humour you would ay that never any did undertake a more difficult peece of buinee. All
that I have done hitherto, is to blind the eyes of Philidas and Amindor, making them beleeve there is none in the world more theirs then I am; and I have o well thriven in my deigne upon them, as they were never well but when I was with them: then he made a report of all the paages unto her. But aid he, though I did intend to dicover unto Diana, how much I was hers, yet uch an awing power he had over me, as I never durt, and I am afraid I never hall, only unlee a long continued practie hould embolden me, for otherwie it cannot be, but Philidas and Amindor will take notice of it: So as, deare Siter, to tell you my condition, it is to tell you, that I am the very next dore unto depair. Callirea who loved her Brother above all the world, was o enible of his pain, that after he had a while thought upon it, he aid thus unto him. Brother, will yoube pleaed to let me contribute my good will towards your atisfaction, and render you a tetimonie of my forwardnee to erve you? Dear Siter, anwered he, though in this or any other buinee, I make no doubt of your good will: yet I am afraid of the uccee; how ever I hall entertaine any thing which comes from you.

Then Brother, aid he, I will go this way to work; you know what a reemblance there is between our faces, our tatures, and our peech, and were it not for a difference in habit, even thoe that are continually with us, will take the one for the other: Now ince the bet way to compae your deign, is to keep about Diana without upition, can a more eaie and ecret way be devied, then for you to be taken for a woman? So may you keep Diana company without giving the leat upition of jealouie unto Philidas, and I may returne unto Geretan in your habit unto whom I will make an excue and ay that Daphnis and Diana kept you with them by force. All the difficulty will be to get his leave to go unto them, which I doubt will be very hardly obtained. Dear Siter, aid Filander, I never made any doubt of your wit or dearnes to me; and now I find you to be the bet Siter that ever man had, ince you are pleaed to take this paines upon you, which I mot humbly beeech you to do, and know, that it is the only way that can keep a Brother alive who loves you above himelfe. Then did he imbrace her with all poible acknowledgments of obligation, which made her more willing to erve him then before: at lat, he aid thus unto him: Sweet Brother let us leave words to them that love lee, and let us think how to put our buinee into action. I hope, aid he, it will eaily be effected, if you can but obtain your Husbands leave, which I hope will alo be effected, if you pretend that your journey is only with intentions to bring the match about, betwixt Amindor and his Neece, which he does very much deire, and telling him that you make no doubt, but that you with the help of Daphnis hall in time bring it to pae. But what coure hall we take with our hair? for yours is too long, and mine too hort, and therefore I doubt will much trouble us: Never take care for that, aid I unto him: for yours is long enough to be dreed up like mine; and I will circumcie mine into your cut. But, dear Siter, aid he unto her, will it not grieve you to part o with your hair? No Brother, anwered he, there is nothing o dear unto me, which I would not part with to procure your contentment, though it were my very skin. At this word he imbraced her, and told her that next unto god he would be his great deliverer from his torments. Then Filander, to loe no time, tooke the firt opportunitie that offered it elfe, of talking with Geretan, repreenting unto him the advantage and feaibilitie of bringing this match about: and becaue Filander deired o much time as to let his hair grow a little longer, he pretended a journey about the dipatch of ome buines, and would hortly return. But Philidas no ooner heard of Philanders return, than he went to viit him accompanied only with Amindor, and would not part with him before they brought him unto us, where he tayed eaven or eight dayes and was not any bolder to declare himelfe unto me than at the firt.

During which time, to hew how hard a thing it is to contrain nature long; although Philidas did counterfeit the Man as well as he could for her life, yet was he forced to reent the paions of a woman: and the addrees and merits of Filander wrought uch effects in her, as he deired they had wrought in me.

Thus the poor Philidas was o much beides her elf, that he could not live out of Filanders fight, and did apply her elfe o unto him, as did amaze him, and had not his deires of being neer me retrayned him, he would never have endured that kind of life. At lat when he thought his hair was reaonably well grown, he returned to Geretan, and told him that he had already broken the Ice of the buinee, but Daphnis, did think it expedient to ee his Neece before he poke in the buinee, and likewie that Amindor alo aw her, and therefore he thought the bet coure was to let Callirea carry her thither, and he to
hew her elfe as complaiant as he could unto Amindor and the ret.

Geretan who deired nothing more then to be rid of his Neece did hearken unto this propoition with a very willing eare and did peremptorily command his wife to make her elf ready for the voyage, who to make him more eager upon it, did eem to be a little unwilling, and hewed ome ignes of orrow to part from her Husband, aying that uch buinee as this, might be wel enough effected without her, and that it would take up a great deale of time, which might better be pent in her houhould affaires. But Geretan who would have her will to yeeld to his in all things, was o extreamly hot upon the matter, that three dayes after, he departed with her Brother and her Neece. The firt dayes Jorney was to Filanders, where they changed habits, which o well fitted each other, that even thoe in their company could not perceive the change: And I mut confee I was deceived as wel as they, and found no manner of difference betwixt them. But well might I be deceived, when Philidas was, who looked upon him with the eyes of Love, which they ay are more obervant then all the eyes of Linx: for as oon as they came, he left the faigned Callirea, I mean Filander, and carried the true into a chamber to ret her elf. All the way as they came, Filander intructed his Siter in all paages, and how he hould find the perons with whom he was to tranact; now though Callirea was reolved to undergo all difficulties, for her Brothers contentment: yet thinking Philidas to be a man, it went much againt the hair of her mind to talk with her. As for us, when Daphnis and I were retired, we treated Filander with all the civilities that are ued amongt women, I mean, uch as either amitie or privacie requires, which that hepheard did receive with much Jollitie; and as he hath ince worn to me, he was almot tranported beides himelfe. Had I not been a meer child in matter of obervation, certainly his actions and behaviour would have dicovered him unto me: but the truth was, hee did counterfeit the matter o exceeding well, that Daphnis was deceived as well as I: while we retired into our chambers after upper Callirea and Philidas did walk into the chamber. I know not what their dicoure was, but ours was nothing but aurance of amitie and cordiall expreions of affection, which Filander ued in uch a paionate way as it was eaie to judge, that though he would have aid nothing, yet he could not be blamed for want of any good wil, but for the want of boldnee.

For my part I was extreamly free in my expreions alo; for beleeving him to be a woman, I thought my elfe to be obliged unto it, by his expreions of good will to me, by his merits, and by the kindred of her and Daphnis.

From this time, Amindor, who before bore me much good will, began to change his affection & to love the faigned Callirea: And Filander fearing his demeans would not pleae this young man, did trive as much as poibly he could to comply with him: and the fleeting humour of Amindor, would not let him receive uch favours, without being in Love. Which I do not at all think trange: For the beauty, the judgement, and deportment of Filander was uch, as that he came nothing hort in the perfections of a woman, o as he might well delude any man.

Oberve what a wanton Love is; and how he ports and pends his time! He made Philidas who was a woman to love a woman, and Amindor who was a man to love a man, and that o extream paionatly that this very particular was ubject enough to dicoure of. Filander he knew how to play the woman mot admirably; and Callirea did o well counterfeit her Brother, and neither of them wanted prudence to carry out the matter.

That cold demeanure which Callirea hewed unto me, removed all caues of jealouie out of Philidas, and beides Philidas did love her; and I mut confee, that eeing her o fall off from Philidas, from Daphnis, and from me, we had an opinion, that Filanders mind was changed: at which I much rejoyced, by reaon of the amity I bore unto his Siter. Seaven or eight dayes were thus pent, and none did think them one jot too long; for, every one of us had a particular deigne. But Callirea, who feared, let her Husband hould be angry at this long tay, did olicit her Brother to make known his deign unto me, telling him, that it was not likely I hould refue his ervice, ince he bad been o familiar with me: But for all that, he had not yet the confidence to declare himelfe: Yet, to delude Geretan, he deired her to go unto her Husband in that dree wherein he was, auring her, that he could not finde any difference between them; and to let him undertand that by the advice of Daphnis, he had left Callirea with Philidas, to treat with Amindor about the marriage of his Niece.

This propoition at the firt did atonih his Siter; for, her Husband was a piece of angry fleh, and the leat digut would move him unto paion. At the lat, her deires to content her Brother in every thing, did move her to yield unto the motion: And to render this excue more colourable, they did peak unto Daphnis concerning Amindors marriage, which, for divers coniderations, he rejected; but, knowing that this buinee was their pretence, under which they got leave to come this journey, and without which they never had obtained it; Daphnis, who was well pleaed with their company, did communicate the matter unto me; and we all agreed, that the bet way was, to eem, as if the project were feaible: And in order to that, Daphnis did write unto Geretan, adviing him to let his Wife to tay a little longer amongt us, the better to effect the buinee, and that he hoped all things would be brought to a happy iue.

Upon this Embaie, and thus clad, Callirea went unto her Husband, who being beguiled by her dree, as well as the ret, he took her for her Brother, and liked the caue of his wifes tay o well, that he willingly conented unto the motion upon thoe termes. Judge, fair Shepheardees, whether I might not well be deceived, ince her own Husband was, and could not ditinguih them.

Now, Filanders affection grew to that height, that he could no longer conceal it, do what he could; and therefore he told me, that though he was a woman, yet he could not chue, but be extreamly in love with me, and hould be much more, were he a man; and expreed himelfe o very paionately, that Daphnis, who loved me very well, did ay, that untill then, he never knew it; but that he her elfe was alo in love me: which was no tranger, then that Philidas hould love Filander. And this diguied Callirea proteted, that the chiefe reaon why he did contrain her Brother to go, was this match which was propounded; for which many o reaons were hewed me, that I eaily believed it to be o. Being thus atisfied with this excue, he poke of her paion unto me, without any difficulty, but till as a woman and vowing unto me, that the very ame reentments and paions which ue to be in men that were in love, were in her, and that it was a great conolation unto her to expree them.

Twelve or fifteen daies thus paed, with o much delighting atisfaction unto Filander, as he hath ince worn unto me, that he never pent his daies more happily, although his deires did well him with abundance of impatiency, which yet did daily augment his paion: And pleaing himelf in thee thoughts, he would very often walk alone to entertain them: Now, becaue he was eldome from us in the day time, he would often make ue of the night, when he thought all aleep, and go into the Garden, where, under ome trees, he would enjoy his thoughts; and uing often to go out thus, Daphnis took notice of it, who lay in the ame Chamber: And as commonly the wore, rather then the better, is upected, he was jealous of Amindor and her; but, for her atisfaction he would watch; and watched o, that eeing the diguied Callirea go out of his Bed, he followed him by the light of the Moon into the Garden, where jut under my Chamber window, he aw him it down, and lifting up his eyes unto heaven, he heard him ay thus aloud:

l.hi: Even as the Moon doth quite outhine,
And dimn another tar;

q.l: So my Diana, mot divine,

l.hi: Trancends all beauties far.

div.p:
Though Filander uttered thee words loud enough, yet Daphnis was o far off, that he could not hear, but here and there a word, and therefore he tepped neerer as gently as he could, though he was o taken up with his own imagination, that, had he walked before him, he had hardly een her, as ince he told me. Aoon as he had gotten her elfe neer him, o as he could hear him igh, he heard him ay in a low voice to himelfe, How unreaonable is my partiall fate, that hath made her worthy of all ervices, and yet me not worthy to erve her? And that he hould not accept of their affections who do love her; yet, to inpire them with extream paions. Ah Callirea! how pernitious proves thy plot unto thy tranquillitie? and how art thou punihed for thy bold preumption? Daphnis did hearken unto Filander very attentively; but though he poke loud and ditinct enough, yet, her prejudicated conceit of his being Callirea, would not uffer her to comprehend his meaning: But afterwards her curious ear heard him utter thee words, But Oh, preumptuous Filander, what excue caut thou finde for thy fault? and what punihment
can equall thy offence? Thou dot love this Shepheardee, yet, how durt thou be o imprudently bold, as to offer this injury unto her? At this word he topt; but till his eyes and his ighs did expree the extremity of his paion: And to divert his ad thoughts, or rather to flatter them, he tarted up upon a uddain to walk, and pied Daplnis, though he, to conceal her elfe, did run away; but, becaue he was reolved to know who it was, he ran after her, and at the corner of the little wood overtook her; and thinking that now he had dicovered all, which he had o cloely concealed, in a kinde of halfe anger, he aid unto her, What, Daphnis, makes you o full of curioity, as o to pie out my actions in the night? It is (anwered Daphnis in a miling manner) to get that out of you by craft, which otherwie I could not: And this he thought he had poken unto Callirea, not having yet dicovered that he was Filander. Well then (replied Filander, thinking he had been dicovered) what great Novelties have you learn'd by it? All, aid Daphnis, that I deire to know. Then (aid Filander) your curioity is ufficiently atisfied. So well, anwered he, that I ee, all your diligence about Diana, and all the great affection which you make a hew of unto her, will in the end be repayed with grief and vekation. Oh heavens! (cryed out Filander) I ee I am dicovered: But wie and dicreet Daphnis, ince you do now know the caue of my being here with Diana, you have in your hands both my life and my death: But urely if you do conider how much I am yours, and how ready I was ever to erve you upon all occaions, I hope you rather wih my contentment and happinee, than my depair and ruine. Daphnis till thought it to be Callirea that poke, and had a conceit, that all thee fears proceeded from Geretan, who would have taken it very ill, his Wife hould do any uch office for her Brother; but to atisfie him, he aid, Callirea, you need not to make any quetion of me; for, I am o well acquainted with your buinee, that I would have contributed my bet counell and aitance, though you had never poke unto me; but, that I may the better erve you, I beeech you acquaint me with the whole buinee, to the end your freedome towards me, may the more oblige me, and your mitrut of me may not offend me. I will, dear Daphnis, aid he, upon condition you promie me to ay nothing unto Diana, untill I conent unto it. This requet, anwered the Shepheardee, might have been well pared; for uch is her humour, that I would never advie you to trut her with it. Hence is my griefe, aid Filander; for I do already o well know it, that I do think my deigne almot an impoibility: For at the firt, when my Siter and I reolved to change habits, he auming mine, and I hers, I did then foreee that all the advantage I hould get by it, was, that I might with more freedome be neer her a while in that diguie, and not be taken for Filander. How's this (aid Daphnis, all amazed) for Filander? Are not you Callirea? The Shepheard, who thought he had known him before, was now very orry that he had o rahly dicovered himelfe; but eeing it was now pat, and that there was no revocation of his words, he bethought himelfe how to make the bet ue of it he could, and therefore aid thus unto her, You ee Daphnis, that I do cleerly trut you with all my hopes, and have freely dicovered the greatet ecret of my oul unto you; a ecret of uch importance, that if any beides your elfe hould know it, all my hopes are dead fore ever; therefore I do put my elfe, and all my happinee into your hand, o, as you mut either become my friend, or ele I mut die. Know therefore Daphnis, that here you ee before you Filander, in the habit of his Siter; and that love in me, and compaion in her, hath caued us thus to diguie our elves. Afterward he related unto her his extream affection, his compliance with Amindor and Philidas, the invention of Callirea, her reolution to go unto her. Husband in a mans habit: and, in hort, all the paages, with all poible demontrations of love: So as though Daphnis did wonder at the bold attempt of him, and his Siter; yet, he aw the grandure of his affection, which might well lead him unto uch follies: Yet, had he been of their counell at the firt, he would not have advied unto this enterprize; but, eeing things did hit o happily, he reolved to aid him all that poibly he could, and to pare no pains nor care to effect his deires: After which promies, with many aurances of amitie, he gave him the bet advice he could, which was, to ininuate himelfe by degrees into my affection For, aid he, the very word of Love does more offend a woman, than the thing it elfe doth; and it is alwaies very welcome unto any, o the name of it be hid. Therefore I think them to be well advied, who do make themelves loved of their Mitrees, before ever they peak of Love; for Love is a thing dipleaing only in the name, though in it elfe it be agreeable unto all. And therefore, that you may finde a more favourable reception from Diana, you mut not o much as name Love, no, nor to let her ee
it, but mut carry the matter o dicreetly, that he may firt love you, as oon as ever he hall know that you love her; for, he being once embarqued, he cannot afterwards retire to the Port, although he hould ee a torm in coming. Me thinks hitherto you have carried it with very much prudence, but you mut till continue it: The eeming to be in love with her, although you eem a woman, is to very good purpoe; for certainly, any Love that is once uffered, will in the end produce a reciprocall return.

We ee, that we do many things with much facility, which would eem full of difficulty, if the cutome of doing them, did not render them eaie unto us. Meats unaccutomed, are often at the firt diguted, which afterwards are pleaant by ue. An ear that is accutomed to Muick, will tune the voice higher or lower unto a right harmonious cadency; when one that is not ued to the Art, will make a jar. So a Shepheardee, who often heares the well tun'd talk of a Lover, will, in time, make her oul ply unto the harmoy of it and in time, will incline inenibly to the reentments of Love; my meaning is he will love the company of that peron, and by little and little begin to pitty his pain and at lat, before he be aware, will love him. Judge Filander, by thee intructions, whether or no I love you, and have pitty of you, ince I do dicover unto you the ecrets of our School: and receive this advice as an earnet of what I deire to do for you.

With uch dicoure as this, the day beginning to draw on, they returned into the houe, laughing at the love of Amindor, who took him for a woman: And falling aleep again, to recompene the lat nights loe, they did lie in bed long in the morning, which gave the young Amindor an opportunity of urpriing them; and had not I entred at the ame time into the chamber, I believe the jugling had been dicovered: for, he going to the uppoed Callirea's bed-ide, his love began to be a little too licentious, and his rah & indicreet hands had like to have gon too far; but, Daphnis deired me to take him off, & to part them; which I did, with no mall contentment to Filander, who, by way of thanks, kied my hand o affectionately, as if I had any ene in me, I might have known him to be really in love. Afterwards, bidding them good morrow, I carryed Amindor away with me, that they might have time to dree themelves. And becaue they intended to put their propoed deigne into execution, preently after dinner, when we all, according to our cutome, aembled under a hade of trees, to enjoy the cool air; although Amindor was there, yet, Daphnis conceived the opportunity to be good: for, to hear uch dicoure in his preence • would remove all manner of upition, and he would not think it trange, if afterwards he hould by chance hear Filander peak like a man unto me. Daphnis then beckening unto Filander, to the end he hould econd her in the deigne, he thus aid unto him, What is it, Callirea, that makes you o mute in Diana's company? The reaon is, anwered he, becaue I am thinking what wihes I hould make, that might make me more ervicable unto my Mitree; and amongt the ret, I had one, which, I think, I ought not to deire. What is it, aid Amindor? It is, aid Filander, that I were a man that I might render more acceptable ervice unto the fair Diana. Why, aid Daphnis, are you in love with her? Yes, anwered Filander, and infinitely more then I am with all the world beides. I hould ooner wih (aid Amindor) that you were a woman again, both for my ake, and for Philidas. It is not the conideration of either of them (aid Filander) hall make me change my wih, Why, (aid Daphnis) do you think that Diana would love you better? I hould hope o, aid Filander, and the Lawes of Nature would oblige her to it; unlee, as in her beauty he trancends her power, o he hould in, her humour didain her ordinances. You may think what you pleae of me, (aid I unto him) but if you will believe me, there is not a man upon earth that I do love more then you. Alo, replyed he, there is none that breathes, which is more devoted to your ervice then I But fair Diana, that happinee you mention, will lat no longer, then untill you hall dicover the poornee of my merit; or, untill ome better object preent it elfe. Do you think me, replied I, of uch a wavering temper? It is not, Fairet, that I think you guilty of the in of incontancy, replied he; but it is becaue I am concious, that the fault is in my elfe. The fault is more on my ide, anwered I: And upon this word, I did embrace him, and kie him, with as much incere affection, as if he had been my iter. Hereupon Daphnis miled in her elfe, to ee me o deceived. But Amindor, jealous (as I think) of us both, did interrupt us; I think (aid he) that all this is in good earnet, and that Callirea does not diemble. I diemble, aid he? Heaven punih me more then ever perjury was punihed, if ever any love was more paionate or incere, than mine to Diana. If you were a man, (aid Daphnis) do you think you could expree your paion
in the language of a man? Though I mut confee (aid he,) that my wit and eloquence is but very hallow; yet I beleeve I hould not tand mute upon uch an occaion, for my extream affection would prompt me, & upply all other defects. I beeech you, fair one' (aid Amindor) let us ee how you could behave your elfe upon uch an occaion. If my Mitris will give me leave (aid Filander) I will; but yet upon condition that he will grant me three requets: The firt is, that he will anwer unto what I hall ask her: The econd, that he will not think, what I hall preent unto her under another peron then Callirea, to be fained, but take them as mot reall and true, though impuiant paions. And the lat is, that he will never permit any but my elfe to erve her in this kind. I eeing every one delighted with the motion, and alo really loving Filander under the notion of his Siter, did anwer him, that for his econd and lat requet, they were granted as oon as deired; but as for the firt, I was o unaccutomed to anwer all quetions, as I was ure they would be but unpleaing. Yet becaue I would not be refractory in any thing, I aid that I would acquit my elfe as well as I could. Upon this word he took me by the hand, and began thus.

I could never have beleeved, Fair Mitris, conidering the trancendency of your perfections, that any mortall durt have loved you, had I not experimentally found in my elfe, that it is impoible to look upon you and not Love. But knowing the heavens to be more Jut than to impoe impoibilities upon any, I tooke it for granted, that they would have you loved, becaue they uffered you to be een. In this beleefe, I aumed the boldnee to look upon you, which I had no ooner done, but my heart immediatly ubmitted. The Law permits one to goe and dipoe of their own; take it not ill, Fair hepheardee, that I give you my heart, which if you refue, I hall for ever diavow it to be mine. Here he topped, to ee if I would anwer him; but in uch a manner, that had not his habit diguied him, I could not have doubted but that he was in good earnet. And becaue I would be as good as my promie, I anwered him thus; Shepheardee, were all thee high applauds which you betow upon me true, perhaps then I hould think they proceeded from your affection to me; but knowing them to be meer flatteries, I mut needs think the ret no better then diimulation.
