This, Fair one, aid he, does too much diparage your judgement for it is impoible to make any doubt of your perfections and merit, but I rather think, that perhaps you are ued with uch excues to deny uch things as you are not pleaed to grant. But I am able and with all truth to wear, by Teutates, and all thats holy (and you may know I am not forworne) that you did never in all your life refue any thing that was given you with a more incere and perect good will. I do know very well, anwered I, that the hepheards of this Country are accutomed to uch language as has little truth in it, nor do they think that the gods will punih all the perfidious oathes of eeming lovers. Whether or no it be the peculiar vice of your hepheards (aid he) I referre it unto your knowledge. But for my elfe who am not of this country, I am not guilty either of their hame or crime: but will out of your mot cruell words draw ome atisfaction to my elfe. If the gods do punih the oaths of perfidious lovers, and if I be guiltiy, then the gods will end the punihment of perjurie upon me: and if they do not, then you mut be forced to confee, that ince I am not punihed, I am no lyer. And if I be no lyer, then you mut confee I am your lover. So let your wit turne it which way you will, it cannot be denyed but that you are the fairet upon earth, or ele there is none in it; and that your beauty is infinitly adored, by that hepheard who preents himelfe before you, and who implores your favour, which he thinks he may merit, if a mot perfect love could ever do it. Whether I am fair or no, replyed I, I will be judged by any indifferent eyes: but how ever you cannot deny that you do diemble and are perjured: and I mut tell you Callirea, that thee expreions which you have ued as a man hall make me reolve, never to credit any words, ince you being a woman do know how o wel to diemble. Why Diana do you interrupt the dicoure of your Servant? (aid he and miled:) do you wonder that Callirea hould expree o much affection to you? No no, it is abolutly impoible to diminih or increae, for it is mot violent & hall be eternall. I will in pite of oppoition love you, & Love you to my grave, and in my grave alo if it be poible; as Tiriias being a woman, became a man, why may I not hope, that the gods may as well change me? Beleeve it (Fair Diana) that ince the gods never made any thing in vaine, it is not likely they hould inpire me with a mot perfect affection to no purpoe. Daphnis eeing this dicoure went a little too farr, and was daingerous, becaue this Lovers paion had a little tranported him, and might dicover him unto Amindor: he did interrupt him, and aid; Doubtlee, Callirea,
your love is not in vain, ince it is imployed to erve this hepheardee, no more then a candle conumes it elfe in vaine, which gives light unto all about it: For all the world adores her as well as you, and you do mot excellently imploy your time if it be in her ervice. Come come (aid Amindor) let us leave this dicoure, ee where Philidas comes who though he be a man, yet he will take no delight in it: Then Philidas came, and every one roe to alute him. But Ami • dor, who was pittifully in love with the diguied Callirea when his coin came, tooke an opportunitie to draw her aide. Then taking her by the arme and eeing none within hearing began to ay thus unto her: Is it poible, fair Callirea, that the language wherein you expreed your elfe unto Diana, hould proceed from your heart? Or did you ue them only to hew the acutenee of your wit? Beleeve me, Amindor, anwered Filander, I am no lyer, and the expreion of my affection to her, was the very thoughts of my heart, and if there be any want of truth in it, it was only want of words to expree my reentments. Unto which with a deep igh, he anwered thus. Since it is o, fair Callire • , and that you are enible of the ame wounds, I cannot but thinke you can be alo very enible of that affection which others bear unto you. And therefore I hall ue no other language to expree my elfe unto you but what you ued unto Diana; only add this conideration unto you, to the end you may know the grandure of my Love, that if the blow may be judged of by the trength of the arm that gave it, then my wound mut needs b • the deeper, ince the beauty of Diana is not comparable unto yours & if you do love her o extreamly, Judge how great the affection of Amindor mut needs be that loves Callirea? For hee knowes not how to declare it better unto you, but by making a comparion of it with your own. Shepheard, anwered Filander your declarations of any Love to me, are both unjut and very offenive unto me, who have a husband that will not with patience uffer uch affront if he knew it. Moreover, ince you peak of Diana, unto whom, I have wholly dedicated my elfe, I mut tell you, that if you will have me meaure your affection by mine, according to the caues which we have to love, I cannot beleeve you have much; ince what you call beauty in me, is not worthy to retain the name of it, if compa •• ed with hers. Fair hepheardee, (aid Amindor then) I could never have beleeved it an offence to love you; but ince it is, I do confee that I merit punihment, and am ready to receive what doome oever you pleae; but you mut reolve to put altogether, and punih me for loving you as long as I live, for it is impoible I should liv • , and not Love. But never think, I beeech you, that the dipleaure of Geret •• n can at all divert me: he who feares neither dainger nor death it elf: can never feare a man. But as to your elfe, I mut • e • ds confee my elfe to blame in comparing Diana unto you ince doubtlee she comes infinitly short, which if you can be o good as to pardon, I will protet never to commit the like error againe. Philander who had an opinion that Amindo. loved me, and who did love m • himelfe, could hardly endure to heare me thus un lervalued; but having a deigne not to dicover himelf, he had o much power over himelf as to put it up and thus anwered him. How is it poible Amindor (aid he.) that your tongue should o much bely your heart? Can you think I do not know that you diemble? And that all this while your affection is devoted unto Diana? My affection (replyed he, as if urpried) Nono, that is wholly yours: may never any love me, if I love any but you: I cannot ay but heretofore I have wihed her well, but her humour is o full of inequalitie, omtimes all fire, and omtimes all Ice, that now I am very indifferent towards her. I wonder aid Filander, how you dare to ay o, for I know he loves you, and you till love her? I will not deny aid Amindor but that he may love me, but who cares. This was right according to Amindors humour, which was ever full of vanitie, and would have all men beleeve, that he could have many good fortunes: At this time Filander found out his artifice: and had he not feared the dicovery of himelfe, he was o incened againt him in my behalfe, that I beleeve he would have given him the lye. However he could not chue but give him a very harp anwer. Amindor (aid he) you are the mot unworthy Shepheard that ever lived and not fit for any good ociety: Can you find a heart to peake thus of Diana, unto whom you have profeed o much amitie? and unto whom you are o much obliged? What can we hope for from you, ince you will not pare her who trancends us infinitly in merit and perfection? As for me, I think you the mot daingerous peron that lives, and uch as would live in ret, mut fly you as from the Plague. At this word Filander left him, and came to us with a countenance o inflamed with anger, as Daphnis knew that he was offended at Amindor: who was o atonihed at the eperation that he knew not what to do. At night Daphnis asked Filander what their dicoure was; and becaue he thought
this might much increae my amitie towards the diguied Callirea. The next morning he related it all unto me, with uch bitter invectives againt Amindor, and o advantageouly for Filander, that I mut confee, that I could never ince forbid my elfe from loving him when I knew him, conceiving, that his reall good-will unto me, did oblige me to it.

But Daphnis, who knew that, if I loved him as Callirea, I hould alo love him as Filander, did advie him to dicover himelfe unto me, telling him, that though at the firt I might perhaps repule him, and be angry; yet, in the end, all would be well: and for her part, he would o olicite in his behalf, that he feared not but to bring all unto a good concluion: Yet all her perwaions could not infue o much courage into him: o as Daphnis reolved to do it her elfe without him, or his knowledge; for, he foreaw, that Geretan would ere long have his Wife home again, and then all the plot was poiled.

With this reolution he came one day unto me, when he found me alone, and after much other-common dicoure, he began thus: Diana, aid he, what hould be the meaning of Callirea's folly? I verily believe he will run out of her wits; he loves you o extream paionately, as, I think, he will not live; All day long he is in your Chamber, and all nights in the Garden; and o pleaeth her elfe with her own melancholy fancy, that I cannot hake her out of her muings. I would I could give her any conolation, (anwered I) but what would he have me do? do I not repay affection for affection? do I not make it appear in all my actions? am I failing in any point of courtey or duty towards her? All this is true, replied Daphnis; but, did you hear her dicoures to her elfe, I believe you would extreamly pitty her: and I beeech you, unknown to her, let us go one night and hear her. I did promie her, that I was very willing, and would go with her aoon as he would; for Philidas would ere long make a viit unto Geretan, and then would be the fittet time.

A few daies after, Philidas, according to his intentions, went to ee Geretan, and carried Amindor with him, reolving not to return of even or eight daies: When he was gone, Filander, according to his cutome, went into the Garden halfe dreed, when he thought every one was a leep. Daphnis, who went to bed the firt, as oon as he was gone, did come to me, and told me: I put on my clothes as fat as I could, and followed her, untill we came into the Garden. When he found where he was, he beckened unto me, to come a little after her; and when we were o neer as to hear, we at our elves down upon the ground: Preently after I heard him ay, But why hould I put my elfe to all this patience? what will all thee delayes do me good? Shall I die, before I dicover my maladie to the Chirurgeon? Then taying a while, he began again with a mot profound igh, Why hould I fear that he will banih me her preence, and doom me to death? for, if I hould die, it is a comfort to horten uch a mierable life, and my death would atisfie for the fault I have committed; if death do not fall upon me, from the incened brow of the fair Diana, will not the violence of my affection caue it? What then hould I do, and what hall I ay unto her? Alas, I would not offend her, if I could poibly help it: And why hould I keep ilence, ince my death will give her mot certain knowledge? What then, hall I offend her? Ah! alas, injury and amitie are never together. Rather die, there's an end: But, if I hould die, do I not deprive her of the mot faithfull ervant ever that he had? Is it poible, I hould offend in adoring her? I will then tell her, and at the ame time open my breat, that the word may more eaily punih my crime, if he condemn me to it. Thus then will I ay unto her, Here, fairet Shepheardee here is Filander in the habit of Callirea, who, in lieu of begging your favour, lookes for nothing but your ury: Revenge your elfe then, Oh fairet, and punih him, and be confident, that if his death will pleae and atisfie you, it is mot welcome to him.

Faire Shepheardee, when I heard Filander thus expree himelfe, my amazement was o great, that I knew not what in the world to do: I was o vexed, and trembled o extreamly, that I would have gon away, and never have looked upon this impotor any more: But Daphnis, to compleat her treaon, held me by force; and, as I told you, being neer this Shepheard he turned his head at the noie which we made; and thinking it was only Daphnis he came unto us: But, when he pied me, and thought I heard him, Oh heavens, aid he, what torment is little enough for me? Oh Daphnis, who could ever have expected this treaon from you? At this he ran away, as if he had been ditracted, though Daphnis called him two or three times by the name of Callirea; but fearing to be heard by others and more fearing, that Filander might do ome hurt unto himelfe, he left me alone,
and followed him, aying unto me in an angry manner at parting, Well Diana, if Filande, do perih, you will reent it as long as you live. Judge, fair Shepheardees, if I was not atonihed at this accident: But o it was, that I could not hit the way out of the Garden a long time; at lat, groping on every ide, and recollecting my pirits, I found my Chamber, where, lying me down upon my Bed, and trembling, I could not cloe an eye that night. As for Daphnis, he earched for Filander o long, that at lat he found him more dead than alive: and after he had chid him, for not cloing with o good an opportunity; and yet auring him, that I was not o much troubled at the accident as he was, he took a little heart to himelfe; but yet not o much as to embolden him the next morning to come out of his Chamber.

I, on the other ide was extreamly offended againt them both, and was forced to keep my bed, let I hould make my dipleaure een unto thoe about us, and particularly unto the Niece of Geretan; but, as good fortune was he had no more wit then there was need of, o as we did eaily hide from her this curvy buinee, which was almot impoible to do, epecially for Filander, who had her company almot continually. Daphnis, he was not a little buied in the matter and perplexed, for, at the firt, I would not look upon her and her excues: but at the lat, he did o overcome me that I promied to forget the injury he had done me, yet vowing, that Filander hould never look me in the face again: and I do think, he had gone away without a ight of me, had he not feared the danger which Callirea would have incurred; for he had a Husband, that was extreamly pervere and peevih, and it was this very conideration that retrained him. But for all the arguments that Daphnis could ue, I never tirred out of my bed, feigning my elf ick, for five or ix daies. And had I not heard that Philidas and Amindor, with Callirea, were returned I had no een him of a long time: but my fears, that Philidas would take notice of it, and let th • s ecret hould come to be divulged all over the Country I did reolve to ee him, upon condition, that he hould never make the leat hew of what was pat, though I had not o much power over my elfe, as not to hew my dipleaure • he promied me, that he would oberve my commands, and kept his promie; for, he durt not o much as turn an eye towards me; and if he did at any time by chance give a glance upon me, it was in uch a ubmiive manner, as did aure me his love was extream. Preently after, as fortune was, Philidas, Amindor and the diguied Filander, came into my Chamber, where, the windowes being cloe, we could the better hide the diorders in our faces. Filander had acquainted his Siter with all paages, and that was the reaon, that the tay of Philidas was not o long as he intended; for he telling him, that her Siter was ick, they returned.

But this dicoure would be very tedious, if I hould not omit many of our triviall quarrells. But o it was, that Callirea being acquainted with all paages, ometimes turning them into rall • rie, and ometimes into eriounee, he o brought it about by the aitance of Daphnis, that I conented unto Filanders tay, untill his Siters hair was grown unto its length again knowing, that it would ruine both her and my elf, if I hould haten her returne. And o it fell out, (as Daphnis did well enough foreee) that during the time Callirea's hair was growing, the dicreet carriage of Filander, and the knowledge of his great affection, began o to flatter me, as I did of my elfe excue his diguie; o, as before he went, he obtained what he o much deired, which was, that I would forgive and forget his Impoturime; and promied him, that as long as he kept himelfe within the compae of his duty. I would accept of his good will, and cherih his merit as it deerved. His contentment upon this did much confirm my opinion of his affection, for it was o great as he could not diemble it. Whilt we were upon thee termes, Philidas, whoe love did till increae, now reolved to dicover himelfe unto the diguied Filander: and in order to this one day when they were walking together under a hade of Trees in the Garden, he poke thus unto him, Well Filander, aid he, cannot all my affection to you become o happy, as to obtain your affection again? Callirea anwered her, I do not know Philidas, what affection you would have, nor how it hould be greater unto you than it is, unlee you your elfe do intruct me. Ah! aid he were your will like mine, I hould quickly intruct you. I do wonder Philidas (aid Callirea) that you having had ufficient triall of me you hould make any doubt. Do you not know, aid Philidas, that extream deire is alwaies followed by doubting. If you will wear that you will never fail me in point of amitie, I will declare unto you omething, that perhaps will make you wonder. Callirea was a little urpried at this, not knowing what Philidas hould mean;
yet, being deirous to know the concluion, he anwered him thus, I will wear Philida whatoever you would have me, nor can I any waies expree my deires of doing you ervice. Upon this, by way of thanks, and being tranported together, Philidas took her about the neck and kied her, with that vehemency, as Callirea bluht, and puhing him away with her hand very angrily asked him, what curvie fahion that was? I do know, anwered Philidas, that my action makes you wonder; but, if you will have a little patience to hear me, I aure my elfe, that you will rather pitty, than have any ill opinion of me. Then he began to relate unto her all the paages betwixt Phormion and Celion our Fathers; the ubtletie of her Father, to let her pae for a man, although he was a woman; and all that I have related already unto you, and then continued in this manner, Now, that which I do require in performance of your promie, is, that knowing my extream affection to you, you would take me to be your Wife, and I will marry Diana unto Amindor, whom my Father hath brought up in his houe, purpoely to that end: And hereupon he added o many arguments to perwade him, that Callirea, amazed beyond all expreion, anwered him, That it was true indeed, he had told her mot trange things, and uch as he could hardly believe, unlee he had ome other aurance than words. Then he, unbuttoning his doublet, did hew him in her breats, a convincing token of her being a woman. Oh heavens! aid he, for hame hew me no more. Callirea then, that he might have the more time to conult with us, did eem, as if he were glad of the motion; but pretended, that he had Parents from whom he expected all his advancement, and, without whoe advice, he could not reolve upon a buinee of this importance; and therefore he charged him, to keep the buinee ecret; for, divulging of it, would give the world an occaion to talk: and aured him, that if nothing was wanting but her conent, he would give him good tetimony of her good-will. With uch dicoure as this they ended their walk, and returned to their lodging, where all that day, Callirea durt not come unto us, let Philidas hould think he hould peak unto us; but, at night, he acquainted her Brother with all the dicoure and afterwards, both of them went unto Daphnis, and acquainted her. You may imagine how great the wonder of every one was; but Filander was mot pleaed, conceiving it conduced much unto the accomplihment of his deires. In the morning, Daphnis deired me to go and ee the feigned Callirea, and the reall one tayed with Philidas, to the end he hould not upect any thing. The heavens know, how I was atonihed at this newes; I protet unto you, my admiration was o great as I knew not whether I was awake or aleep. Daphnis, he complained againt me, for concealing it o long from her: to which I anwered, That I knew nothing of it untill this houre; and when I told her, that though we were Children together, yet, I thought all men to be like Philidas. She laughed untill her ides did ake at my ignorance. At the lat, let Belinda hould dipoe of me according to her pleaure, or, that Philidas hould put me upon Amindor, and he have rah attempts upon me, I promied Filander, at the olicitation of Daphnis and Callirea, to marry him. This was the reaon why (after he had aumed his own habit, and aured Philidas, that he would make the motion unto his Parents) he returned o oon with his Siter unto Geretan, who never had the leat upition of this diguie. Since that time, I permitted Filander to write unto me; and he conveyed his Letters o finely unto me, that neither Philidas nor Amindor ever knew of them.

Hitherto, fair Shepheardees, this buinee had no bitternee in it. But alas, that which followed was o full of wofull wormwood, that I hall never relih any weet again as long as I live. It chanced, to my fatall misfortune, that a tranger travelling through this Country, did finde me aleep, neer the Fountain of Sicomores, whither I was invited by the coolnee of the hades, and the murmuring of the pring, to it me down, and o fell aleep; he no ooner had cat his eye upon me, but he found omthing that pleaed him. Oh heavens what kinde of man, or rather, what kinde of monter, he was! His face was as black as hell; his hair ruffine like, reembling wool, but much longer, and more diordered; his beard like grily moe about his chin; his noe crooked and long, his mouth big, and his lips hanging over his chin like unto tripes; but, nothing was o horrid as his taring eyes in all his face there was not one bit of white to be dicovered. This lamentable Lover was deigned me by detiny, and to take from me all thoughts of ever loving again: For, being ravihed at the ight of me, and tranported with leud deires, he could not chue but come neerer to kie me but, being armed, and onhoreback, the noie awakned me, and o, that as he was looping to atisfie his hellih deire, I opened my eyes:
And eeing this Monter o near me, I firt cryed out, and afterwards did trike him upon the face with all my force. He being half up and half down, and not expecting uch reitance, was o urpried at the blow, as he leaned on the other ide, o as I had time to rie. When I was up, he did rie, and being very heavily armed, and fear adding wings to my heels, he could not overtake me on foot, and therefore he leaped uddenly into his addle, and galloped after me; and when I was almot quite out of breath, poor Philidas who was not far off, hearing my voice, did come running unto me, and aw this cruel fiend purue me with a drawn word in his hand; for his anger at this blow which made him tagger, made him alo forget all love. Philidas did mot generouly oppoe his fury, making it appeare by this lat act, that her Love unto me was as great as her Sex would permit. At the firt he got hold of his bridle, which o incened this Barbarian, that with enequalled inhumanity, he ran her through the body, and he died immediatly, falling between his Hores feet, who fell o to bound and curvet, that he threw his Rider. And becaue Philidas upon the firt receipt of her wound did cry out aloud, and named Filander; he not being far off, did hear the voice, and eeing her in o ad a condition, he was much moved but much more when he aw this Barbarian running after me with a naked word in his hand, and I, as I told you, o out of breath, that I could hardly et one foot before another. How doe you think this poor Shepheard did now behave himelf? I doe not think ever any enraged Liones robbed of her young ones, did run o fiercely after him that carried them away, as Filander did after this cruel Monter; and he being heavily clogged with his Arms, the poor Shepheard oon overtook him, and cryed out. Stay Knight, tay, doe not offer any violence unto her that deerves rather to be adored. And becaue he till tayed not, either becaue his fury had topped his ears, or becaue he did not undertand the Language, Filander took up a tone and threw it at him, which hit him uch a blow upon the head, that he fell to the ground, and which without his Armour had certainly killed him; but getting up again immediatly, he forgot his anger againt me, and turned it o furiouly upon poor Filander, as he having nothing in his hand for defence but onely a Shepheards hook, he could not avoid that fatal blow which he received upon his body: But yet, feeling his enemies word already entred, uch force and courage did his natural generoity give him, that in lieu of recoyling, he advanced, and o far, as till the word was up to the hilt, and gave his cruel enemy uch a blow on the forehead with his Shepheards hook that he felled him to the ground, and eizing upon his throat with his hands and teeth he made a hift to kill him. But, alas, this victory was dearly bought for as this Fiend fell dead on one ide, Filander fell on the other, but o, that the point of his word hitting upon a tone, the weight of his body made it come out of the wound. I, who alwaies was looking behind me to ee whether this Monter did overtake me, when I aw him wounded o dangerouly, forgetting all manner of fear, I topped; and when I almot dead as well as he did ee him in this lamentable tate, at down upon the ground calling him in a mot ad tone by his name; and uing all my diligence to help him but hee had lot o much blood, that hee could not anwer: Yet ee the force of a pure affection; I who had ued never to ee o much blood without a Faint had now the courage to put my handkerchief into his wound, and to tear my other linnen to top the coure of blood on the other ide: This officious diligence did him ome ervice for he having his head in my lap, he opened his eyes, and began to peak: and eeing me all in tears, he forced himelf to ay thus unto me; If ever I hoped for a more favourable End than this, fair Shepherdes. I pray the heavens never to have pitty upon me: I did alwaies foreee, that the meanes of my merit could never bring me to my deired happines; and my fears alwaies were let depair hould drive me unto ome cruel reolution againt my elf. The Gods who do know what is good for us, better then we do our elves, did very well know that I had not lived o long but for you; and therefore they would have me alo to dye for you. Judge then what contentment it is to me, ince I do not onely die for you, but alo to preerve that which is mot dear unto you, your Chatity. Oh my mot fair and dearet Mitris, there wants nothing now, but one thing, to compleat my contentment: And that my oul may ing an Anthem unto you in the Elizian fields, I doe mot humbly beg it. He uttered thee dying words with much pain; and eeing him in that ad condition, I gave him as atisfactory an anwer as his heart could deire: Dearet friend (aid I) urely the Gods never inpired you with uch a weet and pure affection, to extinguih it o oon: I hope yet they will lend you o much life, as may give me opportunities to let you ee, that I will not yeeld
unto you in point of amity no more than you doe unto any in point of merit. And for a tetimony of my unfeigned affection to you, ask what you will of me, and obtain it; for there is nothing that I will deny you. At thee words he took my hand, and drawing it nearer him, I doe kis this fair hand (aid he) with a thankful oul, for all the favours it hath done me. But ah, fairet Mitris, ince I doe uffer the pangs of death for your ake, I doe conjure you by my mot pure affection, and by your own good promie, to let me carry o much contentment with me out of the world, as to ay, I am your Husband, and then my oul, dye when it will, will be at eae. I do vow unto you, fair Shepherdees, that thee words did o pierce my heart, that I was hardly able to utain myelf; and it was onely my deire of pleaing him which gave me courage; and therefore as oon as he had made his requet, I aid thus unto him. Filander, I do conent unto what you doe require of me; and doe wear unto you before all the Gods, and particularly the deities of this place, that Diana receives you for her Husband, and with her whole heart and oul gives her elf unto you. In peaking thee words, I kied him. And I, aid he, do give my elf and oul unto you, thinking my elf mot happy in the glorious Name of Husband unto the fair Diana. Alas, this word Diana, was the lat he ever breathed; for drawing me towards him to kis me, he expired, leaving his lat breath upon my lips. What hould I now doe, fair Shepherdes, ince he is dead? for I did love him with mot perfect affection. I fell upon him, and without either pule or any motion was carried home. Oh heavens, how I did reent this los! and have ever ince preerved o lively a memory of him in my oul, that me thinks I ee him every hour before my eyes; and me-thinks I heare him every minute bid me love him till: And o I do, fair oul, with an eternal love. And if thou hat any knowledg of what is don here below, receive, dearet friend, thee tears which I do offer unto thee, as a tetimony, that as long as Diana lives, he wil love her dear Filander. Atrea, to interrupt the grieving language of Diana, aid thus unto her; I beeech you, fair Shepherdes, who was this montrous piece of cruelty that was the caue of this dire diater? Alas, aid Diana, I know not what they call him, but I am ure he is the caue of my eternal tears. But yet, anwered Atrea, is it not known who he was? They ay, replied Diana, that he came out of a certain barbarous country beyond the Straits, which (I know not whether I term it right) is called Hercules Pillars; and the caue of his coming, o unfortunately for me, was becaue he was in love with a Lady in that Country, who commanded him to earch all Europe over, and to ee if he could find any o fair as her elf; alo, if he met with any Lover, that would defend the Beauty of his Mitris, he was obliged to fight with him, and to end his head, together with his Mitrees Picture over unto her, and her Name. Alas, I would to the Gods, that I had not run away when he followed to kil me, that my life might have aved poor Filander. Upon thee words he hed uch abundance of tears, that Phillis to divert her, turned the dicoure, and did rie up. Me thinks (aid he) you have it too long, it would be better to walk a little. Upon this, all three did rie up, and went towards their village. Leonida, who as I told you, was within hearing, did not loe a yllable of what was aid; and the more he heard, the more deirous he was to hear. But when he aw them gone, without any mention of Celadon, he was very angry; yet in hopes to dicover omthing more if he tayed a while amongt them, when hee aw they were gone, hee came out of her Buh, and followed them, but at a ditance; for, he would not have them think, that he over-heard them. Phillis by chance turning about did ee her, and alo knowing her, did hew her unto her companions who tayed, and eeing he came towards them, they went back to meet her, and to do thoe civilities her quality did merit: o they met and aluted: Leonida full of courteie, after the firt complements, addreed her elf unto Diana, and aid unto her; Wie Diana, I came purpoely this morning from the houe of Adamas my Uncle, to wait upon you and the ret of thee fair Shepheardees, and to ee whether the reports of your virtue Diana, of your beauty Atrea, and your merit Phillis, be anwerable unto what Fame hath trumpetted in your commendations. Diana eeing her Companions referred it unto her, he returned this anwer. Great Nimph, perhaps it had been much better for us, that fame had been more ilent, and not raied your expectation to too great a height; however, ince you are pleaed to do us this honour, we do receive it as is our duty, in all humble gratitude: At thee words, they conducted her into Diana's village, where he was entertained with uch welcome, and o much civility as he wondred how it was poible to find people o accomplihed in Woods and Patures.

The Afternoon was pent in everal quetions which Leonida asked of them and amongt
the ret he enquired what was become of a Shepheard called Celadon, that was the on of Alcippes? Diana anwered that not long ince he was unfortunately drown'd in the River Lignon. And his brother Lycidas, aid Leonida, is he yet married? No, aid Diana, nor doe I think he is in any hate; for the los of his brother is yet too freh in his memory. But I pray, aid Leonida, by what michance was he lot? by endeavouring to help this Shepheardes (aid Diana) who fell into the River firt: And then he pointed unto Atrea.

The Nimph, though not eeming, yet taking notice of Atrea's actions, did ee that her complexion changed and to hide her bluhes he covered her face with her hand and therefore concluded that he did love him really: And to make a further dicovery he continued her quetions. And was his body never found, aid he? No, aid Diana onely his hat was found, and as it was wiming down the River was tayed by ome buhes. Phillis knowing if this talk continued it would draw tears from the eyes of her companion, hee interrupted. I beeech you, great Nimph, aid he, what good fortune for us was it, that brought you unto this place? I told you at the firt (aid he) it was to be acquainted with you, and to enjoy the happines of your good company. Since it is o, aid Phillis, it would not be amis, o it uit with your pleaure, to goe out with us unto our accutomed exercies, o will you bet be acquainted with our way of living, and alo that you give us leave to ue the freedom of our villages before you. With all my heart, aid Leonida, for I know that contraint is never agreeable and Ile aure you, that I did not bring with me any intentions of dipleaing you. Thus Leonida taking Diana by one hand, and Atrea by the other they walked out, untill they came unto that wood which extends it elf as far as the banks of Lignon. They were no ooner et down, but they heard one ing not far off, and Diana who knew the voice turned towards Leonida, and aid, Great Nimph, will you pleae to heir the dicoure of a young Shepheard, who has nothing of Rural about him but his Name and Habit? For being educated in great Cities, and amongt perons of civility he mels not at all of the Country. Who is it (aid Leonidas) It is the Shepheard Silvander (anwered Diana) who hath not been amongt us much above a year. I beeech you aid the Nimph, of what Family is he? It is a quetion very hard to be reolved, anwered Diana: for he himelf knows not who were his Father and Mother, onely has ome far fetcht conception, that they were of Forrets, and therefore he came hither with a reolution to tay. And truly our Lignon would have a great los hould he • d part; for I do not think a more compleat Shepheard ever came into the Country. Your commendations of him, aid the Nimph, is invitation ufficient to goe and ee him, and therefore let us go to him. If he do ee us, aid Diana, and thinks he hall not be troubleome unto you, he will be ure to wait upon you preently: And as he was aying o, he came. For, as fortune was, the Shepheard as he walked epied them, and came to them; but becaue he did not know Leonida he eemed as if he would have paed by, when Diana aid unto him; What Silvander, is it the civility of Cities to interrupt good company by paing by them, and aying nothing? The Shepheard miled and anwered; Since I have inned in interrupting you, the les will I tay in my in. That's not it, aid Diana, which makes you o oon gone, but rather becaue you think there is not merit enough amongt us to tay you; yet if you doe but cat your eye upon this Nimph, I am confident that if your eyes have any judgement you will finde more merit than any where ele That which draws another thing unto it elf (replied Silvander) mut have ome attractive ympathy with that which it doth draw; but ince there is no uch ympathy betwixt your high merits Great Nimph, and my poor imperfections, you need not wonder if your perfections did not attract me unto you.

Your modety, Sir (aid Lemida) does onely make the diimilitude betwixt us: Doe you think it is in your body, or your oul? If in your body, your face and the ret of your parts argues the contrary: if in the oul, me thinks, if you have one that is reaonable, it is not different from ours Silvander found that now he had not to deal with Shepheardees, but with one of a higher train and therefore he reolved to anwer her with more olid reaons than he ued amongt Shepheardees, therefore thus replied: Every thing in the whole univere, fair Nimph, mut be valued according to its own proper quality; for otherwie, Man who is of highet eteem, would be the lowet, ince every animal excels him in ome particular thing or other; one in trength, another in wiftnes, another in ight, another in hearing, another in melling: and o in many priviledges of body. But when it is conidered, that the gods have made all thee Animals for the ervice of Man,
and man for the ervice of the gods, it mut needs be confeed that the gods are above all; from hence I argue, that to know the true value of every thing, it mut be looked into, to what ervice the gods did make them, and it is they that et the value upon things: nor urely the gods could never be o much mitaken, as to equall your merit and mine, and yet make you a great Nymph, and me but a poor illy hepheard. Leonida did in her mind much commend the wit of this Shepheard, who could put o good a gloe upon a bad matter. And therefore to give him more ubject to continue, he aid thus unto him. But allow all this in regard of me, yet why could not thee hepheardees invite you, ince according to your own argument, there is the ame proportion and impathy betwixt you and them? Sage Nymph, anwered Silvander, the lee does alwayes ubmit unto the greater part and where you are, thee herheardees mut do the ame why didainful Shepheard (aid Diana) do you o little eteem of us? I did ay o, aid Silvander, becaue I did eteeme you o much: for if I had an ill opinion of you, I hould never have aid that you were a part of that great Nymph, ince thereby I do not make you her inferiour. Only in that he deerves to be loved, for her merits, for her beauty, and for her quality & you only for your merits and for your beautie. I hould be glad Silvander (aid Diana) that I had o much merit or beauty either, as to obtain the Love of o wel an accomplihed Shepheard as you are. She poke this, becaue he was o far from any thoughts of Love that he was called amongt them The inenible man: and he was very deirous to make him peake of it. Unto whom he anwered, think and beleeve what you pleae, o you will confee you want one of your principall parts. And, which is that? (aid Diana): Your wil, replyed he, for it and the effects of it are contrary. No no (aid Phillis and interrupted him) for I beleeve Silvander loves her as much as her will would have him. The Shepheard hearing her ay o, turned towards Atrea, and aid that they did him wrong to be two to one. The wrong, aid Diana, is offered unto me, for this hepheardee eeing me in combate with a trong enemy; and upecting my courage and trength, would needs aid me.

That is not it which does offend you, fair Shepheardee aid he, for he has more judgement then to make any doubt of your victory; but that which does offend you is, that he eeing me already vanquihed, he mut needs teal the victorie, and the honour of it in offering to give me a blow at the latter end of the combate: but I do not know how he did intend it; for I aure you, if you had not medled, he had not o eaily gotten the glory as he thought. Phillis who had a good natural and pleaant wit, & who reolved to pend that day with Leonida, as pleaantly as he could, did anwer him in a haughty manner, Tis very well Silvander (aid he) that you thinke it a thing o deirable and honorable to me, to vanquih you; but let me tell you, I rank the victory amongt the meanet, that ever I got. Neither ought you to depie it (aid the Shepheard) ince it is the firt you ever got of me. As it is honorable, replyed Phillis, to be the firt, where there is merit; o it is a hame, where there is none Ah Shepheardee, (aid Diana) never ay o of Silvander: for if all Shepheards who are inferior to him in merit, hould be corned, I know not who hould be loved. This, this is the very blow that will overcome him, (aid Phillis) nay doubtlee he is yours: Uncivilized and wild pirits are to urpried at the very firt attracts: for not being accutomed to uch favours, they recieve them with uch a gut, as they are not able to make any reitance. Phillis poke thus in way of mockery; but the gratious defence of Diana had uch an influence upon this Shepheard, that he thought himelfe obliged by the Lawes of courteie to erve her and in that opinion, the perfections of Diana had o much power over him, that he conceived uch eeds of love, as time and practice did increae to a great heights; as afterwards I hall tell you. This dipute paed amongt thee Shepheardees with much delight unto Leonida who admired their quaint wits. then Phillis turning towards the Shepheard, aid unto him: Come, come Shepheard, words are but wind; come to the tet, and tell me truly, Who is the Shepheardee which particularly is your adored Saint? Even he, anwered he, whom you ee me adore. That is as much to ay, aid Phillis, that you adore none but that proceeds, alas from want of courrage. Rather, replyed Sylvander, from want of wil. But you, fair one, who doe o much depie me, I pray tell me, Who is the Shepheard whom you do particularly Love? All uch, anwered he, as have any wit or courage: And he that ees a perfect beautie, and cannot love; certainly wants wit or courage or both.

This is an anwer too generall aid Silvander, pray come to particulars, and tell us that one whom you do love? I wih, aid he, there were any o forward as to attempt it. Then, added Silvander, it is for want of courage. Then Silvander, aid she it is for want of
will. Why aid Silvander, would you have any to think that it is more want of will in you then me I would thoe actions which are decent in you, (aid the hepheardee) were permitted me, do you think it handome in me to leap and run as you do? But let us dipute no longer let Diana be Judge in the buinee and thereby you may ee what confidence I have in my caue, ince I make choice of a partiall Judge. I hall judge according to reaon (aid Diana). Then aid Phillis, ince words cannot jutifie a buinee, is it not requiite to come to proofes? Doubtlee it is (aid Diana). Condemne then this hepheard, replyed Phillis, to render ome proofs of that merit which he aith is in him; and that he undertake to erve and love a hepheardee, in uch a manner as he be contrained to confee that he merits to be loved againe; and if he cannot do that, then, that he ingenuouly acknowledge his unworthynee. Leonida and the hepheardees thought this propoition o agreeable to reaon that with one common voice he was condemned: Not, aid Diana, that he hould be contrained to love, for that mut ever proceed from a free voluntary genius and not from contraint, but I do ordain that he do erve and honour, as you do ay. My Judg anwered Silvander, though you have condemned me without hearing me, yet I will not appeal from your entence; only I require that he whom I mut erve, do merit and ackowledge my ervice.

p.hi: Silvander, Silvander,
p.U: aid Phillis becaue you want courage, you fly unto evaions: but I hall prevent you by a propoition which I hall make. I do propound unto you one, againt whom there is no exceptions, either in matter of wit, courage, or beauty, and that is Diana. For my part, aid Silvander, I do accept of the motion, provided it be with the approbation of all thee beauties. Diana would liave anwered, and made ome excue but at the requet of Leonida and Atrea, he conented upon condition that this eay hould not lat above three monthes.

div.p:
This courthip being Silvanders entence, he kneeled down and kied the hand of his new Mitrie, as if he had taken his oath of fidelitie, and afterwards riing up, he aid thus; Fairet Mitri; I do in all humility ubmit unto your ordinance, but I do mot humbly beeech you to let me make one propoition. And when Diana aid that he had free liberty, he went on. As I have been jutly condemned to make this proof of my elfe for peaking too highly of my own merits, againt a peron who depied me: So, I beeech you why hould this vain glorious Phillis who infinitly outwells me in vanitie, and who was the firt caue of this dipute, why I ay hould not he be entenced to render the like tetimony? Atrea not taying for Dianas anwer, aid, that he thought the motion o jut as he was conident it would be granted, and Diana asking the Nymphs opinion, who was of the ame mind, he condemned the hepheardee as was requeted. I did never expect a more favorable doome aid Phillis; but well, what mut I do? You mut get the favour of ome hepheardee, (aid Silvander.) That, aid Diana is not reaonable, She mut do more then that: For I do ordaine that he do love and erve a hepheardee; and o as he do caue her elfe to be loved, and, he or he of you two, who hall be leat unto her you erve, shall be contrayned to yeild unto the other. Then my deire is, aid Phillis that I may erve Atrea. Siter, aid she, you are about a work which is already done to your hand: but it were much better you made choice of Diana, not only for the two reaons which you alledged unto Silvander, which was, her merits and wit, but alo becaue she is bet able to judge of both your ervices, if they be both addreed unto her; This did carry uch a ound of reaon with it, that it was immediately conented unto: then after Diana had taken an oath, that without any regard but truth, the should do equall jutice at the three months end, It was very pleaant to oberve the paages of this new love. For Phillis was a very excellent ervant, and Silvander feigning to be one, became one in good earnet, as afterwards you shall heare. Diana on the other ide did o well know how to play the Mitrie that any would have thought it to be in reall earnet. As they were thus dicouring, and Leonida thinking this kind of life to enjoy more happinee then any other, they aw two Shepheardees and two Shepheards, comming along the meadow, who by their habits eemed to be trangers; and when they were a little neerer, Leonida who was very inquiitive to know the names of the Shepheards and Shepheardees of Lignon, did aske who they were? To which Phillis anwered that they were trangers, to which Silvander aid, that urely he hould know one of them particulary, whoe name is Hylas, a merry hepheard, and one that loves all he lookes upon; but the bet is, he who receives the blow has the plaiter; for as he can oon love, o he can oon forget; and he has the maddet and mot extravagant arguments, to prove his incontant humour to be the bet, as it is impoible
to heare them and not laugh: truly aid Leonida, his company will be very good, & let us put him upon that dicoure as oon as he comes. That's eaily don, aid Silvander, for he will alwaies be talking of it: but as this is his humour, o there is one with him of a quite contrary dipoition, for he does nothing but pule and grieve for the death of a Shepheardee whom he loved; he is a • ber and dicreet man, but o ad and lumpih, as nothing proceeds from him but expreions of a melancholy oul is he this country man aid Leonida? Fair Nymph, aid Silvander, I do not know, but if you pleae I will ask them: at this word, they were come o neer that they heard Hylas chanting out thee veres.

l.hi: IF any beauty contant make me,
'Tis more her honour, o to take me.

lg.l: I love to change by Jove, and mut

l.hi: Unto my liberty be jut:
And why hould any be o hy
To hun me for Incontancy?
Since if a beauty contant make me,
'Tis more her honour o to take me.

lg.l: It argues beautie in the height
To make a crooked Lover treight,
And 'tis a miracle more high
To make my heart all Contancy:
Therefore if any Contant make me,
' • ie more her honour o to take me.
To tay a tone that till doth tand
Is eaie worke for any hand:
But 'tis a matter much more high
To top an Eagle in the skie.
Therefore if any contant make me
'Tis more her honour o to take me.
But why hould any think it trange,
That I hould for the better change?
Will any that have wit, or eyes,
Not after for a better prize?
Then if a beauty contant make me
'Tis more her honour o to take me,
Come then, dear Mitries, that faine
The prize of beautie would obtain,
Settle my wanton wavering mind
By Carraing and being kind.
For he that can ere contant make me
Has got the honour; Let her take me.

p.hi: Leonida
p.U:
miled at Silvander and told him, That this Shepheard was none of thoe deluders that ue to diemble their in perfections, ince he did put them into a Ballet. The reaon is, anwered Silvander, becaue he does not think it any vice, but glories in it. Aoon as they were come, and all aluting complements performed, Silvander remembred the Nymphs quetion concerning thee Shepheards, and therefore he addreed himelfe unto Tircis, for o was the mourning Shepheard called, and aid thus unto him, Tircis, if it be not troubleome to you, I beeech you tell us, what inducements brought you into this Country of Forrets, and who it is which tayes you here? Tircis then kneeling down upon the ground, and holding up his hands and eyes towards heaven, he thus aid, Oh infinite goodnee, who by thy wie providence, does govern the whole Univere,
be thou for ever praied, for what thou hat been pleaed to take from me. Then riing up, and admiring the Nymph and the ret of the company, he addreed himelfe by way of anwer unto Silvander, Worthy Shepheard (aid he unto him) you asked me what it was which brought and retained me in this Country; and I mut anwer you, that it is your elfe it is you only that I have o long looked for Me? aid Silvander, how can that poibly be, ince I do not know you? That's partly the reaon, aid Tircis, why I have looked for you. Since it is o, aid Silvander, and ince you have been long amongt us, why would you never peak unto me? Becaue, anwered Tircis, I had no acquaintance with you; but, to give you a fuller atisfaction, when you are all et down, becaue the dicoure will be long, I will, if you pleae, give you a full relation.

div.p: Mitr • e aid Silvander is it your pleaure to it down under thee hady trees? You ought to addree your elf with that quetion unto Leonida, aid Diana. I do know very well, fairet Mitree, aid he, that civility commands it o, but love does enforce me unto you. Then Leonida taking Diana by her hand, and Atrea in the other, he did it down betwixt them, telling Silvander, that he was in the right; becaue that love, which hath any conideration of repect above it elfe, is not right love. And after all the ret of the Shepheardees and Shepheards were et round, Tircis turned towards the Shepheardee which came with him and aid unto her: Now, Laonice is the happy and o much deired time, which we have with o much impatience expected, ever ince we came into this Country It rets only upon you to do according to the Oracle Then the Shepheardee, without any reply unto him, addreed her elfe unto Silvander, in this manner.

div.head: The Hitory of Tircis and Laonice.
div.p: I Have heard ay, and I think truly, that of all amities, there is none more affectionate, than that which begins in Infancy becaue, that cutome which is taken in that age, does by degrees become a nature which growing up with years, growes olid and unalterable. This Prologue, generous Shepheard, mut plead for an excue, ince I am forced to tell you that I do love Tircis: I ucked in this affection almot with my milk, and my oul being ever ince nourihed with this food, did receive, as its own, the accidents of this paion Neighbours we alwaies were the amity of our Parents, the equalitie of our ages, and the weet dipoition in Tircis his younger years, were o many weet allurements, to make me his. But, cured Fate would have it o, that almot at the ame time Cleon was born, and perhaps with more graces than I, but certainly, with much better fortune for, as oon as he began to open her eyes, the heart of Tircis was inflamed by them, for h • began to love her in the Cradle About that time I was ome ix years of age, he ten But ee how the heaven dipoed of us againt our wills; aoon as ever I aw him I loved him, and aoon as ever he aw Cleon, he loved her: And though thee were yet but green affections, uch as the age was capable of yet, were they not o mall, but they knew how to make a difference amongt us: Afterwards, growing up with time, they came to uch a height, that, I believe never any exceeded them.

In the Infancy of my Love, you may think, I took no great notice of his actions; but, being grown unto a more oberving age, I found uch coldnee of good-will towards me, tha • I reolved to divert my elf ome other way; A reolution, which many malecon • ented perons may fancy, but never any true Lover could execute, as afterwards I found by a long and ad experience: However, my offended pirit had power enough to make me diemble; and if I could not by any means attract him, then to try at the leat if I could take my leave of him My greatet wonder was, that I could never finde, that Tircis affected any other Shepheardee; and as for Cleon, he raied no upition, by reaon of her youth, ince then not above nine yeares old but when he was grown, and could be enible of Loves Arrowes; he could o withdraw her elfe from him, as any would think, uch a eparation were enough to heal up all wounds: But Love more ubtle then he, did til o wound her heart with the merits, affection and ervices of Tircis that he had no other remedy to run unto, but diimulation; not that he hoped thereby to avoid the blowes of Love, but only to hide them o, as neither her enemy, nor any other, hould ee them. This diguie was armes indifferent, as long as her skin was only a little cratched; but, when the wound was great, then no way, but to throw them away, and acknowledge her elfe vanquihed Thus was Tircis happy in the love of his Cleon, and enjoyed all the pleaant
fruites of it, though at the beginning he hardly knew what his dieae was, as appeared by ome Veres which he compoed at that time.

lg.head: A Sonnet.

l.hi: WHat new ditempers does diturb my oul,
My heart, and all my faculties controul?
Feavers have intervalls, and ometimes burnes,
And ometimes cold, and have their fits by turnes.
But min's an ague of that trange condition,
As never meets with any intermiion.

lg.l: Cleon o fair, o full of flaming fire

l.hi: Has kindled in my oul uch hot deire
As cannot die, nor live in any ret;
My heart, my mind, and all is o poet
With her, who, though the Author of my pain,
I think a pleaure of the highet train.
'Tis trange, that pain and pleaure hould ubit,
And harbour'd be within the elfe-ame breat
But this is true, this my ditemper is,
To corch in pain, and yet to think it blie.
You cannot under tand it, 'tis above
The reach of any, that is not in Love.

div.p:
Aoon as ever Tircis found out the good-will of his happy Cleon, he received it with o much contentment, as his heart was not able to contain his joyes, but his eyes alo did hare in the happinee, and were o much altered from what they were, as they could not chue but end forth ignes of their too much joy. Cleon's dicretion was uch, that he conferred no more favours upon Tircis, in the eye of the world, than ordinary; but, being jealous of her honour, he deired him to counterfeit a love unto me, to the end all eyes might be upon me, and off her; and me ooner than any other, it being long oberved that I loved him. He, who was all obedience unto whatoever Cleon commanded, did accordingly apply himelf unto me: Oh heavens! when I think upon the weetet expreions he ued unto me, I cannot chue, though they were all fale, but cherih them, and wih, ince I can be no otherwie happy, that I were o deceived again. And certainly, Tircis had no hard task to perwade me, that he loved me: For, I did not think my elfe o diagreeable, but that a long continued practice, together with my endeavours to pleae him, might work upon him; at which, the vain-glorious Cleon, did oft make her elfe port with Tircis: but, had Love been jut, and turned the love of Tircis to me into earnet, her mockery might have lightt upon her elfe. This life of diimulation was o tedious to him, that he was not able to endure it any longer; and had not Love blinded the eyes of all Lovers, certainly I hould have perceived it, as well as mot did who aw us together; but I would not lend any believing ear unto them, no more, than unto my mot mortall enemy. And becaue Cleon and I were very familiar, this ubtle Shepheardee was afraid, let time hould dicover my error unto me, which to prevent, he invented this tratagem: Her deigne was, as I told you before, to conceal that affection which Tircis bore unto her, under his cloak of eeming to love me; and it was effected accordingly, for every one talked aloud of the love of Tircis unto me: But Cleon as I told you before, fearing this tratagem would be dicovered, did invent another full as ubtle as the other: She advied Tircis to make me believe, that the world talked very broad of our amitie, and put wrong contructions upon it; and therefore it was neceary, to top all candalous tongues by prudence: and in order to that, he would counterfeit a love unto Cleon, and tell her (aid he) that you make choice of me rather than any other, becaue of your conveniency, in being neer me, and peaking to me. I, who was all inceritie, and no ubtletie, did think this counel to be very good, o as from thence forwards, with my permiion, when we were all three together, he talked with Cleon as he was wont, without any difficultie: And certainly, it was good port to them, and would have been to any other, that had known the diimulation: For, when I aw him o officious about Cleon, I thought he had all that while but mocked her, and had much adoe to forbear laughing: On the other ide, Cleon
oberving my actions, and knowing how I was deluded; he could hardly contain her thoughts of mirth. But ee how good natur'd I was, I did extreamly pitty her, for the griefe he would reent, when he came to know the truth: But alas, afterwards I found, that the pitty belonged unto my elfe; and who, as well as I, might not as well have been deceived? for Love, aoon as ever he takes entire poeion of a oul, does preently expell all diffidence of the party loved. And this diembling Shepheard did peronate his part o well, that had I been in Cleons room, perhaps I hould have doubted, whether he acted a fiction or a truth: Sometimes, when he was betwixt us both, and had given Cleon ome notable demontration of affection, preently he would turn to me, and ask me in my ear, whether he did not act his part well: but, his grand craft reted not in uch a trifle; I beeech you hear what an Arts-Mater he was in his Art, he talked with Cleon in private more often then with me, he would kie her hand, be down upon his knees two houres together before her, and never hid any paage from me, for the reaons aforeaid: But in publick, he never tirred from me and courted me with o much diimulation, that mot had the ame opinion of our Loves: which he did upon deigne, deiring, that I only hould ee his courthip unto Cleon, becaue he knew I did not believe it; but, would not by any means, that any others hould be witnees. And when I told him, that we could not remove that opinion which the people had of our amitie and that none would believe he loved Cleon; then would he anwer me, Why, how hould they ever believe a thing which is not, no, nor well enough diembled? But, aid, he, whatoever we do, we mut deceive Cleon, let others think what they will; for, if he be but handomely deluded, our deigne is almot compleated: Hereupon he deired me, that I would peak unto her in his behalfe, and become as it were, his confident: She, aid he, who has that opinion already, will the more gladly receive the meages, that you hall bring, and o we hall live in more aurance, and freer from all upition. Oh! what a mierable fortune do we often follow? For my part, I thought, that if Cleon did believe I had loved this Shepheard, I hould detroy that beliefe, by deiring her to love him, and by peaking for him as his confident. But Cleon, knowing the dicoure between the Shepheard and me, and living in a kinde of contraint, he thought that by this means, he might mot conveniently receive all her Meages and Letters from him; and therefore he bade the propoition which I made unto her very welcome, and after this treated me as one he loved: And thus I was made ue of, only as a Letter Carryer between them. Oh Love! what a miery didt thou put me upon? But, I am not the firt who has done the like offices for another in thinking to do it for themelves. At that time, the Franks, the Romans, the Goths, and the Burgundians, being all up in Armes, we were contrained to live in Townes; and there being a huge concoure of people from all parts, alo wanting their Country-accommodations, a petilent dieae did o raign in the Town, as mot of the people died of it: o it chanced, that Cleons Mother was infected; and though the dieae was o contagious, that hardly either Parent or kindred, would tay with the party infected; yet, uch was the naturall affection of Cleon to her Mother, that he would never part from her, but would till tay, notwithtanding all the perwaion of friends, who told her, that he offended the gods, in running into a wilfull danger; unto whom he till returned this anwer, If you love me never ue any more of this dicoure; for, do I not owe my life unto her, who gave me mine? and will the gods be offended with me for helping her, who taught me to erve them? In this pious and filiall reolution, he would not forake her Mother, but hut her elfe up with her, and was as buy in helping her, as if the dieae had not been at all contagious. Tircis tood all the day at the dore, and wooed to come in; but Cleon would upon no termes permit him, let if he had, it might have been candalous unto her: But till he waited at the dore and caued all manner of necearies to be brought unto them: yet, o the heavens would have it, that Cleon, notwithtanding all antidotes and preervatives which Tircis brought unto her, was infected. When the Shepheard heard that, it was impoible to keep him from entring into the houe; ince now it was not a time to think upon diimulations, or to fear any teeth of detractors; but he et all things in order, dipoed of his etate, and declared his Will; afterwards, putting it in the charge of a friend to help him, he entred, and hut himelfe up with the Mother and the Daughter, reolving to run the ame fortune with Cleon. It is not materiall to relate unto you, what good offices he did them, and how officious and ervicable he was unto the Mother, for the Daughters ake: But at lat the Mother dyed, and when none was left in the houe but he and his Mitree, whoe maladie till increaed, I do not think the poor Shepheard got one minute
of ret; he held her continually in his armes, and dreed her. She, on the other ide, alwaies loving him did take this lat action for uch an evident tetimony of his love, that hers augmented much more; and her greatet griefe was the danger he was in for her ake. He, on the other ide, had o much atisfaction, as to rejoyce as much as a ad occaion would permit, that he had the means to tetifie his good will. o it hapned that this Shepheardes being in a condition to be cut, a Phyician could not be procured, that would venture to touch her, for fear of danger: Tircis, whoe affection prompted him unto any thing, being taught how to do it, he took the Lancer, and lifting up her Arm, he did cut it, and dreed it when he had done. To be brief, all things of mot danger and difficulty, were eaie and weet unto him, in hopes of doing her ome good. But her malady till encreaed, and brought his beloved Cleon into uch a ad condition, that he had no more trength left than to utter thee words; I am very forry Tircis that the gods are not pleaed to draw the thread of my lamentable life a little longer, onely to tetifie my extreme gratitude: but though I hould live as many yeares, as I have already done dayes, I hould never bee able to atisfie you for the abundance of your affection to me. Thee words were uttered with much pain; but her affection to this Shepheard gave her power to utter them. Unto which Tircis anwered, My dearet Mitris, all I have done, and all I can ever do; is all far hort of my will to do any real ervice; beleeve me, dearet Cleon, my obligations to you are greater than a thouand lives can pay. The heavens which gave me a being only to be yours, would accue me of mipending my time, hould I employ one minute of my life otherwie then in your ervice. He would have continued longer but the Shepheardes finding her elf extreamly ill did interrupt him: Ceae my dear friend and leave talking to me, that I may imploy that little time I have to live, in auring you that I can love you as much as ever my oul is capable of: So eeing my time is very near, I bid thee eternal adieu, and deire three things of you; To love thy Cleon for ever; to enterre my corps near my Mothers, and when you do pay the debt which is due unto humanity, let your corps be layd near mine, that though our bodies could not be united alive, yet they may in death. To which he anwered; The Gods would be unjut, if after they have begun o perfect an amity as ours, they hould o oon detrov it: But I hope they will preerve you, at leat take me away before you: But if they will not, I will onely beg as much life as to fulfill thoe commands you have laid upon me, and then to let me follow you. Be aured, dearet oul, that unlee they alwaies tye up my hands, I will not be long after you. Friend, anwered he, I command you to live as long as the Gods have ordained, that o whilt I am chanting our perfect amity in the Elizian Fields, you may publih it unto the living: And o both the dead, and they living will honour ou • memory. But, friend, I perceive my malady is forcing me to leave you: Adieu, adieu, the mot perfect Lover left amongt the living. At thee words he dyed, leaning her head in the boom of her Shepheard. To repeat his orrows, would but open his wounds, and make them bleed afreh. Oh mot fatal death (cryed out Tircis) that hath robbed me of the better part of myelf, either retore that life which thou hat taken from me, or ele take the ret. Then, to give way unto thoe tears and ighs which this remembrance did revive in his heart, he tood ilent untill Silvander told him, that to grieve for what there was no remedy, was but a tetimony of weaknes. Oh, aid Tircis, I doe grieve becaue there is no remedy; for if there were, I should not grieve. Laonice then continued on: This happy Shepheardes being dead, and Tircis having performed the lat office of amity, he procured her to be interred next her Mother; but the carelenes of thoe who had it in charge was uch, as they layd her corps in another place. As for him, his orrows were uch, as he never tirred off his bed, as if he lived only to obey her commandements. Some few dayes after, enquiring of thoe who came to ee him, where they had laid his beloved corps, he undertood that he was not enterred by her Mother; at which he was infinitely dipleaed; and for a great um of mony hired ome to take it up again, and lay it by her Mother, which accordingly was done: They went unto the place, uncovered the earth, and four of them took up the corps, but having carryed it a little way, the Infection was o violent that they were forced to leave it by the way, and could carry it no further: whereof Tircis being advertied, after he had made great offers unto them to go on, and eeing they would by no means undertake it; What Tircis (aid he) didt thou think the love of gain could work more with them than thy affection with thee? Fie, ie, Tircis, this is too great an affront offered unto thy amity. So, as if he were tranported, he ran to the place where the corps lay; and though it had layn in the earth three dayes, and melt extreamly, he took it up in his arms, and carried it unto the Tomb of her Mother, which was already
covered. Then after this high tetimony of affection, he returned to the Town, and would not be een of any. When all thee paages were known unto me, but yet onely hearing Cleon was dead, I went unto his chamber, to enquire of all particulars: When I came at the chamber door, which tood half hut, and half open, me-thought I heard him igh; and was not mitaken, for looking in at a chink of the door, I aw him lying upon his bed with eyes and hands lifted up to heaven, and his face wimming all in tears. Judge generous Shepheard, whether or no I was atonihed; for I did not think he had loved her, but came rather with intentions to rejoice with him, than to condole. Then, after I had een him in this ad condition, I heard him utter thee words:

lg.head: Upon the Death of CLEON.

l.hi: Tears turn to Rivers; never hide
But wel your elves into a flowing tide:
She's dead, who whilt he liv'd did lutre give
To as much virtue as did ever live:
No faigning now my Love; my grief will how
No hopes are left for Lovers here below:
All that are left are lodged in her grave;
And he that has no hopes, no fears can have.
She liv'd in me, I liv'd in her; and both
So twited were together by an oath
Of faithful Love, as both, though two, but one:

lg.l: And now my Cleon dead is, I am none.

l.hi: But tay; me thinks he is not dead; her heart
To live in me did from her elf depart;
Her body's onely dead; And now I ee
My pirits dy'd in her, hers live in me.

div.p:
Oh heavens! what a weeping tatue was I turned, when I heard him utter thee words! My atonihment was o great, as leaning againt the door, it opened; at which he turning his head, and eeing me, he put out his hand, and bade me it down upon the bed by him; and when he had wiped away ome tears from his welled eyes, he poke thus unto me: Alas, Laonice, poor Cleon is dead, and we are left here below to lament her los. And becaue my grief would not uffer me to return an anwer, he continued on. I know Shepheardes, that you eeing me in this condition, doe much wonder, that the feigned amity, which I profeed unto her, hould make me mourn o exceively for her los. But, alas, remove your error, I beeech you; for I think it is too great a in againt Love to continue any longer under the cover of diimulation, which my affection forced me to aume. And know Laonice, that all this while, I did love Cleon, and all my addrees unto you were but coverings of that love. And therefore if you did ever love me, for Gods ake Laonice, turn that love into pitty, and condole with me this ad diater, which at one blow has cut off all my hopes. If ever I did offend you, I beeech you, pardon me, ince it was committed onely becaue I could not fail in my duty to my dearet Cleon. I was o tranported at thee words, that I went out, and could hardly hit the way to my own home, where I kept my chamber a long time, lamenting this ad diater: And I did with Tircis, whom I till loved, excue all thoe Treaons he had committed againt me and pardoned the diimulations whereby he offended me thinking them no diimulations nor treaons, but onely violencies of love. I was the more eaily induced to pardon him, ince Love, as a Conederate with his faults, did flatter me with ome hopes of ucceeding Cleon in his affection. As I was thus oothing my elf in thee thoughts one came to tell me, that Tircis was gone, and none knew whither, or where he was. This urcharge of orrow, o urpried me as I did immediatly reolve to follow him. And to the end none might hinder me, I departed, o ecretly at the beginning of the night, as before morning I was gotten farre off. Whether I was atonihed when I was alone in the dark, the heavens do know, unto whom my complaints were addreed; but however, Love, who was my ecret companion did inpire me with courage enough to go through with my deign: Following then on my voyage, and taking the path my feet firt trod upon; for I know not which way Tircis went, nor my elf neither; I went wandering like a Vagabond for three months together,
and never heard the leat yllable of him. At the lat, paing over the Mount Dor, I met with this Shepheardes (aid he, and pointed unto Madonche) and with her this Shepheard called Therander, itting under a hady Rock to pas away the heat of the day; And it being my cutom to enquire of all I met concerning Tircis, I undertood by ome igns which they gave me, that he was in thoe dearts, and went wandring and lamenting the los of Cleon. Then I related unto them, all the ame tory which I have told unto you, and conjured them to give me the bet directions they could. Madonche moved with pitty, did give me uch a weet anwer, as I judged her to be ick of the ame dieae I was, and I was not mitaken; for I heard, ince, the tory of her orrows, by which I found, that Love wounds as well in the Court as Country. And becaue there was much reemblance in our fortunes, he deired we might both goe together, ince both were upon the ame quet. I did with open arms embrace the motion, and thought it better to enjoy uch a ad companion, than to be alone. But this dicoure is impertinent, ince I intend onely to relate the tory of Tircis, and my elf. Well, generous Shepheard, after three months quet in this Country, I met with him; and o contrary to his expectation, that hee was extreamly urpried. At the firt, he looked upon me with a loving eye; but afterwards, when he aw the occaion of my voyage was my Love to him, hee openly declared the affection which he till bore unto Cleon, and that it was not in his power to love me. Love, I beeech thee (and not this ungrateful man) If there be any jutice in thee, let me have ome recompence for all my pains.

Thus Laonice ended, and addreed her elf in a ad poture unto Silvander, as if he courted his favour for Jutice in her caue. Then Tircis began to peak in this manner; Though the tory of my misfortunes be, as this Shepheardes hath related them, yet my orrows are infinitely more pittifull, which I will not relate, let I hould too much trouble you, and all this company; onely with this, that when we could not upport our orrows, we did with common conent addres ourelves unto the Oracle to know our dooms from it; and we received this anwer from the mouth of Arontine.

lg.head: THE ORACLE.

l.hi: Look, Lovers, 'mongt the Shepheards that abide

lg.l: Where Lignon like a Serpent there doth glide,

l.hi: There hall you find one Learned in the Laws
Of Love, and Jutice; he hall Judge your Caue.

div.p: And though we have long reided in thee parts, yet you are the firt that asked us of the tate of our fortunes: And therefore we do in all humility ubmit our elves and fortunes unto your doom; beeeching you to determine the difference between us. And to the end all things might be done according to the will of the Gods, the old Matron who delivered the Oracle told us, that both of us were to chue our Advocate amongt the company by Lot; the firt Lot to plead for Laonice, and the lat for me. Upon this he entreated them all, that they would be pleaed to take thee offices upon them, unto which they all conented. The firt Lot fell upon Hylas, and the lat upon Phillis. Hylas he miled, and aid thus; If I were now, as heretofore I was, a ervant unto Laonice, I hould very hardly be perwaded to argue in her behalf, that Tircis ought to love her; but now at this time, ince I am all for Madonche, I am very willing to obey that God who o ordained it. Shepheard, aid Leonida, you may by this oberve the great Providence of this Divinity, who to move one unto change, hath committed the charge of it unto uncontant Hylas, as unto one who bet knows the way; and to move one to a faithful amity, hath cat the Lot upon a Shepheardee that is firm and contant in her actions: Alo uch a Judge is choen as will not be partial: For Silvander is the mot fit, ince he is neither contant nor uncontant in his affection, becaue he never loved. Then Silvander began to peak, and thus aid unto them: Since, Tircis and Laonice, you are both willing that I hould be the Judge of your differences, I hall require you both to wear, that you wil inviolably oberve my Sentence, for otherwie the Gods may be the more incened, and all our labours lot. Which both conented unto, and then Hylas began in this manner.

div.head: The Oration of Hylas in behalfe of Laonice.
div.p:
WEre I to plead before ome hard harted and unnaturall peron, I hould feare let perhaps the defects of my capacity, hould prejudice the jutice of my Clients caue. But ince I am to argue the buinee before you who has the heart of a man (I mean, who knowes the duties of a man well born) I cannot chue but be confident of a favourable judgment, and take it for almot certain, that if you were in the roome of Tircis, you would be extreamly ahamed to be branded with uch a crime. I wil not trive for any far fetcht reaons, to approve that which is o abundantly cleere in it elfe: only hall hint thus much unto you, that the very name of man, does oblige him unto a confeion of his error. And the Lawes and ordinances both of heaven and nature, do all command him to dipute no further in the caue. Does not the rules of courteie and gratitude require, a retaliation for benefits received? Does not heaven it elfe ay, that all ervices ought to be remunerated with ome wages? And does not nature force him to love a faire woman who loves him and to abhor rather then to dote upon dead corps? But this man is a grand offend eragaint all thee acred Laws: for in lieu of all the great favour he hath received from Laonice he has returned high dicourteies; in lieu of all thoe ervices which he himelf confeeth he hath done him, erving him o long for a cloak of his amity to Cleon, he does pay her the wages of ingratitude: and for that dear affection which he ever bore him even from her cradle, he anwers her only with corne. If thou beet a man Tircis, make it appeare thou dot adore the gods, and recompence this fair hepheardee, who has run o many hazards and mieries for thy ake. And if thou beet a man, then urely thou hat the qualitie of one, which is, to love the living and not the dead: If thou dot acknowledge the gods, dot thou not know they ue to punih uch as depie their ordinances? and that
Love never pardons crimes betwixt a Lover and a Loved.
If thou doet confee that he hath erved and loved thee even from her very cradle, Oh heavens, is it ever poible uch a long affection and agreeable ervice hould be payed with corne?

But admit, and uppoe that this affection and ervice being voluntary in Laonice and not courted or deired by Tircis: yet urely I cannot beleeve, Oh jut and wie Silvander, but you wil decree that a deceiver ought to make atisfaction unto the party deceived; and o by conequence Tircis who has o long deluded this fair Shepheardee by his diimulations and trickes, ought he not to repair the injury done her with a reall and unfaigned affection? He has long ued lyes and falities, let him at lat ue truths and honety; nor can I ever think you will decree that Tircis hould Love and live with a dead peron and not a living: but will rather doome his Love to be betowed upon me that can love him again, rather then upon a few could ahes in a coffin.
