But, good Tircis, tell me what thy deigne is: when thou hat drowned the ad reliques of poor Cleon in a flood of teares, dot thou think that it and all thy ighes and groanes can ever raie her up again? Alas, Caron never wafts any over but once, and is ever after deaf to all cries and calls; No no, Tircis, 'tis flat impiety to trouble the tranquillitie of thoe whom the gods have called to themelves: Amitie is ordained for the living, and coffins for the dead: do not then o prepoterouly, give thy affection unto the dead Cleon, and a coffin unto the living Laonice. This does not get thee the name of contant, for Cleon now has no interet in thee: mut one alwaies go naked becaue their firt cloathes are worne? And that is no more ridiculous then to heare you ay, that becaue Cleon your old Mitrie is worn away, therefore you will never have a new one. Fie fie; call your elfe to accompt: acknowledge your error; cat your elf at the feeet of this fair one, acknowledg unto her your fault, and o avoid that entence unto which our jut Judge by this entence will doom you.
Hylas thus ended with much contentment unto every one, except Tircis, whoe teares did tetifie the grandure of his griefe. When Phillis by the command of Silvander began to anwer Hylas, thus.

div.head: The Anwer of Phillis in the behalf of Tircis.
div.p: Oh Fair Cleon, who out of heaven hears the injury that is offered unto thee, inpire me with thy Divinity, for o I may wel eteem thee, if vertue couldever make any humane peron divine: and o furnih me with oliditie of reaons as I may make it mot apparant that Tircis ought never to love any but thy perfections. And you, prudent Judge, whoe widom is infinitly above my hallow conceptions, I beeech you, let the abundance of reaon which is in my caue, upply thoe wants that are in me. And, to begin, Let me tell you Hylas, that all thoe reaons which you have intanced for a proof that the loving party ought to be loved again, though they be fal, yet hall be allowed as good. But how can you conclude from them, that Tircis ought to betray the amitie of Cleon, by beginning a new love of Laonice? Thee are impoibilities, and contradictions: Impoible, becaue none is obliged unto more then they can do. How would you have this Shepheard love when he has no will? You laugh Hylas, when you heare me ay he has none. Faith, I do o, aid Hylas, I pray what has he done with it? He that loves anwered Phillis doth give his oul, it elf & all its faculties unto the party loved; and o by con; equenee his wil is not in his power. But this Cleon, replyed Hylas, being dead has nothing, and therefore Tircis ought to to take his own again.

Ah Hylas, Hylas, anwered Phillis, you talke like an ignorant in Love; for uch gifts as are dipoed on by Loves authoritie are for ever irrevocable. Pray then, aid Hylas, what is become of this will, ince the death of Cleon? The lee followes the greater, replied Phillis, if pleaure be the object of the will, if that ceae to be a pleaure, where's the will? And o it hath followed Cleon: if Cleon be not, then there is no will; for he had never had it but for her. But if Cleon be in ome certain place, as our Druids hold, that he is, then this will is in her hands, o contented in the place where he is, that if he her elfe would chae it away, he cannot returne it to Tircis, as knowing well it would be in vain, but it goes into the grave, and rets with her beloved Ahes: this being o, why do you tax the faithful Tircis with ingratitude, if it be in his power to love any other? Alo you do not only require things impoible, but alo things in themelves contraries; for if every one ought to love the party that loves, why hould he not then love Cleon, who never failed him in amitie? And as for the recompences which you demand, for the Services and Letters which Laonice carried: pray let her remember the contentment he received by them, and how merry he made herelfe as long as this fallacie lated, who otherwie would have droned out a dull and melancholy life. So as if he balance the payment which the ervice, I aure my elfe he will think her elfe very well payed You ay, Hylas that Tircis deceived her; but I ay it was no deceipt, but a jut punihment of love, who returned her own blows upon her elfe, for her intention was not to erve him, but to delude Cleon. Thus Silvander have I briefly anwered the fale reaons of this Sheapheard: and there remaines no more, but to make Laonice confee, that he injured Tircis in her unjut puruing of him; which I hall eaily do, if he will be but pleaed to anwer me. Fair Shepheardee, pray tell me, do you love Tircis? Shepheardee, anwered he all that knowes me knowes I do. If he were forced to be abent, replyed Phillis, and another in the mean time hould court you, would you not change affection? No, anwered he, for I would till hope he would returne. If you heard that he would never return (aid Phillis) would you then ceae to love him?

No certainly, anwered he. Then, Fair Laonice anwered Phillis, think it not trange that Tircis who knowes that his Cleon is in heaven, that he ees all his actions, and rejoyceth in his fidelity, hould not change the affection he bore unto her: nor let this ditance of place eperate their loves, ince all the hindrances of life could never do it. Do not beleeve what Hylas aid, that none ever returnes over the River Acheron; many that have been beloved of the gods, have both gone and come; and who knowes, but Cleon who was adorned with o many excellencies of oul, may find the ame favour from Love: Oh Laonice! were but your eyes permitted to look upon Divinitie; you would ee that Cleon to defend her own caue is in this place, and whipers thee words into my eares, which I utter in her defence. Then would you confee, that Hylas was in the wrong when he aid, that Tircis was mad to love her cold ahes. Me thinks I ee her in the midt of us, and in lieu of a fragile body, ubject unto humane accidents, he is cloathed with glorious imortality;
and chiding Hylas for the blaphemies he had breathed againt her. What wouldt thou anwer, Hylas, if thy happy Cleon hould ay thus unto thee? Wilt thou offer, O thou incontant wretch, to tain my Tircis with thy own inidelity? If he did heretofore love me, dot thou think it was my Body? If thou houldt anwer, Yes, I would then reply, that then he ought to be condemned to love the ahes which I have left in my Coffin, as long as they will lat: For, a Lover never ought to retreat from a Love once begun. If thou dot confee that it was my Soul he loved, which was my principall part: then, Oh thou fond and uncontant inner, why hould he now change his will, ince he is now more perfectly glorious than ever he was? Otherwie, (uch is the miery of the living) I hould be jealous I hould be vexed, and I hould be een by many eyes as I am by his: But now I am delivered from uch mortall imperfections, and am no more capable of any infirmities. And wouldt thou, Hylas, with thy acrilegious perwaions, divert him from me, in whom I only lived upon earth? and, by a mot barbarous cruelty, endeavour to give me a econd death? Oh! mot horrid to hear: Thee words, wie Silvander, do make uch a Turring ound in my ears, as, I do believe, they will make your heart reent them as well as mine. And therefore, to let this divinity argue the caue in your oul, I will be ilent only let me hint thus much unto you, that Love is o jut, as you your elfe ought to tand in awe of his punihing hand, if Laonice's pitty, rather then Cleon's reaons, hould move you.

At this word Phillis made a low congee, intimating thereby, that he had no more to ay in the behalfe of Tircis. Laonice offered to anwer further, but Silvander would not uffer her, aying, that now he was to hear the entence, which the gods would pronounce by his mouth. Then after he had weighed the reaons on both ides, he pronounced this Doom.

div.head: The Judgment of Silvander.
div.p: THe principall point in the caue debated before us, is, to know whether Love can die, by the death of the party loved Unto which I ay, that the Love which is perihable is not right Love; for, it ought to follow the ubject which gave it life; and therefore thoe who love only the Body, ought to encloe their love of that body in the ame Coffin where it is; but, uch as love the Soul, ought, with their love, to flie after this loved Soul, as far as the highet heavens, and no ditance ought to eparate them. All thee things therefore well conidered, I do ordain, that Tircis do love his Cleon till; and that the two Loves which are in us, the one do follow the Body into the grave, and the other the Soul into heaven. That Tircis do not any more diturb the ret of Cleon's Soul, by any compliance unto the importunities of Laonice. This is the Will of the gods pronounced by me.

Having thus given Sentence, not taying to hear the complaints of Laonice and Hylas, he made a low congie unto Leonida and the ret of the company, and went away without any company, but Phillis, who would not tarry to hear the ad reentments of this Shepheardee. And becaue it was late, Leonida went that night unto Diana's houe, with all the ret of the Shepheards and Shepheardees, except Laonice, who was o extreamly offended at Silvander and Phillis, as he wore, he would not go out of that Country before he had done them ome remarkable dipleaure. It eemes fortune did conduct her as he deired; for having left the company, and itting down in the wood where he might with more liberty lament her diaters, her better Genius did repreent before the eyes of her fancy, the inupportable didain of Tircis, how he was unworthy of her Love, and was o ahamed of his fault, as he vowed a thouand times to hate him, and, for his ake, both Silvander and Phillis. Whilt thee things thus paed in her memory, it hapned, that Lycidas, who, of late, was dipleaed with Phillis, for ome coldnee towards him, epied Silvander and her talking together. 'Tis true, this Shepheardee was not altogether o full of triviall expreions of Love to him, as 'he was before her frequent aociation with Diana for that new amitie together with the delight which Atrea, Diana, and he took in being together, did o much take her up, as he minded not thoe fond trifles of affection, which nourihed the love of Lycidas; o as he had a conceit, that the reaon why he was not o converant with him as before, was ome new Love which had diverted her from him: and not being able to imagine who it hould be, that he now loved, he went wandring up and down in places mot melancholy and unfrequented, that he might with more freedome lament his mieries: And as ill luck was, he pied, as I told you before,
Silvander and Phillis in dicoure together, which ight did not a little increae his jealouie; for, knowing the merits of the Shepheard and Shepheardee, he eaily believed, that Silvander, who never yet loved any, had betowed himelfe upon her; and that he, according to the humour of her Sex, did willingly accept of the gift.

Thee coniderations did much tir up his upition; but much more, when they paing by him, and not eeing him, be heard, or thought he heard, the words of a Lover; and thoe perhaps were only ome repetition of Silvander's entence. But, to put himelfe out of all patience, it happened, that having let them pae by, he did rie out of the place where he was, and becaue he would not follow them, took the contrary way, and as fortune would have it, he did it down neer the place where Laonice was, who all this while never aw him. After he had a while nured upon his mihaps, and being tranported with the thoughts of them, he cryed out aloud, Oh Love! is it poible thou houldet uffer uch an injury to pae unpunihed? Wilt thou recompene wrongs and ervices with equall favours? Afterwards, being a while ilent, with croed armes, and eyes turned up to the skies, he breathed out many a ad igh, and then began again.

I plainly ee, that there is not any contancy in any woman: Phillis, becaue he will hew that he is of the ame Sex, and though otherwie full of perfection, yet in this he is ubject to her Sexes naturall incontancy. Phillis, I ay, of whoe affection I have been heretofore more aured, than of my own will. But Oh, my Shepheardee, am I not the very elfeame Lycidas that I was before, and whoe affection has been o welcome unto you? Mut I now be cat off, and Silvander ucced in my happinee? a tranger a vagabond, a man that all the world depieth, and cannot own him for any poeor of any part in it. Laonice, who overheard, hearing him name Phillis and Silvander, and being deirous to know more, he began to hearken more attentively, o as he heard him utter the mot ecret thoughts, both of himelfe and Phillis: and from thence he reolved to ooth him up in his opinion, auring her elfe, that if Phillis loved Lycidas, he hould make him jealous; and if he loved Silvander, he would o divulge it to the world, that every one hould know it. So when Lycidas was gone, for his tormented minde would not let him belong in one place, he came out of her lurking place, and following after, he overtook him as he was talking to Corilas, whom he met upon the way; and faigning to enquire ome newes of a diconolate Shepheard, they anwered, that they knew of no uch. He is a Shepheard, aid he, who wanders up and down lamenting a dead Shepheardee; and I am told he ueth to be every afternoon in the company of the fair Shepheardee, Phillis, and her Servant. Her Servant, anwered Lycidas, who is that? I know not, aid he, but it is uch a name as Silander or Silvander, or ome uch like; he is of a middle tature, his face omething long, and of a very pleaing humour when he will. But who told you, replied Lycidas, that he was her Servant? Both their actions, anwered he; for I know what I have both een and heard of them: But, I pray tell me, if you know any way how I hould meet with him I look for? Lycidas was o urpried, that he could not anwer a word; but Corilas told her, that if he followed on that path, it would bring her through the wood into a Meadow, where they ued to aemble; and let he hould loe her way, he would be her companion if he pleaed. She eemed as if he did not know the way, and was very glad of his courteous offer: So bidding goodnight unto Lycidas, went along with her companion. But Lycidas was o much out of himelfe, that he tood till immovable a long while; but at lat, recollecting himelfe, he ruminated upon the words of this Shepheardee, unto which he could not chue but give much credit. It would be too long to relate his dolefull expreions and injuries he did unto the faithfull Phillis. But all the night long he wandred in the thick wood, and in the morning he was o tired out with his woes and walking, that he was forced to lie down under a tree, and with eyes welled with tears, at the lat he fell aleep.

Aoon as day did break Diana, Atrea, and Phillis did rie, to the end they might be ready to wait upon Leonida, as oon as he was up; but he was o much taken with their weetnee and courtey, that he had dreed her elfe by the firt dawning of the day, that he might not mie a minute of their company, whilt he tayed with them; o as thee Shepheardees, when they opened her Chamber dore, did all wonder at her earlinee; and after all had done their morning complement, they went out of the houe, to begin the ame exercies which they had the day before; and aoon as ever they came into the meadow, they epied Silvander, who, under the colour of a faigned courthip of Diana, began to be really in earnet, and in love with her: He was o intent upon this new growing love,
that he had not cloed an eye all the night, but till paed away the time in thinking upon the dicoure and getures of Diana, which he had een and heard the day before; o as Aurora no ooner began to viit his window, but he was up, and waited for the coming of his new Mitree; and as oon as he aw her, he ung thee Veres as he met her.

lg.l: HOpes, that Ixion like do well o high,
As levell at the heavens upremacy,
Are too audacious, and do aim much higher,
Than does become their duty to apire.
Prometheus when he filch'd Celetiall fire,

l.hi: And o provoked all the gods to ire:
My joyes (aid he) amidt my torments are,
That I have done what none before did dare.

lg.l: Fond Icarus, with his faint feathers plum'd,

l.hi: Like Eagles in the air, to tie preum'd:
But yet in pite of danger, he did aim
At Altitudes, and did attempt the ame:

lg.l: As Eccho for the love of fair Narcie,

l.hi: Did tell the Rocks how great his torment is:
He cheered up himelfe, and aid, if he
Do not me love, no other lov'd hall be.
Although he be all overaignty,
As high as heaven, and be a deitie:
Yet till my high-blown hopes will have the glory,
To enterprie an Act beyond all tory.

div.p:
Phillis being of a very merry and pleaant humour, reolved to undertake the task that was impoed upon her; therefore turning off towards Diana, Mitree (aid he) you mut take heed what this Shepheard aies unto you; for, yeterday he did not love you, but to day he is ready to die for love of you: he hould have begun ooner to erve you, or ele have tayed longer, before he ued any uch language as this. Silvander was o neer as to hear this: and therefore aid, I beeech you fairet Mitree, top your ears from the detracting language of my enemy. Mut you needs, Phillis, build up your own happinee by the ruine of mine? Dare you, Silvander, (anwered Phillis) be o bold, as to peak of happinee before Diana's face? I wonder what impudent phraes you will ue behinde her back, who aume to your elfe o much before her face? Would you have my Mitree to think, that it is not my happinee to erve her (aid Silvander)? and why, I pray, hould I not tell it is o, ince it is nothing but a mot certain truth? You may as well ay, aid Phillis, that he does love you, and cannot live out of your ight. I do not ay o, anwered Silvander; but, let me ay unto you by way of anwer, that I wih with all my heart, it were o: But, do you think it o trange, I hould ay, that I think it a happinee to erve my Mitree? If you do, I pray let me ask, what happinee do you finde in erving her? Though I hould think it a happinee, replyed Phillis, yet urely, I would not brag of it. It is ingratitude, replyed Silvander, to receive a benefit and not to give thanks for it; and how is it poible to love a peron that is ungratefull? From hence I judge (aid Leonida, and interrupted) that Phillis does not love Diana. Mot will concur in that judgment, anwered Silvander, and I believe, Diana her elf does think o. I beeech you, hew your reaon for this opinion, aid Phillis, if you think to bring me into it. The Affirmative part, aid Silvander, mut alwaies be proved, and not the Negative: The quetion is, whether or no you do love Diana? You affirm, and I deny it; and therefore it is your part to prove it. Phillis was at a tand for an anwer, when Atrea aid, Siter, do you hear and allow of what the Shepheard aies? I do hear, but not allow of it, anwered he, for I hould be put upon a
hard task to prove it. If o (aid Diana) I mut think you do not love me: for, Silvander demands nothing but what is reaon. Upon this, the Shepheard addreed himelfe unto Diana, and aid unto her, Mot fair, and no lee jut, Mitee, it is now impoible my enemy can be o impudent as to ay, that I have not an infinite happinee in erving you, you are pleaed to give uch a favourable anwer in my behalfe. By Diana's aying, that Phillis does not love her, aid Atrea, he does not thereby ay, that you do love her, or that he loves you. Should I but hear uch heavenly words, anwered he, come from the mouth of my Mitree, as, I do love you, or, You do love me, I hould not only think this a happinee, but be ravihed with joy, and yet ince he is ilent, it argues a conent unto what he heares: Why therefore may I not ay, that he confeeth he loves me? Did Love conit in words, replyed Phillis, you are more in love than all men I know, put together; and you can argue a bad Caue better than any Lawyer. Leonida was o delighted with the dicoure of thee Shepheardees, that had he not been troubled for Celadon, he could have tayed amongt them as long as he had lived: And that was the reaon he deired them to walk with her towards the River-ide, homewards; and they were very ready to wait upon her: for, beides the complement of common courteie, they were much delighted in her company.

So then, he taking Diana on the one ide and Atrea on the other, they walked along; but Silvander was further from Diana than Phillis, he having taken that place which he deired; at which the vain-glorious Phillis was not a little glad, and laught at the Shepheard, aying, that her Mitree might eaily judge which of them was mot ready to erve her, ince he had applied her elfe o officiouly to be near her, and he never cared. My Mitree, anwered he, did admit you to the honour of that place, for your importunities ake, and not your affection for had you loved her, you would have uffered me to enjoy that place which you do. Nay rather the contrary, anwered Phillis, if I had let any come neerer her than my elfe: For, a Lover thinks he can never be neer enough the peron Loved. That Lover, anwered Silvander, who regards his own particular contentment more, then the contentment of the party Loved, does not deerve the title of a Lover o as you regarding your own delight, in being o neer your Mitree, more then her atisfaction, it cannot be aid you do love her, but your elfe only; for, were I in your room, I hould lead her, and help her to walk, whereas you do only trouble her. Did my Mitree cold with me as you do, replyed Phillis, I know not whether I hould love her or no. I am mot certain, aid the Shepheard, that, were I in lieu of your Mitree, I hould never love you. How dare you offer uch an affront, as to ay, you think you hould not love her upon any condition? This, Phillis, is a grand maxime in the Law of Love, that thoe who can think they cannot love upon any conditions, are no Lovers: for, Love does not admit of any Ifs or Conditions, but is alwaies abolute.

Mitree, I demand jutice, and require it on the part of Love, that you punih this crime of o high a nature, and that you will remove her from that place which is too honourable for her, that thinks he hall not love; and place me in the room, who lives only to love you. Mitree, aid Phillis, I perceive, that this envier at my happinee will never let me alone, untill I quit the place; and I fear he will, with his mooth language, move you to conent unto it: and therefore, with your favour, I will leave it unto him, upon condition, that he tell you one thing which I hall ask him. Silvander never taying for the anwer of Diana, aid unto Phillis, The condition is eaie, and I will never refue it; ince without it, I hould never conceal any thing which he deires to know. Then Phillis did yield him the place, and aid unto him, Envious Shepheard, though the place is not to be bought and old, yet, you have promied more for it than you are aware; for, you are obliged to tell us who you are, and what occaion brought you into this Country: for, you have been long amongt us, and we are all ignorant of what you are. Leonida, who was very deirous to know who Silvander was, aid unto Phillis thus, Believe me, Phillis, you have hewed much prudence in this propoition; for I believe none here, but does much deire the ame atisfaction. I wih, aid Silvander, that I could atisfie your deires; but Fortune hath o denyed it unto me, as I may well ay, that I am more deirous, and almot as ignorant of it as you are: For, Fate only ent me into the world, lets me know that I do live, but conceals from me all other knowledge of my elfe: And that you hould not believe that I am any thing unwilling to perform my promie, I do wear unto you by all the gods, and by the beauty of Diana, that I will truly tell you all that I know of my elf.

div.head: The Hitory of Silvander.
div.p: WHen Aetius was Lieutenant General in Gaul unto the Emperour Valentinian, hee thought it very dangerous unto the Romans, that Gondeoch the firt King of the Burgundians hould be poeed of the greatet part, and therefore reolved to drive him out, and drive him on the other ide of the Rhine, from whence he came a little before, when Stilico, for the good ervice he had done the Romans againt Radagrie the Goth, gave him the ancient Provinces of the Authunois, and Seguinois, and Allobroges, whom he named Burgundy, without the command of Valentinian: and it is to be thought he did it, onely to get all the Forces of the Empire into his own hands: But the Emperour, having his hands full of many enemies, as the Goths, the Huns, the Vandals, and the Franks, who were ready to fall upon him in everal places, he commanded Aetius to let them alone in peace which was not o oon put into execution, but firt the Burgundians had already received great routs, and their enemies made uch ravage and wate, as they carried away with them all they found.

I then being ome five or ix years of age, was with many others carried away unto the utmot Town of the Allobroges, by ome Burgundians, who out of revenge went into thoe Countries that were confederate with their enemies, and committed the ame diorders which they had received. I cannot tell you why they took me, unlee in ome hopes of money for a ranom; but my fortune was o kind unto me, as I fell into the hands of an Helvetian, who had an old and very rich Father, and who taking a liking to me, either for my phyiognomy, or ome pleaing anwer which my young Genius gave him, did take me unto himelf, with intention to educate me in Literature: And though the Son was much againt it, yet the Father continued his deign, and pared no cot or care to intruct me in all Learning, ending me unto the Univerities of the Muilians, in the Province of the Romans. So as I may very well ay, that I had been lot if I had not been lot. However though nothing was more utable to my Genius than Learning, yet was it a continual torment unto me, to be ignorant from whence and who I was; thinking till this to bee a greater misfortune than hapned unto any other. And being much troubled at it, a friend advied me to enquire the truth from the Oracle, for I was o young when I was firt taken, that my memory could not inform me any thing of my birth, or parents, or place from whence I came; but this friend had uch a perwaive power over me, that both of us went together unto the Oracle, and the anwer which we received was this.

lg.head: THE ORACLE.

l.hi: Born thou wert within a Land

lg.l: Where Neptune lately did command.

l.hi: To know the place which gave thee birth

lg.l: Thou cant not, till Silvanders death.

l.hi: This from thy cradle is thy Fate,
To which thou art Predestinate.

div.p: Judge (fair Diana) what atisfaction I received from this anwer. For my part, I reolved to it till and enquire no further, ince it was impoible to know any more, unles I dyed; but lived afterwards in much more tranquillity of mind, referring my elf unto the conduct of heaven, and applying my elf unto my tudies, in which I was o good a proficient, that old Abariel (for that was the name of his Father who took me away) had a longing deire to ee me before hee dyed. Being come unto him, and entertained as well as I could wih, one day when I was alone with him in his chamber, he poke thus unto me.

My Son (for o have I ever eteemed you, ince the rigour of War brought you into my hands) I do not think you to be o ignorant of what I have done for you, as to make any
doubt of my good will towards you. Yet if my cares to intruct your youth have not given you a knowledge of it, I will; becaue I do intend very well towards you. You know that my Son Ahazides, who took you, and brought you to me, hath a Daughter as dear unto me as my elf: And becaue I deire to pend thoe few dayes I have to live, in ret and tranquillity, I do intend to <…> you unto her, and to betow upon you uch a portion of my etate, as I may live with you as long as it hall pleae the Gods. Doe not think, that this is a leight and random deign, but a thing of mature and long deliberation; for having by a well experienced knowledge found, your inclinations utable unto my mind, I reolved to etablih the tranquillity of my old age in you, and therefore ent you to the Univerities, knowing that nothing renders a oul more capable of reaon than learning and knowledge doth: And in your abence I have o dipoed my Grandchild to marry you, as he out of her complacency to me, is contented, and deires it as much as my elf. 'Tis very true, he much deires to know, what, and from whence you are; and for her atisfaction. I have often enquired of Azahides who took you, but he could give no other anwer, but that he found you about the River Rone and out of the Province of Vienoie; but perhaps you might better remember, ince you were then ome five or ix yeares old: And asking him, whether your habit could not give him any knowledge of your Parents, he anwered, No; and that you were o young, that there was no gheing at your Quality by your habit. So as, my Son, if your own memory cannot give you any light unto our knowledge, none ele can.

Then the good old Abariel took me by the hand, and prayed me to tell him, all that I knew, or could remember of my elf. To whom, after many expreions of gratitude and obligations to him for my education, and this propoal of Marriage, I anwered him, that truly I was o very young when I was taken, as I could not remember any thing either of my Parents or Quality. I am extreamly orry for it (replied the good old man); but ince it cannot be helped, I will not o much as mention my deign unto Azahides, until I know how you approve of this my deign. And I anwering him, that I hould be too ungratefull if I did not wholly obey him in all things, he caued me to retire, and ent for his Son, to acquaint him with his intentions, who did abolutely reject the motion, and would by no means hear of it. Afterwards, the good old man, ince he could not obtain his conent freely told him thus much; Ahazides (aid he unto him) if you will not betow your Daughter upon whom I would, I will betow my etate upon whom you would not: Therefore either marry her unto Silvander, or ele I will make him my heir. Ahazides, who was of a very covetous dipoition, and feared to loe the etate, eeing his Father o peremptory, did eem to bend a little, and deired ome daies of conideration, which the good old man did conent unto, deiring to doe all things by weetnes and lenity, and afterwards to acquaint me, but he needed not; for I found it by the eyes and dicoure of his Son, who begun to chide and ue me o ill as I was not able to endure it. Then during the time of conideration which was prefixed, he commanded his daughter, who was much better than her father, upon pain of death (for he was a man of a bloody and murtherous temper) to eem unto the good old man, as if he were very orry her father was not conformable unto his will, and that he therefore would obey him, and would be ready to marry me privately: And all this was only a deign to murder me. The poor Grandchild was extreamly perplexed; for on the one ide the menaces of her cruel father did terrifie her; on the other ide, her affection unto me would not permit her tender years to uch a piece of cruelty, o as in a trembling manner he came to the good old man, and told him, that he would marry me ecretly: And then it was o concluded upon. So as the good man did abolutely command me to be ready, and I, notwithtanding all my doubts, durt not diobey.

The Plot was o laid, that I hould climb up to the window of her chamber, and there marry her ecretly. The houe was eated upon the Lake Lemane, where the waves did beat againt it, and then fell into the Rone, which runs through the middle of it. The deign of Azahides was to draw me up with a rope to the middle of the wall, and afterwards to let me fall into the Lake: where being drowned, no news would be heard of me: for, the Rone, which runs with a montrous impetuoity, would have carried me quite away. A thouand to one, but his deign had been executed; for I was fully reolved to obey the good old Abariel, had not his poor Grandchild moved with compaion, and horrour of the fact, acquainted me with it, the very day before it hould have been done: And in a trembling manner aid thus unto me: You ee, Silvander, that in aving your
life, I do run the hazard of my own death; for I know that Ahazides will never pardon me, but however, I had rather die innocent, than live guilty of your death. After my many thanks, I told her, that he needed not to fear the fury of Ahazides; for I would take a coure both for her afety and my own, but told her that he mut be ure to be ecret. Againt the appointed night I provided my elf <> the mony I could get, unknown to Abariel: And when the appointed hour was come
<…> had taken my leave of the good old man, who came with me to the water ide, I went into the little Boat which hee had provided for me. Then going under the window, I made a hew as if I had tyed my elf unto the rope, but it was only my clothes tuffed full of Sand; then puhing my elf a little on one ide to ee what would be done, I heard it preently fall into the Lake, where, with my Our I beat the water, that they hearing the noie, might think it was I who was fluttering in the water: But I was quickly forced to put further off; for they cat down o many tories, as I came hardly off with my life. Preently after I aw a light in the window, and fearing to be dicovered, I layd my elf all along in the Boat; and o they did not ee me, but thought the Boat floated away of it elf. Then, when every one was gone from the window. I heard a great noie by the water ide where I left Abariel: and as I thought, I heard his cry, caued by my fall into the water, and fearing I was drown'd; but I did reolve not to return, though extreamly orry that I hould not erve the good old Abariel in his old age: But being aured of Ahazides his ill will unto me, I knew that though not at this time, yet at ome other he would execute his murtherous intention: So as coming to Land at the place where I had layd other clothes, and the bet of my things, I took them, and leaving my Boat. I betook my elf to Land, and travelled o long, that, extreamly weary, I arrived at Evians at the break of day, and was forced there to ret my tyred limbs all the day; where not being known, I went, as many others did upon urgent occaions to ask advice of the age Belinda, who was Mitris of all the Vetals about the Lake; and who, as ince I undertand, is Mother unto my fair Mitris. Having acquainted her with all my diaters, he conulted with the Oracle, and the next day told me, that the gods did command me not to wonder at my afflictions, and that if I would ever come out of them, it was neceary I hould look into the Fountain of the Verity of Love, becaue in that water was my onely remedy. And that as oon as I aw my elf in it, I hould know my Father and my Country. And asking her in what place that Fountain was, he told me it was in this Country of Forrets. Then he told me the property and inchantments of it, o courteouly, as I thought my elf infinitely obliged unto her.

Upon this, I reolved to come hither, where at my firt coming I met with Celadon, from whom I had information where this admirable Fountain was: But as I was in my way to it, I fell o ick, as I was forced to keep my chamber ix months: And when I was wel, I undertood from ome about that place, how a Magician, at the intance of Clidamas, had et two Lyons and two Unicorns to guard it, and that the Inchantment could not be diinchanted but by the death of two of the mot perfect Lovers that ever came into this Country.

Heavens know how much I was grieved at this news, ince it had o prevented me in my o much deired hopes. However, ince this was the Country which the Heavens had deigned to give me knowledge of my Parents, I thought it bet for me to tay in it; hoping that at lat thee two Lovers o faithful, might be found out: But certainly it was o rare a thing to be found, as I had little reaon for my hopes. But with this deign I put my elf into the garb of a Shepheard, that I might more freely enjoy the company of thoe about the River Lignon: And to be the more acceptable unto them, I betowed the ret of my mony in a flock of Sheep, and building a little Cabin.

This, fair Leonida, is all I doe know of my elf: And this is the price of that Room which I have bought of Phillis. I am very glad to know o much (anwered Leonida) & do hope your fortune will be good, ince the gods doe eem to have a care of it by their Oracles: and for my part, I am a very zealous wiher of it. So am not I (aid Phillis) nor do I wih he may ever come to the knowledge of his Parents: For if he hould perhaps their merits might work much upon my Mitris: For matter of Etate and Alliance, is more conidered in Mariages, than the love or merit of the party. See aid Silvander, how you undertand it; you are not o much againt me, but that I hope by your means to come unto the knowledge of that which I o much deire. By my means, aid he, how can that be? Yes by your means, aid Silvander; for ince the Lyons mut be quelled by the blood of two faithful Lovers, why hould not I beleeve that you and I are they? Well may I
be faithfull, anwered Phillis, but I am ure I am not valiant, I hall love my Mitrie as much as any in the world; but as for matter of life, I pray you pardon me; for what ervice could I do unto her if I were dead. I aure you, anwered Diana, I do value both your lives infinitly above your deaths, and had rather be my elfe in dainger of death, then to ee either of you o for my ake.

Whilt they were thus dicouring and comming neer to the bridge of Boutree, they epyed a man a far off comming very fat; and when he was neerer, Leonida knew him to be Paris, Son to the great Druide, Adamas, who being returned from Feurs, and hearing that his Neece was to look for him, did end his Son to acquaint her that he was returned: alo to know what occaio¯ moved her to come o alone, it not being her cutom to go with out company. As oon as he knew Paris, he named him unto the Fair Shepheardees, and they according to their habituall civility, when he came neere them did alute him with abundance of courteie o as had not the carrees of Leonida a little diverted him, he could hardly have concealed his udden urprie. Yet after the firt complements were pat, and after he had delivered his Meage unto her. But Siter (aid he for o Adamas would have them call one another) how came you to meet with uch Fair and good company? Truly Brother, anwered he, A good fate brought me to them and I have been two dayes together, neverlee weary in my life then with them. This aid he, and pointed to Atrea, is the Fair Shepheardee o famed, and deervedly for her beauty. Her name is Atrea: and that, poynting at Diana, is the Daughter of Belinda and Celion: The other is called Phillis: and This Shepheard is the unknowne Silvander, whoe merits yet are o known as all the Country does love him. I wear, aid Paris, my Father feares of your falling into ill company, were groundlee and had he known you had been o well, I am ure he would not have been o much diquieted as he is.

Generous Paris, aid Silvander a peron that is owner of o much vertue as this Fair Nymph is, can never be ill accompanied epecially being amongt o many wie and fair Shepheardees as thee. Upon thee words he looked upon Diana, who conceiving her elfe invited to it, anwered; it is impoible, noble Paris, to add any thing unto that which is already compleat, but yet, aid Paris, I had much rather be with her, when he is with you, than when he is alone. This, Sir, proceeds from the fluency of your courteie, anwered he that are pleaed to ue uch language unto trangers: You cannot ay that you are trangers unto me, aid Paris, unlee you ay that I am a tranger unto you, which indeed is a hame unto me, that I hould be o neer a neighbour unto o many beauties of o much merit, and yet hould carcely know them: but I am mot extreamly orry for my fault and hall for the future endeavour to repaire it: As he aid o, he turned towards the Nymph, and, you Siter, aid he, though I came alone, and intended to wait upon you from hence to Adamas, yet I mut needs tay here untill night. I hould be glad, aid he if I could do the like: but I am now forced to go about my buinee, yet I am reolved o to ettle all my affaires, as to live amongt thee wie and fair Shepheardees: for I cannot think any life upon earth, o happy as theirs. With uch expreions as thee he took leave of the fair Shepheardees, after a hundred imbraces and promies to returne again very hortly; and went away o very well contented, as he reolved to quit the vanity of the Court, for the implicity of this life: but her greatet inducement unto it, was her deigne of getting Celadon out of Galatheas hand, and becaue he thought he would preently returne unto this town, where he intended to work upon him under the hadow of thee Shepheardees.

This was the voyage of Leonida, who in her progree, aw the beginning of two great loves; that of Silvander under the umbrage of a wager, and that of Paris both unto Diana: for Paris did ever ince this day, fall o extreamly in love with her, that to get more familiarity with her, he quitted his accutomed life, and put on the habit of a Shepheard, and would be called o purpoely to render himelfe more amiable in the eye of his Mitris, who for her part did honour him, as his merits and good inclination to her did oblige her: but becaue we have much to ay of them, in the equell of our dicoure, therefore we will ay no more of them now.

Returning then unto the Town as they paed through the plain where commonly their flocks did feed, they epy'd a far off Tircis, Hylas, & Lycidas, the two firt of which eemed by their actions to be in a very earnet argument: for the head, the arms, & every part of Hylas did peak as much: As for Lycidas, he was all in himelfe, his hat pulled down over his eyes; his armes foulded, and looking upon his feet, did hew there was omthing which much affected his oul. And when they were within the ken of each other, Hylas
epying Phillis amongt the Shepheardees; he left Tircis and went to her, then without any alute unto the ret of the company, he took her by the hand, and according to the uuall freedom of his humour; in plain tearmes he told her, how great a deire he had to erve her. Phillis being glad to pae away the time with him, aid thus, I do not know Hylas, from whence this deire of yours hould grow. For there is nothing in me which can invite it: if you do beleeve what you ay, anwered he, then you are o much the more beholding to me; and if you do not beleeve it, then you mut think me to be a man of judgement, and knowes who deerves my ervice, and o you mut the more eteem me for it. Never doubt, aid he, but however I hall eteem you, and accept of your amitie according to the merits of its deert, were it for no other conideration, but becaue you are the firt that ever loved me.

As fortune was, Lycidas came in, jut as thee words were poken, whoe jealouie was already grown to uch a height, as it did urpae his affection; and as ill luck was, he came time enough to hear the anwer which Hylas returned unto Phillis, which was this: I know not, Fair Shepheardee, whether you will continue unto me the ame goodnee you have begun; but if you do, I am ure Silvander will forbid the banes; and, if to pleae you, he do not, yet I am ure, that all thoe who aw him yeterday with you, will tetifie, that he is your ervant: I cannot tell whether or no he left his love under his Pillow, but if he did not, you are his Mitree. Silvander never thought of Lycidas his love unto Phillis, but thinking it were a hame for him to diavow what Hylas aid, alo conceiving he hould offend Phillis if he hould; epecially before her face; he anwered thus unto him: Shepheard, you need not eek for any other tetimony in this matter, but my elf: Never think, that the Shepheards of Lignon can o oon put on & off their affection they are dull and groe, and low in all they do; but, as the bigger the Naile is the greater weight it upports, and is harder to be pulled out, o the more groe we are in our affections, the longer do they tay in our ouls So as if you have een me the Servant of this fair Shepheardes, very likely you hall ee me o again; for, we do not ue to change every time we leep; but, if you ue to do o, who have a hot brain, as the baldnee of your head, and curling of your hair doth hew, you mut not judge of us, by your own more nimble and tirring inclination. Hylas hearing this Shepheard's freedome of language, and o pat to his own humour, did think, that either Tircis had told him omething, or ele, that he had known him formerly: And therefore, Shepheard, aid he, have you heretofore een me, or do you peak this of me by heareay? I did never ee you before, aid Silvander; but your phyiognomie and dicoure does prompt me unto what I ay: For, one hall hardly upect another of that fault, whereof themelves are clear. Therefore, aid Hylas, you cannot be exempt from uncontancy, ince you do upect me. Supition, replied Silvander, proceeds either from ome little appearance, or from no appearance but our own imagination: but, what I ay of you is not upon any upition, but upon a certain aurance. Do you call it upition, when I heard you ay that you once loved Laonice, and then quitted her for another, that other for a third, and that third for Phillis, who doubtlee you will quit upon the firt ight of any new commer? Tircis hearing this dicoure, and eeing Hylas at a non-plus, began to fall thus upon him: Hylas aid he, you are now plainly dicovered, and it boots you not to conceal your elfe any longer; the dicerning eyes of this Shepheard can find out your incontancy; and therefore your bet way is, to confee the truth, againt which, if you contend, you will finde, that he will prove you a lyar, and o you will quite loe your reputation: Confee it therefore freely and to encourage you, I will break the Ice and begin; Know, generous Shepheard, that this Hylas is the mot incontant, the mot diloyall, and the mot perfidious Shepheard that ever promied affection. Then added Phillis He does much oblige thoe whom he does not love. What Mitree, anwered Hylas, will you be alo againt me? Can you give any credit to the impotures of this malitious man? Do you not ee, that Tircis, thinking himelfe obliged unto Silvander, for the entence which he gave on his ide, does think to repay it back, by infuing an ill opinion of me into you? What does that argue, (aid Phillis unto Silvander)? What does it argue, aid the incontant Shepheard? do you not know, that it is a greater difficulty to take a place which is already poeed, than one which is not taken up by any? His meaning is, added Silvander, that as long as you love him, it will be hard for me to get into your favour. But, my friend Hylas, I believe you are much mitaken; for, though I ee, he daignes to cat her eye a little upon you, yet, am I very confident of her amitie; for, out of a ound judgment I do know, that he will alwaies make choice of the
better. To which Hylas anwered, Perhaps you think, vain-glorious Shepheard, that you have ome advantage of me; but, I pray, where does it lye? none can ee it, nor does my Mitree believe it. What kinde of a illy thing is he, that never had the courage or confidence, to love and erve above one Mitree? and that too, o faintly and imply, as you would wear he mocked her: whereas I, that have loved as many Beauties as I have een, I have been bid welcome by them all. What pittifull ervice is to be expected from him, that knowes not where to begin? But I, that have courted and erved all orts, of all ages, conditions and humours, I can turn, and winde, and do any thing to pleae or dipleae: And, for a proof of what I ay, I pray give me leave to catechie him a little, that you may ee his illinee. Then turning towards Silvander, he asked him, what that was, which would mot oblige a fair Shepheardee to love? It is, aid Silvander, to love only her. And what is it, aid Hylas, which will mot pleae her? It is, anwered Silvander, to love her extreamly. Do you ee (aid Hylas) what a implician this is: Why, this is the way together corn and hatred; for, to love her only gives her an occaion to think, that it is for want of courage that you dare not attempt to love any ele, and therefore he will corn uch a faint hearted Lover: whereas, did you love all you look upon, he would not think you come to her, becaue you knew not whither to go ele; but, he will then prie you the higher, and will be obliged to love you, epecially, if you particularize her above any other, and tell her ome tories which you have gleaned from others; then, once a week come and profee your ervice, or may be oftner, if a good occaion require, this will render you more pleaing, and invite her to cherih your company. This is the way, fond Novice, to oblige her unto love; but, to pule and pleae her continually, is the only way to make her look aquint at you: Nothing is o tiring and tedious, as thee huge and extream affections; uch as love, o, mut needs be perpetually imprioned, never at liberty, alwaies preent, continually talking to her; he cannot tir a foot but you mut do the like. To be briefe, you are abominably troubleome to her. But, the Devill of all is, if he chance to be at any time ill, and do not mile upon you, nor pleae you forooth, then mut you put the finger to eye and cry; cry tears, inomuch as you force her to flie you. Do you think this to be the way to make her love you: No, no, it is in Love as in all things ele, the Mean is the bet Meaure; o as to avoid all thee frivolous follies, the only way is to love but indifferently; and the bet way to pleae her, is to be pleaant, merry, and jocund; and, above all, never to be mute before her. This, Silvander, is the way to make a Shepheardee love you, and to get her favour. And you, fairet Mitrae, may by this ee how to value my affection. She would have anwered, but Silvander beeeched her to give him leave to peak And then he did examine Hylas upon thee Interrogatories. What is it, Shepheard, that you deire mot when you do love? To be loved again, anwered Hylas. But when you are loved, replied Silvander, what do you deire or expect from this amity? that the peron whom I love, anwered Hylas, do prize me above all others, that he trut me, and endeavour to pleae me. Do you ue poyon to preerve your life, aid Silvander? how can you ever expect he hould trut you, when you are not faithfull unto her? Oh, aid Hylas, he hall never know it. Then I ee, aid Silvander, that you will do that by treachery, which ought to be done with incerity: As long as he does not know that you love another, he thinks you faithfull, and o you hrond your elfe under this fale hadow: You talk of corn, can any thing provoke a generous pirit more unto it, than to imagine, that this man whom I ee o ubmie at your feet, adoring you, hould have his lips blitered with the kies of others; and thoe eyes which eem to adore you, ready to parkle love at every woman they look upon? What hould any woman of any Soul, have any thing to do with a thing common? He will do no more for you, than he will for any one that has the reemblance of a woman; when he peaks to you, his minde is a hundred Leagues off, and is thinking of uch a one, that a thouand to one is ten thouand degrees your inferiour; the words he makes ue of are ome fragments gleaned from another, uch as his heart never ownes: Oh! how horrid a corn deerves uch a man! As to the next point, which he urged to obtain love by, which is, To be jolly, and galliard, and alwaies laughing: Truly, that is a principall quality for a Buffon, or one that has nothing at his heart; but, for a Lover to be of that temper, is aburd, unlee, Hylas, uch a Lover as your elfe. Again, you ay that a mean in Love is the bet; but let me tell you, that he who is but halfe faithfull, is not faithfull at all; and he that loves not in the highet point of extremity, does not love one jot, he who can be indifferent, and love all alike, cannot love one as he ought to do. Valourand Love are reemblant, and he that
can meaure them, or thinks any greater than his own, is neither valiant, nor a lover worth a Ruh. So, Hylas, you ee, that to injoyn a mediocrity in Love, is to impoe an impoibility: And when you love o, you do as thoe melancholly fools do, that think they are expert in all Sciences, and know nothing: 'Tis jut your cae, in thinking you love, when you doe not. But be it o, that one can love a little; Do you not know, that Amity hath no other Harvet but Amity, and all that is owed, is onely to reap ome fruit? How can you, that ow but a little, ever expect to reap much? Ah, Hylas, you little know what belongs to Love: For thoe effects which belong to an extream love, and which you call Troubles, are o indeed, to uch as you, who know not how to love; but uch as are really, and in good earnet in love, and know what acrifices and duties belong unto the Altars of Love, they are o far from calling thoe effects, troubles, as they think them felicities, and perfect contentments. But, Hylas, I will tell you what it is to love; It is to dye in ones elf, that he may live in another: Never to love any thing but what is pleaing and agreeable unto the party loved. The will mut be abolutely transformed into a Mitris: And can you think, that one who loves thus, will ever be troubled with the preence of her whom he loves? The knowledge he hath of being loved, is a thing o infinitely pleaing, as all things ele in comparion of that, have no relih. And if you do but know what it is to love, you will never think that he who loves, can do any thing to dipleae. All his actions are marked with the weet character of love, and cannot be dipleaing. If he chance to commit any fault the fault it elf pleaeth, conidering with what intention it was committed. The very deire of being amiable has uch vigour in a right Lover, as though he cannot chue but be rough to all the world in general, yet will he be ure to mooth and pruce up himelf towards her he loves. And from hence is the reaon, that many, who are not at all rellihed by mot in general, are yet loved and eteemed by ome one in particular.

Do you ee, Hylas, that hitherto you have been ignorant in the Laws of Love, and have only abued the Name of it, and deceived thoe whom you thought you had loved? How, aid Hylas, Have I not loved all this while? What then have I done unto Carles, Amuranthe, Laonice, and a hundred more? You mut know, aid Silvander, that in all orts of Arts, there are both good and bad proficients in them: And o in Love; for ome do love well as I do, and ome ill as you: So as I may be termed the Mater, and you the Changling of Love.

At this every one miled, except Lycidas, who hearing all this dicoure grew higher in his jealous apprehenions, which Phillis did not oberve, thinking it rather an effect of his affection to her, ince in reaon he could never doubt her. One that is ignorant, and knows not that Jealouie in Love is a ucker which draws unto it elf that nutriment which hould go into the branches and good fruit, does not know that the greater it is, the more doth it argue the kindnes of the place, and vigour of the plant.

Paris, who admired the neat wit of Silvander, did not know how to judge of him, but thought, that were he more converant amongt civilized people, he would be unparaleld; ince living amongt Shepheards, he was uch as he found him: And therefore he reolved to contract friendhip with him, to the end he might more freely enjoy his company; and to make them proceed in their diputation, he addreed himelf unto Hylas, and aid unto him, It eems, Hylas, your caue is naught, ince you are o mute, and has not a word more to ay in the defence of it. No wonder, aid Diana; for I beleeve he is pricked in concience. Hylas knowing that he argued all this while againt the truth, & only to put a handom glos upon his fault, he would not reply a word, but looked very attentively upon Phillis, who was got near unto Lycidas, and talked with him in a low voice; and becaue Atrea would not have him hear what he aid, he did often interrupt him, and o often, as he forced him to ay, that if Phillis were as troubleom as he was, he hould not love her. Truly Shepheard, aid he, purpoely to keep him from hearing, If you hould be as uncivil to her, as you are to us, he will make no great accompt of you. And becaue Phillis never heeding this talk, continued on her dicoure, Diana aid unto her, what Phillis is this all the duty you will pay unto me? Will you let me go, and entertain a Shepheard in dicoure? To which Phillis upon a udden anwered, No, no, I beeech you, Mitris, but pardon my error; for I thought that the jolly dicoure of Hylas would have kept you from taking any notice of me, who in the mean time, was talking of a buines which this Shepheard deired ome atisfaction in. And indeed, he poke but truth; for he was much troubled at the faint and cold behaviour of Lycidas. Well, well Phillis (anwered
Diana, in the language of a real Mitris) you alwaies think to cover your faults with excues; but pray take notice, that thee frequent negligences are o many tetimonies of your mall affection, and that when time and place erves, I hall remember how you ue me. Hylas had the hand of Phillis in his, and not knowing how things were betwixt Silvander and her, he wondered to hear Diana ay o; and therefore eeing her ready to begin an excue, he interrupted her, aying, What does my fairet Mitris ay unto this imperious Shepheardes who treats you in uch coore language? Will you yeeld unto her in any thing? Commit no uch in, I beeech you; for though he be indeed fair, yet you have beauty enough to make your party good enough with her, if not excell her. Oh Hylas, aid Phillis, did you but know againt whom you ue this language, you would rather bee dumb all your daies, than dipleae this fair Shepheardes who, did you love her, were able with the leat glimpe of her eye to make you the mot wretched thing that ever loved. Make me o, aid the Shepheard; No, no, he may doe what he will with her eyes, open or hut them, and never hurt me; my miery or happines depends not upon her flames, neither in her eyes, face, nor any part ele, but I doe love you, and more than that, inpite of her will love you. If you do love me, aid Phillis, and I have any power of you, then urely he hath much more. I may be moved by your affection and ervices not to treat you ill: But this fair Shepheardes having no ervices or love from you, will have no pitty upon you. What have I to doe with her pitty? aid Hylas, am I at her mercy? Yes certainly, aid Phillis, you are at her mercy; for my will is her will, and I can doe nothing but what he is pleaed to command. She is the Mitris whom I do love, erve, and adore. So as he; and he onely is all my affection, all my ervice, and all my devotion. See therefore, Hylas, how you have offended her, and what mercy and pardon you tand in need of. Then Hylas, throwing himelf at Diana's feet, after a little time of conideration, thus aid unto her: Fair Mitris ormine, if he that loves could have eyes to ee any thing but the thing loved, certainly, I had een that it is the duty of every one to honour and reverence your merits. But ince my eyes were hut againt all but my fair Phillis, I hall think you too full of cruelty, if you doe not pardon a crime, which I confes, and beg a mercy for. Phillis, who had a mind to be rid of this man, that he might talk unto Lycidas, did interrupt Diana in her anwer, and told him, that Diana would not pardon him, unles upon condition to relate all his Courthips and Adventures which he had ever ince he firt loved: For it was impoible but that dicoure hould be very delightful, ince he had uch variety of Mitrees. Certainly Phillis, aid Diana, you can divine my thoughts; for I did intend not to pardon, but upon the ame condition: And therefore Hylas, if you expect any mercy from me, reolve upon it. How, aid Hylas, will you force me upon uch a Rock, as may chance to plit me; and contrain me to relate the tory of my life before my Mitris? What opinion will he have of me when he hears, that I have had above a hundred; ome of one complexion and humour, and ome of another; what will he think of me? No wore than he does, anwered Silvander; for he knows you to be an extravagant peece, and light as the wind. 'Tis very true, aid Phillis, but becaue I will not poyl any port, I hall deire that I may go about ome buines which I have with Atrea, whilt Hylas is obeying the commands of Diana. So upon this he took Atrea by the Arm, and did lead her to the ide of the Wood, where Lycidas was gone before; and becaue Silvander over-heard her anwer, he followed at a ditance to ee what his deign was, and the evening was very favourable to him; for it began to be dark, o as hee might follow uneen, and tole from tree to tree o near them, as he heard Atrea ay unto Phillis, what trange humour is this in Lycidas, that he hould deire to peak with you at uch a time, in uch a place as this? I cannot tell, anwered Phillis, but he hath been very ad all this evening, and conjured me to come hither; let me entreat you to walk here a little whilt we are together: But it was his pecial charge that I hould be alone. I hall do what you pleae, aid Atrea, but take heed that he be not more dipleaed at you for meeting him at uch undue hours, and alone in uch a dark place. Upon that conideration, anwered Phillis, I do entreat you to take the pains of comming hither: And, I beeech you, walk o near us, that if any chance to come, he may think we are all three together.
Whilt they were talking thus, Diana and Paris preed Hylas to relate the tory of his life, and obey the commands of his Mitris: And though he eemed to be very unwilling, yet at lat he began thus.

div.head: The Hitory of Hylas.
div.p:
WILL you needs have it o, fair Mitris of my Mitris, and you noble Paris, that I mut tell all my fortune ever ince I began firt to Love? I pray doe not think that the refual which I made, was becaue I had nothing to ay: For, beleeve me, I have loved too many to want ubject; but it was becaue me-thinks we want day. I doe not mean to tell you all, but to tell you one of my Adventures; for all would require a little Age before the tory would be ended. Yet in obedience to your commands, I will begin, and beeech you to conider, that every one is ubject unto ome uperiour Power, againt which there is no reitance: That predominate Power unto which I am o violently devoted, is Love: otherwie perhaps you will wonder, that there hould be no chain, either of duty or obligation trong enough to hold me. I mut freely confes, that as every one has a natural inclination, that mine is unto Incontancy, for which I ought not to be blamed, ince it is the decree of Heaven upon me. Amongt all the fine Scituations which the River Rone doth in his impetuous coure viit, after it hath taken in Arar, Ieres, Durance, and everal other Rivers, it daheth it elf againt the old walls of the Town of Arles, the Metropolis of its Country, the bet peopled, and richet of all the Roman Provinces: Near unto this good Town did encamp (as I have heard our Druides ay) the great Commander, called Caius Marius, a little before that ignal Victory which he obtained againt the Cimbres, the Cimmerians, and the Celts, at the foot of the Alpes, who being gone through the Scythique Ocean with intentions to ack Rome, were o defeated by this great Captain, that not one of them came off with life: And if the Roman Arms did pare any, the barbarous fury of their courage did turn their own hands againt themelves, and being ahamed to live, killed one another. Then, the Roman Army, for the ecurity of their Allies and Friends, came to encamp before this Town; and according to the cutome of that Nation, did circle about their Camp with a mot profound and deep Trench, which extended to the very banks of Rone, whoe impetuous ource was uch, as entring into thoe Trenches, did divide its chanel into two wales: The ancient River ran its old coure, and the new had uch a pas by thee Trenches, as did equal the greatet Rivers, and made a mot pleaant & fertile Iland between them: And becaue of the Trenches of Caius Marius, the people call it corruptively, Carmargue; and thee two Armes of Rone running into the Mediterranean Sea, they call the Ile between them Camargue. I hould not have derived the Pedigree of this place o high, had it not been the place which gave me birth, and where my Ancetors have long continued: Where by reaon of the places abundant fertility, many Shepheards reort; and my Predeceors ever held a coniderable rank amongt them; alwayes eteemed both rich and virtuous; and when they dyed, left me enough to live upon; and indeed too oon for me did my Father dye, ince it was the very ame day that I was born; and my Mother, who had the education of me, did doat upon me as her only child, or rather poyled me. Judge what a fine Mater of a houe I was: Amongt the ret of my young imperfections, I could not avoyd that of Pride, thinking that all the Shepheards in Camargue ought of duty to reverence me: And when I was grown to riper years, I thought every Shepheardes was in love with me, and that any of them would bee beholding to me for my affection. I was mot fortified in that opinion by a fair and wie Shepheardes, my neighbour, called Carlis, who carreed me extreamly. I was yet o young, that the pangs of Love could not much torment me, o as I did onely reent the weetnes of her favours, and that was all. My age did not permit me to know whether or no it was Love; but however I was infinitely pleaed in the company of this Shepheardes, and ued uch courthip as they doe who are in love: So as this continual practice made many think that I knew more than my age permitted: And therefore when I arrived at eighteen or nineteen years of age, I found my elf deeply engaged to erve her: But ince I never affected that vainglorious humour which mot Lovers ue to attribute to themelves, which is, to be reputed contant; the kind treatment of Carlis obliged mee much more than that imaginary duty. And therefore, one of my chiefet and familiariet friends took an occaion to divert mee from her; his name was Hermantes, who, ere I was well aware, was o deeply and deperately in love with Carlis, that hee had no felicity or contentment, but in being near her. I being but a Novice in Love, never perceived this new affection, nor had I ubtlety enough
to finde it out: He was omething older then I, and conequently more cunning, and knew o well how to diemble, as I did not think any upected uch a thing: But, his greatet trouble was, that the Parents of this Shepheardee deired this match betwixt her and I hould proceed, becaue they thought it advantageous to her, of which, Hermantes being advertied, and finding, by his dicoure with the Shepheardee, that he did love me, he conceived, that he would fall off from me, if he could procure me to fall off from here He knew well enough, that I would change aoon as a good occaion offered it elfe; and after he had well conidered with himelf how he hould begin his deigne, he thought, that if he could infue an opinion into me, that I deerved a better match, I hould eaily didain her And indeed, he found that no great piece of difficulty; for firt, I had a very good opinion of him as my dearet friend; and next I had a conceit, that there was nere a Shepheardee in all Camargue, but would be glad to entertain me. Upon thee grounds, I dipoeed Carlis from any hare in my thoughts, and made choie of one whom I thought more deerving: and doubtlee I was not mitaken, for he was one that had beauty enough to make one love her, and prudence enough to behave herelfe, her name was Still ana, eteemed to be the fairet and wiet in all the Ile, and uch a one as did draw me out of my former error. But, ee the fondnee of my proud fancy, becaue he had been courted by very many, and all of them batled, I did the more willingly fall on, to the end my merits might be the more noted. Carlis, who did really love me, wondred at the alteration, not knowing what occaion I could have for it; but to reduce me to her ervice, he began to cat about, and ue all manner of allurements he could devie; yet, I being now upon the main Ocean, could not think upon any landing o oon. But, though he was much dipleaed at this eparation; yet, he was hortly after revenged, by the very ame that caued her miery. For, imagining with myelfe, that aoon as I gave Stilliana any aurance of my love, he would freely reigne herelfe unto me; therefore the firt time that I met her at a dancing meeting, I aid thus unto her as we danced together; Fairet Shepheardee, I cannot tell what power it is which you have, nor what kinde of charmes they are which parkle from your fair eyes: but, I am ure Hylas is o much your ervant, that no mortall can be more. She thought I mock'd her, knowing how I loved Carlis, and therefore in a miling manner, anwered thus: Is this the language, Hylas, that you learned in the School of Carlis? I would have anwered, when by the order of the Ball we parted, o as I was contrained to tay till the aembly parted; then eeing her go out the firt, I tepped to her and took her by the hand At the firt he miled, afterwards aid thus unto me, Is it, Hylas, out of reolution, or out of command, that you apply your elfe this night unto me? I beeech you, aid I, why do you ask that quetion? Becaue, aid he I ee o little reaon for it, as I mut needs think it one of thee occaions. It is, aid I, out of a reolution never to love any but the fair Stilliana, and your beauty commands me never to love any other. I believe, anwered he, that you are mitaken, and does not think you peak unto me, or ele you do not know me but, not to let you run on any longer in your error know, that I am not Carlis, but my name is Stilliana. He mut be blinde, anwered I, that takes you for Carlis, he comes infinitely too much hort of you, to take her for you, or you for her: But I do know, too well for my liberty, that you are Stilliana; and it would be more my tranquillity if I knew it lee. Thus I talked her to her lodging, not knowing whether I was welcome to her or no. It was no ooner day the next morning, then I went unto Hermantes, to tell him the paage of the lat night. I found him in Bed; and perceiving me to be netled at omething, Well, aid he, what newes? is the victory gotten before the combat? Ah friend, aid I, I have been pittifully bafled, he didaines me mocks me, and at every word ends me to Carlis he will treat me as a cruell Mitree, and laughs at me. But Hermantes knowing my fleeting dipoition, and fearing that indeed I would return to Carlis, alo that he would entertain me, he anwered me thus, Why, friend, did you ever expect any lee from her? would you eteem her worthy of your love, if he give herelfe unto you, before he knowes whether you do really love her? How could he poibly, at the very firt, give any credit to you, ince all the Ile knowes, you heretofore loved Carlis? Certainly, he were very eaily vanquihed, if o mall an attempt hould win her. But friend, aid I unto him, is it not firt requiite I acquaint her with my lighting of Carlis, before I do declare my love unto her? It eemes, anwered Hermantes, that you are ignorant in Love I mut tell you, Hylas, that when a declaration of Love is made unto a Shepheardee, he never well believes it at the firt, becaue it is the common cutome and garb of all Shepheards, to be courteous and civill, and the weaknee of their Sex, does
oblige men to erve and honour them in generall. On the contrary, upon the leat appearance of any hatred, they do eaily think themelves to be hated; becaue amitie is natuturall, and enmity the contrary. From hence I argue, Hylas, that it is much more eaie to make Carlis believe you hate her, than to perwade Stilliana, that you love her. And becaue you finde, that your affection unto Carlis does tick upon her tomack, your bet way is, to make her know that you do not love this Carlis, which you mut do by ome action, made known, not only unto Carlis, but unto Stilliana and many others. To be briefe, fair Shepheardee, he knew o well how to turn me any way he pleaed, that I writ this Letter unto the poor Carlis.

body.head: Hylas his Letter unto Carlis.
body.p: I Do not write now, Carlis, to let you know, that I do love you, for you have but too much believed that; but it is to aure you, that I will never love you any more. I am ure you will wonder at this declaration, ince you alwaies loved me more then ever I deired. I mut be plain and tell you, that it is your bad fortune, which cannot keep within the compae of our amitie; and my good, which will not let me tay any longer, where it is not worth the taying. And to the end you may not complain of me, I bid you adieu, and give you free liberty to make the bet of your fortune you can, for of me there is no hopes.

div.p: When he received this Letter, he chanced to be in very good company; and as fortune was, Stilliana her elfe was there amongt them, and did o much diapprove of this action, as none in all the company more: which Carlis perceiving, I beeech you all, aid he unto the company, oblige me o far, as to help me with an Anwer for me. For my part, aid Stelliana, I will be the Secretary: Then taking Pen, Inke, and Paper, he writ, as altogether indited, in the name of Carlis.

body.head: The Anwer of Carlis unto Hylas.
body.p: HYLAS, Too great a conceipt of your elfe, is it which perwades you that I do love you; and the knowledge I have of your humour, together with my own will, which never relihed you, is it which ever kept me from loving you: o as all the affection I ever had, have, or hall have, to you, is only in your own conceit. And therefore if you do think, that either my bad fortune, or your good, did conit in any Love I had unto you, you were mot groly mitaken. I do wear unto you, Hylas, by all thoe merits which you think you have, and have not; that I never cared a traw for you. And this advantage I hall get by all this, that for the future, I hall be freed from being troubled with you. And becaue I will not be quite ungratefull, for the pleaure you have done me in this, I hall wih the heavens will continue you in this reolution, to my contentment, as before they put you upon me, to my trouble. In the mean time, live contentedly; which if you doe, as well as I hall, being delivered from uch a trouble, believe it, Hylas, you are happy, and o farewell.

div.p:
This Letter, I mut confee, did a little nettle me; for, my Concience told me, I had wronged this Shepheardee; but my new affection unto Stilliana would not let me acknowledge it, but did prompt me to lay the fault upon her; for, aid I to my elfe, Since he is neither o fair nor pleaing as Stilliana, why hould I any longer love her? Am I to be blamed for her imperfections? For my part, I cannot mend her; all I can do, is to condole with her, her poverty; but yet, that hall not hinder me from deiring and adoring the riches of another. Upon thee motives, I endeavoured to drive Carlis from my heart; and thinking, that now I had nothing to do but to court Stilliana, whom I thought already mine; I deired Hermantes to carry a Letter from me to her, and alo to hew her a Copy of that I writ unto Carlis, to the end, he might not quetion my love to her. Hermantes being truly my reall friend, in any thing which related not unto Carlis, did, without any difficulty, take it upon him, and chuing a convenient time when he was alone in her lodging, preented my Letters unto her, and milingly aid thus: Fair Stilliana, if the fire do burn him that hall approach too neer it, if the Sun do dazzle that eye, which dares look upon its lutre, and if the Sword do wound him that thruts it to his heart, you mut
not wonder, if the mierable Hylas, comming too neer you, be corched; if, in beholding you, he be dazled; and if, in receiving the fatall dart of your fair eyes, he reent the mortall wound in his heart. He would have gone on had not he, in a furious impatiency, interrupted him: No more, no more, good Hermantes, (aid he) you trouble your elfe in vain; Hylas has neither merit enough, nor you eloquence ufficient, to perwade me unto any minde of changing my contentment for his; nor do I wih my elfe o much ill, nor Hylas o much good, as to believe your words: 'Tis well, Hermantes, that I am acquainted with the humour of Hylas, at the cot of another, and not mine own; it is too much that Carlis hath been o baely deluded by him, and let him not make you intrumentall in the ruine of another: As you do love Hylas, o I do love Stilliana; and if you will advie him as a friend, counell him as I do, never to love Stilliana, nor Stilliana to love Hylas, and if he will not believe you aure him, that all his labour will be lot: And as for this Letter which you bring me from him, I care not if I do take it, for I am o well armed againt him, that I do not fear his charmes. Upon this, he opened the Letter, and read it aloud: It was only an aurance of my affection, that I had quitted Carlis for her ake, and an earnet imploring her to love me. When he had read it, he miled, and turning towards Hermantes, asked him, whether he would have her return an Anwer; and he anwering, that he did paionately deire it; he aid, he would; and did, in thee Termes.

body.head: Stilliana's Anwer unto Hylas.
body.p: SEe Hylas what a imple man you are, in thinking I hould Love you, becaue you have left Carlis; whereas there is nothing could more invite me to hate, then that. You ay you do love me: Truly, if any other more jut then your elf, had aid it, perhaps I hould have beleeved him, becaue I do in ome ort deerve it: but I do aure you, and beleeve it, that I neither do nor will Love you: for it would argue in me a mot imple judgement, to love any uch contemptible humour as yours. If you think this Language a little too ruffe and harh; conider, Hylas, that I am forced to it, to the end you may never expect the leat quittance of any love from me. Carlis has told me the mind of Hylas; and Hylas may now tell her mine, if he pleae. If this anwer pleae you, thank the importunity of Hermantes for it: And if it do not, blame your elfe that deerves no better.

div.p:
Hermantes had not een this Letter, when he gave it unto me: and though he imagined that it would prove, ome cold and faint deniall: Yet he did not think he would have been o harp: but he did not wonder at it, o much as my elfe: for I was almot tark mad tearing the Letter in peeces, and throwing it upon the ground: then recollecting my elfe a little, I pulled my hat over my browes, looked upon the ground, croed my armes over my breat, and walked in the chamber without peaking a word unto Hermantes. He tood all the while like a tock, and till fixed his eyes upon me. Thus did we continue mute a long while at lat, I clapped my hands together upon a udden & leaped into the middle of the room. The Devill take her, aid I aloud, let him love her that will for me, there are Shepheards enough in Camargue as fair as he, that will be glad Hylas would Love them. Afterwards, addreing my elfe unto Hermantes. Oh what a foole Stilliana is, (aid I unto him) if he think that I will Love her by force? Why hould I be o illy as ever to think any more upon her? Does he think there are none to love but he?
