I am ure, Hermantes, he twinkled with her eyes, and bit her lipps when he talked with you: but I cannot chue but laugh at her implicity, if he think I care for her more then I do for the veryet tranger in all Gaule: She mut needs twit me with Carlis; yes, I did love her; and wil love her again in pite of a thouand Stillianas, and I am confident that ere long he will repent of her fillinee: but its no matter, let her repent her heart out for Hylas; he will be hanged before he ever love her again As I ued thee expreions I oberved that Hermantes changed colour; but then I was ignorant of the caue not imagining that it proceeded from his fears of my reingratiating my elf into the favour of his Mitris but however he laughed it out, & aid that he wondered at this alteration. Yet no ooner was this coure reolved upo¯ but I thought of a peedy excecution: with this intentio¯ I went to Carlis, of whom I begg'd a thouand pardons for the Letter which I writ unto her, auring her that it was not my fault, but only a rapture of my affection. She who was highly offended as you may
think, after a patient hearing, gave me this anwer. Hylas, if thee aurances of your good will to me were true, I hould be atisfied: but if they be only lyes, never think I will renue with you, ince I do find o much dainger in your humour: he would have continued on, if Stilliana had not come to hew her the Letter I had writen, and to viit her. When he aw me with Carlis, Do I wake or do I dream? aid he in a great amaze Is this Hylas that I ee, or is it a Spirit? Carlis being very glad of this encounter, thus anwered; Yes yes dear companion it is Hylas, you are not mitaken; and if you pleae to come a little nearer, you may heare in what quaint Language he cryes me mercy, and how he repents of all he writ unto me, ubmitting himelfe unto what punihment I hall inflict upon him. Let his punihment be, aid Stilliana, to continue in his affection unto me. To you? aid Carlis, why he wore unto me, jut as you entered, that he loved only me I am ure, aid Stilliana, that Hermantes brought a Letter to me from him within this two houres. and to put all out of doubt, I pray read this, and ee whether or no I lie. I protet, Fair Shepheardee, I was not able to open my mouth, or peak one yllable in my own defence And to dah me the more out of countenance, many other Shepheardees came in, at the ame time, who were all witnees againt me, o as I was not able to tarry any longer: but linking away without giving a yllable to any, I went unto Hermantes, and acquainted him with my adventure, who laughed as long as he could, as the ubject did very well deerve. The noie of this was o pread throughout all Camarque, that I could not open my lips unto any Shepheardee, who did not hit me in the teeth with it of which I was o much ahamed that I reolved to quit the ile for a certain time. You may ee, I was but young when I was ahamed to be called the Incontant Lover: urely at this age I hould not move a foot for any uch-reproaches: you ee (aid Paris) that one mut be an apprentice before he be a Mater; tis very true, anwered Hylas, and the wort is, he often payes for his apprentihip. But to returne to our dicoure. I not being able any longer to endure the perpetuall clamours againt me, I gave order for my houhold as ecretly as I could, and referred the managment of it wholly unto Hermantes, and afterwards took boat amongt many others. I had then no other deign but to travell, and paeway the time, not caring any more for either Carlis or Stilliana, then if I had never een them for I had o lot the memorie of them, in loing the ight of them, as I never gave one igh for them both. But ee how difficult a thing it is to turne the tide of ones inclination I had no ooner et my foot in the Boat, but I aw a new ubject for my Love. There was amongt other paingers, one old woman who was going unto Lions, to pay ome vowes unto the Temple of Venus which he had made for her Son: and brought along with her, her fair Daughter for the ame occaion and with reaon had he the name of Fair, ince he equalled Stilliana, and trancended Carlis: her name was Aymea, who in age could not be above ninteen or twenty: and though Camargue was her Country, yet he did not know me, becaue her jealous Husband (as commonly all old men are that have young and fair wives) did keep her in o cloe, as he never came into our publique aemblies. As oon as ever I aw her, he pleaedme, and do what I could, mut needs love her. But I ureaw it would be trouble enough unto me to delude the Stepmother, and win the Stepdaughter. However, not to tick at any difficulties. I ummoned all the wit I had to my ayd; and conceiving the bet way would be to begin by the Mother, I thought it mot expedient to make my elf knowne unto her, and that ome old love between our families, or omeoutient alliande or other, would beget me ome familiarity with her: and I was not deceived in this opinion: For as oon as I told her who I was, and had given her ome eurvy excue or other for my being diguied, which he took for good; alo aured her, that I would never have dicovered my elfe unto her, but only that he might the more freely accept of my ervice: My Son, anwered he, I do not wonder at your good will to me for your father did love me o well, as you hould have degenerated too much, if you had not ome parkes of that affection remaining in you: Oh my dear Child, you are Son unto a man that was the richet and mot amiable man in all Camargue: As he poke thee words, he took my head and cloed it to her breat, and kied my forehead and her kie did put me in memorie of a chimney which yet retaines a little heat, after all the fire is taken away: for my Father, though he mied marrying her, yet erved her too much for her reputation, as as I have heard ince: but I, who cared not a ruh for all her carrees, further then they conduced to my deigne, eemed to receive them with much obligation, and thanked her for her affection to my Father, beeeching her to let it decend upon his Son: and ince the heavens had made me heire unto all his etate, I hope he would not diinherit me of that which I eteemed
mot, which was the honour of her favour and that for my part I would ucceed my Father in all devotion and ervice to her. To be brief, Fair Shepheardee, I flattered up this old woman with uch candid language, that he loved me, none better; and to gratifie me, he did contrary to her cutom, command her Daughter in Law to Love me alo. Oh that he had been o well advied as to follow her counell? But I never met with any o cold in all her actions; o I was everall dayes with her; and never had the confidence to breake my deigne unto her in words; for Stilliana had put me much out of conceipt of my elf: beides, he was alwayes at the old hagges elbow who twattled continually unto me, of old done deeds, all the day long. It hap • ied, that this great company of paengers with whom we went and mot of them Merchants, they were to touch upon an Iland neere Avignion, and take in ome commodities; and we who were in their company and unaccutomed to uch voyages, being weary with itting o long, whilt thee Merchants were about their buines, we went a hore to walk & amongt the ret this Stepmother unto Aymea was one of the troope. As oon as my Shepheardee was in the Ile, he went along the water ide with other women of her age, and I thrut my elfe amongt them in hopes of an opportunity, whilt the old Beldam was walking with ome others of her own gang. By fortune, Aymea, being parted from her companions and was gathering flowers by the water ide, I tepped to her, and took her by the hand: then after I had walked with her a little further, I began thus to expree my elfe; I hould be ahamed fair Shepheardee, to be o long mute, did I not feare my peech would more offend you, then my ilence. I do not know Hylas, aid he unto me, what occaion you hould have either to be ilent or to peak: Oh Fairet, aid I, my affection does o ecretly burne me, and gives me uch an occaion to declare my pain, that I cannot be ilent; on the other ide my affection puts me in uch fear, of offending her I Love by declaring it unto her, that I dare not peake: o as the ame affection which hould furnih me with words, denyes them, when I am with you: Me? (replyed he preently) pray Hylas be well advied what you ay. Yes you, Fairet, replyed I, I do very well know what I ay. Did I think this to be in earnet, aid he, I hould anwer you after another traine: If you make any doubt of my being in earnet, aid I, I beeech you conider your own perfections, and they will perfectly inform you. Then, with a thouand protetations and oathes, I vented the whole thoughts of my heart unto her: She, without any dimay, coldly anwered, Hylas, never charge me with any of your follies; if you do, I hall know how to remedy them, and then you hall want a ubject to work upon: If my Mothers affection to you, nor the condition wherein I am, will not give a check unto your injurious intentions, I aure you, what duty will not do in you, it hall in me, and I will o take away all occaion from you, as you hall ee, that I am what I ought to be. You ee how calmly I peak, not, but I do abominate your indicretion, but it is to let you ee, that paion tranports me not, but that reaon is the rule of my tongue, and makes me peak o mildly: And if I do finde, this moderate coure will not divert you from your deigne, then will I have recoure unto extream remedies. Thee words uttered o calmly, did touch me o to the quick, that I knew not what to ay; not that I intended to give over, for I knew that the firt aaults are commonly thus repuled: But, as Aymea aw me thus mute and <> , and went away, there was one of her company, that eeing me mue in that manner, came towards me, and making ome kinde of amorous ignes, looking at one through her fingers, he paed by, as if he did invite me to follow: At the firt I followed not, eeming to take no notice but when he came the econd time, I did: and after he had made two or three turnes toward her company, he eemed as if he were out of breach, and did it down upon a green tuft of grae: I, who followed without any deigne, eeing her upon the ground, and in a place where none could ee us, began to port with her, and he made little kinde of reitance, but uch as hewed, that this privacy was not dipleaing unto her; for he did, as I think, purpoely uncover her neck, that the whitenee of her skin might be een better than could be in her face: At lat, riing up, he aid unto me; I did not think, Hylas, you had been uch a ruffling companion, for if I had, I hould not have left my company. If it do dipleae you, aid I, I will begg your pardon; but, if it do not, I was never in my life better payed for my indicretion then now. What do you mean aid he unto me? I do mean, fair Floriante, aid I, that I did never ee any o fair as now I do. See how you can lie, aid he; and then triking me gently upon the cheek, he ran to her company. This Floriante was the daughter of a very brave Cavaller, who was then ick, and dwelt upon the coat of Ara, and he hearing of his icknee, was
going to him, having been with one of her Siters, who was married in Arles. For matter of beauty he was well enough; but he was o full of gawderies, and of uch a galliard humour, as I mut confee, all my good-will to Aymea was forgotten, and o uddainly, as I never at all reented any dipleaure at parting from her; for, this new commer furnihed me with content enough, to cat away all care. Thus then I left Aymea, as I thought, and was all for Floriante: I do ay [as I thought] for it was not entirely, ince very often, when I aw her I took delight in talking with her, though my affection to the other did draw me a little more violently: But, the truth is, when I had well conidered with my elfe, I found, that in lieu of one, I loved both. Indeed it was no great trouble to me; for when I was with Floriante, I never o much as remembered, whether any uch a woman as Aymea was in the world; and when I was with Aymea, Floriante was a hundred miles out of my memorie: Nothing troubled me o much, as when I was far from them both, for then I grieved for both. Thus, generous Paris, did I pend my time, till I came to Vienna, where being in our lodging, (for we landed every night at ome good Town or other) a Shepheardee came, and deired the Mater of the Ship or Boat, to give her room in it as far as Lyons; pretending that her Husband had been wounded in the Warres, and had ent for her. The Mater of the Boat being very civill, did very kindly receive her; and o the next morning he went into the Boat with us: She was fair, and o modet and dicreet, as he was no lee commendable for her vertue than her beauty; but, o ad and melancholly, as he moved all the company to pitty her: And I being ever very compaionate towards the afflicted, I did, amongt the ret, extreamly pitty her alo, and cheered her up as much as poibly I could: at which Floriante was nothing pleaed, nor Aymea neither. Now, generous Paris, you mut conider, that though a woman do put a fained gloe upon it, yet, he cannot for her life chooe, but reent the loe of any Lover, as thinking it an affront unto her beauty; and beauty being a thing mot deer unto that Sex, it is the mot enible thing that is in them. However, I, that began to blend a little Love with my compaion, not eeming to regard thee two Shepheardees, did continue on my dicoure unto this; and amongt otherthings, to the end we hould not let down dicoure, and alo to have more acquaintance with her, I did intreat her to tell me the occaion of her adnee; and he being fluent in courteie, began thus:

The compaion which you eem to have of my griefe, obligeth me, courteous Shepheard, to give you that atisfaction which you deire; and I hould think it a great crime to refue o mall a thing: But yet, I do beeech you to conider the condition I am in, and excue me, if I do abbreviate my dicoure into as little room as poibly I can. Know then, Shepheard, that I was born upon the coat of the River Loire, where I have been educated with as much tender care, as poibly one of my quality could be, untill the fifteenth year of my age. My name is Cloris, my Father's Leonces, Brother to Geretan, into whoe hands I was transferred after the death of my Father and Mother. And here I began to reent the blowes of fortune; for, my Uncle having more care of his own Children than of me, did think himelfe overcharged with me. All the comfort I had was in his Wife, whoe name was Callirea, for he loved me, and furnihed me with all things that I wanted, unknown to her Husband. But the heavens had decreed to afflict me; for, when Filander, Callirea's Brother, was killed, he took his death o adly, that within a few daies after he died, and I was left, with her two Daughters, o young, as could afford me no contentment. It happened, that a Shepheard of the Province of Viennoie, called Roidon, came to viit the Temple of Hercules, which is upon the coat of Furan, eated upon a high Rock, which elevates its head above all the ret of the Mountains: That day on which he came thither, was a day of great olemnitie, and many Shepheards and Shepheardees were there alo. It would be impertinent to relate all paages, and the manner how he declared his Love unto me: but o it was, that ever ince that day he has o devoted himelfe to me, as he became wholly mine. He was young and handome; and as for his Etate, it was much better than ever I could hope for: Moreover, his Spirit and his Body were o reemblant and utable, as did make up a mot perfect compoure. His courthip continued four years, in all which time, I cannot ay, he ever did or thought any thing, which he did not render me an account of, and asked my advice This extream ubmiion and long continuance, did aure me of his Love and merits, and obliged me to love him extreamly. We lived and loved thus above a year, in as much perfect amitie, as could poibly be between two Lovers, and at lat, our joyes were compleated in our Marriage. Now were we as happy as Mortalls could be, conducted we were to the Temple, the Songs
of Hymen did ound on all ides; and being returned to our lodgings, nothing was to be heard but Intruments of joy; and when we were in the height of felicity, we were eparated by the mot avere fate that ever chanced unto any. We were then at Vienna, where the greatet part of Roidor's Etate did lie. It hapned, that ome debauched young fellowes of thoe Townes about Lyons, where our Druides ue to keep the misltoe which they got in the great Forret of Mars, would needs commit ome diorders, which my Husband could not brook but after ome gentle diwaions, did hinder them in the execution; at which they were o incened, that (thinking they could not anger Roidor wore, then to affront me) one of them offered to throw a glae of Inke in my face: but, I eeing the blow coming, turned aide my head, o as I had none of it light upon me but in my neck, the marks whereof are yet very freh. My Husband eeing my breat full of Inke and blood, did think that I was wounded, and therefore drew his word, and ran it through the body of him that gave me this affront, and afterwards, with the help of ome friends, did drive them away. Judge, Shepheard, how much I was troubled; for, I thought my elfe wore wounded than I was, and when I aw my husband all bloody, with a wound which he received on his houlder. But, after this firt fray was parted, and his wound earched, he had no ooner dreed himelfe, but Officers came to eize upon him, and carried him away with uch violence, that they would not permit me o much as to bid him adieu; but, my affection was o much above their denyall, that I did come unto him, and held him about the neck o fat, that they could hardly pull me off. On the other ide, he eeing me in this condition and chuing rather to die, than to part from me, did o hew both his love and courage, that though wounded, yet he broke from them, and got out of the Town: This kept him from an Imprionment, but it made his caue wore in the eye of Jutice, which caued everall Proclamations to iue out againt him: During all which time, his greatet griefe was, that he could not be with me; and his deire of eeing me being very great; he diguied himelfe, and in the night came unto me, and there tayed: God knowes how great my joyes were, and alo how great my fears for, I knew, that his puruers, knowing his love to me, would have all eyes about the houe, and do all they could poible to apprehend him: And it hapned as I alwaies feared: for there he was taken, and carried to Lyons, whither preently I followed, and very opportunely for him: for, the Judges, whom I continually olicited, had o much pitty of me, that they hewed him favour: and o, maugre all the puruit of his enemies, he was delivered. As I had abundance of trouble in the buinee, o, courteous Shepheard, I had abundance of joy to ee him out of all danger: But, becaue his Prion had made him very ick, he was forced to tay a few daies in Lyons, and I with him, endeavouring to cheer him up as well as poibly I could. At lat being out of danger, he entreated me to go unto his houe, and prepare all things for the entertainment of his friends, whom he would invite to rejoyce with him, for his good uccee in his buinee: When I was gone, thee debauched fellowes eeing they could not revenge themelves by Law, they reolved to murder him in his bed and entring into his lodging, gave him two or three tabbs with a Dagger, and leaving him dead as they thought, fled. Judge, kinde Shepheard, what caue have I to grieve at this fatall accident.

Thus ended Cloris her tory, with eyes wimming in tears, which dropped upon her fair breat like links of Pearl. Now, generous Shepheard, this which I am now about to tell you, is a freh gale of Love: The orrowes which I aw in this Shepheardee, moved me unto o much compaion, that though her face perhaps was not able to caue love, yet plain pitty touched me o to the quick, that I mut confee, neither Carlis, Stilliana, Aymea, Floriana, nor all of them together, ever tyed me in uch trong chaines, as this poor deolate Cloris; not that I did not love thoe, but becaue there was yet a place void in my oul for this Thus ee me reolved upon Cloris as upon the ret; but I knew it was to no purpoe to mention my love unto her, untill Roidor were either dead or recovered, for her orrowes had taken up all her oul. Thus came we to Lyons, where every one parted, and my new affection unto Cloris moved me to wait upon her to her lodging, where I did viit Roidor, purpoely to be acquainted with her; for I knew, the way to get into the favour of the Wife, was, to begin with the Husband. She thought, he had been much more wounded than he found him, (for what one fears, is alwaies apprehended in the wore ene) and changed colour when he aw him up, and walking about the Chamber. But ee how things happen, the orrowes of Cloris in the Boat was the ground of my affection; and now her joyes and contentment makes it die, which argues, that a dieae may be cured by its contraries: for, I entred into the houe a captive, and went out a man of liberty, and
Mater of my elfe: But, conidering this accident, I called Aymea and Floriante into my memory again. Now am I preently in quet of their lodgings, and enquiring of every one I met with; at lat by fortune, I found them both together. The next morning was the great Feat of Venus, and according to the cutome of the day, the preceding day unto the Fetivall, the Maids do ing in the Temple Authems, unto the honour of that goddee, and remain there untill midnight: I heard, that the Step-mother of Aymea would be then there in performance of her vow; Floriante, at the earnet requet of Aymea, promied to be there alo: And I reolved to diguie my elfe in the habit of a Virgin, and to get in when it was dark: and when I was in, I tayed in the mot blinde and leat frequented corner of the Temple till it was nine or ten of the clock. Then was the dores hut, and not a man but my elf in, unlee ome that might be as full of curioity as my elfe and o diguied: but when the Hymnes began, then came I out of my lurking corner: And becaue the Temple was very large, and had no lights but uch as was about the Altar, I might the more afely mingle amongt the ret of the Virgins, without fear of being knowne. Then looking about me where Aymea was, I aw her carry a taper unto a young Virgin, who riing up, aprpoached the Altar; and after ome certain ceremonies he began to ing ome taves, which at the end of every tave was anwered by all the company as a Chorus: I know not whether it was the dimnee of the light. (For it does often hide the imperfections of a complexion) or what it was, or whether he was really very faire, but o it was, that as oone as ever I aw her, I loved her. Some affirme that Love proceeds from the eyes of the party loved but this cannot be; for her eye never looked upon me, nor did mine ee her o much as to know her againe; and this was the reaon that I thrut in amongt the Shepherdees that tood neeret her. But, but as ill luck was, after I had with much dainger gotten neere her, he ended her Anthem, and carried her taper into its wonted place, o as it became o darke that though neere her, yet could I not well ee her. Yet in hope that eyther he or ome other would ere long ing again, I tayed there a little longer, but I perceived the light was carried into another Quire, and preently after, one that was there began to ing, as my new, and unknown Mitris had done before: the difference betwixt them both in voice and face, was very great, for neither was comparable unto her that I began to love: o as not being able to hold out any longer, I addreed my elfe unto a Lady was the further off from any company, and counterfetting my voice as well as poible I could, I asked her who it was that ung the lat before. Certainly, aid he, you are a meere tranger that askes this quetion, and does not know her. Perhaps, aid I, I hould know her, did I heare her named. Who does not know that, aid he, by her face, does ask that quetion in vain; but to atisfie you, her name is Cyrcenna, the fairet Virgin that is in all the Country, and o known unto every-one, that if you do not know her, certainly you are of another world. Hitherto I counterfeited my voice o well, that as the night deceived her eyes, o my words did her eares, but not forgetting my elfe I told her, that in recompence of that favour he had done me no man could be more her ervant then my elfe. How's this aid he unto me, who are you that ueth any uch lauguage unto me? then oberving me a little more neerely, he found by my dree and Garb, what I was Then in a great amaze he aid unto me? how durt you be o bold, as thus to break the holy lawes of this acred place? do you not know, that you mut expiate this crime with the loe of your life? The truth is I did not think the punihment had been o great: but eeming unto her, to be a tranger, and ignorant of their tatutes, he took pitty upon me and aid that it was a thing impoible to obtain a pardon, o rigorous was the law. Yet eeing that I did not come with any bad intention, he would do what he could to ave me. And in order to that, I mut not tay untill th • midnight bell did ring, for then all the Druides would come unto the Temple dore with Torches or candles and look upon all their faces. But now the dore was hut, yet he would try if he could get it open; then putting a vaile upon my head and lending me her Mantle, it did o muffle me up as in the night none could know whether I was man or woman: being thus equipped, he told one of her neighbours that came with her he was not well o they went both together to deire the key of the dore upon that occaion. And going all three together unto the dore with a little candle, which he almot covered with her hand, for feare of the wind, we crowded out altogether, and o by her favour I ecaped that dainger: Then the better to diguie the matter, alo out of a deire to know unto whom I was o much obliged, I went amongt the ret, unto her lodging.

But fair Shepheardee, (aid Hylas, and addreed himelfe unto Diana) this dicoure is not yet at the halfe; and me thinks the Sunne is low, therefore I conceive it convenient
to referre the equell untill another opportunitie. Tis very true, courteous Shepheard, aid he, we mut not pend all we have at once. And therefore will ave ome againt another time: beides, Paris who has a long way home, would be put upon the night, hould he tay any longer I can never think the time long, aid he, as long as it is pent in your company. I wih Sir, aid Diana, there were any thing in me worth your acceptation and I hould mot willingly devote it to your ervice: for your merit and civility obliges every one unto it. Paris would have anwered, when Hylas interrupted him by aying; I would to god, generous Paris, that I were you; and Diana, Phillis, that I might have the honour of uch language from her: If it were o aid Paris, you could not be more obliged to her, then both you and I am. Tis true, aid Hylas, but I did never feare being more obliged, unto thoe who already have entirely obliged me; your obligations Hylas, aid Diana are none of the longet dates, for you can break looe from them when you pleae. It's good, anwered he, to have two trings to a bow, for if one fail the other may do ervice: and I do beleeve that Phillis is glad I am of that humour, for otherwie he might leight my ervice. With uch dicoure as this Diana, Paris, and everall other Shepheardees, came to the great Plain where they alwaies ued to aemble, before they parted; and then Paris bidding good night unto Diana, and the ret of the company, he went towards Laigneu.

All this while Lycidas was talking with Phillis; and his jealouie of Silvander did o torment him, that he was not able to bear the weight of it upon his heart untill the morning: he was o much out of himelfe, as he never minded whether any eares could overhear; but thinking he was alone with her, after a hundred deep ighes, he thus began to eae himelfe. Is it poible, Phillis, (aid he unto her) that the heavens hould preerve my life o long as to make me reent your infidelity? The Shepheardee who expected any other dicoure ooner than this, was o urprized at it, that he could not anwer; and the Shepheard eeing her mute, and thinking it was onely to pump for ome excue, continued on: You have reaon indeed, fair Shepheardee not to give me any anwer; for your eyes do too well peak the truth to let me ever hope for any happineie: and your ilence does but too well anwer and aure me of what I deire to know. The Shepheardee being extreamly offended at this language, did in a very angry maner give him this anwer Since my eyes can peak o wel for me, why would you have me anwer you any otherwie? & if my ilence can o wel inform you of my infidelity, that all my former actions cannot aure you of my affection, do you think I can ever hope that words wil be a better tetimony? but I perceive, Lycidas, that you would gladly make an honet retreat: you have a deigne omwhere ele, and not daring it without ome colorable excue of your levitie, you faign thee Chimeras of dipleaure, that your fault may reflect upon me. But, Lycidas, bring out your reaons to the Tet, let us ee what they are; and if you will not, then get you gone and do not accue me with your own crimes: let your continuall complaints wherewith you trouble both heaven and earth, reflect upon ome body ele not me, who am mot mortally dipleaed at them. My doubts did much dipleae me, replyed the Shepheard, but this aurance which your tart language gives me, makes me die. I pray you aid the Shepheardes, what are your feares? Not little ones, anwered he, ince the complaints which proceed from them does trouble both heaven and earth, as you do upbraid me. And if you would know them I will in few words tell you, that I fear Phillis does not love Lycidas. Is it o Shepheard, replyed Phillis; can you think that I do not love you. Yet remember what you did for me and Olimpia? Is it poible you hould conider my former actions, yet make any uch doubts? I do know, anwered the Shepheard, that you did love me; and had I doubted it, my griefe had not been o great as it is: but I feare a great wound though it do not kil, yet it wil leave a carr: and that which love made in you, does only leave a mark that it was a wound.

Phillis turning her head aide at thee words, with a dicontented geture anwered him thus; ince Shepherd I ee, that all my good offices and tetimonies of affection, have no better operation, I do aure you that the greatet griefe I will have, hall be the pains and time I have betowed. Lycidas aw, that he had much offended his Shepheardee; but he himelfe was o full of jealouie, that he could not chue but returne this anwer; This anger, Shepheardes (aid he) is but a freh confirmation of my feares: for to be angry when you are put in mind of a great affection, is a igne it never was accepted. Phillis hearing this reproach, turned aide and anwered; Lycidas diimulation in all manner of perons, did ever dipleae me, epecially in thoe I would lut withall; can Lycidas tel me that he doubts my affection and I not think he diembles? What tetimonies can I give more than I have already? Shepherd, Shepherd, thee words beleeve me makes me upect thoe aurances,
which heretofore you have given of your affection, for it may be that you would deceive me in your Love, as it eemes you do your elfe in mine. Shepheardee, anwered Lycidas, were my affection of the common train, as to conit more in hew then realitie, I hould condemn my elfe, for uffering the violence of it to tranport me beyond the limits of reaon; but, ince it is not of o low an ebb; but, as you know, did flow like an Ocean, you mut think, uch an extream love is never without ome fears, though they have no caue, thoe fears do turn themelves into jealouie, and jealouie into grief, or rather into uch a frenzie, as you may perceive in me.

Whilt Lycidas and Phillis were talking thus, thinking thee words were heard only by themelves, and that Trees have no ears, Silvander was behind a Tree, and lot not a yllable: Laonice alo, who was aleep there, he wakened at the beginning of their dicoure, and knowing them both, was very glad he was there o opportunely, auring her elfe, that before they parted, they would impart many ecrets unto each other, which he might employ to their ruine; and it happened according to her hopes, for Phillis hearing Lycidas ay, that he was jealous, asked him, Of whom? and Why? Oh Shepheardee, anwered the wounded Lycidas, do you ask me this quetion? I beeech you tell me, from whence proceeds all that faint and hollow coldnee, which you have ued towards me of late? and that great familiarity with Silvander, unlee your affection to me had been withdrawn and conferr'd upon him. Ah Shepheardee, you mut not think, but my heart is very enible of uch blowes, ince it hath reented thoe from your fair, but fale eyes: how came you to fall off from me? why would not you peak as familiarly unto me as you were wont? where is all the care which heretofore you ued, in enquiring how I did? and your griefe, when I was at any time abent? You can remember, when the name of Lycidas founded weetly in your ears? and I do remember, when out of the abundance of your heart, you named him when you hould have named another: But now, who but Silvander, Silvander is in the ame heart and tongue, where Lycidas had once a coniderable room; but now, the veriet tranger in all the Country, is preferred before him, that is till the ame Lycidas that ever he was, and was born only unto Phillis, whom he now upects.

The extream dipleaure of Lycidas did force out o many words, as Phillis could not put in one by way of interruption; for, if he opened her mouth to peak, he till continued on with more vehemency, not conidering, that the more he complained, the more his miery encreaed, and that if any thing could cure him, it was that anwer which he would not hear: And, never conidering that it was his torrent of words which hindred the Shepheardee from anwering, he conceived, that her ilence proceeded from her guilt, o as every action that he ued, did more and more augment his jealouie. The Shepheardee all this while was o amazed and offended, that he had not time to convince him of his error; but, though omething dark, he aw her bluh, at leat thought o, which then did put him out of all; taking that for granted now, which he did but doubt of before. Thus, after he had called upon the Gods, that were jut punihers of all infidelitie, he ran away from her through the wood, and would not hear her, when he call'd him back; he followed, intending to convince him of his error, but it was in vain; for, he ran o fat, as he quickly lot the ight of him in the thick wood. In the mean time, Laonice was very glad that he had dicovered this affection, and to ee o good a beginning of her deigne, and therefore he retired: Silvander on the other ide, eeing Lycidas was o apt to be jealous, he reolved for the future to be the bellowes, that would blow it into a greater flame, and would eem, as if he loved Phillis in earnet, the next time he aw him with her.

Leonida in the mean time came to the houe of Adamas, and letting him undertand, that Galathea had extraordinary buinee with him; he reolved to et out as oon as the Moon began to hine, which would be about an houre before day, and accordingly they did o: When they were come to the bottom of the Hill, and had only a long plain to go through, before they came to the Pallace of Iaure, the Nymph, at the requet of her Uncle, began to relate the buinee thus.

div.head: The Hitory of Galathea and Lindamor.
div.p: DO not wonder, I beeech you, Father (for o he called him) I hould entreat you to hear me with patience, and when you ee occaion, to remember, that it is the very ame Love which is the caue of all this, which in former times has driven you upon the like, if not tranger accidents. I durt never have poken to you about it, had I not had both permiion and a command to do it: But Galathea, whom the buines concerns, doth earnetly deire, ince he hath made choice of you for the Phyician to cure her, that you hould be acquainted with it, both the beginning and progres, and that it may be kept ecret from all the world. The Druide (who knew what reverence was due unto his Lady (for o he reputed her) did anwer, that his Prudence taught him to conceal any thing that concerned Galathea, and therefore any promie concerning that, was uperfluous. Upon that aurance (aid Leonida) I hall acquaint you with the buinee. It is a long time ince Polemas firt begun to love Galathea: To tell you how it came to pae, is to no purpoe; but o it was, he did love her. This love proceeded o on, that Galathea her elf could not be ignorant of it, but did many times in private make it appear, that his ervice was not dipleaing unto her: And truly he was a man of very high deervings. As for his Pedigree, it is, as you know, derived from the ancient Line of Surieu, which in Noblenee is not inferiour unto Galathea her elf. As for his Peron, he is very handom; every way o compoed, as to move Love. Above all, he is a great Scholar, and in any Learning can ilence the greatet Doctors. But, Father, all thee things are known unto you, better than I can relate them. But o it was, that thee qualities did o recommend him unto the conideration of Galathea, that he was more favourable unto him, than unto any in the Court of Amais; yet it was with o much dicretion, that none could ever take any notice of it. Then Polemas, having uch a favourable wind, did ail o contentedly in the ea of his hopes, as no man could live more happily than hee. But this incontant Love, or rather incontant Fortune, would have Polemas, as well as the ret of the world, feel the harpnes of thoe Arrows which are hot from his Bow. You may remember the time when Amais permitted Clidaman to betow ervants upon us all. Upon that occaion, Love, like warms, did rie both in Court and Country; & amongt the ret, Lindamor's lot did fal upon Galathea. His merits alo were very high; yet he did look as hily upon him, as the ceremony of that Fetivall would permit her. But he, who perhaps had before that ome uch intention, though he durt not let it break out beyond the limits of his dicretion was very glad of this occaion, under which he might veyl his real paions, as under a fiction. As Polemas did tomack this new Amity at the firt, o the progres of it proved much more vexatious to him. Though Galathea did receive him with ome hew of weetnee, by way of common courteie, and after the example of all the other Nimphs, yet this in any reaon could not be offenive to him, becaue he was obliged to it both by the Law, and the example of others. But when this Courthip went further than the bounders of courteie and civility, then did he perceive it to be in good earnet; and then did he reent uch pangs of Jealouie, as are uuall in a oul that is really in love.

Galathea for her part, never thought of any uch thing, or at the leat did not beleeve, it was o far on: But occaions, which, like drops of rain, do follow one another did o apparently appear, that Polemas might well be excued for uffering himelf to be wounded by o harp a Sword as Jealouie. Lindamor was Generous and Noble, and adorned with all deirable qualities, that a peron well born could poible be: as courtly amongt Ladies, as brave in Martial matters, and as full of Courage and Valour, as any that our Court produced many years. He had arrived to the age of five and twenty yeares, before ever he felt any uch effects as Love ueth to produce in hearts of his age. Not but that he was, of his natural inclination, a much devoted ervant unto Ladyes but being continually exercied in buinees much different from idlenes, he had not leiure to let Love ow any eeds in his oul; for ever ince hee was able to bear Armes moved by a Generous intinct, which invites Noble pirits unto dangerous enterprizes, he was perpetually in Wars, where he did mot heroickly ignalize himelf. Afterwards, coming to ee Clidaman, and to pay that homage unto which he was obliged, at one and the ame time he devoted himelf unto two: To Clidaman as his Lord, and to Galathea as his Lady; comming to Court, without
any deign upon either. But the weet affability of the young Clidaman, and the merits of the fair Galathea, were Loadtones of uch attractive virtue, as did draw him to their ervice. Thus did Lindamor begin to love, and o that he could not umbrage his affection under the veil of courteie and complement. Polemas, as one that had interet, did preently perceive it; yet being friends, he eemed to take no notice, but til courted his friendhip, to the end he might ruin him by Artifice, as afterwards he attempted: And having, as I told you, made profeion of amity already unto him, it was the more eaie to continue it. At this time Clidaman, began to affect Tilting and Juts, wherein for a beginner he got ome honour. But Lindamor was the man that till carried away all the glory and applaue of all. At which Polemas was o tung at the heart, that he could no longer diemble his grudge; o as hee would needs have a turn with him at Tilting, thinking that he being elder, and having a tronger Arm, he might wel enough undertake his Rival, and get the glory; but he proved to be only a foil unto Lindamors lutre. The lat day of the Bacchanals, when the young Clidaman held a Turnement in maintaining the beauty of Silvia, Guyemant and Lindamor did get as much glory as mortal men could do, but epecially Lindamor, who had the favour and good fortune that though Galathea was not the Judge, yet, In pite of Love, hee gave entence againt Polemas. The Nimph, whoe eyes could hardly look upon any but Polemas, could not now chue but highly applaud Lindamor: And oberve how Love does play and mock at the Prudence of Lovers; that which Polemas imagined, would get him the advantage of Lindamor, did mot hurt him, and made him almot his inferiour; for, every one pending their judgments, and comparing the actions of the one with the other, did finde uch a difference between them, that it had been better for him to have it quietly at home. That ame night, Lindamor inpir'd by ome good Genius (which makes me believe, that there are ome daies fortunate, ome unfortunate) declared himelfe in good earnet a Servant unto the fair Galathea, and uch opportunities did fall upon him, as he could not wih for better: For, dancing a kinde of a Dance, which the Franks had newly brought out of Germany, in which, every one catched her whom they mot fancyed; Lindamor guided by Love, but, as I think, thrut upon it by Fate, did teal away Galathea from Polemas, who being more intent upon his dicoure than dancing, never heeded it, but went preently, and twitted the Nymph with her affection unto Lindamor. She, who did not yet think Lindamor to be in earnet, was much offended at his dicoure, and took his language o ill, that it made Lindamor more pleaing unto her: alo, thinking upon ome revenge for his jealouie. I am the freer to peak it, for none was better acquainted with all thee paages than my elfe, who was detined to be a witnee of all the buinee: For, aoon as all were retired to their lodgings, & Galathea in bed, he commanded me to tay by her & hold a Candle, whilt he read ome Letters of importance which came to her. This night deiring to be alone, he dimied all the ret of the Nymphs and when they were all gone, he commanded me to hut the dore; afterwards he made me it down upon her Bed; then, after a little miling to her elf, he aid thus unto me, I cannot chue but laugh, Leonida, at an encounter which I met with this night at the Ball, you know that Polemas has long profeed himelf my ervant and (let me tell it unto you, from whom I wil conceal nothing) that as long as he behaved himelf towards me with honour & repect, his ervice was not dipleaing unto me, but I received him into more favour, then any other in this Court; yet, not out of any love on my ide, I will not ay, but perhaps love did flatter him with ome hopes of obtaining what he deired; but, the very truth is, I never yet found any thing in him which could force me o far as Love: I know not what may be in the time to come, but hitherto there is no likelyhood of it. Now Polemas, eeing I allowed him freedome of talk, and heard him with patience; alo oberving, that I did not expoe my elfe o freely unto any other he is grown o bold, that he knowes not what he does, o much is he tranported beides himelfe: This very night he danced with me, in uch a dull muing manner, that I could not chue but rahly ask him, what he ailed. Shall it not dipleae you, aid he unto me, if I hould tell you? No, aid I, for I never ue to ask a thing which I would not know. Upon this, he went on: I cannot chue, Madam, (aid he) but be extreamly ad at ome paages, which are very frequently in my eyes, and which touch me o to the quick, that had I but halfe as much aurance as I have upition, I know nothing that is able to keep that life which yet is in me. I do proret, I was o ill advied, that I could not imagine what he meant; yet, conceiving that his former amitie obliged me a little unto a farther curioity, I asked him, what paages thoe were which touched him o to the quick? Then looking ghatly upon me a long while, Is it poible,
Madam, (aid he upon a uddain) you hould ask me any uch quetion? Why not, (anwered I)? Becaue, replied he, all thee things are addreed unto you, and it is only from you that they do proceed. Then eeing me tand ilent, for I did not know his meaning, he begun to walk and ay; I do wonder you hould not bluh, and I mut tell you as much, though at the rate of my life: You know, Madam, with what zealous affection I have triven to make my elf appear a mot reall ervant unto Galathea, ever ince the heavens devoted me to become hers you may well ay, that hitherto you never aw the leat or greatet of any action, that did not tend unto your ervice that was the mark which all my thoughts did aim at: o as unlee fortune be extreamly avere unto me you cannot chue, but afford me o much atisfaction at the leat, as to confee, that I am olely yours, and none but yours: And ince it is o, I beeech you judge how great my griefe mut needs be, when I ee, contrary to all reaon in Love, and when I might well have expected ome reward for my affection; when, I ay, I ee in my room another Favourit, and heir poeed of my etate before I die: I beeech you excue the expreion, which flowes from the extremitie of my paion, and forceth jut complaints from my oul, which cannot any longer hold ilent, eeing one triumph over me, that hath got the victory, more by detiny than merit: It is Lindamor I mean, Lindamor, I ay, whoe ervices you entertain and favour above mine; my griefe is not to ee him o happy as he himelfe can wih, but to ee him happy in my raine. I beeech you Madam excue me, or rather excue the grandure of my affection, if I do complain, ince it is only an argument of that power which you have over your mot humble ervant. I peak thus, to oberve unto you, Madam, that you ue the very ame language, and treat him in the very ame manner, you were wont to ue towards me, at the beginning of your goodwill to me, and at that time, when, me thought you knew my affection: This puts me beyond all patience, and o much beyond my elfe, that I am not able to command thoe extravagancies which proceed from my oul, and tranport me beyond the limits of my dicretion. He would have talked on, but his violent paion did o top his breath, that he was not able to continue any longer. Judge you, whether I was not much offended at thee words, for they were o full of vanitie and rahnee, as were not to be endured: yet, becaue I would not give any knowledge of it into uch, who have no eyes, but to prie into the actions of others, I was forced to give him an anwer lee tart than otherwie I hould, and aid thus unto him: Polemas, whatoever you are, and whatoever I be, I never doubted, but that you were my ervant, as long as you dwelt in my Mothers houe, and did my Brother any ervice but I mut needs wonder at thoe foolih termes you ue in your dicoure of Heir, and your Etate truly I know not by what night you can pretend o much unto my amitie, as to call it youre. My intentiond, Polemas, were ever to love and eteem you according to your merits, and never with you any more. And as to what you ay concerning Lindamor, let me draw you out of that error for, if I did behave my elfe towards him as I did to you, I would have you think, I did no more then what I will do unto all uch as hall merit it: for without any further deigne, I mut and will love and eteem worth whereoever I do finde it. Why Madam, aid I unto her, and interrupted her, do you think this to be o mild an anwer? I cannot tell how in any civility it could have been more harp: 'Tis true I mut confee that he is a little too preumptuous, but it cannot be denied, that this preumption in him is not without ome colour of reaon. Of reaon? aid the Nymph preently, why, what reaon can he alledge for it? Very many, Madam, (aid I unto her) but to be ilent in all but one, I mut tell you, that you have permitted him to erve you with more particularitie, then any other. It was, replyed Galathea, becaue he pleaed me better, then any of the ret of my Brothers ervants. I confee it, anwered I, and therefore when he aw himelfe more favoured than any other, could he hope for lee, than to obtain you love? He hath heard of many examples of Love between perons of unequall degree, and might therefore very well flatter himelfe with the like hopes; and I do remember ome Lines which he compoed upon this ubject, and ang them before you, when you commanded him to conceal his affection: The Lines were thee.

lg.head: A Sonnet.
lg.l: WHy Fair one, hould you ever finde
A fault, for being known o kinde?
Is any thing but Deitie,
So glorious as Amitie?
Why hould you uch a vertue moother,
As linketh oules to one another?
All enmitie from human hearts,
When it begins to hine, departs.
But if, proud Beauty, you complain,
And, as inferior, me didain;
Conider Dido, he did deem

l.hi: A Pirate worthy of eteem.

lg.l: Poor Paris, but a common Swain,
Yet his Oenone he did gain.
Diana had compaion
Of her belov'd Endymion.
Love never lookes at Grandure high,
Or values Inequalitie.
A Sheephook and a Scepter are
Within the compae of compare.
Degrees are equall, all's alike,
Where hearts do once affection trike.

div.p: Then Adamas asked her this quetion, How comes it to pae, Leonida, (aid he) that this Galathea by her words, eemes to leight Polemas, and yet by thee Veres, one would judge he loves him, and that he cannot endure he hould diemble it. Father, (anwered Leonida) it is mot true that he did love him, and did give him o many proofs of it, as he had been but a very hallow man, had he not een it: And though he would have diembled it with me, yet, I do know, that he drew him in, by uch artifices and hopes of her goodwill towards him, that I eeing demontrable aurances given him, did think her wholly his. But, he does mot jutly merit this punihment, for that perfidie which he hath ued towards a Nymph, whoe beguiled affection had jut caue for revenge, which Love at the lat did execute upon him. The truth is, he is the baet impotor, the mot ungratefull, and the mot unworthy to be loved, that is under heaven, for his ingratitude; and if he do reent that pain which others have endured for him, he deerves no pitty.

p.hi: Adamas,
p.U:
eeing her o exaperated againt Polemas, asked her, who that Nymph was which he had deceived; for, aid he to her, he mut needs be one of your friends, ince you are o enible of the offence which was done unto her. She now aw, that her paion had carried her too far, and that he had unawares bolted out a thing, which had been kept long a ecret: yet, having a quick wit, he o diembled the buinee, as Adamas took no notice of it. Do you not know, Daughter, (aid Adamas) that the aimes of all men is, to overcome and compae the deigne which they attempt; and the amitie which they hew unto you women when they love you, is but to make the way more eaie: You ee, Leonida, all Love is but a deire of omething which is wanting; that deire being added and cloyed, is no more deire; and there being no more deire, there is no more love; and therefore thoe that would be loved long, are thoe that give leat atisfaction unto the deires of their Lovers. But, aid Leonida, he whom I do peak of, is one of my intimate friends, and I know, he never treated Polemas, but with all the coldnee he could. That, replied Adamas, did tifle deire; for, deire is nourihed by hopes and favours: As, a Lamp, when Oyle is wanting, doth extinguih; o does deire die, when that which hould nourih it, is taken away: Thus does many Loves die, ome, by too many, ome, by too few, favours. But let us returne unto the dicoure betwixt Galathea and you, What was it which he did ay unto you? She aid thus, anwered Leonida, If Polemas had been o dicreet, as to meaure himelfe aright, as he was preumptuous in loving me, he had taken thee favours
as flowing from my courteie, and not love: But this is nothing to the paage that happened at that time, for I had no ooner made an anwer unto Polemas, but Lindamor, according to the order of the Dance, came, and tole me away; and o dexterouly, that Polemas could not avoid it nor by the ame means anwer me, but with his eyes; but truly, he made uch a our • face at me, as I could not for my heart but laugh; as for Lindamor, he either took no notice of it, or ele would not make it appear; but preently after, he talked to me after uch a manner, as was enough to make Polemas mad, had he heard it: Madam, aid he, is not this a fatall exchange? What do you mean, aid I unto him? I mean, aid he, that in this Dance I have tolne you, and in the very truth, you have tollen my oul and my heart. Then bluhing at this, I returned this eeming angry anwer, Fie, Lindamor, what trange language is this? do you not conider who you are, and who I am? I do o, Madam, aid he, and that does invite me to this language: for, are not you my Lady, and I your ervant? Yes, anwered I, but not o as you do intend it; for, it is your duty to erve me with reverence, and not love; or, if it be with any affection, it mut be uch as proceeds from your duty. To which he preently replyed, Madam, if I do not erve you with all humble reverence, never was any deitie reverenced by any mortall; but this reverence mut be either the Father or the Child of my affection; and, call it what you pleae, I am reolved to erve you, to love you, and to obey you; your merits, your perfections, and my own fate has made me eternally yours he that ees and does not love you, deerves not the name of Man: and Clidaman's Lottery, though it was ome caue, yet was it only a cover of my oules affection. Thee expreions were uttered with a vehemency, as made it plainly appear, that his heart and tongue agreed; and I beeech you oberve one pleaant paage; for, aid Galathea to me, I never took any notice of this affection, thinking it to be only in jeat, and I never had perceived it, untill the jealouie of Polemas did hint it unto my thoughts; but ever ince, I have o et my thoughts upon Lindamor, and I have ound him as well capable of cauing love as jealouie; and Polemas ever ince that time hath o dipleaed me in all his actions, as I could hardly endure him: On the contrary, all Lindamors actions did eem o plauible unto me, as I wondred that I hould oberve them no ooner; o as the jealouie of Polemas did quench my love of him, and tranferred my affection upon Lindamor. This change had uch an operation upon Polemas, as ever ince caued him to look aquint upon me, and I am ure my eyes did not look upon him as they were wont. When Galathea poke thus againt him, I was not at all orry, by reaon of his ingratitude; but, on the contrary, the more to prejudice him, I aid thus unto her, I do not at all wonder, Madam, that Lindamor hould win more upon you than Polemas, for their qualities and parts are not comparable, and every one that ees them, are of the ame judgment you are: It is true indeed, I do foreee much jangling will arie; firt, betwixt them two; and econdly, betwixt you and Polemas. And why, aid Galathea to me, do you think he has uch an influence upon my actions or Lindamors? That is not it, Madam, that I do mean, aid I unto her; but, I am o well acquainted with the humour of Polemas, that he will try all manner of waies leave no tone unturned, and will conjure both heaven and earth, to ingratiate himelfe unto that happinee which he hath lot; and will commit uch groe follies, as will be viible unto all, but uch as will not ee them, and uch as will offend both you and Lindamor. No, no, Leonida, anwered he, if Lindamor do love me, he will do as I hall command him; and if he do not love me, he will never care what Polemas does: And as for Polemas, I know how to order him. Upon thee words he commanded me to draw the Curtain, and took her ret, at leat, as well as thee new deignes would permit her. But when the Ball was ended, Lindamor oberving the dicontented looks of Polemas, when he took Galathea from him, he had an opinion that he did love her; yet, having never oberved it by any former paages, he reolved to ask him, and if he did finde him in love, then to diwade him from it and this he thought himelfe obliged unto by their former friendhip: therefore comming unto him, he deired to peak a word with him in private. Polemas being as ubtle as ever was any, did colour his countenance with a gloe of good will, and aid, What is it which Lindamor is pleaed to command me? Oh Sir, aid Lindamor, I never ue commands where intreaties may prevail, and at this time I will make ue of neither; but only as a friend ask you a quetion, which our friendhip obliges you to anwer. Be it what it will, replied Polemas, you may be certain, I hall anwer you with as much freedome, as you can deire. It is this then, aid Lindamor, After I had erved Galathea a good while, according to the Ordinance of Clidaman, I was at lat forced to do it by the commands
of Love; for the truth is, after I had erved her according to the dipoe of fortune, who cat me upon her great merits, he had uch an influence upon my affection, as I did ratifie it by the dedication of my elf unto her; and therefore mut aume to my elfe o much boldnee, as to ay, that I do love her: yet, that friendhip, which is betwixt you and me, being contracted long before this love began, I reolved to tell you, that if it be o, that you do Love her, and have any pretentions unto her, I hope that I have o much command over my elfe, as to make a retreat, and make it appeare that my love is lee then my friendhip, and that the follies of the one ought to give place unto the widome of the other: Tell me therefore, freely, how your oul is affected, to the end the lawes of friendhip between you and me may be oberved: My intention is not to dicover your ecrecyes; and ince I do thus ingenuouly open my elfe unto you, I conceive you need not feare doing the like: for it is not out of any curioitie, but onely a deire to preerve our friendhip, that I ask you this quetion. Lindamor poke unto Polemas in uch a dialect as did become a friend, but like an ignorant lover, that thought uch a thing as a friend was to be found in matter of Love But Polemas the Grand diembler anwer'd thus: Lindamor, this fair Nymph you peak of, deerves the Love and adoration of the whole univere: but as for me, I have no pretentions unto her But withall I mut tel you, that for matter of Love, I conceive every one ought & wil do what he can for himelf. Lindamor did now repent himelf of his courteous and civill language, ince he had received uch an od anwer: and reolved to do what he could to advance himelfe into the favour of this Nymph, yet he anwered him thus: Since Polemas, you have no pretentions unto her, I will endeavour to preferre my elfe, unto a happinee, which to recede from, would be death it elfe unto me. For my part, aid Polemas, my pretentions unto her in matter of Love, are only with an eye of reverence and repect, uch as we are all obliged to render unto her. For my part, replyed Lindamor, I do honour Galathea, as our great Lady; and alo do Love and adore her as my fairet Mitris: I do think my fortune may wel pretend unto uch a height, as to cat my eyes upon her, and do conceive it is no offence unto a Divinity, to Love her. With uch dicoure as this they parted, both of them very ill atisfied with one another: but upon different grounds: for Polemas was tung with jealouie, and Lindamor dipleaed at the perfidie of his friend; from this day they lived at a ditance: for though indeed they were alwaies together, yet they did hide and dignie their deigues and actions, one from another: but Lindamor did not neglect a minute that could be imployed to make his affection appear unto this fair Nymph: and certainly he did not loe eyther his time or paines; for it was o aceptable unto her, that though much love did not appear in her eyes, yet he was ful of it in her heart; and becaue it was a hard matter to conceale o great a fire but ome flame will be flahing out, do what they could, therefore Galathea reolved to talke to Lindamor as little as poible he could, and to devie ome way or other, for conveying letters ecretly betwixt them: And in order to that, her deigne was upon Flurial Nephew unto the Nure of Amais, and Brother unto hers, whoe good will unto her, he had been long accquainted with for he being the Gardiner at Mount-Brion as his father was before him, when Galathea was brought thither to walk, he would often take her in his armes, and gather her what flowers he pleaed: and you know that uch infant amities as are uckt in with the milk, do become almot naturall: alo he knowing that all old people are covetous, he was o liberal unto him that he made him wholly hers. One day, when he was got ome ditance from us, he called him unto her, as if the buinee was to enquire the names of ome flowers, which he had in her hand, and after he had asked him everall uch quetions, he aid thus unto him, in a low voice; Come hither Flurial dot thou Love me? Madam, anwered he, I were the vilet varlet that ever breathed, if I did not Love you above all the world: May I be ure of this thou ayet? aid the Nymph. May I never live a minute, replyed he, if I had not rather neglect my duty to Heaven then to you How? Said Galathea, without any exception? uppoe it were a thing that would offend Amais or Clidaman? I care not whom it would offend, aid Flurial, if you Madam command it, I will never enquire further for I am wholly yours; and though my Lady do pay me my wages; yet it is from you that my ervice is conferred upon me: and beides, I have ever from your very Infancy o loved you, that I did at the very firt dedicate my elf wholly unto you But Madam, I beeech you why o many words? I hall never be truly happy untill you put me to the tryall. Then aid Galathea to him, hark thee, Flurial; if thou continuet in that reolution and wilt be ecret, thou halt be the happiet man alive of thy qualitie, and what I have done for thee in times pat, is nothing in comparion of
what I intend for the Future: but be ure thou beet ecret; and remember that if thou beet not, I hal become thy mot mortal enemy; and aure thy elf nothing lesthen thy life hal atisfy me. Go unto Lindamor and do as he hall direct thee; and beleeve it, I will reward thy vice beyond thy hopes, but till be ure thou dot forget thou hat a tongue. Upon thee words, Galathea came to us and laughing told us, that Flurial and he, had been in a long dicoure of Love; but, aid he, it was upon love of the Garden, and the love of Simples. Flurial, for his part, after two or three turnes in the Garden, eeming as if he had ome imployment, went out, with a mind full of this buinee: for he was not o ignorant, but he knew well enough the dainger he hould incurre from Amais, if he were dicovered, and from Galathea, if he did not execute her commands; imagining the buinee, to be a matter of Love: and he had often heard ay, that all offences againt Love do wound the very heart; At lat, his affection to Galathea and deire of gaine together, made him reolve, ince he had promied to keep his word, and thereupon went preently to Lindamor who expected him For the Nymph told him that he would end Flurial unto him, and by him he might let her undertand any thing he pleaed. As oon as Lindamor aw him, he eemed as if he knew nothing, but asked before the company, if he had any buinee with him? Unto which he anwered aloud, that he came to beeech him, he would be pleaed to acquaint Amais with his long ervice, and the little wages he had received which was due unto him, and thereby he would create him his vaal: then in a low voice he acquainted him with the buinee he came about, and offered to do him what ervice he was pleaed to command him. Lindamor, gave him thankes, and, acquainting him freely what he hould do, he conceived the way was handomly contrived. So as from hence forward, when Lindamor would write unto her, Flurial eemed to preent a Petition unto the Nymph and when he would returne an anwer, he would give it unto him lapped up in that order, which Amais appointed in the buinee upon the Petition. And becaue it is ordinarie for many old Servants to have many things to Petition for; he wanted not occaion to preent every hour a Petition unto her, who often obtain'd uch advantageous anwers to them as were beyond all hopes. All this while the affection of this Nymph unto Polemas, did o wither, that he could hardly peake unto him without didaine: which he not being able to endure, and knowing well enough that all did proceed from her Love of Lindamor, he was o tranported that though he durt not peak much againt Galathea, yet he gave out many diadvantageous peeches againt Lindamor; and amongt the ret, he aid, that though Lindamor was a very brave man, and accomplihed with many remarkable qualities, yet his over good opinion of himelfe did not take his meaures aright, ince he was o preumptuous as to lift his eyes o high as Galathea; and that not only to Love her in his heart, but alo to vaunt and bragge of it, in his dicoure. Which language came at lat to the eares of Galathea; and indeed had o pread it elfe that all the Court was acquainted with it. The Nymph was o much offended at this, as he reolved to treat Lindamor o for the future, as he hould have no occaion to publih her vanities & this was the reaon he would not peake unto him, and thoe who oberved her actions and behaviour, were perwaded that there was no uch thing as Love betwixt them: And Lindamors departure preently after did much help on that belief; for Amais ent him upon a buinee of great importance, as far as the banks of the River Rhine: Yet his departure was not o uddain, but he found an opportunity of talking with Galathea, before he went to know the caue of her change: and watching for his time that morning when he went unto the Temple with her Mother, he came to her, when he was o in the midt of us, that Amais could hardly ee him. As oone as he aw him, he would have changed place, had he not held her by the Gown, and aid thus unto her: Madam, what is my offence? and why this alteration in you? She anwered as he was going away: There is neither any offence in you nor alteration in me: for I am till the ame Galathea, and you are till the ame Lindamor, a ubject too low for me to be offended with. His actions did make it appear, how thee words went to his heart for though he was jut upon his departure, yet he could not give any orders of any buinee, o much was his mind taken up with the thoughs of this matter: At lat, finding himelfe cleerely innocent, he writ this Letter unto her.

body.head: Lindamor's Letter unto Galathea.
body.p: I Do not, Madam, bid my pen complain againt you, but only to deplore that fatall mihap which hath rendred me o corned by her, who was wont to treat me far otherwie. I am indeed the very ame Servant, who ever did adore you with all poible reverence and humility; and you are the very ame Lady, that firt was my adored Saint: Since you did me the honour to take me for yours, I am not growne lee, nor you greater: and if o, then why do you not think me worthy of the ame treatment? I have called my Soul to an accompt for all its action; when you pleae I hall diplay them all before you: As for me I cannot taxe it without fault: and if when heard you can, it will not be a mall comfort unto a poore condemned inner, to know the caue of his punihment.

div.p:
This Letter was brought her, as the cutom was, by Flurial and at uch a time, that though he would, yet he could not refue it, becaue we were all about her: and the truth is, it is impoible any hould carry the buinee better then Flurial did. For he preented his Petitions with uch reverent and pittiful language, o utable unto the thing petitioned for, as he might deceive any whooever; as for me had not Galathea acquainted me, I hould never have taken any notice of it. But it being very hard or indeed impoible, for the young heart of this Nymph to endure without ome Confident, unto whom it might impart it elfe amongt the ret he did me the honour to make choice of me, as mot affectionate, & as he thought mot ecret. So that as oon as he receiv'd this Letter, he eeming to have forgotten omething in her cloet, he went thither and called me, telling the ret of the Nymphs, he would returne preently to them again. She tayed a good while in her cloet, and poke not a word, o as I perceived omthing did much trouble her: but yet I durt not aske her for feare of vexing her: Yet he did it down, and cat Flnuials pettion upon the table, aying unto me, this fool Flurial is continually troubling me with Letters from Lindamor: I pray Leonida tell him that I would have him bring no more: I was a little atonihed at this charge: yet I knew that Love cannot be long without ome triviall quarrells, which in the end does but prove a pair of bellowes to blow the fire into a greater flame: therefore I aid thus unto her: When did he give you any, Madam? Not long replyed he, do not you know of it? No certainly Madam, aid I unto her; Then with a frowning brow he told me that indeed it was true, he was much in her favour; but now he had o much abued her favour, by his rahnee and preumption, that he was quite out with him. I beeech you aid I unto her, what is his fault? The fault, aid the Nymphs, is no great buinee, yet it dipleaeth me more then if it were of greater importance. What a groe peece of vanitie was it in him to report it, that he was in love with me, & that he had profeed it unto me? Oh, Madam, aid I unto her, this can never be true; his enemies certainly have invented it, onely to ruine him, both in your favour and the favour of Amais. This may be, replied he; but Polemas, reports it every where, & yet he is ilent and gives a check unto none of thee reports, But uppoe he do hear the report how can he help them? Said I unto her, what remedy would you have him ue againt them? what remedy? aid the Nymph, why a word, and death to the reporter. Truly Madam, aid I unto her, I have heard ay that matters of love are o ubject unto cenure, that the lee it is medled with, it is the better. Thee, aid he, are but excues, but might he not very well have asked me, what coure he hould take? Had he done o I hould have been atisfied. Have you een the Letter Madam, aid I unto her, which he writ unto you? No, aid he: and more then that, let me tell you, that I never will; but will avoid all occaions of ever peaking unto him. Then, I took the Petition of Flurial and read it aloud unto her; then aid thus; but good Madam, ought you not to love one that is wholly devoted unto you? and can you be o eaily offended againt him, that perhaps never offended you? Come, come, aid he, if he does love me, I will make him pay deare interet for the pleaure he takes in vaunting of our love: if I have heretofore given him any occaion to think I ever loved him, I hall for the future give a top unto all uch conceipts; and, to begin, I pray charge and command Flurial, that he never preume to bring me any thing from this rah and vain glorious man. Madam, aid I unto her, I hall do whatoever you are pleaed to command me; but give me leave to tell you, that I think it requiit to conider a little better upon the buinee; for you may do your elfe an injury by thinking to pite another: you know what kind of fellow this Fluriall is, whoe wit cannot reach beyond his Garden; hould you let
him know of this paage betwixt Lindamor and you; I am afraid he hould dicover the buinee unto Amais, to excue himelfe: For gods ake, Madam, conider what a dipleaure this would be unto you; were it not much better you did expotulate the matter with Lindamor? or, if that do not pleae you, then let me do it; for I aure my elfe, he will give you atisfaction, or ele you may tell him your elfe when he departs, the occaion o • your breaking off with him, without making it known unto Fluriall. As for pea king with him, aid he, I cannot do it, my courage will not permit it; nor will I permit any other, for I wih him not o well. When I aw her o incened againt him, I told her, that he could do no lee than write unto him. By no means, anwered he, too many of my Letters has made him thus preumptuous. At lat when I could obtain no more from her: he permitted me to lap up a piece of paper in the manner of a Letter, and to put it into Flurialls Petition; o he to carry it unto him, and this purpoely, that Fluriall might not perceive this diention: Oh, how Lindamor was amazed, when he opened this blank paper; but the greatet affliction to him was, that he mut depart in the morning betimes, unto a place, where the affairs of Amais and Clidaman did of neceity oblige him to tay a long time: to defer his journey he could not, and to go upon thee tearmes was even death unto him. At lat, he reolved to dipatch another Letter to her preently, more as a thing of hazard, than any hopes of good fortune. Fluriall did his bet indeavour to deliver it preently unto Galathea, but he could not do it, becaue he being extreamly vexed at this fraction, was forced to go into her bed, and did not rie out of it many daies. Fluriall eeing Lindamor was gone, took upon him o much boldnee, as to go into her Chamber; and becaue I was, I mut confee, an ill-willer unto Polemas, I ued my bet invention, to piece up this affection between Lindamor and her, and therefore gave Fluriall an opportunity to enter. Judge you, whether or no Galathea was urpried when he aw him, for he expected nothing lee then this; yet, he was forced to et a good face upon the matter, and to take what he preented unto her, which in appearance was only a Poie of flowers. I would by all means be preent, that I might put in the bet advice I could in the behalfe of Lindamor, and certainly my being there, was not unprofitable to him; for after Fluriall was gone, and Galathea was alone, he called me unto her, and told me, that he had thought not to be any more troubled with Letters from Lindamor, now he was gone; but, for ought he aw, he was as impudent as ever. I, who was a reall well-wiher unto Lindamor, though he knew it not, eeing the Nymph in an humour of talking to me, did eem to be very lack in the buinee, knowing, that to contradict her at the firt, was the way to poile all, and that to ooth her in all he aid was the only way to bend her: And though he was much dipleaed at him, yet Love was till the mot predominant in her minde, and he her elfe was glad that I took Lindamor's part, that he might have occaion of talking of him, and give the anger of her oul ome vent: So as having all thee coniderations in my minde, I was ilent when he talked of him; at lat, he not being pleaed at my ilence, aid thus unto me: Leonida, what do you think of the preumption of this man? Madam, aid I unto her, I know not what no ay or think, farther then this, that if he have offended, he will be extreamly orry for it. But what can I think of his rah impudency, aid he? has he no other ubject for his dicoure but me? Then (looking upon the Letter which he writ) were it not a madnee in me, if I hould uffer him to continue his Letters unto me? To this I anwered nothing. And when he aw me a long while ilent, he aid thus unto me, What's the reaon, Leonida, you do not anwer me? have I not good reaon for all my complaints? Madam, aid I unto her, will you give me leave to peak my minde freely? With all my heart, aid he. Then aid I unto her, I mut tell you, that I think you to be reaonable in all things, but in looking for reaon in Love, for you mut know, that to reduce Love unto the Lawes of jutice and reaon, is to take away its principall prerogative, which is to be a ubject only unto its elfe; o as I conclude, that if Lindamor have failed in matter of Loving you, he is to blame; but if he have failed only againt the Lawes of reaon and prudence, then it is you that deerve to be punihed, for offering to bring Love, which is free, and commands all others, under the ervitude of a Superior. But why aid he, I have heard, that if Love be laudable, it is vertuous, and if o, then it is ubject unto the Lawes of vertue. Love, anwered I, is above that vertue whereof you peak, and gives Lawes unto it elf, without any uberviency unto any: But, Madam, ince you command me to peak freely, I beeech you tell me, are not you more culpable than he is of that whereof you accue him, and of matter of Love? For ay he were o bold as to tell it, that he loved you,
you your elfe is the caue of it, ince you permitted him. Though I had, anwered he; yet out of dicretion, he hould have concealed it. Then, aid I, complain of his indicretion, and not of his Love; but, believe me, he hath more occaion to complain againt your love, ince upon the very firt report, and before you can jutly tax his affection, you have repuled that Love he bore unto you. Excue, Madam, the freedome of my language, if I tell you, that you do him the greatet wrong in the world, in treating him thus, and condemning him before he have anwered for himelfe, and is convinced of his crime. She tayed a good while before he anwered, and at lat aid thus unto me, Well Leonida, there is time enough to make him amends when he returnes; not that I am in any minde to love him, or let him love me, but then I hall tell him wherein he is faulty, and in that, atisfie you, and oblige him to trouble me nomore, unlee he be impudence itelfe. Perhaps, Madam, aid I unto her, you may deceive your elfe, in thinking that his return will be time enough for all this; for, did you but know the violencies of Love, you would never think delaies unto a Lover o tolerable as unto others; therefore the leat you can do, is to ee his Letter. That is to no purpoe, anwered he; But, to atisfie you, give it me. Upon this, he took it, and found it thus penned.

p.hi: BEfore, it was love, now, depair, that dictates to my pen; which mut, if it bring me no comfort, be changed into a Sword, o will it be a thorough, though a cruel cure. This white paper which you have ent me by way of Anwer, is an emblem of my innocency, and argues, you had no accuation againt me to write in it: yet alas, it is a too plain Aurance of your didaign, for from whence ele could your ilence proceed? If there do yet remain in you any memory of my faithfull ervice, let me out of pitty beg from you a Sentence, either of life or death. I am now departing, the mot deperate forlorn man, that ever had once any reaon for hope.
