div.p: This alteration in Galathea's courage, was an effect of Love; for I plainly perceived her heart to melt, but withall, it was no mall argument of her high pirit for, ince he would not give any knowledge of it unto me, and not being able to hold her countenance, which grew pale, he did o tie up her tongue, that he did not utter one word, which did argue any inclination to bend, but went out of her Chamber into the Garden, and pake not one yllable of this Letter: for the Sun began to grow low, and her maladie, which was a dieae of the minde, might better divert and olace it elfe abroad, than in bed; o as after he had leightly dreed herelfe, he went into the Garden, and would have none but me with her: I asked her, by the way, whether he pleaed to return any anwer unto his Letter? And he anwering, No: Will you then Madam, aid I unto her, be pleaed, to give me leave to write unto him? You, aid he, what will you write? What you pleae to command me, aid I. Nay, what you will, aid he, o you will not mention me. You hall ee, Madam, what I will write, aid I unto her. Having gotten this leave, whilt he was walking, I writ, in an Arbour, what I thought mot pertinent, and leat offenive. But he, that would by no means ee it, yet could not have o much patience as to let me finih, but he read it whilt I writ.

body.head: Leonida's Anwer unto Lyndam or, in the behalfe of Galathea.

p.hi: DRaw from your miory the knowledge of your happinee; if you were not loved, but et at a mall eteem, you hould not have known o much; you cannot know your offence, untill you be preent; but however, I bid you hope well in your affection and your return.

body.p: She did not like the Letter hould run thus; but I did over-rule her, and gave it unto Fluriall, with a command, to deliver it into no hand, but Lindamors only: but, drawing him aide, I opened the Letter, and added thee words, unknown unto Galathea.

body.head: Leonida's Potcript unto Lindamor.
body.p: I Undertand that you are gone, & very pitty of your miery moves me, to acquaint you with the occaion of your diater: Polemas hath publihed, that you do love Galathea, and that you do make it your common boat: Such a high pirit as hers, cannot put up o great an offence without reentement: The ame prudence you were wont to be a Mater of, mut canduct you in this buinee. Becaue I do love you, and pitty your miery, I cannot chue but grieve for you, unto whom I promie all the favour and aitance that I can.

div.p:
I ent him this hint, as I told you, unknown unto Galathea; but believe me I did afterwards repent it, as I hall tell you. It was now above a Month ince Fluriall went, when there arrived a Knight armed Cap a pe • , and a Herauld of Armes with him; and the better to diguie himelfe, his face was covered. The Herauld at the Gates of the Town, deired to be conducted unto Amais; and every one, out of curioity to hear what newes, went along with him. The Guards of the Town did let them in, and after Amais was acquainted, they were conducted unto her, who had ent for Clidaman to entertain thee trangers: After the Knight had made a low Reverence unto Amais, and kied the hand of Clidaman, the Herauld poke thee words in a kinde of a trange language: Madam, this Knight whom you ee here, being one of the highet qualitie in all his Country, hearing that any man of honour, might freely demand atisfaction of any that hould wrong him he comes here to ask the ame favour from you, which you never denyed unto any, which is, to permit him in your preence, and in preence of all thee fair Nymphs, to draw a atisfaction from the man that hath injured him, by uch waies, as are allowed unto perons of his qualitie. Amais, after a little conideration with herelfe, returned this anwer, That it was true, this way of defending honour had ever been the cutom of her Court; but he, being a woman, never permitted any to try the matter by Armes: yet notwithtanding, her Son being now at an age able to decide a greater buinee than this, he would refer it wholly unto him. Clidaman never taying for the Herauld's reply, aid thus unto her: Madam, this is the way, not only to be honoured by all thoe who inhabit in thoe Provinces, over which the gods have placed you the great Lady, but it is alo mot jut to punih uch as are faulty, and to honour uch as do deerve it; and the bet way of all, is that of Armes, epeciallly in uch caes, as cannot otherwie be decided: o as if you do not allow of this mot jut way of dicovering the villanies of wicked men, you will encourage all wickednee, and bae men will not care what villany they commit, o they can do it ecretly. Moreover, thee trangers, who are the firt that ever had recoure unto you, would have great reaon to complain, if they hould be the firt that are refued and denied jutice: And therefore, ince you are pleaed to refer the buinee unto me. I hall give this Knight free liberty, to accue and defie whom he will, and will promie him a fair tryall in the field. The Knight then kneeled down, kied his hand, and gave him humble thanks. Sir, aid he, ince you are o noble, I mut acquaint you, that the Knight I am in quet of, his name is Polemas, whom I beeech you to produce, that I may accomplih my end that I came for. Polemas hearing himelfe named, tepped forward, and in his lofty garb, aid, Who is he that is in quet of me? I am the man he looks for. Then the unknowne Knight went to him, and gave him his Gauntlet, and the Herauld aid, Sir, this Knight preents that unto you as a gage, promiing, that tomorrow morning by Sunrie he will meet you, and prove, that you have mot villanouly invented all thoe lyes which you have poken of him. Herauld, aid Polemas, I do accept the gage, and though I do not know this Knight, yet I am certain to have jutice on my ide, ince I am ure, that I never aid any thing againt Truth, and let tomorrow be the day to try it. Then the Knight, after a low reverence unto Amais and all the Ladies, went unto his Tent, that he had caued to be et up without the Gates of the Town. You may well imagine, how this filled all the Court with dicoure, epecially Amais and Clidaman, who loved Polemas very well, and were very orry to ee him in this danger; however, a promie had obliged them to allow the field. As for Polemas, he, like a man of great courage, prepared himelfe for Combat, not knowing his enemy. And for Galathea, who had almot forgotten the injury that Polemas had done unto Lindamor, he thinking, that he did not know his harm came from thence, he never thought of Lindamor, nor I neither, who thought him to be a hundred miles off; and yet it was he, who having received my Letter, reolved
to eek revenge this way. But to be hort, for I am no good fighter, and therefore can make but a bad relation of the Combat; but let me tell you as well as I can, that after a long Combat, wherein both ides had equall advantages, and both of them o full of wounds, that death was much more likely to be both their hares, than life, inomuch as every one began to pitty the loe of two uch valiant men, Amais told Clidaman, that it was bet to part them, and none could be thought more fit for it, than Galathea; he being alo much moved unto pitty, was glad to do the good office, and o with three or foure of us, he went into the lits: When he firt entred, the victory eem'd to incline more unto Lindamor, and Polemas was reduced into uch a bad condition, as he was almot quite pent. Unto Lindamor he addreed her elfe, and pulling him by the Scarfe which hung behinde him he drew him a little back: When he felt himelf touched, he turned uddenly about, thinking he was betrayed, & with uch fury, as the Nymph recoyling, for fear of being hurt, was intangled in her Gown, and fell in the midt of the Lits. Lindamor, who knew her, ran preently to take her up: But Polemas, without regard unto the Nymph eeing this advantage, gave Lindamor two or three uch blowes upon the head behind, as made him toop to the ground; but he got up again o incened againt his enemy, that maugre all Galathea's prayers, he would not leave him, till he laid him under his feet: then getting upon him, he diarmed his head, and when he was ready to give him his dipatching blow, he heard the voice of his adored Lady crying out, Oh Knight, I do conjure you by her whom you love mot, to give me the life of this Knight. I will, aid Lindamor unto her, upon condition, he will confee, that he hath fally reported things of me, and of her, by whom you conjure me. Polemas being as he thought, at the lat gap of life, did confee what they would. Thus Lindamor got the day, and went away, after he had kied the hand of his Mitris, who knew him not, though he poke unto her, his Helmet, and her own fears, kept her from taking any notice of his voice; but, as he paed by me, he aid thus unto me in a low voice, Fair Leonida. I am too much obliged to you to conceal my elfe, and therefore ee the effect of your Letter. Then without any more tay, he got on Horeback, though much wounded, and galloped preently out of ight: this over-much tirring of his body by riding, did him much hurt, and brought him to that extreamity, that being come into the houe of Eluriall's Aunt, where he reolved to lodge, in cae he was wounded, he was o weak, that it was three weeks before he could tirr out of his bed. In the mean time, Galathea was extreamly angry with this unknown Knight, for not leaving the Combat when firt he deired him, being more offended at his refuall, than obliged by what he had given her. And Polemas being, as you know of a high rank, Amais and Clidaman caued him with much griefe to be carried off the field, and dreed with all poible care, inomuch as they began to be in ome hopes of his life.

Every one was extreamly deirous to know who this unknown Knight was, whoe courage and valour had got him the eteem of very many; Galathea was the only peron that had an ill opinion of him: for this proud Beauty remembred the offence, and forgot the courteie; and becaue it was to me only, that he ued to vent her mot ecret thoughts, aoon as he aw me in private with her: Do you know this dicourteous Knight, aid he unto me, unto whom Fortune, and not his Valour, hath given the advantage of the Combat? Madam, aid I, I do know him to be both a valiant and a courteous Knight. He has not hew'd it in this action, aid he; for if he had, he would have left fighting at my firt requet. Madam, anwered I, you do blame him for that, which you ought to eteem him for, ince in doing honour unto you, he thereby was in danger of his life. But, aid he, he would not leave ighting when I deired him. Had he not all the reaon in the world, aid I unto her, to chatie the bae act of Polemas, who would not firt ceafe: for my part, I think he did very well, and Lindamor could not in honour do les then he did. How, aid he, was it Lindamor who fought? The truth is, I was orry that I had unawares named him, but eeing it was out, I thought bet to tell her; Yes, Madam, (aid I) it was Lindamor, who being offended at the report of Polemas, would try the truth of them by Armes. She was extreamly atonihed at it, and after he had awhile conidered upon this accident, he aid thus unto me; Then I ee it is Lindamor who hath done me this dicourteie, that is o hallow in his repects unto me: Was he o inconiderate, as to put my Honour to the hazard of Fortune and Armes? Upon this he was ilent, and extreamly vexed. And I, who would by any means make her know, that Lindamor was in no fault, did thus anwer her; Is it poible, Madam, that you hould thus complain againt Lindamor, and not ee the wrong you do your elfe? What dicourtey has he done you? Has he not
vanquihed Polemas your enemy? How, my enemy, (aid he) Lindamor is much more for he gave Polemas the firt caue. Oh heavens, Madam, aid I then unto her, what do you mean? Lindamor more your enemy, who has no oul but to adore you, nor one drop of blood that he would not pend in your ervice? And can he be more your friend, who by his ubtle dicoure endeavours to tain your honour? But Leonida, replied he, Who knowes whether Lindamor, out of his accutomed arrogance and pride, did not peak thoe words, wherwith Polemas did tax him. But Madam, anwered I, how much are you obliged unto Lindamor, for making your enemy confee, that he did invent them? Oh Madam, I beeech you pardon me, if I do accue you of great ingratitude, when Lindamor hazzards his life, to make it appear Polemas lyed: You accue him of inconideration, and his making the Lyar to confee his Lye; you tax him with dicourteie: Had he not taken himelfe to Armes, how hould the truth ever have appeared? and had he left fighting when firt you commanded him, Polemas had then never confeed what you and every one heard. Ah, poor Lindamor, how I pitty thy fortune? What cant thou poibly do to pleae, ince the mot ignal ervices are looked upon as offences and crimes. Well, well, Madam, perhaps you will not have long to ue thee cruelties; for I beleeve, death, more pittifull than you, will put an end unto your ingratitude and his torments; and may be, at this very hour he is dead, which if he be, then the Nimph, Galathea, is the caue of it. Why do you accue me? (aid he.) Becaue, replied I, when you went to part them, and fell upon the ground, he helped you up, and in the mean while the courteous Polemas whom you extol o highly, did mot baely wound him in two or three places; and I aw Lindamors blood run upon the ground after it; but if he doe die upon it, it is the leat evil he hath received from you for, to be corned after o much duty, is, me-thinks, a miery never equalled. But, Madam, I pray remember, the time was, you aid there was no way to top thee reports of Polemas, but by word and blood: He has done what you deemed the bet, and yet you mut needs tax him for doing ill. Had not Sylvia, and ome other Nymphs interrupted us, I beleeve I hould have omewhat tempered the animoity of this Nymph: But eeing o much company coming in, we changed dicoure; yet my words were not without their effect, though he would not make it appear unto me; but yet I aw it by a thouand ymptomes. For ince that day, I reolved to peak unto her no more, unles he firt asked me. She on the other ide expected that I hould begin: And thus eight dayes paed, and not a word paed betwixt us of this buines. In the mean time, Lindamor was not without his cares, to know what reports went of him at Court, and what Galathea thought. He ent Flurial unto me upon the ame buines, and to bring me a hort Letter: And Flurial was o ingenuous, that he did his buines, and Galathea never took any notice of it. The Letter was this.

body.head: Lindamor's Letter unto Leonida.
body.p: THoe that do doubt of my innocency, are no mall offenders againt truth: Yet as ome that hut their eyes, and will not ee the light, though never o replendent; o I am afraid, Madam, that Galathea, to my grief, does hut her eyes againt the clearnes of my caue. Oblige me, I beeech you, in auring her, that if the blood of my enemy will not wah away the tain that he hath put upon me, I will mot freely adde my own; for I value not my life, ince he does not.

div.p:
I enquired very particularly of Flurial how he did, and whether any knew him: I undertood he had lot much blood, and that did mot retard his cure, but that he was not in any danger. I perceived he could not be known, becaue his Herald was a Frank of Merovia's Army, far off; and thoe about, were not permitted to tir out of the houe: And that Flurials Aunt knew no more of him but that he was the unknown Knight that fought with Polemas, whoe valour and bounty, made them all very diligent about him. Alo that he had commanded Flurial to come and know of me, how reports went at Court, and what he hould do. I commanded him to tell Lindamor, that all the Court was full of his valour, though he was unknown; that he hould ret himelfe, and have a care of his cure, and that I would tudy his contentment as much as I could: But, I told him, it was convenient before he went, 'to ask Galathea's leave, pretending to ee his Aunt. So
the next morning when Galathea was in the Garden, Flurial made a low reverence unto her, and offered to peak with her: But Galathea, thinking it was to deliver ome Letter unto her from Lindamor, was o confued, as he grew as pale as death it elfe: and, let Flurial hould take any notice of this alteration in her face, I tepped forward and aid unto her, Madam it is Flurial who hath been with his Aunt that is ick and beeecheth you will be pleaed to give him leave to go againe unto her for ome certain dayes. Galathea then turned towards me and asked what he was icke of: and I anwered, that it was a dieae of many yeares continuance, and uch a one as was out of all hopes of any cure. Then he addreed her elfe unto Flurial and aid unto him. Go Flurial & return again asoon as you can, but not before your Aunt be recovered, for I ever loved her very well, for her contant good affection to me, Then he continued on her walk, I talked with him and eemed as if I were dipleaed, though I was not, that the Nymph might take notice of me: but aid I unto him be ure Flurial, thou beet both ecret and prudent; for there upon depends either thy happines or thy ruine; & above al be ure thou dot, whatoever Lindamor commands thee: after a promie of al fidelity, he went away, & I began to put on a face of extream orrow: And when I was in any place; where, the Nymph might heare me, I would eem to igh, lift my hands pu to heaven, & clap them both together; & ued all the getures I could poible devie, to eeme the mot grieved oul that ever breathed. She hearing me often mention Lindamor untomy elf, & never o much as name him unto her, but on the contrary did hun all occaions of it; and in lieu of that frolique humour I ued in all company, to be only a lump of melancholy, he began by degrees to be of that opinion I wihed, but not fully: for my deign was to make her beleeve, that Lindamor, as he went off from the combate, was o wounded that he dyed, to the end that pitty might obtaine from this proud oul, what affection and ervice could not. Now my plot was o handomly carried, that it took almot according to my wih for though he et as good a face upon it as he could, yet he was touched to the very quick for Lindamor. So as perceiving me thus mute and ad, he imagined him to be very ill, or wore; and was o extreamly troubled in this conceipt that he was not able to hold any longer.

Two dayes after Flurial was gone, he called me into her cloet, and eeming to talk of omething ele, he asked me, whether I knew how Flurials Aunt did? I anwered, that ince he went I heard nothing. Truly, ayes he, I hould be very orry if that good old woman hould dye. You have reaon Madam, aid I unto her, for he ever loved you and was alwaies very erviceable to you. If he live, anwered Galathea, I hal requite her; and if he die I hall love Furial for her ake. Then I anwered that indeed it was very true, the ervices both of the Aunt and Nephew deerved recompence, epecially Flurial, for his fidelitie and affection could not be corrupted. 'Tis very true, aid he: but for Flurial, what long and ad dicoure was that which you had with him when he went away? I anwered in a faint and ad tone, nothing but deired him to commend me to his Aunt. Recommendations, aid he, do not ue to be o long. Then he came neare me, and laying her hand upon my houlder, Tel me truly, aid he, did you talke of nothing ele? What hould I talke of ele except that, replyed I; for I have no other buinee with him? Now do I know, aid he, that you do diemble. Why do you ay, you have no other buinee with him? have you none that concernes Lindamor? Oh Madam, aid I, I did not think, you could have any memorie now of one that was o unfortunate; then tanding in a ilentand dejected poture, I ighed very profundly two or three times. What is it, aid he, that caueth you to igh thus? Tell me truly, where is Lindamor? Lindamor, aid I, alas, he is not now a man of this world. How, cryed he out, is Lindamor dead? Yes certainly, anwered I, and your cruelty did kill him more then the blowes of his enemy. For going off from the combate, and knowing by everall reports how ill you were atisfied with him, he would never uffer himelfe to be dreed; and if you will needs know it, this was the dicoure I had with Flurial, whom I commanded to try, if he could handomly get away thoe Letters which you have written unto him, that you might burn them, and the memorie of him both together. Oh my god, aid he then unto me, what ad tory is this you tell me? is it poible he hould be thus lot? you hould have aid, replyed I, that it was your elfe that kil'd him, and that it is you that has the loe: for as for him, he is a gainer by his death, & he finds that ret there which your cruelty would never let him enjoy alive. Ah Leonida aid he, I hope all this is onely to vex me, Tel me truly, is he alive? I would he were, anwered I, but why hould you be o inquiitive? I am ure life and death was both a like indifferent to you. And ince your love to him was o little, me thinks you hould
be glad to be rid of that trouble which he was unto you. For you mut think that had he lived he would have been perpetually giving you uch tetimonies of his affection, as this with Polemas was. Truly, aid the Nimph, then I do mot heartily lament the los of poor Lindamor, and wear unto you, that his death wounds me deeper than I could have beleeved it would. But tell me, had he no remembrance of us at his lat end? And did hee expres no orrows to leave us? This quetion, Madam, aid I unto her, is omthing trange; he dyed for the love of you, and yet you ask, whether he had you in his memory? Alas, alas, his memory, and his orrows, were too much for his health; but I beeech you let us talk no more of him: I am confident he is in a place where he receives the wages of his fidelity and where, perhaps, he will ee revenge upon you. You are angry, aid he unto me. I beeech you pardon me, Madam, aid I unto her. I have ome reaon for what I ay; for there is none can give a better tetimony of his affection and fidelity than my elf, and of your ingratitude wherewith you have recompenced o many ervices. Let us leave that, anwered the Nymph; for I do acknowledge you are in the right but I beeech you by the affection you have unto me, to tell me whether he had any remembrance of me in his lat peech? and what words he ued? Will you needs triumph, Madam, in his lat breath, aid I, as you have in all the ret of his life? If you would I will give you full atisfaction. As oon as ever he heard, that you did endeavour by your words to blemih the honour of his Victory, and that in lieu of pleaing you by his Combat, he had gotten your hatred, he pulled off all clothes that lapped his wounds, and leaving them all open, hee would never uffer the hand of any Chirurgeon to come near them. His wounds were not mortal; but when they were putrified, o oon as he felt he could not live any longer, he called for Flurial, and when he was alone with him, he aid thus; Flurial, my good friend, thou mut now loe one that had a deire to doe thee ome good, but thou mut arm thy elf with patience, ince it is the will of heaven. I would requet one peece of ervice more from thee, which is the bet thou ever didt me: And having got a faithful promie from him that hee would doe it, he went on with his dicoure. As oon as ever I am dead, open my breat, take out my heart, carry it unto the fair Galathea, and tell her, I ent it, to the end, that after my death I may not retain any thing which was not my own. As as oon ever thee words were poken, he lot both peech and life. Now this fool Flurial, in performance of his promie unto him he loved o dearly, brought hither the heart of Lindamor, and, but for me, would have preented it unto you. Ah Leonida, aid he then, is it certain he is dead? Oh heavens, I hould never know of his icknes? Would none tel me of it? Oh Leonida, you were much too blame. Madam, anwered I I did not know any thing of it; for Flurial tayed all the while with him becaue he brought none of his own ervants with him: But if I had known of it, I think I hould never have acquainted you, ince I knew you to be o avere unto any thing that came from him. Then leaning her head upon her arm, he commanded me to leave her by her elf, as I think, that I might not ee her tears, which began already to trickle from her eyes: Yet I was no ooner gone, but he called me back, and never looking up, bade me command Flurial to bring what Lindamor had ent unto her; for he would by any means have it. Then I went out in ure hopes that my plot would take effect according to my expected deires. Mean while, when Flurial was returned unto Lindamor, he found him full of impatient longing for him, but my Letter gave him full atisfaction. It was thus penned.

body.head: Leonida's Anwer unto Lindamor.
body.p: YOur Jutice is o apparent, that the mot dim eyes cannot deny its plendor. Content your elf with this, that thoe whom you mot deire hould ee it, do confes it. As the wounds of the body may be far from being healed, though the danger be over, and therefore mut have time for it: So it is with the wounds of the mind; the danger being removed by your valour and prudence, you mut refer the ret unto time, remembring the wounds which cloe too hatily are ubject to feter, which afterwards becomes more dangerous than the wound it elf. Hope well, for the accomplihment of your deires; for you may do it with reaon.

div.p: I writ thus unto him, purpoely that his grief might not be a prejudice unto his wounds, and that they might the ooner heal: Preently after, he writ back thus unto me.

p.hi: SInce you command it o, I mut, and will hope; and mut confes that all my happinee and hopes of it have their dependency upon you. Yet Love, which is alwaies accompanyed with doubting, commands me to tremble. But let heaven do what it pleaeth, I know at will not deny me a Grave.

div.p: My anwer in hort was, becaue I will not trouble you with too many Letters, that as oon as he found himelf able to travail, he hould finde ome way or other to come and peak with me; and as briefly as I could I let him undertand all the dicoure between Galathea and me; alo how he reented the news of his death, and deired to have his Heart. But oberve the force of a great affection: Lindamor, that had o many everall wounds, and lot o much blood, as did narrowly endanger his life; yet, beyond all hopes of Chirurgeons, aoon as he received my lat Letter, he did rie out of his bed, dreed himelfe, and within two or three dayes after got on Horeback to come unto me; and becaue he durt not come by day, for fear of being een, he put himelfe into the habit of a Gardiner, calling himelfe Couen unto Fluriall, and reolved to come into the Garden, and there behave himelfe as occaion hould require: Telling the Aunt of Fluriall, that he had made a vow before the Combat, and mut needs go and perform it, before he went out of the Country; and fearing the friends of Rolemas, he diguied himelfe in uch a habit, and deired her not to peak of it: The good old woman would have diwaded him, and advied him to defer his voyage untill another time. But he being inflamed with zealous devotion, told her, that if he did not perform it before he went out of the Country, he hould think himelfe ubject unto all the cures of all the gods. So to prevent meeting with any, he went in the night, and came o happily into the Garden, as he was uneen of any. Fluriall carried him into the houe, in which there was then none but a drudge that helped him to dig, whom he made believe that Lindamor was his Cozen, whom he would teach the trade of a Gardiner. Thus Lindamor expected the morning with a longing deire, and the night eemed longer than ordinary unto him, that waited for effecting his deires. Morning was no ooner come, but Lindamor was in the Garden with a pade in his hand: Had you but een him with this tool in his hand, and how aukwardly he handled it, you would have known, that he was not much vered in it, but knew better how to wield a Spear than a Spade; and I have heard him ince wear a hundred times, that he was never in all his life o ahamed, as when he did preent himelfe before his Mitree in that habit, and that he was in two or three mindes, whether he hould return or no: but at lat, Love urmounted the hame, and kept him there untill we came.

As fortune was, the Nymph came that day into the Garden, with many of my Companious; asoon is he pied Flurial, he trembled like an Apen leaf, and cat her eye upon me, but though I endeavoured to peak with him, yet I could not, becaue this new Gardiner was o neer him, who was o altered in his habit, that none of us knew him. As for me; I might as well as any of the ret be excued, for ince he never acquainted me with his deigne, I hould never have believed he would have attempted it, untill he had firt acquainted me; but he has ince told me, that he did conceal it from me, becaue he knew I would not have permitted him to come thither in that manner. Dreaming then of any other than him, I did as inquiitivly ask Flurial who this tranger was, as any in the company; and he anwered me in a faint voice, that he was his Aunts on, whom he intended to intruct in the trade of Gardening. Upon this anwer, Galathea, as inquiitive, but not o couragious, as I, eeing me in dicoure with him, came to us, and hearing that he was Fluriall's Oozen, did ask him how his Mother did? Now was Lindamor put to his hifts, fearing leat his tongue, though not his habit, hould betray him; yet, counterfeiting his Tone as well as he could, he anwered in a Country-like language. That, bleed be God, he was now pat the wort, and then made uch a Leg, o like his Language, that all the Nymphs could not chue but laugh: but he eeming to take no notice of them, nor tirring his cap, but giving it a curvy remove with both his hands, he fell ill-favour'dly to his work •• . Galathea, in a miling manner, told Fluriall, that if his Conen were as good a Gardiner, as he was an Oratour, he would be very uefull unto him. Madam, aid Flurial,
he can peak no better than he was taught; Country people all peak o, Yes, yes, aid the Nymph, and perhaps he is held for a prime fellow amongt them. After this, he returned to her walk. This gave me an opportunity of talking to Flurial, for my companions were all got about Lindamor, and every one had their quetions to him, unto which he anwered, but o ill-favour'dly, that he forced them all to laugh, for it was in uch a manner, as made them all believe he was in good earnet; and though he did anwer unto every quetion, yet hee never tirred his cap nor head, but eemed very intent upon his work. In the mean time, I asked Flurial, how Lindamor did And he anwered, that truly he was yet very ill; for Lindamor had commanded him to tell me o. But where lies his icknee, aid I unto him, for thou ayet, his wounds are almot whole? You will know, Madam, aid he unto me, by this Letter which he hath writ unto my Lady. His Lady, anwered I, hath an opinion that he is dead, but give me the Letter, and I will carry it unto her. I dare not indeed Madam, anwered he, for he hath exprely forbidden me, and tyed me unto it by an Oath. How, aid I does Lindamor mitrut me? No, aid he, but on the contrary, deires you to make the Nymph till believe that he is dead: But, it will be both advantageous unto him and me, that I do deliver it with my own hands. I was now very angry with him, and had continued in longer dicoure with him, had I not feared notice would have been taken: Yet, I could get nothing more out of him; but for a concluion, the Nymph mut receive it from his hand: But when I told him, that he had been long with the Nymph, and he might have preented the Letter unto her: He anwered me only with a hake of his head, whereby I perceived, that he would not give it unto me. Galathea perceiving our long dicoure, and deirous to know upon what ubject it was, did leave her walk ooner then uuall, and calling me unto her, asked me what it was? I told her freely the reolution of Fluriall; but, in lieu of the Letter, I told her it was the Heart of Lindamor, and how he was worn to deliver it to none but her, unlee he hould betray the trut of the dead. Then Galathea anwered me he may deliver it unto me, under colour of preenting me with a Basket of Fruit, in which the Heart may be put in the bottome. I anwered, that this might well be done; but I know, Fluriall the fool will deliver it with his own hands, in expectation of ome reward for the ervices he hath done you. Oh, aid he, if that be all, let him ask what he will, and I will give it unto him. This, Madam, aid I, will eem a kinde of ranome, with which you redeem the heart. No, no, anwered he, the Ranome I am to pay for it, is Tears, and thoe drawn from my hearts blood. Perhaps he was orry for aying o much; but however, o it was, he commanded me to peak unto Flurial, which I did, and ued all the language I had to get this Letter from him, even as far as threatnings, but all in vain for he told me once for all, that neither heaven nor earth hould make him forworn: If my Lady, aid he, will have it, let her come in the evening to the bottom of the back taires which comes from her Chamber into the Garden, the Moon hines, the way is not o far, and I have known her come the ame journey as late; when he heares me, I am confident he will allow of my reaons. When I heard this, I was extreamly angry at him, and told him, it was his duty to obey Galathea before Lindamor, that he was his Mitris, and that it was in her power to do him good or harm: and to be hort, that it was not likely he would take o much paines for it: but he till reolutely told me thus; Nymph, it is not Lindamor whom I do obey in this; but it is my oath which I have vowed unto the gods; and if I cannot performe it, there is no, remedy; I can returne to the place from whence I came. When I aw him thus reolute, I was almot out of all patience: for had I been acquainted with Lindamor's deigne, ince it was gone o far, doubtlee I hould have econded him; but being ignorant of it, I thought Flurial o far from all reaon, as I knew not what to ay: At lat, I returned to the Nymph with his anwer, who was o extreamly angry at him, as he could have found in heart to have turned him out of her Mothers ervice, had I not hinted unto her the danger that might have enued by his dicovery. Three or foure daies paed thus, before the Nymph would be brought to do as Flurial deired: At lat, Love, that commands all, forced her to tell me in the morning, that he had no ret all night, that Lindamor's Ghot haunted her all the night, and told her, that it was the leat thing he could do for his memory, to go down a pair of tairs, to get his heart out of the hands of another; and that I hould acquaint Flurial, he would be there that night. Oh heavens! what joy was this unto the new Gardiner, he hath ince told me, his heart was never in his life o well'd with joy, as then; for he began to depair of his plot taking effect, and eeing the Nymph never came into the
Garden, he feared that he knew him. But when Flurial acquainted him with the reolution that was taken, this was uch a reurrection of Love, as if one hould die to make another mourn, and revive to make them rejoyce. The night being come, and every one retired to their lodgings, the Nymph did put her elfe into her night dree, and cauing me to open the dore, he went firt; and, I wear, he trembled o, that he had much ado to go; he told me, that he had uch an unuuall beating at her tomack, as took away all her trength; whether it was her being in the dark without light, or her going out at an undue time, or her apprehenion of Lindamor's heart, I know not; but whatoever it was, he was much unlike her elfe: At lat, growing a little more confident, we came to the bottome of the taires, where we preently found Flurial, who had waited long for us: The Nymph went before, and going into a Jeemine Arbour, which was o cloe, as to keep out the Moon-hine, or any ight from the windowes of the houe, he began to ay thus to Fluriall in a great rage: 'Tis very well, Flurial, are you grown o tiffe in your own opinions, that you will not do what I command you? Madam, anwered he undauntedly, it was to obey you that I have failed in this, if it be a fault; for did not you command me, that I hould punctually do whatoever Lindamor commanded me? Now, Madam, beides your command, I am obliged by oath unto Lindamor, to put his heart into no hands but yours. Well, aid he, and ighed, where is his heart? Here Madam, aid he; if you pleae to come hither into this corner, you will better ee it than where you are. When he came to the place, he aw a man tanding upon his feet, and without peaking a word, bowed himelfe unto her. Oh heavens! aid the Nymph, what's here? Flurial, ee, here's a man. Madam, aid Flurial, and miled, it is a heart that is preented unto you. How? aid he, a heart: Then would he have run away for fear; but he took hold of her Gown, kied it, and held her. I hearing thee words, came neerer, and preently knew him to be the ame that Fluriall called Gozen. Upon a uddain I knew not what to think: I aw Galathea and I my elf with two men, the one of which was unknown unto us; o as we knew not what to do. Cry out, we durt not; fly, Galathea could not; to put any hopes in our own trength, we could not. At lat, all I could do, was, to lay hold on his hand that held Galathea by the Gown, and not able to do more, I began to cratch and bite him, which I did o upon a uddain, that the firt thing he aw was his hand bitten. Oh weet Leonida (aid he then unto me) how would you ue your enemies, if you ue your ervants thus harply? Though I was almot quite out of my elfe, yet me thought I hould know that voice, and asked him, who he was? I am, aid he, one that comes to bring Lindamor's Heart unto this fair Nymph. Then kneeling down upon the ground, he thus addreed himelfe unto her: I mut needs confee Madam, that this preumption is great, but yet not equall unto that affection which produceth it. Here, Madam, is the heart of Lindamor, which I preent unto you; I hope the preent will finde as good a reception from the hand of the Donor, as from a tranger. But, if my diaterous Fate do deny me that which Love doth promie me, having offended againt a Divinity whom I only adore, then condemn this heart which here I do bring unto you, unto what cruell tortures you hall pleae; for, o his pain may pleae you, he will endure with contentment, ince you do ordain it unto him. Now I knew him to be Lindamor, and Galathea alo, but not without abundance of wonder to us both, to ee at her foot him, whom he thought dead; and I, in lieu of a Gardiner to finde a Cavalier, who yielded unto none in all the Country. Perceiving Galathea o urpried that he could not peak, I began to talk unto him, and aid: Is it o Lindamor, that you delight to urprie and affright Ladies? this is not an Art, that becomes uch a Cavalier as you profee your elfe. I mut needs confee unto you, weet Nymph, aid he unto me, that it is not a becomming act of a Cavalier, but it is of a Lover, and I am no lee. Love that intructs all, has taught me to be a Gardiner. Is it poible, Madam, aid he unto Galathea, that this extream affection which you have caued, hould beo dipleaing unto you, as you mut needs delight more in the death of him that owes it, then his life? Will not this heart I have brought, finde as good a reception alive as dead? But, if you will needs have me die, here's a Ponyard will do that, which no time can ever do, for it will put an end to all. The Nymph anwered nothing unto all this, but aid, Oh Leonida, have you betrayed me? Upon this, he went in to another Walk, where he did it down; for he was o much tranported out of her elfe, as he knew not what he did. Then Lindamor did fall upon his knees again, and I went to her, and aid, Why Madam, do you ay, I betrayed you? how can you accue me for this? I vow unto you, that I knew nothing of the buinee: but it is Flurial that hath deceived us both.
But, I thank God, we are all deceived the better way. Thanks be to God, here that heart of Lindamor which Flurial promied; he is here alo ready to do you any ervice: And have you not good reaon to be glad of this Treaon? It would be over tedious to relate all our dicoure at this time: out at the concluion, peace was made between all parties, and o, as this Love was tyed with a harder knot then ever it was before; but upon this condition, that he hould at this very houre depart unto the place, whither Amais and Clidaman had ent him. This departure went hard, yet obey he mut; and o after a parting kie of Galathea's fair hand, he went away, in full aurance to finde her the ame he left her. But it would be impertinent to particularize every circumtance: Lindamor returned to his charge, did his buinee and with the permiion of Amais and Clidaman, returned unto Forrets, where giving a good account of his Commiion, he was honoured and carraed according to the merit of his vertue. But all this did not halfe o much revive his oul, as the favourable apect which this Nymph did afford him, who ever ince his lat departure o increaed in affection to him, as Lindamor might well ay he did equall him in Love: And this Courthip came to that height, as one night, when they were in the Garden together, he did often move her for leave, to ask the conent of Amais unto their Marriage, being confident, that o many ervices as he had done, both unto her and her Son would invite her to grant him that favour. To which he anwered; You have more reaon to doubt their good-will than your own merit; and be lee aured of your own deervings, then my good will: But yet, I would not have you mention it unto them, till Clidaman be married I am younger than he and I may well tay o long. You may perhaps, Madam, anwered he, but o cannot the violence of my paion: But, if you will not grant me this remedy, yet grant me another, if your affection be uch as you ay unto me. If I can without prejudice to my elfe, aid he, I will. Then after he had kied her hand; Madam, aid he unto her, Promie me, before Leonida and the gods, who are witnees of our dicoure, that you will be my Wife, as I do vow, by all that is acred, to be your Husband, and never look upon any other. Galathea was urpried at this, yet eeming as if it were by my perwaion, though indeed it was by her own affection, he gave him that atisfaction, and wore unto him; upon condition, that Lindamor, to avoid upition, hould never return into the Garden, untill their Marriage was declared. Now was Lindamor the mot contented man that ever was, being full of hopes, and wanted nothing but the promied concluion of all his deires. But Love, or rather Fortune, did mot extreamly thwart him. Oh Lindamor, how vain are all thy purpoed hopes? At that time Clidaman went with Guyemant, to try their fortunes in Armes, and went into Merovea's Army but though he went away ecretly, yet was he quickly dicovered. And becaue Amais would not let him be there in that ort, he levied all the Forces he could, to end unto him, and committed the charge of them unto Lindamor, contituting Polemas the Governour under her in all the Provinces, untill her Son's return; and this he did, as well to atisfie two uch eminent men, as to ever them; for ince Lindamor's return, they were alwaies jarring. Polemas was very well contented and Lindamor went not with an ill will: The one was glad he was to tay with his Mitree, and the other hoped by his ervices o to oblige Amais, as to facilitate the way unto that happinee, which he apired unto. But Polemas finding himelfe in disfavour of his Mitree, and that his Rivall had robbed him of all, he put no confidence in any of his ervices or merits, but had recoure unto cunning and artifice: In order to this, he procured the mot crafty fellow that ever was of that trade, whom he acquainted with every one about the Court, hewed him in ecret Amalis, Galathea, Silvia, Selires, my elfe, and all the ret of the Nymphs; and did not only hew him their faces, but acquainted him with all the ecrets which he knew betwixt any of them: And after a full information of all paages, he deired him to take upon him to eem a great Druide, and a mot learned Conjurer: He eated himelfe in the great wood of Savignew, neer the pleaant Gardens of Mount Brion, and cloe by a little River which runs through the Wood: He tayed ome certain daies, giving himelfe out to be the greatet Diviner that ever was; inomuch as his fame reached unto us, and Galathea went unto him to know her fortune. This crafty Impotor did know o well how to carry himelfe, and delude others, with o many circumtances and ceremonies, as I mut confee, he deceived me as well as the ret. The main aime and concluion of all his craft was, to tell Galathea, that the influence of the heavens had given her choice of a great happinee, or a great miery, and that it mut be her own prudence that was to ditinguih betwixt them; that both thee two extreams did depend upon Love; that if
he contemned his advice, he would be the mot mierable woman in the world: And on the contrary, the mot happy, if he followed his counel. Then looking in her hand, and then her face, he aid unto her, Such a day when you are in Marcelles, you hall ee a man clothed in uch a colour; if you marry him, you will be the mot mierable woman upon earth. Afterwards he hewed her in a glas, a certain place upon the banks of the River Lignon, and aid unto her, See here is the place, go unto it uch an hour and then and there you hall find a man, whom if you marry, will make you infinitely happy.

Now this Climanthes (for that was this Conjurers name) had ubtilly got knowledg of the day that Lindamor was to depart, and the colour of his clothes he would wear; and his deign was, that Polemas under a colour of going to Hunt, hould goe unto the place which he had hewed her in the glas. Now hear, I beeech you, how things hapned. Lindamor was clothed as Climanthes told her, and Galathea remembring it, was o atonihed, that he could not give him one word by way of any anwer. Poor Lindamor thought it to bee his departure which made her o ad, and o kiing her hand, hee went his wayes better contented than his fortune allowed him any reaon for.

Afterwards, the day approaching on which Climanthes told her he hould meet with the man that would make her all happinee, upon the banks of the River Lignon, hee would not fully acquaint me with her deign, but only aid he would try whether the predictions of the Druide were true. So hee took with her onely Silvia and me, her Nure, and little Meril. The Nure was he that mot fortified her in opinion of thee predictions, as commonly all old women are very upertitious in uch things So as this Nymph oberving the day that Climanthes told her of, he prepared her elf the night before to goe unto that place, and in the morning dreed her elf to the bet advantage he could, and alo commanded us to make our elves ready. Thus we went in a Chariot to the place appointed, where being come at the very ame hour that Climanthes named, we found a Shepheard almot drowned, whom the waves had cat upon our ide. This Shepheard was one Celadon, who accidentally was fallen into the River, and had doubtlee been drowned, if wee had not aved him: So Galathea apprehending him to bee the man that was to make her happy, began then to love him o, that hee would needs have us carry him in the Chariot unto the Palace, before he revived; for then the and and mud had o choaked him, that he looked as pale as death, and had no kind of motion or beauty in him. For my part, I cured the Conjurer, and did foreee we hould be put to abundance of trouble with him; for I wear unto you, I was never o put to it in all my life: But ince the Shepherd revived, & his complexion came into his face he appeared to be a very handom man, and of a wit above the capacity of a Shepheard. I never aw any in our Court more civiliz'd, nor more deerving love: So as no wonder Galathea hould be o deperately in love with him, as hee cannot be abent from him either night or day. But certainly he is much mitaken in him; for he is mot deperately in love with a Shepheardes called Atrea: So as all thee things make not a little againt Lindamor: For the Nimph finding all true that this Impotor told her, he is reolved rather to dye than to marry Lindamor, and tudies all waies to win upon the affection of this Shepheard, who does nothing even in her very preence but igh for his abence from Atrea. I know not whether his imprionment be the caue (for hee will not let him goe out of the Palace) or whether it be the abundance of water which hee wallowed when he was in the River; but o it is, he is fallen into a mot violent Feaver: So as not knowing what to doe for his health, Galathea commanded mee to come in all hate unto you, to the end you might ee him, and tell us what was bet for him.

The Druide tood very attentive unto this dicoure, and had everal conceits according to the ubject of his Neeces words; and perhaps, ome not far off the truth; for he perceiceived that he was not altogether exempted either from love or blame. Yet he did very dicreetly diemble it, and told her he was very glad to erve either Galathea or Celadon, whoe Parents he ever loved; and who though he was a Shepheard, yet he was decended from the bet of our Knights, whoe Ancetors made choice of that kind of life as more tranquill and happy, than that of the Court, and therefore he honoured him, and would be glad to erve him. But yet this kind of living with him was neither afe nor honourable for either Galathea or her. And when hee came to the Palace and aw their deportments, then he would tel her how he hould demean her elf. Leonida being a little ahamed, anwered him, that he did intend long ince to tell him of it, but truly he had neither the confidence nor the conveniency to do it: Yet of a truth, Climanthes was the caue of all this. Oh, anwered Adamas, could I but catch him, I hould with uury pay him for fally uurping
the title of a Druide. That Sir, aid the Nymph, will be an eaie matter by the means that I hall finde out: For he told Galathea, that he hould come four or five times to the place where he was to meet with this man that would make her happy, in cae he did not meet with him the firt day: And I know that Polemas and he coming too late the firt day, will not fail to be there the dayes following: And whooever will catch this Conjurer, mut hide themelves in a place where I hall direct, and they will be ure to find him. As for the daies of his comming, I can bee informed from Galathea, though for my part I have forgotten them.

With uch dicoure as this, the Druide and the Nymph beguiled the length of the way, and they were both o attentive, as they were at the Palace of Iaures before they were aware. But the Druide extreamly diliking this kind of life they led, did intruct Leonida what he hould ay unto Galathea, but whatoever hee did, not to let her know that hee diapproved any of her actions: for, aid hee, uch courages and pirits as the Nymphs mut be wonne upon by weetnes and lenity, not by rigour and force. And you Neece, I pray conider and remember your duty, and know that thee follies of love are dihonourable both for thoe that own them, and thoe that favour them. He had continued on his Intructions had they not met Silvia at their Palace gates, who conducted them unto Galathea: At that time he was walking in the Garden whilt Celadon repoed himelf: As oon as ever he aw them, he went unto them; the Druide kneeled down, and kied her hand; Leonida did the ame. Afterwards the Nymph embraced them both and thanked Adamas for his paines in comming to her, promiing requital upon the firt occaion. Madam, aid he unto her, all my ervices are but jut duties, and the very bet of them cannot merit half this expreion: I am orry onely that I want occaions to make the grandure of my affection known unto you, and if I have not at any time been deficient, it was onely want of opportunities, not of any will to erve you. Adamas, anwered the Nimph, the ervice which you have done unto Amais, I take as done unto my elf: And what I have received from your Neece, I accept of as from you: And therefore, conidering all circumtances, I have had ufficient tryal of your goodnes. I do acknowledge your ervices pat to be great, but this which I am now to imploy you in, is the greatet, and will be the mot acceptable unto me, for no greater cure can be than of a wounded pirit. We wil talk more of it at leaure; in the mean time goe and ret your elf: Silvia will conduct you to your chamber, whilt Leonida does give me an accompt of what he hath done. Thus the Druide was dimied, and Galathea carraing Leonida more than uual, asked her what he had done in her journey? Unto which Leonida gave her a atisfactory anwer: Madam, aid he I thank the gods that I have found you more joyful than I left you. Friend, aid the Nimph, Celadons recovery is the caue: for you mut know, that you were not gone a mile from hence before the Feaver left him, and ever ince he hath o mended, as he himelf hopes within two or three daies hee hall be able to rie. This, anwered Leonida, is the bet news I could deire, and had I known as much, I hould not have brought Adamas hither. But to the purpoe, aid Galathea, What does he ay to this accident? For I aure my elf you have acquainted him with it. Pardon me, Madam, aid Leonida, I told him no more than what I thought could not be concealed from him when he came: He knows of the affection you beare unto Celadon, which I told him was onely an effect of your pitty. Hee knows the Shepheard very well, and all his family, and is confident he can perwade him unto what he pleaeth: For my part, I think, that if you doe imploy him, hee will doe you good ervice, but then you mut be ingenuous and peak freely and openly unto him. Oh my God, aid the Nymph, do you think this poible? Certainly when hee undertands the whole tory he will never apprehend it unto my contentment; for his prudence and judgement is o great, as I doubt he will rather condemn, than further the buinee. Madam, aid Leonida, I do not peak without ome ground; you hall ee if you do imploy him, what ervice he will doe you. Thus the Nimph was the mot contented peron in the world, fancying her elf already at the very top of all her deires. But whilt they were thus dicouring, Silvia and Adamas were talking of the ame buines: For this Nymph being at the firt very familiar with him, did at the firt peak openly unto him. Adamas much deiring to know whether all his Neece had related was true, he entreated her to relate unto him all he knew, which Silvia did without any diimulation, and as briefly as he could, in this manner.

div.head: The Hitory of Leonida.
div.p: KNow, that for the better undertanding of what you deire, I am forced to touch upon all the particulars of Leonida's life, whoe Detiny eems to twit together all her deignes with thoe of Galathea. What I hall ay concerning her, is not by way of reprehenion or blame, nor with any intention to divulge her faults; for in telling them unto you, I think them to be as ecret as if they had never been told. You mut know then, that the beauty and merits of Leonida, had long ince gotten the affection of Polemas; and the merits of that Cavalier being very high, your Neece gave his affection a kind reception, yet behaved her elf with o much dicretion, that it was long before Polemas knew it. I know that your elf have loved in your time, and knows better than I doe, how hard a thing it is to hide love. And o it was, that the vaile being taken away, both of them did know that both of them were lovers and both loved. However, they durt not of a long time declare it. After the Fetivall which Amais did Solemnize every yeare, as her day of Marriage with Pimander: So it was, that after dinner we all walked in the Garden at Mont-brion, and he and I et our elves down under ome Trees to helter our elves from the heat of the Sun. No ooner were we et, but Polemas came to us, eeming as if but accidentally; though I oberved, that he followed us by the eye, a good way ditant. And becaue we at ilent a long while together, alo he having an excellent good voice, I told him he would much oblige us if he would ing. I hall do o, aid he (pointing at Leonida) if this fair one wil be pleaed to command me. Commands, aid he, would hew indicretion; but if you have any Song that is new, I hall think my entreaties very well betowed. I hall, anwered Polemas; and moreover, I will promie you, that this which you hall hear, is o new, as it was made during the time of the Sacrifice this morning, whilt you were at your Prayers. How aid I unto him, is my companion the ubject of the ong? Yes certainly, anwered he, I am a witnes of it, and then he began thus.

lg.head: Upon a Lady at her Prayers.

lg.l: A Saint in Sacred Temple paid
Devotion to the Gods, and pray'd:
She that all humane hearts adores,
Adores the gods, and help implores;
And he whoe mercy may men ave,
With eyes and voice doth mercy crave.
Although he does her eyes diarm,
And will not uffer any charm
In either voice or eye to glance,
As might their lutre more advance,
Such charming influence till they have,
As mut all eyes and ears enlave.
Her eyes with holy Zeal inpir'd,
Half hut, as high as heaven apir'd,
And courted it, with uch a glance,
As if her oul were in a trance.
Such raptures of Coeletial Love
Mut needs both Earth and Heaven move.
Great God (aid he) I do implore
Mercy from thy abundant tore.
Have mercy on me too (aid I)
Oh fairet female Dietie.
Religion bids you to impart
To others with a willing heart.
Since thou art pleas'd, O God (aid he)
To call us Children, O then be
A Father, not a Judge evere.
Since you the worlds fair Mitris are
Oh then be mine, and kind, (aid I)
Reembling o a Dietie.
Conider Lord (aid he) how I
Have Eence from thy Majety:
'Tis onely Thou I doe adore,
And hall doe o for evermore.
So it is onely you, aid I,
VVhom I adore eternally.
Meaure thy Mercy, Lord (aid he)
According to thy Love, not me.
Meaure your pitty then, aid I,
According to my Amity.
Here then he topt, and went not on
Only in Contemplation.
Her prayers were heard; but mine, alas
Rejected were as poor and bae:
Yet I dare confidently ay,
Mine were as full of Zeal as they:
She onely by her Faith obey'd,
I aw the Saint to whom I pray'd.
Her Prayers did find an eaie task;
Who could deny when he did ask?
But I poor illy mortal mut
Return a inner to my dut,
And never any mercie find,
Since he didaineth to be kind.

div.p:
Wee were both very attentive unto his air, and perhaps I hould have heard more, had not Leonida feared let Polemas hould out with omething which he deired hould be kept ecret; and therefore as oon as ever he had done inging, he began to peak. I dare lay a wager, aid he, that I doe know her of whom this Song was made; then whipering him in the ear, as if he would name her, he bade him take heed what he aid before me. He very cunningly anwered aloud, No, no, you are mitaken, I wear it is not he whom you named. Then I perceived, that he did conceal her elf from me; and therefore eeming as if I would goe and gather ome flowers, I parted from them, but not o farre ditant but till I held an eye upon their actions. Now ince Polemas and he fell off, he hath confeed all unto me, but when they were in league together, I could never make her tell mee any thing. But being then together, they fell to dicoure, and he did firt begin it. Come, come, Polemas, aid he, why doe you jet thus with your Friends? Tell mee truly, upon whom was thoe Veres made? Fair Nymph, aid he, your own oul can tell you as well as I, for whom they were made. How hould I know, aid he, do you think I can divine things? Yes certainly, anwered Polemas, and I doe think you one of thoe who does not obey that god who peaks by your mouth, but rather will be obeyed by him. How do you explain this aenigma? (aid the Nymph) I do explain it thus, replyed he; The god of Love doth peak by your mouth, otherwie your words could not be o full of Fire, as to kindle o many flames as they doe in the hearts of all thoe that hear them: And yet you do not obey that god when hee commands, That all thoe who love, hould be loved again; but you, all diobedience, doe make all thoe who love you, to think you infinitely fair, but not at all loving, no not o much as pittifull. I peak, Madam, for my own particular, and can afely wear, without the leat danger of perjury, that never any beauty under the Sun
was, and is more loved than you by me. When he uttered thee lat words, he bluht, and with a mile he anwered thus; Polemas, Polemas, old Souldiers can hew their valour by wounds and never ue to brag of it, but you that talk o much of yours, would be put to your hifts to hew them, if Love your Captain General hould ask you where they are. Cruel Nymph, aid Polemas, you are much mitaken; for I would onely bid him look upon the fair eyes of my enemy, and fully atisfie him; for then he would receive uch wounds as I have in my heart, and never complain of me. However, it is my glory to have uch a worthy author for my wounds. Should Love enter into argument with me, I hould ooner atisfie him than you; for he would be enible of my pain, which you never can, becaue a fire cannot burn it elf. You can never be o enible of our tears, who are o full of rigour, that though we do adore you as fair, yet we can hardly commend you as humane. Leonida did love Polemas, but as yet hee would not let him know it: On the other ide, he feared, that if he hould put him quite out of hope he hould then quite loe him; and therefore he anwered him thus; Polemas, if your affection be uch as you ay, then time will give me better knowledge of it, than all your well poken words can, which are too eloquent to proceed from affection; for I have heard ay, that affection cannot be without paion, and paion will not permit a pirit the freedome of dicoure: But, when time has told me as much as you have done, you may think, I am not uch a tone, but I hall be enible of your merits, and your amity may perhaps finde a favourable reception; untill then, never hope for any more from me, then what you may from all the ret of my Companions in generall. Polemas would have kied her hand, by way of aurance, but he forbad him, aying, Cavalier, be dicreet, many eyes are upon us; if you ue any uch things, you will loe me. Upon this he roe up, and came to us, who were gathering flowers. Thus was the firt overture of any affection between them, which gave occaion unto Galathed, to intermeddle in the buinee; for eeing this paage in the Garden, and having a deigne upon Polemas, he would know that night what had paed between Leonida and him. And being ever very familiar with your Niece, he durt not abolutely deny the truth of this addree; but Galathea preed the matter further, and would needs know the very ame words which paed between them; unto which your Niece did partly anwer truth, and partly diemble; but he aid enough to exaperate Galathea o much, as from that very day he reolved to get his love, and went to work with o many artifices, as it was impoible he hould reit. Firt he began with Leonida, and charged her, to let this love betwixt Polemas and he, go no further; then told her, that it was her bet policy to root it out for he knew, that Polemas had another aime, and made ue of her only to laugh at: Further, if Amais hould come to know of it, he would be much offended. Leonida who then had no more ubdety in her than a little Child, received the words of the Nymph us from her Mitree, and never penetrated into the depth of her deigne, but was for ome daies o trange unto Polemas, as he could not chue but wonder what the matter was. This, at the beginning, made him more hot upon this addree, as it is ordinary for young pirits to be mot violent upon that which is mot difficult unto them. And indeed, he did o continue his courthip that Leonida had much ado to diemble the affection which he bore unto him, inomuch as Polemas perceived well enough that he loved him. But ee how love had ordained it: After three or foure months continuance, in his mot violent proecution: of his courthip, and when he had attained to as much aurance, as almot he could deire, his affection began to lack, and loe its violence, and by degrees grew o faint and bold, as it was quite dead.

The Nymph did not take any notice, that he was ingle in this affection; the truth is, Galathea was partly the caue; for having a deign upon Polemas, he did ue uch artifice, and was o indulgent towards him as it may be aid, he did inenibly teal him: for when Leonida was hurp with him, Galathea was weet; when the one did flie his company, the other carraed him; and all this o long together, and o openly, that Polemas began to cat his eyes upon Galathea, and a little after, his heart followed; for, he eeing himelfe favoured by the greater, and leighted by the inferiour, he began to embrace the miling fortune. But Oh! wie Adamas, ee how it pleaeth Love to play with hearts. At this time, Agis, at the motion of Clidaman, became a Servant unto your Niece, not o much, as you know, by election, as by intigation. At the firt, this new Cavalier did apply himelfe in all becomming courthip unto his new Mitree, and he was till wholly devoted unto Polemas: Agis, who like a Mier, that has till his eye upon his treaure, did take notice of it, and complained unto his Mitree, but her faint and hollow anwers, in lieu of extinguihing
his jealouie, did by little and little tifle his love: for, conidering what looe hold he had of her oul, he reolved to let it go, and be gone himelfe. The bet receipt (as I have heard ay) for the cure of a Lover. For, as Love has its beginning from the eyes, o its decay mut needs be, from not eeing them; which cannot be but in abence, where oblivion wallowes up all memory of the party loved: And o it did in Agis, he was no ooner gone but all love vanih'd out of his oul, and entertained didain in lieu of it, o as Leonida, in triving to get Polemas, lot him, who perhaps would have been entirely hers. But the rallerie of Love reted not here, Polemas mut have his hare as well as the ret; for jut about this time, the affection of Lindamor began to break out; and, as Leonida had lot Agis for Polemas, and polemas Leonida for Galathea; o Galathea cat off Polemas for Lindamor. It is a task too hard to relate all their particular follies: but o it was, that Polemas eeing himelfe paid in the ame coin that he payed your Niece, would not for all that, be out of either hope or love; but on the contrary, did ue all inventions to ingratiate himelfe, but all to this very houre in vain; But yet, this atisfaction he found, that he, who was the caue of his miery, did not enjoy that happinee he aimed at: For, whether it was by reaon of his tratagems, or the will of the gods, I know not, but Lindamor is out of favour as well as he: And it eemes, Love could never finde any ret in the breat of Galathea, the memory of one was no ooner out, but another was preently in; and now, at this very time, her thoughts are all upon a Shepheard, whoe qualities as a Shepheard may indeed merit much, but never to be Galathea's Servant; and yet he is o extreamly paionate and tender of him, that if his-icknee hould continue, I know not what would become of her; for I never aw one o carefull, nor o troubled, as he hath been, ever ince he was ill. But this is not all, mot wie Adamas; Your Niece is alo o taken with Celadon, as I know not whether Galathea or he be more, and hereupon great jealouie is grown betwixt them: and though I qualifie the matter as well as I can, yet o it is, that I do depair of it for the future: And therefore I thank the gods that you are come; for really without you; I know not how to carry my elfe betwixt them. Excue me in peaking thus freely unto you, ince it is upon a buinee that concerns you; the affection I do bear unto you, contraines me to it.

Thus did Silvia end her dicoure, with abundance of demontration of her hatred, againt this kinde of life, for which Adamas did much eteem her. And to begin the cure of this Shepheard, and thee Nymphs (for the lat of thee was the greater difficulty) Adamas asked her advice. For my part, aid he, I would firt take away the caue, which is this Shepheard, and the effects may of themelves follow; but this mut be done with much artifice, ele Galathea will never let him go. 'Tis very true, anwered the Druide; but in the mean time, untill that can be handomly contrived, care mut be taken, that he do not fall in love with them; for there is uch a ympathy between Youth and Beauty, that if they hould conjoyne affections once, all eparations will be in vain. Oh Adamas! aid Silvia, did you but know Celadon as well as I do, this would be the leat of all your fears; for he is o rooted in the love of Atrea, that all the beauty in the world except hers cannot hake him, epecially now he is ick, for his care may well be more of his cure than any thing ele. Fair Silvia, anwered the Druide, you peak as one that is ignorant in Love, and never knew the force of it; this little god can do uch miracles, that when there is leat appearance of any effects, even then will he hew his power: Be not therefore o ecure, for there is no kinde of vertue whatoever, that is Armour-proof againt Love. Chatity it elfe cannot do it, witnee Endymion. Away, away, aid Silvia. Oh! wie Adamas, why do you terrifie me with o great a dyater? Becaue, aid he, I would have you arme your elfe againt the forces of this god, let being too ecure in your opinion of that which you judge impoible, you hould be urpried before you be prepared. I have heard ay, that Celadon is o handome, o dicreet, and o every way accomplihed, as he is furnihed with all perfections which caue Love, and therefore there is danger: Treaons of Love are o hard to be dicovered, that not one of a thouand can ee them. Nay, nay, aid Silvia, let me alone for that, and tell me only what I hould do in this buinee, that we have already dicovered. I do conceive, aid the Druide, this cure mut be wrought very much by the eye; and when I have een how the world goes, we hall order things to the bet advantage we can, and in the mean time, let us keep our deign ecret. Hereupon Silvia left Adamas to his ret, and went to Galathea, who with Leonide was by Celadon's bed ide; for they hearing he was awake, they could neither of them hold from him: He eteemed Leonida very much, her carraes did oblige him to it; but Silvia's humour
pleaed him much better. A litter after, they fell into dicoure of Adamas, much extolling his widome, prudence, and goodnee: Upon which, Celadon asked, whether it was not he who was on unto great Pelion, of whom o many wonders are reported? The very ame, aid Galathea, and he is come hither purpoely to be your Phyician. Oh Madam, anwered the Shepheard, he mut have abundance of Art if he can cure my dieae: but, I am of opinion, that when he knowes it, he will o depair of my recovery, as he will not undertake the cure. Galathea thought, that he had poke of the dieae in his body: But is it poible, aid he, that you hould finde your elfe o ill? I am confident, that if you would but help your elfe, you would be able to quit your bed in two or three daies. Perhaps not, Madam, aid Leonida, for ome are o inwardly ick, as they themelves do not know of it, untill it be at the height. Their dicoure had lated longer, had not the Druide come, to ee how quares went; and he found him well enough dipoed in body, for the Malady was pat the height, and in its Decline; but when he talked with him, he found the dieae to be mot in the minde, though he did not believe it was for any of thee Nymphs: Yet like a prudent Phyician, he would feel how the pule of his minde did beat: and therefore to begin the cure, he would try how he tood affected firt to Galathea; and in order to this, when all the Nymphs were retired he hut the dores, and began thus: I ee, Celadon, aid he, that your atonihment is not little, to finde your elfe exalted o uddenly unto uch a height of fortune, as this you enjoy; for I am confident it was above your hopes, ince being born a Shepheard, and brought up in a Village, you are now carraed, cherihed, and waited upon by Nymphs, and uch as are accutomed to command; and more then that, uch as command the whole Country: You have great reaon to be thankfull unto the gods for it, and pray, that it may continue. Adamas poke in this manner, purpoely as an invitation, to make him peak the truth of his affection, thinking by this means, & eeming to approve of it, he would dicover himelf. Unto which the Shepheard anwered with a deep igh; Father, aid he, if this be uch a high fortune, then certainly my mouth is out of tat; for I did never in all my life relih more bitter Wormwood than this, which you call good-fortune, and ince I came into this condition wherein you find me. Why, (aid the Druide, the better to dicover his ubtlety) is it poible you hould be o inenible of your happinee, as not to ee the Grandure unto which you are advanced? Alas, alas, aid Celadon, all this does but hew me a Precipice and menace me with the greater fall. Are you afraid, aid Adamas that this good fortune will not lat? I fear (aid the Shepheard) that it will lat longer than I would have it. Why hould Sheep languih and die in a great water, where Fihes thrive and play? Becaue, anwered the Druide, it is againt their Nature. And do you think, Father, (aid the Shepheard) that it is not againt the nature of a Shepheard, to live amongt o many great Nymphs? I was born a Shepheard, and o habituated to a Village-life; as nothing but things of my own condition and quality can pleae me. But is it poible, aid the Druide, that Ambition, which is o naturall unto men, cannot invite you to quit your woods? Cannot beautie allure a young heart unto it, and divert you from your firt intentions? The ambition which every one ought to have, anwered the Shepheard, is, to do that well which is their duty to do, and in that, to be the prime amongt thoe of their own rank; and that beauty which becomes us to look upon, and ought to attract us, is that which we may love, and not that which we ought to reverence, nor look upon, but with eyes of repect only. Why do you imagine, aid the Druide, that there is any uch Grandure amongt men, which merit and vertue may not arive at? Becaue, anwered the Shepheard, I know, that all things ought to keep themelves within the limits and bounds that nature hath placed them: A Ruby, though never o excellent in its kinde, can never become a Diamond; and he that hopes to elevate himelf too high, or, to ay better, to change his nature, and to make himelfe more then he is, will but pend both his paines and his time in vain. The Druide now amaed at the wie coniderations of this Shepheard, and very glad to ee him o far from any thoughts of Galathea, began to deal with him in this manner: Son, aid he, I am extreamly glad to find o much widome in you, and do aure you, that as long as you continue in this minde, the heavens will houre all manner of felicities upon you. Many are o taken up with vanities, and tranported with them, that they run out of their wits, and that upon much vainer hopes than thee I propound unto you: And what becomes of them at lat? jut nothing, unlee after long and intolerable paines, a ad repentance, for uffering themelves to be o long deluded. You have reaon to thank the heavens, that have endued you with this knowledge, before you come to repentance; and you have great reaon
alo to pray, that they will preerve you in the ame minde, in the ame tranquility, and weetnee of life, in which you have hitherto lived. But ince you do not apire unto any Grandure nor Beauty, what is it then, Celadon, that will tay you here amongt thee Nymphs? Alas, anwered the Shepheard, there is nothing can tay me by my good will; it's only Galathea that keeps me here in the nature of a Prioner, and the truth is, I would have tryed all waies to make an ecape, had not my icknee prevented me; and if no way would have hit, I hould have been o unmannerly, as to have gone away by force When I would peak unto Galathea about it, he eemes o extreamly angry, as I mut confee; I durt not mention it any more unto her: But, in the mean time, my tay here has been o tedious unto me, that I do accue it to be the principall caue of my malady. And therefore, Father, if ever you will compaionate the mierable condition of an extreamly afflicted peron, I do conjure you by the great gods, whom you do mot reverence and adore, by your own good genius, by the memory of your worthy Father, great Pelion, that you will take ome pitty upon my life, and by your prudence, added unto my earnet deire, to help me out of this weariome Prion, for o I hall call it as long as I tay here. Adamas extreamly glad to hear how paionately he expreed himelfe, did embrace him, and after he had kied his cheek, aid thus unto him: Yes, dear Son, be confident I will do as you deire; and aoon as your dieae will permit, I will ue all poible means to facilitate your getting out of this place; continue only in this minde, and recover as oon as you can. Then after much other uch dicoure as this, he left him, o much contented, that if Adamas would have uffered him, he would have quitted his bed that very houre.

In the mean time, Leonida, who would not uffer Galathea to run on any longer in that errour, which Climanthes had infued into her, one night, when Silvia and the little Merill were retired, he at down by her beds-ide, and after ome common dicoure, he aid thus unto her; Madam, I have met with ome newes in my journey, newes that concernes you, and I would not upon any termes conceal it from you, becaue I hall thereby extreamly undeceive you. What is it, aid the Nymph? It is, aid Leonida, the mot ubtle piece of knavery that ever Love invented, and I believe, you will not be orry for my voyage, though it were for nothing ele, but the dicovery of it. This Druide that reided here, is the mot wicked fellow, and the cunninget knave, that ever deluded any one. Then did he relate all that he heard, from the mouth of Climanthes and Polemas, and all the plot that was invented, only to dipoee Lindamor, and ingratiate Polemas in his room. At the firt, the Nymph was atonihed; afterwards, the love of this Shepheard did o flatter her, that he was perwaded, Leonida poke this out of deigne, to divert her affection from this Shepheard, and to enjoy him her elfe; o as he did not give any credit to what he aid; but on the contrary, turning it into laughter, aid thus unto her: Go, go, Leonida, go to bed, and to morrow perhaps you will be more ubtle, and know how to diguie your tricks better: Then he miled, and turned to the other ide. This did o extreamly offend Leonida, as he reolved, whatoever came of it, to et Celadon at liberty: In order to this deigne, he went the ame night unto her Uncle, unto whom he ued this language; Father, aid he, you ee Celadon is now recovered, why hould he tay any longer here? I pray conider what prejudice it may bring upon us all hereafter. I would gladly have undeceived Galathea, and divert her from the perwaions of the impotor Climantes; but he does o dote upon Celadon, as whooever hall motion his departure, is her declared enemy: but I do conceive, the uret way is to get him gone, which we can never do without you; for her eye is o continually upon me, as I cannot tir a foot, but he takes notice of it, and upects me.
