Adamas did a little wonder to hear his Niece ay o, and had an opinion, that he was afraid that he perceived the good-will he had unto this Shepheard, and therefore he would blinde him: However, conceiving to cut up Love by the roots, the bet way would be, to get Celadon away; he told his Niece, that he did very much deire the ame, but knew not how. The way, aid he, is the eaiet in the world: Get the habit of a Nymph, put it upon him, he is young, and has not a beard; this way he may get out, unknowne who helped him, nor can Galathea tell whom to blame. Adamas found this invention to be good, and the ooner to put it in execution, would preently go and get this habit made, under colour of going to fetch ome Phyick for Celadon, letting Galathea to undertand, that though he was out of a Feavour, yet he was not out of danger to relaps, which he could eaily prevent; and did communicate the deigne unto Silvia, who did very well approve of it, o he would not tay too long before his return. Celadon was no ooner awake, but Galathea and Leonida went into his Chamber, under pretence
of eeing how he did. Adamas perceiving how aiduouly indulgent thee Nymphs were, did think delay to be very dangerous; and after ome ordinary quetions concerning his dieae, he turned towards Galathea, and deired her to give him leave to enquire of ome particulars, which he durt not do before her. Galathea uppoing it to be omething that related to his icknee, withdrew, and gave Adamas an opportunity to acquaint the Shepheard with his deigne, and promied him to return within two or three daies at the furthet. Celadon conjured him unto it, by all poible intreaties, knowing, that without him his imprionment would lat long. After he had aured him that he would, he took Galathea aide and told her, that though the Shepheard was at that preent very well, yet there was great fears of a relaps, and therefore it was requiite to prevent it in order to which, he would go and provide uch Medicines as were proper for it, and return again. The Nymph was very glad of this; for, on the one ide, he deired the Shepheards cure; and on the other, the preence of Adamas began to be very troubleome unto her, foreeeing, that he could not be o free with her friend Celadon in his preence. Adamas knew her minde well enough; however, aoon as dinner was done, he went his way, leaving the Nymphs in perplexity enough; for all three had different deignes, and each of them aiming at their everall ends, of neceitie they mut deceive one another: And this was the reaon, that they were commonly all three about his bed together, but epecially Silvia, purpoely to keep them from talking with him in private; but for all her vigilancy, Leonida found a time to tell him the reolution of her and her Uncle, and had this further talk with him: I hope, Celadon, (aid he unto him) that when you are at liberty, you will not be o ungratefull, as to forget this good office, but will then conider of it, and of the affection which now I do bear unto you; at leat, you will remember the injuries I have received from Galathea for your ake: And if Love which in any other would produce a reciprocall love again, have not the ame effects in you; yet I hall be extreamly glad to hear from your mouth, that I am not diagreeable unto you. Celadon, who already knew of this growing affection, had a deire to tifle it in the cradle; but fearing, let if he hould dipleae her, he hould fall off from that coure which he had reolved upon with her Uncle, he would give her uch an anwer, as hould till keep her in the ame minde; and therefore aid thus unto her: Fair Leonida, what a trange opinion would you have of me, if forgetting Atrea, whom I have o long erved I hould begin a new affection unto you? I peak very freely to you, becaue I know, you are not ignorant of my devotion to her. Oh Celadon, anwered Leonida, you need not hide it from me, for I know as much of your affairs as you your elfe does. Then, Fair Nymph anwered Celadon, ince you do know it o well, how can you think I hould force my love from her, that has the ole power of my oul, my life, my elfe, and all I have? I pray, look upon all the actions of my life, and then tell me how I hould give you atisfaction, and what I hould do. Leonida could not hide her fears at this dicoure; yet, being wie, and conidering how againt her duty it was to live in this manner, alo that all would be in vain, he reolved to become a Mitree of her own will; but this being a work of greater difficulty, than to be done as oon as thought upon, he thought it bet to take a little time, and conult with her pillow upon it: In this reolution, he poke thus unto the Shepheard; Celadon, aid he, I cannot now take that counel with my elf which is neceary, I had need to have a little time to muter up all the powers of my oul before I can reolve. Their dicoure had continued longer, had not Silvia interrupted, and aid unto Leonida, Doe you not know Siter (aid he) that Flurial is come? and hath o ecaped the guards of the gates, and came to Galathea before any of us knew of it? Hee gave her ome Letters: I know not from whence they came, nor from whom, but I am ure they made her change colour two or three times. Leonida preently imagined that it was from Lindamor, and therefore he left Silvia with Celadon, and went to Galathea to be atisfied. Silvia then eeing her elfe alone with him, hee began to talke o kindly unto him, that if any there could have made him in love, doubtles it had been he. And ee how Love is pleaed to thwart our deignes: The other two Nymphs who courted him with all poible artifice to make him in love, could not do it; and this who never aimed at it, did come nearer the mark than either of the ret: By which is to be oberved, That Love mut bee free, and will not be obliged by any, but it elf and whom it pleaeth.

Whilt Celadon was in thee thoughts, Silvia, who thought upon nothing but occaions of dicoure, becaue he was much pleaed with his converation, and delighted to hear him peak, he aid thus unto him; You cannot believe, Shepheard, how much I am pleaed
with your company; and I wear, that if Galathea be of my mind, we will have more of it than formerly we have; for I finde by you there is abundance of delight to bee taken in your villages, and in your honet freedom, ince you are exempted from all ambition, and by conquence from envy; and doe live without any artifice and lander, which are the four Pets of our Court-life. Wie Nymph, anwered the Shepheard, all this is mot true, if we were out of the power of Love; but you mut know, that the very ame effects which Ambition produceth in Courts, Love does produce in the Country; the envy of a Rival is no les than a Courtiers; and the Artifices of Lovers and Shepheards are nothing inferiour unto my others; and o detraction and cenuring of others is as rie amongt us as you. The truth is, we have this advantage of you; for in lieu of two enemies which you have, which are Love and Ambition, we have but one of them. And from hence it is that there are ome particular men amongt us which may be called happy; and none, I believe amongt you Courtiers: For, uch as doe ecape being in Love, doe not ecape the allurements of Ambition; and uch as doe ecape Ambition, have not uch frozen ouls, as can reit the flames of o many Fair eyes; whereas wee that have but one enemy, may the more eaily reit him, as Silvander hath hitherto done; a Shepheard truly full of excellent perfections, but more happy than wie; for he having yet never met with any beauty that pleaed, or could attract him, he never holds familiarity with any Shepheardes, which is the reaon that he preerves his liberty; for my part I beleeve, that unles one do love ome where ele, it is impoible to be long with an amiable beauty, and not love her. Silvander anwered, I am o little vered in this cience, that I ubmit unto what you ay; yet I doe believe it is omething ele than beauty which caueth Love, otherwie one Lady that is loved of one man hould be loved of all. There are (anwered Celadon) everall anwers to this poition. All beauties are not looked upon with one and the ame eye: Colours, ome pleae one eye, ome another none all: So of Beauties, all eyes do not judge alike; but Silvanders reaon me-thinks is above all. If any ask him why hee never was in Love, he will anwer, that he has not yet found his Loadtone; and when he has found it, then he hall infallibly love as others do. What does he mean, aid Silvia, by his Loadtone? I know not, replyed Celadon, whether I can well inform you; but hee is a man very well tudyed, and held amongt us for a good Scholar: Hee ayes, that when great Jupiter firt formed man, and all ouls he touched every one with a everal peece of a Loadtone, and afterwards put all the peeces in a place by themelves: Likewie the ouls of women, after he had touched them, he put them in a Magazine by themelves: Afterwards when he ent the ouls into bodies, he brought thoe of the women to the place where the Loadtones were, which touched the oules of the men, and likewie the ouls of the men into the place where the loadtones were which touched the women, and made every one to take one peece: If there were any theevih ouls, they took everal pieces and hid them. Now when that man meets with that woman that has that piece which touched his oul, it is impoible but hee mut love her; the Loadtone hee hath, doth attract his oul: And from hence proceeds the everall effects of Love: For thoe who are loved of many, are thoe theevih ouls who took many peeces of the Loadtone: If any doe love one who loves not him again, that was one who took her Loadtone, but he not his. Many quetions upon this were put unto him, unto which hee anwered very well: Amongt the ret I put this, How comes it to pae (aid I) that one Shepheard loves many Shepheardees? Thus, anwered he, the peece of Loadtone which touched him being amongt the ret, when Jupiter did mingle them all together, it broke; and being in everal peeces, all thoe who have them, doe attract his oul; but perhaps thoe who are taken with o many everal Loves, will never love much, becaue thoe little bits cannot have o much force as if it were a whole one. Moreover, aid he, from hence it comes to pae, that we do often ee ome perons love others, who in our eyes are nothing amiable. Alo from hence proceeds thoe trange loves which ometimes fall out; As that a Gaule brought up amongt many beauties, hould fall in love with a barbarous tranger. Diana asked him, what he could ay for Timon the Athenian, who never loved any, nor any loved him? His Loadtone (anwered he) is either till in Jupiters Magazine, or ele he who took it, dyed in her cradle: So as when we doe ee any one who does not love, wee ue to ay, his Loadtone was forgotten. But, ayd Silvia, what could hee ay unto this, that none did love Timon? That ometimes (anwered Celadon) Jupiter did count the pieces that remained, and finding the number come hort, becaue ome theevih ouls had taken more than they hould, he ent thoe ouls into their bodies without tones; and hence it comes to pae that many Shepheards and Shepheardees, who are accomplihed with many excellent
qualities, yet are disfavoured, and none loves them. But Corilas put this quetion to him; One loves another a long time, How comes hee to quit her, and love another? Silvander anwered unto this, That his Loadtone, who changed, had been broken; and hers, whom hee loved lat, was a greater peece than the other; as wee ee a peece of Steel between two Loadtones, will goe to that which hath the greater force, and o the oul will goe to that party who hath the mot attractive power. Truly aid Silvia, this mut needs bee an admirable Shepheard, that is full of uch fine conceptions; But, I beeech you, tell me, Who is he? I hall hardly tell you that, Madam, (aid Celadon) for he cannot tell himelf; yet by the judgement we can make of him by his good qualities, he is from omegood place; for you mut know that he came into our village not long ince with a very hort pittance of etate, and without any acquaintance onely this hee aid, that hee came from about the Lake Lemane, where he had been brought up of a child, Since he has got acquaintance, every one is ready to help him: Beides, being an excellent Herbalit, and having great knowledge in the nature of Animals, his Flock o increaes under his hands, and he thrives o well, as at this hour he may be called Rich, at leat in content. And, fair Nymph, it is no great difficulty to attain unto o much wealth; for Nature is contented with a little, and we who live according to her Rules are Rich, if contented; and our contentment being eaily obtained, our Riches are quickly gotten. You are, aid Silvia, much richer in happines than we are. But you poke of Diana; I know her onely by ight; Pray tell me, who was her Mother? The Mother was Belinda, anwered he, Wife unto the age Celion, who dyed young. And Diana, aid Silvia, who is he, and what humour is he of? She is, aid Celadon, one of the fairet Shepheardees about the River Lignon, and let mee but except Atrea, and I will ay, he is the fairet: for, beides thoe that are obvious unto the eye, he has o many beauties of mind, as no more can be aid or deired than is in her. Oftentimes we have been three or four of us Shepheards together, looking and admiring her, and alwayes concluded, that there was no perfection which could be wihed, but was to be found in her. And though her genius be not very inclinable to love, yet he is uch a incere lover of Virtue, as hee does oblige more that way, than others doe by their mot violent affections How comes it to pae aid Silvia, Has he not many ervants? No, anwered Celadon; he will not entertain any: The deceit which the Father of Philidas did put upon her, does hinder her. And truly it was the mot notorious trick that ever I heard of. Were it not too much trouble to you, aid Silvia, I hould bee very glad to undertand it from you, and alo to know who Celion and Belinda were. I feare, anwered Celadon, that the tory will bee o long as to weary you. No, no aid the Nymph, we cannot better employ the time, whilt Galathea is reading her Letters. Then, in obedience to your command, anwered hee, I hall do it as briefly as poibly I can: And thus he began.

div.head: The Hitory of Celion and Belinda.
div.p:
IT is mot certain, fair Nymph, that Virtue, be it never o naked, is yet mot lovely in it elf; and has o many attracting Adamants in it, that as oon as any oul is touched with it, it mut needs love and follow it. But when this virtue meets with a fair body, it is not onely lovely, but admirable; all eyes and pirits are ravihed at the lutre of uch a glorious viion. And this will bee apparently een by the dicoure I intend to make you of Belinda. Be pleaed to know, that not far off hence, about the River Lignon, there was a very excellently well quallified Shepheard, called Philemon, who after a long Mariage had a Daughter whom he named Belinda, and who being grown up to ripe years, appeared in beauty both of body and mind, admirable. Not far off her houe inhabited another Shepheard, called Leon: As neighbourhood had contracted a firm league of Amity betwixe thee two houes, o Fortuns would have ome equality alo between them, and betowed one Daughter upon Leon, whoe youth promied much beauty for the future, her name was Amaranthe: The amity of the Fathers begat a frequency of Society between the Daughters. They were from their cradles brought up together; and ince, did alwayes keep their Flocks together alo: As they grew in tature, o in beauty: Many young Shepheards courted their amities, but all their ervices and fair profeions of affection could obtain no more from them, but a civil and courteous reception. It hapned that Celion a young Shepheard about thee parts, having a Sheep that trayed, he came to look for it in Belinda's Flock, where he her elf was: She retored the Sheep with o much kindnee, as the finding of this trayed Sheep, proved the loing of himelf; and from that time hee began
to be enible, that fair eyes have power to offend; for before he was o ignorant, that no uch thought could ever enterunto his oul: but, be his ignorance what it would, he o carried the matter, as knowing his dieae, he made it known unto that Phyician, from whom only he could expect a cure. Belinde, by his actions knew his dieae almot as oon as himelfe, for at the firt, he could not tell her his minde; but his affection growing with his age, it came to uch a Grandure, as he did reent it in good earnet, and was contrained to change his childih Pati •• es, into a very curious Courthip, Belinde, on the other ide, though he was c • urted by everall other Suitors yet he entertained Celion's affection better han any of the ret; but yet, no otherwie, then a Siter to a Brother, which he did plainly make appear unto him one day when he thought to have declared his minde unto her: She kept her flock by the River ide and was c • nt • mplating her own beauty in the water The Shepheard took this opportunity and holding his hand before her eyes, in an amorous manner, he aid thus unto her: Take heed fair Shepheardee, l • ok not in the water, let you hould incur the ame danger, that others have done by the like action. Why do you ay o, aid Belinde who did not undertand him? Oh fair Shepheardee, aid Celion, you ee more beauty in this River, than ever Na <>
did in the Fountain. At thee words, Belinde bluh'd, which did the more advantage her beauty; yet he anwered him: How long, Celion, have you wihed m • o well? I have wih • d you well very long, aid the Shepheard, and believe it, this good-will is confined unto no other time then the end of my life. Then the Shepheardee, bowing towards him, told him that he never made any quetion of his affection, but ever received it with as much benevolence, as he offered her own unto him. To which Celion preently anwered: I do kie this fair hand by way of thanks, for o great a favour, and by way of promie of that faithfull ervice which Celion vowes unto you, as long as he lives. Belinde perceived by the zealous utterance of his words, and the kie which he paionately imprinted upon her hand, that he meant of another kinde of affection then he intended and therefore would not let him go on in his errour: Celion (aid he unto him) you are very far off that which you do fancy to your elfe you can finde out no readier way to banih me your company than this; if you do deire I hould continue the ame affection to you, which I promied, continue you alo within the ame compae, which your vertue did ever promie me; otherwie I will break off all manner of familiarity with you, and protest never to love you: I could (as the cutome of thoe that are loved is) chide and brawl with you, but I will not, becaue I would freely have you know that if you behave yourelfe otherwie than becomes you, you can never have any hopes in my affection. She added many other bitter expreions, which did o atonih Celion, that he knew not what to anwer; only he cat himelfe upon his knees at her feet, and without any capitulation, but ubmiion, asked pardon, and proteted, that his affection hould proceed no further; but, as he did caue it, o he hould regulate it. If you do behave your elfe o, aid Belinde, you will oblige me to love you, otherwie, the contrary Fair Shepheardee, replyed he, my affection is now born, and uch as it is it mut live; for it cannot die but with me, o as I cannot remedy it, but with time but I will promie to give it uch a check, as you hall command; and let me never be bleed with any favour from you, if you finde any action of my life that can dipleae you. To conclude, he permitted him to love her upon thee termes. And thus thee two Lovers lived long in uch contentment, as they had good caue to thank their Fates for it: Sometimes he would end Letters unto her, by his Brother Diamis who preented them unto her, under a colour of preenting her with ome fruit. She would often return him uch atisfactory anwers, as he had ome reaon to be contented with And this affection was carried with o much prudence as few perceived it; Amaranthe her elfe, though he was continually with them had been ignorant of it, had he not accidentally found a Letter, which her companion had lot: And ee I beeech you the conequences of it, with this Note, That it is very dangerous for any young oul to come neer the fire of Love. Till now, this Shepheardee never had the leat reentment of any love, no, nor o much as any minde of being loved; but, as oon as he aw this Letter, whether out of envie to her companion, whom he thought no uperiour in beauty; or becaue he was of that age which is mot apt to take fire; or whether this Letter contained uch hot and ervent expreions, as would thaugh a piece of Ice: o it was, that he began to well with deire, not only to love, but to be loved again, by this Shepheard: And then he read over the Letter again everall times, which was thus penned.

p.hi: IF your fair eyes, were as full of truth, as they are of motives to love, the weetnee which at the firt they do promie, would then make me adore them with as much contentment, as they do now produce in me vain hopes; but they are o far from making good their deluding promies, as they will not o much as confee them; and are o far from curing my wounds, as they will not o much as ay they are the cauers of them. The truth is, they can hardly deny them, if they do but conider, that no other Beauty but theirs, could ever make them o great. However, as if you intended to make your cruelty to equall your beauty, you ordain that affection, which you inpired, may cruelly die in me. Oh heavens! was there ever uch a mercilee Mother, as to murder her own child. But I, that am more dear of any thing that comes from you, than of my life, will never uffer uch a piece of injutice; and therefore I am reolved, to carry this affection along with me to my grave, hoping till, that heaven, conidering my patience, will once move you to be as pittifull unto me, as you are now dear and hard-hearted.

div.p: Amaranthe read over this Letter everall times, and ere he was aware, ucked in the weet poyon of Love, as a weary peron by degrees falls aleep; If her imagination brought the face of this Shepheard before her eyes, Oh how full of beauty and handomnee he fancyed him? His behaviour and mind was agreeable, his wit rare and every part o exquiite, as he thought her companion infinitely happy in his love. Then would he read the Letter over again, and when he came to the end of it, he flattered her deires (being blown by the bellowes of vain hopes) with an opinion, that Belinde did not yet love him, but that he her elfe might perhaps eaily get him; but this poor fond Lover never took notice, that this was the firt Letter he writ unto her, and that ince this, much alteration might be. Belinde's friendhip ometimes gave her a check; but love preently urmounted friendhip. In concluion, he writ this Letter unto Celion.

p.hi: YOur Perfections may well excue my error, and your Civility may as well receive that affection which I do offer unto you. May I perih, if I love any that is inferiour unto you, but uch is your merit, as I make it my glory to love you, and my hame to toop o low, as to love any other. If you do refue this offer, it will be for want of will or courage; and which of the two oever it be, it will be more dihonourable to you than me, that you refued me.

div.p: She gave this Letter her elfe unto Celion, who not imagining what it hould be as oon as he came to a private place, he read it, but not with more wonder than corn; and had he not known her to be the dear friend of his Mitree, he would not have daigned her an anwer: yet, fearing left he hould ome way or other prejudice him, he ent her this Letter by his Brother.

body.head: Celion's Anwer unto Amaranthe.
body.p: I Cannot tell what is in me, that can move you to love me: However, I do think it to be as great an honour, that uch a Shepheardee hould daigne to look upon me, as I do think it a misfortune, that I cannot receive uch an happinee. Oh! that it would pleae my Detinies, to let me give my elfe unto you, Fair Amaranthe; I hould think my elfe the happiet man alive, if I could live in your ervice; but ince it is not in my power, I beeech you excue me, and blame neither my wit nor my courage for that, which is hindred by a compulive Neceitie. It would be abundance of happinee and glory unto me, to be in your favour, but it would be as much griefe unto you, to finde a continuall impediment in my affection; o as I am forced mot humbly to beeech you, even by your vertue, to temper your too hot paion, by a moderate affection, which I hall with all my heart entertain, for there is no impoibility in that; but whatoever is in me, that is within the compae of poibility, is wholly at your ervice.

div.p: This anwer had been ufficient to have diverted her, if Love of its own nature, were not like unto Gun-powder, which the more it is retrained, the greater force it hath: Her apprehenions did oppoe againt thee difficulties, ome hadowes of reaon, as that Celion could not o oon cat Belinde off; that it would argue too great a levity in him, if he hould upon the very firt Summons deliver up the Fort. But time told her to her cot, that this was but a meer hadow of reaon; for ever ince that day, this Shepheard did to didain her, that he hunned her company, and often choe rather to be without Belinde', then have hers with it. Now perceiving her elfe to be imba • qued upon a Sea o full of dangers as was impoible to avoid a Ship-wrack, and finding her elfe not able to brook o great a dipleaure, he grew o ad, as he hunned all company and places, where any pleaure was to be found; and at lat fell ick in good earnet: Her dear friend, Belinde, came preently to viit her, and not dreaming of any thing, deired Celion to come with her; but the ight of a happinee which one cannot have, augmenteth the deire of it the more, and this viit did but more feter the dieae of Amaranthe. Night being come, all retired to their lodgings except Belinde, who was very much troubled at her companions miery, though he did not know what it was; for when he asked her any quetion, he was anwered only by ighs at which Belinde was atonihed. And at lat, a little offended at her, he aid: I did not think, Amaranthe, that you had loved Belinde o little, as to conceal any thing from her; but I ee I was deceived: And whereas hitherto I could ay that I loved you, now I can only ay, that I love a diembler. Amaranthe, whoe mouth was cloed with very hame, when he aw Belinde alone with her, and being prompted unto it by the violence of her affection, he reolved to make tryall of the mot deperate remedies that might cure her dieae. Laying hame aide therefore, as well as he could he opened her mouth two or three times, to declare the whole buinee but the word died as oon as it was on her lips, all the could do, was to profer ome interrupted words but at lat, holding her hands before her eyes, as not daring to look her in the face whom he poke unto: My dear Companion, (aid he unto her for o they called one another) our friendhip will not permit me to conceal any thing from you, knowing very well, that whatoever is poken unto you, will be ever kept as ecret, as if locked up in my own heart; but I beeech you excue an extream error, which; to atisfie the Lawes of friendhip, I am forced to open unto you. You ask me where my pain is, and from whence it proceeds? Know that it is Love, which arieth from the perfections of a certain Shepheard. But alas, being at this word overcome with hame and orrow, he turned her head to the other ide, and was ilent, but turned her ilence into a torrent of tears. Belinde wondred and knew not what to think; but, to cheer her up, I could not believe (aid he unto her) that a paion o common unto every one, hould o much trouble you. To love is a thing mot ordinary; but, to love the perfections of a Shepheard, argues an act of judgment. I pray tell me, who this happy Shepheard is. Amaranthe fetched a igh from the very root of her heart, and aid: Alas, alas, this Shepheard loves another. But who is he, aid Belinde? Since you will needs have it, aid Amaranthe, it is your Celion; I ay, yours, my friend; for I know he loves you, and didaines me. Excue my follies, I beeech you, and without notice taken leave me alone to endure my own torment.

The wie Belinde hearing this, was o ahamed of her companions error, that though he loved Celion as well as poible, yet he reolved, upon this occaion to render a trange tetimony of her friendhip, and turning towards Amaranthe, aid thus unto her: Truly, Amaranthe, I am extreamly troubled, to ee you thus tranported with this affection. And though our Sex has not an abolute authority over Love, yet thanks be to the gods eeing you in this condition, I have, and wil give you a cleer tetimony of my being your faithfull friend. I do love Celion, I will not deny it; yet it is as a Siter may love a Brother: But I do love you alo as my Siter, and will have him to love you more then me, (for I know he will obey me). Ret therefore your elfe contented, rely upon me, and when you are well recovered, you hall ee how much Belinde is yours.

After much other uch dicoure, night called upon Belinde to retire, leaving Amaranthe o full of contentment, as, forgetting all orrow, in a few daies he recovered her former beauty. In the mean time, Belinde was not a little troubled, but eeking for an opportunity to acquaint Celion with her deigne, at lat, he met with one as fit as he could deire: By fortune, he found him playing with his Ram, in that great Plain where Shepheards do commonly feed their Flocks: this Animall was the leader of the flock, and was o well taught, that he eemed as if he undertood his Mater when he poke unto him; in which
the Shepheardee took o much delight, that he tayed longer there; at lat, he would try whether the Ram would obey her as well as him, and he eemed much more obedient: What do you think, Brother, aid he unto him, of the acquaintance betwixt your Ram and me? I think, fair Shepheardee, (aid he) that he is yours, if you will be pleaed to do me the honour to accept of him; but it is no wonder he hould be o obedient unto you, for he knowes, that if he had not, I hould have diowned him for mine, having heard me often ay and ing, that, All I had was more yours than mine. 'Tis very well, aid the Shepheardee, I will try whether I have o much power over you, as you eem to give me; and will not only command, but earnetly entreat a thing from you. There is nothing, anwered the Shepheard, which you may not more abolutely command. Then Belinde, eeing this fit opportunity, began to open her minde thus: Since that day we firt began our friendhip, Celion, I have ever thought my elfe obliged to love and honour you, more than any peron living and I would not have you think I do intend to leen this love, for it hall accompany me to my grave; and yet perhaps you would make it diminih, did I not advertie you before hand, that my life and my friendhip hall leen together. Thee expreions made Celion admire, not knowing what he intended: At lat he told her, that he waited to know her pleaure in much joy and much fear: Joy, becaue he could think upon no greater honour then her commands; and Fear, becaue he knew not what he meant yet, death it elfe hould be welcome, if it came by her command. Then Belinde went on thus: You have ever, as well as now, given me uch full aurance of your obedience, that I cannot doubt of it; and therefore I hall not only intreat, but conjure Celion, by all the amity he bears unto Belinde, that he will obey her in this one thing: I will not impoe any impoibilities upon him, nor to leen the love which he bears unto me, but on the contrary, would have him rather to augment it. But before I go any further, I pray you let me know, whether your affection was ever of any other quality then it is at this time. Then Celion, looking more cheerfully than before, anwered, That heretofore he did love her with uch affection and paions, and with the ame deignes, that youth ueth to produce in hearts, mot tranported with Love, and in this, he would not except one that did exceed him; but ince, that her commands had uch power over him, as he hath moderated his paion; and his friendhip has o urmounted his love, as he hath had no thoughts of her, but uch as would not offend a Siter. I protet, Brother, replyed he, for o I will hold you to be as long as I live; you could never have obliged me more than by this. Know then what it is I do deire from you, only this, that preerving till inviolably this affection which you do now bear unto me, you will place your love upon one of the fairet Shepheardees about Lignon Perhaps you will think this a trange office from Belinde, but your wonder will vanih, when I tell you, that he is one whom I do mot love; for it is Amaranthe: Her, I do command you to love, by all the power that I have over you, for he has earnetly begg'd it of me. She was thus haty in her command, becaue he feared, that if he hould have retarded it any longer, he hould not have had power to reit his upplications, which he foreaw he would make. What do you think, fair Nymph (aid Celadon to Silvia) became of poor Celion? he looked as pale as death it elfe, and o much out of himelfe, as he could not peak one ingle yllable: But at lat, when he had a little recovered the ue of his languihing tongue, and in a Tone, like one in the midt of Torment, he cryed out: Oh cruell Nymph! have you preerved my life hitherto, thus inhumanely to ravih it away? This command is too ful of cruelty, to be heard & live; and my love is too great, to let me die without depair. Alas, if I mut die, let me die faithfull; and if there be no other way to cure Amaranthe, but by my death, I will mot freely acrifice my elfe unto her health, o you will but change the doom of your command, and bid me die loving only you. Belinde was much tartled at this, but not altered: Celion, aid he unto him, leave off all thee vain expreions, you will give me caue ele not to believe what you told me, if you do not atisfie me in the firt command that I do impoe upon you. Cruell Shepheardee (aid the ad Celion) mut you needs command me impoibilities? for though I dare not love you beyond your commanded limits; yet, command what you will, I cannot love any other.

Pitty did begin a little to melt her heart, and it was abundance of content unto her, to ee, that he whom he loved mot, did mot certainly love her: And this perhaps had altered her reolution, had he not been reolutely fixed to take away all thoughts from Amaranthe, that he was tung with the ame dieae; therefore he contrained all her pitty to retreat, which began already to draw tears into her eyes; and to the end they
hould not be een, he went away, and at parting aid unto him; Think well upon it, Celion, and be certain, I will never ee you again, unlee you will effect my entreaty, and your own promie. Whether Celion had a ad dejected oul eeing himelfe o far from any conolation or reolution, let them, that ever loved, judge; He was two or three daies like a man lot, he ran into the Woods, and hunned all manner of company: at lat, an old Shepheard that was an intimate friend of his Fathers, and one that was very wie alo loved Celion very well, eeing him in this condition, and perceiving, that nothing but effects of Love could thus ditract him, he was ome comfort unto him by his counell; For in his younger daies, he himelfe had been in the like traits; and began to mock Celion, for being o much troubled for o poor a buinee, demontrating unto him, that the remedy was eaie, and o very eaie, as he was ahamed, that Celion, who was reputed wife, and a man of courage, hould not hit upon it I know, aid he, that to fulfill this command of Belinda's is at the firt a matter of ome difficulty, and he will think your affection to be extream, but that will oblige her the more to love you; yet, ince you have made uch profeions of obeying her, it will content her, if you do diemble, and eem, as if you did obey what he has commanded. This counell ounded well in the ears of Celion, and was accordingly executed. But before this, he had writ this Letter unto Belinde.

body.head: Celion's Letter unto Belinde.
body.p: HAd I merited o ruffe a Treatment as this which I have received from you, I hould ooner have dyed than endured it; but ince it is for your contentment, I hall entertain it with a little more willingnee, then if in exchange you had hidden me die: Since I have wholly dedicated my elfe unto you, it is but reaonable you hould have the whole dipoure of me: But I beeech you conider, that as long as this contraint lats, o many daies are navihed from my life; for I cannot call thoe daies life, that are full of orrow and death: Shorten them therefore, Oh mot evere Shepheardee, if there be but one park of pitty remaining in you.

div.p:
It was impoible that Bolinda hould not reent thee expreions, which he knew proceeded from a mot perfect affection; withall, it was impoible any thing could divert her from her deigne She did advertie Amaranthe, that Celion would love her, and that he would know it as oon as he was recovered: Which advertiment did o haten her recovery, as he did make it appear, that to the cure of the body, the cure of the minde is not unprofitable. But Oh! what a lamentable contraint did Celion live in, and how intolerable was his torment? He grew o lean, and was o altered, as he was not knowable. But ee the extream everity of this Shepheardee, he was not contented with what he had done; but becaue he thought Amaranthe had ome jealouie of their affection, he was reolved to drive the Naile o to the head, that neither of them hould think, he jeated The Shepheards addree unto Amaranthe was oberved by every one, for it was openly declared; the Father alo of this Shepheard being acquainted with the commendable vertues of Leon, and knowing his family to be honourable, he did not diapprove of this Match. Belinde her elfe did propound the Marriage, and it was almot made up before Celion knew of it but when he heard of it, he could not forbear peaking unto Belinde, and was o plain with her, that he was halfe ahamed: but the Shepheard eeing words would not do, he reolved upon another coure, and a better way, which was, to apply himelfe unto his Father: Sir, aid he, I hould be very orry to diobey you in anything, and more in this than any other thing. I ee, Sir, that you do like of this alliance with Amaranthe, and as becomes me I have made addrees to her, and I do know no Shepheardee more affectionate than he: But, Sin, give me leave to tell you, that I do love her better for a Mitree than a Wife; yet I do humbly beeech you, command me not to tell you my reaon. Upon this, the Father had ome upition, that he knew of ome ill quality in the Shepheardee, and did heartily commend the prudence of his Son, who he thought had uch a command over his own affections. Thus this Match was broken off, and the former paages being publickly known, many did ask the quetion, from whence this coldnee of the buinee hould proceed: The Father, he could not hold from peaking of it unto his familiar friends, and they unto others, o as Amaranthe at the lat came to hear of it, who at the firt was much grieved; but afterwards eeing her own folly, in thinking to make her elfe loved by force, he did by degrees fall off, reolving to entertain the next
motion of marriage that was offered. Thus were thee Lovers eaed of an intolerable burthen, but it was to be loadned with one much more heavie.

Belinde was now at an age full fit for Marriage, and Philemon very deirous to ee her well betowed; he would have been very glad to entertain Celion; but Belinde, hating marriage as much as death, had charged him not to peak unto her; yet promiing him, that whenoever he aw her elfe forced to marry, he would acquaint him, to the end, that then he might put in for a hare of her, and demand her in Marriage: And this was the reaon, that Philemon perceiving the coldnee of Celion, he would not offer her unto him. In the mean time, Ergates the prime Shepheard of all the Country, and one who was generally eteemed for his many vertues, did make an overture of Marriage with her; and becaue he would not have the buinee talked of, untill he was ure of peeding, he, who did treat about the matter, did carry it o cloely, that a promie was made of the Marriage as oon as asked; for Philemon making himelfe ure of his Daughters obedience, did firt pae his word, and then acquainted her. At the firt, he could not reolve what to do becaue he was a man whom he had never een: However, this lofty pirit, that never would ink under the burthen of any miery, did preently roue up it elfe, and did not eem the leat dicontented at it for her own ake, which was more than he could do for Celion; and now her error of obtinate hatred againt marriage, mut be wahed away with tears. So it was, that to be as good as her promie, he acquainted poor Celion, that Philemon intended to marry her. As oon as Celion had this o much deired permiion, he did o olicite his Father, that the very ame day he made the motion unto Philemon; but it was too late, for which Belinde's Father was very orry for he loved Celion much better then Ergates. Oh heavens! what griefe, when he heard the doom of his misfortune; he went immediately out of the houe, and never reted till he found Belinde. At his firt accot, he could not peak, but his looks did ufficiently tell what was Philemon's anwer. Though he tood in as great need of ome good counell as he, and trength to upport this blow: yet he would hew her elfe o tout, as not to toop to any dyater: but he would not hew her elfe o inenible, as not to hew how he reented the Shepheards miery, but made it appear unto him, that it did dipleae her: Whereupon he asked him, how her Father relihed the motion? The Shepheard related the very ame anwer which Philemon gave, adding o many ighs and ad lamentations, that he had been a very Rock, had he not been moved at them; yet he did interrupt him, urmounting her elfe with as much vertue as poible, and told him, that lamentations were only for poor weak pirits, and did not become perons of courage; and therefore he did both himelfe and her wrong, if he ued any uch expreions. Celion, (aid he) where is that brave reolution, which you aid, you had armed your elfe withall, againt all accidents whatoever, except at the change of my affections can any thing ele make you tagger? Conider, that words do no good at all, only make thoe that hear them, think wore both of you and me? For heavens ake, do not tain my honour with that pusillanimity, which hitherto I have with o much pain avoided; and ince there is no better remedy be patient as I am: perhaps the heavens will hereafter contrive things better to our contentment, then we at this time ought to deire For my part, I will avoid the misfortune as much as I can poibly; and if there be no better remedy, we will reolutely fly from it, and leave one another. Thee lat words made him almot deperate, imagining, that her great courage proceeded from the faintnee of her affection. Could I as eaily reolve upon this accident as you, (anwered the Shepheard) I hould think my elfe unworthy of your Love; for a hollow faint affection deerves not uch a happinee. For a reward of all my ervices you bid me reolve to loe you and does implicitely bid me not depair, if I ee you, Another's. Ah Belinde! with what face can you look upon your new friend? with what kinde of heart can you love? and how can you ever carrae him, ince you have promied a thouand times never to love any but me, ince your heart has o often worn never to be any but mine? Well, you do command me to leave you, and to obey you, I will do o; for the lat minute of my life, hall be the firt of my diobedience. I pray the heavens, you may be as happy in your new choice, as I hall be mierable. Live and enjoy all contentment with Ergates; and may you enjoy as much good fortune together, as I have will to do you ervice; may this new affection well with all delights, and lat as long as life, whilt I am ure my mot faithfull affection will be moothered with extream griefs. Belinde did let Celion peak o long together becaue he feared, that if he poke, her tears would do the office of words, and that would argue too little power over her elfe. Oh proud beauty, that had rather be
cenured for want of love than reolution? But at lat, finding her elfe confident enough he aid thus unto him: Celion, you think that all this is an argument of your affection but I think the contrary; for how can you love me, and have uch an ill opinion of me? If you took this opinion up ince this lat accident, it is to be believed, that that affection is not very great which can o uddenly change: If you have not an ill opinion of me, how can you poibly think, that once I did love you, and now do not? Conider how unlikely it is, that Celion, whom I loved above all the world, and whoe humours were ever as agreeable to me, as my own, hould be changed for Ergates? whom I never aw, and whom rather then I will marry, I will marry a Grave. If I be forced, it is by the commands of a Father, whom neither in duty nor honour I ought to diobey. But is it poible you hould o oon forget all thoe vowes and protetations which I have made unto you, never to marry? How comes this change to pae? For if you did love me without marrying me, why cannot you love me till without marrying me? And when I have a Husband, who can forbid me to love a Brother till, with as much affection, as is due unto a Brother? Adieu, adieu, my Celion, live, and love me, who will love you to the lat, whatoever becomes of Belinde: At this word he kied him, which was a greater favour than ever yet he did him, and left him o much out of himelfe, that he could not utter one yllable. When he returned to himelfe, and conidered that love ought to bend unto duty, and that there was not one park of hope left, which could help him out of his griefes, like a man that ravelled in his reolutions, he wandred up and down Woods and unfrequented places, where he did nothing but lament his cruell dyfater; do what all his friends could, they could not perwade him from this errant life.
Thus he lived many daies, in which he moved the very Rocks unto pitty. And to the end, he who was the caue of his miery, might a little reent it, he ent her thee Veres.

lg.head: Celion, upon the Marriage of Belinde and Ergates.

lg.l: 'TIs hard, by Jove, that after o much love,

l.hi: And ervice paid, you hould anothers prove.
Mut I, that erv'd a Prenti hip of orrow,
See you anothers joy and blie to morrow?
And have no other wages for my pains,
But ad remembrance of anothers gains?

lg.l: You once did love me well, 'tis very true:
But Oh, this fatall, Did, does griefe renew.
What am I better for a Love that's pat,
When you are in another's a mesembrac'd?
When you are once anothers halfe, not mine,
Away my oul with orrow needs mut pine.
Had he more merit or more love than I,
Then were I ilenc'd in my miery.
But this is cruell Martyrdome, that he
In one hort day hould finde felicity
Without deert and I denyed am,
Who long had lov'd and merited the ame.
Oh cruell memory of happinee that's pat?
Out of my thoughts, ince hope is quite defac'd:
There is no reaon you hould harbour there,
Where nothing is but horror and depair.

div.p:
Although he eemed by his actions to be quite out of any hope, yet there was a little park left, becaue the Contract of Marriage was not yet pat; and he knew, that ome Matches have been broken off, which were believed to be as currant as this: But when he undertood, that the Writings were Signed and ealed on both ides; Oh! in what a dimal
depair was he then; then did he wring his hands together, cratch his head, tear his hair, beat his tomack; and, in hort, was o tranported and beides himelf, that he was in a hundred minds to go and kill Ergates; and when he was upon the very point of putting it into execution this conideration amidt his fury did come into his minde, that this perhaps would offend Belinde; unto whom, for all his madnee, he writ everall Letters full of love and reproaches which he could hardly read without tears; and, amongt the ret, he ent her this.

body.head: Celion's Letter unto Belinde, in his Tranport.
body.p: WHat, incontant Shepheardes! mut my miery equall my affection? mut I till love you, when I ee you claped in the armes of another? Surely, the gods do punih me for loving you too much, or rather indeed, for not loving you enough, yet I do love you as much as ever any other in the world can: And yet, for gods-ake tell me, why I hould love you, ince you do love a peron whom I do not? And then again? why hould I not love you, ince I did once love you o well? Faith, me thinks I have no reaon to love you, becaue you are ungratefull, your oul is a very tone, and is inenible of any love. But, be you what you will, you are till Belinde; And can Belinde be, and Celion not love her? Should I love you then, or hould I not love you? pray, Shepheardee, be judge your elfe. As for me, my pirit is o much troubled, that I cannot dicern any thing, but that I am the mot afflicted peron in the world.

div.p: At the lower end of this Letter, he writ thee Veres.

lg.l: I never can excue
Such fond incontancy,
As you, it eemes, do ue
In changing Amitie.
To change for better, may
Be called Prudence good;
But for the wore, I ay,
Is madnee undertood.

div.p: When Belinde received this Letter and Veres, he had a good minde to end him one of hers; for hearing what a trange kinde of life he lived, and what language he ued againt her, he was much dipleaed at it, conidering that it gave occaion of dicoure unto uch, as have no ears nor tongues, but to hear and talk of the buinee of others: Her Letter to him was this.

body.head: Belinde's Letter unto Celion.
body.p: IT is impoible I hould any longer indure the injuries, which your trange kinde of life does both your elfe and me. I cannot ay, but that you have reaon to complain againt our fortune; but I mut needs alo ay, that any wie peron cannot, without abundance of blame, play the fool: Though your raptures and tranport does let all the world know, that you are ready to die for the love of me; yet, you do thereby force me to believe, that in reality and truth you do not love me; for if you aid, you would never thus dipleae me. Do you not know, that death it elfe cannot be more horrour unto me, than that opinion which you do raie in every one, of our Amity? Take heed therefore, dear Brother, I intreat you, and by that name conjure you, to have a care how you blemih my honour. If you cannot endure this dyater, without divulging it to the cenorious World, then I conjure you to go away, that my name may no more be brought into quetion. If you do atisfie me in this, then you will make me believe, that it is a uperfluitie, and not defect, of Love, which hath made you erre thus againt me: And this will oblige Belinde to keep in memory her dear Brother, whom, in pite of all thee in upportable injuries, he loves.

div.p:
Although Celion was o tranported, that he was hardly capable of any reaon that his friends could urge unto him; yet his affection did o open his eyes, as he aw, that Belinde
advied him well. So as reolving upon travel, he took order for his departure, and the day before he was to goe, he writ unto his Shepheardee, intimating his intentions of obeying her, and deiring o much favour onely, as to take his leave of her before he went. The Shepheardee, who did really love him though he did foreee that this would but augment his orrows, yet would not deny him his requet, but appointed him to meet her the next morning at the Fountain of Sicamours.

Day did no ooner dawn, but the diconolate Shepheard did drive his Flock towards this Fountaine, where taying by the ide of it, and fixing his eyes upon the coure of this treame, he waited for his Shepheardee, and after a long ilence, ighed out thee Veres.

lg.head: The comparion of a Fountaine unto his Griefs.

lg.l: THis retles River that doth run
Wave after wave as it begun,
Is like my Sorrows, that doe flow
Upon my oul woe after woe.
As like a Vagabond it wanders,
Murmuring it elf into Meanders.
So I mut glide away, and rove,
Murmuring againt my Fate and Love.

div.p:
Whilt this Shepheard was thus talking to himelf, and o troubled at this dyater, as he talked loud enough to be heard a long way off, Belinde, who had not forgot the time and place of appointment, as oon as ever he had rid her elf of her company, hee came unto him, o troubled at the thought of loing him, as he could not o hide her orrows, but ome appeared in her face. Ergates, who was that morning got up betimes to walk, by fortune pied her afarre off, and eeing hee was by her elf, as if he ought for ome cloe place, hee had a minde to ee whither hee intended to goe; and following her at a ditance, he aw he went towards the Fountaine of Sicamours; then looking a little further, hee aw, though it was very early, a Flock feeding: Ergates not being ignorant of all paages betwixt his Shepheardee and Celion, had a conceipt that it was his Flock, and that Belinde was going unto him. Although hee did not upect the Chatity of his Mitris; yet he was eaily induced to beleeve that he did not hate him, imagining that o large a Courthip had never been, if it had been diagreeable unto her. And o, to atisfie his curioity, as oon as he aw her amongt the Trees, o as he could not perceive him he crept nearer, and hid himelf in a buh, from whence he could ee the Shepheardee itting upon the graie eats about the Fountain, and Celion upon his knees before her. Oh how he was tartled as oon as he aw this! Yet becaue he would hear what they aid, he crept cloe under the hedge which was about the Fountain, and o heard every yllable what the Shepheardee aid. What, Celion, aid hee, is this your profeion to pleae mee? Hath this accident more force upon you, than the power which you have given me, hath? Where is your courage Celion, or indeed where is your affection? Have you not out of your love to me urmounted greater difficulties than this? Where is your affection? What is become of thoe reolves which you once profeed? Would you have me beleeve that you have lee affection unto me now, than at that time? Oh Shephead, rather rob mee of my life, than of that good will which you long ince have promied unto mee. How comes it to pae that hitherto I have had as much power over you as I could deire? And why hould I have any lee for the future? Ergates heard alo what Celion anwered. Is it poible, Belinde (aid hee) that you can make any quetion of my affection, or the power you have over me? Can you be o forgetfull of all thoe tetimonies which I have rendred you of it? And mut I urvive that good opinion which you ought to have of mee? Can you, Belinde, tax mee in any of my actions, or ever doubt of my obedience unto all your commands? I pray, before you doe entertain any uch ill opinions of mee, aske Amaranthe what he thinks: Nay, ask Belinde her elf, if ever he impoed any difficulty upon mee, which my affection has not urmounted? Even at this very time, when I ee you are giving your elfe unto another, I am ready to leave you in the arms of one more happy than my elfe, by putting an end to my dyaterous love, and banihing my elfe for ever
from you. Alae, can you ay, that this is any want of affection or will to obey you, ince I doe reent it more dimally than death it elf? Oh Shepheardee, what trange miundertandings are betwixt you and me? For if you doe doubt of my affection becaue I upport this dyater and live, I will tell you that your extreme reolutenes is too certain an argument of your mall affection. But to what purpoe hould I retain any hopes of you, ince another (O fatal word) another mut enjoy you. At this word, the poor Shepheard, without any trength or thought leaned upon Belinde's knee, and there wooned: Whether Belinde was toucht to the heart at this, I leave you to judge, fair Nymph, ince he did love him as well as was poible to love, and eemed onely as if hee did not reent this ad eparation. When he aw him in this wounding fit, and thought there was no witnes but the Sicamours and Fountain, he would not conceale from them what hee had kept o ecret from her all companions: Alas (aid he and held up her hands) Oh ye overaigne powers, either deliver me from this miery or from my life; either remove this cruel dyater, or let this cruel dyater remove me. Then cating her eyes upon Celion, and thou, O too faithfull Shepheard (aid hee) who hadt not been o mierable if thou hadt not loved me, Oh that the heavens would either give thee that contentment which thy affection deerveth, or ele take mee out of the world, ince I am the onely caue that thou enduret thee mieries, which thou doet not deerve. Then pauing a while, he went on; O how hard a thing it is to love well, and be wie both together? I know very well that my Father has good reaon to betow me upon the prudent Shepheard Ergates, becaue the Alliance is convenient for him; but alas, what's that to mee, as long as my love and affection lookes another way. I know Ergates deerves very well, and I could never hope for a more advantageous match than him; but how hould I give my elfe unto him, when as Love hath dipoed of me unto another? Reaon is on my Fathers ide, but Love is on mine: And not a love newly begun, but a love even from my cradle, by a long continuance hath o ininuated it elf into my oul, that he is more my oul than my oul it elf is. Oh heavens! Is it poible to loe my oul and live? Tell me, Belinde, wilt thou not be utterly undone, when it is gone? As he uttered thee words, a river of tears ran from her eyes, and fell upon the hands and cheeks of the Shepheard, who coming to himelfe by little and little, caued the Shepheardes to be ilent, and wipe away her teares from her eyes let hee hould take any notice of them: And changing her countenance and voice, pake thus unto him; Shepheard, I mut needs confee I am very enible of your pain, and did I doubt of your affection, I were the mot ungreateful peron in the world. But, alas, what will my acknowledgements and enibilitie avayl, ince heaven hath ubjected mee unto the will of him who gave mee my being? Would you wih me to requite him with diobedience? But admit I hould uffer my affection to tranport me beyond my duty, Will that, Celion, et us in any more tranquillity? Can it be any contentment unto you if you doe love me, to ee me grieve and mourn away all my dayes? Doe you thinke my diobedience to my Father will not be a terrour to my concience as long as I live? Yes, yes, and more unto me than any other, who have ever diallowed it in others; and I cannot for very hame fall into that inne my elf. Let us arme our elves therefore, O Shepheard, with this reolution, that as hitherto, our loves though extream, could never make us commit any crime againt our duties, o for the future let us never uffer it to force us unto it: Beides, where there is no remedy, complaints are but unprofitable: My Father hath betowed mee upon Ergates, and this gift can never be revoked but by Ergates himelfe: And what mall hopes is there in that? But ince I had dipoed of my affection before my Father, I doe promie you, and vow before all the gods, epecially before them of this place, that in affection I will be yours unto my grave: And neither Father, nor Husband, nor the Tyrant, Duty, hall ever be able to make me break my Vow. Heaven has given me unto a Father, this Father has given my body unto a Husband, and my Duty commands obedience unto my Father; but neither Heaven, nor Father, nor Husband can hinder mee from having a Brother, whom I will love, as I have promied you, whatoever becomes of me. Upon thee words, foreeeing that Celion would break out into complaints and teares, hee did rie up, and kiing his cheeks as hee bade him Adieu, aid thus unto him, I beeech the gods, Shepheard, give you as much contentment in your voyage, as I hall want when you are gone. Celion had neither power to anwer, nor courage to follow her, but lifting up his hands, and looking after her as long as he could ee her, at lat the trees interpoed: Then lifting up his watry eyes unto heaven, after many a deep and ad igh he turned the other way, not caring what became of either Flock, nor any thing he had
left in his Cabin. Ergates, who lay hid all this while under a thick buh, heard all their dicoure, and was more atisfied with the vertue of the fair and wie Belinde, and more admired the trength of her courage, and excellency of her reolution, then is poible to expree. After he had been a long time in a ravihing contemplation of all thee paages, and conidering upon the extream affection that was between thee two Lovers; he thought, that it would be an act unworthy of himelfe, if he hould be the caue of their eparation, and that heaven had brought him o opprotunely to this ad farewell, purpoely to let him ee that errour which unawares he was going to commit. Being then reolved to labour their contentment, as much as poibly he could, he began to follow Celion; but he was already o far gon, that he could not overtake him; but thinking to finde him in his Cabin, he took a little path which conducted to it: but Celion was gone another way, and without peaking to any of his kindred or friends, he wandred up and down like a vagabond many daies, without any deigne, unlee to hun all men, and to gather uch wild fruits, as extream hunger made him gather in the woods. Ergates eeing his deigne frutrated that way, after a day or two's earch after Celion, he came unto Belinde, hoping to undertand from her which way he went, and as good fortune was, he found her in the ame place where he bad adieu unto Celion, being alone by her elfe at the Fountainide, and thinking upon the lat accident in that place, which had drawn into her eyes abundance of tears even from the very root of her heart. Ergates, who aw her afar off, came neerer and neerer as cloely as he could, purpoely to urprie her; and eeing tears trickle from her eyes like two Fountains, this ight moved o much pitty in him, as he wore, not to leep, untill he had given a remedy to her griefs; and to loe no time, tepping to her, he aluted her very kindly. She being-thus urpried, with tears flowing from her eyes, to diemble the matter, faigned, as if he were wahing her elfe at the Fountain, and putting her hand preently into the water, he wahed her face; o as if Ergates had not een her tears before, he could hardly have known he had cryed: That which made him mot admire her vertue was, that preently he put on a countenance of laughter, and turning towards him in a very courteous manner, he aid thus unto him: I had thought, kinde Shepheard to have been alone: but I ee you are come hither upon the ame occaion as I did, I mean, to take the freh air, and wah your hands and eyes at this clear Fountain, and truly it is the bet and clearet Spring in all the Plain. Wie and fair Shepheardee, anwered Ergates, and miled, you have good reaon to ay, that the ame occaion brought us both hither, for it is very true; but in aying, that both of us come hither with intention to wah our elves in this water, I mut needs contradict you, for it was neither of our deignes. As for me, aid the Shepheardee, I hope you wil give me leave to tel you, that none knowes better than my elf with what intention I came. I do agree, aid Ergates, that you do know it better than any other; but for all that, you cannot make me believe, that the ame occaion which you ay brought you hither, was really and truly the occaion. What then, aid he, do you think it was? As he asked this quetion, he put her hands before her face, eeming as if he rubbed her forehead; but indeed, it was to hide that colour, which he perceived came into her face: Which Ergates taking notice of, and being deirous to put her out of that pain, in which he aw he was, did anwer her thus: Fair and dicreet Shepheardee, never think to diemble any longer with me, who knowes as well as you do the very ecrets of your oul; and that you may the better believe me, I will tell you, that you were now thinking upon the lat farewell which you gave unto Celion in this place. Who I? aid he, in a great amazement. Yes, you anwered Ergates, but never be orry that I know it: for I do o much eteem your vertue and merit, as I will do all I can to give you full contentment. I know of all the ervices this Shepheard hath done you, and with how much honour he hath courted you; I know with how much affection he hath continued it this many years and more then that, how you have affected him. The knowledge of all thee things makes me deire death, rather then be any caue of your eparation. Do not imagine, that any matter of jealouie makes me peak thus, for I never had the leat upition of your vertue; epecially ince with thee ears, I heard all the wie dicoure you had with him. Neither think but that I believe, I hall loe my bet fortune in loving you; but the only reaon which reduceth me to give you unto him, whoe you ought to be, Oh wie Belinde, is becaue I will never uffer my contentment to be with your eternall griefe. And, becaue I hould think my elfe culpable both to god and man if I hould be a caue, why o pure and vertuous a Love hould be broke betwixt you; I mut alo tell you, that in thus doing, I deprive my elfe of the bet alliance I ever could have, and hall loe
my own content, for the atisfaction of yours. Me thinks I do in this, but what my duty commands me, and it will be no mall atisfaction unto me, to think, that if Belinde be contented, Ergates is an intrument of it. Only this I hall require, and in it you will oblige me, that ince I am a caue of your reunion, you will be pleaed to take me in, as a Third amongt you two; and that I may have the ame hare in your affection, which you promied unto Celion, when you thought to have married Ergates, o as both of you may receive me as a Brother. I am not able, fair Nymph, (aid Celadon) to expree the joy of this diconolate Shepheardee; nor do I think, that he her elfe did know what language to ue, for the expreion of her thanks; but taking him by the hand, and itting down by the Fountain ide, he told him all the whole tory that had paed betwixt Celion and her elfe, and after a million of thanks, he entreated him to go himelfe to Celion; for the tranport of this ad Shepheard was uch, that he would not return with any ele that hould go and eek him, becaue he would never believe this tory, if he heard it from any other. Ergates, who would by all means finih the good work he had begun, reolved to go the next morning with Diamis, Celion's Brother, promiing not to return, untill he had found him, and brought him back.

Being thus gone, and taken the firt way their feet light upon, they wandred up and down in quet of Celion; and long had they looked in vain, if he himelfe, tranported with fury, had not returned into Forrets, with a deigne to kill Ergates, and with the ame word, reach the heart of Belinde, not being able to live, and let another enjoy her. In this rage he et forward; and becaue he fed upon nothing but roots and herbs which he found in the high way, he was grown o weak, that he could hardly walk; and had not his rage upported him, he would have fallen down: needs therefore mut he ret himelfe very oft, epecially in the heat of the day. Being thus weak and weary, he at down under ome hady Trees, cloe by a fountain; and after he had a while reented his affliction, he fell aleep. Fortune, that was now weary with afflicting him had a minde, it eemes, to make him compleatly happy, and directed Ergates and Diamis jut to the ame place, and by chance Diamis walked firt. As oon as he aw his Brother he knew him, and looking behinde him, told Ergates, who being much rejoyced at it, would needs go and embrace him but Diamis would not uffer him, aying, I beeech you, Ergates, do not acquaint my Brother too uddenly with this newes, let it hould caue his death by exceive joy; therefore I conceive it better, to let me acquaint him with it by little and little: and becaue perhaps he will not believe me, you may come after, and confirm him in what I aid. Ergates thinking this advice to be good, he went behinde ome Trees, where he could not be een, and Diamis went forward It may be aid, he was inpired with ome good pirit; for had Celion een Ergates firt, perhaps his deperate rage might have proved fatall to him. As oon as Diamis came up, his Brother waked, and began to fall into his accutomed complaints; and, after he had aluted him, he aid thus: I thank the gods, Brother, that I have o happily found you, to deliver a meage which Belinde hath ent unto you. Belinde, (aid he preently) What! can he have any memory of me, now he is in the armes of Ergates? Ergates, aid Diamis, has none of Belinde in his armes; and I hope, if you have any reolution, never hall. Do you doubt, Brother, aid Celion, that my reolution will fail me upon uch an occaion? I would ay, Prudence, replied Diamis. I fear no prudence will erve, anwered Celion, to alter that coure which Detiny hath reolved upon. Detiny, aid Diamis, is not o much your enemy as you do imagine, nor are your affairs upon uch bad termes as you do think them: for, Ergates has refued Belinde. How, aid Celion, Ergates refued Belinde? It is mot certain, (aid Diamis) and that you may the more believe it, Ergates himelfe will tell you as much. Celion hearing this newes, was o amazed, that he tood till, and could not anwer of a long time; but at lat, recollecting himelfe, he aid thus unto him: Surely, Brother, you mock me. No, aid Diamis, I do wear by the great Theatates, Heius, and Thamaris, and by all that is acred unto us, that I tell you truth, and that ere long you hall hear it from Ergates himelfe. Then Celion lifting up his hands and eyes unto heaven, Oh gods, aid he, unto what happy end have you reerved me? Then his Brother, to interrupt him, aid thus: Never talk any more, Brother, of miery and death, but of joy and contentment; and above all, prepare your elfe to thank Ergates, for the favour he hath done you, for I ee him coming towards us. At this word, Celion roe up, and eeing him neer, he ran to embrace him, with as much good will, as a little before he intended ill: But, when he heard the truth of the whole buinee, he fell upon his knees before Ergates, and would have kied his feet. I
hall omit all their dicoure, Fair Nymph (aid Celadon), and onely tel you, that Ergates when he was returned, gave Belinde unto him, and with the conent of him and her father, he married her; only, deiring both Celion and Belinde to accept of him as a third in their incere affection, he devoted himelf intirely unto them, and would never marry.

This, fair and wie Nymph, aid Celadon, is their Fortune, which was extreamly happy unto them all three, as long as the gods permitted them to live together; for a little while after a Sonne was born unto them, whom they named Ergates, becaue of the affection which they bore unto the kind Ergates, and to preerve him longer in their memory: But it hapned that in the cruel Plunder and Ravage which ome trangers committed in the Provinces of the Sequanois, Viennois, and Seguntians, this little childe was lot, and doubtles dyed for want. A few years after they had a Daughter which was called Diana. But neither Celion nor Ergates, had much joy of this childe, becaue they both dyed preently after in one day. And this Diana, of whom I peak, is hee who is held amongt us for one of the fairet and wiet Shepheardees in all Forrets.

Celadon was thus relating unto the Nymph the Hitory of Celion and Belinde, whilt Leonide and Galathea were dicouring upon the news which Flurial brought; for as oon as the Nymph aw Leonide, he took her aide, and told her, that he would not have Flurial ee Celadon; for, aid he, he is o much a creature of Lindamors, as he will tell him all hee ees: Keep him therefore in dicoure, till I have read my Letters, and when I have done, I wil acquaint you what news. Upon this, the Nymph went out of the chamber, and carried Flurial with her: Then, after ome other talk, Well Flurial, aid hee, what news dot thou bring unto thy Lady? Very good, anwered he, and uch as both you and he will be glad to hear; for Clideman is well, and Lindamor has done uch wonders in a Battle, that Merovia and Childericke doe eteem him as his virtue deerves: But here is a young man with me that would peak with Silvia, and is denyed entrance by the Guards, hee can relate all particulars better than I; for hee came from thence, and I but from my Aunts, where one of Lindamors men brought thee Letters, and tayes for an anwer. Dot thou not know, aid Leonida, what his buines is with Silvia? No, anwered he, he would never make me of his counel. He mut enter, aid the Nymph; o going unto the doore, he remembred that he had een him with Ligdamon, and uppoing her companion deired the buinee hould be ecret, hee would not ask him any quetions, eeming as if hee knew him not; onely told him he would acquaint Silvia. Afterwards, drawing Flurial aide. D • t thou know, Flurial (aid he unto him) the misfortune that is faln upon Lindamor? No, aid hee, wee all think him to be extreamly happy; for hee has got o much Glory, that Amais at his return cannot deny him Galathea. Oh Flurial aid he, didt thou know how all things goe here, thou wouldet confee, that the voyage of our Friend is to him a voyage of death, and I beleeve when he returns he will dye of grief Oh my good God aid Flurial, what's the matter? It is as I tell thee, Flurial, aid he, and there is no remedy againt it unlee it comes from thee. From me, aid he, if that will doe, be confident there is nothing in the world which I will not doe. Then, aid the Nymph, bee ure thou beet ecret; I will tell thee more anone, but now I mut ee what the poor abent man has writ unto me. He ent them, aid Flurial, by a youngman unto my Aunts, and he hath ent me hither with them, and here is one directed unto you. She opened it, and found thee words.

body.head: Lindamor's Letter unto Leonida.
body.p: ALthough I find that ditance and abence has but little power upon my oul, yet I am afraid it hath too much upon yours, whom I adore. My Faith bids me hope wel, but my Fortune menaces me with the contrary. However, the aurance that I have in my prudent Confident, makes me live in les fear: Remember therefore, that you doe not deceive the hopes I have in you, nor fail the asurance which I have of your friendhip.

div.p:
Well, aid the Nymph; Flurial, I would have thee goe this night to the neeret Lodging thou cant find, and return to me in the morning betimes; for then I will acquaint thee with a tory that hall make thee wonder. Then he called for the young man that would peak with Silvia, and carried him as far as Galathea's Anti-chamber, where bidding him to tay, he entered, and told the Nymph what he had done with Flurial. Here Leonide,
aid hee, pray read this Letter which Lindamor hath written unto me: Which hee did, and found thee words.

body.head: Lindamor's Letter unto Galathea.
body.p: NEither the length of my voyage, nor the horrours of VVar, no nor all the beauties of Gaule, are able to make the memory of your mot faithfull ervant, for get you, Madam, one minute. So as not being able to deny my affection the curioity of knowing how my mot adored Lady doth; after I had kised your feet a thouand times, I doe preent unto you, all the good fortune which Armes have favoured me withall, and lay them at your feet, as a Divinity unto whom I owe them. If you will but be pleaed to accept of them, I hal think myelf more honoured thereby, than by all that Renown which Fame can trumpet in my praie.

div.p:
I care not a traw, aid Galathea, neither for him nor his victories: He would oblige me much more if he would forget me. For Gods ake, Madam, aid Leonide, do not ay o; did you but know what a high eteem both Merovia and Childerick have of him, I cannot thinke but you would et a higher value upon him than upon this Shepheard: A Shepheard that does not love you, but even before your face, ighs for a Shepheardee who has his heart. You will ay, perhaps, that all this I ay is aid out of ome cunning Artifice. It is very true, anwered Galathea. Well Madam, anwered he, you may think and ay what you pleae, but I doe wear unto you by all that's acred, that what I told you concerning the Impotor Climanthes, and the crafty Polemas, is mot true. Leonide (aid Galathea) you doe but loe your time: I am fully reolved what to doe, and therefore talke no more. I hall do, Madam (aid Leonide) as you command me, if you will give me but leave to ask you one quetion, and it is this, What do you intend to do with this Shepheard? I will have him love me, anwered he. How, I beeech you, do you think this love will end, aid Leonide?. How eager you are, aid Galathea, to know future events? Let him but once love me, and we will afterwards ee how it will end. Although we cannot know future events, aid Leonide, yet every one does propoe unto themelves an end at which they aym. I have no other end, aid Galathea, but that of Love, nor aym at any thing ele, but that he hould love me. That certainly is all that you can aim at, replyed Leonide; for there is no likelyhood you hould ever marry him; and if you hould not marry him, what then will become of your honour? Your honour, I ay, which you have ever been o tender of, will be extreamly endangered. This new affection cannot urely o blinde you, but you mut needs ee what wrong you do yourelf, to have a man your Lover, whom you would not have your Husband. And you, Leonide, aid he you that make uch a cruple of it, have you any deire to marry him? I? Madam, anwered he, I beeech you; do you think me o low in my own thoughts, as to look upon uch a illy fellow as he? But if ever there were a man that was within the compas of cauing me to love, the repect I owed you, made me retreat if I did love him. When? aid Galathea. Do you remember Madam, anwered Leonida, when you commanded me to make no more account of Polemas? Oh, very well remembred to no purpoe, aid Galathea; But did you never love Celadon? Madam, anwered he, I doe not love Celadon any otherwie than as a Brother; and in that he aid true; for ince the Shepheard and he had the lat dicoure, he reolved to change her love into friendhip. Well Leonide, aid the Nymph, let's leave this dicoure both of him and Lindamor, for we have had too much of it. But what anwer, aid he, will you return to Lindamor? Nothing, aid he, but ilence. Mut hee then whom he ent hither, aid he, return without any anwer? Let him take his own coure, aid Galathea. As for me, I am fully reolved, that neither for his ake, nor any others, will I make myelf mierable. Is it not neceary then aid Leonide, that Flurial comeback? No, aid he. Leonide then told her that there was a young man who deired to peak with Silvia, and that hee thought it was from Ligdamon, becaue he would deliver his Meage unto none but Silvia herelf. Then tell him where he is, aid the Nymph; we need but draw the Curtains of Celadons Bed; for I doe aure my elfe he will bee glad to hear what Ligdamon hath writ, ince I beleeve you have already acquainted him with their love. 'Tis very true, aid Leonide but Silvia is of uch a haughty pirit, that I am confident he will be much offended, if this Meenger hould peake unto her before Celadon. Let it urprie her, aid
Galathea, and go you before to bid the Shepheard, that he peak not, and draw the Curtains, whilt I conduct the meenger into the Chamber.
