Thus thee Nymphs went out, and Galathea, remembring he had een this man with Ligdamon, asked, From whence he came, and how his Mater did; alo, what newes he brought from him? I come, Madam aid he, from Merovea's Army; and as for any thing from my Mater, I have it in my Commiion to tell it only unto Silvia. You are very cloe it eemes, aid Galathea; But do you think, that I will permit you to ay any thing unto my Nymphs, unknown to me? Madam, aid he, I will deliver my meage before you, if you pleae, for I had it o in command epecially before Leonida. Come then, aid the Nymph: And o they came into Celadon's Chamber, where Leonida had before et all things in order, not acquainting Silvia with it, who, at firt, was atonihed; but afterwards, eeing Galathea with the young man, he preently imagined, that it was to keep Celadon from being een. Silvia's urprie was very great, when he aw Egides, for o was the young man called, whom he knew preently for though he was not down-right in love with Ligdamon, yet was he not exempted from much good-will unto him; he did imagine, that he brought ome newes from him, yet would not ask him. But Galathea addreing herelfe to the man: If you will deliver your meage unto Silvia, aid he, here you may, ince he and Leonida are both here. Madam, aid Egides, addreing unto Silvia, Ligdamon my Mater, and the mot faithfull of all the Servants which your merits acquired, hath commanded me to acquaint you with the tate of his fortune deiring nothing ele from heaven in recompence of his fidelity, but that your heart might be moved unto ome parks of pitty, though Love could never come neer the Ice of it. What, aid Galathea, and interrupted him, you peak, as if he had made his Will: How does he? Madam, aid the man, addreing unto Galathea, I hall tell you, if you will pleae to give me leave: Then addreing himelfe unto Silvia, he began thus.

div.head: The Hitory of Ligdamon.
div.p: AFter Ligdamon had taken his leave of you, he departed with Lindamor, and promied to himelfe, to obtain that by this voyage, which his ervices could not do at home; hoping either o to ignalize his nameby his acts of valour, that he might become agreeable unto you; or ele in dying, to make you grieve for his loe. In this deigne, they came into the Army of Merovea, a Prince adorned with all Perfections requiite in a Conquerour; and came o opportunely, as the Battle was to be fought the eventh day after; o as all the young Cavalrie had no other cares, but to burnih up their Armes, and get their hores in good order. But it is not of them I am to peak, therefore paing all them over in ilence, only what relates unto Ligdamon, give me therefore leave to tell you, that the aigned day of Battle being come, the two Armies drew out of their Camps, and in ight of each other ranked themelves into Battalia. Here a Squadron of Hore, there a Battalion of Foot; here the Drums, there the Trumpets; on one ide the neighing of Hores, on the other ide the voices of men, did make uch a noie, as if B • llona had roared in the field, and diplayed her mot horrid Banners. As for me, I never having been before in the like ervice, I was o deaned with the noie, and dazled with the hining of Armes, that the truth is, I knew not where I was; yet my reolution ever was, not to abandon my Mater, though nothing was to be een but Engines of Death. But, all this was nothing, compared to that horrible confuion, when all thee Squadrons met, and when the word of Combat was given.

The Cavalrie and Infantry: Men, Armes, Hores, and Engines, made a mot affrighting thunder. After we had received everall clouds of Arrowes, I cannot tell you, how I came to be with my Mater in the midt of his enemies, where I did nothing but admire the miracles of his word. I wear, fair Nymph, one wonder makes me forget another, o many did Ligdamon perform; and uch was his valour, that Merovea deired to know his name, having oberved him above all the ret of the Cavaliers. The firt Squadron was already victorious, and ours rallied to fall upon the econd, when the Enemy with his whole Body marched upon them, and o uddenly, that Merovea could not relieve them in time. And certainly, if he had found a Captain lee experienced than this, he had effected his deigne: But this great Souldier, imagining the depair of his Adverary, ent preently three freh Squadrons, two, unto the two wings, and the third in the arrear of the
firt; and o well, as they utained a great part of the firt hock; yet we, who were advanced, were much oppreed with numbers. At the ame time, both Bodies of Infantry being joyned, that of Merovea had the better; and look, how much we gained ground upon the Hore, o much the Infantry of the Enemy lot. So it was, that upon the enemies firt Charge, many of our men were troden down, beides thoe whom Arrowes had at the firt un-Hored; amongt the ret, Clidaman was one, his Hore being killed under him with an Arrow. Ligdamon, who ever had an eye upon him, aoon as he aw him upon the ground, did ride up, and lay about him o couragiouly, that he made a Wall of dead bodies about Clidaman, who, in the mean time, had leaure to recover himelfe from under his Hore, and who doubtlee, without my Maters help and valour, had been troden to pieces; for Ligdamon lighted from his Hore, and et Clidaman on the back of him, whilt he himelfe was o wounded and preed with enemies, that he could not get upon that Hore which I led. Now was our party forced to recoile, wanting the invincible Arme of my Mater; and we were in uch a deperate condition, and we were amidt o many enemies, as there was no hopes of any life. However, Ligdamon would never render himelfe; and though he was wounded and weary, yet there was not an enemy, eeing what deadly blowes came from his Arme, that was o bold as to lay hold of him: At the lat, five or ix came galloping up with all their fury, and he having run his word into the firt Hore, it broke at the very bilt, and the hore, being run through the heart, fell upon him: I ran to help him up, but halfe a core more that was fallen upon him, hindred me. Thus both of us halfe dead, were carried away; and the accident was the more dylaterous, becaue almot at the very ame time, our Party recovered what they had lot, by the reliefe which Childerick brought from the Rear guard, and were Maters of the Field, burning all the enemies Hutts, mot part of them being taken or killed. As for us, we were carried unto their principall City, called Rhotomages, where my Mater was no ooner arrived, but many came to viit him; ome aid, they were his Coens others his friends, though he knew not one of them: For my part, I knew neither what to ay nor think of it, when I aw o many trangers carraing, and making o very much of him: yet much more was our amazement, when a Lady, well attended, came to viit him, aying, he was her Son, with o many demontrations of affection, as he was almot out of himelfe; and much more, when he aid, Oh Lydias my Child, how great are both my joyes and fears, at the ight of you in this place? Alas! how am I afraid to ee you in this cruell Town, ince your enemy Arontes, is dead of thoe wounds which you gave him, and ince you are condemned to death by Jutice? For my part, I know no other way but to ranome you preently, and hide you, till you be able to get away. Ligdamon was extreamly amazed at all this, and knew that he was taken for ome other; but he could not anwer her, becaue at the very ame intant, he who took him, came into the Chamber, with two Officers of the Town, to take a lit of the names and qualities of the Prioners; for many being taken they intended to exchange them. The poor Lady was much affrighted, thinking they came to eize upon him, and carry him to Prion; and hearing them ask his name, he told them her elfe but my Mater aid, his name was Ligdamon, a Seguian: She had an opinion, that he would diemble his name; and to remove all upicion, went preently to her houe, with a reolution to ranome him before he was known. The truth was my Mater did o reemble Lydias, that every one did take him for the ame. This Lydias was a young Gallant of that Country, and being in love with a great Beauty, had fought with Arontes, his Rivall, and killed him, yet had time enough to ecape the hands of Jutice; but, after the death of Arontes, was o proecuted by his friends, that Lydias, though abent, was condemned to death. Ligdamon was o wounded that he could not think of thee things. I foreeeing what danger might enure, till preed the Mother to ranome him, which he did, yet not o ecretly, but the Enemies of Lydias were acquainted with it; o as the very ame day that this good Lady paid the ranome, and carried him to her houe, the Officers of Jutice came and carried him to Prion, ay what Ligdamon could. Thus being by every one taken for Lydias, he was in very great danger: but much more the next morning when he was examined upon uch interrogatories, of which he was o ignorant, that he knew not what to anwer. However, the Judges perited in their former judgment, and confirmed it, giving him no longer term than the healing of his wounds. The noie was preently all about the Town, that Lydias was a Prioner, and condemned to die, not only as a Murderer, but as a Rebell, being taken in Armes for the Franks; and therefore, as the cutome of that time and place was, for uch an offence, he was to be put into a Den
of Lions; nothing ele was talked of through all the Town: At lat, it came to my ears; upon which I diguied my elfe, and with the help of that good Lady, who had paid his ranome, I came to Paris, unto Merovea and Childerick, whom I acquainted with the accident at which they were much atonihed, thinking it almot impoible, two perons hould reemble o much as to finde no difference; but to prevent any danger, they preently ent two Heraulds of Armes, to acquaint the enemy with their errour. But all this conduced to no purpoe, but confirmed them in their opinion, and rather hated the execution of the Sentence than otherwie. The wounds of Ligdamon were now healed, o as they pronounced the Sentence, That he hould die by Lions, which hould be his Executioners; yet, being of a noble Family, they would do him o much favour, as to let him wear his Sword and Dagger, as Armes belonging to a Cavalier; with which, if he had o much courage, he might defend himelfe, or at leat, generouly revenge his death. At that time they returned unto Merovea, that thus they alwaies punihed their own Countrymen, who were Traitors unto their Country. Thus ee poor Ligdamon in mot pittifull danger; yet, his Courage that never fainted, unlee in matters of Love, eeing there was no other remedy, reolved to defend himelfe as well as he could. Lydias being one of the bet Families of the Neutrians, almot all the Citty aembled to behold this Spectacle. When he was ready to be put into this cloe horrour, his only requet was, that he might fight with thee Lions one after another. The people hearing this jut demand, did approve of it by their acclamations and clapping of hands, in pite of the proecutors. Now, ee Ligdamon alone in a great Court, and the Lions eeing their prey through ome Bars, did roar o horridly, as would have chilled the blood of any, but him; who taking notice which dore firt opened, let he hould be urpried, he aw a huge hungry Lion come out, who at the firt, pawing with his foot upon the ground, and triking himelfe with his taile, he began to tretch forth his paw, and open his clawes, as if he would hew him what death he hould die. Ligdamon eeing no afety but in his own valour, asoon as ever he aw him begin to walk, he darted his Dagger o dexterouly to the Lions breat, as the point of it pierced his heart, and the beat fell dead immediately. Great was the hout of the people! for every one oberving his courageous behaviour, his valour and dexterity, they did wih him well in their very hearts. But he, that knew the everity of the Judges would not be thus atisfied, he ran preently to take his Dagger again, which he had no ooner got into his hand, but another Lion, no lee furious then the firt, came running furiouly upon him, o as Ligdamon was like to be urpried, but he tepped a little aide out of this raging Animal's full carrier, and cut him over the eyes; upon which, the furious beat turned o hort upon him, that Ligdamon tepping back to fetch another blow, he fell; but o, that in falling, the Lion coming over him, he ran him into the belly, and o mortally, as he fell dead as oon as the firt did. Whilt Ligdamon was thus fighting for his life, a Lady, one of the fairet of all the Neutrians, kneeled down before the Judges, beeeching them to tay Execution untill he had poken unto them; her name was Amerina, the very ame for whom Lydias had killed Arontes, and who, though much ahamed, yet, pake thus unto the Judges: Sirs, Ingratitude is a in as great as Treaon, and I deerve a punihment as great as his, did I not ave his life, as he formerly ventured his to ave my honour. Therefore I do preent my elf before you, and claim the Priviledge, which is, That any condemned Peron hall be delivered, if any Virgin do come and ask him for her Husband: Aoon as I heard of your judgment, I came with as much hate as I could, to demand him; and ince I am now come yet in the nick of time, I hope you will not deny me jutice, and him to be my Husband. The people hearing this, houted for joy, and cryed, Favour, Favour; and though the enemies of Lydias did urge the contrary, yet it was concluded, that the Priviledge hould be oberved: But alas! Ligdamon came out of one danger, to enter into another, and greater; for being brought before the Judges, they let him undertand the cutom of the Country, which was uch, That any man who was condemned for any crime, hould be releaed from execution of Jutice, if any Virgin came and demanded him for her husband: o as if he would marry Amerina, he hould be releaed to live with her. Ligdamon, who did not know her was extreamly put to it for an anwer: Yet eeing no other remedy to avoid the danger wherein he was, he promied that he would, hoping that time would finde out ome expedient to get out of this Labyrinth. Amerina, who knew that Lydias alwaies loved her, was not a little amued to ee him o faint & cold in the buinee; yet thinking that the terror of the danger in which he was had made him o, he pittyed him the more, and carried him into the houe of Lydias Mother, who procured
this Marriage, knowing there was no other way to ave her Sons life, which caued her to pree on this Marriage as oon as it was poible, thinking that it would the more pleae her Sonne, whom he knew was in love with Amerina. But, alas, all this was to haten his death. Oh my dear Mater, When I think upon thy lat words which you pake unto me, I cannot chue but wonder, how it is poible I hould live. All things being ready for the Marriage, and the time of Ceremony being come, he took me aide, and aid thus unto me; Oh Egides, my friend, Didt thou ever ee uch a peece of Fortune as this, that they would make me beleeve I am not my elf? Sir, aid I unto unto him, me-thinks your fortune is not bad; Amerina is fair and rich, every one ayes her Parents are of the bet Families in all the Country, What can you deire more? Oh Egides, aid he, thou talket merrily; but didt thou know the condition I am in, thou wouldt pitty me: I know thy fidelity, and therefore I trut and conjure thee to carry this Letter unto the fair Silvia, and tell her all thou hat een: And tell her further, that I did never love any but her, nor will I ever love any other: Upon thee words hee gave mee this Letter, which I have carefully kept ever ince that morning when he went unto the Temple, and when he called me, making me wear again, that I would the next day come in all hate unto you; Then came a Meenger to conduct him to the Nuptial Chariot, in which Amerina already was, with one of her Uncles, whom hee honoured as her Father. Shee fate in the middle betwixt Ligdamon and Carites (o was her Uncle called). Before the Chariot went all their own Family, and after it followed their Kindred, Friends, and Allies. In this Triumph went they unto the Temple, and when they came there, they were led up to the Altar of Hymen, upon which five Torches were lighted; on the right ide of Hymen was placed Jupiter and Juno, on the left ide Venus and Diana: As for Hymen, he was crowned with Flowers and weet Marjerome, held in his right hand a Torch, and in his left, a Vail, of the ame colour of Amarine's. When they came firt into the Temple, the Mother of Lydias and Amarine lighted their Torches. Then the chiefe Druide comming unto them, addreed his peech unto my Mater, and asked him this quetion: Lydias, will you have Amarine to be the Mother of your Family? It was long before Ligdamon would peak; but at lat, he was forced to ay, Yes. Then the Druide turning towards her: And you Amarina, Will you have Lydias for the Father of your Family? And he anwering, Yes, he then taking their hands, and putting them together, he aid: And I, in the teed of the great gods, do give you one unto another; for ever after, eat your bread together. And then taking the Barley-cake, my Mater broke it, and, according to the cutome, they did eat of it together. Now there reted no more to be done to compleat the Ceremony, but to take the Wine and drink: Then he turned towards me, and aid: I do conjure you, Friend, as the bet ervice you ever did me, to give me the Cup: Which I did, and alas, too oon. Aoon as he had it in his hand, he aid in a loud voice: O ye great gods, who know that I am not Lydias, do not revenge my death upon this fair Lady, whoe errour, in taking me for ome other, more happy than my elfe, hath redeemed me from one kinde of death, to give me unto another: Upon this word, he drank up all that was in the Cup; which was contrary to the Cutome, for the Husband hould have drunk one halfe, and the Wife the other: Upon which, he miled, and aid unto him: It eemes, Lydias, you have forgot the Cutome, for you hould have left me a part. God forbid, wie Amarina, aid he, for it is poyon, which I have choen to finih my life withall, rather then fail in my promie to you, and in my affection which I owe unto the fair Silvia. Oh my god, aid he is this poible? And then thinking that he was Lydias, but that during his abence, he had changed his minde, and not deiring to live without him, he ran with the Cup in her hand to the Bottle, where the poyoned wine was, and before Ligdamon was aware, had drunk it off; for the Apothecary, whom Ligdamon had prepared had filled the Bottle full: Afterwards returning to him, he aid; You cruell man, had rather have death then me, and I, rather then be without you. Oh Amerina, aid Ligdamon, I confee, that I had offended, if I had been him you took me for: but, believe me, now I am upon my lat breath, I am not Lydias, but Ligdamon, and time will dicover the error: However, I chooe death, rather then break my promie made unto the fair Silvia, unto whom I have conecrated my life, ince I am not able to atisfy both. Then he continued: Oh fairet Silvia accept of this good will I now offer unto thee, and of all my actions, let this lat be bet received, ince it is imprinted with the noble character of Fidelity. The Poyon now began to work by degrees upon the pirits of thee two new-marryed perons, o as he could hardly breathe, when turning his head towards me, he aid, Go, go, my friend, go,
and do thy buinee, relate what thou hat een, and that death is more welcome unto me than life, which would have tained that Fidelity, which I have vowed unto the fair Silvia. Silvia was the lat word he ever pake, for as he uttered it, his Soul departed out of his Body into the Elizian fields, where if ever any Lover was happy, it is he, in expectation of eeing you there with him. Is it then certainly true, (aid Silvia) that Ligdamon is dead? Alas! too true, anwered he. Oh ye gods! cryed out Silvia. All he was able to do, was, to lie down upon the bed, for her heart quite failed her; where after he had been awhile, he called for Leonida, to take Ligdamon's Letter, and to tell Egides, that he would have him erve her. Thus Egides with-drew, with eyes wimming in tears. Now did Love hew his power; for this Nymph, who never much loved Ligdamon alive, now he heard of his death, he expreed as much griefe, as was poible for any Lover. Upon this occaion, Galathea talking unto Celadon, he aid, That hereafter he would think it impoible, that a woman hould never in her life love any one; for, aid he, this Nymph hath been too cruell unto all thoe that loved her, that ome have dyed for very griefe, others have been banihed out of her ight by depair; and this very man, whom he now laments for, he did heretofore drive into uch extremity, that but for Leonida, he had then dyed alo o as I durt have worn, Love would have ooner harboured in the mot nowie part of the Alps, than in her heart; and yet you may ee, unto what he is reduced now. Do not think this to be Love, Madam, aid Celadon, but rather Pitty; for, he had been the hardet piece of Marble that ever was, had he not been extreamly perplexed at this report. For my part I think Ligdamon more happy, than if he were alive, ince he loved this Nymph o extreamly, and he was o hard hearted unto him: For what greater happinee can be, then to be at the end of miery, and to enter into felicity? How joyed would he be, to ee Silvia mourn for him, and et a value upon his affection? No, no, Madam, Ligdamon is not to be mourned for o much, as Silvia; for you hall ee, that all her minde and fancy will run upon Ligdamon: The dicoure, the garb, the affection, the valour, and briefly, every action of this Lover, will, in revenge of her cruelty, continually torment her minde, and will in revenge, be the Executioner of Love's jutice. This dicoure was poken o loud, and o neer Silvia, that he heard it all, and it did but increae her griefe: o as he went out of this Chamber into her own, where he could no longer retrain her tears: for, hutting the dore after her, and deiring Leonida to leave her, he threw her elfe upon the bed, where, with watry eyes, and folded armes, he called to minde all the former life of Ligdamon, how great his love was, how patiently he endured all her rigour, with what dicretion he erved her, how contant he was in his love, and in the end, aid he, all this is now encloed in a little piece of earth. Then calling to minde her own demeanor, her dicoures, her farewells, her impatiencies, and a thouand more particulars, he was forced to ay, Oh fatall memory, let the ahes of my dear Ligdamon ret in peace; if thou dot torment me thus, I know he will not be contented with it. At lat, after he had been a while mute; Well, aid he, it is reolved upon, be my life long or hort, as it hall pleae the Fates, I will never ceae loving my dear Ligdamon, nor forget his affection or vertues. Galathea in the mean while opened Ligdamon's Letter, which was in Leonida's hands, and found in it thee words.

body.head: Ligdamon's Letter unto Silvia.
body.p: IF you are offended at my over-boldnee in loving you, my death will revenge your Quarell: If you tood neutrall and indifferent, I am confident, this lat act of affection will have uch an operation upon your oul, as will gain me ome more eteem; which if it do, I hall cherih my reemblance of Lydias more, then my own birth; ince by the one, I was but a trouble, and by the other, acceptable unto you.

div.p: Thee are the great revenges of Love, aid Celadon: And I do remember another, though upon another ubject, how a Shepheard writ this Epitaph upon a jealous Husband,

lg.head: An EPITAPH. Upon a Jealous Husband.

l.hi: HEre, in this durty Dungeon, lies

lg.l: One of god Cupid's enemies.

l.hi: The wages of his crime was death,
Who troubled all, whilt he had breath.
This Tyrant ever made a Theft
Of Love, which ought to be a gift.

lg.l: This was the man, who, Argos ey'd,

l.hi: More faults than ever was, epi'd.

lg.l: And out of his depraved Minde,
Still look'd for what he would not finde.
But Love at lat did top his breath,
And in revenge did end him death.
Love injur'd, though he make no hate,
Will be revenged yet at lat.

div.p: It is mot true, anwered Galathea, Love never uffers an offence committed againt him, to ecape unpunihed; and hence it is, we ee o many trange accidents in all human actions. And therefore Celadon, I wonder that you po • not tremble for feare, and every moment expect an Arrow of revenge from that god. Why hould I fear, aid the Shepheard, ince it is I that am the offended party? Ah Celadon, aid the Nymph, were all things equally ballanced, you would finde your offences committed much greater, then thoe you have received. This is the very height of miery, aid Celadon, that a peron afflicted hould be thought happy, and when his pain is palpable, yet not to be pittied. But I pray tell me, Shepheard, aid the Nymph, does not Ingratitude, of all crimes and offences that are accounted great, hold the firt place? Doubtlee it does, anwered the Shepheard. If it do, aid Galathea, how can you clear your elfe, ince for all the love and affection I have hewed unto you, I receive nothing but a hollow faintnee and didain from you? This for all; conidering what I am, and conidering what you are, I cannot conceive, how I have any waies offended againt Love, that he hould punih me with o much rigour. Celadon was extreamly orry for beginning this dicoure; but ince it was already on foot, he reolved to clear himelfe, and therefore aid thus unto her: Madam, I know not how to give an anwer unto your peeches, but by bluhes; yet Love, which makes you peak, contraines me to anwer. That which you call ingratitude in me, I mut call Duty; and if you hall pleae to ask me my reaon, I hall give it. What reaon can you give, aid Galathea, unlee that you do love another, and that your faith is obliged to her? But let me tell you, that the Law of Nature is before all others, and that Law commands us, to eek and prefer our own good before anothers: And can you deire a greater good than my affection? Whom have you in the Country like me, who can do as I can for you? Thee are meer mockeries, Celadon, to init o much upon thee follies of Fidelity and Contancy; termes invented only by old women and ugly to keep uch within their Pales, as their faces has et at liberty. They ay, all the Vertues are chained together; Contancy cannot be without Prudence: And can it be any Prudence to let go a certain good, only to avoid the bare name and title of Incontant? Madam, (anwered Celadon) Prudence never taught us to thrive by any hamefull means; nor did the Lawes of Nature ever command us to build, before we have a ure foundation. Is there any thing more dihonet and hamefull, than not to oberve and be punctuall in promies? Is there any thing fuller of levity, than a Minde, that like a Bee, flying from flower to flower, is till in quet of new weetnee? If Fidelity be once lot, Madam, what ure foundation can I have in your affection? Since you follow the Law which you peak of, I hall remain no longer in this happinee, then you tay in a place, where there is no Man, but my elfe.

The Nymph and the Shepheard dicoured thus, whilt Leonida went into her Chamber, to dipatch a Letter unto Lindamor, which was, to invite him home with all hate,
otherwie to depair for ever: And the next morning, when Flurial came again, after he had given him her Letter, he aid thus unto him: Go Flurial, let thy love to Lindamor be een in thy hate; for delay may be no lee then death unto him. Go, or rather, flie; bid him return with all peed, and in his return, go traight to the houe of Adamas, whom I have gain'd to him; there he hall finde the mot notable treachery in Love that ever was invented; but if it be poible, let him come unknown. Thus Flurial departed, o deirous to erve Lindamor, that he would not go unto his Aunts, becaue he would loe no time. Thus three or foure daies paed on, during which time, Celadon began to long for the return of the Druide, in hopes, that when he came, he hould then get out of this place; and to make the time eem lee tedious, he went ometimes into the Garden, and ometimes into the Woods; but never without the company of one of the Nymphs, and often all three: Silvia's humour pleaed him bet, as mot ympathizing with his own, and therefore he courted her as much as he could.

It hapned one day, being all four together, that they paed by the Grotto of Damon and Fortune; and becaue the entrance eemed to be very fair, and made with much art, the Shepheard asked, what it was? To whom Gaelathea anwered, Will you ee, Shepheard, one of the greatet proofes of Love's power, that ever was? What is that, aid the Shepheard? It is, aid the Nymph, the Loves of Mandrague and Damon; as for the Shepheardee Fortune, that is ordinary. Who is that Mandrague, aid the Shepheard? If one may know what the Worker is, by the Work, aid Galathea, you will finde her to be one of the greatet Magicians in all Gaul; for 'twas he, who by her enchantments, made this Grotto, and many other Rarities that are within it. Then entring in, the Shepheard was ravihed with the curioity of the work; the entrance was very high and pacious; on both ides, in lie • of Pillars, were great Statues, which with their houlders, upported the Arches of the Portall: The one repreented Pan, the other Syringes, which were mot indutriouly carved into hair, veines, eye-browes, and beard; alo the hornes of Pan were excellently wrought: The Arch without was of Rutick work, and the Vault, both without and within, was adorned with abundance of excellent Statues, which being hollow within, conveyed water into everall Fountains, and every one of them repreented ome effect of the puiance of Love. In the midt of the Grotto was a Tombe, ome twelve or fourteen foot high; and all about it hung uch pictures, as the ight of them deceived the judgment: The pace betwixt every piece was filled up with a Demi-columne of black polihed Marble, and at the top was a Cornih of white Marble, unto which the everall pictures were chained. After Celadon had contemplated them in generall, he was o full of curioity, as he deired to know more of the particulars, and therefore to give an occaion to the Nymph to ay omething more upon every part, he commended the Invention and Art of the worker. Thee are the pirits of Mandrague, (aid the Nymph) who were left here, to tetifie, that Love does not pardon either old or young, fair or foul; and to relate unto thoe who come hither, the unfortunate Loves of Damon and he, and of the Shepheardee Fortune. But, aid Celadon, is this the Fountain of Love's Verity? No, aid the Nymph, but that is not far from hence: But would I had o much ingenuitie, as to interpret thee Pictures unto you, for the tory is very well worthy of your knowledge. As he was beginning to expound them, he aw Adamas enter, who being returned, and not finding the Nymphs within, imagined that they were gone to walk; and after he had hid the clothes which he brought, he came after them. Galathea no ooner aw him, but he cryed out, Oh Father, you are come in excellent good time to help me out; and then addreing unto Celadon, Here's one, Shepheard, aid he, that will atisfie you in the tory of thee Pictures. Then after he had asked him how he did, and after alutations on all parts, Adamas, in obedience to the Nymphs commands, and to atisfie the Shepheards curioity, going with them neer the Tomb he began thus.

div.head: The Hitory of Damon and Fortune.
div.p:
AS the Work-man is pleaed to make his work, and form it into what he pleaeth, o likewie the great gods, by whoe hands we are all formed, are pleaed to make us act uch parts upon the Theater of this world, as they have put upon us: But amongt all, there was none that had uch fantaticall imaginations as Love; for he makes the old grow young, and the young old, and all in the twinkling of an eye. This Hitory, which is
fuller of truth than I wih it were, will make this o evident, that it cannot be denyed, as by the equell of my dicoure you will finde.

div.head: The firt Picture.
div.p: BEhold there a Shepheard, itting upon the ground, with his back againt an Oake, <> legs acroe, and playing upon Bag-Pipe. That is the Shepheard Damon, whoe perfection of face gives him the title of Fair. This young Shepheard fed his Flock upon the banks of Lignon, decended from one of the bet Families about Mount Verdam, and nor far off in kindred from the old Cleontine, and Leonida's Mother, o conequently my Allie. Oberve how his face, beides the beauty of it, does lively repreent a peron, whoe cares are only to content himelfe; for you cannot finde the leat cloudy imagination in his brow. Then on the contrary, remove your eye, and oberve thoe Shepheardees that are about him, then you will judge by their compoure of face, that they are not without much paines: For, as Damon's pirit is quiet and free, o thee Shepheardees have hearts extreamly paionate towards him; and yet you ee, he will not daigne to betow a look upon them: And therefore there is placed by him on the right hand, that little boy, with a Bow, and a Torch in his hand, his eyes bound up, his back winged, and upon his houlders a Quiver. This is Love, who being much offended at the didain of this Shepheard to thee Shepheardees does wear that he will be revenged of him. And for the imbellihment of the piece, oberve well the haddowes and proportions of every part; oberve how the arme of the Shepheard, does as it were, tir and blow his Bag-pipe which is betwixt his arm and body, and how the Pipes end at which he blowes, hath a little lot his colour; the reaon of it is, becaue the mouth of the Shepheard hath worn it away. Look upon the left hand, and ee how his Flocks doe feed; ee how ome lie down in the hade, and thoe two Ra ••• s running againt each other with all their force. The duty of the Dogs is not to be paed by unoberved, how like Centinels, they are placed upon hills, and ready to run upon any neceity. Do but look well upon the curious indutry of the Painter, for whereas Dogs that are dull, and leep without care ue to lie round, and hide their heads often under their pawes; thee here do lie after another manner, to hew, they do not leep, but ret themelves only; for they do lie upon their four feet, with their noe upon them, and eyes alwaies open. But let us look upon the other Picture.

div.head: The econd Picture.
div.p: THis is quite contrary to the other; for that is all Didain this Love: That hewes only pride and corn, in this appeares nothing but humility and weetnee; And this is the caue of it: Look well upon yonder Shepheardee, which itteth under that hade, how fair he is, and handomely dret. Look how the gentle winde whitles her hair backward, and makes it pread upon her houlders: It is the fair Shepheardee Fortune, in whoe favour Love promieth revenge upon Damon, who is that Shepheard which is next her, leaning upon his Sheephook.

Oberve thoe little Cupids which are all o buie about them, and each of them attentive upon what he doth; ee how one of them is taking meaure of the Shepheardee's eyebrow, and gives it unto another, who having tollen ome of that Beautie's hair is making a Bow tring of it for his Companion; ee how he its upon the ground and twines it betwixt his finger and his thumb; and that he may the better twine it a third fetches him a handfull of a Lovers tears, to wet his fingers. See how another is bending his Bow, etting the one end of it to the ground, the other to his breat, and leanes upon it to make it bend. Cupid, who is a little higher, having in his left hand a Bow, and right hand behinde his ear, as if he were ready to let an Arrow flie; ee how he drawes back his arme, lifts up his elbow, his three firt fingers open, and the ret cloe, and o levells at a mark, which he hits: for the poor Shepheard, whom he hot at, was o wounded, that nothing but death can cure him. But look on the other ide, and ee how Anteros, with Violets and Roes, drees the arme and head of the fair Shepheardee Fortune, and tying a Chain about the neck of the Shepheardee, gives the end of it unto the Shepheard. This repreents unto us, that the merits, love, and ervices of this Shepheard, which are denoted by thoe flowers, do oblige Fortune unto a reciprocall love of him. And if you think it trange, that Anteros here hould be repreented bigger than Cupid, it is to let you undertand,
that Love which proceeds from Love, is alwaies greater then that from which it doth proceed. But lee us pae to the third.

div.head: The third Picture.
div.p: LOok here upon your pleaant River of Lignon, ee how it has a double ource, the one comming from the Mountaines of Cervieres, and the other from the Chilmaell hills, and meet a little below the Merchants Town of Boinge. How well the Channell is drawn? how the River runs crooked, and the banks full of Offers? Do you not know the Wood there, which joynes to the great Plain, where the Shepheards ue to feed their Flocks? If that tuft of Trees on the left hand, where the River cringles it elfe like unto a Serpent, and makes a halfe Moon in another, eem trange unto your eye, and is not o at this houre, you mut know, that the Picture notwithtanding is true; for ince it was drawn, ome Trees are decayed, others cut down, and others growne in their room. Then look a little lower the River, and behold a flock of heep feeding in the hade; that is the flock of Damon, whom you may ee there in the River up to the Middle: Oberve how that young copps of Trees do bid reitance to the Sun, and as it were, rejoyce, that they have another under them and yet, uch is the piercing curioity of the Sun, that it findes a paage between ome leaves, for ome of its rayes: Take notice how well the hade and the rayes are repreented. But certain it is, that the Shepheard cannot be urpaed in beauty; look wel upon the delicate proportion and ymmetry of his face; his tall and proper tature; and ee how every part is painted in the height of perfection; although he toopes a little to reach the water, and with his right arme waheth his left, yet for all that, you may eaily perceive his perfect beauty. Then cat your eye upon the other ide of the River, and there you may behold uglinee in its height, as on this ide you did beauty: for there amongt thoe dirty Ruhes, you may ee the Sorcerene Mandrague, looking upon the Shepheard as he is bathing himelfe; ee how he is dret, as it were, in pite of thoe that look upon her: her rufled hair, her foul and naked arme, and her pittifull petticoat, tucked up higher then her ugly knee: I believe, and o would any that he was going to conjure. But ee here the trange effects of Beauty. This old Hag, with one hip in her grave, with her little, lean, wrinckled, and meager face, and hair as gray as old age could make it; he is not ahamed to fall in love with this young and lovely Lad: If there be any ympathy in Love, as they ay there is, I wonder where it could be betwixt Damon and her; look what an extay he is in, how he lifts up her hoary head, and withered hands, and intending to mile makes a mierable mouth: But be he as ugly as he is, he intends to love and court this Shepheard. Then lift up your eyes a little higher, and ee how Venus and Cupid in that cloud, looking upon this new Lover do eem as if they laughed at it. Certainly this was ome wager, which that little god had laid with his Mother, that he could make this wither'd tump betir her elfe in Love; or if it were not upon a wager, it was to hew by this old hag, that dry wood burnes better and ooner then green; or ele, to hew his power upon this aged Monument, he would try what heat was in his Torch, with which, it eemes, he can inpire new oules; and, in a word, make life revive, and come out of the grave.

div.head: The fourth Picture.
div.p:
PAe then unto the next, and you hall ee night very well repreented; See how in that gloomy hade, ome Mountains do a little appear, but o, as you can hardly tell what they be. Oberve how thee tars do eem as if they twinkled; there is Ura major, which though it have even and twenty tars belonging to it, yet the judicious workman has repreented clearly unto us but twelve; and of that twelve, but even that hine clear. There again is Ura minor; And conider, that though all thee even tars do never hide themelves, yet one of them is of the third Magnitude, and foure of the fourth; and yet to us, they eem all of the ame proportion. There is alo the Dragon, unto which belongs thirty and one tars; yet thirteen only to be een, five of which are of the fourth Magnitude, and eight of the third. There again is Adrian's Crown, which hath in it eight tars, whereof one is more plendent then the ret. Behold there the Milkie way, by which, the Romans ay, that the gods ued to go and come from heaven. How well thoe clouds are repreented? how in ome places they cover the sky with a dusky thicknee, in others lee,
as they are more or lee in height, o in clearnee. Now let us conider the Story of this Picture: Look upon Mandrague in the midt of a Circle, with a wand in her right hand, and an old worm-eaten book in her left, with a candle of green wax, and a pair of rotten pectacles on her noe; ee how he eemes to mutter her mouth awry, her browes like clouds, and every action eemes to groan out her affection: Oberve how her feet, her arms, her left ide is naked, being on the ame ide with her heart: All thoe phantames which you ee about her, are Demons and Spirits, which he conjures up unto her by her charms, to know of them what he hould do to make Damon love her They tell her of his affection unto Fortune, and that there is no better way, then to tell him, that this Shepheardee loves another and not him; and in order to that, it is requiite, he hould preently change the vertue that is in the Fountain of Loves verity. Before you go any further, oberve the art of the Drawer; ee the effects of Mandrague's candle in the dark, how light it is on her left ide, and how dark it is on the other ide of her face, as if it were two different complexions. Then ee what a difference the hadow of this candle makes amongt the Demons, ome in darknee, ome in light, as he does turn her elfe. Oberve again the Painters art in drawing his ditances, omethings at hand, and ome afar off; Mandrague here is far off at the Fountain of Loves verity. But for your better undertanding, be pleaed to know, that a little before, there was a fair Shepheardee, the Daughter of a very cunning Magician, was ecretly deperately in love with a Shepheard. Whether it was, that the charmes of Magick had no influence upon the charmes of Love, or that he was o attentive upon his tudies, that he did not minde her; but o it was, that after a mot extream affection, and didain of the Shepheard, he took it o to heart, that he dyed, and all her Fathers skill could not help her: At which the Magician being extreamly orry when he undertood the occaion, to eternize her memory, he changed her Tombe into a Fountain; which he called the Verity of Love, becaue whooever looked in it, he hould ee his Mitree, and if he did love him, he hould ee her and himelfe together; and if he did not love any, then he hould appear alone. And this is the vertue that Mandrague would change, to the end, that when Damon came to look into the Fountain, he might finde that his Mitree loved another, and o his affection unto her might die, and he her elfe might poee it. See how he did inchant it, what Characters he makes about it, what Circles, what Triangles, and od Figures he ueth. Before he began to conjure, he called all her Divells about her, to her aide; yet Love being tronger then all they, they durt not attempt any thing againt him, only counelled her, to betray thee two faithfull Lovers, and to forbear that qualitie for a certain time. Now ince the vertue of this Fountain did ut come unto it by a Magician; Mandrague, who excelled all her Predecesors in that Science, might eaily obtain that requet. But let us pae to the next Picture.

div.head: The fift Picture.
div.p:
THis Piece contains two actions: The firt is Damon, when he came unto this Fountain, to be atisfied in thoe doubts into which an angry Dream had put him. The other, when being deceived by the art of Mandrague, and aw that the Shepheardee Fortune loved another, in depair, he killed himelfe. Now let us ee how thee things are repreented: See Damon there with his Faulchion, for he was in his hunting equipage; oberve how his Dog followes him, look how that obervant Animal eye's his Mater; for whilt he looked in the Fountain, the Dog fixed his eye upon him, as if he were deirous to know what it was which o amazed him. Mandrague had in a dream let him ee Maradon, a young Shepheard, who taking one of Cupid's Arrowes, opened Fortune's breat, and took away her heart. Damon, as all Lovers are, being in much doubt, as oon as ever he waked, got up, and went to the Fountain, to ee whether his Mitree till loved him. I beeech you oberve very well his amazement, if you compare his face which is in all the other three Pictures, with this, you hall finde a trange alteration. Thoe two faces which you ee in the Fountain, is the Shepheardee Fortune's, and the other the Shepheard Maradon's, which the Witch caued to be repreented rather then the other: and o Damon believed his Shepheardee loved Maradon, which beliefe made him reolve upon death. Do you ee how the water eemes to tremble, that is caued by poor Damon's tears, that had dropped into it. But let us pas on to the econd Action: The dead man whom you ee lying upon the ground, is poor Damon, who being deperate, killed himelf with
his Falchion. His action is very naturally done, with one Arm engaged under his body, being urpried with the uddennee of the fall, and having no trength to recover himelf; his head hanging over his right houlder, his eyes half hut, and half turned upwards; his mouth open, his teeth apparent, and o all ignes of a udden death: A man quite dead is not repreented, but a man betwixt life and death, as if there were a medium. Look how the blood is running out of his wound; I do not think you ever aw any thing more naturally repreented. But let us ee what is in the other peece.

div.head: The ixth Picture.
div.p: NOw be pleas'd to look upon the ixth and lat Peece; which containes four actions of the Shepheardee Fortune: The firt is a Dream which Mandrague caued her to have; The other, how he went unto the Fountain to clear her doubts: The third, how he complains againt the Incontancy of her Shepheard: And the lat is, how he dies, which is the concluion of this Tragedy. Let us look upon all thee particulars: Look upon the Riing of the Sun, oberve how long the hadows are; how the sky is not o clear on the one ide; ee how clouds and mits are expelled; and how thoe little Birds do dree and prune themelves againt its approach. Pae your eye a little further, and ee the Shepheardee Fortune aleep in her bed and how the Sun hines through the window upon her naked breat: Alo the leeve of her mock being looe, the beauty of her Arm as high as the Elbow is to be een. See how the Daemons of Morpheus doe hover about her; all which are o many ervants unto Mandrague, and inpire her with a minde to goe unto the Fountain of Loves verity; which accordingly hee did, having dreamed that her Shepheard was dead; and therefore hee came to the Fountaine of Loves verity, to know the truth: She had no ooner cat her eye upon the water, but he aw Damon; but, alas, he aw by him the Shepheardes Melinde, a fair Shepheardes, and one who was never upected to love Damon: yet, though hee neither did love her, hee was by this Sorcery to appear: See how Fortune bewails the accident in the very ame place, where Damon was almot dead. Behold how adly he its againt yonder Rock; her arms croed upon her breat: It eems as if he ighed, and her heart panted, her eyes looking up to heaven, asking revenge upon the Peridie which hee beleeves Damon to bee guilty of; and becaue her paion was extream, he complained againt him in a very loud tone: And Damon, who you ee near her, though hee was at the lat gap, yet hearing the lamentation of his Shepheardes, and knowing her voice, did call unto her. She hearing a faint hollow voice, went towards him. Oh heavens! how the ight of him did amue her? and forgetting the occaion of her comming thither, when he aw him in that condition, he asked who had ued him o: It is, aid hee unto her, the change of my fortune: It is your Incontancy which hath deceived me with a hew of affection. To be brief, it is the happines of Maradon, whom I aw in the Fountain next you; and doe you thinke it poible I hould live and ee you love another? Fortune hearing this, Oh Damon, aid hee, this Fountain is an errant Lyar; for it hath alo hewed me Belinde next you, whom I ee dying for the love of me. Thus thee two Lovers found out the fality of this Fountain, and being more aured than ever of each others affection, they dyed in each others Armes; Damon of his wound, and Fortune for griefe of his death. Behold there the Shepheardee itting againt a maie Rock, and Damon leaning his head in her lap, taking his lat farewel, and bidding her, Adieu. See how indulgent he is about tying up his wound, and tooping to kie him, whilt her lap is full of blood. That old hagg which is next them, is Mandrague the Witch, who finding them both dead, cured her Art, hated all her Daemons, tore her hair, and extreamly grieved at the death of thee two faithful Lovers, and her own contentment. Look a little further off, and ee how Cupid weeps, his Bow and Arrows broken, his Torch extinguihed, and his eyes wimming in teares for the loe of thee two faithfull Lovers.

Celadon was all this while very attentive unto the dicoure of the age Adamas, and often blamed himelf for want of courage in not uing the ame remedy Damon did. And becaue thee coniderations made him very mute, Galathea taking Celadon by the hand, and going out of the Grotte, he aid thus unto him; What doe you think, Celadon, of the effects of Love? I doe think, aid he, that the effects of Love are implicity and folly: And it is a popular errour, wherewith every one is apt to cover their ignorance or excue their faults, alwaies to attribute thoe effects unto ome Divinity, when they do not know
the caues. Why, aid the Nymph, doe you think, there is no Love? If there be, replyed the Shepheard, it mut be nothing but weetnes: But bee it what it will, Madam, you peak of it unto one that is the mot ignorant peron that lives: For, beides my qualities, which will not permit me to know much, my dull capacity, renders me incapable. Then the aid Silvia replyed unto him, Celadon (aid he) I have een you in a place where all in it have thought you not o ignorant in matters of Love. Fair Nymph, anwered hee, in what place oever that was, there was much beauty in it, if you were there: but as too great a fire rather burns than warms, o your beauties are too high for our Rutique hearts; for they do rather make us admire than love, and adore rather than erve. With uch dicoures as this, all this faire company went homeward, where Dinner waited for them.

As oon as day did break, Leonida, according as it was reolved upon over night by Adamas, her companion, and Celadon; did come unto the Shepheards chamber, to dree him in thoe clothes which her Uncle had brought. But the little Merill, who by Galathea's command did alwayes tay with Celadon, as well to be a pye over the actions of Leonida, as to wait upon the Shepheard, did a long while hinder their deign. At lat, ome noie or other that was made in the Court, made Meril run out to ee what the matter was. Then Celadon did rie immediatly, and the Nymph (ee what love will doe) did help to dree him for without her hee knew not how to put his clothes on handomly. Preently after Meril returnes, yet Celadon hearing him, went into a Wardrobe, and hee was no ooner entred but Meril asked where Celadon was? He is in the Wardrobe, aid the Nymph, and will come out preently, what wouldt thou have with him? I would tell him, ayd the boy, that Amais is coming hither. Leonida was a little urpried, that he could not finih what he had begun; yet that he might goe and give Celadon ome counel he ayd unto Meril, Go little Meril, run and acquaint thy Lady, let he be urpried: The Boy ran as fat as he could, and Celadon came out laughing at the news: Oh why do you laugh, aid the Nymph, her comming will hinder your going out? Come, come, aid hee, make hate and dree me; for amongt o many Nymphs I hall the more eaily teal away. But whilt they were very buie at their work, Galathea entred, and upon uch a udden, that Celadon could not get into the Cloet. You may well imagine how both Leonida and Celadon were urpried at this accident: Yet the crafty Leonida eeing Galathea enter, he held Celadon, and would not let him hide himelf but turning towards Galathea, and eeming much troubled Madam, aid he, if you doe not ue ome means that my Lady come not hither, we are all undone; for my part I am doing what I can to diguie Celadon in a womans habit, but I am afraid I hall not have time enough. Galathea, who knew not at the firt what to think of this Metamorphois, did much commend this witty invention of Leonida's, and when he aw Celadon o well diguied he could not chue but laugh, and aid unto Leonida, Friend, but for you we had been all undone; for we could never have hidden Celadon amongt o many Nymphs as will come with Amais; but now wee are well enough, and may afely hew him unto all your companions, who will take him for a woman. Thus Galathea, after it was agreed upon that Celadon hould ay he was Coen unto Adamas, and called Lucinde, went out to meet her Mother. I mut ingenuouly confee (aid Celadon, after he was gone) I was never in my life o atonihed as at thee three accidents. Firt, at the coming of Amais. Secondly, at Galathea's urpriing us; and thirdly, at your udden invention. Shepheard, aid Leonide, what I do, proceeds from my deires to rid you out of your pain; and I would to the gods you knew my heart, then would you find what happinee I wih you. By way of gratitude for o great an obligation, aid the Shepheard, I cannot chue but tender you my life, ince you have preerved it. Thus they talked till Meril came into the Chamber, and eeing Celadon almot dret, hee was ravihed, and aid no live peron could know him; for hee that was continually with him, had he not een him dreing, hould have been mitaken. Who told thee, aid Celadon, that I was diguied? My Lady, aid he, and commanded me to ay your name was Lucinde, the Coen of Adamas, and to acquaint the Druide with it, who could not chue but laugh when hee heard it, and promied to doe as my Lady commanded him. In the mean time, Amais was come out of her Coach, and met Galathea at the tairs foot, with Silvia and Adamas. Daughter, aid he unto her, me-thinks you have been too long in olitude, and I am come to diorder you a little. The good news I have received from Clidaman and Lindamor, does o rejoyce mee, that I cannot contain my joyes alone, and therefore I am come to make you a participant with me, and would have you goe with me
unto Marcelles, where Bonefires hall be made through every treet. I doe much rejoice at your happinee, Madam, aid Galathea and wih it may continue eternally: But truly, Madam, this place pleaeth me o well, that I have no deiring Genius to leave it. No more you hall long, replyed Amais, but becaue I will not goe thither untill night, let us walke together, and I will acquaint you with the news I have received. Then Adamas made a low reverence, and aid, Certainly, Madam, your news is very good, ince you are tirring o early to impart it unto your Daughter. I have received it (aid hee) two or three daies ince, but found that I could not enjoy the contentment of it alone, and truly the news deerves to be divulged. Thus they talked until they came into the Garden: when as they began to walk, Amais took Galathea on one ide, and Adamas on the other, and then he proceeded thus.

div.head: The Hitory of Lydias and Melandre.
div.p: Conidering the trange variety of accidents which are caued by Love, me-thinkes it mut needs be confeed, that the Wheel of Love does turn about as fat as the Wheel of Fortune, and that Paion caueth as many changes and alterations in humane affairs; as any thing ele. The examples of thee are o frequently before our eyes, that it is impertinent to intance them: And yet when you have heard this which I intend to relate, you will confes you never heard of any more remarkable. It is known unto you, how Clidaman by hazard and Lot became a ervant unto Silvia, and how Guyemant in bringing a Letter unto her from his Brother fell in love with her. And ince that, I believe you are not ignorant of their deign in departing both together to goe unto Merovea: Nor how I ent a great number of the young Cavalrie under the conduct of Lindamor after them: But I beleeve, you do not know what they have done ince they went. And therefore I do at this time intend to make a relation of their voyage unto you, for it is worthy of knowledge. As oon as Clidaman came unto the Army, Guyemant who was known, brought him to kie the hands of Merovea and Childerick, under the notion of a young Cavalier, decended from a noble Family, who deired to erve them. Hee was received with open Armes, epecially coming at a time when the enemy did menace them with a Battle. But when Lindamor came, and it was known who Clidaman was, he was honoured and carraed beyond all expreions; for he had already o ignalized himelf, that both friends and enemies did know and eteem him. Amongt other Prioners which he and Guyemant took (for they alwayes went out together in any enterprie) there was one amongt them that came out of Great Britane, o handome, but o ad, that he moved Clidaman to pitty him. And becaue his imprionment made him eem extreamly ad, one day he ent for him; and after he had asked him everal quetions of his Being and Quality, he asked him the caue of his adnee, telling him that if it did proceed from his imprionment, hee ought like a man of courage to endure it, and thank the heavens that he fell into their hands, ince he was in a place where he had all civil treatment, and that his want of liberty proceeded onely from the command of Merovea, who had charged that no prioners hould yet be ranomed, yet hee would doe his bet endeavour to procure him his liberty. The young man thanked him, but it was with a deep igh; which Clidaman more wondering at, did aske him the caue. Unto which he anwered; Sir, this adnee which you ee in my face, and thoe ighs which o often teal from my breat, doe not proceed from my imprionment which you peak of, but from another more trict than it; for my ranome will ere long dioblige me from this, but nothing lee than death can bring me out of the other. I hould alo endure it with patience did I not foreee my own death, and the ruin of the peron who keeps me o cloe in prion. Clidaman did by his peech imagine that it was Love which troubled him, and by himelfe conidering the pain of his prioner, his pitty moved him to promie him that he would procure his liberty as oon as poible, knowing by experience what paions and perplexities of mind ueth to accompany them that are deeply in love. Sir, aid hee unto him, ince you know the power of Love, and that your noble Country makes mee beleeve, that what knowledge oever you have of mee, you will not alter your good will unto mee; therefore upon a promie not to dicover mee, I will tell you a thing which will make you wonder. Then Clidaman promiing ecreie, he began thus.

Cavalier, bee pleaed to know, that this habit which you ee mee wear is not my own;
but Love, that is able to metamorphie women into men, hath made me aume this dree; for I am not a man, but a woman, one that is decended from as good a Family as any is in Brittain, and my name is Melandre, who, conducted by trange fortune, is fallen into your hands. There was a man whoe name is Lydias, that fled out of his own Country, and came to London, having killed a man in Duell, and, to avoid the rigour of the Law, was forced to forake his Country. Being in London, as it is the cutom of our Nation, he found o much civility and courtey, that there was not a houe of any noble note, where he was not familiar; and amongt the ret, he was as free to my Fathers houe, as he could be unto his own. Now becaue he intended to tay there, untill he could afely return into his own Country, he intended (the better to conform himelfe unto the Britih humour, where every one has a particular Mitree) to eem as if he were in Love: And in this reolution, (I cannot tell whether good or bad) he fixed his eyes upon me; and either out of affection or convenience, he began to profee himelfe my ervant. I will not tire you with a long dicoure upon thoe diimulations, thoe courthips, and thoe oathes; that he ued unto me: But o it was, that after a long addree of courthip, (for he tayed there two years) his handomnes, his courtey, his dicretion, and his valour, had uch an influence upon me, that I did love him without any diimulation. I hould bluh to confes thus much, did I not think you a peron that hath tryed the force of Love; or to tell you, that the beginning of my love was the end of my tranquillity. Things being thus, it hapned, that the Franks, after they had gotten the better in o many Battles againt the Roman Emperours, againt the Goths, and againt the Gaules, they turned their Armes againt the Neutrians, and brought them unto uch termes, as they were foroed to end unto London, their antient Allie, to demand aid, who, according to the Alliance made between them, did grant them aid, by the conent of the King and States. This newes was preently divulged throughout all the Realm, and we, who were in the chiefe City, firt heard of it. Lydias began to think upon his return the very firt houre, auring himelfe, that his Countrymen, being in need of uch as he, would eaily abolve him from the death of Arontes: Yet, becaue he ever promied me, that if he went, he would carry me with him, he concealed his deigne from me, either as intending to deceive me, or ele fearing I hould hinder his departure. Yet, as there can be no fire o cloely covered, but there will be ome moak; o he could not o cloely hide his hot deire of departure, but I heard of it. Asoon as I came to the knowledge of it, the firt time I aw him, I took him aide: Well Lydias, aid I unto him, are you then reolved I hall not know your intentions of leaving me? Do you think my affection o feeble, that it is not able to follow the wort of your fortune? If your affairs do urge you to return into your Country, why hould you not let me go with you? Ask my Fathers conent unto our Marriage, I am confident he will be glad of our alliance; for I know he loves you. But, Lydias, do not perjure your elfe o much, as to leave me here deolate behinde you; for if you do, the gods will punih you. Unto all this, he faintly anwered, That he had no thought of returning, but that he valued his preence with me above all affairs, and that I did him wrong to doubt of it; but his actions hould force me to confes it. Yet, for all thee fair words, this perjur'd man went away within two or three daies after, with the firt Forces that went out of great Brittain, and took his time o jutly, that he came to the Sea-ide jut as they were Embarquing themelves, and o he Embarqued with them. We were preently advertied of his departure; yet, I was o perwaded that he loved me, as I was the lat that did believe it, o as he was gone eight daies before I could ever believe, that a man o well decended as he was, could be uch a deluder and ungratefull man: but at lat, many daies being pat, and I never eeing nor hearing of him, I began to think my elfe deceived, and that he was really gone. You may well imagine I was much troubled at it, when falling ick upon it, I was in uch a condition, as the Phyicians not knowing my dieae, gave me over for dead: But Love having a minde to hew himelfe a better Doctor than Aeculapius, did cure me by a mot trange Antidote; and ee how contrary his effects are unto our reolutions. When I knew of the flight of Lydias, for o it may be called, I found my elfe o offended, that after a thouand invocations of the gods, as witneses of his perfidies, I wore, that I would never love him, as often as he wore that he would love me; o as it may be aid, both of us were perjured; for when my hatred was in the height of fury, a Ship coming in from Calice, to bring newes of the Armies happy landing, I heard, that Lydias paed over, with intention, to fight under the Banners of the Brittih Forces; but as oon as the Governour of that place, who was a Cozen unto Arontes, was advertied
of it, he did imprion him, as being already a peron condemned, and that he was quite undone; for the Governour had very great credit amongt the Neutrians. That indeed there was a way to ave him, but it was o difficult, that none durt attempt it; and it was this: As oon as Lydias was eized upon, he asked the Governour the reaon, why a Cavalier of o great a reputation as he was, would not rather revenge his quarrells by the way of Arms, rather then by the way of Jutice? For, it is not the cutome of the Gaules to have any recoure unto Jutice, but unto Combat, in points of honour; and uch as do not o, are reputed cowards and dihonourable. Lypandas, for o was the Governours name, did anwer him, that were he not already condemned by Jutice, he would try it with him by Arms; but it being a dihonour to him, to fight with a man that was dead in the Law, if he had any friend that would undertake the Quarell for him, he would fight with him upon this core, that if he were overcome, he would et him at liberty; and if not, then Jutice hould have its coure: And that his kindred or friends might have the more time to prepare themelves, he would keep him a month in his power; if none came to preent themelves in that time, then he hould be delivered up to be punihed according to his merits. And that no advantage might be on either ide, the Combat hould be with Sword and Dagger in their hirts. Now Lypandas, being reputed one of the valiantet men of all Neutria, there was none o tout as to undertake this Combat: alo the friends of Lydias not being advertied of it, they could not do him this good office. Oh Sir, what trange apprehenions had I, when I heard this newes? I mut confee, I was never in all my life o confued in my thoughts, no, not when this perfidious man left me. But though I knew, waves do beat in vain againt a turdy Rock, yet, I mut pay the tribute due unto Love, and arme my elfe in this quarrell, though it did cot me both honour and life: And after I had long, but in vain, lamented the loe of the unfaithfull Lydias; at lat, I mut think upon his preervation And in order to that, being tranported with this new Fury, or rather, this old Love newly revived, I reolved to go unto Calice, and advie with the kindred and friends of Lydias about it. Then taking order, as ecretly as poibly I could, for my voyage, one night I tole away in this habit you now ee me have; but o bad was my luck, that I tarried above a formight for a hip The heavens know what became of Parents when they heard of my departure, for I never heard of them ince: great is my fear, that my Father's old age will never brook this croe; for he loved me as tenderly as himelfe, o as I have ince wondred a hundred times, I hould ever undertake this voyage: but, the truth is, it was Love, not me, that was the caue. But to return to our dicoure, after I had waited above fifteen daies for a paage, at the lat I met with a hip which went for Calice, when there was not above five or ix daies of Lydias his tearm to expire. I was o ea-ick, as I was forced to keep my bed two daies; o as there was but a very little time left, to conult with the friends of Lydias, not knowing where to finde one of them, nor where they dwelt. Imagine how this did trouble me, o as I thought my elfe rather come to ee him die, than any way to help him to live. Oh ye gods! how will ye dipoe of us? Tears did night and day flow from my eyes. At the lat, the very day before the expiration of the tearm, being reolved to die with Lydias, or before him, I reolved to enter into Combat with Lypandas. What a reolution, or rather depair, was this? I had never handled a word in my life, nor did well know in which hand I hould hold the word, and in which the dagger; yet was I fully reolved to enter the Lits againt a Cavalier, whoe profeion was fighting, and had gotten the title of Brave and Stout: But all thee coniderations were nothing unto me, who was reolved to die before him, whom I loved above my life; and though I knew that I could not ave him, yet was it ome atisfaction to me, that I hould give ome tetimony of my affection. One thing did exceedingly trouble me, which I endeavoured to avoid, which was, that if I hould be known unto Lydias, this would hinder my deigne, for we were to fight without Armour; which to remedy, I writ a note unto Lypandas, by way of challenge, and deired him, that ince we were both of us Cavaliers, it would be handome, if we ued uch Armes as Cavaliers do, and not to fight naked like deperate people. To which he anwered, That in the morning he would be in the field, and that I hould come Armed, as he would; yet, it hould be in his choice which way they hould fight. The next morning I preented my elfe in the field, armed Cap a pe, but o loaded, that I could hardly tir; thoe who aw me tagger, did think it either fear of fighting, or weaknes, as indeed it was. Preently I aw Lypandas come prancing, as if he would kill me with his looks; but I was not atonihed, untill Lydias was brought upon a Scaffold, to ee the fight. I did o extreamly pitty him when I aw him in that condition, as I tood
tock till a great while, and could not tir: At lat, the Judges carried me unto him, to know, whether he would accept of me for his Champion. He asked me who I was? Then counterfeiting my voice as well as I could, I aid unto him, Let it atisfie you, Lydias, that I am the onely One that will undertake this Combat for you. Since it is o, replyed he certainly you are a peron of great valour, and therefore I do accept of you. So when I was going away, he aid unto me, Cavalier, be confident, that your quarrel is mot jut. Then I retired, with uch full reolution for death, that I tayed for nothing but the ound of the Trumpet, to ummon us unto the Combat. Upon the firt ound, I et out but my Hore did o jog me, that in lieu of carrying my Lance as I hould have done, I let it fall which way fortune would, and it fell o luckily upon my Hores neck, that in lieu of hiting Lypandas, it ran his Hore into the body, who being wounded ran preently away in pite of his Mater and fell dead under him. Lypandas was o over-eager of doing bravely, that he mied his blow. As for me, my Hore ran even whither he pleaed; for I had enough to do in holding me by the Pommel, let I hould fall. And hearing Lypandas bidding me turn again, and upbraiding me for killing his Hore, I turned my hore back, after I had got my word in my hand, as well as I could though with much ado: But my Hore, asoon as he was turned having more courage then his Rider, began of himelfe to gallop, and ran furiouly upon Lypandas; and he tepping aide, ran his word into my Hores body as he paed by, and preently I perceived him to hrink under me; and having lot my tirrups, he fell under me, and o far off Lypandas, that I had time enough to get out of the Saddle, and recover my elfe from my Hore: Then came Lypandas towards me, with his word up ready to trike at me: and I mut tell you that had not Love born up my Armes better then my elfe did, he had dipatched me; but eeing him o furiouly make his blow at my head, Nature had taught me to hold up my left arme, for otherwie, I had never remembred my buckler that was upon it; but his blow upon it was with uch fury, as it truck it againt my face, and made my eyes to parkle. When he aw me tagger, he offered another blow more heavie then the firt; but uch was my fortune, that holding up my word, his and mine clahed together: and both of them broke. Lypandas eeing both of us upon the ame advantages, did ay unto me, Thee Armes are equally favourable unto us, I will try whether others will do the like, and therefore let us cat off our heavy Armour, and fight in our hirts, for I will have the Combat o decided. Cavalier, aid I unto him, by what is pat, you may ee your elfe in the wrong; our quarrell is not mortall, therefore releae Lydias, and let the Combat alone. No, no, aid Lypandas in a rage, both Lydias and you hall die. Then I will try, aid I, whether I can retort that Sentence upon your own head. Then getting as far off Lydias as I could, for fear of being known, I put off my Armour, with the help of thoe who brought us two other words and daggers. And when my doublet was off, I took a word and a dagger, and went into the middle of the Lits: I mut tell you, that I had much ado to hide my breats; for my hirt, do what I could, did not o hide them, but the fulnee of my Papps were palpable to be een; but that was the farthet off every ones imagination and as for Lydias, he could not know me; for being in mans habit, and the weight of my Armour having put me in o a very high colour, I was much altered. At lat Lypandas and I were within ten or twelve paces one of another. Now did I look for nothing but death, being aured, he would run me through at the very firt puh: But the fortune of Lydias was o good, for it was his life I only feared, that this high-minded Lypandas running extream violently at me, he chanced to tumble, and his head fell at my feet, and at this fall he received two wounds, with his own weapons; the one with his dagger, that ran him through his right arme, and the other with his word, which cut him jut over the eyes. As for me, I was o frighted with this fall, that I thought my elfe dead and him too; and therefore tepping back two or three paces, without doing him any hurt, I thought to vanquih him more by my courteie then valour, and aid unto him: Rie Lypandas. I will not hurt you when you are down. He being much tunnyed with his fall at firt, did afterwards rie, thinking to run upon me with all the trength he had: but one of his wounds had blinded him, and the other took away the ue of his arme, o as he could neither ee nor hold his word: Which I perceiving, I took courage, and lifting up my word I ran unto him, aying: Yield thy elfe, Lypandas or ele thou dyet. Why hould I yield my elfe, aid he, for the conditions of our Combat were not o; let it uffice, I et Lydias at liberty. Then the Judges comming in, and Lypandas having ratified his promie, they led me out of the Lits in triumph: But fearing let I hould receive ome wrong in a place, where Lypandas had all
the power, after I had put my Armour on again, I went to Lydias, with my Helmet pulled down, and aid unto him: Lydias, render thanks unto the gods for my Victory; and if you deire to have any dicoure with me, I will go unto the Town of Regiaque, where I will tay for you fifteen daies, for after that terme, I mut go about ome buinee, which will carry me far from hence. You may enquire for the orrowfull Chavelier, for under that name and notion I pae. But I beeech you, aid Lydias, hall I not now know unto whom I am o much obliged? No, aid I unto him, it will not be good neither for you nor me: And o I left him. Then providing my elfe another Hore, I came to Regiaque, where I tayed. As oon as I was gone, this fale Lypandas did imprion Lydias more cloe than before; and when he was charged with his promie unto me, he did evade it, by aying, That it is true, he promied me liberty, but he did not tel me when: and therefore it hould not be this twenty years, unlee upon a condition, that I hould become a Prioner in his room, and o pay the ranome of his liberty with the loe of my own. Lydias told him, that this was the height; both of ingratitude and perfidie. This did o offend him, that he wore, unles I came within fifteen daies, and put my elfe into his hands, he would transfer him over into the hands of Jutice. And when Lydias intanced his perjury to him. I have long ince, aid he, worn unto the Neutrian Lords, to maintain Jutice, and I am more obliged to keep my firt oth, than my econd. The firt day paed on, & I did not think much; but when I heard no newes of Lydias, I ent a man to enquire of him: by him I undertood what Lypandas had done and the term he had et: And though I did foreee his cruelties, yet I reolved to get Lydias out of his hands, nothing being o dear unto me, as his preervation; and by fortune, the very ame day you took me Prioner, I was going unto him; and all the adnee you ee in me, and thoe deep ighes you have oberved to ecape from me, did proceed, not from your imprionment, (for that is weet unto me, compared with my expectations of the other) but they proceed from my fears, that this unworthy Lypandas will put Lydias into the hands of his enemies, who gape for his life; for of thoe fifteen daies that were prefixed, ten of them are already pat, o as I am out of all hopes to do this good office for my poor Lydias. Upon thee words, her tears hindred her tongue, and he was forced to be ilent, with o many apparent ignes of orrow, that Clidaman was moved unto compaion, and to comfort her, aid thus unto her: Courageous Melandre, do not let your pirit droop for this, but roue up the generoity of your oul: The gods, who have preerved you in greater dangers, will not let you ink under lee. You may asure your elfe, that I will ue my utmot power to give you your deired contentment. But ince I am under a Prince whom I would not dipleae, I mut obtain your liberty from him, and will promie you, to olicite him with all my power. So upon thee fair promies, he went immediately to Childerick, and beeeched him, he would be pleaed to favour him o far, as to mediate unto the King his Father, for the liberty of this young Prioner. The young Prince, who loved my Son, and knew that his Father would be glad to oblige Clidaman, went preently to Merovea, who granted his Sons requet. Then, becaue the time was hort, he went immediately unto Melandre, and having drawn her aide, aid thus unto her. Sorrowfull Cavalier, I hope now you will change that Epithite, ince better fortune begins to hine upon you: The heavens begin now to mile upon you; and in tetimony of what I ay, know, that now you are at liberty, and may dipoe of your elfe as you pleae; the Prince of the Franks hath given me the dipoe of you, and the duty of a Cavalier obliges me, not only to give you your liberty, but to offer you all the aitance I am able. Melandre hearing this unhop't for language, did leap up for joy, and cating her elfe at his feet, did kie them by way of gratitude: and when he aw that he was to pay no ranome, which he could never have paid in the compae of that fifteen daies: Noble Cavalier, (aid he) you do make it appear, that you do know what it is to Love, ince you are o pittifull unto uch as are poeed with it: I pray the heavens to make you as happy, as you are courteous and worthy of all good fortune. Needs would he have gone away that very night, but Clidaman would not permit her, becaue it was dark; yet the next morning, as oon as day did appear, away he went, and never tayed, untill he came at Calice, where, by good fortune, he arrived the very day before the expiration of the time.
