She had made her comming known unto Lypandas that very night, had he not been jealous of his perfidie, whom he was to deal withall; and he tayed untill the morning, to the end, there might be more witnees of the wrong he hould do her, in failing of his promie. The day being come, and pat noon, when all the principall men of the Town, to honour the Governour, came unto his houe,
in comes the orrowfull Cavalier, and preents himelfe unto him: At the firt, he was not known, for none had ever een him but in the Combat, where fear had altered his countenance; and now every one drew neer to hear what he would ay. Lypandas, aid he, I come here to ummon you, to be as good as your promie, from the friends and kindred of Lydias; otherwie they tell you by mee, that they will publih you unto the world, for a fale and perfidious promie-breaker. Stranger, anwered Lypandas, go and tell them, that Lydias is yet better then he hall be within thee few daies; for before this day be don, I will transfer him over unto uch hands, as will revenge my quarrell. As for my promie, I think my elfe to be abolved from it, by putting him into the hands of Jutice. As for any new conditions I do init upon my firt, which is, that he with whom I fought, do put himelfe into my hands, to the end, I may have my will of him, and releae Lydias. What will you doe with him, aid he, when you have him? When I once have him, anwered he, and when I am to render you an account of my actions, then you hall know. Since it is o, aid the ad Cavalier, end for Lydias, and him whom you deire hall put himelfe into your hands. Lypandas, who did extreamly deire to be revenged upon his enemy, ent for Lydias: Lydias, who knew this to bee the lat day for his terme, did thinke this ending for, had been to transferre him over into the hands of the Law: But though hee did foreee a certaine death, yet hee did rather deire it, than to ee him who had fought in his caue, in any danger. When hee came before Lypandas, he aid thus unto him; Lydias, this is the lat day that is prefixed you to bring your Champion into my hands: The young Cavalier is come hither to that end, which if he do then you are at liberty. Melander all this while did o turn her face from Lydias, that he could not know her and o aid thus; Yes Lypandas I have promied, and I will perform: I would you would be as punctual in all your promies: But 'tis no matter, I am he whom you deire, and who values not any cruelty or rigour you can ue againt me, o my friend here may be out of his pain. Then every one fixed their eyes upon her, and remembring the actions he ued when he fought, they knew her to be the ame. Her beauty her youth, and her affection moved every heart unto pitty, but Lypandas, who being extreamly incened againt her commanded her preently to prion, and to let Lydias go. Lydias eeing himelf o infinitely obliged, would not uffer it, but Melander came to him, and aid in his ear, Go Lydias; as for me, I know how to get out eaily when I will; Go and erve Merovea, and particularly Clidaman, who is the procurer of your liberty; and tell him you came from me. 'Tis impoible I hould goe, aid Lydias, before I know who you are. I am the orrowfull Cavalier, aid hee, and that's enough, and you need know no more.

Thus Lydias went with an intention to erve the King of the Frankes, ince hee who twice aved his life would have it o: But in the mean time Lypandas did exprely command, that Melander hould be well guarded, and hackles put upon her hands and feet, not caring if hee had dyed with the miery. Judge in what a ad condition this young woman was; her victuals were bad, her lodging mierable, and all accomdations wanting: So as if her affection had not been ome comfort unto her, it was impoible hee hould have lived o long in that miery. In the mean time it was divulged throughout all Neutria, that Lydias by the procurement of a friend was releaed from his imprionment at Callice, and was gone to erve the King Merovea, and thereupon was declared a Traitor of his Country. Yet he failed not to go unto Merovea's Camp, where he found out which was Clidamans Tent. As oon as Lindamor and Guyemant aw him, they ran to him, and embraced him with abundance of love and courteie, at which hee was extreamly atonihed; for they took him for Ligdamon, who a little before was lot in the battle which they had with the Neutrians, and was o extreamly like him, that any one would have taken the one for the other. At the lat, being known to be Lydias, Melanders friend, he was recommended unto Merovea, before whom Lydias related the whole tory of his imprionment, and the courteie which he had received from an unknown Cavalier: Alo how he came by this unknown Cavaliers command to erve him, epecially Clidaman. After the King had received him, and given him thanks for his good wil unto him; Clidaman poke to him, and aid, Is it poible, Lydias, you hould not know him that has fought for you and is now in prion to releae you? No certainly, aid hee, I doe not know him. This is the tranget thing I ever heard of, aid Clidaman, did you never ee any that did reemble him? Not that I remember, aid Lydias, and wondered. Then aid Clidaman, I hall relate unto the King a tory, the mot worthy of compaion that Love ever caued:
Then he related how Lydias went into Great Brittaine, the courteies he received there, the affection of Melandre to him the promies hee made to carry her into Neutria with him when he went away, his flight, and his imprionment at Callais. Poor Lydias was o atonihed to hear o many particulars of his life, that he knew not what to thinke: But when Clidaman related Melandres reolution to aume mans habit, and to ight a Duel with Lypandas, and all that I have formerly related, every one was ravihed. Oh heavens! aid Lydias, is it poible I hould be o blind? What hould I doe to anwer this obligation? You can doe no lee, aid Clidaman, than give that life to her which hee has preerv'd. That is little, anwer'd he, unlee accompanyed with affection. Whilt they were thus in dicoure, every hearer concluded, this noble act of this Womans, deerved, that this great Army hould goe and aault Callais for her ake. I protet, aid Merovea our Army cannot be better employed than in the recue of o virtuous a Lady. Night being come, Lydias told Clidaman, that whilt he was at Callais a prioner, he dicovered a weak place in the Walls of the Town, where had he but a few men, he could infallibly enter. This being reported unto Merovea, it was approved of. So Lydias had given him five hundred Archers, and three hundred Men at Armes for the execution of this enterprie. In concluion (for I will not relate all particulars) Callais was taken, Lypandas imprioned, and Melandre releaed out of her captivity. But, I know not how it came to pae, nor why, yet as oon as all was quiet, after the Town was taken, Lydias and Melandre went away, and it was never ince known what became of them. In the mean time, poor Ligdamon hath been mot mierably tormented for Lydias; for, being taken prioner by the Neutrians, he was mitaken for Lydias, and condemned to death. Clidaman procured Merovea to end two Heralds at Armes, purpoely to let them know that they were mitaken, but they would not beleeve it. Thus was Ligdamon put into a den of Lyons, where they ay hee did things beyond Man: but doubtlee he had dyed amongt them, had not a fair Lady demanded him for her Husband, which cutome did at that time ave him, but hee dyed preently after; for hee loving Silvia, would not marry that Lady, but choe death rather than her for, jut upon the very Marriage, he poyoned himelfe; and hee alo, <…> to be Lydias, did poyon her elfe in the ame Cup. Thus poor Ligdamon dyed, o lamented by every one, that his very enemies did pitty him: But Love had a mot notable way of Revenge upon Lypandas; for when hee knew Melandre to be a woman, and remembring her virtue, beauty, and affection, hee fell o deperately in love with her, that the poorman had no other conolation but to talk of her. My Sonne ent me word, that he endeavoured to get his releae and hoped to obtain it.

Thus ee, aid Amais, how they live in the plenitude of Honour, and none in all the Army more eteemed than they. I pray heavens to continue their good fortune, aid Adamas: And whilt they were thus talking they aw Leonida, Lucinde, and the little Meril coming towards them; I ay Lucinde, for o it was agreed Celadon hould be called. Amais, who knew her not asked who he was? It is one that is Coen unto Adamas (anwered Galathea) her name is Lucinde, one that is o fair, and every way o virtuous, as I deired her to tay with me ome certaine dayes. She eems, aid Amais, as good as fair. I doe beleeve, Madam, aid Galathea that her dipoition would be very pleaing unto you, and if you think good he hall goe with us unto Marcelles. By this time Leonida was come o near that Lycinde bowed her elf, and kied the hand of Amais with o good a grace, as any one living would have taken her for a woman: Amais did her the honour to kie her, and aid that any who had a relation to Adamas were as dear unto her as her own children. Then Adamas began to peak let if the diguied Lucinde hould have anwered, her voice might betray her; but hee needed not to feare that; for hee knew o well how to feigne her voice, as it did rather help to deceive them. However at this time he uffered Adamas to anwer, and after a low reverence hee went amongt the other Nymphs, watching her opportunity how to teal away. At the lat, Dinner time being at hand, Amais went into the houe, where finding meat upon the Table, every one dined with a merry heart, except the fair Silvia, who did mot adly reent the death of her dear Ligdamon.

When Dinner was done, ome of the Nymphs had a minde to play; others to view the houe; ome to walk in the Gardens, and others to fit and dicoure in the Chamber of Amais: Leonida eeming as if he would make her elf ready for her going with Amais, went out of the Chamber, and preently after Lucinde followed; and then eeming as if they would walk, they went out of the Catle, having mot of the Shepheards clothes under
their Petticoats, and when they were got into the thick of the Wood, the Shepheard undreed himelf, and putting on his own cloathes, he thanked the Nymph for her good aitance, offering her in exchange, his life & all that did depend upon it. Then the Nymph with a deep igh aid unto him, Well, Celadon, have I not performed my promie? I pray remember yours alo. I hould think my elfe, ayd Celadon, the mot unworthy man that lives, if I did not perform all my promies unto you. Then, Celadon, aid he, remember what you wore unto me; for I am reolved to put you to the Tet this very hour: Fair Nymph, anwered Celadon, dipoe of me as far as I am able, as freely as you can of your elf; for I am fully reolved upon obedience. Have you not made a promie unto me, replyed the Nymph, that I hould earch into all your life pat, and if I found any thing which you could doe for me, you would doe it? And he anwering that it was true, then Celadon, aid he, I have done as you did bid me, and though they ay Love be blind yet I have o much light left in me, as to know that you ought to continue that love which you have o often promied unto your Atrea; for diguts of love will not allow any one to be perjured or unfaithfull, and therefore ye ought not to fail in your duty, though they have treated you ill. The faults of others can never excue or wah away our own. Love therefore the fair and happy Atrea, with as much incerity of affection as ever you did: erve her, adore her, and more if it bee poible; for Love requires extreames in his acrifice. But yet, I know, that the good offices which I have done you, does deerve omething. And becaue Love can never be payd but with Love, you are obliged to pay mee in the ame coyn, if no impoibilities doe intervene. But ince one heart is not capable of any more but one love, let me be paid with what it can: And ince you cannot love me as your Mitris, I would have you love me as your Siter; and ever hereafter to love mee, cheerih me, and treat me in that manner. Celadons contentment cannot be expreed, after hee heard this language; for he confeed it was infinitely his own deire: And therefore, after he had given the Nymph a Million of thanks for her affection, hee vowed to receive her as his Siter, and under that notion to doe whatoever hee commanded him. And o they parted extreamly well contented and atisfied one with another. Leonida returned to the Catle, & the Shepheard to his voyage, hunning all uch Plains where he thought he might meet with any Shepheards of his acquaintance. And leaving Mount Verdun on the left hand, he went unto a little riing ground, from whence he could view mot of thoe places where hee was accutomed to feed his Flock, where Atrea was wont to come unto him, and where they ued to hade themelves from the corching Sunne in the heat of the day. Briefly, this Propect preented to his eye, all thoe contentments which hee had been o long deprived of: And in contemplation of them hee ate down under a hady tree, and ighed out thee Veres.

lg.l: YOnder's the place my fairet Sun
Did blis mee, 'fore the day begun:
Whilt th'other like a luggard lept,
Or out of drouie bed was crept;
She crown'd with Violet and Roe,
Did there her early elf repoe,
And with her elf uch light did bring
As made thoe fields appear a Spring.
The other Sun with his hot rayes
Such over-corching heat diplays,
As dryes and withers every plant,
And makes the Ploughmans heart to pant.
My Sun with influence o weet
Such onely as have ouls doe greet;
On thoe he never heat imparts,
But burneth onely Lovers hearts.

l.hi: Yonder's the Fountain which doth claim
From Sycamors, a borrowed Name;
There did my Shepheardee Divine,
Whilt her fair hand was linkt in mine.
Anwer my Love in equal flame,

lg.l: Celadon hall ne'r forget the ame.

l.hi: For there he vow'd to her, and wore
Eternally her to adore.

lg.l: Under yond preading leaved tree,
Which haddowed both her and me,
Puret vermilion there did eek
For harbour in her lovely cheek
When he did bluh for hame, to hear
A Shepheard wear, that he was fair.
No, no, aid he to me, for I
Fair would be onely in thy eye.
But O, thou hollow Rock, where we
So oft have been in ecrecie:
Where is that Love which we did vow,
And what becometh of it now?
Did he and I the gods adore,
And all in vain their help implore?
Have I not reaon to complain,
Since he does pay me with didain?
And thou old Tree, whoe barkie leather
Defends thee from the tormy weather,
To thee I doe addres my plaint,
And doe this ad divorce lament.
How oft did we our Letters hide
Within thy old worm-eaten ide?
But now, alas, too plain I ee
Both thou and he all changed bee.

div.p: Thee thoughts and imaginations had kept Celadon longer in that place, but for the coming of a diconolate Shepheard, who pittifully lamenting his loe, came towards him, ighing out thee Veres.

lg.head: Upon too over-oon a Death.

lg.l: YOu that my weeping eyes do ee,
Did you but know what miery Has well'd my heart,
In lieu of blaming me you would
Adde all the orrows that you could, And take my part.
Within the gloomy hade of death
The fairet that had ever breath Inhabits now.
VVhy hould not detiny, o tart,
As well my body as my heart, That place allow.
No ooner he her elf did how
Amongt us mortals here below, But he was gone:
So as it eemeth he was ent
Onely to make us all lament, And her bemoan.
As loving I vy clings about
A wither'd Tree when life is out, Even o would I:
And live contentedly I could,
If cloe to her but cling I could Untill I dy.

div.p:
Celadon having no mind to be een by any that could know him, when hee pied this Shepheard a good ditance off, he concealed himelf behinde a thick buh, and when hee was pat, he followed him at an uneen ditance, untill he aw him it down, and then hee crept o neare that hee could heare all his ad complaints. The humour of this unknowne Shepheard ympathizing with his own, it welled him with a curioity to know omthing from him both concerning his own Mitris, and his alo. Therefore going to him, he began to peak thus, Sad Shepheard, I doe wih thee joy with all my heart, ince I can doe no more, I hope thou wilt take my wih in good part; and in requital of my love, I pray thee tell me whether thou doet know Atrea, Phillis, and Lycidas; and if thou dot, then tell me all thou knowet of them. Kinde Shepheard, anwered hee, thy civil language obliges me to pray, that thou mayt never have any uch occaion of orrows as I have: And I will freely tell thee all I doe know concerning thoe perons you mention, although my own grief forbids me to meddle in any other buinee but my own. It is about a month or ix weeks, ince I came into this Country of Forrets, not as many doe, to try what the Fountain of Loves verity will hew me; for I am but too certain of my ad fate; but by the commandment of the gods, who from the fertile banks of the famous Siene, ent mee hither with aurance that I hould here finde a remedy againt my mieries: And ever ince I came, I have taken up my lodging in uch Villages as eemed mot agreeable to my condition and humour, with a reolution to tay as long as the heavens hall permit me. This deign hath moved me to enquire of all the Shepheards and Shepheardees of thee parts: I am able to atisfie you in any thing you deire to know of them. All I deire to know, aid Celadon, is to be atisfied how they doe. All of them, aid he, are well; but they are all troubled very much at one act of blind and fickle Fortune; and that is, at the loe of one Celadon (a Shepheard altogether unknown to me) who was the Brother of Lycidas: This lot Shepheard was o loved and eteemed of every one, that he is generally lamented by all, epecially by thoe three perons whom you named unto me. It was conceived that this Shepheard was a devoted ervant unto Atrea, and it was the enmity of their Parents which hindered them from Marriage. How is it reported, aid Celadon, this Shepheard was lot? It is variouly reported, anwered he; Some peake as opinion leads them, others according to circumtances and appearance; and ome, as others doe report: So as it is divers wayes related. As for me, I came hither into thee quarters the very ame day he was lot; and I doe remember that every one was o affrighted at the accident, as none knew how to make a perfect relation of it. In concluion (and that is the bet received opinion becaue Phillis, Atrea, and Lycidas themelves doe ay it) that this Shepheard leeping cloe by the River ide, he fel in, and Atrea alo, but her clothes did ave her. Celadon imagining that they had prudently invented this report, to take away occaion of talking ill upon the accident, he was very glad; for his feares alwayes were, that reports would reflect much upon Atrea's honour, and therefore hee asked him further; But what doe they think, aid he, is become of this Shepheard? That hee is dead (anwered the ad Shepheard) And I aure you, Atrea takes it o adly, that though hee puts the bet face of it he can, yet every one aies, it is almot incredible, that hee hould be o much changed; however, for ought I ee, he is o fair that (except Diana hinders her) I never aw any fairer, except my dearet Cleon, and indeed they three may well be compared together. Every one, aid Celadon, will peake well of his own Mitris; and Love has a quality, not onely to blind, but to change the eyes of Lovers; o as there was never any Lover that thought his Mitris ugly. This, anwered the Shepheard, were omething, if I were in love with Atrea or Diana; but ince I am ever incapable of that, I may be a
competent judge: And you who eem to doubt of this Shepheardees beauty, you mut needs be either a tranger, or ele ome ill-willer. I am neither of thoe two, aid Celadon, but truly I am the mot mierably afflicted Shepheard that is in the whole world. I hall never grant that, aid Tircis, unlee you except me: For if your miery proceed from any thing ele but Love, the pain cannot be o great as mine, ince the heart is the mot tender part we have, and is mot enible of any orrows: And though your miery doe proceed from love, yet it mut needs ubmit unto mine; for of all the mieries in love, depair is the mot intolerable; didain, anger, hatred, jealouie, abence, or any thing is hort of death; for this pale Goddee with her fatall hand, does cut away both hope and life; o as I the mot mierable amongt all men living, doe complain of a miery without any remedy or hope. Celadon anwered with a deep igh, Oh Shepheard, how much doe you erre in your opinion? I doe confes that the greatet mieries are thoe which doe proceed from Love, of which I have had a full experience: But I cannot by any means allow that thoe mieries which are without hope are the mot ad; nor indeed doe they deerve to bee reented; for it is a meer act of folly to weep for a thing which cannot bee helped. And Love, anwered hee, what is that but a meer folly? I will not enter upon that, aid Celadon, before we have done with the other; for that alone will take up much time. But I pray tell me, Doe you lament this death out of love, or not? Certainly out of love, anwered he. If it be out of love, anwered Celadon, then I have heard Silvander, and all our learned Shepheards ay, that Love is nothing but a deire to enjoy that beauty which you find in the peron loved. 'Tis very true, aid the tranger: Then, replyed Celadon, Will any reaonable man deire a thing which cannot bee had? No certainly, aid Tircis. Then, aid Celadon, the death of Cleon ought to be the cure of all your grief; for ince you confee that deire never ought to be where there is no hope of obtaining; and that Love is nothing ele but a deire; Death, which puts you out of all hopes to enjoy, ought by conequence to put you out of all deire; and deire being dead, all Love hould die with it. The ad Shepheard anwered, that whatoever he aid, he was ure that his miery was mot extream; and becaue he would not revive the memory of his dead Cleon, hee would not argue the matter any longer, onely thus farre hee aid, Shepheard, that which comes under ence is more certain than that which is onely in opinion: And therefore all thoe reaons which he alleged could not convince him of that which he was o enible of: So recommending him unto the tuition of Pan, Celadon and he parted: And Solitude being mot uitable to a Lovers thoughts, Celadon went on through the Woods untill hee came to the Bridge of Boutree: and paing over the River there, he was in doubt which way to wend; but this was his full reolution, to obey Atrea, who had forbidden him to ee her, untill he did command him. At lat, being come near Bonleiu, the habitation of the chat Vetals, hee was ahamed that he had o rahly approached that place; and therefore intending to goe farther off, hee went into a Wood, o thick and boggy, that hee had much adoe to get out again. This forced him to draw nearer the River; for the thinne gravel was lee troubleome to him than the thick mud: So walking along, untill hee was weary, hee looked for a convenient place to ret upon, intending to keep o cloe untill night that none hould ee him: At the lat, hee cat his eye upon a little Cave, whoe entrance on one ide towards the River the water had wahed; and the other ide was o covered with Trees and Buhes, as thoe in the way could not ee it; nor had he himelfe taken notice of it, had hee not gone along the River ide. The place did o pleae him, that he reolved to pae away the ret of the day in it, and not to come out of this Grotto untill night: And therefore hee beganne to trim it up as well as he could, removing the Rubbih which the River had brought into it. The place was nothing ele but a Rock, which the water beating upon, had by degrees worn away, and made a Cave, and that in uch various Rooms, as if it were done on purpoe; o as tooping a little, hee entred into a room like a Bed-chamber: the place was about ix or even paces in length, and as much broad: It was about the height of a man, though in ome places, the points of the Rock were troubleome, which the Shepheard did by degrees break off with a Flint: Hec contrived himelf a place like a bed, which he covered with Moe; and having fitted all things in this manner, he laid his coat, and uch things as troubled him, upon his bed, and then looking upon the ground, he found a Letter, which he knew to be from the fair Atrea, which hee did let fall. Hee rouzed up himelfe, as out of a deep leep, and came into the entrance of the Cave, where looking upon the dear paper which he held in his hands, after a hundred zealous and amorous kies, hee aid; Oh thou mot deare paper, heretofore my great
joy, and now the occaion of my mot bitter orrowes: Upon this, opening it, the firt thing that preented it elfe to his eye, was Atrea's Character joyned with his: This did o frehly revive the memory of his former happinee, as now he was reduced almot unto tearms of depair. Oh ye Characters, (aid he) too true tetimonies of my misfortune, why are you not eparated from mine, to wait upon the will of my fair Shepheardes? Time was, when you might have done me good ervice; but now, that uch fatall dyaters have eparated us, why are you here? Perhaps it is to make it appear, that the heavens howre all their dyaterous influences upon me, but can never make my will ditinct from Atrea's. Upon this, he at down upon a great tone, which he had rouled out of the River, to the entrance into the Grotto; and then, after he had wiped away all the tears from his eyes, he read thee enuing words.

body.head: Atrea's Letter unto Celadon.
body.p: HEavens grant, Celadon, that thoe aurances which you have given me of your affection, may continue for ever: And I do paionately deire you to believe, that I do hold you more dear than if you were my Brother, and am yours to my very grave.

div.p: Thee few words of Atrea's, caued abundance of miery unto Celadon; for after he had many times read them over, they did make his wounds to bleed afreh; for, he recollected into his memory one after one, all the favours that ever this Shepheardee did him, which moved him unto o much regreet, as had not night approached, he had not uffered his eyes to ceae from crying, or his tongue from complaining, againt what his heart uffered; but darknee caued him to enter into his Cave, and being very weary with walking and grieving, he fell aleep. Two daies were pat, before this ad Shepheard ever thought of eating; for he was o taken up with ad thoughts, and his mind was o full of melancholly, as he never thought upon any meat, but was o ditempered with tears, that his eyes eemed two Fountains: and had he not feared offending the gods, in cauing his own death, and wore, in thereby loing the Idea of his fair Atrea, doubtlee he had ended the coure of his life; but eeing he was contrained unto it, he did viit that bag of victualls which Leonida had furnihed him withall, which proviion lated him many daies; for he did eat as little as poible he could: At lat, he was contrained to have recoure unto roots and fallads. All the day long, if he aw none neer his olitary habitation, he would walk upon the gravelly hore, and often engraved the caue of his orrowes upon the bark of Trees; ometimes he would engrave Atrea's Characters and his own; then upon a udden would he deface them, aying, Thou art deceived, Celadon, this is not a time for Characters: for thou art till contant, and, to thy grief all things ele are changed. Let all thoe tetimonies of pat happines alone; and if thou wilt needs be writing in Characters, engrave with them thy tears, thy orrowes and thy death, as mot uitable unto thy condition. When night came, then his ad thoughts came freher into his memory for darknes being more it for it, his imagination was the tronger; nor did he ever retire, unles it was night and if the Moon hined, he would walk all night long, and ometimes inde himelfe aleep under a tree in the morning. Thus this ad Shepheard, leading this diconolate life, he was grown o pale and lean, that he was not knowable; and ometimes when he went unto a Fountain to drink, he would wonder to ee himelfe in the water; his hair was grown all into diorder, his eyes hrunk, his noe harp and long, o as it was a wonder he hould live. Oh! had Atrea een him in this ad condition, what abundance of content would it have been unto her, to ee by undeniable arguments, that he was perfectly loved by the mot faithfull and compleat Shepheard of all Lignon.

The Moon had been twice at the full, ince Celadon ecaped out of Galathea's hands; and till, in obedience to the commands of Atrea, he durt not preent himelfe unto her, but enlked himelfe in his Grotto: And though three months were compleatly pat ince his loe, yet, the reentments of it were o freh in the oul of his Shepheardee, that all her prudent circumpection was not able to conceal it, from uch as had any obervance over her. It eems, heaven, as a punihment upon her, denyed her that remedy, which Time uually affords unto thoe that are ubject unto orrow; for, in lieu of allaying the bitternee of it, he did daily dicover new occaions, and matter for her griefe, and when any reentments did divert her memory of them, her eyes would then ix themelves upon
no objects, but uch as were ad; which to avoid, he kept her elfe mot commonly in her Cabin: But, her greatet affliction was, he was deprived of that conolation, which is found, even in the greatet misfortunes; I mean, he could not lay the fault upon any but her elf, nor could he find out any excue to turn it another way: And certainly, it had bin abolutely impoible for her to have lived under uch a load of griefs, if the ociety of Diana & Phillis had not helped her to bear the burthen; for the preence of reall friends, is doubtlee one of the mot overaigne remedies that griefe can receive; and thee two reall friends not being ignorant of it, they had o great a care of her, that one or both of them were continually with her; they would pull her out of her Chamber by force, and carry her into the mot unfrequented places, for unto others they would not, let they hould meet with ome accidents, which might bring Celadon afreh into her memory; o as thee kinde Shepheardees did weeten many an houre, and tole many a bitter minute from Atrea.

Silvander on the other ide, under pretence of a faigned addree unto Diana, did fall o extreamly in reall love with her, as he hath been an excellent example unto all the Country, and, at his own expences taught them this Doctrine, that Love will not be jeated withall. He findes now o many compulive caues of love in that Shepheardee, as he admires he hould be acquainted with her o long, and love her no ooner: And though this task of courthip which he had undertaken, was the Origen of his dieae; yet, he made no complaint, becaue Diana, without any offence, allowed him liberty to expree his paion; for uch was the violence of his love, that if it had not been allowed ome vent, it would have broke him, and he could not poibly have lived without it. When he conulted with himelfe, he plainly aw, that he had made a diadvantageous change, epecially when he remembered how happy he was, an abolute Mater of himelfe; oft did he muter up all his arguments drawn from reaon, to rid himelfe from this new ervitude; and when he found that reaon was too weak to do it, he would arme himelfe with violent reolutions againt it. But alas! look how oft he tryed all thee waies o oft did he ee, that it is in vain for any man to trive agant the ordinances of heaven; and that whoo is wie, will rather comply and ubmit his will thereunto. And therefore every morning and night, when civility denyed him Diana's company, he ued to retire himelfe from all manner of company, as well, becaue all the world without her was irkome unto him, as to conult more freely with himelfe, and to conider, which way he had bet take, to effect his deires: And though he aw many impoibilities in the puruit of his affection yet, for all that, he could fix upon no reolutions, which concluded not in advantage of his love: If at any time he tarted a deigne to make a retreat, Oh, how uddenly would his heart give a check unto himelfe? If he determined to purue, Oh, what difficulties, what rubs, and how many Martyrdoms did he foreee? What hall we do, Silvander, (would he ay to himelfe) ince both puruit and retreat are equally impoible? Then would he ay in anwer to himelfe: Thy bet way is to do, as the heavens they would have thee. Can it be imagined, that the heavens would ever have made her o admirably fair, but only, that all thoe who ee her, hould love her? And ince in going both forward and backward, thou findet equall impoibility, chue that coure which is mot agreeable to the will of heaven and to thy elfe. She is made o fair, purpoely to be loved and adored; and for my part, I will far ooner quit my life, then her ervice. What then needs any further conultation, ince the will of heaven and my own, do o well agree upon it?

As he was in dicoure with himelfe, he chanced to be neer the pleaant River of Lignon, oppoite to a Rock, which reounded an Eccho, that ditinctly anwered to the lat yllable of every entence: And therefore, after much turbulency of pirit, he roued up himelfe, as if awakned out of a dream, and aid, Why hould I thus turmoile my elfe in o many ravelled contrarieties? The Eccho which inhabits in this place, will tell me what it hath heard from the mouth of my fairet Shepheardee; and therefore it is the mot infallible Oracle which I can conult withall. Then clearing up his voice, he began to enquire thus of it.

lg.head: ECCHO,

l.hi: TEll me, where goes my cries and care,
Thou blabbing Daughter of the Air?

lg.l: To the Air.

l.hi: Do't think my heart, which Torments nure,
A better End will meet, or wore?

lg.l: Wore.

l.hi: What then doth mean that charming eye,
Which eemes to love eternally?

lg.l: A Lie.

l.hi: If o, then what will me recover,
And from my Errour me deliver?

lg.l: Leave her.

l.hi: How! leave her, ait thou, to another?
How can I leave her, when I love her?

lg.l: Love her.

l.hi: The bet advice that thou couldt frame:

lg.l: But, did Diana ay the ame?
The ame.

l.hi: Had he but aid, that he did Love,
Oh! then I hould mot happy prove?

lg.l: Happy prove.

l.hi: And o I hould, could I but finde,
That thou wert ure this is her minde?

lg.l: This is her minde.

div.p:
Although Silvander knew well enough, that he was his own Anwerer, and that the Aire being beaten by his voice into the concavities of the Rock, was reverberated into his ears; yet could he not chue, but reent great conolation from the aupicious Anwers which he received; conceiving, that nothing was governed by Chance, but all by an Allwie Providence, and therefore he believed thoe words which the Rock returned to his ear, were inpired into his tongue by ome good Demon, that loved him; o as in this opinion, he followed the cutome of all Lovers, who ue to flatter themelves in what they deire, and find uch hopes out of very bare appearances, in which there in no appearance of reaon. After he had given thanks unto the Genius of the Rocks, and to the Nymphs of Lignon, he intended to go and preent himelfe unto his Shepheardee, at the field of Mercury, for there he ued to call, in her way to Atrea; and as he winded his coure that way, he epied afar off the Nymph Leonida, and the generous Paris, who hearing his voice turned towards him, as well to enquire of the Shepheardees Atrea Diana, and Phillis, as to enjoy his good company: For though Paris did well enough know what affection he bore unto Diana; yet did he love and eteem him very much, becaue he could never believe, that that wie and dicreet Shepheardee could prefer him before himelfe, by reaon of the grandure of Adamas, who for his quality of Grand Druide, was, next unto Amais, the mot honoured by all the Country: never conidering, that Love ueth not to meaure by the Ell of Ambition or Merit, but by opinion only. Silvander, whoe education in the Phocencian and Maellian Univerities, had compleatly civilized, though the meeting of Paris was but halfe pleaing to him, yet he turned to the Nymph and him, to alute them. I need not ask you (aid Leonida unto him, and miled) what thoughts entertained you in this olitary place, for I am ure, that Diana was the chiefe: But I would gladly know, why you do prefer the thoughts before the fight of her; and what occaions does invite you from her preence? I will not deny, Madam, aid he unto her, but that thoe pleaing thoughts whereof you peak, were my deer companions, as well in this place as every where ele, when I am abent from Diana: But, that I hould think them more deer unto me then the ight of her, give me leave to tell you, that though it ought to be o, yet I have not obtained o much Matery of my elfe; and though you now ee me without her, it is only to pae away more weetly in contemplation thoe houres, which her r • pat does contrain me to be abent from her: And indeed, I was jut now going unto
her, at the field of Mercury: for now's the time he ueth to be there, in her way to Atrea, and my intention was to wait upon her. And we (anwered Leonida) came with reolutions, to pend the remainder of this day with thoe fair Shepheardees; and therefore I beeech you, Shepheard, conduct us thither; and by the way, tell us, why the thoughts of her you adore, ought to be more dear unto you then her preence, which is the firt caue of them? For my part, I conceive it o dicordant to reaon, that I cannot imagine how it hould be.

Silvander, in obedience to her commands, hewing a Path-way which was a nearer cut thorough a great Meadow, began thus to reply; The quetion, Great Nymph, is of no uch great difficulty to be undertood, if it be but taken as it ought; for it is mot certain that the eyes are the doores by which Love firt enters into our oules. If any doe fall in love upon report of beauty and perfection of abent parties, that is either a love not lating: nor violent, being rather a haddow than any real love; or ele the oul which received it, had ome grand defect in it elf; for reports having commonly as many falehoods as truths, that judgement which builds upon any uch uncertain foundation, cannot bee found, nor proceed from a well-tempered oul; but as that which produceth a thing, is not the ame which gives it nutriment, and makes it grow up to perfection, o it may be rightly aid of Love. Our Ewes bring forth their Lambs, who at firt doe eek a little nutriment from their Milk, yet it is not that Milk which brings them up unto perfection, but it is a more olid nutriment which they receive from the grae which they feed upon: So likewie the eyes may conceive and produce a green infant-affection, but there mut be omething more olid and ubtantial to make it grow unto perfection, and that mut be by a knowledge of the virtues, beauties, merits, and a reciprocal affection of the party loved. Now this knowledge does take its originall indeed from the eyes, but it mut bee the oul which mut afterwards bring it to the ret of judgement, and by the tetimonies both of eyes and eares, and all other coniderations, concoct a verity, and o ground upon it. If this verity bee to our advantage, then it produceth in us uch thoughts, whoe weetnee cannot be equalled by another kinde of contentment than the effects of the ame thoughts. If it be onely advantageous to the party loved, then doubtlee it doth augment our affection, but yet with violence and inquietude: and therefore no quetion but abence doth augment love, o it bee not o long as that the very image of the party loved be quite effaced; Whether it be that an abent Lover never repreents unto his fancy but onely the perfections of the peron loved; or whether it bee, that the undertanding being already wounded will not fancy any thing but what pleaeth it; or whether it be that the very thought of uch things does adde much unto the perfections of the party loved: Yet this is infallibly true, that he does not truly love, whoe affection does not augment in abence from the peron loved. For my part (anwered Leonida) My judgement is much different from yours, and I have ever been of opinion, that abence is the greatet, and mot dangerous enemy which Love hath. Preence, replied the Shepheard, is without comparion much more, as wee may ee by dayly experience; for you hall find a hundred loves that change in preence, for one in abence; and to demontrate, that preence is more enemy unto love, conider, that if one abent ceae loving, its ceation i • without any violence of trugling, and the change is onely becaue the memory is by degrees mothered with oblivion, as a fire is with its own ahes; but when love breaks off in preence, it is never without a noie and extream violence, and (which is a trange argument • o prove my aertion) converts that love into a greater hatred than if the love had never be • n And that proceeds from this reaon; A lover is alwaies either loved or hated, or held in a degre of indifferency; if he be loved, as abundance is apt to glut, o love being loaden in preence with too many favours, grows weary: If hee be hated, then hee meets with o many demontrations of that hate every minute, as at length he is forced to eae himelf If hee be in a degree of indifferency, and finds his love till lighted, he will at length, if he be a man of any courage, make a retreate, and reit the continuall affronts which are put upon him; whereas in abence, all favours received cannot by their abundance glut, ince they do rather et an edge upon deire: And the knowledge of hatred entring into our ouls onely by the ear, the blow marts not o much as that which is received by ight: and likewie didain and light, bee much more tolerable in abence than in preence; doubtlee therefore abence is much more fit to preerve affection than preence is. I mut needs confee (anwered the Nymph) that there happens many accidents in preence which detroyes love, that abence is exempted from. But for all that, you cannot perwade
me, but that I mut needs think the ight of the party loved, does augment love much more, than by not eeing her; for carrees and favours are the food of love; and thoe which are conferred in preence, are far greater, and more enibly obliging, than any others. I thought, Madam (anwered the Shepheard) that I had already ufficiently anwered your demand; but ince it is your pleaure to deire more clear reaons, I hall endeavour to give them. It hath already been aid, that Love doth firt begin at the eyes, but it is not the eyes that doth nourih it: Beauty and goodnee without any more, give it a growth in us, when they are once known: Now the knowledge of this Beauty indeed comes firt by the eyes; but when that knowledge is once in our ouls, wee may love afterwards without the help of eyes, which you will eaily grant if ever you were in love: Conider, and tell mee, would you loe your love if you lot your eyes? No, certainly, and therefore you mut needs confee, it is not your eyes which does preerve your love. As for the knowledge of goodnes it is produced either by actions, or by words, both which doe tand in need of preence, to be firt known, but afterwards not at all; for that knowledge is afterwards preerved in the ecret Cabinet of the memory, whereupon a oul does afterwards ufficiently feed. Then I beleeve you know, Madam, that the more knowledge one hath of the party loved, the more doth love encreae; but then, it is apparent, that the turbulent motion of the enes, doe infinitely hinder the clearnee of the undertanding; and as the plummets of a Clock, the one cannot acend unlee the other doe decend, o when the enes are up, the undertanding part mut needs bee down and o the contrary, when the enes are abent, the Intellectuals are bet preent, and does work more perfectly than they would if they were diturbed by any objects of the eye, which is able to doe nothing ele but look, and deire, and igh. If you would think eriouly upon any matter, has not wie Nature taught you to put your hand upon your eyes to the end that the ight hould not divert the undertanding another way? And therefore hence you mut needs conclude with me in my argument, and confes, that Love digets it elf better in abence than in preence. But if it be o, aid Paris, how comes it to pae that all Lovers hould o paionately deire the ight of them they love? It proceeds from ignorance, anwered Silvander: He cannot attribute unto himelfe the name of a Lover, who thinkes his love o great that it is impoible it hould augment: If any be of that opinion, he will never eeke after any means to increae it, nor bee in any quet of further knowledge, but rets himelfe contented with as much onely as his eye can afford him, without any deeper contemplation. But, O great Nymph, what a vat difference there is betwixt a love that is nourihed by the eyes, and a love that is nourihed by the undertanding? As much doubtles as the oul is uperiour to the body, o much is the undertanding to be preferred before the eyes. And abence in uch is o far from diminihing love, that it augments and begets freh and violent deires to augment it; and contemplation of a Beauty does imprint it deeper into the fancy than any eye can. If it be o, aid Paris, I wonder you doe not abent your elfe from Diana, to the end you may the more love her. I told you before (anwered Silvander) that I ought to doe o, but that I have not yet obtained o much matery over my elf; for, generous Paris, we are all but men, I mean all imperfect; and the imperfections of humanity are not upon a udden removed: We are all enitively inclined, and love to ee, tat, mell, and touch, and mut needs hanker after thee corporal enes. This is the point unto which I have not yet arrived, and unto which I ought. Reaon will forbid uch coniderations, and bid us act all by the intellectual faculties: Nature betowed the enes upon us onely for intruments, by which the oul may receive the knowledge of things, but not to be our companions in the pleaures and felicities of them, as being altogether incapable of o great a good.

This dicoure had continued longer, if they had not by chance heard Phillis ing neare the field of Mercury: Shee was itting with another Shepheardee under a hady tree, looking upon their Flocks as they were feeding untill the heat of the day was over. As oon as Silvander heard her tone hee turned his head that way and knowing them, hee turned his head again o uddenly, that Leonida could not chue but mile. What doe you hear and ee aid he, which caueth you to turn your head o quickly away? I have een, Madam, aid he, her whom I never ee without orrow: Phillis I meane, the mot cruel of my enemies, ince he is the caue of my ervitude. At the very ame time, Lycidas was walking the ame way, and was upon them before he was aware. Jealouie which made him fly all company, made him hun Silvander more than any other; but now Civility contrained him to alute Leonida and Paris, and being invited to follow them, though at firt he would have
deired their pardon with ome frivolous excues: But Leonida, who loved him for Celadous ake, was o importunate with him, that he was forced to make one in the company: And Paris, who was very deirous to know where Diana was, did ask him, if he knew who it was that was with Phillis under that hady Tree. Lycidas, who had not yet taken notice of them, looked, and then anwered, that it was Atrea. Then going on their way, Leonida reumed the dicoure, which he had begun with Silvander; And why Shepheard, aid he unto him, are you o offended againt that Shepheardes? for though hee be the caue of your love, yet is hee alo the caue of your becoming a more accomplihed man: And I beleeve you will confes that love is able to adde much ornament unto our oules; and if it be o you are rather much obliged unto her. I mut needs confee, anwered Silvander, that I believe without Phillis, I had not fallen in love; but I mut tell you withall, that he is the caue that I have lot my liberty, and am lee my own than hers whom I adore: And I mut alo tell you, that liberty is of o high a price, that I am not o much obliged to her for making me more accomplihed, as I am diobliged to her for the loe of my dear and deirable freedom. But, added the Nymph, by her means you may perhaps obtain the affection of her whom you adore and love. And a well born oul, as yours is, will et uch a value upon that, be it at any rate whatoever, as he cannot complain againt her who is the caue of it; A well born and generous oul, replyed he, will not upon any termes thank her who is the caue of her ervitude; for ervitude, be it in what degree it will, is till ervitude. At the firt when Lycidas heard Phillis named, he tood till with much attention, but after he had heard all the dicoure and replyes of Silvander, he did beleeve that he really loved her; and not being able to hide his Jealouie as he deired, he could not chue but ay unto him, I beeech you, Shepheard, tell mee, Doe you indeed love this Shepheardee o much as you eem to doe? Silvander, who never thinking of Lycidas, had talked thus unto Leonida, and knowing that this quetion did proceed from Jealouie, hee had a minde to keep him till in his doubt, and therefore would not either deny, or confee what he asked, but onely aid thus unto him; I beeech you, Lycidas, tell mee what you doe think? I ee anwered he, o many diimulations, that my judgment cannot determine any certainty upon them. Since my diimulations, aid Silvander, doe blind your judgement, I beeech you tell me, what is your deire? My deires, anwered Lycidas are not any thing dependant upon you, whoe actions are very indifferent unto me: and therefore, I referre them unto your own imaginations. Since you are not pleaed to acquaint me with your will, aid Silvander, if I doe any thing which hall dipleae you, blame your elf only, and arm your elf with patience. Lycidas would have replyed, and perhaps omewhat harply, if Leonida, who foreaw it, had not hindred him with an excue that he was deirous to hear Phillis ing; for they were o neare as to hear her words, which were thee,

lg.l: CUpid with left hand hot awry,
His Bow did tart, his Arrows fly
Mot commonly too low or high,
And fayleth in his Archery.
Or if he hit the mark, I fear
That all his Arrows poyon'd were,
In lieu of Love did Frenzy bear;
For Jealouies no other are.
If Lovers needs mut Jealous be,
And from uch venome ne'r be free,
Then fie upon't, my Prayer hall be,
From Love good Lord deliver me.

div.p:
Silvander intending to make Lycidas as Jealous as poibly he could, and eeing Phillis very attentive upon her Song, alo Atrea upon thoe thoughts which this Song revived in her memory, he left Leonida, and ran unto her; fell down upon his knees, kied her hand,
then roe up and acquainted her with the comming of Leonida and Paris. Phillis had not o much leaure as to check him for his rude intruion, becaue Leonida was o neer, that he was forced to rie, and pay that civill duty which was due unto her. Silvander offered to lead her by the arme, but he eeing Lycidas in the company, did repule him, which was no mal wound in the oul of the jealous Lycidas, who perceiving that Phillis aw him, did believe, that he repuled him only, becaue it was in his preence. But after all complements of all ides were performed, all of them at down under a hady tree, and Silvander reolving to add fewell unto the jealouie of Lycidas he fell down upon his knees before Phillis: Well, my fair hepheardee, aid he unto her, how long is it your pleaure our war hall continue? What terme have you limited unto my ervices? How long will you delight in thoe pains which you have caued me to endure? Though you do imploy all your Art and Armes againt me, yet, I hope in the end the victory will be mine. Phillis knew well enough, that this hepheards peeches had relation only unto the wager that was between them, who hould love Diana bet, and therfore received his expreion, in that ence they ought to be undertood. But Lycidas, who thought that this wager was only an invention betwixt them, to umbrage their affection, he took it in another ence. Which he plainly perceiving, he cat her eyes alwaies upon him, and to undeceive him in his opinion, anwered Silvander in this manner: Shepheard, Shepheard, there is no uch neceity of uing all my power to vanquih you, in the wager that is betwixt us, and therefore I dare aume o much confidence as to tell you, that I hall get the victory. Silvander knew what Phillis deigned, and therefore, by way of contradiction, anwered her: None can be ignorant of your power and Silvander, the leat of any Shepheard about L • gno • , ince he hath o often reented the effects of your beauty. If it be o, replyed he, you are like unto thoe that blinde themelves with looking at the Sun, when as the Sun is not in any fault, nor ever mindes them. Ah Shepheardes, anwered he, whoo does behold the Sun-hine of your eyes, and is not blinded, is unworthy to behold it. I cannot tell (aid Phillis, and bluhed at his words) what your deigne is in peaking thus, but I am ure, our Mitres hall be acquainted with thee disembling expreions, which, ince the wager is to be determined very hortly, I am very confident will cot you very deer, and then you will feel the mart of over late repentance. Do not think, Shepheardes, aid he, that I hall ever repeat of any expreions of my affection to you, but on the contrary, I ought rather to be orry, that I have been o long without any declaration of it, and ought not to fear the menaces wherewith you threaten me. Phillis knew well enough, and Atrea alo, that he mocked her; but that was no atisfaction to the upition which thee words did kindle in the minde of Lycidas, who perceiving how Phillis was netled at them, was the more fortified in his opinion. At the lat, he aid unto him. I think, Silvander, that you have laid a wager, that you would dipleae me with this language; or ele you come to practie upon me what you hall ay unto your Mitres. If that be his aime, aid Atrea, his bet way would be, to be plain, and peak unto you, as if you were Diana her elfe, and not to diemble o unto you. Nay, nay, aid Silvander, that's all one, my aime is to let her undertand the qualitie of my affection. And then he prepared himelfe to proceed. I conjure you aid Phillis, by her, whom of all the world you love mot, to let me be quiet, and content your elfe, that I do know more of your affection, then you can expree. Thee conjurations, aid he, are too powerfull to be contradicted, and the declaration which you have made too advantageous, not to content me; and therefore ince it is your pleaure, I am ilent. You do oblige me by it, aid Phillis, for I cannot endure your language; it is more fit you went and helped Diana, whom I left in her Cabin, much troubled about her beloved Lamb Floretta, which is dead, or neer it. If you command me, replyed Silvander, and will undertake the charge of my flock till I return, I will go unto her. Nay, aid Phillis, if that be all, I do command you; and will undertake the charge of your flock. Then Silvander, as if he durt not diobey what he commanded, went unto the place where Diana was, leaving Phillis very glad of his departure, and Lycidas the mot jealous Shepheard in all the Country: For, though Silvander's language did much dipleae, yet, the dipleaures which he oberved in Phillis, were much more tinging; and her conjuring him by the peron whom he mot loved, was mot of all offenive to him: But her taking the charge of his flock upon her, this action pierced him to the very heart and yet the poor Shepheardee did all this, only becaue he thought Silvande • 's language was offenive unto Lycidas. Thus ee, how our deignes do ometimes produce effects quite contrary to our intentions.

Mean time Silvander coming to the Cabin of his Shepheardee, he found all that Phillis had aid was true; for he found Diana itting upon the ground, with her beloved heep in her lap, which eemed to be dead, ometimes rubbing it, ometimes putting alt into its mouth, but all to no purpoe, for the heep tumbled upon the ground, and lay for dead, which grieved the Shepheardee very much, for he loved it above all the ret. When he was out of all hopes, and perhaps accued ome of her neighbours of Witchcraft, for looking upon it with ome malevolent eye; Silvander came in, and after a alute asked her, what he did upon the ground? You may ee without asking me, aid he if you do but look in what a condition my dear Floretta is in. The Shepheard kneeled down, looked eriouly upon it, and topped its noe with one of his fingers, to hinder it from breathing: But aoon as it was let alone, after a little faint neez, it began to turn round about untill it fell. Silvander having dicovered its dieae, looked very jocundly upon Diana: Trouble not your elfe, fair Mitree aid he unto her, your beloved Floretta will recover again; it dieae is not caued by any Witchcraft, but rather by the heat of the Sun, which having offended the brain, hath caued this dieae, which is called the Vertigo, a convulion of the nerves, which have their cource from the brain, and caueth them to go round. Time doubtlee will cure it, without any other Phyick; but yet I know a Simple, which growes in the next Meadow, which will be an infallible cure, which, if you pleae to give me leave. I will apply. Pleae (aid the Shepheardee, glad of the good newes) yes with all my heart; and that I may be acquainted with that herb againt another time, I will go with you. I hall be mot glad of that, replyed he, in a double repect; the one, in doing you an acceptable piece of ervice; the other, in having your company, which I hall think the bet betowed part of my time. Upon this, they left the heep in cutody of thoe in the Cabin, and went to gather this Plant: Diana all the way gave the Shepheard thanks for his good will: And Silvander having by chance oberved the Plant as he came, he went preently to it again, and gathering a good quantity, they queezed the juice of it into the ears of the Sheep, which had no ooner received it, but it immediately began to hake its head, and after two or three neezes, it began to bleat, and call for the ret of his fellowes, and began to eat. But Silvander taking it by the neck, did put it into a room by it elfe, and wihed Diana not to let it come out all that day, by reaon of the Sun's heat. Diana not contenting her elfe with the cure of her beloved heep, and with the knowledge of the herb, would yet by any means know the name of it. The Plant, replyed Silvander, hath many names; ome give it the name of Cla • e, others Cleer-eye, or All-good; and we call it Scarliol, or wild End've. But I beeech you, why are you not as carefull to preerve all that is your, as this beloved heep? When I ee them ill, aid he, I will apply the remedy, not only unto my own, but unto any's ele, aoon as I can. I would you were as willing to do o, replyed he, as I ee you are the contrary. Good Silvander, replyed Diana, do not poil the courtey you have done me in curing my deer Floretta, by injuring me with uch a thought: but we had better go, and eek out my Companions, who doubtlee are all in much trouble for me. Upon this, he went to the field of Mercury, full of joy for the cure of her heep; and by the way he undertood, that Leonida and Paris were with thoe Shepheardees, unto whom he went: Preently after, he aw them all comming towards her; for Paris hearing of Diana's griefe, deired all the company to go unto her, and try if they could give any good advice for the cure of her heep: But when they aw her comming afar off, they tayed, uppoing the heep to be either cured or dead; and as chance was, it was jut in the field of Mercury, where foure waies met: And becaue the bais on which the tatue of Mercury did tand, was raied above the levell three teps, they at round about it, and ome looking one way, ome another, Leonida epied two Shepheards and a Shepheardee, coming, as it were from mount Verdun, who eemed to be at ome odds; for the actions of their hands, armes, and all parts, did hew them to be in ome paionate dipute, epecially the Shepheardee, who thrut from her ometimes the one, and ometimes the other, and would not hear them: ometimes they tood till and held her, as if they were deirous to make her the judge of their controvery; but he till truck away their hands on both ides, and then ran away from them, untill they overtook her again. Had they not ometimes kneeled down before her, and otherwhiles ubmiively kied her hands, to tay her; one would have thought by her flight, that they would have offered ome violence unto her. And drawing neer this tatue of Mercury, without taking any notice of the good company that was about it, Leonida hewed them unto all the company, and asked, if any knew them? I have often een them, aid Lycidas, in the
Town next adjoyning unto mount Verdun: They are not originally of that place, but trangers, whom the fortune of their Parents contrained to come and dwell in this Country. If you deire to ee a young pringing beauty, give great hopes of rare perfection, look but that Shepheardee in the face; and if you could by any means invite them to relate the difference that is betwixt them, I am confident it would prove an excellent diverion: for they are both in love with that Shepheardee, and he will not entertain either: It was once my chance to hear ome of their diputes from their own mouths, and in my judgment it was worthy of notice. The Shepheardee is called Celida, he that is the taller on the right hand, is called Thamires, and the other Calidon. Lycidas had no ooner aid this, but the trangers were o neer them, that every one perceived the reports of Lycidas concerning Celida to be mot true; for the lutre of her beauty was o admirable, as it attracted all eyes upon her; and though there might be found ome nice defect in her beauty, yet any one might judge that time would bring it unto exact perfection. Whilt every one was in a cenorious contemplation of her, Leonida, prompted by the report of Lycidas, was very deirous to know their difference; therefore he advanced towards them, and after a civill alute, invited them in the name of all the company, to it down and ret themelves upon the tairs where they did it. Celidea, who was full of civility, and knew what reverence was due unto the Nymph, and alo very glad to avoid the importunities of the two Shepheards, he did mot willingly accept of Leonida's offer: And when all were taking their places, Diana came unto them, and after all civill alutations, he at down amongt the good company. Lycidas not being able to endure, that Silvander hould it next Phillis; he tole out of the company before any took notice of him, and went to entertain his own ad thoughts in the thick of the wood. Then Leonida, having caued Celidea to it next her on one hand, and Atrea on the other, Diana at next the tranger, and Paris next her. And becaue Phillis had taken her place next the ad Atrea, Silvander was with Thamires and Calidon; and though they did not it about the tatue, yet their backs were towards the fair Shepheardees, and could not ee them. Paris and Phillis did it a little turning from them yet o, as by a little turning their bodies, they could both ee and peak unto them. Being thus ranged, Leonida eeing Celidea's modety would not permit her to peak, and intending to inpire her with more confidence, he thus broke ilence Although, fair Celidea, you were unknown unto us by ight; yet the fame of your beauty hath reached all our ears, which wells us all with extream curioity, to know both you and your fortune. Lycidas hath partly acquainted us with the difference that is betwixt you and thee two courteous Shepheards; but ince there goes various reports of it, we hould be extreamly glad to hear the truth from your own mouth. Madam, anwered the tranger, I hall be very loath to requite your civility with a tedious Hitory of our dientions; but, if the knowledge of it will any way contribute unto your ervice, I hall mot freely do it. Although the relation and remembrance of things pat, be nothing pleaing unto me; Yet, great Nymph, I cannot chue but deire, that you might entertain the time with ome other, and ome better dicoure. Madam, aid Calidon, ince this hepheardee is unwilling to undertake the atisfaction of your knowledge, I beeech you impoe the task upon me; let me be the Relator both in the preence of her and Thamires, to the end they may correct me, if I deviate from the truth. Great Nymph, aid Thamires, ince it is I that am mot interreed in the buinee, it is mot reaonable you hould receive it from my mouth. Upon that account, replyed Celidea, it belongs mot unto my elfe to be the relater, for you are both combined againt me. I finde no reaon in that, aid Calidon; for though, fair Celidea, you are againt us both, yet both of us are for you: And as for Thamires, I would have him know, that he who has mot wrong, has mot reaon to complain: And, great Nymph, it is mot peculiarly proper unto me, to inform you, of the extream injury that is done me; for it is I whom the fair Celidea hath injur'd, in refuing me, and it is Thamires that hath wronged me, in offering to ravih that from me, which Love hath ordained unto me, and he himelfe hath give me. To return your own arguments upon your elfe, aid Thamires, it is I that ought to peak, being the mot injured; I, that have reaon to complain againt Celidea, becaue he did once love me, and now does not; and againt Calidon, becaue he is the mot obliged unto me, and yet the mot ungratefull. And I, great Nymph, replyed Celidea, have mot reaon to complain, becaue I am the But, at which both their importunities and vexations are hot at, and both of them are reolved to vex me to death, rather then let me enjoy any quietnee; o as if the party mot interreed, mut mot complain, it is both their parts to be ilent, and give me the liberty
to tell my dolefull tal • . The dipute had lated longer, if Leonida, in a miling manner, had not put an end unto it: and impoing ilence, he propoed, that the difference might be decided by Lot; and all being contented, the Lot fell upon Thamires, o as all fixing their looks upon him, after an humble reverence, he began thus:

div.head: The Hitory of Celidea, Thamires, and Calidon.
div.p: SInce it hath pleaed the great Tautates, to make choice of me for a relater of the dientions that are betwixt us, I do profee, that though it be the cutom of all interreed perons to peak only what is to their own advantage; yet I will not conceal and diguie the truth in the leat manner, upon this condition, that when every one hath aid all they can for themelves, I may have liberty to alledge my own reaons apart. Be pleaed to know then, great Nymph, that though both Calidon and my elfe do dwell in that Town which adjoynes unto mount Verdun, yet we are not of that Country; our Fathers and their Predeceors are Boyens, who heretofore came out of Gaul, with the King of Belovees, and went to eek out new habitation beyond the Alpes; who, after they had planted themelves there, and continued many ages, were in the end expuled out of thoe Townes which they had built, by a people called Romans; ome being plundred of all their goods, went into Hircania; others returned into their own ravaged Country; our Ancetors came into Gaul, and at lat, linked themelves by Marriages unto the Seguians. Thus, wie Nymph, I do preent unto your knowledge, that you may the better judge, how great the amity betwixt Calidon and me ought to be; for, being both of us Boyens, both decended from the ame tock, and are Coens, both trangers, and heretofore both friends; all thee circumtances are o many inviting arguments to love one another. Alo, I do ingenuouly confee, that I did ever affect him as dearly, as if he were my own on; I may well be allowed to ue that phrae, for I have done him the offices of a kinde and good Father, having educated him with as much indulgent care, as his own Father, who was my Uncle, could; even in his Infancy, when he had not o much knowledge as to dicern good from bad, then, and ever ince, was my indulgency over him. This fair Celidea was brought up by the prudent Cleontines, a neer neighbour unto my habitation; and though he was then of an age far unlikely to caue love, (being carce nine years of age) yet I mut confee, that her Infantine actions did much pleae me, and did take me in uch an unaccutomed manner, as I uited my elfe to her own young ports; and though I was an age of years above her, yet I played with her, as if I were as young as he: How oft have I wiht us of an equall age, and that her time might go forward, and mine backward? How many times have I triven to withdraw my elfe from this vain affection? But not having power to do it, when he came at ten years old, her beauty did put forth uch hopefull budds, as I was then not ahamed at my loving an Infant: And I remember, upon this ubject, I compoed thee Lines.

lg.l: AURORA, uher to a day,
The fairet in the month of May,

l.hi: Did never promie one o gay.

lg.l: And would you early Roes pick,
And Lillies, that are timely, eek?
Behold them pringing in her Cheek,
The Sun did never rie o cleer,

l.hi: No • halfe o radiant all the Year,
As he, in budding, does appear.

lg.l: But if her Morning be o bright,
Her Noon, when Beauty is at height,
Will quite eclipe the Sun of light.
If Beauty do begin o oon,
And charme i'th Bud, before well grown,
What will it, when the Bud is blown?
I'le venture ods, that then he hall
Enflame both gods, and men, and all
And Mitree be Imperiall.
Heaven, I beeech thee, let us finde
Her heart like to her eyes, both kinde;
Ele make our hearts and eyes both blinde.

div.p:
Now becaue I did foreee, that this Beauty would be the object of many eyes, and that my heart would not burn alone, I reolved to be the firt that hould ininuate himelfe into her minde: And conidering, that her age was not yet capable of any olid affection, I courted her with childih toyes, and ometimes talked of Love, of Paion, of Deire, and of Flame; not that I thought her able to reent uch things yet, but my end was, only to accutome her to thoe phraes, which commonly does more offend the ears of hepheardees, then the effects themelves do. I continued this life above a year, during which time, I would ometimes teal a kie, ometimes put my hand into her boome, and indeed, great Nymph, o tampered with her, that I did extreamly win upon her affection; for, when he came to be eleven years of age, he loved me, as he her elfe aid, as well as he did her Father; and her affection growing every day, he vowed unto me, that he loved me much above the degree of either Father or Brother: And when he accomplihed the age of twelve, he loved me above all the world. And indeed, he was o void of all malice, and o eay to be wrought upon at that age, as I could have engaged her unto any thing, if I had not deigned to marry her when he was a little older: But that conideration, together with the reall affection I did bear unto her, did retrain me from all manner of evill thoughts. But, becaue her implicity made me fear, let any other hould deceive her, ince many began already to court her, I was continually laying before her that high eteem which every one did et upon contancy and fidelity; how contemptible thoe were, that loved many; how almot all Shepheards are unfaithfull and deceivers, and there was no credit to be given to their words; nay, that it was a grand fault in any young woman to hear them. But one day, when he anwered me, That if this be a fault, then he ought not to uffer me to peak as I did; I perceived, that he was till in her innocent Infancy, ince he did not know my aim; and therefore I read her a loving Lecture upon Love and Amitie, telling her, that we came purpoely into the world to love; that without this vertue, there was no delight in life; that it was Love which made all bitter weet, and paines eaie; that whooever was without that quality, were extreamly mierable, becaue none could ever love them; that he aw before her eyes the example of her Father and Uncle; her Mother did Love her Father, and her Aunt her Uncle; but uch as love above one, are corned by every one. But I beeech you, replyed he, are hepheards alo obliged to love but one? Doubtlee they are, anwered I: And do you not ee, that I do love only you? But I beeech you, tell me, aid he, did you never love any one before I was born? and if I hould die, would you not love ome other? I could not chue but laugh at this downright demand, and in anwer to it: Know, my Fairet, (aid I unto her) that I did never love any till you did come into the world; and if you hould die before me, my love would die with you, and never live again for any other. And if you hould die before me aid he, mut I of neceity do the like? If I mut, pray Father teach me how I mut bury my Love in your Coffin. Daughter, aid I unto her, and miled, you mut till let your love of me live in your memory, as I hould of you, if you did die before me. But how, aid he, hould I love one that is dead? When you did at any time kie me, and put your hand into my breat, if I did ask you, why you did o you alwaies anwered, that it was, becaue you loved me: And when you are dead, mut I do the ame? Fair Daughter, (aid I unto her, taking her in my armes, and kiing her) hepheardees never ue to hang upon the necks of thoe hepheards whom they love, nor ue any uch carraes as tetimonies of their loves unto them: It is enough for them to uffer, and not act uch things. I beeech you tell me, replied he, is uffering ones elfe to be kied and carraed in this manner, a tetimony of love? Doubtlee it is, (aid I unto her) and therefore they ought
not to uffer any o to do, unlee uch as they do love. And how do hepheards expree their loves, aid he unto me? As I do, anwered I, when I kie you, and take delight in playing with you. It eemes, aid he, that when one would kie me, and play in that manner with me, I may by that know he loves me.

I do relate the implicities of this young Shepheardee unto you, Madam, that you may the better know, of what nature that affection was which he bore unto me, and with what indulgent care I brought her up, more like a Father then a Lover; you may hereby conceive, how much beholding he ought to be unto me, for not loving her after a vicious manner, nor working upon the implicity of her age and dipoition; for you may perceive by her Quetions and Anwers, that her minde might have been tempered into what Mould oever I would. Perhaps you will wonder, that I, who was of more olid years, could take any delight in the converation of one who was o very young; but if you will pleae to conider, that Love is alwaies a childe, and takes mot delight in youth, you will not think it trange, that ince I mut love with a mot pure and incere affection, an innocent and harmles beauty hould be mot agreeable unto mee. And the very truth is, it was not I that was the author of this affection to her, but it was heaven that forced mee to love her whether I would or no. For I did often abent my elf from her, and oppoed all manner of arguments that reaon could ugget againt it, but that did rather augment than diminih my affection, which in the end grew to a mot extreame height. About this time Calidon returned out of the Boyen Province, and was ome eighteen years of age, or thereabouts. He was taller than uually that age allows any; handomly proportioned; his complexion, for a brown, extreamly fair; his mind, his garb, and his dicoure, was higher than perhaps his quality required, but yet not at all proud nor vain-glorious. I mut confee, that when I aw him o much improved, I loved him better than I did before: For before, I did love him onely in conideration of Conanguinity, and upon the recommendation of my Uncle; but when I found him to be o amiable, o extreamly well accomplihed, and every way o well improved, that I having neither Wife nor Child, or then intending to marry, reolved to make him my Heir, after my death, unto all my etate, which perhaps was not very inconiderable. And to oblige him unto a reciprocal good will unto me, I declared as much unto all my Kindred and Neighbours. Now becaue I did foreee that dwelling in my houe, it was almot impoible but he hould fall in love with the fair Celidea, I gave him a mot trict charge to look upon her onely with the eyes of a Brother, and not of a Lover: He proteted with a thouand aeverations and oaths, that he would obey me in this, and all things ele, and would not doe any thing in the world that hould dipleae me: Yet before the Moon had run a full coure, he was charmed with Celidea; and not daring to declare it unto her or me, or any ele, after he had languihed a while, hee was forced to keep his bed; his eyes hrunk into his head, his complexion grown yellow, and grown o lean and altered, as he was not knowable. I brought the mot knowing and experienced Phyicians in all the Country unto him: If Fame cryed up any man, I pared neither cot nor pains till I got him. I caued Sacrifices to be offered upon every Altar of the Country to appeae Tautates, Heus, Tharamis, and Belinus, if Calidon by chance had offended them. I ent to enquire of every Oracle and Augurer: I ent for all the Bardi to come and pray with him: I ent alo for the bet Muicians, to try if Muick would allay the Melancholly which oppreed his oul. To bee hort, there was not one age Sarronide which at my requet did not come to viit him, and give him wie precepts againt grief and orrow. But all thee had no operation; nor could all the teares which I hed by his beds ide, get him to tell me the caue of his dieae. Thus languihing in this manner, and no remedies could doe any good upon him, there was an old Phyician, a friend of mine, who hearing of my orrows for Calidon, came unto me, to comfort me in my affliction; and after as good and wie advice as any humane Prudence could give, hee bade me reign Calidon and my own will into the hands of Tautates, and to believe, that if I did it unfeignedly, I hould receive more comfort than I could from all men living. When he was ready to goe away, he deired to ee Calidon: We went both into his chamber, he fell into talk with him, and conidered him very eriouly he felt his pule, oberved his actions and getures; turned him every way to finde out his dieae: And after hee had been two hours with him; Young man, aid hee unto him, chear up, and bee aured that you hall not dye of this dieae; I have found out the caue, and I have known many ick of the ame, but never knew one dye of it. Then going out of the Chamber, he took me aide, and aid thus unto me; The age I have attained
unto, is great, and though I have not employed all my time very well, yet not all unprofitably: I have tudyed the art of Phyick very long, and have attained unto no meane reputation; I have been employed by many of the bet quality amongt the Boyens, the Seguanonans, and the Allobrogians: Long experience have I had in my Art, which makes me peak with more aurance than any that is younger than my elf can. Let me tell you, that Calidons dieae proceeds not from the body but the mind; and if his body be ick, it is becaue of the near union it hath to his ick mind, which makes it reent the pain as if it were its own, as we ee one friend enible of the pain of another. And though thee kinde of maladies be very painfull, yet are they not o dangerous as thoe of the body; for the mind is not ubject to corruption, or diolution of parts, but onely to change its quality. I tell you this, that you may not depair of the young mans cure, whoe Malady, I think I have very rightly dicovered; And by all ymptomes, I finde that he is extreame paionately in Love, and is either leighted, or ele dares not declare it.
