As oon as ever the Phyician aid o, I preently apprehended, that certainly it was with the fair Celidea; and becaue of my forbidding him, hee durt not peak of it. When the Phyician perceived me ad, in lieu of rejoycing at the matter, hee asked mee the reaon, to whom I anwered, that I was more in fear of him than ever, becaue his malady was without the compae of my cure, and he might love one I had no power over, or ele a tranger, or perhaps ome enemy, and therefore I aw no reaon to rejoice. There is a remedy, aid he, againt any thing but death, and therefore never fear but I hall keep Calidon alive; and if you will pleae to give me leave to be with him a few dayes, I hall dicover well enough whether he be in love with any that has any dependance upon you, or with a tranger. You cannot hope, aid I unto him, ever to get it from his own mouth. No, no, aid he, that's not the way; but fear not, I hall bring it about: Matters of Love be they never o cloe, may eaily be dicovered, if prudent artifice be ued.

But, great Nymph, I hould be extreamly tedious if I hould relate every trivial paage, therefore for brevities ake, I hall onely tell you, that this Phyician was for even or eight daies never from Calidons bed ide. In the mean time, he advied me to get all the young Shepheardees in the neighbourhood to come and ee him, under pretence of orrow for his icknee. As for the Phyician, hee was alwaies holding him by the arme, and felt his Pule, to know when any caued an extraordinary motion in him. So it was, that Celidea at that time was gone a journey with Cleontine, and tayed away five or ix daies, and therefore he was almot the lat of all the viitants, though the nearet neighbour: I contrived it o, that all my friends and neighbours ent both their Siters and Daughters to my houe; & when we were almot out of all hope to dicover what I deired to know this way, one came to tell us, that Celidea was at the door. As fortune was, the Phyician held him by the arm at that time; and his pule did beat a lower pace than it had done all the day; but as oon as ever he heard Celidea named, it began to beat as if he were in a mot high Feaver. The Phyician finding this, did look him in the face, and aw his eyes more quick and lively than ordinary; his complexion came into his cheeks, and he aw o great an alteration every way, as hee would hardly tay till Celidea entred for better aurance; but when he entred, his pule then did keep a mad mans time, and all parts were different from their ordinary temper. Therefore drawing me aide, Thamires, aid he, It is not Celidea which enters into the Chamber, but it is Calidons Wife, if you would have him live. Oh heavens! how thoe words pierced me to the heart? They truck me dumb, I was not able to peak one word. Afterwards, when I had a little recollected my elf; I asked him, whether conidering the condition he was in, it were fit to marry him? No, aid he, it will be enough if you can procure the Shepheardes to give him ome knowledge of her affection; and in the mean time you may talk with Clcontine, who being wie, will not bee againt a match o advantageous.

The Phyician went away, and left me in a wore condition than his patient. Oh what trange contrarieties were in my oul? One ide bade mee yeeld Celidea unto Calidon, for friendhip ake; Love, on the other ide forbade the banes. But, aid Friendhip unto me, Calidon will dy if you doe deny her; and there is no Phyician but this, can cure him: And Love anwered, how cant thou live thy elf, if thou doet not enjoy her? Cant thou not urmount a vain paion (aid Friendhip) and be ruled by the Laws of Reaon? What reaon is it, replyed Love, to dye thy elf, to make another live? Doe you not conider (replyed Friendhip) that Calidon is young, and therefore lee able than thy elf to mater his unruly paion? Wilt thou that art arrived at grave and tayed yeares, hew thy elf weaker
than he, or, to expres it a little better, wilt thou buy a little tranitory pleaure, that is pat almot as oon as had, at o deare a rate as the death and eternal loe of Calidon? Away, away, change thy minde, conider not what thou art, but what thou houldt be: Think how the Father of that young Shepheard will reproach thee: Did he not with his lat dying breath recommend his young childe then in his cradle unto thy indulgent care? Didt thou not wear he hould be as dear unto thee as thy elf? Doet thou not remember the many good offices thou receivedt from him? Oh Thamires do not buy thy repentance at o dear a rate: Repent, repent for hame of an act o unworthy an ancient Boyen, from whence it is thy boat to be decended, and let not thy oul be continually gnawed upon by an evil concience?

I mut confee, that thee coniderations had uch a prevalency with me, as I did once reolve to part with Celidea, and reign her unto Calidon. But, O Madam, what extream difficulties did I finde in the execution of it? Firt, to the end this young Shepheard might recover his health, I begun with him, and acquainting him with my knowledge of his dieae, I hewed him my extream deire of his cure: At the firt, he denyed it unto me, but at lat hee did confee it with watry eyes, and asked me forgivenee, with o many apparent ignes of orrow, that eeing his errour was by a mot compulive power of Love, I could not chue but take his fault upon my elfe. But the grand difficulty was to peake unto Celidea for hee was o farre from loving him, that hee did down right hate him. And certainly this hatred proceeded from an Antipathy in Nature, ince he had not the leat haddow of any caue for it; and the Shepheard had o many excellent good qualities, that in all reaon they hould rather have gotten love than hatred: And yet hee would alwaies ay unto me, that Calidon of all men hee knew, hould be the lat man he would love. But being reolved to make this overture, o contrary both unto her will and my own, I was at an extream puzzle where, and how to begin. At lat, I thought it bet to break the Ice by degrees for to bid her downright to love Calidon, was not the way, both in repect of her affection to me, and diaffection to him. I went therefore to work by degrees, and now he was not to be treated as a child: I hinted unto her my extreame orrows for the Shepheard; how dear his life was unto me, and how I hould never enjoy any delights if I lot him; That Phyicians and all knowing perons told me his malady proceeded from nothing ele but orrow; and not knowing what was the caue, I could not chue but deire all them that loved mee, to tudy how to make him merry, or at leat to finde out the caue of his icknee: And that he being one whom I loved and honoured mot, hee was in ome ort obliged more than any to endeavour the cure of this Shepheard for my ake: Therefore I conjured her by our friendhip, to ee him as often as he could, and to carrae and cheer him up, to keep him from that melancholly which would kill him. She who did really love me, did promie to doe it o oft as he conveniently could: And indeed did o, which on the one ide did content me, and on the other did o grieve me, as I did thinke I hould not live. I had a conceit that her familiarity with him would in time engage her to liking of him, which afterwards might the more eaily make her bee perwaded unto love: Shee having no other deign, did onely as hee promied, but did not change her minde. However this wrought good effects upon Calidon, who receiving o many favourable viits, and being o kindly carraed above his expectation, did in a hort time begin to recover: And though he was not preently cured, yet there was apparent ignes of amendment. Now becaue that hee was weary of this life, and becaue I aw my deign did not take according to my thoughts, I intended to oblige her another way. I addreed my elf unto Cleontine, acquainted her with my affection unto Calidon, with my intention of making him my Heir; I repreented unto her the quality of this young Shepheard, his virtues, and to be brief, with the love he had unto Caledon, and ued all manner of arguments that might advance the match. Judge great Nymph, if I went not very farre, and whether he be not much obliged unto me. Cleontine thinking the Match to be advantageous, did thank me for my good will unto Celidea, then gave me her word that he would ue all her endeavours in favour of Calidon; but that the young Shepheardee had a Mother who loved her exceedingly well, and hee could not dipoe of her without her conent: But he would motion it unto her and in the mean time prepare Celidea as wel as poibly he could. Thus, Madam, you ee how mierable my fortune was: I invented all poible ways to deprive my elfe of the onely good that could render my life pleaing unto me; and I did foreee, that though I did bring it pae, yet I hould reap no contentment by it. Had I obtained for Calidon that which I did endeavour, what could I ever have hoped for in my
life? Had I not obtained it, how hould I have grieved for that Shepheard, who was asdea • unto me, as if he had been my own child? This being my condition, which I knew not whether to tearm a death or a life one day after I had received Cleontine's anwer, I went unto Celidea, with whom I was not o familiar as formerly: My dear and fairet Daughter, (aid I unto her) Cleontine has acquainted me with her intention, and I conceive, that you ought to approve of it. Then fearing he hould ask me what it was, I eemed to have earnet and uddain buinee to do, and went away, leaving her in a great doubt what it was: But I went away with a ad heart; for, trive what I could againt my own will, I could not blot her out of my oul; and as often as I fancyed Celidea in the armes of another, I mut confee, that I had not reolution enough to endure the very thought of it. Imagine in what condition I hould have been, if the Marriage had taken effect, which truly I did mot vigorouly endeavour for Calidon's fake?

Then Cleontine, thinking my propoition advantageous for Celidea, he took her aide, and broke the matter unto her: Then, before he asked her opinion of it, he told her what was he •• ; and the more to induce her, told her, how much he was obliged unto me, for motioning it unto her. That Shepheardee Madam, can bet tell you, how he tarted at the motion, epecially when he heard that it came from me: but o it was, that he had much ado to conceal her anger in Cleontin's preence; yet, giving her a very modet anwer, though it were very far from her thoughts, he referred her elfe unto her judgment, and the pleaure of her Mother, unto whom he was never diobedient. In concluion, being reolved to marry a Grave rather then Calidon, he came unto me. Aoon as ever I aw her, I perceived that omething did trouble her, for her eyes trembled in her head; her eye-lids frowning and her colour higher than ordinary. But I could not imagine that he hould be offended againt me, nor believe, that Cleontine had told her the motion came from me. As fortune was I was under a great Elme alone, which tood by it elfe almot in the midt of Mount Verdun's plain, neer the high way. As oon as ever I aw her I did rie up, and holding her hand as I was went, I was amazed to ee her pul back her arme, and look upon me with an angry eye: Thamires, aid he, how dare you take her hand, whom you have given to another? Was it not enough, and too much, that you have abued me as long as ever the innocence of my age could endure it? Do you think your elfe o ubtle, and me o imple, that now, being pat a child, I cannot ee your cunning perfidie? When he aw me tand amazed, and did not anwer: Nay, nay, Thamires, aid he, never think to deceive me any more by your words, nor aurances of amity; I am now grown more crafty, and I wih to god I had alwaies been o then I hould not have now o much reaon to complain of you. But go, ungratefull peron and cruell, (yea, I may mot jutly call you both ungratefull and cruell, ince you have o ungratefully forgotten the reaons you had to love me, and ince you have o cruelly abued my innocency by your craft). Away ungrateful and cruell man! What did you ever finde in me, that hould give you any occaion to ue me thus? Was there ever any old enmity between our Parents that you would revenge upon me? Did I ever attempt againt your life? Have I ever poken againt you or any of your friends? Did I ever fail in my word or friendhip? Have you ever found any fault in me, that did invite you to cat me off? Or, do you now think me not wie, or rich, or fair enough, for you? If it be to revenge the fault of a Father upon a Daughter, me-thinks it, hould be an act unworthy of Thamires? If I did ever attempt againt your life, why did you not take mine away at a blow, but put me into the power of an enemy, with whom I hould live a dyinglife every minute? If I be not fair enough, nor o vertuous as to pleae you, good Thamires, go and eek out a better. But alas, why mut I as a pennance for a fault in nature, be put into the hands of him, whom nature it elfe makes me abhor? For gods ake leave me in the ame liberty you found me, when by your craft you began to deceive me, and content your elfe with thoe orrowes I hall have all my life, for not knowing your deigne ooner. If ever I failed in friendhip, I mut confee, you are jut in doing the like. But, Thamires, I beeech you, lay it in my dih and tell me, wherein I ever failed. Ah! mot unnaturall Shepheard, you are mute, and cannot peak a word; Is it for the ham: for the wrong you have done me? or, have you any new piece of ubtlety againt illy Celidea? Go, go, perfidious and diloyall Thamires. This act hath put me out of opinion, that ever you loved me. The knowledge of your tyranny hall keep me for ever from ubjecting my elfe unto any man in the world. Never think, that all you can do, hall ever make me Calidon's. Death hall be more welcome unto me, then the mot accomplihed Shepheard in all this Country. Let the memory of this be a ad tain upon
thy oul to eternity: And I am confident, the jut gods will ee me revenged. In offering to give me unto Calidon, you have for ever deprived your elfe of the truet and mot faithfull affection that ever was; and never hope it will revive, unlee an univerall conflagration hould et the whole world a fire, and o kindle this love in me again. Away, away, there is not a man upon the face of the whole earth, but Monters, and Tigers, that would devour me. Upon this, taking from her neck a platted Chain which I gave her, as he gave it into my hand, he broke it in pieces: Thus, aid he, is our love to one another for ever broken, and never to piece again. She had no ooner poken thee words, but he ran away with a piece of the chain in her hand, and left the other in mine, who was in uch an extay, that I was not able to peak one word by way of excue, nor follow her one tep I mut confee Madam, that thee words did ting me to the very heart; and when I did eriouly conider what good reaon he had to peak them, I could not lay the blame upon her, but wholly upon my elfe: However, I kept my elfe till contant to my reolution, of endeavouring the contentment of Calidon. He, knowing that I had poken of it unto Cleontine, and hearing the report of their Marriage publickly divulged, he did not much wonder, that his Shepheardee hould never ee him; but when Cleontine came to viit him, conceiving it but fit for her o to do, ince their Marriage was o much poken of; o as in a few nights he recovered his former health, and got out of his bed, and a little after out of his Chamber. In the mean time, Celidea was much perplexed and having no other hopes, but in the tender affection of her Mother, ince he aw I had gained Cleontine, aoon as ever he aw her, he fell down upon her knees, and would not rie, untill he had obtained a promie, never to marry her againt her will. Celidea was o exceedingly contented with this aurance, as hcould not ret, untill he had advertied us of it, thinkinking her deires not compleatly atisfied till then. It is very hard to ay, great Nymph, whether I was more orry, or more pleaed; for on the one ide, I feared Calidon's relaps; and on the other, I was glad that none hould enjoy Celidea. But when I aw Calidon, though omething ad, yet in health, I mut confee, that I was extreamly pleaed at Celidea's repuling him, and did in my heart commend her prudence and reolution; for I had a conceit, that all he did was only to reerve her elfe for me, not imagining her anger againt me was o high, as utterly to extirpate the affection which he bore unto me; o as recollecting my elfe, I did confee, that the injury which I had done her, was not with a deigne to extinguih my love unto her, (for I never had any uch intention, nor could ever hope to be o much Mater of my elfe) but only had a minde to acrifice it unto Calidon's health. So then mut the act which I would have done be phraed: for my aim was only at the aving of his life, and not at the atisfaction of his pleaures. Thee coniderations being often in my minde, Love began to be more violent in me then ever; and eaily it might, for having reigned this fair one unto Calidon, only to ave his life, and eeing that he lived till, though he was not his elf, I conceived, that my quitting her having wrought its intended effect, I might very jutly fall on upon my own core as I fell off for Calidon's. Upon this account, I went to the hepheardee, I hewed her the reaon why I dealt o with her, and why I did now dedicate my elfe wholly to her ervice, befeeching and conjuring her, to pardon and forget the fault, if he thought it to be one. To be briefe, I ued the bet arguments and eloquence I could devie, to advance my caue; but I found her to be o exceedingly altered, that all my arguments, excues, and reaons, could not move her more then they could a Rock, nor obtain the leat glance of a favourable look upon me As fortune was whilt I was peaking to her, Calidon comes in, and thinking to finde me a very good econd, he advanced towards us, to peak to her for himelfe; but when he heard my words, never man was more amazed: he durt not then apbraid me with breach of faith and abuing him; but tepping back three or foure paces, with folded armes: Oh heavens! aid he, is there any loyalty in any man living? Is it he that brought me up, lie whom I call Father, and he, who hitherto hath done me all indulgent offices is it he, I ay, that puts a dagger into my heart, and ends me to my grave? Unto which I returned a faint anwer, hewed him the reaons why I quitted Celidea, and why I did again apply my elfe to her. But Love did o tranport him into uch violent raptures, that there could be no bitter invective, wherewith he did not apere me. But the hepheardee did laugh at us both: Nay, nay, aid he, never trive for Celidea, for neither of you have the leat hare in her: Not you, (aid he, and turned to Celidon) for I never did love you: Nor you, (aid he, and turned to me) becaue you are extreamly unworthy of that love, which once I did bear unto you. Then he left both in a confued
amazement: We alo parted. And ever ince, that hepheard hath continued with one of his Kinmen, and never came at his own Cabin. Three Moones have changed ince this eparation, and do both he and I what we could, we could not obtain one good word from her; but, the more violent we are in our loves, the more violent he is in her hatred. In the mean time, uch is my extream affection to her, that it will not admit of the leat diminution, but does till more and more encreae: o as did he but know it, I do believe, that ince he did love me before, out of an opinion I loved her, he would love me much more now, becaue I do love her now much more than I did then, and more than any man living can.

Thus Thamires ended his relation; and after a while of ilence, he began again. Now, Madam, aid he, as chance was, we met this hepheardee upon the banks of the River Lignon; and becaue love continues in us and didain in her, we both of us hewed her the bet reaons we had, to convince her, that he ought to love one of us. I pleaded, that it was I upon whom her election ought to be.: Calidon, on the other ide, whom I have o much obliged by many good offices, he very opinioatively maintaines, that it belongs to him. Now knowing that your widome can much better undertand reaon, then I can expree, I would with all my heart, to put an end to our long dientions, (for we are already grown the common talk of our Town) that you, great Nymph, would be pleaed to hear our reaons and arguments from our own mouths, and ordain what you hall conceive to be jut, for I hall mot freely ubmit my elfe unto your judgment: It would be a work well worthy of your elfe, it would be acceptable to the gods, and would infinitely oblige us all unto you. Leonida thanked him for the pains he had taken, in the relation of of the matter; and did aure him, that if he, and all thoe who had any interet in the buinee, did think her able to be the Judge, he would mot willingly arbitrate the matter, according to the bet of her judgment, upon condition they would all promie to oberve it otherwie, all their labour would be but lot. Thamires kneeled down upon his knees, and aid: Oh, great Nymph, I do refer my life, my death, and the contentments of them, unto your wie judgment; if I do diobey your doom, let our Druides excommunicate me from ever aiting them at their holy acrifices, and forbid me for ever coming into the acred groves, or our celetiall woods. For my part; aid Calidon, if I do not the ame, may the Mileto of the ninth year be never wholome unto me, let the great Tautates animate all his furies againt me, and never let me be at ret, if I do not ubmit unto your judgment as proceeding from the great god. And becaue Celidea tood ilent, Atrea aid unto her. Are not you pleaed, fair Shepheardee, to be rid of all the importunities which you receive from thee two Shepheards, and refer your elfe unto the judgment of this great Nymph? I am mot willing to be rid of them anwered he; but I am afraid to fall into a greater miery: And certainly, I hould refer the hazard of this judgment unto any, if the gods had not advied me the lat night in a dream, to take another coure: For, preently after midnight, me-thought I aw my Father, who hath been long dead, open my breat, take out my heart, and cat it as a tone in a ling over the River Lignon; then poke thee words unto me: Go, my child, unto the other ide of the fatall River Lignon, there thou halt finde that heart which o much torments thee, or ele a full atisfaction and ret, untill thou comet unto me. Upon this, I awaked and therefore I am reolved to pae over the River, to ee if I can finde that tranquillity which is promied unto me. However, Madam (aid he, and addreed her elfe unto Leonida) you may be certain, that I hall never diobey any command which you hall impoe upon me, ince I do believe that the gods will peak by your mouth. Since it is o, aid Leonida, I do promie you all three, to give as jut a Judgment, as I my elfe would receive upon the like occaion: And that I may not erre in my judgment, Paris and thee fair Shepheardees and Silvander, hall help me with their advice, before I pronounce the Sentence. And therefore Calidon, aid he, hew me your reaons, why you conceive Celidea ought to be yours, and not Thamires's, who hath o long been her Guardian, and brought her up as his own? That Shepheard then riing up, and after a low reverence, he began in this manner.

div.head: The Oration of the Shepheard Calidon.
div.p:
OH great god of Love, who by thy unreitable puiance hat ravihed from me all that reaon was wont to have over my will, hearken I beeech thee, unto the upplication of the mot faithfull oul, that ever reented the power which beauty, by thy means, hath over the hearts of men; and inpire me with uch language and reaon, as thou didt, when I was weary of Celidea's corn, and was reolved to decline from her ervice. Let this great Nymph be moved with my arguments; let her, whom thou hat given me, and who was alo given me by him that had the greatet interet in her, be preerved and kept for me, both againt her own corn, and againt the violencies of him that would ravih her from me. Were it not in hopes of aitance from this divinity whom I invoke, I durt not, great Nymph, open my mouth againt a peron, whom of all men in the world I am mot obliged unto: For I mut needs ingeniouly confee, that Thamires, by his weet indulgency towards me, has more obliged me, than my Father, who gave me life; the one gave me only a being, but the other a well-being. Thamires has been troubled with all the vexations of my child-hood, and hath brought me up even from my Cradle; he hath pared no paines nor cot in my education, nor care nor prudence in cauing me to be well intructed; o as the Appellation of Father is in all reaon his due, and I mut acknowledge my elfe his Child, having received from him all thoe indulgencies, which thoe names require. And in confeing all thee obligations, how can I open my mouth againt him, without incurring the ugly brand of ingratitude? If this dipute did depend only upon my elfe, I had rather be in my grave leeping with my fathers, and wih that my Cradle had been my Coffin, rather then oppoe Thamires in any thing: Thamires, I ay, who hath made me what I am: Thamires, unto whom I owe all I have: Thamires, in whoe ervice, when I have pent all my life, yet halfe my obligations are not cancelled. But alas, it is all long of himelfe; it is Love which commanded me; he himelfe alo commanded me. Let Thamires tell me, whether it be poible, that a heart which Love hath touched to the quick, can diobey him in any thing? If he have found this to be true by experience, then I do conjure him by the god of Love, who hath uch power over his oule, to pardon that fault which I have been forced to commit againt him; and that he give me leave to maintain, that all reaon ordaines Celidea to love me, and that there is none but my elfe that can pretend unto her. For to begin with the firt point, what can Calidea anwer if I call her before the Throne of Love, and if in the preence of this equitable company, I do complain againt her in this manner? This is the fair one, Oh great god of Love, which preents her elf before thee This is he whom thou hat commanded me to love and erve, upon hopes of uch reward as thou uet to give unto thoe that follow thee. If from the firt minute of my beginning, unto this intant, I did ever contrary thy will, if I have notalwaies continued in a full reolution to pend my whole life in thy obedience; Then, Oh Love, who looket into all hearts, and eet all my deignes, let me be punihed as a perjured villain, and let all the thunderbolts of the great Tharamis fall upon me, as a perfidious peron. But if truth and my words agree, and if never any loved like me, why dot thou uffer her to deceive my hopes? why does he not make good thy promies? and why wilt thou let her laugh at all thoe mieries, which thou hat made me to endure for her? Aoon as ever I aw her, I loved her, and aoon as ever I loved her, I did dedicate my elfe and oul to adore her. But perhaps this affection is unknown unto her, or I have only acquainted the olitary Woods and Rocks with it. No, no, Oh Love, he hath heard my complaints, he hath een my tears, he knowes of my affection, omthing from my own mouth, more from Thamires, Cleontina, and other of my friends; but mot of all from the effects of my paion. Has he not een me in the bed of death for her? has he not held me by the hand, and pulled me from my grave, aying unto me, Live, live. Calidon, thy pretenions are not hopelee? And ince I had uffered the very pangs of death, why did he call me from that ret, which my grave would have given me? If it was to make me die again without pitty, it was extream cruelty? Mut I be punihed with a econd death, for obeying and adoring her? But perhaps he will ay, that I ought to meaure her by my own Ell, and conider, that as I have not power to quit her and love another; o he being engaged another way, he cannot diengage her elfe to love me. Oh Love, thee are only words, bare excues Let her hew the contract of this engagement, and if thou dot not preently adjudge it to be fale,
then let me be condemned. She never loved any, but the hepheard Thamires, as he hath told me; but I dare ay farther, and maintain, that he never loved this Thamires. Did he love him? Alas, when? Even when he was not able to love, when her hands and mind were wholly taken up with childih Gew-gawes; when her deires could not reach any higher then to be a little Fine, or to make a Baby, and dree it, and talk to it. Was he not wholly ignorant what Love was? or if he did at that age love Thamires, or thought it to be love; mut he needs love him till? Alas, alas, uch young green affections as that is like our clothes, to be cat off when we will. Oh! puiant god of Love, how ignorant was he, or rather, how did he depie all thy tatutes and ordinances? Is it not by thy Lawes declared a mot capitall crime, to think, that ones Love hall ever end? What then hall we think of this hepheardee, who could not o much as think, becaue he was uncapable of deire, but who is really retreated from that love, which he bare unto him, as he her elfe told Thamires? Can it beaid, Oh great deity, that he was ever one of thy ubjects? Wilt thou acknowledge her, or let her enjoy thoe priviledges which he pretends unto, or uffer her to oppoe me? But if it be o, that thy uper-abundant goodnee, which trancends the goodnee of all other deities, will allow her to enjoy the benefit of true Lovers, becaue he flies unto thee for anctuary, and may plead, that loving Thamires will not love me, no, nor o much as look upon me, how can he anwer this, that he her elfe hath confeed, he would not love Thamires any longer? With what excue can he palliate her impiety? And why dot thou not punih this high diobedience? If thou dot not, then he is the only one, that depiing, is not punihed; and I the only one, who adoring thee, does not finde the reward of thy accutomed goodnee.

I do believe, Oh great Nymph, that Celidea being thus accued before the Throne of this great deity, he can hardly anwer, nor avoid being condemned, to give me atisfaction for all the paines I have taken, and to render love for love, whilt Thamires cannot oppoe me with any particular interet: For what interet can he claim in that, which he hath freely given me? He hath etated the whole title upon me, and is o far debarred from any right, that he ought in reaon rather to defend and maintain my title, againt all men living, ince it was from him I derived my title. But perhaps he will ay, that it was his meer free and voluntary act, without any conideration, but his own love to me, and therefore is not obliged unto any warrantie. But why, Thamires, do you call that a meer voluntary act, which you have confeed before your Judge, that you were obliged unto it by your promies, unto my dying Father, unto whom you were much obliged for everall benevolences? Do you call that a meer free act of your will, which you were contrained unto to be quit of o many obligations? Do you think you do oblige your Creditors, by paying your due debts? I mut confee, great Nymph, that Thamires hath paid both principall and interet, which renders him not to be ungratefull; but I do abolutely deny, that there was nothing in this act which did oblige his will. But admit it o, that it was an act of his own meer free will, and that he did it of himelfe; did not the effect of this will aime at his own peculiar atisfaction? If he do but conider the debt due unto the memory of my Father, and his aime of obliging me by this act, of giving Celidea unto me, he will finde, that it was not an act of pure and meer free will, but a way to atisfie himelfe, by paying that debt which was due to my Father, and a way to purchae my obligations unto himelfe; o as what he hath done is but a loan, which I mut perpetually pay interet for, and which he may claim as an obligation upon me to pay: If I hould ail in paying my acknowledgments, he might jutly call me ingrate; but he cannot ay that he gave me Celidea freely, ince in conideration of himelfe, and by the rules of human prudence, he was obliged unto it, and hath o debarred himelfe, as he is obliged to maintain my claim unto her, againt any that hall hinder me from enjoying her. The god of Love be my witnee, Father, (for o I will call you as long as I live unlee you forbid me) the great god of Love be my witnee, I ay, whether it grieves me not to the very foul, I hould oppoe you in this buinee. You your elfe doe know, in what a ad condition you have een me: You know, how Love had almot brought me to my grave, and you mut needs confee, that it was the power of Love which compelled me to dipleae you; uch was the force upon me, that I had no free will unto it at all but was forced by a compulive neceity unto it: Nothing ele under the Sun could have made me contradict your commands; if there be let the gods punih me as the mot ungratefull peron that ever breathed. But Father, ince there was an unreitable force upon me, I beeech you pardon my weaknee, and do not you your elfe help me to complain againt you; for, were not
you the caue of all this? For ince it was wholly in your dipoe, why did you bring me from amongt the Boyens before you had married Celidea? Could you think, that being your Kinman, I hould not ympathize with you, and o be in danger to love her as well as you? But perhaps you will ay, that you thought your command upon me not to love her, was enough to keep me within the bounds of my duty, and make me look upon her onely as my Siter. But, wie Thamires, I doe wonder you hould not remember the follies of youth; and that it is the nature not onely of all thoe of that age, but generally of all men whatoever, to think things that are mot forbidden to be mot weet: I admire you hould forbid me loving her before ever I aw her, as if you had a minde to make me love her by the ear, before he was een by the eye. What was this, but to awaken my deires, and to kindle a fire; like a Flint which is trucken, which before was cold, and had no appearance of heate in it.

But perhaps again you will ay, that you did allow me to love her in the degree of a Siter, and o limit my deires as I hould neither offend you nor my elfe; you in not contraining me too much, and me in not confining me too narrowly, but allowing me to keep within your precribed limits.

But, O great Nymph, conider, I beeech you, what kind of command this was: Thamires hewes me a beauty of an infinite lutre, allows me convere with her; commands me to love her, but will not have my love tir one foot beyond his limit, nor love her above the quality of a Brother. Oh heavens! what did he think I was made of? Can Love that thinkes the whole univere too narrow a compae to be confined unto, and who dipoeth of all our wills according to his pleaure be hemmed up in uch trait limits as hee precribes? Will Love be ruled and governed by the will of any but himelfe? But what in the name of Heaven does Thamires thinke of me? Does hee conceive that I have more power than either Men or Gods, or the whole World hath? It had been but jut to have meaured me by himelf; and if he could have tamed his own affections and paions, then might he have had ome reaon to impoe the like task upon me: But that hee who had experience of his own trength, and of Loves power, for him, I ay to command a thing which he himelfe could not oberve, whoe age and experience had great advantage over my green years, this was too much, too unreaonable. Perhaps again he wil complain, that I have not payd him uch repect as is due unto a Father, & that his great indulgency towards me might very well oblige me unto much more than all this. Alas, alas, does he not conider, that what I did was done by compulion; and that I had rather dye than fail in any point of duty to him? The torments I did endure, when I was in the very Arms of death, is a ufficient tetimony of all this. The grave Phyician found it by my Pule, and alteration in my complexion: Let him conider, that uch was my repect of him, that I choe death rather than I would dicover the caue of my Malady. If he will blame any, he mut blame Nature, for not giving me power to command my Interior motions, as well as my Tongue and exterior actions and parts: Alas, I would never have received life from him but on condition that Celidea might be mine: I doe confee that never man was more obliged unto another than I am to him; I know that never Kinman received more indulgent kindnee from another Kinman; nor ever any Child greater tetimonies of affection from a Father than I did from Thamires when he reigned Celidea unto me: But now at this time, ince he offers to ravih her from me, May I not rightly ay, that never man received greater injury from another? never Coen more unkindnes from a Coen, nor child more tyrannique treatment from a Father, than Calidon from Thamires? So as now all my former obligations to him, are cancelled and changed into o many injuries: For, Thamires, though it is true, you had a care of mee in my very cradle, though you have brought me up with all indulgent care; though you have declared mee your Heir, yet for all thee, if you doe deprive mee of that thing which farre above all the world is mot dear unto me, and which you your elf did give me, doe you not give me a death much wore than that which you preerved me from? And if I doe not enjoy that which you would ravih from me; your etate, your education, nay, my life it elf is of no value unto me. Conider, wie Thamires, that to take back a gift by force, doth more offend him that did receive it, than if being asked it had been denied him; and therefore, wonder not if I ay that this act hath cancelled all my obligations unto you. Which to prevent, I beeech you joyn with me, and own what I hall ay unto Celidea on your behalf; How is it poible, my fair Daughter (would I have you ay unto her) that Calidons extream affection hould find no acceptance from you? Will all my perwaions and recommendations of him reach no farther than your eares, and have no effectual influence upon
your oul? Have you not often promied that I hould have the abolute dipoe of you? If it be o, why doe you not make good your promie? Did I ever propoe any unto you who was not worthy to be loved? Is he whom I doe now motion unto you uch a one, or unknown to you, or without kindred or friends? I beleeve there is not a Shepheardee in all the Country, that would not thinke his amity to be advantageous unto her. The wie Cleontine thinks it o, and o does your Mother, though out of an over-fond tendernee he will not command you any thing againt your mind: But perhaps you ay, that, Thamires, it is you only whom I love, and cannot love any other; unto you have I wholly given my elf; you have the abolute power over me, and may do any thing with me but giving me unto another. The heavens doe know, my fair Daughter, how pleaing this declaration of yours is unto me, and that there is nothing under heaven can be more acceptable unto me: But if you doe indeed love me, you will endeavour to preerve my honour, and love me under the name of Calidon, who is my very elf, and of my very blood. As for his oul, he loves you as I doe, o as there is a ympathy betwixt us: And ince amongt friends, all things are in common, o ince I love him, I have nothing he hath not a hare in as well as my elf: So as if I have any hare in your affection, as you ay I have, he mut of neceary conequence be a participant with me. Doe not complain againt me for this, and ay, that I break faith with you, and change you for another; for I am fully reolved never to love any but you; you, you onely were the beginning, and hall bee the end of my affection. But ince Detiny forbids me to enjoy you, and contrains mee to bequeath you unto another, both by the Laws of Duty and Nature, I hall think it, faire Daughter, an infinite contentment to ee you his whom I have made choice of, whom I have brought up, whom I love, and whom I have choen, not onely for my Heir, but alo for my Companion in all the etate which the Heavens and Fortune hath, or for the future hall give me. You are obliged unto this by our Friendhip, as well as I am by my duty. Love therefore my Calidon, if ever you loved me, and make it thereby appear, that you are but a Lover, and Religious towards the Gods, who certainly would never have given me liberty to part with you againt my will, had they not o decreed it in their infallible Detinies.

Great, and wie Nymph, this is the language which Thamires doth, or ought to ue, of which I am onely the intrument; And which, as I conceive, is o jut, and o worthy of himelf, as I hope he will not diown it. And therefore, after I have vowed by the great Tautates, that Calidon doth infinitely love Celidea, and that there never was a more faithfull Lover than he, I will ue no other arguments or reaons but his own, and o referring my life, my death, my happinee, my miery, and my All unto your wie dicretion I pray unto the Gods to endue you with all Widom and Jutice.

Calidon concluding thus with a low and humble reverence, he went unto Celidea, and falling down upon his knees before her, hee waited for her anwer. Thamires he proferred to peak, but Leonida told him that Celidea was to peak before him, ince he had already poke unto the matter: So, that Shepheard going againe to his place, Celidea, by the Nymphs command, began thus.

div.head: The Anwer of the Shepheardese Celidea.
div.p: I Am o unaccutomed, great Nymph, to peak upon uch a ubject as this, epecially before o much company, that though I doe bluh, and expres my elf with a trembling tongue, yet I hope it will be no prejudice to the jutice of my caue. Were I not mot confidently aured that my reaons not to love this Shepheard, are in themelves o clear, that they need no manner of artificial dree to illutrate them unto you, I durt not be o bold as to open my mouth upon this ubject: I perceive the eloquence of Calidon is much above mine; I want both wit, pirit, and eloquence to gloe a matter as he can: My words are onely imple, and utable to my reaons; which though not many, yet valid enough to make it manifet unto you, that ince I never did love Calidon, I ought not to beginne at this intant, nor continue that affection which once I had unto Thamires, ince I have o many reaons to the contrary.

But where hall I begin? What Divine Powers mut I ask aitance from, in this dangerous combat? I am aaulted, not by Love but by Monters of Love. A combat ful of danger indeed, ince my wel or ill being depends upon it: And Monters of Love indeed they are, ince
they will make me love by force, and compel me to love and hate according to their wills.

I have heard our great and wie Druids ay, that Hercules, whom we ee erected upon our Altars, with a Club in his hand, and a Lyons skin upon his houlders, was in his time a great Hero, who by his trength and valour quelled Monters, and was a great Patron of Truth. From whom therefore in this extream neceity hould I implore aid, ooner than from this valiant Hero? And the rather, becaue as I have heard, hee loved a Lady of Gaùle; and doubtlee will for her ake afford me the aid I implore. To him therefore do I addree my elf to ubdue thee montrous pirits, and to furnih me with o much eloquence and audacity as may make my reaons apparent unto my Judges. I beeech thee therefore, by thy valour, O great Hercules, and by the fair Galathea our Princee, I conjure thee to deliver me from thee montrous Lovers, and o to cleare my reaons unto this Nymph, that he may give a jut judgement, and keep me from loving both Thamires and Calidon.

And to begin, what dot thou mean, Calidon, by calling me before the God of Love, whom thou dot make both thy Judge and thy God? Dot thou think, that he hath any power over us, who are ahamed that his Name hould be in our mouths, though it do reach our ears? A Maid, Calidon, who ever corned to have any thing to do with this Love, is now ummoned to appear before his Throne to receive her doom: And cant thou expect I will make any other anwer, but that let this God of Love doom what he will I will not obey him? But I prethee tell me, when I have oberved his tatutes, and am contrained to live according to his will, what recompence may I expect from him? onely this, to be called the mot amorous Maid in all the Country. A very brave and honourable title indeed for a maid of any quality, and one that deires to live without a blemih upon her honour. Therefore, Oh Shepheard, never ummon mee before his Tribunal whoe Power and Juridiction I will not acknowledge, and unto whom I doe declare my elf to bee an enemy.

If you will have me give an anwer, let us both appeal unto Virtue and Reaon, and certainly wee need not goe any farther than this great Nymph, who is pleaed to take o much pains to hear our differences. Before her I hall anwer unto any thing you have or can object; which as I conceive may be reduced unto three heads: Firt, that I ought to love you, becaue you love me, and becaue I knew it: Secondly, becaue the favours which you received from me in your icknes, and which, as you ay, caued your cure, have obliged me: And latly, becaue Thamires hath given me unto you.

But, Madam, that I may give full anwers unto all thee objections, I beeech you command him to anwer unto my quetions, that you may come to the knowledge of the Truth out of his own mouth. I ask you, Calidon, what allurement did I ue, to make you in love, the firt time you begun to love me? When he aw he tood ilent, and gave no anwer, he addreed her elf unto the Nymph; Madam, aid he, I beeech you command him to anwer me: And Leonida appointing him o to doe; You ask me a quetion aid he, which you your elf can bet reolve; but ince you will needs have it from my mouth, I will tell you; It was the favour which I received from you, in being pleaed to hew your elf unto me at the Sacrifice which was celebrated at the ixth of the month. Was I the onely woman that aited at the Sacrifice (aid Celidea) and were you the only Shepheard of the Town that was there? No, anwered hee, for almot all the Shepheardees and Shepheards of the Town were there alo. What one act was it, I beeech you, replyed he, that did attract your affection? In this, anwered Calidon, you mut acknowledge that my love was the decree of heaven; You did no ooner turn your eyes towards me, but as oon as ever I aw you, I loved you, as if I were forced unto it by ome interior power, which it was impoible to reit. But perhaps (aid the Shepheardee) when I knew you did love me, did I ue any art to cherih it, or augment it by any freh favours? No, aid he, my affection did beginne without you, continue without you, and augment without you, I mean without your contributing any thing unto it but by being your elf. But on the contrary, the firt time you knew it (for though I did not dicover it by my words, yet I knew you did perceive it) Oh what harh treatment did I receive from you? And what extreame dilike have you ince hewed? So as if I be as you ay, a Monter of Love, I am o, becaue it is a thing mot montrous that a Lover hould o long preerve his affection maugre o many rigorous affronts and caues of hatred; for I may afely ay, that every one of your actions towards me deerves no other name but of Rigour and Hatred: So
as it is apparent when you came to viit me in my icknee, your deign was to ave my life, onely that afterwards you might murder me more cruelly. Then Celidea replyed thus; You ee, great and wie Nymph, by Calidons own mouth, that if hee did love me, it was without any contributing to it by me, unlee by being my elf; and againt that, what remedy can I invent? What would he anwer if I hould ask him thee quetions before the Throne of Reaon and your elf: Since Shepheard I never did conent unto any of your addrees, why would you have me participate in your own troubles, hame, and errours? Is it not enough that I have all this while endured your importunities without revenge? You doe love me you ay, and becaue you love me, I mut love you again: But pray hear what Reaon aith; You have loved Celidea, and in loving her, you have offended her, and what other recompence can you expect from her but hatred? The truth is, Shepheard, that being unwilling to be revenged of you, as in reaon I might, I contented my elf with hating you in my very oul, and for Thamires his ake I pardoned the ret. If you doe object that I doe know of your love by your teares, and by your icknee: Alae, this does not oblige mee one jot the more to love you, but rather to hate you more extreamly.

Tell me, Calidon, ince Thamires hath taken o much care to bring you up in literature, and travails, in what part of the world have you een it decent for a young maid as I am, to love, or uffer her elf to be loved? If it bee not the cutome in any place of the world, but where Vice is held for Virtue, doe you not infinitely offend in tempting mee to that which is contrary to my duty? You love me, you ay, becaue you cannot chue but doe o. Good friend, how am I obliged unto you, for doing that, which you cannot chue but do? You do excue your elfe to Thamires, for loving me againt his will, by aying, that you are not to blame, becaue you are forced unto it. Can you think your elf exempt from blame, in inning by compulion? and do you think your elfe worthy of recompence, for being forced unto a thing, whoe contrary deerves a recompence? Either confee your elfe culpable towards Thamires, or ele ceae eeking a recompence for your forced ervice, But if you do love me againt my will, am I to be punihed for it? Did I ever entreat you to it? did I ever give you any occaion? You ay, No. Will your love be any contentment or advantage unto me? Shall I become more fair, more vertuous, or ever the better by it? Oh heavens! Calidon, where are your wits? Are you mad, to ask a recompence, where a punihment is deerved? Or rather, what an impudent affront is this, before this great Nymph, to demand •• vour and wages of me, in lieu of a pardon, and in lieu of repenting for your faults. I believe you will ay, that I hould not have flattered you in your errour, nor kept you alive when you were ick by giving you good language. But, Calidon, have I not good caue to ay, you are an ungratefull man and does not acknowledge the good office I did you, in micontruing of it, and taking it in another ene then you ought. Did a guilty peron ever finde or think his Judge too milde or weet? or, did any offendor ever complain, that in lieu of punihment, he received favour and courtey? Becaue I wihed not your death, am I blamable for aving your life? You accue me for having pitty upon you, and hewing favour intead of revenge, and would have me punihed for it. Judge, Madam, how his undertanding is out of the way, and how he takes reaon the wrong way. But Shepheard, neither blame me, nor commend me for my act, ince according to your own argument, it was an act forced upon me, which ought neither to be recompened nor punihed. It was my affection to Thamires, who conjured me unto it by all the obliging arguments he could devie, which induced me unto it. I ee, Calidon, that you do mile, that I hould ay, it was my affection unto Thamires, which moved me to treat you in that manner, becaue you conceive, that he who a little before did declare her elfe uch an enemy to Love, cannot now well ay, that Love had uch an influence upon her oul. But Shepheard, you are much mitaken, if you think, that in being an enemy unto Love, I am o alo unto Amity and friendhip, or void of that vertue, which makes us think of things as they ought to be. I have heard ay, great Nymph, that one may love two manner of wayes; the one according to reaon; the other, according to deire. That which hath reaon for its rule, is called vertuous and honet Amity; and that which uffers it elfe to be tranported with deire, Love. With the firt of thee we do love our Parents, our Kindred, our Friends, our Country, and both in generall and particular, all thoe in whom any vertue hines. As for the other, thoe that are infected with it, are tranported and ditempered, as with a frenzy Feavour, and do commit o many groe faults, that the name of it is as infamous amongt perons of honour, as the other is good and laudable.

I hall without a bluh then confee, that I did love Thamires, but withall I mut tell you, it was for his vertue. If Calidon do ask me, how I can ditinguih and dicern between thee two kinds of affection, ince the one does commonly appear in the habit of the other? I hall anwer him, that the wie Cleontine teaching me how to behave my elfe in the world, did give me the difference: Daughter, aid he, my age hath furnihed me with experience in many things, and hath taught me, that things are the mot certainly known by their effects; and the better to dicern after what manner we are loved, conider the actions of thoe that love us; if you finde them to be irregular, and contrary to reaon, vertue, or duty, flie them as dihonourable; if on the contrary you finde them to be moderate, and not ramping beyond the limits of honety or duty, then cherih them, and eteem them as vertuous. This apient leon, Shepheard, teacheth me to cherih the affection of Thamires, and to flie yours: For what effect does the love of Calidon produce? Violencies, raptures, tranports, and depairs, were never the effects of vertue. If the love of Thamires be conidered, we hall finde it to be all vertue: When did he begin to love me? At a time, when there was no likelyhood any vice could invite him to it. How has he continued this affection? So, as neither duty nor honety could take the leat exception againt it. But why did he give over? For the reaons which he himelfe hath given. Whether reaon do not appear in all this, I refer my elfe, Madam, unto your judgment. Thee coniderations moved me to entertain the affection of Thamires, and reject the love of Calidon. And this Amity, and nothing ele, did enforce me to viit this Shepheard when he was ick; to give him uch good words as might recover him; and all this, as well to atisfie Thamires, as out of a naturall compaion, which all ought to have one unto another. If I did fail in my love to Thamires, Calidon, for your atisfaction, I will confee it and repent, with a protetation, to love Thamires no more, nor fall into the like fault. But I cannot believe, that therefore I am obliged to love you; for if I hould, it would be to correct one errour by committing another, which is wore. Perhaps you will alledge againt my defence, that having given the whole dipoition of my elfe unto Thamires, and he transferring me into your hands, I cannot contradict his dipoall of me. This is an excellent concluion indeed: I chue you for my husband preently after you may give me unto another; this is very fine Logick. You mut know, Calidon, that the reaon why I gave Thamires all the power of my elfe, was, becaue I did love him, and he loved me; and therefore if he have any power over me, he mut love, that is the implicite condition of his power; but if he do not, then, the caue ceaing, the effect mut needs ceae: and therefore if he do not love me, he hath no power over me. But haply you will reply, that he wears he does continue loving me till, and that it is reaon, not want of affection, which made him transfer me over unto another. I mut anwer both him and you, Shepheard, that I do not believe him; and yet, if reaon can o well perwade with his affection, why hould not reaon have as much power over my affection? Is there any reaon I hould love him, whom nature and reaon both forbids me to love? Nature forbids the banes, for ince the firt houre I ever a • you, there was uch a contrariety in my heart, and uch a ecret antipathy in it againt you, that I diliked every thing I aw you do. Believe it, Calidon, what I ay, proceeds not from any corn of you, but from the very truth; I had rather chue to ret in my grave, then live with you: not but I do know and confee, you deerve a much better fortune; but the reaon is, becaue Nature does hold me from you with abundance of violence, and without any caue: And ince it is o, upon what pretence can you deire I hould be yours ince Nature does forbid it, and Reaon likewie, which neverthwarts Nature? Go, go, Calidon, live in quietnee; do not wilfully endeavour to make two perons mierable; for the truth is, you will be as mierable by it as my elfe. If you do love me, let it uffice, that your love is mot troubleome to me, and do not trive to urcharge me with an intolerable burthen, by forcing me to love you. And be aured of this, that Lignon hall ooner run backward, then you hall finde any place in the affection of Celidea.

This, Madam, is the Anwer, which I hall give unto the hallow reaons of Calidon. But now, I have another more dangerous enemy to encounter withall, who has better Armes, and who gives more marting blowes: I mean, the ungratefull Thamires; Thamires, whom I did really love, and whom I thought had loved me as well as any poibly could. But alas, what would he have now? Can he expect any thing from her, whom he hath betrayed into the hands of her mot cruell enemy? Does he yet hope for any love from her, whom he hath mot ungratefully wronged? Whan colour, and upon what ground can he deire me to love him? Is it, becaue he did love me, or becaue I loved him? This,
Madam, had been ome reaon at that time; but now, ince he has left loving me, and would force me to love another and not himelf, why does he urge unto me the time pat, which is not, nor ever will return? The memory of that time is an argument to hate him the more, ince I do finde him at this preent o unworthy. I do confee I did love him; but, when he reigned me unto another, he did demontratively hew, that he neither did nor does love me: And therefore let him not think it trange that ince my affection did proceed from his mine hould ceae as well as his; for his was the caue, and mine the effect, and the caue ceaing, the effect mut follow. Why did he cut up a Tree, from which he expected fruit? He hath done me more wrong then I him, ince he was the firt offendor, and yet I am atisfied, I complain not, I can quit him with a very good will, and cannot wih he hould court me again, becaue it is a thing impoible to obtain me. What is it he would now have? Does he not know, that as long as our love was mutuall, I was his, and he was mine, and then by the Lawes of Amity he might dipoe of me as his own? If he have given me unto Calidon, how can he pretend me to be his? If he have any thing to require from me, he mut addree himelf to him unto whom he hath given me; if he can have his conent, I will afterwards conider what I have to do; if he cannot, why does he complain of me? or ask me, for what he has given away? He hath acrificed me, as he aith, to Calidon's health, manifeting thereby, that Calidon was dearer unto him, than I was, and in very good time: But can he not be contented, that his acrifice is accepted, and that his deer Calidon is recovered from death? Would he o acrilegiouly recall, what he has dedicated unto the gods? Remove, Thamires, all uch thoughts out of your oul, let the gods do punih you for it; and do not hope, that ince I have been offered unto the gods for the health of Calidon, I will ever toop o low as men again. The truth is, ince I have been o ill treated by the man whom I mot eteemed, it would be extream imprudence in me, to put my elfe into his hands again, who knew not how to make any better ue of me Perhaps Thamires would have me again, that he might om other time ave the life of ome friend or kinman; or ele courts me now, to keep me againt Calidon fall ick again: But be aured, that my own life is much deerer unto me, then his life is unto whom you have given me; and therefore I have all the reaon in the world to look unto my elfe before any other. If I did betow ome tears at thy departure Thamires, I will laugh at your return. Oh, how liberall you are, to give away that which is anothers? But, Oh you heavens, how jut you are, ince when you aw me offended by thee two Shepheards, and knowing my innocency, you would vouchafe to take me into your protection, and have revenged my quarrell, even by my enemies themelves. What dipleaure does this perfideous man receive, even from him unto whom he hath given me? And what torments does this importunate perecutor of my ret receive, even from him, who gave him all the right he has to pretend unto me? What lee can be expected upon them, than divine vengeance? And I make no quetion, Madam, but you will ratifie the doom of heaven, and give entence on my ide.
Thus Celidea ended, and by making an humble reverence unto the Nymph, did hew, that he had no more to ay: And therefore Leonida commanded Thamires to give his reaons, o as he began thus.

div.head: The Anwer of the Shepheard Thamires.
div.p: I Perceive, great Nymph, it happens to me, as unto him that made a word for one, who thrut it into his heart; for I, that educated this Shepheard and Shepheardee with as much indulgent care as was poible; I that taught them to peak, and how to live in the world; yet thee two do wound me to the very heart and oul, o as I have no hopes left, but in your favourable judgment. It eemes, they make me the very Butt of their ingratitude, and would have me bear all their own faults; but, though thee aperions do deeply wound me, yet, I had rather be the offended, then the offending party: And truly, I am naturally uch a deadly hater of ingratitude, which is the bane of all humane ociety, that I had rather receive the blow from the hand of another, then give it.

Perhaps by acknowledging the faults which you both have committed, you will be ahamed, and repent of the wrongs you have done me, in requitall of all my indulgency towards you: And then, all your gilded language which you have employed to my ruine, will be a hame unto your elves, ince I do till love you both, and ince my affection is
yet much above all the injuries you have done me. Now, my children, I doe pardon you, and pae by the follies of your youth; but then, I do expect you hould confee your faults, and acknowledge my favours, and that you doe confee a lee affection than mine, could never pardon uch ingratitude. I perceive, Madam, that I doe peake unto deafe ears, and pend my advice upon tones which hear me not. I have hither to applied the mot milde medicines, to ee if weetnee would cure them, but ince Lenitives will not doe, Corroives mut; and ince they continue till obtinate, I mut purue them with Fire and Sword.

Thee are the mot ubtantial reaons which Calidon hath alleadged: You have given Celidea unto me, and you are obliged unto it by the confidence which my Father did put in you, by the affection which you profeed unto me, and by your hopes of obliging me. And you have offended me much more in offering to take her from me after the gift of her; than if you had at the firt denyed her unto me: This, great Nymph, is all he hath aid with uch a huge flourih of words, both againt mee, againt himelfe, and againt reaon.

Ungratefull Shepheard, wilt thou thus trample upon my goodnes and indulging over thee? You ay that I did give Celidea unto you; and why I beeech you, did I give her? was it was becaue I was weary of her, or onely to pleae you? No, no, ay you, it was only to ave my life. Well then, you mut confee you owe your life unto me; and are you not extreamly ungratefull in offering to take his life away that preerved yours? If I did give her unto you onely to ave your life, what wrong is it to aske her againe, now your life is aved, and you well? But haply you will ay, that though you are recovered, yet it was onely in hopes that Celidea hould remaine with you; what though you have recovered your health, ince now you are not in any danger? Courteie and dicretion teacheth us, that when in caes of neceity wee make ue of any thing which is our friends, we hould retore it with the interet of thanks. It eems you are very farre from o much courteie and dicretion, ince when I gave you ome hopes of Celideas favour, and gave you thereby your life, now you are recovered you would take her and them for your own, and endeavour by gloing language to cover your ingratitude. But, Madam, perhaps he wil ay, that if I do take her from him, he hall fall into the ame danger he was before: No, great Nymph, you ee by experience that now he is aured Celidea will never be his, he onely grows a little more melancholly; but his life is not at all in danger, and therefore to ave his life being the reaon of my act, and not the atisfying of his pleaure; ince his life is aved, I may without offence take her back unto my elf. But admit his life were at the take, would not my life be the ame? For hould I bee deprived of this fair one, death would be more certain unto me than life. Judge, Madam, I beeech you, whether I ought not to have a greater care of my elf than him. If he conceive that I ought to yeeld Celidea unto him, to ave his life becaue his Father loved mee, and recommended him unto me, why does he not as well conceive himelf obliged to yeeld her unto me, ince my life is as well concerned, and that upon the very ame conideration of amity which his Father profeed unto me; Is it not his duty to have as great a care of my life as I had of his? He knows, ungrateful man that he is, I cannot live if I be denyed her, and is he not extreamly ungratefull if he doe deny her unto me? Is hee not unworthy the title of Son unto him that hath o much loved him? Can he think, that becaue I loved him, therefore I am obliged to part from the thing which is mot of all the world dear unto me? Is he not unworthy the name of Kinman, ince he does not value my life? Nay, may I not diown him for a Friend, ince he will not doe the ame offices for mee in my neceity, which I did for him? Nay more; May I not account him the mot cruel enemy I have, ince he purues me againt all reaon, with uch violent arguments to my very death? The very thought of Ingratitude from uch as we have obliged, is o extreamly odious unto all, as I cannot poibly give punctual anwers unto every particular intance of this Shepheard, who hath o extreamly offended me. Give me leave, I beeech you, Madam, to preent this offer unto him in a few words; As he ows his life unto mee for yeelding Celidea unto him, I will releae him of that obligation, o he will yeeld her again unto me. And to make it appear that he is out of all danger, he cannot deny but that it is above a month ince Celidea refued him: She told him that he would never love him; he let him know that her Mother promied not to marry her againt her conent, and at the ame time told him, that heaven and earth hould meet before he would contract any affection with him; yet for all this, ye ee he lives, and trives to take away the life of him
that did preerve him. Since he is mot certainly aured that Celidea will never be his, is he not the mot ungratefull peron in the world, in offering to hinder mee from obtaining her? There is not any hopes for him, and hee would alo ruin all mine. Should he deire that another hould enjoy this happinee before me, the whole world would never know the like Ingratitude. I gave him that which was mine, and hee will not let me have that which is not his: I aved his life by depriving my elf of that which was mot deare unto me, and he will refue that unto me which never was his. But, great Nymph, all thee hot diputes 'twixt him and me, are me-thinks, to no purpoe, ince his misfortune, and my too much affection unto him, hath taken from us both, that happinee which we are diputing about. What right can you have unto Celidea, ince he does not love you? You will ay no other, but from your affection to her, and from my gift. But, Shepheard, what pretence can you have from your affection, ince you ee he didains and refueth you? And what can you pretend unto by my gift, ince I gave you no more than what I had my elf to give? Now all the right that I had, depended upon her own will, and if this will be contrary unto mine, what power or right had I in it? Therefore, Shepheard, you can have none, nor make the leat haddow of pretence unto any. Now, I beeech you, let us ee what right I my elf can pretend unto. Oh heavens, how great would it be if there was no Calidon in being? An affection begun in the Cradle, o long carefully continued; a courthip o full of pure intentions; an affection o violent, and o long in poeion of favours; all thee would make my caue very trong, if Calidon were not in the world, or had no eyes, or ele if he could have guided them according to reaon.

I mut needs confes, fair Celidea (and o I do with teares in my eyes, and orrow in my heart) that you have more reaon to complain of me than all your words and mine can expree. I acknowledge, that never did any affection receive a greater affront than yours hath by my imprudency; yet who hould endure, nay overcome great difficulties, but thoe who have trength and courage? 'Tis true, I have extreamly wronged you, but may not you make this an occaion to hew how highly you can love, by paing by and pardoning uch an offence? What tetimonies of your love have you heretofore promied me? What is it which you have not aid you would urmount for my ake? I do now ummon you unto your promies, and put you to the Tet; And what greater tetimony can you give, then by this occaion which I now offer unto you? When I did oblige you by my ervices, by my affection, and by all manner of obequious obervancie, you did continue your affection unto me: But this is no tetimony of affection, it is rather an acknowledgement of a debt: It had been a right tetimony of your affection, if you had continued when I did hate you. Fortune would have this occaion to preent it elf, though I am extreamly orry for it, to put you to the tryal of your affection; and as a ummons to keep your word: I hope you are not like unto thoe, who vaunt that they doe not fear dangers, yet at the very firt encounter of an enemy, will ubmit without reitance. But you objected againt me, How can you hope, Thamires, to gather any fruits from love, ince you have cut up the Tree? Oh fair Celidea let me tell you, I had rather cut away my life than that deare Tree of Love: Nay, though I hould offer it, yet it would be impoible for me to do it. But admit that I had imprudently cut it up, you know that the Mirtle is the Tree of Love, and why would you have it to be the Cypres? The Mirtle is of a nature, that the more it is cut, the more branches it puts forth. Oh that I could ee this effect in your oul, that I might beleeve there is growing in you this Tree of Love, and not a Tree of Mourning.

But admit my fault, in guilting you, to bee o great as you make it, mut my fault make you to commit the like? If you think o, then you mut confee, that you catch at bad examples, and not at good ones, unlee, as I doe leave you, o you leave me, and when I doe return unto you, you doe return unto me alo: Otherwie, you are more moved with an offence than with a full atisfaction for it; and evil hath a greater predominancie in you than good: But this is unworthy of Celideas oul, which promieth all goodnee and weetnee.

But you ay, that ince I have given you unto Calidon, if I would have any thing of you, I mut ask him. This would puzzle mee to anwer, if I had not heard you ay, that it was impoible for me to give you unto him. Now the matter is brought to that pae, as you mut be either his or mine: If you will not be mine, becaue I have imprudently given you away, then Celidea you mut be Calidons. Conider whether this change be pleaing unto you: If on the contrary, you will not be Calidons, then you cannot deny but you mut be
mine, ince having been mine before, and my gift taking no effect, all right in the world is, that the thing given hould revert unto the firt poeor: And you ought not to be offended with me for offering you as a Sacrifice for Calidons recovery, becaue Sacrifices which are offered unto the gods, are alwaies of the bet and mot precious things we have. Nor doe not think that by continuing to love you afterwards, I doe commit any acrilege, nor doe prophane any acred or holy thing, ince we doe all love the gods themelves: The greatet command which they doe impoe upon us mortals, is to Love them. But for Gods ake doe not ay that I ask you onely to acrifice you again for the recovery of ome other: For my deire is onely to have you again for my own ake. I doe confee my fault, and will not init upon any other argument or reaon, but my extream affection; and will not argue with her any where but before the Throne of Love. I doe here protrate my elf upon my knees, and vow by all eternity, never to rie as long as I live, unlee I be ingratiated into Celideas favour again.

As he pronounced thee words, he kneeled down, and his eyes flowed with uch a River of Tears that all the company did pitty him, Celidea her elf was a little moved, and putting her hand before her face, did turn her head the other way.

Then the Nymph, eeing they had no more to ay, did rie up, and taking Paris, Silvander, and the Shepheardees aide, did ask their opinions upon this difference: Their opinions did much vary, ome to one ide, ome to another: At lat, and after a long and erious debate, they all returned to their places, and Leonida pronounced her entence in this manner.

div.head: The Judgement of the Nymph Leonida.
div.p:
THree things doe preent themelves unto us, upon the difference betwixt Celidea, Thamires, and Calidon: The firt, Love: The econd, Duty: The third, an Offence. In the firt, we oberve, three great Affections; in the econd, three great Obligations; in the third, three great Injuries. Celidea hath loved Thamires from her Cradle, Thamires hath loved Celidea, though he be elder; and Calidon hath loved her from the firt time hee ever aw her. Celidea hath been much obliged unto the virtuous affection of Thamires; Thamires much obliged unto the memory of Calidons Father; and Calidon much obliged unto the Indulgency of Thamires. Again, Celidea hath been extreamly offended with Thamires, for giving her unto Calidon; Calidon no lee offended with Thamires and Celidea: Thamires offended with Calidon for refuing to doe the ame courteie he received; And Celidea offended with Calidon for offering to contrain her will, and making her to loe him whom he did love. All thee things being long debated, and eriouly conidered, we conceive, that as thoe things which Nature produceth, are alwaies more perfect then thoe that are produced by Art, o the Love that comes by a natural inclination, is greater, and more etimable than thoe affections that doe proceed from deignes or obligations. Furthermore, thoe obligations which we receive in our own perons, being greater than thoe in the behalf of another; o it is certain, that a benefit obligeth more than a memory. An offence which hath any tincture of ingratitude, it is much more hainous than a bare offence without it, and deerves a greater punihment. Now, we do find that the Love of Thamires does proceed from a natural inclination; for commonly uch loves are reciprocal, and o he loving Celidea, he was loved again: But o is not the love of Calidon, whoe terile affection produceth nothing but hatred and corn. Moreover, the good offices which Calidon hath received from Thamires, doe render him more obliged, than Thamires can be upon the core of an Uncle. Again, Calidons offence againt Thamires having a tain of Ingratitude upon it, is much greater than the offence of Thamires againt Calidon, ince Thamires may almot cover it with the name of Revenge or Chatiment. Therefore, in the firt place, we doe ordain that the love of Calidon do ubmit unto the love of Thamires: That the obligation of Thamires be eteemed lee than the obligation of Calidon; And the offence of Calidon greater than the offence of Thamires. And as for that which concerns Thamires and Celidea, we do declare, that Celideas obligation unto Thamires is above the offence of Thamires, in repect of his pure and innocent love; and in repect of his carefull and indulgent education of her, o as hee would be ingrateful if he did not think her elf much obliged: 'Tis true, his offence is not mall, when in diadvantage of his affection, he would needs atisfie the obligations
which he thought he owed unto Calidon. And yet in conideration there is no offence but may be pardoned by a peron that truly loves, we doe ordain, with the advice of all thoe who have heard the difference, That the Love of Celidea hall urmount the offence which hee hath received from Thamires; And that the Love which Thamires for the future hall bear unto her, hall urpae that affection which hitherto he hath born unto her; for uch is our Judgement.

This was Leonida's Sentence, which hath ince been oberved by all three; though the poor Calidon received it with o much digut, that but for the extream didain of Celidea, he hould hardly have upported it. But his malady at this time proved to be his remedy, when from a more ound judgement he conidered how much he was obliged unto Thamires, and how great his folly was, in thinking to make Celidea love him by force. But at the firt, thee coniderations had not o much power upon him, as to cut off all his hopes at one blow: which the Nymph wiely foreeeing, and to avoyd the complaints and teares of this Shepheard, as oon as ever he had pronounced the lat word of her Sentence, he did rie up, being partly invited unto it by the night which came on apace, and he had no more day left than to carry her unto her Uncles houe. Therefore, after hee had aluted all the fair Shepheardees, he and Paris entreated Silvander to conduct them through the Wood of Bonlieu, let they hould loe their way, it being very late, and too troubleom for the Shepheardees to accompany her.

Thus they parted; and preently after, the Nymph and Paris dimied Silvander, and came unto the houe of Adamas, as he was ready to goe unto his upper. Silvander as he returned, left Bonleiu on his left hand, a Temple where many Vetals, and chat Daughters of Druids doe inhabit, under the charge of the venerable Chriante, and hee went through a Wood o thick, that though the Moon was up and hined, yet hee could not hit his way. And indeed his own wandring thoughts as well as the darknee of the Wood, did put him beides his aym: For hee was o wholly taken up with Diana, that he minded nothing ele; And walking on, he came at lat upon an open place, where hee aw the Moon, he was a little pat her Full, and hined very clearly. The Shepheard fell down upon his knees, to adore her; and becaue of the conformity in Names between Diana and her, he loved that Starre above all the ret in the Cope of Heaven. Having thus adored her, and Diana in her, hee tood up, and fixing his eyes upon her, he uttered thee Lines.

lg.head: A Comparion between DIANA and the Moon.

l.hi: MOt glorious Star that hines o clear
And radiant in the pangled Sphear,
As makes the Night like Day appear,

lg.l: Jut o does my Diana fair.

l.hi: Like to thy elf o chat, her breat
With o much cruelty is dret,

lg.l: As it is fond Acteons bet

l.hi: To court her with no looe requet.
Of all the Tapers in the Night,
'Tis thou that gives us greatet light:
Of all the Beauties, none o bright,

lg.l: Diana is the prime delight.
Yet when Diana I think upon,

l.hi: You doe not hold comparion;

lg.l: For you had one Endymion,
But my Diana ne're had one.

div.p: Oh heavens, (cryed he out then) what then will become of thy Silvander, ince he will not admit of any Endymion? Can it poibly be, that Nature, who cannot chue but be pleaed with her workmanhip, hould not finde one in all her Treaury worthy of her?
