Can he poibly betow o much beauty upon this Shepheardee, and make her incapable of Love? However, they have no eyes; that are not delighted with o rare a piece of excellency. Does not the gods allow, that as our hearts receive the greatet blowes, o our hearts hould reent the greatet contentment? Did they make her o fair, and not to be loved? Or if we do love her, did they make her to conume us? Ah! alas, I ee, that as this beauty was made to be loved o it is for her own glory, and for the torment of thoe who love her as I do. This thought gave him uch a top, that he left walking; and after a long agitation of thoughts, he uttered thee Lines.

lg.head: That no Conideration whatoever, can hinder him from loving his Mitree.

lg.l: WHy does my thoughts ugget,
And bid me not to love her,
But et my heart at ret,
She's aimed for another?
If for a Mortall, why
Not I, as any other?
If for a god? then I
Will worhip and adore her.
'Mongt mortalls there is none
Can equall flame with me;
Nor 'mongt the gods not one
That can more zealous be.
What though this cruell oul
Didains all them that love her?
Love will at lat control,
Or Reaon needs mut move her.
If Reaon will but do't,
By Merit I'le her gain:
If Love will bring her to't,
I'le love and love again.

div.p:
The Moon then, as if purpoely to invite him to a longer tay in that place, did eem to lend him a double lutre. And becaue he had left his flock with Diana's, and aured himelfe, he would out of her curtey take all requiite care over it, he reolved to pend part of the night there, according to his uuall cutome; for he took abundance of delight, in entertaining himelfe with his new thoughts, that retiring from all company, he ued to get into ome private valley, or ome olitary wood; and day would oftentimes overtake him, before he began to think of any leep, making his long and amorous thoughts ee both the evening and the morning. Thus at this time did he wander, chuing that path which by chance his foot did fall into; and after he had fancyed a thouand Chimera's, he found himelfe in the midt of a thick wood, and knew not where he was; and though at every tep almot he tumbled againt omething or other, yet could he not give over his pleaing thoughts; all that he aw, furnihed his fancy with ome conceit, and fed his imagination. If he chanced to tumble upon any thing: I found greater rubs (would he ay) in my deires. If he heard the leaves hake when they were moved by ome blat of winde: I tremble more for fear (would he ay) when I am by her, and when I would acquaint her with my reall paions, which he thinks to be fained. If he look'd up and aw the Moon, he would ay: The Moon in the heavens, and my Diana upon earth. This olitary place, ilence, and the pleaing light of the night, caued this hepheard to walk o long with the
weet entertainment of his thoughts, that being got into the thick of the wood he lot the light of the Moon, which was <> by the leaves of trees, and deiring to get out of that gloomy place, he no ooner looked about to make choice of a good path, but he heard one not far off talking; and though he made choice of that place for privacy, yet his curioity invited him to know who thoe were that paed away the night without leep, auring himelfe, that they were ome that were ick of his own dieae; and making it appear by this, that every thing lookes for its like, and that curioity hath a great power in Love, ince, when he was o weetly taken up with his own thoughts, that he depied all the world in comparion of them, except the ight of Diana; yet was he content to forake them, to ee who thee were; o as quitting them for a time, and giving way to his curioity, he turned that way from whence he heard the voice. He had not gone above fifteen or twenty paces, but in the mot obcure part of the wood, he found himelfe cloe by two men, whom he could not poibly know, as well by reaon of the darknee, as becaue their backs were towards him; yet he knew by their habits, that one of them was a Druide, and the other a Shepheard.

They were et under a Tree, which pread its leaves over a chrytall fountain, whoe pleaing murmur invited them to pend part of the night in that place. When Silvander was motdeirous to know them, he heard one anwer the other, thus: But, Father, it is very trange, and I cannot ufficiently admire it, that you hould by your dicoure intimate as much, as if it mut be confeed, that there are many other beauties more perfect, then the beauty of my Mitree; which truly I cannot believe, without an unpardonable offence: For certainly, every one does think his own the fairet; and to confee he is not, is a crime, both againt his Mitree, and againt Love. Then he heard the Druide anwer in this manner: My Son, there is no doubt of what I ay, nor any fear of offending her Beauty, or Love; and I am confident, that I hall in a few words make you undertand it: You know, that all beauty proceeds from that overaign goodnee which we call God, it is a Ray of himelfe, and trancends all his other creatures; and as the Sun, which we ee, does enlighten the Aire, the Water, and the Earth, with the ame beams; o alo the eternall Sun, does enlighten the angelick Undertanding, the rationall Soul, and the Matter. But, as the cleernee of the Sun appears more bright in the Air than in the Water, and in the Water then in the earth: o the illumination of God appears with greater lutre in the Angelick Undertanding, then in the Rationall Soul; and in the Rationall Soul, more then in the Matter. Into the firt, he hath infued Ideas; into the econd, Reaon; and into the lat, Formes. The Druide would have gone on, had not the hepheard interrupted him in this manner: Your dicoure, Father, is a little too high, and you do not conider the capacity of him unto whom you peak; my wit is too dull to oar o high: But if you will pleae to make me undertand, what the Angelicall Undertanding is, what the Rationall Soul is, and what the Matter is, of which you peak, perhaps I hall undertand omething more. My Son, aid the Druide, Angelicall Undertanding is that pure Intellect, by which they ee that Soveraign Beauty, and are adorned with all kinde of Ideas. The Rationall Soul is that, by which men are ditinguihed from beats; it is it by which we come to the knowledge of things which is called Rationall. The Matter, is that which falls under the Senes, which is imbellihed with divers forms that are given unto them, and by which you may judge, whether he whom you love, has in perfection the two lat beauties, which we tearm Corporeall and Rationall, and which we may without any offence ay, that there is in others greater beauties then in hers; which you will undertand by a comparion of Bottles, full of water; for, as the greater do hold more then the little ones, and yet the little ones are as full as the greater: o it may be aid of all things capable of beauty; for there are ubtances, which by their perfection of Nature, can receive much more beauty then others, which yet cannot be termed imperfect, becaue they have as much perfection as they can receive. And under this notion comes the beauty of your Mitree, whom you may ay is perfect, and yet without offence confee, that he hath lee beauty then thee pure Intellectualls which I peak of. If you be not too much tranported with young and imprudent affections, and et too great a price upon the beauty of her face, you will et your whole affection upon the beauty of her minde, in which you will finde omething o lating fair, as will give you as much delight and atisfaction, as the beauty of a face gives you orrow, and perhaps depair. I have heard much dicoure upon this ubject, anwered the Shepheard, but it o much dipleaed me, that I did not remember it. But I remember, that one of you Druides endeavoured to prove, that the minde, the eye, and the ear,
have only their parts in Love: For, aid he, Love is only a deire of Beauty; and there being three orts of Beauties, that of the fight, of which the eye is the only judge; that of harmony, of which the ear is only capable; and that of reaon, which the minde can only dicern, it mut follow, that the eyes, the ears, and the minde, have only their atisfactions. If any other Senes do intrude, they reemble thoe impudent guets, that come unto Marriages before they be invited. Oh Son, aid the Druide, this is a Doctrine which perhaps is undertood by many, but certainly followed by very few; and therefore no wonder, that o many vexations and misfortunes do fall out amongt Lovers. For Love, which mot certainly is the greatet, and mot holy of all the gods, eeing himelfe o many waies offended by uch as call themelves his Votaries, either in contemning his ordinances, or prophaning his purity, does very often chatie them, to the end they may know their faults. For, my Son, what are jealouies, didains, landers, quarrells, infidelities, and all breaches of amity, but punihments of that great god? Did our deires tretch no further then dicoure, no further then the ight, nor no further then the ear, why hould we ever be jealous? why didainfull? why angry? why enemies? why treacherous? and briefly, why hould not all love, and be loved, ince, then, the poeion of another would not one jot leen our happinee? Then Silvander heard the Shepheard interrupt the Druide with a deep igh, in this manner: Alas, Father, how true is your dicoure unto all Lovers, but my elfe? for my love is full of purity and chat deires, as it cannot offend the mot demure Vetall. Let the god of Love be the mot evere of all the gods, yet I am ure, he can finde no fault with my affection; and yet for all this, never was Lover o rigorouly treated as I am. Son, aid the Druide, many things do produce different effects, according to the ubjects they meet withall. A Line which is treight, is not made only to draw another traight Line by, but often to know what is not traight. Thoe dyaters which you reent, though in others they are called punihments, yet in you, they may be termed tetimonies, and proofs of your love and vertue, which will at lat o turn to your advantage, as you may with reaon ay, that you had never been happy, unlee you had been mierable. And in the interim be aured, your Mitree will repent of her fault, and the wrong he does you. After this, becaue it was very late, he roe up, with intention to go away, and took the hepheard by the hand, who as he followed anwered thus.

I beeech you, Father, and conjure you, by your love unto me, not to ay my Mitree is in any fault, much lee that he does me wrong; for he having power to dipoe of me as much as my elfe, you will offend the mot perfect piece that ever nature produced, and will more dioblige me by uch language, then your aitance can pleae me. Silvander hearkened very attentively unto their dicoure, and though he did very preciely oberve all their actions, yet uch was the obcurity of the place, that he could not know them: and though he thought he knew the Druide, yet, eeing only his back, he was not certain. As for the hepheard, he was altogether unknown unto him, o as he did not remember he ever heard his voice before. This incertainty therfore caued him to follow them, hoping for a better dicovery by the Moon, when they were out of the woods; but keeping at a good ditance, let he hould be een by them, he lot them amongt the Trees, and never ince could tell what became of them, which being very orry for, he left not his quet of them untill mot of the night was pent; but wearinee at the lat made him look for a place to ret in not knowing how to hit the way unto his Town. When Silvander was aleep, he waked not untill the Sun was very high. The Shepheard that dicoured with the Druide in the night, was as early as Aurora; and the place of his dwelling being very neer, as he was taking his uuall morning-walk, he epied Silvander aleep: He having not been above a month in the Country, and having no acquaintance with any Shepheard, he was very deirous to know who Silvander was, and therefore went very oftly to him. He no ooner et his eye upon Silvander's face, but he knew him to be his mot intimate friend; the remembrance of their former acquaintance, and of the pleaing life they had lived together, caued his eyes to flow in tears: Then retiring back a few paces, and hiding himelfe behinde a great Tree, let if Silvander waked, he hould pie him, he looked upon him very eriouly, and in a low voice uttered thee words: Oh, my dear friend, and mot faithfull companion, Silvander, how glad, and how ad both, doth this meeting with thee make me? Our friendhip, that now ees thee o ad, will not let me rejoyce at the ight of thee; and yet the ight of thee brings into my memory that happy life I lived, ever ince I was firt acquainted with thee, untill that fatall entence which my Shepheardee pronounced againt me; a entence which I cannot remember, but with a ad heart I mut needs
call for death to relieve me, finding experimentally the Proverb to be mot true, That none are o mierable, as thoe that have been happy, and now are not. Who is able without a flood of tears to think upon my pat felicity, and to ee my preent miery? Upon this, he was ilent; and going further back, becaue he aw Silvander tir a little, and looking about him, aid thee words: Oh fairet Shepheardee, how cruelly do you treat this poor Shepheard? The tranger knew he was aleep; but not knowing who was the Shepheard that he poke of, he went neerer him; and when he looked him in the face, he found it all tears, which found a paage through his eye lids, though they were cloe. Then did he conclude, that it was himelfe he poke of, which he thought to be very trange, when he remembered, that his humour was wont to be extreamly avere unto Love, inomuch as he was commonly called, The Shepheard without affection: But conidering what power Beauty hath, he believed that now he was no more exempted from the wounds of Love, than other hepheards of his age; and he was the more confirmed in this opinion, when he remembered, that ome had told him of the wager that was between him and Phillis. This conideration made him look upon him and ay: Ah Silvander! I ee thou art now far unfit to give any counel unto others, and for ought I ee, tandt in need of counel thy elfe My friendhip cannot chue but pray, that Love would be more pitifull unto him, then it hath been unto me, and make him more fortunate then I have been. Then going gently away, he went unto the place where he lodged; and he was no ooner et upon his bed-ide, but thinking upon his encounter, Silvander's affection unto him came into his minde, what great familiarity had been between them, and what fortune it was hould bring him into this place. It is, aid he, to give a beginning unto a better life, and to put an end unto my torments. Alas that cannot be, for nothing can make me lee mierable then I am, unlee it be death. Perhaps the heavens, foreeeing the end of my daies, conducted Silvander, my bet friend, unto me, to bid me my lat Adien, in the name of himelf and all the ret of my friends. This conideration took up his thoughts a good while, and at lat made him reolve upon a thing which never came into his minde before, which was, to write unto his Mitree; for her evere banihment of him had o damped his pirit, that he durt not aume o much boldnee: But now verily believing, that his coure of life was neer an end, he conceived himelfe obliged to take his leave of her in ome ort or other, before he went out of the world. Then he took pen and inke, and writ a Letter, and after he had folded it up, he upercribed it, Unto the fairet, and mot loved Shepheardee in the whole Univere. Then he went unto the place where he left Silvander, and going gently to him, after he had kied the Letter two or three times, he put it into his hand: Oh happy Paper (aid he) if thy good Fate do bring thee into the hands of her, upon whom all my contentment depends, touch her to the heart; and if thou cant not move her to any pitty, yet force her to believe, that though he be changed from me, yet my affection hall ever be the ame to her. And thou Silvander (aid he, putting the Letter into his hand) if love will yet give thee leave to look upon the beauty of her, unto whom this Letter is directed, give it unto her: Good hepheard, I beeech thee do this good office for thy friend, as the lat that he can hope to receive from thee or any ele Then this hepheard went away with folded armes, and dejected eyes, untill he came to his lodging. Preently after, Silvander awaked; and becaue he aw the Sun of a great height, he looked about which way he hould take homeward; and rubbing his eyes after his leep, he made ue of that hand in which the Letter was; he wondred extreamly when he aw it, but much more, when he read unto whom it was directed. Do I leep, (aid he) or do I wake? Is it a dream, or is this a Letter which I ee? Then looking well upon it: No, no, aid he, I do not leep, but I have a Letter in my hand, which is directed unto the Fairet, and mot loved hepheardee in the whole Univere. But, if I be not aleep, why am I ignorant who gave it unto me? Had I it before I fell aleep? No, no, I had it not. It mut of neceity be, that ome did put it into my hand when I was aleep: This may very well be, for there is not one of all the gods that has not loved the beauties of the earth; the god of Love himelfe, who wounds others, has not been exempted; o as it eemes, they think our hepheardees more fair then their goddees. Why hould I not think, that ome of thee Immortalls, or ome Faun, or Demi-god, having een my fair Diana, is fallen in love with her? Then conidering a little with himelfe: But, aid he, who is it unto whom this Letter is ent? Let us ee, certainly it will tell us. Then unfolding the paper, he read it from the beginning to the ending; but, when he found the concluion of the Letter to be thus ubcribed, The mot unfortunate, yet, the mot faithfull of your ervants: Oh! cried he, there
is no doubt to be made, but it is my elfe who writ this Letter: It mut of neceity be, that my good Angell that has a care of my life, having read the thoughts of my oul, has writen them in this paper, that I might hew them unto Diana. The very truth is, there is not any beauty that can caue uch violent paions, as this which I do read, unlee the beauty of my Mitree; no Lover is able to conceive o much affection, unlee it be Silvander: So as there is no doubt to be made, but that this Letter being directed, Unto the fairet, and mot loved hepheardee in the Univere, I ought to give it unto Diana; and being written, by the mot faithful and unfortunate hepheard, it mut be Silvander. Thus Silvander went away in a perwaion, that this Letter was directed unto Diana; and deiring he hould ee it, after humble thanks given unto his kinde Angel, from whom he had received this good office, he went that way which he thought the hortet cut unto his Town, with a deign, that if he did not meet her, to go in quet of her aoon as he had dined; o as not meeting her, he dipatched his repat aoon as poibly he could, hee let forth his flock out of the fold, which had too long waited for him, and took the path that conducts to the Fountain of Siccanours, hoping there to heare of her; and he was not deceived in his hopes, for as oon as he entered into the meadow adjoyning to it, he aw her itting under a thick buh with Atrea. Love well'd him immediately with a deire to hear their dicoure uneen, ince they eemed to be very erious at their work; and in order to this deign, he crept from Tree to Tree, and from Buh to Buh, till he got o neer them unperceived, that he could hear what they aid, having left his flock a little behinde him in the wood, under the tuition of his Dog. In the mean time, Atrea talked thus unto Diana: Certainly Phillis does not deerve o much favour from you; and I mut confee, that I am a little jealous of her, though I have laid no wager with her, as Silvander hath; for I would not have her, or any ele in the world, have a greater hare in your favour then my elfe. Fair Atrea, anwered Diana, it belongs unto me to beg the favour of your affection, which I do with abundance of zeal, o as in this I will not yield unto Phillis, of whom you peak. Dearet Siter, replyed Atrea, your merits do o much trancend all others, as they do render you much above the common rate of Love. But, how comes it to pae, aid Diana, I hould be o long with you, before I could obtain this happinee? I mut needs confee, anwered Atrea, that I was either blinde, if I had been with you o long, and not loved you; or ele I mut confee, we are not Mitrees of our own wills, but that there is ome upream power which dipoeth of us all as it pleaeth: Diana bluhed at thee words, and weetly cating down her eyes, anwered her: Your language, dear Siter, would put me to the bluh, if I were not wholly devoted to be yours; but this will, which you mention, makes me take all that comes from you for favours, though if they hould come from any other, I hould eteem them no better then mockeries. If you hould take my expreions in that ene, aid Atrea, you would injure that affection which I do bear unto you, and that which you have promied unto me. This mutuall affection, aid Diana, is too holy and too acred to be injured; and therefore to obey you, and pleae my elfe, I will believe, that your expreions are commendations of me, which does proceed not o much from truth, as from your affection to me, which makes things eem to be greater, then truly they are, and cats a mit before your eyes. Unlee, dear Siter, aid Atrea, you hold me for one of a very weak judgment, you will believe, that they do proceed both from truth, and from my affection alo. As for truth, aid Diana, I do et a high etimation upon it; and as for your affection, I do deire it above any thing upon earth. Upon thee words, they both embraced and kied each other, with abundance of zealous affection; which Silvander eeing, he wihed himelfe Atrea a hundred times, that he might have received the like favours. After this, they et themelves down again, and falling unto their work again, he thought that he heard them name him; and therefore, that he might hear the better, he crept neerer unto them, and aw, that his Mitree was making a bracelet of her hair. When he was beginning to be jealous, let any but himelfe hould wear it, he heard Atrea ay: Silvander would be very jealous, if he aw his enemy in greater favour than himelfe. I do believe, aid Diana, that he did ask it of me with that deigne. I do think o alo, aid Atrea; but you do wrong the hepheard in it, if you do favour the one more than the other; you are not as good as your word, becaue you have promied the contrary. The advantage which I eem to confer upon Phillis, aid Diana, nor the wager it elfe, is not of any great importance; beides, the hepheard did never requet me for it, as he did. But I do beeech you, (aid Silvander, hewing himelfe unawares) if he do requet one, I hope you will be pleaed
to betow it. The hepheardees hearing him peak, were much amazed; and their wonder was o great, as they were a long time before they pake one word, only gazed upon one another, fearing he had heard the dicoure they had a little before he came.

At lat, Atrea began to peak, and told him thus: Fie, Silvander, I wonder your dicretion hould be no more, then to harken unto the ecrets of others. Do you o little repect your Mitree, as to teal a hearing, when he would not have any hear but me? I do not know what ecrets you mean (anwered Silvander) but I am ure, that the curioity which invited me hither, was, only to hear my own ecrets from the mouth of my fairet Mitree; it is from her that I mut be informed and I am very orry I came no ooner, ince all that I heard informes me no further, then concerning a Bracelet, which, with much injutice, is intended for Phillis. You need not be orry, hepheard, (aid Atrea) for comming no ooner, ince if you had, your crime, in offering thus to teal the ecrets of your Mitree, had been no lee then his, that tole fire from heaven; and in reaon, you could not expect a more milde chatiement.

Oh! anwered Silvander, it is not any fear of punihment which can give a top unto my jut curioity; for I do o much eteem the means of rendring her proofes of my affection, as all manner of punihments are weet unto me, upon that account. Good Silvander, (aid Atrea unto him) how can you think to give her any tetimonies of affection this way? I will tell you, fair hepheardee, (aid Silvander) hould I not render her a mot infallible tetimony, if knowing what he deires hould be ecret, I hould conceal it? For we now live in an age, when every one does not only tell all they know, but all that they do imagine. In o doing, hepheard, (anwered Atrea) you do make your dicretion appear. But more affection, aid he. As for dicretion, aid Atrea, I will allow it; but as for affection, I will refer my elfe unto her, to whom it is addreed. I will make anwer for her, aid he. Would you have Silvander, who heretofore was a declared enemy to Love, yet now mut love and adore; would you, I ay, have him make his love known? But how comes it to pae, fair Mitree, (aid he, and addreed himelfe unto Diana) that you would not anwer unto what I ay, but eemes, as if my dicoure did not concern you? Perhaps the reaon is, anwered Diana, becaue I mut not be your Mitree above fourteen or fifteen daies. If that do trouble you, aid he, you may eaily finde a remedy, by obliging me by your favours to continue in your ervice, as your beauty and perfections have hitherto mot really contrained me.

Ah Silvander, anwered Diana, let us talk no more of any favours and ervice, ince the terme of three Months precribed for your faigned affection, is almot pat; it would be too great a trouble to you, to contrain your naturall inclination any longer.

Fairet hepheardee, anwered Silvander, I would not have you believe I do think your ervice any trouble; but I'le aure you, that it is abundance of delight unto me, to do any ervice upto a peron of o great a merit; inomuch, as though my Nature were contrary unto Love more then it is, yet hould I with abundance of delight, continue in uch a ervice.

Although, hepheard, you hould (aid Diana, and miled) yet it is agreed upon but by one party; for though your naturall Genius do incline that way, yet, you can never hope, that I will. Thee words did touch Silvander's heart o to the quick, ince he perceived by them, that he had gained a mall influence upon her good-will, as he was not able to hide his ad reentments of them; but his countenance did plainly dicover them by changing colour: Which Atrea perceiving: How now, Silvander, aid he unto him, what! does your heart fail you? It were trange, replyed he, if uch cruell language from my Mitree, hould not extreamly trouble me; yet, do not think my heart hall ever fail me, though he and the heavens have the dipoure of all my hopes and life. Is not this, anwered Atrea, rather rahnee in you, then courage? and are you not too preumptuous, in denying uch powers? No, replied the hepheard, it is a mot true, reall, perfect, and mot faithfull love which makes me peak o. By thee and the like expreions, Diana perceived, that Silvander did really love her. Silvander, he did foreee abundance of difficulties, and very mall hopes unto himelfe. And Atrea did conceive, that Love had laid a foundation of an exquiite and lating affection. And though they all three had different thoughts, yet were they all true, as afterwards you hall perceive. But Silvander interrupting the ubject of this dicoure, addreed himelfe unto Diana: I hope, fairet Mitree, aid he, that this Bracelet of your fair hair, which you have made for Phillis, is only to be rid of her importunities; and if it be o, you are obliged to favour Silvander
as much as her; and let you hould be taxed with partiality, you ought to treat us both with equall favour, though the affection which you have caued in my oul, cannot be equall'd by any other. And why not, aid Atrea, taking the part of Phillis, ince both sour affections do proceed from the ame caue; one grain of corn produceth everall ears: Allthough the caue of our affections be the ame, aid Silvander, yet the effects may be different. But experience hewes the contrary, aid Atrea, for the affection of Phillis hath obtained that favour, which is denyed yours. This is not: or want of any love, anwered the hepheard, but for want of good fortune: yet, ince the dropping of water upon the hardet Marble, will, in continuance of time, pierce it; why may not I as well hope, that my Love and fervency of prayers long continued, may as well work upon the marble heart of this fair one? Then, after he had looked upon her, or rather adored her a long while, be fell down upon his knees: If Love, my fairet Mitree aid he unto her have any influence upon beauty, and if prayers caued thunderbolts to fall out of the band of Jupiter, how is it poible, that the extream affection of Silvander, and his mot zealous upplications cannot obtain as much favour, as the hallow affection and troubleome importunities of Phillis hath obtained from you? If it cannot, I may with as much reaon ay, that the way to obtain love is not to love; and the way to overcome an obdurate heart, is not, by prayers and earnet upplications; but only by diimulation, and vexing importunities.

Silvander ued many other uch expreions as thee, by which the hepheardee gathered more aurance, that love had taken root in him. And Atrea knowing Diana's minde not to be very avere, from granting Silvander what he asked, would needs oblige them both by one act; and therefore joyned her prayers unto Silvander's, and he prevailed o with Diana, that the Bracelet which was intended for Phillis, was betowed upon this Shepheard; yet, upon a condition, that he hould keep it no longer, then the end of the terme which he was to erve her, which he meant was to end within a few dayes; which the hepheard with ome difficulty aented unto; but remembring, that though the time of his faigned ervice would oon expire, yet he remembred alo: that the time which he was to erve her <…> earnet, would lat as long as his life. It is impoible to expree the thankfulne ••
<>
Silvander's oul, but much more his atisfied reentments: Let it uffice, that he, who heretofore was wont to depie all manner of favours from Love, and who could not imagine any could finde any contentment in uch follies (as he called them) that he does now confee, that there is no felicity comparable unto this favour which he now reented. And when he was in the midt of his weet imaginations, it eemes, Love had a minde to compleat his joyes, in making the hepheardee Phillis to enter: For he, whoe happinee is unknown to any but himelfe, cannot be aid to be compleatly happy; but the more it is known, the more happy he is, and much the more, when this happinee does not come by Fortune, but by Merit. Aoon as Silvander aw her, he ran unto her, and in a mot jocund manner, hewed her the arme, on which he had already put his mot beloved Bracelet, and paed it often before her eyes, aying: Here, Phillis, here is the earnet of my enuing Victory. Phillis, who had been eeking Lycidas, with a deire to convince him of his jealouie, and could not finde him, was o ad and o weary, as he needed not to counterfeit any anger, nor change any countenance to tetifie her dipleaure and orrowes, which this favour might have caued in her. And becaue Silvander was very troubleome unto her, not only in this Act, but in being the bellowes, which did blow up the jealouie of Lycidas, he aid unto him in as harp a manner as he could: This earnet, hepheard, which you hew me, is rather an argument of your little merit, then of any enuing victory; for o it is uuall to do, only to make all even. What do you mean by that, aid the hepheard? I mean, replyed he, that on that end which is too leight, they ue to put ome weight to counterpoie it, untill the journey be ended; but when they are arrived there, then they throw away that which was only to make an equall ballance. So till we are arrived at the end of our terme, Diana does wiely ballance that ide which is the leighter, by her favours; but afterwards, he will give her judgment without any regard unto the weight of my affection, or the levity of your little love: And then, God knowes on whom the victory you peak of will fall. Silvander miled, and anwered: It is rather the cutome of mierable people to be envious, and leen the happinee of others, which they infinitely eteem by their language.

Phillis, without any further reply, left him, and went unto the two hepheardees, and was extreamly offended at them: And becaue Diana laid the fault upon Atrea, and
Atrea could not well excue her elfe, Silvander began to peak for them both, addreing himelfe unto Diana: I beeech you, fairet Mitree, aid he, conider how prudent Love is, and how wiely he governes the actions of thoe he is pleaed withall. You thought hitherto that Phillis loved you, and indeed I know none, but have in ome ort been deceived by her diimulations. Love, who knowes all the interiour faculties of the oul, and purpoing to undeceive you, hath caued you to favour me with this Bracelet of your hair, not onely as a mark of my affection, but alo to dicover the hollow affection of this deluder by her jealouie: For as it is a thing impoible, that two contraries hould be at the ame time in one place; o much more, that love and jealouie hould be at the ame time in one and the ame heart. Silvander's aim was, only to torment Phillis the more; for knowing how jealous Lycidas was, he doubted not but to trouble her, by propoing, that Love and Jealouy are inconitent: And he being touched to the quick could not chue but anwer him thus: Pray, Shepheard, what reaons and arguments have you to maintain o bad an opinion? Such, aid he, as will make you confee your elfe of the ame; at the leat, if you know what the reaon is. Love is nothing but a deire and every deire is hot: Jealouie is nothing but a fear, and all fear is as cold as ice; and how can you imagine uch a cold Child hould be the iue of uch a hot Parent? We ee, aid Phillis, that flint, which is cold, will end orth parks that are hot. Mot true, anwered Silvander; but fire never produceth cold. Yet by your favour, replied Phillis ahes, that are cold, do proceed from fire. Yes, anwered the hepheard but when the ahes are cold, the fire is not in them. Phillis was almot non-plut at this reply; and much more, when Diana poke. So likewie, aid he, when cold jealouie begins, Love, that is hot ends. Mitree, replyed Phillis, my enemy may well get the victory, if he have o good a Second as your elfe. Then turning her elfe towards Atrea: And you, fair hepheardee, aid he I may jutly think you a very ill friend, if eeing me aaulted by two, you will not take my part. Atrea anwered very adly: I do hold it for a thing o certainly true, that jealouy may proceed from love, as not to bring it into any doubt. I will not dipute it, let I hould be forced to confes, that I my elfe did not love, becaue I was jealous as I do ee you are forced to confes, that being jealous of Diana, you do not <> her; or at the leat, being in doubt whether jealouie may proceed from love, you are not well asured whether you love her or no. I do kis the hand of this fair and jut hepheardes, aid Silvander, who, without repect of perons, peaks with o much truth in my advantage. If you be obliged unto me, aid Atrea, then urely you do think, that I did peak partially in your favour; for none are beholding unto him that peaks truth, more then to him that payes a debt jutly due. Mot true, anwered Silvander, if it be taken in the rigour of jutice but we do live in an age, wherein o few do follow vertue imply and cleerly, as we may think our elves obliged unto thoe, that will but acknowledge any benefit, although they are obliged unto it. But what can you argue againt that experience which we daily finde, aid Phillis unto him? For I know a hepheard, who after he had loved long, and fell into extream jealouie: yet afterwards recovering out of it, did continue his affection long after: Can you ay, that this was a fire extinguihed, which produced thee ahes? It is not impoible, (anwered Silvander) but one that is well may fall ick, and after that icknes, grow well again; nor, that a fire may be put out, and afterwards kindled again. Affection that was long hot, may be put out by cold jealouie, and that jealouie being gone, it may become as hot as ever it was before: But it cannot be, that health and icknes, hot fire and cold ahes, love and jealouie, hould be in the ame ubject at the ame time. And for a full clearing of this truth, let us oberve the effects of love and jealouie, and by them judge, whether the caues from whence they proceed, have any conformity together. The effects of Love is an extream deire in our oules, to ee the peron loved, to erve her, and to pleae her, as much as poibly we can. The effects of jealouie, is a fear to meet her whom we love, a carelesnes to pleae her, and a didaining to erve her: And who can think uch contrary effects can proceed from one and the ame caue? If we do, we mut confes, that nature will detroy her elfe, if he will have contraries to conit together. Phillis would gladly have anwered, but he was o non-plut, as he knew not where to begin; at which Diana could not chue but laugh, epecially when he conidered the jealouie of Lycidas. And to add more matter for her perplexities, he did purpoely peak in this manner: Jealouie is a igne of love, as old ruines are ignes of ancient buildings, which are the greater, the more magnificent the Edifice was: And therefore, a great jealouie cannot proceed from a little love. But, as we cannot give the name of buildings unto thee ruines,
o jealouy cannot be called love. And if I may judge by my own humour, if I did love, I hould not have power to be jealous. And what would you be, aid Phillis, if he whom you hould love, hould love another? His enemy, anwered Diana, I would ay, hate him: And though I do foreee that uch an accident would dipleae me, yet, it would be more, for being deceived o long, then for being o oon forgotten. But, if that hepheard hould be jealous of you, aid Phillis, what then would you do? I would ue him o, anwered Diana, that he hould never love me again. But uppoe you hould deire he hould love you, aid Phillis, what way would you take? The way of a Precipice, anwered Diana; for I hould then think my elfe worthy to end mierably, if I hould love one, whom I knew did not love me. Oh! Diana, aid Phillis, how freely you peak? Nay, Phillis, aid Diana, how paionately you dipute? If you have need of a remedy againt this malady, either take that which I would give you, or arme your elfe with patience to endure any dipleaure that can befall you, and be aured, the number of them will not be a few.

Thus thee fair and dicreet Shepheardees dicoured with Silvander, And becaue Atrea thought that if it continued any longer, it might breed ome ditate, he had a mind to interrupt them; therefore he roe up, and eemed very deirous to walk, o as taking Diana by one hand, and Phillis by the other, he motioned to walk, aying, they had been itting too long. Then Silvander as he was officious in waiting about his Mitris he cattered the Letter which was put into his hand in the Night time: and Phillis having till her eye upon him, It ell no ooner upon the ground, but he took it up, hee not perceiving her; and carrying it unto Atrea, would needs read it before he would retore it to him again. But as oon as ever he and the ad Shepheardee did cat their eyes upon it, they conceived it to be the hand of Celadon. This apprehenion did touch Atrea o to the heart, that leaving Diana with Silvander, and taking Phillis aide, he was contrained to it down upon the ground. Phillis eeing her countenance much changed asked her how he did, and what was the caue of her o uddain alteration? Oh my good Siter, aid Atrea, what a trange trembling hath urpried me? and what a perplexity hath the ight of this Letter put me into? Did you not oberve how every Character does reemble the writing of my poor Celadon? Suppoe it be (aid Phillis, who deired not that Silvander hould take notice of her diorder) why hould you wonder o at it? Perhaps it is one of his Letters which Love will retore unto you by the hand of Silvander, as being mot due unto you. Alae, my dear Siter, aid Atrea, me-thought I aw him this very lat night o ad, and o pale, that I tarted, and o awaked out of my ad Dream: She would have gone on, when Diana and Silvander came unto them, very orry to ee her face o much and o oon altered. But Phillis, who would by all meanes hide this urprie from that Shepheard, did make a ign unto Diana, and then addreing her elf unto Silvander, Shepheard, aid he, Atrea hath a very great deire to impart her minde freely unto Diana, if you were not preent. Oh my enemy, anwered he, our hatred is not o great as to make me uncivil unto Atrea: I know it is not fit that Shepheards hould heare all the ecrets of Shepheardees, and therefore I will retire into the next Grove, and wait there untill you call me. And o making an humble reverence unto Diana, he went into the Wood. And not to bee idle, he took his knife, and began to cut Letters upon the barks of trees. In the mean time, Diana undertood from Phillis, how the ight of a Letter, which fell from Silvander, and eemed to be the hand of Celadon, had troubled Atrea: Then hewing it unto her, and he looking upon it a long time very eriouly; It would be very welcome news which Silvander hath brought, aid Diana, if it was Celadon that writ this Letter; for mot certainly it is very newly written, it is o freh, as if it were written this very hour; o as if this be Celadons hand, be aured he is not dead: But let us ee what is within, perhaps we hall learn more in it. Then opening the Letter, they found thee words.

body.head: To the mot Faire, and mot loved Shepheardee in the whole Univere, the mot unfortunate, and the mot faithful of all her Servants wiheth that happines which Fortune hath denyed unto himelf.
body.p: MY uperabundant affection will never conent I hould give the name of pain and torment unto that which your command hath caued me to uffer. But I may ay, that the condition wherein I am, which perhaps another would finde intolerable, does content me, ince it comes with an injunction from you. If it be your pleaure to continue your harp commands any longer, I hall be till all obedience: So as though I cannot aure you of my fidelity in this life, yet all the bleed ouls in the Elizian fields do know, that I am the mot faithfull, yet the mot unfortunate of all your ervants.

div.p: Ah my dear Siter, aid Atrea, It is Celadon who writ thoe words: I know it by his tyle and manner of writing; but perhaps it is long ince it was written. It beares no date (anwered Diana, who held it in her hand) but I ee by the writing that it is very freh; you may ee the dut how it ticks upon the Ink till, as if it were newly cat upon it. Siter, aid Phillis, there is no better way, if it bee dicreetly carried, than to know from Silvander the place where he found it, or who gave it unto him. Siter, aid Diana unto the ad Shepheardee, if you can but hold your countenance, that he may not ee the alteration in it, I am confident we hal learn all from him. And becaue it will be difficult to recollect your elfe upon a udden, I will goe my elfe and talke with him, and you may follow after me. So hee went unto Silvander, whom he found engraving Anacroticks upon the Names of his Mitree and himelf, upon the firt tree he found. But before he began to work in bark, he had engraven upon a oft tone at the Root of a Tree, a Dial, whoe trembling Needle was turned towards the North, with this Motto, I am touched; ignifying thereby, that even as the Needle of a Dial being touched with an Adamant, does alwayes turn that way, becaue, as ome Philoophers hold, the Element of the Loadtone is there and by a puiant and natural ympathy doth attract every part of it elf unto it elfe; o his heart, being touched with the beauty of his Mitree, doth turne it and all its thoughts towards her: And the better to explain his conception, hee added thee Veres.

l.hi: The Needle of a Dial Northward turnes,
If touch'd by Adamant:

q.l: My Heart touch'd by Diana, burnes,

l.hi: And after her does pant.

div.p:
When he was come unto him, he had jut finihed thee Characters; and when he aw her, he turned himelfe in a very jocund manner towards her, and aid: Oh my fairet Mitree, what good Fate ent you hither unto me? Better Fate then you could expect, anwered he; for I am not only come my elfe unto you, but I have left behinde me two of your greatet enemies. Since it is o, anwered he, I do much more fear your blowes. My blowes, aid the hepheardee, do not offend; or if they do, it is only uch as would have them do o. It is very true, aid Silvander, they do indeed offend none, but thoe as would have them do o: but yet that's the reaon, why there are o many wounded; for all thoe that ee you, do deire to receive your wounds. The blowes which are deirable, replyed Diana, need not be feared. Your wounds, anwered Silvander, are deired, but not deirable; and are terrible, but not terrifying. When I did ay, that I feared them, it was rather to hew what I ought to do, then what I did. I hall but laugh at you, aid Diana, if you know your own good, and will not follow it. But to leave this dicoure, pray tell me, hepheard, from whom this Letter is, and to whom it is directed? Silvander not knowing how he lot it, returned this anwer: My heart, and your eyes, if they did but look in a glae, would anwer for me, that it is directed unto you, as, Unto the mot fair, and
the mot loved hepheardee in the whole Univere: And your everity and my affection may tell you, that it comes from me, The mot unfortunate, yet the mot faithfull, of all your ervants. But, (aid Diana unto him, and then Atrea with Phillis came to them) if this Letter came from you, why did you not write it? Becaue, aid he, I found a better Secretary than my elfe; and I mut needs ingenuouly confee, that there is omething upernaturall in it, ince I found my own conceptions in it, without writing them; and ince you have it, and I never gave it unto you: But, my good Angell, who was my Scribe, eeing I was too low in preenting it unto you, did teal it from me, though I did tay only for an opportunity of privacy to preent it. And why o, aid Diana? Do you think I will receive any Letters in private, which I would refue in publick? My intention of privacy, replyed Silvander, was in conideration of my elfe, and not of you, becaue I had rather receive a denyall from you without a witnee, then before the face of my enemy: But I ee, that he who aumed the boldnee to write of me, has found out a way to let you ee it. I hall receive your excue, (aid Diana) upon condition, you will tell me, who was your Secretary. This lat night, (anwered the hepheard) after a long meditation and entertainment of my own thoughts, I chanced to fall aleep in a wood not far ditant hence; and in the morning when I awaked, I found this Letter in my hand: At the firt, I was much amazed at it; but after I had read it, I conceived, that ome good Angell which loved me, and had read the ame thoughts in my imagination, did write them in this paper for me, to preent them unto you. Phillis, who had wit at will, eeing Diana mute, did ask him, if he knew the way unto the wood. No, aid he, if there be none but you that would go unto it: but, if it be the pleaure of my Mitree, I will wait upon her unto it; and I aure my elfe, that the Trees which heard me almot all the night, will relate the dicoure which I had with my elfe amongt them. Atrea being very deirous to ee the place, did make a igne with her eye unto Diana, that he hould take him at his word; who thereupon asking, whether they had time enough to go and return, and being anwered, Yes, he intreated him, to conduct them all thither. Silvander, who was full of civility, and who deired nothing more paionately, then to do any ervice unto his fair Diana, did freely conent to hew them the way. So Diana turning towards the hepheardees, purpoely to umbrage Atrea's deigne, did very particularly intreat them, they would be pleaed to go along with her, and they hould command her as much another time. Atrea, who was very glad, that Silvander took Diana to be the Author of this deigne, did anwer, That he would mot willingly follow her, whitheroever he was pleaed to go. So committing the charge of their flocks unto one of their neighbours, who came accidentally, Silvander took the hortet way to the wood, and conducted them thither.

Where the way was narrow and bad, Silvander alwaies went before; but aoon as they came into the Meadow, which is often watered by the River Lignon, he waited upon his Mitree, and led her by the arme. She, who had Phillis on the other ide, who was betwixt her and Atrea, did accept of her hepheards ervice with a very good will, let the length of the way hould weary her; and giving him her left arme: You, Silvander, (aid he) I make ue of you in this voyage as my Servant; and of you, Phillis for my Companion. Phillis deiring to make Silvander talk, that the company might be the lee weary, and who would not have a word, o much to her advantage pronounced by Diana, to pas unoberved, he addresed her elfe unto the hepheard, and asked him, what he thought of this favour? That it is greater, anwered Silvander, then we deerve. But, replyed Phillis, how do you take the difference that he puts betwixt us? As a faithfull Servant ought to take what is pleaing unto his Mitres, aid Silvander. But you, aid the hepheardes, who are o great a tickler againt jealouie, have not you ome parks of it your elfe, in eeing the great favour which your Mitree hath conferred upon me? I do perceive, aid he, that you meaure my affection by your own, ince you think any thing that pleaeth my Mitres, can dipleae me: But however I were a meer implician in matters of Love, if I did not think the favour he hath done me, to be a very great honour unto me, and diadvantageous unto you. Diana hearing this anwer, miled; and Phillis, who expected another kinde of an anwer, was o urpried, as he knew not what to ay, but looked earnetly upon him: yet, he beginning to walk; Phillis, aid he, that mile is only a cloak for your ignorance; I have not yet made you undertand, neither by my words nor my actions, any of Love's myteries; but I do not accue any, except the defects that are in your affection. If I do not undertand thee myteries, aid Phillis, you might accue me
of ignorance, but not of defect in affection, ince undertanding is not an act of will, as affection is. You are mitaken, aid the hepheard, and this is one of thoe myteries you are ignorant of, and whereof I do not accue either your undertanding facultie, or your will, but this fair Diana. How, aid Diana, do you make me culpable of the ignorance of Phillis? I do not think you culpable, fair Mitres (replyed Silvander) but I do ay, you are the caue (as I have learned from an antient Oracle) by which I undertand (aid he, and turned towards Phillis) that I am better loved by our Mitres then you are. Atrea, who had not yet poke: This dicoure (aid he) is the mot obcure, and the reaons the mot intricate, that ever I heard. Will you but pleae to give me leave, aid Silvander, I am confident I hall cleer them unto you, and make you confes them as well as my elfe: And for your better undertanding, I ay once again that the reaon why Phillis does not undertand the myteries of Love, is becaue he does not love enough, and that for this defect in her love I ought not to accue her will but Diana onely, as an ancient Oracle tells us, by which I know, that he loves me more then he doth Phillis; and this is the reaon: When you deire to know what is the will of the gods, unto whom do you ue to addres your elves, to come to the knowledge of it? Doubtles, aid Phillis, unto thoe that are Priets in their Temples, and whoe office it is, to wait at their Altars. And why do you not rather addres your elfe, aid Silvander, unto thoe that are more knowing than unto thoe Miniters of the Temple, who commonly are ignorant in every thing ele but their Office? Becaue, aid Phillis, the gods do more freely communicate themelves unto thoe that are entred into thoe myteries, and more familiar about their Altars, than unto any trangers, though they be more knowing. See (aid Silvander then) the power of Truth, which contraines you to peak it againt your intention: For if you do not undertand the myteries of the god of Love, is not that a igne you are a tranger unto him? For you confee, that the gods do communicate themelves more freely unto thoe who erve in their Temples, and wait at their Altars. But which way hould they erve at the Altar of the god of Love, unlee it be by Loving? Hearts are the only acrifices which are acceptable unto that deity Do you not ee then Phillis, that if you be ignorant in thee myteries, it is not a fault in your undertanding, but in your love And if it hould be o, (aid Phillis) which I will never grant, how can you accue Diana for any defects in my affection? Is he not fair enough? or, are not her merits ufficient to make her elfe loved? This, aid Silvander, is a econd mytery of that god which I will explain unto you. Diana has no defects neither in beauty nor merit, but he is all perfection; the defect is only in your elfe, that you do not love enough, and that your love does not equall thoe admirable excellencies which you ee in her: But, it is impoible you hould love her in that height, becaue he does not love you, according to the Oracle of which I poke. Venus eeing her Son o little, did ask the gods, what he hould do to make him grow: To which quetion he received this anwer, That he hould get him a Brother, and then he would grow to full proportion; but as long as he was alone, he would never grow. Do you not ee, Phillis, that this anwer was given againt you, and in favour of me? For, if your love be little, and a dwarfe, the reaon is, becaue it hath not a Brother. If mine, on the contrary, do excell the highet, it is, becaue Diana, my mot fair Diana, hath given it one, whom he loves, whom he honours: nay, whom he adores. And do you think, Silvander, replyed Phillis, that he does love you better then he does love me? It can be no more doubted, anwered the hepheard, then truth it elfe The gods do never lie, Oracles are the interpreters of their will. How dare you tax an Oracle with any untruth? No, no, Phillis, ince I do love this fair Diana better then you do, mot certainly he does love me better then he doth you; otherwie, the gods would be impotors, and not gods. Many have been deceived, aid Phillis, in the undertanding of Oracles. 'Tis true, anwered Silvander, but when that is, the contrary event doth preently dicover it and o they remain not long undeceived: But, the Oracle of which I peak, is anwered by uch conformable effects, both in you and me, that it would be impiety to doubt it; ince, do what you can, you cannot make your love o great as mine: And to confirm it the more, is it not a common received opinion, that whooever will be loved, mut love? Why, hepheard, (aid Phillis, and interrupted him) do you think by loving much, to make your elfe much loved? If you would give me leave to expound this mytery unto you, aid Silvander, perhaps you would be as ready to confee it, as you have been to interrupt me; but this is all I will ay, if the way to get love be to love, then there is no doubt, but that Diana, who contraines me to love her with uch ardency
of affection, doth love me extreamly. Phlllis was dumb at this, not knowing what to anwer the hepheard, who indeed defended his caue but too well. Atrea whipered Diana in her ear: Never credit me again, (aid he in a whiper) if this hepheards jeat do not turn to earnet, and if he do not, like children, who play o long with their finger about the candle, that at lat they burn themelves. Diana anwered, that uch a thing might perhaps be, if I were as capable of burning, as he is of being burned; but, ince he himelfe is only in the fault, let him only bear the punihment: as for me, I do not intend to participate with him. This talk had continued longer, if Phillis had not interpoed, and chid them for taking Silvander's part. We did not take his part, anwered Diana; but we may well ay, that you are too weak to argue with him, for his knowledge is much above yours. But I would gladly know, aid Phillis, how he can conceive, that what you aid unto him at the beginning, was more advantageous to him than to me; for, I do apprehend it to be a greater honour unto me, ince you did thereby choe me to be your Companion. She did confer that honour indeed upon you, anwered the hepheard, but her affection upon me. No, no, replyed the hepheardee, under the name of Companion is both affection and honour comprehended, for they do almot ignifie the ame thing. You may as well aert, anwered Silvander, that affection and flattery are the ame, and not contrary. If that peron whom you love bet hould tell you, that your perfections do trancend any goddee, would you not ay, this is groe flattery? And why, poor deceived thing that you are, do you not think the ame of Diana, when he ayes, that you are her Companion? For, as you your elfe expound it, that Companion ignifies, one like her elfe; and her perfections are o trancendently above all other women, as there cannot be a greater difference between men and gods, then betwixt you and her. Poor blinded Phillis, do you not ee, that this weet word which is o pleaing to you, is only pure flattery, which my Mitree is pleaed to put upon you, to acknowledge in ome ort that hallow affection which you bear unto her? For, ince he cannot love you, he will give you atisfaction in this coyne. In taking you for a Companion, he hewes flattery, and flattery hewes mall affection: On the contrary, in taking me for her Servant, he hewes the good will he bears unto me, ince I am capable of that favour, if any mortall man be. Oh impudence! (cryed out Phillis). Oh love! anwered Silvander. Why, replyed the hepheardee, do you think your elfe worthy to erve her, whoe merits are above all mortalls? The greatet gods, aid the hepheard, are erved by men, and are pleaed with their ervice and duty: Then why, if I be a man, as I hope you do not quetion, will you not permit me to erve and adore my goddee, epecially, ince he her elfe requires this holy duty from me? Phillis tanding mute, and conidering well of Silvander's reaons, he knew not how to anwer one word, but did really think, that Diana did confer a greater favour upon Silvander, then upon her; and therefore addreing her peech unto her: Mitree, aid he, upon conideration of my enemies reaon, I finde, that he is in the right, and that you have conferred more favour upon him than me: Is it poible, you hould do it intentionally? If you did, I hall have a jut occaion of complaint, and take it ill, he hould be o much advanced above his merit. I ee, aid Diana coldly, that opinion hath a greater power of you then truth, and you are guided only by it: Within this quarter of an houre, you were boating of the favour which I did you, in preferring you before Silvander: And now, this opinion being changed, you complain of the contrary, o as I am afraid, that your affection alo is nothing but opinion. No quetion of it, aid Silvander; for every word he hath poken is an argument of it. Is it any argument of Love, Phillis, to finde fault with the actions of your Mitree? If they be to my diadvantage, aid he, would you have me to think well of them? It were but your duty to conform your elfe, and trive to get more love then you have, aid Silvander. Would you have Diana conform her elfe unto your will, or ought you to conform your elfe unto hers? I wih to the gods, aid he, that I had as much advantage over her, as it eemes he hath given you over me. If it were o, aid Silvander, pray tell me, which of you two hould be the Mitree and which the Servant? Truly, hepheardee, I do not think you ever received the leat cratch in Love's War. Atrea, who ilently heard their difference, was at lat contrained to ay thus unto Diana: I think, wie hepheardee, that this hepheard will take away from Phillis the ue of her tongue. No, aid Silvander, it is rather Love; for hitherto he thought that he had loved, but now he ees the contrary.

Thus thoe fair Shepheardees deceived themelves in the length of the way; and the Sun hining very hot, they asked Silvander, how far it was yet unto the place which he
conducted them unto; and undertanding that they were about the mid way, they reolved to ret themelves at the next Fountain, or the next good hade they come unto; and Silvander told then, that they hould preently come unto uch a one, where they hould finde a Cherry tree full of ripe fruite: In order to this reolution, they doubled their pace; but meeting with Laonice, Hylas, ••• cis, Manduates, and Thirander, they tayed awhile. Thee hepheards and hepheardees were walking together, eeking for cool hades, and pleaent Fountaines, for they were trangers; and having no flocks to keep, they paed away the time as pleaantly as poibly they could: And intending not to part that day they walked up the banks of the delectable River of Lignon. Now thee two Companies being met, Hylas preently left Laonice, and came to Phillis, and he left Atrea and Diana, and went to him; at which Silvander was not orry, thinking himelfe in more abolute poeion of his Mitree. Tircis eeing Atrea alone, for Thirander did lead Maduntes, he addreed himelfe in a humble manner unto her, and offered his ervice in leading her: She, having a great eteem of that hepheard, epecially becaue there was a conformity betwixt their fortunes, did very willingly accept of his offer; o as every one had a Companion, except Laonice, who, as I told you formerly, having an extream deire to be revenged of Phillis and Silvander, all her aime was, to watch an occaion of doing them ome michiefe: And to compae her deigne, he kept a pying eye upon all their actions, hearkn •• unto all their dicoure, epecially when they poke low, or in ecret; and when <…> by their getures, that they poke any thing affectionately. She had formerly <…> partly a caue of the jealouie of Lycidas, and had ince learned much of Sil ••••••
and other hepheardees, yet more from her own upicions then any ele: But <…> much more, and became o knowing, as it may be aid, he knew all <…> as well as themelves. Alo, there being none in the company who upected her deigne, he had more free accee to hear, none taking any notice when he <> them. After he had <> upon all the hepheards and hepheardees, and <…> Companion to divert her he got as neer as he could unto Silvander, who led Diana;
<…> to whom he wihed mot ill, and having already an opinion of their being in love the paionately deired to dicover more. Diana, who had no deigne at all upon Silvander, though he did wih him better then any hepheard of Lignon, did not care whether her words were heard or no: And Silvander took no heed, becaue he was o attenive unto what his Mitree aid, as he did hardly ee the ground he trod upon, which gave Laonice a better opportunity to hearken. Silvander then, aoon as he was alone with his Mitree: Well, my fairet, (aid he unto her) what do you think now of Phillis and me? I do think, anwered he, that Phillis of all perons in the world, is the wort lyar; and that of all the hepheards I know, Silvander is the bet diembler: for certainly, you can counterfeit a paionate part the bet of any living Ah hepheardes! replyed Silvander, it is an eay matter to counterfeit what one does really reent. This, replyed Diana, is that which confirmes what I ay: I could never believe, that a feigned paion could be gloed with words and actions, o reemblant unto truth. Ah Diana! aid he, how far hort are both my actions and my words of declaring the truth of my affection? Could you but ee my heart as wel as my face, you would have a better opinion of me. I mut confes, the wager betwixt Phillis and me hath been a caue, that I have had the honour to be often <> you: But, I cannot keep my elfe within the confines of our wager. Oh my fairet Mitree, do not be here it poible I hould: Your perfections are too high to be loved, only by a eeming to love. Heavens be my witnee, and I attet all the acred duities of thee olitary places, that I do love you with a mot reall, perfect, pure, and eternall affection.

The reaons why this hepheard poke thus, was, becaue he aw, that within a few <> his terme of <> months would end, and that after it, he hould finde more difficulty to expres his affection, knowing the humour of this hepheardes well enough, o as he reolved to make ue of his time: And though it did but further his deigne very little, yet was it not altogether in vain; for by this he had accutomed his hepheardes unto uch dicoure which perhaps i • not one of the leat acts, whereof an advied Lover ought to make ue for cutome renders things eay, which at the beginning atonih us, and which we think impoible. Diana hearing this language, though he thought it true, yet would he not eem to believe it; but continuing as he begun, This, hepheard, aid he, does more confirme main the opinion I had of you; and you may believe what I ay to be true, if you do oberve how faintly I hear and anwer you; for did I give any credit unto your
words, be certain, that the firt word you hould peak unto me, hould be the lat word that I would hear. Silvander would have anwered, had he not been prevented by an encounter. Atrea and Tircis went firt, Phillis and Hylas next, Mandonte and Terander after them, Diana and Silvander the next; and after them, the lie Laonice. In this order, they followed the path which Silvander hewed them, and without much noie they came into a very pleaant Wood which was in their way. The dicoure of Atrea and Tircis being only upon things indifferent, they epyed in the thick of the wood, under a hade, three hepheardees, with the generous Paris, the on of Adamas: the hepheardees were unknown unto Atrea; as for Paris, he was of late grown o familiar amongt all that company, as there was none in all that Town, which did not both know and love him. His love unto Diana brought him unto that acquaintance, and to make himelfe more plauible, as often as he came to ee his Mitree, he put on the habit of a Shepheard, and with his hook in his hand, frequented that company, as if he had been of the ame quality: Such power hath Love, to free the mot generous oules from all ambition. And becaue one of thoe hepheardees did at that time ing, Atrea and Tircis topt, and turning towards thoe which followed them, did make a igne, that they hould make no noie: But becaue the Song was almot ended, they heard only this lat vere of it.

q.l: By Thought or Deed did I offend?
By Deed, I neer did condecend:
And if by Thought I did amie,
Ple wear my thought a Traitor is.

div.p: The voice of this hepheardee was o ravihing, that all the company were very orry they came not till her ong was ended: But Hylas leaving Phillis, to get a little neerer, he no ooner et his eyes upon them, but he kn • w them: Had any oberved him, they might eaily have een, that thee hepheardees were not unknown unto him; yet, that he might hear what they aid, he contrained himelfe as well as he could: Then he heard her that ung, ay; Generous Paris, ince we have atisfied your curioity and deire, we hope you will acquit your elfe of your promie made unto us. I hall never deny you (anwered Paris) any thing, that is within the compae of my power. Then taking a Lute, which thee hepheardees had, he ung this Song unto that Intrument.

lg.l: WHen Hylas did the plendid eye
Of Phillis, his fair Mitree, py:

l.hi: Was ever uch a glorious Queen,
(Said he) unlee in heaven een?

lg.l: Fair Phillis, with a bluhing Aire,

l.hi: Hearing thee words, became more fair:
Away, aid he, you need not take
Freh Beauty, you more fair to make:
Then with a winning mile and look;
His candid flattery he tooke.
Oh tay, (aid he) 'tis done I vow,

lg.l: Hylas is captivated now.
If he for liberty complain,
Let him (aid he) take it again.
'Tis more divine (aid he) in you,
That conquer can, and pardon too.
A captive Prioner is blet,
When he does fear to be releat:
That Lover's happy, who does cry,
When any does his bonds unty.

div.p: Asoon as this Song was ended, thee trangers asked him, who Phillis, and who Hylas was? If you did ever hear, aid Paris, of the Plain that is called Forrets, and in it, of the delectable River of Lignon, certainly you have heard the names of the fair Shepheardees, Diana and Atrea: This Phillis, of whom you enquire, is a deer Companion unto them; as for Hylas, I can tell you nothing, unlee it be, that he is a tranger, but of the weetet and mot jocoive humour, that ever my converation cop'd withall; for he was never tired with the ervice of any hepheardee, but till will quit her after ix daies courthip, before any ditate hall be on any ide. Did he not dwell in a place called Camargue (aid one of thee trangers) which is in the Roman Province? And Paris anwering, Yes; Oh then, aid he, you need not tell us any more, ince we know both his Name and Country; as for all his other conditions, we know them well enough to our own cots: And after he had paued awhile, he began again in this manner.

div.head: The Hitory of Palinice, and Cercenea.
div.p:
I Shall never think any thing trange, generous Shepheard, when I remember Hylas, and conider, that mot things do conit only in Opinion. For nothing is o directly contrary unto each other, as vertue and vice; and this man, taking the one for the other, doth hew us, that it is meerly opinion which puts the price upon all things: And doubtles he is the mot uncontant piece that ever thought himelf in Love; and he will go about to prove by arguments and reaons, that it is a vertue to change, or love many at once; and that this is no incontancy. Alo, it is quetionles, that he peaks as he thinks, and his arguments and reaons are the iues of his heart. I remember that when he came from Camargue unto Lyons, he got into the Temple amongt the women, at the grand Feat; and if Palinice had not hewed much compaion upon him (for o is the name of this my Companion) certainly he had payed very dear for his curioity: but he finding, that his fault proceeded from folly, and not malice, diguied him with a vail, and got him out of the Temple, then carryed him to his lodging, which was in a demi-Ile, betwixt the Rone and the Arar. This courtey was enough to oblige Hylas, unto a gratefull viit of Palinice: and her modety was uch, as would have given a check unto any but Hylas, from moving any matters of Love unto her: Yet, before the third viit was paid, he acquainted her with his minde, and was as familiar, as if he had been brought up with her from his cradle. You have, fair one, (aid he unto her at the very firt accot) preerved my life, and good reaon it hould be imployed in your ervice; and I will do it, though only out of gratitude: And not to detract from your firt favour which you have done me, I beeech you accept this offer of my ervice, and believe, that there is no peron upon earth that can love you better then I, nor whoe heart is well'd with more affection. My Companion, who was unaccutomed to any uch expreions, did, at the firt, anwer him very coldly; but eeing he perited, he grew angry, and would not uffer him to ue any uch language: At the lat, when by his continuall viits he found his humour, he did nothing but laugh at him, which did not offend him at all; for he had this good quality, that as he was free with every one, o he allowed every one to be free with him. However, his Love did o increae, that my companion did grow weary of him; not but that Hylas is certainly a man of much merit, and is owner of many qualities which deerve Love; but he being a Widow, and not intending to marry, this courthip could not but be very diadvantageous to her. It eemes, that the Heavens had pitty upon Palinice, and at the ame time ent her a Companion, and preently after that another, to help her to upport a burthen o heavie. Palinice had a Brother, who had been long a devoted Servant unto Cercenea, my companion, who now its next me. And repect being mot in the hearts of thoe that love mot, Clorian (for that was the name of Palinice's brother) had not yet the confidence to acquaint the fair Circen • a with his affection: She, on the other ide, was yet too young to dicover it by his actions: o as Clorian loved, and in vain, becaue his love was not known. Hylas in the mean time, continued his frequent viits unto Palinice; and as he aid himelfe, it being one of Loves chief precepts, to get the favour of the kindred friends, and ervants of the party loved, he courted the friendhip of Clorian with all obequious offers he could make, which was no difficulty to obtain, becaue the young man was all civility and weetnee, and had an affection to get the love of all: But Hylas being more ubtle and crafty, as being older, and having travelled, he faigned,
what Clorian did in good earnet; o as he was only a uperficiall friend, whilt the other loved him as his Brother; and the enuing tory will make this appear: For Clorian's affection unto Cercenea daily augmenting, and not daring to make it known unto her, Hylas took notice of it. Cercenea took a journey to ee her Father, who was ick in a Town, within the Country of the Sebuians, towards the Allobrogians by reaon whereof, Cercenea was long abent from our Town and conequently from Clorian. And becaue, as I have heard ay, there is no greater comfort to a true Lover then to think often of the party Loved, Clorian did often retire himelfe into a houe which he had in that Town, that tood upon the top of a hill, towards the Sebuians: From this place might be viewed the Rone on one ide, and Arar on the other; and one might alo ee the Forret of Mars, called
<> : and if the tops of high Trees did not obtruct the eye, quetionles it might ee further from thence, then any other place. When he turned towards the Temple of Venus, I • might ee as far as the Seguian Mountains; when he looked towards Arar, he might behold the
<> ; and when towards the Rone, he might ee as far as the huge hills of
<> , beyond the plains of the Sebuians. And certainly it was a mot lovly propect every way. It was to this place whither Clorian did commonly retire himelfe, and looking towards the Sebuian plains, did ravih himelfe with thoughts of his fair Cercenea. It hapned, that Hylas being very familiar with him, and not finding him in the houe, he made no quetion but he was gon unto this Mount; and being jealous, that his Companion was in Love, (for he knew, that this olitude, and melancholly muing, could proceed from no other caue) he went up the tairs as oftly as he could, and finding the dore halfe open, he aw him looking out of that window towards the Sebuians, o ravihed in his own thoughts, that he could not hear it thunder, and therefore could not hear the noie which Hylas made, in opening the dore and entring; but he himelfe poke o loud, that Hylas could hear thee words.

lg.l: MIld Zephyrus, that wantonly

l.hi: Amongt all fragrant flowers doth file,
Filching from them that weetet are;
Thou dot by theft perfume the Air.

lg.l: If ever pitty did thee move,
Waft o're thee plaines unto my Love;
And blow my thoughts into that breat,
Where they can only finde a ret.
But carry with thee on thy wing,
Thoe amorous Sighs I adly ing.
Tel her, in this my ad retraint,
She is my fair and only Saint.
Thoe lovely Twins, her lips, will yield
Odors more weet then all the field:
But when thou thus perfumed art,
Return and let me have a part.

div.p: Have I taken you, Clorian, (aid Hylas, taking him about the neck, and kiing him) I mut confee, you are the cloet Lover that e're I knew; yet, you cannot hide your elfe from me. No more I will not, (aid Clorian, after a little conidering with himelfe) for neither at this time, nor any other, will I ever hide any thing from you. I am atisfied almot, aid Hylas, upon condition, you will ingenuouly confee, what I do already know. What is it, replied Clorian, which you deire to know of me? I will not ask, aid Hylas, what your malady is, but only from whence it proceeds. Oh Hylas, (aid he, and ighed) you need not ask me who the caue is: But, I would to the gods, you could as eaily give me any comfort, as I can freely atisfie your curioity. So itting down upon a Couch, he told him of his affection, and how the love he bare unto Cercenea was o great, as he durt never acquaint her with it.

When Hylas heard the name of Cercenea, he thought he had heard of it before, though he could not well remember when or where, and therefore he asked him, which of all thoe he had een, was he? Since you do not know her name, anwered Clorian, I believe you never aw her; for her beauty is uch, that it is impoible you hould ee her, and not enquire her name, and make you remember her: But when I calculate the time of your comming unto this Town, I believe you never aw her. I came, aid Hylas, at the lat F • at which was celebrated unto Venus. Clorian, after a whiles conideration, anwered him, That he could not ee her, unlee he came that very day, becaue the morning after, he went away unto her Father who was ick in the Province of the Sebuians, and never returned ince. Well, aid Hylas, though he be never o fair, do you think, that he would not be loved? Can you believe, that thoe only who are ugly, will permit it? No, no if uch hould be told, they are loved, they would think themelves jeer'd. I do not think, aid Clorian, that if Beauties b • told they are loved, they will be offended, but their modety may. How, aid Hylas? let her be as modet as he can, do you think he will be angry at being loved? Ah Clorian! their modety is not any orrow for being loved, but only becaue they doubt, whether what is aid be true. And indeed, where is that woman, who when he is aured of a mans affection, is not extreamly well pleaed with it, and gives him no tetimony of her atisfaction? No no, Clorian, of all the actions which we do, next unto thoe that preerve life, there is none o naturall as this of Love: And can you imagine women uch enemies to Nature, that they will hate what is naturall? Come, come, let me give you advice, which unlee you be a very Novice in Love, you will follow, and finde, that I am my Arts Mater in uch things. Let Cercenea know, that you do love her, and that aoon as poibly you can; for, the ooner he knowes it the ooner will he love you. May be at firt he will turne her head aide, and bid you talk no more of any Love: Perhaps hee' • eem to be in a great fury, and will not peak to you: But however, do you continue and be aured, that if you be but aiduous, you will win her. When they give us thee peevih anwers, and refue the affection which we preent unto them, they put me in minde of thoe Phyicians and Lawyers, that refue the Fee, yet put out their hand. I am older then you are, I have run through ome parts of the world, and let me tell you, I have loved many; this gives me encouragement to peak the more freely unto you, and you mut not take any exceptions. Be certain that never any faint hearted Lover ped well: And in matters of Love, no fault is o great, as, being too repectfull. He that will peed well, mut dare attempt, ask, begg importune, pree, take; nay, he mut ravih. Did you never know the humour of women, Clorian? Hearken unto the great Oracle, which in our time poke thus.

q.l: Shee'l flie away, and yet would fain
