With all her heart be overta'n.
She will deny, yet eem to daunt
A Lover, when he fain would grant.
She will reit, that you at length
May eem to vanquih her by trength.
For thus her honour does ordain,
She hould reit, and yet but faign.

div.p:
He that has no courage to do thus, let me advie him, to take upon him ome other trade then that of Love, for he will never thrive by it. Clorian, therefore my counell is, that you do aume o much confident boldnee as not only to declare your love unto her, but to hope, that he will love you again, o you will but let her know your minde. I cannot, generous hepheard, remember all the documents and amorous advies which Hylas gave; but I undertand ince from Palmice, who heard her brother relate them, that he did make himelfe appear to be his Arts Mater in uch things. But, the concluion of all was, that ince Clorian had not o much confidence, as to declare his Love unto his Mitree; as oon as he returned, which would be within a few daies, Hylas hould be his Advocate, and peak for him. Hylas did very willingly accept of the imployment; for, aid he, I hall oblige two at once by it; to wit, Clorian, in doing him the good office, and Cercenea, in bringing her uch good newes. It hapned that preently after, my Companion returned to the Town; and though the death of her Father had put her into a mourning habit, and though her own adnee was uitable unto it; yet all her orrowes had not
at all leened her beauty, but had added uch a kinde of weetnee unto her countenance, as invited all that aw her to love her, by reaon of a certain attractive compulion, which rendred her much more pleaing. Hylas, in proecution of his promie, no ooner heard of her return, but he courted all opportunities to ee her, in which Palinice was not unwilling to help him, becaue her Brother deired it. She, who knew nothing of their deigne, and believed it to be only out of curioity, was glad to atisfie her Brother, though he cared not for the company of Hylas. As fortune was, Cercenea's Mother would offer a acrifice unto the gods, for the oul of her Husband, and did invite Palinice as one of her bet friends; thither he went, and with her Hylas: But ee, if he be not as good a friend as a faithfull Lover: he no ooner aw Cercenea again, but he was deep in love with her: I ay, aw her again becaue looking upon her, he remembered, that he had een her before in the Temple of Venus, when Palinice aluted her; and becaue he then found ome parks of good will unto her, his firt flames did kindle again in his heart, as eaily, as any Sulphure at the fire. Looking upon her therefore very eriouly, he began by degrees to remember, that Cercenea was he whom he aw in the Temple, and remembring how excellently he could ing, and all that Love could make him apprehend at the firt ight, he quite forgot his promie unto Clorian, and thought only how to peak for himelfe. Thus you may ee how dangerous a thing it is, to imploy a Second in uch a buinee. He accoted her, afterwards aluted her: And he, out of weet civility, returned him a alute again. Then both being in the Temple, and every one going to their devotion, he aid thus unto her: I ee, fair Cercenea, that the ight of you is fatall unto me, and comming hither to be an aitant unto your acrifices, I am become a acrifice my elfe. She, who knew not the man, or ever heard of him, did look him in the face; and then, after a little conideration, he concluded him to be a tranger, both by his language and habit; becaue, though they were made according to the garb of our Town, yet he did wear them in that manner, as was plain he was a tranger: For trangers, though they do diguie themelves in our fahion; yet, they have ome trick or other in their Air, by which one may ee, they are not of the ame Country. And I do believe, that this difference is lee found amongt the Franks, then any other Nation. Now Circenea not knowing Hylas, he thought, that he had taken her for ome other; and therefore, after he had looked upon him, he turned leightly another way, and gave him no anwer.

Hylas not atisfied with this, he pulled her by the Gown, and aid: What, fair one, no anwer to a civill quetion? I thought, aid he, that you had not poken unto me, or that you had addreed your peech unto ome other; for I do not know what you mean, by your fatall ight and your acrifice. It is to you only, fair one, whom I peak, aid he, and to none other but your elfe: that is, to the fairet, and mot Angelick beauty, that e're my eyes did ee, whoe firt ight of you, had like to have cot me my life, and o doubtlee will the econd, if I do not finde you as kinde and favourable, as Palinice was at that time. I pray, aid he, how kinde was Palinice unto you? She av'd my life, anwered he, when the night before the Feat of Venus, your beauty kept me o long in the Temple, that I knew not how to get out. I do not remember any uch thing, aid Cercenea, or that I ever aw you. Whether you did or no, replyed Hylas, yet love you I mut; and in lieu of aiting at your acrifice, as I did intend to do, I have aited at that acrifice, which Love hath made of me unto you: However, I hould think my elfe extreamly happy, if I could finde any room in your affection. I ee, aid he, you are a tranger, and doe not know me; and I do believe, that my affection is very indifferent unto you. Upon this, he turned away, and one of her Companions comming accidentally into the Temple, he gave her place unto her, as if out of courtey, and got as neer her Mother as poibly he could; and all the while that the acrifice lated, he would not come neer him. But Hylas having broke the Ice, he would go through, and was not a man that would it down in the mid way.

He found a way, by the means of Palinice, to come into Cercenea's Chamber, and in concluion, grew very familiar, making Clorian believe all this while that it was for his ake he frequented her company o much. But uch was the humour of Hylas, as he did not think it enough to deceive his friend, and to love both Palinice and Cercenea; but, one night as we were walking together, he expreed himelfe as fair unto me as unto them, and that before he knew my name.

Hylas, who as I told you before, was hearkning, he could not chue, though it was contrary to his deigne, but hew himelfe, and ay: Why, fair Florice, do you think it
was your name that I was in love withall? Hylas repented he had o rahly hewed himelfe; but thee trangers were exceedingly atonihed, when they aw him o urpriedly; and though they looked fully upon him, yet by reaon of his alteration in habit, they knew him not at the firt. But Atrea was very glad, who thought the dicoure of this tranger to be very long, and that it hindred her from that atisfaction which he hoped for, in this voyage; yet, he eemed to be orry, and with the ret, all hewed themelves. But Hylas eeming, as if he had purpoely interrupted Florice, did run to her, and embraced her, and afterwards aluted the ret; then turning to her again: Well, fair Hitorian, aid he, mut you needs renew my orrowes, and make thoe wounds which you gave me to bleed afreh? Oh, aid Florice, you need not fear any wounds, ince you have o many remedies, 'Tis true, anwered Hylas, if all wounds were cured with the ame remedies. But, to let this dicoure alone, I beeech you tell me, what deigne brought you unto this place? The deign, aid Florice, was not to meet you here. If it had, aid
<> , it had been but an act of civility and my ervices perhaps might merit as much: But I ee, I have ow • d upon an ungratefull piece of ground, which does not render a profit worth the pains. Somtimes, aid Cercenea, good land may bring forth weeds in lieu of corn, becaue the feed may be naught or owed out of eaon, and the ower may be wort of all; and perhaps ome of thee may be the caue of that terilitie wherewith you tax us. I know, Cercenea, aid he, that you have beauty enough to make men love you, but withall, you want no di •• in and corn for thoe that do adore you. And I do know, aid Palinice, that as you have been ever very fertile in new deires, and freh affections, o you never wanted words wherewith to accue others of your own faults. Then Hylas tepping back two or three paces; This is too much, aid he, to fight againt three at once; Hercules himelfe would not undertake two. Upon this, Atrea, Diana, Phillis, and the ret of their company came in and caued the dipute to end.

It was the cutome of all Lignon hepheards, when they met any trangers, to ue them with all poible aitance, conceiving themelves obliged unto it by the Lawes of Hopitality: This cutome of civility invited Atrea, Diana, and their company, to treat thee trangers accordingly, and afterwards to ask them the occaion of their voyage? Unto which Florice anwered in the name of all, That being ent into this Country by direction of their gods, who had forbidden them to reveal the caue, they durt not diobey them, and therefore they could not give them atisfaction. Then enquiring who thoe hepheardees were, and Phillis telling her their names,
<>
addreed her elfe unto Atrea: I mut needs confee (aid he) that I am angry with my elfe, for not knowing you to be the hepheardee Atrea, whoe beauty being too high to be conined unto o narrow a Country as Forrets, the lutre of it hath hined into the Countries all about it: But I do beg your excue and confee, that now I am dazled and confued with admiration, at o much lutre as is in you and Diana: And I do begin to hope, that our voyage will be properous, ince it meets with o happy a beginning. Atrea all civility, did anwer her in as good language as poible; and then kiing them, Hylas interrupted: Good Florice, aid he, what do you think of our Villages? did you ever ee any greater Beauties in your Cities, with all their Arts? Have not I good reaon to quit them all for thee fair hepheardees, ince the implicity of my humour and pirit doth more ympathize with their naturall beauty, then with thoe artificiall tricks which are ued in your Townes? If ever you did order your actions with judgment (aid Florice) I mut confee it is in this; but nor for any conformitie of humours that is betwixt thee fair hepheardees and you, for in that, you are far different: but becaue Hylas having been all his life very wavering in his affection unto all others, will become more contant here, if at the leat perfection of beauty be able to do it: and for my part, I do believe he is, ince not finding any better in any other place, he is forced to ret here. It does concern me, aid Phillis, to anwer, becaue Hylas is my ervant; yet believe it, I will not anwer for his fidelity, ince I mut needs think, that having once loved o great a Beauty as yours, and falling off, that it is not beauty which makes him in Love. What then, aid Hylas, can it be? An humour of changing, aid Florice, and a certain levity of minde, that will not let you continue foure and twenty houres in one opinion. Oh! aid Hylas, you are a partie, and therefore your judgment may be upected. If you mean, anwered he, that I am the party offended, I do freely forgive the injury, and do think my elfe more obliged unto you for your changing, then I hould have received atisfaction in your contancy: And if you think me a party, that does pretend any thing unto you, believe it, Hylas, I will with
all my heart quit all my pretenions, unto any that will have them, who, if they will receive them, they will more oblige me by it, then they will finde benefit by the gift. You have reaon to dipoe thus of me, aid Hylas, halfe angry; for you may as freely dipoe of me, as of the tars.

All this while, Paris had addreed himelfe unto Diana, whom after he had aluted; This, aid he, is a more happy encounter, than I could ever have hoped for, ince I did the leat expect you here. It is indeed happy for me, aid Diana, ince we hall enjoy your company, unlee thee fair trangers do deprive us of it. At this word he bluh'd, knowing that Paris loved her. As this bluh did pleae Paris, o it had a contrary effect in Silvander, who knowing that Paris loved her, could not defend himelfe againt ome tings of jealouie, when he aw the good reception of his Rivall; and this experience taught him to confee, that jealouie might proceed from love. The hepheardee, who had no inclination to hate Silvander, took notice of it, and o did Laonice, though the hepheard did diemble it as well as he could; and they had known it better, if Atrea had not parted them; for, deiring mot paionately to finih their journey, he broke company: And becaue Paris had taken Diana by the arme, Silvander went towards Phillis, who eeing him comming: It eemes (aid he unto him) that we are too too many, and that, though we were abent, they could entertain themelves. I cannot deny it, aid Silvander; I mut hrug my houlders patiently, and pay this kinde of tribute without murmur. When he would have anwered farther, Hylas came to them, and not caring for thee trangers, ran unto Phillis, and let Palinice, Cercenea, and Florice, as if he had never loved them. Diana, who could not chue but admire this humour in him, did make a igne unto Phillis by way of wonder. Phillis, who did eteem him as an excellent man to make port, after he had looked upon him: But Hylas, (aid he unto him) can I believe you to be in earnet? Can you doubt it, aid he, •• nce I have left all thee whom I did love, to wait upon you. That is an excellent argument indeed, aid he; but, I pray tell me, did you ever love thee trangers whom you have left to come unto us? You may gather as much, aid he, from Florice's own mouth. I had ome reaon (aid he) to ask this quetion; for if you did ever love them, how could you finde a heart to leave them o oon, in a place where they are trangers? Even as I have heretofore left others for them, aid Hylas, o now I do leave them for you; and I mut needs confee, that if my affection unto you were not much above all termes of civility; I hould have thought my elfe in ome ort obliged to wait upon them. Doubtlee, aid Phillis, you do very much oblige me; but I do admire, that ince you did love them, you hould now make o little account of them. I did love them, 'tis true, aid Hylas, but I will do o no more, my love to them is now dead; and me-thinks this hould be no uch great piece of wonder, to ee a man free, when the cord which tyed him is broken. I do believe, aid Silvander, that Hylas did never love thee trangers; for if he had, he would have loved them till, ince the cords of Love cannot be broken. Though they cannot be broken, aid Hylas, yet I am ure they may be untied. No, aid Silvander, all Love knots are Gordian knots. If they be, aid Hylas, I have a word as well as he, who when he could not untie them, did cut them, and I am ure I have done o everall times.

Never believe you did love them, aid Silvander; for if you had, you would have loved them till. Shall I not believe what I do know, aid Hylas? But, to do you a pleaure, I will not believe it. But pray trouble neither me nor your elfe any further; keep your elfe to your own melancholly humour, and vex me no more with your impertinent opinions.

Phillis, who was dicreet, and eeing Hylas in his angry altitudes, to interrupt him, aid thus: However, Hylas, I mut needs be angry with you, for hindring me from knowing ome things which thee trangers had begun to relate. Mitree, anwered he, I had rather never have loved them, then you hould mie of your atisfaction by any means of mine. I know, anwered Phillis, that the love you bear unto them, and the atisfaction you peak of, will not trouble you; for, ince you do not love them now, what will it concern you, whether you did or did not love them? Why, my Fairet, aid Hylas, do you not eteem pat contentments? If my contentment do not continue, aid Phillis, the remembrance of it does but grieve me the more. The ervices then that were done you a week ince, aid he, are vanih'd; if it be o, the wore for Hylas. Silvander anwered in the behalfe of Phillis: Your Mitree, aid he, does not peak of ervices, but of contentments received; and before you complain, it is requiite to know of her, whether your ervices be in that rank. Hylas
anwered: Thoe who mitrut their own merits, as you do, may make that doubt, but not I. Silvander, who knowes that Love cannot be paid but by Love again, and he, unto whom I devote mine, hath more goodnee, then not to acknowledge it, and more judgment then not to eteem it. Silvander would have anwered but Phillis interpoed: I do eteem Hylas, aid he, as I ought to do, and do acknowledge, his merits are very worthy to beloved; nor need he think his ervices are forgotten; for, he continuing to love me, they are all eteemed as preent: And if this declaration do pleae him, I will requet one thing of him which he ought not to deny me, unlee he would have me think, that he does not love me. Command, fairet, aid Hylas, what you pleae, but two things; that I die, or that I ceae loving you; and I obey: for if I die, I cannot love you, and if I do not love you, I cannot delight in any life. May you, and your love to me, aid Phillis, be immortall, and o they hall before they die, by my command. But my deire is, to have a relation of that from your own mouth, which you hindred Florice from imparting to us. Diana hearing this requet, and being much offended with the extremity of the Suns heat, did ay, he would be a very willing Auditor, o they could finde out an umbrage from the Sun's heat; for he believed, the dicoure of Hylas would be very pleaant.

Atrea, who longed to go about their buinee, did think as much, and therefore in compliance unto Diana's will, he aid, that he would make one. So, aid Hylas, it hall not tick upon me; and I hould think my elfe to be very bad company, if I were not very willing to give you atisfaction, and my elfe alo, for I do believe, there is as much delight in thinking upon old and pat Loves, as if they were preent; for the delights of Love are commonly more in the imagination, then in the thing it elfe; and in relation of things pat the oul doth cat her eye upon thoe images which remain in the fancy, and looks upon them as if they were preent. And therefore let us look out for a convenient hade, from the rayes of the Sun. It is impoible, aid Silvander, to finde a more convenient place in all the Wood, then by this little brook which you ee; for the coolnee of the hade, and murmure of the water, is very inviting; beides, it is nothing out of our way. All the company concur with him; and when they came unto it, every one began to wah their hands, and it round the Fountain of it, unlee Silvander, who got into a great Cherry Tree, which made part of the hade unto the Fountain, and brought ome of the bet Cherries unto Diana, who gave ome to Paris and the hepheardees, and picking out ome of the bet, he gave them unto Silvander, aying; Here Silvander, I mut needs give you ome, who gave them unto me. I would to god (aid he, and kied the hand that gave them) you would receive all I give you with as good a will as this. Then taking his place as neer her as he could, Hylas, when they had eaten all their Cherries, began his dicoure thus.

div.head: The Hitory of Parthenopea, Florice, and Dorinde.
div.p: I Have often laughed in my thoughts, at all thoe who condemn incontancy, and are profeed enemies againt it, conidering, that they themelves are not able to be as they ay, nor more contant, then thoe, whom they brand with that vice; for, when they do fall in love do they not fall in love with Beauty, or omething they think that is pleaing unto them? Now when this Beauty doth fade, as time doubtlee will make all Beauty do, are not they incontant, in till loving thoe faces that are now grown ugly, and retain nothing of what they were, but only the very name of a face? If to love that, which is contrary unto that which was loved, be incontancy; and if uglinee be contrary unto beauty: then he that did love a fair face, and continues loving it when it is ugly, mut be concluded incontant. This conideration makes me think, that the way to avoid incontancy, is alwaies to love beauty, and when it fades, farewell love; finde ome other that is fair, and till love beauty, and not its contrary, unlee you be uncontant to your firt love. I know full well, that this is point blank againt the opinion of the vulgar: But, by way of anwer, let me tell you, that the Heard of people, the vulgar, is but a heard of rude and ignorant beats and in this, they give a true tetimony of it.

Do not think it trange, fairet Mitree, nor you generous Paris, if in relating the tory of my life you hear of many uch changes: For, I am o carefull not to decline from this contancy, that I had rather quit all thoe whom hitherto I have loved, then recede from it. You have formerly been acquainted with the caue, why I came out of Camargues,
how I came unto Lyons, why I loved Palinice and Cercenea. And when I interrupted Florice, he would have told you, how he began to captivate me; but becaue he forgot ome things which are requiite you hould know, I hall peak out that, which he did o ubtlely conceal, and then relate the tory of my life, if we have time enough.

Be pleaed to know, then, fairet Mitree, that Clorian was very ill advied, in employing me to be his poke-man unto Cercenea; in uch a buinee as that, it is dangerous to make choice of a friend, that is better accomplihed then himelfe; a hundred to one, but in lieu of Friend, he becomes a Lover; and he that ent him, not loved; for, if his Mitris have any wit, he will chue the better. The truth is, when I went with Palinice unto Cercenea, in the behalfe of Clorian, my intention was to erve him as a friend, and to ue all poible addrees, which might conduce unto his contentment; but, aoon as I aw this Beauty, I remembered, that I my elfe was in love with her, ever ince I aw her that night in the Temple; o as now the tate of the quetion was whether I hould tifle Friendhip, or tifle Love; and after a long debate with my elfe unto which I hould yield, I concluded, that the lat commer mut give place unto the firt. Love told me, that it had taken poeion of my oul almot aoon as I was born, and that my affection unto Cercenea, was before my love of Palinice, which was the caue of my friendhip with Clorian; and therefore my friendhip coming after my love, it is injutice if I let it keep till in poeion. No urely, thought I, we ee the Lawes allow primogeniture in Children, and Nature it elfe eemes to approve of it. This was the reaon why I applyed my elfe unto Cercenea, as Florice hath told you. And I beeech you judge, whether I am obliged to endeavour the contentment of another, before my own. Why hould he upbraid me with the name of Traitor to my friend? For, if of two evills, the leer be alwaies to be choen; if killing ones elfe be the wort of murders, who, that is in his enes, will ay, but I had better betray friendhip then love, and have a greater regard unto the preervation of my own life and contentment, then the life and contentment of Clorian? Clorian loved me, and I loved Cercenea; Clorian deired me to peak for him, and my affection bad me peak for my elfe: If I did not atisfie Clorian, I offended againt my friendhip to him; if I did not atisfie my affection, I offended againt Cercenea and Hylas. I do love Clorian, and I do love Hylas alo. Put elfe and another in the cales, and elfe, I dare ay will out-weigh: So I and Clorian. The gods did favour my deigne, o as Cercenea, after ome courthip, did love me may be, as well as I loved her, and when you know what aurances of it he did give me, I believe you will ay as much as I. But becaue there was ome unto whom he owed duty, and particularly her Mother, he deired me to let her faign as if he loved Clorian, becaue there was already ome probability of a Marriage betwixt them, being both of one Town, and one quality. Moreover, Clorian being very rich, her Mother would doubtlee like well of the Match; whereas if my love unto her had been dicovered, being a tranger, and perhaps had a wife in ome other place, he would have diallowed of it, and perhaps charged her daughter not to ee me.

I was very glad of the motion, becaue I knew not with what language I could put Clorian off any longer, having worn out all my excues, till they were thread-ba • e, o as he eeing me o much with Cercenea, and yet doing nothing for him, began to be in ome doubt of me. Then I acquainted Cercenea with all paages betwixt Clorian and me, and how he had employed me to peak unto her. But, fairet Mitree. I told her by way of mocking him, let if I hould have et forth unto her his affection as it was, he hould entertain any parks of love unto him; but, I did it o dexterouly, that Cercenea had a greater minde to make ue of him as a cloak for her love of me, with lee upition and told me. That her Mother had often propoed him unto her for a Husband, and that he knew he had ome good will unto her. Then I went unto Clorian, unto whom I faigned a long Prologue, as an introduction of what I intended to ay; I related unto him the peeches, anwers, and replyes, that I made in his behalfe, and did aure him, that I had made a way for his affection to finde a welcome. Oh! what thanks did he give me, and what promies to erve me upon the like occaion: for which I thanked him, but did not deire to be in his hands as he was in mine. At the lat, he took heart, and according to my advice, he reolved to peak of it unto Cercenea; but, with more fear and heart-beating, then if he were to fight with the mot valiant man alive: Yet, the courage which I had infued into him, and aurance that he hould be welcome to her, did make him urmount thoe fears which had olong ilenc'd him; and finding an opportunity, he acquainted her with his intentions in the bet language he could invent, the effect of which was, that he bore unto
her o much humble repect, as, without me, he never had durt to declare his affection unto her; that it was all purity and vertuous deires. Truly (anwered he) you have a very good friend of Hylas, and you may well think him o, and by all meanes preerve uch a Jewell; for he hath done nothing above a month, but continually talk in commendation of you: Alo, you may undertand from him, that I am not o obdurate as you imagine, but does think my elfe obliged to entertain a man of your merit, when you come with honet and pure deignes of Marriage, as your friend tells me you do; and therefore I am contented to live with you, according to the purity of uch affection; but I hall be very glad to have Hylas a witnee of all that paeth betwixt us, that he may arbitrate all matters betwixt us. I mut be briefe, my fair Phillis, otherwie an age would not erve, to relate all the accidents that befell me. But be pleaed to know, that ever ince this day, Clorian was o far ingaged, that he could not retreat; and becaue their Parents began to take notice of it, I did acquaint her Mother, that Clorian did intend to marry her Daughter, and that, becaue I thought it an advantageous Match unto Cercenea, I had contributed all my endeavours to bring it about; but, ince I had not yet poken of it unto his Father and Mother, I deired, that the buinee might be kept ecret. Cercenea's Mother knowing Clorian to be rich and well born did heartily thank me for my endeavours, and did deire, that if Clorian had any uch minde, he would peak unto her, and he would keep it as ecret as he pleaed; but he deired, to have that atisfaction from himelfe. I aured her, he hould; and accordingly, within a few daies after, we went unto her again, and Clorian told her more then I had done. Thus all things went very well; for my part, I was welcome to the Mother, more welcome to Clorian, but mot of all to Cercenea. You ee into what a pae I was brought: to eem as if I did not love this fair one, I was forced to quit my place unto Clorian, and to peak for him. When there was any company, I tood before them, that Clorian might uneen kie her hand; but, it vexed me to the oul, when he kied her mouth, as often he did in my preence: And though it did dipleae me very much, and Cercenea more, yet we did contrain our elves, that he and I might have ome opportunities ometimes of privacy: For the Mother, believing me to be a mediator only for Clorian did give me all the liberty I could deire. Nay more, I brought her Letters from Clorian, and oftentimes did anwer them my elfe, for he did only write them, and god knowes, not without much laughter and jearing of him.

Thus did I live, the mot contented man alive, till Fortune upon a udden turn'd the wheel and yet it went not o neer my heart, as it would anothers, becaue I had o good a receipt againt all uch maladies. The Facchanalian Feats being at hand to be celebrated. Clorian and I reolved to maintain a Tournement. Clorian took for his device a Picture of Circe (with Circenea's face) amongt the Companions of Ulyes, with this Motto, To her had fewer Charmes. But I not daring to declare my elfe as he did, I did a little diguie her name, and painted a Syren, and Ulyes tyed to the Mat of his Ship, with this Motto, What B • nds would be ufficient? I thought that I had done very well, and that he was infinitely obliged unto me for it: But ee the Fate. As chance was, there was a young Beauty in Lyons, whoe name was Parthenopea, a neer neighbour unto my lodging, with whom, how ever it came to pae, I had no great familiarity; for it was not my humour to have any fair neighbours, and not to viit them. When I was in the Lits, thoe that were curious, began to interpret our devices; as for that of Clorian, every one could eaily undertand it, Circenca's face, and the clinch of her name, did ufficiently dicover it: But, as for mine, none could give it a meaning. At the lat an old Knight that was upon the Scaffold, amongt the Ladies where Cercenea was, and Parthenopea, and whoe age excued him from being in Armes, he aid, that it was eaie to dicover his meaning; and then addreing himelfe unto Parthenopea: It is for you, fair One, aid he, that he enters into the Lits. At this, he bluh'd and thinking her elfe wrongfully accued, did anwer: If it be for me, he is very ecret in his matters, for he never poke to me. Take heed (aid Cercenea, who thought her elfe concerned) that you do not diemble, and carry it more cloe then he doth. It is an eay matter, aid he, to carry that ecret which I do not know. If you pleae to know the reaon of my opinion (aid the old Knight) I hall tell you, and I am confident your judgments will agree with mine. I hall be very glad, aid he, to undertand this ecret from you. You ee then (replyed the old Knight) that he bears a Syren upon his Shield, with this Motto, What Bonds would be ufficient? he could not more plainly name you, then by the painting of a Syren; for the Ancients ay, that the Syrens were three Daughters of Achiloes, by the Nymph Calliope; and were called Lygra,
Leucoia, and Parthenopea; and your name being Parthenopea, he could not more clearly expree his meaning then by a Syren, and Ulyes tyed to the Mat of a Ship, meaning, that nothing can hinder him from being yours, if by your favours you will be his. Then all the company cryed out; Oh Parthenopea, how cloely have you kept it? But you had now better to confee then deny it. For my part, aid he, it is all one whether it be o or no, for it concernes me but a little. I hope then aid Circenea, you will not be angry if we call him your Knight. I do not care aid he, but have a care you do not call him wrong. The report went preently amongt the Ladies that I was the Syren's Knight, and Clorian Cyrenea's. For my part, I knew nothing of it, but took notice, that as I paed under the Scaffold, Cercenea cryed out unto me, Adieu the Knight of Parthenopea, but I knew not what he meant.

At lat, the Tourney being ended, every one retired; and Clorian and I thinking we had behaved our elves very well, aoon as we had put off our Armes, we went unto Cercenea; but he being infinitely incened againt me, did not look upon me with her uuall weetnee, but when I poke to her, he would give no reply, but, Let me alone, Knight of the Syren, and in a corning manner, turned away from me. I was o innocent in what he accued me of, that I knew not what to think, unlee that I had ill acquitted my elfe in this Tournement, which I undertook to maintain: But not conceiving, that I had done any wore then my Companion; and eeing that he cherihed him, I could not imagine what to think.

That night I retired, unatisfied; for I could not obtain o much favour, as to peak with her in private, but went away much dipleaed at my fortune. But the next morning, a chance happened, which poiled all my affairs. Being that morning in the Temple, I aw there Parthenopea, with one of her Aunts; and eating my elfe by chance by her, I perceived he did not look upon me with the eye of an enemy: She was fair, and conequently one of thoe, who by the Lawes of Contancy, I was obliged to love; and therefore I got a little neerer unto her, and watching for an opportunity of peaking unto her, he leaned towards me, and aid How Sir, do you like the Tournement? It is my part, aid I, to ask you that quetion, ince it is the office of uch Beauties as your elfe to judge. I do not ask you, aid he, how you did behave your elfe, for every one can witnee, none could do better; but I would gladly know, whether you be not weary after all the pains you took? Since, fair one, aid I, you have given uch an advantageous judgment for me, it is impoible I hould be weary. We were in a place where long dicoure was not handome, and therefore he anwered me only with a mile, and turned the other way When prayers and devotions were done, he went out of the Temple; and I conceiving my elfe obliged by her language to wait upon her to her lodging, which was neer, I took her by the hand, and by the way I undertood how it was the opinion of every one, that I maintained the Tournement as her Knight. I being glad to umbrage my affection unto Cercenea, and moreover taken with the favours of Parthenopea I anwered her, that it was true and that not daring to declare it by my words, I made choice of that way. After much dicoure, and when we were come unto her lodging he took off her Scarfe, and laid it upon the table; afterwards her Mask, and tanding to the fire, he talked unto me and I perceived, that what I had done, was not dipleaing unto her, becaue he till renewed the dicoure upon it: And the more I aw my ervice pleaed, the more fell I in love with her. In concluion, before I parted, I took her Scarfe which lay upon the Table, and though he made a little reitance, yet I put it about my neck, and told her, That ince I undertook a Tournement for her, without any mark of my affection, it was reaonable I hould have that, as a tetimony of my being hers; her reitance was not great, and therefore I carried it away, and wore it about my neck all the ret of the day. However, becaue I would not loe Cercenea, I would not go into any place where he was in probability of eeing me: But he whom I doubted the leat, which was Clorian, told her, not intending any hurt unto me, that I was the mot contented man in the world, with the favours of Parthenopea, and thereupon told her of the Scarfe. Oh how this went to her very heart, for he did really love me, and yet he made no hew of any dicontent. But the next morning when I went unto her, and Clorian not there: Oh Knight of the Syren, aid he, what have you done with your fine Scarfe? I mut tell you that I did love Cercenea much better then I did Parthenopea, and would not loe her upon o mall an occaion; and therefore I wore a thouand oaths that when I undertook the Tournement, I had not the leat thought of Parthenopea; but upon the word of Syren only, which had a reemblance unto Cercenea.
But, aid he, why did you not tell me of it? Becaue, anwered I, I thought the thing o plain, that you would know it this way. And what do you (aid he) concerning this Scarfe? I mut confes, aid I unto her, that I took it from Parthenopea yeterday, being deirous to diguie my affection unto you under that vail. Cercenea tood ilent a while, and then began thus: Well Hylas, I wil believe all you tell me provided you will give me atisfaction in one thing. It hall be impoible (aid I) if I do not. Give me the Scarfe, replyed he, which you took from Parthenopea, and in exchange, I hall give you another which is better. I was very loath to do it, and would gladly have come off with an excue, but it was impoible.

As oon as he had it, he put it upon her arme, and gave me another, which indeed was much better; and the ame day, knowing that I was not in my lodging, he went with ome of her friends (under colour of walking) unto my lodging, and ent to ee if I was not within: A ervant of mine, whom he knew, came to her, and told her, that I was not in my lodging. This good company and my elfe (aid he) were deirous of his company to walk with us: But prethee do me the favour to go and tell Parthenopea, that we tay here for her to that end; and in reward of thy ervice, take this Scarfe, and wear it all this day for my ake. Then he put about his neck that Scarf which I had from Parthenopea. This varlet thought himelfe mighty brave, and much honoured in this favour, and gave her mot humble thanks; and to hew his ready obedience, ran as fat as he could to deliver his meage unto Parthenopea, who eeing her Scarfe about the fellowes neck, he had an opinion, that I caued him to wear it in corn of her, and hearing his err • nd, did know very well, that it came from Cercenea, and that I had given it unto her; which did o extreamly offend her, that I could never ince renew with her, and much lee with Cercenea, who abolutely declined me, although he plainly aw, that I did love her better then I did Parthenopea. But practiing this Maxime, that one mut hate them whom they have offended, o he knowing her treaon to be great, he would never conide in me again. I was contrained to return unto Palinice, but tayed not long; for it being then the pringtime of the year, thee Ladies would many in a company, enjoy the weetnee of the aire, and go into the Country in a Barge, up the calm and mooth River of Arar, paing away the time, one while in muick of Intruments, another while in that of Voices and ometimes landing, would dance upon the dazie Meadowes. As ill luck was, I had no acquaintance amongt all this good company, but only Palinice and Cercenea; however, I thrut in amongt them, and undertook to entertain them all: I aw they all whipered, and asked who I was and Palinice had a great deal of trouble in telling my name unto all that asked her: But preently after, I was as well known as any in the company, for, holding dicoure with the firt that did offer any, they found my humour o pleaing, that all of them deired my friendhip. As long as the Barge went upward, although the River ran o ilent, as one could not tell which way it ran; yet, ometimes it would make uch a noie againt the tream, as they could ue none but Intruments: but when it went downward, the waves made only a little dahing againt the Barge, and then thoe who had good Voices, did ing what came into their fancies. Amongt this aembly of Beauties, there was many Knights, and children of Druides, to keep them company, and pae away the evening with more delight. This was the firt time I ever aw Theombres: This man had almot paed the Autumne of his age, in uch a good opinion of himelfe, as he thought all Ladies like to die for the love of him: For my part, I never could oberve any taking quality in him; yet certainly, he had ome features, which was not dipleaing unto ome: Amongt the ret, Florice was one, who might come into the catalogue of thoe who are called Fair: Indeed he was fair, all her features pleaing, but above all her eyes were o weet and alluring as I mut confee, I never aw uch; her tature was tall, and her minde o majetick, as one might eaily ee, he was above vulgar extraction; and indeed he was of that Family, who vaunts to be decended from the great Ariovites. And though this fair Lady was uch, as there was not one in all the Country, but did, and ought, to yield unto her, both in merit and beauty: Yet, Theombres was more in her affection, then any in the Town. And becaue it was long ince this Love began, and hung in a kinde of languihing continuance, Theombres thought it bet to awake it, by ome parks of jealouie; and therefore eemed as if he were in love with a young Beauty, called Dorinde, who indeed was Mitree of ome beauty, but yet yielded in all unto Florice: Now Dorinde being gone out of the Town unto one of her Uncles, Theombres, to continue his diimulation, did alwaies, when he ung, take Dorinde for the ubject, and, as I remember, one Vere of
it was, that when he departed, he vowed to keep him continually in her memory, which he took to be o great a happinee unto himelfe, that he would not change fortunes with any Angell in heaven. The fair Florice did think her elfe much concern'd in this, and it being poke in her preence, he was the more offended; and therefore in defence of Dorinde, who was ome waies allied unto her, he anwered him in this manner.

lg.l: DORINDE did but only play,

l.hi: And fool you, when he o did ay;
Knowing without a wrong, he may
Fale coine, to uch as fale are, pay.

lg.l: Perhaps the vainee of your minde
Does make you brag, that he is kinde;
To hew, that favour you can finde,
From one o fair and well inclin'd.
If uch a promie hee did vow,
'Twas only to be rid of you:
So being but a parting blow,
Shee's not oblig'd to think on't now.

div.p:
This retort upon Theombres by Florice did o pleae me, that ever ince, I reolved to love her, and add her unto Palinice and Cercenea. And preently after, rowing by a very pleaant Meadow, it was the generall vote to land in it, and enjoy the beauty of the place: Some began to ing, others to dance, and others to gather flowers, or to walk. Florice was one of thoe, whoe Genius was to make Noegayes and Garlands; he had eparated her elfe from company, and et down upon the grae, perhaps in ome thoughts of what Theombres had aid. I accoted her, not with an intention to fall on, but to try her, and as I found her tractable, o to go on, or make a retreat; alo my conceit was, that Cercenea being made thereby a little jealous, might be moved to repentance: but it hapned quite otherwie, as you hall undertand. However, I fell upon my knees by her, and was very officious in helping her to gather flowers: She, very civilly, took them at my hands, but wondred, that having never een me before, that I hould take o much paines. I perceived it well enough, but till waited, till her words gave me an occaion to let her know, that I loved her. My reaon, why I treated her at uch a ditance of repect, was, the grandure and tate that he kept, which in truth was uch, that of all I ever loved before, I never tood in uch reverentiall fear, as of her. It hapned as I hoped for after he had received many of the flowers which I gathered, he told me, I had taken too much paines, and that I would think her to be uncivill, if he uffered me to continue. To which I anwered, That I thought every one obliged to do her all ervice, ince he had o excellently well defended her friend in her abence. Do you mean Dorinde, aid he unto me? The very ame aid I, in whoe peron you have obliged all others. Truly, aid he, I could not endure the vanity of Theombres; for you ee what he is, and yet he thinks, we are all ready to die for the love of him. Then certainly, aid I, Ladies mut needs be either very loving, or of very little judgment; for I think him to be rather a remedy againt Love, then of any capacity to caue it. I am clearly of your opinion, aid he; for, if I had an inclination to love, this man of all men living hould be the lat I would chue. If you hould love him, aid I, it would be a grand offence againt the gods, who having adorned you with o much beauty, you would that way profane it. I cannot tell (aid he) what beauty there is in me: but I am mot ure, that I could never love him. Cannot you tell what beauty there is in you, aid I? then you cannot tell what all the world doth ee; but, perhaps it is only your modety, which makes you eem ignorant of it. No, no, aid he, I do really believe, that there is nothing in my face which can merit that name you give it: But, be it what it will, pray let's talk no more of it, for more would be out of eaon, and little delighting. I hall obey you, aid I unto her, but it hall be with this protetation then, that I will never peak again what I think, and what you have forbidden to be in my mouth, hall as long as I live ret in my heart. We had dicoured longer, had not the company
called us away, for they were already gone into the Barge. Then he roe up without making any anwer, and putting her flowers in a corner of her Gown, I took her hand, and conducted her to her company, where not daring to revive the dicoure which we left, let I hould be too bold (for o much forwardnee in the firt declaration of Love, is a igne of but little affection) I contented my elfe at this time with what I had already aid. At lat, the generall genius of the company was all for inging, and when it came to my turn, I ung thee enuing Veres, to aure Florice, that all which I had aid, was true.

lg.l: FAiret, you murder my deires,
Which yet, to none but you apires.
I wear by your fair eyes, that are
More plendid then the Sun by far.
I wear by my own heart and oul,
Which you imperiouly controul.
I wear by your own weetnee, which
Does all my faculties bewitch.
I wear by your didain and corn,
Intolerable to be born.
I wear by all that amorous fire,
Which makes men love you and admire.
By all my hopes, and all my fear,
And all my hot deires I wear.
I wear by your fair elfe, that is
The Center of my happinee.
I wear by all that life affords,
And yet you credit not my words.

div.p: Thus, fair Phillis, was a good foundation laid; for, ince the very firt time I aw Florice, it was impoible for me to make a retreat; yet it angred me, that I hould loe Palinice, as well becaue I was obliged unto her, as becaue he was really a woman of much merit. Moreover, the love of Cercenea much grieved me; for this young Beauty being offended he leighted all the reaons I could bring in to convince her. However, though he did not love me, yet it vext her to ee, that Florice hould have a more abolute power over me, then ever he could have, thinking this to be an argument, of her being inferiour in beauty: And this was the reaon why he did me all the ill offices he could both to Palinice and Florice. But o it hapned, that her malice did me no harm, but did more for me, then all my ervices perhaps of a long time could have done; for Florice preently found, that Cercenea, did peak it out of a paionate partiality, and therefore he gave no credit unto her: And on the contrary, conidering and oberving my actions more neerly, he began to finde them agreeable, and by little and little to pleae her; o as Love, like a lie and ubtle pie, did inenibly ininuate himelfe into her oul. However, I being very deirous to keep my elfe in Palinice's favour, I was a little vexed.

But learn this from me, Silvander, (aid he, and turned towards that Shepheard) that there is none whom women eteem more, then thoe who are in love with them. Nor none whom they more depie, aid Silvander, then thoe that leave them, and love another. But upon this conideration, aid Hylas, I endeavoured to keep fair with all, if it was poible, but all in vain; for Florice was too full of vanitie, and had too over good an opinion
of her own merits, to entertain a heart in which any other had a hare. And this proud oul reolving to be ole Mitree and to love none but me, he did one day do me o much favour, as to aurence of her love. But, aid I unto her, what hall we do with Theombres, (thinking to upbraid her with him)? She preently anwered me in my own element. Let us give him unto Palinice. I undertood her meaning well enough and therefore I wore unto her never to love any but Florice and that if he would banih Theombres out of her ight, I would promie her, never to look upon Palinice again. Nor becaue you deire it, aid he but becaue he does extreamly dipleae me, I will wear and protet unto you, that I will never love him, and that if it were handome, I would banih him out of my ight; for when you conider that action well, you will finde it to be a greater wound unto me, then it can be atisfaction unto you. Since this time, he gave her elfe wholly unto me, and I, contrary to my own nature, did give my elfe wholly unto her, and declined all others. From morning untill night I never tirred out of her lodging: unlee he went; and if any came upon viits, they mut be perons of great eminency, if they did interrupt our dicoure. At every word, I was in her mouth, and he in mine, and we could not peak, unlee the one called the other as a witnee. Judge yet, whether Palinice and Cercenea had not enough to talk off. This was the reaon, why all the Town made it their common talk; and reports alwaies encreaing by going, they went o much in diadvantage of Florices honour, that at lat they came to her ears, by a friend who acquainted her. She repented her elfe of the imprudent carriage of the buinee, though too late: She acquainted me and told me, that we mut be more circumpect in our expreions of good will; and the better to hide it for the future he willed me not to come unto her, but at night, and o give a top unto reports if it were poible. To give her atisfaction, I refrained comming for a while; but becaue he was as much dipleaed with the deprivation of my company, as I of hers, it was reolved betwixt us, to finde out ome way or other, to avoid the cenure of the world, and yet be together. After conideration he advied me to eem as if I loved ome, who ued to be familiarly with her, and under that haddow, I might come unto her: And upon erious thoughts, none deemed more fit for this purpoe then Dorinde, as well, becaue he was her coen, and frequently familiar, as becaue he was fair, though not very ubtle: And though he was not o fair as Florice, nor o rich, nor o well decended; yet, he did excell the mot, both in beauty and merit. The day that I declared my elfe Dorinde's ervant, was that, upon which the people celebrated a Feat, in memory of the retauration and building of their Town by Nero, after that mot terrible fire, which in one night conumed it to the ground. At this time of publick joy, every one did trive to appear as fine as poibly they could, as well to ait at the acrifices offered unto Jupiter, the Retaurator, and to the Titular gods, as to be een in the Theaters and publick Shewes. Dorinde, deirous to be een and oberved, did et out her beauty with all the illutrations that Art could devie. Before the day ended, I did o accot Dorinde with my expreions of that affection I had unto her, that he did believe them. At that time and day, I became acquainted with a young Cavalier called Periander, a man indeed full of civility, dicretion, and weetnee: This man eeing me o obequious to Dorinde, and finding my humour agreeable unto his own, reolved to make me his friend: And I, on the other ide, being deirous of acquaintance in that place, where I intended to tay, ince Love did o oblige me to it; I thought him to be a man of merit, and therefore was glad to have him my friend. This encounter of friendhip, which proceeded from one and the ame ympatheticall caue, was ooner contracted betwixt him and me, then betwixt me and Dorinde, although Florice, the better to diguie her own love, did contribute all that poibly he could unto it: But poor Florice did not foreee, how he was harpning a word which gave her a deep wound he did not know, how it was alwaies my humour, never to ee any Beauty, but I mut needs love her a little; o as ere I was aware, I was in Love with Dorinde as well as with Florice: yet, I did love Florice better, he being more fair, and of a higher rank. Two months were pent in this manner, and the friendhip betwixt Periander and me grew to that height, that we were commonly called the two Friends; and becaue we both deired a continuation of it, we took reciprocall oathes, of a mot faithfull and perfect friendhip, calling the gods to witnee to the oath which we had taken, and to be punihers of him, who hould violate the Lawes of friendhip. After this protetation, nothing was in the oul of one, but it was dicovered unto the other. It hapned one morning (for commonly we lay both together) after much dicoure upon the Beauties of the Town, he asked me, whether
there was any of them which I loved: And anwering him; Yes: He told me, that before he would ask me who my Mitree was, he would tell me who was his I deire, aid I unto him, to be the firt in that freedome, becaue you were the firt that asked the quetion. Then I related unto him all the addrees which I had made unto Dorinde, ince the lat two months, but would not by any means mention Florice, as well, becaue I loved her more and deired that that Love hould be kept ecret, as becaue I knew that one of his conens did court her in Marriage. As oon as I had named Dorinde: How, (aid he) do you love Dorinde? Dorinde, the Daughter of Arcingentorix. The very ame, aid I; and I do aure you, that I have courted her above this ix months. Oh heavens! cried he, how cruelly doth love treat me? And after he had paued a while; I do wear, aid he, and protet, that it is he whom I have long loved. Could a greater misfortune befall me! I had rather die then retreat, and if I continue, I hall offend againt the Lawes of Amitie. I was much atonihed to hear him ay thus; for, though I loved him, yet it went againt my heart to leave Dorinde unto whom Love had kindled new deires in me: And therefore, after I had held my eyes up to heaven, as one that was much troubled, I aid thus unto him: Brother, ince our Loves did begin in us before our Friendhip, it argues a ympathy in our humours, which forceth us to love the ame; but however, let the Lawes of Friendhip be inviolable; ince we have thus far agreed, let our prudence endeavour to continue o for the future; and in order to that, let us ee whom this Lady mot affects: To think that our friendhip hould make us quit her the one unto the other, this would be rather tyranny then friendhip; and to think, that we can continue Rivalls and Friends, is Folly. What then hould we do? Let us refer all to Reaon, and ee which of us he loves mot. Tell me, I do conjure you by the Oath which we have taken, whether it be true, that he doth love you, and what tetimonies of it he hath given you? I do wear, Brother, (anwered he) that I will not tell you a lie, either in this, or any thing you hall ask, I will firt die a hundred deaths. Know then, that it is impoible I hould give you any aurance that he loves me, ince her dicretion and modety keeps all cloe in her own oul: Then (aid I unto him) ince we are both in one condition, let us wear by our friendhip one unto another, and call all the divinities to punih mot rigorouly the perjured, that he who can obtain mot affection from her and give a tetimony of it unto the other, he hall only enjoy her: By this means we hall not offend againt the Lawes of Friendhip it being mot reaonable, that he whom he loves mot, hould enjoy her, and the other quit her. I conceive your Propoition to be very jut, (aid Periander) and I wear by all the gods not to werve from it.

I beeech you, generous Paris, conider the Natures of mot men. Before Periander declared his affection unto me I did love Dorinde; but much lee then ince: And as a fire is augmented by the agitation of the winde; o my affection was much more violent, being oppoed by the affection of Periander. This was the reaon, why I devoted my elfe unto her more then before. But having pent ome daies in courting her without effect, and fearing that Periander being of that Town, and having many kindred of good rank, hould make a farther progree into her favour then my elfe. I reolved to ue the ubtlety of the Fox, where the trength of a Lion would not prevail: I had recoure then unto Policie, thinking that in Love, ubtleties were lawfull and jut. I caued a little Mirror to be made, no bigger then the plain of my hand, but as rich as poibly Art could make it, both in the curioity of the Gold work, and in the Enamell, which added much to the value and beauty; afterwards I put my own Picture, which was drawn to the life, between the Glae, and the table of Gold which held it; o as when the Mirror was opened, nothing could be een but the Glae and work about it. Afterwards I went to an old woman, who got her living, by carrying Jewells and other pieces of curioity, unto private houes to ell; and told her, that I deired to turn this Mirror into Money, and therefore he would do me a great pleaure, if he could ell it for me. She promied, he would do her bet. But I told her, that I had preent ue of money, and would let it go at any reaonable rate. She anwered me, that things done in hate were never well done; but till he would do her endeavour. So he went away with my Mirror, yet, he was no ooner gone out of my lodging, but I ent for her back, and told her, that my occaions were o preing, as if he could but get halfe the worth, or lee, he hould let it go; but advied her, before he went any whither ele, to carry it into the houe of Arcingentorix: I know, aid I unto her that he hath a Daughter whom he loves very well, perhaps he will be glad of uch a preent for her. Indeed, anwered the woman, I did intend to offer it unto him before any other,
becaue it was long ince I was at that houe Go then, aid I unto her, and before you carry it any whither ele, let me know what the Father or the Daughter will give for it. I will not trouble you with all the goings and commings of this woman: but o it was, that my plot took effect, and Dorinde bought it, as well for its curioity of workmanhip, as for the cheapnee; not giving the third part of the worth for it. Things being thus ordered about five or ix daies after, I aw it hanging by her ide, and he making very much of it. Then I thought it requiite to accomplih my plot as oon as I could; for it was to be feared, that becaue the glae was o extreamly thin and fragil, it might break, and then my picture would be een; to prevent which danger, I went unto Periander, and asked him, Whether he had any thing advanced himelfe into Dorinde's favour? To which he very ingenuouly anwered, That he was not one jot more in her favour, than the firt day he aw her, that he knew not whether he hould accue her Nature, or his deficiency in Merit, or his hard Fortune; yet, all his contentment was, that he aw he treated him as well as any other. No, no, Brother, aid I unto him, do not accue your own Merits, not the Nature of Dorinde; for your Merits are much above your Fortune; nor is he inenible of Love's Darts; but that affection which poeeth her, is the caue of all this coldnee, both towards you and all others: And to hew you your errour, though I know it will vex you at the firt, yet I will tell you the truth Believe it, Brother, (aid I and embraced him) that I am in uch poeion of her, as he cannot ee but with my eyes. The truth is, I did never in all my life meet with o cloe and o dicreet a Lover as he is; for he is o afraid her paion hould be known, as he will not in publick o much as look upon me, unlee forced unto it by the Lawes of civility; but, when we are in private, if you did but ee how paionately he does carrae me, you would admire the trange command he hath over her elfe, in not making demontrations of it any where ele. And to the end you hould not think this to be a forged tale, I will give you uch certain knowledge, as hall undoubtedly aure you of all I ay. But, I do conjure you, by all the acred Lawes of Friendhip, (ince what I hall tell you, is only to undeceive you) that you do never dicover me, for it will nothing at all profit you, but may ruine me in her opinion. Then vowing he would not, I continued; Did you never take notice of a Mirror (aid I unto him) which of late daies he hath worn by her ide? And he anwering, Yes. Then know (aid I unto him) he weares it for my ake, and the love of me. Now, to put you out of all doubt, the firt time you ee her, take out the glae, and then take out a little paper which is between the glae and it, and you hall finde my Picture. There is no quetion, but he will be very orry that you aw it; but however, my friendhip obligeth me to dicover this ecret unto you, rather then let you run on in your errour. Periander hearing this, tood as if immovable, and tared, as if he had een the face of Medua: But after he had conidered upon what I aid, he concluded, that if it was o, then he would quit her unto me, and abolutely fall off. And to know the truth, aid he, though I do not upect your words, yet, I would go out of her ervice, by letting her know the caue, o as he hould not accue me of levitie. So he went immediately unto her lodging, where he found Dorinde by her elf, who tayed at home to entertain two Ladies which intended a viit unto her. She, who did really love Periander better then all thoe that courted her, did yet make very little hew of it; and as oon as he aw him, he went to meet him, according to her accutomed weetnee and civility. But he, who came with a bad opinion of her, and conceiving all her kindnees to be but diimulations, he began to look upon her and all her actions with didain. Almot as oon as he, thee expected Ladies came alo, but went preently away again. Periander could not chue but wonder at her freenee to him and all others: But having no minde to carry any longer in a place, where he thought him elfe o unworthily treated and betrayed, he would ee, whether all that was aid was true; and therefore took the Mirror in his hand, eeming as if he much admired it; and as he offered to take out the Glae, it broke, at which he tarted, as if it had been done by chance, and eeing the glae broken: Mitres, aid he, I beg your pardon, I am obliged to make amends, and put in another Glas. She anwered him, that it was a mall matter, and not worth the pains; upon this word, he held out her hand to take it again; but he, thinking that he would not let him have it, let he hould ee the Picture in it, he was the more backward in retoring it: and in this dipute, he took out the Glas, then the paper, and then he found what I had aid was true. Although he did believe me before, yet when he aw my Picture, he was o urpried, that he could not peak of a long time; and the amazement of Dorinde was no les. Periander, who tood
mute, looking ometimes upon the Picture, and ometimes upon Dorinde, and conidering her amazement alo, had an opinion, that he only eemed o, to be thought ignorant of it; therefore he was extreamly tranported with anger: Let me tell you, aid he unto her, that both in well loving, in ecrey, and in diimulation, you are the mot admirable, that ever I knew. Periander, aid he, I do protet by all that's acred, that I am ignorant of it. Take heed, aid he, how you invoke things that are acred; but, ince you are not the firt whoe humour hath deceived me, I will leave the place to another, that I may have o much contentment, as not to be the lat whom you will deceive. Upon this, he went away in an extream fury. Dorinde did all he could to undeceive him, but that did more augment his opinion of her diimulation. Thus he left her, and to oberve the Lawes of friendhip, he reolved upon Travell, not knowing any better way to overcome Love then abence, which yet would not do, as I hall tell you afterwards.

Now look upon me as arrived at the port of my deigne, having the place free unto my elfe. But Oh! generous Paris, when I went to ee Dorinde, Oh how he was dipleaed at me? She had ent for her who old her the Mirror, and forced her to confee of whom he had it; and finding it to be my elfe, I cannot expree unto you the greatnee of her anger: Perfidious Impotor (aid he unto me) why would you o mortally offend one, that never gave you any. occaion for it? How durt you, after o great an injury, be o impudent as to come in my ight? I had before han I prepared my elfe for a chiding, yet could not endure it without a bluh; but knowing, that the only way to top an impetuous torrent of fury, was, to let her jut anger cool a little, before I gave any anwer; therefore I tayed mute untill he had vented all he had to ay, and then I anwered her thus: I mut needs confee, that all your reproaches are jut; but alas, I cannot complain againt you for it, only againt Love, who having inflamed my oul towards you, did freez yours towards me. Had Love been jut, it would in ome ort have cooled my too ardent affection, and then I hould not have been forced to offend you, and needed not have ued any tricks, to drive away my Rivall from you. But alas I ee that I am a very Novit in Love, ince I look for any reaon in any thing it doth. But for all that, fair Dorinde, you do me wrong in complaining againt my actions, ince being but effects of Love, yet you hould expect them to be quared according to any rules of Reaon. I mut confee, that I have inned againt the rules of Reaon, but not againt Love; and I beeech you take me not as rationall, but as amorous, and mot extreamly wounded with the darts of Love.

I expreed the extremity of my affection with o much dejected humility, and paionate language, as it had a good melting influence upon her oul, o as within a few daies after, he began to mile upon me, and pardon my offence; and ee how an ill chance is ometimes profitable, for that which was the caue of her anger, was it which augmented her good will unto me: and conidering the artifice which I had ued, he had an opinion that I did mot certainly love her. And this conideration caued Thcombres to mie his Mitree; for he devoted her elfe wholly unto me, o as it may eem, that I did love her only to make her hate him: And yet for all this, I loved Florice much more then I did Dorinde: Truth is, that when Dorinde's favours did flow more then uuall upon me, I did begin to love her more; for nothing doth kindle affection and augment it o much, as favours.

Living then thus ambodexterouly with Florice and Dorinde, Florice began to enter into ome upition of me, and the common brute of this affection was blown all over: Therefore one day he poke unto me as if he were quite altered; and I, who did really love her, did vow and wear, that all my courthip of Dorinde, was but an effect of her own command to cover thereby my affection unto her: That if he would, I would never look upon Dorinde again, and told her, that if he would but look her elfe in a glae, and look upon Dorinde, that ight would give her better aurance of my ervice and affection, then all my words could. To be brief, with good language I brought her into a good opinion of me; yet I was forced to promie, that I would give her all the Letters which Dorinde writ unto me. Take heed, aid he unto me, let you hould promie and not perform, for that would for ever loe me, if I come to know it. I will never fail in any thing I promie (aid I unto her) and much lee unto Florice, then unto the gods. Thus were we upon better termes then ever. And becaue none was o dear unto me as Florice, yet had I a corner in my heart for Dorinde, and was much delighted in her company; he conferred many favours upon me, and I courted her o cloe with everall Letters, that he anwered me in Letters again, which I preently carried unto Florice, who read them, and kept them carefully.

p.hi: Hylas
p.U: eeing Silvander it neer Diana, and whipering, then laughed together, he broke off his dicoure, to anwer what he had a conceit they aid. I believe you laugh, Silvander, aid he unto him, at my loving Florice, and yet held correpondency with Dorinde. If I do meet, in my way unto the happinee of Florice, with any delights in the converation of Dorinde, do I contradict the Lawes of reaon, if I do receive them? Should I refue that good which the gods do end me, and which your unnaturall auterity diallowes? Now becaue Silvander would be no interruption, he would not return an anwer: And Hylas eeing him ilent, after he had hook his head, he fell into the dicoure from which he had digreed.

div.p: See now, aid he, the iue of thee Loves; the frequent converation which I had with Dorinde, began to encreae my love unto her the more. And in as much as the conferring of one favour drawes on another, that is greater, o he did every day give me cleerer evidences of her love, which was a caue, that our Letters began to alter tyle, and became more affectionate and paionate then uuall. This was a reaon, why I gave them unto Florice but eldome, and then only thoe which had fewet expreions of affection, and craftily kept the ret to my elfe.

Thus I lived for a while in a ea of delights, being welcome unto both; but it was too high to hold, and this happinee did not lat long: For it hapned one day, that as I pulled ome things out of my pocket, in the preence of Florice and other company, he epied two or three little Letters, lapped up after the very ame manner as Dorinde's were, which I had given unto her: She began preently to upect the truth, and many daies paing, and I not giving them unto her, he concluded her elfe to be deluded, and reolved to teal them from me; and becaue I took no notice, he eaily got them out of my pocket, whilt I was talking unto others, who did what they could to abue me, and give her a better opportunity to play the thief, thinking he did it only to make me eek them. She took them out o dexterouly, that I perceived not; he went away immediately, and was no ooner come unto her lodging, but locking her elfe up in her cloet, he threw them all upon the Table, and found five; ome very frehly written, and others of a longer date. The firt he took, which was lat writ, contained thee words.

body.head: Dorinde's Letter unto Hylas.
body.p: I Have here ent you the picture which you deired of me, not to make you loe the peron whom you have wone, as heretofore you did with the like-preent; but to aure you, that you have as much power over her that ent it, as you have of the Picture when it is in your hands. If it were permitted me, I hould be as often with you as it is; and though it be in that more happy then I am, yet it is les, in not knowing the happines it enjoyes, which I hould eteem infinitely above my life.

div.p: Then throwing this Letter upon the Table with an angry look, and puhing away the ret further from her, he went back a pace or two. Then folding her armes, and lifting up her eyes: Oh heavens! aid he, can this poibly be true? Hat then betrayed me, Hylas? Couldt thou o long fool me, and I never ee thy treaon? Then tanding ilent a long while, at lat, he truck both her hands upon the Table, and aid: Well Traitor, thou halt not pae unpunihed, I will dicover thee unto her whom thou hat betrayed as well as me, and perhaps we hall both grow a little wier by thy follies. She had no ooner fixed upon this reolution, but he lapt up all her Letters, and went to Dorinde, and deired her to go into her Cloet, and then hutting the dore: Sweet coen (aid he unto her) I am come to manifet my affection unto you; but upon condition, that when I have dicovered a ecret unto you, that you do prudently conceal it. I know that Hylas hath long courted you, and that you have long thought he loved you; but I come now out of my true affection to you to undeceive you, and to let you ee, that he hath deceived you. Upon this Dorinde bluh'd, and eemed a little hie. No, no, aid Florice, do not think, Coen, to hide that, which I do know better then your elfe: I ay, better; for you only know your own intentions, and not his, but I do know both. If you do, aid Dorinde, I mut confee you to be very knowing; but what, I beeech you, do you know of mine? I know, aid he, that you do love him, and ent him your picture, and receives all his addrees.

Dorinde being touched to the quick, he had not o much impudence as to deny it, but looked down, and bluhed more, holding her hands before her face for hame. Do
not vex, Dorinde, aid he, that thee things hould be thus known, but rather rejoyce they are fallen into my hands, & not anothers who lee loves you; if you love your own honour, withdraw your affection for the <> from this man, who courts you only to get uch favours from you as he brags of. There hath been heretofore ome familiarity betwixt him and me, and that is the reaon (which you have reaon to be glad of) that he hath addreed himelfe unto me. I do not think you ever poke one yllable unto him, which he hath not told me; and becaue it would be too long to repeat them, ee here mot of the Letters you have written unto him, which you may do well to burn, let he hould make ue of them hereafter to your diadvantage. Dorinde both eeing and knowing them, he did ingenuouly confee, that he did believe I loved her, and therefore thought her elfe obliged unto what he did; but, for the future, he would hate me a thouand times more then ever he loved me: She thought her elfe infinitely obliged unto Florice, for this dicovery, and commended her for the bet friend in the world. Then both of them began to inveigh againt me with all poible bitternee, epecially Dorinde who thought her elfe the mot offended. Florice having revenged her elfe upon me according to her deires, returned unto her lodging, fully reolved never to love me again, no, nor ever to ee me again if it were poible: But, when the heat of her anger was a little cooled, and when he began to recall into her memory the dicoure which Dorinde and he had, he remembered, that what affection oever I had unto Dorinde, yet I had never acquainted her with the affection I had unto Florice, nor of any favour I ever received from her; concluding from hence, that I loved her more then I did Dorinde, o as he began to repent of what he had don; for he did believe, that if I <> dicoured any thing concerning her, he hould certainly have heard of it upon this occaion. The more this came into her minde, the more he repented of her too much hate, or, aid he, what though he did viit her? I my elfe was the caue: If he did court her, I did command him o to do: If he did love her, it was, becaue he was amiable: If he did receive her favours, it was the better to cloak that affection which he bore unto me And the truth is, being young, very few of his age would have refued uch a fortune. If he did diemble with me and not hewe me how much he was favoured, it was, becaue he thought I hould be angry at it; and all men of reputation, will preerve the honour of thoe who do oblige them, but mot certainly he loved me more then her, ince he never poke of our affection. Thee thoughts made her condemne what he had done, and extreamly repent of the fault which he had committed, and earnetly deire a reconciliation.

On the contrary, Dorinde jutly incened againt me, and welling with anger, after a flood of tears, flowing upon her cheeks and breat, he went into her Cloet, and vented all the bitternee and animoity that her orrowes could inpire into her tongue: And as fortune was, jut as he was wiping the tears from her eyes, I came to her houe, and when he heard me walking, he ran and pulled to the dore, which he had left open when Florice went out, and which, her minde being upon other things, he had forgot to hut; yet, he could not do it o uddenly, but I aw how red her eyes were with crying; and when I wondred, both at her tears, and that he hould deny me entrance, he opened her Cloet, and tanding in the dore: Perfidious Traitor (aid he, and called me by my name) are you come with any deignes of injury unto me?

And becaue I anwered nothing, being o urpried that I could not peak: Perhaps, ungratefull wretch, aid he, you will deny your villany? Ah mot wicked peron! (aid he, and hewed me her Letters, here are all the tetimonies of my too eay beliefe; but know that there is not one of thy treaons which is not known unto me; and be certain, that thou hat made me forever thy mot mortall enemy. Then he puhed me out of the dore and hut it o uddenly, that I could not hinder her. Thus, fairet Mitris, eeing he would not open the dore, I went away the mot ahamed man in the world, but o incened againt Florice, that revenged I would be at what rate oever; for it was he, I knew, that took my Letters, & I aw it was he that gave them unto Dorinde, purpoely to dipleae me. I did imagine, that it was envie or jealouie, which made her commit this crime againt our amity; and conceiving, that nothing would more vex her, then to eem, as if I had quitted her for Dorinde, I reolved to break off entirely with her, and devote my elfe wholly unto the other. The greatet difficulty was, to appeae Dorinde; but I armed my elfe with a full reolution, to endure all manner of didain and anger, rather than not be revenged upon Florice.

Within a few daies after, I went in this deigne, unto Dorinde in her Cloet; for the dipleaure
which he had received, made her more retired then uuall; and offering to hut the dore upon me, I fell down upon my knees o uddenly, as he could not avoid me; then, after I had begged a thouand times for a pardon, I told her all the truth; to wit, how Florice having long loved me, and to keep our affections more ecret, he commanded me to faigne a courthip of her; which accordingly I did, both at the firt, and when I gave her all thoe Letters; but afterwards, comming to love her in good earnet, I then gave Florice no more. Oh! yar, aid he unto me did you not carry her the lat which I writ alo? 'Tis true, (aid he) that he hath them, but he tole them from me; and if you will not believe me, ask of thoe who helped her to play the thiefe. Then I named two, who had een her teal them, and told me of it; and therefore, when Florice ound her elfe punihed by her own invention, he acquainted you with all that could break off your affection from me. But is not Love jut, in making her uffer that harm which he prepared for you? Why hould he make your beauty the cloak for all her deignes? May the gods never be favourable unto me, if I do not hate uch things mot abominably, and if I do not love you above all the world, and into whoe favour I do deire mot to ingratiate my elfe. Let not her jealouie and lander of me, have a greater influence upon you, then my affection hath, and let not her anger, at my didaining her for you, prejudice me in your good opinion. I ued many uch expreions, which at the firt did not operate according to my deires and expectance; but o dipoed her, that when I made the theft of Florice manifet unto her, he would pardon me: And preently after, we renewed love upon t • icter obligations, then ever before, which took me off from Florice as much, as if I had never een her; and I did it without any contraint: for it is mot true, he was fairer then Dorinde, and of a higher rank and quality; yet, my anger againt her had o changed my eyes, as this Beauty did not at all pleae them, but made me leight her.

Florice for a while did endure all this, eeming not to care a jot what became of me, as if all my actions were very indifferent unto her but at length he repented, and extreamly grieved that he had o lot me; and being aured, that I did once love her alo thinking, that a reall affection could not o eaily extinguih, he conceived, that if he did eem, as if he loved ome other, doubtlee it would have o much influence upon me, as would make me return again unto her: And in order to this deigne, he could not think of any more fit to fool then Theombres, becaue he thought his dipoition was amorouly inclined, and becaue he had formerly loved her.
