Then he began to carrae Theombres with all imaginable expreions, and hew, as if all he aid or did, did pleae her epecially when I was within compae of taking any notice, and then he would talk to him, and whiper, as if he had made choice of him, for the only Cabinet of all her ecrets. I preently oberved this redintegration, and told Dorinde, who could not chue but laugh, when he heard how Theombres was embarqued. Florice eeing I did not return unto her according to her expectance, did the more multiply her favours upon him, inomuch as many did dilike her behaviour, and acquainted her Parents with it; for, he was o free and open in the dipenation of her favours, as in lieu of hiding them, as is uuall, he expoed them to the view of every one, nay, tudied how to make them een, otherwie I had not come to the knowledge of it for I never aw her but in publick, and when I was with her in any publick place, I hunned her. Now her Father, as I have told you, being advertied of this Love, did exceedingly reprehend her, and much more her Mother, who for honour and chatity was an eminent example to all the Country. At the firt, h • would have gloed the matter with an excue; but afterwards, eeing excues would not do it, he did confee it, and aid, that it was true, Theombres did court her, and that he could not chue but love him. But her Mother, who could not upon any termes approve of her behaviour, did tell her in a very angry manner, That Theombres did not give o many tetimonies of his love to her, as he of her love to him. To which Florice, in much diorder anwered, That Theombres did court her in the way of honour; and ince his End was only at Marriage, he could do no lee then allow of him. If it be o, aid her Father, let him acquaint us with his intentions, otherwie we hall think, you only invented this, thereby to excue your elfe. She, who had a very reverentiall repect and fear of her Father and Mother, and who beides, had ever lived in great reputation, did think it expedient, that Theombres hould make ome overtures of Marriage unto her Parents, yet not intending to go any further, then a meer motion; for he hoped, that it might be eaily broken off: Therefore he poke unto Theombres concerning it, who was joyed at it beyond all expreions; and not to loe a minute of time, he entreated two of his Uncles to make the motion unto
Florice's Father and Mother; which accordingly they did, with o many fair offers, as they were received as well as they could deire; for he was very rich, and an advantageous Match unto Florice, which being known and conidered by her Parents, they would not prolong time, but did conclude the Marriage that ame day, and the more willingly, becaue they believed it agreeable unto the liking of their Daughter. Thus is Florice's Marriage with Theombres made up, all things agreed upon, Writings ealed, and nothing wanting but a Priet to Marry them. But Oh! what a wonder was all this unto Florice, when he heard of it? Her Father thinking he would be very glad of it, would himelfe be the meenger of the newes: But, when he told her how all things went, though he would have faigned, yet he could not, but broke out into a deluge of tears, at which her Father was much amazed: How, Daughter, aid he unto her, this is very trange; does Florice cry at what he her elfe deired? I told you, Father (aid Florice all in tears) that Theombres courted me in way of Marriage, but I never told you, that I did deire it. Were not you the caue, aid the Father, which moved Theombres to make the motion? It was upon your command, replied he, and not upon my own deire; and I did believe, you would have given me ome time to conider upon it. Come, come, (aid he in an angry manner) you knew well enough how uch buinees ue to be carried. Reolve with your elfe, that ince they have gone thus far, they hall go on. What! would you be further courted, and give all the world an occaion to talk of you? Would you have further time, to make me more ahamed? No, no, Florice, content your elfe, I have bluh'd enough for you already, when your friends acquainted me with your behaviour, and I will prevent it for the future if I can. Upon this, he left her alone, and went to his Wife, who hearing what dicoure had paed, came to her with all the harp language which he could invent, and for a concluion told her, that nothing but death could hinder that Marriage from taking effect, and therefore he mut reolve upon it. Thus, poor Florice was in a wore condition than ever; for, he had not only lot me whom he loved, but was likely to be enjoyed by another, whom he loved not, but hated wore then a death. Imagine in what a wildernee of thoughts he was and what various combats was in her oul: In concluion, he reolved, that death hould be the remedy againt all her retlee afflictions; not that he had o much courage as to kill her elfe, (for the thought of uch a cruelty made her to tremble) but becaue he thought her life was not able to endure o many ad and tormenting mieries. But ee the trange conequents of Love; he did not o much grieve for the loe of me, and at her being anothers whom he loved not, as to think, that I hould put a bad contruction upon that affection which he expreed unto me: For, though he was angry at me, becaue of Dorinde; yet, he did love me, and excued me for loving her no more, accuing her elfe with the offence which he had committed againt me. Being thus perplexed, and ince he could not avoid her Marriage with Theombres, he reolved to give her elfe o much atisfaction at the leat, as to let me know, that her minde was not changed, and that her affection hould for ever be the ame as I had found it: Her Letter was thus written.

body.head: Florice's Letter unto Hylas.
body.p: WHen you look upon this hand, perhaps you will remember, that you have een it heretofore, when you loved her that writ it, and that now o much offended you. Conider how great my affection is unto you, ince after o great an injury, I take pen in hand, to let you know the condition he is in, whom once you o much loved, and who loves you till infinitely above all the world, maugre all the injuries you have done me. Know, that by the rigorous Lawes of Marriage, I am now going to be anothers, and that there is no other remedy, unlee you will this very houre prevent it: Auring my elfe, that my Parents woudl be better pleaed with your Alliance, then that of Theombres, unto whom, alas, I am detined, unlee you do love me as well as I love you.

div.p:
When this Letter was brought unto me, I was orry at thoe frequent reports of this Marriage; and though I was reolved to be wholly Dorinde's, yet I could not chue but reent the loe of Florice; for I eteemed her lot, in the alliance of Theombres. And ee the ubtlety of Love: He knew well enough, that to aault me openly was in vain, becaue I was till in mine anger, and therefore he would go another way with me. Firt, he propounded unto me my hatred of Theombres, how undeerving he was of this advantage,
and how happy he would be in Florice. Then he repreented unto me, the beauty and merits of Florice, what pitty it was that uch a man hould enjoy her; and brought into my memory all thoe favours which I had received from her: To be briefe, he did o imprint thee coniderations in my oul, that ere I was aware, I was more in love with her, then with Dorinde; o as when her Letter came unto my hands, and conidering with a ound judgment, the beauty, the quality, and the merits of the Writer, I did acknowledge that I had done her wrong, in quitting her for another much inferiour; and repenting of it, I intended to return to her again. Truth is, when I conidered the remedy which he propounded, to break off her Marriage with Theombres, I knew not what to reolve upon; for I hated that fatall Tie of Marriage more then I can expree; not with Florice in particular, but with any woman in generall; conceiving that there was no greater tyranny nor lavery amongt the ons of men, then that of Marriage. Thus was I in a Labyrinth of ravelled reolutions; for on the one ide, Dorinde was not dipleaing unto me; on the other ide, I could not endure, that Theombres hould enjoy Florice, epecially in the way of Marriage: But, after a long contet with my elfe, I reolved to renew that love which was betwixt us, and to do all that poibly I could to prevent Theombres. And in order to this reolution, I eemed, as if I had not received the Letter which he had writ unto me, which I might eaily do, becaue he who brought it, left it for me at my lodging, I not being then within: So taking pen, inke, and paper, I writ thus unto Florice.

body.head: Hylas his Letter unto Florice.
body.p: ARe you mad to marry Theombres? Have you o oon forgot Hylas and his affection, that you hould prefer this man before him? Can you content him, and make me grieve for you? Oh ye gods! will ye permit it? or if ye do permit it, will you no! punih the ungratefull Florice?

div.p: The reaon why I eemed, as if I had not received her Letter, was, becaue he hould not think it was her invitation, but my own affection, which made me return unto her; for, had I come upon her ummons, he would have thought my love lee, which I would not have her think. When he received my Letter, he was extreamly joyed, to finde that I loved her, and was orry, when he aw I had not received hers, therefore he writ unto me again, to let me know, that he had advertied me of a coure which I hould take, to free her from that miery which was prepared for her. And becaue he feared her Letter was lot, he repeated it again in this. But I, without returning any anwer unto it, eemed as if I was gone out of the Town, as not being able to endure the ight of her Marriage with Theombres; and to the end he might believe it, I gave order, that almot at the very ame time, another Letter from me hould be carried unto her. It was thus indited.

body.head: Hylas his Letter unto Florice.
body.p: SInce it is impoible, but Florice mut needs follow the coure of her fatall detiny, I mut needs alo depart the Town, not being able to endure a ight o deplorable unto my elfe: I had rather take the unhappy ucces by my ears, then by my eyes, which I do reerve to wim in tears at uch ad newes. The gods give you as much content, as you have left me little, and may it continue as long, as my marting miery will lat, which will be to my grave, where I will lament your incontancy, and my own ad fate.

div.p:
Now, fair Phillis, I writ this Letter unto her, to the end he hould think, I had not received hers; for otherwie, I had been obliged unto an anwer, unlee I had utterly declined her, and rather conented unto a death then to marry her; not, but that I did infinitely eteem her, but thee bonds of Marriage were mot horrid unto me, and I had o good an opinion of my elfe, as I thought it certain he would not be denyed me, if I asked her of her Parents: And leat he hould be troubled about her Letter which he had written unto me, I caued it to be carried back unto her by one of my ervants, who was intructed to let her know, that I was gone out of the Town two or three daies before; and ince he knew not whither I was gone, nor when I would return, he brought it back unto her, let it hould be lot. She did not know that it had been opened, for it was ealed with
the ame eal, both he & I having long ince each of us a Seal as like one another as poibly could be made. Shee took the Letter with a ad igh, and afterwards enquired, why I went away, and what urgent occaion had contrained me to be gone o oon? He anwered her according to my intructions, That he knew nothing; only, he never aw me o ad in all his life as I was at my departure. Ah me! (aid he then, with a mot profound igh) I am afraid he will return too late for my contentment. Then, to hide the tears which trickled from her eyes, he turned the other way. When this man returned, he told me all that he aid and did; and I mut needs confee, I pittyed her, but I could not for my life reolve to marry her: Therefore I kept my elfe cloe untill the Marriage were pat, and ent the man every houre to hearken newes: At the lat, I heard that all was concluded. I hould be too tedious, fairet Mitris, if I hould relate all the artifices which he ued; but let me only tell you, that the night before the Marriage, he writ thee words unto me.

body.head: Florice's Letter unto Hylas
body.p: Could I end you my life in this paper, as well as the truth of my intention, I hould not complain at heavens injutice in detinating me to fail, both in my love and in my duty. Tomorrow is the lat day of my life, if I may call that a death which takes away all my contentment. If Hylas do love me, mierable as I am, and will accompany my orrowes with his, let him reort to my grave.

div.p: Judge, whether this Letter did not touch me to the quick, ince I did really love her: but, eeing no remedy but to marry her, I mut confee, my affection was not of force enough, to bring my will unto it.

The next morning he was contrained to igne the Contract, and to agree unto all that her Father and Mother would have her; but, with uch incredible griefe and trembling, that her legs were not able to bear her, nor her hand to guide the pen, wherewith he ubcribed her name. Oh ye gods! aid he unto one of her Companions what a mot cruell Law is this, that ordaines the innocent to igne their own death? But when he went to the Temple, and through the treet where my lodging was lifting up her eyes to the windowes, he aid thus unto her elfe: Why, Oh happy lodgings, are not the gods as favourable unto me as you? And, as fortune was, I being at the window, which I held halfe open, to ee her pae by, he epied me: But, Oh ye gods, how this viion went to her heart? he fell into a woond, and lay in the armes of thoe that went with her: And let I hould do the like, I was contrained to lie down upon my bed, and tirred not from it mot part of that day At the lat, he was married with o many tears, as every one pittyed her. And becaue I feared, let he having een me, he hould think; I did but only give out that I was gone away, I procured an intimate friend that ame night to let her undertand, that I was departed, only becaue I would not ee this unhappy Marriage, and that my intention was, never to return again; but, ince my affection would not give me leave to be o far ditant, I was contrained to return, but arrived in the mot unfortunate minute that could be; and that it was abolutely impoible I hould live, unlee he gave me ome aurance, that her affection was not changed. She, as if he never heard him, took a Ring off from her finger, and put it into his hand: This Diamond, aid he may aure him, that it hath lee contancy, then the affection which I promied unto him.

Now hear, I beeech you, what hapned: That very ame night, and, I believe, about the very ame houre, when Theombres had her in his armes, I was in my bed, and held my hand upon my breat, having the Ring upon my finger. I know not how, but it cut me, and made o deep a wound, that my hirt and heets were all bloody, and ever ince, hath left a mark upon my ide, neer my heart. Oh heavens! (cryed I out upon a uddain, thinking upon the wrong which I had done Florice, and Theombres had done me) how enible am I of the offence and injury that is done unto my affection. Perhaps I have inited too long upon thee particulars; but I beeech you excue Hylas, ince he was never o touched to the heart by any other, except by you, my fairet Phillis. Or except any in this Company, aid he. But, pray tell us how you left Dorinde? Unto which Hylas replyed thus: When I was in the depth of my perplexities (for indeed I did love Florice, as well becaue he was fair, as becaue I thought Dorinde loved another) the heavens helped me out with as good an occaion as I could deire. Periander, who, as I told you, was contrained to quit Dorinde unto me, and, not being able to ee me enjoy her, was gone out of the Town,
was at length forced to return, as not being able to endure o long out of her ight; and though he did foreee, his orrowes would be greater in eeing, then in hearing, of our affection; yet could he not chue but return, thinking it would be ome conolation unto his wound, to ee the hand that gave it. And becaue he came at the firt to ee me, aoon as he came, I reolved to give, as they ay, two blowes with one tone, to rid my elfe of Dorinde, and to oblige Periander. Two or three daies paed on, and he never talked one word unto me concerning Dorinde; and one time, being eparated from the Company, I aid thus unto him: Periander, it is impoible for my affection unto you, to uffer my elfe to be a caue of that melancholly which I have oberved in your face, any longer; I love you too well, than to ee you uffer for my ake: You do not doubt of my affection unto Dorinde, but you hall lee doubt of the affection I have unto you; And to give you evident tetimony that it is not a little, I releae this Dorinde unto you, whom my good fortune took from you; and the affection I bear unto you, hall urmount the love I bear unto her: Receive her, therefore, Periander, from me, and be aured, that I hall lee grieve to part with her, then to ee you thus ad for my ake, or be deprived of your preence. If ever any condemned peron was joyed when a Pardon came, Periander was as much, when he heard this; and yet his dicretion and affection unto me, made him at the firt refue it; but when he aw I perited in this minde, he received it with o many thanks, as I was contrained to tell him, that he was jutly his due, knowing very well, that he did urmount me in love, as my good fortune and cunning urpaed his

Then I retired by little and little from Dorinde, and Periander on the contrary advanced. But, in the mean time, I attempted upon Florice, I found out the means to peak unto her, and aured her of my affection. To be briefe, I contrived it o, as there was never better correpondency betwixt us; and that which mot helped me, was, the hollow-hearted affection which he bore unto Theombres: 'Tis true, he had alwaies ome upition of Dorinde, and therefore after he thought that he had made me hers, he told me peremptorily, that he would have me o clearly and openly break off with Dorinde, as he hould never be in any doubt of it afterwards; otherwie, he hould live in a continuall incertainty of my affection, and that he had rather part fair with me, then live in uch continuall apprehenions. I deired, that my breach with Dorinde might be done by ome civill way, and leat offenive unto her. But he would needs have it done by ome rude and publick affront, and he would not be perwaded otherwie At the lat, I reolved upon it.

Upon the ixt of July, all the Gallantry of the Town went with the Druides to gather the acred Miletoe, in the Forret of Mars, called Erieu; and then Florice charged me to atisfie her requet. All the Ladies were trimmed in their gayet drees, and every one in the Athenian habit. The acrifice being ended, and publick rejoycings beginning, I took Periander apart, to the end he hould not be offended at what I did; I told him how I aw Dorinde had ome hopes yet in me, and therefore he did not receive his ervice; o well as he ought; but I would undeceive her, and dah all her hopes. Then eeing her with Florice, and in the midt of the bet company, I went to her, and after ome common dicoure, I aid unto her o loud, as all about her might hear Now I ee Dorinde, that what is told me of you, is true. What's that, (aid he, and miled, little expecting uch an anwer as I gave)? That you have (replyed I) the bet opinion of your elfe, of any peron in the world. Then he bluh'd, and asked me the reaon of my judgment. Becaue, aid I, you meauring others by your elfe; as you do love all you look upon, o you think every one is in love with you; and I know you are in that errour concerning me thinking that I am ready to die for the love of you: but, I would have you know, that your merits are too mean to make me uch a fool; if you think otherwie, undeceive your elfe, and be aured, that Hylas is ahamed he ever loved you; or if he was uch a fool, that he is wier now. Imagine, noble Paris, how blank Dorinde was: For my part, I would not exchange a yllable more with her, but went away, and left her mot pittifully out of countenance. Ever ince, Florice was the mot atisfied that is imaginable, and wholly devoted her elfe unto me And as Theombres tood for a Husband, o I enjoyed her as a Friend. But Dorinde, extreamly incened againt me, reolved to do me all the michiefe that poibly he could, and dicovering the intimate familiarity betwixt Florice and me, he deigned to thwart it: And becaue I did not ee her, though I was orry for it, for I did love her, though leethen I did Florice, he thought Periander would be a fit intrument to work her ends by; therefore he began to hew him more countenance then accutomed, and, by degrees, eemed to love him better; at which Periander was o joyed, that he almot never tirred from her:
Having lived a while thus with him, he acquainted him with the deceit I had ued, in putting my Picture in the Mirror, and that he hould not doubt it, he ent for the woman who brought it to ell. To be brief, he told him o much in my diadvantage, as he cooled his affection unto me; and all this out of a deigne, to get by his means, ome of Florice's Letters from me; & therfore continuing her dicoure: He is (aid he unto him) wholly devoted unto Florice, but it is only, untill ome other pae before his eyes; for he is the veryet knave, and arrantet weathercock that ever was. But (aid he unto him, and held his hand in hers) will you do me one very great pleaure? And he anwering, that he would do any thing to erve her. She made him wear, he would be as good as his word. Then went he on: You know, that Florice and I are friends and allies, I cannot believe that he does love him: I beeech you tel me all you know. Undeceive your elf in that, aid he unto her, aure your elf he does love him, and there is hardly a day, but he hath a Letter from her. Oh my god, aid he, can you not help me to the ight of one of her Letters? Very eaily, anwered he, for he is very carelee of them. In this, Periander aid right; for the truth is, I know not what I did with all thoe he writ unto me, nor was I angry with my elfe for my carelenee. Well, aid Dorinde, now I hall ee, whether or no you be a man of your word, and whether you love me; for if you do, and this be o, you will preently bring me one of them. Periander, without any regard unto our friendhip, whether it was by vertue of Dorinde's command or out of revenge upon me, for putting that trick upon him, but he came that very night to lie with me, as he often ued, and tole away one which I received in his preence, and the next morning, as oon as he could get into Dorinde's Chamber, he brought it unto her: It contained thee words.

body.head: Florice's Letter unto Hylas.
body.p: THe man who is in the world only for our torment, goes tomorrow out of the Town: If you come, all the night hall be ours, and the ret of the time I pend in abence of him I love, I cannot call mine.

div.p:
You know, generous Paris, that upon uch Letters, they never any ue to write Supercriptions, let the Writer hould be dicovered by the Direction; and therefore Dorinde, after a thouand thanks to Periander, went into her Cloet, and upercribed it, Unto Theombres, afterwards ealed it up very handomely with a Seal, and giving it unto a creature of her own, intructed him what he hould do, and commanded him to carry it unto Theombres in all hate, becaue he undertood, that he was to go out of Town the ame day: The fellow did as he was directed, and o nimbly, that whilt Theombres was reading the Letter, he lipt away, and came to Dorinde, and told her what he had done. I refer it unto your imagination, fairet Mitree, whether the Husband was not amazed, when he aw his Wife's Letter, and much more, when he read it: It wrought this influence upon him, that whereas before he hould have gone out of the Town ingle, now he mut go double, and carry his wife with him; but not before he had hewed the Letter unto her, and had hreudly reprehended her for it. She excued her elfe as well as he could, telling him, it was long ince this Letter was writ, and that it was Dorinde who had now written the upercription of it. To which Theombres anwered, that whenoever he writ it he was to blame, and could not be excued. She replyed, that Dorinde and he being intimate friends, did often ue to write uch unto each other, and invite themelves thereby to come and viit one another; and that Dorinde being angry with her, and knowing that he was to go out of Town, had, in revenge upon her, ent him this Letter, which truly, aid he, you may well believe to be o, ince the upercription is written with Dorinde's own hand; and that if he would, he could hew everall others of the like nature, as I might of hers had I been as carefull in keeping them as he is. Theombres was omething atisfied with this excue, yet not o, but he contrained her to go with him out of Town, and would not let her have more leaure, then to write one word unto Hylas, and left it in the hands of her Maid, in whom he had good aurance of her fidelity. For my part, I thought he had tayed at home, and that Theombres had gone by himelfe therefore I went at night to the uuall place of meeting. But this Maid opening the dore, he gave me Florice's Letter, and hut the dore again immediately againt me. and would not peak one yllable unto me: This made me fear ome dyaterous accident had hapned, and therefore returned to my lodging, where as oon as ever I got a
light, I read this Letter with extream impatiency, and found in it thee words.

body.head: Florice's Letter unto Hylas.
body.p: SHe who writes now unto you, is the mot mortall enemy you have, intimating unto you, that neither Dorinde nor your elfe, have villany enough to make me die, but that the heavens will let me live, to be revenged upon you both. In the mean time, for get my name, as you have done all my favours:

div.p: Oh heavens! how this Letter went to my heart, I was in uch a trange confuion of thoughts that I could not imagine why Florice hould write thus, I pent all that night in walking up and down my Chamber, and as oon as it was day, I ent a ervant to finde out a way, how I might peak with her who gave me the Letter; but it could not be, all that day: When night came, I undertood all from her, how Florice had an opinion, that I had given this Letter unto Dorinde, which made her believe, that I did only diemble, when I eemed to cat off Dorinde, and did it only to delude her. I put my hand preently into my pocket, and not finding my Letter, I did uppoe, that Periander had tollen it from me: After a thouand protetations of my innocency unto this Maid, I went away with reolutions of revenge: But when I met my friend, and with a frowning brow taxed him with his theft, he anwered me, with a mile; If I have dipleaed you, aid he, I am orry; but you may well forget it, if you do but conider, that now we are upon eeven termes, for your tealing of Dorinde from me by your artifice of the Mirror. But friend, aid I unto him, I have retored your Mitree unto you, and you have caued me to loe mine. I know not anwered he, how to give you atisfaction in that, unlee by retoring her unto you, in acquainting her with my theft. Truth is, I did love Periander, and perhaps as much as I did any of thee Ladies; therefore I received his excue, conceiving it to be the only means to reingratiate my elfe into Florice's favour: And therefore turning all into rallarie, we waited for Florice's return. But, Theombres being but halfe atisfied with his Wife's excues, he reolved to tay a while in the Country, the better to dicover who made any addrees unto her, and to finde out her humour; and he tayed o long, that I was in the interim pat my patience; therefore I went to ee Criide, and eeing her, loved her; and the truth is, he did deerve it, for I never in all my life, aw a more lovely and attractive tranger.

Atrea had taken much delight in the dicoure of Hylas, had it been at any other eaon but being extreamly deirous to be at the place where Silvande: found Celadon's Letter, he was impatient at any thing which gave a top unto it: And this was the reaon, why upon the firt occaion which preented it elfe, he made a igne unto Phillis, that it was time to be gone, and that he was weary of o long a tay. When he aw that Phillis did not undertand her meaning, and likewie aw Hylas offering to continue his dicoure of Criide, he prevented him with thee words: I did not think, that the beauty of Phillis could have had o much power over o free a pirit, as to hold him in one dicoure above an houre; but, ince her rigour does not conider his contraint, let us hew our elves more kinde and dicreet, in interrupting him; for, the heat of the day being over, walking will be more delightfull then talking. Upon this, he roe up, and the ret of the Company followed her.

Hylas taking Phillis under the arme: I am very glad, fairet Mitree (aid he) that he, who is the mot inenible, does reent ome of that pain which you put upon me, and does ee the love I have unto you. He meant this by Atrea, whom he thought to be a peron that never had loved any: And ee how commonly our judgments are deceived by appearances and hewes; for, Phillis deiring to leave him in that opinion. Thoe, aid he, who do love well, do never ue to give tetimony of their affection by the report of perons, who do not know how to love, but by their own obequious ervices. And as for that patience which you have been put to, in peaking o long, I believe you are as ufficiently payed for it, by my hearing you o long. This, aid Hylas, is the intolerable arrogance and ingratitude of all the Shepheardees in this Country. And becaue Phillis would follow the ret of her Companions, he lead her by the arme, and continued thus: Becaue you will not be obliged unto me, you will not only deny me the merit of my patience but you think I am beholding unto you for hearing me: By what Law, I beeech you, is this? The ame, aid he, that a Lord doth impoe upon his Slave. Nay, rather, aid he, a Tyrant
upon his People. Why, replyed Phillis, do you take me for a Tyrant? Surely there is this difference betwixt us that I do not ue any force or violence againt you. Can you ay o, aid Hylas, and not bluh? Do you think it is not by force, that Hylas hath continued o long under your power? I pray, aid he, where are my Fetters, my Manacles, my Compulions, and my Prions? Ah! mot ignorant, and too much diembling hepheardee, aid Hylas, your Chains are o trangely indiolvable, that I would not be delivered from them, for all the freedome and liberty in the world. Judge, if your Manacles be not very trong, ince Hylas cannot break them; Hylas, I ay, whom a thouand Beauties could never hold, nor keep him from breaking looe from them all. In the mean time, Paris having taken Diana by her hand, Silvander, out of his dicretion kept a ditance; for he would force his affection, and in his repect unto his Shepheardee, give place unto Paris, as all the hepheardees were very ready to pay all due repects unto him, who for their akes; had quitted the grandure and eminency of his quality. As fortune was Mandonte was alone, and becaue I herander was taken up with Laonice, Silvander took her hand, and reolved to wait upon her during all the voyage; and though he made this addree unto her at the firt, becaue he knew not where to finde a better; yet afterwards, he was well pleaed with his choice, for this hepheardee was both fair and dicreet, and had ome features in her face and actions, which did much reemble Diana; not that he was o fair as he, nor o like being together; but if aunder, they had much one of the other, in their reemblance.

p.hi: Silvander,
p.U:
ince he could not be with Diana, was very glad his lot fell upon one that had any thing like her; but much more, when by dicoure with her, he found a neerer reemblance in her Tone; and therefore, ever ince this day, he was much pleaed with her company; yet a little after, he payed very dear for his delight. Tireis waited upon Atrea, Paris upon Diana, and Hylas upon Phillis, o as Therander eeing his place was taken up by Silvander, he was forced to fall upon Laonice. She, who kept her eyes continually upon Phillis and Silvander, did oberve how that hepheard was much pleaed with Mandonte, and that he might know more, he deired Therander to go neerer them, which his jealous apprehenions prompted him very eaily to do; yet, they could not hear any thing, but common dicoure. They had not walked above a quarter of an houre in a long Meadow, but Silvander hewed them the Wood, unto which he would conduct them. Preently after, they entred into a thick Cops; and becaue the Path was very narrow they were contrained to go in file. At lat, Silvander, who, as their conductor, walked firt, he much wondred, to ee ome boughes of trees heaped one upon another, in the fahion of an Arbour, which obtructed his pae. All the Company going through this Arbour, came up to him, to know why he tayed, and eeing no path: How now Silvander, (aid Phillis) do you that undertook to be our Guide, conduct us thus? I mut confee, aid he, that I have lot the way which I went the lat morning; but, I believe this to be a neerer and better. The way, aid Hylas, is very good, if you had conducted us to Hunt, for I ee nothing but Wood. Silvander was vexed that he lot his way, but he was more amazed then before, when heaw another more pacious Arbour in the form of a Temple: at the entry, there was ome Veres written, which Silvander tayed to read. All the Company being weary they called upon him everall times. He, in a great amazement, turned towards Diana: Mitree, aid he, do not repent your elfe of the pains you have taken, in comming hither; for, though you are a little digreed of the way, yet, you hal ee here a wonder of the Wood: Then taking her hand, he conducted her to the entry: the ret of the Shepheards and Shepheardees followed in ile, and longed to ee this rarity of which Silvander poke. Before the entrance was a Court of green grae, about thirty paces quare, environed with thick wood on three ides, o as none could ee them. A chrytall Fountain, which took its originall oppoite to the Porch, or rather, Arbour, of this Temple, did, Meander like, run by the one ide, which rendred the place mot delectable. This Grove was ever a place, that had been dedicated as acred unto the great Heeus, Tentates, and Taramis: And there was no hepheard that ever durt preume to drive his Flock neer this Thicket; and the reaon why it was never frequented, was, let they hould diturb the olitude and acred ilence of the Nymphs, Pans, and Egipans. The grae was never ullied, the wood never felt the axe, nor was broued by any cattle, and the Fountain was never defiled by any foot: o as this little Grove, dreed into the fahion of an Arbour, or rather a Temple, did plainly demontrate, that it was dedicated unto ome deitie: And therefore all thee Shepheards approaching the entrance with reverence, before they paed any further, they
did read the Veres which were written upon a Table of wood over the Porch: They were thee.

l.hi: Unles with acred Love you be enflam'd,
Unto this acred place, be all aham'd
To enter: Here's the Grove, where, every day,
A Heart, that is all Love and Zeal, doth pay
Religious duty; here he doth implore,

q.l: And here divine Atrea doth adore.

div.p: The Shepheards and Shepheardees tood amazed at this Incription, and looked upon one another, as if they were deirous to know, whether any of the Company did either know, or had een this before. Diana addresed her elfe unto Silvander; Is this the place, Shepheard, (aid he) unto which you did intend to bring us? No, anwered he, I never aw this place in my life before.

It is evident, aid Paris, that thee boughes have been lately lopped and put into this order, for the leaves of them are yet green. However, aid he, we mut go in But, let we hould offend the deitie, unto whom the place is conecrated let us enter in with all poible reverence; and firt, let us make our elves as clean as we can.

Every one conented, except Hylas, who anwered, That for his part, he had nothing to do there: For aid he, ince all thoe are forbidden to enter, that are not enflamed with an holy Love, I know not whether or no I ought to enter: I know that I am enflamed with Love, but, whether it be holy or no, faith I am not ure. How, Servant, (aid Phillis, and miled) a defect in your Love! What do you in our company? For my part, anwered he, I have abundance of affection after my own fahion; but, what know I, whether it be uch affection as thee Veres means? And I have heard ay, that it is not good jeating with the gods. See, Hylas, aid Silvander, what a hame your impure affection doth bring upon you in this good Company. You ay very true indeed, aid Hylas, but did you take this act as you ought to do, you would rather commend me for it for, in being obedient unto the commands of the divinities which are adored in this place, I do make it appear, by my great reverence of them, that I do reverence them as I ought to do; whereas you, who depie their commands, do prophane the acred place by your preumptuous boldnee: for, your own oul, if it would not diemble, can tell you, that your affections are not o acred as is required. I hall anwer you preently, aid Silvander. Then he and all the company wahed their hands, put off their hoes, and with bare feet entred into the Arbour. Then Silvander turning towards Hylas: Hearken, Hylas, aid he, and be a witnee of my words. Afterwards reading the Veres again, and lifting his eyes up to heaven, and kneeling: Oh great deity (aid he) who is adored in this place, I here enter into the acred Grove, being mot aured, that I do not contradict thy will, knowing my love to be o holy, and o pure, that thou wilt be pleaed to accept the vowes and upplications of a oul o amorouly anctified as mine; and it this profeion which I here make, be not true, punih, O great deitie, this my perjury and preumption.

After this, with hands lifted up, and head bare, he entred into the Arbour, and all the ret after him, except Hylas. The place was pacious, ome ixteen or eventeen paces round, and in the midt, a great branch-oreading Oake; at the root of this Tree was erected a gray Table, in the form of an Altar upon which tood a Picture, & in it two Cupids drawn, who did trive with one another for a branch of Mirtle and Palm wreathed together. As oon as this devout company was entred, every one fell upon their knees and after they had in private adored the deity of the place Paris approaching the Altar, and taking upon him the office of a Druide, having gathered ome Oake leaves: Accept (aid he) O great deitie, that is adored in this place, the humble devotion of all this zealous Company. I do with all humility and devotion, offer unto thee in their names, a few leaves of this bleed Tree, under whoe hade it pleaeth thee to be ador'd. Then every one aroe, and went unto the Altar, to look upon the Picture which was upon it; in which they aw two Cupids, as I told you, who holding in both their hands a branch of Mirtle and Palm wreathed together, the one did trive to take it from the other. The Limner was exquiite in his Art; for thee little lovely Boyes were plump and fat, yet, their Mucles and Nerves might be een which by reaon of their triving eemed to be raied up; both their right thighes were advanced, and their feet almot touched each other; both their armes
were tretched out, and their bodies leaned backwar I, as if they knew, that the further off a weight is, the heavier it is; and the weight of their little bodies, lent more trength unto their triving armes. Their faces were both fair, but bluhing, by reaon of the blood which came into them by triving, which the great veins upon their temples and foreheads did ufficiently tetifie. And the Artit had been o carefull, and wrought it with uch indutry, that though he did repreent an action, which made it appear, that both of them would vanquih; yet, one might perceive by their countenances, that there was no enmity betwixt them, having, for all their Combat, mixed a kinde of weetnee and miling in their eyes, and about both their mouths. Their Torches which were on each ide of them, which they had let fall, by chance, fell one againt another, o as they united together, and made but one, by this means added lutre to each other, and gave the greater light with this Motto, Our Wills are but one. Their Bowes were o linked and twited one with the other, that they could not draw them but both together; their Quivers, which were hung upon their houlders, were full of Arrowes; but by the colour of their feathers one might know, that thoe which the one had, belonged unto the other, becaue in the gilded Quiver, were ilver feathered Arrowes, and in the ilvered Quiver, gilded Arrowes. The Company had looked long, and not undertood this piece, i the hepheard Silvande, at the requet of Paris, had not interpreted the ignification Thee two Cupids (aid he) do ignifie the Lover and the Loved; this Palm and Mirtle-wreath doth expree the victory of Love, for the Palme is an emblem of Victory, and the Mir • e of Love. The Lover and the Loved do trive, which hall be victorious; that is, which hall be mot loving. Thoe Torches, whoe flames are joyned together, and by this union, more plendent, doth h • w, that reciprocall Love doth augment affection. The Bowes intertwited and linked o together, that one cannot draw them without the other, do teach us, that all things are o in commun betwixt friends, as the puiance of the one is that of the other, o as neither can do any thing, unlee his Companion contribute his, which the changing of the Arrowes doth more illutrate. One may alo ee by this conjunction of Bowes, and Flames, and change of Arrowes, and union of two Wills into one, that the Lover and the Loved are but one: So as I perceive, this Picture repreents unto us that the endeavours of two Loves to get the victory one over the other, their contet is not, who hould be bet Loved, but who hould bet Love, giving us to undertand, that the perfection of Love conits, in triving how to Love, and not how to be Loved. Now if this be o, fairet Mitree, aid he and turned towards Diana, you may ee, how much you are in my debt. I mut ingenuouly confes, (aid he) that after this rate I had rather be in your debt, than have you in mine. Hylas, who tood at the entrance, and durt go no further, though he had a great deire unto it, and the more, when peeping in, he aw the gray Altar, and Picture upon it: And becaue he could not well ee, he employed his ear with all attention, to hearken unto Silvander's dicoure, and heard what he aid unto Diana. I perceive, fairet Mitres, aid Silvander, that neither you nor I are repreented in this piece, ince they in it are both Lovers and Loved; you are loved, but do not love; and I do love but am not loved, and all this more by ill fortune, then by reaon.

There is no difference betwixt us, aid Diana, but in words; for I call that reaon, which you do call ill fortune, and yet it is the ame thing. If all the difference (aid he) were only in words I would not care; but the wort is, that which you call reaon and I ill fortune, fills me full of all mieries, and its contrary would make me the mot happy hepheard in the whole Univere Afterwards he turned towards the Picture and as Diana would have anwered: I beeech you, my Fairet (aid he) do not talk any more of your mall affection to me, but let me ee what is yet more rare in this Picture. Then taking her by the hand, he read thee words, thus written in the bottom.

lg.head: The twelve Statutes, containing the Lawes of Love, which, upon pain of his high dipleaure he commands all Lovers to oberve.
The firt Statute.
lg.l: HE that's a perfect Lover, and a jut,
And as he ought; love infinitely mut.
Extreames in Love allowed are, as bet,
Mediums will never make a Lover blet,
But odious are: All Mediocrity,
Signe is of Treaon, not fidelity.

lg.head: The econd Statute.
lg.l: Let him th' puiant god of Love adore,
And let him love ome One, and not one more:
Above one Object, never let his eye
Once look upon, or wantonly epie.
It is decrced by Loves Emperiall Law,
That he his Blie from this one Fountain draw.

lg.head: The third Statute.
lg.l: Unto this fair One and her ervice, he
Mut dedicate himelfe and liberty;
He mut his heart and all delights reigne
To her, and only her, himelfe conine.
The rate he ets upon himelfe, mut be,
According as he loves him, o mut he:

lg.head: The fourth Statute.
lg.l: If he advancement to himelfe does eek,
Let his ambitious aime be at the cheek,
Which gave his love a life; let him confee,
She is the center of his happinee,
Which he does only aim at, and apire
To et the lutre of her glory higher.

lg.head: The fifth Statute.
lg.l: Let his affection to his Mitris, be
So dear, o chate, o full of purity,
As he fruition of her hall depie,
Before a tain upon her honour rie.
If hers and his come in comparion,
Let him prefer hers far before his own.

lg.head: The Sixt Statute.
lg.l: If any offer to apere the fame,
Or cat a blemih on his Mitris name,
Let him unheath his anger, give the lye
To him that offers uch a calumny.
If any dure to put affronts upon her,
Let him then die, or vindicate her honour.

lg.head: The eventh Statute.
lg.l: Then let his love arrive at uch a height;
As he eteems her 'bove all mortall weight.
The Sun, the Stars, and glories of the skies,
He value mut inferiour to her eyes.
Perfection in the abtract he mut deem her,
And think him guilty, that does les eteem her.

lg.head: The eighth Statute.
lg.l: He mut inflamed be with fits of Love,
So violently hot, as they mut move
His pule to beat a mad-mans temper: He
Mut igh, mut languih, and halfe dead mut be,
And ever in uch violencies well,
As, ask him what he ailes, he cannot tell.

lg.head: The ninth Statute.
lg.l: He mut forake his habitation,
His oul mut ever live by love alone.
He mut no being have, but on the core
Of her, whom he does worhip and adore.
So into her transformed he mut be,
As that without her eyes he cannot ee.

lg.head: The tenth Statute.
lg.l: Thoe daies that in her preence are not pat,
He mut eteem as abolutely lot:
Court all occaions, Let him pare no pain,
To bring him back into his heaven again:
And whilt his body does a ditance finde,
Let him be preent with her in his minde.

lg.head: The eleventh Statute.
lg.l: For her, he mut depart even from his reaon,
Bid welcome unto Manacles and Prion:
In harpet torments, think himelfe at eae,
So he thereby his fairet Saint hall pleae.
And all without expectance of rewards:
To love her is the honour he regards.

lg.head: The twelfth Statute.
lg.l: He mut not think it poible his Love,
Should ooner then the firmet Rock remove.
If any, uch advice to him hall ue,
Let him as Heterodox the ame refue.
Who o hall ever uch an errour move,
He is a very Schimatick in Love.

div.p:
Hylas hearing what Silvander read: I do not think, Silvander, aid he, that one word of all this is written in that Picture which you have in your hand, but you, having long ince compoed them after the rate of your melancholly genius, do now, to give them the more authority, and the more eaily to delude the Company, do put them upon the core of that Picture. That might have been, aid Silvander, if there was none here but my elfe that could read; or if thee Lawes were contrary unto Reaon, or the antient Statutes of Love. If it were not as I ay, aid Hylas, you would bring me the Picture hither, that I might ee it. If you do think, aid Silvander, that this acred place would have been profaned by your body, I have greater reaon to think, that thee holy Lawes would be polluted, if, by your reading, your oul hould have any communication with them. This moved all the Company to laugh; and this uncontant Lover would have replyed, yet could he not be heard: For, Silvander having et the Picture upon the Alar, and done reverence unto it, every one followed Paris, who opening a little dore made of
Oyers, he paed out of this Arbour into another more large: over the dore was written on a table of wood, thee Veres.

l.hi: If through Loves Temple you dare boldly venter,

q.l: The acred Temple of Atrea enter,

l.hi: Where Love, by his commanding Law, decrees,
I hould adore her ever on my knees.
As unto her I dedicate my daies;
So likewie nights, my orrowes to her payes.

div.p: Atrea was he, who was mot concerned at this; whether it was, becaue of the name, in which he thought her elfe mot intereed; or whether becaue he heard peak of the dedication of dayes and orrowes; o it was, he did apprehend, that by it was meant the fortune of the poor and unfortunate Celadon. She looked, and long pondered upon this incription, and in the mean time, the ret of the company going a little farther, and finding a Vault like to the firt, but much bigger, they all fel down upon their knees, and having paid their particular devotions in ilence unto the deity, to whom that place was conecrated, Paris, as he did before, o now, offered for all the Company, an Oaken bough upon the Altar. It was of grae, like unto the other, but made triangular; and in the midt tood a goodly Oake, whoe top urveyed all the Trees of this acred Grove. It eemed by this Tree, that Nature was wanton in her production of it, having from one tock ent forth three everall branches, three everall wayes, yet mot admirably united at the top, without the help of any Artifice; on one branch was written upon the bark Heius, upon another, Belinus, and on the other Tharamis; upon the tock which ent forth thee three branches, Tautates, and at the top where they reunited, Tautates again.

Thee things, which were according to the cutomes of their Religion, did not much atonih them, for they did ue to worhip god under Oakes; but that which they aw on the left hand, amazed them very much; it was another Altar, of grae alo, with two great Pots of earth out of which did grow two tocks of Mirtle, betwixt which was a Picture, over which the two Mirtles twited their branches, into a reemblance of a Crown. This was apparently viible not to be Naturall, but wreathed in that manner by Art. The Picture repreented a Shepheardee; at the top of it was written, This is the goddee ASTREA; and at the bottome, this:
div.q: More worthy of our Adoration, than we of her.
div.p: As oon as Diana looked upon it, he turned towards Phillis: Did you never ee any (aid he) whom this Piece reembles? Reembles, aid he? it is the very ubtance of Atrea: I never aw Picture o exquiitely done, nor more like, in all my life: Is not that the very ame heephook, which Atrea hath in her hand? Oberve the Letters C and A which are upon it, and intertwited together with knots. You are in the right, aid Diana; and ee, there is Melampus lying at her feet: that Dog is very knowable by his Marks, halfe his head white, the other black; and upon the black ear, a white pot: Oberve alo the white lit about his neck in fahion of a coller, and the ilver halfe Moon upon his able coat; alo the black and white lit along his legs. Silvander came to her, and Phillis, and aid unto them: Amongt all the Flock there, I have found which is that that Atrea loved bet; There it is, all white, except the ears, which are black. Atrea hearing all this dicoure, tood atonihed and mute, and, with admiration, beheld all he aw; yet going neerer the Altar, and finding everall pieces of paper lapped up upon it, he took one of them and opening it with a trembling hand, he found thee Veres.

lg.head: Wanting the Subtance, Shaddowes comforts be.

lg.l: IF any paenger do ask, who, in this Grove,
Gave me this Picture? Know, that it was Love
'Tis all my joy, my ole felicity:
Wanting the Subtance, Shaddowes comfort be.
My drooping oul, wel'd to the brim with grief,
And like to break, did beg of it reliefe.
Although thou art not halfe, aid I, yet ee,
Wanting the Subtance, Shadowes comfort me.
To render homage unto thee, I dwell.
Within the confines of this hady Cell.
Be o indulgent, as to ay to me,
Wanting the Subtance, Shadowes comfort thee.
Though by a fatall, dire, and dimall doom,
Unto thy Subtance I mut never come:
Yet, this fair figure may a witnee be,
VVanting the Subtance, Shadowes comfort me.
Oh! Fairet figure e're was left in pawn,
Or ever was by any Pencill drawn.
No Lover ever loved, as I Thee;
VVanting the Subtance, Shadowes comfort me.
I do adore thee then, without Idolatry,
Not as an Image, but a deity.
For by experience I do plainly ee,
VVanting the Subtance, Shadowes comfort me.

div.p: Atrea retiring her elfe, he read and pondered thee veres; and the more he looked upon the Hand, the more he thought it did reemble Celadons; o as after a long combat in her elfe, he could not poibly retrain her tears, and to hide them, he turned her elfe towards the Altar. But Phillis, who was as full of wonder as any in the Company, having taken up another paper, he went unto her uppoing, that the reaon why Atrea did thus eparate her elfe from the Company, was, becaue he knew this Picture, and thee Papers were Celadons. And Diana alo following her, Phillis beckned unto her to go back, let Silvander and Paris hould follow her alo; which igne he quickly undertood, and therefore turning towards Atrea's Picture, he opened ome of thoe papers which lay upon the Altar: The firt he laid her hand upon, was this.

lg.head: Upon the Eyes of a Picture.
lg.l: PAinter, I ask thee, what they are,
That park les in thoe Eyes o fair?
VVhat are they oules or flames that fly,
And hover o about that Eye?
They are flames, which death to foules do give,
Or rather oules, that makes Love live.
'Tis trange, that from the elfe ame eyes
A Life and Death hould both arie.
The works of gods all wonders are,
And o thee Sun • eemes ure as rare.
To think them human is a in,
Since reverence from the gods they win
To love them they command thy heart,
Since thou to look allowed art.
'Tis true, but yet my heart doth bear
In it, uch reverentiall fear,
As bids devotion pay, not Love,
To one that equalls gods above.
But tar, the gods, who blesings houre,
VVill not require above our power.
But try, I ay, and thou wilt prove,
Thou cant not look, but thou mut love.

div.p: Whilt Diana, to amue the company, did read thee Lines aloud, and thee being ended, took others, of which the Altar was full, Phillis addreed her elfe unto Atrea: Oh heavens! dear Siter, (aid he unto her) how I am amazed at all I finde in this place? For my part, anwered Atrea, I am o much out of my elfe, as I know not whether I be aleep or awake Look upon this Writing, and then tell me, whether you ever aw the like unto it? This, anwered Phillis, is Celadon's writing, or ele I am not Phillis. There is no doubt of it, anwered Atrea; and I do very well remember, that he writ this lat line, VVanting the Subtance, Shadowes comfort me, upon a little Picture which he had of me, and which he wore about his neck, in a little bag of perumed Leather. I pray ee, aid Phillis, what is in this paper, which I took up from under your Picture.

lg.l: Stay, tand, and gaze, did e're eye ee
A Saint o pure, o fair as he?
Can any be o dully dumb,
As not Idolater become?
And rather all the gods give o're,
Then not o fair a Saint adore.
But oft: ere I devotion pay,
Let me conider what I ay.
Thee flaming Beauties are not eyes,
Only a Picture which I prize:
It is not reall, only hade,
By an in genious Artit made.
Are they not eyes? Can any Art,
Like them, o captivate a Heart?
Sure Pictures, be they ne're o like,
So mortally can never trike.
But be they what they will, I'me ure,
No Mortall can the blowes endure.
Since by their power, I wounded am,
I'le flie them, to avoid the ame.
But why, fond Lover, wilt thou flie,
From uch a fatall piercing eye?
Thy heart's already wounded by it,
What e're it be, 'tis vain to flie it.

div.p:
Oh Siter, aid Atrea, it is mot certainly Celadon that writ thee Veres, it is without any manner of doubt: for, about three years ince, he did write them upon my Picture, which my Father had of me to give unto my Uncle Focion. Upon this, tears flowed from her eyes. But Phillis, fearing the ret of the Company would ee her: Siter, aid he, this is rather a caue of rejoycing then orrow; for, if Celadon did write it as I do believe he did, certainly he is not dead, although you think he was drowned; and if it be o, what greater caue of joy could you have. Ah Siter (aid he, turning the other way, and puhing her from her) for gods ake do not torment me with any uch language, Celadon is too certainly dead, by my folly; and I am mot mierable in the loe. I ee the gods are not yet contented with thoe tears, that I have already hed for him, ince they have brought me hither, to give me a freh ubject for more: But, ince they will have it o, I will turn my elfe wholly into tears; and though I cannot wholly wah away my offence by them, yet, I will never ceae, untill I have lot either my eyes, or my life, or both. I do not tell you, aid Phillis, that Celadon is alive; but I mut tell you, that if he did write thee Veres, I mut of neceity conclude, that he is not dead. Siter, aid he, our Druides tell us, that we have oules which never die, although our bodies do; and o in that ence he may live. I have heard ay, anwered Phillis, that it is our duty to give a buriall unto the dead, and to put a piece of mony in their mouths, to pay the Ferry-man, for wafting them over the Stygian Lake; and that uch as are deprived of buriall, are a hundred years wandring about the places where they lot their bodies; and how can you tell, but that the
oul of Celadon having lot his body, and being denyed that charitable office, may be wandring about the fatall River of Lignon, and till retain the ame affection and thoughts which he had before? Ah Siter, aid Atrea, thee are but meer phantams; Celadon is certainly dead, and thee are the tetimonies of his affection, and my folly. What I do ay, anwered Phillis, is grounded upon more then phantaims and Chimeraes, and I hint then upto you, out of my deire to contribute unto your tranquillity. I do know it, Siter replyed Atrea; but conider, that if I hould think Celadon alive, and afterwards finde him to be dead, nothing could preerve my life; this would be, to ee him die twice: and the gods, and my own heart do know, how near his firt death did bring me to my grave. Yet, you may receive this atisfaction by it, anwered Phillis, as to know, that death could not extinguih the affection which he bore unto you. That, aid Atrea, conduceth unto his glory and my punihment. Nay rather, aid Phillis, this contruction may be made of it, that he being dead, does cleerly and without a cloud ee, the pure and entire affection which you bear unto him, and that the jealouie, which caued your anger againt him, did proceed only from the uperabundance of your love; for I have heard ay that our oules eparated from the bodies, do till ee and behold them. This, anwered Atrea, would be the greatet atisfaction that I can receive; for I do not doubt, but as my imprudence did give him great caue of griefe, o this ight of my affection would give him contentment: For, if I did not love him above all the world, and if I do not continue til in the ame affection may the gods never love me. Thee two Shepheardees were talking thus, whilt Diana entertained the ret of the Company, ometimes in reading the papers which he found upon the Altar and ometimes a king Paris, Tircis, and Silvander, what was their thoughts of thee things. There is not any here but knowes, aid Paris, but this Picture was made for Atrea and conceives, that he who put it in this place, does not only • ove, but adore her. For my part, aid Silvander, if Celadon were not dead, I hould believe thee Characters to be his. How aid Tircis, Celadon who was drowned ome three or four months ince in the River Lignon? The ame, anwered Silvander. Did he, aid Tircis, love Atrea? I have heard ay, that there was a mot inveterate enmity betwixt their Families.

The beauty of this hepheardee, anwered Silvander, was greater then their hatred; and ince he is dead, I hope there is no danger in aying o. Nor do I believe there would, aid Diana, if he were alive; for, he being o dicreet and Atrea o wie, their affection could not offend any. Atrea hearing what they aid of her, though her eyes were not yet dry, he could not chue but anwer them: Thee tears, aid he, which I cannot hide, do tetifie, that Celadon did love me; but thee Manucripts do tetifie, that Atrea hath rather offended againt Love then Duty: But, to give him atisfaction after his death, I will ingenuouly confee, more then decency would permit me when he was alive, and ay, I did love him. Upon thee words, all the company came to her, and Diana hewing her the papers which he had in her hand: Is this aid he, Celadon's writing? Doubtlee it is, anwered Atrea. Then, aid Diana it is a igne he is not dead. Unto which Phillis anwered, That is it of which we have been peaking; but he tells me, that Celadon's oul, which wonders about the River Lignon, did write them. Why, aid Tircis, was he not buried? That's the reaon, aid Atrea, why he wanders thus; for they never made him a Tombe. This, aid Paris, was mot carelely done, to let o brave a oul as Celadon's uffer o long pain for want of a little care. You may ee, aid Tircis, how little thoe that are alive do care for the dead; o as I eteem them to be wie, who bury themelves alive. Indeed, aid Diana, it is very trange, that this hepheard; o much loved and lamented, not only by all his Kindred, but by all the Neighbourhood, hould not have that charitable office done him, which many have, who are lee loved. Perhaps aid Thorander, the gods did o ordain it, to the end, he hould not o oon have that place he had o much loved, and being recompened with his love, he had rather tay ome while neer her he had adored. However, I conceive, aid Tircis, that even as our bodies cannot be in the Aire, Water, or Fire, without much pain, becaue being ponderous and heavy, they mut perpetually be unquiet, as long as they are in uch pure Elements, as have no olidity in them to ret upon; o the oul, eperated from the body, not being in its proper Element, as long as it is amongt us, is in continuall pain, untill it enter into the Elizian fields, where it will finde another Earth, another Aire, another Water, and another Fire, more perfect, proper, and uitable unto its nature, then unto our dull, and groe bodies. And therefore when my dearet, and o much loved Cleon, dyed, I was in a reolution not to bury
her, that I might have retained her dearet oul the longer about me; but, our Druides convinced me of that error, and told me, as I have told you. For my part, aid Sivander, ince for went of buriall, men hall tay ome time longer in the place where they dyed, I heartily deire all my friends, that if I do die in this Country not to bury me, that I may the longer look upon my fairet Mitree; for, there are no joyes in the Elizian fields comparable unto that bleed viion, nor any pains that a oul can uffer, by being out of its proper Element, but are recompened by it.

That would do very well, aid Tircis, if after we be eparated from our bodies, we did retain our affections: but, our Sages tell us, that our paions are only • ibutes of humanity, and the gods did betow them upon us, to the end, the race of men hould not fail; but after death, oules being immortall, and not in a capacity of engendring, our Paions and our Loves are lot in it, even as our deires of eating, or drinking, or leeping. But, aid Silvander, if Celadon did write thee Papers, it is not likely he hath lot his affection & love unto this Shepheardee. Who knowes, aid Tircis, but that the gods, who are infinitely jut, were pleaed to give him that particular atisfaction, in recompence of that pure and acred affection which he had unto that hepheardee? If o, aid Silvander, why hould not I hope to finde the gods as jut and favourable unto me, as him, ince my affection hall not yield unto him or any other, either in purity or zeal? But, aid Atrea if the gods do hew him this as a favour, would it not be impiety, to deprive him of that contentment, by endeavouring to give him a buriall, and o et him out of this world? No, aid Tircis, for the gods do favour him in it, only as a comfort in the pains which he is continually in, being contrained to be abent from heaven, o contrary to its nature.

The Shepheards were thus dicouring, when Phillis, epied a place, which eemed, as if ome had been upon their knees, for uch marks were imprinted upon the earth; and becaue it was jut oppoite to the Altar, and he alo pying a piece of Parchment cloe by it, he went to ee what it was, and opening it, he found thee words.

div.head: A Prayer unto the goddee Atrea.
div.p: OH great and puiant goddee, although your perfections cannot be equal'd, and though all our acrifices come infinitely hort of your merits; yet, I beeech thee, let them be acceptable in thy ight, ince if you hould receive none, but uch as are worthy of you, the gods themelves mut be the Victim. This which I here mot humbly offer unto your divinity, is a Heart, and a Will, which were never dedicated unto any, but only your elfe. If this offering be acceptable, look with the eyes of pitty upon that oul, who ever found them full of love, and by an act worthy of your elfe, • rid it out of that pain, in which it hath long languihed. I do mot heartly beg this favour by the name of Celadon, if ever the name of your mot faithfull and affectionate ervant, can merit from your divinity o much glorious atisfaction.

Phillis making a igne with her hand, and calling Atrea: Come hither, Siter (aid he) ee what Celadon asks, and you will finde what Tircis aid, to be true. Then, all comming neer, he read aloud this prayer, whilt Atrea did accompany every word with a tear, though he did trive all that poibly he could to retrain them. When Phillis had ended: Truly, aid Atrea, I hall atisfie his mot jut demand; and if his Parents will not build him a Sepulcher, which they are obliged unto by Conanguinity, he hall receive one from me as his friend. Upon this word, going from that place, all the Company went back to Hylas, who was not idle all the while; for, eeing them all very erious and intentive in the other Arbour, he came into that where was the twelve Statutes of the Lawes of Love; and taking the Picture in his hand, he read them, then altered them according to his own humour; and having a quick and ready Wit, he changed them thus.

lg.head: The twelve Statutes of Love, falified by the Incontant Hylas.
The firt.
lg.l: HE that's a perfect Lover, and a jut,
And true, never love infinitely mut.
Extreames in Love are never counted bet,
Mediums will ever make a Lover blet,
And happy bee: All Mediocrity,
Signe is of prudence and fidelity.

lg.head: The econd.
lg.l: Let him no puiant god of Love adore,
But let him love ome One, and many more:
Above one Object, alwaies let his eye
Still look upon, and wantonly epie.
It is decreed by Loves licentious Law,
That he his Blie from many Fountains draw.

lg.head: The third.
lg.l: To many fair Ones, and their ervice, he
Mut dedicate himelfe and liberty;
He mut not heart and all delights reigne
To one, and only her, himelfe confine.
The rate he ets, upon himelfe, mut be,
As many love him, o himelfe mut he.

lg.head: The fourth.
lg.l: If he advancement to himelfe does eek,
Then let it be, in loving every cheek,
Which can give love a life; let him confee,
In loving many is his happinee,
Which he does only aim at, and apire,
To make the lutre of his glory higher.

lg.head: The fifth.
lg.l: Let his affection to his Mitris, be
So dear, o weet, o full of amity,
As the fruition of her he hall prie,
Above all tains of honour that can rie.
If hers and his come in comparion,
None mut be dearer to him than his own.

lg.head: The ixt.
lg.l: If any offer to apere the fame,
Or cat a blemih on his Mitris name,
Let him conceal his anger • give no lye
To him that offers uch a calumny.
If any dare to put affronts upon her,
Let him not die, to vindicate her honour.

lg.head: The eventh.
lg.l: Then let his love arrive at uch a height;
As that his judgment may be pure and treight
All Suns, and Stars, and glories of the skies,
He value mut uperiour to her eyes.
Perfection in the abtract do not deem her,
Nor think him guilty, that does les eteem her.

lg.head: The eighth.
lg.l: He mut inflamed be with fits of Love,
So temperately hot, as they may move
His pule to beat a gentle temper: He
Mut never igh, and pule, and halfe dead be,
Nor ever with uch violencies well,
As, ask him what he ailes, he cannot tell.

lg.head: The ninth.
lg.l: He mut not quit his habitation,
Nor think his oul can live by love alone.
He mut ome being have, beides the core,
Of her, whom he does worhip and adore.
Not into hor transformed o to be,
As that without her eyes he cannot ee.

lg.head: The tenth.
lg.l: Thoe daies that in her ervice are not pat,
He mut not think as abolutely lot:
Some good occaion may reward the pain,
Though it ne're bring him to that heaven again:
And when his body does a ditance finde,
Let him contented be within his minde.

lg.head: The eleventh.
lg.l: For her, he mut not derogate from reaon,
Or welcome bid to Manacles and Prion:
Can he intorments, think himelfe at eae,
Though he thereby the fairet Saint hould pleae.?
Since all without expectance of rewards,
The honour vain to love her, he regards.

lg.head: The twelfth.
lg.l: He mut not think it impoible his Love,
Should ooner then the firmet Rock remove.
If any, uch advice to him hall ue,
Let him as Orthodox the ame perue.
Who o hall ever uch advice o're move,
He's far from any Schimatick in Love.

div.p:
Hylas made all the hate that poibly he could, in altering thee twelve Statutes, and that the alteration might be lee dicemed, he firt eraed out what he thought fit with the point of his knife, then did polih it with the haft of his knife, then did write upon it what he had changed; and when all was done, he et it in its place again, and went out, unperceived by any; o as when they came out, he was found itting at the entry, as if he were fat aleep: and becaue ad Atrea, going out the firt, did take no notice of him, he lay till, and would not tir; but when Phillis, who came after, pied him in this lazy poture: How now, Hylas, (aid he unto him) how have you pent your time, whilt we have been viewing the greatet rarities, that are in all the Country? Faith, I have ome
thoughts (anwered Hylas, riing up lazily, and rubbing his eyes) which trouble me, more then ever I did imagine they could. What are they, aid Phillis? I will tell you, aid he, if you will promie to do one thing forme, which I hall ask. I will not engage my word, aid he, before I know what it is. You may do it, aid Silvander by adding conditions, that he hall ask nothing which is unfitting for a wife and vertuous hepheardee to grant. Upon that condition, aid Phillis, I will. Know then, fairet Mitree, (aid Hylas) that I do believe, this place to be really a acred Grove, which is dedicated unto ome great divinity; for, ever ince I heard Silvander read the Lawes of Love, I have had uch inward remore, as I cannot be at quiet within my elfe; conceiving, that I have hitherto lived in a mot groe errour, and contrary unto thoe Statutes, which the god, who is adored in this place, hath commanded unto all thoe who will love; inomuch as I am ready to abjure my errour, and ubmit my elfe unto the Lawes which he hath ordained: There was only one thing which hindred nie from doing it, whilt you were within the acred Grove, and I will declare it unto you: You know, fairet Mitree, that ever ince there was any ympathy betwixt my heart and you, and ince Hylas firt called himelfe your ervant, I never found in all this Country a more contradicting pirit, nor an humour more antipathyous unto mine, then that of Silvander; upon all occaions he hath thwarted me, and ued all artifice to ubvert whatoever I intend; as in that unjut Sentence which he gave againt Laonice, only becaue I poke for her; otherwie he could not be o groe as to prefer one that was dead, before o fair and accomplihed a hepheardee. Calling thee things into my memory and conideration, I had a conceit, that he read the Ordinances of this god after another manner then they are written, and only to croe me: Therefore I do conjure you, not only by your promie, but the honour you owe unto Love, and the deity of this place, that you will take o much paines as to fetch me hither thoe Lawes, that I may read them my elfe, be atisfied in my doubt of Silvander, and follow thoe Lawes all the ret of my life. Is this requet uncivill, Silvander, and unfit to be made unto a wie and vertuous hepheardee? No, aid Silvander; but I rather think it in vain. No, aid Hylas; but let us make another promie to one another. Promie me before all this Company, that you will follow thoe Statutes which are there written, as long as you live, and I will do the like. I hall, aid he, mot willingly; for I have long ince promied the ame unto the gods. You do promie then, aid Hylas. I do, aid Silvander, and that without any reciprocall promie; for, I love you better, then to make you perjured. For my part, anwered Hylas, I do wear unto you, calling to witnee the gods of this place, and let them punih, which of us two hall firt fail. I do aure you, aid Phillis, that eeing o great a change in Hylas, I hall mot willingly let him ee the twelve Statutes. Then going into the Arbor, and making an humble reverence, he took them, and brought them unto this uncontant Lover, who, with bare head and knee upon the ground, did ay, I do receive thee acred Lawes, as comming from a god, and brought by a goddee, proteting and vowing unto the great gods or this acred Grove, and calling all this Company as witnees, that I will all my life oberve them as religiouly, as if the god Heius, Tautates, and Tharamis had ordained them. Then riing up, till bare headed, he kied them, and being invironed with all the Company, he began to read them with a loud voice. But when Silvander heard him read, that one ought not to love infinitely: Fie, hepheard, aid he, read truly, and you will finde it otherwie. I think I do, aid he, and hewed them unto Phillis, who read them as he did. This cannot be, (aid Silvander); then comming neerer, he deired to ee them. I ee, aid Hylas, that he who ueth to deceive others, does think, others will deceive him: I doubt you will read them otherwie then they are writ. I hall read them truly, aid Silvander; but pray let me ee them. Me-thinks (aid Hylas) it may uffice, that Phillis aw them, and you may very well trut her. I wear (aid Phillis) that Hylas read as was written, and no otherwie: I cannot believe it aid Silvander, unlee I ee. Then read them your elfe, aid Hylas, o you will read them truly. Then Silvander took them, and wearing he would read them without any alteration, he began to read: But, when be found Hylas was in the right, he knew not what to think; and wondered more, when looking further, he found the ene of every Vere altered. Now Mitris, aid Hylas, what do you think? had I not good reaon to upect Silvander, ince, you ee, he read quite contrary to what was writen? Come, Shepheard, aid he to Silvander, what do you ay to all this? Will you be a man of your word, or will you be fale? Silvander anwered not a word but was more amazed at this, than any adventure he ever met with; but till looking upon the Statutes,
Diana came unto him, and looking alo upon them, was alo amazed: Silvander, aid he, tell me upon your faith, and confee the truth, when you readd them at the firt, were they written as they are now? I protet, fairet Mitree, aid he, when I readd them, they were not as they are now. Then Diana taking them into her hand, did look upon the writing a little neerer; which Hylas perceiving and fearing his jugling hould be dicovered. Come, come, Silvander, aid he what needs all this talk? I am ready to keep my word, and will you be perjured? You take me very hort, aid Silvander; and believe it; I have ome great upition of knavery; for I am ure, that the Statutes which I aw, were as then I read them, and now I ee they are quite contrary: o as I am much in doubt, that there is ome fallacy. This is but a very bad excue, aid Hylas; how do you think a new Table could be made upon uch a uddain? As they were thus talking, Diana, who looked upon them very narrowly, he found, that though the Inke was alike, yet there was ome difference on ome Characters, and then rubbing them with her finger, the new written went off, and the raure appeared; then holding the Parchment betwixt the Sun and her eye, all the raures and old writing eaily appeared, which having found out: Now, aid Diana, I can end both your diputes, for in one and the ame place, you may finde what you both eek for; you, Silvander, may finde it written as you did read, and you Hylas, as you did correct it. Then comming to them, he did demontrate it unto them both; for betwixt the Sun and the eye one might plainly ee, where the Parchment had been cratched, and might, though dimly, ee, what had been old written, and what newly. Every one of the Company did confirm what he aid, and all flocking about Hylas: Come, hepheard, aid they, tell us truly how you did this. Hylas eeing himelfe dicovered by the trict obervance of Diana, was almot forced to confee the truth; yet, not before he had worn many an oath that it was the injutice of thoe Lawes, which moved him unto it; for, aid he, they are o very unreaonable, as I could not poibly forbear correcting them as they ought to be. None could forbear laughing, to hear him talk o, but more, when they conidered, into what a damp Silvander was truck at the firt. And becaue it grew very late, and they had tayed very long in that place, Phillis would have carried back the Statutes to the place from whence he had them: But all were of opinion, that it was fit they hould firt be corrected as they were at firt; and that Hylas, to extenuate ome part of his offence, in entring into that place which he was forbidden, and for daring to falifie the Statutes of Love, he was cenured to erae all that himelfe had written, which accordingly he did: More, aid he in obedience unto my Mitree, then to appeae the anger of Love or Silvander. Take heed, aid Silvander, that this be not too much preumption and infidelity Had Hylas heard thee lat words doubtlee he would have replyed; but he being gone into the Arbour, no anwer was given. In the mean time, all the company went their waies, and took a little path which Silvander had choen. And becaue Atrea was out of hopes to hear any more newes of Celadon; that could pleae her, he had a minde to return back, and in order to that, he left Tircis, and came to him Me-thinks hepheard, aid he unto him it is too late to go any further, and night will urprie us, before we can return to our Cabins. That's true, aid the hepheard; yet that, me-thinks, hould not hinder you from going on, ince we are o neer the end of our journey; and though you hould return, the day would not erve you above halfe the way. But, aid Atrea, where hould we lie? The place unto which I hall conduct you, aid Silvander, is not far from the Temple of the good goddee and I am ure the venerable Chriante will bid you all very welcome. I would know, anwered Atrea, whether this be agreeable unto my Companions. And then taying till the way was a little broader, he made Silvander's propoition unto them.
