There was not one, who did not very well approve of it, ince it was impoible to return unto their Townes by day light.

In this reolution then, they went on and Silvander not quitting Atrea, did hew her the Wood where he found the Letter, which caued this voyage. This aid Atrea, is a place very retired to receive any Letters in. You will more think it o, aid he, when you are there; for, it is the mot alvage and rude place, and the leat frequented, of any about all the River Lignon. So as none could hit the way aid Atrea, except you and Love. For my part, aid he, I know what it is, and as for Love. I will be ilent; for, I have heard ay, that ometimes when he would throw flames into a heart, he has burnt himelfe; and who can tell whether he did not o, by the beauty of my Mitris? and if any thing cure him, it is doubtlee the Fillet which he hath before his eyes. Ah Silvander! (aid the Shepheardee) that Fillet does not hinder, but he can ee when he pleaeth, and his Arrowes
hit o right upon the mark they are aimed at, as it is not likely one that's blinde did hoot them. I have een, wie hepheardee (aid Silvander) a blind man, who could hit the way unto every houe, and turn at every turning in the Town, having gotten it by a long cutome. And why may we not well ay, that Love, who is the prime and eldet of all the gods, hath by a long accutomacy, learned to hit the hearts of men, though he be blinde; and to hew you, that it is more by cutome then skill, oberve, that he loves us only in the eyes, and yet hits our hearts: If he were not blinde, do you think he would wound with Love o many unequall perons, Superious with Inferiours, and Shepheards with Queens. But I peak this as a peron intereted, for I, that does not know what I am, it hath caued me to love Diana, whoe merits are above the degree of any hepheards, and it hath made Paris, who is Son unto the Prince of Druides, to love a hepheardee. As for your merits anwered Atrea, you do equall the perfections of Diana, and Diana, by her vertue, doth trancend the grandure of Paris; o as the inequality is not o great, as to make you accue Love of blindnee. Silvander tood mute at this reply; not, but that he could eaily have anwered, but becaue he was orry, he had by his words given knowledge of his affection, and repented of them, fearing it would offend Diana, if he hould know of it. But by good fortune, his words were well addreed; for Atrea, knowing what pure and incere affection he bore unto Diana, he would mot willingly have left him all aitance. And the nature of all uch as know how to love well, is, never to prejudice the Love of another, unlee it be prejudiciall unto their own:

By this time, they were come unto the Wood, and therefore Silvander aid unto her: This, wie hepheardee, is the Wood which you have o much longed to ee, but being already Sun-et, we have not time to view it. If we do finde in it, aid he, as many rarities, as we did in that from whence we came, I hall think our journey and time very well imployed. With uch dicoure as this, they entred into the Wood, and it grew o dark, as they could not ee one another, nor follow, but by the voice; then going further into the Wood, he o lot his way, as he was forced to confee, that he knew not where he was: The caue of this was a Plant over which he walked, which they of the Country do vulgarly call Wander-weed, becaue it hath a quality, to make thoe that tread upon it to wander out of their way, and, as the common bruit was, there was much of it in that Wood. Whether this be true or fale, I cannot tell; but o it was, that Silvander and all the Company could not finde their way again all that night, though he turned and winded almot through all the Wood, and at the lat, they were all o wildred, as they were contrained to follow one another, by taking hold of each others clothes; for the night was o dark, as if it were o purpoely, to hinder them from getting out of the Wood. Hylas, who by chance was got betwixt Atrea and Phillis: I begin, Mitree, aid he, to hope well in the ervice which I have done you. Why, aid Phillis? Becaue, aid he you are very much afraid to loe me and whereas I was wont to follow you, now you follow me.

'Tis true, aid he; but you mut thank Silvander for it, whom you ay is your greatet enemy. I cannot tell aid Hylas, whether I hould more thank him for the favour I receive from you, or chide him, for the pains I have taken. You may judge of that afterwards, aid Phillis, when you have put the pleaures and the pains which you have received, both into a ballance. I wih, Mitris, aid Hylas, that you would hold the ballance, and judge which was the heavier. Every one did laugh at the good-will of Hylas; and Silvander, who heard it, anwered him only thus: I confee, Hylas, that I am a blind man, who leads many others. But the wort is, aid Hylas, they are blind only becaue they truted too much unto your eyes. If you had been out of the Company, aid Silvander, we had not been o blinde. Why, aid Hylas, did I put out your eyes? No, aid Silvander, but you did take away our means of eeing, holding us o long in dicoures of your incontancy, and by falifying the acred Lawes, which did put us upon the night. Silvander, aid Hylas, you put me in minde of thoe, who when they had found good Wine, did blame it, becaue they were drunk: Good friends (may the Wine ay) why did ye drink o much? And good friend, Silvander, why did you hearken to me o long? Did I nail your ears to any pot? No, aid Silvander, there were tronger chaines in that company and place, then yours. But be it as it will, we are now o wandred out of the way, either by reaon of the night, of by going over the plant Wonder-weed, as there is no hopes of getting into the way again, untill it be day, or at the leat, untill the Moon do hine. What's then to be done, aid Paris? No better coure, aid Silvander, then to ret ourelves under one of thee Trees, untill the Moon do hew her elfe. Every one
approved of the motion: And the hepheards preading all their Coats upon the ground, under the dryet Tree, the hepheardees did it upon them, and o reted altogether till the Moon appeared.

Although the night was already far pent, when thee hepheardees did it themelves down upon the Coats of the Shepheards; yet, being unaccutomed to uch a Canopy as the Cope of heaven, and unued to it upon the grae in the night, they talked a long while, before any leep did eize upon their eyes: And becaue the horrour of the night did poee them with fears, they laid themelves cloe upon an heap. Diana being next Mandonthe, did ask her, what fortune brought her into that Country? Wie Diana, anwered he, the tory of it is both too long and too tedious; let this, I beeech you, erve for all, that the ame Love that is o Regent in your Villages, hath as great a Soveraignty over Ladies and Knights; and it is it which brought me hither into this tate, although my quality hath raied me above it. If it be only your fears of being tedious to us, aid Phillis, I dare undertake for all the Company, that this objection ought not to hinder you, from giving us a relation of it; for we have all longed to have the atisfaction from you: And I conceive no time more convenient than now, ince we are without the hearing of any hepheard. The reaon, aid Diana, why I in particular do deire it, is, becaue thoe who ee us aunder, do ay, that we reemble one another very much o as me-thinks, I am as much concerned in your fortune as my own, and obliged to enquire after it. It would be great glory unto me, aid Madonthe, to reemble uch a Beauty as yours; but I wih, for your tranquillities ake, that your fortunes may never reemble mine. I am much obliged unto you, aid Diana, for your good will; but every one hath their own loads, and knowes bet where the hoe doth pinch them, and others are not concerned further then by way of compaion: Therefore I beeech you give atisfaction unto our requet Then I beeech you give me leave, aid Mandonthe, to peak in a low voice, that the hepheards, who are neer us, may not hear; for, I hould be extreamly ahamed, they hould be witnees of my errours, epecially Therander, for ome reaons which you hall undertand by the equell of my dicoure. Then he began in this manner.

div.head: The Hitory of Damon and Mandonthe.
div.p:
IT is bet for me, wie and dicreet Company, to relate the tory of my life unto you by night, that darknee may hadow my hame in relating my follies, for o mut I praie thoe occaions, which made me quit the quality unto which I was born, and aume this in which you ee me: For, though I am now in this habit, with a heep-hook in my hand, yet, I am no hepheardee, but decended from Parents more noble. My Father, following the fortunes of Thierres, had gotten uch reputation of a Souldier, that in his abence, he commanded all his Armies; not becaue he was a Viigot as he was, but becaue he had great authority among the Aquitains. This King did o love and honour him, that he was obliged to dedicate himelfe wholly unto him; in whoe ervice, beides the Etate which he inherited from his Ancetors, he o enlarged his poeions, as there was none in all Aquitain that could vie with him in riches. Having lived thus many years, his greatet griefe was, that he had no other Child but me. And though his death was uddain, yet it was with o much honour, as I hold it to be the bet piece of his fortune: For, after he had raied the Siege of Orleans, and purued Attiles as far as the Cathalaunique Country, Thierres, Merovea, and Etius, gave him Battle. As fortune was, my Father fought that day upon the right hand of his King, who had the left Wing, and Merovea the Right; and almot the whole trength of Attiles was upon Thierres ide. After a long fight, the King of the Viigots was killed, and my Father alo, who, after he had received a hundred wounds, was found upon the body of his King, to defend whom, he received thoe blowes which were made at him; which Torrimond, his Succeor and Son, did take o well, as he buried his Father and mine both in one Tomb; and after the Battle was won engraved mot honourable Incriptions, to his eternall memory. When my Father dyed, I was about even or eight years of age, and began then to reent the rigours of Fortune: For Leontidas, who ucceeded my Father in his Charge, and whom Torrimond loved above all the Cavaliers in Aquitain, did ue uch artifice, as I was committed unto his Guardianhip, and almot ravihed from my own Mother, under a pretence, which they called, Reaon of State aying, that having uch great poeions, and o many places
of trength he would ee, that I married my elfe unto uch a one, as was very well affected unto the ervice of Torrimond. Thus was I deprived both of Father and Mother, the one, by death; the other, by reaon of State: Yet, Fortune was o favourable unto me, in the honety and weetnee of Leontidas, that I could not deire better offices then thoe I received from him, nor wanted he any thing, but the name of a Father. But his Wife was of another nature, for he ued me o cruelly, as I may ay, I could not hate death more then he.

Now Leontidas his deigne was, to educate me, untill I was at Marriage etate, and afterwards to betow me upon his Nephew, whom he intended to adopt his Heir, having no Children of his own. But contraint being the greatet means to hinder a generous pirit from complacency, it hapned o, as his Nephew had never any affection unto me, nor I to him, both of us conceiving our Fortunes o noble, as we needed not any additions to make them greater. Thee coniderations, and ome others more ecret, did hinder our affections unto one another: But, when I came unto age of more dicretion, I found greater impediments then thee: For, the Courthip of many young Gallants, who addreed themelves with abundance of honour and repect, made me think, the faint and hollow love of Leontidas his Nephew did dihonour me. On the other ide, he being vexed, that I hould o leight him, he retreated, o as I never aw him, but as a tranger, of which I was not a little glad. And though the repect which every one did bear unto Leontidas, by reaon of the extraordinary favours which Torrimond hewed him did tave off many from openly declaring themelves; yet, there was a Cavalier, a neer Kinman unto Leontidas, who, notwithtanding all thoe coniderations did undertake to erve me, though he had but mall hopes to obtain. At the firt, he had no deigne to embarque himelfe in good earnet, but only to keep himelfe out of idlenee, and to make it appear, he had both merit and courage enough, to love and court the love, of her, that was eteemed the highet Match in all the Court. When this young Gallant began to erve me, he was a man without any repect, violent, and quick, and o couragious, that the praie of Temerity was more his due, than that of Valiant. But, ince Love took him into dicipline, he changed all his imperfections into o many. Vertues, and made him o amiable as ince, he is grown the very pattern of civility and gallantry, unto all the Cavaliers of Torrimond. His name was Damon, neer kinman unto Leontidas, of whom the King had at the firt no good opinion; but ince he began to change, the King alo changed his minde. But Leontidas being one, that was extreamly obervant of every ones actions, he took uch notice of his deigne, that he could not endure him, becaue he thwarted his aimes, of giving me unto his Nephew: And to give a top unto this new courthip, he did o peremptorily forbid me from eeing him, and him, from peaking unto me, as both of us were extreamly offended at him. We, loving better becaue forbidden had ever ince a greater deire to ee each other than before, o as you may believe, that this prohibition was it only, which did oblige me to it. When Damon began firt to court me, his humour was o dipleaing unto me, as I could not endure him; but, after Leontidas with menaces and harh language did exprely forbid me eeing him, and eemed to ditrut me: he vexed me o extreamly, as I reolved with my elfe never to love any other: And therefore I did with all poible diligence correct his vices, which his nature did mot incline him unto; ometimes blaming them in others and ometimes telling him, that my humour was not to love thoe that were addicted to them. Thus forming him into a new modell, when I aw the conditions of this young Cavalier were changed, I loved him much more, then if he had begun to erve me with the ame qualities and perfections; for, every one is much better pleaed with the works of their own hands, then any others: yet, I did carry my elfe o dicreetly towards him as none could perceive that I did love him, and tood o upon my guard, as he had not o much boldnee, as to declare his minde unto me by his words: But at lat, thinking that all his ervice was lot, if I did not know his intentions he reolved to take more heart, and put it to the venture: and becaue he thought it more expedient to do it by Letter then Tongue, after a long diputation in his minde, he writ this.

body.head: Damon's Letter unto Mandonthe.
body.p:
MADAM, It is extream temerity, to love an owner of o eminent perfections; but, I conceive it my duty to erve and adore them. And if you will extinguih the affection
of thoe who love you, you mut alo extinguih thoe perfections which caue you to be loved; which if you will not, do not think it trange you hould be diobeyed; for, force does alwaies excue an offence, that is committed againt their will; and neceity does not acknowledge thoe Lawes, which the gods themelves do impoe.

div.p: He was not a little perplexed, how he hould bring it to pae, that I hould ee this Letter, for he knew, that I would not receive it unles by ome Artifice. And ee what inventions Love hath. He came unto me eeming to entertain me with ome Court-newes, and told me two or three paages which hapned very lately: at the lat, he told me, that he had dicovered a new League of Love, but feared to tell me the Parties; becaue the Lady was one of my friends, and the Cavalier one of his. Why, aid I unto him, do you think me to be o indicreet, as I cannot conceal what is not fit to be known? Oh no, aid he; but my fear is, let you hould be an ill willer unto my friend.

And why o, anwered I? a pure and honet Love cannot offend any one. I plainly aw; (weet hepheardees) that he was perplexed, and knew not what to do; but I could not imagine, that it was any buinee concerning his own particular, ince if he had any uch minde, he might have pok unto me long ince, having had opportunities to do it: And therefore I was very urgent with him, and more perhaps then I ought to be. And at the lat he told me, that as for their names, he durt not tell them for everall coniderations, but he would let me ee a Letter which he had found that morning. Upon this, he put his hand in his pocket, and hewed me the Letter which he had writ unto me, which, without any cruple, I took and read, but knew not his hand, becaue I had never een it before. But as I had before a little deire to know their names, o after the reading of it, my deire was extream, and was more urgent then before: At which he miled, and put me off with ome bad excues. Why Damon, aid I, will you not give me o much atisfaction, as to tell me what I ask? I am affraid (aid he) that I hall offend you, if I hould obey; for he; unto whom this Letter is addreed is very much a friend of yours. Nay, certainly, aid I, you will much more offend me by your diobedience. Then I am (aid he) betwixt two great extreams; but, ince the fault which I hall commit is by your command, it will be the lee, and therefore I will obey. Then taking the Letter, he read it aloud; but when he came to the end, he topt, and named no body. See, fairet Shepheardee, the trange effects of Love; ometimes it hurries the pooret and baet pirits into incredible impudence, and other times it makes the highet courage to tremble at uch things, as the meanet peron would not dorre at.

p.hi: Damon
p.U:
erves for an example of this; ince he, whom no dangers could make tart, had not o much courage, as to tell his name unto a woman, and a woman, whom he knew, wihed him no harm. But, as his courage failed him, o my undertanding more; for I might well have known by his fear, that it neerly concerned him; and I well believe, that it was Love which did infatuate me, intending by us, to make his puiance the better known unto others; otherwie, certainly I had een it ince I did love him, and ince, they ay, the eyes of Love looks though tone-walls. However it was, I mut confee, I did not apprehend it; and eeing him tand ilent: What, Damon, aid I, mut I know no more? Truly I did think, that I had a greater power over you then I ee I have. From thence it is, anwered he, that my ilence proceeds; for, your too much power over me; makes me mute, and yet what I have aid might have ufficed you; for what can I declare more, after I have read the Letter, and you heard my voice? How, Damon, (aid I to him, extreamly amazed) was't your elfe that writ it? It was I, aid he and he'd down his head and looked upon the ground. Then I beeech you tell me, aid I, unto whom it is directed? Since it is your pleaure to know it (aid he directly) it is unto the fair Mandonthe. Upon this word, he was ilent, purpoely, as I believe, to ee how I would receive his declaration. I mut confee, I was much urpried, for I expected any other anwer then that; and though I did love him, and that with a reolved will; yet honour which ought to have the firt place in our oules, did make me think, his words did offend me: And though I knew, that I my elfe was the caue of his boldnee, yet would I not excue him upon that, conceiving, that notwithtanding he ought to have held his peace. The truth is, the love I had unto him was a good Advocate for him, and though it could not quite qualifie my reentments of honour, yet it did infinitely weeten them. At the lat I anwered him thus: Damon, I did little expect this treaon from you, in whom I durt have truted, as in my elfe; but, by this act, you have taught me never
to trut in any young and rah peron; yet, I will not lay the whole blame upon you, becaue I my elfe am partly guilty, in living with you heretofore as I have don: but, your over boldnee hall caue me to be more advied for the future; I hall hereafter take heed, both of you, and all that reemble you. Madam, aid he unto me, if you call it treaon to love you, I mut confee, I have betrayed you, and hall do as long as I live, knowing, that neither you, nor any in the world, can imagine the grandure of my affection: And if you do think, that my youth made me o bold, I hall maintain it againt all men, that never was age more prudent then this youth, nor ever any prudence more wie then this temerity, which you blame me for. If I have failed, and that you are guilty of it, your manner of living with me is not the caue, but becaue being o admirably fair, and full of all perfection, it is impoible any hould look upon you, and not commit the ame fault. Alas, did you not tell me, that a pure and perfect Love could not offend any? And why hould you now judge otherwie againt me? But, if my words do offend you, here's Damon that poke them, offers his breat unto you, and the heart that adores you; chatie him as you hall pleae, and if he refue any thing you hall doom him unto (unlee forbidding him to erve you) hold him for the wort of Traitors, and the mot unworthy of your favours of any man alive. Had you been contented (aid I unto him) to have given me ome tetimonies of your affection, by your humble repect, and not by uch impudent language, I had then found ome reaons to love you, as now I do to hate you. Do you think, Damon, I can put up thee injuries without revenge? Do you not remember who my Father was? Have you been ignorant of my life, and what care I have had, not only to be as I ought to be, but alo to preerve my fame from all manner of candall? Conider thee things, and if you do continue, you will make me perecute you by all the waies I can invent Madam (anwered he preently) never et before me any pains you can imagine; he that can endure the anger of your fair eyes, need not to fear all the torments in the Univere. Do not think I am ignorant who you are, nor from whom you are decended; your vertues are too deeply engraved on my oul, and I am too much obliged unto thoe, who gave you a beeing in the world, ever to loe the memory of them. But if I have only offended you in words, and not out of any deigne, but to do you ervice, forget, Madam, I beeech you, and forgive my tongue; command me to be dumb, o you will let me adore you in my heart, and I will never peak again. But, if you think your reputation, of which you are o jutly tender, would be blemihed, by my telling the world that I love you, you would take the only way to force me unto it, if you hould do according to your menaces; for, it would be impoible, but my affection would break out, and o that which I now tell you in private, would be publihed all over the Court; and, would not that much more offend you? Before you pronounce your doom againt me, I beeech you, Madam, conider well upon what I have aid, and that if my fault have dipleaed you, why hould you do wore, in publihing it unto all the world?

div.p: It would be a hard task for me (wie hepheardees) to repeat all the reaons which Damon alledged, and though I cannot expree them well, yet I aure you he did. I mut confee, I do approve of their counell as very good, who ay, that a Lover ought not to declare his affection unto any Lady, before he have obliged her unto ome kinde of good will unto him, for then the offence which he receives by the declaration, will be mitigated; and he will hearken unto his words with a more favourable ear. I did approve of it, I ay, at this time by experience; for, I could not poibly part from him, though I did reent the injury which he did me. And on the contrary, before our dicoure ended, I did conent he hould love and erve me, o it was with honour and dicretion. And becaue Leontidas had his eye perpetually upon us, I commanded him not to ee me o often; and, to deceive him, to diemble as well as poible he could. I do remember, that at that time, Leontidas, though a great and a wie Captain, yet was poeed with the love of ome woman, who eeming to love him, did get what mony they could from him, yet in ecret favoured others. Damon compoed ome Veres, which he ent unto me: And becaue we feared, let if our Letters hould be lot, our names would make known, what we deired hould be ecret: I called him Brother, and he me Siter. I think that I remember the Veres yet, which were thee.

l.hi: Although he belch out envy at my blie,
And vomit venome at my happinee.
Although by looking in our eyes, he ee,
VVhat he does think within our oules to be.
Although that I am not my elfe, he knew,
Having no life, dear Siter, but from you.
Although he plot, to make us jealous be,
And tain our actions with black calumny.
Although he hould divorce me from my joy,
And all my dearet happinee detroy.
Yet, pite of fate, and him, and all that's ill,
Do what they can, yet I hall love you till.
Maugre his malice, pite of all the lies,
That bitter tongues againt us can devie.
Tortures and torments, all is one to me,
Even in my grave, till yours I vow to be.

q.l: I wih this irkome Argus would employ

l.hi: His hundred eyes (and not us thus annoy)
In watching of his Mitree, whom, they ay,
Another loves, and yet he does her pay.

div.p: But to return from whence I digreed. Ever ince, Damon did o regulate and conform himelfe unto my will as I could not deny, but that I did love him; and indeed, he was uch a one, as it was hard to do otherwie, epecially conidering, how his affection unto me, had made him change his vices into vertues. And becaue, to delude the eyes of Leontidas, we did not peak together, unlee as we accidentally met, and never in the preence of any; many had an opinion, that the generous pirit of Damon would not long endure the didain which I ued towards him, and that he was quite fallen off from me. Leontidas himelfe was alo deceived, though his Wife, who was of a very upicious nature, did till aure him of the contrary; and becaue he did mot paionately deire to betow me upon his Nephew, to atisfie his minde, he et over me a Woman, whoe office was, to be a pie over all my actions, without making any hew of it; her name was Leriana, and well in years, yet of a very pleaing nature, but withall, as ubtle and crafty as ever lived. I was not o quick-ighted as Damon, for preently he dicovered the deigne of Leontidas. But I, finding her to be very good company, and one that did trive all he could to pleae me, I could not believe he had any bad intention. He, continually telling me, that he would deceive me, and bidding me to take heed of her, we reolved to go more ubtlely to work: And becaue it was not in our dipoe to turn her away, we thought it mot expedient to eem, as if her company was very pleaing and welcome unto us: By this artifice we thought we hould oblige her, not to do all the ill offices he could, but to make Leontidas think, that we had no deignes, but what we were willing he hould know.

Oh how well advied had we been, if we had put this determination into execution, after a more olid conideration. Leriana eeing what carraes I ued, did hew her elfe o deirous to pleae me, that at the lat, I began inenibly to love her: And he on the other ide, taking notice of the applications which Damon made unto her, did believe, that he loved her; and this beliefe, together with the beauty of this young Cavalier did quickly invite Leriana to love him, o as there was none of us, but poor Damon, who was not deceived; yet he payed the dearet for our errours, though he knew all this from the firt, yet could he not help it. I hall as long as I live remember the words he ued, when he aid unto me: Siter, you do love Leriana, but take heed he deerve it; I am afraid you will finde it, when it is too late her deigne is naught, both againt you and me; for, the Wife of Leontidas ets her over you, only as a pie: And believe it, the carraes which you have commanded me to ue unto her, has made her believe, that I love her, and therefore he wiheth me no harme. So much the better, Brother, (aid I unto him) for I know you cannot be in love with her, nor hall I be jealous. However, the good will he bears unto you, will perhaps keep him within compae, and hinder her from doing you any hurt. Pray heavens, Siter, aid he, it falout o; but I am in fear, this affection will end quite contrary; for, it is impoible I hould continue my carrases long unto her then, when he finds her elfe deceived and leighted. Oh heavens, what michiefe will he not be apt to do unto me? No, no, aid I unto him, he can never think to win upon you by:
force. I pray god, replyed he, that I prove a bad diviner, and that he do not do all he can to do us michiefe. I did ee, that this woman was very kinde unto him, but I could not imagine, he could be in love with him, only thought, that her application to him, was out of her deire to be complaiant. Now though Leontidas did treat me with all poible weetnee, yet, the harh uage of his Wife, made me almot weary of my life. I told Damon, that he ought to conider the mierable life which I led; that I had no contentment, but in him, nor conolation, but in Leriana; that I did not think, Leontidas and his Wife had any intentions of etting Leriana as a py; or if they did, I thought they might be deceived, and that this woman thought her elfe o obliged by my carraes, as I am almot ure he loves me. Damon eeing me in this opinion, could do nothing but hrug his houlders, and durt never ince peak of it unto me, for fear of dipleaing me. And ee what force this good opinion which we have of a peron, hath over us: I did plainly ee her applications unto Damon, but could not imagine it was with any bad intentions conceiving it to be only out of complacency. Oh how the vizard of diimulation does diguie vices, and makes us mitake them for vertues? And upon this ground, I was very angry with Damon very often, conceiving he did not treat Leriana as he ought, ince I had told him that I loved her, and that this was the leat thing he could do for me, to make much of thoe whom I cherihed. This Damon knew well enough, and durt not complain, let he hould make the matter wore, only nourihed in his heart an extream hatred againt her which he had much ado to hide. On the contrary, Leriana did o grow every day in affection to him, that eeing he took no notice of it, he could not chue but write a Letter unto him, o full of paionate expreions, that Damon could not diemble, but did put hero out of hopes, as he did not only tifle her love to him, but entertained a mot deadly hatred in its room: Could he have proved what he knew of our affection, doubtlee he would have done it, in accuing him unto Leontidas; but our happines was, that what familiarity oever was betwixt us, I never poke the leat thing of it before her; but, ince that I found her o ubtle and crafty, as I did believe, if he could not have made any proofes, yet he would notwithtanding inform; but that which retrained her, as I thought, was her Letter which he writ unto Damon, by which Leontidas might have een her to be but a bad woman; yet, this conideration was nothing, becaue he might ay that he did eem to love Damon, only to inmuate her elfe into the more credit: And doubtles Leontidas and his Wife had believed her, having entertained o good an opinion of her, as they thought her to be one of the gravet and wiet Matrous in all Gaul. But as I was mitaken in my affection to her, o alo Damon was much to blame; for, had he hewed me the Letter which Leriana writ unto him, doubtlee he had hewed me my errour, and we had not fallen into thoe misfortunes, in which ince we have lived; and the reaon, as I think, why he did not, was, becaue of his harp anwer which he returned, fearing, if I aw it, I hould be angry with him. But however, he kept it o ecret as I knew nothing of it.

Now Leriana plotting revenge upon this Cavalier, he conceived no way would bring it about, but uch occaions as I hould give her, thinking, that keeping in familiarity with me, it was impoible but ome occaions would preent themelves, which would fit her purpoe; and in order to that, he courted me, and followed me as cloe as my own hadow. She having a mot notable piercing wit, which would dive into the very thoughts of perons, he found, that Therander did love me; I ay, this ame Therander whom you ee here with me. It is requiite (age Shepheardees) that I acquaint you with his condition, as for his peron, you ee what it is; Be pleaed to know therefore, that his Father following mine in all his martiall expeditions, they were both killed the ame day Thierres dyed: And this Therander being brought up of a child in my Fathers houe; he conceived uch affection to me, as the difference of our qualities could not retrain him from looking upon me otherwie then he ought; and perhaps I might ignorantly be the caue of it, for the great inequality betwixt us, made me receive his ervices, not as a Lover, but as a dometick. But Love, who is blinde, did make him entertain uch thoughts, as were far from any grounds of reaon: yet Leriana, who was far more ubtle then I, having cat her eyes upon him, and found out his intentions, he thought him a fit ubject for a begining of her revenge: She knew very well, that amongt all the bitters of Love, there is none o harp as that of jealouie, nor o eaily infued into a oule that loves well; he began therefore to ininuate her elfe into familiarity with him, expreing much goodwill unto him, offering him all the aitance that lay in her power; and briefly, did by
degrees get him acces unto me, and opportunities to peak with me: But finding, that his modety would not permit him to declare his affection unto me, he reolved to infue more courage into him: And in order to that, one day when they were together, after ome far-off dicoure, to be a prologue unto the main buinee, he told him, that he and I had often wondered, he hould never make choice of any Mitres, and that I hould ay, I could not imagine the caue; that it could not be for want of will, for his age would not permit that; and therefore it mut needs be want of courage, though if he did et himelfe out, he might get the favour of the fairet Lady in all the Court; and therefore that I could ee nothing but that, or that he thought none worthy of him. Therander, who believed her, and who was touched to the very oul: Alas, alas, aid he, both my Lady and you, have but ill oberved my actions, ince you have not found out my follies. Alas, I do love, and do love in uch a place, that it is better for me to it till in ilence, then declare it, in any hopes of obtaining. Slie Leriana knowing his meaning very well, yet eeming not to undertand him, did till turn and winde her dicoure o, as he got out of him the name of Mandonthe, but with o many excues, as he aw it very requiite to continue her deigne, in infuing more courage into him; and therefore he told him, That he aw no uch inequality betwixt me and him, but that he might very well go on; that though Fortune did not favour him with any great Etate, nor could derive his Pedigree from any great Ancetours; yet, his vertues did upply thoe defects, and made him equall to me in merit. All this he told him, to make him the more confident of himelfe, and much more which he invented; as, That he knew by my words, that I did very much eteem him, nay, love him, and was weary of Damon for his ake, and would often ay unto her, that Damon was changed into Therander. Thus did he infue as good a conceipt of himelfe as poibly he could. Having, thus laid a foundation for her treaon, he would now found how I tood affected; and ometimes naming Damon, as if by chance, he would till be harping upon Therander, and omething in his commendations. All this I did not undertand, for I had never cat any eye upon him: And finding me to peak of him as of a peron indifferent, he had an opinion, that I would receive Letters, if they were handomely given unto me. The time of the year was at hand, when it was cutomary to preent New-years gifts: She conceived, that a pair of perfumed Gloves would be a handome cover for a Letter, and therefore procured one from Therander, and put it into the finger of a Glove, and when he aw her time, that the bet and mot company was with me, he preented her New-years gift unto me. By fortune, Damon was preent; and becaue he feared, let meeting with it, I hould not make it known unto every one, he told me, that there was a eam unripped, and he would mend it: Upon this, he took that wherein the Letter was, leaving the other in the hands of thoe that deired to mell at it. But I finding the Paper in the finger, I asked what it was? To which he anwered, that it was the eam which rippeed when I tryed them. I, who did not undertand this piece of ubtlety, replyed, that it could not be o. She, with incredible impudence, anwered, that he her elfe had ripped it, and that I could not have it untill it was mended. I perceived, that there was omething which was to be diembled amongt o much company; but I was too young and imple to apprehend it, or to diemble: Yet Damon, who had his eyes alwaies upon us, and who knew by experience how ingenious Love makes men, he preently conceived, that there was ome Letter in the Gloves, which mut be concealed from him, but he could not devie from whom it hould be; as for Therander, he was out of all upition, yet, now he began to have ome thoughts of him. For my part, though I had a deire to do nothing but what was fitting; yet I had a great deire to know, what it was which was in this Glove, and therefore retired as oon as I could. When I was alone, I took out the Letter, and opening it, I found thee words.

body.head: Therander's Letter unto Mandonthe.
body.p:
AS being contrained, & not as eteeming my elf worthy, I do aume o much boldnes, MADAM, as to call my elfe, Your mot humble Servant. If you will be erved by none but uch as are worthy of you, uch then only mut have the honour to ee you. Though we have not merits, yet we have deires, which are more intolerable to us, becaue they are lee accompanyed with any hopes. But, if Love, continuing his ordinary miracles, hall make an extream affection pleaing unto you, I hall then, Madam, eteem my elfe infinitely happy, and you be mot faithfully erved: For I do know, that though all the
hearts in the world hould joyne their forces together, to love and adore you, yet, they could not all equall the grandure of my Paion.

div.p: The flatteries of this Letter did pleae me, but comming from Therander, I was ahamed of them, wondring that uch a one as he hould dare to look upon me in this way: I was alo offended with Leriana, thinking it trange he hould be the bringer of any uch Letters; and I was long in conultation with my elfe, whether I hould complain of her, or take no notice of it: I reolved at the lat to tell her, that I had throwne it into the fire, and never read it; and becaue I would flie all occaions, as well to top all reports, as becaue I would have no occaion to put away Leriana, whoe humour was very agreeable unto me; and though I knew he was in a fault, yet my youth, and the affection I had unto her, contrained me to forget it, and to eek for excues in her behalfe. A few daies after, he came unto me; and becaue I did not wear the Gloves which he gave me, having an opinion they came from Therander, as well as the Letter, he asked me, what I had done with them? I have given them away, aid I unto her, becaue they were not fit for my hand. And the Paper within them, aid he, what have you done with it? I threw it into the fire, anwered I; was it of any importance? Did you not read it, aid he? And I anwering, No: She aid, that he was very glad of it, becaue he was deceived by one whom he truted but he thanked god, that the fire had purged away the fault.

What was it, (aid I unto her)? You hall never know from me, aid he; and I aure you, that ince I did know what it was, which was within this houre, I was extreamly afraid you hould have read it, and came now purpoely to hinder you. This crafty woman did think, that I had read it; but finding me not o well dipoed as he deired, he thought it neceary to imprint a good opinion of her elfe in me, and to disemble as well as I. And becaue he knew I loved Demon, he accued me with it, and condemned it; thinking that he could not build her deignes upon a better foundation, then the ruines of that affection which I bare unto this Knight; and therefore he turned her wits wholly to ruine it: And becaue he knew very well, that I had no ill opinion of my elfe he fancied, that Damon's affection unto me, was the caue of mine unto him; her deigne was therefore, to put me into ome doubts of him, conceiving there was no better way then jealouie, and that a generous pirit does more reent didain, then any other offence: And though jealouie may proceed from everall caues, yet the principall is, when a Lover ees the party Loved, loves another, taking this new affection for an argument of didain, and conceiving, that as he whom he loved did merit all his love, o alo he ought to have all hers; in which he failing, he doth attribute it unto didain.

But when he went about to execute her deigne, he found it to be a piece of no mall difficulty, ince this Cavalier did not look upon any woman but my elfe; beides, it was requiite, that Leriana hould have ome power over her, of whom he hould make me jealous, to the end, he might the better mould her unto her ends; moreover, that uch a one be ecret, and fair, and of uch a quality, as might eem probable he deerved to be loved; it was very hard for her to finde all thee qualifications in one peron: But he, whoe acute wit never found any thing impoible, after many a daies quet, in vain; at lat, reolved upon a Niece, whom he brought up, and to upply all defects by her ubtlety. This was a young wench, whoe name was Ormanthe young, both in age and pirit, who indeed was owner of a fair face, but o hallow in all attracts of Love, as very few deemed her fair; yet notwithtanding, Leriana had an opinion, that he could o intruct her, that where nature was defective, her art would upply. In order to this, he took Ormanthe to task, chid her for the little care he had of her elfe, told her, he might be ahamed to ee all her Companions courted and loved, who were much lee fair then he was, and that he could not oblige the meanet Cavalier to love her; he told her, all this proceeded from her carelenee and want of wit, and that for her part if he did not reolve upon better coures, he would end her home to her Mother; for, if he tayed any longer in the Court, he would arrive at no other title, but an old Maid. Ormanthe, fearing that her Mother would give her but coore treatment, if Leriana hould end her home, he fell down upon her knees, with tears in her eyes, and beeeched her to pardon all her faults, and promied, that for the time to come, he would wholly conform her elfe unto her will. Leriana eeing o good a beginning, continued: Ormanthe, aid he, all thee tears and protetations will be in vain, if I do not ee you change your behaviour and way of living; all your Companions are courted, and you are the only one that is
not. Do you think it is not a great griefe unto me, to ee all the young Beauties in the Court waited upon, and when they walk, every one hath her Gallant to lead her, nay, ome two or three, and you the only one that none looks upon? This, believe it, is a great digrace unto you. Thoe who look you in the face, and finde it fairer then mot of your Companions, mut needs ay, that if you be not courted, it mut be, becaue you are poor, or that there is ome fault, either in your Race, or in your Peron: And truly, all this proceeds from your carelenee, and from your rude and rutick nature, which makes every one to hun you. And indeed, I know that Damon has a good minde to love you; I know it, becaue he has got ome of his friends to tell me as much, and yet he can never finde a way how to approach you, you are o inacceible, and becaue your retired humour will never give him an opportunity; he is the greatet Gallant in all the Court, and this would be a great honour unto you. Should this good fortune preent it elfe unto any one of your Companions, Oh! how welcome it would be? What indutry and artifice would they ue to bring it to pae? Ormanthe, let me tell you this once for all, if I do keep you here in Court any longer, I hall expect, and deire you hall give, all occaions unto Damon to love you, and do not fear, to let others ee the favours you do him; for his deigne being to marry you, he will not think them diadvantageous to him. This was the lecture which Leriana read unto this young Wench: And truly, it was eed not owed in barren ground, but produced plentifull effects. Ormanthe being naturally of a free and affable humour, without any diimulation, and being put forward by Leriana's intructions, he did ever ince that day apply her elfe with o many carraes unto Damon, that he and all that aw it did wonder: The noie of it went o far, as I came to hear of it, and that by the artifice of Leriana, who by the means of Therander, caued it to be poken of in a place, where I might come to know of it; and to the end I hould think there was no jugling in the buinee, Therander never poke of it, but caued ome of his friends. However, I could not believe, Damon could love this foolih Wench better then me; ince me thought, her beauty did not equall mine, as my Glas aured me: Moreover, when I conidered my extraction and Ormanthe's, I could not imagine, he hould be o inconiderate in his choice, as to leight me for uch a one; which this crafty Leriana knowing very well, he was put upon a greater piece of artifice. There was an old woman, Aunt unto Leriana, who had lived all her life in much honour and reputation: Leriana did contrive the matter o, as this good old woman was acquainted with the carraes, which Ormanthes ued unto Damon, which were uch, as when he heard of them, he could not ret untill he ent for Leriana; and he ent for her, to meet her in my Chamber, purpoely that I might ee when he poke unto her. Their dicoure was long, and the anger that I oberved in them, made me deirous to know (when this good old woman was gone) what the matter was. She eemed very unwilling to tell me, and tood a long time without an anwer: At the lat, becaue I was very urgent with her, he aid thus unto me. See, Mitree (for o he called me) how ubtle Damon is; but yet, not o ubtle as my elfe: he thought, that by his feigning love to you I hould not ee the affection which he bears unto Ormanthe: This ubtlety had been good, had it been unto any other but my Niece; but, this doth o neerly concern me, that I mut needs look neerly unto it; and he hath carried the matter o far beyond all prudence, as he mut needs be blind that doth not ee it. I think, that I have been told of it by above a hundred perons, and this good old woman came hither purpoely to tell me of it; it is growne the common talk, and o dihonourable to my Niece, as I were to blame if I did uffer it, ince he is under my charge. I have chid Ormanthe many times for it, but I think he hath bewitched her: For my part, I know not which way he takes him; for, though he be my Niece, yet, I mut needs ay, there is not any one more unlikely to make one in love with her, then he. Oh! how thee words went to my heart? I retired into my Cloet, whither this crafty woman followed me, being too well experienced in uch accidents, to be ignorant of the operation thee words had in me. And becaue I did put my whole confidence in her when we were alone, it was impoible for me to retrain my tears, or conceal from her my affection, which I had o long hid. Oh! what extream contentment Leriana received by this declaration: And though her whole deigne was only to divert me from the love of Damon; yet, he knew it was not yet time to trike, but mut firt weaken it a little more, before he did down-right attempt it: And in order to that, he would needs make me believe, that he was very much a friend unto that Cavalier, purpoely, becaue I hould not mitrut her; and therefore he poke thus unto me: I mut confee, Mitree, that you
have eaed my heart; yet I am orry, I hould buy my eae at the expence of your orrowes. Had I thought that Damon had loved you, I hould never have feared his loving my Niece; he is a man of better judgment, then to change you for any other, it is only but ome flah of youth, which makes him go a little atray from you, he will return again, I warrant you; and therefore let not this withdraw your affection from him: However, I make no doubt, but this act does much afflict you, and dipleaeth you as much, as if it were ome grand injury; and the reaon is, becaue Love is a child, and is offended at a trifle. But, Mitree, let it not trouble you any more; if you will but ue a remedy which I hall precribe, you hall both be preently cured, I will warrant you. Do you not know, that an over great light doth dazle? and that too great a noie doth deaf? So perhaps the beams of your affection, hining too freely upon him, hath leened his love; for my part, I am apt to believe it o: I know, young pirits are ordinarily ubject unto uch things, and being too well aured of what they enjoy, they grow carelee, and kick at abundance, which does beget in them new deires. But againt this dieae, as againt many others, contraries mut be applied. I am confident, that if you did but eem a little to withdraw from him, he will preently return to his duty, and cry you mercy for his fault. You may believe, Mitree, that I do love you, becaue I ue this language unto you; and I do give you the ame counell, as, if it were my cae, I would take my elfe. In concluion, this cunning Piece of ubtlety o diembled the matter, as, with many thanks, I promied to follow her counell. It hapned, that Damon finding me omething faint towards him, and laying the blame upon the carraes which Ormanthe ued towards him, did by degrees withdraw from her, and hunned her as much, as if he had been the Woman, and he the Man. Leriana took notice of it as well as I; and not to let lip any good occaion, one day, when we were by our elves in my Cloet, he asked me, whether her counell was not good? and whether I would not believe her another time? And I anwering, Yes: She continued; Then, Mitres (aid he) we-mut do as good Phyicians ue to do, who having prepared the humours by ome leight medicines, do afterwards draw them quite away by remedies more trong. I will acquaint you with an art, which I have een much ued amongt Lovers. There is nothing which a Lover does more harply reent, then paugs of jealouie, nor which awakens him more, nor will ooner make him return to his duty: If Damon were a little touched with it, you hould ee how oon he would return, how he would cat himelfe at your feet, and acknowledge his offence. I could not chue but laugh when I heard thee words, thinking, that I was not able to obtain o much power over my elfe; yet conidering, what good effects her firt counell produced, I reolved to believe her in this: But, (aid I unto her) of whom hall we make ue of for this buinee? She durt not propound Therander unto me, becaue of the former paages, but he had a deire it hould proceed from me, and therefore he anwered me thus: This quetion, Mitree, is very pertinently asked, and it mut be adviedly thought upon; for, he mut be uch a one, as will not hurt your reputation, and therefore I do conclude, he mut be one, of whom you may abolutely dipoe, and one, o far inferiour to you, as you may withdraw when you pleae, and he not dare to be offended, or that every one hould believe you did but fool him. Then looking upon the ground, and cratching her head, as if he were much puzled to finde out one, upon a udden he looked upon me, and aid; Why hould we look o long for one that is o neer? who better then Therander, you may do what you pleae with him, and he dare not be offended; beides, he is dicreet, and has no mall affection unto you already; o as I cannot imagine one more fit for uch a purpoe then he. When he named Therander, I remembered the ormer paages, and did think, that he made choice of him ooner then any other, becaue he loved him; but alo I knew, that his quality and dicretion was uch, as were very uitable for the buinee which I intended him for: And though my high pirit did forbid me to cat my eyes upon one of o mean a rank; yet, my affection unto Damon, and my deire to recall him, did make me condecend unto Leriana's counell: And therefore I began to look with a more favourable apect upon Therander, and to talk with him; but it was with much hame, when I perceived any aw me. Damon, whoe affection was extream, did preently perceive this alceration. And Leriana told Therander, that his dicreet and humble carriage unto me, had wrought uch good effects, as that I loved him almot as well as he loved me. The leat hadow of a favour from me, eemed to be great and ubtantiall; and though I did behave my elfe to him in a way of indifferency, yet, the leat yllable I poke, was a favourable entence; and this made him to brisk up himelfe, and look bigger then ordinary,
and all by the fale hopes which this ubtle woman had infued into him: So as Damon oon oberved all this; & calling to minde the Letter which he aw me receive in a pair of Gloves, and from thence drawing many diadvantageous coucluions, both againt himelfe and me, he did believe, that through the olicitations of Leriana, I had entertained the affection of Therander, and rejected him. After he had patiently endured thus a while, in hopes of ome change, but finding none, he being not able to endure it any longer, reolved to upbraid me with it; and becaue Leriana was continually with me, he could not poibly finde any opportunity of peech with me, unlee in the Chamber of Leontidas: And therefore, as I was riing from the Table, and far off this woman, he eeing that he could have no better occaion, did cloe with it, and aid unto me: Is all this, becaue you have a minde to kill me, or becaue you would try, how a peron that loves infinitely can endure rigour? I anwered him faintly, Your death does concern me no more, then my rigours concern you. He would have replyed, but Leriana came to us, and by her preence, contrained Damon to be ilent; and beides, I turned towards her, and did not give him the leaure. This crafty woman looking upon me, did make a igne, that this was an effect of her advice, and afterwards whipering in my ear; This aid he, is a very good beginning, continue your leighting him, and you hall ee a trange operation. Ah, mot ubtle woman! he had good reaon to ay, a trange operation; for it did operate o, as made me as mierable a woman as ever was. So, age Shepheardees, I did continue leighting him, and would not daigne o much, as to turn towards this Cavalier, who went out of the houe o much out of himelfe, as he was ready to heath his Sword in his own breat; and I believe, had not his intention of killing Therander retrained him, he had executed this trange reolution againt himelf: And that which hindred him from falling preently upon Therander, was his fear of dipleaing me, knowing that it would be a great wound unto my reputation, if, upon that account, he hould aault him; and therefore, when the ury of his paion was a little cooled, he went on, and tudied for ome other pretence of quarrell. When he met Ormanthe, who according to her cutome, came, and took him about the neck he was in no very good humour, did puh her a little back, and told her, That he wondred he was not afraid of that cenure, which all people would give upon uch actions. Whom hould I fear, or care for, (aid he) o I be but pleaing and welcome unto you? Were it of no other, aid Damon, yet you ought to tand in fear of Leriana. Of Leriana (aid he and laughed)? Damon, you are deceived, for I am ure, that I cannot pleae her better, then to carrae and make much of you. This Cavalier knowing, that Leriana wihed him ill and hearing thee words, did preently upect ome treaon; which to prevent, and taking Ormanthe aide, he deired her to tell him, how he knew, that Leriana would be pleaed with her for this? Ormanthe, who was far from a deep Polititian, and who thought, to excue her elfe, by laying the fault upon her Aunt, he told him all the dicoure of Leriana, and the commands he had laid upon her o to do.

Damon, who was very wie, after he had a little thought upon it, did plainly ee, that the change in my affection did proceed from an opinion, that he loved this Wench; and eeming to take no notice of it, he left her, with a reolution to tell me, let Leriana ay what he would. Fortune, it eemed, favoured him with a fit opportunity; for the ame day, Torrimond intended to hunt; and becaue the Queen was wont to accompany him, I, with the ret of my Companions, took hore, and waited upon her. The Stag being roued, and all the Doggs following full cry after him, all the Company full peed followed after the Chae. Now began all the Hunters to part; thoe who had the flightet Hore, left the ret behinde them. Damon, who was well mounted, kept his eye till upon me, and eeing me eparated from all the Company, he took into a way which he thought I would pae; and feigning that his Hore had fallen upon him, he eemed as if he had hurt his leg; and to procure the more beliefe of it, he dirtyed his head and houlder on the one ide and his Hore alo, giving his Man charge to keep at a ditance. When I was paing the way, he croed it, and taking my Hore by the Bridle, he tayed him; at which I was much urpried, fearing, that his love had tranported him beyond his dicretion: but fearing, that if I hould eem too fearfull, he would grow more bold; I made a vertue of neceity, and poke to him in a confident tone, aying: What do you mean, Damon? how dare you be o bold as to interrupt me in my way? Neceity, Madam, anwered he, which hath no Law, hath contrained me to commit the fault: if, after you have heard me, you hall deem it worthy of punihment, I will promie you to receive it, or any thing
that hall give you atisfaction. Then lifting his eyes up to heaven: Oh ye gods, (aid he) who hear and ee the ecrets of all diembling hearts, be witnees unto what I hall ay unto this fair One, and if I do not ay truth, you are not jut, if you do not punih me before her fair face. Then turning towards me; I will not at this time, fair Mandonthe, (aid he) either excue my elfe, or accue you, for the choice you are pleaed to make of Therander before me, and your forgetting o many vowes and oaths which you invoked the gods to witnee: But I mut needs complain againt my fortune, which will not let me avoid that miery, which I do foreee. As oon as ever Leriana came to you, me thought ome Daemon foretold me, of the harm which he would do me; you know, how oft we reolved never to confide in her; but, my bad detinies, more trong then all our reolutions, hath made you change your minde, and would needs have you to love her: If you do but finde any contentment in it, though I endure the mot cruell torments that ever oul uffered; I hall thank the gods, and pray them to continue it. But, it being a thing impoible for me to leave you in any doubt of my fidelity; and though I know it will be in vain, and that you will not credit it; yet, I mut needs tell you, how maliciouly and craftily he hath ruined all my happinee. Then he told me, how Leriana loved him, how he had carraed him, how he rejected her, and how deadly he did hate him for this refuall; and to verifie what he told me, he hewed me the Letters which he had written unto him, and acquainted me with the counell and intructions he gave Ormanthe, to apply her elfe unto him, only to make me believe, he was in love with her; and acquainted me, how he came to the knowledge of all this, and how this malicious woman did not value the honour of her Niece, o he could thereby ruine me, and make you love Therander, which he knew he could never do, but by ravihing from me the honour and happinee of your favour. But Oh ye gods! is it poible he hould ever bring it to pae? can I o much as ever doubt it, ince I aw the Letter in the Gloves, and ince I ee you o kinde unto him, that is o much unworthy of you? But, what better evidence then your own words, can I have to aure me, that I am mot mierable, that I am condemned, and that I am for ever lot?

Well, Mandonthe, ince it is my bad fortune to be a caue, that the generous pirit which I ever knew to be in you, is not only tained with Incontancy, but with a choice that is bae and dihonourable; I am reolved not to urvive your affection, but will make it appear, that I have love enough to wah away your offence with my blood. Imagine, wie Diana, how I was amazed at this expreion; I was o truck with fear, as I could not anwer him, or peak one word of a long time. And when I began, with intention to give him all the atisfaction he could deire, I aw the Chae comming upon us, and it was o neer us, as, not to be een alone with Damon, I was contrained to part from him, and had not time to ay any more but this: Truth hall alwaies prevail. Then witching my Hore, I rid into the Wood, very orry that I could not give him a better anwer. I would have commanded him to follow me if I durt, but I was afraid any hould ee us together, and therefore referred it untill a better occaion. Now oberve, I beeech you, how the gods does mock at mortall prudence; I made choice of the next morning, to put poor Damon out of his pain, and it was that day which brought him more torment.

I need not tell you how he paed away that night, it is eaily imagined that he had not any good ret; but, as oon as day came, he went out of his Chamber; and it being about the houre I was ued to rie, he went to walk in a Gallery, out of which, he might ee into my Chamber, when the dore was open, intending to go in, as oon as he undertood that I was out of my bed. But, as fortune was, I awaked very late that morning, as well, becaue I was weary with hunting the day before, as becaue I at up very late, reading and muing upon the Letters which Leriana writ unto him, and he had given unto me: In which I found uch upplications and expreions, as were mot unworthy of any woman; for in the concluion of one of them, I found thee words: Accept, Oh dearet and lovely Damon, the prayers of her, that wholly gives her elfe unto you, upon no other condition, but only to be yours; and this, if not out of Love, yet, I beeech you, out of Pitty. Truly I was extreamly atonihed at it, and I vexed o, that I hould be o extreamly deceived, as I could not cloe my eyes a long time after I was in bed. But whilt Damon, as I told you, was walking in this Gallery, Leriana, who aw him there, would try, whether a Lover could be put to death by dipleaure; for, having found Therander alo at the ame time, he carried him unto a window, jut under that on which he aw Damon leaned ometimes, when he was weary with walking; and having oberved, that he
was there at that time, he poke thus unto Therander, in a voice loud enough, and purpoely to be heard: And to the end you may know, dear Brother, that Mandonthe does really love you, and that he does but laugh at all thoe, who think he loves them, he commanded me yeterday, when he came from Hunting, to give you this Ring, which he caued to be made purpoely for you: She deires you to love her, and to wear it as a ymbol of your affection; he hath another, which he wears her elfe, jut like it, which he will alwaies wear, as an aurance, that her will hall never differ from yours, more then the Ring he ends you differs from hers. Oh heavens! what treaon is this? Is it poible uch villany hould be invented by any human pirit? For the truth is, I had a Ring jut like that which he gave him, and had worn it long; and this wicked Devill got another to be ecretly counterfeited, purpoely for this end. Damon, who, as I told you, leaned upon the window, and hearing her voice, did preently know it, and leaning his head further out of the window, to hearken more attentively, he heard all thee words that I have told you: And becaue he did put her arme out of the window, purpoely that Damon might ee the Ring, he remembered very well, that he had een me have uch another. And whilt he was thus leaning himelfe out of the window, he heard Therander anwer her: I wear by all the gods (aid he) that this Ring is o beyond all expreions welcome unto me, as I do wih Mandonthe may never love me, if I do not wear it to my grave, as a tetimony, that I am eternally hers, and that it is infinitely dearer unto me, then my own heart. Upon this, he took it, and after many kies, he put it upon his finger.

Whether or no Damon was tranported, and whether he had not reaon to trangree the limits of duty, I leave you to judge, wie Diana; and yet, he had o much power over himelfe in his anger, as he neither did nor aid any thing, which could give any knowledge of it, let if any knew it, he might be hindered in the execution of his deigne. At the ame time, the Queen went into the Temple, to be preent at the acrifices which were offered almot every morning; and becaue Lcontidas's Wife never left her, I went alo, as the ret of the Court Ladies did; of which, Damon not being advertied untill we were all in our Coaches, he took Hore, and overtook us, as we were entring into the Temple. And ee how unfortunate we were, I was fully reolved to admit of all his excues, and to aure him that I did love him, what demontrations oever I had given to the contrary; and to make good my words, I would have broke off all friendhip with Leriana, and all familiarity with Therander, and ought out for opportunity to tell Damon as much. But he, being abued by the treaon of fale Leriana, when he aw me, he looked with uch an angry brow, and o leighted me, as I became offended with him, not knowing or imagining what caue he hould have o to do; yet, preently after, remembring how I had made him jealous, I did excue him. We all went into the Temple, and the acrifice begun, during which, I oberved, that he looked upon me very often, but, with uch angry eyes, and brow beating frownes, as plainly poke him to be very much tranported. But hear, I beeech you, into what an extaie this paion did hurry him: When the acrifice was offered, and every one in the midt of their zeal and devotion upon their knees, he roe up, and with a loud voice uttered thee words: Oh great god, who art adored in this acred place, by all this devout aembly; if thou beet jut, why dot thou not punih a oul, that is the mot perfidious, and mot cruell, in all the world? I demand jutice of thee in her preence, to the end, that if he have any thing to alledge in her defence, he may: but, if he cannot, and thou not punih her, I will ay, thou art either unjut, or impuiant.

You may imagine, wie Shepheardee, in what a cae I was in, and how fearfull I was, let he hould ay more, and make it known, that it was I of whom he poke. All the Aembly turned their eyes towards him, as well, becaue he poke with a voice full of terrour, as becaue of his unaccutomed way of doing it. But he, after this, aid no more, only kneeled down upon his knees, and eemed very zealous at his devotion. This moved many unto various cenures; and it was well for me, that I had a Hood over my face, which kept it from being een; for doubtlee, my very bluhes would have betrayed me, and told all the congregation, that it was I he meant, His friends and kinmen thought this prayer to be very uneaonable, and as oon as all divine ervice was done, they ought for him, to tell him their opinions; but, they all mied of their aimes, for he thrut himelfe into the croud, and lipt away to his lodging; where, after he had et all his buinee in order, he writ a Letter unto me, and put it into his pocket; then writ thee words unto Therander.

body.head: Damon's Challenge unto Therander.
body.p: IF the injury I have received from you were of that nature, as could be atisfied with any thing but blood, I hould not deire, Therander, to ee you alone with a word in your hand: But, ince I can no other way receive atisfaction, and being aured, your courage will not be more backward in fighting then offending, I end this man unto you, whom you know to be my ervant, and who will conduct you to the place where I am, without any other Armes, then as we uually wear by our ides; promiing you, by the honour of a Cavalier, that you hall finde none to defend your elfe from, but him, whoe name is Damon.

div.p: He gave command unto a young man, whoe name was Halladine, who erved him, and whom he loved very well, both for his affection and ingenuity, that he hould bring him a Hore to the out-ide of the Town-walls, and another for himelfe, and this in all hate, and o ecretly, as none hould ee Halladine did as he was commanded. And when they were thus both out of the Town, Damon left the high-way, and chuing out a place fit for his purpoe, and out of the common paage, he acquainted Halladine with his intention, gave him his intructions and the Letter which he writ unto Therander. The young man, deirous to erve his Mater according to his commands, found out Therander, and delivered his meage o handomely, as none took any notice of it. But, why hould I pend any more time upon this ubject? Therander went, they fought, Damon was Conquerour, and left Therander bleeding upon the place, with three dangerous wounds in his body: 'Tis true, Damon was but in little better condition; but he had trength enough to take the Ring, which Leriana gave to Therander, off his finger, whilt he was in a ound; and getting upon his hore, he rid away, commanding Halladine to follow him.

As for my part, I had a great deire to give this Cavalier all contentment, and looked about for him with as earching eyes as any in the company, wondring I could not ee him. After dinner and not dreaming of this michance which hapned, as I and one of my Companions was walking in the Garden, I aw Halladine comming, who addreing himelfe unto me, asked, if Leriana was not here lately? And cauing her to be called, he addreed himelfe unto her in this manner.

Leriana, My Mater knowing how welcome the newes I bring would be unto you, hath commanded me to tell it unto you, not for any affection that is betwixt you, but becaue knowes Mandonthe loves you. Then he related the whole paage of the Combat, and afterwards continued on: When he was got on Horeback again, aid he, and when I aw him ride into places leat frequented, I wondred; for he was much wounded, and I could not chue but cell him, that I thought it more neceary to eek out a good Chirurgion, to dree his wounds. He anwered me, we hall finde one preently Halladine, never fear it. I thought he had aid true, and believed him, following him till, with abundance of pitty, for he had lot a great abundance of blood. At lat, he came to the banks of the River Garrone, and to a place where there was uch a Precipice, as was a terrour to look down. Being come unto this place, he would light from his Hore; but he was o weak with the loe of o much blood, as I mut needs help him to alight. Then leaning his back againt the Rock, he pulled a Paper out of his pocket, and holding it in his hand, aid unto me: This Letter is directed unto the fair Mandonthe, be ure you give it unto her. Then pulling out the Ring which he took from Therander; Give her this alo, aid he unto me, and aure her from me, that death is very welcome to me, ince I have given a tetimony, that I did deerve it better then he unto whom he gave it; and ince my word hath ent him out of the world, whom he thought o worthy of it: conjure her by her own merits, and the affection he once vowed unto me, that he never betow it hereafter upon one, whoe Love is dihonourable to her, and who could no better keep it. I took the Letter and the Ring which he gave me; but eeing he had not trength enough to utain himelfe, and that he grew very pale, I took him under the arme, bad him be of good heart, and not thus be a murderer of himelfe: And pulling out my handkerchiefe, I would have topped that wound which bled the mot But he, taking it hatily out of my hand: Stay, tay, Hallidane, aid he, never think of living, now I am out of Mandonthe's favour. Then holding my handkerchiefe under his wound, be received the
blood as it ran out; and when it was almot full, he held it to me, and poke thee words: Make it appear, Halladine, upon this lat occaion, that my love to thee, and my choice of thee for thy fidelity, was deerved: And as oon as I am dead, carry this Letter and this Ring unto Madonthe, and this handkerchiefe full of blood unto Leriana, and tell her, that ince he could never be atisfied with doing me hurt as long as I lived, I have ent her this blood to top her inatiable malice. Oh Sir, (aid I unto him) hall I live to ee you die for any woman living? Rather command me to heath my word in their hearts, and to let them know, they are not worthy to ue uch a noble Cavalier in this manner But, ee the height and trength of his affection! though he was in uch a pittifull weak condition, that he could hardly peak; all he was able to do, was, to lean againt the Rock: yet, when he heard me utter thee words, he tarted up in fury, took his word in his hand, and doubtlee had killed me, had I not aved my elfe by nimblenee. And eeing he could not reach me: Away, away, thou wicked and diloyall Servant, (cryed he out) daret thou peak o irreverently of the mot deerving Woman in the whole Univere? If I live, thou halT die by no other hand but mine. Then finding extream feeblenee to eize upon him, he endeavoured to get near the point of the Rock: You do loe, this day, Oh fairet Madonthe, (aid he) him, whoe affection is onely worthy of your merits. Then, (Oh heavens!) he leaned over the Rock to throw himelfe down, and was almot quite gone, when I uddenly took hold of his Helmet; but, his weight, and the terrour of the Precipice, was more likely to pull me after him, than I to pull him out of it; and, I mut confee, that fear of death made me let go my hold, to ave my own life. I ran to the bottom of this Precipice, fetching a great compae round about, in hopes to finde him there wimming down the tream: But alas! I could never ee, nor ever finde more, of the body of my poor Mater. When I had done all I could, and all in vain, I thought it my lat duty to fulfill his lat commands, and therefore I came hither. It is to you, Madam, (aid he) that this Letter and this Ring is due • ; and though they be prinkled with his blood, yet, be not afraid to take them, for, it is the mot noble and generous blood that ever came out of a man. And this is thy due (aid he to Leriana, and gave her his handkerchief full of blood) take it, and glut thy damned rage; and be ure, that if the gods be jut, they will houre vengeance upon thee. Upon this word, he threw the handkerchiefe at her eet, and beginning to cry, he went away in a ad and deperate ury, and would not give one word more.

I need not tell you, how this meage went to my heart. I cannot, if I would, expree my ad apprehenions; I was o quite pat my elfe, as they carried me to my Chamber; and, as fortune was, I met thoe that brought Therander, who was not quite dead. When I was come to my elfe again, and my pirits a little better etled, I cat my eye upon the Ring which Halladine brought me; I took it to be the ame I did ordinarily wear, and comparing them together, I found no difference, but that it was a little newer and bigger. I could not imagine why they hould be made o jut alike, nor who gave it unto Therander. At lat, I read the Letter, and found it to be thus written.

body.head: Damon's Letter unto Madonthe.
body.p: SInce Leriana's malice is more predominant in you, than my true affection, and hath caued you, in lieu of being favourable unto me, to cat your eye upon a peron, who is o much unworthy of you, and to confirm your good acceptance of him by the gift of a Ring: I am reolved to make it appear by Armes, that he, upon whom you confer thee favours, is not able to preerve them againt him, whom you have o unjutly refued: And that if either Valour or affection can merit them, none can pretend unto them more then my elfe. Yet, conceiving my elfe not worthy to live, and love one that can didain me for a man of uch mean merit and valour; if the fate of Armes do favour me, as I do not doubt but they will, I promie you, that the ight of me hall never make you deire any revenge, for taking away from you your dear Therander; if either Sword, or Water, or Fire, can give death to a mot mierable man.

div.p:
Thee expreions, o full of extream tranport, did make a mot trange wound in my oul; uch an odd tupification of orrow eized upon me, as I cannot tell you what I either aid or did. So it was, that being got to bed, I lot my witts, thinking alwaies that Damon
followed me, and the handkerchiefe of blood was till before my eyes; o as it was no more then requiite I hould have one alwaies by me, to add ome conolation. Leriana, who thought that I was ignorant of all her wicked devices, would needs be with me, as uuall, and the better to diemble it, came crying to my bed-ide: But, as oon as ever I aw her, I mut confee, I had not o much power over my elfe, as to diemble my hatred of her, and indeed, I thought it in vain, ince Damon was dead: Away, away, mot wicked and perfidious wretch, (aid I unto her) away, thou very Pet of all human ociety, come not near me with thy damned and hellih tricks, had I as much trength as will, I would trangle thee with my own hands, and tear thy heart in pieces. Thoe who were in the Chamber, being ignorant of the caue I had for thee expreions, were infinitely atonihed at them. But he, who had the readiet wit in her wickednee, of any that ever breathed, went from me, holding up her hands and eyes, and told them, that, to hee great griefe, I was mad, and quite out of my wits, which they eaily believed, having heard me utter ome odd expreions; and thus he went out of my Chamber with this excue.

In the mean while, Therander recovered, for his wounds were not mortall, and the loe of blood only was the caue of his ounding. Preently after, I alo began to be my elfe again and to enquire, what reports went of me at Court: I undertood, that every one talked according to their everall fancies, but that all in generall blamed me for the death of Damon, and how every one thought, that Leriana had told many a tale unto Leontidas and his Wife; and at the ame time, I aw Therander come into my Chamber: The very ight of him made me tart, and having no minde to peak with him, when he fell down upon his knees at my beds ide, I turned my head the other way. 'Tis very true, Madam, aid he) you have no reaon to look upon a man, who, of all men in the world, is the mot unworthy of your apect; for, I mut needs confee, I merit that lee, then any man that lives, ince I have given you o much caue to hate me. But, if your goodnee will be pleaed to daigne me a hearing, perhaps you will not deem me o culpable as now you do. And becaue I anwered him very harply and would not give him leave to peak, my Nure, who was with me, took his part, and told me, that I ought to hear him; for, if he were not in fault, I had no reaon to treat him o; and, if he were in fault, then I might, after a hearing, with more reaon banih him my preence. Well, well, aid I, what do you think he will, or can, alledge? I know as well as he, he will ay, that the affection he bears unto me, hath forced him to do what he did: But, what have I to do with his affection, if it be o prejudiciall to me?
