I hall not, Madam, (aid he unto me) init only upon that affection you peak of, though perhaps to any other, that might be a better plea and excue, as you think it; but, I hall go further, and tell you, that never any were o perniciouly & ubtlely conened, as you and I have been by Leriana. And hereupon he told the whole tory of her jugling artifice, how he infued o much confidence into him, as to look upon me, to peak unto me, to apire unto my favour; how he puffed him up by reports unto him of favours from me, what tratagems he invented againt Damon, how he made the world believe he loved Ormanthe, how he intructed illy Ormanthe for that purpoe, and how he gave him a Ring from me, which he conceived to be the caue of the quarrell betwixt Damon and him. Now Madam, (aid he, and continued) do you think it poible, but that uch hopes as he infued into me, hould well the mot prudent oul that ever was? Alas, I dare not o much as wih o great a happines; but me-thinks, I may in reaon be excued, ince I was meerly drawn in, and poed up with vain hopes by the artifice of Leriana, with whoe peridie I thought fit to acquaint you, that you may hereafter beware of her, and her wicked devices, with which he has cheated both you and me. Then he let me undertand, how this wicked woman, eeing he could no longer deceive me and him, and being alo reprehended by Leontidas and his Wife, for having o little care of me; he, to excue her elfe, had told them all that her ubtle imagination could devie againt us; how I was in love, and how I was loved by many, and o many, as he could hardly number them: and amongt thoe whom he named, Damon and Therander were not forgotten. At which, Leontidas was o angry, and his Wife more, both againt me and againt him, as he thought it fit to acquaint me with it, to the end, I might take the bet coure I could. And latly, he made uch humble upplications, that I would pardon him, for daring to love me, and uch erious protetations, to live for the future as he ought, that I was contrained by the intreaties of my Nure, to pardon him.

But now, wie Shepheardees, I hall acquaint you with one of the greatet villanies that ever was invented againt an innocent peron. I told you before, how Ormanthe, by Leriana's command, was extreamly fond of Damon; and you mut know, that he was not o ill favoured, nor o diguted, but her kindnees to him were well accepted, o as he proved to be with Child. The poor illy Wench preently acquainted her crafty Aunt with it, who at the firt was much atonihed and offended at it; but afterwards having recoure to her accutomed ubtlety, he plotted and intended to make ue of this occaion, to make Damon believe, that I had this Child by Therander; and therefore he exprely charged Ormanthe, to tell no body of it in the world; and afterwards, becaue her belly began to well, he taught her how to dree her elfe, that it might bet deceive the worlds notice. But when Damon was dead; and that all things were changed, yet he reolved to purue her plot, and make ue of it to my ruine; and thus he went to work. Since this ad accident of Damon, I kept my bed almot continually unlee in the afternoones I roe, and hut my elfe up in my Cloet, and there tayed till nine or ten of the clock at night, entertaining my own melancholly thoughts alone, and none knew where I was, except my Nure and ome Maides that waited upon me, whom I had charged, to tell none in the world where I was. And becaue it might be thought trange I never went to the Queen, if it were known I was not ick, I faigned my elfe to be o; and to deceive the Phyicians, I did not complain of a Feavour or any other known dieae, but ometimes of a Megrim, othertimes of my Teeth, of the Collick, and uch like. And becaue my friends would ometimes end to viit me, not daring to come themelves, for fear of offending Leontidas and his Wife, who were very potent with the King and Queen, I commanded my Nure to put ome of the Maides into my bed, who hould receive the meages for me, and who faigning to be unwilling to peak, my Nure hould make the anwer; the Windowes being cloe hut and the Curtains drawn, no light almot came into the Chamber, o as none could tell whether it was I or no. Leriana knew by her Niece, that it was my contant cutome to hut my elfe up in my Cloet, every afternoon: And becaue I was no hater of Ormanthe, though he had been imply intrumentall in my miery, therefore I permitted her to be alwaies amongt my Maides: for, what he had done, was not out of any malice unto me: And at this time, he told Leriana all paages concerning me, more out of implicity, then any hatred unto me. But her Aunt, whoe aime was abolutely to ruine me and my reputation, nay, even to take away my life, let I hould make known all the villany unto Leontidas, he thought, that he had met with a fit occaion to effect her wicked deires. And becaue he was ure, Therander had acquainted me with her artifices and tricks, which he had ued againt Damon and me he turned all her affection to him into mortall hatred. And there being never in this world a pirit o full of ubtlety and malice, as this woman, he aimed to be revenged upon Therander and me both at once; and thus he had laid her plot. She asked Ormanthe, how long he thought her elfe to have been with Child? and upon reckoning up of the time, he found, that he was within a month of her Account; of which Leriana was very glad: And after he had bid her be of good courage, he commanded her, to keep her big belly very cloe, and that as oon as ever he found any throwes of Labour to be upon her, then to acquaint her; and in the mean time to get into my bed in my room as oft as he could. And making this to be the foundation of her treaon, he went unto the Wife of Leontidas, and falling down upon her knees, mot humbly beeeched her to pardon her carelenee in obervance of me. And becaue he knew, that the aimes of this Lady were more at my Etate then me, and ince there was no likelyhood, that her Nephew would marry me, he added thee words: If you will be pleaed, Madam, to take me into your favour again, I hall hew you a mot infallible and jut way to make all Madonthe's Etate yours. The Lady hearing this propoition, o uitable to her humour, he began to hearken unto it, and asked her, what way was it that he meant? I hall in few words acquaint you, (aid this wicked devill) but, Madam, upon condition, that you will pardon a new fault which I hall acquaint you withall. And commanding her to peak freely, Leriana thus continued: Madonthe, (in the peron of whom, god, Madam, eemes to love you, ince he would not let her be in your houe) is the mot mierable and lot woman in all Aquitain; and I mut confee, I never thought, that one o young as he could have deceived one of my age; her modet behaviour, her high looks her family from whence he is decended, and thoe good examples which he had of you, might well move me to anwer for her chatity as for my own; and yet for all this, I have dicovered, that he is with Child, How! Madonthe,
with Child, aid the Lady? Yes, Madam, (anwered Leriana) and more then that, he is ready to be brought to Bed. But how, replyed he, and from whom do you know this? Madam, aid he, I mot humbly beeech you to pardon me, and to believe that I was not o carelee in the charge which you gave me, as you imagine: Conidering her demeanour, I might eaily be deceived, and could never imagine, he hould ever look o low, as to love uch a man as Therander. I ee now, that jealouie has clearer eyes then any prudence; for Damon found this out, which my eyes could never ee. At lat, I came to know it by the means of a Midwife, unto whom he had addreed her elfe for a Medicine, to make her elfe micarry: But, the good woman being vertuous, and hating uch wickednee, did anwer her, That he could not, becaue now the Child was entirely formed, nay, ready to be born; but, he would do thus much for her, he could make her labour o eaie and peedy, as none hould ever know any thing. Now this woman came and acquainted me. And becaue I was very deirous to know who the father was, I asked her, if he could upect any peron? Very hardly aid he unto me, unlee it be Therander, for, as oft as I looked upon her belly, or he thought upon the danger he was in he would ay nothing ele, but, Ah Therander, thy affection will cot me dear. This makes me judge it to be him. Now Madam I beeech you conider, how could I keep her from this man? a dometick, a bae man, infinitely her inferiour: Could I ever imagine, he hould look o low as him? But, ince he hath rendred her elfe unworthy of your alliance, let her be punihed according to her merits, and make her an example unto all of her age, whilt you do enjoy that Fortune and Etate, which he is unworthy of; and this is the way: You know, Madam, that by our Lawes, every woman who offends in Chatity, is to die by fire. We hall very eaily convict her of this crime, ince he hath a witnee of it in her own belly. And becaue thoe who are thus condemned, do not only loe their lives, but their Etates are alo conicate to the King, be you the firt that hall beg Mandonthe's. Leontidas came into the Room, and finding Leriana there: How (aid he to his Wife) can you endure the ight of her, who is the caue of our dipleaures? His Wife, full of deire to be Mitris of my Etate, went to him, and took him to the window, there told him how the cae tood: And though he was a peron of honour, and a generous minded man; yet, he wrought o with him, that at the lat he conented unto what he deired: So calling Leriana, he commanded her to tell him the truth, and be ure to ay no more, then what he could jutifie. She, with an incredible impudence, repeated all, that before he had told unto his Wife, and farther told him, that if he would not believe her, let him finde out any Midwife, o he were one that was unknown to me, and let him receive the truth from her report. Leontidas thought this to be a good way & the next morning he ent for one. It hapned o, as that day her Niece, by her command, was in my place in bed; and to keep my Nure for taking any notice of what he intended to do, he ent for her unto her Chamber, under pretence of ome earnet buinee with her, o as there was none in my Chamber of any judgment; and o Leriana going in with the Midwife, and having fully intructed her Niece what he hould ay, he went unto her, and aid: Madam I promied to bring one unto you, who would adminiter ome comfort unto you; I have now kept my word. Ormanthe, in a low voice, anwered, that he was very welcome. Are you pleaed, Madam, aid the Midwife, that I hould ee in what condition you are in? Yes, aid Ormanthe. Then he put her hand into the bed, and upon her belly, and did uch things as are uuall upon uch occaions: and as fortune was, the Child tirred, o as the pains of Labour were preently upon the poor Wench; and in lee then two houres, he was, without any noie, or any in the Room that could take any notice, brought to bed. Leriana eeing things fall out o well according to her deigne, he ent the two Maids who were in the Chamber upon two everall errands, and o was alone in the Chamber; he caued her Niece within an houre after to rie, and in the mean while, they held the little Child unto the fire. Then to compleat her treaon, he, with the Midwife, carried it tark naked unto Leontidas, being very deirous that every one hould ee it as he went out of my Chamber and Lodgings: I heard it cry into my Cloet where I was, but never mitruting any uch villany, I would not be diverted from my ad thoughts. She addreed her elf firt unto the Wife of Leontidas, and this tetimony, together with the Midwife, did give her uch aurance, as he did believe it, and Leontidas alo. But the better to cover her treaon, he beeeched the Lady to content her elfe with my Etate, and that if he would be pleaed to pare my life, he was confident, conidering the fault I had committed, that I would be willing to cloiter up my elfe all the ret of my daies, amongt the Druides Daughters or Vetalls:
and that this would be acceptable unto god, to ave my life, and not to tain o noble a Family as mine with an act o infamous. That though my fault was great yet he could not forget the affection he once did bear unto me, as long as I did behave my elfe as I ought; and therefore he could not chue but make this requet. The Wife of Leontidas having no deigne upon my life, but only upon my Etate, did conent unto it; but Leontidas himelfe, being a man of honour, was long before he could conent unto it: But at lat the importunities of his Wife, together with the diembling tears of Leriana, and the remembrance of his obligations unto my Father; all thee did o work with him, as they both commanded Leriana to perwade me, unto what he had propoed.

But this not being the deigne of this devillih woman, he deired them firt to let ome daies pae, and beeeched Leontidas and his Wife, to let ome go with her, to ee in what condition I was: Which they did, commanding an old Lady, and an old Cavalier, in whom they had good aurance, to wait upon Leriana. She, with the Midwife, after the Child was put to Nure, conducted them into my Chamber, went to my bed, and when he found me not in it, he eemed amazed; he turned up the clothes, and hewed them the ignes of a Woman in Child-bed; and faigning not to know where I was, did eek about for me, and at lat found me in my Cloet: She called them unto her, and hewed me unto them through the chincks of the dore. All this while I knew nothing, but was then laid down upon a little Couch, with my hand under my head, muing upon the mierable fate of Damon, o as they might eaily ee the ad thoughts of my heart by my face. This wicked wretch made them believe, that my being ill proceeded from my being newly brought to bed, which they, eeing my ad poture, did very eaily believe: And being thus deceived, they returned, and made their report unto Leontidas and his Wife. In the mean time, Leriana taying alone with the Midwife, did change the heets of my bed, and all things, that might give any knowledge of what had paed. Afterwards conjured the woman not to peak of it, but to oberve the time and the place very preciely; and then they went out of my Lodging. My Nure preently after returned, and finding nothing altered in my Chamber, did wonder at nothing, but not to ee Ormanthe in my bed; but, uppoing he had ome buinee, he made no great matter of it. Night being come, and the uuall time of my going to bed, I went into it, and lept till the morning, without any manner of imagination of thee things. In the mean time, Leriana had invented trange Meages and Orations in my name, telling Leontidas and his Wife that I did mot humbly beeech them to have pitty upon me; that I did acknowledge my life to be in their hands; that I did wholly give my elfe unto them, and that I deired no more, but to be hut up in ome retired place, where none could ee me; that as oon as I was able to tir abroad, I would come and beg pardon for the fault which I had committed, and deire leave to equeter my elfe from the world. To be briefe, wie Shepheardees, this hellih woman did o well manage her wickednee, that ix weeks paed thus on. In the mean time, Ormanthe was o well recovered, as if he were a Maid again, and o, as none could imagine he had been with Child, but was fairer then before. Leriana had o well intructed her, that when I asked her, why he went away without telling me? he anwered, That he durt not knock at my dore for fear of diturbance, and that when he went, he thought, that he hould not have tayed away above two or three daies at the mot, and o thought to have returned, before I hould take notice he was gone, though her buinee with her Aunt did keep her longer. I received her excue, and only told her, that he might well have asked leave.

Things being in this condition, Leriana feared nothing now, but the being convinced of a lie, and therefore reolved to execute her malicious deigne. She had two Coen germans which were Souldiers, and had gotten the reputation of the mot valiant Blades in all the Court of Torrimond; moreover, they were poor, and had no other hopes, but in being Heires unto Leriana's etate. She, intending to make ue of their valour did oblige them both by preents, and by giving them freh hopes of her Etate; which did tie them o unto her, that he could not command any thing which they would not execute. After he had made her elfe ure of them, he began to change her tale with Leontidas and his Wife, telling them, that I took courage; that I did not now think any more of leaving the World, but that I had quite forgotten my duty unto them. To be briefe, within a few daies after, he told them, that now there was nothing to be hoped from me, but by force, and that I did deny all; and in aying o, he eemed to be o much offended at me, as he confeed, I was not worthy of that favour which they would hew me. And becaue the
Wie of Leontidas gaped till after my Etate, he asked her, how he could convince me? We have, aid he, very good witnees; but, though we had not, yet ince truth is on our ide, I have ome that will maintain it by Armes againt any whooever hall maintain the contrary: And you know, Madam, that uch things as are dubious, and cannot be made apparent by convincing proofes, the truth of them is to be tryed by Armes. Leontidas, who was a peron of honour, and who began to be very angry at the craft which he conceived I ued: No, no, aid he, I am very certain he is in a fault; it hall be my elfe who will accue her, and I will maintain it againt all men whomoever. Leriana, who had made her elfe ure of her two Coen-germans and who above all deired to eem very affectionate unto Leontidas, he turned towards his Wife: Madam, aid he unto her, I had rather die, than my Lord hould enter into Armes upon this occaion; I beeech you divert him from it, or ele I protet I will meddle no more in the matter: I have Leotaris, my Couen german, and his Brother, who will undertake the charge; and indeed it is mot fit they hould, for it is not handome to beg the Etate of one, whom he doth accue. Leontidas perited in his will; but his Wife would by no means ee him in o much danger, and thinking it not handome he hould be my accuer, and at the ame time beg my Etate of the King, he o prevailed with him, that he referred it unto the Kinmen of this woman. This being the reolution, Leriana pake unto Leotaris, promied him her Etate, made an aurance of it by Writing; and briefly, o obliged him and his Brother, as they would have attempted either againt heaven or hell; and, right or wrong, would arme themelves againt me. Leriana being aured on this ide, backed by the opinion of very many, and alo with the authority of Leontidas, he preented her elfe before the King, accued me, offered to prove her accuation, and ett forth the buinee o colourably, as every one believed it to be true: And let Therander hould dicover all her wicked devices and forgeries, he made him a party in the accuation, aying, he was the Father of the Child purpoely to diable his tetimony againt her.

The Queen, who was a Princee full of honour and vertue, did joyne her prayers with the accuation of this wicked woman, and did require I hould be punihed according to the rigour of the Law. Leontidas is called, who being ahamed of the buinee, made the ame requet. This act being to the dihonour of his family, his wife beeeched the Queen, to become a mediator for the Etate, which the King did freely grant: And yet this good Prince calling to memory, the good ervice which my Father had don Thierres his Father, he was very orry for this dyater. The firt newes I heard of all this, was, when the Officers of Jutice came to eize upon me locked up my Chamber and Cloet and carried me before the King, never telling me for what. Oh heavens, in what a cae was I in, when I heard the words of Leriana? it was long before I could peak; at lat, recollecting my elfe, I kneeled down before the Queen, beeeched her not to believe this wicked woman; I proteted unto her by all that is acred, there was no uch thing, that there could be no proofe againt my chatity, and beeeched her out of pitty to favour the caue of a mot innocent. The King was more moved at my words then the Queen; whether it was, becaue he remembered the ervices of my Father, or becaue my youth and face moved him to pitty; but o it was, that turning towards Leriana: If you do aver (aid he) any thing which is not true, I do vow by the oul of my Father, that you hall uffer the ame punihment which you have prepard for others. Sir, (aid he, with an impudent brow) I will prove what I ay, both by Witnees and by Armes. And both, aid the King, are allowed you. Then cauing us to be eparated, I was committed to afeguard, and Therander alo; and it was commanded that witnees hould be produced: Then the Midwife and the Nure of Ormanthe's Child, did tetifie their knowledge in the buinee; the old Cavalier and the old Matron of whom I poke, did the like; he produced everall witnees, who aw her go out of my Chamber with the Child. To be briefe, the proofes were uch, as if god had not preerved my innocency, I had been condemned. By fortune, the Judges being in my Chamber, and reading the Depoitions againt me, I knew not what to do in this affliction but only to have recoure unto the gods; and then, lifting up my hands and eyes to heaven, I prayed; Oh! ye mot omnipotent gods who do ee into my heart, and know, that I am innocent of all this which I am accued of, be my upporters, and declare my innocency. And then, as if inpired by ome good angell, I turned my elfe towards the chimney, and addreing my peech unto the Judges: If thee accuations (aid I unto them) be true. I beeech the gods that I may never breathe again; and if they be fal, I beeech them, that this hot coal may not burn me: Then preently tooping, I took up a
great coal of fire, and held it in my hand naked, till it was extinguihed, not being at all burned. The Judges amazed at this proof, would needs touch the coal, to try whether it was cold, but they quickly withdrew their hand; then they looked into my hand, to ee if there was any igne of burning, but they found it no more touched, then if it had never touched fire; you may imagine whether they were atonihed or no: But o it was, they made a report of this unto the King, who ordained, that Leriana hould be acquainted with it, to ee, if this tetimony of my innocence, would make her decline her accuation: But he alledged, that I had procured ome receipt, which kept the fire from burning me, and that her Witnees which he produced were without exception, and that this proofe by fire might perhaps have been allowed, if it had been ordained and appointed by the Judges; but, ince it proceeded from my own will, it was to be upected of much artifice. To be briefe, age Shepheardees, he moothed over her villany with o many colourable arguments of truth, as all the favour I could obtain from the King, was, to ordain, that the matter hould be tryed by Armes, and that within fifteen daies, we hould finde out the Cavaliers, which hould enter into the lits for us.

The newes of all this was quickly dipered throughout all Aquitain, o as my Mother heard of it as well as others; and becaue Leriana had produced o many Witnees, he believed, as almot all others did, that I had committed the fault whereof I was accued; and he having lived alwaies in great honour and ame, it grieved her o much, as he fell ick, and being old withall, he died within ten or twelve daies after he firt heard of it; but, in uch a bad opinion of me, as he would never end to ee me nor ait me in my jutification. And ee how many everall waies the gods were pleaed to afflict me; for, this grieved me more, then I am able to expree. Thus was I without Father or Mother, detitute of all friends, and univerally blamed by every one. I mut confee, I did many times intend to throw my elfe out of the window, to rid my elfe out of o many orrowes; but, till the gods preerved me in hopes that my innocency would at lat appear, putting into my minde, that if I hould die o, I hould leave all Aquitain in a bad opinion of me. But, when Leriana offered Leotaris and his Brother for her Champions, and when neither Therander nor I could name any, as well, becaue we were not prepared for it, as, becaue no man would enter into o bad a quarrell, as every one thought this was: I mut confee I was atonihed, and now more then ever grieved for poor Damon, auring my elfe, that had he been alive, I could not have wanted a Champion. Therander, on the other ide, he mut defend his caue by fighting, both with Leotaris and his Brother, one after another. But the terme being pat, the King in favour allowed us eight daies longer, and they being pat, he added three more: without any further delay, at the expiration of which, we were brought into the Lits, I all in mourning, and without any other company, but the Officers of jutice; and Leriana, on the contrary, all triumphant, and in the company of many Gallants; he was upon another Scaffold, oppoite to that where I was. Leotaris and his Brother were already in the Lits, armed Cap apé, and bravely mounted vaunting the more, becaue they believed to finde no Antagonit but Therander, for none ele could we finde, becaue Leontidas, who was the Kings favourit, did take Leriana's part; and thoe who heretofore had made addrees of Love unto me, and would have undertaken a hundred uch Combats for me, were now all cold and backward, becaue I had leighted them for Therander. Thus you may ee, a falhood is hardly to be known from truth, when it is ubtlely diguied with a handome gloe. At lat, Therander enters the Lits againt them both, hoping, that the jutice of his caue would bear him out. It was ordained by the Judges, that if during the Combat, any Cavalier would preent him elfe for me, he hould be received; and that Leotaris and his Brother, might fight with Therander, both together, or everally, if they would. Thee two Brothers were men of great courage, and perons of honour, o as they would undertake him one after another; but Leriana would not by any means uffer it, o as they ran both of them together againt him. Judge, age Shepheardees, in what a condition I was; I do aure you, that I was o much out of my elfe, as I could not ee any thing. I looked at. At lat, the command was given, and the Trumpets ounded. Therander, who was couragious enough, putting his confidence in the gods, and jutice of his caue, et purrs to his Hore, and with his Lance, hit the Brother of Leotaris, and doing him no hurt, brake it; but he himelfe at the ame time, was dimounted by two Lances, with the adle betwixt his legs. Leriana eeing o great an advantage on her ide, he was all joy; I, on the contrary, all fear. Therander eeing himelfe in this extremity, did not for all that loe his undertanding,
but running to his Hore, he pulled the bridle off from his head, before his Antagonits could return upon him: The Hore being of a high pirit, and finding himelfe without either bridle or adle, began to run up and down the place, and, as if the gods had inpired him, came to Leotaris and his Brother, and began to paw with his feet, and bite with his teeth, kicking and bounding, and did o fiercely aault them that they, in lieu of fighting with Therander, had enough to do to defend themelves from this Animal: This did amue them a while, becaue they could not kill him o oon as they did imagine becaue of his nimblence and perpetuall motion; but at the lat, they dipatched him, and being animated the more againt Therander, reolved to dipatch him alo preently; and therefore falling both upon him in the heat of their fury, he had no other way but to run cloe to his dead Hore, which lay gaping in the end of the Lits, and which did him ome ervice after his death; for the Hores of his enemies did boggle o at him, that their Riders could hardly come neer him, and this prolonged the Combat: At the lat, Leotaris eeing he could not get his Hore any neerer he alighted from him, and o did his Brother from his; and leaving their Hores both looe in the place, went both up to Therander, and fell upon him, who certainly did as much as one man could well do, but having to deal with two of the toutet Cavaliers in all Aquitain, at once, it was impoible for him to make any long reitance. He had received everall wounds, and lot o much blood, as he had not trength to defend himelfe any longer, when the gods, out of pitty unto me, did end a Cavalier, who deired entrance into the Lits, in defence of me and Therander: The dore was preently opened unto him; and becaue he aw Therander in great extremity, he purred his Hore furiouly up unto them; but when he was come neer, he tooped, and cryed out unto them; Hold Cavaliers, and do not any longer offend againt the Lawes of Chivalrie; come off that wounded man, and fall both upon me, who am ent hither purpoely to punih you. Leotaris and his Brother hearing his voice, did recoile, and were orry that they were both on foot, and therefore ran towards their Hores: But the tranger rid up to them, and told them, That if they had their Hores, they hould receive it as a courtey from him, and not from their own nimblenee. But get up, aid he, I corn to take the advantage of my Hore againt you. They both did infinitely eteem this generous act of this tranger; but I was very orry for it, conceiving, that he might very well have taken all advantages againt thoe, who had fallen both at once upon Therander. But this tranger had more noble thoughts, and would not let that which was blamable in others, be any example unto himelf. Whilt I was in thee thoughts, Leotaris and his Brother had both mounted themelves, who never conidering the courteie they had received, fell both at once upon him; but they found a tronger arme to deal with, then Theranders. I cannot, age Shepheardees, particularize this Combat unto you, for my fears were uch, as I hardly aw it; let it uffice I tell you, that this tranger hewed uch wonderfull trength and valour, that Leriana thought him a devill, and not a mortall man. After they had fought a while, I perceived, that though he was ingle, yet he had the advantage of them. As for Therander, he was o weak, as he was not able to rie. But this tranger, to the wonder of all the pectators, did give the Brother of Leotaris uch a fatall blow, that he truck his head from his houlders. Leotaris eeing this, his fury welled with revenge: But the tranger, having now to do with no more but him, did wound him in o many places, that he was o weak with the loe of blood, as he fell from his Hore to the ground, and falling with his head foremot, the weight of his body and his armes broke his neck. The tranger alighting from his hore, and eeing him dead, he went unto Therander, helped him to rie, and et him upon one of the Hores of his enemies; and then taking his own, he addreed himelfe unto the Judges, and aked them, if he had any more to do? And they anwering, No: Then he required that I hould be et at liberty, which was commanded that very minute. Then he came unto me, and asked me, if he could do me any further ervice? Yes, Sir, aid I unto him, in two things; the one, to conduct me home, and recue me from the tyranny of thoe, who have ravihed me from my dearet Mother; and the other is, that I may know the name of him, unto whom I owe both my life and my honour. As for my name (anwered he) I hall take it as a favour, if you will not force me to make it known; And as for waiting upon you, unto the place where you deire to be, I hall do it, o it may be preently.

Whilt things went thus on my ide in this place, the gods did evidence, that they never forake the innocent; for it hapned, that my poor Nure, having not o much courage as to ee me die, and thinking it impoible, that Therander could maintain it out againt two
uch Cavaliers, he tayed in my Chamber, crying and making mot lamentable moan. Ormanthe, who had received all the courteies he could deire, both from her and me, was exceedingly moved at it, and being very imple without any ubtlety, he could not chue but tell her, how her Aunt alwaies aured her, that I hould not die, but only deired, that I hould be beholding unto her for my life, to the end, I hould be a better friend unto her. Ah! weetheart, aid the Nure, it is mot certain our Mitree mut die, if Therander be overcome, the King himelfe, according to the Lawes, cannot ave her. Alas, alas, aid Ormanthe, hall my Lady be burned? Nay, nay, aid my Nure, it is too ure. Ah me! mot mierable wretch that I am, replyed the Wench, how can I ever expect that the gods will pardon me for her death? Why, aid my Nure, are you any waies guilty of her death? Oh Mother! aid Ormanthe, if you will promie me to tell no body, I will tell you a trange accident. And my Nure promiing ecreie, he told her, that it was he who had the Child, and told her all that I have related unto you. Sweetheart, weetheart, aid my Nure preently, let us go preently and ave her life; believe it, the gods will be well pleaed with it; and moreover I will undertake, you hall have what you will of my Lady. Thus was the truth dicovered.
The Wench followed my Nure, who, to be briefe, addreed herelfe to the Queen, and acquainted her with the whole buinee, whilt the tranger was talking unto me.

The wickednee of Leriana being thus dicovered, both by Armes, and the confeion of this Wench, the King commanded, he hould be burned in the ame fire that was prepared for me; though he did inveigh againt her Niece, aying, That my Nure had uborned her, and that he was not of age to be a competent Witnee, epecially againt her above all others, becaue he had chid and chatized her for thee vices. But all thee allegations were invalid, the truth was evident enough, by the particulars and circumtances which this Wench did peak of, and by the report of the Midwife, who confeed, that he never aw her face. Every one began to clap their hands and the people eeing the villany of Leriana, began to throw tones at her. The King commanded jutice hould be executed, and he eeing her elfe ready to be throwne into the fire, being much moved at the memory of all her wickednee, he confeed the truth; he deired audience, declared all her wicked practices, asked me pardon, and then voluntarily threw her elfe into the fire, where he ended her daies, to the contentment of all thoe, who heard of her wicked and malicious waies.

Whilt thee things were thus in agitation, the Cavalier who had delivered me, deiring not to be known (as it is thought) retired himelfe, and none took notice which way; and I not finding him, was extreamly grieved, he hould depart with o few thanks for what he had done: I ued all the means I poibly could to hear of him; but after all enquiry, all I could hear, was the next morning from a Country man, who met him, and whom he deired to come unto me from him, and let me know, that had he not been urged by extream importancy, he would have tayed longer, and waited upon me whither I had commanded him; but he had promied ome aitance to a Lady, who lived towards the Town of Gergovia; and that if I had any more ervice to command him, I might hear of him at the Golden Mount; and that he might be known, he would not change the Device which was upon his Shield. Then asking the man, what it was, becaue I was o atonihed the day before, that I took no notice of it? He told me, that it was a Tiger feeding upon the Heart of an Human body, with this Motto, Thou givet me a Death, and I maintain thy Life.

Now, dicreet Shepheardees, to abridge my tory, it was ordered, that I hould be free from the Guardianhip of Leontidas, becaue his Wife had begged my Etate, and be et clearly at liberty. The poor illy Ormanthe, ince he was only educed by the ubtlety of her Aunt, he was hut up in one of thoe houes deigned for uch punihments, where the women there do live very well, only they mut never come out. I hall now make a trange relation unto you: I did till love Damon mot extreamly, and the memory of him ince his death was o imprinted in my oul, that he was commonly alwaies before my eyes: But ince this accident, and ince I aw this trange Cavalier, I know not how, but I began to change my firt affection, and placed it upon him; and though I never aw his face, yet, I mut confee, I love him, o as it may be aid, I was in love with a face of Armour: I know not whether my obligation to him was the caue of it, or whether his valour and courage, and noble minde, forced me unto it; but o it is, I never loved any ince that day, but this unknown Cavalier; and in tetimony of it, after a long expectance
of his return, and hearing no newes of him, I reolved to go my elfe unto Gergovea, and the Golden Mount: After I had conulted with my elfe about this deigne, I acquainted Therander with it, who offered me all his aitance; and I addreed my elfe unto him, rather then unto any other, becaue ince the day he fought for me, he had wholly dedicated himelfe unto my ervice; and becaue I had often heard him ay, that he was infinitely deirous to know that valiant Cavalier, who had o bravely relieved us. I gave out therefore, that I would go and viit my Etate; I prepared my Train, I left the Court, and came to my own houe, where leaving all my retinue, I took with me only my Nure for a companion, and Therander to defend me, and o etforwards towards the Golden Mount. The Country was extreamly rough and mountainous, almot never without now and ice; my poor Nure dyed there, and having interred her, I was much grieved to be alone with Therander; but I preently met with Tircis, Hylas, and Laonice, whoe company pleaed me o much, that, not to loe it, I reolved to put on the habit of a Shepheardee, as now you ee me, and Therander in the habit of a Shepheard. Then after we had tayed a while amongt the Mountains, in hopes to hear ome newes of him I was in quet of, I reolved to come into this Country, ince he appointed us to make that way, thinking, that when I came to Gergovea, I hould haply finde this Cavalier, unto whom I was o much obliged.

Madonthe was thus telling her tory, and not without bedewing her cheeks with tears, whilt Paris and the ret of the hepheards were talking together; for their mindes were poeed with that malady, which above all others is an enemy to leep. For Tircis, he loved his deceaed Cleon, although he was out of all hopes of ever eeing her again. And becaue there was none of them o free as the incontant Hylas, he bore it out the bet of any in the company, and was leat troubled with his Love. Tircis, thinking upon his dear Cleon, he could not chue but igh very loud, and Silvander at the ame time did the ame. See, aid Hylas, what difference there is betwixt thee two ighes. What is the difference, aid Paris? The difference is, aid Hylas, that Silvander doth igh o, to cool the fire which corcheth him; and Tircis ighes and blowes, to kindle that fire which heretofore did corch him. Hylas had aid very well, aid Tircis, if he had aid, he had thought o; for this is only a meer imagination of a oul that knowes not how to love. How now, Tircis, aid Hylas, do you alo upbraid me, that I know not how to love? I thought there had been none but that fantaticall Silvander, who had been of that opinion. If you would judge according to reaon, aid Tircis, you would be of our opinions. Why, aid Hylas, is it requiite, that to love well, I mut needs Idolize one that's dead, as you do? Did you but know how to love, aright, (aid Tircis) quetionlee, if you hould meet with o great a misfortune as mine, you would think your elfe obliged in duty o to do. How, how, aid Hylas, in love with a Grave, a Coffin? believe it, hepheard, I will never be in love with any uch Mitrees: But, come a little to reaon, what contentment, and what end do you aime at in uch a love? Love, aid Tircis, is a great god, which can aime at or deire nothing but himelf; he is his own Center, and has no aime or inclination, but what begins and ends in himelfe: Love is like a Ring, it begins where it ends, and ends where it begins; it is perpetuall, it aimes at no ends, but is pleaed and contented with its own nature. Thee are delicate dreames indeed, aid Hylas; for my part, I believe them to be all fables, invented by ome illy women. What is it, Hylas, (aid Tircis) which you think o far from truth? All that you ay, anwered Hylas, is o palpably groe, as I were mad if I did not ee the implicity of them.

You ay, Love deires nothing but it elfe, and I ay, we ee the contrary; for we never deire any thing, but that which we have not. If you did undertand, anwered Tircis, how by the infinite power of Love, two perons becomes but one, you would know, that a Lover can deire nothing but himelfe; for as oon as you do undertand, how a Lover is transformed into the peron Loved, and the peron Loved into the Lover, and both becomes but one, though being Lover and Loved they are two, you would finde, Hylas, and confee, that ince the Lover deires nothing but the peron Loved, and ince he is himelfe both the Lover and the Loved by this conjunction, he can deire nothing but himelfe. See, aid Hylas, how the old Proverb is truly verified, one Errour begets a hundred. You would perwade me into a beliefe of things impoible, as, that the Lover becomes the peron Loved: why, by this argument, I am Phillis, for I do love her, and yet I am Hylas, and I do deire her. The concluion, aid Silvander, is not good, for you do not love her: Had you aid, that I, in loving Diana, were transformed into her, you had
aid right. Well, aid Hylas, are you then Diana? is your Cap there changed into a Coyfe, and your Coat into a Gown? My Cap, aid Silvander, does not love her Coife. Very good (aid the incontant Hylas) if you be changed into Diana, you hould then dree your elfe in the habit of a woman: It is not handome, that o wie a hepheardee as you are, hould diguie your elfe thus in the habit of a man. There was none in all the company could forbear laughing at the pleaant expreions of this merry hepheard; Silvander himelfe could not hold: But afterwards, he anwered him thus: I will, if I can, convince you of your errour: Know therefore, that there are two parts in a man, the one is the Body, which we ee and touch, and the other is the oul, which we cannot ee nor touch, but is known by words and actions; for neither words nor actions are parts of the Body, but of the Soul, which makes ue of the Body only as an intrument and organ; for the body does not ee of it elfe, nor undertand, it is the Soul which does it; and o by conequence, when we do love, it is not the Body which loves, but the Soul; and o it is only the Soul which transformes it elfe into the peron Loved, and not the Body. But, aid Hylas, I do love the Body as well as the Soul; and o, if a Lover be changed into the thing Loved, my Soul hould be changed as well into the Body of Phillis, as into her Soul This aid Silvander, does thwart the Lawes of Nature; for a Soul, which is pirituall, cannot become a Body, no more then a Body can become a Soul. If it be o, aid Hylas, that the change be but in part, and that part be the Soul, it is that part which I do leat care for. In this, aid Silvander, you do make it evidently appear, that you do not love; or at leat, that you do love againt reaon: For the Soul ought not to debae it elfe, unto that which is interiour unto it elfe; and therefore they ay, that Love ought to be betwixt equalls; that is a Soul to love a Soul, which is its equall, and not the Body which is its inferiour, and which Nature gave him only as an intrument. Now to make it appear, that the Lover becomes the party Loved, and that if you do love Phillis, Hylas is Phillis; and if Phillis love Hylas, Phillis is Hylas, conider what the Soul is; It does conit, Shepheard, of the Will, the Memory, and of the Undertanding: Now Philoophers do hold, that we can love only that, which we do know; and if the knowledge, and the thing known, be one and the ame thing, it mut conequently follow, that the knowledge of him who Loves, and her who is loved, is the ame. That if the Will of a Lover, ought not to differ from the Will of the peron Loved, and if he do eek her by his thoughts, which is onely an effect of the Memory, as well as by his corporeall eyes, who can doubt, but that the Memory, the Undertanding and the Will, being changed into the peron loved, his Soul, which conits of thee three faculties, is changed alo. By Tautates (aid Hylas) you fetch it very high; and though I have been long a Student in the Mailian Schooles, yet I cannot reach you. It was there, aid Silvander, where I learned this Philoophy. Though you have puzzled my brains with your dicoure, aid Hylas,, yet you cannot demontrate unto me, that a Lover is changed into the Loved, ince there is one part left out, which is the Body. The Body, aid Silvander, is not a part, but only an organ or intrument of the Soul; and if the Soul of Phillis were eparated from her Body, would it not be aid, there is the Body of Phillis, and not Phillis her elfe? And if that be properly poken, then it mut be undertood that Phillis is omewhere ele; and if you do love aright, it is into that Phillis into which you hould be transformed; o as if this be o, you can have no deire out of your elfe: for, compriing all your love in your elfe, you do alo comprize all your deires within your elfe. If it be o, (aid Hylas) that the Body is but the intrument, which Phillis maketh ue of, I will give you that Phillis, and let me have the ret, and ee whether you or I hall be better contented. But to end all our differences, it were good if we could get a little leep. Upon this, he was ilent, and would not give any further anwer: Alo all the Company by little and little fell aleep, except Silvander, whoe oul being welled with abundance of reall affection, he could not cloe his eye of a long time after.

In the mean time, Madonthe, as I told you before, had related the tory of her fortune unto thee fair hepheardees; and becaue a great part of the night was already pent, leep did by degrees teal into the eyes of Phillis, and her: But Atrea, who could not leep, till talked with Diana, who for her part, eeing how extreamly Silvander loved her, he began alo to love him, although her affection to him did inenibly begin, he not taking any notice of it: At the firt, it was no more, then a meer acknowledgment of his merit, (o requiite is Knowledge before Love) and afterwards, ordinary converation with him, did win her to a liking of his company; at lat, his addrees unto her, with o
much reverence and dicretion, made her love him; yet without any deigne or intention o to do. Atrea, who entertained the ame thoughts of Celadon, not being in dipoe to leep, and eeing Phillis and Madouthe both fat, alo thinking that none could hear her, he poke thus unto Diana: Siter, I mut confee, that one imprudent act doth draw many orrowes after it, and when one fault is once committed, it requires abundance of widome to repair it. Conider, I beeech you, how this crime which I committed againt the affection of Celadon, hath hurried me into a ea of orrowes; I do verily believe, that as long as I live, nay, and after my death too, if the dead have any knowledge of pat actions as I believe they have, I hall never ceae my grief, for my offending againt the fidelity of Celadon; yet, you ee unto what a pae this fault hath brought me: This love, which with o much paines and care I have o long kept ecret, and would hardly acquaint my dearet companions with it; ee, I ay, how I do at this houre my elfe dicover it unto trangers, who are not any waies in the world obliged unto me. Ah! could I recall that happinee which I have lot, me-thinks I could manage it with more prudence. Siter, aid Diana, all human imbecillity hath this property, that the malady can very hardly be known untill it be preent; the gods themelves only will be eteemed perfect and wie: And you mut think, that if the loe of Celadon which you caued, had not fallen out that way, doubtlee it had ome other; for, there is nothing firme and truly olid amongt men. I cannot ay, but perfect prudence may a litle foreee, and mitigate thee accidents; but believe me, Siter, we mut know withall, that we are all but human, and full of imperfections. You ee, anwered Atrea, how ome do pae their lives: more weetly than others, or at the leat, their actions are not een or known unto the world; and I need not go any further for an intance, then in your misfortune in Philander; but who can blame you for it? Ah Siter! aid Diana, there is no harper reproofes of our faults, then the knowledge that we our elves have of them. It is very true, aid Atrea, but you mut needs confee, that as any good which we do enjoy; is better and greater for being known; o alo the orrowes and pains, when they are known, are far more bitter and marting: And hence it is, that every one trives to hide and conceal the afflictions which befall them, and oftentimes had rather they were greater and ecret, then lee and publick. Now, Siter, there is one thing, which my affection to you prompts me to advertie you of, unto which me thinks your prudence ought to apply ome remedies; and I am ure, if before my misfortune did befall me, I had met with a friend who had freely poken unto me, I hould not have been o adly ahamed as I am. Siter, aid Diana, this is a great argument of your good affection to me; and you will infinitely oblige me, if not only now, but alwaies, you will tell me your opinion of all my actions, freely, and clearly, and epecially now, when all are aleep.

Although thee two Shepheardees did think, that none did hear them, yet they were deceived; for Laonice, who was in the company, although he eemed to be aleep, yet he was awake; and being extreamly deirous to hear more, that he might, according to her deigne do them a dipleaure, he litened with a mot attentive ear. On the other ide, Silvander eeing all his company aleep, and hearing the heph eardees talking, he thought that he heard the voice of Diana; and having an itching deire to hear their dicoure, he tole o gently neer them upon his hands and knees, as he could hear them very ditinctly; and by fortune, he came jut as Atrea did begin to ay thus.

Do you remember what I aid unto you yeterday in you ear, when Silvander diputed with Phillis? Was it not (aid Diana) concerning the affection of that hepheard towards me? The very ame, anwered Atrea; and be pleaed to undertand, that ince, I have dicovered it more plainly by the dicoure which I have had with him, and you may mot infallibly expect a mot extream and violent affection from him: If this affection be dipleaing unto you, it is requiite you keep him at a ditance from you, though I cannot tell whether that will do any good, ince his humour is of uch a nature, as the more it is croed, the more violent it will grow; but if it be pleaing unto you, it is mot requiite you ue abundance of dicretion, that it may not be known unto any but your elfe. Siter, (aid Diana, after he had a while conidered upon it) I ee you make your love unto me mot evidently appear, and will keep any thing ecret which I hall ay; I will therefore open my very heart unto you, but with a hearty deire, that what e're I hall ay may go no further, no, not to Phillis her elfe, if it be no offence to the friendhip that is betwixt you. I hould think, anwered Atrea, my elfe unworthy of your love, if I hould impart any ecret which you hall trut me withall, unto any other; nay, I hould think my elfe
to be a mot horrid Traitor: And as for Phillis, be confident, Siter, that as I would not do any act which might wound that affection I bear unto her, o he hall never make me offend againt the love I have vowed unto you. Not that I have any diffidence in the dicretion of Phillis, (aid Diana) but becaue I would, if I could, hide it from my own elfe. Upon this, he paued a while, and then continued: When I lot Philander, (as, Siter, I have told you) I was o exceedingly grieved at it, that for a long time after, I reolved never to love any again, but to pend all the ret of my mourning daies in an eternall widowhood: For, though Philander was not my Husband, yet I do verily believe he had been, if he had urvived Philidas. In this reolution, I may mot afely and truely protet unto you, I have lived hitherto, o inenible of any love, as if I had neither any eyes or ears, to ee or hear any motion that was preented unto me in that kinde; Amidor, kinman unto Philidas, can tetifie as much, who, though of a wavering humour, had parts ufficient to make himelfe loved, and who before he married Alf • runte, did often offer to take me upon what conditions oever I hould require: Witnee alo the poor Nicander; I call him poor, becaue of the trange coure which he took after my refuall. To be briefe, witnee all thoe, who ince that day have made addrees of love unto me. The memory of Philander has unto this very day o defended me againt all others, as I have not had o much as any thought of love. But I mut needs confee, that ince the faigned addree of Silvander, I perceived my elfe much changed: I know, this hepheard at the firt, did only court me for a wager; and yet as oon as he began, his addrees did pleae me. On the contrary, the generous Paris did very really love me, and quitted the grandure of his quality for my ake and yet for all his merits, I could finde in my elfe no other love unto him, then that of a Siter unto a Brother. To finde out the reaon of all this, is a thing impoible, but yet it is mot certainly true. Now, Siter, if I do ay, that I do love Silvander after another manner, mitake me not; do not think that I am in love with him, but that I do reent the very ame beginings, which I remember I reented at the beginning of my affection unto Philander. I beeech you, Siter, (aid Atrea unto her) what is it which pleaeth you bet in him? Firt, (aid Diana) I perceive, he never loved any before; and this cannot be attributed unto any tupidity of his undertanding, ince he does plainly evidence the contrary by his dicoure: Then he does o handomely ubmit himelfe, and gives me uch an abolute power over his will, as he never peaks a word, but he fears the offending me. Then again, there is a continued and contant dicretion in all the actions of his life, you hal never ee him either too much or too little in any thing he does: and latly, which is the prime caue of my amity, I do think him to be an honet, plain, open-hearted man, and without vice. I do aure you, Siter, (aid Atrea) I do oberve the ame qualities to be in this hepheard; and for my part, I do think, that if ever the heavens do detinate you to love any, you will be very happy in him. But let me tell you, that if you will avoid dipleaures, you mut ue all your prudence. I do wonder, Siter, aid Diana, why you hould ue this expreion unto me; for know, that though I do love him better then any other I ever aw, ince the loe of Philander; yet, I would not have him to know it, or that I have any intention to let him erve me; and that if he hould be o bold, as to declare it unto me, I do aure him, I would treat him o, as he hould never dare to peak of it twice unto me. But, Siter, aid Atrea, what is then your intention? To punih us both, anwered Diana; I mean to chatie him for his preumption in loving me, and alo to punih my elfe, for my fault in liking him, to the end, we may both be more jut, and better advied. But, Siter, aid Atrea, this deigne in my apprehenion is very pernicious; for by this, you bring your elfe no atisfaction, but much orrow, and perhaps extream hame. Take heed, let in holding a flint, you trike fire, if you trike it againt any thing which is harder, and o the hidden fire dicover it elfe. Young pirits and hearts, if they do love well, and if they be prudent, they will dicreetly hide their affections, and not dicloe them unto any of their acquaintance; but, when they are trucken, I mean, when they are rigorouly ued, then they are o tranported with their paions, as it is impoible they hould diemble. And this, believe it, cannot be without abundance of vexation and orrow, in the oul of her that is concerned; for, on which ide oever the reports go, they cannot be advantagious to the woman. Your widome, Siter, does enable you, to give very good counell unto any other; but the wiet eyes are often blinde in their own cae: And this invites me to ask you, Whether do you love this hepheard? or you do not love him? for if you love him not, then break off all manner of conference, and all correpondency with him, and o entirely and peedily,
that he may not have one park of any hopes from you: And in this, do not flatter your elfe and ay, that a woman cannot help it, if men will needs love her, no more then he can hinder them from looking upon her; this is an excue to fool ome illy peron withall: For, at the very firt, the fire mut be quenched, all hopes mut be taken from him, not in part, but totally and entirely. If there be found ometimes ome opinionative and obtinate man, it is only for a few daies; for certainly, Love, no more then all other Mortalls, cannot live without nutriment, and the proper nutriment of Love, is Hope. But then, if you do love, as you ay, and as indeed he deerves, then, Siter, me thinks it is a great folly, to deprive your elfe of that which pleaeth you. Siter, aid Diana, that which pleaeth is not alwaies honourable, nor reaonable; and ince they are not, vertue commands us to hun them; and, for my part, I had rather die, than do otherwie. I make no quetion of it, anwered Atrea, for I am mot confident of Diana's vertue. But pray let us ee whether this act be contrary unto reaon or honour. Is it any way in the world contrary to reaon, to love a generous, wie, handome, and dicreet Shepheard? For my part, it eemes unto me o full of reaon, as I can ee no contrariety in it. Now any thing that is reaonable, cannot be dihonourable; and ince it is not, why hould you not love him? It is an eay matter to conclude in the advantage of this hepheard, aid Diana, as long as none does contradict it; but to argue thus: Is it reaonable that Diana, who hath ever held a good repatation amongt the hepheards and hepheardees of this Country, hould marry an unknown hepheard? one, who has nothing but himelfe, and what his ingennity acquires? I believe you will decline from your firt opinion upon this conideration: And upon this caue, I am fully reolved to uffer his addrees and affection no longer, then I can faigne and eem not to believe it: But, if be hould bring me to that pae, as I could not umbrage my elfe under this hadow, I do protet I will preently dicard him and never permit him to ee me; or, if he did either ee me, or peak to me, or love me, I will treat him in uch a manner, as he hall believe me in good earnet, and, I think love me no longer. And what will you your elfe do, aid Atrea, in the mean time? Doubtlee I will love him, anwered Diana, and I will punih my elfe for my offence in o doing. I do foreee, aid Atrea, that this vain Chimera will afford you but fale contentment, and that this deigne will beget in you many a mortall dipleaure.

Whilt thee hepheardees were thus dicouring, and thinking that none did hear them, Laonice was o attentive, that not to loe one yllable of what was aid, he durt hardly breathe, for, there was nothing which he did o paionately deire, as to dicover this which he heard. But Silvander was ravihed, and when he heard at the beginning thoe favourable expreions of Diana, Oh! how happy did he think himelfe? Afterwards, when he heard the counell which Atrea gave her, and how he took his part, how much did he think himelfe obliged? But when at lat, he heard Diana's dire reolution: Oh heavens! in what a dump was his oul mother'd? It was well for him, that thee hepheardees had a dipoition to leep, otherwie it had been impoible, but he hould have dicovered himelfe to be there, by ome of his deep and groaning ighes; for, he could not obtain o much of himelfe, as to go further and igh at eae, o deirous was he to hear the end of their dicoure; and therefore I ay, it was well for him, that after they had bid goodnight unto each other, they preently fell aleep; for then he retired, and went to his companions, looking whether any of them were awake; and finding them to be all fat aleep, he began to entertain his own thoughts, and lifting up his eyes, he contemplated upon the Stars, and the various Chimaeraes which were formed in the Clouds; but he found none amongt them o various as his own thoughts, upon the dicoure which he had heard, buying his knowledge, that Diana loved him, very dear, making a doubt, whether he was more obliged to his curioity, which let him know he loved him, or diobliged unto it, for hearing that cruell reolution which he had taken. This imagination held a long debate in his oul: At lat, Love, out of very pitty, cloed his eyes, and uffered him to fall aleep.

But now it is full time to return unto Celadon, whom we have long left in his Cell, without any company but his own thoughts, which had no other ubject for themelves, but his pat happinee, and his preent miery. Fifteen or ixteen daies paed thus on, with o little care of his life, that orrowes nourihed him more, then any other thing which he eat: All his delight was in his imaginations in which he paed away his daies and nights, which were all one to him, ince being o ditant from the eyes of Atrea, all eemed dark. There was not one paage in all his life which came not then into his memory;
and to his miery, he alwaies tayed longet upon thoe, that were mot ad, as mot uitable to his preent condition: If at any time he had any more pleaing, he preently gave them a check, as not eaonable for o ad a oul, to ee any contentment. Thus pending his time in uch ad exercies, and his food being very bad, his countenance was o altered, as it was not knowable; and certainly he could not have lived long, if the heavens, (who perhaps reerved him for ome better fortune) had not ent him ome conolation.

The ame day that he ecaped out of Galathea's hands, by the help of Adamas, Silvia, and Leonida, Galathea was contrained to wait upon her Mother unto Marcelles, becaue of ome publick ceremonies of joy which they were to perform, for the happy uccee which Clidaman had in the Army of the Francs. But when he came there, and heard that Celadon was ecaped, he was in uch a fury againt Leonida, that he forbid her to come into her preence: This fair Nymph being weary of the Courts noie, he retired to the houe of her Uncle Adamas, who was as tender of her, as if he had been his own Daughter, as well by reaon of Conanguinity, as becaue he was recommended unto him by Belizar his Brother, before his death. And though he lot all hopes from her pat ervices, yet, he was very glad to recover her liberty at that rate; but much more, in hopes to ee Celadon again, uppoing he would be near Atrea; and though he believed, his affection unto Atrea would dah all her hopes in him, yet he thought it would be a mot pleaing atisfaction unto her, to pend all her time neer him: And therefore finding Paris to be very well dipoed unto uch a viit, about ome two daies after he came unto her Uncles, they went both together unto the Townes where thee hepheardees frequented; but when he came there, and enquired of Celadon, and heard that he was not yet returned, but that they all believed him to be dead, he was extreamly atonihed: However, in atisfaction of Paris, who was an adorer of Diana, and in pleaing her elfe with their good company; he was a frequent viitant, and grew into uch familiarity with thee hepheardees, that they did infinitely love her, and he them, and lived with them as if he were a hepheardee, with which kinde of life, he was o pleaed, that he would often go unto them with Paris, and it being not above a mile betwixt both their habitations, he would often go by her elfe; and the way was o pleaant, by reaon of the delectable River of Lignon, and the delightfull Groves which he went through, as it was impoible he hould be weary. It hapned then, that reolving one day to go alone, he paed over the Bridge, and walking along the River ide; though there was no path, yet the way was delightome, by reaon of the pleaure he took in looking at the fihes, which flocked by troopes unto the River ide; and o delighting her elfe along the water ide, he came unawares unto the Fountain, where Celadon ued to gather his VVater-Crees, which was his food. As fortune was, that hepheard being laid down, was fallen aleep a little before. When the Nymph firt pied him, he took him for Lycidas, becaue thoe two Brothers were both of a tature and proportion, and ued to habit themelves both alike; and though Celadon was a little bigger, and had a more full and pleaing face, yet comming neerer him, he was mitaken, as well, becaue he thought Celadon was not in that Country, as, becaue his face was much changed; or ele becaue he thought, that Lycidas being full of jealouie, as he knew he was, might very well be retired from all company into that olitary place: And therefore he ett her elf down by Celadon, thinking him to be Lycidas; but eeing he did not wake, he reolved to go on her voyage, and leave him to his ret: but before he roe, he epied a little bag, wherein he was wont to keep his Letters, which hung a little out of his pocket; he gently took them, without any diturbance to his leep, and after this piece of theft, he went away, leaving the hepheard aleep, who preently after awaked; and becaue the Sun began to be hot, he went for hade unto the thicket part of the Wood: But the memory of his hepheardee being the Center of all his thoughts, he opened a little Cae which he wore about his neck, in which was the Picture of Atrea; and after he had a while contemplated it, he read thee words, which formerly he had written upon the ide of it.
div.q: VVanting the Subtance, Shaddowes comfort me.
div.p:
Alas poor mierable Celadon, aid he, how cant thou now ay, that being deprived of the true good, the fale ones hould comfort thee? The good thou hat is meerly imaginary, and the true good is ravihed from thee, by her who is the owner of it. Afterwards looking eriouly upon the Picture, and peaking unto it, as if to Atrea her elfe: Is it poible
Oh my fairet Shepheardee, (aid he) that I hould thus dipleae you? But is it poible, that having dipleaed you, I hould yet live? If I did dipleae, it is abolutely impoible that it hould be with my will; nor is it poible, I hould deire to live after uch a crime. If he would have me live, Oh! why does he banih me from that place in which I can only live? And if he would have me die, why does he not poitively command it? But alas, what more expree command can I expect, then her command never to come into her preence? She knowes, that the ight of her is my life; and in forbidding me to ee her, does he not command me to die? This, doubtlee, were enough to make me eek a death, did I not know, how that which is reaonable in the judgment of others, is without any hadow of reaon in her. All others think it a thing mot jut, to love thoe that love her, and that amity ought to be rewarded with amity; but he thinks it reaonable, to hate thoe who do love and adore her. Why then hould I not think, that this command of living from her, is rather to make me live and uffer the more, then to abridge my pain by an anticipated death? But that cannot be it which he requires of me; for he knowes well enough, that I am not able to live o. Did he ever demand of me any proofes, but uch as are impoible? witnee this command from her own mouth, and thoe Letters, by which he commanded me to counterfeit affection unto another. Then hutting up that dear Picture to read thoe Letters which he had ent him: Well, aid he ince I mut not live to my own contentment, I will live to her glory. Then putting up the little cae into his breat, he put his hand into his pocket, to take the Letters which were in a little bag, but when he could not finde them, he turned out all that he had in both his pockets, and not yet finding them, he went to his Cave, thinking that he had left them there; but not finding them neither, there was not a tut in all the Cave, nor betwixt the Cave and the Fountain, nor between the fountain, and all the places he had been at that day, but he turned it over and over; nay, not a leaf which was likely to hide them, but he ought under it; o vexed was he at the loe, and o deirous was he to finde them: For, as thee Letters were infinitely dear unto him, as being written by the fair hand of his dearet hepheardee; o he loved them, as the witnees of his fidelity, and as the weetet entertainment that he had in the mierable life which he led. At lat, eeing all his laborious quet to be in vain, and that there was no hopes of finding thee beloved Letters: Alas, alas, (aid he, lifting his eyes up to heaven) what unjut Daemon hath ravihed from me that little remnant of contentment which I had? for a Daemon certainly it mut needs be, ince no mortall ever ueth to come hither; or if they did, they would never have been o cruell. Well, well, Celadon, aid he, yet thou art happy in this thy mierable life, though thou hat lot thoe happy tetimonies of thy pat felicity; comfort thy elfe in thy loe, and render thanks unto heaven, that hath made thee o conformable unto the will of thy dearet hepheardee, and make it appear, that neither her rigour, nor the force of Fate, can ever make thee weary in obeying her, nor ever eparate thee from the thoughts of her; it is but it, that ince thou hat lot her good-will, thou houldet alo loe all manner of conolation.

In the mean time, Leonida rejoyced very much in her Larcenie, and having got a good ditance from this hepheard, he opened the little bag which contained thee Letters, which he believed had been written by the hand of Phillis; and being out of meaure deirous to ee into the ecrets of that hepheardee, he poured them out into her lap, and the firt which he light upon, was this.

body.head: Atrea's Letter unto Celadon.
body.p: THat you do love me, I believe, and you may know it by this, that I am well pleaed you hould give me aurance of it. If you have as much undertanding, as you have reentment of Love, you may know, that I do love you; by my permitting you to tell me, that you do love me: And by this, you may aure your elfe, that you have from me as much, as it eemes you wih to make you happy. If after this declaration you are not contented, I hall ay, that you do not love Atrea, ince Amitie ought to deire nothing, but Amity again.

div.p:
When Leonida aw the name of Atrea, he topped, and lifting the paper neerer her eyes, he read that word two or three times over. At lat, remembring the jealouie that had been betwixt Celadon, Lycidas, Atrea, and Phillis, he believed, that perhaps it was
not ill grounded, but that Atrea did love Lycidas; and therefore lapping it up, he put it in her boome, and took another, which he found to be thus written.

body.head: Atrea's Letter unto Celadon.
body.p: MUt it not needs be now confeed, that I do love you more then you love me, ince I have ent you my Picture, and could never obtain yours by all my prayers? But, Love is jut in it, ince he knowes, that he alwaies ought to help thoe, that are in greatet neceity. The faintnee of your affection hath more need of uch a remembrancer, than mine hath. Receive it therefore as a tetimony of your own fault. But, what do you think of me, Celadon? Can you believe, I love you, and yet doubt of your affection? No, no, I do but feat, Shepheard; for, had I that opinion of you, I would not deire, you hould have that beliefe in me, and therefore never doubt it; but be mot certainly aured, that as long as I make it appear, that I have a memory of you, I do think my elfe truly loved by my Son.

div.p: Surely (aid Leonida, extreamly atonihed) Lycidas has found thee Letters, amongt ome of his Brothers things, after his death; me-thinks if it had been o, he hould not have carried them about him, for fear of loing. Then he took another, which he found thus written.

body.head: Atrea's Letter unto Celadon
body.p: IT eemes, my Son, that you have lee courage then I have: You ay, that it is a igne, that I do love the lee, but ee how I prove the contrary: That which makes me urport all the mieries which I endure for your ake, is certainly the affection which I bear unto you. Now that affection which makes me urmount the greatet mieries, mut needs be great; and therefore this courage which you blame in me, is a mark of my great affection. Never be tartled at the threats of our common Enemies (for o, Celadon, I call call them, and not Parents) if you will have me think your affection equall unto mine; which, for your ake, does not only urmount, but corn, all manner of mieries and afflictions.

div.p:
Leonida read this Letter, not well knowing what he did: Now he began to upect, that it was Celadon and not Lycidas; and much more, when he remembered, that Galathea had poken to her of ome uch Letters. Oh heavens! aid he, certainly it is Celadon: Where was my eyes, that I could not know him when I aw him? Then he lapped up the Letters, and went with all peed unto the Fountain, where he left him; but extreamly angry he was with her elfe, when he found him not there, and broke into many expreions of griefe: Then he turned about every way, to ee if he could finde any relicks of him; but he was retired into his Cave, after his long and laborious earch, for what he had tolne. At the lat, Love, which is alwaies very circumpect, prompted her to take notice, that the grae about the Fountain was troden, and that there was a new Path, not halfe beaten; he imagined very aptly, that this Path would conduct her to the place where the hepheard was: And indeed, Celadon uing to pae between his Cave and that place, had made a kinde of a Path. Leonida then taking it for her guide; he had not followed it foure or five hundred paces, but he came to the Rock, where Celadon made his retreat; yet, the trees and buhes being very thick about it, he was afraid to approach neer, let it hould prove the den of ome Wolfe or wilde Boar, or at the leat, of many Serpents. As he was tanding thus in upence, he thought that he heard him breathe, which aured her, that ome was there; but knowing, that Serpents do ometimes hie in the ame manner, he therefore trode very circumpectly and cautiouly, and o oftly, that Celadon never perceived her: And though he did afterwards make ome noie, yet the hepheard was o attentive upon his own thoughts, that he took no notice of her. Now he was got o neer the entrance, that he heard him breathe plainly, and ometimes peak, yet he could not undertand the words; but comming a little neer, and putting her head a little into the entrance, he heard him ay thus: Now heart begin to hope well; for, as the nuffe of the Lamp ceaeth to burn, when the flame hath conumed all the Oyle; o may I hope my mieries will ceae,
having by little and little conumed all the comforts and contentments that I have. Oh happy loe! how I would cherih thee, if by thy means, I go out of this mierable life which I lead? Oh my dearet Papers! how I would blee the day on which you were ravihed from me, if my grieving for your loe would end <> ? For, alas! there is no hopes left, that my orrowes hould ever end, but with my life. Leonida hearing this, was moved with much compaion knowing him now to be Celadon; and was alo urpried with uch a udden joy, that though he had a great deire to let him complain on, and hearken longer what he aid; yet, he was contrained to go to him with open armes, and cry unto him: Ah Celadon, away with thee lamentations and orrowes, you have had too many of them; 'tis time now to change your coure of life, and enjoy ome pleaant dayes. You may eaily imagine, that Celadon was extreamly urpried, when he heard this voice upon a udden, and eeing her come unto him, for he had not een any of a long time; and his pirits being wholly retired into his thoughts, he had poken all this, before he heard or knew what he aid. He tarted up upon a udden, but the life which he had lived, and bad food together, had o weakened him, that he was contrained to it down again preently. Then the Nymph gave him leaure to recollect himelfe, and itting down by him, took him by the hand.

Well Celadon, (aid he unto him) did you o impatiently deire to get out of Galathea's hands, only to live thus? Is it poible, our company hould be o dipleaing to you, that you had rather be amongt enlee Rocks and wild Woods? The Shepheard having recollected his pirits, did faintly anwer: You ee, fair Leonida, unto what Love hath brought me, and what power you have over thoe that love you. How is it poible, aid he, that Love hould make you thus neglect your own preervation? Is it poible, anwered the hepheard, that you, who vaunts to know what Love is, hould doubt, but that my affection can endure the greatet extremities? However, replyed the Nymph, if I were condemned to die, I would at the leat ask him that condemned me, the reaon why I am condemned. What better reaon can be given, aid Celadon, then that he, who has the overaigne power over me, will have it o? o as the reaon of my ill-being is, becaue my well-being dipleaeth her. Oh Celadon! (aid the Nymph, and pittyed him) in what a mierable condition you are? See, age Nymph, aid he, how you are mitaken, I cannot deire more happinee, then the miery which I endure; for, can I wih a greater happinee, then to pleae her? If my miery pleae her can I grieve for it? No, no, I mut rejoyce at whatoever is pleaing unto her. Oh happy Celadon (aid he) and in one thing the more happy, that Atrea does not know that thou art happy. Leonida hearing thee expreions, tood atonihed, and looked upon him with admiration: At lat, after he had been a long while mute, he aid unto him: I mut needs confee, hepheard, that if this be the way to love, there is only you amongt all men living, that can follow it. But, hepheard, take heed, that as many good things are corrupted and poiled with abue, o your melancholy and obtinacy do not corrupt your affection. I care not for all the accidents that can come, aid the hepheard, o my Love be not offended. But, aid Leonida, do you love Atrea? You aske me a quetion, anwered he, unto which you are able to give an anwer your elfe. If you do love her, (aid the Nymph) you ought to love all that's hers, and if o, then you ought to love your elfe, ince you are o entirely hers, that you are not your own. Since I do love Atrea, replyed the hepheard, I ought to hate all that he hates: Atrea hates the mierable Celadon, why then, fair Nymph, hould not I? Every one, aid he, is obliged, to have a greater care of their own preervation, then of the love or hatred of any other. That Law, aid the hepheard, is good and allowable amongt Men, but not amongt Lovers. Why, aid the Nymph, do they ceae to be Men, when they become Lovers? If you do mean a man, aid he, that is ubject unto all orts of mieries and inquiotudes, I do confee, that a Lover remaines a Man till; but, if that Man have any will of his own, and judges of things as they are, and not according to the opinion of another I deny, that a Lover is a man, ince as oon as ever he becomes a Lover, he does o dipoee himelfe of his will and judgment, as he neither willeth nor judgeth, but as he willeth and judgeth whom he loves. Oh, the mierable condition of a Lover! (aid the Nymph). But much more mierable (anwered the hepheard) is he, that loves not, ince he cannot enjoy the mot perfect and highet happinee, that the world affords; for, the very leat of Loves joyes, does exceed all others that the world hath without it.
