Is there any pleaure comparable unto thoe, that conit in the thought? When a Lover thinks upon the beauty of her that he loves; nay, when he does but remember any one of
her actions, nay, even the very place where he lat aw her; do you think he would change his contentment, for any diverion in the whole Univere? He is o jealous, and o carefull to entertain this very thought, that let he hould make any a harer with him, he will retire into the mot olitary and unfrequented places, that he can finde; he cares not for the ociety of men, or all the delights that men can devie, and ue to court with uch care, o he may but enjoy his own thoughts. Now, Leonida, ince the contentment of thoughts are uch, is it poible, the weaknee of any human heart hould think to endure o much blie, as to enjoy the ight of her whom he loves, to hear her peak, to kie her hand, to hear her own mouth pronounce the word, I love you? Is it poible he hould hear this, and not be ravihed, and be diordered with too much felicity and delight? I do not mention thoe great and lat aurances, which one receives when he is loved, nor thoe languihments in the breat of the peron loved; for, thee are contentments of o high a nature, as they cannot be guted without tranport, and abolute ravihment out of our elves, nor can they be expreed by any words, unlee imperfectly. Now tell me, fair Nymph, whether the condition of a Lover be o mierable now, I ay, when you know what high felicities he does enjoy? I do confee, (aid the Nymph, after he had heard him with admiration) that Celadon does love, if to love be, to be out of his wits, and to live only upon bare thoughts. Alas! I cannot chue but think his condition extreamly mierable, in finding uch contentments in uch vain imaginations and Chimeraes; and I am o far from thinking them felicities, as my opinion of the contrary is much fortified. But Shepheard, let us leave this dicoure, ince I ee it will do you no good, and tell me, how you have lived ince I left you? Wie Nymph, anwered Celadon, as I have lived ince you met me, o have I lived ince I parted from you; for, as oon as ever I left you, I hut my elfe up in this place, expecting untill either Love or Death releaed me. But why, Celadon, aid he, do you not go unto your own Town, where your friends and kindred do o much grieve for you? Atrea, aid he, who has a far greater power over me, than either any Parents or friends, hath forbidden me ever to ee her, untill he command; and therefore, as I told you, I have hut my elfe up in this Cell, untill either Love or Death releae me. But, if my adored Shepheardee had commanded me never to ee her again, doubtlee I had hut my elfe up in my grave with death: And as oon as I came to my elfe again, after my fall into the River, I knew, that Lignon would not give me a death, becaue he did not peremptorily command it; but, remembering her words, and that her banihment of me was not for ever, only untill he commanded me to return, I have lived in this manner as you ee, expecting till Love recall me, as it eemes he hath promied; or ele untill death do it for her, which hall be welcome unto me in this life which I live. But poor deceived hepheard, replyed the Nymph, how can you ever hope he hould recall you, as long as he is ignorant where you are? Love, anwered he, which conducted me hither, knowes the place well enough where I am, and does daily viit me; and ince it is by it, that I do hope he will recall me, there is no doubt, but it will without me let her know the place, unto which it hath conducted me. If your imaginations, replyed the Nymph, had an influence upon others, as they have upon your elfe, all this you ay might perhaps be; but believe it, hepheard, the gods will never help thoe, who will not help themelves; and do not think, that I peak without good reaon, for I am very certain, that if Atrea did know you were alive, he would paionately deire your company. How fair Nymph, (aid he preently) do you know that? I know it, aid he, by that adnee which its in her face. Perhaps, aid the hepheard, that proceeds from ome other caue. But where have you een her ince we parted? I hall be very glad, aid he, to entertain you with a dicoure upon this ubject, and to relate unto you all that hath hapned ince we parted, o I can but by it cheer you a little up, and roue you out of this dull kinde of life. Believe it (aid Celadon) that the ight of you does bring me more content, then any thing in the world could, except Atrea; and ince I am deprived of her, your dicoure will be very pleaing unto me. Then Leonida began thus.

div.head: The Hitory of Galathea.
div.p:
SInce, Celadon, you do deire to know, how I have lived ince I parted from you, which is ome fifteen or ixteen daies ince, I will very willingly make a relation of it unto you, upon a condition that if you be weary with the length of the dicoure, we may
break it off, and finih it another time, when any convenient opportunity hall preent it elfe. Know therefore, that in my return from conducting you, I came into the Palace of Ioures, at the ame time when Amais was taking Coach, to go unto Marcelies, and carrying Galathea with her; becaue being deirous to render thanks unto Heius, for the happy uccee of her Son Clidaman, which he had in the Battle againt the Neutrians, he would by all means have Galathea with her, purpoely to render the olemnity more celebrated. And becaue retardment in uch actions as thee, does in ome ort reemble oblivion; and oblivion, ingratitude; he departed o oon, that he carcely gave the Nymph time to tell us what we hould do with you; and though he was extreamly troubled at it, yet he durt not let it appear, let Amais hould take notice of it, who alwaies held her by the hand, not out of any upition, but only the more to carrae her. he being thus contrained to go with her into the Coach, all that he could do, was to ay thus unto me: You, Silvia, and Lucinde, come after us in my Coach, and follow us with all the hate you can. I made a low reverence, and hewed by my actions, that I did undertand what he aid; but I did not intend to obey her, becaue my aimes were only upon you: And though I did well enough foreee her anger, yet, I preferred the good office which I intended to you, above it, chuing rather to fail in my duty to that Nymph, then in my affection to you. However, faigning as if my going out were in obedience to my Uncle, I met Silvia, who was in quet of me, and I told her, how you was ecaped, whilt none took any notice of you. But I was never in all my life o urpried, as when in my return from you, I met Amais and Galathea, as they were taking Coach; for, I had been utterly undone, if they had pied me out of the dores. But I did addree my elfe unto my Uncle and Silvia: Father, aid I unto him, and miled, and you my dear Companion, you mut needs both of you help me out in this buinee. Daughter, anwered Adamas, never fear any blame for what you have done, as long as it is but what you ought to do, nor ever grieve upon uch occaions; the gods, upon whom all events depend, are o jut, as they will ever bear you out; and if at any time the contrary eem to happen, take peciall notice, Daughter, that it is to redouble the contentment, and as if they hapned only to augment your joyes. And becaue it is very expedient, you endeavour to preerve your elfe in the favour of your Mitree, Silvia hall tetifie, that you did not any thing, but what he knowes of very well; and to make the matter more eaie for you, I am contented, that you hall both of you have ome upition of me; for, I hall not be orry that he hould think, that I do hate any thing which is contrary unto vertue: and I would permit you to charge me down-right with the act, but that it is neceary I hould be omething in her eteem, only to draw her off from thoe foolih and fale imaginations, which Climanthes hath infued into her. With uch dicoure as this, my Uncle did encourage us to continue in this laudable deigne: Afterwards he went homewards, and we towards Marcelles; but firt conulted together, what Anwers hould be given unto Galathea, let we hould contradict one another, knowing very well, that no eye is o quick and penetrating, as the eye of Jealouie. In the mean time, Galathea's minde was only on her dear Lucinde, commending my wit and ubtlety in putting you into that habit, hoping, that under that hadow, he might without any upition have you alwaies with her; not, hepheard, that he had ever any unchat or unworthy thoughts, but deigning to marry you, and not daring to declare it as long as Amais lived, he thought he might alwaies have you in her preence under that umbrage. And though he could not doubt of the affection which you had unto the fair Atrea, yet flattering her elfe he hoped, that the ight of o much grandore and magnificence, would eaily withdraw your love from that hepheardee; o as hugging her elfe in thee thoughts, he was the mot contented woman in the world, and nothing eemed tedious into her, but the length of the way: But, when he came to Marcelles, and did not ee her dearly beloved Lucinde amongt the ret of her Nymphs, Oh! how he was diordered? and what hate did he make in going to her Chamber, and from her Chamber into her Cloet? I, who plainly foreaw this torme, did follow her, but not with that alacrity as uuall; and I mut needs confee, that being in ome ort guilty of treaon, I did fear her preence; and yet, let he hould upect me, as oon as he did call, I ran unto her, and commanding me to hut the dore: Well Leonida, (aid he unto me) what's become of Celadon? Madam, (aid I unto her, eeming much atonihed and dipleaed) I cannot tell; for, as oon as ever you were gone, Silvia and I looked for him all over the Palace, and not finding him, we cannot devie what hould become of him, unlee Adamas can tell us. How's this, (aid
Galathea, urpried at this unexpected anwer) do you know no more of him? And eeing I did not anwer: Did not I command you, aid he, to have extraordinary care of him? Am I no better obeyed than thus? Go, go, Leonida, go immediately to your Uncle; if Celadon be there, bring him hither, or otherwie, never come again into my preence; and aure your elfe, I hall make you fell the mart of this offence, as well as my elfe. Seeing her o angry, and fearing, that replies would but aggravate, I made her a low and humble reverence, I went away, to acquaint my Companions with it. Silvia not being far off, followed me out of the Chamber, and I acquainted her with all the dicoure of Galathea, and how he commanded me to retire. I knew, aid Silvia, that it was impoible this buinee hould end, without making her extreamly angry; but I hould have imagined any thing, rather than this coure he hath taken: What will every one think of your departure? How can he hide it from Amais? Well, my dear Companion, (aid he unto me) I ee, all the blame is laid upon you, though I have equally contributed to the ame fault, (if that which we have done deerve not praie) but ince it is o, I hall ue all my bet endeavours, to have you recalled as oon as poible: In the mean time, if any enquire of me the caue of your abence, I hall ay, That Adamas deired Galathea, to let you be with him for a certain time, in hopes that ome affection may grow betwixt his Son Paris and you; and I hall ay this as a ecret, to the end it may make the lee noie in the world. After this, we kied, and recommended each other to the tuition of the gods: And o I went unto my Uncle, unto whom I related the whole paage.

In the mean while, Galathea being alone in her Cloet, and eeing all her hopes, and all her deignes blated, he was o urpried with orrow, as he laid her elfe down upon a green Bed, and could carcely breathe: At lat, he tarted up with a deep igh, and cating her eyes upon a great Glae which was over againt her, he aw the tears that trickled down her cheeks: Alas, alas, Galathea, aid he, what is thy Beauty worth, which hath caued o many Idolaters, ince it is not able to captivate him, whom thou mot deiret to pleae? a poor depiable Shepheard depieth it. Am I not the mot unfortunate woman in the world, ince a mean and ungratefull Shepheardee is able to do more then I am? Oh! how pleaing and weet were my deignes, at the firt; and at the lat, how bitter and vexatious are they all turned? Then being ilent for a while, he broke out again: But is it poible, Celadon, thou houldt not love me? Can I no way wean thy affection from a illy hepheardee? Can a rutick country Beauty have a greater influence upon thee than mine? Has the heavens, to torment me, made thee o pleaing and o illy? She had continued longer in thee exclamations, had not Silvia knocked at the dore, and acquainted her, that Amais her Mother was comming to ee her. She preently drying up her tears as well as he could, and lying down upon the bed, he put a handkerchiefe over her face, feigning to be aleep; and therefore Silvia went to meet Amais at the dore, and acquainted her, how Galathea was not well, telling her, that he thought her dieae to be nothing but a little head-ach, which a little ret would cure. Amais did eaily believe it, when going neerer Galathea, he aw her face red, and burn like fire. The Nymph, at the comming of her Mother, eemed as if he were aleep, and tarting up, did her reverence unto her; and holding her hand before the eyes, he confirmed what Silvia had aid. Amais advied her to go into bed, and to ret that night, that he might be better dipoed to be a pectator of the publick Bone-fires of joy, which were to be made, and lat two or three daies. After this, he retired, purpoely to give her the more time of ret. Galathea was very glad of this excue to be along; and when all was gone out of her Chamber he undreed her elfe, and went to bed, uffering none to be in the Chamber but Silvia, whom he commanded to tay by the bed ide, that he might near if he called. Silvia, who knew her dieae, prepared her elf with remedies accordingly; but he was mitaken, for the Nymph tayed untill it was night, and never gave one word, expecting that Silvia hould firt begin. At lat, when it was upper time: Go Silvia, aid he, go to upper, and end ome other in you room; as for me, I will not eate any thing. Madam, anwered Silvia, I beeech you give me leave to tay with you; for, my meat will not do me any good, as long as you are not well. Sweet-heart, aid the Nymph, I thank you, and believe it, I take you good-will unto me very kindely, in pite of the ingratitude which I finde in others. But tell me freely and ingenuouly, I intreat you (aid he, and drew the Curtains) did you ever oberve, that Leonida helped Celadon to ecape? Madam anwered Silvia if he did, I mut needs ay, he is the mot ubtle woman that ever lived, for he never tirred one tep without me; and if you will be pleaed to let me tell you
what I think, I will aure you, Madam, that if any helped him to ecape, it was Adamas; for I oberved, that as oon as ever you were et at dinner, he took Celadon apart, and talked with him very paionately a long time. Moreover, I oberved, that after you were gone, when he aw us earching all about, and much troubled, he miled two or three times and told us, that it had been well, if Celadon had never come there. How, aid Galathea, is it o then, that Leonida never conented unto it? Madam, (anwered Silvia, very dicreetly) I will not wear he is innocent, but I dare wear, that I think he is not; and that if any be to blame, beides that ungratefull hepheard, it is Adamas. Do not tell me thus, aid he, to excue your Companion; I know that you are very good, but had he any advantage over you, he would make ue of it againt you; he is the craftiet and mot jealous, that ever I aw of all thoe that are about me, and epecially when I peak of you. Madam, anwered Silvia, the conideration of any of my Companions, hall never make me fail in the duty which I do owe unto you; and as for their envie and jealouie, it hall never make me tart or recoile from my well wihes unto Leonida; for I believe that if he did not love you, he would never be jealous of any that comes about you. Sweet-heart, aid Galathea, and kiing her, I do finde you o dicreet for your age, as for your ake, I will recall Leonida, whom I have forbid my houe; but with this intention, that you hall be alwaies neeret unto me, and unto you I will impart all my ecrets; your young years hath hitherto kept me omething reerved from you, but now I finde, that though you be young in years, yet you are old in widome and dicretion: and therefore from henceforth keep as near me as you can; and though I do not call you, yet enter freely into what place oever I am, for I would have it o. And to the end Leonida hould think her elfe obilged unto you, end her word what you have done for her, and bid her return. Madam, (anwered Silvia, and making low reverence) the honour which you do me is o great, that I hall never forget it, and hall not think, that any merits of my own, but only your free goodnee, did invite you to do me this honour; I hall receive it as the greatet bleing: of heaven, and do vow, Madam, that I will never fail in that fidelity, which is owing unto your ervice, more then I will in my duty to the gods themelves. And as concerning Leonida, would it not be expedient, that you tayed untill the day of publick joy, when Adamas will be there, to the end, you may eem as if you remitted the offence for his ake? But, weet-heart, anwered he it is Adamas that I am angry withall, for it is he that hath offended me. Madam, replyed Silvia, give me leave to tell you, what counell my Mother gave unto me when I left her: Daughter, (aid he unto me) whenoever any of your Companions does you any injury, remember that you never hew as if you wihed them any ill, untill you have found the means how to be revenged; for, if you do it at another eaon, and hew teeth before you be able to bite, it will but exaperate them the more againt you. So, Madam, you hould not hew your elfe dipleaed at Adamas, untill you can make him reent your dipleaure, let when he ees himelfe out of your favour, he hould either ay or do omething, that may more dipleae you. Thus by the prudence of this Nymph, Galathea's anger againt me, was partly mitigated, and he reolved to make no hew of any dipleaure to my Uncle, untill times changed; of which, Silvia did preently advertie me, to the end, Adamas might be at the Feats, which Amais prepared.

But in the mean time, Polemas was not without abundance of vexation; for he aw, that by every Letter which came from the Army, L • ndamor was highly extolled, and the Trumpet of Fame ounded his name louder then any's ele, and thereby extreamly ecliped the glory of his Rivall; But that which vexed him to the heart, was, The Impoture of Climanthes did not operate unto his advantage, and not knowing what was become of him, he was the mot blanked man that ever was, yet, though he did daily ee the Nymph, and often talk with her, he never eemed to take any notice of it; o as one day as Galathea was talking with him, to try whether what I had told her concerning the tratagem of Polemas and Climanthes was true, he eemed to know o little concerning it, that the Nymph believed, I had invented all thoe tricks to the advantage of Lindamor, as I heard ince by the report of Silvia, to whom Galathea imparted every thing.

However, I lived a life in the mean time not diagreeable to my minde, had I had the happinee which now I have, of eeing you. For, Celadon, you mut know, that Paris is o extreamly in Love with Diana, as he, quitting his former garb, is now in the habit of a hepheard, and affects no exercies, but uch as belongs to them. Do you mean that Diana, (aid Celadon) which is Daughter unto the wie Belinde? The ame, anwered
the Nymph. I aure you, aid the hepheard, he is one of the fairet, the wiet, and mot accomplihed hepheardees, that I know, and one who deerves a good fortune; and I pray unto Tautates, that he may enjoy all the good fortune in the world. I am of your opinion, aid the Nymph; but I do not believe, that he will marry Paris, for he has told me, that truly he does love and honour him, that he knowes what an honour it is he hould make any addrees unto her, and what a great advantage uch a Match would be to her; but yet, though he knowes not why he cannot love him otherwie then as a Brother, and that though he knowes him to be a man of great merit, yet he can love him no otherwie. How, (aid Celadon, and interrupted her) does he peak of thee things o familiarly unto you? I aure you, I think it very trange, when I remember her humour, which was wont to be o reerved and cloe, even from her bet beloved Companions, Atrea and Phillis, that they knew very little of her intentions. Oh hepheard! (anwered the Nymph) there is great alterations within this three or foure Months, ince you have been there; for Atrea, Diana, and Phillis are all one, they are alwaies together; and ince your uppoed loe, Diana may be aid to ucceed in your room. Moreover, if you remember Silvander, whom they called, the Shepheard without affection, he is now o deeply in love, that except Celadon, none is comparable to him; and it came thus to pae: Phillis and he fell into ome difference concerning their merits; and becaue that hepheard, being educated in the Mailian Schooles, and having an excellent acute wit, did produce better and more valid reaons, then that hepheardee could, he, out of a pleaant humour, propounded, that Silvander, to give a tetimony of his merits, hould court and erve Diana with as much obequious obervance, as if he did really love her. The hepheard accepted of the propoition, upon condition, that Phillis hould be contrained to do the ame. After much dicuion, Atrea, Diana, and I, did ordain, that both of them hould court and erve the ame hepheardee, and that at the three months end, that hepheardee hould judge, which of them two had mot merits to make themelves loved. This being thus reolved, Diana was made choice of to be their Mitree; o as ince this time, Phillis hath acted a paionate part o very well, as no hepheard could better acquit himelfe. Now, ee what is the iue of this fiction, Silvander, who, as I told you, was all inenibility, is become by his counterfeiting o deperately in love with Diana, as every one does plainly ee that he goes farther then the bounds of a iction; and I know, that Diana will give her judgment on his ide; for, though he is a hepheardee of great modety and widome, yet it is well enough known, that this courthip does not dipleae her; and for my part, I mut confee, that I know no hepheard, except Celadon, who is more worthy to be loved. And becaue of this faigned courthip, Phillis is almot continually with Diana, and Silvander leaves her as eldome as poibly he can. Lycidas, your Brother, thinks, that there is a matter of Love betwixt Phillis and Silvander, and is o fully perwaded of it, as he is o jealous, that he cannot endure they hould be together. And ince Phillis cannot banih her elfe from the company of Atrea, and ince Diana is alwaies with Atrea, and Silvander with Diana, poor Lycidas, not being able to endure it, never ees Phillis, unlee at uch meetings when he cannot avoid it. This is a great alteration indeed (anwered the ad Celadon) and I mut confee they are all much to be pittyed, epecially Lycidas, who is fallen into the very wort dieae of Love; but I do not think it trange, for I know, the nature of my Brothers temper was alwaies apt to take uch impreions: For my part, I mut protet, that we are not Brothers in that: I cannot deny, but that I was once jealous, but I think it is, becaue all Lovers are once in their lives ubject unto it, as they ay little Children are, of a certain dangerous malady, which never comes unto them but once. Phillis alo is to blame, who, having given o many aurances of her good-will unto Lycidas, will uffer him to enter into any doubt of her affection; but I do believe, that he knowing this jealouie of my Brother does proceed from an excee of Love, he uffers it with more patience. As for Silvander and Diana, I mut confee, it is impoible, that two ubjects for love hould be more equally met; for, as Diana does urpae Silvander in Beauty and Etate, o the vertue and merits of the hepheard, do equally ballance the Scales: Yet, I do infinitely pitty them both, for I know them mot abolute Maters of themelves and actions; but now I know by experience, into what a Chaos of confuion and troubles they are plunged o as I mut needs pitty them, for making uch a diadvantageous change. Thus, wie Nymph, we may ee, that there is no aured happinees amongt mortalls. Celadon, anwered the Nymph, you would be Tautates himelfe, if you could perwade them, that they are not much happier
then before; nay, Silvander himelfe thinks o, whoe company is much more pleaant then it was wont to be, as I have heard from thoe who knew him before. For my part, aid Celadon, I am of that hepheards opinion; for, though there be ome pains in the life of Love, I pray tell me, in what kinde of life there is not o as well? But if you do conider thoe contentments which a Lover receives, in loving and being loved, I believe you will agree with me, that there is no happier life then that of Love. Ah Celadon! (aid the Nymph, with a great igh) how dearly are thoe contentments bought, I refer it unto your own elfe, if you would but ingenuouly confee your paion. Every one that loves, replyed Celadon, does not meet with Atrea's. But, aid Leonida, ince you are of this opinion, why do you ay, you pitty them? Becaue, anwered Celadon, as it is a pleaing thing to conquer, o the contrary, to be conquered; therefore I fear, that there being abundance of labour and pains to be taken in Love, let they hould be overcome or atonihed at the difficulties, and retire, before they have urmounted them. And therefore, have I not good reaon to pitty thoe, who I ee do enter into a danger, the iue whereof is o uncertain? But I do much wonder, how you hould know o much of Diana, whom I know to be alwaies the mot reerved and ecret of all our Shepheardees. The love of Paris, anwered he, is the caue of it, who hath made me ee her ofter then otherwie I hould. I had a good inclination of my own to go unto your Town, in hopes to finde you there; and when I was thinking upon ome good excue for it, I met with Paris, who, that night I returned, poke thus unto me: Siter, (aid he, for Adamas would have us call Brother and Siter) do you remember how much contentment we received that night, we lay in the Town of Atrea and Diana, and how pleaing their converation was? I, who knew very well he had been oft there ince, did anwer him thus: I do, Brother, aid I; but I do believe, you have a better memory then I, and, as I have heard, have better reaon. It is true, aid he unto me; and I cannot deny, but that the merits of thoe fair and dicreet Shepheardees, have much invited me to get their friendhip, and more then I make appear. Brother, aid he, you tell me more then I aske. 'Tis no matter, replyed he, and miled, I will ingenuouly tell any thing unto you, in hopes, that you will not deny me one requet that I hall make unto you, and which I do conjure you unto by our friendhip. Aske what you will Brother, (aid I unto him) for I cannot deny you any thing upon that conjuration. I beeech you then, (aid he) that ince you do not return unto Marcelles, you will be pleaed to walk ometimes upon the banks of Lignon, and pae away ome afternoones in the company of thoe fair and dicreet Shepheardees, and give me leave to wait upon you: you will think this place here to be very dull, having been accutomed o long to the Court; but the banks of Lignon have hades o cool and pleaant, as it is impoible you hould be weary: you shall ee the ilver treams o clear, and o filled with all orts of fishes, as you will admire; you shall hear all orts of Birds make the Woods Eccho, with a thouand varieties of voices; you shall finde uch clear, cool, and curious Fountains, as will invite you to drink of them. To be briefe (aid I unto him, and miled) we hall meet there the fairet and weetet Shepheardeses in all the Country. 'Tis very true, aid he, and I hope all thee will invite you to go thither. All thee invitations, aid I unto him, do not move me o much, as the deire you have of going thither; you are my Brother, and my friend, and under that notion I will fulfill whatoever you shall deire: But ince your deire is to ee thoe Shepheardees, I would gladly know which of them you love bet, I mean, Atrea or Diana. Siter, aid he, you are growne very inquiitive of late. I confee it, aid I unto him; but if you put me to ask the quetion twice, I will ay, you are grown very ecret of late; for even now, you told me more then I asked. But, Siter, aid he, which of them do you think I may in jutice addree my elfe unto? I undertand your meaning, aid I unto him; you think I will ay, Atrea, but, Brother, take heed, let Diana do not make your deires devour you. I protet unto you, Siter, aid he unto me, I would with all my heart be in danger to be devoured by my own Dogs, as Acteon was, upon condition, I had the happinee to ee this Diana naked Is it poible, aid I unto him, that you hould value your life o little? Nay, aid he, I eteem my life at a high rate; but I do eteem the ight of o much beauty infinitely higher, ince I mut die, and perhaps oon, before I can enjoy any contentment equall unto this; have I not reaon to venter it betimes, to enjoy o high a felicity whilt I may? For my part, anwered I, though I think thee deires a little too looe and extravagant, yet I will not blame you; but I am afraid, they will cot you much pain and orrow. I will venter that, aid he; but, Siter, tell me freely, will you, for my ake, become
a Shepheardee one houre in the day? How do you mean, (aid I unto him) would you have me take the habit of a Shepheardee, as you do of a Shepheard? No, no, aid he unto me, that would be too troubleome to you, and nothing conducing to my ends; I only deire you to be with thoe Shepheardeses, and let me accompany you. I hall do, Brother, what you would have me, aid I unto him; but take heed, this way do not prejudice your deigne; for in eeing Diana, under colour of keeping me company, he may perhaps think her elfe not obliged unto you for your viit. Diana, aid he unto me, is not a peron who inits upon uch ceremonious vanities, but is able out of her judgment to dicern my actions, and dicerning them, commend my dicretion.

This reolution then was fixed upon amongt us; and that very night, Paris told Adamas, that if he thought good of it, he would wait upon me the next day a hunting, and that I much deired it. Whitheroever he pleae, aid Adamas unto him; for uch was my love to her Father, as I can never ufficiently acquit my elfe of it unto his Daughter. This declaration did anwer the expectation of Paris, and therefore the next day, as oon as we had dined, we went down the Hill of Lacquier, and paing over the River Lignon, at Trelin Bridge, we followed the River-ide, untill we were over againt Boutreux, we left the Temple of the good goddee on the right hand, and came unto a little riing hill, from whence we might ee all the turnings and windings of Lignon, and the Plaines, where the Shepheards and Shepheardees did drive their Flocks to feed: Then, by a little path, we decended into the plain: See, Brother, aid I unto him, and pointed with my finger, yonder upon the right hand, is that tuft of Trees, where I firt aw Atrea, Diana, and Phillis; and had you been with me in Silvia's room, perhaps we had oberved more then we did; for, we being weary with walking, we fell aleep, and in the mean time, thee three hepheardees came, and at down cloe by us, and not pying us, doubtlee they did not it in ilence; but as ill-fortune was, when we awaked, they were gone. 'Tis true, that ince I came by my elfe, and it was then when you met me, and when I heard all the tory of Diana. Ah Siter, (aid he up on a udden) I remember the time very well; it was then when I began to love another above my elfe. But, Siter, I conjure and beeech you, by all obligations of friendhip, to tell me all that you know: Does he love any one? See, aid I, and miled, how jealous you are already? What did it concern you, if I knew more? Be contented, that I tell you what I think is requiite and neceary for you to know. Ah cruell Siter, aid he unto me, you ue me as they do Children, hew them an Apple, to make them the more deire it, and then not give it them. Lovers indeed, aid I, are little different from Children. But, Siter, aid he, can you not tell me, whether he loves me or no? It is more to be feared, that he will not love you, (aid I unto him) then that he will love any other. Although you threaten me extreamly, aid he, yet I am more glad of the aurance which you give me, that he loves no other; then I am orry for the doubt which you make, that he will not love me. Why, anwered I, will you not enjoy a good, if another have any hare with you? Before I can give you a full anwer, aid Paris, I mut make a long ditinction of Goods; but I will briefly tell you, that there are ome, which the more communicable they are, the better they are; and others, which are more to be eteemed, the lee they are communicable: and in this lat order, mut I rank the Goods of Love. I think, anwered I, that if I were in a capacity of loving, I hould be of the ame beliefe. But, let not this fear diminih the favours you receive; for you may be mot certainly aured, that thoe favoure you receive from her, (if ever you arrive at that Good) they will not be common.

Now, Celadon, I have made this long dicoure unto you, to the end you may judge, how deeply Paris is in Love. Now I hall tell you omething concerning Silvander and Lycidas. Walking thus down into the Plain, we epied Silvander, who itting under a Tree, was o intent unto the Muick of his Bag-pipe, as he took no notice how Diana, knowing his voice, tole gently behinde a Buh to hear him, and not be een; and Diana was o deirous to hear, that he did not ee Atrea and Phillis, who eeing her, and having the ame curioity, did teal on the other ide, uneen either by Diana or Silvander; but we were mot pleaed at Lycidas, who being upon a little Hill, looked upon Phillis, as he crept gently upon the ground, let Silvander hould ee her; for having an opinion, that the love which he bare unto that Shepheard, was the caue of her deire to hear him, he tood with croed armes, and eyes o fixed upon her, as if he were a Statue; I had not known him at that ditance, but for Paris, who aw him often. Now as we were walking down the Hill, we aw your Brother pul down his Hat upon a udden, and turning his
back upon his Shepheardes, he came tamping towards us, and never aw us; but till as he went, cratched his head, tamped upon the ground, truck himelfe upon the breat, and lifted his eyes often up to heaven. Thee paionate actions made us very deirous to hear what he aid, and therefore hiding our elves behinde a great Buh which was by the way ide, we took notice, that upon a uddian he fell down, as if he had been troubled with a fit of the falling icknes: We tole neerer and neerer unto him, untill we could hear him igh out a hundred ymptomes of jealouie, aying, That he had all the reaon in the world to be jealous, and that all oaths, and former aurances of affection, hould never perwade him to the contrary; but that he was jealous with judgment, ince he aw Phillis upon her knees before him he loved. Then after a hundred uch expreions, we aw him rie up, and look backward, to ee what Phillis did, and a little after, went neerer her, then returned again to the place from whence he came. He did not perceive us, becaue he was o totally taken up with his thoughts of Phillis, o as I think, if we had tood directly before his eyes, he could not have een us. We followed him; and when he had couched himelfe cloe by Phillis, we couched behinde him, and heard Silvander ing thee Veres.

lg.l: GRand Fabricator Love, the form hath laid,
And out of me another World hath made:
The Earth is my Fidelity, which tands
Immovable, by any mortall hands.
And as the World upon the Earth is founded,
So this, on my fidelity is grounded.
If any its of jealouie do make
This Earth of my fidelity to hake,
And caue my contant heart to quake and tremble,
Imprion'd windes exactly they reemble,
Which being in the earth enclos'd, they make,
All hearts to tremble, and the earth to quake.
My Tears the Ocean is; as oon you may
Empty the Sea, as them dry up or tay.
My Tears o many torms are, which rebell,
And makes this Sea to bluter and to well.
The flowing Rivers of my eyes do pay
Their contant Tribute to this welling Sea.
The Air my VVill is, which is pure and free,
And alwaies waits on my Fidelity.
The VVinde is my Deire, which moves my VVill,
As wanton Aire by winde is moved till.
And as in caverns we do ee the Winde,
So my Deire is in my heart confin'd.
That Fire inviible, which in the Aire,
Thoe ecret Flames which burn my heart up, are
And as this Element no eye doth ee,
Even o my Flames with in me mother'd be.
But as all flames ome nourihment do crave,
So mut mine die, or nourihment mut have.

l.hi: My Hopes the Moon is, which doth till encreae,
Or ele diminih alwaies more or lee:
And I do find it by experience true,
She has no light, but borrowed from you.

lg.l: For if you do not, like the Sun to th'Moon,

l.hi: Some lutre lend, then all my hopes are done.

lg.l: The Sun is your incomparable eye,

l.hi: VVhich does out-lutre any in the skie:

lg.l: As th' other Sun life to the VVorld doth give,

l.hi: So Lovers die, unlee you bid them live.
'Tis day when you appear, and it is night,
Mot dimall dark, when you are out of ight.

lg.l: My Summer is my joy, when you do pleae
To hine upon me, and my heart to eae.
My VVinter is my fear, when you with-draw,
And is not pleas'd my frozen fear to thaw.
But now, alas, what fruit can Autumn bring;
VVhen I can finde no flowers in my Spring.

div.p: Thus Silvander ended his Song, but not his thoughts; but on the contrary, decanting upon the lat Vere of it; Alas! aid he, though Love will not let my Autumn bring any fruites, yet he might very well let my Spring afford me ome flowers. Is it not thy cutome, (Oh thou little god) to nourih hopes in many, whom thou never meanet to content, and why does thy cutome faile in me? But till I mut needs ay, thou art jut, for thou couldt not chatie my preumption with a leer punihment. Yet, I mut needs complain; for though the punihment be jut, yet it marts; and though I am culpable, yet I am enible withall. After thee expreions, he was ilent, and whilt he was turmoiling himelfe in a ea of various thoughts, he gave Diana leaure to cat her eye upon her companions; and eeing they perceived her, he was ahamed; therefore tealing gently unto them, he aid thus unto Phillis: I pray, Servant, whilt Atrea and I get a little off, tay you here, that if the Shepheard do hear us, you may amue him; for I would not upon any termes have him know, that I heard him. So Phillis making a igne that he would, Diana and Atrea went away. I oberved, that Lycidas uppoed, thee two Shepheardees would have perwaded Phillis to go with them, but that her love, which he uppoed he had unto Silvander, would not let her leave him: The actions of his head, hands, and feet, perwaded me in this opinion. In the mean time, Silvander began to ing this Song.

lg.head: That to adore Diana is the only Happinee. A Song.
lg.l: SIt till, Silvander, ne're complain,

l.hi: Againt thy fate or any pain:
For, uch a Mitris is thy lot,
As never man a fairer got.
Be thankfull, Man, and think it honour,
To acrifice thy elfe upon her.
For never ince the world was made,
VVas o much light without a hade.
Put heaven to boot, the Angells there,
(Compar'd with her) they are not fair.
Ceae then complaints, and think it weet,
If thou from her thy death do meet:
A better death thou cant not die,
Then murder'd by o fair an eye.

lg.l: Love on, Silvander, never faint,

l.hi: But till adore o fair a Saint.
'Tis perfect Martyrdome to die,
For uch a weet Idolatry.

div.p: This Shepheard perhaps had continued longer, if Driope, Diana's Dog, had not broke looe from her, and run fawning upon Silvander, for he was wont to make very much of him for his Mitrese's ake. The Shepheard preently roe up, and looked round about, but could not ee her; yet, he aw Lycidas hearkening, and Phillis, who eeing him rie, went to him, as Diana deired; but as he went towards him, he epied Lycidas, which made her change her intention; for he knowing, that he was jealous of Silvander, he turned another way: and this made Lycidas the more upect her, thinking he did it purpoely to hide it from him. Silvander, who knew both their hearts, and being reolved to augment the jealouie of Lycidas, he faigned, as if he did not ee Lycidas, and ran unto Phillis, and taking her hand, did imprint two or three zealous kies upon it; afterwards asked her, how Diana and Atrea did? The Shepheardes was very orry that Lycidas did ee all this, and o perplexed at it, as he knew not how to anwer him. Paris and I, who intended to follow Atrea and Diana, we now went unto Silvander and Phillis. Lycidas, extreamly ill atisfyed with all this, turned another way, as if he had never een us. We foure being together, we went that way Atrea and Diana went, after Silvander had taken order, both for his ownflock, and that of Phillis's. This was a ore heart-burn unto Lycidas, and his jealouie was much more increaed by it, when he aw that Shepheard o carefull about the flock of Phillis, o as your Brother was continually turning his head towards us, to ee what we did.

I profes (aid Celadon, and interrupted her) he is much to be pittyed; for I have found, by my little experience of it, that jealouie is one of the mot extream fortunes of a Lover. But, fair Nymph, what became of him afterwards? I cannot tell, anwered he, for I aw him not all the day after: and as for us, we went unto Diana and Atrea, who, as I believe, tayed for our company: and we pent all that day together with much contentment: Paris, he applyed himelfe unto Diana; Silvander, unto Phillis; and I unto Atrea, whom indeed I finde to be mot worthy of Celadon's affection. Fair Nymph, aid Celadon, I beeech you give me leave to be a little more inquiitive. What is it, aid Leonida, that you deire to know of me? Did you ever hear, aid Celadon, o weet a voice as hers? has he not a kinde of an harmonious accent in her pronunciation, which charmes the ear? Certainly he has, aid the Nymph, and that which mot takes me, is, that he ueth no art or affection in her language, but all her expreions are plain, and full of modety and civility. But I beeech you, weet Nymph aid Celadon, did he never peak of me? She did, aid I, but it was my elfe who began the dicoure; for I knew, the reaon why he poke o little of you, was, the opinion which every one had of your affection to her. For heavens ake, weet Leonida, (aid the hepheard) tell me what dicoure you had together? It was not much, (aid he unto him) yet I know not whether I hall remember it or no: I was very deirous to hear what was become of you; and when Paris deired me to go unto your Town, I had not the confidence to peak of you: And when I aw Paris o deeply in love with Diana, as he minded nothing but her, and not finding you amongt the hepheardees, I was extreamly troubled. At lat, after ome other dicoure, I told her, how I did not think, that the hepheards of Lignon had been o civilized as I found them: The firt time I tayed with them, was purpoely to ee, whether the reports I had heard were true; and Silvander that day confirmed them all. I mut confee, (anwered Atrea) that Silvander is a very well accomplihed hepheard. But, Madam, had you come at another time, I believe you would have found better atisfaction; for there was a time, when we had a mot excellent company of hepheards. What is become of them, anwered I? Some, aid he, are dead, as the poor Celadon; others are o grieved for the loe of him, as they are grown o many lumps of melancholly, and frequent none, but olitary places, as Lycidas; and ome are o atonihed at the accident, as they have quite left the fatall Lignon: and indeed, we are all o ad ever ince, as we do not eem the ame we were. Celadon, replyed I, was not that he whom I heard talk off, when I was lat here? The ame, (aid he unto me, with a deep igh) Was he your Cozen (aid I unto her)? No, anwered he, but on the contrary, his Father and mine were mot mortall enemies: But, Madam, he was the mot gentle and finet hepheard in all the Country; and though there was a mot deadly enmity between our two families, yet his weet and good conditions contrained me, and every one that knew him, to reent his loe. At this he changed colour and putting her hand before her eyes, he eemed as if the rubbed her forehead. I perceived by this dicoure, that you were not yet returned unto her, ince I left you; and knowing, that he could not tell me any thing, that could atisfie my longing deires
of eeing you, and that uch talk would only grieve her, I changed dicoure; and preently after, it being late, Paris and I retired. It was then I heard from Silvander of your Brother's jealouie; for walking by the River ide, I asked him the caue of your Brother's adnee, and why we could never ee him? And he told me, that Lycidas being a devoted ervant unto Phillis, he was jealous of her and him; and that he, to torment him the more, did eem as if he were in love with Phillis, and gave out all the demontrations of it that poibly he could. Thus, Celadon, did we pend that day; and ince that, becaue I could not hear any newes of you, I viited this Company every day, thinking, that being in the company of thoe whom you loved, I was in ome ort with you. This was the reaon, that when Amais, after great preparations of joy, was contrained to leave them, becaue of the newes of Merovea's death, though Silvia, by the command of Galathea, did let me know, that I might return unto Marcelles when I would, yet I would not go, becaue I took abundance of delight in the ociety of thee dicreet hepheardees. Why (aid Celadon) did Amais grieve o, for the death of that King? Becaue (as I believe) Clidamant was with him, (anwered I). Now, let my Uncle hould make me return unto that Nymph, I did conceal Silvia's Letter from him. But, Celadon, tell me truly, do you not envie me, for eeing Atrea, and peaking with her as oft as I would? I hall not be orry at any thing that pleaeth you, anwered he; but I could wih my elfe a hare in the happinee. And why (anwered the Nymph) do you deprive your elfe of it? Ah Leonida! (aid he) could you but look into my heart, you would ee I do not; but I can take no delight in eeing her, and in eeing her dipleaed. But why (aid the Nymph) do you think he will be dipleaed with eeing you? Becaue (anwered the hepheard) he hath commanded me never to ee her, untill he command otherwie. How can he command otherwie (aid Leonida) if he never ee you, nor knowes where you are, but thinks you to be dead? Ah Nymph, (aid the hepheard) Love is a mot puiant god; and as he has blindely found out a way to banih me her preence, he may alo finde a way to recall me when he pleaeth. Are you then reolved (aid Leonida) not to preent your elfe before her? I had rather die, anwered he, and therefore let Love do as it lits. Upon this, he aroe, purpoely to change dicoure, and taking the Nymphs hand, he came to the dore of his Cave; but when he aw him in the light, and perceiving him o extreamly altered, he could not retrain her tears; which Celadon eeing: Nay, nay, weet Nymph, aid he, never grieve at the alteration which you finde in my face, for it is a igne, that ere long I hall have a long ret. It would be too tedious to relate all their dicoure. But, to be briefe, all her arguments and perwaions could obtain from him no more, then this, that he would uffer her to viit him ometimes. At the lat, the Sun being almot et, he was contrained to leave him, with a promie to ee him very often.

For all Leonida's reolution, of not loving Celadon, yet could he not extinguih the flames of her firt affection to him; o difficult a thing it is to expell this paion, when it has once taken deep root in a heart which entertains it; and therefore this meeting with him was no mall contentment unto her; but her orrowes, to ee him in uch a mierable condition, were as great, and the greater, when he thought upon his trange reolution; o as her joyes to finde him, and her orrowes to finde him thus, did a little puzzle her which to adhere mot unto: All the way he went, he was inventing what coure he hould take, to diwade him from this coure of life: Sometimes he was in a minde, to acquaint the hepheardee Atrea with it, in hopes, that her influence might effect it. But this minde changed, as oon as he conidered, that this was the way to put her elfe out of all hopes to get his love, knowing very well, that if Atrea once knew he was alive, and could finde him, he would give him uch weet demontrations of her good-will unto him, as would blat all her hopes of him. Changing therefore this opinion, and having heard, that Adamas had been a great lover of Celadon's Father, he thought it expedient to acquaint him with his coure of life, auring her elfe, that he would do all that was requiite and fit. Yet notwithtanding, when he conidered, that the place where Celadon was, was as fit a place as he could wih, to enjoy his company alone, and to expree her own paion, he conceived the bet way was, to acquaint none as yet, but to try what time would doe, and to divert him from his ad thoughts as much as he poibly could; and if he found, that her preence and artifice could not work upon him, then it would be time enough to acquaint her Uncle. This then was the coure he fixed upon; and to effect it, he failed not to viit him every day. The hepheard knowing, that all this could not proceed from any thing but love, he was dipleaed at it, thinking, that if he uffered
o much indulgency from this Nymph, he did offend againt the promie of fidelity unto his hepheardee: Beides, he thought all thoe houres that were pent in thee viits, were lot, becaue they kept him from entertaining his own dear and weet thoughts; o as in lieu of growing more joyfull, he became more ad; which the Nymph perceiving, and eeing that he did every day grow leaner and paler; he conulted with her elfe, and at lat reolved, to have recoure unto the age advice of the grave Adamas; but to acquaint him with it in uch a manner, as he hould be ure not to upect any thing, to her diadvantage.

Being therefore one evening in a better humour then ordinary, he went unto her Uncle, whom he found walking upon a Tarrae, which had the propect of all that plain from whence he came: After alutation, the Druide asked her, where he left Paris? To which he anwered, that all the hepheardees were o kinde and civill, as to accompany them as far as the Temple of the good goddee, and Paris went to conduct them back again: But, Father, aid he, I have met with a fine encounter, which tayed me o long, that I thought Paris would have been back before me. What is it aid the Druide? It is Celadon, anwered Leonida; you mut know, that ince he went from the Palace of Iaures, in lieu of going to his kindred and friends, he has retired himelf into a Cave, where he o hides himelf from all his acquaintance, as every one yet thinks him dead. Why, aid Adamas, does he o? I believe, anwered h, that he is very ick in minde, and will not live long, for he can carcely go; he eats nothing but grae, and is grown o lean and ad, as you cannot know him. Why, think you, aid the Druide, that it is in his minde? I conceive o, aid he, becaue he peaks after an interrupted manner, and o little, as it is eaie to ee, that dicoure dipleaeth him; I do believe, the love he bears unto Atrea is the caue of it. If it be o, anwered Adamas, he is the more like unto his Father; for, Alcippe was once o very much tranported with his love unto Amarillis, that I did never in all my life ee one commit greater follies; and therefore it was, that he left a Country-life for the Court, and continued long in the exercies of Chivalry. Is it lawfull for them, aid Leonida, thus to change their quality? Child, aid the Druide, neither Celadon nor any of thee hepheards about the banks of Lignon, nor mot of thoe about the Loire and Furan, are of a wore extraction then you your elfe are; you mut know, that their Ancetours made choice of this kinde of life, as mot weet, and leat ubject unto inquietudes. Indeed, this Celadon, of whom you peak, is your neer kinman: For, the Houe of Laigneau and his, did branch both out of one tock, o as Lindamor and he are your Coens in the ame degree: My Grandfather, and the great Grandfather of Lindamor and Celadon, were Brothers. Leonida hearing how neerly they were allied, was atonihed, fearing let this conanguinity hould forbid the banes of her loving him, as Love commanded her to do; yet, let her Uncle hould take any notice of her fears, he aid unto him; That ince they were o neerly allyed, they were the more obliged to have a care of him, and that the avage life he led was uch, as he verily believed he could not live long. It is very fit, aid the Druide, that we have all the care of him that poibly we can; and therefore, to hew my indulgency towards him, I will go unto the Cave of the old Cleontine, and conult with her about him: Perhaps the heavens have a care of him, and keep him thus hid, to prevent ome great misfortune; for I have known ome others, that have been o preerved from divers blats of malignant fate, which did threaten them. Whilt they were thus talking, Paris came in, and interrupted them, for they would not acquaint him with it, o as Adamas and Leonida went betimes to bed, that they might be the more early up in the morning, to go unto Cleontine.

Mount Verdun is a great Rock, reembling a pointed Diamond, which tands in the midt of the plain towards Mount Brion, between the River Lignon, and the Mountain Iaures; were it a little more upon the right hand towards Laigneau, then Marcelles, Iaures, and Mount Verdun, did make a perfect Triangle. It eemes Nature took delight in imbellihing this place above all others in the Country; for, it being elevated in the very heart of this Plain, o equally on all ides, it raied it elfe by uch eeven degrees, and at the top did leave jut room for a Temple, which was dedicated unto Tautates, Heius, Tharames, and Belinus; and being the mot famous in all the Forrets, it is here where the Lubages, the Sarronides, the Vaces, and the Bardes, do dwell in Grattoes, which they have made about the Temple, in which they aemble themelves when the Druides command them. But that which is mot admirable, is, that this great Rock, which is above foure thouand paces about, when it begins to rie from the levell, and above foure hundred
paces high, and at the top above five hundred paces broad; yet, it is o covered with earth, planted with Vines, o full of grae, and o green, that thoe of the Country corrupting its name, do call it Mount Verdun, or green Mountain, in lieu of Mount Vatodun, which ignifies the Mountain and dwelling of Priets or Sacrifices; for in the language of the Celts, Dunum ignifies Fortree; and Vates, in the Roman language, ignifies Priets, Prophets, or uch as give Oracles; and ince the Gaules had any communication with the Romans, they have not only mixed their language, but alo their manner of acrificing, complying themelves with a victorious people, o made uch a micellany, as they do retain unto themelves equally halfe Roman, halfe Celt. This Mountain became thus peopled with Bardes, Eubages, Surronides, and others, by Dryus, the firt Intitutor of the Druides, who inpired this place with a certain kinde of divinity, and left a mark of it unto Poterity. This Rock, which, for its magnitude, may well be called a Mountain, is naturally o hollow, as within it is but one vat Vault; it hath three entrances, o pacious, that a Coach may enter; they are commonly kept hut, and opened only when the Oracle is to be conulted with, and then a Druide, after a acrifice, opens the dore, and askes the quetion: Preently there iues an impetuous winde, which comming from the concavities of this Vault, makes a trange confued noie, eeming to be a kinde of ill pronounced voice. The Druide holding his head as far in as he can, tayes there, with his mouth open as long as the noie continues; afterwards comes away, with his hair diordered, his eyes taring, his face changed, and voice altered from what they were, and with actions, as if tranported, does give the Oracle, which very often, the pronouncer her elfe does not undertand.

Now thee three entrances, are dedicated unto three of their gods, or indeed, unto one god under three everall names; the one unto Heius, whom they conult with in matters of War; the other unto Thamaris, when future events would be known; and the other unto Belinus, unto whom all Lovers do addree their acrifices and upplications. And thee three entrances are never all open at a time, but upon the ixteenth day of July, when having gathered abundance of Mileto, they come and trew it all about the Vault. At this time, if the Soveraigne Lady of the Province have a Daughter, he may enter, and make choice of him whom he will have for her Husband; with whom, and the grand Druide, they may view all that is in this Cave, and ee all the wonders which the great Druide left in it.

This was the place unto which Adamas with Leonida did reort in the morning, to conult with Thamaris; and after the acrifice of a white Bull, according to the cutome, and after Cleontine had dreed her elfe in Vervin, and prinkled the blood of the acrifice at the entrance, he put a piece of Lawrell in her mouth and chewed it; then touching the dore with a branch of Mileto, preently it opens with a great noie, and he taking hold of the hinges, leanes all her body in, and opening her mouth to receive the winde which comes out of the Cave, he tayes there a good while, and at lat, comes unto the place of acrifice, where the Druide and all the ret do tay upon their knees, and bare-headed, praying unto Tentates. When he is come back, he goes unto the Altar, and there, with an afrighted viage, and hair taring, with a trange hoare voice, he uttered thee words.

lg.l: SAge Adamas, the heavens decree,

l.hi: You by your prudence mut be he,
That mut help out his Infancy.

lg.l: The gods themelves do it ordain,
When he his Mitree does obtain,
Your age hall happy be again.

div.p:
Adamas, after thanks unto Thamaris, and beeeching him to make him undertand his will, let by ignorance he hould erre, he went away, fully reolved to ait Celadon all that poibly he could, ince the gods did promie to make his age happy, if he obtained his Mitree. He had before a very good inclination towards him, as well becaue of the neer conanguinity betwixt them, as becaue of that hepheards merits; but much more,
ince this anwer from the Oracle, evidencing hereby, that a peron intereted, is much more olicitous in any buinee, then one that is only obliged by duty. Taking the way therefore towards Lignon, he asked Leonida, where Celadon's habitation was? And he hewing him the way, they came at lat to the buh which covered the entrance into the Cave, where he took up his habitation; and fearing, let if he aw them, he hould flie them, they went as oftly as they could to urprize him. As fortune was, he lay jut at the entrance into his Cave, o near the River, that as he leaned upon a hillock, and aw his tears drop into the River, they heard him utter thee words.

lg.head: Celadon comparing himelfe unto the River Lignon.

lg.l: HOw I increae this Chryt all River,
Which of my orrowes is a mirrour:
I may my elfe compare to thee,
And thou of me reemblance be.
From Scources two thou dot arie,
VVhich may be from my flowing eyes;
More welling waves thou never had,
Then I misfortunes great and ad.
As thou dot glide without deigne,
So without hope away I pine.
Thy cource from Mountains high doth flow,
From Beauty high proceeds my woe.
Through Rocks o hard thou find't a way,
Through Rocks of griee I pas each day.
Though our reemblances be uch,
Yet, in one point we differ much.
Thy waves increae by falling nowes,
And frit addes tears unto my woes:
And yet, (which I do mot admire)
Thou art all Cold, and I all Fire.

div.p:
Ah! River, River continued he, thou that art a witnee, how I am now the mot mierable, as formerly I was the mot happy, hepheard in the world, why wat thou o mercilee, as to ave my mierable life when it was in thy power to put an end unto all my orrowes, by taking this pittifull life away? Will things that are inenible conpire againt me, and deny me that, which naturally they betow upon others? But perhaps thou art loth to loe thy third cource, knowing that my tears did more abundantly well thy Chanell, then both thoe from whence thou hat thy originall: If this was the motive that moved thee unto this cruell pitty, I'le aure thee, thou art not deceived ince as long as I live, my tears hall never fail thee. Upon this lat word, a mot profound igh gave a top unto his voice, o as for a while his tongue was ilent; and as he was beginning again, Leonida unawares tirred. He turning his head that way, he was extreamly urpried, to ee Adamas with her in that place; he preently aroe, and came to alute the Druide, who advanced towards him. The thin and pale looks of Celadon did not a little atonih Adamas. And having former experience of the force of Love, he conceived, that this violent malady might reduce him unto a more dangerous condition, if no remedies were applyed. Therefore after common aluations and dicoure, he took him by the hand and caued him to it down and then began this dicoure unto him: Son, what a trange condition is this, in which I finde you? Was it to live thus, that you requeted me to help you out of the pain that you were in, within the Palace of Isaures? Did you intend to hut your elfe up in this Cave, and live like a alvage from the ociety of men? You are born, Celadon, unto a better fate, the great Thamaris tells me as much; he has betowed upon you great Flocks, and large Patures; and do you think your elfe not obliged to render an account of them? All under the cope of heaven is his, we are all but his Stewards, and quetionlee he will exact a particular accompt; and, Soh, when that time
comes, what will you then anwer? Although he hath ubmitted thee things unto our wills; yet, our very wills are not our own, and we may expect a evere punihment, if we dipoe of our elves otherwie than as we ought. How can you think it reaonable to live without any care of Flocks, or Friends, or Kindred, or Men? Dare you contemn thoe remedies, which that great god hath upon this occaion put into your hands? Perhaps you will ay, that your affection unto the hepheardee Atrea, does force you unto it. But, Son, conider well with your elfe, that if you have offended her, all your ervices cannot wipe away the offence, as long as you keep at ditance from her; and if you have not offended her, how can you ever hope or think he hould know your innocency, if he never ee or hear of you? Now, my Son, I do grant, that for the time pat, you had ome reaon to abent your elfe from her preence, nay, from all the world, to the end he may ee, what power he hath over you, and that you value the loe of her favour as the loe of your reaon. But now that time is expired, you mut now return unto your elfe again, and make it appear, that you are both in Love, and that you are a man. Though your orrowes may deprive you of your reaon, yet, now reaon ought to revive, that he may not repent of having a Servant who is not a Man. Unto this Celadon returned this cold anwer: I would to god, Father, that your apient advice were addreed unto one capable to receive it; as for me, I mut confee, there remaines nothing of a man in me but my memory, having lot both my undertanding and my will; and I believe, this memory that remains with me, is only as a nourihment of my ad thoughts; o as he whom you now ee before you, is not Celadon the Son of Alcippes and Amarillis, whom the great Druide Adamas heretofore did honour with his friendhip; but he is only one, that the heavens conerves here amongt the Woods, as a tetimony, that Celadon knowes how to love. In anwer unto all you object, let this erve for all, I love: For, age Adamas, if I do love, I need not fear, that Tharamis will be offended at me, for doing that which Love commands, ince he would have me, or at leat permits me, to love. Now thoe who do permit a thing, they permit all that depends upon it; and who can deny, but that this mierable life which I lead, is a dependency of this love? Can he be called a Lover, who has eyes that will look upon any thing but that he Loves? Ah! Father, doubtlee I do love, and I am blinde unto all Flocks, and Friends, and Kindred, and all Men living. If the heavens, as you ay, have given me any thing, why hould it exact an account of me, ince I do reigne them back again as freely, as ever they were betowed upon me? If any account be required of Celadon, it mut be required of her whoe Celadon is; as for me, I have nothing to account of, for I have reigned all, the heavens would have it o, for it is by detiny that I do love, and the heavens do know it: As oon as ever I had any will, I gave my elf wholly unto her, and have continued o ever ince. To be briefe, the heavens are pleaed with it, otherwie I had not been o happy as I was many years. If therefore the heavens would have it o, do know it, and were pleaed with it; how can they in jutice punih me, for doing that, which I cannot chue but do? Do what thou wilt with me, Oh great Thamaris let what will become of my flocks, let my Friends and Kindred have what opinion of me they pleae; they all ought to be atisfied with this anwer, that, I do love. But, anwered Adamas, will you alwaies live thus? The election (anwered the hepheard) does not depend upon him, that hath neither will nor undertanding.

If you do, (aid Adamas) you will ceae to be a man. That (replyed the hepheard) has been a long time the leat of my cares. But, if you do love, aid the Druide, why do you not enforce your elfe to ee her whom you love? If I do love, anwered he, do you think I will dipleae or diobey her whom I love; nay, do you think, that I do not receive extream contentment and delight in pleaing and obeying her? But, aid the Druide, he does not know that you do obey her. It is no matter, anwered he, whether he do or no, I mut do my duty. The Druide knew not whether he hould eteem him for the acutenee of his wit in thee anwers, or blame him, for the errours he was in: but conceiving, that his malady was not yet at the height, therefore he would not apply any violent remedies, untill he had tryed ome more milder; and therefore, after a while of ilence, he aid thus unto him: Now, Celadon, what I have aid, was, becaue I thought my elfe obliged unto it by the Lawes of friendhip, and duty of my charge, and not to contrary you in any thing; only one favour I hall deire from you, which I hope you will not deny, ince it will conduce much unto my contentment: You mut know, that I have a Daughter, whom I love above all the bleings, which the goodnee of Tharamis hath betowed upon me; I have long wanted my greatet contentment, in wanting her, and I am afraid,
it will be longer before I hall ee her again. Now the firt time I aw you at the Palace of Isoures, 'tis true, I loved you for Alcippe's and Amarillis's ake, but much more, for your great reemblance of my dearet Daughter; therefore I conjure you, by her that hath mot power over you, to be pleaed, that I may ometimes interrupt your olitude, that I may in your face ee the Picture of her, whom I love above all the world. The hepheard, who was full of courtey, anwered, That he would take it for a very particular favour, if he would be pleaed to take the paines; and that he thanked Nature for favouring him o much, as to give him a reemblance of any he loved; and that if he had not excluded himelfe from all the world, he would come to his houe and preent him his ervice. To be briefe, Adamas reolved to viit this hepheard very often, hoping by degrees to draw him out of his melancholly Cell. True it was, that Alexis his Daughter had a little reemblance of this hepheard; and he being by their Lawes to tay amongt the Druides Daughters, in the Cells of Carnutes, untill he was forty years of age, Adamas did take delight in eeing Celadon, who had a kinde of reemblance of her. It had been ordained by Dis Samothes, and ince confirmed by great Druis, the firt Intitutor of the Druides, that thoe Priets which had any Sons, hould end the eldet of them unto the Schooles of Carnutes, where they pent ten years in learning their Science, ten years more in teaching others; and ten years more yet, they officiated in the publick Sacrifices and Judgments: and afterwards they might return to their homes, and exercie the charge of Druides throughout all Gaul. If they have none but Daughters, they are contrained to end their eldet, after ten years of age, unto the ame place; where they are intructed, do intruct, and at lat, judge, as I told you before. For, the Gaules do build very much upon the judgment of thee Female Druides: And thee times being expired, they may return to their Fathers, and may marry.

Now this coure being reolved upon, Celadon was he that reaped the mot profit by it; for Leonida did at the firt retore unto him thoe Letters, which he tole from him, which was a good preage of better fortune, having often heard ay, that as one misfortune eldome comes alone, o alo one good fortune drawes on another. And he being very often viited, ometimes by Leonida, and ometimes by the Druide, he was much diverted from thoe ad thoughts, which would quite have conumed him; beides, the care of Adamas was uch, as he ent him victualls very often ecretly, which much revived his drooping pirits.

The affection of this Nymph, and the goodnee of Adamas, was a happy encounter for Celadon, for both of them were carefull of him beyond meaure, and indeed beyond their duty and quality; but, the greatet comfort unto this hepheard, was, that this Nymph furnihed him with Pen, Inke, and Paper, becaue being alone, he did employ himelfe much in putting his paionate thoughts into writing, which gave him much contentment in the reading them. For, the wounds of Love are of uch a nature, that the more they are mothered and kept in, the more they feter; and talking of them is as overaigne a remedy, as can be received in abence. Now Adamas conceived, that too much thinking did but feter and rancle the melancholly of this hepheard, and therefore he advied him to pae away his time, ometimes in the acred Groves, which were neer, and there engrave ome fancies upon the barks of Trees, and furnihed him with tooles fit for the purpoe. This Shepheard having gotten a little more trength, and recovered ome of his former complexion, alo reauming his undertanding facultle, he was enible of this good counell which Adamas gave him, to hun this carelee and idle kinde of life wherein he lived; and therefore he took his advice, and fell to work. Adamas in this did, like a good Phyitian, conider the dieae which he was to cure, and there eaoned all his counells with ome deignes of Love. You ee, Son, aid he unto him, that though according to our Statutes, we ought not to erect Temples unto Teutates, Heius, Belinus, and Tharamis our god; yet, ince the Romans, by their Armes, brought in trange gods unto Gaul, and loing our antient freedome, we were contrained to acrifice after their fahion, we have Temples, in which our god is adored amongt us; and becaue the cutome of it is become a Law, it is lawfull for you, Celadon, to dedicate part of this Grove, not only unto the highet and prime divinity, but as a mot perfect work of that divinity, unto your fair Atrea, which our great god will as well allow, as thoe Temples that are dedicated by trangers, unto the goddee Fortune, unto the goddee Sicknes, or the goddee Fear. Therefore, aid he unto him, let me advie you to prime and dree up this goodly Oake, to cut away the thick underwood, and make a
place, which we will dedicate unto Amity. At the root of the Oake, cat up a bank of gras, in form of an Altar, upon which I will et a Table, which hall be an emblem of Amity. When this is finihed, we will make another more pacious, which hall be under that Oak, which truly is one mot admirable; for out of one tock three branches do grow, and afterwards reunite themelves into the ame bark.

You ee, (aid he unto him) that this is a mot lively ymbol of Teutates, Heius, Belinus, and Tharamis our god. How, Father (aid Celadon) you name foure, and yet you ay, our god? you hould have aid, gods; and I have oberved, that you have ued the ame expreion more then once. Son (aid the Druide) this is one of our greatet myteries in divinity; and though we Druides ought not to reveal it unto any, but uch as are intructed in our Schooles, yet I hall declare unto you as much, as you are capable to undertand.

Know therefore, my Son, that the great Dis, Samothes, preently after the diviion of men, by reaon of the confuion of Languages, being well intructed by his Grandfather, both in the worhip of the true God, and in other Sciences, he came by the Armorick Sea into this Country, which yet unto that very day we called Gaul, and which a little after, changed it for the name of France: Who afterwards peopling it, he etled his Scepter there, planted the Religion of his Fathers, and intructed ome of the bet Wits amongt them with his own Documents and Sciences, who ever ince after his own name were called Samothes. This man was the firt King of the Gaules, who was o pleaing both unto god and men, that he had a long, properous, and peaceable Raigne; and after him his Poterity in uch renown, as all the world did ring with his, and the valour of the Gaules. Afterwards the Romans uurped the Dominion of the Gaules, by reaon of our own civill dientions, who being full of animoity and faction amongt our elves, did invite them amongt us, and asked aide of them, whoe ambition hath ince devoured us; teaching us, but too late, that no trangers will ever love us better than we do our elves. But that great god, whom Samothes taught us to adore in purity of heart, not deiring to continue his anger againt us for ever, after we had been a while under the Dominion of thee trangers, did deliver us from them by the Armes of the Francks, who ay themelves to be decended from the ancient Gaules. Now to return unto our dicoure. The fourth King which raigned in Gaul, who decended from the great and holy Samothes, was the wie and learned Dryus, from whom the Druides took their denomination. But thoe are mitaken, as well as the over-bold Greeks, who boat, that they were o called from their word Drys, which ignifies an Oake; for, before Letters or Learning ever came into Greece, we called them Druides, and the Sciences were in Gaul before they did know o much as how to read, as the name of Druide teacheth us, which in the Language of Samothes's Grandfather does ignifie, Contemplator, from the word Driim; and, as you know (my Son) our principall part of Profeion, conits in contemplation of the works of God.

Now this great Dis, Samothes, and after him, our holy Dryus, did command us to worhip god, not according to the erroneous cutome of Nations, but as they had been taught by their Fathers, and becaue the dull ignorance of the people was uch, as they could not comprehend that upream goodnee and infinite power, which they called Thau, comprehending all, they gave him three names; Heius, which ignifies Strong; Belinus, which ignifies Man god; and Tharamis, which ignifies Preerver, teaching us by thee three names, that god is the omnipotent Creator and Preerver of men. But ince, through the alteration of time, and ignorance of people, which changeth all things, epecially names, in lieu of Thau, they ay Thauta, and Thautes, and Theutates. In lieu of Jehus, Belenas, and Thaharamis, the apiration in the middle being harh to pronounce, they ay, Heus, Belinus, and Tharamis: And the people had uch a power over the more knowing part of men, as they, to be undertood, were forced to call them as the people did, and conent unto their errour.

But, Father, aid the hepheard, are not Teutates, Heus, Tharamis, and Belinus, the ame gods which are called Mercury, Mars, Jupiter, and Apollo? Are all thee but one god? Son, aid the Druide, I wih I were able to make you undertand what you ask; but where your undertanding will not reach, let the beliefe which you have in me upply. Know therefore, that trangers eeing how the Gaules adored and called upon Thautates in all their affaires, when they took any journey, and in all their actions; moreover conidering, that they were naturally lovers of eloquence, they thought, that it was Mercury
whom they called upon, aying, that he was the god of Eloquence, the director in Voyages, the inventor of Arts, and the Protector of all Merchants and Traffick. Afterwards oberving, that in our Wars we invoked Heius, they thought him to be Mars, who was by them held to be the god of Armes. And when we deired to be purged from our ins, they aw us call upon Thamaris, & they thought him to be Jupiter, from whom they expect all chatiement, by reaon of the thunderbolts that are attributed unto him. Beides, they conceiving, that pardon of ins being to be had from the greatet of all the gods, they aid he mut needs be Jupiter, becaue he was the greatet and mot puiant. Then, becaue we had recoure unto Belinus, when we wanted health for our elves or friends, or deired to have children, they perwaded themelves, that it mut needs be their Apollo, whom they thought to be the firt inventor of Phyick; beides, attributing unto him the guidance of the Sun; nay, very often taking the one for the other; and knowing, that the Sun gave life unto all Animalls, and moreover, that Man and the Sun did generate Man, they had om reaon to think, that it was our Belinus.

But mot certain it is (dear Son) that there can be but one god; for, if one be not omnipotent and all puiant, he is not god: if there were two omnipotents, or two puiants, the omnipotency and the puiancy would be divided. Moreover, they mut needs be either alike or dilike; if they be alike in all things, they mut be the ame, and o only one; if they be dilike, then good mut be different from good, which cannot be. I intance only in thee familiar arguments, becaue I will not puzle your undertanding with uch as are more obcure and more ublime, although they be tronger and more preing. I did ever believe (aid Celadon) that there was but one god and one lord over us all, and above all the ret of the gods; but, I believed alo, that as amongt Men, we ee, that Kings have their ubordinate Officers, o that there are inferiours or petty gods under him, which is the upream and great one of all, whom we call Tautates, and the others, Heius, Tharamis, and Belinus, which, next to him, are to be adored. This beliefe (anwered the Druide) hath ome colour and reaon in it, yet it is a great errour; for thoe whom you named lat are not gods, but only denominations of the great Tautates: But, though I mut confee, he hath ubordinate Officers under him, as Terretriall Kings have; yet, you mut undertand, that worhip and adoration is due only unto one god. Why then, Father, aid Celadon, are they placed in our Temples o neer the great Tautates?
