Son (aid Adamas) I told you before, that the Romans mixed their Religion with ours: You mut know, that by our Lawes, it is forbidden to make any image of god; for, an Image being a repreentation of omething, and there mut needs be ome proportion betwixt the thing repreenting and the thing repreented; we do conceive, that there is nothing amongt men, which can hold any proportion or reemblance with god, and therefore we do exprely forbid it; and indeed, we do diallow of any Temples, thinking it mot groe ignorance to imagine, an infinite immene deitie within any walls can be confined; and think it a mot preumptuous boldnee to imagine, any houe can be worthy of him. And therefore, after the manner of the Antients, the Father and Grandfather of the great Samothes, did command us to adore god in Groves and in Fields; yet, Groves were conecrated unto him, by the devotion of the people, let they hould be profaned: And in thoe places, they made choice of great Oakes, under which god was worhipped. And hereupon it was, that the Romans entring into our Country, and eeing our acred Groves and manner of our Sacrifices, did with amazement ay, that we, amongt all men, had the greatet knowledge of god, and that the Gaules were the mot religious and fullet of devotion, of any people in the world. But the Conquerors alwaies giving what Lawes they lit unto the Conquered, they did mot tyrannically uurp, not only upon our Land, but our Souls alo; changed our ceremonies, made us worhip their gods, forced us to build Temples, and to receive their Idolls, to repreent Tautates, Heius, Belinus, and Tharamis, under the figures of their Mars, Mercury, Apollo, and Jupiter. And becaue this went much againt the conciences of our Druides, one of their Emperors by publick Edict in Senate, banihed and abolihed our Religion, and chaed the Druides out of the Empire: But for all that, the great Tautates permitted this only, to make tryall of their vertues, and not to abolih them; manifeting, that he never does entirely forake the good. So as maugre the malice and tyranny of thee trangers, we have till preerved ome purity in our Sacrifices, and worhip god as he ought to be, and even in this Country, we have ever acknowledged the power of thee uurpers, out of the repect they alwaies had unto Diana, of whom they think our great
Nymph is a repreentation. And now at this time, the Francks have brought with them their Druides, and making it appear they were formerly Gaules, our authority and acred cutomes are revived again in plendor. But, Father (aid Celadon) I have een in our acred Groves, Images of great Dis and of Hercules. The reaon of that was, (anwered Adamas) becaue they were men and not gods; and being but men, they may be repreented. But (replyed Celadon) if they be not gods, why do you et them upon Altars? You mut know, (anwered Adamas) that they were men, who for their vertues were like unto gods, and as uch, we ought to honour them, and preerve their memory, to the end, others may take them for paternes of vertue: But trangers, who were ignorant of our intentions, did think, that we did adore and worhip them, and ay, that Dis was Pluto, from whom we ay we are decended; and gave unto Hercules the irname of Gaulois, becaue we much honour his memory, as well becaue he was full of heroick vertues, as becaue he married the fair Galathea our Princee, and Daughter of Celtes our King. You tell me things, aid Celadon, which do much ravih me, and I beeech you, Father, go on, and tell me what I hall do, when I hall enter into thoe Temples, where I hall finde the Images of Jupiter, Mars, Pallas, Venus, and uch like gods and goddees. Son, anwered Adamas, you mut be very well advied when you do go thither: and above all, be ure you do not take them for gods, but only Vertues Puiances, and Effects of one onely god. In Jupiter, you mut adore the omnipotency and majety of god; in Mars, his power; in Pallas, his widome; in Venus, his beauty, and o of all the ret: By this means, you will render unto our great Tautates, that worhip which is his due, and hew your elfe jut unto thoe vertuous Perons and Heroes, in honouring them dead, as you would have done if they had been alive. And o much for this time; and if you do frequent my company, I hall acquaint you with more. Now, Child, leaving this dicoure, let us make the form of a Temple here in this Grove, which was long ince dedicated unto Teutates our god: It being in a Grove, we hall oberve our antient Ordinances; and becaue a Temple, we hall obey thee trangers. I will write upon this miraculous Oake, the acred name of Teutates; and upon the three branches, that on the right hand, I will write Heius, on that in the middle, Tharamis, and on that upon the left hand, Belinus; and then upon the top of all, where they are united together, we will engrave the acred name of Teutates, to hew, that we mean only one god, under the notion of thee three words or nominations.

If I durt dicover unto you the acred and profound myteries of our religion, I hould acquaint you with an Interpretation, which Samothes, the mot knowing man, did leave unto us, and which, by tradition from Father to Son is come unto us, how that thee three names do ignifie three perons, which are but one god, god the mighty, god the man, and god the preerver; the father, the on, and the preerver; and all thee three, do make but one Tautates, which is god: And it is unto the Mother of this god man, unto whom our Druides, twenty ages ago, did dedicate an Altar in the Cave of Carnutes, with the tatue of a Virgin upon it, holding a Child in her armes, with this Incription: To the Virgin, who hall bring forth a Child. But thee myteries are too high for your capacity, and let we hould profane them, it is better to be ilent. Let us go on with our work. Perhaps ome learned Druide may come into this acred Grove, and will adore Teutates in purity of heart as we do; he will commend our work, and approve of our good intentions.

Thus did the Druide dicoure upon the hidden myteries of his religion; and becaue they were above the undertanding of the hepheard, he would ay no more. But as oon as thoe three names were engraved upon the Tree, they kneeled down and adored them, and never approached them, but with abundance of reverence. Now let Celadon hould be tired in his devotion by working, he called the Temple by the name of the goddee Atrea: And, Son, aid he, this is no offence unto the great god, o you honour this Atrea only, as the mot perfect piece of work that ever they hewed unto men. Celadon did eaily conent unto this, and with incredible zeal, he worked o aiduouly, as within a few daies he finihed the Temple, according to the Druide's appointment, who commending his diligence and indutry, and the more to encourage him, did bring him the Lawes of Love, and the Embleme of reciprocall Amity. But approaching the Altar of Atrea he knew not what to et upon it; yet after he had a while thought upon it: If you were a good Limner, aid he unto him, I am ure the features of the fair Atrea's face is very freh in your memory, you may draw her Picture, and et it upon this Altar, which
is dedicated unto her; but ince you are not yet o good an Artit, I will caue a Table to be made, and only write her name upon it. To which, the hepheard returned this anwer: You have ome reaon, Father for your beliefe, for the features of her fairet face are not only imprinted freh in my memory, o as me thinks I alwaies ee her; but alo her peech, her garb, her attire, and all her actions, are o lively in my oul, as me-thinks I do continually ee them. But, though I am no Artit in Limning, yet I am able to hew you her reemblance, upon condition, you will retore it unto me again: Upon a promie of which, he unbuttoned his breat, and opening the Cae which he wore about his neck, he hewed him Atrea's Picture: But, Father, (aid he) if you do loe it, or not retore it unto me again, mot certainly I hall die, no excue or conolation can ave me. After Adamas had vowed by Tautates, that he would retore it, the hepheard, after a mot zealous kie of it, did trut it into his hands. The Druide looking upon it: Truly, Son, (aid he) I mut needs confee, I never aw a face more fair, nor in which I dicover o much modet love and weet everity; happy is the Father of uch a Child, and happy the Mother who bare her, happy the eyes who ee her; but infinitely happy he that mut enjoy her. Afterwards he put it up into the Cae, with a promie to retore it very hortly, which he did accordingly, within five or ix daies.

It was in this place, where Atrea and all the Company did finde o many Veres and Writings of Celadon's; for he was o pleaed with his works, that he was continually before the Image of his hepheardee, and adoring her in his very oul; As imaginations and fancies came into his head, he writ them down, and laid them upon the Altar, as offerings unto the goddee Atrea. It was this hepheard and Adamas whom Silvander aw in the night; for the Druide, by frequenting him o continually, did make him forget mot of his ad thoughts; and the hepheard alo, did think him elfe o exceedingly obliged unto him, for his indulgent aitance, as he did infinitly honour him. Leonida, ince this, went not o oft to viit the hepheardee as he was wont. In the mean time, Celadon lived thus, ometimes more, ometimes lee afflicted, even as his thoughts gave him leave, untill he met with Silvander, into whoe hands he put the Letter which he writ unto the hepheardee Atrea, who ince, caued all thee hepheardees and hepheards to come into this place, where having lot their way, they were contrained to ret themelves, with intention to depart as oon as the Moon began to appear; but the paines and toile which the hepheardees had taken all the day, and a great part of the night, had o tired them, that they lept longer than they intended; for when the Moon was up, and very light, the hepheards themelves were all aleep. But on the contrary, the ad Celadon, according to his cutome, was up betimes, purpoely to entertain his own thoughts, and none met him, for his ue was, to walk mot out when others lept, and hut up himelfe all the day. The Sun did not yet appear, when it was his fortune to walk towards the place where this company was; and being wholly taken up with his ad thoughts, never minding any thing about him, never man was o planet-truck as he was, when upon a udden he epied Atrea: he had a thin handkerchief upon her eyes, which did a little cover her face, one arme under her head, and the other by her ide, her petticoat a little ruffled up, o as one might ee the delicate proportion of her leg; the admirable purenee of her neck was plainly een, the azure veins upon a nowy skin did ravih; and becaue he was a little trait laced, he unlaced her elfe, and the rich treaure of her breats appeared; her hair was looe and lay negligently upon her lovely cheeks. Oh! what a viion was this unto Celadon? he was o amazed, that he tood tock till, without any pule or breath, or any igne of life, but the beating of his heart, and his ight which was fixed upon this fair object. It was with him, as with thoe who have been long in darknee, and come uddenly into the rayes of the Sun, and are dazled with too much light, and cannot ee. Preently after, having a little recollected himelfe, he began to conider what he aw; looking ometimes upon her lovely face, ometimes upon her breat, whoe treaures were never before dicovered; and he wihed, Argos-like, that he had a body all of eyes. But in the midt of this pleaing contemplation, a thought came into his minde, which blated all his joy. Retire, retire, unfortunate hepheard (aid he) retire from this bleed place, let it be no longer profaned with thy unhallowed eyes: Hat thou o oon forgot her commands? Dot thou not remember, it is not lawfull for thee to preent thy elfe before her eyes? Away, away, for hame offend no longer. Thus he went away, with folded armes, and eyes lifted up to heaven, as if he had left heart oul life, and all behinde him: His thoughts and his way were much different; for the further he went from Atrea,
the more his thoughts followed him. When he was out of ight, he was o troubled, as he was forced to tay: To go on, aid he, I cannot; to return, I dare not; and to tay here, is to no purpoe: What then hould I do? Go, go, aid he, and receive that favour, which the heavens, unasked, does betow upon thee. But how can I contradict the command of her, whom I did never diobey? But, anwered he, it is not contradicting her command; for he did not command me, not to ee her, for then I hould put out my eyes; but her command was, that I hould not come in her ight; and how can he ee me when he is aleep? Take Love therefore for thy guide, and under his conduct go and adore her. Being moved with this conideration, he turned back, and went as oftly as he could, let he hould awake her; as oon as he came o neer as to ee her, he kneeled down, adored her, and preented this prayer unto her, in a whipering voice.

Oh great and puiant goddee! ince it is more god-like to pardon then to punih, I mot devoutly protrate my elfe upon my knees before you. I will not argue the matter with you, nor aske, whether my torments, which I have uffered through my ins, be not above the grandure of them, ince I inned ignorantly; only I beg for pitty. Shew your elfe all divine in pardoning, and remitting me to my lot felicity; for my ubmiion may as well move you to pardon, as my unknown offence unto punihment.

This was the prayer of the ad hepheard, not daring hardly to let the words go out of his lips, for fear of waking her, unto whom they were addreed. Then he aroe and went neerer to her, the better to look upon her: As he was deeply in his contemplation, Phillis turned her elfe from one ide to the other, yet not opening her eyes, nor waking. This put Celadon in uch a fright, that he ran as fat as he could unto his ad habitation, where he no ooner was, but thinking upon this encounter, and that of the day before, he knew not whether he hould take it as a good or a bad preage. At the lat, thinking upon that Letter which he put into the hand of Silvander, (for he uppoed Atrea did know of it) he reolved to hazard another; and therefore, to loe no time, he went to write it; let he hould be too late, and the hepheardees awake. He upercribed this as he did the firt, and went with all hate to the place where he left his hepheardee; but being afraid he hould be awake when he came neer her, he crept behinde ome Trees, and looking every way, he knew they were till aleep; but he found the company was greater then he perceived at the firt, becaue then he did not ee the hepheards, of whom we poke before; and, to ee whether any of them was of his acquaintance, he went gently towards them; the firt he aw was Silvander: Oh faithfull friend, (aid he, in a low voice) how much am I obliged unto thee, for doing more for me then I durt ever ask? Then turning his eyes upon the other foure hepheards, he knew none of them; yet he thought, he had een Tircis heretofore. Finding them all thus aleep, he went towards the hepheardees. The Sun was already a good height, and finding paage through the leaves, it began to hine in ome places upon them, o as if this hepheard had been as impartiall a Judge of Beauty, as he was a perfect Lover, he could hardly have told unto which of all thee he hould have given the prize of Beauty: But as the long griefs of Atrea had then made her yield omething unto Diana, o the affection of this hepheard did upply that defect, and gave judgment on Atrea's ide. Then looking particularly upon Atrea, he kneeled down, and could not chue but kie her fair hand, afterwards did put the Letter into her breat; and being tranported with love, he could not chue but kie her mouth: Oh how the hepheard was ravihed! he had almot quite forgot all fears of waking her, and leaned o upon her, that he began to awake, and opened her drouie eyes, when he was halfe rien up; and had not the Sun-beams, which hined upon her face, dazled her eyes, doubtlee he had known him; this was the reaon he could not ee him, but as a haddow, and when he began to look after him, her hair was o intangld with a few ruhes that was under her head, that they did hinder her; o as he could not chue but cry out aloud Phillis tarted up and asked her what the matter was? But Atrea was o atonihed, that he could not peak, but till untangled her hair. Phillis eeing Atrea up, and let a paper fall, he aroe alo, and was very officious to take it up, following her ome twenty paces from the place where they lay. Then Atrea at down under a Tree, extreamly pale, and ready to wound, which Phillis eeing, he helped her all he could; and when he was a little come unto her elfe: Oh dear Siter, (aid he unto Phillis, with a deep igh) what is this which I have een? Then he was ilent a long while, and could not peak for ighing; a little after,
he began with a very great igh, and aid: Oh Siter, I have een Celadon, I mean his Ghot. At this word [Celadon] her voice failed, and her tongue could not do its office; but he joyned her hands together, and lited her eyes up to heaven, as if from thence he begged help. Phillis eeing her in this condition believed, that he had been in ome afrighting dream: Siter, aid he unto her, there is no credit to be given unto any dreams, they are no more but the working of the fancy and imagination, upon uch ubjects as have been een or thought upon; nor are they any preages of things future, only images and fancies of things pat. Ah Siter, aid Atrea, this was no dream; I aw him with thee eyes, and as oon as ever he aw I looked upon him, he vanihed into aire. Perhaps, Siter, (aid Phillis) you did but think your elfe to be awake, for o it often happens in leep. No, no, (aid Atrea) I was awake. And how did you ee him, aid Phillis? I was (aid Atrea) betwixt leeping and waking, when I heard ome ighing about me, even about my face; and when I opened my eyes, I aw the oul of Celadon before me: but, Oh heavens! how glorious and full of light it was? the Sun it elfe had no more plendent lutre; And, Siter, I was even dazled at the ight of it, untill I came hither; but as oon as ever I did cat my eye upon him, he vanihed like lightning. Oh glorious Soul! thou hadt good reaon not to let the ight of her fully thee, who was o undicreetly carelee of thy life. How infinitely am I obliged unto thee, who having o much reaon to hate me, yet makes it appear, that thy love continues. Phillis, with much amazement, did now believe, that certainly it was the oul of Celadon, and therefore aid thus unto her: All we can do for thoe who are departed this life, is to preerve their memory, to talk often of their vertues, and to render them the lat office of pitty, which is buriall; therefore I am of opinion, that it is requiite, for your own contentinent, and atisfaction of this oul, who o much loved you, that you do caue a Tombe to be built, in which it may ret, and to preerve the memory of him amongt us as long as poibly we can. That hall I do, aid Atrea, as long as any life is in me. But, Siter, (aid Atrea) would it not be taken ill, that I, who am not a kin unto him, hould render him this lat office of a Sepulcher? What can be aid, (anwered Phillis) but that his kindred neglecting their duty, you have done what they ought to have done? Were he alive, there might ome doubt be made of it; but being dead, they may well imagine, that your pat amity, which is known as well as your name, would require o much of you. As Phillis was thus talking to her, he held in her hand the paper which he took up, and Atrea cating her eye accidentally upon it, and knowing it to be Celadon's hand, he asked her, what Letter that was which he held in her hand? Phillis anwered, that he took it up, eeing it fall from her as he aroe. I did feel omething (aid Atrea) fall from my breat; but I was o much out of my elfe, that I never minded it. Then taking it, and reading the Supercription, he aid, it was that Letter which Silvander found. That cannot be, (aid Phillis) for I have that in my pocket; and putting her hand into it, he pulled it out. What hould it then be, aid Atrea? I am ure it is the ame hand. Then reading it, he found thee words.

body.head: Celadon's Letter unto the Shepheardee Atrea
body.p: IF the occaion of your comming into this place, where all that remaines of Celadon yet is, was only to ee what power you have over him, it was too much paines for a thing of o little value. If any parks of compaion brought you hither, what ervices can merit o great a recompence? If fortune only, without any deigne, was your conductor, it was too kinde unto one that is o mierable: So as whatoever the occaion was, there was no reaon for it. That affection which I had unto you, was beyond all bounds of reaon, and therefore it is mot jut, that reaon hould didain him, who didained reaon. However, I thank you, as the vam hadow of a man can do, (for truly • am no more) for comming to ee what power you have over me, for it is one of my greatet deires to live in your memory. I thank you alo, that you would permit pitty to bring you hither; for though it be very late, yet conolation is better late then never. Alo I do thank you, For • o lowing fortune into this place, ince I know by it, that it was only long of her, I did no ooner reent the effects of your weetnee. This lat conideration moves me to ay, that as you are the fairet Shepheardee in the whole Univere; o ince fortune and my own contancy wi •• have it o, I am the mut unfortunate, but the mot affectionately faithfull, of all your Servants.

div.p: Now did thee hepheardees believe, that Celadon was dead indeed, and Love made Atrea reolve, to render him the lat duty of her amity. Then he went to wake Diana and the other hepheardees, becaue it was late; when they came, they found Silvander looking upon Diana as he lept; and, gazing like an immovable Statue, he uttered thee words in a very loud voice: Oh! how this fair one deprives me of that ret which he takes her elfe? See how many Cupids play about her lovely face! Who can chue but love her, and loe that ret which he findes? To look upon her and to love her, is one and the ame thing. And if he captivate thus when he is aleep, and without deigne, what is he able to do when hee's awake, and will ue her power?

He poke thus loud, becaue he was not afraid of awaking her, ince he commanded him o to do, as oon as the Moon hined. But Celadon's good fortune would not have it o, to the end he might enjoy the happinee of eeing his Mitree in that place. After Silvander had uttered thee words, he kneeled down to kie her hand; but fearing to be een by thee two hepheardees, who he aw were not in their places, he roe up, very orry he had done o much, if he were een. In the mean time, thee two hepheardees looked upon him, and Phillis, who was very deirous to divert Atrea; Never trut me, Siter (aid he unto her) if this hepheard do not love Diana, and is not o ubtle as he thinks himelfe. I poke yeterday with Diana (anwered Atrea, very adly) and for ought I could perceive, he can expect nothing but much orrow; for, he will neither love him, nor uffer him to love her. That reolution (aid Phillis) may in a hort time bring Silvander into the ame condition with Celadon, and Diana into the ame tate with Atrea. Ah Siter, (aid Atrea) Silvander may run that fortune; but as long as Diana is free from love, her fortune will never be o bad as mine. I do confee (replyed Phillis) that if he be really exempt from love he is not in that danger; but, if he be exempt only out of diimulat ••• , what think you then? That he will be happy only in opinion, aid Atrea, and in deed and truth mierable. But there is no likelyhood of that, Diana's humour, and Silvander's perfections, being uch, that neither the hepheardee nor he, can be ubject unto uch dyaters. Upon this, Phillis took her by the hand and walked towards Diana; yet anwered her; Oh Siter (aid he) you are deceived, if you be of that opinion: for, as concerning the merits of Silvander, believe it, that when a hepheard has a deigne to pleae, he prueth himelfe up, and is quite another man from what he really is: And hence it is, that we often wonder to ee ome hepheards loved and welcomed, who are thought not at all pleaing or handome; and from hence, I believe, the Proverb came, that, Love makes all eem handome: Nay, I will ay more, I never yet aw any hepheard dipleaing unto her he courted, if there were not ome other occaion of hatred then his love; for, their courthip and deire to pleae, does make them dree up themelves in the moothet garb they can, purpoely to render themelves complaiant: as this is the quality of all in generall, o more pecially in Silvander, whoe wit, and handome compoure by nature, may eaily upply all defects. And as for the humour of Diana, her affection unto Philander is an infallible argument, that he hath not been alwaies inenible of Love; and why may not that which was once, be again. For my part, I do believe, Love is as good an Archer as ever he was, and has not forgotten the skill he ued, the firt time he wounded her: and Silvander may have the ame fortune Philander had. In this (aid Atrea) you and I do differ in opinion, and I do think it impoible, Diana hould ever love again; for I think, a Maid, who never was in love, may eaily be allured by the pleaing flatteries of it; but impoible, that a tayed peron, who did once love, and lot the peron loved, hould ever let love take any root again in her oul: And me-thinks the Cypree-Tree is a right emblem of my affection, which, when once cut, never puts out branch again. As oon as he had aid o, they were come o neer unto Diana, that Phillis could make no other anwer but this: Siter, we hall quickly ee, which of our opinions is the right.

Whilt thee hepheardees were thus talking, Paris, Hylas, Tircis, and Therander, being awakened by Silvander, they came to the hepheardees, and poke o loud, that they awaked Diana. She was much ahamed, to ee her elfe almot quite undret, amongt all that good company; and therefore holding her hair with one hand, and covering her breat with the other, he went further from them behinde ome Trees: Atrea and Phillis followed her, and whilt he dreed her elfe, related unto her Atrea's viion, how the Letter fell from her breat, and how Atrea had reolved to build a Tombe for the oul of Celadon, ince his Kindred neglected it.
This office (anwered Diana) is indeed full of piety and pitty, and for my part, I hould not diapprove of it, if it would not be an occaion of much talk and wonder, that the enmity of your Parents hould be changed into o much good-will. What wonder will it be, replyed the ad hepheardee? It would be more trange, if this enmity hould continue after death. If Celadon were alive, doubtlee I hould not let the affection which I bear unto him, be known. But, alas! ince to my oules eternall adnee, he is not alive, I would not have both earth and heaven ignorant of it. And upon this reaon, I do ground my reolution; my friends will never finde fault with any thing that hall pleae me, and as for the ret, I will never deprive my elfe of my contentment, to content them. Since you are reolved upon it, anwered Diana, I conceive, that the ooner you do it, the better; and if you will take my counell, it hall be before you depart hence. But (aid Phillis) where will you finde things neceary for it, unlee we firt go unto our Town? The Temple of the good goddee (aid Diana) where the Druides Daughters, and the Vetalls do inhabit, is not far from hence, and they will not deny any thing that is requiite for o good a work. But let us call Paris and the hepheards, and ask them their advice. Upon this, Phillis called them, and they came unto her. Then Diana taking Paris aide, acquainted him with the viion and deigne of Atrea; and becaue, aid he, detraction and calumny is apt to apere the puret innocency, I deire this courteie from you, that this Tomb may be erected in your name, though intended by the hepheardee. You may command me all that is within the compae of my power, aid Paris, for I am devoted wholly unto your ervice. After Diana had given him very hearty thanks, he deired him to acquaint all the Company with this intention; which he did, o dicreetly, as every one, except Silvander, believed, that this deigne proceeded from him; but that hepheard, not being ignorant of Atrea's affection unto Celadon, did upect this to be an handome umbrage: And becaue he highly eteemed Atrea's • he, he himelfe helped in the diimulation, and offered to go unto the Temple of the good goddee, to borrow uch things as were neceary for it. Atrea her elfe would go alo, thinking that her preence would prevail much, becaue of the affection which Chriante, the Governee of the Druides Daughters, had unto her. She therefore deired Phillis and Laonice to tay there with Diana, whilt Madonthe and he went with Silvander and Therander unto the Temple, which was cloe by, with a promie to be back again, as oon as Paris and the other hepheards had raied up a bank of gray Tur • es, and prepared flowers and all things neceary. Thus went the hepheardee Atrea away; and Paris beginning to work, made choice of a place neer that where they lept, which was a little plain, void of Trees, where abundance of everall orts of flowers did grow, as if it were purpoely reerved for uch a buinee. Tircis and Hylas, with the iron of their heephooks and knives, for want of better Tooles, did cut the Sods of grae, and pilde them one upon another, in the modell of a Tombe, whilt Diana, Phillis, and Laonice, did gather variety of flowers to trew upon it, when the ceremony was to be performed; every one was o diligent in their everall charges, that they finihed it in a little time. Now there wanted nothing but a columne to be et upon it, which hould demontrate the place where Celadon dyed, and contain his Epitaph: but having no Hatchet to cut it, nor Inke to write withall, they were at a great tand. At lat, Tircis remembered, that at the Temple of the goddee Atrea, Hylas had found ome way to write, when he falified the Lawes of Love, and therefore doubtlee he left the pen and ink there; therefore they deired him to go and fetch it. He, in obedience to the commands of his Mitree, went immediately, and promied to return preently. Paris, deirous to have all things ready, addreing himelfe unto Diana, he told her, that it was requiite to make choice of a Pole to upport the Piramis, that they would try if they could cut it with their knives; and let they hould be wanting when Atrea came, they would go to look for one that way which he was to come. Leaving therefore the River upon the left hand, they went into the Wood, to look for this Pole amongt the young Trees: But they went through the Wood, and never minded this Pole; for Diana, he thought, that Paris did look out for one that was fit, but Paris was o taken up with the thoughts of her, that he never minded either North or South-Pole, nor any ele; which Diana perceiving, he aid unto Tircis: I thought, that we hould not have been o curious in our choice of this Pole, as not to finde one in all this Wood. I conceive (anwered Tircis) that there are many good ones for the purpoe. It mut be a very great one (aid Paris) otherwie it will not erve. But it mut not be too great and tall (aid Tircis) let the winde hould preently blow it
down; o as if it be about twenty foot long, it will be big enough. 'Tis very true anwered Paris; but I mut needs confee, that my thoughts were o much upon another thing, as I never minded or looked for one. How, aid Diana, and miled, have you made us loe all our labour? Then Paris turning towards Tircis, deired him to make choice of one that was fit, and aid unto Diana: Blame me not, I beeech you, fair Diana, for the fault which I have committed, for it is abolutely impoible to be o neer you, and think upon any thing ele. That excue (anwered Diana) might be mine as well as yours; for I being o neer you, my thoughts alo might have been as much of you. If your merits and mine were equall, (anwered Paris) or our wills the ame, then perhaps it might have been your excue as well as mine. If there was any fault, it was on my ide, anwered Diana. Yes, aid Paris preently, for there was nothing in me which could take up your thoughts. I do not apprehend that to be the caue, aid Diana, for I do eteem and honour you as I ought to do. I would to god, Diana, (anwered Paris) that you were as jut as you are fair. Wherein do you think me unjut, (aid Diana) for how hould I eteem and honour you more then I do? This eteem and this honour, of which you peak (aid he) is not that which I demand; but if you would be pleaed to change this eteem into affection, and this honour into familiarity, I hould be fully contented and atisfied. I know you (anwered he) more reaonable, then to deire any more: Content your elfe, generous Paris, that I do love and eteem you as much, as if you were my Brother: I know, that I being a hepheardee, and you as you are, I ought not to go any further; but I had rather offend againt the Lawes of civility, than dipleae you, ince it is your pleaure to have it o. This, replyed Paris, is a beginning of what I deire, but not all. In this (anwered Diana) as in all things ele, your deires mut be ruled by reaon. Is it not reaonable (aid Paris) that Diana hould make choice of one, whom he will create happy, and with whom he may live happily? This choice (replyed Diana) is a piece of great difficulty, and I will ever refer it unto thoe, that are wier than my elfe. Who are they, aid Paris? Who hould they be, anwered Diana, but my Mother and my Uncle? Paris would have replyed, if Tircis had not interrupted him, and told him, that he had found out a fit Pole. Diana was very glad of this, for this dicoure began to vex her. Paris, on the contrary, was very orry; for he deired to know of her, whether he would be pleaed to let him peak unto them concerning it. But Diana fearing it, he deired Phillis not to be o far from her as he had been, let Paris hould fall into this dicoure again: But having made choice of a Pole, they tryed to cut it; but their knives not being trong enough, they were contrained only to mark it, and tay till Atrea returned, believing, that Silvander would not forget any thing that was requiite for the buinee. Walking therefore towards the Temple of the good goddee, and Paris till hoping to fall into his dicoure again, they epyed, as they were going out of the Wood, a hepheardee, itting under a hady Sycamour, and her hair being very long and curled, as it covered her almot all over as he at, they could not imagine what it hould be; but approaching a little neerer, they knew her to be a hepheardee; yet, ince her dihevelled hair would not let them ee her face, they were very deirous to approach neerer: And as they were looking upon her, they aw a young hepheard come, and fall upon his knees before her, who urpried her before he had time to rie: Neither this hepheard nor hepheardee were known unto any of this Company, although they were both inhabitants in their neighbouring Town. As for the hepheardee, he might well be aid to be fair, and the negligence of her hair and habit, rather added then took away from her handomnee. But this Company was mot of all amazed, to ee another hepheard, who epying them, did look upon them with a trange dicompoed action, yet had a deire to conceal it, and himelfe both; ometimes he thrut his head out of the buh which covered him, and hearkened what they aid with a mot attentive ear; othertimes he did hake and cratch his head, and upon a udden hold both his hands up to heaven, then let them fall again in a paionate poture. To be briefe, he was o impatient to ee them together, that abundance of paion appeared in all his actions. On the other ide, the hepheardee eemed o dipleaed with the ight of him that kneeled before her, as he would not daigne him a look, but made all the hate he could in dreing her elfe, that he might be gone from that place. Diana and her Company eeing the beauty and didain of this hepheardee, alo the affection and ubmiion of him that kneeled before her, and the paionate apprehenions of him that looked on, they had a great deire to know more of the buinee; and therefore, untill Atrea returned, they approached as neer as they could uneen unto
them, & then they heard the hepheard with a deep igh ay thus unto her: Is it poible, fair hepheardee, that neither my deire to erve you, nor the power you have to make your elf adored, hould have any prevalence with you? I know not (anwered he didainfully) what your deires are, nor what my power is; but I am ure, that any thing which comes from you can never pleae me. This (anwered the hepheard) is the wort of misfortunes that ever could befall me. If cutome (replyed the hepheardee) do make things difficult to be eaily upported, me thinks you hould not o deeply reent the misfortunes of it, ince you have been o long accutomed unto it; for, ever ince the firt houre you declared your minde unto me, I did o cleerly acquaint you with mine, as you might that firt time have known as much, as you have ince found, or ever hall do. Oh Doris, (anwered the hepheard) if my oul were as regardlee of your didaines, as your heart is of my prayers, certainly I hould never have reented them: But alas, this cutome renders me more enible, as he, who has a heavy burthen upon his back, the longer he carries it, the more inupportable it is. The hepheardee was a long while without reply, and was intent only upon dreing her elfe; but eeing he offered to begin again, he interrupted his peech: Adrates, aid he, all your language is to no purpoe; and let me tell you this once for all, that I will neither love nor be loved; and unlee you will have me mot abominably hate you, trouble me no more. Oh ye gods! (aid the hepheard) what dimall doom is this? Then turning towards her: Is it poible, aid he unto her, that the gods hould be weary of being adored by mortalls, and that you hould be weary of being o by me? Nay, Adrates, aid he, never wonder at it, for I am no goddee; or if I were, any acrifice hould be more acceptable unto me than yours; and I had rather be without any temples or altars, then have uch adorers. Upon this lat expreion, he had done dreing her elfe, and therefore he took up her heephook and went away, leaving this poor hepheard o adly afflicted, that he had not power or boldnee to follow her.

p.hi: Diana
p.U: eeing her depart thus, he had a minde to call upon her; but eeing alo that he went towards the other hepheard, he thought it better to tay, and hear more: And indeed, the other hepheard eeing her comming towards him, he went to meet her, and held her by the gown, let he hould go away; he deired to be out of his hands, but the hepheard preently kneeled down, and begged pardon for his fault. It is not your fault only in thus holding me, that you ought to repent of, aid he; but, hepheard, becaue of that fault, which hath quite extinguihed all the good-will which I did bear unto you. As for that, anwered he, in lieu of language, I will expiate it with my blood and life; but dare not beg, unlee in ilence and ubmiion, ince indeed I do not well know what it is Palemon, replyed he, there is none o ignorant, as he that will not know when he may: But that is all one to me, for I am o perfectly cured of the wound, that there is not any mark of it remaines. It is an eaie matter, aid the hepheard to cure a wound that was but very mal. I will not tell you, anwered he, how it began to feter, let I hould increae your vanity; but let me tell you, that I had rather die, then relape into that dieae out of which I am recovered; and I had rather never ee any whilt I live, then ee you in the condition and tate in which you were wont to be: Alo, I charge you to talk no more of it, nor to retain me by any force. Since you are pleaed, aid he, to forbid me peaking; yet, I beeech, permit me to ing, what my heart does adly reent. Then he ighed, and ung out thee Veres; which he, to vex him, anwered.

div.stage: A Dialogue, between Palemon and Doris.

l.hi: IF I do any love but you, may I
Be damn'd, and tortur'd be eternally.
May I a Statue turn, and never move,
If any other but my elfe I love.
Love or love not, yet you l'le till adore,
That you my contancy may ee the more.
Love or love not, faith all is one to me:
But that I love you, you hall never ee.
Though heaven and earth conpire to croe my will,
Yet will I vanquih them, and love you till.
My heart is o avere to love, that I,
Rather than love, a hundred deaths will die.
Your pride, in corning all men living, mut
Be punihed in you, if heaven be jut.
If heaven be jut, as none deny it dare,
It will us keep both in the mindes we are.
It is mot jut, if you, to love, it move,
But mot unjut, in taking hopes from love.
If you to love, and me to hate, it move,
'I will punih you, and will revenge my love.

div.p: Though Doris was very tart in all her anwers, yet the hepheard did take ome kinde of delight in eeing and hearing her talk, but he, deiring to avoid his company, he came towards the place where Diana was, who eeing he could not hide her elfe any longer, he and her company advanced towards this hepheardee, and after common alutations, aid unto her: I wonder not, weet Doris, that thee hepheards whom I ee with you, hould be o much captivated with your beauty, ince it is uch, as thoe mut needs be blinde, that do not admire it; but, I mut needs wonder at the cruelty you ue towards them, ince you are the only he, who didaines that which is their own, and which you have gotten by uch fair and deer armes. Whilt Diana was aying o, Palemon came to them, and heard Doris return this anwer.

Sage hepheardee, that beauty, which out of your complaiance you are pleaed to call mine, is mot really and truly your own, and to be admired by all uch as ee you: And I do not know with what armes I have captivated thee you peak of unlee uch as are very unhappy in making uch a conquet. Beauty, aid Diana, does well become all women, but pride and preumption does much eclipe beauty. Did you know, anwered Doris, the occaion which makes me peak thus, you would wonder at the power which I have over my elfe, in being able o much as to look upon this hepheard. Upon this, Palemon kneeled down, and with his hat in his hand, addreed himelfe thus unto Diana: I do beeech and conjure you, Oh mot wie and dicreet hepheardee, by the peron whom you mot do love, and by that weetnee which your eyes do promie, to take o much pains as to hear our difference; if you hall think me culpable, I will not value my life; but if, on the contrary, he be in the wrong I hall only aske leave to erve her as long as I live.

Diana would have anwered, when he aw Atrea returning from the Temple, with a greater company than he carried with her; for the Nymph Leonida was there, and Chryante, the Governee of the Druides, with ome of the Virgins, who came to honour the Funeralls of Celadon, bringing with them the Priet of that place, who did officiate in the daily acrifice of the Town, in the Temple of the good goddee. This Priet brought thither all that was neceary for the empty Tombe of Celadon; the Druides Daughters were loadned, ome with flowers, others with milk, and others with wine and water, and did drive before them the heep and young bulls requiite for the acrifice. Lycidas alo, being come that morning unto the Temple of the good goddee, to pay ome vowes, and make ome prayers, which haply his jealouie prompted him unto, he likewie came, being acquainted with the deigne of Paris, for the Ret, of his Brothers oul, though it went to his heart to ee Phillis and Silvander there; and having made choice of a great Sowe to acrifice, according to the cutome, unto Ceres and the Earth, he gently followed after this Company.

Diana therefore eeing this great company following Atrea, he could not give anwer either to the hepheard or hepheardee, only this, that the Nymph Leonida, who was comming with o many Druides, would beglad to hear their difference; and after the Ceremony was ended, at which they would do an act of pitty, if they would be
preent he could compoe all the buinee betwixt them. So, not taying for any anwer, he with Paris advanced, and went to alute the Nymph and Chryante. After ome common dicoure, the Priet asked, where Celadon's Tombe was erected, and being conducted thither by Paris, he went about his work: But firt, he began with the Sowe which Lycidas brought, as a acrifice unto Ceres and the Earth; then killing the Sheep and young black Bulls, he kept the blood of them in bowles; he ordered the Druides Daughters according to the Ceremony, unto ome he gave the acred Milke, unto others the Wine, and made choice of Lycidas to carry the Altar-water. Then going to the Tombe, he prinkled all thee things with a little bough of Cypree, calling divers times upon the oul of Celadon. Then they poured the Water, the Wine, the Milk, & the Blood upon the Tomb, calling till upon the oul of Celadon. Then all the Druides Daughters and others, with their hair diheveled begun with tears & ad condolings to lament the los of Celadon: When they had continued a while in this pittifull office, the Priet began to go round about the Tomb three times, and every one following, & trewing Roes and Flowers upon the gras, he aid in a loud voice: Adieu, CELADON, adieu, for ever adieu; may thy oul ret, and the earth be light upon thee. The Nymph Leonida did the like, trewing Flowers upon the Tomb, though he knew well enough he was not dead. Paris followed her, and all the hepheards and hepheardeses in a file after him. Whilt the Druides Daughters were inging this ad Hymne, and lamenting the los of this hepheard, every one, according to the cutome told what they knew of his life and actions, how generally he was loved, how he honoured his Father and Mother, how affectionate he was unto all his Kindred, how often he had vanquihed all thoe that contentended with him at any Exercie, uuall amongt hepheards, and how every one lamented his untimely death, as a great los unto all the Country. It was well for Atrea, that all thee hepheards and hepheardeses went about Celadon's Tombe in a confued order, and bad eternall adieu unto him; for had he gone by her elfe alone, he had given them all a knowledge of her orrowes, which, being amongt others, did not at all appear. Now all thee Ceremonies being performed, there remained no more but the erecting this Pole, in reemblance of a Columne, intimating the place where Celadon dyed; which the Priet not knowing, Atrea was to inform him, which was no mall renewing of her orrowes; this Column then being erected, there remained no more, then to fix upon it Celadon's Epitaph, which Silvander had writ in a Table which the Priet had brought; for Hylas was not yet returned from fetching the Inke and Pen from the Temple of the goddes Atrea. The Epitaph and Incription which Silvandar writ, was this.
To the Eternall memory of the mot beloved Shepheard about the River Lignon.
Love, that had imprudently been a caue of CELADON's death, hath payed his repentant tears, broke his Bow and Arrowes, and extinguihed his Torch.

Full of orrowes and lamentation for o ad a loe, he leaves them upon his Tombe, as an eternall tetimony of his tears, who having lot o amiable a Subject will never imploy his Arrowes and his Torch again, in vain.

Every one applauded the Genius of Silvander, epecially Atrea and Diana, conceiving, that had he known their mindes, he could not have compoed a better Epitaph. When all their lamentations were ended, Leonida took Chriante by her hand, and went with her out of the Wood, all the Company following them. And it eemes, Diana had forgotten Palemon's requet, when Adrates and he beeeched her, to move Leonida and Chriante unto a hearing of their complaints, and to judge as they thought reaonable. Diana therefore addresed her elfe unto Leonida: Great Nymph, aid he, a little before
your comming, thee hepheards, offended againt this hepheardes, would have referred their differences unto me; but I advied them to tay, untill this ceremony was ended, and then to addres themelves unto you and the wie Chriantes, if you would be pleaed to take o much paines as to hear them, auring my elfe, that the judgment which you two hould give, would be o jut, as they would willingly be concluded by it. The Nymph, who was all civility, did lend a willing eare unto this hepheardes, and thee two hepheards: Chriante did the like, and when he offered to peak, Palemon and Adrates falling upon their knees, aid thus unto her: If any Lovers ever merited any pitty upon their paines, believe it, Madam, thee two are they that may bet claime it; o as you do an act worthy of your elfe, if you will be pleaed to hear their difference, and to ordain, not as reaon, but as love inpires you; for it is only from Loves jutice, and not from any other of the gods, that we expect or deire reliefe. Truly, aid the Nymph, if you, fair hepheardes, do think, that the venerable Chriante and my elfe, are able to hear and determine your differences, we hall be very glad to ettle you all in tranquility, if we can. Doris, with a weet and reverend modety, anwered thus: Great Nymph, thee hepheards here, will but abue that favour which you do them, in hearing them, and do make unto you a upplication, which is very diadvantageous unto themelves, manifeting, that they know not what they ask for if you hould be pleaed to take o much pains, as to hear us, you will dicover the knavery and infidelity, and the oolery and troubleomnes of the other. However, Madam, ince your goodnes does infinitely urpas our follies, I will refer unto the judgment of you and the reverent Chriante, upon condition, that both they and I be obliged, to obey and abide whatoever you hall doom. I do vow, aid Palemon, that I will rather diobey the gods, then your commands. And I, aid Adrates, do protet, that I will love you as long as I live, what doom oever be made to the contrary; but I do protet withall, by the holy Mileto, that if I be doomed to quit you, you hall never be troubled with my affection. And by this you may know, that the affection of my Rivall is inferiour unto mine Adrates, Adrates, (aid Palemon then) you are much mitaken, if you think, I will obey the doom of this great Nymph, if it command lee then the end of my life; o as you intending to live after the entence, and I to die my paion being greater then yours, I am uperiour to you in true affection. Adrates faintly anwered: Since you can o abolutely dipoe of your life, and of your death, it argues, that you have a power over your elfe. But alas! my affection is o wholly Mitree of my will and oul, as it will not let me dipoe of my elfe o freely as you do.

If Leonida had not interrupted them, they had not o oon ended their dipute, o exceedingly deirous they were to hew unto Doris the grandure of their love. But the Nymph, taking the venerable Chriante by one hand, and Doris by the other: Let us (aid he) finde out a place convenient for us to it down in, that we may with more eae hear the reaons which each will alledge. Upon this, every hepheard took a hepheardes by the hand; Tircis, Atrea; Paris, Diana; and Silvander, eeing his place taken up, and oberving, how Lycidas looked aquint upon Phillis, and would not come neer her, he reolved to augment his miery, ince he was without any reaon jealous of him; and therefore he addresed himelfe unto Phillis, and would by all means take her hand: But he, who oberved the eye of Lycidas, turned away to avoid him, eeming as if he went to call ome of her companions. But for all that, Silvander was reolute, and turned as well as he. Phillis, durt not publickly refue him, let thoe who aw her hould take it ill; and not enduring he hould thus follow her, he aid unto him: Do you think, Silvander, that I am at all obliged unto you, for being thus officious about me for want of another? Silvander knew very well why he aid o, but, as if he were ignorant, he came to her eare, and eeming to whiper, he preently went away from her, and eemed very angry that Lycidas aw him. This went to the very heart of Lycidas, for he thought, that he left Phillis only becaue of him, and that certainly there was a cloe corepondency betwixt them; and therefore, not being able to endure this ight, he endeavoured by little and little to retire.

But Phillis being very deirous to be reconciled unto him, and eeing him linking away: Lycidas, aid he, will you go away? I pray you come hither, and hear the dicoure of thee trangers. There is very good Company without me, anwered he, ince there is too much contraint where I am. Were I of your counell, aid Phillis, I would advie you to value your own contentment above any others. I ee, aid Lycidas, that you give
me uch counell as you do follow your elfe, and I am very orry I cannot do the like; but truly, I have not o much power over my elfe. Phillis did very well undertand what he meant, and was netled to the very oul: yet, faigning otherwie, he anwered him thus: I believe, Lycidas, that if the Nymph hould undertake to agree all differences in the Company, you and I hould not be out of the number. I do believe the ame (aid the hepheard, and bluhed for anger) but it would be Silvander that were the fittet judge. And why Silvander, aid the hepheardes? Becaue, aid he, there is none that is better informed. Upon this, not taying for any anwer, he flung away into the Wood as fat as he could. This paage did o ting the oul of Phillis, that one could not get a good word from her all that day.

Whilt Leonida and the venerable Chriante were in quet of a convenient place to it down in, they epied ome hepheardees in the Wood, comming towards them; for, the Trees being at a good ditance from one another, without any underwood, one might ee a great way, both through and beyond it. When Leonida asked who they were, none could tell her; but when they were a little neerer, Hylas, who was amongt them, was known to be one; and preently after, the hepheardeses were alo known to be Palinice and Florice, with whom Hylas met upon the way, and tayed with them, never thinking upon the Inke which he went to eek; and had they not asked him whither he went, and from whence he came, he had not remembered what he went about; but this quetion putting him in memory, he deired them to tay a little, till he went for the Inke, and he would return to them. Then he acquainted them with the Ceremony of Celadon's Tombe, unto which they came to be aitants; but they came too late. Leonida not knowing who they were, he deired to ee them. And Hylas, whoe tongue was never mute, came on a jolly pace, inging thee veres.

lg.head: That he is a Fool, who loves and is not loved. A Song.

lg.l: WHen I a Lover pale do ee,
Ready to faint and ickih be,
With hollow eyes, and cheeks o thin,
As all his face is noe and chin:
When uch a Ghot I ee in pain,
Becaue he is not lov'd again;
And pute, and faint, and wound, and cry:
Oh! There's your loving Fool, ay I.
For, love with love hould be repaid,
And equally on both ides laid.
Love is a load, a Hore would kill,
If it do hang on one ide till.
But, if he needs will be o fond,
As rules of reaon go beyond,
And love, when he's not lov'd again,
Faith, let him take it for his pain.

div.p:
Thee trangers were o neer Leonida and Chriante, that the Nymph knowing Hylas, he roe up to alute them, and Chriante alo, being informd by her who they were, he did the ame. And becaue Phillis laughed at Hylas, for not bringing the Inke: Do you think, hepheardee, aid he unto her, that I came into Forrets to do any ervice for the dead? Thircis, that has nothing ele to do, may do well to employ his time in uch melancholly moods; but as for Hylas, he is of another temper: And therefore do not think it trange, if by an honet leave I tell you, that if you do not like me as I am, you mut never think to finde any alteration in me when I am old. Phillis, who had other matters in her head, did thus anwer him: I wear, Hylas, if you were of any other temper then what you are, I hall not love you o well as I do. But, as I mut not hope to change you, o you mut not think to make me any other then what I am; and therefore, when I
would laugh, let me laugh, and let me be ilent when I have no minde to talk, and I will allow your humours the like liberty; o in this freedome we hall live both contentedly, and without any trouble to one another: Oh Mitree, aid he, how dearly do I love you, nay, rather adore you, for this humour; I did never think to meet with uch a jolly one: And in aying o, he hugged her, and would have carried her in his armes, but he would not let him. Every one laughed at the anger of Phillis, and the humour of this hepheard. In the mean while, Leonida and Chriante having found out a convenient place, they took their places; as for Paris, he kept alwaies cloe unto Diana, which was no mall dipleaure unto Silvander, ince he durt not, out of repect, approach: This was the reaon, that being deprived of the happinee in talking with her, he would enjoy the happinee of eeing her and therefore eated himelfe jut over againt her. Every one being et, Palemon and Adrates kneeled down before Doris, and, ay what the Nymph and Chriante would, they would not rie. At lat, the hepheardee, by command, began thus.

div.head: The Hitory of Doris and Palemon.
div.p: I Have ever been of opinion, great and wie Nymph, and you, venerable Chriante, that if there be any obligations amongt Mankinde, to tye one unto another, it is Amity: Whether this be o or no, I refer it unto the judgment of any who were ever loved. I being thus in this beliefe, after I had been long loved by this hepheard, I thought my elfe in ome ort obliged, to render him amity for amity. The truth is, this amity at the firt, had but a very lender and faint beginning, and I could not imagine, it hould ever grow into that magnitude it did; it did inenibly take o deep a root by long continued converation, as when I perceived it, I found it was not in my power to root it out; and o, as I never quetioned his affection, nor could he deire any thing of me, which he obtained not, atleat, in any reaon. Yet notwithtanding, I know not how, to my mifortune, when he was in full aurance of me, he did even then mitrut me, o as he was not contented, I hould leave frequenting all thoe whom I was accutomed to ee, but would needs have others deprived of eeing me; o as not being contented with my not viiting any of my Companions, but if any of them came to ee me, it was a thing intolerable unto him.

Have I not all the reaon in the world to be offended at him, for this bad opinion of me, which his jealouie hath infued into him? For gods-ake judge, into what extream tyranny is his amity changed: Yet neverthelee, rather then dipleae him, I choe rather to loe the good-will of all my friends, neighbours, and acquaintance, rather then he hould receive any dis-atisfaction from me. God knowes, in what a trange contraint I lived; and though I did trive to be as agreeable to his humour as I could, and to content him, and though it was pleaing to me o to do; yet, my trange retirednee from all hepheards and hepheardees, from all my friends and acquaintance, as if I were ick of ome infectious dieae, was extreamly hard unto me. If this jealouie of his did proceed from his affection unto me, was not he as much obliged to do as much for me, as he contrained me to do for him? But he was o far from that, as during all this time, which I may well terme a alvage life, (for truly o was mine become, only to be uitable unto his humour) he would not viit me above halfe a quarter of an houre in a day, viits o hort, as I could do no more then ee him, but hardly peak one word unto him. Judge; I beeech you, whether I have not good reaon to ay, that his affection is turned into tyranny, ince he was growne like unto thoe, who at the firt, under a colour of good husbandry, do afterwards grow o niggardly, both unto themelves, and thoe that depend upon them, as they will not allow a ufficient competency to live upon. For, I do believe, his life was no more pleaing unto him, then mine unto me, unlee in this, that his was voluntary, and mine contrained. But ee, whether I was not very good unto him, and loved him very well: I endured all his tyranny without the leat murmur; and had not he himelfe releaed me, I my elfe never had. The lat tetimony which I gave him of my obedience (for o I may phrae it, better then affection) was uch, as was enough to qualifie all his pervere and odd humours.

Be pleaed to know, great Nymph, that I lived very young without Father or Mother, under the tuition of a Brother, who being elder then I, was ever o affectionate
and indulgent towards me, as he did very well upply the want of Father, both in the education of my Peron, and management of my Etate, and abundantly officious, in doing me the offices of a very Father. He being thus good unto me, common reaon, beides other coniderations, commanded me, to conform my elfe unto his will, as much as poibly I could, and contrary him in nothing. Palemon, without any conideration of all this, would needs have me abolutely to break off from him; not that I hould go out of his houe, for he knew not whither ele I could go, but that I hould not have any corepondency with thoe whom he loved; nay that I hould forbid them the ight of me. Thoe who live under the authority of another, do know, whether this be feaable or no. Yet, to let him ee, how ready I was, to give him any tetimony of my affection, I did attempt to give him atisfaction in this. My Brother, amongt the ret of his neighbours, did love a hepheard whoe name was Pantemon, a man, truly, who was qualified with all good conditions to render him amiable and pleaing; he was wie, civill, repective, affable, couragious, and a good friend, and amongt hepheardees, he was the mot dicreet in all the Town. Thee qualities did invite my Brother to love him, and there grew o greet a familiarity between them, that they were never aunder. Now I mut needs confee, that as he loved my Brother very well, yet I know not, whether he oberved any thing in me which pleaed him, or whether it was, that he bore good will unto the Siter for the Brothers ake; yet o it was, that I knew he loved me. Now you hall ee, whether I did not behave my elfe as I ought to do with Palemon: As oon as ever I knew this, I told him of it, and related unto him all paages, and all the demontrations of affection which I oberved in him. If I had had any deignes, you may imagine, I would never have done thus. Oh heavens! what reverence, what honour, and what ubmiion did this hepheard render unto me? His merits and affection were o worthy of all entertainment, together with my Brother's friendhip, that as I did undertand ince, he did intend to marry us together. But I, notwithtanding the relation of a Brother's friend, did receive his addrees with more aintnee, then any other: For knowing he loved me, I thought it an injury unto the affection of Palemon, if I gave him any countenance, though civility in any other might have done it without offence. This was the man, whom Palemon charged me not to ee. And how do you think it was poible for me to obey him? Pantemon had a greater deire to obey me, then Palemon had reaon for his requet; for, how could I give him atisfaction? which way hould I forbid him my Brothers houe, who perhaps loved him better then he loved me? However, I took Pantemon aide, and acquainted him with my will. I will manifet my affection unto you, aid he, not only by the effects of my affection, but alo by the effects of your hatred: You are pleaed, without any re • on, to banih me your preence; and the wrong which you do me, hall evidence my love, ince to hew what power you have over me, I will without the leat murmure obey your commands, though mot unjut; to give you contentment, I will deny it unto my elfe, and retire out of your ight: Though I loe this happinee, yet hall I not loe the leat of my affection to you, but will preerve it entire as long as I live, though without all hope; for your merits bid me to love, becaue you are your elfe, and not to leave loving, becaue you do not love me. Pantemon, (aid I unto him) this power which you give me over you, does make me extreamly orry to banih you from me, and that I am not in a condition to dipoe of my own will; and I do aure you, that your merits, and that affection which you expree, makes me grieve, that I can do no more for you; but I beeech you, believe it for a mot certain truth, that it is not without ome reaon, and much griefe, that I do make this requet unto you. If you could have any hopes in me, you had the more reaon to be angry; but ince you cannot, what pleaure can you take, in rendring me mierable by loving me, without any hopes, but in my dipleaure? You need not ue any more words to perwade me (anwered he; my affection, which is wholly devoted unto your will, prompts me unto more then you can ay: I hall, untill the very lat minute of my life, do whatoever you hall command me, without any other aime, end, or deigne, but only to obey you. Yet, if my affection, my ervices, and obedience, can merit o great a favour, I hall beeech and conjure you, by him you love mot, and who perhaps is the caue of my banihment, that when I bid you my lat and eternall adieu, you will permit me o much honour, as to apire unto a kie of your lip. I cannot chue, Oh great Nymph, but bluh in my relation: But however, I mut confee the truth, I did permit him, conceiving, that his goodnes did oblige me unto as much. Preently after, he departed, and I never found him ince in any place, where it was probable I hould ee him.

Now, I beeech you, were not all thee tetimonies of my affection enough, to oblige this ungratefull hepheard for ever unto one? But I found him quite contrary; for afterwards, he would never ee me, neither in the way of a Lover, no, nor o much as in the way of a Friend. I much deired to know the caue of his retreat, and therefore I did employ a faithfull friend to go unto him from me: But no other anwer could be gotten, but this, that, Love drives out Love, as one naile dxives out another. Upon this, I had two conceptions: Firt, that he was fallen in love with ome other hepheardee, and this econd love had driven out the firt unto me. Secondly, that by his leighting of me, he gave me counell to do the ame. Being thus abandoned and foraken, though it was extreamly requiitie to ue my bet armes againt uch an accident, yet would I not make ue of any uch, as my enemy ent me; for corning them as his, I thought them unworthy of my elfe, and I eteemed them perfidious, becaue I eteemed their Inventor o. I had recoure therefore unto other remedies, which, though more low, yet more certain in their effects, which was, Time: Time, I ay, was my Armes, and it which taught me the ue of them; it was both my Phyician and my Phyick. And truly, as mot things that are low, are yet mot ure, o the cure it wrought, was through; not for a day, but I thank god, for all the ret of my life. I ay, I do thank god, for indeed I had abundance of reaon; for great Nymph, when I call into my memory the life I lived, as long as this perfidious man eemed to love me, and compare it with that which I do live now, I mut needs confes, that I am more obliged unto him for betraying me, then I am unto Pantemon for obeying me For then, (I cannot call it a life, but a lavery) my affection was not affection, but obedience; and his love was not love, but tyranny. Now this diloyall man, being (as I believe) envious at my happy life, or ele not contented with once triumphing, he mut needs make a econd attempt: And, as at the firt, he urpried me by ubmiion, and great demontrations of a violent affection, o he thinks now to catch me with the ame bait: And therefore, Oh great and wie Nymph, you ee him here on his knees before me, uing uch language and expreions, as they do who are really in love. But he does not conider, that finding my elfe weaket on that ide, I have more trongly fortified it: I am fully reolved to hold him out at armed end, let him attempt as long as he will; his diimulations, in lieu of love, have renewed uch extream didain of him in my oul, that I cannot endure the very ight of him: And if his deigne was to dipleae me, I mut needs confes, he hath brought it to pae; but if that be not his deigne, (as he wears, and would make me believe, it is not) but that, as a jut punihment from heaven, he hath revived his flame, that he himelfe was the only author of his own misfortune, and that he is prepared for punihment; I mut then confee, that in giving me this occaion of revenge upon the wrong he hath done me, he is a jut man, but till no good Lover. But yet, why does he tell me of his misfortunes and mieries? me, I ay, who would not o much as remember that he is in the world. Or why does he take up uch Armes, as thinking to hurt me with them, he wounds himelfe? He cannot ever have any hopes to obtain any thing from me, whoe oul marts with the memory of what is pat, as oft as I look upon him. Let him therefore let me alone, and leave me, to enjoy that happinee which he conferred upon me by a contrary deigne. If the heavens, as often they do, have converted that unto my happinee, which he prepared for my miery, why is he orry I hould enjoy it? I know better how to make ue of thee favours from heaven, then he hath of thoe, which I have done him heretofore. Let him acknowledge and confee, that the heavens have mot jutly maintained my caue, and defended my innocent affection againt the mot ungratefull and perfidious peron, that ever pretended to be a Lover. If, like a loing gameter, he ask any thing for his lat hand, this, great and wie Nymph, is all I can do for him; I will confee my elfe atisfied for his ingratitude, and forgive it; I will pitty him, upon condition, he will never ee me, nor trouble me any more; and this hall be all the revenge I will take, for all his injuries.

Thus the hepheardee ended, with o much colour in her face, as rendred her fairer then he was wont to be. Then Leonida perceiving, he had no more to ay, he commanded Palemon to peak, what he had to ay for himelfe. Then the hepheard riing up, after an humble reverence unto the Nymph, he began thus.

div.head: The Anwer of the Shepheard Palemon.
div.p:
GReat Nymph, I acknowledge that to be mot true, which I have often learned from divinity, That gods and goddees do never come into any place, without doing ome good. You, who in your merits and quality, are a repreentation of them amongt us, were no ooner come into this place, but you may <> me undeceived, and convinced of that errour wherein I have long lived, if I can call that a life, which hath brought me more torments then death it elfe. I do mot ingenuouly confee, all that this fair hepheardee hath related unto you, is mot true, and that I am infinitely more obliged unto her then either he or I can expree. But having heard her reproach me, for complaining, that the heavens, as envious of my blie, hath kept me from it, I hould think this to be a greater occaion of orrow, and to accue it of injutice, did I not know, that all men are in the like condition, and that there is no perfect contentment here below. I cannot chue but beg leave to grieve, for the wrong this fair hepheardee hath done unto that affection, which he hath promied me, by miinterpreting mine, and taking that for an injury, which he ought to take for the greatet aurance and demontration of my affection. But, Oh great god of Love! how dare I complain againt her, ince thou hat commanded me to think all well that he doth? I will therefore ue no complaints againt her, for my heart will not give me leave to contradict her in any thing. But, Oh wie Nymph, I will endeavour to let you ee, by telling the truth, that Palemon doth love, and that Doris has no reaon to believe the contrary. And, to be as briefe as I can, he does confee, that I did love her, and that he did love me; but why does he upbraid me with any infidelity? Her reaon is, becaue I was jealous, and I confee I was. But if he did love me as he aies he did, for loving her, why hould my affection be pleaing to her, and not the effects of my affection? If all that looked upon her, made me jealous, if their converation, their words, nay, their very lookes, made me upitious, was not this a mot certain tetimony, that I did infinitely love her? She hath often told me, that to doubt of her, was to offend her, and to make a initer contruction of her. Ah great Nymph, did this fair hepheardee know as well how to love, as her eyes do to make her adored, he would ay, that this was rather extream love, and the high opinion of her, which made me doubt her. Had I not thought her mot worthy to be erved by every one, I hould never have thought, that every one had erved her. And had I not been of that beliefe, how could I have been jealous of every one? Jealouie therefore, Oh fair Doris, is not a leer igne of affection and violent love, then ighes and tears are; for, it hath its originall from the knowledge one hath of the perfections in the peron loved; but ighes and tears do often proceed from her cruelty only, and from the torments which they reent by reaon thereof. She therefore knowing, (Oh great Nymph) that I was jealous, ought he not therefore to encreae her affection, in ome ort to ballance the weight which mine endured? but on the contrary, he rewards me with cruelty, he her elfe unties the knot of that amity, which o many ervices and demontrations of a perfect affection, ought to have made indiolvable. And to give ome colourable pretence for all this, he alledgeth faintnee and coldnes on my ide, and negligence and careleenee, which, alas, was only in her own opinion. She alledgeth, that at that time, I abented my elfe from her. Indeed, when I conider this allegation, I mut confee, that all actions may be upected, when the effects produce contrary emblances, or are not known unto thoe, that have interet in them. If I hould ask you, fair Doris, what opinion you had of me, when my fortune had brought me into your acquaintance, I am confident you will ay, that I loved erved, honoured, and adored you, with as much faithfull zeal of true affection, as ever any hepheard could. And let it not dipleae you, if before this great Nymph and reverent Druide, I beeech and conjure you to tell them, who that hepheardee is, that ever I adreed my elfe unto, except you; or you ever heard of? If you do not know, nor ever heard of any, but mut needs confee, my affection was never placed any where ele, why do you complain of me? and why hould you upect, and put a miinterpretation upon my actions? Me-thinks it is but very ill Logick, to conclude, that Palemon did love me; but becaue he ees me not o oft as he was wont, therefore he does not love me. Were it not a better piece of ophitry in the Schooles of Love, to argue thus? Palemon does not ee me o oft as he was accutomed, but I know there is ome urgent occaions which keeps him away. Had you been thus compaionate upon the torments I endured, in being abent from you,
and judged others by your elfe, you had never o cruelly offended him, who did never offend againt the affection which he promied. But perhaps you will ask me, what I did mean by o many minute viits, whereas formerly whole daies would not content me? I hall tell you, Oh age Nymph; and when you have heard me, you will not make uch a initer contruction of my actions, as this fair one doth of my fidelity; only I beeech you to conider, the kinde of life which I led at that time, and amongt what company I lived. I can, and truly, ay, Oh great Nymph, that never man lived a more alvage life then I; no, not uch, whoe profeion is to inhabit amongt Rocks and Dearts, excepting only, when my affection contrained me once a day to ee her; for, as oon as day began to dawn, I went out of my Cabin, and hunning all manner of company, I did not return untill dark night, retiring my elfe, ometimes into the mot cloe and unfrequented Caves, and other times upon the tops of the highet Mountains, o olitarily alone, as nothing but my own thoughts could finde me out; but they till kept me o good company, as they did often invite me unto ome uch place, from whence I might ee her habitation, thinking the very ight of the happy walls where he dwelt, to be no mall conolation unto me. Nothing could withdraw me from this kinde of olitary life; no, not the friendhip of Neighbours, nor duty to Parents, nor care of my Flocks, nor any thing in the world ele, but only my deire of eeing her every day once, and that in uch hort viits, as, to my orrow alwaies when I returned, I thought I did but only go thither, and not ee her. Now my extream affection unto her was the caue, why I did not acquaint her with my reaon for this kinde of life.

Now, great and wie Nymph, it was ever my opinion, that he who loves as he ought to do, ought to be more tender of her honour whom he loves, then of his own contentment. The malice of ill dipoed men is never o weak nor drouie, but it may alwaies finde out ome ubject to apere thoe that are mot vertuous: And at this time, our frequent viits were eyed, and gave occaion unto thoe malignant pirits, to pit their venome, and talk very broadly; and yet, o cloely, that all the diligence I could ue could never bring me to know, who were the authors of thee poyonous Impotures. What hould I do in uch a cae? To undertake a long voyage, I could not, becaue I was not a free Mater of my own actions; and to ceae to love her, had been to ceae to live. Since our great familiarity was it, which gave a colour for their calumny, what could I better do, then top the black mouthes of candall, by abridging my elfe of my own contentment, in not being o frequently with her? For, I thought my elfe obliged to preerve her honour and reputation, at any rate whatoever. If he complain, that I did not acquaint her with this untill now, he may as well complain againt my extream love of her; for, the reaon why I did not impart it unto her, was, becaue I was loath to make her a partner in my orrowes; for I know, that he, who was ever o carefull to keep her honour free from all calumny, could not endure to hear of thee, without extream vexation, and ad reentment.

Now, great Nymph, I beeech you to conider, by this mot true relation, whether uch effects are uuall amongt vulgar affections, and from thence you may perceive the quality of mine; and being uch, as gives a manifet proof of its grandure, why may I not, and with reaon, aske as well ome proofes of hers, ince love is never requited but with love again. As for the buinee of Pantemon, which he alledgeth as a great matter of complaint againt me, I conceive, my apprehenions of him did not proceed from an ill grounded jealouie, as he termes it, but from abundance of reaon; for this hepheard, as he her elfe confeeth, being uch a one as he is, it was probable, he would rather love him then corn him. Moreover, the friendhip betwixt her Brother and him, was no mall ground for my upitions; but epecially, the favourable eye which he cat upon him, which indeed was uch, as knowing of my jealouie, he was more to be blamed, for behaving her elfe o, then I, for thinking o: And indeed, their Marriage was openly poken of, o as from hence I had trong grounds for jealouie; and he, to cleer her elfe, had good reaon to do as I requeted. If friendhip have a priviledge above love, he might well have denyed my requet; if it have not, why hould he think it trange, my love hould deire a preheminency above that amity, which he had unto her Brother?
