From hence it was, great Nymph, that all our mieries had their originall; for when I was angry with her, for the countenance which he gave unto this hepheard; he anwered me, that her Brothers affection unto him was the caue of it. But when I replyed, that the report of her Marriage unto him was o common, as it was impoible I could endure
to hear it: What would your fantaticall upicion (anwered he, with an angry look) have me to do? You may call it what you pleae, (aid I unto her) but I hall never be at ret, untill I ee him banihed from you. Well, (aid he, with a more angry eye) I will give you atisfaction this time; but I wih this may be the lat of your odd humours. he expreed her elfe in uch a manner, as made me more upect her, then if he had denyed me with ome handome excue. This made me reolve to look more narrowly into the matter, and trut unto no eyes but my own. Oh mot unhappy diffidence! Oh what an abominable reolution was this, which hath cot o much orrow, uch extream torment, and o many tears? In order therefore unto this deigne, I pied out a time, when Pantemon went unto her Chamber; for, as fortune was, either for dipleaure, or for ome ill dipoednee, he kept her bed that day: And going up a back pair of taires, which conducted to her Lodgings, I came through a Lobby into a little Cloet, which had a dore over againt her bed. Such was my misfortune, as I could, through the key-hole, ee all they did, but being at too far a ditance, I could not hear one word.

I aw, and too plainly for my contentment, this hepheard it by her bed-ide; I aw him take her hand, and kie it everal times; I aw him talk bare-headed, and at lat, kie her lip, without any reitance; and for ought I could oberve, he anwered him with no words of anger. Oh heavens! what a dagger was this to my heart? I knew not what to do with my elfe; I knew not how I hould uffer this and live. But, uch was my extraordinary affection unto her, that though I had thee bitter reentments, yet it made me contantly to endure any thing, which I thought pleaing unto her. Pantemon went away, and I alo; he, very ill atisfied with me; and I, abolutely mad at him. Thus did Love drive us both away.

Now, I beeech you, great Nymph, tell me: Would you have thought I had loved her, had not this gone to my very oul? Could my reentment be lee, then to retire my elfe? or, Could it be carried with more dicretion, then never to peak of it unto any? I do confee, I did endeavour to regain my liberty; and when I found abundance of difficulty, in unlooing the cords wherewith he held me, I aid everall times to my elfe, That I would cut thoe I could not untie. And when I was thus triving with my elfe, it is true, he ent one of her friends unto me. But what could I think of her meage more, then that it was a continuation of her deluions? Could I poibly give the lye unto uch dear witnees, as my own Eyes? So, being full of anger, I made that anwer which he thus complaines of, which was, That one Nail drives out another. Now, ince I had a beliefe, that he had thus ungratefully betrayed me, how could I give her a milder check? I was obliged unto as much by the Lawes of my affection, which would not let me lie now, no more then before. If he took it in any other ene then I intended it, her innocence was the caue of it, and my error made me ay o. She does not know of any other Love, that ever driv my love of her out of my heart; and yet, my fears of dipleaing her, hath even untill this time, deprived me of my greatet contentment. When I at any time reolved to upbraid her for all this, Love, which had ever a great prevalence in my oul, retrained me, and gave me a check, telling me, that this would too much offend her, whom I once loved o well; that it was not handome to twit her with her faults, and make her ahamed of them; but that I hould be well contented, with being looe from thoe perfidious obligations, in which I had been o long entangled. Oh! this advice was mot pernicious unto me; for doubtlee, had I at the firt told her what I had een, he would have related unto me all that he had done; and o I hould have received as much atisfaction, happinee, and contentment, as I have ince uffered torments and mieries. But abenting my elfe wholly from her, it was long before I knew, that Pantemon had left her: And the wort was, I durt not o much as enquire, let I hould hear omething, which would encreae my griefe. At lat, my love being tronger then my reolution or my anger, I did by degrees go neer her, and at the very firt ight, forgetting all the wrongs which, as I thought, I had received, I applyed my elfe more unto her then ever before. But how did I finde her? he had the ame eyes, the ame mouth, and the ame beauty; but he was not the ame Doris, who, when I left her, loved none but Palemon, eteemed none but Palemon, and carraed none but Palemon. At this ad return, I aw nothing but didain, found nothing but hatred and reented nothing but rigour and anger; o as untill very now, it was impoible for me to let her know, the caue of my retirement, becaue he would never let me tell her, but till interrupted my peech.

Now, Oh great Nymph, if thee things be not tetimonies of a mot faithfull and violent
love, I will not deire her favour; though the favour which I ask, is not a pardon of any fault committed againt love, but only, for loving her too much, perhaps more then he would have me, or more then he believes. If Love would let me complain againt her, as in reaon I may, I hould tell her, that the hath done abundance of wrong, both unto Love, unto Doris, and unto Palemon: For, Love may complain, that he hath extinguihed that fire, which blazed with o pure a flame, that Vertue it elfe could not be offended with its heat; and in lieu of it, he has kindled flames of anger and pleen, o mothered with black moak, that in lieu of enlightning her oul, they fill it full of darknee and confuion. But Doris has greater reaon of compliant, that o leight a ground hould make her perjured, and break o many reiterated Oathes, worn unto that unfortunate hepheard, never to change her minde. And what can he anwer Palemon, if he hould ay unto her: Is it poible, unthankfull hepheardee, that o many years ervice, o many tetimonies of affection, o many aurances of my fidelity, hould not make you have a better conceipt of me? 'Tis true, I was jealous; but was it not a fruit of Love? I beeech you, why not jealous, if amorous? Who hould I be jealous of, but of her I love? But, admit it be a fault, and ought to be punihed; is it not the rigour of jutice, to equall the punihment to the crime? But admit, that it ought to equall it, and that an eye for an eye, and an arme for an arme, ought to expiate the in; yet, why hould you punih me for being jealous of you? for then, the ame punihment ought to be inflicted upon you, ince you were alo jealous of me. Is this an act glorious, and worthy of a Lover? But perhaps you will ay unto me, You cat me off, and quitted me, and has therefore rendred your elfe unworthy of any favour. Well, uppoe I did cat you off; you mut therefore cat me off alo; and perhaps you have done it already. Suppoe us to be both upon equall tearmes, I have cat you off, and you have cat me off. But now, when I return again, with abundance of repentance and orrow for what is pat; are not you obliged by the Law of Like, to do the like? Here I am upon my knees before you, with as many bitter tears of repentance, as ever Lover had; and can your anger extend o far, as not to re-admit me into my former happinee. Forgivenee is the greatet glory of the gods, and it has this operation, that it converts the greatet offenders into the greatet lovers.
Thus Palemon ended, and Leonida and Chriante prepared themelves to give Judgment, when the other hepheard deired to be heard, what he could ay for himelfe.

div.head: The Hitory of the Shepheard Adrates.
div.p:
I Beeech you, great and puiant Nymph, and you, venerable Chriante, to tay your judgment, untill you have heard me, that you may have the better conuance of our differences, and be able to put a jut concluion unto all our mieries and inquietudes. I have loved this hepheardee, even from her very Cradle; I have never ince ceaed loving her, but till encreaed in my deires to do her ervice: I have endured all her didaines, and patiently uffered her, to place all her affection upon another, before my face. Length of time has not leened my love, nor diverted my deigne; her rigours could never afright me, and yet hitherto, I could never make her leave the leat of her cruelties. She equally ballanced her elfe with favours unto Palemon, and disfavours unto me, and ever mot cruelly corned both my love and patience. But all was one, all her affronts did but the better enure me, to endure the intolerable burthen of them; they were o far from diverting me from her ervice, that the more difficulties and mieries I met with, the more did they confirme the violence of my love. Oh heavens! can any man, infected with this dieae, be wie? Can he look for any cure, when his will cannot conent unto it? All uch as give me any counell againt Love, are my declared enemies; and though all manner of hopes were blated, yet my affection was unalterable, it was never in the leat degree tartled or leened. No, great Nymph, I had rather die, then diminih the leat park of that flame, which burned me. She has een me everall times wim in tears before her; he has een me fall at her feet, out of my wits. But neither my tears, nor danger of my life, could ever obtain any thing from her, but corn and mockery: A jut reentment whereof had been revenged upon Palemon, if my love could have conented unto any thing, that might dipleae this cruell one. But this paion of revenge was o unable to make me undertake uch a deigne, as I am ure, he cannot taske me with the leat blemih in my affection; and whatoever he is pleaed to ay of me, I may truly, without any otentation,
give my elfe the name of, A Lover without a fault; for jealouie could never finde any harbour in my oul, as it did in this too happy hepheard; nor did I ever think any ill, or finde any fault with any of her actions. Love can be my witnee, that even her very rigours were welcome to me, when I conidered, that they were pleaing unto this fair Doris. And though I am not o far out of Fortunes favour, but any other hepheardee would perhaps look upon me with a favourable eye; yet mot certain I am, that I never profeed any fidelity to them, but abundance unto her. But Love, not to let o much didain go unpunihed, and not to forake a Love o pure as mine, hath uffered her to reent the bitternee of didain, by the divorce betwixt her and this hepheard. But before Palemon ever loved her, I did; yet, for all her bitter treatment, he never aw the leat alteration in me. I was the firt that erved her, I am the only one that has continued contant, and hall be for ever in the ame minde. I do not et thee things before her eyes by way of reproach, but for truthes-ake only; yet uch truths, as hall not put her unto any ad remembrances, for o I mut needs phrae my pat ervices. And though her cruelty hath been uch unto me, yet mut I in ome ort excue her, ince being engaged unto Palemon, perhaps he had offended againt her fidelity, in doing otherwie. But now, when, thanks be to the Fates, he hath quitted him, what reaon or colour can he have for her cruelty, ince he tells you, that he loved Palemon, becaue he thought it reaonable, to love him who loved her. Upon her own ground, reaon, and judgment, I do appeal unto you, great Nymph, wearing unto you by her fair elfe, for a greater oath cannot be, that never did any Beauty caue a greater, more incere, or more faithfull love, then that of Adrates unto the fair Doris.

Thus Adrates ended his Oration, with o many demontrations of a perfect love, as all that heard him were partners in his reentments. And the hepheardee Doris, eeing he had aid all he could, after an humble reverence, anwered thus.

Great Nymph, I am very orry for this hepheard's ake, that all he hath aid is true; for, ince he loves me o well, it grieves me, that he hould be ill treated; yet, you may perceive by what hath been aid, that the fault is not in me, but it is himelfe only, that purues his ill fortune. The firt time he declared his minde unto me, we were both o young, that neither knew what Love was; o as what he aid unto me, moved me no more, then a peron who was nothing at all concerned. Afterwards, he travelled, and when he returned, he found me not mine own, for I had given my elf unto Palemon: So that, as at the firt time, he might complain of my ignorance in love; o at this econd, he might much more complain of my too much knowledge in it. But he has no reaon at all to complain againt me; for, hepheard, can you complain againt me, who was not capable of love, for not loving you? Lay the blame upon Nature; accue thoe Lawes unto which he hath ubmitted us all. Then, can you think it trange, I will not love you, when my will was not my owne? Alas, I have but one heart, and one oul, and one will. You may with more reaon complain, (and that me-thinks is the only plea you have) that you did addree your elfe unto me too oon, and returned too late. You ay that I never looked upon you, but with corn, but was ever very avere from hewing any favour unto you. Truly, Adrates, if you rightly interpret my actions, you will finde, that you are more obliged unto me for that, then if I had done otherwie For, had you received any atisfaction from me, unto what a trange extremity would your love have been driven, that was o great, maugre all my rigours? Conider, Adrates, that favours from me, would rather have been aggravations, then any conolations in your miery: Beides, I could not have hewed them, without much offence unto that incere affection, which I had promied Palemon. I mut needs confee, that it is jut to love one that loves us; but I do not ay, it is injutice, not to love all thoe, that have any affection unto us; for if it were, there would be no fidelity nor aurance in love; if it were o, you your elfe were obliged, to render a reciprocall love unto the hepheardee. Bebliena, who is ready to die for you. But I mean, that a woman being free from all other affection, may, without blame, love him that loves her, if there be no other reaon of hatred, but his love. Now this cae is nothing reemblant unto that betwixt you and me; for I being engaged another way, I cannot contract any new affection with you, without a ruine of that which I have contracted already. Had I diembled with you, or held you in hopes with any mooth language, you might with reaon complain againt me; but, if I did ever tell you my minde plainly and freely, are you not obliged unto me for it? Have I not a thouand times over entreated, conjured, nay, commanded, as far as I had any power over you, that you hould
extinguih your affection to me? And have you not alwaies anwered me, that you would, if you could do it and live? And when you did continue on was it not for your own ake, and not mine? But, great Nymph, ee how that which, as I gather from his word • , he thinks to be his advantage, does deceive him. Doubtlee he thinks, that my affection unto Palemon was the only caue, which kept me from giving entertainment unto his. And indeed, he no ooner heard of the dientions betwixt that hepheard and me, but preently he was blowne up with hopes to effectuate his deires; and, to loe no occaions of promoting them, he hath ever ince that time o importunately preed me, that I may, and with reaon, call him, rather my enemy then my friend. But he is much deceived in thee thoughts, and does not conider, that if ever this affection of mine do ceae, I hall with it o ceae from ever any other love, as I hall never reent any effects of it again.

Thus ended Doris. Adrates would have replyed, but Leonida commanded ilence; and taking Chriante, Atrea, Diana, Phillis, Madonthe, and Laonice aide, he asked them their opinions and advice. But being long in conultation, and the hepheards, who were not called to counell, being impatient, and could not be idle, Hylas addreed himelfe unto Doris: I do admire aid he unto her, that you hould be angry for being too rich. How do you mean, anwered he? I mean, aid Hylas, that you ought to entertain, not only thee two hepheards, who love you; but alo, as an evidence of your beauty, all thoe that would offer themelves unto you: For, it is a womans honour to be loved and courted by many, beides the benefit he may get by it. I do believe, (anwered Doris, very carelely) that this would be a good way for thoe, who would be eteemed fair, and are not; or, for uch as prefer that vanity, before tranquillity and olid contentment. If it be a Good to be loved, replyed he, the more that love you, the more good you have. And if it be ill, replyed Doris, the more I am loved, the more ill it is. True, replyed Hylas, but how can it be ill, to be loved by many? They will hate us in the end, anwered he. Yes, replyed he, if you do not content and entertain them. How hould one atisfie and content many replyed Doris, when it is impoible to atisfie and content one? But, aid Hylas, is it not good to have many Servants? They will in the end become our enemies, aid he, and in loving me, they will more trouble then benefit me. You mut have a care, aid he, to keep them your friends. The paines, replyed the hepheardee, is above the pleaure. The gods, aid the hepheard, do never think themelves troubled, that many hould bring offerings unto their Altars. Mot true, anwered he, but it is a peculiar priviledge of the gods, to do good unto many, without any trouble to them. Me-thinks, aid Hylas, that ince love depends upon the will, and ince the will does extend it elfe to all it pleaeth, there hould be no great pains in loving everall perons. The Lovers of this age, anwered he, are not contented with matter of will, but they would enjoy it in the effects; an I therefore I think it impoible, that the will hould be divided amongt everall perons at one time. Every one of them, replyed he, mut but have a part. This, anwered the hepheardee, I do think to be mot impoible: But, uppoe it might, ince the love of one is o painfull, what would a great multitude be? Then it eemes, aid he, that you will love but one. One, anwered he, is too many, and therefore I will love none at all. And you, hepheards, (aid Hylas unto Palemon and Adrates) what do you ay to this? We (aid Palemon) do make it appear, that we think one to be enough. How aid Hylas, mut one love but one? Nay, fewer, anwered Palemon, ince we are two, and love but one. The dicoure of Hylas had continued longer, if the Nymph had not returned with all her company and topped him: She therefore, and every of them, taking their places again, he pake thus.

div.head: The Judgment of the Nymph Leonida.
div.p:
ALthough we do oberve in this difference before us, everall accidents which eem contrary to one another, yet none of them are contrary unto Love; for, it is not more naturall for Fire to flame and burn, then for Love to produce uch dientions amongt Lovers; and thoe who go about to take them away, do attempt a thing, no lee impoible, then to take away heat from fire, or keep it from flaming. On the other ide, conidering, that he does not love, who does not wholly and entirely dedicate himelfe unto her he loves, we conceive it, to be a kinde of treaon, to let any other have a hare in his affection. And though we do expree our elves only in the Maculine peron, yet it
doth hold as well in the Feminine. Therefore, all things being long and eriouly debated and conidered, we do conclude, that it would be unjut, that love hould be extinguihed by a thing, that is o naturall unto it elfe; or to divide it amongt many, upon any conideration whatoever. And we do declare, that thee fallings out, and little quarrells, are only renewings of love, and that to divide or change affection, is a crime of the highet nature that can be committed againt Love. Upon this ground, we do ordain, that Doris hall love Palemon, and that Palemon being aured of her affection, hall for the future give her ome better tetimonies of his love, then by thoe of jealouie; though we do conclude, that jealouie be a igne of love, but it is a igne of love, as icknee is a igne of life; for, as one cannot be ick, unlee he live, o one cannot be jealous, unlee he love; but, as icknee is a igne of an ill tempered life, o jealouie is an argument of an ill tempered love. Doris hall pardon, and receive Palemon into her favour again, and forget all former dipleaures, conidering, that Love is a mot violent paion; and makes one commit many things, which are not allowed of by him that committed them, nor ever would be, had he not been infected with that dieae. And to avoid thoe dipleaures which he hath reented for the time pat, we do ordain, that as Doris hall treat Palemon as the peron whom of all the world he loves bet, o likewie Palemon hall ubmit himelf unto the will of Doris; for, if he will be free, it will at lat fall into tyranny. And as for the patient and unfortunate Adrates, we do ordain, that it hall be in his choice, whether he will continue an example of a faithfull and unfruitfull affection, by loving Doris till, without any hopes of being loved again; or whether he will, by breaking the cords of his firt love, by violence, by anger, or by depair, atisfie the affection of her, who loves him, and is ready to die for him.

This was the judgment of the Nymph, which produced three very different effects in thee three perons; in Palemon, an extream contentment; in Doris, o great an atonihment, as he tood peechlee; but in Adrates, uch a uddain tupification of pirits, that he fell down as dead. So as whilt Palemon, in an extaie of joy, and with a thouand confued expreions, endeavoured to thank his Judge, for o favourable a judgment; Doris aid not a word, but fixed her eyes upon the ground, as not knowing whether he hould be glad or ad: and Adrates, lying all along without any ene, did move all that aw him unto o much griefe, that Doris her elfe did pitty him. All the Company flocked about him, and lent him all poible aitance. When he came unto himelfe again, Leonida, accompanyed with Atrea and all her Companions, left them all three together, but they continued o, not long; for preently after, Palemon taking Doris under the arme, went towards Mount Verdun; and Adrates following them with his eye, and loing the ight of them amongt the Trees: Farewell (aid he) you happy and mot perfect Lovers; go and enjoy, both your happinee and mine, whilt I, by this mot unjut Ordinance, do all my life lament the loe of that felicity which you enjoy. Thee were the lat words he uttered out of a ound judgment, for a long time; for ever ince, his pirits were o troubled, that he lot his wits, and committed uch aburd follies, that even uch as could not chue but laugh at him, could not chue alo but pitty him.

Hylas, finding no jutice in this Judgment which the Nymph had given, did maintain his opinion againt all thoe, who conceived, that this difference could not be better determined. And becaue Leonida & Paris were not ignorant of his humour, they were very deirous to pae away the time in talking with him; and in order thereunto, Paris began thus: Me-thinks, Siter (aid he) that you have done poor Adrates abundance of wrong, and might have well given a milder entence for him. Are not you of that opinion, Hylas? For my part, (anwered he) I believe, the heavens had a minde to punih the fool Adrates; for otherwie it was not likely, they would have uffered him to be thus condemned; but I mut needs confee, that his fond and foolih paion, does not deerve a lee punihment. You, Hylas, and I, (anwered the Nymph) are of very different opinions; for his love unto Doris, continued with o much contancy and reolution, me-thinks, is o far from deerving any punihment that I do much commend him for it; and therefore I gave him leave to continue it till, if he would. A very fine leave indeed, aid Hylas: Why? you might as well give him leave to live all his life in miery; for my part, I think you were very rigorous in it; and I am ure, that were it my cae, I would revoke your judgment. What judgment would you have given, (aid the Nymph, and miled) if you had been in my room? I hould have contented them all three, anwered he. I
am ure (aid Silvander, and interrupted them) that this Ordinance proceeds from a olid and well digeted judgment. I am ure, (aid Hylas) that uch as are of Silvander's melancholly temper, are not fit to be Judges of Love; but if you will olidly and eriouly conider the reaons why one hould love, you will ay, that I am in the right, and that Doris, Adrates, and Palemon, might have been all three contented and atisfied. How could that poibly be, aid the Numph? By ordaining (replyed Hylas) that Doris hould love them both, and that both of them hould erve her; for by this means, they would have had what they deired, which was, that he hould love them, and he would have been better erved.

There was none in the Company that could refrain from laughing, when they heard this judgment, epecially Leonida. Which Hylas eeing: It eemes, great Nymph, aid he, that I have made you all very merry, and that you mock me. Nay rather, (anwered he) it eemes, Hylas, that you mock us. Excue him, Madam, aid Silvander, for he peaks as he thinks. If your thoughts (aid he unto Silvander, almot angry) be different from mine, you think but very ill; and I would gladly know what arguments you have, to blame my judgment in this. Silvander anwered very carelely; Common ene tells us, that what many have a hare in is entirely poeed by none: If many have hares in the love of Doris, Adrates and Palemon can have but their parts; and he that has but a part in love has nothing of it at all. But why (aid Diana unto Silvander) do you peak thus unto Hylas? do you not know, how he does not undertand that language? Truly (aid Hylas) you do very well to put in your vie alo; for perhaps Silvander alone is not Babell enough, to confound all the World. Then addreing himelfe unto Leonida: Did you ever Madam, hear uch an aburd opinion, (aid he) as this of Silvander's, that if one have but a part of a thing, he hath nothing at all: Will any one think, that there is no water in a River, becaue the Sea is not in it? I would gladly know what this Common Sene is, which teacheth uch fale Doctrines. Silvander anwered: If Love could be divided, and till remain Love, as Water may, and till be Water, I hould yield unto you. Water is of uch a nature that the leat drop is Water, as well as the whole Sea; but Love, on the contrary, is no longer Love, if the leat part be wanting; and to prove this to be a truth, Love does conit principally in an extream affection, and perpetuall fidelity; if you take either of thee parts from it, it is love no longer, & I believe, there is none in the Company, except Hylas, but will confee it; for, if the extream be wanting in the affection, or if fidelity be wanting, it is treaon, and not love; if fidelity be in it, and not perpetuall, it is not fidelity but perfidie: So as, Hylas, I mut conclude, that who o hath only one part of Love, hath nothing of it at all. If it be o, that Love is a thing individuall, it had been againt reaon to enjoyne Doris, to divide her love, partly to Palemon, and partly to Adrates. Upon this Paris began to peak: Me-thinks, Hylas, aid he, that we have reaon of our ide, but Silvander has by his dicoure gotten the favourable opinion of all the Company; and let me tell you, that if you do not anwer him, I hall acknowledge what he aith. Generous Paris, (aid Hylas) whatoever Silvander aies, or whatoever you think, yet truth will never change; and for my part, I am ure, experience is more certain then all manner of words, for there is no arguing againt it. Now Silvander has nothing, but a few mooth handome words, to prove what he aith; but I have found what I ay, by o many effects, and familiar experience, that I will never eek any further then my elfe for any arguments: For, I have loved many at once, and ay what he will or can, I am ure I did truly love them; and therefore may not Doris do the ame? Many (replyed Silvander) do think, they do things, when they do them not: All Artificers, but more epecially thoe that do addict themelves unto the Arts and Sciences, which are not Mechanicall, have a very great opinion of what they do, and very few, but think their own works much better and more perfect then any others, when as it is apparent, they do but deceive themelves, and very often, great imperfections are een in them by others: Selfe-love is ever blinde, but alwaies open to the eyes of others. Hylas thinks he loves, and that he loves well, though he be but a very bad workman; and therefore, whooever would love aright, and not erre, mut never take him for a pattern. Who, then (aid Hylas) my elfe? If any, (anwered Silvander) believe it, Silvander is he? See (aid Hylas) one of the greatet pieces of preumption that ever elfe-love produced: Do you think, none but your elfe can love well? I ay, (anwered Silvander) that my affection is pure and perfect, that you cannot tax it with any fault; nay more, that you cannot name me another, that excells me. So, o, (aid Hylas) was ever any o over-weened and arrogant as
this hepheard? Is he the only one that knowes how to love? Came he from heaven? Is he the great pattern unto men, and gives them the Lawes of Love, and can meaure the grandure and perfection of our wills? Fair Nymph, if it would not be too tedious unto you, I beeech you give me leave to hew him his error. Then cocking his Beaver with one arme a kembow, and the other accompanying by its geture the violence of his peech, he poke thus: I oberve two things, Silvander, in your peech; the one, that your affection is pure, and perfect, and unalterable; the other, that I cannot name another more accomplihed. Can any thing be added unto that which is perfect? I am confident, you will ay, No; for, if it would admit of any addition, then it wants omething, and cannot be perfect. That thing unto which nothing can be added, mut be arrived at its extremity, and therefore it mut be confeed, that whatoever is perfect is extream. Now, if your affection be perfect, then nothing can be added unto it, nor can it be made greater then it is, nor more accomplihed. Now tell me preently, What is Love? Is it not a deire of beauty, and of a good which you want? But your love is a deire of a good which you want: Therefore it mut conequently be confeed, that omething may be added unto your Love, which it hath not. Moreover, you ay, that your affection cannot be taxed with any crime: If I hould ask you, whom it is you do love, you would anwer, that it is Diana. If I hould aske further, who this Diana is, you would reply, that he is the mot perfect hepheardee in the world. Then anwer I, If this hepheardee be o perfect as you eteem her, are you not very bold, in daring to love one that is o full of perfection? For, there mut alwaies be ome proportion, betwixt the Lover and the Loved; and I cannot believe, that all your preumption can perwade her, that you are o perfect as you think your elfe. Perhaps you will charge me with the ame fault, in loving Phillis, who, you will ay, hath much more perfection then I. But I am of a contrary beliefe unto you; for I do not hold her for uch a one, as you do your Diana: I do confee, he is owner both of beauty and merit; and am I without? She has wit, o have I: She is wie, I am no fool: She is a hepheardee, I am a hepheard: She is Phillis, and I am Hylas. Is there not an eeven conformity and equality betwixt us? So as in anwer unto all you can aske, I propoe it as a more perfect love then yours; o as if one deire to love aright, Hylas, and not Silvander, mut be the pattern. For, to what purpoe is it to love, unlee to have contentment? But what contentment or pleaure can thee drooping melancholly Lovers have, who are perpetually muing and fretting at their hearts, againt this Bug-bear and Chimaera of Contancy. Diana, does Silvander ay, does not love me; alas, he loves another, and cornes me; but for all that, I will love, and erve, and adore her, let I hould be taxed with incontancy. Phillis, does Hylas ay, does not love me, he loves another, and cornes me; why hould not I change this ungratefull woman for another, that will love me, and corn ome other for my ake? Shall this Bug-bear, of being taxed with incontancy, hinder me? Ah friends, I pray tell me, what kinde of Beat is this Incontancy? Who did it ever devour? What dieae did it ever breed? Did any ever die of it? How many have you een in mourning by reaon of it? No, no, it is a meer imagination, a fancy, a chimaera, or rather an invention of ome ubtle Lover, who eeing her elfe growne ugly, or ready to be changed for ome other, that was fairer then her elfe, did broach this opinion, and made it to be thought a mortall in, to be Incontant. Will any man, in his witts, be thus deluded? Can he be o illy, as to conume all his life without any comfort? Do you call this Love, forooth, and Contancy? May it not with much more reaon be called madnee and folly? What! languih in the lap of an old, ugly, and ungratefull Mitree! Fie, fie, it is an errour far unworthy of a man, that pretends unto any wit or courage. Let not Silvander therefore ask any more, wherein I can taxe his Love, or where I can finde one that is more perfect; for I am confident, there is not one in the Company who will not ay, that Hylas loves, and Hylas alone loves, as a man of wit and courage ought to do.

Thus ended this incontant hepheard, o moved with his own arguments, that he was as hot as any fire. Every one miled, and looked upon Silvander, in expectation of what he would ay; and he, to give them atisfaction, very leightly anwered thus.

I thought, Madam, I hould have encountred with a Shepheard, in the preence of Ladies and Shepheardees; but for ought I ee, I hall finde him an Athenian Oratour, o much is Hylas tranported with his eloquence: Yet, I wih, (o confident I am in the goodnee of my caue) that he, of us two, who hall be condemned, may be o everely chatied, for peaking o boldly before uch acred Altars, as he hall either give his Oration
the lie, or ele be plunged in the River Rene. That is not reaonable, aid Hylas, unlee I had been advertied of it, before I began to peak, or might have uch Judges, as I did not upect of partiality. Why, aid the Nymph, do you upectus? Becaue, aid Hylas, you believe all that Silvander aith, to be an Oracle; and becaue he has been a while at the Mailian Schooles, you admire all he aies, and think him to be alwaies in the right. No, no, Hylas, aid Silvander, never refue to abide the judgment of this great Nymph, and the venerable Chriante; never fear, hepheard, I ee they are not dipoed unto rigour: and the wort will be, but an acknowledgment of your errour. And therefore I will begin.

You ay, Hylas, that there is no perfect love, without an acquiition of ome deired good becaue Love is only a deire of ome good which it wants. But, Madam, I humbly beeech you, before I anwer this hepheard, to pardon me, if, for the dicovery of his ubtleties, I ue ome termes, which are not frequently ued amongt us. Therefore, anwer me, hepheard: Does any deire that, which they do poee? You will ay, No; becaue deire is only of omething wanting: But if Love, as you ay, is only a deire, do you not ee, that to poee what one deires, is to quench Love, ince none does deire that which they poee? Why, aid Hylas, doth not one love that which they poee? If they do not, I had rather you hould love; and that I hould not love, to the end, you may deire, and I may poee. I do not ay o, (aid Silvander) but I ay, that Love is not only a deire to poee, as you would perwade; but on the contrary, poeion and enjoyment does rather make it die then live. If enjoyment do not make it live, replyed Hylas, yet it is enjoyment which gives it perfection. No, neither, aid Silvander, for enjoyment is not at all neceary, to make a perfect Love. A Diamond is as perfect a Diamond before it be wrought, as after the Artit hath polihed it. For, if the perfection of Love did depend upon this Enjoyment, it would not be in the power of him that loves to love perfectly, ince the enjoyment does not depend upon him, but upon the conent of another: And yet, Love, being an act of the Will, which is guided as the Undertanding thinks good, and the Will being free in all that it does, this act of his Will cannot depend upon any other then himelfe.

But admit, that Love be nothing but a deire, mut it be concluded from thence, that Love may be encreaed, by the enjoyment of that which one deires? If you conider it well, you will ay, that Love is rather lee by it; for, our oules do in this reemble a Bow, the more the tring is tretched, with more violence doth it hoot its Arrowes. So our oules do hoot out more violent deires, when the thing deired is hard to be accomplihed, than when it is eaie and in our power. If deires do leen at things eaily accomplihed, much more when it is glutted: And if Love be only a deire, how can you think, that deires will be augmented by enjoyment, which do diminih and glut them? Therefore, Hylas, do not ay, that my Love being a deire, cannot be perfect without enjoyment: And do not accue of arrogance, becaue there ought to be an equall proportion betwixt Diana and me; unlee you will deny, that men may love the gods, for then I hall yield unto you: But if you confee, that to love the gods be the greatet commandment upon us; then I ask you, hepheard, whether there be a greater diproportion betwixt Diana and me, then betwixt Thautates and Hylas. And to convince you of your errour, it is requiite, I explain this ecret mytery of Love unto you. We cannot love, unlee we do know the thing which we do love. Oh, aid Hylas, how fale is that poition? For, I do love above a hundred Ladies and Shepheardees, and yet I never knew one of them well; for, as oon as I found them to be peevih and didainfull, I left them, and was angry with my elfe, for thinking otherwie of them then I found them. This reaon, (anwered Silvander) ought to make you confee what I do ay: For, you did love that which you knew not; that is, having an opinion, that they were full of perfections, you judged them amiable, you loved them; but finding out the truth, you left loving them; and by this you ee, that the knowledge of the perons, was the originall and ource of your love; and truly, if the will from whence love begins, be never moved unto any thing, but what the judgment thinks good, there being no likelyhood, that the undertanding can judge upon a thing, of which it hath no knowledge; I do wonder how you can imagine, one hould love that which he doth not know. I do confee, that as the eye may ometimes be deceived, o may the undertanding, and may judge that amiable which is not: But yet, Love mut come from knowledge, be it true or fale. Now this being o, have you not learned in the Masilian Schooles, that undertanding, and the thing undertood, are but one and the ame thing? What! till harping upon the ame tring, aid Hylas, are you
Diana, Silvander, as you were the other day? Truly, Diana, (aid he, and turned towards her) you are a very pretty Boy: And you, Silvander, (aid he, and turned towards him) you are a very handome Wench. Believe me, hepheard, you are excellent good company, and will ere long be as pleaant a Fool, as ever was in Forrets. Every one began to laugh at this, Silvander himelfe could not hold, hearing how he interpreted what he had aid, and his way of peaking; and therefore he continued thus: You may very well, hepheard, aid he, make your elfe merry with me, ince I had no more wit then to prophane thee myteries, by communicating them unto you; nor hould I have done it, had we been alone, but I was contrained unto it, becaue I would not leave thoe that hear us, in an errour. But, though you will not allow what I ay for Orth • dox, yet perhaps you will hearken unto what your elfe aid, concerning Phillis: I mean, that you did alledge the good opinion which you had of your own merits, and the merits of Phillis, as a good argument, and that you did not eteem he • s uch, but that yours might equall them. Now if you had this beliefe of your elfe, why will you not allow me to take the ame advantage of elfe conceit; for I do think, that the ame proportion that is betwixt the fire, and the wood which the fire burnes, is betwixt Diana and me. Now if you deny this to me good friend, why do you take more priviledge to your elfe? But I dare with aurance affirme, that Hylas does not love Phillis; I hall maintain it to be abolutely impoible: For the chiefe Ordinance of Love, is, That a Lover do think all things mot perfect in the peron Loved. And truly, it is a Law mot jut, and grounded upon great reaon; for, if a Lover ought to love his Mitree above all things in the whole Univere, ought he not to eteem her above all things, ince his will directs him alwaies unto that, which his undertanding tells him is bet? But it does plainly appear, that it is Hylas you love, and not Phillis, by aying, that none loves, but for their own contentment. Now the pains which Lovers do voluntarily take, only in doing ervice unto thoe they love, does plainly make the contrary appear. And have you not heard ay that we live more where we love, then where we breathe? I hall never believe that, anwered Hylas; this is nothing but talk, that comes from uch idle imaginations as yours. Had you aid (replyed Silvander) that the talk came from uch a wounded imagination as mine, you had aid right for the imagination of a Lover is o: We ee ome ready to die upon the wound of one little word, upon the cat of an eye; nay, ometimes upon very upition: Sometimes you hall ee a Lover deny unto himelfe all manner of ret and contentment, only to enjoy the ight of the party loved, for one minute. But, Hylas, did you know what a felicity it is, to be a fool in uch occaions, you would confee, that all the widome of the world is not comparable to this pleaing folly: Were you able to comprehend it, you would never aske, what pleaure and contentment thoe faithfull Lovers, whom you phrae melancholly and penive, do receive; for you then would know, that they are o ravihed in contemplation of the party whom they love and adore, as, corning all that is in the whole Univere, they do not repent of any thing more, than the loe of that time which they pend any where ele; and their oules not being well able to contain the grandure of their contentment, they tand atonihed at o much treaure, and o many felicities, which trancends their knowledge. Know, that the happinee which Love doth recompene unto faithfull Lovers, is the ame that he may give unto the gods: And thee Lovers, raiing themelves above the nature of men, do almot make themelves gods; for all other pleaures which you do o highly prie, are uch only, as a batard-Love does afford, unto uch Animals as are without reaon; and uch men as are only taken with them, they do degenerate from the nature of Men, and become almot Animals, deprived of all reaon. Into uch a Monter, Hylas, do you degenerate, when you do love otherwie then as you ought; uch a Montroitie, I ay does appear in you, ince there is no proportion in it, and, like Monters, it cannot produce its like; and, to be briefe, like a Monter it cannot live long. On the contrary, my love is every way o perfect, as nothing can be added or diminihed, without an offence to reaon; for, both in grandure and quality, I can, without any vanity, ay, that it is arrived at perfection. In aying, that my affection could not be blamed or taxed, I had great reaon to ay o; for he, from whence it doth proceed, did never produce any thing, but what was mot perfect. And I know, that the gods would chatie me, if I hould dare to offer unto a oul o perfect as hers, an affection that could any waies be blamed.

Silvander would have continued, when Hylas, not being able to be patient any longer, interrupted him in this manner: Silvander, how long do you intend to abue the
patience of thoe who hear you? How long will you fill their ears with your vanities and fond imaginations? And how long, do you think, I can endure the impertinences of your language. All the Company were urpried to hear Hylas come out with his expreions in o loud a voice, as every one began to laugh o loud, that he was forced to be ilent. And becaue the day was almot pent, and Leonida was to return unto Adamas, to relate unto him all thee paages; as Hylas was beginning to peak, he aid thus unto him: No, no, you have diputed long enough, Hylas, for one time; the reverend Chriante is not accutomed to be o long from the Temple of the good goddee: Let it uffice, hepheard, that we know, you have very good arguments againt Silvander, but we entreat you to refer them untill another time; in the mean time, we will go away in this belief, that if you had had time to expres your elf, you would have gotten the better of him, as yet he hath got the better of you. See, (aid Hylas, halfe angry) how there will be till ome imperfections or other in our natures. What do you ay, replyed the Nymph? I ay, anwered Hylas, that though you be a Nymph, yet you make it appear, you are but a woman, and has not patience to hear out the truth, but is pleaed with the tickling flatteries of this hepheard, who does but deceive you. You do not at all offend me, (aid Leonida, & miled) in calling me a woman; for truly I am o, and would be o, and would not change exes with the mot accomplihed man in the Country: But I know not why you hould accue me with the fault that Silvander hath committed, in alledging very good reaons; and with the fault which Hylas hath committed, in anwering him o very ill.

Quetionlee Hylas had replyed, if he had heard the Nymph; but he being gone away in a chae, he did not hear thee lat words. And Leonida eeing it was very late, he went with Chriante and the Druides Daughters, unto the Temple of the good goddee, and afterwards went to Adamas, Paris not following her; for his affection unto Diana was uch, as he enjoyed no felicity but in her preence. Thus the Nymph went unto her Uncles, and Paris taking the contrary way, went unto the fair hepheardees, and tayed with them a long time.

Leonida deired very much to relate unto her Uncle, all that had been done for Celadon; and by fortune he met him, walking upon a Tarrae, which was hadowed with Sicamours, before the houe. He wondred to ee her return o oon, and he telling him the caue, he could not chue but laugh, that every one hould be o deceived. I think, aid Leonida, that it will be a good inducement unto him, to leave this kinde of life which he lives; for, if he hould be acquainted, that his hepheardee loves him, and laments his loe, doubtlee he would take a reolution to ee her; but I do not conceive it o fit for me to tell him, as for you, auring my elfe, that the amity and repect he bears unto you, will have better operation upon him, then all the Rhetorick I can ue, for your words have more weight and olidity in them, then mine have. I hall tell Celadon, (aid the Druide) but I know not what effects my peaking will produce; for I know he loves me, and bears much repect unto me in all things, but concerning his affection: And I mut confee, that I had long ince acquainted the hepheardee Atrea where he was, knowing that he loved him, had I not feared it would have been a means, to make him go unto ome other alvage and retired place, where I could not finde him again; but my fears of loing him did retrain me. It is now two daies ince we aw him, and therefore it will not be amie, if tomorrow we give him a viit, and do the bet we can to prevail with him.

In this reolution therefore, they went to bed, and in the morning, day did no ooner appear, but Leonida got up, and Adamas alo, o that as oon as they were dreed, they et forward. That morning, the hepheard was not gone out of his Cave, but was beyond meaure penive at the paages of the preceeding day; yet very glad, and wel pleaed with his fortune, that had given him leave to ee the fair Atrea once more before he dyed: And conidering, that he had never received uch a favour from her, as at that encounter, except when he was a young Child, when he aw her in the Temple of Venus; he cryed out: Oh mot happy misfortune, that hath been more favourable unto me, then my bet fortune! Oh the goodnee of Love, which in his greatet torments gives the greatet contentments! Who would ever retire himelfe from thy obedience, ince thou hate o great a care of all that are thine? Whilt this hepheard was thus entertaining himelfe, Adamas and Leonida came to him. And becaue Celadon's face did tetifie the contentment which he received, the Druide and the Nymph, after common alutations, told him, that they much rejoyced to ee him look better then he did, and hoped, that he had received ome
kinde of comfortable courage. The comforts which you do finde in my countenance, anwered Celadon, are like unto Suns in Winter, which rie late and et early, and which indeed do give ome light; but it is through o many muddy clouds, that neither the light nor the heat do much warm. Then he related to them his encounter with Silvander; how he had put a Letter into his hand; how he aw Atrea with all the hepheardees, and had put a Letter into her breat. But alas, Father, (aid he) this happinee was too great for me, and I am afraid, that it was only to make me more enible of my orrowes; and that heaven, to make me more ad in my mierable condition, did only let me ee her, whoe I ought to be, if there were any jutice in Love.

No, Childe, anwered the Druide, Love having care of you, and intending to make you more happy then you are, hath given you this mall contentment, let you hould be driven out of one extremity into another knowing very well, that uch udden changes are very dangerous. And in confirmation of what I ay, Leonida will tell you what he hath een, and what declarations of amity he has een the fair Atrea make. Then the Nymph acquainted him with the empty Tombe, that was erected for him, with the ceremonies, the tears, and dicoure of every one, and particularly of Atrea; and that you may give credit unto what I ay, (aid the Nymph) let us go and ee Celadon's Tombe, for it is o neer this place, that perhaps you heard the voices of the Druides Daughters, and the Priet. You tell me uch tories, (aid Celadon) that I hould hardly believe them, had they come from the mouth of any other. I would not have you, replyed the Nymph, give more credit unto me, then to the veryet tranger in the world; but come, and believe your own eyes. Upon this, the Druide and Leonida got him out of his Cave, and conducted him into the Wood, where his empty Tombe was erected: Oh! how atonihed he was, and how preently he began to read that Incription which Silvander had et upon it? and having read it three or foure times over: I mut needs confee, (aid he) that you told me truth. But having received o great a contentment, would it not be want of love, if I hould have any deire, ince I mut not ee her? Doubtlee (aid Adamas) if you hould live a Reclue, and never ee her, it would argue want of courage and love in you. Want of Love! (anwered the hepheard preently) Ah no: I confee, it might argue want of courage, which upon this occaion might fail me, becaue I have uch abundance of Love. I hould believe, (anwered Adamas) that you do not love Atrea, if knowing that he loves you, and you may ee her, you abent your elfe from her preence.

Love, anwered the hepheard commands me to obey her, and ince he hath commanded me not to ee her, do you call it want of love, if I oberve her commandment? When he laid that command upon you, (aid the Druide) he did hate you; but now he loves you, and grieves for you, not only as abent, but as dead Be it as it will, anwered Celadon, he Commanded me; and be it as it will, I will Obey her. Yet, replyed Adamas, as perfect an oberver as you are of her commands, you have already diobeyed, ince you have een her, and were preent before her eyes. She did not forbid me (aid Celadon) from eeing her, but only not to come in her ight; and how could he ee me, when he was aleep? Since it is o, aid the Druide, I will finde out a way, that you hall ee her every day, if you pleae, and he hall not ee you. I conceive that, (aid Celadon) to be very difficult, for he mut either be aleep, or ele I mut be cloe hid in ome place. No, replyed the Druide; for more then that, you may peak to her alo if you pleae. This cannot be, (replyed the hepheard) unlee I be in a very dark place. You hall (aid Adamas) be in the open light, and ee her, if you have but courage, or if Love have the power to make you attempt it. Do not think, Father, (anwered Celadon) that there hall be either want of love or courage in me, provided I do not diobey her commands. Now ee (aid the Druide) how I do intend to contrive it. It is the goodnee of the great Tautates, to give me a Daughter, whom I deerly love above my own life: This Daughter, according to the rigour of our Lawes, is educated amongt the Druides Daughters, in the Monoteries of Carnutes; it will be above the expiration of eight long years, before I can have any hopes of her comming out. Perhaps you may remember, how I told you, how there is a great reemblance betwixt you and her, both in age and face. Now I do intend to give it out, that he has been ick, and upon uch an occaion, the antient Druides will allow her to retire, untill uch time as he be able to officiate in the neceary Exercies: A few daies after, you hall aume her habit, and I will receive you into my houe, under the notion and name of my Daughter Alexis: And it is very requiite
to give out that he is ick; for, your way of living thee lat two Months, hath o altered your face, and taken away that freh colour which was wont to be in your cheeks, as any that ees you would be deceived. And though the reemblance which is betwixt you be not o great, but that when you are both together, a great difference may be found, it is no matter; for it is o long ince any in this Country aw her, that though the reemblance were lee, yet when they hear me call you Daughter, they will certainly take you for her. I ee nothing in all this, but one inconvenience, which is, that every year we all ue to aemble our elves at Dreux, a place o neer the Carnutan-Monatery, that the Druides and Priets may come to dicover, that my Daughter is not gone from thence: But this hall be no top; for it will be two months before thee Druides do aemble, and they mut tay there two months more, and god knowes, whether before that time you may not have changed your habit and life. Now, Celadon, conider, whether all this be not very feaable. Ah! Father, (aid Celadon, after he had a while thought upon it) do you think, that Atrea by this means will not ee me? Do you think, andwered the Druide, that he can ee you, when he does not know you: How can he know you, when you are in uch a habit? But, Father, (replyed Celadon) let me be habited as you will, I hall be till Celadon in reality; o as I hall thereby diobey her. That you are till Celadon, is true, anwered Adamas but till you do not by this diobey her command: For, he has not forbidden you to be Celadon, but only, that he hall not ee this Celadon. Now when he ees you, he does not ee Celadon, but Alexis. And, for a concluion of all, if he do not know you, you do not offend her; and though he hould know you, and be angry, and command you to die; yet, were not uch an end better, then to languih to death in this manner? This, Father, aid the hepheard, is a good reaon, and I will ground upon it; therefore, Father, I will put my elfe, my life, and my contentment, all into your hands; dipoe of me therefore as you pleae.

Thus did Adamas work upon the obtinacy of Celadon; and to the end he hould not change his minde, he returned that very houre to take order for what was neceary, and epecially to pread abroad a report, that his Daughter was ick, and was to return home. For it was the cutome of Druides Daughters, when they were ick, to come out of their Monateries; and if their Parents were negligent, the Ancients of the Monatery would end unto them, for they held it as a great misfortune, if any dyed there. Therefore he gave out, that the Antients had ent unto him, that his Daughter was to come home, and that he expected her every day. Adamas and Leonida were very buie, in providing all things neceary for Celadon, who, in the mean time, had leaure to bid adieu unto Lignon, and to take his leave of his Woods, and of his Cell, but epecially of the Temple of the goddee Atrea. And when he was tricked up in the habit of a Nymph, (for o the Druides Daughters of that Country were dreed, when they returned from their Monateries) and was ready to depart, they thought it expedient to tay till night, to the end, none might ee him come alone; and in the mean time, Adamas iutructed him, what to anwer unto each, who enquired how the Druides Daughters lived, or of their Ceremonies, Sacrifices, Schooles, or Sciences; but, aid he, the bet way is, to peak as little as poibly you can, epecially before uch, as are knowing in the affairs of the world; as for others, it matters not, for they will believe any thing you tell them. Now the day being almot done, they went from that place at the entrance, into which Celadon had engraved thee Lines with the point of his knife upon a Rock, with much paines and time, having begun them that very day, he reolved firt to leave the place, for an eternall memory of his being there. The Lines were thee.

q.l: Within this hollow, dark, and rocky Cell.
Didain and Love a long time both did dwell.
Before you enter, if their wounds you fear,
Turn back and flie, there's no abiding here.
For, as a Coal is hot, though it eem dead,
After the flame is quite extinguihed:
Even o, Didain and Love, though abent be,
Yet relicks of their fire may leave for thee.

div.p:
This buinee was carried on by Adamas with o much prudence, that Paris himelfe could not dicover any thing, reolving to deceive him if he could, ooner then any other,
to the end, that he might the better deceive others: He therefore took this uppoed Alexis for his Siter, whom afterwards we will no longer call Celadon. As good luck was, when Adamas came home, Paris was not there, and therefore he could not ee how he came alone. As oon as he came there, Adamas got her to bed, giving out, that he was weary, by reaon of travell and her icknee; o as Paris aw her not untill the next morning; and Adamas and Leonida would not uffer her to come out of her Chamber, whoe windowes were o hut; that the little light hindred him from dicovery, what they deired to keep cloe, and they continued thus everall daies: Though this Artifice was uperfluous, becaue he knew o well how to carry her elfe, o that none could upect her; yet, this did give her better confidence, becaue in this condition, he received the viits of neighbours, who went all away in a full beliefe of her being Alexis.

Some daies paed on, in this manner; at the lat, he began to walk up and down the houe, and to go abroad, pretending, that the freh aire would conduce to her health. the eituation of the place was very pleaing and delectable, having a view both of the Mountaines and Plaines, and the pleaant River of Lignon, from Boen as far as Feures. This was the reaon, why Pelion, the Father of Adamas, did chue that place to build in. And ince that, Adamas had caued a very umptuous Tombe to be built, in memory of his Brother Belizar, and planted a pleaant Grove, which almot joyned to the houe, and extended it elfe towards the Mountaines. In this place, Alexis and Leonida went often to walk, becaue of the pleaant walks and propect; and becaue they were to walk up a riing Hill in the Woods, Alexis would ometimes take Leonida under the arme, when they were not een. And one time amongt others, when they were up betimes in the morning, and Alexis did offer her that ervice: This (aid the Nymph, and miled) is a piece of ervice, which you had rather do unto another, who perhaps wihes you not o well as I do. Oh Nymph, (aid Alexis, and ighed) I beeech you for gods-ake, not to renew the remembrance of my mieries; do you think I can forget them, having uch a deep reentment of them as I have? Thus they dicoured till they were in the Grove, which being higher then the Houe, did better dicover all the plain, o as there was not a turn of the River Lignon, from Boen, where it fell from the Mountains, unto Fcurs where it fell into Loire, which they did not eaily dicover. This propect had uch an operation upon the uppoed Alexis, that he could not chue but ay aloud: Oh my ad eyes! how can you live, and endure the ight of this happy River, where you have left all your contentment. Leonida deiring to interrupt her I believe, aid he, of all that ever loved, you are the only one, who does not delight to ee the place, where you have had o much pleaure: The memory of pat mieries is pleaing to the thoughts, much more hould the memory of happinee received. The ad Alexis anwered; That which renders the memory of mieries pat, to be pleaing, is it, which makes the memory of happinee to be full of intolerable wormwood; for the conideration of having pat the mieries, doth rejoyce; and the conideration of having no more happinee, doth make one ad. But my greatet grief is, that I do not know the occaion of my miery; this conideration, I wear unto you, Leonida, does wound me to my very oul: I have made a mot exact examination of all my life, but I cannot finde one act which I can condemn. To think, that a light humour, or any deigne of changing her affection, were in her, is too great an offence, and would give the lie unto thoe convincing tetimonies which I have to the contrary. To believe, that he treats me thus without any reaon, that would argue in me too little knowledge of her, of whoe leat actions I have had full experience. What then can be the caue of my miery? Oh ye gods! I think, that the tongue not being able to expree the miery, nor the thoughts able to comprehend the grandure of it, you will not let the undertanding have a knowledge of it. Then continuing in thee ad thoughts: Do you ee, great Nymph, aid he, a little Ile which Lignon makes, cloe by yonder Town, which is beyond the River, a little neerer Mount Verdun, and a little ditant from Julicu? There it was we paed over, by throwing great tones into the water, to tep upon, becaue at that time we ought out for the mot ecret places, to avoid the ight of our Parents, epecially my Father; who finding no remedy againt this affection, which he aw encreae before his face, he intended to end me out of Gaul over the Alps, to ee the great Cities, thinking, that ditance and abence would have that operation upon me, which all his forbiddings and charges to the contrary could not effect: And becaue we were advertied of it, we ought out for the mot obcure and unfrequented places that we could finde, there to pend that hort time we had to be together, in free dicoure; ometimes
becaue of the conveniency of the place, we went into yonder Rock which you may ee is omething neerer us, which is hollow, and left Lycidas or Phillis as Centinells, to advertie us when any paengers came by becaue being neere a high way, we might be heard. At one time above the ret, we paed over by great tones into this little Ile of Lignon: And though we had already taken leave of one another everall times, let we hould be urpried (for my Father concealed from me the day of my departure) yet till we were taking leaves and bidding adieus to the lat. When we were there, and could perceive no body, he at downe upon the ground under a Tree: I kneeling before her, tooke her hand; kied it, wahed it with my teares; and as oone as I could peake, I ayd thus unto her.

Now my fairet Atrea, I mut be at a fatall ditance from you, and will not die, becaue you bid me live: but how hall I be able to do it ince the very thought of this ditance is o intolerable, that it is ready to take away my life, as oft as I thinke upon you: To this he anwered nothing, but pulled me by the arme and made me it beides her, purpoely becaue I hould not ee thoe teares which tood in her eyes, and afterwards guhed out. And becaue I expected he hould ay omething, I was a while mute: he in the meane time wiped her eyes, and me thought I heard ome imprioned ighes which he retrained and would not let have a vent, let I hould heare them. I all this while, conidering in ilence my future fatall miery, at lat poke thus unto her. Alas, my Atrea, will you not, will you not pitty a poore hepheard, whoe cruell Father and fate will banih him from you? She anwered me with a deepe igh: Can you have any memorie, Sonne, of my pat life, and make any doubt, but that I hall mot adly reent any thing that hall dipleae you? Beleeve it Celadon, I will make it apparent that I do love you, and hall give cleerer tetimonies of it. I raied my elfe up, to ee what tetimony this would be that he would give me of her affection; but he turned her head the other way, and with her fair hand puhed me into the place where I at before, to the end I hould not ee her teares, of which he was in point of honour, ahamed. Perhaps, aid Leonide, it was her lofty pirit, which would not let any know, that Love could conquer her.

Whatoever it was, aid Alexis, he made it evident unto me, that he did love me. But why, my Fairet Atrea, (aid I unto her) do you not command me to tay with you, if my abence be dipleaing unto you? Can you think that the Command of a Father, or any thing upon earth can make me diobey what you ordaine? Sonne, aid he then unto me; I had rather die, then divert you from your voyage; It would be too great an offence both againt your duty and my owne honour. Do not think I make any doubt of that abolute power which I have over you: I judge of you by my elfe whom I am ure, neither the power of Father, authority of Mother, deire of Kindred, or alutation of Friends, hall ever make me do any thing againt that affection which my heart has unto you. And to the end you may depart from me with ome contentment, carry this aurance with you, I do vow and promie in the preence of all the gods whom I call to witnee, and by this oul which you love o well (aid he and layd her hand upon her Bret) that neither heaven nor earth hall ever make me love any but Celadon, nor keep me from loving him eternally. Oh mot trange Language? (aid Alexis then and ighed) trange indeed they hould be poken unto him who ince was o out of favour.

A few dayes after, I departed, and paed over the affrighting Precipices of the Sebucians, Caturgians, Bravomecians and Carrocleans as farre as the Seguiians, where the very horrour of death did often appeare unto me, yet all thee were not able to divert me from my thoughts. And having paed thee, I deired to avoyd the dangerous Mountain of Caturiges; therefore taking into the Rone, I reolved to go down that Lake, whoe waves do beat againt the ragged Rockes of this hideous Mountaine; but alas I found no more comfort by water then by Land; but on the contrary was in much greater danger of death by blutering winds and waves, dahing us againt the Rockes: but all this while, my thoughts were till the ame.

At the going out of this Lake, I croed through the great wood of Caturiges: And after I was pat Ieres, a River which comes from Centrons, I croed the traight vallyes of Carroclees and Bramovices which conducted me as farre as the Cotian Hills Leonide being very deirous to divert him from his ad thoughts: I beeech you, aid he unto him, Relate what you have eene rare in your voyage: That, (anwered Alexis) would be too long: for Italy is the very wonder of the world: But I hall relate unto you, one
very pleaant adventure which I met withall. And I beleeve we hall have time enough for it.

div.head: The Hitory of Uraces and Olimbres.
div.p: BE pleaed to know therefore Madam, that Alcippes intending to end me far enough from Atrea, he commanded me to lay aide the habit of a hepheard, that I might be more fit to keepe good company; for in thoe Countryes perons of any quality do all live in great Townes which they call Cittyes, where their Pallaces of Marble, and magnificence of furniture is able to amaze beholders: And none but vile perons and Peaants do live in the Country. Yet every one of the Province was extreamly affrighted at the comming of a Barbarian by Sea into Italy, who plundered almot all the Province, epecially Rome. I was o extreamly deirous to render my elfe amiable, as hoping thereby to make Atrea love me the better, as I was trangely welled with curioity to learne and enquire of every thing. Comming therefore neere the Appennine Hills, I heard that there was ome Mountaines which burned continually: And that I might be the better able to give an account of them at my returne, I would needs ee them But in my way thither, I met with an encounter which gave a top to my deigne: For I had not gone up the hills above two thouand paces, or two miles as they call them there, but I heard a voyce which pittifully lamented, and becaue I had a conceipt that happy it might be ome who tood in need of helpe, I turned that way as my eare guided me. And I had not gone a hundred paces but I pyed a man lying all along upon the ground, who not eeing me, broke out into thee expreions. Should I live, or hould I die, amidt o many fatall misfortunes? If I live, how can I endure o many torments: And if I dye, alas I hall never ee her again? Into what a mierable condition has my fate hurryed me? Since I cannot be happy either in life nor death? Oh mot mierable Uraces, (aid he) how long wilt thou uffer thy elfe to be thus flattered by vaine hopes? Why hould they let thee pae away thy dayes in uch cruell torments? And how cant thou preerve a life that is o unworthy of thy actions and thy corrage? Thou that hat a heart o daring as to lift thy eyes o high as Caears wife, thou that hadt o much corrage as to revenge thy love, and embrue thy hands in the blood of both, art thou now growne o faintly timerous as to live and ee the deare Eudoxe in the hands of a Vandall, who has carried her into the heart of Affrica and perhaps has a deigne upon her chatity? Oh heavens, how cant thou uffer uch a beauty, who deerves all adoration, to be o unworthily ued and made the prey of a cruell Barbarian? Cant thou endure that o divine a beauty, hould run the mot mierable fortune that ever humane did? Thou hat een it, Uraces; thou hat een it with thy owne eyes, and yet thou art alive: Thou art till the ame Roman Uraces who loved this divine Eudoxe: And thou hat revenged and delivered the Empire and the faire one from the Tyranny of Maximus? Oh Die, Die for hame, man; Let thy word do that which griefe will not, and by that Signall act, wah away the dihonour of urviving the liberty of Eudoxe.

Thus paionately did this tranger expree himelfe; and being tranported with fury he drew a hort word which hung by his ide, and doubtlee had run himelfe to the heart, if a companion of his had not run in and taken hold of his arme, jut as he was ready to give the mortall thrut; but in aving the life of his friend his hand was very dangerouly cut: For Uraces perceiving himelfe eized upon, and his mind being prepoeed with the thought of death he made his thrut, and gave his friend a very great wound: So as this friend not being able to hold him with that hand, and fearing he hould execute his cruell deigne, he fell upon him, aying, Uraces hall never die as long as Olimbres lives: A brave reolution of a friend: At the name of Olimbres, I aw the other man who was before o paionatly tranported, preently come to himelfe, and as if he had got a fall from the top of a high precipice was atonihed at the coming of the other. Friend (aid he) what Daemon did conduct you to this unfrequented place to hinder me from following my adored Eudoxe: For follow her I will, either with Uraces, or with his Ghot? Uraces, aid he unto him, the Gods who are preervers of friendhip, and no ill Daemon have prompted me to eeke you this three dayes, not to hinder you from following Eudoxe, if it be your contentment, but to accompany you: for my friendhip would not allow me to let you make that voyage alone: And therefore, if you will needs execute
your deigne, firt thrut that word in thy hand into the heart of thy friend, and afterward, when it is red, and reeking with my blood, execute thy deigne, or do what thou wilt. Ah Olimbres, aid he, this requet is incompatible with our friendhip: Can you think, my hand has any power to hurt Uraces's friend? Think me not o cruell, as ever to conent unto the death of him, whoe life was ever deerer to me then my own. But, if you have any compaion upon my miery, I conjure you by our pure friendhip, to let me go out of this mierable life. Can you think, aid Olimbres, that I will not immediatly follow you? Have I not courage enough, to take away my life, that I may follow yours wel as you follow Eudoxe? Do you think Death to be good or bad? If it be bad why wil you give it unto him, whom Olimbres, your friend, loves deerer then himelfe? If it be good, why will you not let Olimbres, whom you love, be a partaker with you? Oh, no, anwered Uraces, Olimbres hall live to eternity, before he die by the hand of Uraces:
• bl • , it will be a great tetimony of friendhip, to let me execute my deigne, which only can wipe off my hame, in urviving my happinee. In aying thee words, he endeavoured to draw out his arme, which his friend had engaged under his body: Which I perceiving, and fearing, that he who was wounded had not trength to hinder him, I went gently up to them, and taking the hand of Uraces, I forced open his fingers, and eized upon his word. And Olimbres's triving, had caued him to loe much blood. He preently perceived himelfe to faint; and apprehending, that the loe of his blood was the caue, he aroe from off his Companion, and hewed him his hand: Friend, aid he unto him, I am ready to wait upon you to Eudoxe; and if you will die, I hall think my elfe happy to follow you. Then preently he fainted, and fell into his friends boome. Uraces fearing the loe of him, he left off all thoughts of killing himelfe, to help his friend, and running unto a Fountain which was cloe by, he brought ome water in his hat, to throw in his face. In the mean time, I knowing that his dieae proceeded from loe of blood, I took a little moe, for want of a better remedy, and applying it to the wound, I tyed it up with my handkerchiefe, and had not done, when Uraces returned, who prinkling the face of his friend with told water, and calling upon him with a loud voice by his name, he brought him to himelfe again. When he opened his eyes: Alas friend, (aid he) why did you call me? Let my oule go contentedly out of the world, and let it attend you whereoever you go: Have this beliefe, I beeech you, that he cannot cloe up her daies more happily, then by your hand, and in doing you ervice. Olimbres, aid Uraces, if you do depart to follow me, I mut go before you; and therefore never think, that my hand hall make any paage for your oul, untill it hath with the ame word ent mine out of this mierable habitation. Upon this, he looked about for the word which I had taken away; Which I perceiving: Do not think, Uraces, (aid I unto him) to execute your cruell determination with this word; heaven hath ent me hither to tell you, that there is nothing in this world o deperate, which it cannot remit unto its former condition, when it pleaeth; and hath alo ent me to hinder you, from making any attempts upon the life, either of your elfe or your friend, for your life is his, not yours: But if you do attempt any thing againt your life, I tell you from the great god, that in lieu of following this Eudoxe, which you do o paionately deire, he will lead your oul into infernall obcurity, and quite take away your very memory. I hall now, Nymph, (aid Alexis) relate unto you a mot trange effect. Olimbres hearing thee words, was o ravihed with joy, that he would needs rie, and fall upon his knees before me; but his weaknee hindred him, only he turned towards me, and held up his hands: But Uraces did protrate himelfe at my feet: Oh thou welcome meenger from heaven, (aid he unto me) I know thou art o, both by thy voice and countenance; here I am, mot ready to obey, whatoever thou commandet. Perhaps (aid Leonida) they took you for Mercury, becaue they ue to repreent him young and fair, as you are 'Tis true, anwered Alexis, they did take me, either for Mercury, or ome Celetiall Meenger. I know not why, but to keep them in that opinion, I gave this anwer unto Uraces: god, O Uraces, doth command thee, and Olimbres alo, to live and hope. Upon this, taking out of my pocket a little leather Bottle of trong-Water, after the fahion of the Viigots, I caued Olimbres to drink a little, and giving him my hand, I aid unto him: Stand up, Olimbres, the heavens will quickly cure thee of this wound, and therefore let us go unto the next Town. It was very trange, to ee what effects this conceit did produce in this man; for, thinking that I was ent from heaven, and thinking, that the hot Water which I gave him, was
omething that was divine, he took uch heart and trength, that he followed me almot as well, as if he had received no hurt; yet I fearing let he hould faint again, I turned towards Vraces, and aid unto him: Although the heavens are able to give uch trength to your friend as is neceary, yet it would not be amie, that you took him by the arme, and holped him to walk; for god is pleaed to ee men help one another, through the effects of his goodnee. Upon this, Vraces went to his friend, and deired him to lean upon him; o as we came to the next Town, where by fortune we found a Chirurgion, who dreed the hand of Olimbres, and appointed him to keep his bed for a certain time.

As for me, I retired my elfe into another Lodging, very glad that I had done this good office, although it was a hinderance unto my deigne; for the day was o far pent, that I had not time enough to go and ee thoe burning Mountains. Uraces was very orry when he aw me depart, for he had a great deire to accompany me; but the Lawes of friendhip would not let him leave his friend in that condition. I did plainly perceive his deire, and to take him off it, I told him; That he mut needs tay with his friend, and not to tand upon the circumtance of complement; for, as for me, the gods would reward me, for the aitance I had brought them. If I would have uffered it, I think he would have throwne himelfe at my feet, by way of thanks; but I forbad him, and preently retired my elfe into another Lodging. But Uraces following me, he oberved the place where I entred, and hearing me ask for Lodging, he returned to his friend, to tell him, that though I was gone out of their Lodging, yet I was not gone out of the Town, therefore hoped I would ee them again: For, great Nymph, they had uch an aured confidence in me and my aitance, as they aured themelves, that by my help, they hould ere long ee Eudoxe.
