But Uraces finding his friend aleep, he preently returned to the place where I was; and eeing me at my repat he tood a little amazed; but when the cloth was taken away, and we two alone together, I bad him hut the Chamber dore: Afterwards, though with much ado, I caued him to it down, and to put him out of his errour, I aid thus unto him: I perceive, noble Cavalier; that the aitance which you have received from me, has made you think me omething above a man; and I am not orry that you have this opinion, to the end I might divert you from your horrid intention. But now, ince I ee you reduced unto former reaon again, I will no longer keep you in your errour. Know therefore, that I am a Celt, whom you do call a Gaul, born in a Country, the Inhabitants whereof are called Seguians and Forretians: Certain occaions, which would be too long, and uelee to you, to relate, have brought me out of my native-Country, and invited me to remain here in Italy for a certain time. Yet, I do take it for a particular providence from heaven, that I was o happily conducted to the place where you were, ince uch good effects enue upon it: I give heaven mot humble and hearty thanks for it, and you are obliged to the like; for, you may be mot certainly aured, that god would not have recued you o trangely from the very brink of death, if he had not reerved you for omething, either to his glory, or your own honour & contentment. I aw, that Uraces grew pale at thee words, and changed colour two or three times, eeing himelfe mitaken in his hopes, that it had been ome divine aitance. I mut confee, aid he unto me, that I was deceived; for, eeing you in a habit different from ours, your face o fair, hearing your voice o weet, and your peech o grave; moreover, you comming inviibly upon us, and in uch a nick of time, I mut needs confee, I took you for ome meenger from the great god: But, ince I undertand from your own mouth, that you are but a man, mortall as we are, I do believe it; yet believe withall, that you were ent by that great god, only to preerve the life of two mot faithful friends. And though in my firt opinion, I hoped for ome extraordinary aitance from heaven; yet now, in this opinion wherein I am, I will not be quite out of hopes in you, ince it cannot be denyed, but that there was ome extraordinary and particular care of us and our lives, which comes from ome great god, or great angell, who has made you the Intrument of it. Do not doubt, aid I unto him, but that you are reerved for ome better fortune, ince you are in o trange a manner preerved from eminent danger; for, the gods never do any thing, but for our good. And becaue I am a tranger to you, and altogether ignorant of that fortune, which you did o much condole, I hould be very glad to hear it from your own mouth, that I may know who it is whom the gods have ent me to preerve. Then with a a deep igh, he anwered me thus: The heavens had reaon to punih me, as the mot ungratefull peron that ever breathed, if I hould deny the relation of my whole life unto
him that hath preerved it. I hall therefore mot willingly atisfie your curioity, upon a promie of ecreie; for being dicovered, it may cot the loe of that life, which you have preerved. And upon aurance of ecreie, he continued thus.

Alexis would have continued her dicoure, and related all that Vraces told her, but the comming of Adamas gave a top unto her; for both Leonida and he were contrained to rie, and render that honour unto him which was due. The age Druide, taking one in one hand, and the other in another, he began to walk in a Laund, which though haded from the Sun, yet had a mot delicious propect towards the Wood of Ioures: And whilt they were dicouring upon everall ubjects, one came to acquaint them that Silvia was arrived, and already entred into the houe. Alexis was very hie, and would not be een, let he hould be known; but conidering, how willing that Nymph was to help her out of the Palace of Ioures, he hoped he was not changed: Yet Adamas had no minde that Silvia hould ee her, fearing, let the young years of that Nymph, and the favours which he lately received from Galathea, hould make her peak more then he hould; he would have kept the matter o cloe, that if he could, he would have kept it from his very elfe. Therefore he commanded Leonida to go unto her Companion, but be ure, that if he deired to ee Alexis, to tell her, that they were buie together concerning their Offices, and that he being to return very hortly unto Carnutes, and finih out her terme, he would not be een, but as little as poibly he could. So Leonida thus intructed, went to Silvia, who when they met, kied and embraced each other, as if they had not met of even years before. After thee firt complements, Silvia told her Companion, that the Country had not a jot blated the freh complexion of her cheek. And Leonida, in requitall, told her, The Court Beauties were alwaies above the Country Complexions, as plainly appeared, by comparing theirs together. Afterwards, Silvia aid thus unto her.

div.head: The equell of the Hitory of Lindamor.
div.p: THough, Siter, I had no buinee to invite me unto a viit; yet, my deires of eeing you are invitations ufficient. But I mut tell you, that at this time, that deire was not only my conductor, but alo ome buinee I would impart unto you, and, if you think good, unto Adamas alo; a buines which I thought fit to let you know, becaue Galathea and we may receive much contentment, or much dipleaure by the reult of it. Know therefore, Siter, that Flurial is returned from the place whither you ent him, and hath brought Letters from Lindamor; and wondred much, not to finde you at Marcelles, and would have come hither; but Galathea took notice, that he talked unto me, and upecting that you ent him to me, for he knew of the journey which you had commanded him to make, he called him to her, asked him, from whence he came, and what was his buinee to me. He, thinking he had don well, without concealing any thing, anwered her, that he came from Lindamor; and preently hewed her ome Letters which he had. She asking, who ent him that voyage: He anwered, that it was you, ince we were at the Palace of Isoures. Galathea then turning towards me, and haking her head: Do you ee, aid he, what humour your Companion is of? And, refuing the Letters, he commanded him to give them unto me, to end unto you. Afterwards he went into her Chamber, and commanded me to follow her. This was the reaon, that I could not ay any thing unto Fluriall, but only taking his Letters, I bad him tay there, till I had done talking with the Nymph. What do you think of your Companion, aid he unto me? is he not fully reolved to do me all the michiefe he can? Madam, aid I unto her, I cannot tell what to ay unto it, he mut be talked with, to know what her buinee and deigne was. I know it (replyed he) better then he will tell you, for he will not confee unto you the truth; he has acquainted Lindamor with my love unto Celadon. Can it be poible, Madam, anwered I, that he hould take o much pains, as to write that newes o far, and by uch a dangerous way? See what is in Lindamors Letters, (aid he unto me) and I believe you will finde, that I do not lie. Then taking the Letters out of my hand, he broke open the Seales and read them: The firt was directed unto you, and having brought them, you may read them. Then putting her hand into her pocket, he pulled them out, and gave Leonida that Letter which was directed unto her, which was in thee terme

body.head: Lindamor's Letter unto Leonida.
body.p: IT eemes, you conceive my preence to be requiite, and I think the like, but in a different manner then as you expect. Doubtlee it is requiite two waies: The one, to bring me out of this mierable life wherein I am, it being impoible for me to live, and ee uch an alteration in my Lady. And the other, in taking revenge upon him, that is the caue of my miery: I vow by all the gods, that the blood of this perfidious Rivall is the only atisfaction I can take for o great an offence, I hall, to thee ends, come to you, within the compas of that time, which the bearer hereof will tell you. In the interim, if you think it convenient, let my Lady ee the Letter which I have writ unto her, importing, that the end of my life, and the death of that Villain, hall tetifie unto her, that I cannot live, without a fulfilling of her promie; nor die, till I have taken revenge.

div.p: See, aid Galathea unto me, (continued Silvia) what I alwaies mot feared: The imprudence of Leonida, or rather, her malice, is o great, that he has told Lindamor of my affection unto Celadon; and this report is the caue, that he will come and kill him. I had rather die, then that hepheard hould receive the leat harm for my ake. Alas, how eaily may hee do it, ince the poor hepheard never thinks upon it, nor has any Armes, but his heephook? Can there be a more pernicious malice then hers, in procuring his death, who never dipleaed her? I believe rather, it is rage; for he loves him, and becaue he leights her, he will be revenged. Madam, anwered I, I cannot believe, that my Companion has committed this fault, though perhaps he may as great; for, upon reading of Lindamor's Letter, I cannot think he peaks of Celadon, but Polemas; for why hould he phrae Celadon perfidious? And why not Celadon, (replyed he preently) as well as Polemas? Becaue, Madam, aid I unto her, he has acquainted Lindamor with the Artifice, which Polemas practied with the fale and counterfeit Druide. And why, Silvia, (aid he unto me) do you yet believe, that Leonida told you or Lindamor truly, concerning that Druide? Do you not know, that it was meerly a device of her own pernicious invention, to make me cat off Celadon, that he her elfe might olely enjoy him? Now let me tell you, if you do not know it already, that he is o extreamly in love with him, that he cannot endure I hould look upon him: And had he as much power over me, as I have over her, he would never have uffered me to come into the place where he was. Did you never oberve Silvia, how he feeds upon him with her eyes, if I may o expree my elfe, and to look off him, is a death unto her? To ee me neer him, truck her to the heart, and welled every vein with jealouie. I have many a time oberved, the variety of paions that are in her; I have een her ometimes, no fire hotter, and immediately upon a udden, as pale as death; ometimes he would be all talk, and afterwards as mute as if he had not tongue. I have often een her o fix her eyes upon him, as if he would have look'd him through, and I have laughed at her in thoe extaies and ravihments. And he, deiring to engroe him wholly to her elfe, and take me off, has invented this tale he hath told you, which is as fale, as the gods are jut and true. Upon this, he took another of Lindamor's Letters, which was directed to her elfe, which you may read, (aid Silvia): Which Leonida took, and found in it thee words.

body.head: Lindamor's Letter unto Galathea.
body.p: SInce my fatall abence does not only deprive me of your preence, but alo ravih from me the honour an • happines of your favour, I do vow, that I will live only to render a tetimony, that I do better deerve that happines which you have promied unto me, than that perfidious man, who is the caue of my digrace. This wicked Villain hall never apire unto that honour, either by Love, or by Armes, or by Artifice, as long as I do live: He hall ere long confes what I do ay, or ele that word, which he hath already felt the harpnes of, hall cut his throat, who lives now too happily, for the mierable and unfortunate Lindamor to endure.

div.p:
When Leonida had read this Letter: I aure my elf, Siter, aid he, that Galathea did finde, that her o deerly beloved Celadon was not in any danger of his life, by any means
of mine: but rather that Traitor Polemas, who is the caue of all our miery. May Heius punih him by armes, and Tamaris by Thunderbolt, that my Lady may know, I did not lie when I related unto her the wickednee of Climanthe and the coening Lover For every yllable I aid unto her is true: If I did lye let the Sacred Mileto never be Salubrious unto me. To be brief, Siter, I weare by all thats Sacred that this is true: And though I do not care for returning unto Marcelles as long as he continues in this humour, yet I hall be very glad you would take all occaions and ue your bet endeavours to let her ee her errour. Not for any other end, but becaue I would vindicate my honour, and live within the compae of my owne quality without reproach. Siter, aid Silvia, you need not ue o many othes to aure me of the ubtility of Polemas, For I did ever beleeve it, both from what you told me, and from my owne obervation of his actions. And you may beleeve, I will take all occaions, ue my bet Arguments, and not leave one tone unturned to perwade the Nymph of the truth. But I mut not flatter you in this; For I cannot hope either any words or perwaions will work with her, untill her minde be better ettled, which perhaps will be too late, unlee God end ome unlookt for meanes: For I ee that Polemas hath a bad deigne, which he would not hide, but for his feares that he hath of Clideman and Lindamor, whom he knowes to be armed, and o much in favour with King Childerick who is ucceor unto the great Meroveus and who has a very great particular love unto Clideman and Lindamor, epecially unto Guyemant, o as he cannot be without them. Polemas being ubtile and crafty, does feare that if he hould attempt any novelty in the State, thee Frankes would by force ruine all his deignes. But to let Matters of State alone which hould be medled with by more able perons then we are: Let me tell you, Siter, that when Galathea read Lindamors Letter, he plainly found that Celadon was not in danger: therefore halfe of her anger was over. Did I not tell you Madam (aid I unto her) That Lindamor did meane Polemas? Tis very true, (aid he unto me) and I confee that I accued Leonida wrongfully: but it was my compaion unto that poore hepheard which moved me unto that language. Madam ayd I, I beeech you beleeve, that Leonide would willingly never do you that dipleaure; but he knowing very well that you did not love Polemas, he had good reaon to deire that Lindamor might obtaine the happinee of your favour; becaue there is a neere relation of Kindered betwixt her and him. For be pleaed to know Madam, that Lindamor is of the illutrious blood of Lavieu, and he of Fieur, which have bin o long linked together by alliances that thoe two families eeme but one. On the contrary, there was ever emnity betwixt the houe of Surieu and that, o as he may well be excued, if he did deire and endeavour to defeat Polemas from the happynee which he pretended unto. I do know (anwered Galathea) that there hath beene great emnity betweene the houe of Lavieu and Surieu: and ince the combate betwixt Lindamor and Polemas, there hath been no amity betwixt them: And I mut needs confee, Leonida has reaon for what he did, for it is Naturall to deire that the Family from whence any do derive themelves, may flourih and be advanced. And had I knowne it ooner, I hould not have taken her protection of Lindamor o ill, whether it was againt Polemas or againt Celadon: Alo when I conider upon what you tell me, I am apt to beleve that it was Adamas who helped Celadon to ecape, to the end that Lindamor being as you ay his coen might arrive at his deire, and I do think Leonida to be innocent in the matter. Therefore in that conideration, and becaue he did not end unto Lindamor any of our paages in the Pallace of Ioures, I will pardon her: yet, aid he, we mut make further ue of her in a buinee, which by her meanes may be effected. Here Silvia topt; and leaving her dicoure upon that ubject, aid thus unto Leonide: You ee Siter, that I do hide nothing from you, becaue our friendhip bids me be open unto you, but if you hould dicover me, I am utterly ruin'd: And therefore I beeech you be as ecret in it as poible you can: I had rather I were eternally dumb, (aid Leonida) then I hould commit uch a fault. Know then (continued Silvia) that Galathea after he had well bethought herelfe, aid thus unto me; you ee, Silvia, how extreamly I am troubled with thee two men, I meane Lindamor and Polemas; and I mut confee that whooever would rid me of them, would infinitly oblige me. For I am ure they will never let me be in any quietnes, nor uffer Celadon to be neere me: And therefore I would try if I could be hut of one by meanes of the other, which may be effected by the mediation of Leonide, whom I would have you counell, to acquaint Lindamour with all that Climanthe aid concerning him: but to take epeciall care that he do not thinke I have any thoughts of Celadon. And to the end he may thinke, if I have not quite forgotten that
hepherd you may tell her that the preence of Lindamor who is a man of o much Merit will make me forget him: by this meanes Lindamor will either detroy Polemas, or Polemas him. So hall I be rid of one, at the leat, and both if good fortune's favour be o much, as that one kill theother. I do not deire this hould be by death, but rather be rid of them ome other way. But I am o extreamly petered with them, and do love Celadon o well, that if there be none other remedy, I conent unto it, o it be not by my hand, or knowne that it proceeds from me.

I mut confee Siter, that when I heard thee words, I was atonihed, and reolved to acquaint you, not to incite you unto what he deires, but rather to divert you. I anwered the Nymph, that it was firt requiite to know of Flurial what time Lindamor aid he would come; which he thought to be expedient, and therefore commanded me to call him: which I did: but before he poke unto her, I charged him not to tell Galathea the time of his comming nor the place where he would be: and that if he asked him, he hould ay, that he would come much latter then the time he told him. Though the fellow had no great matter of wit, yet he had ome apprehenions which made him tagger at my perwaions; yet at lat he harkened unto them: then I brought him to her, and he lyed o confidently, that he beleeved him. And becaue he thought it expedient that I hould come unto you, to get you to write unto Lindamor, or at leat to let him know what Polemas had done againt him; I thought good to bring Flurial with me, that he might tell you more then perhaps he would me but he feares that you are angry with him for o imply giving your Letters unto Galathea, that he dare not come in your ight. Now me thinks that though he did very imply in it, yet he ought not to be o chid for it as to loe him. True (aid Leonide) and perhaps he hath not done o much hurt as he thinkes, ince by his meanes Galathea hath read Lindamors Letter which I hould not have dared to preent unto her, leat he hould have banihed me as he hath already. Aure him therefore, that I am not at all angry with him but rather pleaed, Silvia upon this, went out and called for Flurial whom he told what he had done; and afterwards brought him unto Leonida who looked upon him very kindly, and aured him that he was nothing dipleaed with him: Then asking him every particular of his voyage, he began to anwere thus.

I was afraid, Madam, that I had committed a fault, and therefore beeeched Silvia to make my excue but ince, thankes be to Cod, it proves otherwie, I am mot heartily glad of it, and thinke it to be the greatet happinee that could come unto me: For I have vowed my elfe o much unto the ervice of Lindamor that though he may perhaps find me failing in my wit and dicretion, yet never in my fidelity and affection. Therefore as oon as I had your commands upon me to go unto him, I went with as much hate as poibly I could and came unto a City called Paris, where Meroveus then was, being returned from the Neutrian Country: This City is eated in an Ile, o as the walls about it are wahed with a River which runs round on all ides of it: And o as there is no comming to it but by bridges. As oon as he aw me, I oberved a great alteration in his countenance but he being in bed then, and having many perons about him, he could not peak unto me, nor aske me the occaion of my voyage: But when he was alone, he called for me: and asking what buinee brought me thither, I told him, that he would be bet informed by your Letter. Is there none (aith he preently) from my Lady? You will know all (anwered I) by that Letter. He changed colour when I aid o unto him: thinking that certainly there was ome great alteration or other in the wind, but when he had read your Letter I never aw a man o amaz'd I cannot tell what was in that paper, but it was like to have cot him his life. I do remember, aid Leomda, the very words: they were but hort, and therefore Siter, I would have you heare them, that you may acquaint Galathea with them, if you think it requiite.

body.head: Leonida's Letter unto Lindamor.
body.p:
AS I have heretofore told you, that you might trut in me; o I mut tell you now that you mut trut to your elf: not that the leat thought of my affection to your ervice is diminihed: but becaue the ubtility of Polemas is uch, as that it hath taken away all my power to erve you. Your buines goes o very badly on, as you mut not expect any good uccesunles you peedily returne. I cannot ay any more unto you unles it were by word of
mouth, it not being fit any but your elfe hould know of that, which none but your elfe can remedy.

div.p: You gave him, aid Silvia, a very hot alarme, and I do not wonder he hould bluh when he redd it; for, uch newes might very well caue the like effects. How could I write any lee, aid Leonida, is it not true? For my part, I cannot tell a lie, epecially to my friends, and uch as trut in me. Your words replyed Flurial, were very effectuall. By fortune, there was none with him, unlee a young man who waited upon him in his Chamber. He had uch a command over his orrowes, as he retrained his complaints, till he had commanded this young man and my elfe to retire, and wait in his Wardrobe, untill he called for us: Then cauing the Curtains to be drawn, he began to igh o loud, that though the dore was hut, yet we could hear him. Then I enquired, what was the caue of keeping his bed, and I undertood, that it was by reaon of ome wounds he had received in a skirmih, wherein the Neutrians were defeated by the valour of Clidaman and Lindamor; and becaue I was very inquiitive after newes, and deired to know all paages, the young man made this relation to me.

I believe, Fluriall, (aid he unto me, for he knew my name, having often een me in the Gardens of Mount-Brion, and in his Maters Chamber, when you ent me to him) that you have heard of the Battles that have been wone from the Neutrians by the King; yet, with the aitance of Clidaman and my Mater. I aure my elf alo, that you have heard talk of a Lady, (he did name her (aid he unto Leonida) but I have forgot it) who putting her elfe into the habit of a man, did follow beyond the Sea a Neutrian, whom he loved, and who reembled Ligdamon o much, who was taken for him, and dyed, becaue he would not marry a woman, for whom that man fought, and killed a man, for which Murther being banihed, he fled into a Country beyond Sea, I cannot hit upon the name of it; and afterwards upon his return, was Prioner, by a kinman of him that was killed: And had it not been for this Lady of whom I mean, he had been put into the hands of Jutice; but he fought for him, and tayed in Prion her elfe to releae him.

This intricate tale of Flurial's, made the Nymphs to laugh; though Silvia, in memory of Ligdamon, and Leonida alo, had a good minde to help him out: Thou dot mean, Flurial, aid Silvia, the fair Melander. True, true, aid he, that's her name. And Lydias, continued the Nymph, who was kept in Calice by Lypandas, becaue of Arontes his death. The very ame, (aid Fluriall, and clapped his hands together) but I hall never remember their names, and therefore I hall finih my relation, upon condition, that you will help me out. Now, this Lady (continued he) was the caue of Calice being taken by the Francks, and Lypandas (I cannot tell whether I name him right) was made a Prioner. As for Melander, who was in Prion, as oon as ever he was releaed, he would go unto Lydias, thinking that Ligdamon, who was in the hands of his enemies, had been Lydias, as every one reported him to be. As oon as Lydias heard of this Ladies departure, he followed after her, not fearing any everity of enemies, nor rigour of jutice. But Lypandas, who was in Prion, knowing that he had kept a Woman Prioner, and that he had fought with her, he fell o in love with her, that he never left oliciting, till he obtained his liberty, and then went as fat as he could to the Town whither he was gone; I have quite forgot the name of it, for it was a very hard word. Was it not Rhothomages, aid Leonida? The very ame, aid Flurial. Oh god, what fine tories could I tell you, if I had a good memory. But o it was, that the King's Son fell upon ome of the Enemies, and defeated them, after a long Combat, in which Lindamor was o wounded, that he was forced to keep his bed. Truly, aid Leonida, you are an excellent toryteller, and therefore I pray proceed. My memory, aid he, is not o as I wih it; but I had rather not tell many things, then lie.

Now whilt this young man told me thee things, Lindamor ighed, and ometimes poke; but I could not poibly hear what he aid, becaue the dore was hut: At the lat, I heard him call me, and not drawing the Curtains, he aid unto me: Fluriall, I would have thee return to morrow, and I would be before thee, if I could endure a Hore-back, but I will preently follow thee; tell Leonida, that I will come to the houe of Adamas, and it hall be within this twenty nights at the leat, if my wounds will give me leave. Upon this, he commanded me to take my ret. But I was much atonihed, when they told me that very ame night, that they thought him dead two or three times, and
that his wounds were o much changed upon a udden, that he was in great danger of his life. I do believe, that the Letter which you writ, was the caue: He continued long in this condition, o as I could not be dipatched of a month after, within which time, he grew better, and not in o much danger. Beides his wounds, he had uch a Feavour, as caued him very often to talk lightly, and ordinarily name Galathea, Leonida, and Polemas; Love, revenge death. At the lat he recovered, but not o well, as to go out of his bed; and the Phyicians told him, that he mut not tir out of his Chamber, at the leat of fifteen nights: And therefore he dipatched me, aying, that before the ixteenth of the next Month, he would be here, and gave me the Letters which you have een; commanding me to tell you many fine words, which did only ignifie thanks, and which, in good faith, Madam, I have quite forgotten.

The Nymphs could not chue but laugh at Fluria's dicoure, and good memory: And becaue they would talk together, they commanded him to go out, and tay till Silvia returned, epecially to have a great care he told none, when Lindamor would be back. Then being alone together, they reolved to tell Galathea plainly, the truth of that voyage, hoping, that perhaps the merits of Lindamor would make her more coniderate; but by all means to conceal from her the time of his comming, let if he hould know it, he hould advertie Polemas; not out of any good-will unto him, but only that he might tand upon his guard, and that Lindamor intending to kill him, they might be both in a poibility of dying; or that o acquainting him with the deigne of Lindamor, he might challenge him the field, and there die. This then being the deigne, Silvia thought it expedient, to communicate the matter unto the age Adamas; and to know his opinion: But Leonida told her, that he would acquaint him with it at leaure; but now, he was very buie with his Daughter. And hall not I ee her, aid Silvia? It will not be convenient at this time, aid Leonida; for they are both exceedingly buie, becaue it is not much above a month, before the Druides aemble at Dreux: And I do believe, that for this year, my Uncle will be exempted, becaue of his Daughter, whom he will be contrained to bring back, whoe preence he would enjoy as long as poible he can: Yet, if you pleae I hall acquaint them, for I know they will be extreamly glad to ee you. No, no, aid Silvia, I am very glad, that Adamas reolves to tay at home this year; for I believe, his preence will be more neceary unto us then we imagine: I will not by any means diturb them; it ufficeth me to know, that they are well. Then, after ome other dicoure, Silvia took her leave, and returned unto Marcelles, where Galathea was, in a longing expectation for her, deiring to know what dicoure Leonida and he had; but, above all, to know what newes of Celadon, auring her elfe, that Leonida could tell. But when he undertood, that the hepheard was not in his Town, and that none knew where he was, he was not a little perplexed, but knew not how to accue Leonida; for he imagined, that if this hepheard had ecaped by her contrivance, he would never have uffered him to go out of the Country. After he had conidered with her elfe, he aid, That perhaps Leonida is not acceary to Celadon's departure, becaue he went away out of the Country in that manner. Truly (anwered Silvia) I believe, he never o much as thought of any uch thing, and I dare anwer for her, almot as much as for my elfe. But, if he were not (replyed Galathea) why hould he not come again, when you ent unto her from me? Madam, (aid Silvia) I beeech you, give me leave to tell you plainly, what anwer he gave unto me. I do not only give you leave, aid the Nymph, but I command you, to tell me. Be pleaed to know then, Madam, aid Silvia, that after he had read my Letter, he anwered: That he knew very well what honour it was, to do you any ervice, epecially to be about your peron, not being ignorant, that we are all obliged, both by nature and your merits, to devote both our ervices and lives unto you: But when he conidered the trange opinions you have entertained of her; and the bad treatment, thoe opinions have caued her to receive from you, he had rather loe the happinee of your preence, then to be in danger, of farther incurring your disfavour, and become the talk of all the Court: That a Maid has nothing more deer unto her, then her honour and reputation, and your upitious of her, have caued many diadvantagious reports to go of her: That he alwaies courts occaions, to obtain the honour of your favour, by all poible ervices he is able to do; yet, mot humbly beeecheth you, not to take it ill, that he does not return again. At this time when I pake unto her, he gave me the ame anwer; adding many vowes and protetations, that what he had told you concerning Polemas and Climanthes, was true; o as I mut needs ingenuouly confee, that I do believe
her. Do you think, aid Galathea, that this can be? Madam, anwered Silvia, I ee no impoibilities in it; for it is mot certain, Polemas does love you, and has ubtlety enough to invent this trick: Now I am the more apt to believe it, becaue the very ame day you found Celadon, Polemas was een alone in the ame place, walking there very long, manifeting thereby, that he had ome deigne in it. How do you know this, aid the Nymph? I have learned it, aid Silvia, from everall perons, being very inquiitive to dicover the truth; o as enquiring where Polemas was that day, I undertood at the firt, that he was not at Marcelles: Afterwards, earching more narrowly into the truth, I dicovered, he went out of Fours, having only one man in his company, whom none did know, of whom he made very extraordinary much of. At lat, I undertood from many, that thoe who earched for Celadon along the River Lignon, found him alone, walking in the ame place where you found the hepheard. Truly, (aid Galathea) this tale does not a little trouble me; o as if it be true, I mut needs ay, I have wronged Leonida, in treating her as I have; for, till now, I thought this to be a meer trick. Madam, (anwered Silvia) I aure you, that Polemas was long in that place at that time, as well as many daies enuing, without any company: Now, judge you, what could his buinee be there. I mut now confee, aid Galathea, that Polemas is a knave; and could I dicover the truth, I would make him repent of his knavery. Mean time, I would have you get Leonida to return unto me, auring her, that he hall have my love, o he will live with me and you, as he ought to do.

On the other ide, Leonida, as oon as her Companion was gone, returned to Adamas, relating part of the newes which he heard, and handomely concealing what he thought he might take ill. Now, becaue it was dinner time, the Druide, Alexis, and he, retired unto their Lodgings.

Twelve or fifteen daies being pat, ince Alexis left her ad habitation and mot of the Neighbours had payed all their civill viits unto Adamas, a Servant came and told him, a certain number of hepheards came to peak with him, amongt the ret, one, whoe name was Lycidas. At the name of Lycidas, Alexis tarted: Which Adamas oberving, let Paris hould do the ame, he ent him to ee who they were. Paris undertook this Commiion with a very good heart, becaue he was in fear of his dear Diana's welfare In the interim, Adamas looked upon Alexis, aying: I am afraid Daughter, let your hatred unto this Brother hould dicover, what we deire o much to conceal. It is impoible replyed he, but I hould be urpried at this unexpected newes; therefore, if you pleae, I will withdraw into the next Chamber, till thee hepheards be gone. No, aid Adamas, for doubtlee they come hither to ee you: Beides, it is not good to put Paris himelfe in any doubt. Alexis did not reply, becaue he heard the voice of Lycidas at the tairs foot. Preently after, all the Company came into the Hall, where the Druide received them with extraordinary demontrations of love. The mot eminent amongt them was Diamis, Diana's Uncle; Phoceon, Uncle to Atrea; Lycidas, Silvander, Coridus, Amidor: And though Tircis and Hylas were not of that Country; yet, having ojourned foure or five months in their Towne, they came with them for loves-ake, and good company. Phoceon, the mouth of all the ret, preented their good affections to the Druide, together with their cordiall deires to do him ervice: Afterwards told him, that two occaions had principally invited them thither: The one, to congratulate with him in his joyes, of eeing his Daughter Alexis: The other, to acquaint him, that it had pleaed the great Tautates, to end ome Mileto into the Grove belonging to their Town; therefore they came to beeech him, he would be pleaed, according to their cutome, to take o much paines, as to come and make a acrifice of thanks. Then the Priet addreed himelfe: Sir, aid he, what I hall relate unto you, is very trange: As I was earching out Mileto for the new year, I found things, that are no lee then wonders, in the acred Grove of Heius, Taramis, Belinus, our great god Theutates. Firt a Temple of Hazells and young Oakes, o twited and plaited to a great Oake in the midet, as there is an arched Vault, o pacious, as to contain many people: In the midt, is a bank of Grae, in form of an Altar, upon which tands a Picture, repreenting reciprocall Amity, together with the twelve Statutes of the Lawes of Love. Within this, we found another Temple, dedicated unto the goddee Atrea. Oh Sir! I cannot chue but admire the mytery. There are in this, two Altars, the chiefe of which is Triangular, under the mot wonderfull Oake that ever was; for, having but one tock, it divides it elfe into three branches, then rejoynes themelves into one bark again at the top, in uch an admirable manner, as that they make
but one Tree, and preads it elfe above all the Trees in the Grove. There we found the falubrious Mileto, o freh, and well growne, as by the report of all the Priets, none in all the Country is comparable unto it. There the acred name of the great Tautates is engraven, with the names of Heius, Tharamis, and Belinus, upon the three branches, which doth evidence unto us, that god loves the place, and would be there adored.

Thus the Priet related thee things unto the Druide, who knew them better then himelfe, being the Inventor of them. It was a cutome amongt the Gaules, that a Month before the ixteenth of July, they earched throughout all the Country for an Oake that had the finet Mileto; then to make a report of it unto the grand Druide, to the end it might be ceremoniouly gathered: To that end, all the Priets aembled, eeking for it in all the groves; then when they found it, they gave it a mark. Now thinking it to be a igne of gods love, that it hould be found in the Grove next their own Town, the People of it were wont to offer a particular acrifice of thanks, where the grand Druide ued to officiate, if he was pleaed to favour them o much. Now, foramuch as Adamas did very much love thee men, beides his deigne upon Alexis, upon whoe contentment, he thought, his own depended, according to the Oracle; therefore he promied to go with them, whenoever the Priet would advertie him. The Shepheards returned their thanks in the bet expreions that poibly they could. Although (aid Adamas, and miled) I have ome reaon to be orry, that the hepheardees of your Town are the only neighbours, who have not favoured me with a viit, in congratulation of my Daughters return; yet, I mut needs let them know, that I do eteem them above any in the Country. Paris deiring to excue his Mitree with the ret, did humbly make addree unto him: Father (anwered he) I beeech you excue them, for I have heard them reolve, to come and ee my Siter; but Atrea being o ick, as forced to keep her bed, hath a little deferred it, becaue they deire to have her company. Since it is o, aid Adamas, I am atisfied with the excue; otherwie, I hould take it a little unkindly. Phoceon then addreing himelfe: It is mot true aid he, that my Niece hath of late been very ickly; o as I conceive her bet Phyick will be to marry. You may do very well (aid Adamas) to let it be your indulgent care, for he is now of a fit age for it.

Whilt Adamas was thus talking with thee hepheards, Leonida and Alexis entertained others. But as oon as Lycidas fixed his eye upon his Brother, it was long before he could draw it off; for, he thought he aw the very face of Celadon: then conidering it a little more preciely, he admired, that two perons hould reemble one another o much; yet, the etled opinion of his death, the authority of the Druide, who aid, he was his Daughter; the habit of a Nymph, together with a little alteration in the face of Alexis, did make Lycidas give the lie unto his own eyes. After a little longer looking upon her, he could not chue but ay thus: Madam, If I did as much reemble him, whom you love mot, as you do the peron whom I love and honour mot, I hould hope ere long to engratiate my elfe into your favour. Kinde Shepheard, (anwered Alexis) I am glad I have any reemblance of the peron whom you love; for, knowing from my Father how he eteemes you, I hall take any occaion to continue that amity you bear unto him. The obligations we do owe unto the Father, (anwered Lycidas) together with the merits of the Daughter, commands us to do you all ervice; but me above all others, who does ee him live again in your face, whoe life was deerer to me then my own. Thee were the firt complements which paed between the two Brothers.

Though Leonida contrained her elfe as much as poibly he could, yet he could not chue but mile, to ee how Lycidas was deceived; but fearing, let Alexis hould not at the firt, act a womans part very well, he interpoed, eeming to be very zealous in enquiring, how all the hepheardees her friends did: Therefore, good Lycidas, (aid he) leave off your fine complements, and tell me, how all my dear friends do. Some (anwered Lycidas) are merry, others ad, and ome neither merry nor ad, but do glide away time moothly, without extreams Who is it, (aid Leonida) that is o inenible either of mirth or orrow, as he reents neither? It is the hepheardee Diana, anwered Lycidas; for, he loving none, is neither merry nor ad ince if thee do not proceed from love, they do not deerve the name. I do believe, aid Leonida, that you do think as you peak; but every one is not of your opinion. Thoe that think otherwie (aid he) are like unto thoe Antients, who thought Water and Akehornes to be the finet food, when they knew not what Wine and Wheat was; but now, we think that to be food only for Beats: So thoe who have tryed the weets and bitters of Love, will confee, that all others are nothing in comparion. Do
you think (aid Leonida) that Diana never did love any, nor does love any yet? For what is pat (aid Lycidas) I will not anwere; but for the preent, I beleeve he lets all matters of love alone; you tell me ill newes for Paris (replyed Leonida). This, aid the hepheard is the folly of our Towne, for I verily beleeve that Diana is not enible of the honour which Paris doth her: yet if I be deceived, I am not the firt that is mitaken in Women Well: aid Leonida, let us leave Diana for this time, and tell me who is he that is the ad one? It is Atrea (anwered Lycidas) for Phoceon a covetous Uncle, who, as mot old men do, thinkes there is no happinee but in marrying his Neece richly, will needs betow her upon a Boyen hepheard called Calydon, whom he never aw above one minute at the mot, and whom he does not love, yet for my part I beleeve the old fellow will bring the match about.

Is not this Calydon, (aid the Nymph) Nephew unto Tamares? The very ame (anwered he). But (replyed Leonida) has he forgot his love unto Celidea? Oh Madam, (aid he) Celidea is not the ame he was: the accident of her loe was indeed very trange. Why, aid the Nymph, is Celidea lot? he may be termed o (anwered he) and the heart of Tamire is now wholly upon marrying Calydon. Though Alexis was talking with Corilas, Hylas, and Amidor, yet he lent an eare unto Lycidas, whoe words went o to her heart, that every one tooke notice of her, becaue at the firt he bluhed, then preently after grew as pale as ahes: This caued Leonida to aske her how he did, and to ay that this was a relique of her old dieae, therefore deired her to it downe. Hylas who from the firt ight of her had a good mind to her, o as Phillis was almot quite out, and this in his heart, he took her by the arme and made her it downe as it were by force; then itting by her, his eyes were never off her face. In the meane time Leonida and Lycidas went unto the window, there continued on their dicoure: but Lycidas till eying Alexis, he firt aid; I cannot chue but looke upon the faire Daughter of Adamas; for he has uch a reemblance of my poore Brother, both in her features and Aire, as I can finde no difference betweene them, but in habit. Is it long (aid Leonida) ince he dyed? It is (anwered he) about four monthes ince. I have heard o many good reports of him (aid Leonida) that I am orry I never aw him. As for his Interiour parts, I cannot decribe him unto you (aid Lycidas). But as for his face and actions, looke upon Alexis who is the jut picture of him: The very ame eyes, the ame mouth, the ame ymmetrie of every part. Alexis all this while did uffer all that Hylas aid, but it was with much adoe: Oh heavens? (aid Lycidas) the very ame mile! the ame turne of his head! Was there ever uch a reemblance as this? Leonida fearing that his conideration of her reemblance unto Celadon, might dicover that he was Celadon indeed, he aid thus unto him. But Lycidas to returne unto our former dicoure; when Paris erected his Tombe I heard that Atrea did infinitly love him, and could not chue but breake out into many expreions of it: I would it had pleaed the gods (anwered Lycidas with a deep igh) that he had never loved him, for then my brother had bin now alive. Why, aid Leonida, do you accue her for his death? I have heard that he has o grieved his loe, as he herelfe hath been in danger. The tory (aid Lycidas very faintly) would be too long and tedious to relate now; but if he be unhappy in marrying Calydon, who loves her not, It is the jut revenge of love upon her for the death of Celadon who adored her, of which he is too guilty: Is it long ince Celadon was lot (aid Leonida). It is about twelve or fifeene dayes ince, (anwered he). Then (aid the Nymph) it was preently after he received our judgement: Ten or twelve dayes after, aid the hepheard, I aure you all that knew her, laments her loe, For my part, aid the Nymph, I never heard of it untill now, yet beleeve me I do deeply reent it: but pray Lycidas tell me, how it came to pae.

div.head: The Sequell of the Hitory of Celidea.
div.p: I Had thought Madam (anwered Lycidas) that you had heard of this pittifull tory, becaue it was an accident o trange, as every one reported it, as a great wonder. But ince I perceive you have not, Be pleaed to know, that poore Calidon being by your entence condemned, he grieved beyond thought: Yet after a long condoling of his ad fate, reaon began to take place. He etting before his eyes his duty unto Thamire, the didaine of Celidea, and his oath to obey your doome, he rooted that domineering paion out of his oul, and et his heart at ret.

In the mean time Thamires acquainting Cleontine with his deigne and epecially Celideas Mother, within a fortnight all things were in that forwardnee, as there wanted nothing to conummate the marriage but going to bed together. That night being come, the houe was all joy in hopes of that upport which all Celideas friends expected by her mariage with this rich man. Untill jut now, Calidon obeyed your doome; But when he began to thinke that this very night Celidea was to be in the armes of another, and not his, all his reolutions failed: his eyes aw that, they never aw before, and his heart began to have other thoughts. He retyred himelfe to a corner of the chamber, and there drooped in his owne thoughts whilt every one was dancing. Thamires who loved him as his owne Sonne did doubt from whence this adnee proceeded, o as out of pitty he went gently to him, and heard him uttering thee words.

lg.l: A Lover cannot live and ee,
His mitres any other's be,
For he that loves can never yeild,
Another mater of the Field.
But though I dye, I hall retaine
A memory of mourning paine,
So when I have reign'd my breath,
Sorrowes will follow after death.
So whether I do live or dye,
My fate is onely miery
And adder Fate ure none can have,
As not to ret within a grave.

div.p:
Thamires hearing this, did exceedingly pitty him, and more, when after thee words he aw him lift up his hands and eyes, and o wel'd with teares, that he was not able to peak, he withdrew gently to tell Celidea in what condition he found him, deiring her to give him ome conolation. The hepheardee was very willing to obey Thamires, nor was he deirous to loe Calidons favour, ince he was to live with his Unckle, therefore he went unto him, whom finding in that condition, How now hepheard, aid he unto him, what all alone when we are in dancing? Ah hepheardee, anwered he, you may well allow me that liberty, ince all your mirth is at my cot; but I wih it were without offence to god or you, that I might end my ad dayes, before this night came to put me out of all hopes of any contentment. What do you meane? (aid the hepheardee) my meaning is, replyed he, that did I not offend the great Tautates in putting my elfe to death, and you, in making you to loe a mot faithfull ervant, this very hand hould dipatch my life, before that night come in which I hall ee Thamires enjoy her whom my affection onely can merit. Celidea eeming to take no notice of any uch things; I thought aid he, that you had forgotten all thoe follies, and I do wonder they hould be till in your memorie. How? (replyed Calidon with a deep igh) can Calidon ever forget Celidea? are you not afraid Thamires will punih you for an offence o great againt my love? Take heed your offence be not greater (anwered he) when you call to minde the promie made unto Leonida to oberve the entence he hould pronounce: have you o oone forgot it? or do you think the gods ever will? How can you ever hope that the Mileto of the new yeare, hould ever be alubrious unto you, ince you wore by it to obey your doome? Ah hepheardee (replyed Celadon) Do not think I have forgot the unjut judgment of that pittilee Nymph (pardon me Madam for repeating his words) The memory of it is too adly freh, to be o oone forgotten; nor do not thinke I am of opinion that the gods forget my oath; no nor that I care whether the Mileto of the new yeare, be Salubrious or no, ince in loving you, there is nothing in this world that I do care for. Yet, Do you not tand in feare (aid he) of the jutice of the gods after your death? The gods, aid he, can inflict no more paine then I uffer in my life: For there are not more cruell torments then thoe I endure. Yet not withtanding do not thinke me o ill an oberver of what I have promied: you may remember my vow was, to oberve the Nymphs judgement, as long as I lived: well (aid he) do you not diobey it by thee expreions unto me? No, anwered he, for do you not perceive that I have been dying
ever ince that doome was pronounced? For life is not to live, but to live well. Now ever ince that fatall moment, I have beene o far from living well, as I have not onely lot my happynee, but all my hopes of it. If you call languihing a life, I ay againe, let the Sacred Mileto be never Salubrious unto me. When no hopes are left, let life go whither it will, for nothing can do me good ince you are gone. If the gods will but heare the prayers of a mot deolate man, I hall oone die. What advantage can you hope for (aid he) in dying? From it (aid he) I expect all my felicity: for none is to be hop't for here, ince I cannot love you unlee I offend the gods, or you whom I do feare. But, mot cruell hepheardee, what was your deigne in coming unto me? Was it to tryumph once more over poore Calidon? or are you like thoe merry minded people, who when they have killed a poore mierable Innocent that never did them harm, they come to ee how great the wounds are which they gave him. That, ad hepheard, aid he, was not the caue which invited me hither: but it was to trye if I could divert you from your ad thoughts: o as if I could without offence to the will of the gods, I would give you ome conolation. How? (aid he preently) does it not uffice you, that I dy • by the cruell hand of fate and by the injutice of men, which has taken from me all that I can call life, but you mut alo add a vaine compaion, which you eeme to have of me, onely to make me die with more griefe? Would you have me think you pitty me? Nay nay, never talke to me of any pitty, or health, or remedy, or any hope, for I am as incapable of any good, as you are of will to do it.

It was now late; o as the Ball being ended, Celidea according to Nuptiall cutomes was conducted to bed, and afterwards Thamires unto her; Calidon he went both out of the chamber and the houe; and by fortune did lye downe under ome great Elmes by the way ide neere unto the houe. Where after he had a while conidered the happinee of Thamires, and then his owne ad fate, his heart o failed him, as he fell into a wound, and continued in it, till Cleontine and her company coming out of the houe, found him lying all along as if he were aleep. But offering to wake him, and eeing he did not tirre, Cleontine herelfe tooke his hand; which finding to be very cold, becaue all the naturall heat of the outward parts was retired to the heart, he cryed out, Oh, Calidon is dead. Many that heard her voyce did run unto her: So as when they aw him in that condition, the cry was o loud as it caued all the neighborhood to reort thither: many ran into the houe till, crying out aloud Calidon was dead, Calidon was dead: In o much as Thamires heard the noie; and hearing nothing named but Calidon and Death, he doubted ome diatrous accident: Therefore leaping out of bed, he run to the dore to call ome of the houe, and at lat was told that Calidon was dead. Thamires loved him as dearely as if he had been his owne Sonne: So as at this ad newes he fell down the taires to the bottom: his ervants tooke him him up, and carryed him to his bed: his pule failed and he by degrees grew o cold, as if he had not been well looked unto he had been in as bad a condition as Calidon: but the application of good remedies together with Celidea's care, did do him much good. Whooever had een this faire and young Bride thus all undret wahing the face of her brid-groome with her teares, and had not been mooved unto pitty, doubtlee his heart was made of Marble. The looenee of her garments together with the negligent care of herelfe, added much unto her beauty: She having recovered him unto his enes did bathe her kies in a flood of teares. But the poor hepheard being unenible of any paion, but orrow of his friends loe, did faintly receive her kies, and puhed her away with his hand, as if he did not care for them: he would hardly look upon her, onely till asked what newes of Calidon: but hearing none that was good, I ee, aid he, that as he dyed for the contentment which I have, o I mut dye for the griefe which he had. Then riing up in a fury, halfe naked, he run to the place where poore Calidon lay along as if he were abolutly dead. Every one gave place unto him, as well out of repect, as compaion at his greife which doubtlee was very great, ince he had left Celedea, and didained that happinee which he had o long and o zealouly deired. When he aw Calidon, thinking him to be dead, he fell upon him but o unfortunately, as he hit his forehead againt a harp tone, on which they had laid the head of Calidon; his face was immediately all blood and there he remained in a wound. Thoe that were about them, did heare the blow which Thamires had, and had an opinion, that he was hurt. But did not think he was hurt o much as he was. Had they not oberved him o long without either motion or peech, they had taken notice of it too late. Now, cryes began againe a freh, and the clamours of all thoe who beheld this lamentable pectacle, grew very loud. Judge what horror this was
unto Colidea, when he aw her Husband and his Nephew lie together like dead men. By fortune, as they carried Calidon in a chair into his Chamber, he revived. Then eeing o many people about him, and all meered with the blood of Thamires he knew not what to think, but that he was in a dream. When he aw them carrying his Uncle, who was yet enlee, with a great wound in his head, he imagined, that ome body had wounded him; therefore tranported with rage, he roe up and asked, who was the murderer: He took up a tone, and held up his arme, as ready to throw it at him, who had done the the homicide: But, when he heard how it was; How, aid he, am I my elfe the murderer? Is not revenge as well due to me as to another; nay, more, ince there was more obligations upon me. Upon this, he lifted up his arme, intending to knock himelfe in the head with the tone; but he was prevented by friends, who held his arme, took away the tone, and never let him go, till he was better etled in his reaon.

In the mean time, Thamires, by reaon of the loud clamours, and the good remedies which were applyed unto him, he was no ooner dreed and put into bed, but he came out of his wound: When his eyes were open, and he could peak, the firt word was, the name of Calidon, asking where his body was. Calidon (anwered one) is much better then you are. How, aid he, is not Calidon dead? Oh my friends, I pray do not mock me. He is alive, aid another; and if you will not fall into a wound again when you ee him, we will bring him hither very well recovered. Oh god! aid Thamires, if this be o, ue all your bet remedies to cure me alo. Upon this, he offered to rie, but the Chirurgions would not uffer him. Now becaue Calidon was as impatient to ee Thamires, it was thought requiite for the etlement of their pirits, to let them ee each other, though they feared, it would caue the wound of Thamires to bleed afreh; but conceiving, this inconveniency would be lee, then that which might arie by retraining them, they brought Calidon to the Chamber, who eeing Thamires in that condition, and having heard all the paages, he kneeled down before him, and asked him pardon, for the griefe and pain which he had put him unto: Excue, good Father, aid he unto him, the little power that I had to command my elfe; I come to aske you pardon upon my knees, and beeech you to believe, that I will never ret, till I have given atisfaction for my fault. Son, (aid Thamires) rie up, and let me embrace thee Had I thought, that Celidea would have ever been thine, he hould never have been mine: My greatet griefe is now, that heretofore there was one impediment unto thy deires, and now there is two: The firt is, her will, which was ever o avere unto thee, that he would never conent to be thine: The other is, the Marriage of her and me. Could her will change as well, as I could remedy the lat of thee impediments, believe it, Calidon, my death hould be welcome to me, o I could thereby render thee contentment. Calidon would have anwered, but he could not, becaue Thamires at the ame time, addreed his peech unto Celidea; And you; Celidea, aid he, who ees how extreamly Calidon does love you; is it poible, you hould not change your will, and affect him? Cannot his affection, his merits, and my prayers, obtain o much from you? Was Celidea born to kill both Calidon and Thamires, both with love and orrow? Celidea, all in tears, would have anwered, but Calidon prevented her: Father, aid he, the ordinance of heaven, and the will of this fair One, mut be as it is; Tautates knowes what is fit, better then we our elves: There is no reaon, that two perons, who merit all manner of good fortune, as Thamires and Celidea do, hould change their fortune for my mot mierable ake. For my part, I do vow, and cal heaven and earth to witnes, that I wil never whilt I breathe contradict the judgment, which the heavens have given by the mouth of the Nymph. What then, aid Thamires, do all thee tears, thee complaints, and thee woonings ignifie? They are tetimonies, anwered Calidon, that I am but a man. As good Chirurgions will not take their hand from the wound, though the Patient complain and cry; o you ought not to ceae from that good work, which it hath pleaed Tautates to ordain. I deire no other favour, but leave to complain, and to cry out when the pain torments me. Nay, nay, (aid Celidea, in a very violent and paionate manner) let neither of you put your elves unto that trouble; the great god Tharamis, will ecretly inpire me with a means, how to et both your hearts at ret: It is not reaonable, that all your prayers and demontrations, hould any longer be without producing ome effects; but withall, the will of Tautates mut be done, nor mut the good opinion I had of you from my very cradle, hew out no parks of will towards you. And you, Calidon, it is not fit you hould conume away your life in this manner: No, no, live both of you contentedly; give me only leave to think upon
it foure or five daies, and you hall ee, how heaven will direct me unto means, to eae you both of your orrowes. Upon this, he entreated Thamires, he would be pleaed to excue her from lying with him for foure or five nights, to the end, he might the better contrive the way, how to accomplih her deigne. Thamires, who begun to be enible of the mart which his wounds caued, who would have conented unto his own death; to ave the life of Calidon, he did freely grant her requet. Then after ome other dicoure upon this ubject, the Chirurgions eeing, that the hopes which Celidea had put them into, would conduce unto their ret, and conequently unto their recovery, they advied all the company to withdraw. Calidon caued a bed to be brought into the Chamber of Thamires, becaue he would not leave him. On the other ide, Thamires was o pleaed with the expreions of his Nephew's affection to him, as he much deired to have him alwaies with him. Celidea was the mot perplexed of any, for he would not impart her determination unto any one, let he hould be prevented in her deigne, though he did not yet know how to effect it: Her deigne was much different from the humours of all women whatoever; for knowing, that it was the beauty of her face, which was the caue of the paionate love, both in Thamires and his Nephew; alo conidering, that it only was the caue of the divorce betwixt them, he reolved to make it o ugly for the future, as that they hould hereafter grow as cold at her deformity, as heretofore they were enflamed at her beauty; hoping by this means, to bring Calidon to his enes again and to give atisfaction unto the world, that he never conented unto thee follies. After he had long thought upon the way, and not liking the way of a knife, by reaon of the blood and cruelty, unto which her courage could not conent; at lat he addreed her elfe unto her Nures Mother, whom taking aide, he let her undertand, that he had a mot deadly hatred unto a hepheardee her neighbour, who had infinitely wronged her; that he was fully reolved upon revenge; that her hatred went not o far as death, but only deired a revenge upon her face, as upon the thing which he mot valued. In order to this, he deired her, to acquaint her with ome Plant or other Receipt, which would o mar the face of this Maid, as it hould never recover its beauty again. The good woman, who loved Celidea very well, did very dicreetly anwer: That any uch cruell deires of revenge was unhandome, and did not become her: That if the other had wronged her, the bet way was, to refer revenge unto Heius, who had power to do it: That if he did her elfe take revenge, it was to be feared, that he unto whom it was done, would pay her back double in her owne coyne. To be briefe, he ued all poible arguments and perwaions, to divert her from this deigne. But Celidea, whoe deigne was different from what he made appear, did till reolutely perit in her requet, telling the woman, that he upon whom he would be revenged, was not a peron that could revenge again; beides, it hould be carried o ecretly, as he hould never know from whence it proceeded; therefore conjured her in all love, to atisfie her requet; proteting that if he did not, he would caue her to attempt omething that was much wore. The good woman anwered, that he hould be very orry, to be a caue of any wore accident, therefore within two or three daies he would give her an anwer. Do not fail me then, aid Celidea; for if you do, you will be the caue of a far greater michiefe. The terme being expired which this good woman took, only to pae on time, he deired a longer. But Celidea, who knew that this was only delay, yet he eemed to believe her, whilt in the interim, he would take the bet way he could to accomplih her deigne; etting a face of beliefe in the good old woman upon it, let he hould dicover her intention unto Cleontine. Celidea then eeking out for any way to disigure her elfe, as ill luck was, he came in the morning unto Cleontine's Chamber, when he was in bed; and becaue Cleontine was accutomed to wear a pointed Diamond upon her finger, as a token, that he was dedicated unto Theutates, as you know, Madam, it is the cutome of all our Druides, he ued every night, when he went into bed, to put it off, and to take it again in the morning. So it hapned, that Celidea taking up this Ring, he put it upon her finger, and from one to another, trying which it would bet fit, perhaps not thinking what he did; which Cleontine perceiving Daughter, aid he, are you willing to wear that Ring, upon the ame conditions that I do? If I were able, anwered Celidea, there is nothing in the world I hould more deire. How then can you think, aid Cleontine, to atisfie both Thamires and Calidon, as you have promied? That anwered he, would be the bet remedy of all others; for, they are o religiouly dipoed, as if I were once dedicated unto Theutates, neither of them would offer to have me out again. Love, aid Cleontine, is above either duty of
religion: But pray, Daughter, tell me, which way do you think to give them both atisfaction; for truly, I cannot undertand, which way you can do it? For in the firt place, you are Wife unto Thamires; therefore if you would, you cannot dedicate your elfe unto Theutates, without his leave: But, uppoe you were a Druide, do you think that would content them both? No urely, but rather dicontent them both, ince, then, both are deprived of you. Mother, (anwered Celidea) the great gods will doubtlee inpire me with ome way or other, and by their aide, I do not doubt but I hall effect it; for in them I put my whole trut. Daughter, (aid Cleontine) the gods do never fail thoe that trut in them, and therefore ince you make them your confidence, I hall believe you may bring it to pae. Cleontine would have continued on her dicoure; but Celidea by accident, did give her hand uch a cratch with the Diamond, that he cryed out; at which Cleontine tarting: What have you done, aid he, have you cut your elfe with the Diamond? A mall cratch, anwered Celidea, though the pain of it did make me cry out. You think it mall, aid Cleontine, but you are deceived; for the mark will never out, and the cut is very hard to be healed. Then looking into her hand, and eeing it much cratched: Believe it, Celidea, aid he, you have a mark as long as you live, and had it been upon your face, it had been quite poiled. How, aid Celidea, is a Diamond o venomous? The mark of it, aid Cleontine, will never out; and that's the reaon, why I leave it off every night, when I go to bed. Oh! how glad was this young hepheardee, when he heard of this ecret? he thought that the gods had purpoely taught it her, to accomplih her deigne. I hall now acquaint you Madam, with the trange reolution of this young woman. It was already five or ix daies ince Thamires received his hurt; and his wound not being dangerous, he recovered o fat, that he began to go out of his Chamber. Calidon and Thamires both did ummon Celidea to the performance of her promie. She, with a miling brow, told them, That tomorrow he would give them both content. At night, when her Aunt was in bed he tole her Ring; and when he came into her Chamber, he caued all to go to bed, and hut the dore: Then he et her elfe down by a Table, upon which tood a Glae, in which, againt all Fetivalls, he was wont to dree her elfe: As oon as ever he aw her fair face in it; Oh Mirrour (aid he) with whom I was wont to conult with o much care and circumpection, how to adorn this face? How different is the occaion now, that makes me take thy counell? I was wont by thy advice, to make my elfe more fair; but now I come to know, how I hall blat this beauty, which was formerly o deer unto me. Upon this, opening the Glae, and eeing her face all well'd with tears: Oh eyes! aid he, you were not human, did you not lament the loe of that beauty, which heretofore did well you with o much delight. Afterwards being ilent a while, and conidering particularly her beauty, her grace, the jut proportion of her parts, the lively and weet lutre of her eyes, the frehnee of her roie complexion, the compoure of her mouth, and briefly, all the pleaing parts of her face: I know very well, aid he, Oh my mot precious and dearly loved treaures, how valuable you are; but alas, what are you worth unto me, if I cannot enjoy any contentment in preerving you? I have formerly eteemed this beauty as my highet and richet jewell, I know how much I have been courted for your ake; but when I hall charge you before the Throne of Reaon, to have been the caue of all the torments I have endured: when I blame you, for the diention that is betwixt the Uncle and the Nephew; nay, when I charge you, as guilty of their blood and ruine; nay more, perhaps of their death, what can you ay in your own defence? what reaons can you alledge, why I hould till retain and preerve you? Perhaps you will ay, that it is a very weet thing to be fair; but tell me, how bitter are thoe effects, which that weet doth produce, and how I hould avoid them, by preerving you? Perhaps you will reply, that love is the effect and conequent of beauty, and nothing in the world is more pleaing, then to be loved and carraed. Perhaps again you will ay, that whilt I am fair, every one will adore me, and when I am foul, every one will didain me. But for all that, let me tell thee by way of anwer, that in doing o trange an act, every one will admire me, and be apt to believe, that there is ome hidden perfection in me, which does trancend this outward beauty. Alo in defacing thy luter, I hall but anticipate time of a few minutes: For, this beauty which we o much prize, for all our carefull preervation, will quickly fade, a few years more will ravih it from me: Is it not therefore better to part from it voluntarily, having o good an occaion, and to acrifice it unto the tranquillity of Calidon, who hath born me o much affection? What will the wort conequence be of it? Why, when I am ugly, fewer perons will love me; I cannot hope to finde any
affection, but from Thamires: Now if the affection of Thamires be grounded only upon my beauty, it will quickly fall off when my beauty decayes; but, if he have <…> any other bais for his love, certainly he will love me the more, becaue I have made my elfe wholly his, ince none ele will yet look upon me. To be briefe, it is this beauty, which hath caued all the mieries, both of Calidon, Thamires, and my elfe. I will eae them therefore and my elfe too, by parting from that, which would of it elfe ere long part from me: I will et them both at liberty, and my elfe at ret. Now, Madam, I hall relate unto you a mot trange and generous act: Celidea, as oon as he had aid o, took the Diamond, and with a reolute hand, did cut the skin of her fair face in everall places; though the pain of it was extream, yet he cut on, till gnahing her teeth, till he had made five or ix long and d ••• gahes in her cheeks and forehead, o as all her beauty was quite defaced. Imagine, Madam, how adly he mut needs reent this act; but he did not at all eem to be orry for it, only put a cloth about her head, put out the Candle, went into her Aunts Chamber, laid the Ring in its place, and went to bed; you may eaily imagine, he took no greatret that night. But when morning was come, and every one awake and up, Cleontine wondered he did not ee her Niece; and fearing he had not been well, he went oftly to her bed-ide; but when he aw her all bloody, he cryed out, thinking he had been dead: All the houe ran up to her, and found her kiing Celidea, though her face was nothing but wounds, and congealed blood: Oh heavens! Daughter, (aid the good old woman) who has thus inhumanly ued you? What barbarous hand could finde a heart to poil this fair face? Celidea, in a low voice, beeeched her, to let her ret, and he hould know who had done it, as oon as Thamires and Calidon were come. Chirurgeons were immediately ent for, and Thamires, hearing in what condition Celidea was, he ran preently to her Chamber; but when he aw her, he tood immovable, and gave no ignes of life, but only by tears in his eyes. At the lat, after a little recollecting of himelfe: Is this Celidea, whom I ee in this ad plight, aid he? Could the gods ever permit uch a piece of cruelty? What Tiger, in the hape of a Man, could have a heart to do it? Was ever o much inhumanity executed? Celidea turning gently towards him: Thamires, aid he, though you have lot the face of Celidea, yet he hath preerved all the ret of her elfe; if you will permit me to take revenge, I will tell you who hath done this unto me. Calidon upon this came into the Chamber, which hindred Thamires from returning anwer; and Calidon hearing of this accident, he had run himelfe o out of breath, that he could not peak, yet one might hear him utter vowes, that the villain who had thus injured Celidea, hould not live till night. Oh Calidon, aid he, do not wear, let you hould be perjured; perhaps it may be uch a one, as you had rather die then keep your oath. I do wear till by Heius, replyed Calidon, and by my own oul, who ere he be, except Thamires, he hall die. Upon this, he kneeled down by her bed ide, and offering to kie her hand, he puhed him back: Calidon; aid he, why hould you offer to kie my hand? Look upon my face, and take notice, that I am not now the ame Celidea, whoe beauty you o much eteemed. The hepheard was o tranported with fury, that he had not yet looked upon her; but when he fixed his eyes upon her, and aw her o gatly transformed, he tood more atonihed then Thamires: Then laying his hand upon his eyes, and turning his head the other way, it was impoible for him to endure the ight, and tared like a man that had been frighted. She all the while was not at all angry, but with incredible courage endured it. Then holding out her hand unto Thamires: Friend, aid he unto him, I hope this will be contentment unto you, to ee, that I am all yours, and that none now can or will ever pretend unto me: This face thus disfigured, was only done, to make me only yours. I cannot believe, Thamires, but that your affection unto me was built upon a better foundation, then a fading face. Now becaue I ee you deirous to know, who it was that made me thus; know, Thamires, that it was Calidon: And you, Calidon, know, that it was Thamires. Did you put her into this condition, cried they both out? Yes, aid he, it is Calidon, and Thamires, that have thus wronged Celidea: But have a little patience, and you hall hear, how. Every one did wonder at thee words, but epecially the two hepheards. And when Calidon offered to peak, he interrupted him thus: Calidon, do not go about to excue your elfe; for, though Thamires and you both be the caue, yet you are more to blame then he. There is none that knowes me is ignorant, how Thamires hath loved me from my infancy, and hath ever ince continued his affection to me; this affection became reciprocall, as oon as ever I was capable of Love; and as his addrees unto me did invite me to love him, o the
good entertainment that he found from me, invited him to continue it: And indeed how happily had we lived unto this very day, if Calidon had not cat his eye upon me; o as I may ay, and Thamires knowes it, that never two loved each other better, than Thamires and Celidea: But as oon as Calidon came, all our happinee and contentment was blated; firt, by his icknee; afterwards, by the gift which Thamires made of me unto him, which I could never conent unto. Truth is, after I had long endured the faintnee of Thamires, I and the fiery affection of Calidon, I rejected them both, as in reaon I might, ince Calidon had made me loe Thamires, and Thamires without caue, had reigned me to Calidon. Afterwards, when I was wholly adjudged unto Thamires, by the Sentence of the Nymph Leonida, yet till was I tormented by him; when he was in all reaon obliged to decline me, both out of duty of a friend, and the Nymphs command; yet till he perited, and would needs die. On the other ide, the kinde nature of Thamires, eeing his Nephew in that condition, did leave me in bed, and made it appear, that his affection unto Calidon was greater, then his love to me, whom he had courted with o much earnetnee and paion. I was extreamly atonihed at this accident, when I was told, that both my Husband and his Nephew were brought in chaires as dead. I mut confee, that when I aw them, and heard how all was, I knew not what to reolve upon. But afterwards, conidering the whole tate of the matter, I lifted up my heart unto Tharamis, beeeching him to advie me what coure to take, to compoe this buinee. Doubtlee he did inpire me with the means. This therefore, Oh hepheards, was the holy inpiration: Conider (aid that god unto me) the violent affection of Calidon, and be aured of this, that he will never leave you, as long as you are fair; never think, that either religion to the gods, or any duty to men, will retrain him: Nor can you imagine, that Thamires, though he be your Husband, and love you above his life, can ever enjoy any contentment, as long as he ees his Nephew o tormented. As for your part, What kinde of life can you hope to live, as long as you are the caue of both their mieries? To give your elfe unto Calidon, your own will cannot conent unto it; beides, you are already devoted unto Thamires, that nothing can eparate you, but death. The violent paion of Calidon will not uffer you to be quiet with Thamires; nor can the kinde nature of Thamires, endure the continuall dipleaures of his Nephew. What then, Celidea, caut thou do? Put on a generous reolution, and deprive thy elfe of that, which is the root of all this diention. Caut thou think it any thing ele, but the beauty of thy face? 'Tis true, anwered I; but in loing that beauty, I hall alo loe the love of Thamires as well as Calidon; and if o, I had better die. You are deceived, anwered he, the love of thee two hepheards is different; Thamires loves Celidea, and Calidon adores the beauty of Celidea. If your fears hould prove true, you had better die preently, then live long; and be aured, that when age has made you unhandome, Thamires will ceae to love you. But, let that be the leat of your fears, Thamires loves Celidea, and let Celidea become what he will, till Thamires will love her.

This, Shepheards was the acred counell, which the gods did inpire into me, unto which I durt not be diobedient, and therefore ought out for means to put it in execution; o as having heard my Aunt ay, that the wounds which were made by a Diamond, would never heal, I intended to acrifice that beauty which was in my face, unto your tranquillity and union. But, Oh my Thamires! I hope you will not ceae loving Celidea, though he has not the ame face he had; for, what he has done, was only to atisfie the deires of Calidon, that he might be entirely yours. Thus ended Celidea, leaving all that heard her full of admiration at her generous act. It would be too long and tedious to relate Calidon's reproching her, the dipleaure of Thamires, the orrowes of Cleontine and Celidea's Mother, with all thoe that conidered her condition. But o it was, that when the Chirurgions had dreed her pittifull acrificed face, they all concluded, that he would never recover her beauty again; for the cuts were o deep, and in uch places, that they had for ever poiled all her delicate features and proportion. So it falls out, that Calidon eeing her o deformed, his fiery flaming paion did quite extinguih; and Thamires, as he hoped, continues his love; o as he has ever ince lived in abundance of atisfaction and quietnee, and o much eteemed and honoured by every one, as he hath vowed, that he never in all her life received halfe that contentment from her beauty, as he has ince from her deformity.

You have related (aid Leonida) the mot generous and commendable act, that ever was done by a woman; and I am extreamly glad to hear, that uch a vertuous reolution
hould proceed from one, o neerly allyed unto me, as Celidea is; I beeech the gods, to make her as happy in Thamires, as Thamires has reaon to love her, and eteem her vertue. Now (continued Lycidas) Thamires thinking he hall never have any Children, he would gladly make a match between Calidon and Atrea; and to invite Phocion unto it, he offers to give him all his Lands and Flocks.
