Atrea, who grieves o for the loe of Celadon, and reolves never to love any again, he will not upon any termes hear of it; and when her Uncle made the motion unto her, he did nothing but weep; inomuch as when he preed her unto it, he anwered, That he would pend all the ret of her daies amongt the Vetalls and Druides: o as in order unto that, he deired me to peak unto the venerable Chriante about it. Do you think, aid Leonida, that Chriante will receive her, without the conent of her Parents? I asked her the very ame quetion, anwered Lycidas, but he anwered me, that Atrea having neither Father nor Mother living, he might dipoe of her elfe; and that if he could not dipoe of her elfe this way, he would then enter into her grave. I perceive, aid Leonida, that he is exceively afflicted: But I pray tell me, who is contented? Would I durt tell you, anwered the hepheard. Why hould you make more difficuly in telling me that, replyed the Nymph, then in telling me the ret? There are many reaons for it, replyed he, but, ince I have gone o far, I will venter to go a little farther, therefore, Madam, be pleaed to know, that it is Phillis whom I mean: But, I mot humbly beeech you, to ask me no farther. I cannot chue, aid he, but well with a trange curioity at your requet, and do wonder, why you hould o conceal that, which I do o extreamly deire to know: For, loving Phillis as I do, why would you not have me enquire of her contentment? But I perceive, you do trictly oberve the Lawes of Love, the chiefe of which is, to Conceal and be ilent. And becaue he would needs eem, as if it did not concern him: Nay, nay, aid he, never think to hide your elfe from me; for, hepheard, I do know more of you, then you imagine: Can you think, I could frequent the company of all your hepheards and hepheardees, and not hear, how you are a ervant unto Phillis; and how, after a long continued ervice, you are at the lat growne jealous of Silvander? Certainly I hould have been of a very dull compoition, if eeing o compleat a hepheard as Lycidas, and loving Phillis as I do, I had not enquired of your life. If I did eem, hepheard, as if I were ignorant, it was only out of dicretion, for I do know as much of your affaires, as you do almot your elfe; and if you will, I will tell you uch particulars, as hall make you confee it. Lycidas hearing her ay o, he was extreamly confued, and thought, that all her knowledge came from Atrea and Phillis. I perceive, aid he, that you are acquainted with my follies, and that things are not o ecretly carried, as I wih they were: But to make it appear, that I am as much your ervant, as your Informers can be, I will tell you more then they could, ince they are paages which hapned, ince they had the honour to ee you; till beeeching you to be ecret. I have o great an eteem, anwered the Nymph, both of the verue of Phillis, and of your merits, as you may be mot certain, I hall be ecret in any thing that concernes either of you: And you may ee, I can be ilent, ince I was o long before I imparted unto you what I did know. But when you told me, that Phillis was contented, I wondred, becaue I knew her to be much troubled at your faintnee and jealouie. Oh great Nymph, (aid Lycidas, and miled) great alterations have been, ince I had the honour to ee you: Oh how oft have I been upon my knees? Believe it, Madam, Phillis knowes how to bring me into my enes, and can make me know my duty: Had I but time to tell you the whole eries of the tory, you hould ee what abundance of difference there is, betwixt a Lover and a Wieman. I do not know any thing, replyed the Nymph, which I more deire to know; and as for leaure, you may have time enough, ince Adamas, Phocion, and Diamis are entred into dicoure; for old men will never have an end of their old tories. The Nymphs chiefe end in holding him thus in dicoure, was, in conideration of Alexis, let he hould take too much obervance of her; and conceiving the firt time to be the mot dangerous, becaue when the opinion was once fixed, it would better pae afterwards for currant, therefore he deired him to proceed. Lycidas thinking it would be pleaing unto the Nymph, began thus.

div.head: The Hitory of the jealous Lycidas.
div.p:
YOu know Madam that the familiar converation which was between Phillis and Silvander by reaon of their triving which hould make Diana love them bet, was the caue of my jealouie. A jealouy, which I may well ay, was within a mall degree of madnee. Inomuch as I have often wondered, how it was poible I hould live in that torment: The paines of death could not be greater: Every houre, ome accident or other added freh tortures: my eye could not turne itelf without findingout ome new aggravation of miery: And wort of all, when I had greatet curioity to find out the caues of my dipleaures: Nay my imagination would fancy things o beyond all manner of reaon; as I wonder how it was poible my judgement hould be perverted. When he poke any thing freely unto Silvander, Oh how every accent pierced me to the heart. When he was ilent, and did not peake at all, I concluded he diembled; when he carraed me, I thought he had a deigne to deceive me; when he lighted me, I aid this was a igne of a change in her affection: when he hunned Silvander, I thought he did o, let I hould ee her; if he applyed her elfe unto him, then I thought he was deirous to vexe me, and hew how well he was contented in her new affection. If he was not at any time ad, then I aid there was ome amorous quarrell fallen out betwixt them. To be briefe, every thing he did offended me: And when there was nothing to ground my dipleaure upon, I hould accue my judgement for being o imple, as not to ee their diimulations. How oft have I wiht my elfe no eyes, that I could not ee neither Silvander nor Phillis. But to what purpoe would that be (aid I preently after) for though I were blind, yet they would love? But, aid I, it were much better to loe my love, ince the thought of it doth thus torment me, and ever will, till I be in my grave. See unto what extremity I was driven, ince in lieu of loving Phillis, I did hate her. I could have wihed her ugly, and yet I hould have been very orry if he had lot the leat part of her beauty and handomnee. And this I found preently at the ame time: for he having had three or foure fits of an ague, which had caued a little alteration in her face, I was o dipleaed at it, that he herelfe oberved me. Living therefore, or rather languihing in this manner, and almot reduced unto an abolute depaire, the gods had pitty upon me. One Night Silvander chanced to fall aleep in the wood, neere unto the Temple of the good goddee: when he awaked he found a Letter in his hand; not knowing how it came. Upon his returne he hewed it unto Diana, and the hepherdee Atrea: they thought it to be writ by the hand of Celadon: and they hoping to heare more of him in the place where this Letter was found, they entreated Silvander to conduct them thither. When they were there, night o urpried them, that they were forced to tay there, untill it was day. During this hort time, Atrea fell aleep, and had uch dreames and viions as caued her to think that Celadon was in pain, and that his Ghot walked, becaue he had not received the lat office of a buriall: he therefore reolved to erect an empty Tombe for him, but thought it more expedient to be done in the name of Paris then her owne; thee ceremonies were o long and the hepheardees o weary, that at their return they went into their owne cabins to ret themelves. For my part I left them betimes, and after I had dined retired my elfe into a thick covert neere the way which conducts to our Towne: It is o thick with underwood, as, though it joyne upon the high way, yet it was impoible I hould be een. And yet I could plainy ee all paengers going or comming. After a long entertainment of my owne thoughts, leepe did o urprie me, that I did not waken untill the Sun was almot et. And intending to retire, I would firt ee whether any were in the medow, that I might avoyd meeting with Philis. By fortune I epyed Atrea and her, who having reted themelves in their Cabins, came to walk in the freh Aire of that place. On the other ide, I aw Silvander following them, thinking, (as I beleeve) that Diana would come unto them, I hid my elfe againe in the covert, deireous to ee what they did, and beleeving they would give me ome freh knowledge of their affection. But it happened, that Silvander eeing them it downe under the covert where I was, he came to it amongt them. Phillis he quitted her place and went ome twenty paces from them. Then I heard Atrea call her, and Silvander beeech her to come unto them. Oh what marting wounds did thee words make in my heart? Yet Phillis came not: but hewed herelfe to be very much dicontented at the Shepheard. But whereas this might well have
contented me, it did the more offend me, conceiving that there are alwayes uch pretty quarrells amongt lovers, as do but renew love. Phillis was ome twenty paces from them, as I told you, and would not come neere them, but till walked alone by herelfe: At which Silvander began to mile, and at lat he could not hold but laugh very loud. Phillis hearing him and being much enflamed with anger againt him; Silvander (aid he unto him) your behaviour towards me, does make me hate you even to death: and beleeve it, if ever any occaion of revenge offer it elfe unto me, I will lay hold upon it. The hepheard hearing her utter thee words with o much paion, he burt out into uch a violent fit of laughter, that he could not give any anwere. Well well (aid Phillis) laugh on, uncivill hepheard, do your wort to offend me, perhaps I hall one day finde an opportunity of revenge, and if I do not take it, never trut Phillis againe. When Atrea aw this, he took part with Phillis: I did not think (aid he) that Silvander whom I ever found dicret and full of civility, would offer to offend Phillis without any caue. Phillis hearing Atrea ay o, he was more animated againt the hepheard: He cares not a traw (aid he) for offending me; but he has good reaon for it, for he knowes I never cared for him, nor can he well incene me more againt him, then I was before. Oh how this diention did pleae me? and yet I could not chue but be angry he hould o light her. Silvander, he adreed himelfe unto Atrea. Are you, faire hepheardee (aid he) o angry againt me? I thought that you would have taken my part. I can never take part againt reaon (anwered Atrea) but me thinkes you might do much better then to give my companion o much occaion to hate you. Truly (aid he in erious earnet) although you are partially biaed on Phillis ide, yet I am contented you hould be the judge of our difference. Provided he wil before you, declare the occaion of her anger againt me; and when you have heard us both, I will preently ubmit unto what punihment you hall pleae to entence: Who I, aid Phillis, hould I reaon any buinee with you? No no, I had rather I were dumb as long as I lived then to have any thing to do with h you. For all this, replyed he, I would tell you omthing which perhaps would make it appeare that Silvander is more your ervant then you imagine. Then turning towards Atrea, he beeeched her to intreat Phillis to it downe, which he did: not, aid he, that I have any deire to heare you, but only becaue I will do whatoever Atrea commands me. Silvander without any reply unto her, began thus. I beleeve Phillis you do not think me o ignorant in the affaires of the world, as that I hould never hear of that affection which is betwixt you and Lycidas. Nay perhaps you will wonder I hould know o much and eeme o ignorant. So as you will not judge this Silvander whom you wih o ill, was o little your ervant as you think him. But o it is hepherdee that I did know all particulars, from uch as are inquiitive into the buinees of others, and afterwards I knew both from your elf and Lycidas. Do you not remember how one day when you retired your elfe from much company, you commanded Hylas to relate the tory of his life and the adventures of his everall Loves? Do you remember when you went away, you deired Atrea to go along with you? Have you forgotten how you went into the wood to peak with Lycidas who waited there for you? and how Atrea told you that you hould take heed let he tooke it not ill? alo how you anwered her, that he was o importunate that you could not deny him, but therefore you tooke Atrea with you? Now, hepheardee, think well upon the dicoure which you had with him: you need not tell it unto me, for I know it all as well as if I had heard it.

At this, they both bluhed, and tood o amazed that they could not peak but looked upon each other. Nay, never be troubled (aid Silvander) that I do know all thee things, for I am dicreet enough to conceale any thing: but if you pleae, faire Atrea, I will tell you how angry Lycidas was againt you, and what paines you tooke to qualfie him; you may ee, I do almot know as much of your buinees as you your elves do: Know Phillis that I was not ignorant either of the jealouie of Lycidas, or the caue of his jealouie. I am ure (replyed my hepheardee and looking him in the face) that you have o behaved your elfe towards me, as hath extreamly troubled both Lycidas, and me, and your elfe alo. Oh, hepheardee (anwered he) you are more obliged unto me, then you imagine; for what would you have me to do? Since you knew (aid he) that Lycidas was jealous of you, you hould have abented your elfe from me. You bid me do things impoible, (replyed he) and uch as had been infinitly prejudicall unto you, if I had done them Impoible, becaue I having undertaken to erve Diana and you being continually with her, it was impoible for me to be abent from you unlee I had been abent,
from both. Had you been o good a friend to me as you might (aid Phillis) you would rather have abented your elfe from Diana, and hazard the loe of your wager, then have made Lycidas o jealous, and me o ad: for that hepheard was much your friend, and I had never given you any occaion to be mine enemy. I perceive hepheardee, (anwered Silvander) that you never conidered the hurt which you would have done me: nor how impoible it was for me to do it. If I did do you any hurt, aid Phillis, it was out of ignorance, for I did not intend it: However, replyed he, you did do me hurt, and I was very enible of it. I beeech you which way (aid Phillis) are not you the caue of my undertaking to erve Diana? (anwered he) What then (aid Phillis) why do you accue me? I do accue you (aid Silvander) of all the mieries that ever I reented. For in lieu of counterfeiting love, I do love in good earnet. Upon this, the hepheard made a top, as if he were orry he had aid o much: which Atrea perceiving. Never vexe, aid he, nor bluh at the confeion of a truth; perhaps thee words are not the firt that gave us knowledge of it. I am not ahamed, anwered he, that I hould ay, I am Diana's ervant, but much ahamed of mine owne immerits of that honour. If Diana (anwered Atrea) were to be wone by merits, I know none that may better pretend unto her then Silvander.

I wih with all my oul, Faire hepheardee, replyed he, that every one were of the ame opinion. Oh Madam, aid Lycidas, how pleaing were thee words unto my oul? How, aid Leonida, is it poible Silvander hould love Diana in earnet? Doubtlee he doth, aid he, and I hall tell you more another time; but for the preent, I hall onely tell you how I was delivered from my tormenting jealouie. I heard therefore how Silvander continued his dicoure thus: Now not being able to be abent from you, becaue of your continuall preence with Diana, what would you have had me done? be you your elfe the Judge. You ought not, anwered Phillis, to have given Lycidas any occaion of jealouy, at the firt: and afterwards, when you aw how jealous he was, though you could not be abent from me by reaon of Diana, yet you might very well have behaved your elfe more modetly and coldly to me, when Lycidas was preent: Oh what a Novit in love you are, aid he, did you take notice of the minute when Lycidas grew firt jealous? No aid he, and do you think, aid Silvander, that I hould perceive it better then you? Dieaes in love, do beginne like other dieaes, inenibly, and none can have knowledge of them: So as I could not give a top unto the originall of his jealouy no more then you could: As for the progree, I think that I have infinitely obliged you by it: becaue had I then declined you, or poke lee affectionately to you, what might he have thought? only that the caue of my declining you and behaving my elfe otherwie then uually, I did intend to delude him, and held a private corepondency with you? would he not have bin more enflamed with jealouie. Believe it Phillis, it was very requiite I hould continue my carriage towards you as I begun it; otherwie, he would certainly have upected it diimulation, and concluded Diimulation to be a co-incident unto Love.

I being now put out of all my long and tormenting doubts, and plainly finding that there was no love betwixt them, I cryed out, Oh Phillis, Silvander is in the right: Then I ran and fell downe upon my knees before them, at which they were both o atonihed as they looked upon one another and could not peak. For my part I was o over joyed at my fortune, as I knew not what words to chue whereby I might thank love for the favor. At the lat I addreed my elf unto her in this manner, my fairet Shepheardee, I mut needs confee my fault deerves punihment no pardon: I am here upon my knees at your mercy: Doome me to what punihment you pleae, o you will but forget my crime. Such expreions as thee I ued unto her. At which without any returne of anwer, he turned towards me, and looked upon the ground. Both he and I tanding mute, Silvander would needs be a caue of my contentment as he had been of my orrowes. Therefore, hepheardee (aid he) as I have been a witnee, that Lycidas hath been jealous without caue, o hall I witnee that you are fuller of revenge then love, if you do not accept of this atisfaction which he offers. Never tudy any longer what you have to do, pardon him as you ought; His affection deerves it, and yours commands it. Siter, aid Atrea, Silvander ayes very truly: and you may be certain of this, that it was rather excee then any defect of love which hath caued Lycidas to commit this errour: and if it be a fault, he repents and hath done ufficient pennance. Then Phillis looking upon me: Lycidas (aid he) you have o extreamly offended me, that it is very hard to pae it over: but
ince Atrea will have it o, I pardon you, but with a vow, that if ever you relape into the like fault, you hall loe all hopes of ever recovering my affection again. Fie, fie, Lycidas, continued he, could you be o weak, and think me o light, as to love every one I looked upon: Were the aurances which I had given you of my affection, o mall, as that you hould o eaily doubt them? Doubtlee he had continued on, (for I was not able to peak) if Atrea had not interrupted her: Siter, aid he unto her, you have aid enough, Lycidas is all penitence and ubmiion, and you will in againt the goodnee of your own nature, if you inult too much upon him. Phillis, after a little conideration, addreed her elfe unto her Companion, in this language: Siter, I will not only pardon the offence, but alo forget it, provided, that for the future, he never give me any occaion to remember it. Thus, Madam, was I cured, thus was my crime pardoned; and Silvander and I, have lived ince in o kinde a familiarity, that, next my poor Brother, I never loved any man better. And are you not afraid, (aid Leonida) that Silvander and Phillis being o much together, hould make you jealous again? For, he that loves is naturally ubject unto upition. No, aid Lycidas; for firt, I have full aurance in the affection of Phillis; and econdly, Silvander's love of Diana, who I know cannot admit of a Companion.

Thus Lycidas and Leonida dicoured, whilt Hylas entertaining Alexis, began by little and little to be in love with her. And he having an opinion, that this would be a meanes to make it more believed, that he was a woman, he endeavoured to kindle his flame as much as he could; and though he had never een him before, yet Leonida and Paris had acquainted her with his pleaant humour. Hylas, according to his free humour, cryed out upon a udden: Phillis, I have thought upon it, I mut now fairly bid you Adieu; all that I can do, is, to give you the ame liberty, that I take my elfe. Silvander and Corilas hearing this uddain reolution, and eeing that Alexis could not peak for laughing, they could not chue but take the part of Phillis, purpoely to begin occaion of ome pleaant dicoure. Why, hepheard, (aid Corilas,) do you cat off the fair Phillis in this manner? She has reaon to oberve this, as one of her black and fatall daies. What can I help it, aid Hylas? Why is hee not as fair as Alexis? Oh heavens, (replyed Corilas) who can hereafter have any aurance in your affection? That may this mot lovely Nymph, anwered he, who is fairer then Phillis. But, aid Corilas, is not this a mot manifet igne of your levity and ficklenee? Not at all, anwered he, but rather an argument of the great beauty in Alexis. If beauty be the matter, aid Corilas, Phillis is not defective in it. She hath lee then Alexis, aid Hylas, for he is not able to hold me, now I have een the other; and therefore I mut fairly take my leave of her. Silvander, who had been long ilent, eeing Corilas did not reply, he undertook the dicoure for him: It is not any defect in the beauty of Phillis, aid he, which moveth this hepheard to make his retreat, but it is his owne naturall incontancy. Very well, (aid Hylas) do you call it incontancy, when one goes on tep by tep, unto the place where they intend to arrive? No, aid Silvander. And yet, aid Hylas, uch a one does et his foot, ometimes upon the ground, ometimes in the air, ometimes before, ometimes behinde: And is not this incontancy as well as that which you lay in my dih? For, intending to arrive at a perfect beauty, I do et one foot before another, and never leave changing, till I arrive at my intended place. Even o have I done, by all I have hitherto loved, untill I found Alexis, who I finde to be the mot perfect beauty of all. This might hold good, anwered Silvander, if you could demontrate to us, that you do merit to love Alexis: For, as you have gotten the name of Incontant, by loving o many; o now, you will get the name Preumptuous, in loving Alexis. Alexis was long ilent, taking great delight in the dicoure of thee hepheards; but when he heard her elfe o highly commended, he thought it fit to peak: Did I as much merit the affection of Hylas, aid he, as I am willing to entertain it, certainly he hould have no mall reaon to love me. Then tuming her elfe in a miling manner towards Hylas: Servant, aid he unto him, take heed, let the language of this hepheard hould divert you; for, you would wrong both your elfe and me, if it hould: It would be a hame for you, to attempt an enterprie, and o oon give it over; and it would be too evident an argument of my little merit, if you hould o oon quit me. But, Hylas, aid Silvander, do you not dread the dipleaure of Teupates, in addreing your elfe unto one, who is conecrated unto him? Ignorant Silvander, aid Hylas, the gods do command us to love themelves; and how can they be angry with
us, for loving that which is theirs? You ee, aid Alexis, that this hepheard hath ome deigne upon us, he would cunningly turn you from me by artifice; for he knowes well enough, that if I will, I can leave off that profeion, which I have taken upon me.

Whilt thee hepheards were thus talking, Adamas was entertaining Phocion, Diaonis, and Tircis; and becaue he eteemed them very much, both for their age, their vertues, and for his deigne, in making a Match between Celadon and Atrea, he did all that poibly he could to bid them welcome: And becaue Tircis was a tranger, and had never een the raritles of his Houe, he asked him, if he would take o much paines as to walk, and ee it: And hearing him anwer, that he did infinitly deire it, he took him by the hand, and willed Paris to do the like unto Hylas and the ret of the hepheards, if they had a minde. Alexis, with the help of Hylas, who led her by the arme, followed Adamas, with the ret of the Company. The Houe was very fine, and furnihed with many excellent ingularities; but becaue the dicoure of it would be too long, we will peak no more of it, then what is pertinent to our purpoe. They entred then into a large Gallery, which had a propect of Plaines on the one ide, and Mountains on the other, which made it very delectable and pleaant. The ides was Wancot fretted, and, betwixt the windowes, hung with Maps of the everall Provinces of Gaul: At the higher end, hung Pictures of everall Countries, Kings, and Emperours, and amongt them, the Portractures of everall very beautifull Women. The top was adorned with Gold and Azure, very richly imboed, with many everall devices. Every one fixed their eyes upon that, which was mot agreeable unto their fancies: But Hylas, whoe heart was all for beauty, looking upon a Picture which contained two Ladies: See, (aid he) two very delicate faces; Which of thee two hould one judge to be the fairer? Adamas, who heard him: That (aid he) on the right hand, is the Picture of the Mother in Law; and the other on the left, the Daughter in Law: Both of them were two Princees, as fair and as wie as ever any, and as much toed and turmoiled by the tormes of Fortune, as any in our Times. This, which eemes the more aged, is the wie Placidia, Daughter unto the great Theodoius, Siter unto Arcudius and Honorius, Wife unto Contantius, and Mother unto Valentiniaen, all five Emperours, whoe Pictures are a little farther off. The other is the Picture of Eudoxe, Daughter unto Theodoius the Second, and Wife unto Valentinian, whom Generio carried into Affrica. They were two Princees (aid Tircis) of great beauties, and as great extractions: But wherein was their Fortunes o avere? I hall briefly tell you, (replyed Adamas) and hall thereby acquaint you with ome of thee Pieces which you ee here. Then, after a while of ilence, he began thus.

div.head: The History of Placidia.
div.p: THEODOSIUS, the firt of that name, Emperour of the Eat, one of the greatet Princes the World had, ince Augutus; he had three Children: One, Arcadius, who after him, was Emperour of the Eat: Another, was Honorius, who was Emperour of the Wet: And the third, was the wie Placidia, whoe fortune was o various, that we ee in her, how Vertue is ordinarily croed: For, he being at the dipoe of her Brother Honorius, and he under the government of Stilicon, unto whoe Guardianhip the great Theodoius had committed him, during his nonage, he was o variouly toed and tormented by everall accidents, as if Fortune had made choice of her, to hew the power it hath in all human things, of which Stilicon was the greatet caue, who having great power over the peron of Honorius and the whole Empire, his ambition apired at more abolute authority, and aimed to make himelfe ole Emperour, as when his deignes were dicovered it did plainly appear. He being a man of a deep reach, and managing his matters o, as might mot condure to his deired end and grandure, he thought it expedient for him to make ue of policy and ubtlety, where it was impoible for him to compae it by force. His way was therefore at the firt, to tretch his authority to the highet pitch before he made his intentions known, and afterwards, to fortifie himelfe, by marrying his Daughter unto young Honorius; for the very name of Father in Law to an Emperour looked big, and procured him a great honour and fear. Afterwards, he held ecret intelligence and correpondency with all uch, as he thought fit intruments for the advancement of his deigne: And latly, reolved to weaken the Forces of the Emperour as much as poibly he could, that when opportunity erved, he might the more eaily eize upon him.

At that time, all the world looked at Rome with an envious eye, and made it the butt of their Armes: The Goths, the Fruncks, and Burgundians, in Gaul; the Vandats and Almaines in Spain; the Anglois and the Picts in Britany; the Hunnes and the Gipides in Pannonia; To be briefe, every part of the whole Empire was o divided, as no part was entire but Italy. It fortuned, that Alarick King of the Goths, would not uffer it to enjoy more tranquillity, then Its neighbours of the Wet; and therefore fell into it with uch a vat number of People, as it was impoible for Honorius to reit him; inomuch as to get him out again, he was advied to make a Peace with him, upon what termes oever he could get; unto which, he being of ho Warlick dipoition, but above all things loving tranquillity, he lent a willing ear. Peace then being propounded, it was o prudently managed, that Alarick conented to retire beyond the Alpes, into ome Provinces which were aigned him by the Emperour. At which, Stilicon, being malecontent, as thinking this agreement prejudiciall to his deignes, he o tampered with an Officer, then in pay under the Emperour, that he procured him to charge ome of Alarick's Forces, as they were marching away without any mitrut: At which, Alarick was o incened againt Honorius, that he returned to Rome, beieged it, and, at the end of two years, took it, and entirely acked it: Although Honorius, to make it appear, that he never conented unto this perfidie, did put the Traitor Stilicon to death, as oon as ever he heard, that he was the author of it. Thus this ambitious man came to a mierable end, but not before he had put all Italy into a mot mierable flame: For Alarick, after he had plundered and burned this great City, and not yet loadned with pil, he pillaged all the Country about it, and laid it o adly wate, as would have moved any Barbarian unto pitty. But that which was mot deplorable, beides the ruine of o many Temples, and the loe of o many rarities, with which the Emperours had erected and adorned this City, was the mierable fortune which befell this wie Princee, who through the careleenee of a Brother, was detitute of all uccour. She, who by extraction was Daughter unto the Cears, and Siter unto two Emperours, was, through the fault of another, a Captive in the hands of thee Barbarians, her Country burned, the Temples prophaned, and he in danger to loe her life, or, that which was more deer unto her; had not Ataulfus, a Prince of Alarick's blood, been taken with her beauty and vertue, and thought her worthy to be his Wife. But this Prince, eeing her o fair and o wie, and knowing her to be Daughter to the great Theodoius, he fell o paionately in love with her, that he courted her in Marriage; and preently after, by Alaricks conent, did marry her. You may imagine, what force this wie Princee did ue upon her elfe, before he conented unto this Marriage and Alliance, and how prudent he had need to be, in behaving her elfe amongt uch a rude and barbarous people, o wiely as he did; god did in this make it appear, that he had pitty upon mierable Rome; for, had it not been for this Alliance, it had been utterly ruined for ever. For it o fel out, that Alarick dyed at Corienes, and the Prince Ataulfus was by the common voice of the Army choen King. If you look upon that Piece next unto Placidias, you will imagine him to be a terne and alvage peron, more delighted in blood and war, then peace; and he had no ooner gotten the abolute power, but he went to Rome, with a deigne to burne and utterly demolih it, thinking, that as long as the Walls of this Town tood, there would be till a Roman Emperour; which name was o odious unto him, that he would abolutely detroy the very memory of it. When this prudent Princee undertood his intention, he was reolved to do all that poibly he could to prevent him, the utter ruine of her Country wounding her to the very oul. At the firt, he hewed her elfe welled with abundance of griefe and orrow, tears did abundantly flow from her fair eyes, he refued her ret and meat, and never ceaed tormenting her elfe, but when Ataulfus was by her, and then he contrained her elfe to put as good a face upon it as he could. This Prince, who loved her o well as to marry her, could not long endure to ee her live thus, but he mut needs aske her the caue of her dicontents; unto which he made this anwer; I have done all that I poibly could O great King, to hide my exceive orrowes from you, fearing I hould but the more vex and trouble you with them: but, ince nature will not permit me to conceal the adnee of my oul any longer, and ince the goodnee of Ataulfus unto the wretched Placidia is uch, as to ask me; I do mot humbly beeech you, take it not ill, if I hed my tears in lieu of my blood, for my Country's ad deolation; and if, to top the ruine of it, I could effect it, I would much more willingly hed my blood then my tears. My Country, Oh great Sir, my native Country that gave me breath, it bleeds, and it is ready to bleed
to death; and can you think, I would not mot willingly part with my life to top the wounds' Alas, it would be better imployed that way, then in your ervice. Since you are pleaed to do me o great a favour, as to aske me the caue of my orrowes, I beeech you give me leave in all humility to aske you, What advantage will the ruine of Rome and all Italy be unto you? Does the riches and the treaures of it, invite you to it? Surely thoe are things too low, and unworthy of your high courage; beides, thoe are things that cannot be expected out of an already ruined and plundered Country, or a demolihed and halfe burned Towne, which hath been already ravaged by a vat Army: Is it any glory that you expect to get by it? I cannot believe it; for, what glory can be added unto that, which you have already; or, what hopes is there to get, in ruining thoe Walls, which are already demolihed; in maacring a naked and diarmed people, who cannot be brought into greater ubmiion then they are? If it be a hame to wound a dying man, what honour can you expect, in giving freh wounds unto a dying people? If you think to trengthen your Dominion by it, be pleaed, Oh great Sir, to let me tell you, that it would be mot horrid cruelty to do it, by exterminating all the people of Italy. Should you put them all to the word, you would be in lee ecurity then you are; for, you would thereby incene and raie againt you, the Armes of all Aia, of all Affrica, and of all the ret of Europe, whereof Italy is but a poor pittance. Judge, great King, what likelyhood there is, that you, or any human upon earth, hould withtand o many Provinces, conquer o many Kings, and get to himelfe o many Worlds, for o may the Kingdomes and vat extent of the Roman Empire be called; o as the ruine of Italy will bring upon you the hatred of god and man: Men will revenge the wrong, done unto the capitall City upon earth; the gods will be offended at the ruine of that Towne, which is the miracle of the world, and which they have raied to that height, to pleae themelves, and atonih men.

If you will but be pleaed, to take all thee things into your wie, and erious conideration, you will finde it much better, to make your elfe friends, and to oblige my two Brothers and their Empires, confirming, by a good correpondency with them, that alliance which is already betwixt you. Why, Sir, did you honour me, to make me your Wife? Was it, to make my two Brothers your enemies? was it, to ruine my Country? was it, to ee my friends and kindred carried away Captive into a trange Country? Oh! What a ad and fatall marriage was this unto me? Had it not been much better for me, that the firt day the Towne was taken, had been the lat of my life? Upon this, that wie and prudent Princee fell down all tears at the feet of Ataulfus, and kied them, with o many ighes and groanes, as the Kings pitty did urmount the cruelty of his nature, o as he took her up, kied her, and aid unto her: Ceae ceae, all your tears and ighes, my dearet Placidia, I do freely give unto you, your City and Country; and to make it appear, how much I do deire your contentment, I do vow and wear by the oul of my dead Father, that I will never turne my armes againt any of your Brothers, whoe friendhip and amity, for your ake, I will by all waies court.

The King of the Gothes thus mollified and vanquihed, he concluded a Peace with Honorius, and went out of Italy into thoe Provinces, which were agreed by Alarick his Predeceor, he hould have. But his people, who were of a martiall temper, and had lived many years in Armes, they could not endure to hear upon any tearmes of Peace; and therefore by a publick edition, did put him to death.

Now was Placidia in no lee danger, then at the taking of Rome; for a popular tumult is like a torrent, that carries away all that will top its fury; Yet, this wie Princee, who foreaw uch a danger long beforehand, he obliged the prime Officers in the Army, by all the good offices that poibly he could imagine; and indeed, as long as he was amongt them, he was honoured and loved more then ever any Queen was.

This generous pirit did not hrink from her zeal and love unto her Country and her Brothers, in the leat manner, by the death of her Husband; but, after he had a while lamented her ad mihap, he tranacted the matter o, that a Grandee Prince amongt the Gothes, of whoe amity he was well affored, was choen King, his name was Segerick. This new King acknowledging his obligations unto Placidia, and thinking the amity of the Roman Emperours very neceary, for the etablihment of his Crowne, he hewed himelfe o affectionate unto it and her, as he procured unto himelfe the odium of the Army, who preently after did murder him, as they had done before Ataulfus. But this generous Queen, who could never be daunted by any misfortue, nor weary with any
paines for the good and ecurity of the Empire, he brought it o to pae that Vulius was choen King. This Vulius was a great and a wie Commander, who having before his eyes the example of two Kings his Predeceors, he reolved by prudence to avoyd the like end At his firt comming to his Crowne, therefore, he made a hew as if he were a profeed enemy unto the Empire, made great preparations againt it, and faining to be farre out with the wie Placidia, he ent to denounce warre againt her Brother. Who being advertied underhand by his Siter, he pread abroad reports of a puiant Army, which he would raie againt the Goths, and o frighted thee Barbarians by the aide of Vulius, that in concluion the people demanded peace; which was concluded to the great contentment of Placidia. Who now eeing the Empire etled, and ecured on that ide, deired to be out of their hands, and went into Italy. Where he was received by her Brother, and the people, as if he had been a great Generall, unto whom the tryumph belonged. It eemes now fortune was weary of tormenting this wie Princes: And he was o beloved and honoured by every one epecially Honorius himelfe, as remembring the cares and paines he had taken in delivering the Empire from the Tyrannique Arms of the Goths; and how much both he and all Europe was beholding to her: They reolved eeing he had no Children, to marry her unto one whom he would allie unto the Empire, to the end he might after him, be Mitree of thoe Dominions, which he had o long and o prudently preerved.

In order unto this deigne he look't upon one of the greatet Captaines in all the Armie, whoe valour, and wie conduct did render him mot worthy of a great command: his name was Contantius; a man of a very antlent Familiy, and high vertue: His Picture is next unto that of Placidia, in whoe apect you may oberve uch a grandure of pirit and corrage as is not commone. And indeed he was one of the greatet Peronages, that the Empire had a long time before. This was he, unto whom Honorius gave his Siter: And at the ame time ent him into Spaine with a great Armie againt the Almaines, the Swedes, and the Vandals. The good King Vulius, hearing that Contantius was huband unto the wie Placidia, he aited him with all his forces, and followed himelfe in peron. This was the reaon why Contantius at his returne gave Aquitaine unto the aid Vulius, where he lived quietly and in good corepondency with the Romans.

This great Contantius got the better of the Almanes, killed their King called Acatius and afterwards vanquihed the Swedes. And doubtlee the Vandals had been driven out but for the revolt which Attalus had caued in Rome, intending to declare himelfe Emperor, becaue Honorius had no Children, nor had named any ucceor For Contantius leaving his Enterprie in Spaine unperfect, he came to Rome, and eizing upon the rebell he confined himelfe unto the Hippodrome: At which Honorius was o well pleaed that he made him his aociate, and declared him Augutus. Fortune who commonly econds one favour with another; did o by Contantius: So as now behold him a conquerer in Spaine, Tryumphant at Rome, and an Aociate in the Empire. One great favour more he added unto all thee which was not inferiour to any of the precedent: And gave him two children by his dearet and o highly beloved Placidia, the one called Valentinian, and the other Honoriques of whom I have been very curious in getting their pictures. This peece is Valentian's next unto Eudoxe, his wie; Daughter unto the Emperour Arcadius: And that peece is Honoriques next Attilia, who, after he married him, followed him into Pannonia.

Now behold Placidia and Contantius at the highet tep of their felicity. But it eems fortune had onely made truce with this wie Princee, not a lating peace. For when her husband had prepared a formidable army, to reduce Spaine entirely unto the Empire, he fell ick of a violent dieae, and a few dayes after dyed. All the comforts that this wie Princee now had, was in the lamentations and love of the whole Empire: And alo in the two Children, which her husband had left her, whom he educated with all poible care.

There was at that time a very wie and valiant Captaine in the army whoe name was Aetius, Sonne unto the great Gaudentius who was laine in Gaule. I mut needs confee that I am very partiall towards him: for having made long warre in the neighbor Provinces, we never received any harme by him, or his Army. But on the contrary, I have known him, o careful for our preervation, that indeed all the Gaules are obliged unto him I was therefore very carefull in getting his Picture which I have placed next that of Attilia, becaue it was he who held this courge of god from the Gauls. Oberve in his Aquiline
noe his Generoity: in his large forehead full of wrinkles, his Prudence: and his quick and parkling eyes, his Vigilance and Celerity. Indeed he was one of the mot prudent, and mot valiant men of his time: he could foreee things, before there was any hadow of appearance unto others; he was infinitly courteous: and o liberall, as in imitation of Alexander he reerved nothing to himelfe but Hope. This was he who was made choice of, by Honorius to proecute the Enterprie in Spaine, in whom the advice of Placidia had a great troake. But how mierable is the man that lives by the opinion of others! for if he have no reputation, he is corned: and if he have reputation, and do not preently anwere that opinion which men have of him, he is upected too light in the ballance. And the wort is when he meets with uch as have no experience. It was the misfortune of this great peron, who thinking to go into Spaine without any tay in Gaule, he was much deceived: For finding the Burgundians ready to eize upon the Country of the Heduois and Seguanois: and that the Frankes under the conduct of Pharamond their King had paed over the Rhine and would quarter in Gaule, he was forced by this at home, to make head againt them, before he paed any further; which he did, o happily, that he ent back the Burgundians to the place from whence they came; and forced back the Franks over the Rhine where they tayed: yet not without many dangerous skirmihes, as you may imagine. For the rankes, of all the Northerne people are the mot hardy and warlick, and have a great conformitie with the Gaules, both in their Lawes, Policies, and Religion: which argues that formerly theywere all but one people and that the Franks originally were Gaules. But however, Pharamond went back over the Rhine, and by the prudence and valour of Aetius was forced to tay there: Now though Aetius was victorious, yet was he o much weakned that when he paed into Spain, he found himelfe weaker then thoe he was to undertake, for the Vandals fortifying in the Betique, under the the conduct of Generick, were growne very puiant. The Swedes and Almaines entered into Meridea, and there quartered: And the Gothes after the Death of Vualius having lot all good will unto the Romane Empire, and not contented nor contianing themelves within their limits in Aquitaine; they enlarged them in Spain, o as what the Romans had, was the leat part: Which contrained this great Captaine, eeing his enemies tronger then himelfe, to ue prudence more then the word, and to make them enemies amongt themelves: o as he thought it mot expedient to temporize with them till he epied his advantage, and to run no hazards in the meane time.

But Aetius having already chaed the Burgundians and the Franks away, Honorius expected that as oon as he was arrived in Spain, he hould preently heare newes of the defeat of the Vandals, Swedes, Almaines; and Goths: And eeing the newes was long in comming, he upected him, and had an opinion that he was lack in his enterpries. This Prince was timerous and having never been in armes, he was ignorant in matters of warre: So as he knew nothing by ight, but meaured every thing by the happy ucces of the great Theodoius, and Contantius: In o much as mitruting Aetius, he called him back, and ent Catinus in his roome.

This Catinus was a great freind of Aetius: And therefore the affaires of the Empire went the better, becaue Aetius gave him the bet intructions that he could, opening unto him all their deignes and the meanes to put them in execution. In the mean time he returned to Rome, where he gave an account of his actions unto Honorius. But finding that the Emperour had ome jealouie of him, he retired unto his owne houe, and lived a private peron afterwards: eeing thee jealouies did daily increae, and that they would quetion him for his life, he was forced to ave himelfe in Pannonia amongt the Hunnes and Gepides; And it it was a very prudent conideration which moved him to fly unto them rather then any other: For had he gone to the Franks, Burgundians, Gothes, Viigots or Vandals, It might have been aid that the Emperor had jut caue to upect him, and that he had held a compliancy with them. But this could not be aid of the Hunnes and Gepides, becaue they were carcely knowne unto the Romane people. Placidia being extreamly angry with her Brother, as well for the loe of Aetius, as for the bad carriage of every thing ele, he reolved to retire unto Contantinople to her Nephew Theodoius, whither he had gone long before, had not Arcadius her Brother, lying upon his death bed, committed his Sonne Theodoius unto the Protectorhip of Idigerdes King of the Perians: & Parthians. For though he was his friend and confederate, yet the people had beene long enemies of the Empire, and therefore he did not like that any trangers hould have the government of her Nephew. Yet Idigerdes hewed himelfe a very good man, in the buinee:
And becaue he could not go in peron, he ent a very great Captain unto Contantinople, to govern the peron and the tate of this young Prince, who was then about eight years of age. The name of this Parthenian was Antiochus, a man who did acquit himelfe o well of the charge committed unto him, as his adminitration was clear and blamelee. If you will turne your eye that way, you may ee the Picture of Idigerdes, neer that of Arcadius; next him, is Theodoius the econd; and next that, his wie and honet Governour Antiochus; you may perceive by his phyiognomy, that he was a downright honet man, free from ambition. When Theodoius was out of his Guardianhip, Placidta reolved to go unto him, and carry her Children with her. Now, this prudent Princee being infinitely beloved, and the young Valentinian began to promie great hopes of himelfe, many Senators and Knights of Rome preferred their Sons unto his ervice. Placidia was very glad, that he could thus oblige the principall Senators of Rome unto her Children, amongt the ret Uraces, Son unto a prime Roman Knight; I do name him, becaue he did revenge the death of Valentinian.

Silvander then interrupting the Druide: I beeech you, Father, pardon my interruption; If you do mean that Uraces, who killed Maximus, there is none in the Company can give you a more particular account of him, then my elfe; for, I being then at the Masilian Schoole • fortune, his Ship ran ahore, where, I believe, both he and his friend Olimbres had dyed, but for the help which I and my Company gave him; and afterwards, taying untill his hip was trimmed, he related unto me the particulars of his life, which was hard to be known from any but himelfe.

That is the very ame (aid Adamas) of whom I peak; and when you have heard out what I hall tell you concerning the fortune of this wie Princee, I aure my elfe the Company will be very glad to hear a relation of Uraces from you. But, to return from whence we left. Know, that whilt Honorius lived in this manner Aetius lived in Panonia, but was not idle: for, Revenge being the weetet thoughts of an injured peron, and being very enible of the wrong Honorius had done him, he tudied how to make him repent the unjut uage of him in this manner: And being a man, whoe name and reputation was every where famous, he eaily perwaded thee Barbarians unto what he would, repreenting unto them, how eaie a matter it was, to make attempts againt Italy, epecially, by means of that intelligence which he held there; and etting them a longing after their Riches and treaures. This people, who deired nothing more then changing their cold habitation, hearing of the fertility and riches in Italy, they burned with deire to enter into it. When they had raied a vat number of men, and were ready to enter, it eemes, god had ome pitty upon the Empire, and allaid this torme by the death of Honorius. Aetius, wihing no ill unto Italy, but only unto Honorius, hearing newes of his death, did preently change deigne; and told the Barbarians, that it was neceary he hould go firt unto Rome, to ee how things tood, and what Forces they had. They preently approved of what he aid, and promied him all poible reliefe and aitance. He returned therefore in confidence of Catinus his friendhip, with a deigne to make himelfe Emperour; but finding the faction of Honorius to be very great, and tanding in fear of a great Captain, called Boniface, who had the command of the Affrican Forces, but much more of the young Emperour Theodoius, he thought it better to put it upon one John, who was the principall Secretary unto Honorius, with whom he ever had good correpondency; therefore he made him to take the title of Emperor upon him, and under his name ordered and dipoed of all things: and certainly, he hewed a great deal of prudence in it; for, Theodoius not approving of this John, declared Valentinian, his coen-german, the Emperour of the Wet: And knowing, that the Sword was the bet prop of the Scepter, he raied a very great Army, and ent it into Italy, under the conduct of a very experienced Souldier, called Artabures; and this Souldier made his knowledge in martiall matters, very well appear unto Catinus: Yet, the Sea was o contrary to his deignes, that a torme cat him upon the coat of Ravenna, the ret of his Fleet was dipered into everall places: But Apar, the Son of Artabures, who accompanied his Father in this expedition, being by fortune not in the ame hip: when the torm was over and heard of his Fathers fortune, he rallied together all the Fleet that poibly he could, and landing in the night, entred Ravenna with all his Forces, through the negligence of the Guardes; and when day was come, he took John, cut off his head immediately, and delivered his Father.

The wie Placidia came to Ravenna, with the young Emperour her Son, almot at
the ame time; and within a few daies after, things ucceeded as well as he could wih: For, Catinus comming out of Spain, not knowing of this John's accident, he thought to joyne his Forces with thoe of his friend Aetius, and their Emperour, and to that end, made very long Marches; of which, Placidia being advertied, he ent Artabures to top his way, who met him at Verceill, gave him Battle, defeated his Army, and brought him Prioner to Ravenna. And, as if heaven would entirely ettle the Empire upon Valentinian, Aetius, who was at Rome, expecting the Forces of Catinus, and alo from the Hunnes and Gepides, he was taken Prioner by the adherents unto the Faction of Honorius, who brought him to Ravenna unto Placidia.

In this occaion, this great Princee hewed her elfe, to be of a mot generous and prudent pirit; for, in lieu of taking revenge upon thee two great perons, by putting them to death, he thought, it would be a greater advantage unto Valentinian, if he could make them his faithfull Servants. As for Catinus, he did not much care for him, o as perhaps he would have handled him more roughly, had it not been in conideration of his friend Aetius, whoe judgment, experience, and valour, he knew, and thought would be very uefull unto her Son, by reaon of the great reputation he had with the Hunnes and Gepides, who, at his intigation, had made great preparations to enter into Italy, and were already upon their March. Moreover, he conidered that Honorius, by his upitions of him, had given him jut occaion to leave his ervic •• and therefore, to ave himelfe, he went amongt thoe Barbarians, whoe Forces, he feared, might infinitely impede the event of her Son's Empire.

All thee things therefore well conidered, he thought that if he did punih Catinus, he hould extreamly offend Aetius, by reaon of the amity betwixt them; and therefore, in keeping Catinus in afetie, he conceived it would keep the other the more unto his duty, almot forcing him unto it, to ave the life of his friend. In this reolution, he put Catinus a Prioner into the Hippodrome, from whence a few daies after he releaed him, purpoely to oblige Aetius the more, unto whom, in the mean time, he gave liberty, and in lieu of punihment, conferred favours upon him, excuing all he had done upon the ill grounded jealouie of Honorius She procured Valentinian to end him generall into Gaul, againt everall Nations that poeed it. Before he went, in proof of his fidelity, he tranacted o with the Hunnes and Gepides, that when they had et foot in Italy, they returned back, and went into Pannonia. As oon as he came into Gaul, he raied the Siege of Archilla, which Thierry, the Son of Vualius, the good friend unto the Empire, had urrounded, and relieved the place, when it was reduced unto great neceity. Afterwards, making head againt the Burgundians, he driv them back unto the limits, unto which the Emperour had confined them. As for the Francks, though he could not at that time keep them from making ome progree under their King Clodion, yet, he kept them out of Gaul, o as they got nothing on that ide the Rheine. And becaue the Britaines were not able to reit the Picts, though the Romans had made there a trong Rampart, in form of a Wall to defend the Brittaines from the incurions of their neighbour-people and enemies, he ent Galucon thither, with a Legion which was then in Paris.

Hitherto all things went according to the wih of the wie Placidia, and the Emperour her Son: But Boniface was the firt, who ruining himelfe, made them be of the loing hand, both in Affrica and Spain. This Boniface was Governour in Affrica, who was an inveterate hater of Catinus, and by conequence of Aetius: He hearing how Placidia treated them, and of the great power he had conferred upon Aetius, in making him a Patriarch, and in giving him the charge of all Gaul, he reolved to withdraw himelfe from under his obedience; and therefore not following his commands, he would not according to order return to Rome. At which Placidia being offended, he procured Mahortius to be ent thither with a great Army. Some had a upition, that this was the artifice of Aetius, to ruine him in the opinion of Placidia and the Emperour. However it was, Mahortius being defeated by Boniface, Valentinian ent Siulphus thither, whoe Picture you may ee next that of Valentinian I was very deirous to have it, as well for his valour and prudence, as for his contant fidelity unto his Mater, conceiving that his excellent qualities, rendred him worthy to be placed amongt o many illutrious perons. This Siulphus, at the firt, eized upon Carthage, and forced Boniface to fly into Mauritania, where finding no afety for himelfe, he called in Generick, King of the Vandalls, who then was in the Betique. This Vandal was very glad to come out of Spain, becaue the Goths, under Thierry their King, having not room enough for themelves, did o
pree upon the Vandals, and tormented them, that they were not able to defend themelves. When Boniface offered Generick to hare Affrica with him, he was reduced unto uch a pae, as he knew not which way to turn himelfe; but he took that part which Boniface preented unto him. He left the Betique, which was ever ince called Vandaluia, and went into Affrica with his Wife and Children; but he learned from Boniface, what it was to trut unto Barbarians; for, as oon as he came unto Affrica, he eized upon Mauritania, and confined poor Boniface unto the inacceable Mountains; afterwards, he made his peace with the Romans, upon condition, he might keep what he had gotten from Boniface. Valentinian willingly conented unto it; and thinking, that all the ret of Affrica was ecured unto him, by this new Peace made with this Vandal, he called the valiant Siulphus from Carthage, to employ him in Italy and Gaul. But Generick kept his word no better with him, then he had done with Boniface; for, Siulphus was no ooner in Italy with all his Forces, but the Vandal eized upon Carthage, and drove the Romans quite out of Affrica; o as this great City was eparated from the Empire, untill the valiant Scipio reduced it unto the Common-wealth.

At that time, there lived in an Affrican Towne called Iponne, a great and vertuous peron named Augutine, a very friend unto Boniface and one that adored only one god; and though he did differ from the Religion that we profee, yet was he much neerer it, then the antient Romans; for, he offered acrifices of Bread and Wine as we do, and would not upon any termes admit of any plurality of gods; but above all, he reverenced the Virgin who was to have a Child, unto whom we have for many ages dedicated an Altar in the Carnutan Monotarie. But to return unto our dicoure. It eemes, that at that time it pleaed the great god to change the people of one Country into another, and to make great revolutions, epecially in Europe: For, the raigne of the Vandals begun to begin in Affrica, the Viigots in Spain; for as oon as the Vandals were gone, they planted themelves there. The Anglois eated themelves in Brittain, becaue Galicia being called away by the Emperour, to be ent into Affrica, the Picts did o torment that Kingdome, that the Brittaines were forced to call the Anglois to their aid, who ever ince rendred themelves Maters of it. The Francks, under Clodion and afterwards Merovius, did plant themelves where now they are. Thus, wie hepheards, do the heavens when they pleae, make revolutions, changes, and alterations in Kingdomes and Dominions.

Now the wie and prudent Placidia, being grown into great years, and having had great experience of fortune's variety, eeing her elfe unable to upport that great weight of affairs which he foreaw would fall upon Valentinian, he did extreamly deire to ee him married, as it had been long before reolved upon, unto the Daughter of her Nephew Theodoius, who ever had the ame intention. And things were o managed, that Valentinian went unto Contantinople, where the Marriage was olemnized, to the great contentment both of Theodoius and Placidia; of Theodoius, becaue his Daughter was to be an Empree, which he mot deired; and of Placidia, becaue he conceived, this alliance would be a great trength unto her Son againt his enemies, and would oblige Theodoius to help him upon all occaions, as he did, before her Son returned from Contantinople; for, he ent with his Daughter Eudoxe, a great Army, to be employed which way oever Valentinian pleaed.

Thus, age hepheards, have I acquainted you with the life of her, who has run through variety of fortunes, o as it may be aid, that Placidia was all her time the very Butt, both of good and bad fortune: For, he had been Daughter, Siter, Wife, Mother, and Aunt unto Emperours; and he had been taken Captive by Barbarians, and lived, to lament the death of mot of thoe, whom he mot loved. However, we may conclude her happy, ince he dyed at Rome, a Mother unto an Emperour, who loved and honoured her, and infinitely lamented throughout all the Empire; for he dyed, preently after her Son was returned into Italy with his Wife.

Thus Adamas ended his dicoure, which caued all the company to fix their eyes upon the Picture of this great Princee, conidering every lineament of her face, and admiring her vertue. But Alexis remembring what Silvander had aid, concerning the fair Eudoxe, and deirous to know, whether he had heard a relation of the tory, as he had, from the mouth of Uraces, which he had begun to relate unto Leonida, when Adamas interrupted them, he deired that Nymph in a low voice, to put Silvander in minde of his promie. But it was o late, that Adamas would not uffer the old hepheards to go away
untill the next morning. Leonida deiring to pleae Alexis in all things poible, and very deirous alo to hear the tory of Eudoxe, he ummoned him to the performance of his promie. He offering to excue himelfe, becaue it was late, Adamas anwered, that this hould be no excue for him for he would not uffer them to go away that night. Diamis, Phocion, and Tircis, made ome dorre at it; but Hylas was very forward to accept of his invitation, aying, Let thoe that will go, go, and thoe that will tay, tay; for his part, he was all for the tayers, and would with all his heart tay, as long as Alexis was there. Adamas miled at this and after thanks, he o intreated all the ret, that it was impoible they hould deny him, therefore all itting down, Silvander began thus

Since it is your deire, age Adamas, and you, great Nymph, that I hould relate the fortune of the fair Eudoxe, be pleaed to give leave, that I tell you, how I came to know it, and from whom I heard it, to the end, you may give the more credit unto the relation. Now, though you ee me in a hepheards habit, and though I have long had the charge of a little Flock, where thee age hepheards do dwell; yet for all that, I am not this Country-man, nor was I brought up a hepheard; but on the contrary, uch indulgent care was had of my education, that to render me the better accomplihed, I was brought up in the bet Exercies and Arts, that Youth could be employed in; o as if I did not much benefit my elfe and my undertanding, it was long only of my dull capacity. To this end therefore, I was ent unto the Phocenian and Masilian Schooles, where I pent much time in tudy; and there being much good company, we ued many exercies for recreations ake, in the intervalls of our tudies; ometimes we hould go upon the Sea, ometimes play upon the Lute, ometimes Run, Leap, and Pitch the Bar, or ome other recreation to keep us from idlenee, which is the rut of Life and Mother of all Vice.

It hapned in Summer time, that five or ix of us in company, after we had wearied our elves with the Book, we went to bathe our elves; and to that end, went out of the Towne towards Liguria, unto the point of a Rock, which hot it elfe into the Sea, from whence we were accutomed to leap with head formot into the water, and hould oft times touch the bottome with our hands. At this time, being upon this Rock, and undreing our elves, we were prevented by a udden torm of Wind and Rain, which was preently econded with Lightning and Thunder; the heavens grew immediately of a dusky colour, and the waves began to rie o high, that we were hardly afe upon the top of this high Rock, with uch fury and violence did the waves dah againt it. It was terrible to ee, how uddenly the day was turned into night, to hear the trange roaring of the Sea, and to conider the Chaos and hideous confuion of this raging Element; and certainly, this blutering torme had forced us away, if ome good Genius had not tayed us: We did imagine, that many hips would uffer much dammage by it; and becaue the winde did blow towards us, we reolved to tay till the torme was over, to ee, if by fortune we could be helpfull unto any Sea-beaten paengers, but, to helter us a little from the rain and winde, we crept into a little corner of the Rock, where we were wont to hide our clothes when we bathed our elves. The torme had lated above two houres, when we begun all to be weary; and when we were upon the point of going away, the sky begun to cleer up, and it left raining. Then we came out of our Rock, and going up to the top of it, we began to look, whether we could dicover any thing upon the Sea. The winde wafted away all the cloudes, and the Sun began to hine; yet, the waves ceued not, becaue the winde continued till as great and high, as any time before. As we were dicouring amongt our elves, upon the boldnee of Marriners, epecially of him that firt adventured to Sea, how terrible the enraged Sea was, and that a wie man would never trut himelfe with it, one of our company, who was more obervant of the Sea, then of our dicoure: Hold, (aid he) me-thinks I ee a hip. Upon this, we aroe, to ee whether what he aid was true. At the firt, none but himelfe could ee any thing; but preently after, omething might be dicerned: The winde was o high, that it wafted thee hips preently neerer us, and then every one plainly dicerned them. There was neither Sailes, nor Mat nor Tackling to be een, the torm had contrained the Marriners to take them all downe, and nothing made ue of but the Rudder, which was carcely able to reit the Tempet. The ight was very pittifull, for the winde was o high, as they could not keep themelves from jutling one againt the other. The cries of thoe that were within, which the winde wafted unto us, was lamentable to hear; they were all on the Deck, upon their knees, holding up their hands to heaven: Mot of them, eeing the hore,
were undret, hoping, if the hip came any neerer, to ave themelves by wimming. As fortune was, a boyterous wave dahed them againt our Rock; the great ruh which the firt gave againt it, made it recoil back with uch a violence, as meeting with another which followed it, it broke a great part of the Poop and Prow of the other; and when the Sea was ready to wallow them up, another wave came, which dahed them with o great a force againt the ame Rock, as the hips were quite overwhelmed: Oh god, what a lamentable pectacle was this! Some laid hold upon the points of the Rock, and trove to get footing, till ome help came; others eized upon the roots, which grew in the Rock, and o hung by the armes; and ome, who had laid hold of uch roots, they breaking both fell into the Sea, till the waves brought them back; ome got upon boards and poles, and uch like, but mot were drowned. That which moved mot compaion, was to ee ome women, who had no other help for themelves, but their cries. I mut confee, this moved me o much, as being halfe undret, I hated to trip my elfe naked; and though the danger was great, by reaon of the windes and waves, I would do that to relieve them, which I had often done for my pleaure, I leaped from the Rock into the Sea; and being in the water, I aw two women embracing each other, ready to inke; I took one by the hair, and wimming with my other hand, I drew them both ahore, where leaving them halfe dead, I went again into the water, to help two men, whoe amity moved me to compaion; for one of them, who could wim, had got the other upon his back to ave him; but his load was o heavy, or ele he that was upmot, who was younger then the other, did hang o about the neck of his friend, for fear of drowning, as he having neither trength nor breath left, had already unk two or three times into the water: I took him that could not wim by one hand, o as eaing the other, he took heart, o as we got to hore. All my Companions, after my example, did the like, o as we aved many of them. And becaue I thought the gods commanded me to have a particular care of thoe, whom I had aved from hipwrack, after I had put on my clothes, I went unto them, and aited them all that poibly I could; after I had gotten ome of the water which they had wallowed, from them, they began to be reaonable well, epecially the women, who had been in mot danger. They thought themelves o obliged to us, that they deired to know our names, and of what Country we were; and when they heard me ay, that I thought my elfe either a Seguian or a Foretian: Oh god, (aid one of them) the men of uch a Country, as one of them, are detined to recall us from death. I asked them, why they aid o, eeing it was not a fit time for it, ince they were o amazed with the hipwrack, that they were carcely able to breathe, nor do any thing, but hold up their hands, and lift up their eyes, in admiration of their miraculous ecape: And becaue they were almot all naked, I thought it fit, before I carried them to the Town, to get them ome clothes to cover them, for it had not been decent to have carryed them otherwie. I went unto the Town, and met with o many perons, who being very compaionate, relieved me with cloths for them, as I had relieved them with life; and when I brought them to the Town, they were quartered in uch Bourghers houes, as ued to have compaion upon men in the like cae. For my part, I defired thoe two whom I had aved, to go with me, becaued they eemed to be men of merit. We cannot part, aid they, from thee two women whom you have aved, both becaue they are committed unto our charge, and becaue perhaps it would be inconvenient for you. Not at all, (aid I unto them) o you will be contented with the littlenee of your lodgings; but it would rather be a great atisfaction unto me, if you would do me the favour. So they all foure followed me. And becaue I had a friend in the Town, who had better lodgings then my elfe, I carried them unto the houe of a rich Townman with whom I had familiar intimacy, knowing his liberality and pitty to be uch, as he would bid uch men in uch a condition very civilly welcome; and o he did, for he did accommodate them with all things neceary. Now you mut know, that thee men whom I had thus aved, were two principall men in Rome, the name of the one was Uraces, and of the other Olimbres; o as they ent preently to their houes, and furnihed themelves with mony and many ervants. But, in atisfaction of my promie, be pleaed to know, that whilt they expected a return from Rome, thee two Cavaliers would not be without me; o as quitting my tudy, I accompanyed them unto all uch places, unto which their curioity invited them, in which I took much delight, for their converation was very weet and pleaing. At the lat, deiring much to know who they were, unto whom I had done o good an office, one night, when I was alone with them in their Chamber, (for the two women commonly retired, as oon as upper was done) I entreated
them to tell me, why they hould ay, when they heard I was a Seguian, that thoe of that Country were detined to ave them from death? Unto which, the elder of them thus replyed.

div.head: The Hitory of Eudoxe, Valentinian, and Uraces.
div.p: COurteous Silvander, (aid one of them, for he heard I was o called) your deire is mot jut, and I am obliged to give you atisfaction; it is all the reaon in the world you hould know the lives of them, whom you have aved, and the conditions of uch, as are o much obliged to you. Nor had we deferred it o long, had we not been in ome fears, that if we were known, we might receive ome dipleaure from ome ecret enemies. And therefore we intreat you to be cloe, and take no notice of us, let all the pains you have taken in aving our lives, hould be lot; alo, let any hould hear us, I beeech you hut cloe the dore. Which being done, we all at down, and he began thus.

Know, that Theodoius, Son unto the Emperour Arcadius, and Granchild unto the great Theodoius, being Emperour of the Wet, he married Eudoxe, the Daughter of Leontinus, an Athenian Philoopher. Although this Ladies extraction was not o illutrious, as equalized the Majety of an Emperour, yet, uch was both her beauty and vertue, as he deerved to be raied unto the highet degree of honour amongt men. Theodoius had but one Daughter by her: and becaue he did mot paionately love his Wife, he called his Daughter after her name, o her name was Eudoxe; and as if beauty and all excellencies were fatall unto that name, this young Princee in the very budding of her years, did appear uch a beauty, as he excelled her Mother; and every one confeed, that nature had made her o perfectly fair, as it was impoible, any higher degrees of it could be added unto her. At this time, Placidia being but ill atisfied with her Brother Honorius, he went unto Contantinople, to her Nephew Theodoius, for he was Daughter unto Theodoius the great, and Siter unto Arcadius. She carried along with her Valentinian and Honorique, her two Children. I was at that time preferred very young unto Placidia, to be brought up with her Sons, as many other of the Roman Senators Children of my age were; and when he left Italy, there was o great affection between Valentinian and me, that the one could not be without the other.

The Emperour Theodoius eeing his Uncle Honorius had no Children, he reolved to betow his Daughter upon Valentinian, and to make him Emperour of the Wet, after the death of Honorius. The wie Placidia, who aw this Match would be advantagious to her Son, he commanded him to apply himelfe as much as he could unto this Princee. But ee what contraint in love produceth! Valentinian could never love her, though he was the fairet Princee in the world: yet, becaue he would not dipleae Placidia, nor his Coen-german, upon whom all his fortunes depended, he diembled the matter o, that every one thought him really in love with her.

I being brought up with this young Princes, I mut confee, that I did very inconiderately cat my eye upon her, and fell o fatally in love, as it was impoible for me to make a retreat. Should I ay the ight of her was a happinee unto me, that hath cot me o much orrow and pain? But why hould I make any doubt in the quetion, ince notwithtanding all my paines and orrowes, never was man more happy in uch a generous deigne, then my elfe? So then, I became a ervant unto this Princee. And there being then Tournements held in the Hippodrome, at which Eudoxe was preent as Valentinian entred the Lits, under the notion & name of the fair Eudoxe's Cavalier, it may wel beaid, I did the ame, being o captivated with her beauty and vertue, that never man was more. At the ame time there was a young Lady, of the bet Families in all Greece, preferred unto the young Eudoxe, to be brought up with her, her name was Iedore, and it mut needs be confet, that there was none in all the Court (alwaies excepting Eudoxe) which was comparable unto her. Valentinian no ooner cat his eye upon her, but he fell preently in love with her: But, he was o charie of her honour and reputation, as knowing, that Valentinian could not marry her, he would not allow of his addree, but at the firt, did refue it in as milde a manner as he could; but afterwards, did reject it in a more harh manner, then perhaps the quality of Valentinian deerved: And though he was very hot in puruance of his affection, yet did he behave her elfe o, as he forced him to retreat in appearance, becaue he vowed, that if he continued, he would acquaint Theoodoius
and Placidia with it. This young Prince fearing to dipleae the Emperour and his Mother, did o conceal his deires, as none could ee them, except Eudoxe and my elfe. In the mean time, my affection till encreaed, though this young Princee did not perceive it. The priviledge of my youth permitted me to ee her when I pleaed, without upition, and I was o perpetually aiduous and diligent about her peron, as he employed me ofter, then any other of my Companions. And though at that time I hardly knew what Love was, yet I took uch infinite delight in being neer her, in receiving her commands, erving her, and ometimes kiing the thing which he gave unto me, as he did attribute it unto my civility. I remember, one day as he was walking in a Gallerie, where there was abundance of rare Pictures, there was amongt the ret, that of Icarus, whoe wings failing, fell into the Sea Uraces, (aid he unto me) what does thee cattered feathers, and this man falling into the Sea, ignifie? Madam, (aid I unto her) he was a young man, who being inflamed with a generous courage, would not he contented to flie o low as his Father, whom you ee by him; and becaue his wings were et on with wax, the heat of the Sun melted them, o as he was forced to fall, as you ee him. Truly, anwered he, he was very rah and inconiderate. However, replyed I, he was of a mot generous and noble pirit To what purpoe, aid he ince it brought him to his death. Death, (anwered I) is very welcome, when it leaves a brave memory behinde it. What! aid he unto me, do you commend his act? I do o much commend it, Madam, aid I, as I would not refue to die, upon conditions of the like glory. This Princee was at this time about ome twelve years of age, and I about fifteen or ixteen; an age, yet hardly capable of Love's reentments, and yet I was not abolutely free; however, I had not o much boldnee, as to dicover any thing unto her. I perceive, aid he, that you do eteem your life but very little. Doubtlee, Madam, (aid I unto her) there are many things which I do eteem much more. What! aid he, for when we are once dead, all that we leave behinde us concernes us not. Honour and Love, anwered I. What is this honour, aid he unto me? It is an opinion, replyed I, which we do leave of our elves, and of our courage; and Love, is a deire to enjoy omething, that is great and noble; and therefore, Madam, I hould not refue to die in any generous acts or in doing you ervice; firt, for the glory I hould have by it; and econdly, for my affection unto you. How, (aid he, Unto me? like a very childe) have you any love to me? How do you know it? By the effects, anwered I; for, when I am out of your ight I burn till I ee you again; and when I do ee you, I am vexed that I hall not ee you long enough. How did you come by this dieae, (aid he unto me) and what is the caue of it? Your perfections, Madam, (aid I unto her) and your beauty, hath caued this dieae, by taying long with you. Were I as you (anwered he) I would tay as little as poible could be: but, is there no remedy for the cure of this dieae? Yes, (aid I unto her) if you pleae to love me as well as I love you. How! (aid he preently) would you have me burn when I ee you not? Good Uraces, look for ome other Receipt, for, believe it you hall not have this. I remember, that when I have burned my finger, I was in o much pain, as I will hardly undergo o much again for your cure.
