I durt not reply, becaue there were many Ladies and Knights talking together in the Gallery, and took no notice of us, though they were there to accompany the young Princee; but her childhood, and my youth, permitted me to be with her without upition.

But afterwards, he grew more knowing, and I grew more in love then before: Valentinian, whoe whole deigne was upon the fair Iidore, did hold Tournements as oft as he could; for, having a good agility in that exercie, he thought by that means, to ininuate himelfe into the favour of that wie Lady, till eeming, as if all he did was for Eudoxe. Now, becaue he commonly took uch as were of his own age, and there being not above two years difference betwixt him and me, I was alwaies of his party. Fortune it eemes had a minde to favour me, and conferred the Prize very often upon me, which eeming as if it were in behalfe of Valentinian, I alwaies carried unto Eudoxe; and when he received it, he permitted me to kie her hand Oh, how well did I think all my pains betowed? Yet, I carried the matter with o much dicretion, as he could not poibly be offended, although he did ometimes remember the dicoure which I had formerly with her; for, conceiving them to be but imprudencies of Infancy, he paed by them, thinking that age would better intruct me in my duty. The firt time that he upected the contrary, was, one day when he was walking in the Emperours Garden; after he had wearied her elfe with walking, he et her elfe down in the hade, and fell aleep in the lap of Iidore. There was a great knot of young Cavaliers dicouring together, not far off the
Arbor where he lept, when a Bee, did ret it elfe upon her faire lippe, and after it had ucked it a while, it did ting it very much. The paine caued her to tart up, and laying her hand upon her paine, he complained againt Iidore for the little care which he had off her Valentinian who was walking in the Garden, hearing her cry, and when he was come, eeing her chide Iidore, he told her, that I had a receipt that would preently cure her, and that he had eene the experience of it upon many, and particularly upon my elfe within this two dayes. What will he do? aid he unto him, he will peake ome certaine words (anwered Valentinian) upon the place which is pained, and the paine will immediatly ceae: Then he asked me, whether it was true, and I anwered, yes, and that it never ued to faile me, nor did I think fortune would be lee favourable to me in curing her, then he hath been in curing others: It vexed her extreamly that I hould bring my mouth o neere hers, and giving me her hand, he commanded me to try upon it. But I drew my mouth neerer her lippe, and touched it; he took away her hand and pulled back her head, telling me that this was a kie and not a receipt, and would not permit me to ue it; but the raine did o much increae, as it forced her to bid me teach it unto Iidore, and he hould ue the charme upon her lip: This was much againt my will; for I did extreamly long to have the celetiall happinee of kiing her lip, though I was very orry for the paine he endured. Love did advie me to teach other words unto Iidore, to the end that finding no eae by them, he might have recoure unto me: My deigne did take according to my wih; for he muttering a few groe idle words which I taught her and uing other ceremonies, the paine ceaed not. At which Valentinian laughing, Do you think Mitree (aid he) that any one can adminiter this receit? For my part, I profee unto you, I have tryed it, and I found a preent eae? Now if it do you no good it is becaue Iidore hath omitted omething: Upon this going out of the Arbor, he returned againe, and brought in with him all the young Cavaliers. Her pain did exceedingly encreae, and her lip began to well, when he turning towards me, Will you ay upon your faith, Uraces, (aid he) that the receit is good? I do weare unto you Madam (aid I unto her) by that honour which I owe you, that I never knew it faile, and I am orry Iidore knowes not how to do it aright: but I wih I were for this once a woman, that I might do you this ervice. I know not, Madam, aid Iidore, why you hould be o crupulous but I am confident that if you did ee how your mouth is welled, you would ue any remedy to help it. But pray tell me, Uraces, replyed Eudoxe, will you be long in applying your receipt? As little a time as I can Madam, anwered I. Then going to her, he went into the mot obcure part of the Arbor as being ahamed to be eene, and the exceive pain forced her to let me ue my Enchantment.

Was ever any Sorcerer o happy as my elfe? I poke the words upon her lippe: but when I tooke hers, between mine, and as I ucked it did pree it a little; certainly if ever any did dye of delight it would have been Uraces. She went away from me and bluhed for hame; This (aid he) is the tranget receipt that ever was: But Madam (aid Iidore) Do you finde any amendment? Me thinkes, anwered he, that I do. Your paine Madam (aid I unto her) will preently be gone; but I hall have it all my elfe. How Uraces (aid he), mut you have it all your elfe? yes Madam (anwered I) the condition of this receipt is uch, that he who cures, mut have the paine: he who did not undertand it, or at leat eemed o; Truly Uraces (aid he) I am very much obliged unto you, for taking my pain upon you. Madam, anwered I, could I as well take upon me all the paine that ever hereafter you hall endure, be confident, it hould never trouble you. Iidore miled and aid, Madam if you have as much good will unto him, as he has unto you, you mut preently cure him of his paine, as he hath yours. I had rather, in this be beholding unto him (anwered he) than he unto me; and I am ure he is o civill and courteous, that he will not now give me that paine againe which he hath taken from me: Mot true Madam (aid I unto her) but I mut tell you my paine is not o much in my lippe as my heart. She undertood my meaning very well, though he eemed not to heare me, and had not Iidore beene preent, I had talked more unto her.

I hould be too tedious (Silvander) hould I relate the whole Series of my affection, from the beginning; I hall therefore tell you onely what is neceary for you to know, and omit the ret. Love did at the lat render me o hardy, as I reolved to declare unto her the reentments of my oul: yet I was long in dipute with my elfe whether it hould be by Letter or by word of mouth: at lat I concluded it better to ue my tongue then pen, having long ince learned, that to write where one may peake, argues too much feare,
and thoe who aske any thing fearefully, do teach how to deny: beides, I aw there was much difficulty in the conveying of Letters unto her: But, Oh heavens, how oft did I turne back againe, after I was gone out of my lodging with this reolution? But heaven at the lat favoured my deigne, and afforded me an opportunity.

Eudoxe ued very often to frequent the Emperors Gardens: And I was alwayes very officious & ready to be imployed in her ervice; though it were but to gather her a flower in a day, I was well centented with it and having long ince learned that love does as often begin by trifles as by things of greater importance which very eldomfall out, & that thoe ervices which oblige much, doe rather produce emnity then love, but that nothing winnes more upon another then affection; therefore I was very aiduous in erving her upon every triviall occaion. Not one of her ervants was o officious as my elfe. It happened one day, that Valentinian followed her, for Iidores ake, into the Garden; and Iidore being a little weary, they eperated: Eudoxe continued walking, and Iidore went into an Arbour, where he found eates of grae, covered over with boughes: he had not beene there long but Valentinian who was walking with Eudoxe, began to complaine of wearinee, and made that his pretence for going to it downe in the ame Arbour: Iidore offered to go out, but he held her by the gowne: Eudoxe eeing this, looked upon me and could not chue but mile: I thinking this to be a fit opportunitie to put my intended reolution into execution, I would not let it lippe. I miled therefore as well as he, and he asked me why I did o; to which I anwered very freely that it was becaue Valentinian had left her to go unto Iidore. And why, Uraces, (aid he unto me) do not you the ame? I Madam (aid I unto her) do you think I have o little judgement? Me thinkes (aid he) that you ought to do it, becaue it is fitter that you hould do her ervice then Valentinian. I know very well Madam (aid I) that there is much more equality betwixt Iidore and me, then betwixt Valentinian and her, but I mut needs confee that I had rather commit a fault contrary unto that of Valentinian. How do you meane? (aid he) I meane Madam (aid I) that rather then erve one who is equall unto my elfe as Iidore is, I would dye for the love of one who is above me as you are: How me? anwered he, do you Uraces, know what you ay? I ay Madam (anwered I) that I had rather dye adoring You, then live and love Iidore: and that the vat inequality betwixt us could never put me out of this mind ince the firt day I had the glory to ee you. Surely (aid the Princee) you are out of your wits, otherwie you would never talke thus to Me. Do not thinke o Madam (aid I unto her) for I am ure I never poke more truly, nor with a ounder judgement. She tood till and looked tedfatly upon me, and afterwards aid, Is this language, Uraces, in earnet or in jeat? I do weare Madam (aid I unto her) by that ervice which I owe you, that I did never in my life utter words more unfainedly, nor with a more reolved will then thee; and take them as you will, hate or treat me as you pleae, I hall never change.

Uraces, (aid he unto me) I am very orry for your folly: I have eteemed you and your ervice above any that have been educated under the Emperor my Father: But ince you are growne o beyond all bounds of reaon impudent, and quite forgot your duty and ditance, be aured, that if ever you ue the ame liberty of language againe to me, I will make you repent of your rahnee, and acquaint both Valentinian and the Emperor with it. Madam (anwered I) did I not feare that thoe who are in the garden would oberve me, I would aske pardon upon my knees for my preumptuous crime: but I beeech you give me leave to ay, that all your menaces cannot prevaile with my will: this affection is rivetted into it, heaven and earth cannot diolve it: and therefore there is no hope that any feare of the Emperor, or any conideration of Valentinian can divert me. 'Tis true, I may be ilent, and languih away for the love of the faire Eudoxe: and o I beleive I hall. Now for a proofe of this and not to offend you any longer with my impertinent talke, I do weare unto you by that eternall humble ervice which I owe you, that I will never peak to you of it againe. But remember this, that as oft as I do you any reverence, or bid you good morrow, my heart then ayes unto you Madam, that Uraces is dying for the love of you, and tacitly tells you that you will never have a more faithfull ervant then he: And when I take my leave of you, or bid you good night, then do I ay, how long is it your pleaure I hall be mierable? and how long will your rigour lat? And to begin (aid I adly to her) permit me to take my leave of you and bid you good night. Upon this I made a low reverence and retired, let I hould too much offend her with my words: but as I went, I oberved that he turned the other way and miled; which gave my heart no little hope.
Thus, kind tranger, have I lived ever ince with her, never making any emblance of what was pat except by my good morrowes and good nights; which when none could ee her, he would often anwere with a •• ake of her head, as if he were till offended at the memory of that which I hinted unto her. Above ixe Months paed on this manner, and all the while he hewed not the leat kind of any reception of my affection. At the lat I vanquihed: one morning when Valentinian was leading her to the Temple, I went to her, and making an humble reverence I aid, good morrow Madam. At which he miled, and turning towards me; Uraces, (aid he) your good morrowes are very kindly accepted. Oh heavens? how can I expree my joyes? I protet I never hoped for any happinee, epecially when nothing was talked of but the mariage of Valentinian and her. Yet I undertood ince, how that, which I believed would have ruined my hopes, was that which obliged her, more unto me: For he perceiving how his affection to Iidore encreaed, and all his expreions unto her, were onely to pleae the Emperor, he reolved to entertaine my love, rather then to be the wife of an Emperour, and to accept of my ervice, ince Valentinian was wholy devoted unto the ervice of Iidore. I knew her reolution preently after: for upon the firt opportunity which preented it elfe, he told me, that my contancy, and Valentinians affection unto Iidore had overcome her: And that if I did continue till in my dicreet behaviour he would continue her affection to me: So as ever ince that day, he permitme to call her in private, my Princes; and he called me her my Cavalier. Judge, Silvander, whether ever man was more happy then my elfe. For Eudoxe was abolutely the fairet Princes in the whole world; aged about caventeene or eighteen yeares, and never loved any one but I.

Whilt we lived thus in this manner, Honorius who marryed the Daughter of Stilicon, dyed without Iue: And becaue a Roman whoe name was John, his Principall Secretary was elected Emperour by the meanes of Catinus and Aetius, the Emperour Theodoius intending to make his coen Germaine Valentinian, Emperour of the Wet, he would end him thither with his Mother Placidia. I made a florih as if I were deirous to make one in this voyage but indeed my deires were to tay for the gaurd of Eudoxe: For though the deire of glory did invite me into Italy, yet love kept me at Contantinople, by tronger tyes: for this faire Princes did o econd her promie, as her affection was no lee to me, then mine to her. At the firt, I believed her intention was not to go o farre But love in this reembles death; for as one cannot dye, o one cannot love, by halves. Now as I was pumping for a good excue to tay at home, the Emperour received inetlligence of a great Army which was marching towards Contantinople. This newes invited many to tay, who otherwie in point of honour and duty would have gone under the conduct of Artabures, who carryed a very great Army by Sea; having with him, Apar his Son; a very valiant and fortunate Commander, as afterwards he made it evidently appeare by taking John in Ravenna, and delivering his Father. Now though I was not jealous of Valentinian, for all Eudoxe's favourable apect upon him, becaue I knew it was onely to pleae Theodoius, yet I eemed as if I were, and eemed to rejoyce very much at his departure.

I hall not now relate unto you, the voyage of Valentinian, for I believe you have heard it by many: But o it was, that after all things were et in good order in the Wet, he returned to Contantinople. Where he was received by Theodoius as if he were his Sonne: And by the olicitation of Phacidia who tayed in Italy, the marriage of the faire Eudoxe was concluded upon. It is impoible I hould expree my ad reentments upon this occaion: I could not believe it, and was o urcharged with feares and orrow, that, but for Eudoxe, I had not been able to have upported them. But he who was wie and prudent, though it grieved her to the very oul that he was to be his whom he did not love, yet he urmounted her orrow by reolution. And becaue he aw in what paine I lived, he gave me the opportunity of peaking to her in her cloet, when none was preent but Iidore, whom he did infinitly love Well my Cavalier (aid he unto me) I ee you till doubt of my affection; and complaine againt me.

My fairet Princes, (aid I unto her) had I not been accutomed to receive more favour from you than I can any way merit, you might have had ome reaon to ay o now, when I do receive o high a one, as trancends all degrees of gratitude, to acknowledge ufficiently. But why will you not give me leave to complaine of my fortune, who hewing me the good which he may give, me gives it unto another, whoe merits in matter of love are inferiour unto mine? my Cavalier, anwered he, live contentedly, and be aured,
that Uraces enjoyes all that a violent affection can obtaine: And what favour I hew unto any other is more out of duty then love, and ince it is o, what reaon have you to complaine againt your fortune? My reaon for it, replyed I, is as great as my obligation unto you for this aurance. Why (my fairet Princes) hould I not complain of her who in lieu of favouring my affection, does deprive me of that which onely can bring me unto the happinee which I deire? Oh Cavalier (aid he) you do offend me. What? would you not have loved me, but onely to obtaine that of me which my duty deires you? What did you think of me, and how little did you love me, if you have o bad an opinion of me? I was not able to anwer her, eeing how he took it; but kneeling down, with a deep igh, I topped my mouth by holding her hand upon it. At the lat, I roe up again, and anwered her: I mut needs confee, my fairet Princee, that I do love you more then you would, and more then reaon would; but who can love you lee? I mut confee, that neither reaon nor duty, can meaure the grandure of my affection; and if I do offend you in it, I beeech you pardon me, conidering, that to love you lee, would be to prophane your beauty. Alo, I beg your pitty, who have o much courage, & yet want o much merit. And yet you might well winke at thee faults, if love had a little more force in you. I do not undertand you, aid he unto me. Alas! replyed I, how hard a matter it is to make you undertand it by my words, if love will not make you conceive it? But, I mean, my Princee, that if love had a little more power over you, this duty which you peak of would have lee; the too-happy Valentinian would enjoy what he is in quet of, and I, what I deire. Oh Cavalier (aid he, with a deep igh) did you but know the reentments of my oul, and what retraint it is in, you would know, that Love hath as much power over me, as it can have over any heart: If I do deny you any tetimony of this power, conider my birth, and unto what Lawes it obliges me. Had I been the Daughter of the Athenian Leontine, as my Mother was, I might have dipoed of my elfe and my affection; but being Daughter unto the Emperour Theodoius, Grandchild unto the Emperour Arcadins, and having Theodoius the great unto my great Grandfather, do you not ee, I am not my owne but theirs, who gave me my beeing? It is the Tribute of humanity, and the Law of divinity, to ubmit unto Emperours and Grandure; Reaon of State, as well as Love, is to be conidered. This is no newes either to you or me, we both foreaw this long ince; and when I firt et my eyes and affection upon you, it was till with a reolution to marry Valentinian; I am confident you had the ame thoughts, the firt day you began to love me. What is it then which now troubleth you? What accidents have hapned, which hould divert us from our firt principles? Thee words touched me o to the quick, that I could not permit her to go on without interruption: Can you think, Madam, aid I unto her, that thee are coniderations of Love? Can love be confined to any Lawes of duty? Oh heavens! how infinitely are you and I mitaken? You, in thinking that you love; and I, in thinking that you loved me. Then, topping a little, I began again, when I aw he offered to peak: The Lawes of Love, Madam, are far different from thoe you mention, and if you would know what they are, read them in me, and you will finde, that as the great inequality which is betwixt us, could not keep me from lifting up my eyes o high as my fairet Princee, o it hould not divert you from looking o low, as your poor Cavalier; for, there is no more difference betwixt you and me, then betwixt me and you. And as to what you alledge concerning your birth, ince it is o high, that it is in the uperlative degree, and can admit of no higher then you are, why hould you not in lieu of looking at Grandure, which can receive no addition in you, cat your eyes upon your own contentment, to the end, that as you are by birth the greatet Princee in the world, o you may be, by your choice, the mot contented Princee that ever was? You ay, that I began to erve you, in the opinion, that Valentinian hould be your Husband: Oh, Madam, I mut confee, that when I firt devoted my elfe unto your ervice, I thought my elfe able to upport that opinion; but, ince my affection is o encreaed, that it is abolutely impoible for me to endure it, what can you anwer me, but that your affection is weak, ince it is not augmented more then it was at firt? I wonder, my fairet Princee, how you can deny your favours unto me, who adores you, and confer them upon one, who does not love you. Can you ever conent, that your beauty, which without all dipute, may be the recompence and perfect felicity of any true Lover, hould be enjoyed by one that didaines it, and does not value it? How can you endure his carraes, and not pitty the pain of your poor Cavalier? Iidore, who heard our dicoure, and was very deirous to favour us, not out of any amity
he bare unto me, or any deire he had to have any hand in uch buinees, but out of a hope, that this affection might pae o far, that perhaps it might break off the Marriage of Valentinian and Eudoxe; and to give us more opportunity of talking together, he withdrew her elfe into a little Cloet, in which at the lat he fell aleep. I preently perceived it, though I had my back towards her, becaue paing betwixt the candle, I aw her hadow againt the wall, which made me oberve her when he went away. The Princee, who was leaning upon her arme in the Couch, and was very attentive upon what I aid unto her, never oberved her, though he went cloe by her. And becaue my lat words touched her to the quick, he tayed a long while before he anwered, and till looked upon the ground: At the lat, he raied her elfe up, and with a deep igh, aid thus: Oh my Cavalier, how cruelly do your words wound my oul? But what can I do? What will become of me? If I do not marry Valentinian, what will be thought of me? And if I do marry him, unto what a torment am I detined? At thee lat words, I aw tears trickle down her cheeks, and he durt not peak more, let her words hould too much betray her own weaknee. Thee tears moved me to much pitty, giving me no mall aurance, and much augmenting my courage. I mut confee, (kinde Silvander) that I never hoped to bring this Princee unto this; but finding more love in her then I did imagine, I took upon me more boldnee then ever I intended. I approached therefore a little neerer unto her then before, and eeming, as if I would only upport her drooping head in my breat, my mouth was jut betwixt her eyes; I durt not at the firt kie her, only eemed, as if what I did, was not done intentionally; but eeing he aid nothing, I decended by little and little, untill my mouth met hers; and becaue he gave me no check, I put my hand into her breat, but with o much ravihment, that I trembled like a leafe haken with the winde. Since that time, I have been in many dangers, and everall deep-fought Battles, but I was never o enible of fear, as upon this occaion. Thus he permitted me this freedome; but when I grew to be a little bolder, he aid thus unto me: Fie, fie, my Cavalier, what do you mean? Iidore will ee you. It is long ince, my fairet Princee, (aid I unto her) he left us alone. How, (aid he, and tarted up) is not Iidore here? he is very much to blame in leaving us alone. Why, Madam, aid I, we have no buinee for her. Perhaps not you, replyed he, but I have; and if you do love me, as you ay you do, be contented with thee favours which I have permitted, and pree me not to confer more upon you, then I ought or can. I thought, that the preence of Iidore would have retrained you from offering any thing, but what decency allowed; and could have wihed, it might have been he, and not I, that hould have given you the check, to the end, you may ee how willing I am, to give you full aurance of my affection; but ince he is gone, and ince you cannot keep within the limits of what you ought, I am contrained to tell you, that if you make any attempts againt my honour, I will permit you, but upon condition, that I have, a naked Dagger in my hand, to pierce my heart preently, for the fault which you hould contrain me to commit: If you would have me live, then contrain me not, I beeech you to permit that, which I ought not to do, unlee I die. I mut confee, thee words did put me into uch a confuion, that riing from the place where I was, and falling down upon my knees, I proteted unto her, that I would never eek for any further tetimonies of her affection, nor atisfaction to my deires greater, then thoe he hath been pleaed to hew unto me. If you do o, aid he unto me, I will as long as I live allow you the ame privacy you have received; and this proof of that affection which you bear unto me, hall be pleaing unto me, knowing, that right love can keep within the limits of decency. Upon this, he took my head in both her hands, and kied me, as an earnet of her promie, and we pake o loud, that we awaked Iidore. Now becaue the night was far pent, and the candles almot out, Eudoxe called her, and asked what a clock it was. 'Tis time, Madam, aid he, that we go to bed, for every one is aleep except you. Do you think, Iidore, aid the Princee, that Valentinian is not now awake for his Mitree? I know not what he does, aid Iidore; but I am ure, if I were in bed, I hould leep oundly. I anwered her, That it was in bed where he would finde her. What! anwered he, would you be any where ele? The Princee laughed, and aid unto her: What do you think on, Iidore? I believe you are yet aleep. What would you have me do, (aid he, and rubbed her eyes)? Uraces makes a fool of me.

Now becaue it was late, Eudoxe roe up, kied me, and commanded me to retire, which I did, but not without uing the priviledge of kiing her, which he had given unto me: And becaue he aw, that Iidore oberved her, and aid nothing, Eudoxe aid thus
unto her: What do you look at, Iidore? I look, Madam (anwered he) whether the Bee have much trng you. What Bee, aid the Princee? The Bee in the Garden, anwered he, againt which this Cavalier hath o often given you a Receipt. Upon this, taking the Candle which was upon the Table, he lighted me down the tairs into the Court; but not before Eudoxe miled, and aid unto her: Take heed, let being alone with him, he do apply the ame Receipt unto you. Neverfear, Madam, (aid he) that Receipt will not do any effect upon me, becaue I do not believe in his words.

See upon what termes I was, when Valentinian married this fair Princee, whom preently after he carried into Italy. I hall pae over my orrowes and dipleaures I had, epecially the marriage night. But thoe of the fair Eudoxe were no lee, as afterwards he told me; and Iidore, whom he carried with her, when he left Greece, becaue of the great confidence he had in her. You may imagine, that Valentinian did not contrary her in it. But as this firt night was almot intollerable to me, o I needed not to eek out for an excue, in not following this fair Princee; for, I was fallen extreamly ick, upon the great dipleaure which I conceived, when Valentinian departed. After I had recovered my health, I begged leave of the Emperour to follow Ariobindes and Ailas, two great Commanders, which he preferred unto Valentinian, with an Army, to ait him againt the innundation of the barbarous people, who threatned from all ides to fall upon the Empire. My age and my jut requet, eaily obtained what I asked. But, as ill luck was, this Army was countermanded back, becaue Attilas, with the Hunnes, Almaines, and Gepides, and an infinite world of people, were upon their March towards Contantinople. This countermand was no ooner brought unto Ariobindes and Ailas, but they heard of the death of Theodoius, who being infected with the Plague, dyed uddenly, without Iue-male. I had no dipoition to carry this ad newes unto the fair Eudoxe, but beought Ariobindes, that I might accompany the Meenger whom he ent, eeming very deirous to ee Italy, before I returned; which requet he eaily granted unto me. In our way, we came to Naples, and from thence to Rome, where I was welcomed with all deirable caraes. Eudoxe did adly reent the death of her Father, as nature required of her; and during the dayes of mourning, Valentinian received intelligence, that Pulcheria, the Siter of Theodoius, who had married an old Generall, called Marcianus, had gotten him to be elected Emperour. This Marcianus was he, whom Generick King of the Vandalls, having him Prioner in Affrica, did ee the Eagle flie, and with whom he afterwards contracted a great league of friendhip. And becaue he was a very great Commander, and of high reputation, he quickly forced Attilas to retreat into Pannonia, where envying his Brother Bledas, he traiterouly murdered him, that he might remain ole King over all thoe barbarous People. When I had intelligence of the election of this new Emperour, and that Attilas was repuled, I conceived, that then there was nothing which could invite me out of Italy; but that, War being on all ides, it was better to tay where my Love invited me. As I was in thee coniderations, the Emperour was advertied, that this Attilas, who may well be phraed, the courge of god, had taken Gaul for his firt deigne: and having by his Armes ubjected Valamer and Ardarick, Kings of the Otrogots and Gepides, he contrained them to joyne with his Forces, which were compoed of Erulians, Almains, Turingians, Marcomances, and of ome Francks, who remained in their old habitations beyond the Rhein, when under the great Pharamond, this warlick People forced their paage, and poeed themelves of that Country, which now they hold in Gaul, and which began then, from the name of Francks, to be called France. As oon as this newes was made certain, the Emperour re-inforced the Army of the Patriarch Aetius, who was one of the bet and greatet of all the Roman Captains, and who had the charge of the Gaules. Now though it went much againt my minde to leave the fair Eudoxe, yet, go I mut: and when I asked leave of her: Why, my Cavalier, (aid he unto me) will you be o far ditant from me? What caue have I given unto you? Have you o lender affection, as to leave me thus? My fairet Princee, aid I unto her, if I hould not go in this expedition, wherein all the Gallantry of the Court are employed, what will the world think of my courage? What will they think, if I tay at home? Nay, what would your elfe think of me? Unto which he anwered, with a mile: I remember, that before my Marriage, none of thee excues were urged. What! do you love me lee now then before? Believe it, though I will keep within compae of my duty, yet I do love you as well now as then, and hall be very orry to part from you. Then he kied me: Remember
(continued he) that you return quickly, and be till faithfull. Thus I left her, and went unto Aetius.

In the mean time, Valentinian, who was infinitely in love with the wie Iidore, continued till his addrees, but with abundance of warinee and dicretion; and thinking, that her denyall proceeded only from ome fears, as commonly young women have, that it would poil her Marriage, if it hould be known, that he was loved: Therefore he reolved to marry her; and thinking with himelfe, who in all the Court was mot fit for her, he pitched upon Maximus, a Roman Knight; of great authority; he was thought the fittet peron for the buinee, as well, becaue he was often in Rome, o by conequence he might eaily ee her; as becaue he was very ambitious, and by doing him honours, he might the more eaily deceive and abue him. Maximus, who deired to marry, and who expected his advancement from the Emperour, received this offer as a very great honour; for, the Lady was very fair, and of an illutrious Family; alo, had as good a reputation as any in the Court. Iidore, on the other ide, was not againt it; for Maximus was as rich as any in Rome, and had been twice Conul. Alo the Empree, who infinitely loved this Lady, was very glad that he was to be married in Rome o advantageouly. There being therefore no obtruction in this Match, Marriage was preently conummated, to the contentment of them both. But when the Emperour, ome few daies after, offered ome addrees unto the wie Iidore, he found her more lack and cool in her affection, then before; at which the Emperour was o vexed, as he reolved to have no longer any recoure unto upplications. It hapned then, that he and Maximus being at play, as they often ued, fortune was o avere to Maximus, that he lot all his mony; and having nothing about him to make take, but a Ring which he uually ealed withall, he pulled it off from his finger, put it to the take, and lot it. The Emperour conceiving, he had met with a good occaion to accomplih his deigne, he pretended ome important buines, and leaving one in his room, he bad him play on upon credit, till Maximus had quitted all he had won; which he did, only upon deigne to amuze him the more. In the mean time, he ent to the wie Iidore, in her Husbands name, commanding her to come and viit the Empree, and as a token of his deire, hewed unto her the Ring of her Husband. She giving credit to the Meenger, and upecting nothing, went, and was conducted into the Garden being told that the Empree was there: Being brought into the mot retired place of all the Garden, you may imagine how atonihed he was, when he aw her elfe in the hands of Valentinian: She began preently to look very pale upon it, and to tremble. The Emperour eeing it, took her by the hand, and would have carried her to it downe in an Arbour, which was in the midt of the Garden; but eeing her elfe alone with him, he refued to enter; yet, he taking her by the arme forced her in, and hut the dore after them. Oh heavens! Silvander, in what a terrible affright was poor Iidore, when he aw this violent beginning; it was as great, as if he had been brought to the place of execution. But the Emperour, thinking to vanquih her by fair words, and thinking, that no woman would deny him, he at down by her, and poke in this manner: I make no doubt, fair Iidore, but you think this tratagem which I have ued, very trange, and, perhaps, are angry with me for it; but I hope, when you conider the violence of my affection, how long it hath continued, and how neither my owne reaons, nor your rigour, can quench it, I hope, I ay, that you will pardon my boldnee, that you will not think this action trange, but will render my affection ome atisfaction, before you depart from hence: Every thing does invite us to it; firt, my unequal'd affection; next, the quality of him who loves you, who being Emperour, you may apire unto the Empire, if you will render me as much atisfaction, as my love deerves; and latly, the conideration of Maximus may move you unto it, ince you may ee by his Ring, that he does not only conent unto it, but deire it. What then, my fair Iidore, hould hinder you, from giving atisfaction to my longing deires? Then offering to kie her, he turned her head the other way, and would not permit him, but beeeched him, to it down and hear her, deiring if it were poible to overcome him by weetnee: I mut needs confee, Sir, (aid he unto him) that I am infinitely amazed, to ee my elfe alone with you, in this dark and olitary place, and o much againt my minde, ince upon it, depends the ruine of my honour and my life; but, I have a great confidence, that you will do nothing againt reaon, or my will, epecially when I do conider, who you are, and who I am. Conidering you as your elfe, why hould I fear, being in the hands of the
great Valentinian, Son to the generous Emperour Contantius, the mot accomplihed of any that ever wore the name of Cear? Valentinian, I ay, whoe Mother was the wie Placidia, the honour and patterne of all Ladies. Can you think, great Sir, that I am affraid of you, whoe widome is known throughout all the world, and whoe prudence every one admires; alo one, from whom Jutice is generally expected. I hould hew my elfe too ignorant of my Emperour's excellencies, did I doubt his goodnee, or fear any harm from him in this olitary place, where I am alone with him: No, no, I dare trut my elfe any where, in the hands of my honoured Emperour: but I mut needs confee, I think it trange that I hould be brought hither by the conent of Maximus: It vexeth me to the oul that he hould thinke me o unworthy, and that I hould have one to my huband who is the very hame, and corne of men.

Now Sir, I will not aske what it is you would have of me, nor what occaion brought you to this place. That Traytor who is the owner of this Ring, and your owne dicoure does but too plainly tell it. But I do mot humbly beeech you, great and good Sir, to conider that I have no more honour when this is gone, and if you love me, let me live worthy of great Cears love: Conider Sir, that you trample under your feet, the honour and the life of her you love, and will o much injure your owne honour and reputation, as well as mine, as I know it will be impoible for you, to repaire it againe. You tell me that in rendering you this atisfaction, I may pretend unto the Empire: Oh heavens? can you think me worthy o much as to live after o great a crime, and taine unto mine honour? If you do beare any good will unto me, preerve me untained untill you can make me uch as you ay, and tay till it hall pleae the gods to bring it to pae. If there be any truth in your words, that you do love me. And if you do love me, never offer that which will make me exteamly hate you. Can you imagine, I hall ever love him that raviheth away my honour, which is much dearerto me, then my life? No, no, Sir; I never can. But I beeech you, think upon Contantius your Father, think upon Placidia your Mother, and think upon God, who hath miraculouly eated you in the Throne: he hath given you power to vanquih John, by the hand of young Apar: John I ay, who otherwie had poeed the Empire: he hath overcome for you, the valiant Catinus, by the valour of Artabures, who a little before was a prioner in Ravenna: he hath ubjected unto you, the Prudent Aetius, by the meanes of thoe who hardly knew you: He hath defeated Boniface the Uurper of Affrica; he hath made the Puiant Generick King of the Vandals your friend: To be briefe, what has not this great God done for you? And how thankfull ought you to be unto him? Now Sir, the very ame god who has done all thee for you, does at this very intant ee you, and oberves what caue you will give him either to continue his favours, or to end you punihments: Conider what mierable accidents and fatall tragedies, have heretofore bealne this Empire, upon the like occaions as this.

Oh mot omnipotent Diety, rather howre downe all thy thunderbolts upon me, and hide me in the profundity of the earth, then uffer me to be any caue of moving thy wrath againt this Emperour. Upon this, he kneeled downe, and continued; And you, great Sir, I beeech you rather put me to death, then ravih from me, that which makes me worthy of your love, or before you make me intrumentall to bring the odium both of god and men upon you. Now Sir, hew, that you are truly Cear, and be as well a commander over your paions, as you are victorious over your enemyes.

p.hi: Valentinian
p.U:
eeing her upon her knees, he tooke her up, and was o moved with her expreions as he was ahamed of what he had done, and wihed that he had never attempted it. Her words did o flow with reaon as fat as her eyes with teares: o as working upon her good nature, they forced him into a reolution of overcoming himelfe, and promied her with an oath, that he would never ue any force againt her. But he beeeched her to take his affection into her conideration, to forget what he would have attempted, and that when Maximus and Eudoxe dyed, he hould marry him. The wie Iidore hearing thee words, began to take: heart; to promie him all that he deired, and to beeech him, he would permit her to depart. Upon this Valentinian kied her hand, and with a deep igh, called unto him Heracles the Eunuch, whom he truted mot of any in the Court and whoe counell he mot followed: This Eunuch, was a very wicked man, nothing pleaing, only faithful. But he was the mot coveteous wretch, and the greatet flatterer that ever breathed. This was he who carried the Ring of Maximus unto Iidore, and conducted
her into the Garden: Now becaue the Emperor deired that this buinee might be carried with all ecrey that was poible, he tooke none with him but this man, whom he commanded to tay behind the Arbor, and to come unto him when he called. Heracles, hearing the Emperors voyce, ran preently unto him, thinking that becaue Iidore would not conent unto the Emperours will, he called him to helpe: but when he heard, that he was commanded to conduct her back: Is it impoible Sir, (aid he) that words hould o farre prevaile, as to let o faire an opportunity to lippe? and to let her go without one touch? Shall a little feare make you loe o faire an opportunity? Do you think he would have given you uch weet language, but onely to get out of your hands? Do you init upon what will be aid concerning your elfe, or her? The wort report that can be, will be only this, that you were infinitly in love with a faire Lady. What hurt is there in all that? the wort will be but nine dayes wonder. Whatoever you do, will be done in ecret betwixt you two, and what wound will that be to any reputation. As for any matter of concience alas Sir god knowes, that though you be Cear yet you are but a man and will excue it as a humane lip as well in you as in others. If he hould pardon none that are guilty of uch a crime he would be alone in heaven; few mortalls would ever come there: loe not therefore uch an opportunity, which you will repent, if you let it lip and make no ue of it.

div.p: The wie Iidore, eeing the Emperor lend an eare unto the wicked perwaions of Heracles, offered to anwere unto what he had urged, but the Eunuch being afraid, did interrupt her thus: Sir, (aid he) do not hearken unto the voyce of this Syren who peakes onely againt her owne concience, and would be glad to be forced unto that which he denyes: beleeve it, if you let this opportunity lip, he will dieteeme you, and mock you: and if you will give me leave to hold her, he will thank me: and you hall ee whether or no, I ay true: Then offering to lay hands upon her, he gave him uch a blow upon the face, as blood immediately guhed out of his noe: but the Eunuch being accutomed unto uch encounters, and eeing the Emperour aid nothing, did get behind her, and foulded her armes within his, o as he could not tirre. Then he began to cry out, and make the bet defence he could; but all to no purpoe: for the Emperour, by the helpe of Heracles had what he deired of her. Ah Valentinian (aid he unto him) thou hat done an act unworthy of thy elfe; and I will dye, but I will be revenged; Then he fell upon Heracles and with her nailes and teeth, hurt him in a hundred places, and not being able to do him any more hurt, he ran out of the Arbor to eeke for omething wherewith he might kill both Valentinian and herelfe: but as fortune was he found nothing, he till thinking upon this injury, would gladly have killed herelfe, he truck her elfe upon the face, tore her haire, and ued all the actions of one tranported. When Valentinian aw her in this condition; he began to perwade her, to aske her pardon, to accue the Eunuch, and promiing to do for her whatoever he would aske. She being hardly able to tand, for wearinee and orrow, at downe upon a eat, o much out of her elfe as he was hardly able to peake. Valentinian came to her, did et himelfe downe by her, continued his upplications, and told her that her husband knew nothing of it; and then related to her how he came by the Ring.

The Emperour told her this, to the end he hould not tell Maximus and to give her ome conolation in knowing that her husband was ignorant of it: for her greatet dipleaure was, to think that her husband hould conent unto it. But when he heard that he was innocent, he was much better atisfyed, hoping now, that he would revenge her wrong. After he had at adly a long while and poke not a word, he contrained herelfe o, that Valentinian thought her a little better atisfied: for he eemed much contented that Maximus knew nothing of it, and conjured him to keep it ecret both from him and all the world, to the end he might live till in the good opinion of every one. The Emperour, who did mot paionatly love her, & who but for the Eunuch had never ued any force, he promied her with a thouand oathes that he would do whatoever he deired: and charged the Eunuch that he hould never peake the leat yllable of it to any in the world. After he had tyed up her haire, and dreed herelfe as well as he could, he went home, where he expected the comming home of her husband, whom Valentinian found till at play, and had recovered ome part of his loes: Night being come, he went home, where he was no ooner come, but according to his cutome he went to ee his wie and deare Iidore: he was in her cloet all alone, o wel'd with teares, as when he aw
her he was atonihed and entreating him to it downe by her, husband (aid he unto him) do not wonder to ee me in this condition: I have o much occaion for it, that I will live no longer: but, before I die, atisfie me o farre as to weare, that you will revenge my death. Maximus, who did extreamly love this Lady, both for her wiedome and beauty, he came to her as his cutome was, to kis her and to know what it was which o much troubled her. But he recoyled, and aid unto him: It is not reaonable, Maximus, that you hould come any neerer unto this defiled body; I am not now the ame Iidore, whom you have o much loved, and who never loved any but you. I am another woman, who dares not call you Husband. The mot wicked and cruell Tyrant that ever was, hath defiled me, and I will not live any longer, ince I am not worthy to be your Wife. Upon this, he related the whole paage unto him, and hewed him the blood of Heracles, which dropt upon her, as he held her. I hould be too long and tedious, if I did relate all the complaints which paed betwixt Maximus and her.

But o it was, that Revenge was reolved upon; but he deired her, upon any termes, not to horten her daies, let he hould incene the gods againt her, telling her, that he would carve her o much revenge, as hould give her atisfaction: He told her, that ince there was not an act of her will conenting, he hould not think her the lee chate, nor lee worthy of being his Wife then before: And that in order to his deigne, he would have her aure Valentinian, that he had never acquainted any with it, to the end, he might think himelfe the more ecure. She carried the matter o, that the Emperour never made quetion of it, and he gave him back her Husbands Ring, the better to perwade him. About this time, Eudoxe was brought to bed of a Daughter which was called Eudoxe, after her own name; and about a year after, was delivered of another, who bore the name of her Grandmother, Placidia.

In the mean time we were in Gaul, expecting Attilas, where Aetius was making all neceary preparations. This Barbarian, having gathered together a very vat Army, as I told you, he intended to fall upon Contantinople; but being prevented in that by the wie conduct of Marcianus, and not being able to maintain that world of People which followed him, either in Pannonia or Germany, which was growne almot deart, by the paage of o many Nations through it, he determined to fall upon the Wetern Empire, which was already well haked, and begun to totter. The aitance which Generick King of the Vandals promied unto him, was no mall pur unto his deigne. This Vandal having gotten the Daughter of Thierres King of the Goths, in marriage unto Honorius his Son, he had a conceit, that he would poyon him, and under this pretence, he cut off her noe, and ent her back into Gaul unto her Father; and tanding in fear of his anger, he thought it mot expedient for him to fortifie himelfe, with the friendhip of the Hunnes, by promiing them all manner of aitance. Attilas who promied unto his ambition no lee then all the Wetern Empire, having recruited and put his Army into good equipage, he marched towards Gaul; but firt dipatched an Envoy unto Thierres, then the mot puiant King of all thoe that poeed it; for, he held almot all Spain, and a great part of Gaul, that is to ay, from the Pirennian Mountains unto the Loyre. And becaue Attilas feared the grandure of this puiant Barbarian, he let him undertand, that his comming into Gaul was only againt the Romans, and that they two would divide the Empire betwixt them, as oon as it was overthrowne. He ent the ame meage unto Gondioch, King of the Burgundians, and unto the valiant Merovius, King of the Francks, and ucceour unto Clodion, the Son of Pharamond. He treated and tranacted o ecretly with Singiban King of the Almaines, as he promied to take his part. But Aetius, who was as wie a Captain, as was in the whole world, knowing his ubtlety, did dicover it unto thee Kings, giving them to undertand, that when the Romans were defeated, Attilas would turn all his forces againt them, and make them Tributaries to himelfe, as he had already done Valamer and Ardarick, and the ret of his Neighbours; and that the amity of the Emperour Valentinian, was more neceary and honourable for them: Neceary, in repect that the Roman Empire was o great, and urely etablihed, that it was impoible for them, having o puiant a Neighbour to their enemy, to leep quietly in their houes. As for Attilas, he was but a torme, which looked foul, but would quickly be blowne over. That the Amity of the Emperour was more honourable unto them,
becaue Valentinian was a great Prince, and a good, and that they were already linked in amity with him. That he had given the Burgundians their habitations where they dwelt; and that the amity of Vualius, with Contantius, the Father of Valentinian, had gotten the Viigots all that they held in Gaul. Briefly, That they had experience already of the Roman Empire, which might put them out of all doubt: Whereas it would be a mad olly in them, to trut Attilas, whoe ambition was uch, as that againt all rights, both divine and human, he would not uffer his Brother Bleda to be his partner, but mierably put him to death. Thee Remontrances caued the Francks, the Viigots, the Burgundians, and the Almaines, to confederate themelves with Aetius againt Attilas, who, after ome years, fell into Gaul, with five hundred thouand fighting men: The firt he fell upon was the Francks, plundering and firing almot all their Townes; but it was only of uch, as had not the courage to pae over the Rheine with the firt, who took up their habitations in Gaul. At the lat, he came to a Citty of Carnutes, called Orleans, which he beieged, and doubtlee had taken it, if the Francks and Viigots had not appeared with uch an Army, as contrained him to rie and go away. This Army, and that of Aetius, was compoed (as well as the Army of Attilas) of everall Nations, as of Francks Viigots, Sarmatians, Almaines, Armoriguans, La • eiuns, Burgundians, Saxons, R • barolds, Auvergnians, Heduois, and everall other people of Gaul, together with Lombardian Auxiliaries. Attilas, mitaken in his attempt (for he thought, that Sig • ban, King of the Almaines, would have put Orleans into his hands) not knowing well whether he hould fight or return, retreated unto the plain of Mauriack, when enquiring of the Priets what would be the iue of the Battle, they anwered, that he hould loe it; but the chiefe of the enemies ide hould be killed. Attilas, who thought, that this mut needs be Aetius, he reolved to fight not caring which way it went, o this great Captain might dy, hoping afterwards to recruit another Army, when his enemies wanting uch a Conductor, he would preently make the Roman Empire a Tributary. The next morning therefore, Battle was given. I could give you a particular relation of all the Fight, for I was in it, and fought next Aetius that day; but it would be too long, and not pertinent to our dicoure: But o it was, that Attilas was overcome, and forced into his Camp, which he had fenced about with his Carriages: And becaue he had an opinion, the Enemy would fall upon him there, he caued a great heap to be made, of all the Saddles and Baggage of the Army, intending to et it on fire, and to burne there, rather then to fall into the hands of his enemies. I aw him that day, and the next morning alo; and one might plainly ee, by his minde and garb, the vanity which was in the oul of that man. But Prieus, Secretary unto Valentinian, who was ent into Syria, before he came into Pannonia, he told me, that he never in all his life aw a more imperious or haughty minded man, aiming at no lee, then the Monarchy of the whole world; and then gave himelfe the title of King of the Hunnes, Medes, Goths, Danes, and Gepides. He alo took upon him the title of, The terrour of the world and, the courge of god. And becaue I asked him, whether his tature was equall to his courage: he anwered me, That he was rather low then tall; that he had a large breat, a great head, little eyes, but quick and parkling; his noe flat, his hair browne; his trutting pace hewed the pride of his minde, and the whole Symmetry of his face, poke him to be a lover of War.

Moreover, he was ubtle; and though he was couragious, yet eldome ued to fight in peron, unlee in great extremity, reerving himelfe alwaies for a great neceity. As he was very cruell and inhumain to his enemies, o was he very weet and courteous to uch as ubmitted, or having offended, asked pardon; unto whom he would alwaies keep promie inviolable, and defend them againt all whomoever.

This character which Prieus gave of Attilas, at his return to Rome, did caue Honorica, Siter unto Valentinian, to deire a Marriage with him, as afterwards I hall tell you. But in the mean time, to return unto Aetius, be pleaed to know, kinde Silvander, that this great Captain being out of Attilas's danger, yet he knew, that he was entring into a greater; for, hould the Francks, Burgundians, and Viigots, come to know their own trength, they might much offend the Empire. To keep them therefore in ome fear, he thought it expedient to ave Attilas, thinking, that the fear
they would have of o great an enemy, would keep them alwaies united to the Emperour And becaue Thierres. King of the Viigots, was lain in this Battle, and Thorimond and Thierres, his Children, in revenge of their Father, would needs force Attilas in his Camp, he eemed to love them much more, then he hated Attilas, and advied them to return in all hate unto Tholoue, with the ret of their Army, let their Brothers who were left there, hould eize upon the King dome in their abence. Thorimond, who was of a ditrutfull nature, and knowing that he had three other Brothers in the Country, called Frederick, Rotomer, and Honorick, alo taking Aetius for his friend, without more delay, he took the Body of his Father, and went in all hate into Aquitain, where he was very well received, his Brothers having no uch intention, as Aetius perwaded him. Thee Forces being thus eparated from our Army, it remained o weak, that every one was of opinion, that it was bet to let Attilas go away; and that a prudent Captain will make a Bridge of gold ometimes for his enemy to pae over. Thus therefore this enemy of the Empire ecaped the hands of Aetius; and though this great Souldier had a good intention in it, yet afterwards, the Emperour took it very ill.

I alwaies followed Aetius in all this lat expedition, and durt not leave the Army, as well becaue everall occaions of fighting preented themelves, as becaue the fair Eudoxe commanded me o to do, being deirous I hould be abent from her, let any hould take notice of my familiarity with her: god only knowes how much it was againt my will, and how often I reolved to depart, etting all coniderations of duty and dicre •• behinde me; but, when I remembered the expree command which he had laid upon me, I could not diobey it. Yet I tayed therefore in the Army about twelve years, at the end of which time, this Battle which I have told you of was fought. 'Tis true that in this long exile, I received many Letters from Eudoxe, by which he did till continue unto me aurances of her favour. And becaue I had a great deire to do omething, which was worthy the amity of o great a Princee, I let pae no occaion of ignalizing my elfe, and giving tetimonies of my courage; by this means I got much reputation in the Army, but more in the opinion of the fair Eudoxe, who comming to the knowledge of it, by Letters which Aetius writ unto the Emperour, he rejoyced at it. I hall as long as I live remember a Letter which I received from her, after this great Battle; it was thus written.

body.head: Eudoxe's Letter unto Uraces.
body.p: IT is only my Cavalier, that can atonih his enemies by his arme, and his friends by his valour. Twice, to relieve the Roman Eagle, and recover it from the Francks and Gepides; thrice in one day, to et Aetius upon his Hore, when he was ready to be trodden in pieces by his enemies, are actions mot worthy of him, who has my heart. Since fortune hath hitherto econded your valour, I do forbid you to venture your elfe o far for the future, as you have done for the time pat: And I command you to preerve your elfe, not as your own, but as mine; have a care therefore of that which I give you to keep. And when Aetius leaves the Army, come you alo, and give me an account of it; that as you have hared with him in his pains and dangers you may hare alo with him in that honour and welcome, which all Italy will give him, and which I will prepare for you.

div.p:
During the time I was in the Army, I fell into a great intimacy with a young Roman Cavalier, called Olimbres, the ame you ee here; many good Offices paed betwixt one another, as in uch places many occaions fall out, which tie uch knots of friendhip, as never are looed, o as nothing ever ince could eparate us. This Cavalier, in repect of the amity betwixt us, was o much in favour with Eudoxe, that he was called to the Senate, and created a Senator: And certainly, next her, he pried my friendhip at the highet rate, unlee Placidias; for you mut know, that the intimacy of affection which was betwixt us, would never let us part, ince the firt beginning of our acquaintance, unlee it were in the ervice of each other. So as he eeing me reolved upon a return for Rome, when Aetius returned, he would needs come with me; and
ince, nothing could be o ecret, which was not communicated unto one another; I freely acquainted him with my affection to Eudoxe, and her favours to me, yet impoed a trict injunction of ecrecy upon him, and to take no notice of it let he hould be offended at me. This declaration was a caue, that he growing into familiarity with Eudoxe, he preumed o high, as to cat his eye upon Placidia, her Daughter, and began to court her, when he was not above twelve years of age, hewing in this a ympathy of humour betwixt him and me; for, it was at the ame age when I began to court her Mother, whom this her Daughter did much reemble. Olimbres was younger then I, being then not above even and twenty years of age, and I about thirty five, and the fair Eudoxe about thirty. The fair Eudoxe and I took notice of this growing affection, and Placidia did not give it any check. And though Olimbres was neither King nor Emperour, yet Eudoxe was not offended againt this affection, becaue Olimbres was very rich, and of as illutrious a Race, as any in Rome, his Father, Grandfather, and great-Grandfather, being all Senators, and oftentimes Conulls; o as upon thee coniderations, o it came not to the eye of the Emperour, he was not againt it, epecially for the friendhip ake, that was betwixt him and me.
I thought fit to acquaint you with thee things, before I related my reception by the fair Eudoxe, let I hould be contrained to interrupt my dicoure.

Know therefore, kinde Silvander, that we returning with Aetius, we were welcomed into Italy with all poible honour and thanks; the Roman-people made uch acclamations, when this great Captain entred into the Town, that never was a greater triumph. But the Emperour had no great liking unto all this; for, this grandure of courage which was in Aetius, the prudence wherewith he managed all • is actions, the applaud which the people gave him, and the honour which all Italy rendred him, did make Valentinian o jealous of the grandure of Aetius, as he ever after looked aquint upon him, and was apt to hearken and conent unto any ill counell that was given him. But for my part, who looked after no matters of State, but was wholly intent upon the favour of the fair Eudoxe, as oon as I arrived with Aetius, and had kied the Emperours hand, I went unto the Empree, where, pretending I had ome buinee with her from my Generall, I aw her in private, and received uch a welcome, as my twelve years eemed well imployed, ince army return I received uch extraordinary favours. Being at the lat contrained to go out of her Cloet, lot my too long tay hould beget upicion, I went unto the wie Iidore, as to one, whom, next Eudoxe, I loved and honoured mot; but, I found her o changed from what he was wont to be, as I wondred at it: I asked her the caue, but all the anwer I could get, was tears, at which I wondred more: I thought at firt, that cares of Marriage might perhaps be the caue; or ele perhaps, her Husband was very harp with her, or ele didained her for ome other; and this doubt made me horten my viit ooner then I would: But when afterwards I oberved, that Maximus did love her, and infinitely carraed her; and when I looked upon the riches and plenty of his houe, I was quite out of my firt opinion, and could not imagine what hould be the caue of her adnee. But one night, as I was talking with the fair Eudoxe, I undertood, that he came very eldome at Court, and was o altered, as he hardly knew her. I began preently to upect the buinee, though not all, yet in part; and enquiring whether the love of Valentinian continued; unto which he anwering, that he never took any notice of it: Believe it, my Princee, aid I unto her, that there is ome ill undertanding betwixt them; the Emperour hath done her ome dipleaure, or would do, and that keeps her from comming to the Court; for, you have not driven her away by any disfavour, her Husband is not unkinde, Dometick affairs cannot trouble her; and therefore her griefe mut proceed from ome higher caue: Were it any malady of body, it would appear. I do believe, (aid he) that you are in the right; for, he never ees me, but with tears in her eyes; and when the Emperour comes where he is, I hall ee her change preently, and go away as oon as poibly he can: I have often asked her the reaon, but I could never get her to tell me. Upon thee coniderations, he commanded me to go unto her from her, and ue my bet endeavours to dicover the caue; but all my labour was lot, and I could finde out nothing, but a great animoity againt the Emperour. When I made this report unto Eudoxe, I advied her to eem, as if he knew omething concerning Valentinian, and that perhaps would make her dicover more. And it hapned
as I did imagine; for, being one night all three in the Cloet of the Empree, and Iidore falling into her uuall tears, Eudoxe eemed unto her, as if he knew the caue; upon which, he began to confee unto us, the injury which the Emperour had done her, and fell into uch paionate expreions againt him, as the fair Eudoxe could not chue, but accompany her in her tears. I did extreamly compaionate this good Lady, and I mut confee, that had it been any but the Emperour, I hould have offered her my hand and word, in revenge of the wrong do <…> to her: but againt him, whom I acknowledged for my Lord, unto whom I had pro <…> my fidelity, and from whom I had received many benefits and much honour, <…> ld ooner have dyed, then entertained any thought of uch a thing, or attempted any thing againt him or his Etate. When they had condoled together a long while, and that I could peak unto Eudoxe: Madam, aid I unto her, me-thinks you have now a good occaion offered to make me the mot happy man alive. How, anwered he? You may, my fairet Princee, aid I unto her, revenge your elfe, by the ame armes you are injured, and do three or foure actions worthy of your elfe: Firt, you will be revenged upon him that hath wronged you; next, you will give ome atisfaction to your dear Iidore; and you will recompence me, and make me the mot contented man upon earth. The wie Iidore, who had not poke a long time, by reaon of her tears, did reply before the Empree: Madam, (aid he, and fell upon her knees) I protet unto you, I conceive, that this is the mot jut revenge and bet, that I can any way receive; nor is it reaonable, that he who does o ill requite a happinee, which the heavens have given him, hould enjoy it without the ame meaure that he ueth unto others. Madam, he is unworthy of you, and you are unjut, if you continue any longer his: The injury which he hath done unto you, his ingratitude unto the Emperour your Father, the dihonour he hath done unto your Houe, and the affront put upon the mierable Iidore, whom you have heretofore loved, does invite you to grant the requet, which Uraces makes unto you: What harm can come unto you by it? You do love this Cavalier, he is dicreet, none can ever know it, and you may this way weetly revenge an injury, which is any other way irreparable. The Empree miled, and anwered us: Perons that are interreted, are not compleat judges; you do both of you advie me to a revenge, which will offend me much more then before: If the Emperour have committed a fault, 'tis true, I do receive an injury by it; but ince I have not the dipoe of his actions, I am not culpable of his crime. Now hould I commit the ame fault, I hould be culpable as well as he. Fairet Princee, (aid I, and interrupted her) there is a great deal of difference betwixt the caes; for, you hall never hear me complain of any force, which you have ued upon me. I do believe, anwered he, that it would be an act of your free will; yet, let me tell you, that if you will be truly my Cavalier, you mut make it an act againt your will; for, that title does oblige you, to preerve my honour as deerly as my life. Madam, anwered I, I know not why you may not take this revenge, nor can I ee which way it hould concern your honour, ince none hall ever know it. If none do know it, anwered he, then where is the revenge, for that which is never known, nor reented, is as if it never were? But, my Cavalier, I hould be glad of revenge, o it could be without any injury unto my elfe; and ince this way cannot be, but upon that core, let us talk no more of it, and turn our thoughts upon omething ele. The wie dicoure of this great Princee, did top both our mouths; All we were able to anwer her, was, that he deerved a better Husband then Valentinian, or ele, Valentinian a wore Wife then Eudoxe.

However, the refuall of this way of revenge, which perhaps had contented the minde of this offended Lady, was a caue, that Iidore, never letting her Husband ret, did continually olicite him to revenge the injury, which both he and he had received. Maximus, who had not forgot it, but only eemed o, that he might the more home-ly execute his Deigne, he tudied night and day which way he hould bring it to pae: At lat, aiming at no lee revenge then the life of the Offender, he thought, that if he did attempt any thing againt the Emperour, his Forces that were in the hands of Aetius, and the authority and prudence of that great Captain, might be his own ruine; therefore he thought it much conducible unto his deigne, to take Aetius out of the world, and Valentinian being weak on that ide, might be the more eaily ruined: But when this coure was reolved upon, all the difficulty was, to execute it; for, the great
power of this valiant Commander was uch, as it was a very hard matter to hurt him by force; and his prudence and circumpection was o great, that any policy could not deceive him. He thought therefore, that there could be no better intrument of his ruine, then Valentinian himelfe, whom he knew to be of a very jealous nature, guided by vile and unworthy perons, and feared the very hadow of any danger. He addreed himelfe unto Heracles, who ever ince, as a ecret punihment of heaven, did bear the marks of Iidore's nailes in his <…> he acquainted him with the upicious grandure of Aetius, the honour all Ita ••
<…> him at his return, the applauds which every one gave him, the love which the people bare him, the affection of the Souldiers, the riches he had gotten in Gaul, his liberality, or rather prodigality towards all the credit he had amongt trangers, the correpondency he held with the Empire's enemies; and briefly, to confirm all upition, he intanced, how when he might have quite ruined Attilas, he aved him, and gave him paage, with a promie probably of aitance in his pernicious deigne: That ince, he hath made unto himelfe a friend, not only of the Viigots and Burgundians, who are already in Gaul, but alo of the Francks and Vandals, by the means of whom, he hath ruined the affaires of the Empire, both in Affrica and Spain: Alo by tampering with the Angles, hath lot Brittain and almot all America; and that his ambition was o great, that if he be not prevented, much dange may be expected to enue. That for his part, he concluded, that for the publick afty, it was expedient to banih him, not only out of the Empire, but out of the World, becaue a man o ambitious as he was, would never be won, either by fair means or oul. Heracles, who was naturally puillanimous and effeminate, and conequently very upitious and cruell, was eaily perwaded, that Aetius had ome ill deignes, and that it was requiite he hould be prevented. In this opinion, after thanks unto Maximus, for his care of the Empire and publick good, he went unto Valentinian into whom he infued uch aprehenions of great and udden danger, that he caued Aetius to be killed the very ame day by his Eunuchs; an act, which rendred him o odious unto every one, as from that time, he almot ceaed to be Emperour, being obeyed only as a Tyrant; and certainly, he ound preently after, that Proxmus, a Roman Knight, anwered him very truly, when he asked him, whether he had not done well in killing Aetius: As for that, (anwered he) I leave it unto your own judgment; but I know very well, that your left hand hath cut off your right. For, Aitlas moved by the love of Honorica, who had ent him her Picture, and being ill treated by her Brother, deired to be out of his hands, and to marry this Barbarian King: Moreover, being exaperated by his ambition, eeing his grand enemy Aetius dead, he put his Army into a poture, and fell upon Italy o furiouly, that our firt Forces which oppoed him were defeated, and none but Townes held head againt him, amongt the ret Aquilea, which, after a three years Siege, he took, and pulled it down to the ground. The Padoans at the ame time, and a People called the Venteians, flying from the fury of Aetilas, retired themelves into ome little Iles of the Adriatick Sea, with their Wives, Children, and Goods, and all that was pretious unto them, where draining the Lakes and Marihes which they found there, did plant themelves. At the firt, they called the place Rialte, meaning, as I think, Rive-al • e, which ignifies a high Bank, becaue the place there is higher then the ret. And ince finding the place convenient, they reted there, and afterwards called it Venice, and the Inhabitants Venetians. As oon as Aquilea was demolihed, all thoe that could ave themelves, did run to thee Iles which were about Rialte, and there built Guards. Thoe of Concorde Gaorly, thoe of Altine Vorcelly; briefly, thoe of Vincentia, of Bree, of Mantua, of Bergame, of Millaine, and of Pavia, eeing how afely thee firt lived in thoe places, they retired thither alo; and building together as well as they could, they became uch friends, that ince, they make but one People, who being compoed of everall Nations, could not agree upon the election of a King; but, to remove all jealouie, did agree upon common Lawes, and began to live in the way of a republick, ditinct, and eparate from the Empire.

The reaon why I have o long inited upon this, is, becaue all Atrologers, who have calculated the fate of thee fugitives, do ay, that never was Republick founded upon o happy a point as this; not for any great and large extent of Dominion, but for its long continuance, which eemes, as if it would never have an end, untill all things
ublunary mut have an univerall change; their lives are very pleaant their Lawes are very good, and they are excellent both in Peace and War; their Armies have been victorious; God has given them the Sea for their Walls, and does in every repect favour them, o as there is great likelyhood of future Grandure. Thee Iles do not now appear to be Iles, but a great City, built upon an infinite number of Bridges; the Sea is their treets, which running through in o many parts with o much art is admirable as well as their originall. But to returne to our <> from whence I digreed, after Attilas had taken Aquilea, he made towards Rome: and doubtlee had acked it, if Valentinian for want of corrage had not rendred himelfe Tributary; and conented that his Siter Honorica, hould be his wife. But this dihonorable peace being made, he retired into Pannonia, where upon his marriage night, and after abundance of wine and banquet, being gone to bed he was found dead in it, in the morning Some aid it was by bleeding at the noe which choaked him: others, that he was killed by one of his wives: which way oever it was, he dyed the very night of his marriage eaing the Empire, by this meane, both of feare and Tribute. Valentinian in this neceity, found what a fault he had committed in killing Aetius, having not one Captaine that could top this Barbarian nor any that cared for doing him ervice, ince he had hewed himelfe o bad a pay mater. For my part, I was ahamed to be in Italy, and ee things in uch trange deolation; and would have tryed to have ruined my elfe with it, had I not by Valentinians and Eudoxes command beene ent unto the Emperour Marcian to demand ayde, as oone as Aquilea was beieged: but I found Marcian very faint towards Valentinian, as well becaue of Aetius his death, as becaue Attiles ent him word, that his coming into Italy was onely to obtaine Honorica, with whom he was in love. And knowing that Valentinian did obtinately deny her unto him, he would not relieve him in this neceity into which he had brought himelfe by his ill government, and without reaon. Whilet I was negotiating this buinee, I fell o icke, that every one left me for dead and ome told Eudoxe that they aw me buried. You may imagine how he mourned for me: for I may truly ay that never any loved more then he me: my dieae was very dangerous being a potted Fever and I continued in it, above eight moneths, and a friend of mine did write unto Idore intimating my condition, for I was not able to write my elfe. In concluion, having tayed in Contaninople ome eighteene or twenty months to no purpoe, I reolved to take hip for Ravenna, where Valentinian was retreated with Eudoxe for his afety.

Italy, being thus ettled in peace Petronius Maximus the husband of wie Iidore. began to think upon his revenge, all things eeming to econd his deigne. He was a man of great Authority in the Empire; For he was Patriarch, and having a deigne of revenge, and happily to make himelfe Emperour, he had long beforehand gotten the love of the people and the Souldier; of the one by his liberality for he was very rich; and of the other by his popularity in econding all requets which was made for the eae and freedome of the people. And to render Valentinian odious unto every one, he advied him ecretly not to recompence the Souldiers either with honours or benefits, and to lay uch a load of taxes upon the people, as hould alwayes keepe them poore, and unable to attempt any novelty; and the better to accomplih his deigne, he exaperated all the friends of the great Aetius, as much as poible he could, and courted himelfe into intimat familiarity with them. The Emperour never doubted of any of thee things, for he knew Maximus was of opinion that it was bet to ruine Aetius: beides it was now o long ince the murder was committed, that he beleeved every one had forgotten it. And as for his injury done unto the wie Iidore, he beleeved he had not acquainted her husband with it, ince in o many yeares he never made hew of any dicontent Briefly, he lived in uch a carelee ecurity, that he permitted the greatet friends of Aetius to be about his peron. Which Maximus having long oberved, and eeking for a meanes how to atisfie the wie Iidore, who was continually putting him in minde of it, one day taking Thrailes apart who was one of the greatet friends which Aetius had, and who then had the guard of the Emperours peron, he et before his eyes the untimely death of his freind, and the carelenee of Valentinian, intimating what an eaie matter it was to take revenge upon him; in o much as he moulded him unto his owne will: And not being content with revenge only, he went further, and reolved to uurpe the Empire: Maximus told Thrailes that when
this was come to pae, he hould find full atisfaction and contentment. This reolution being taken, it was not long before it was put in execution: For Thrailes had the opportunity when he would, being alwayes neere the peron of the Emperour. One day therefore when Valentinian dyned in private, Thrailes and Maximus; did mierably murder him and Heracles the Eunuch, not for any offence that he made, but for the counell which he gave the •• perour when the wie Iidore was forced. Thus dyed Valentinian after he had raign •
•• irty yeares. Had I been neere his peron at that time, doubtles I had dyed in defence of him: For though the act which he had committed againt Iidore was wicked; yet there can be no caue whatoever, for lifting up a hand againt a Soveraine. Advie one may, but never chatie, much lee take that life away, which to ave he ought to loe his owne. I was then at the acrifice with the faire Eudixe, where the tumult was o great, that for afety of herelfe he was forced to go out of Rome. For Maximus having committed this homicide he knew that wickednee mut never be done by halves; and therefore finding the power in his hands, by the meanes of Thrailes, and ome whoe friendhip he had gotten, and alo being aured of the peoples conent, he preently caued himelfe to be elected and proclaimed Emperour: and all this without the leat oppoition though the Towne was full of tumult. Iidore was preently advertied of it, both by her husband, & by the common report of Valentinians death. And he had uch an inveterate hatred of him, that he could not believe unles he aw him dead. Therfore he left her houe & went to the Palace, and eeing his corps without a head, he waht her hands in his blood, & received uch a trange contentment in his death, that for very excee of joy, he fell downe dead. I was then, as I told you, with the faire Eudoxe, and would not leave her in uch a dyatrous fortune; but waited upon her whither oever he pleaed, in tetimony of my affection and fidelity. The hate we made was uch, that we hardly tooke any with us.
