And loing our way in the night we were forced to take up lodging in a wood: She had none with her but her two Daughters, Olimbres, and two young men who uually followed us, and who were much troubled in looking to our hores: So as there was none with her all the night but thee two young Princees; Olimbres, and my elfe. I did lye downe upon the ground, and he laid her head upon my breat, her two Daughters lay at her feet; and thus paed away the night as well as we could. Our intention was to get out of Italy, and to go unto Contantinople to Marcianus: For ince Maximus had killed the Emperor, and had taken upon him the title of Augutus, we feared he would be revenged upon her for the injury done unto Iidore. Though the night was very dark, and ad to the faire Eudoxe, yet I mut confee it was the weetet night unto me, that ever I had in my life: for I had my hand continually in her boome, and her lips cloe unto mine. Love knowes how I was thus tranported, and how oft I was ready to cat off all repect. Which he perceiving, and finding her Daughters to be both aleep, he whipered me in my eare, and aid thus unto me: Fie, fie, my Cavalier, do you think the gods are not enough incened againt me, but you mut needs provoke them more by mooving me to commit freh offences? After this he was ilent, and giving me a kis, he laid her head where it was before: this was a ufficient tetimony that he loved me, and after this favour I laid my mouth unto her eare, and aid thus unto her. But, my fairet Princee, what offence would it be, ince now you are nobodies but your owne? Would you have me tay untill another hall enjoy you before my face? Is it poible you hould reerve your elfe for one who never loved you, or for one that can never love you o well as I? Then he et her mouth unto my eare: My Cavalier, (aid he unto me) do not offer to offend againt god or my honour: and, to put you out of all thee doubts, receive this Vow. I doe vow and weare unto you Uraces, by the great god whom I adore, that I will never marry any man but you: and if what I have been, would permit me freely to dipoe of my elfe, I would take you to my husband this very houre: I do beleeve your affection uch unto me that after I have been Empree you would not have me hold a lee degree: Fortune perhaps will o dipoe of you, that I may with honour give you contentment, and then, cure me if I prove fale. In the meane time, live with this atisfaction, that I will never marry any but you: and for aurance of what I weare, take this kis, and then joyning her lips to mine, he continued very long upon them: Judge, kind tranger, whether I did receive the oathes with all my heart,
ince I never deired any thing more paionately. Then I anwered her thus: My fairet Princes, I receive this promie with uch a thankfull heart, and affectionate oul that in exchange I do entirely give you my elfe. And I do vowe and protet that I will never revoke my gift: but give me leave to weare by that great God, before whom you have made this promie that if ever it happen with your conent or otherwie, that any one do enjoy you as a husband, I will kill him with the ame hand which now you hold in yours: Unto which he aid in mine eare, I hall hold you for a faint hearted Traitor, if you do not: After this, he laid downe her head, and we paed away the night as we begun it: But alas I did not long enjoy this happinee of being with her, no more then my friend. Olimbres the happinee of being with Placidia: For the next morning, the Tyrant Maximus hearing that Eudoxe and her two Daughters were ecaped, he ent o many men everal wayes, as at the lat they found us, and carryed us back, do what Olimbres and I could in defence of ourelves: Who after everall wounds, and I more then Olimbres, we were carryed to this Tyrant: who not being contented with the murder of Valentinian and uurping the Empire, but would take a full revenge or rather a confirmation of his uurpation, and, to give it a gloe, would marry the faire Eudoxe: Oh heavens? what would he not have done to prevent it? But, Oh heavens! how did I reent it? I was o wounded both in my thigh and in my right arme, that I was not able to tirre out of my bed: o as I was diabled from doing her any ervice. In concluion, the Tyrant eeing that Eudoxe would not conent unto his will by faire meanes, he ued her o coorly that within twelve dayes after the death of Valentinian, he forced Eudoxe to be his wife. I heard the newes of it by Olimbres who was already recovered, and who never tirred from my beds ide. And when I knew not how to judge of this Act, but was in doubt of Eudoxes conent, I received a Letter from her which was this.

body.head: Eudoxes Letter unto Uraces.
body.p: IF Eudoxe be not mierable, then never any in the world was. I am in the hands of a bloody Tyrant, who hath forced me unto an unjut marriage: I call the great God by whom I ware unto you for a witnee that I never did nor wil conent unto it with my heart or will: I ummon you to the promie which you made at that time. If you permit me to lament my ad fortune to ee my elfe in his hands, who hath o unjutly ravihed me from you, I hall cure you, and accue you with want of affection: Keep therefore your word as I will mine, and let ate do her wort.

div.p:
What attempts would I not have dared, if my power had been equall to my will? or if my wounds had permitted me? But alas I was in a condition farre unfit to do any thing to another, when I was not able to run my elfe through with my word, when I heard Eudoxe was to be enjoyed by a Tyrant: and but for Olimbres, perhaps I had erved my owne turne, for he was o carefull of me that I could not do any thing to my elfe; but gave me o many diverting reaons to the contrary, that he kept me alive nine or tenne dayes till I was o happy as to ee the wie and faire Eudoxe enter into my chamber. She had obtained this leave of Maximus, telling him it was but reaonable to ee him who had been wounded in her defence: Maximus who deired to gaine me by faire meanes if poible, and having no upition of me, o handomely did we carry the matter, and o dicreet and faithfull was Iidore unto her Mitree, that Maximus permitted her. So he came to ee me, and leaving all her followers at the dore, he brought with her none but the little Princee Placidia, knowing that Olimbres would o entertaine her in dicoure, as he would not mind what he aid. She came to my beds ide, and itting downe offered to peake, but could not: At lat eeing teares flowe from mine eyes, and that I was not able to utter one word, he turned herelfe, o that none hould oberve our griefe. Thus ilently we at along while; and poke not one word. At lat having tooke a little courage I poke thee words. For ought I ee Madam, there is none loers by the bargain but Valentinian and Uraces: He in loing his life his Empire and his wife: and I the favour of the faire Eudoxe. But alas his loe is nothing unto mine, for being dead he has lot all enibility of
miery, and I that am alive can onely be called mierable becaue I do reent my miery. She anwered me, firt with her teares which he could not retraine, and then by her words: Will you, my Cavalier, help to augment my griefe, and in lieu of giving me ome comfort and pitty, will you by your reproaches make me more mierable? But it is well done; I am contented to be killed, ince I ee Uraces does not love me. Oh heavens, cryed I, as loud as I could, being offended at her words, and orry I had cryed o loud, for two or three came running to me to know what I ayled, to whom I anwered that my wounds pained, (but the paine was gone) and when they were gone alo I began to peake againe. How Madam? Does not Uraces love you? Can you ay it, and not bluh? are you not afraid the heavens will punih you for the wrong you do me? Uraces not love you Madam? how long have you knowne him changed? was it before Valentinian dyed? No, you have writ the contrary. Was it ince his death? No urely, you cannot chue but remember my vowes and promie. But perhaps it is ince the wrong you have done me in giving your elfe unto this cruell Tyrant. If o, tis time indeed to change my mierable life for a happy death: but you may thank Olimbres that I live, for he onely has hindred me from dying. But ince I live, you may be certaine, that you hall live no longer then till I recover o much trength as to take a life away: though you do not love me yet you might well have rendred me ome tetimony of pitty. But what pitty or compaion can I expect from the wife of a Tyrant? how can I ever think you any thing but a peece of ingratitude? if you would live and enjoy your tyranicall husband: do you your elfe reach me my word, that you may ave your own life and his, and ee that it is not want of will but trength that keeps me alive. She not being able to endure I hould continue any longer, coming neerer anwered me thus In aying that Valentinian and you are the only loers, you might very wel have put me into the number, for ince you do not love me, my los is the greatet of all: Did I not feare our dicoure would be oberved, I would ay more, and weare that I love none but you, and beeech you to beleeve that as you are kept alive by force, o revenge keeps me, for I do not take this Maximus either for husband or Emperour; but for the mot cruell Tyrant that ever was in Rome: Were it not in deire and hopes of this revenge, I would not live a minute, and ee you thus wounded. But heaven which is jut does promie me revenge for the blood of Valentinian, and for the wrong which is done unto Uraces and the mierable Eudoxe. In the meane time (my Cavalier) take corrage and recover of your wounds as oone as you can, for there is no other meanes to come unto our deired ends, but that. This declaration was comfort enough to my oul, in o much as I recovered of my wounds very uddainly: For this time, he would ay no more, but went away, to prevent all upition of our deigne. But about three or four dayes after, he came to ee me againe, told me the manner how Maximus had killed Valentinian, and how he intended to marry her, as he aid himelfe, at which he was o extreamly offended as he reolved to dipatch him ome way or other, out of the world. Oh my Princee, (aid I unto her) you mut do nothing imprudently, for if you once failn your enterprie, you can never after hope to attempt it without abundance of danger to your elfe; beides, you would do me very great wrong, if you employ any other hand but mine in the blood of him who is the Parricide of my Soveraine, and the raviher of you. This is the coure which I conceive bet to be taken: Valentinian, long before Attilas turned his armes againt Italy, had concluded a peace with Generick King of the Vandals, and left all that he had in Affrica unto him, upon condition he hould be his friend and confederate. This Barbarian hath ever ince made great demontrations of love unto the Emperour, and would never take part with any that were his enemyes: Make knowne unto him the wicked machinations of Maximus; acquaint him with the murder of Valentinian; hew him how he hath uurped the Empire: complaine unto him of the force he offereth unto you, and ummon him unto the promie upon which Affrica is his: Feare not but he will relieve you: for though he be a Barbarian, yet he is generous, and it is their Nationall vertue to keep promie unto death, and more unto the dead then unto their loving friends: Now, to make ure work, becaue all thee Barbarians are naturally greedy and covetous, offer him the Empire, that he may be more eager upon it: tell him what friends and meanes you can make for him in Italy. And that you are able to make his way eay unto him, by the aitance of thoe who are adherents unto you againt the murderer of the Emperor: now though I
mut need ay, it is hard to endure, that any Barbarian hould ever Lord it in Italy; yet better o, then to be without revenge. Eudixe conidering a while upon what I aid, did anwer me, that all the difficulty in the buinee would be, how to treat o ecretly and peedily with this Barbarian, that he might be in Italy before it was dicovered; and conidering my preent condition, he knew not whom to employ, that would be quick enough in the expedition; that he had rather die a hundred deaths, then ever Bed with this Tyrant; that he could put it off a while, by counterfeiting icknee, but that could not be long. I advied her to continue her counterfeiting and the better to delude the eyes of thoe who aw her, that he hould every morning ue the ome of Brimtone to her face and hands, which would make her look o pale, that every one would believe her really ick. As for dipatching into Affrica, it was my misfortune to be in uch a cae, that I could not; and beides, I had made a vow never to go out of Italy, untill I had killed the Tyrant: But that he might very well trut my dear friend Olimbres, who, I was ure, would be both faithfull and diligent in her commands, and that I would anwer for his fidelity and capacity. She, who deired nothing more then revenge, and to be out of this Tyrants power, referred the whole management unto me, and deired me to dipatch him with intructions, which I did; and Olimbres hewed himelfe o wie and diligent, that within fifteen daies he arrived at Carthage, negotiated o with Generick, as he dipoed him unto Revenge, unto Uurpation, and to the Plunder of Rome; inomuch as within two months after, he et foot in Italy, with three hundred thouand fighting men, compoed of Affricans, Moors, and Vandals, which put uch a terrour into the City and all the Province, that every one fled to the Mountains, Woods, and Rocks. And becaue we did olicite him to come traight to Rome, that he might take the Tyrant, he made all the hate that poible he could, without any halt, or tay in any Townes by the way.

This put Maximus into uch a fright, as without eeking to make any reitance, he permitted every one to hift for themelves as well as they could, and for his part, he fled into the Mountains with the ret. I was by this time well recovered of my wounds; and had not the fair Eudoxe charged me to the contrary, I had executed my deigne; but he till retrained me, untill for more afety, the Vandal was neerer the Town. But now, eeing that in lieu of defending his uurped Etate, he left it as a prey unto the Barbarians, I was affraid let he hould ave himelfe, and that when Generick had left Italy, he would then returne againe unto his Tyranny. This was the reaon why I followed after him, with ome of my friends, and overtook him upon the banks of Tiber; and though mot of my Company was tired out, yet I reolved to charge him, and let him go no farther. I challenged him therefore, and charged him with his wickednee, in the death of the Emperour, in the uurpation of Italy, and in the force ued againt Eudoxe; and being guilty of all, he refued to fight with me, but purred away as fat as he could: At which his own men were o ahamed and animated, that all joyning with my friends, they rid after him, and by chance, my Hore having better heeles then the ret, I firt overtook him, and gave him uch a blow upon the head, that he fell to the ground, where thoe that came after me, dipatched him out-right, o much was every one incened againt him, for his perfidie and cowardie. Thus ended this Tyrant, o hated by his own men, as when he was dead, they cut him in pieces, and threw him into the River, as if they would wah away his crimes in that manner; but all the water in the River Tiber could not wah away halfe of thoe which he had committed, againt the Emperour, againt the fair Eudoxe, and againt the State.

I have hitherto related the mierable accidents which befell Eudoxe and me but thee which I have now to relate, are much more dyatrous; for alas; they have brought me into this mierable condition in which you ee me. Now did Generick enter the City and he found no reitance, not o much as a dore hut againt him. Eudoxe received him, giving him the title of Augutus, and telling him, that the Empire owed their liberty unto him; and, briefly, did him all the honour, and gave him all the thanks, that was poible. But this Barbarian, in lieu of being more gentle and affable by thee favours, they made him more haughty and intolerable; In lieu of friendhip, he proved an enemy, and carried himelfe, not as a Prince who came to relieve a ditreed Princee,
but as a Conquerour, who by force of Armes, after a long War, had conquered an enemies Country. He gave up the Towne for plunder, and making no difference between acred and prophane things, he pillaged the Temples of all their Veells and Treaures, and of all thoe Rarities, which the people and Roman Emperours for many ages, had, out of their devotion, preented unto them. And after this ad confuion had lated fifteen daies, he ran over mot part of Italy, till he came to Parthenopea, where he did nothing but wate and poile the Country; and when he was even glutted with poile and rapine, he returned into Affrica, having loadned his Ships with the riches and rarities that he found in the City. But alas, not being contented with thee inanimate things, he ravihed away with him uch perons, as he thought might be uefull to him, and amongt the ret, Oh heavens! he carried away the fair Eudoxe and her two Daughters, Eudoxe and Placidia: I was then cloe by this deolate Princee, when he ent her word, that he was to prepare for her departure within three daies after: She fell into a wound at the meage, and was very neer death; but I wih to heaven, that he and I had both dyed, rather then carried captives into Affrica. Oh heavens, how can I remember this accident and live? I went out of Rome with ome of my friends, not acquainting any with my deigne, not o much as my deer friend Olimbres, with whom I could not peak when I went, becaue he was with Generick, who had taken him into his friendhip, ince his Affrican voyage, and who by Eudoxe's command never tirred from him that he might ave the Town as much as poible; o as at his requet, he did many favours unto everall perons. I ent afterwards to him, to the end he hould aure Eudoxe, that I would either get her out of thee barbarous hande or die. She, who had a very olid and ound judgment, did know very well, that my enterprie was impoible by reaon of that numerous body of men that Generick brought with him, which exceeded the number of three hundred thouand men: Had he known where I was, doubtlee he had kept me from executing my deigne; but, let I hould be urpried by the Vandals, I never tayed a whole night in a place I had rallied together about a thouand Hore, and if I had had a little more time perhaps I had got up uch an Army, as hould have eaed thee Barbarians of our poils, which they were carrying into Affrica, or at leat, hould have felt the weight of a Roman Arme; but I had only eight daies time. And not being able to endure they hould carry away Eudoxe, I reolved to fight this great and terrible Army, with this little handfull of men, thinking my life could not end upon a more noble account, nor in a better caue. Having ambucado'd my elfe in a Wood, neer the way of Hotia, I aw ome part of this great Army march in very bad order; but my aime being only at Eudoxe, I kept my elfe till cloe, till I aw ome Chariots comming, in which I perceived ome Ladies; and uppoing them to be the ame I did expect, I encouraged my men, telling them, that this would be an act worthy of a Roman name. Upon etting purs to my Hore, and they mot couragiouly following me, we charged thee Chariots, whoe Guard was above ten thouand Barbarians. I hal not relate the paage of this charge, for it is impertinent: But o it was that we routed them; and had Eudoxe been there, as I thought he was doubtlee I had delivered her out of thee barbarous hands: but, as ill luck was he was till behinde; and thoe Ladies which I aw, were uch, as had been taken in the City and Country, and were to be carried with the ret of the Booty into Affrica. Oh heavens! how was I grieved, when I aw my elfe thus mitaken? and had all the Army on my back; for, upon this Tumult, the Vanguard recoyled, and the Reerguard advanced and drew into Battalia; o as I was environed on all ides with o great a number of enemies, as we could expect nothing but ruine: Some ran away, others tayed; for my part I laid me down amongt the dead, and was tripped of my clothes as they were; and it was happy for me, for my clothes being carried by a Souldier, Eudoxe knew them and hewed them unto Olimbres, who would not leave her. All that he aid, was: I ee, Uraces, at the lat hath met with that Ret, which Fortune ever denyed him. Upon this expreion, he wouned in her Chariot. Olimbres running after him who had my clothes, he asked where he got them; and being told the place, he went preently unto it, and ought till he found me; how ad was he, when he aw me! However, he got leave of the Vandal, to do me the lat office of buriall: He would needs return to Rome, and have me carried alo upon Boughs. I was o jogged
in the carriage, that I gave ome ignes of life. Olimbres eeing this, was beyond all meaure glad, and brought me into the firt houe they came unto, where I received uch Cordialls, as I recovered out of my long woun. You may imagine, Silvander, how glad I was, when carrying my friend to his grave, I found him alive; thoe who aw me did plainly ee, that his life was as deer unto me as my own; yet, we had both been happy had we ended our daies then, for then I hould not have grieved at the abence and ravihment of the fair Eudoxe, nor Olimbres, at parting from his dear Placidia. This conideration made me reolve upon death, as oon as I heard this peridious Generick had carried Eudoxe and her two Daughters away; but the great care which my friend had of me, kept me from the execution of my deigne, as long as my wounds kept me in bed. But when I had recovered my elfe of thee wounds, and was able to get upon a Hore, I tole away as ecretly as poibly I could from him; and taking the way towards Tucany, I hid my elf in the Appennine Mountaines, intending to die with hunger or ome uch hardhip, not being willing to hed my blood, for fear of offending the great god, who puniheth Homicides. At the lat, the languihment of this life, made me reolve upon a more udden death; and when, cating off all conideration of heaven, I would have run my word to my heart, my dear Olimbres came, and tayed my arme, o by this means, gave me a life the econd time. Then afterwards, when I till perited in my reolution to effect my intentions, a young man came in, whoe beauty and widome did make us think, that comming in uch a nick of time, he was ome meenger ent from god, purpoely to divert me from my deigne. I mut confee, that at the firt I thought him o, and was o obedient to his words, that I had no minde to kill my elfe, hoping to receive from him ome upernaturall aid; o as being thus deceived, we all three went unto the next Town, to get Olimbres dreed of a great wound which I gave him, when he offered to take the word out of my hand, where with I would have killed my elfe. But when I undertood, that this young man was a Seguian, as you are, and that he came to the place where I was, by meer chance, I confee, I took a tronger reolution of dying then before, and doubtlee had, but for this young man, whoe name was Celadon, as afterwards he told me, who ued uch trong arguments, and gave me uch good reaons, that I reolved to tay till the recovery of Olimbres. There was in this place an old and grave Chirurgeon, (who dreed the wound of my friend) whoe age and travells in everall Countries, had got him great knowledge and experience: this man took peciall notice of our orrowes; and as one word may ometimes dicover what we deire to keep ecret; o I did not o well diemble the matter, but he did partly upect my deigne; o as one day he took me aide, and aid thus unto me: Think it not trange, Sir, that I, unasked, intrude my elfe to give you ome counell; my age, your merit, and my duty to god, invites me to it; take therefore in good part what I hall ay. I know, that you are eized with extream orrowes, and that you have a deigne againt your own life. Do not offer it, for god, after your death, will mot everely punih all murderers of themelves. And beides, to kill ones elfe, argues a defect in courage, as if you durt not look a dyater in the face; and as thoe who fly for fear of their enemies, o uch as kill themelves for fear of any dyater, do flye out of the world for want of courage, and becaue they dare not abide one of fortune's blowes. God hath given unto man judgment and prudence, to make his election by olid and ound reaon; and becaue man, being poeed with paion, can neither judge nor chue aright, he hath given him a communicative oul, to the end that making choice of one or more friends, he may ask counell of them, in all matters of importance. And becaue friends are very often intereted in their friends buinee, this god, not leaving man without a good guide, hath given him Judges and Kings, to order and decide all manner of doubts and controveries.

This great Creator of men, loving them as his Children, would furnih them with all that is neceary both to live and to die; and to that end hath inpired the Mailians, to contitute prudent Judges; it eeming unto them, that death is no injury, but a tribute of nature, and therefore it would be unjutly done to deny that remedy unto uch, as with reaon do demand it: And therefore they have erected a publick Theater in their City, where they ue to keep poyon, and will give it unto him to drink, who hall deire to die, if it be o, that the Councell of ix hundred do adjudge that his reaons why he deires death; be good.

I do hint this unto you, Sir, that if you be oppreed with any ad dyater, you may rid your elfe from the tyranny of it, by the judgment of o many, worthy, wie, and prudent perons. For my part, becaue you hall not think I give you uch counell, as I will not take my elfe, I am reolved within thee few daies to make my addree unto them, being incited thereunto by a contrary opinion unto yours; for, I have lived along age, full fourecore and nineteen years, in great felicity, according to my rank and quality; rich, in the gifts of fortune, above any of my profeion; happy in Children, beloved of my Neighbours, eteemed of every one; and as I have lived, o I would die happily; I would not tay o long, as untill my hundreth year, let I hould tempt ome dyater, to make me die mierable; having learned, that if Priamas had dyed a little before the loe of his Town, he had been the greatet Prince of all Aia.

This good old man ued this language unto me, which had no mall operation upon my thoughts; for, as oon as I came to Olimbres, I made this relation unto him: and the reult was, that we would all three for company go unto this place, and put an end unto our daies. But heaven would not have it o, for he dyed when you relieved us. Thee two Women which you aved, were his two Daughters, who came along with him, to cloe his eyes, if the Councell of Six Hundred had granted him the poyon. We thought our elves obliged to ait them, and not to forake them, till they had found the Corps of their dead Father, and given their lat duty unto him, who never had any misfortune in his life; and to the end, that after his death he might be happy alo, in being interred by the hands of his own Children.

But to return unto that which concernes us. We were fully reolved to proecute our deigne, and to make it appear, that it was not the loe of Etate, or hipwrack, or any uch, did move our wills unto it, being very rich, and owners of great poeions, we ent unto our houes for our ervants to come unto us, with a coniderable umme of many.

Thus Uraces ended, moving me infinitely to compaionate his fortune and Eudoxe's. And having anwered, that I have een many, who had petitioned the Counell of Six Hundred for this poyon, and that it was granted unto ome, and refued unto others. He deired in all favour to keep it ecret, let ome friend unto Maximus hould prevent them, and hinder their death. Then he asked me, how the Requet or Petition ued to be preented, in what termes, and what ceremonies were ued. To which I anwered, that the thing was very eay; one to addree himelfe unto a Magitrate, epecially appointed to receive uch Petitions: That he would make report of it unto the Councell of Six Hundred: That none ever ued to name themelves, becaue there hould be no repect of perons, and the Petition mut be in this Forme.

body.head: A Petition, Preented unto the Councell of Six Hundred, demanding the Poyon.
body.p: THe high and overaign Councell of ix Hundred, are humbly requeted to grant unto the Petitioner, the favourable Cure of all human mieries, by vertue, and according to the age and generous Lawes of the Mailians, who are ordained Judges upon earth betwixt Fortune and Men. And to that end, he humbly beeecheth, that a certain day may be asigned, on which he may produce his reaons and arguments before you. And o god preerve and augment your Grandure.

div.p: They deired a Copy of this, to the end they might not mitake; and having promied one unto them, I continued. After they have aigned you a day, (aid I unto them) and after you have laid before them the occaions, which move you unto a deire of death, which mut be done in as clear and hort a method as you can, without naming your elves or any other: If they finde your matter jut, they will grant your requet. When I had poken thee lat words, I plainly aw by the tears of Uraces, that he did deire death; but I perceived, that Olimbres was invited unto it, only out of affection unto his Companion, from whom he would never part.

After a few dayes, thus pent, their ervants came unto them out of Italy being many in number, and bringing abundance of riches with them. All things being then in readynee, they entreated me to accompany them before the Judges, and to do them this lat and lamentable office. Which I did with much orrow, for I loved them, and was afraid the Councell would think their requet jut. They preented their Petitions, and were aigned the third day after; for that was the terme which was given them, in which they might change their minds. But Uraces was contant, and reolute in his opinion: and with Olimbres preented themelves both being very well habited and attended: And being called before the Councell, they were asked their reaons, why they would dye; Uraces briefly anwered thus.

div.head: The Requet of Uraces.
div.p: I Deire to dye, Masilian Lords, becaue life is dipleaing, unprofitable, and hamfull unto me; dipleaing, becaue loving and being loved by a mot faire and vertuous Lady, he is carried away a lave into a trange Country; unprofitable, becaue the raviher is infinitely puiant above my trength: And hamfull; becaue, having worne a thouand times unto this Lady, that as long as I lived, he hould not wrong her: It is a mot abominable hame for me to live and uffer it. Now the great God having given life unto men, for their good, there is no reaon it hould be enjoyed if it be bad. For this caue, age Sirs, I do preent my elf before you, in hopes to obtaine that comfort which you do not ue to refue unto mierable men: and be mot certaine of this, that you did never grant it to any more mierable, nor who deired it more then my elfe.

The peech of Uraces, caued every one to fixe their eyes upon him, admiring his contancy and reolution of language for he did not alter either in voyce or complexion. Then Olimbres addreed himelfe in this manner.

div.head: The Requet of Olimbres.
div.p: I Deire to dye, Masilian Lords, for the ame reaons which my freind hath formerly alledged; for as he, o I, have lot her I love; and more, becaue I ee that he my friend deires to dye. For loving him above all the world, all the world is nothing to me if he leave it. Amity is nothing but an union of two wills; and I do not love him, hould I conent unto a diunion. It is againt the duty of any man of honor, to ceae loving, where once he is with reaon fixed: all reaon contraines me to this amity: for he is trancendently vertuous: an unparalelled friend, and I owe him my life. Were it not an aburd contradiction of reaon, if I hould faile in poynt of friendhip? Therefore, grave and wie Sirs, ince heaven has ordained you for a comfort unto the afflicted, deny not this remedy unto me, let you hould contradict your owne lawes and ordinances, which you have for many ages adjudged to be o jut and acred.

Every one admired the reolution of this contant friend. The Councell, after a long debate was in doubt whether they hould grant or deny their demands, untill the Principall of the Councell by the advice of them all, asked Uraces, whether he would permit his friend to dye? Unto which he anwered, No. And why? (asked the wie Mailans.) Becaue (anwered Uraces) he ought to live and comfort, if he can, his unfortunate Lady and mine. Have you (aid the Masilian) permiion from the Lady that you love, to dye becaue you are not able to relieve her? I have not (anwered Uraces) for I never aw her ince this misfortune happened: But I dare aure you, that her generous heart would conent unto it; and if he were in my place he would make the ame requet which I do. The Lords of the Councell after this, did long argue the matter amongt themelves: And it was reolved and agreed upon; and the Principall with a grave and audible voice gave this Judgement.

div.head: The Judgement of the Councell of Six Hundred.
div.p: UPon the requet preented unto us by thee two Petitioners to obtain the conolation of all humane mieryes, the Councell doth ordaine that before it be granted unto the firt Petitioner, he hall procure the permiion of the Lady whom he loves, to dipoe of his life, and upon a certificate of the ame, his deire hall be granted. As for the other; ince his friend will not conent unto his death he is declared incapable of obtaining the favour. And becaue both of them are lovers and loved, and becaue a lover ought not to live for himelfe, but for the Peron whom he loves, therefore by conequence he neither can nor ought to dipoe of his life, without the permiion of her whoe he is.

Oh heavens? (cryed out Uraces having heard this doome) how hall I pae away my ad dayes and nights? Then making an humble reverence to the Lords, he went from the Councell, but o ad that he could not obtaine his demand, as every one did admire the contancy and firme deire of death. Olimbres was not o eager of it, becaue his deire of death was onely to accompany his friend: and therefore was very glad of the denyal. Then they retyred to their lodgings, much lamenting their mierable fortunes. And the noye was pread not onely all over the Towne but alo through the Country, that two great Roman Perons were come purpoely to demand the poion. Upon this, a great Atrologer, who was deirous to know who they were, came to viit them. This man was very old, and had wholly addicted himelfe unto that cience, o as he was growne very admirable in predictions. This man being advertied of their deigne, fearing that their corrages dipoing them o eager of death, and the poion being denyed them, that they would have recoure unto the word, he deired he might advie them according to the rules of his Art. With this intention he went unto them one morning when they were alone in their chamber. He deired me to be his conducter becaue we had ome acquaintance, when I was a tudent there. I hall not make any relation of the particular dicoure which they had, for they were very long. But o it was that punctually knowing the time of their Nativities: having long contemplated upon their Phyiognomies and hands, and having drawne ome lines in paper which he parted, and then joyned together; he aid thus unto them. Sirs, live, and preerve your elves for a better eaon, which the heavens do promie unto you. As for you (aid he unto Uraces) you hall recover her whom you have lot, by the meanes of a man whom of all the world you love bet: you hall enjoy full contentment and poee her many yeares, in the ame Towne where your love firt begun. And you (aid he unto Olimbres) you hall marry her whom you love: you hall bring her back unto her Country with her Mother; you hall not dye till an Emperour of the Wet be made. Thee things which I tell you are infallible, and nothing can divert them.

The reputation of this man, had uch an influence upon Uraces that he reolved to believe him, and follow his counell; and conjured him by the great God whom he adored, to ait him with his bet advie. Then he propounded unto him the hatred of Generick, and the danger he hould incurre by going into Affrica. You mut, (aid he) end back all your dometiques into Italy, and make a hew as if you would kill your elfe, to the end the report of your death may be pread abroad: ome few dayes after, you mut deigne your elfe in the habit of a lave and put your elfe into the ervice of your friend, who may carry you into Affrica where he hall meet Generick, and doubt not but that being thus unknowne, you will compae your deires. I would advie you to go unto Contantinople, there tay till Olimbres come to you with Eudoxe and Placidia: for I finde by my obervations that he will bring them thither. But I have three reaons to ay that you mut go into Affrica. Firt becaue I do foreee that you mut be taken for a lave, and you cannot avoyd it: Secondly, that perhaps your tay there will be very vexatious to you in being o long without your friend, and not eeing her you love and latly that you may ait Olimbres with your counell, who will have occaion to tand in need of it. Moreover, it is very neceary that you make • report run, that you are dead, to take away all upition from Generick, and all the
ill will that he may conceive againt Olimbres; if you tay either in Greece or in Italy, it is impoible, but ome or other will dicover you. Thus did this wie man advie him, and after he had committed him to heavens cutody, he went home to his houe.

Uraces having conulted long with himelfe what to do, at the lat reolved to oberve him punctually in every thing; and therefore one evening, having gotten a bladder full of blood cloe to his ide, under his clothes, he went to walk by the Sea-ide, with mot of his dometicks following him, and many others of the Towne, where after he had made a long and ad dicoure of his mieries, and complained extreamly againt his refuall of poyon, faigning that he would not live any longer, he thrut a knife into his ide, and made the blood in the bladder run out in great abundance, o as every one thought him dead. Then getting from amongt them, he threw himelfe into the Sea, leaving us his Cloak in our hands, Olimbres and I eeming, as if we endeavoured to hold him. It was now twilight, and he could wim very well, o as plunging himelfe over head, and wimming under water, we preently lot the ight of him. Every one was tricken with wonder, Olimbres lamented extreamly, purpoely to make it be believed, that his friend was dead: Then telling what his name was, the newes of his death was divulged far and neer. In the mean time, I went unto the place where I knew he would retire himelfe, and bringing him the habit of a Slave, and lodging him in a poor houe, I accommodated him with all things requiite.

It hapned the next morning, Olimbres eeming to earch for the body of his friend, found the Corps of the good old Chirurgion, and bringing it unto his two Daughters, they rendred him the lat office of a Sepulcher, as if heaven would not let this happy old man want any dues that belonged unto men, after his death: His Daughters erected him a Tombe, and I, at their requet, did write his Epitaph, which was fixed upon it. A few daies after, Olimbres ent all his Dometicks, together with thoe of Uraces's, and the two Daughters of the old Chirurgion, into Italy; and taking others, he went with his friend, diguied like a Slave, into Affrica, much deiring my company: But, ince my detiny was, to obey him who brought me up, I would not diobey his will.

This, Madam, (aid Silvander unto Leonida) is all that I know concerning the fortune of Uraces, who for his fidelity, deerves all manner of contentment. Leonida would have anwered, if Hylas had not tept in and interrupted her: Did you ever hear (aid he) of uch a fool, the veryet fool that ever made profeion of any love? What! erve all his life for no other contentment, but to be called, My Cavalier, and to call her, My fairet Princee, or at the bet, to have but ome few dry and mierable kies? And this, forooth, mut be thought enough, to make him run o many hazards of his life, to pil o much of his blood, to demand poyon, and at lat to turn lave. For my part, I think he is rightly erved, and let him take all his labour for his paines; let him wear the habit of a lave into Affrica, for all his life has been nothing but a lavery. Adamas and all the Company could not chue but laugh at the opinion of Hylas, and had it not been upper-time, I believe he had not paed without an anwer. But the Druide roe up, and taking Tircis by one hand, and Phocion by the other, he took a turne or two in the Gallery, whilt upper was etting upon the table, and every one oberved what he thought mot rare; and amongt the ret, Tircis looking upon a King, armed with many Pennons and ornaments hanging about him, with a countenance full of gravity: Father, (aid he unto him) I beeech you tell me, who is this, who bears upon his Shield of Gules, three Diademes, Or? It is Pharamond, aid the Druide; the firt King of the Francks, who made the Romans feel the weight of his victorious Armes in Gaul. And who is that, continued Tircis, that is next unto him, that beareth Azure, a Cat, Argent, armed Gules? It is (aid Adamas) Gondioch, King of the Burgundians, who took this Animall for his Armes. And, who the other, (aid Tircis) who bears Or, three Ravens,, with their wings diplayed, Proper, and purple Tallons? It is (anwered Adamas) the King of the Gepides, called Ardarick. Who is he, replyed Tircis, who bears Gules, a Falcon, with wings diplayed, Or, crowned Argent? I need not ask you, for you have already told me, that he is called Attilas, King of the Hunnes. It mut needs be confeed, that you have been very curious, not only in getting the Pictures of o many illutrious perons, but alo in adorning them, and arming them as they were wont to be.

In the mean time, Hylas, who held Alexis by her hand, he was dicouring upon other ubjects; for, being growne deperately in love with her, he could not upon any termes leave her. Adamas, who took notice of it, and was very glad that he was o mitaken, becaue it would more delude others. When he was going out of the Gallery, he turned towards Hylas: Well, hepheard, (aid he unto him) which is the Piece whom you think fairet in the place? Hylas made preent anwer, that it was Alexis. But, aid Adamas, I mean, of the Pictures which you have een. Have een! aid Hylas, nay, I have no eyes to look upon any thing but Alexis: And if you look for any atisfaction to that quetion, you mut aske Tircis; for thoe are Pictures only of dead perons, and he loves uch above any that are alive. I am able to anwer for my elfe, aid Tircis, that I do ee none fairer then Alexis, nor which pleaeth me better. How (aid Hylas, who began to be jealous) Hylas, I ee then, is not the only incontant man in the Company, ince you are growne a liker of any. But Mitree, (aid he unto Alexis) let it not trouble you, for he is better for being incontant. Why, Servant, (aid Alexis) do you ay o? Becaue, aid he, that he was wont to love none but dead people. Do you not ee, replyed Tircis, that if I love death, I mut needs love Alexis, ince her beauty is able to kill as many as death it elfe? Ah! (replyed Hylas) if you take it in that ene, I have done: But to make us both contented, let her give death unto Tircis, and life unto Hylas. Both you and I hall be very well contented, replyed Tircis, in receiving either a life or a death o weet. Upon this word, every one going out of the Gallery, they at down to upper, which being ended, and a good part of the night pent in dicoure, they were all conducted to their Chambers, where having reted themelves, they went the next morning to their own Homes, o atisfied with the courteous civility of Adamas, and with the beauty and good behaviour of Alexis, that every one did highly commend them; but epecially Hylas, who not being able to hold from extolling the perfections of his new Mitree, by fortune they met with Atrea, Diana, and Phillis, in the great Meadow, with Madonthe, Laonice, Pallinice, Cyrcinea, and Florice, which expected their return, to hear a report of the beauty of Alexis, which they had already heard of. And Phillis addreing her elfe unto Lycidas: Well, hepheard, aid he unto him, how do you like this o much cryed up Beauty? I will not anwer you, aid he, untill you have asked Hylas. Well, Servant, aid he unto Hylas, what reports will you afford us? And becaue he anwered not: What, Servant, aid he not peak unto your Mitree? You my Mitree, aid he, and I your Servant! No, no, if you think it, believe me, you are mitaken; for I aure you, I think of nothing lee. How! Servant, (aid Phillis, and eemed to be troubled) will you not have me to be your Mitree? Good hepheardee, aid he, do not ue the word, Servant, and the word, Mitree, o familiarly, for they are not eaonable amongt us. At what Game (aid he) have I lot you, Hylas? At the Game of the Fairet, anwered he. Do you not know, that it was alwaies my cutome, to leave thoe I loved, as oon as I found one that was fairer: Aske Florice, Cyrcenea, Palliuice, Madonthe, and Laonice, if I did not o by them: If none of thee will tell you, then ask Phillis, your very good friend; for if he will confee the truth, he will tell you, how I have left her for Alexis, who indeed is the fairet and mot lovely, that ever I aw. Every one did laugh heartily at the dicoure of Hylas, and Phillis amongt the ret, who aid thus unto him: Why, hepheard, are you then fully reolved to love me no longer? It is poible, you hould quit me for a Druide? But my comfort is, it will be long, before you can have any fruition of your love; for Alexis cannot marry, untill her time with the Carnutans be expired. Hylas miling and haking his head at this: I aure you, hepheardee, aid he, you tell me a thing, that would make me in love with Alexis, if I were not o before; for ever ince I began to look upon women, I never loved any yet o, but I began to hate her, as oon as ever I thought of marriage: So as if Alexis be not content with her time, I will give her as much more, and yet love her. Now let me tell you, there is an odd kinde of ambition in my love, which I mut by all means trive to atisfie. I have already loved Maides, Wives, and Widowes: I have courted my Inferiours, my Equalls, and my Superiours: I have erved fooles, crafty ones, and good ones: I have met with everity, courtey, and inenibility, to either love or hatred: I have tried old ones, middle aged, and very children: I have liked the fair, the black, and the browne, beauties: I have made addrees unto ome, that did love me; unto others, that did not love me: I have tryed all conditions, and all humours, that can be in women. But I mut
confee, I never courted a Druide or a Vetall before, I have been hitherto a Novit in that holy Tribe; and I think, the gods have ent me this fair Alexis, to the end, I may make it my boat, that I am the mot perfect and experienced Lover that ever was None in the Company could forbear laughing. Florice, he addreed her elfe unto him: Hylas, aid he, are you not afeard, that Tharamis will blat you with lightning from heaven, for offering to court one that is dedicated unto him? Oh! Florice, aid Hylas, you that are o religiouly devoted unto the gods, have not you dedicated your elfe unto Tharamis, and yet you have had Theombres in your armes a thouand times, and never feared any blating with lightning from heaven? 'Tis true, (aid Florice, very faintly) but things that are abolutely forbidden, do more offend the gods, then thoe which are indifferent. A very fine excue indeed, aid Hylas, and well found out; pray tell me, where do you finde, that the gods did ever forbid it? If you had ever een a Druide or a Vetall received into their Orders, by their Antients, aid he, you would not have asked me this quetion. Oh, Oh, aid Hylas, I do now undertand you very well; it is the old drie Druides that does forbid them, but yet they are no gods: It is a Law made only by men, men that are old, and not able to enjoy the pleaures of youth, and therefore are envious, and deny unto youth what their age is deprived of. Fie, hepheard, (aid Tircis) mingle not things prophane with things acred, and conider, that the gold of Apollo's Temple, which cot us Gaulians o dear, was dedicated unto him by men. Oh my good friend Tircis, aid Hylas, how long is it ince you became o amorous? You, I ay, who were not wont to be contented with the Living, but would rake the Tombes and Monuments for one, whom it pleaed the gods to take unto themelves from amongt men; you, that were not wont to be converant amongt the living, but the dead, do you now come to talk of the gods, and of things that belong to living men? Oh, Hylas, (aid Tircis, and ighed) how infinitely you wrong me; I do confee, that I do love Cleon, and I hall rather loe the memory of my elfe, then of her and her perfections. But wherein do I offend the gods, or in my duty towards men? Would it not be infinite ingratitude to the gods, not to honour their mot perfect work? And he were not a man, that would not love or forget that thing, which above any in the world is mot worthy of love and memory.

Thus thee Shepheards dicoured, whilt Lycidas related unto Phillis and the fair Atrea, what he had een in the houe of Adamas, and how fair Alexis was. Truly, aid he, I hope, that I may without offence tell you, that he is the very perfect reemblance of my dear and dead Brother, when he was in his greatet beauty; for, I did never in all my life ee two faces, no, nor any Glae, repreent a more exact reemblance. Is it poible, aid Atrea. So true, aid Lycidas, that I know no difference between them, but in their habit; and to tell you truly, me thought Alexis to be a little fairer of the two. Oh heavens! aid Atrea, can you favour me o far, as to help my eyes unto this long'd for ight? Then turning to Diana, and whipering her in the ear: I promie you, Siter, aid he, that if I can obtain the favour, I will go with her, and turn Druide. Oh god, Siter, aid Diana, never think of uch a ad eparation, or ele reolve, to take Phillis and me with you. Oh, aid Atrea, that is too unreaonable, for it would be too great a wrong unto Silvander and Lycidas. Diana would have replyed, but Atrea made a igne unto her to be ilent, let they hould be heard. After this, all the Company retired to their own homes, reolving to viit Adamas and the fair Alexis within three daies after: A terme, which Atrea thought to be an age, o extreamly did he long for a ight of this o much beloved reemblance. In the mean while, Celadon was as impatient for a ight of her.

div.trailer: The end of the two firt Tomes of Atrea, according to the Originall.
